column24: so it was decided to perform the infiltrations at home. In March 2001
column25: 2 months after the end of the second series and after considering that the lesion was not going to reduce further in size
column26: it was decided to perform the enucleation under general anaesthesia using a buccal approach through the upper vestibule. Macroscopically the lesion corresponded to a fibrous
column27: encapsulated
column28: non-friable
column29: non-bleeding lesion that was easily enucleated from the bone cavity.  The histological diagnosis corresponded to a GCL. The description of the pathological anatomy highlighted that the lesion was predominantly fusocellular with collagenised sectors and also noted the presence of osteoid and bone trabeculae lined by osteoblasts. In summary
column30: the patient received 12 corticosteroid infiltrations in 2 series and then underwent enucleation of the lesion. Clinically and radiographically
column31: at 22 months follow-up there is no evidence of residual lesion or recurrence. The patient had no adverse effects to corticosteroid treatment.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 47-year-old woman who
column2: with no previous digestive symptoms
column3: was found to have carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels of 20.2 ng/ml in a routine follow-up analysis by her gynaecologist. She underwent: a) an abdomino-pelvic ultrasound scan that revealed the presence of a 6.5 x 5.6 cm retrouterine mass that appeared to be dependent on the right adnexa; b) a complete colonoscopy with no findings; and c) a diagnostic laparoscopy that revealed the presence of a mass dependent on the cecum
column4: highly vascularised and with a smooth whitish surface
column5: with both adnexa normal and a hypoplastic uterus. Referred to our department
column6: a computerised axial tomography (CAT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis confirmed the existence of a pelvic mass of cystic appearance measuring 11 x 8 cm
column7: anterosuperior to the bladder and close to the terminal ileum
column8: which was encapsulated and without signs of infiltration of neighbouring organs
column9: ascites or adenomegaly in the vicinity. Elective surgery was performed
column10: describing the presence of an appendicular mucocele of 12 cm in diameter with no free fluid or implants in the peritoneum
column11: and an oncological right ileocolectomy with ileotransverse anastomosis was performed; the postoperative period was uneventful
column12: and the patient was discharged on the 5th postoperative day.  The histopathological study of the specimen showed an ileocaecal appendix measuring 9 x 5.5 cm occupied by mucoid material
column13: being reported as "mucocele secondary to appendiceal mucinous tumour of uncertain malignant potential"; it was not possible to certify the degree of local invasion due to parietal calcification. The eight lymph nodes isolated from the resection specimen were free of neoplasia.  After 3 years of follow-up
column14: the patient is asymptomatic and her most recent tumour markers and CT scans are absolutely normal.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 54-year-old male patient
column2: smoker and moderate drinker
column3: allergic to penicillins
column4: with a history of episodes of maxillary sinusitis and pansinusitis. He was diagnosed with a plasmacytoma of the left frontal sinus following a sinus puncture biopsy in another hospital
column5: where it was surgically excised by means of an incision at the level of the left eyebrow and an osteotomy of the anterior wall of the sinus. A fragment of the sinus cavity was obtained for anatomopathological analysis confirming the presence of the plasmacytoma. Histopathological analysis of the excised sinus mucosa was also performed
column6: which was reported as a possible abscessed mucocele (mucopiocele). He was subsequently referred to the haematology department of our hospital for further treatment. Bone scintigraphy showed pathological deposition of the tracer in the maxillary sinus
column7: nasal bones and frontal sinuses
column8: suggesting the presence of myeloma. Three cycles of chemotherapy were administered one month apart
column9: consisting of vincristine
column10: adriomycin and dexamethasone + Aredia (1st cycle); cyclophosphamide
column11: etopoxide
column12: dexamethasone + Aredia (2nd cycle); and cyclophosphamide
column13: adriomycin
column14: dexamethasone + Aredia (3rd cycle). Two days after the end of the third cycle of chemotherapy treatment
column15: an increase in tumour was observed in the frontal region
column16: with signs of local inflammation of 24 hours of evolution. On examination
column17: a soft tumour was palpable in the frontal region
column18: draining abundant purulent material through two orifices located in the eyebrow
column19: with headache and fever of 38ºC. Samples were taken for culture and antibiogram (no microorganisms were isolated). Skull X-ray showed a radiolucent area at the level of the frontal bone. CT and MRI confirmed the presence of thickening of the frontal bone and occupation of its cavities with a lytic area on the left side suggestive of osteomyelitis with areas of sequestration at frontal level.  The patient was referred to our Maxillofacial Surgery Department and after evaluation of the patient
column20: it was decided to carry out surgical treatment. A butterfly incision was made in the glabellar region including the fistulous tract. After detaching the flap
column21: the frontal sinus
column22: which had lost its external table
column23: was visualised
column24: cleaned and curetted
column25: and the sinus walls were reamed with rotating material. A 50 cc cortico-cancellous bone graft was taken from the right proximal tibia using a trocar
column26: which was mixed with a previously prepared PRP growth factor-rich fraction concentrate. 250 cc of venous blood was drawn to prepare the PRP
column27: centrifuged using a two-stage technique (Platelet Concentrate Collection System PCCS; 3i/Implant Innovations
column28: Palm Beach Gardens
column29: FL®)
column30: and the two fractions were separated. Prior to application
column31: the PRP clot was activated by calcium chloride. In total
column32: a mixture of 40 cc of material was obtained
column33: with which both sinus cavities were completely filled. The surgical wound was sutured and plasma poor in growth factors was placed over the scar.  The curettage material from both sinus cavities was sent for pathology analysis. The result reported the presence of mixed inflammatory tissue with bone and soft tissue involvement
column34: ruling out recurrence of plasmacytoma
column35: and the diagnosis was chronic osteomyelitis of the frontal sinus. The patient was discharged after five days of hospitalisation with no symptoms or postoperative complications. There were no complications at the donor site
column36: and the patient was discharged without discomfort. CT scans were performed six and twelve months after the operation
column37: showing complete filling of the sinus cavity
column38: with no signs of disease. The patient had no further frontal swelling or discharge
column39: headaches or fever. The aesthetic appearance of the surgical wound is very satisfactory....   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 26-year-old male referred to General Surgery after being diagnosed accidentally after an imaging test by the Digestive Service of a mass in the left diaphragmatic crura following admission due to a flare-up of IBD. Personal history: extrinsic bronchial asthma
column2: Schonleich-Henoch purpura in childhood
column3: ileal Crohn's disease diagnosed in 2004 and smoker. Physical examination revealed abdominal pain on palpation in the right flank related to his IBD process and no masses or megaliths were palpable. Computed tomography (CT) identified terminal ileum with thickened walls and signs of vascular proliferation in relation to Crohn's disease
column4: in addition to a lesion measuring 7.6 x 4.4 cm with well-defined borders and low density with septate areas with greater enhancement in the left diaphragmatic crura. A CT-guided percutaneous puncture was performed and the anatomopathological result was reported as abundant necrotic material with numerous polymorphonucleated leukocytes and frequent histiocytes with negativity for malignant cells. Mid laparotomy and access to the left infradiaphragmatic retroperitoneal cavity was performed with removal of the mass that was intimately attached to the adrenal gland
column5: upper pole of the kidney and left diaphragm with excision of part of it and direct suture of the latter. The postoperative period evolved favourably and the patient was discharged on the 7th postoperative day without immediate complications. The definitive anatomopathological report was of an irregular bronchogenic cyst of elastic consistency measuring 8 x 4 x 4 x 4 cm
column6: cavitated and with a purulent appearance. The microscopic description was reported as cystic formation with lumina lined by simple pseudostratified columnar epithelium and ciliated cells. Scarce goblet cells. Isolated smooth muscle bundles. No evidence of malignancy.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 70 year old woman with a history of AHT and recently diagnosed with neoplasia of the lower rectum
column2: treated with chemotherapy (5-fluorouracil analogue) and preoperative radiotherapy completed 2 months before surgery. She was admitted to the ICU after surgery (abdominoperineal amputation) due to suspected bronchoaspiration during anaesthetic induction with oximetric repercussions and ventilatory difficulties. She was sedoanalgesiated
column3: intubated and connected to MV. Radiological findings showed no infiltrates indicative of parenchymal lung involvement. Initial evolution was good
column4: and she was extubated without incident after 48h. She presented progressive worsening in the following 2 days radiologically (right basal parenchymal parenchymal involvement)
column5: gasometrically (non-invasive mechanical ventilation (NIV) was required to maintain pulse oximetry at over 90%) and clinically (persistent tachypnoea with poor respiratory mechanics)
column6: so she was reintubated. She started with a persistent fever of over 39oC
column7: resistant to antipyretics and physical measures. Microbiological samples were taken (blood culture
column8: urine culture and bronchoaspirate). Antibiotic treatment started in the operating theatre was maintained. Laboratory tests showed a significant inflammatory reaction with C-reactive protein of 50mg/dl without leukocyte reaction (<10
column9: 000×103/μl). She remained intubated and connected to MV for 7 days
column10: during which time fever persisted with peaks over 39oC
column11: with radiological improvement without infiltrates and persistently negative microbiological samples; an abdominal CT scan was performed and complications derived from the surgery were ruled out. The patient was extubated afebrile
column12: with compensated blood gases and good response to spontaneous respiratory tests; despite optimal conditions at the time of extubation
column13: she had to be reintubated in 12 hours due to respiratory failure. She again began with high fever and repeated negative cultures
column14: so fibrobronchoscopy was performed with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) and samples were sent to microbiology (culture and PCR for herpes
column15: CMV and respiratory viruses) and pathological anatomy. Percutaneous tracheostomy was performed and the BAL results were received
column16: showing early positive HSV-1 PCR (qualitative test) and
column17: histologically
column18: the presence of cells showing multinucleated nuclei
column19: with ground-glass chromatin and intranuclear inclusions; immunocytochemically
column20: nuclear positivity for herpes virus was found. Antiviral treatment was started with acyclovir 10mg/kg/8h i.v. with clinical improvement
column21: disappearance of fever and progressive disconnection of the respirator until full respiratory autonomy.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Patient aged 94 years
column2: allergic to penicillin and derivatives
column3: with no medical or surgical history of interest
column4: who does not take regular medication. She reported that in the last 4-5 days she had presented episodes of epigastric abdominal pain with nausea and abundant vomiting with bilious characteristics
column5: for which reason she came to the emergency department. There have been no alterations in stool rhythm or stool characteristics. There was no fever or other associated symptoms. Physical examination: blood pressure 120/80 mmHg
column6: heart rate 106 bpm
column7: O2 saturation 96% with FiO2 21%
column8: temperature 36.3o C. Conscious. Orientation. Slightly dehydrated. Normal colour of skin and mucous membranes. Good distal perfusion. Eupneic. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds at 100 bpm
column9: panfocal systolic murmur predominantly in aortic focus. Pulmonary auscultation: normal vesicular murmur. Abdomen: soft
column10: depressible
column11: not painful on palpation; no masses or visceromegaly
column12: no distension or tympanism. Normal peristalsis. Rectal examination: normal stool remains in the rectum. Lower extremities without oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis. After the initial assessment
column13: the following was requested: - Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 105 bpm
column14: without repolarisation
column15: depolarisation or conduction disturbances. - Chest X-ray: normal cardiac silhouette with no acute pleuroparenchymal alterations. - Blood tests: haemoglobin 11 mg/dL with haematocrit 35%. Urea 51 mg/dL with plasma creatinine in normal values. Medical treatment was started with fluid therapy and antiemetics
column16: and given clinical suspicion of a possible obstructive process of the upper digestive tract as opposed to a motor disorder (gastroparesis)
column17: it was decided to perform an oral endoscopy. During the oral endoscopy
column18: a solid formation of spherical morphology and yellowish colouring of about 3 centimetres in diameter was identified
column19: which was embedded in the duodenum and caused obstruction of transit at this level. The patient was diagnosed with biliary ileus due to lithiasis lodged in the duodenum (Bouveret's syndrome). The usual treatment for this entity is surgical
column20: but given the advanced age of the patient
column21: it was decided to try endoscopic extraction. First of all
column22: the duodenum was disimpacted
column23: using a net loop
column24: and then the pylorus was crossed in the opposite direction
column25: and the lithiasis was transported to the stomach. Once there
column26: lithotripsy manoeuvres are carried out without success. Subsequently
column27: a polypectomy loop was used to partially introduce the lithiasis into an overtube
column28: as the diameter of the lithiasis was larger. The lithiasis was extracted endoscopically through the oral cavity. Subsequently
column29: the mucosa of the stomach and duodenum was examined without observing any erosions or mucosal lesions.  After removal of the lithiasis
column30: the patient's clinical picture was resolved and she was asymptomatic. She underwent analytical and radiographic control without complications and was discharged from hospital after 24 hours.  |O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Female patient
column2: aged 38 years
column3: diagnosed with coeliac disease with anti-transglutaminase antibodies 46 U (v.n. up to 5) and duodenal biopsy compatible with coeliac disease. She subsequently had two spontaneous miscarriages and a cerebral transient ischaemic attack. Currently in the sixth month of pregnancy with anticardiolipin antibodies IgM 75 MPL/ml (v.n. up to 20) and anticardiolipin IgG in normal values. Haematological study showed no other prothrombotic alterations. She continues treatment with subcutaneous heparin and a gluten-free diet.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O

column1: A 16 year old female student
column2: in good general condition
column3: came to our Unit
column4: claiming to have been raped two months prior to the interview. She had not reported the incident due to personal reasons. She consulted about lesions in her mouth of approximately two weeks' evolution
column5: which caused difficulty in phonation and swallowing. During the anamnesis
column6: the patient showed insecurity and concealment in her answers. Examination of the buccal mucosa revealed the typical opaline
column7: slightly raised
column8: greyish-white plaques of syphilitic secondarily and other white lesions surrounded by a red halo
column9: some multiple and some solitary. In figure 1
column10: the white plaques can be seen in both commissures and
column11: in the lower labial mucosa
column12: in the midline
column13: three more plaques. The one closest to the sulcus
column14: opaline white
column15: well circumscribed. Another plaque
column16: approximately 2 cm in diameter
column17: shows a small central red area
column18: and close to the semi-mucosa
column19: another similar one can be observed.  In figure 2
column20: similar plaques are found on the left edge of the tongue
column21: near the tip and in the posterior area. On the right edge
column22: in the middle and posterior part
column23: two similar plaques
column24: each 1.5 cm in diameter
column25: can also be seen. Close to the tip of the tongue
column26: on the edges and extended towards the ventral side
column27: a rough surface can be seen in figure 3. It was clinically diagnosed as hairy leukoplakia (LV) and could not be removed by scraping. The patient gave authorisation for an HIV test
column28: which was carried out the following day and the result of which was delivered in person approximately thirty days later. After a first reactive VDRL (128 dls)
column29: the fluorescent treponema antibody test (FTA-ABS)
column30: the treponema haematoagglutination test (TPHA)
column31: and a spirochete demonstration of the exudate from one of the oral lesions or "dark field test" were requested
column32: with a positive result. A mucosal biopsy was performed with a presumptive diagnosis of hairy leukoplakia. Due to the high serology titres obtained
column33: classical treatment for syphilis with benzathine penicillin injections was immediately instituted. The result of the LV biopsy was confirmed. The patient did not return to the clinic and did not withdraw the HIV result
column34: which was reactive. We have tried to locate the young woman to inform her of her condition
column35: monitor the effectiveness of the syphilis treatment
column36: and establish a possible treatment and follow-up of her immunodeficiency.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 64-year-old male
column2: diabetic and hypertensive. He had severe chronic kidney disease (stage 5 with GFR 11 ml/min/1.73 m2). Scheduled for total right hip arthroplasty due to severe coxarthrosis. He underwent haemodialysis the day before the operation
column3: his "dry" weight being 69 kg. At 9:20 a.m. we performed spinal anaesthesia with a 25 G sprotte needle (Pajunk®) with 2.5ml of bupivacaine 0.5% (12.5 mg) obtaining a complete block without incident. At 10:00 a.m. a 25 µg/h fentanyl patch (transdermal therapeutic system -TTS) is applied. The operation was uneventful. On arrival at the post-anaesthesia recovery unit (PRU) (12:30 a.m.) a perfusion of 6 grams of metamizole over 24 hours (in 500 ml of physiological saline at a rate of 21 ml/hour) is started. The patient is admitted to the postoperative acute pain unit (PACU) maintaining the fentanyl patch for 48 hours and rescuing the pain with 200 µg transmucosal oral fentanyl (maximum every 4 hours with a maximum of 4 doses per day). At 16:00 she was discharged to the ward with a score of 2 on the visual analogue scale (VAS). At 22:00
column4: due to a pain peak
column5: a dose of oral transmucosal fentanyl is administered; it subsides after 15 minutes. At 12 hours after removal of the patch (60 hours after the operation) another pain peak appeared
column6: requiring a second oral fentanyl. The VAS on the 2nd and 3rd days was 0. It was on the third day
column7: coinciding with the change from bed to armchair
column8: that the patient reported nausea which subsided with ondansetron 4 mg i.v. During his stay in the care of the ADU he had no vomiting
column9: pruritus or constipation; the quality of sleep and night's rest were good.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 68-year-old asymptomatic male
column2: with no history of interest
column3: referred for study of a lesion at the level of the uncinate process of the pancreas. The lesion was detected incidentally by abdominal ultrasound performed for the study of low back pain.  The abdominal CT scan showed an inhomogeneous mass at the level of the uncinate process with an anteroposterior diameter of 3.6 cm
column4: blurring of the peripancreatic fat and dilatation of the main pancreatic duct.  An examination was carried out with linear echoendoscopy equipment (PENTAX UX 3630) where invasion of the bile duct and adjacent structures was excluded. The cytological study of the material obtained by echoendoscopy-guided FNA was negative for malignancy. With the suspicion of adenocarcinoma
column5: a cephalic duodenopancreatectomy with lymph node dissection was performed. Macroscopically
column6: a well-demarcated greyish lesion measuring 1.8 cm x 1 cm with a soft consistency and a necrotic appearance in its centre was described with a histopathological diagnosis of a lymphoepithelial cyst.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 42-year-old man
column2: resident in Mérida (Extremadura)
column3: with a personal history of type I diabetes mellitus and chronic prostatitis
column4: consulted three weeks after ingestion of an unsanitised dairy product due to fever and general malaise. Complementary tests showed an unaltered haemogram
column5: biochemistry
column6: coagulation tests and conventional radiology. Blood cultures in conventional and Ruiz Castañeda media were negative. The serological study for Brucella was: Rose Bengal: positive
column7: sero-agglutination: positive (1/20) and antibrucella-coombs: positive. Treatment was started with Rifampicin 900mg/day plus doxacycline 100mg/12h for 6 weeks. After five months he suffered a relapse and presented with lumbar pain and fever. On examination the left iliac region was impacted together with a positive psoas sign. A computerised axial tomography (CAT) scan showed L5-S1 spondylodiscitis with involvement of the surrounding soft tissues and a small bilateral psoas abscess. It was decided to resume previous antibiotic treatment with the addition of ciprofloxacin 400mgr/12h. After one month
column8: given the poor response to treatment
column9: transcutaneous drainage of the psoas collections was performed. In view of the poor evolution of the patient
column10: a new CT scan was performed
column11: showing the existence of large bilateral psoas abscesses and involvement of the surrounding tissue together with spondylodiscitis at L5-S1. The patient was referred to our department where he was operated on by the urology and neurosurgery departments together
column12: with drainage of both muscles and L5-S1 discectomy. The postoperative period was uneventful and the patient was discharged with antibiotic treatment with doxycycline 100mgr/12hours together with septrim forte 1/12hours for four months.  The patient is asymptomatic with good general condition until the last check-up three years after surgery. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 46-year-old man presented for consultation with viral conjunctivitis in the right eye (OD) that had been evolving for ten days and had not improved with treatment with tobramycin and dexamethasone. His personal history includes condylomas on the penis without urethritis six months ago and current permissive sexual relations. Ophthalmological examination showed visual acuity in OD of light perception and projection. Biomicroscopy of the anterior pole of the OD showed superior corneal thinning with an imminent risk of ocular perforation and the patient was treated with corneal coating with multilayer amniotic membrane.  As the conjunctival exudate culture results were positive for Neisseria Gonorrhoeae
column2: intravenous antibiotic treatment was started with ceftriaxone at a dose of 1g/12 h and topical treatment with ceftriaxone reinforced eye drops (50 mg/ml) for 21 days. One month later
column3: the patient's OD visual acuity was 0.8; biomicroscopy of the anterior pole showed superior corneal fibrosis with good transparency in the central part and a well-formed anterior chamber.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 22-year-old man (68 kg.
column3: active military
column4: with no previous history of interest
column5: who was hit by a projectile (9 mm. calibre)
column6: from an accidental pistol shot
column7: at close range
column8: in the right thigh. After primary assessment and initial care he was evacuated to the HGD "Orad y Gajías"
column9: where he was diagnosed with a fracture of the distal third of the right femur
column10: open Gustilo type III
column11: comminuted
column12: and without displacement. In the rest of the examination no lesions were observed. Exhaustive cleaning and debridement of the wounds on the right thigh was carried out
column13: and the right lower limb was immobilised by means of a posterior cruropedic splint. Antibiotic prophylaxis
column14: tetanus prophylaxis and antithrombotic prophylaxis were instituted.  In the tertiary assessment of the patient at the "Gómez Ulla" hospital
column15: an axial CT scan of the right femur was performed
column16: with multiplanar and volumetric reconstructions. A comminuted fracture of the distal third of the right femur was determined
column17: with multiple small fragments displaced to the posterior compartment. After presentation of the case in a clinical session of the service
column18: surgical treatment was decided using an external fixator.  Surgical intervention was performed by placing an XCaliber external fixator (Orthofix®) with four femoral pins
column19: in static and monoplanar configuration under intradural regional anaesthesia and sedation. No surgical or anaesthetic incidents were recorded during the operation.  The injured patient had a good postoperative evolution
column20: starting partial loading 24 hours after the operation. Five days after hospital admission
column21: the patient was discharged home
column22: with subsequent clinical-radiological follow-up on an outpatient basis. Two months after the operation
column23: the patient had limited knee joint balance and delayed healing at the fracture site. At the four-month check-up
column24: a CT scan revealed a lack of healing at the fracture site and knee joint stiffness with a rigid stop at 30o flexion. After removal of the external fixator at 18 weeks
column25: the patient was reoperated on a scheduled basis
column26: under intradural regional anaesthesia and sedation
column27: for refreshing of the fracture site and internal fixation by means of retrograde femoral endomedullary nailing using a T2 nail (Stryker®)
column28: and for treatment of the knee extension contracture
column29: a modified Judet technique quadriceplasty was performed
column30: after which a gain in joint balance was observed
column31: flexing the knee against gravity to 110o.  The immediate postoperative period was uneventful
column32: and the patient began early rehabilitation treatment programmed by the Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation Service of the HCDGU. In the controls after surgery
column33: the patient presented a knee joint balance of 110o of flexion with full extension
column34: with normal gait and without pain. At present
column35: the patient is fully reincorporated to his usual activities.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 40-year-old male of Bulgarian nationality with a personal history of gastro-oesophageal reflux and incompetent cardia
column2: not previously operated on or transfused
column3: employed as a metal carpenter
column4: smoker of 15-20 cig/day and a moderate ex-drinker until 4 years ago. His family history included his mother
column5: father and a brother with nephrolithiasis. He had been seen 21 days before admission for pain in the right flank with irradiation towards the ipsilateral testicle
column6: which was classified as probable renal colic and treated with analgesia
column7: with favourable evolution; he subsequently started again with similar symptoms accompanied by nausea without thermometric fever or micturition syndrome; he did not report loss of appetite or weight. He returned to the emergency department where an abdominal ultrasound scan was performed describing the presence of grade II/IV hydronephrosis and a 6-7 cm mass in the right reteroperitoneum
column8: for which he was admitted for further study. The patient reported pain in the right renal flank/fossa radiating to the ipsilateral teste without nausea
column9: vomiting or thermometric fever. Examination revealed only positive right renal suction. ECG in sinus rhythm at 76 bpm; chest X-ray with no significant pathological alterations. Blood tests showed fibrinogen 478 mg/dL (150-450)
column10: ESR21 mm/hour (2-15)
column11: urea 52 mg/dL (10-50)
column12: creatinine 1.4 mg/dL (0.6-1.2)
column14: human gonadotropinacorionic acid 7 UI/L (0-5) and alpha-fetoprotein 2.2 kU/L (0.5-7). An abdominopelvic CT scan was performed showing a single "soft tissue" mass of rounded morphology (7 x 5.5 cm) with a uniform density and a focal area of lesser attenuation that "encompasses" the inferior vena cava and the right ureter with grade 2 hydronephrosis; the lesion is well defined and no adenopathy or accompanying satellite lesions can be seen in the middle retroperitoneum (between the aorta and the inferior vena cava). Urgent referral was made to the Urology Department
column15: which performed a right nephrostomy. A trucut biopsy of the retroperitoneal mass was performed under ultrasound guidance and the specimen was sent to anatomical pathology
column16: which reported it as a neoformation consisting of large cells arranged in nests
column17: with little cohesion and a cytoplasm of imprecise limits
column18: generally finely vacuolated
column19: The nuclei are rounded or cleaved
column20: with a large nucleolus and the cells are arranged in nuclei and are surrounded by a large number of small lymphoid cells
column21: corresponding to mature lymphocytes. The tumour cells are positive for C-Kit and are compatible with a classic seminoma-type germinal tumour. In view of this
column22: a testicular ultrasound scan was performed
column23: showing a 16 mm nodular-ovoid
column24: isodense lesion with a peripheral hypodense halo
column25: located in the upper half and subcapsular anteriorly
column26: as well as another small hyperechoic nodule of approximately 5 mm
column27: compatible with a right testicular tumour. He was subsequently referred to the Urology Department
column28: after consultation with Oncology
column29: to perform an orchiectomy and subsequently undergo chemotherapy cycles in the Oncology Department.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 29 year old patient attended the Emergency Department of our Hospital with a mildly painful erection of ten hours' duration. The patient reported having had four similar episodes in the last three months
column2: but in all of them the erection had subsided within three to four hours at most. The patient denies any history of penile trauma
column3: the use of drugs or other medication
column4: including intracavernous injections. There were no other accompanying symptoms such as asthenia
column5: anorexia or fever. Blood gasometry was performed on the blood taken from the corpora cavernosa
column6: obtaining analytical results for venous blood (pCO2 163.1 mmHg
column7: HCO3 13.2 mEq/l plasma). Given this priapism of prolonged duration and the absence of signs of high-flow priapism
column8: we proceed to try to reverse the erection as soon as possible
column9: in order to calm the pain and avoid irreversible damage to the corpora cavernosa. A 19 G intravenous catheter is punctured in both corpora cavernosa
column10: blood is repeatedly aspirated and allowed to drip out. After this first step
column11: no decrease in erection is obtained
column12: so a solution of phenylephrine (alpha-adrenergic agonist) is prepared in saline solution at a concentration of 0.1 mg/ml. Two ml of the solution is injected into a corpus cavernosum and then compressed. This manoeuvre is repeated again in the contralateral corpus cavernosum. If there is no response
column13: a new phenylephrine solution is made by mixing 10 mg of phenylephrine in 11 mg of saline and 20-30 ml of this solution is injected into each of the corpora cavernosa to wash them. After repeating this last manoeuvre several times
column14: penile flaccidity is finally achieved. During his stay in the emergency department and after achieving flaccidity
column15: blood tests were drawn and revealed a marked increase in the blood leukocyte (414 x 109/L) and platelet (1100 x 109/L) counts. Suspicion of a myeloproliferative syndrome led to consultation with the Haematology Department
column16: which diagnosed chronic myeloid leukaemia.  The patient subsequently underwent an allogeneic bone marrow transplant from an HLA-identical family donor. The evolution of his haematological disease was favourable and the priapism was completely resolved with the treatment of the chronic myeloid leukaemia and without alteration in sexual potency.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 13 year old boy referred to the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Department from the Paediatrics Department for 4 days of asymptomatic swelling of the right cheek. He reported no other symptoms and no weight loss. Physical examination revealed a solid
column2: elliptical mass between the body of the malar bone and the anterosuperior part of the right maxillary bone. There was a boundary between the lesion and the surrounding muscle and it did not infiltrate the skin. Intraoral examination revealed a firm
column3: mobile and painless mass in the gingiva at the bottom of the vestibule of the right upper hemiarch. No other findings were found on examination of the head and neck. A biopsy was performed with intraoral access. Histologically
column4: the mass consisted mostly of a compact proliferation of small cells. At higher magnification these cells consisted of round
column5: uniform nuclei
column6: revealing granular chromatin with peripheral condensation
column7: as well as scanty
column8: slightly eosinophilic cytoplasm. The stroma was sparse with occasional fibrous tissue tracts. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positivity for CD-99.  Subsequent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed the presence of a well-demarcated
column9: encapsulated solid tumour measuring approximately 24 × 13 mm located anterior to the right maxillary sinus
column10: with anterior displacement of the zygomatic musculature. The lesion did not show infiltration of neighbouring structures and showed intense gadolinium enhancement after gadolinium administration
column11: suggesting high cellularity of the lesion. No underlying bone changes or significant adenopathic growths were identified.  Prior to treatment
column12: distant metastases were ruled out by biopsy and bone marrow aspiration
column13: in addition to a full-body PET-CT scan. Treatment for ESS was administered following the Euro-EWING 99 protocol. The control MRI showed disappearance of the lesion
column14: although with persistent thickening involving the affected facial musculature (inferior aspect of the orbicularis oculi and levator labii superioris)
column15: together with minimal enhancement after contrast administration. Surgical treatment of the remaining lesion was then performed
column16: with extensive resection of the affected facial musculature and soft tissue. The maxillary bone plane was approached
column17: without resection
column18: as no tumour infiltration was observed either clinically or radiographically. The patient was discharged on the second postoperative day in good general condition with no postoperative complications. Histological analysis of the surgical specimen revealed absence of malignant cells and negative margins. The control MRI findings were described as postoperative changes from the baseline study
column19: with no criteria for underlying tumour recurrence or recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 22 year old male attended primary care (PC) with a personal history of functional murmur in childhood
column2: seasonal allergic rhinitis
column3: smoker of 10 cigarettes a day and weekend drinker. Family history of no interest. After performing an ECG at the primary care clinic prior to travelling abroad to study at a private university in the United Kingdom
column4: a generalised negative T wave was observed from V2 to V6 and in the inferior face
column5: with isolated ventricular extrasystoles. Physical examination revealed blood pressure of 140/70 mm Hg
column6: normal cardiopulmonary auscultation at 60 beats per minute with no other data of interest. With these electrocardiographic findings
column7: he was referred to the cardiology department.  The complementary studies requested from the PC were normal (blood tests with haemogram
column8: biochemistry and coagulation; lateral and posteroanterior chest X-ray). The echocardiogram showed significant dilatation of the right ventricle (55 mm)
column9: with a hypokinetic lateral face and mild tricuspid insufficiency. The holter monitor shows sinus rhythm and migratory atrial pacing with frequent ventricular extrasystoles and some ventricular triplets. Cardiac MRI shows an enlarged right ventricle with moderator band hypertrophy with thin wall with some hyperintense areas within it suggestive of fatty infiltration
column10: with small dyskinetic sacculations. The left ventricle
column11: valves and pericardium are normal. With the suspected diagnosis of ARVC
column12: treatment with beta-blockers was started. The patient remained asymptomatic and underwent regular check-ups. Upon his return to Spain two years later
column13: after playing a basketball game
column14: he developed syncopal symptoms and it was finally decided to have an ICD implanted. One month after admission
column15: he was referred to the Rehabilitation Service to assess the possibility of starting a Cardiac Rehabilitation Programme (CRP). The patient continues to lead an active life today
column16: one year later
column17: with follow-up from Primary Care and check-ups by Cardiology.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present a 63-year-old female patient with a history of arterial hypertension and angor pectoris
column2: referred to our department from a rural hospital. The reason for the consultation was the chance finding of a left renal mass in an ultrasound scan
column3: and the patient did not report any symptoms. Blood tests showed only a slight eosinophilia. As complementary studies
column4: intravenous urographies were performed in which a mass effect was observed at the level of the left flank
column5: with a smooth and well-defined border
column6: depending on the upper pole of the left kidney
column7: with extrinsic compression of the pyelocaliceal system
column8: measuring 16 x 10 cm. CT scan revealed a mass measuring 17 x 12 x 19 cm in the upper pole of the left kidney
column9: with cystic areas
column10: compatible with multilocular cystic nephroma
column11: with no adenopathy. The DMSA scan showed a differential renal function of 63% for the right kidney and 37% for the left kidney.  A new ultrasound scan showed an image compatible with a large hydatid cyst
column12: with structures compatible with vesicles inside. The hydatid serology was negative
column13: so it was decided to submit the patient to an MRI which did not definitively clarify the diagnosis either: mass in the upper pole of the left kidney with a complex internal structure
column14: well delimited
column15: without contrast uptake
column16: with calcifications
column17: suspicious of a renal hydatid cyst or multilocular cystic nephroma. In view of the aforementioned results
column18: the next step was the ultrasound-guided puncture of the renal mass
column19: with negative serology for hydatidosis
column20: although a liquid with a crystalline appearance was obtained. Finally
column21: the patient underwent surgery in which the diagnosis of hydatid cyst was confirmed and a partial cystectomy was performed
column22: preparing the operative field with compresses soaked in rivanol.  Postoperative evolution was favourable
column23: and treatment with albendazole 400 mg every 12 hours for one month after surgery. At the present time
column24: the patient remains asymptomatic (the arterial hypertension she had before diagnosis is maintained) and the control serology was negative again

column1: A 36-year-old woman

column39: thoracic and abdominal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The findings of these examinations were within the normal range. During admission

column41: as detailed in table 1. The first

column55: posterior tibial

column1: A 19-year-old male died suddenly while doing weight training exercises in a gymnasium. Death was witnessed by several witnesses who saw him become unconscious and faint. Basic and advanced cardiopulmonary resuscitation manoeuvres were performed for 55 minutes. The patient's medical history included valvular heart disease
column2: without specifying the type or degree of involvement
column3: and several relatives who had died of cardiac pathology. The family was uncooperative in providing information. The external examination performed during the autopsy showed signs of cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Normal build
column4: weight 84 kg
column5: height 176
column6: 5 cm
column7: body mass index 27
column8: 12. Internal examination revealed cardiomegaly (heart weight 555 g)
column9: concentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle (free wall of the left ventricle and interventricular septum of 2.1 cm each) and pulmonary oedema (right lung 665 g and left lung 550 g). The macroscopic cardiac examination revealed a thickening of the aortic valve leaflets
column10: which significantly reduced the permeable area
column11: which measured with the measuring cone was 0.5 cm2. After opening the valve annulus
column12: the circumference measured 7 cm
column13: and a bicuspid aortic valve with a medial raphe in one of the leaflets next to the left ostium was visualised. The cause of death was established as aortic stenosis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 80-year-old patient admitted for right lower lobe pneumonia with pleural effusion. He presented a sudden worsening of his respiratory condition and was admitted to the ICU. Chest drainage was performed
column2: obtaining 2
column3: 640 ml of purulent fluid. On the eighth day
column4: the patient began oral tolerance
column5: with diet-like contents coming out of the drain. Suspicion of oesophago-pleural fistula led to the administration of methylene blue
column6: with immediate discharge through the thoracic drainage. Endoscopy was performed
column7: describing a three-centimetre ulceration in the distal third
column8: right lateral face
column9: covered with fibrin
column10: with a fistulous orifice of more than eight millimetres in its lower part. Biopsies taken from the ulcerated area showed superficial gastric mucosa with mild inflammatory infiltrates and intestinal metaplasia
column11: with no histological signs of malignancy. Once the diagnosis of benign oesophageal pleural fistula in relation to Barrett's oesophagus was confirmed
column12: a removable "Hanoster" type stent was placed as a rescue treatment.  Since leaving the ward
column13: the patient had maintained feverish peaks
column14: so a CT scan was performed
column15: which confirmed the presence of an abscess in the right lower lobe
column16: so an endothoracic drain was placed
column17: with an outflow of chocolate-coloured contents
column18: and the consequent clinical improvement of the patient. Methylene blue was administered again
column19: and bluish liquid came out through the tube. Given the persistence of the oesophago-pleural fistula
column20: it was decided to transfer the patient to the General Surgery Department. Oesophagogram: stent in the distal third of the oesophagus
column21: with contrast leakage in the middle third and at the distal end
column22: the latter in a posterior direction. The patient was operated on and a transhiatal oesophagectomy plus substernal gastroplasty was performed
column23: with a favourable post-operative evolution

column1: An 80-year-old man who presented clinically with haematuria and left flank pain. Fist percussion in the left renal fossa was positive. Imaging techniques revealed a mass in the left renal fossa that blurred the renal silhouette. The patient underwent nephrectomy with proximal ureterectomy. In the nephrectomy specimen
column2: the renal parenchyma was almost entirely replaced by a whitish heterogeneous lesion in which cystic cavities of necrotic appearance with friable and poorly demarcated intracavitary papillary formations and poorly demarcated yellowish areas combined randomly with others of necrotic and/or haemorrhagic appearance could be seen. When cut
column3: a firm consistency was observed
column4: mainly corresponding to the whitish-greyish areas
column5: although in other locations a soft and even crunchy consistency was observed. Histological examination showed a neoplasm consisting of a proliferation of spindle and polygonal cells with marked atypia and nuclear pleomorphism
column6: which adopted a solid growth pattern. More than 75% of it showed differentiation to osteo- and chondrosarcoma although squamous differentiation could also be demonstrated
column7: mainly lining the inner surface of the previously described cystic formations. The high cellular atypia observed was made more evident by the presence of abundant multinucleated giant cells located within the solid spindle-shaped areas and around the areas of osteosarcomatous differentiation (14) (the latter are probably in fact atypical osteoclasts). The tumour contacted the renal capsule without going beyond it
column8: invading vascular structures of the hilum and the adipose tissue of the pelvis. After rigorous sampling of the surgical specimen
column9: few foci with a histological pattern of clear cell carcinoma could be seen. The immunohistochemical study of the neoplasm showed positive immunostaining for cytokeratins in both the clear cell and spindle cell components
column10: the latter also being positive for vimentin (13). Based on the above
column11: the diagnosis of renal sarcomatoid carcinoma with a predominance of areas with malignant heterologous differentiation (osteo- and chondrosarcoma) was made
column12: referring to the presence of foci of carcinoma with a clear cell pattern and areas with squamous differentiation.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 39-year-old male patient came to the Emergency Department with proptosis of one year's evolution in both eyes (AO)
column2: with no decrease in visual acuity (VA). He had no other symptoms of note and no other history of interest. On examination
column3: the patient had a VA of 0.5 in the right eye (OD) (referred to as amblyopic by the patient) and 0.8 in the left eye (OI). Hertel exophthalmometry was 25 mm in the OD and 23 mm in the OI. The biomicroscopic and tonometric examination was normal. Fundus examination showed papillary oedema in the OD. The Farnsworth colour test was normal. In the campimetric study the OI was normal but in the OD there was an inferonasal defect
column4: which was not strictly quadrantanopsia. A computed tomography (CT) scan was requested and reported as ectasia/thickening of the sheaths of both NO in the context of bilateral exophthalmos more marked in OD. Suspecting the presence of bilateral meningocele
column5: it was decided to periodically observe the patient without performing any additional diagnostic-therapeutic act. Today
column6: 16 years later
column7: the patient has a VA of 0.6 in OD and 0.8 in OI. Exophthalmometry and campimetry have remained stable. The papillary appearance of the fundus has hardly changed. He continues with his regular check-ups.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A ten-year-old boy
column2: with no personal history of interest
column3: presented to the emergency department of the primary care centre with abdominal pain lasting four hours
column4: fever of 40°C
column5: vomiting of food and diarrhoea with traces of mucus. Abdominal examination revealed diffuse abdominal pain
column6: slightly more in the right iliac fossa
column7: with signs of peritoneal irritation. Laboratory tests showed 12
column8: 200 leukocytes/µl (91% neutrophils) and slightly elevated C-reactive protein (CRP). The patient was referred to the nearest hospital with the suspicion of an acute abdomen for further investigation. An abdominal ultrasound was performed
column9: showing a tubular image
column10: aperistaltic and incompressible with the transducer
column11: compatible with acute appendicitis. It was decided to perform surgery
column12: after receiving informed consent from the parents
column13: and an appendectomy was performed
column14: during which a cecal appendix with mild inflammatory signs was observed. The postoperative course was torpid
column15: with persistent fever (38.8°C)
column16: generalised abdominal pain without peritonism
column17: vomiting and diarrhoea. An abdominal ultrasound scan showed dilatation of the small bowel loops
column18: suggesting incomplete obstruction. The CBC continues to show leukocytosis with left shift and elevated C-reactive protein. Given the incongruence of the patient's symptoms and the operative findings
column19: it was decided to opt for conservative treatment
column20: a stool culture was performed and empirical antibiotherapy was started while awaiting the results of the stool culture
column21: which showed Campylobacter jejuni sensitive to gentamicin. Antibiotic treatment with gentamicin was started
column22: with which the patient's evolution was satisfactory
column23: as the clinical picture resolved and the patient was discharged ten days after surgery. column1: Male patient
column2: aged 28 years
column3: seen in urology for presenting left varicocele. In the study of this pathology
column4: a large mass dependent on the left kidney was discovered
column5: which displaced the abdominal structures; the left renal vein and cava were observed to be displaced
column6: but permeable. Clinically
column7: the patient reported abdominal pain
column8: asthenia and weight loss. There was no haematuria or voiding syndrome. Physical examination revealed a large abdominal mass. Laboratory tests (routine blood tests
column9: blood and urine biochemistry
column10: coagulation) were normal. Testicular ultrasound confirmed a large left varicocele; abdominal ultrasound
column11: magnetic resonance imaging and thoracoabdominal computed tomography (CT) demonstrated a mass in the left kidney
column12: measuring 25 × 20 ×14 cm in maximum diameter
column13: compressing and displacing abdominal structures
column14: as well as the renal and cava vein. The rest of the examination was normal (T2N0).  The study was completed with a bone scan (negative for bone metastases)
column15: a fine needle puncture-aspiration (atypical cells suspicious for malignancy) and an arteriography where displacement and rotation of the abdominal aorta was observed. In view of the results of the study
column16: it was decided to perform a radical nephrectomy; the operation was uneventful and the postoperative period was favourable; the patient was discharged 7 days after surgery. The anatomical pathology report described macroscopically a large encapsulated tumour mass of 4
column18: measuring 27 ×23 ×15 cm
column19: where no kidney was recognised. The microscopic description confirmed the diagnosis of renal fibromyxoid sarcoma. Subsequent evolution Followed up in the outpatient clinic by the urology and oncology departments (which decided not to give complementary treatment)
column20: the patient was doing very well and all the complementary examinations carried out 9 months after the operation (blood and urine tests
column21: thoracoabdominal CT scan) were normal. Three months later an extensive local recurrence was detected in the thoracoabdominal CT scan
column22: a mass in the left renal cell with local extension (approximately 20 cm) affecting the spleen and pancreas
column23: which it displaced but did not appear to infiltrate.  It was decided to treat with surgery for a large multiloculated tumour infiltrating the spleen
column24: the tail of the pancreas
column25: the greater gastric curvature and the left diaphragm. Resection of the tumour
column26: including the affected diaphragm
column27: vertical gastrectomy up to the angle of His
column28: splenectomy with resection of the tail of the pancreas and splenic angle colectomy were performed. The anatomical pathology report confirmed that this was an abdominal and retroperitoneal recurrence of high-grade sarcoma
column29: compatible with fibrosarcoma
column30: adherent to the gastric wall
column31: spleen and pancreas. Treatment was completed with chemotherapy (6 cycles of adriamycin/ifosfamide/Mesna) and radiotherapy
column32: which was well tolerated and responded (control CT scan within the normal range). After four months
column33: a new relapse was observed in the abdominal CT scan
column34: for which he received chemotherapy treatment and 8 months later the patient died.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column28: and haemoglobin and haematocrit were found to remain stable.  With the diagnostic suspicion of non-traumatic rupture of a pre-existing pheochromocytoma

column30: which were normal
column31: and urinary catecholamines and metanephrines. In the 24-hour urine of the day after admission

column33: noradrenaline: 151.1 mcg (VN: 12.1-85.5)
column34: metanephrine: 853.5 mcg (VN: 74-297) and normetanephrine: 1396.6 mcg (VN: 105-354). After 10 days
