column1: We present the clinical case of a 41-year-old woman with no history of interest
column2: except for arterial hypertension
column3: who presented at home with a sudden episode of severe headache in the occipital region
column4: accompanied by a progressive decrease in the level of consciousness. She had presented similar episodes of headache in the previous week
column5: although of lesser intensity
column6: which subsided with anti-inflammatory drugs. The emergency services attended her at home
column7: where orotracheal intubation was performed due to a low level of consciousness. She was transferred urgently to a hospital with neurosurgical services. On admission
column8: a simple cranial computed tomography (CT) scan showed a right cerebellar intraparenchymal haemorrhage with a volume greater than 4 cm3
column9: with discrete oedema and obliteration of the IV ventricle. It was decided to evacuate the haematoma and place an external ventricular drain. After surgery
column10: he was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). He underwent deferred CT angiography and cerebral arteriography with no obvious vascular anomalies.  During his stay in the ICU
column11: he had a torpid evolution due to intracranial hypertension during the first few days. After withdrawal of sedation
column12: he awoke with an adequate level of consciousness and 48 hours later he was conscious; the neurological examination revealed nystagmus in all directions
column13: bilateral facial paralysis
column14: predominantly right tetraparesis
column15: left dysmetria and predominantly right hyporeflexia with right extensor plantar cutaneous reflex. On the eighth day of her admission to the ICU
column16: she was extubated in the morning and remained eupneic throughout the day with a normal ventilatory pattern. That same night she began to experience hypoventilation which led to severe respiratory acidosis and secondary respiratory arrest requiring intubation and MV. Given the clinical suspicion of respiratory centre involvement
column17: magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brainstem was performed
column18: showing changes secondary to the evacuation of the right cerebellar haematoma and revealing lesions in the bulb and pons
column19: which had not been seen in the previous control CT scan. It was decided to perform a percutaneous tracheostomy for invasive mechanical ventilation (IMV)
column20: which she required mainly at night. Finally
column21: she was discharged to the ward where it was possible to close the tracheostoma and she continued with non-invasive mechanical ventilation (NIV) with nasobuccal mask.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 83-year-old patient with a personal history of hypertension and a mixed endometrial carcinoma
column2: endometrioid and clear cell
column3: stage T1N0M0
column4: which was detected one year before the current admission due to metrorrhagia. The patient underwent hysterectomy with bilateral adnexectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
column5: completing treatment with adjuvant brachytherapy
column6: which was completed 5 months before the current admission. She attended gynaecological oncology outpatient clinics and has been free of disease to date. On admission
column7: she presented with progressive asthenia
column8: anorexia and weakness of two weeks' duration
column9: disorientation and bradyphasia of two days' duration
column10: as well as constipation
column11: polyuria
column12: nocturia and polydipsia. A control blood test at her primary care centre showed a calcaemia of 15.35 mg/dL (reference values [v.r.] between 8.8 mg/dL and 10.2 mg/dL). A blood test was performed in the ED showing a calcaemia of 16.1 mg/dL with an ionic calcium of 6.3 mg/dL (r.v. between 4.2 mg/dL and 5.4 mg/dL)
column13: with a normal physical examination
column14: abdominal X-ray and electrocardiogram. She was diagnosed with hypercalcaemic syndrome and treated with rehydration
column15: intravenous zoledronate and furosemide
column16: with calcaemia decreasing to normal values between the third and sixth day of treatment3
column17: 4. The patient was admitted to the internal medicine ward where she was found to have: ESR 106 mm/h
column18: albumin 3.16 g/dL
column19: PTH 21.5 pg/mL (r.v. between 7 pg/mL and 82pg/mL)
column20: 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 9.9 ng/mL (r.v. between 6.6 ng/mL and 46.4 ng/mL) with negative tumour markers. Given the patient's personal history of uterine neoplasia
column21: a bone scan was requested
column22: which was normal
column23: and a thoracic and abdominal CT scan showed a 10 cm x 8 cm Douglas pouch mass with peritoneal tumour implants and pulmonary metastases. A transvaginal biopsy of the Douglas cul-de-sac mass was performed and confirmed a recurrence of her neoplastic disease. The patient is currently in a palliative care centre.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Mrs. T.P. is a 36-year-old woman who was employed from the age of 25 to 33 as a welder
column2: using styrene
column3: in a plastic tank factory. Approximately one year after starting work
column4: she became pregnant and was on sick leave until the age of 27
column5: as required by law. As the patient was exposed to styrene again for professional reasons
column6: she began to enjoy the subjective effects of volatile solvents
column7: including styrene and acetone. When the patient was 32 years old
column8: the company doctor recommended that she be removed from her job
column9: after urine tests showed elevated levels of styrene metabolites. After a year
column10: the patient decided to leave the factory. However
column11: her addictive behaviours had not only persisted but had extended to alcoholic household detergents
column12: hair sprays and motor fuels. Acute anxiety symptoms first appeared suddenly at work when the patient was 28 years old. Her first panic-like attack included dizziness
column13: trembling
column14: leg weakness and paraesthesias. Acute episodes of anxiety recurred and resulted in frequent absences from work for several days to recover from residual symptoms
column15: such as headache and vertigo. After leaving work she was depressed for a few months and was treated with antidepressant medication. Although she recovered from her affective disorder
column16: the residual anxiety symptoms were complicated by agoraphobia. Finally
column17: the patient developed duodenal ulcer at the age of 35 years. The main chronological relationships between occupational exposure
column18: substance abuse behaviour
column19: anxiety symptoms and life events are shown in Figure 1.  At the time of consultation
column20: the patient was unemployed and separated from her husband
column21: lived with her son in her mother's house
column22: presented with fluctuating anxiety and persistent symptoms of mild depression and
column23: although inhalant abuse was sporadic
column24: the patient reported withdrawal from volatile substances in recent days. The most prominent mental disorders on examination included vertigo
column25: psychic and somatic tension
column26: paraesthesias
column27: weakness in the legs and mild agoraphobia. The patient was dissatisfied with her prescribed antidepressant treatments (i.v. maprotiline
column28: v.o. paroxetine) and was dependent on anxiolytic drugs (mainly alprazolam). Psychiatric and psychological assessment Table I refers to the SCL-90-R scores and indices. Specifically
column29: the patient scored positive on all symptoms listed in the anxiety dimension in the last 7 days
column30: and all but two (palpitations and tremor) obtained maximum scores; in contrast
column31: the patient scored low on chest discomfort (which is an item of the somatization dimension).  We also administered the WAIS and the Rorschach test
column32: since abnormalities in performance on these instruments had been found among workers exposed to medium-low concentrations of styrene (Jégaden et al. 1993
column33: Lindstrom & Martelin 1980). Our patient showed an uneven profile of intellectual abilities on the Wechsler scale
column34: with obviously lower scores on two subtests: arithmetic and number series (mainly on the inverse series); apart from possible organic damage
column35: the loss of ability to concentrate may be due to anxiety. The Rorschach revealed a personality prone to emotional pain
column36: somatisation
column37: insecurity and depressive mood; the ego structure
column38: although fragile
column39: was well preserved; possible organic signs were below the threshold. Overall
column40: psychological assessment was consistent with neuroticism
column41: but did not demonstrate brain damage. Neuroimaging Axial and coronal magnetic resonance (MR) images were obtained after injection of medium contrast (gadolinium-DTPA). Previous MRI scans in inhalant abusers showed: a variable degree of brain atrophy
column42: poor differentiation between grey and white matter
column43: increased periventricular signal intensity and moderate hypointensity of the thalamus and basal ganglia on T2-weighted images (Yamanouchi et al. 1995). In our patient
column44: no signs of intraparenchymal intensity alterations or intracranial areas of hypersignal were observed
column45: so it was concluded that there was no brain alteration.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the clinical case of a 33-year-old man who consulted for progressive enlargement of the right testicle over three months. He reported no pain or urinary symptoms. He had no allergies or pathologies of interest. He reported normal psychomotor development with no history of cryptorchidism or hydrocele during childhood. He denies alcohol
column2: tobacco or other drug use. Physical examination revealed a diffuse increase in the size and consistency of the right testicle with negative transluminescence. The left testicle is normal. There were no palpable inguinal lymphadenopathies or in the rest of his anatomy. There was no gynaecomastia
column3: visceromegaly or peritoneal irritation. We decided to perform a testicular ultrasound in primary care
column4: and found a diffuse alteration of the ultrastructure without the presence of cysts or calcifications. We requested a complete blood analysis with tumour markers
column5: a chest X-ray and a preferential referral to the urology department. Both haemogram and basic biochemistry were strictly normal
column6: as were AFP
column7: Beta-HCG and LDH. The chest X-ray was also normal. Given the long waiting time for the urology consultation
column8: we decided to refer the patient to the hospital emergency department with the complete work-up performed in primary care. A regular testicular ultrasound was performed which confirmed: "Right testicle increased in size with diffuse alteration of echogenicity
column9: without calcifications
column10: with diffuse increase in vascularisation. Inflammatory process of the right orchitis type
column11: however
column12: given the time of evolution
column13: a neoplastic process cannot be ruled out". He was admitted to Urology and a radical right inguinal orchiectomy was performed. Pathological anatomy reports: "Classic seminoma with a diameter greater than 8 cm
column14: without evidence of infiltration of the tunica albuginea. Remains of testicular parenchyma with foci of intratubular germinal tumour. Epididymis and resection edge of the spermatic cord with no evidence of malignancy. In view of these findings
column15: an abdominopelvic computerised tomography (CT) scan was performed for staging: "No mediastinal
column16: hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy of significant size was observed. Right paracardiac adenopathy of 6 mm and micronodule of 4 mm in LM. No pathological retroperitoneal or pelvic lymphadenopathy was observed. There were findings compatible with mesenteric panniculitis and bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy with a reactive appearance secondary to surgery. The rest of the study showed no other findings. He was referred to Oncology with the diagnosis of pure stage I seminoma. Given that more than 80% of cases never relapse
column17: in correlation with the European Association of Urology Guidelines
column18: it was decided to perform surveillance without the need for adjuvant treatment. However
column19: the small but clinically significant risk of recurrence supports the need for long-term surveillance2 and initiation of salvage radiotherapy or cisplatin-based chemotherapy. As recurrences occur mainly in the first 2 years
column20: follow-up CT scanning is recommended every 3 months in the first year
column21: every 4 months in the second year and every 6 and 12 months in the following years3. Our patient has been followed up for more than 3 years
column22: with no data of relapse. The non-specific findings present in the first CT scan have disappeared and tumour markers remain negative to date.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a one-month-old male
column2: of Moroccan origin
column3: who came to the emergency department with vomiting
column4: refusal of food and abdominal distension of 4 days' duration. The pregnancy was controlled
column5: with no obstetric or perinatal history of interest
column6: and the baby was born at term with a weight appropriate for his gestational age. Examination revealed a fair general condition
column7: with cutaneous and mucosal pallor and generalised oedema
column8: predominantly in the lower extremities. A polyfocal grade IV/VI systolic murmur was auscultated. The abdomen was distended
column9: with presence of superficial venous network and ascites. Laboratory examination showed normocytic normochromic anaemia
column10: leukocytosis with normal formula
column11: creatinine less than 0.2mg/dl and urea 10mg/dl
column12: increased cholesterol and triglycerides
column13: and decreased total protein and albumin
column14: in addition to hyponatraemia
column15: hypokalaemia and hypocalcaemia. Parathyroid hormone was slightly elevated. Urine proteinuria was in the nephrotic range with a proteinuria/creatinuria ratio of 33.7.  Given the suspicion of CNS
column16: intensive diuretic and antiproteinuric therapy
column17: antithrombotic prophylaxis
column18: adjuvant treatment with alpha-calcidiol
column19: iron
column20: calcium carbonate and levothyroxine
column21: as well as enteral nutrition with hyperproteic and hypercaloric formula were started. He required treatment with serum albumin and erythropoietin. The cardiological study diagnosed moderate valvular pulmonary stenosis and atrial septal defect. The genetic study found Frameshift type mutations for the NPHS1 gene
column22: Intronic Variant type for the NPHS2 gene and Missense type for the WT1 gene. At three months of age he was readmitted for seizures secondary to severe hypocalcaemia. Due to the high levels of intravenous calcium required for its control through a peripheral venous access
column23: a third-degree burn occurred
column24: which required the placement of a skin graft. He required intensive care on two occasions at 4 and 6 months of age due to sepsis secondary to Staphylococcus hominis and Enterococcus faecalis
column25: respectively
column26: which were resolved with empirical antibiotherapy and subsequently according to antibiogram. Finally
column27: the patient died at 8 months of age due to bilateral pneumonia associated with pneumothorax with decompensation of his underlying pathology that caused refractory hypoxaemia.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 65-year-old Ecuadorian woman
column2: with no personal or family history of interest
column3: came to the ophthalmology outpatient clinic for a painless decrease in vision in the right eye (OD) of 3 to 4 months' duration. The maximum visual acuity (VA) in the right eye was 0.5 and in the left eye (LO) it was 1. Extrinsic and intrinsic motility was normal. In the OD there was papillary oedema with some subretinal exudate. CT and orbito-cerebral MRI
column4: luetic serology
column5: angiotensin converting enzyme
column6: Lyme serology and chest X-ray were negative. The systemic apparatus study was not significant. Mantoux (PPD)
column7: already in the first 24 hours
column8: had a 25 mm induration with areas of dermal necrosis. Chest X-ray was repeated and was also negative. CSF puncture showed an outflow pressure of 16 cm H2O with normal biochemistry and negative culture. CSF electrophoresis was performed and no oligoclonal bands were detected. Urine culture and sputum culture were also negative for mycobacterium tuberculosis growth. Suspected ocular tuberculosis was tested with isoniazid 300 mg/day for 3 weeks with subjective improvement in OD vision although maximum vision was still 0.5. He was treated with isoniazid 300 mg (9 months) together with rifampicin 600 mg (9 months)
column9: pyrazinamide 15 mg/kg (2 months) and ethambutol 15 mg/kg (2 months). One year after the first consultation the OD's visual acuity was 0.9 and his examination was normal.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male patient diagnosed with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis with anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies
column2: treated with steroids

column8: required several admissions for intestinal occlusion

column1: Adolescent aged 14 years
column2: admitted for treatment of a cervical disc herniation at C4-C5 level. One month earlier she had begun to suffer from right cervicobrachialgia and cervical muscle contractures
column3: without neurological deficits. The pain improved with conservative treatment
column4: but a few days later she began to have difficulty abducting her right upper limb. Physical examination revealed a loss of strength in the right deltoid and biceps (grades 2/5 and 4/5 respectively). There were no sensory alterations or pyramidalism in the lower limbs. Cervical spine X-rays showed loss of height in the vertebral bodies of C4-C5-C6
column5: as well as calcification at the level of the C4-C5 disc. Cervical MRI revealed a voluminous right C4-C5 disc herniation involving the ipsilateral root. A cervical computed tomography (CT) scan showed that the herniation was calcified. A complete analytical study was performed
column6: showing no abnormalities in the haemogram
column7: erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) or phosphocalcic metabolism. A scintigraphy ruled out pathological uptake.  This patient had been diagnosed at the age of 10 years with idiopathic intervertebral calcifications following a radiographic study due to cervical pain. This study showed the existence of a calcification at the level of C4-C5 and several calcifications at the dorsal level. An MRI ruled out any disc herniation. Until the current episode
column8: she had been asymptomatic
column9: except for occasional back pain. Given the patient's neurological deficit
column10: surgical treatment of the disc herniation via the anterolateral approach was chosen. During surgery
column11: an intervertebral disc with fine calcifications was observed. When the posterior common vertebral ligament was opened
column12: a whitish
column13: pasty material came out
column14: which was under moderate tension. The pathological report of the material obtained was fibrocartilage with foci of calcification. One month later the patient had fully recovered from her deficits.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 5-year-old boy with an unremarkable personal history and adequate paediatric control. The parents only emphasised that he was a child who did not eat much. A week before the incident
column2: he presented with an upper respiratory tract cold without fever or other associated signs. The parents report that he also presented non-specific abdominal discomfort
column3: accompanied by increased bowel sounds and nausea without vomiting. He was assessed by his local paediatrician
column4: who found no specific pathology and prescribed a soft diet. At 0 hours on the day of death
column5: the child woke up with unfocused abdominal pain. Over the next few hours
column6: he felt nauseous and had several episodes of vomiting
column7: first of food and finally mucous vomiting with no hematic or bilious traces. At 5 a.m.
column8: he was found to be weak and cold and was given a hot bath
column9: and in the bath he was found to be unresponsive to stimuli. The assistance of an emergency team was requested
column10: who found him in cardiorespiratory arrest and started CPR manoeuvres without success. A legal autopsy was performed. He was a normal male child
column11: 1.17 m tall
column12: with no signs of obesity or malnutrition
column13: with pale skin and mucous membranes. A complete autopsy was performed with opening of the three cavities and the anterior cervical plane
column14: following the recommendations of the Council of Europe [1]. No significant pathological alterations or developmental anomalies were observed. During the autopsy
column15: the examination of the abdominal cavity revealed a collection of serohaematic fluid of approximately 0.5 litres. The stomach shows little food debris with no haematic traces
column16: coffee grounds or bilious debris. The walls of the duodenum are preserved and the intestinal contents are normal. About 20 cms from the duodeno-jejunal angle
column17: the colour of the intestinal walls turns dark red
column18: maintaining this colour change until about 5 cms from the ileo-caecal valve. This last segment of the ileum is clearly narrowed with fibrous changes. Inside the segment of small intestine with parietal changes
column19: there is a haematic content of approximately 1.5 litres.  The position of the intestinal loops is altered by the presence of an anomaly in the closure of the mesentery of the cecum. There is an eyelet of about 3 cm in diameter located immediately next to the cecum
column20: through which the extensive passage of the small intestinal loops and part of the descending colon can be seen
column21: which is dilated and lateralised to the right and interrupted in its course by the passage through the eyelet
column22: continuing towards the rectum from the said eyelet.  The cause of death is estimated to be haemorrhagic shock secondary to mechanical obstruction and necrosis of the small intestine due to transmesocolic hernia with internal herniation of the small and large intestine.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 52-year-old white man consulted the Faculty of Dentistry of the UDELAR in Montevideo due to pain caused by an exophytic lesion in the right jugal mucosa. His personal medical history included occasional intestinal bleeding. Family history includes: father died of intestinal tumour
column2: brother operated for intestinal polyps and sister recently hysterectomised with bilateral oophorectomy; the family does not know the reason for this intervention. The patient has three healthy sons. Clinical examination reveals large head circumference
column3: hypertelorism
column4: broad nasal bridge
column5: prominent forehead and adenoid fascia. Multiple asymptomatic skin-coloured papular lesions are observed around the facial orifices. Careful clinical examination of the rest of the skin reveals palmoplantar keratoses simulating flat viral warts and non-keratotic papular lesions in the axillae
column6: groin and chest.  The oral examination shows: partial edentulous lower jaw
column7: total edentulous upper jaw (full denture upper jaw)
column8: deep palate and fissured tongue. The mucosa is covered with asymptomatic
column9: rounded papular lesions with defined borders
column10: without changes in colour
column11: smooth surface
column12: sessile or pedunculated and of variable size (no more than 1 cm). They are located on the cheeks
column13: rims
column14: attached gum
column15: lips and tongue.  The lesion that is the reason for consultation is on the cheek in the occlusal line; it is the largest and suffers trauma due to the prosthesis. His excised biopsy showed a non-specific papillomatous lesion. With the presumption of Cowden's disease
column16: the patient was referred to a multidisciplinary team comprising a geneticist
column17: dermatologist
column18: gastroenterologist and internist. A cranial computed tomography (CT) scan was performed
column19: which showed no alterations
column20: and intestinal endoscopy revealed mantle polyps. The anatomopathological report indicated hyperplastic polyps
column21: one of the serrated type associated with dysplastic changes. The paraclinical examinations and the phenotypic characteristics of the patient led the team of geneticists to confirm the diagnosis of Cowden's disease. To date
column22: no studies of the genetic material have been carried out. Subsequently
column23: the children are scheduled for testing. The middle son (21 years) has some of the clinical features of the disease (see table 1). The 27-year-old son has a weak expression of the syndrome phenotype
column24: while the youngest son (13 years old) has so far no alterations.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 38-year-old male patient was seen for right-sided coxalgia of one and a half years' duration
column2: with mechanical characteristics. He reported pain with physical exercise and slight limitation of mobility in certain postures. A mechanic by profession
column3: in his spare time he used to cycle (40 km a day at weekends)
column4: run 3 times a week for 50 minutes and walk for an hour on non-running days. The pain has progressively increased
column5: and at present he only walks. Physical examination revealed pain on palpation in the middle third of the right inguinal region with pain on flexion
column6: adduction and rotation
column7: especially internal rotation (positive shock manoeuvre). The hip joint balance is 110o flexion bilaterally
column8: internal rotation of 10o right
column9: 40o left and external rotation of 30o right
column10: 40o left. Muscle balance on the Daniels scale is 5/5 global bilateral. There is no pain on palpation of sciatic points and the Valleix
column11: Fabere
column12: Lasegue and Bragard manoeuvres are negative. There was also no pain on palpation of the iliotibial band and the Ober test was negative. In the gait examination
column13: we observed an absence of claudication and monopodal alternating right-left support is stable
column14: with negative Trendelenburg. The patient had pain on walking with forced flexion of the hip and knee. The simple anteroposterior (AP) X-ray showed a hump-shaped deformity in the right femoral cervico-cephalic region. The requested blood count
column15: biochemistry
column16: thyroid hormones
column17: antibodies and acute phase reactants were normal.  In view of these findings
column18: an MRI of the hip was requested
column19: which showed slight subchondral alteration
column20: with bone oedema in the right hip
column21: with cortical irregularity and slight synovitis in the joint interline
column22: with distension of the ilio-psoas bursa. The femoral head has a small bony islet and the alpha angle is greater than 50o. Arthrography shows a pinching of the antero-superior and postero-inferior joint interline
column23: an incipient femoral osteophyte collar with small antero-superior subchondral lesions of the femoral head and small foci of oedema in the anterosuperior acetabulum. There is no avascular necrosis or lesions in the labrum. A juxta-articular cystic lesion is also visualised in relation to the greater trochanter.  With the diagnosis of LEVA type femoroacetabular impingement syndrome (also known as CAM)
column24: the patient was prescribed magnet therapy treatment (15 sessions) to improve the pain symptoms and bone trophism. Pharmacological treatment is prescribed with an association of oral glucosamine-chondroitin sulphate 400 mg every 12 hours for 3 months and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs on demand if pain is present. She was instructed to rest in sports to avoid shock to the joint
column25: with controlled active physical activity
column26: recommending not exceeding 90 degrees of hip flexion and avoiding rotations. Referred to the arthroscopy unit of the traumatology department for assessment of arthroscopic surgery.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 50-year-old Caucasian woman with CKD secondary to polycystic kidney disease started haemodialysis in 1987 and received her first cadaveric donor kidney transplant in 1988. As complications of the transplant
column2: he presented acute rejection treated with steroid shocks
column3: antithymocyte globulin (ATG) and anti-CD3 monoclonal antibody (OKT3)
column4: returning to haemodialysis in June 2009 after loss of the renal graft due to chronic nephropathy. He was diagnosed with "non-A
column5: non-B" hepatitis in 1987 in connection with polytransfusion of blood products
column6: and HCV-RNA positive (genotype 1a) was subsequently confirmed. In November 2009
column7: five months after return to dialysis
column8: treatment was started with pegylated IFN α2a
column9: 135 μg weekly
column10: and RBV 200 mg every 48 hours
column11: with oscillating erythropoietin support throughout treatment. In February 2010
column12: he started with fever and haematuria
column13: so the dose of antiviral treatment was reduced and embolisation of the renal graft was performed on suspicion of acute rejection of the non-functioning graft. Treatment was resumed with IFN and RBV at the initial dose
column14: which had to be suspended at week 40 due to the appearance of exudative erythema multiforme with no response to corticosteroid treatment. The patient had a rapid viral response with undetectable load at week 4 of treatment and subsequent SVR. In July 2011
column15: she received her second cadaveric donor kidney transplant. She currently maintains normal renal function and negative viral load.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 12-year-old girl was followed up by the Paediatric Infectious Diseases Unit due to left chest pain associated with pneumonia. After resolution of the pneumonia
column2: the chest pain persisted
column3: so she was referred to the paediatric pneumology and paediatric orthopaedics departments and finally to the paediatric surgery department. She presented with a picture of selective left costal pain of 3 months' evolution
column4: which was not related to postural changes or respiratory movements
column5: was continuous and was not relieved by oral analgesics. On examination
column6: she presented with more intense pain on palpation of the left costal border
column7: with the most painful point being located at the junction of the 10th left rib with the 11th rib. The rest of the examination revealed no pathological signs
column8: nor did the chest X-ray. Initial anti-inflammatory treatment was recommended
column9: ruling out other diagnostic possibilities. Since there was no improvement
column10: excision of the junction of the left 10th rib with the 11th rib was indicated under general anaesthesia. In both cases there was a resolution of symptoms from the first postoperative day. After four years of evolution
column11: we can qualify the result as satisfactory.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 39-year-old female patient
column2: 59 kg and 160 cm tall
column3: with a history of four spontaneous abortions of seven to ten weeks with a live embryo. The sterility studies she had undergone were within normal limits
column4: except for a diagnosis of heterozygous Factor V Leiden6. This alteration results in a variant of human coagulation factor V that frequently causes an inherited hypercoagulability disorder
column5: most commonly among Eurasians. In these cases
column6: the factor V Leiden variant cannot be inactivated by activated protein C. In pregnant women with this abnormality
column7: prophylactic administration of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) at therapeutic doses adjusted per kg of body weight is recommended as soon as gestation is diagnosed and up to 6-8 weeks postpartum. It should be noted that in the last gestation the patient experienced a miscarriage despite being treated with LMWH
column8: so the haematological origin of these miscarriages is ruled out. With the previous obstetric history (G4P0A4)
column9: the patient began a new pregnancy with a therapeutic regimen of LMWH enoxaparin 40 mg/24 h
column10: as soon as she was aware of this. At five weeks the patient underwent an immunological study. The results showed NK cell values above normal
column11: with 18% of peripheral NK cells and 95% of them with CD56+CD16 expression (17% of the lymphocytes). According to the algorithm proposed by Ramos-Medina3 et al. for the patient's age
column12: these values imply a high risk of presenting an immunological alteration associated with reproductive failure. Based on the study carried out
column13: they conclude that: a percentage of NK cells > 18% is the best variable for discriminating women with reproductive failure
column14: and for women over 35 years of age
column15: CD56+CD16 cell values above 13% define a special subgroup of patients with a high risk of pregnancy loss (100%). Off-label use of this drug is requested. After authorisation by the centre's management and the signature of the pregnant woman on the informed consent form
column16: the administration of the IGs regimen described in the literature was started. It starts with IGs 400 mg/kg body weight
column17: every four weeks
column18: from the knowledge of week 4 to week 13
column19: once a month; then 200 mg/kg monthly until week 36
column20: since it has been shown that GIs cross the placenta more intensively after the third trimester. After two doses of IGs
column21: a new immunological study is requested
column22: showing a reduction of NK cells to 8% with 90% CD56+CD16 markers (7.2% of lymphocytes). Figure 1.  Treatment was administered according to schedule with no incidents or relevant adverse effects with respect to the established IGs regimen. At week 40 + 1 the pregnant woman had a live birth by elective caesarean section. She was switched to a thromboprophylactic regimen of LMWH the day before the operation and discontinued the same day. The therapeutic dose is restarted at 12-24 hours and continued for two months.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient
column2: a 55-year-old man with no known allergies diagnosed with gastric adenocarcinoma
column3: was admitted in November 2001 to the Digestive Department of the Hospital Son Dureta where he underwent a subtotal gastrectomy with reconstruction of the transit by means of a Billroth II gastrojejunostomy. Five days after the surgery
column4: the patient's clinical situation required the prescription of artificial nutrition
column5: and the administration of TPN via the central line was started. The preparation administered was Kabimix® (see detailed composition in table I)
column6: a 2
column7: 553 kilocalorie diet supplemented in the Pharmacy Service with a multivitamin preparation (PMV) (Cernevit®) and trace elements (Addamel®) on alternate days. 48 hours after the introduction of parenteral nutrition
column8: it was decided to change the type of diet in order to administer a formula more suited to the patient's nutritional requirements
column9: so the patient received the Kabiven® formula supplemented with the same PMV and trace elements every other day
column10: starting with the vitamins. Within 24 hours of starting the infusion of this diet
column11: the patient presents with a significant disseminated pruritic rash requiring the administration of oral dexchlorpheniramine. Mechanical complications caused the loss of the central line
column12: leading to the decision to withdraw the TPN and initiate oral tolerance. On the eighth day after surgery
column13: the patient reported severe abdominal pain
column14: which led to an exploratory laparotomy and the detection of an abscess with a biliary collection. TPN was restarted by administering the Kabiven® diet supplemented with the aforementioned PMV. A few hours after starting the infusion
column15: a new episode of disseminated pruritic skin rash occurred
column16: which led to the definitive suspension of TPN.  In March 2003
column17: the patient went to the emergency department of the aforementioned hospital for fever and abdominal pain
column18: was diagnosed with cholangitis and was admitted to the Digestive Department. In addition to antibiotic and analgesic treatment
column19: an absolute diet was prescribed and
column20: due to the history of hypersensitivity
column21: TPN was avoided
column22: and an amino acid and glucose solution (Aminoven®
column23: table III) was administered
column24: without erythema being observed or the patient reporting pruritus. After 48 hours
column25: lipid emulsion (Intralipid® 10%
column26: table III) was added centrally without any complications. On this occasion
column27: it was decided not to administer PMV or trace elements to the patient. After several days of hospitalisation
column28: progression of the gastric neoformative process was observed and the patient died in April 2003.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 36-year-old woman assessed in our clinic. Her personal history included a diagnosis of epilepsy at the age of 15 and menstrual migraine. The first of these was due to several episodes of loss of consciousness preceded by feelings of dizziness
column2: sweating and tinnitus
column3: which occurred approximately every two months. She was treated with valproic acid (VPA) for two years
column4: during which she remained asymptomatic. The menstrual migraine started at the age of 21 years
column5: usually with a marked vegetative cortex and severe vomiting. At the age of 24
column6: after vomiting during migraine attacks
column7: she began to lose consciousness again
column8: from which she recovered spontaneously a few seconds later. However
column9: on one occasion
column10: while unconscious
column11: she began to make guttural sounds and had a generalised seizure lasting one minute. She was evaluated by a neurologist
column12: who performed an electroencephalogram (EEG) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain
column13: all of which were normal. With the clinical diagnosis of epilepsy
column14: she was started on treatment with zonisamide (ZNS) at a dose of 250 mg daily. The patient continued to suffer from episodes of loss of consciousness
column15: although less frequently. They were usually preceded by tinnitus
column16: sound distancing
column17: palpitations
column18: a feeling of faintness and weakness. At this time he came to our clinic for the first time. A new EEG showed right temporal slow waves and a single peak wave discharge in the same location after hyperventilation
column19: without clinical symptoms. We continued the study with a tilt table test
column20: during which she suffered a regular episode of intense dizziness with palpitations coinciding with a complete left bundle branch block (LBBB). She was therefore diagnosed with an intraventricular conduction disorder and a subcutaneous Holter-electrocardiogram (ECG) was implanted
column21: and the ZNS was progressively withdrawn. In the following months she presented three new episodes of loss of consciousness
column22: with stress as the only apparent cause. One of these occurred during sleep
column23: awakening with vegetative cortex and
column24: for the first time
column25: was accompanied by urinary incontinence; another was preceded by asthenia and an ascending epigastric burning sensation
column26: also associated with lateral tongue biting and subsequent confusion. The Holter-ECG reading of one episode showed a LBBB
column27: but no changes were recorded in the other episodes. As the episodes continued and new clinical features were added (urinary incontinence and lateral tongue bite)
column28: we performed video-EEG monitoring and simultaneous ECG recording. The intercritical tracing showed the presence of slow waves and right temporal epileptiform discharges
column29: sometimes in the form of prolonged bursts of rhythmic waves. During the study
column30: she presented with an episode of self-limited dizziness
column31: similar to those initially described
column32: which on EEG recording corresponded to organised rhythmic theta activity in the anteromedial region of the right temporal lobe
column33: then spreading to the ipsilateral posteromedial region. Coinciding with the clinical onset
column34: a bundle branch block appeared on ECG. A brain MRI showed slight dilatation of the temporal horn of the right lateral ventricle
column35: with no other alterations.  Based on the data obtained
column36: we concluded that the episodes were compatible with focal seizures of right temporal origin
column37: in the context of focal epilepsy of unknown cause
column38: as we did not find a clear lesion in the brain MRI. She started treatment with levetiracetam (LEV) at a maximum dose of 2
column39: 000 mg/day
column40: without the episodes disappearing and with side effects (mainly insomnia and irritability)
column41: so it had to be replaced by oxcarbazepine (OXC) up to a dose of 1
column42: 800 mg/day. With this drug he has been free of episodes and without side effects.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 45-year-old man who presented with bilateral ocular pain
column2: intense photophobia and decreased visual acuity (VA). A fortnight earlier he had been diagnosed with keratoconjunctivitis
column3: probably adenoviral
column4: and was being treated with tobramycin eye drops (Tobrex
column5: Alcon Cusi
column6: Barcelona) and cyclopentolate hydrochloride (Cicloplegic
column7: Llorens
column8: Barcelona). She reported itching
column9: photophobia and redness for 3 months
column10: concomitant with asthenia
column11: cachexia and a weight loss of 16 kilograms (kg). His personal history included chronic alcoholic pancreatitis
column12: non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus
column13: smoking and a cholecystostomy with percutaneous shunt performed 11 months earlier. Ophthalmological history includes excision of a pterygium in the OD associated with betatherapy 5 years earlier and a posterior sclerocorneal lamellar lamellar graft due to trauma. On examination
column14: the patient had finger-counting VA (cd) at 3 metres in the OD and light perception and projection in the OI. The OD showed intense vascular injection
column15: microcystic epithelial oedema
column16: superior peripheral ulcerative keratitis (PUC)
column17: 4-cross tyndall and posterior synechia
column18: with intraocular pressure (IOP) of 16 mmHg and a non-relevant fundus oculi (FO). The OI shows a very severe injection of conjunctival
column19: ciliary and episcleral vascularisation
column20: 360º pannus
column21: pterygium
column22: a central corneal ulcer with stromal necrosis
column23: hyphema level occupying half of the anterior chamber (AC) and 360º posterior synechiae
column24: with IOP of 26 mmHg and unexplorable FO. Corneal sensitivity is normal in both eyes (AO). He was admitted to the hospital to start a study and treatment with oral prednisone 1 mg/kg/day (Dacortin 30 mg
column25: Merck
column26: Barcelona)
column27: oral doxycycline 100 mg/12 h (Vibracina 100
column28: Pfizer
column29: Madrid)
column30: atropine eye drops 1%/8 h (Atropine 1%
column31: Alcon Cusí)
column32: tobramycin and dexamethasone/4 h (Tobradex
column33: Alcon Cusí) and carmellose sodium 0.5/h (Viscofresh 0.5%
column34: Allergan
column35: Madrid). Seven days later the hyphema disappeared
column36: but a level of hypopyon appeared in the OI
column37: so vancomycin eye drops at a concentration of 50 mg/ml/h (Diatracin Injectable 500 mg
column38: Lilly and Dista
column39: Madrid)
column40: and gentamicin 14 mg/ml/h (Gevramycin 40 mg injectable
column41: Schering-Plough
column42: Madrid)
column43: with negative corneal cultures for bacteria
column44: fungi
column45: viruses and parasites
column46: were associated. A diagnostic-therapeutic upper conjunctival excision OD ruled out vasculitic lesions or the presence of herpes simplex virus (HSV 1 and 2) by immunohistochemistry
column47: showing intense acanthosis and an absence of goblet cells. Systemic examination ruled out any signs of rheumatic involvement
column48: with negative serology for infectious diseases and markers of rheumatic diseases and vasculitis
column49: except for elevated C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Laboratory tests revealed macrocytic and hypochromic anaemia
column50: a pattern of severe lipoprotein malnutrition
column51: hyperglycaemia and elevated liver enzymes. Malabsorption studies revealed mild malabsorption and decreased fat-soluble vitamins [vitamin A: 0.24 mg/ml (micrograms/millilitre) (N:0.4-0.8)]
column52: and vitamin A carrier proteins [retinol binding protein (RBP) and prealbumin]. Chest X-ray
column53: cranial and thoraco-abdominal computed tomography (CT) were normal. The orbital CT scan showed mucosal thickening of the right maxillary sinus with normal ENT examination. Ocular ultrasound ruled out vitreo-retinal involvement of the OI. A diagnosis of calorie and protein malnutrition with vitamin A deficiency was made
column54: and treatment was started with a high protein and high calorie diet without sugar
column55: pancreatic enzymes and oral vitamins. The evolution was favourable
column56: with resolution of the AO picture after 2 months and a VA of 1 OD and of cd to 1 m OI. The OI presents a central leukoma limited inferiorly by a lipid keratopathy and posterior synechiae
column57: which still prevent seeing the FO.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 25-year-old female patient came to the Nutrition Clinic for monitoring of her nutritional status; seven months earlier she had been diagnosed with Ulcerative Colitis (UC)
column2: and during this period she had received treatment with corticosteroids: methylprednisolone 1.5 mg/kg/24 h IV during two months of admission and 30 mg/24 h of prednisone orally in a descending dosage for the remaining five months. He reported arthralgia in both knees
column3: and on examination showed pain on posterior rotation in both femoral heads
column4: more evident in the right hip
column5: which also showed limited internal rotation; the left knee had reduced flexion movement
column6: and on gait examination there was claudication to the right side. No markers of autoimmunity were detected
column7: and plasma concentrations of calcium
column8: phosphorus and vitamin D were within the normal range. Bone densitometry (BMD) showed osteoporosis at the lumbar spine (T score - 3
column9: 1) and osteopenia at the femoral neck (T score - 1.5). Plain radiographs showed data suggestive of grade II NA in both femoral heads
column10: more evident on the right side; in the knees an osteochondral lesion was observed in the internal femoral condyle of the left knee with irregularities in its articular surface. MRI confirmed necrotic lesions in both femoral heads and in both knees
column11: both on the tibial and femoral side. The next MRI
column12: performed only 3 months later
column13: showed evidence of subsidence in the right hip.  The patient was treated with alendronate and calcium and vitamin D supplementation for osteoporosis
column14: corticosteroids were discontinued and weight bearing of the affected joints was advised.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 47-year-old man
column2: with no past history of interest
column3: with a history of headache and occasional vertigo in the last four years
column4: who consulted for a non-specific vision disorder. The neurological examination was normal
column5: except for the detection of a right lower homonymous quadrantanopsia in the campimetric study. There were no associated malformations or anomalies in or outside the central nervous system. Computed tomography (CT) was normal. An MRI study was performed which showed
column6: in T1 sequences and in parasagittal projection
column7: two foci of hypersignal located in the quadrigeminal cistern and in the upper lip of the left calcarine fissure compatible with the diagnosis of lipomas. No surgical intervention was performed
column8: and the patient remained with identical symptoms two years later. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 74-year-old female patient referred from Gynaecology Outpatient Clinic to Urology for recurrent urinary tract infections (UTI) with hypogastric pain of at least six months' duration. Her personal history includes a hysterectomy via the vagina for uterine prolapse seven months ago in another centre
column2: requiring readmission 18 days after surgery for fever and pain
column3: with a diagnosis of vaginal vault abscess that drained spontaneously
column4: with the clinical picture disappearing; the tests performed on admission showed: ECHO and CT scan of vaginal vault abscess with no other findings. No DM. No hypertension. No known allergies. No haematuria. No cramps. Sporadic urinary tract infections. G2 A0V2
column5: no leakage.  When she was referred to our clinic for urinary tract infection and UTI
column6: she was accompanied by a simple urinary tract X-ray which was reported as normal
column7: although a weakly calcified outline was clearly seen in the pelvis in the bladder area
column8: and a transvaginal ultrasound scan reported probable bladder lithiasis
column9: a diagnosis for which she was referred to the Urology Department of our centre together with the repeated urinary tract infections.  Given the finding in the accompanying simple X-ray and transvaginal ultrasound with intravesical lithiasis
column10: non-mobile and with the surgical history referred to
column11: the presence of an intravesical foreign body is suspected from the outset due to probable loss of material used in surgery. Urethrocystoscopy was performed on the same day as the consultation to confirm the suspected diagnosis
column12: which was confirmed
column13: and a large "gauze pellet" was observed adhered to the bladder wall
column14: which could not be moved because it was calcified; a pelvic CT scan was requested to assess the extension and size as well as the relationship with the area.  With the definitive diagnosis of intravesical lithiasis due to a foreign body
column15: probably abandoned during the hysterectomy surgery
column16: it was proposed to extract it by cystoslitectomy or more correctly "cystogasomectomy" by means of an open bladder opening
column17: finding the foreign body described. After a good evolution the patient is asymptomatic
column18: the repeated urinary tract infections have disappeared
column19: although in the two years of follow-up she has had an isolated episode
column20: the patient leads an absolutely normal life.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 72-year-old man
column2: with no medical history of interest and under treatment with anti-inflammatory drugs since 2011 for chronic cervical pain
column3: attended the emergency department reporting significant gait disturbance and progressive loss of strength in the limbs over the last 6 months accompanied by dysphagia for solids and moderate dyspnoeic symptoms. Physical examination revealed spastic left hemiparesis
column4: generalised hyperreflexia
column5: positive Romberg's sign and ataxia. MRI showed soft tissue thickening around the odontoid process leading to severe stenosis of the spinal canal
column6: especially in the left half
column7: with involvement of the bulbomedullary junction and voluminous anterior syndesmotic proliferations at C2-C6
column8: predominantly at C4-C5
column9: which deformed and partially obliterated the airway.  With a diagnosis of Forestier's disease
column10: the patient initially underwent transoral surgery
column11: with resection of the anterior arch of the atlas and the odontoid process without neurological improvement
column12: so an external anterolateral cervical approach and resection of the anterior osteophytic projections of C3-C4-C5 were performed. Postoperative evolution showed progressive clinical improvement of dysphagia and hemiparesis with absence of respiratory symptoms.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 78-year-old man with a personal history of allergy to sulphonamides and thiazides
column2: ex-smoker and ex-drinker
column3: chronic bronchitis with home oxygen
column4: chronic atrial fibrillation
column5: peripheral arteriopathy and chronic venous insufficiency. His usual treatment was furosemide
column6: pentoxifylline
column7: acenocoumarol
column8: omeprazole
column9: oral iron and paracetamol. She was admitted to our hospital for antibiotic treatment and treatment of mixed ulcers with a torpid evolution. Physical examination on admission: blood pressure 100/61 mmHg
column10: mixed ulcers with exudate on both lower limbs; the rest of the examination was of no interest. Blood tests on admission: creatinine 1.5 mg/dl (previous 1.4-1.6 mg/dl) (Cockcroft-Gault 28 ml/min)
column11: uric acid 9.4 mg/dl
column12: albumin 3.2 g/dl
column13: haematocrit 27.8 %
column14: haemoglobin 8.9 g/dl
column15: other blood tests normal. Culture of the exudate from the ulcers was positive for Pseudomona aeruginosa and Streptococcus beta non-A non-B sensitive to cefepime. Antibiotic treatment was started with cefepime at a dose of 2 grams every 8 hours i.v. for 10 days. On the fourth day of antibiotic treatment renal function remained stable with serum creatinine of 1.4 mg/day. On the tenth day of cefepime treatment (when the antibiotic was discontinued)
column16: previous renal function deterioration was noted
column17: with serum creatinine of 2.8 mg/dl. One day after discontinuation of cefepime
column18: this deterioration of renal function persisted and the patient also presented confusional syndrome and restlessness
column19: for which reason the Nephrology and Neurology Departments were consulted. The anamnesis was impossible to perform due to the patient's excitability and restlessness. Serum therapy with isotonic saline solution was started. Renal ultrasound showed reduced kidney size (8 cm). An electroencephalogram (EEG) was performed
column20: which was pathological
column21: with the presence of bilateral electrical status (constant bilateral slow
column22: sharp and triphasic wave discharges). A cerebral axial computed tomography scan was also performed
column23: with the only finding being cortico-subcortical atrophy. Given the suspicion of neurotoxicity caused by cefepime
column24: phenytoin was prescribed with a loading dose of 1000 mg i.v. and then 100 mg/8 hours i.v.
column25: and urgent haemodialysis was performed through a catheter in the left femoral vein for 3 hours. Pre-dialysis plasma levels of cefepime (24 hours after antibiotic discontinuation) were measured and were 50
column26: 087 µg/ml. After the first dialysis session the patient was calmer and more alert. Given the clinical improvement after the first dialysis session and considering the high mortality rate related to cefepime-related neurotoxicity
column27: three more haemodialysis sessions were performed
column28: with undetectable pre-dialysis cefepime levels in the fourth session. The new EEG
column29: after 4 dialysis sessions
column30: showed a dramatic improvement over the previous recording. After three days without dialysis
column31: serum creatinine remained at 2.7 mg/dl. One week after discharge from hospital
column32: the recovery of renal function (creatinine 1.6 mg/dl) was observed at the outpatient clinic
