column1: A 57-year-old man
column2: with a personal history of COPD
column3: smoker of 15 packs/year and moderate drinker
column4: consulted for a fast-growing
column5: painless tumour
column6: firmly adherent to deep planes
column7: of one month's evolution
column8: in the region of the sternal manubrium. Plain X-ray and CT scan with intravenous contrast and three-dimensional reconstruction of the thorax showed a tumour measuring 5-6 cm in diameter in the sternal manubrium with cortical destruction. There were no signs of mediastinal infiltration or infiltration of the clavicles. (See Figures 1 and 2).  General laboratory tests showed no significant alterations
column9: with normal immunoglobulin studies (IgG
column10: IgA
column11: IgM and beta 2 microglobulin). A FNA was performed and a surgical biopsy was performed
column12: finding an atypical cytology that was not conclusive of the histological type. Immunohistochemistry tests were positive for the following markers: CD 138; CD 68 (isolated); LAMBDA (some cells); KAPPA (intense positivity in almost all cells). Plasmacytoma was suspected. Bone scintigraphy only showed increased uptake in the region of the sternal tumour and both sternoclavicular joints. Bone marrow biopsy showed no pathological findings and urine examination revealed the absence of Bence-Jones proteins. Wide en bloc removal of the sternal manubrium and partial resection of both clavicles
column13: the first two ribs and the body of the sternum
column14: including the skin overlying the tumour
column15: were performed. No mediastinal infiltration was observed. Coverage of the resulting defect with a polypropylene mesh and suture of the pectorals in the midline. There were no postoperative complications. The fixation and stability of the chest wall were satisfactory from the immediate postoperative period. Hospital stay was 7 days. The anatomopathological description of the operative specimen indicated abundant mononucleated plasma cells intermixed with multinucleated ones with immunohistochemical positivity for antiCD138 and lambda chain antibodies and negativity for kappa chain antibodies. The resection margins were free of disease. Treatment was completed with radiotherapy (50 Gy in 30 sessions over 4 weeks). At the 6-month postoperative follow-up
column16: no clinical or tomographic signs of disease progression or late postoperative complications were evident.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 56-year-old woman with moderate congenital mental retardation
column2: dyslipidaemia and hypothyroidism came for consultation due to progressive constipation
column3: increased abdominal perimeter and weight loss of 8 kg in the last 4 months. Physical examination revealed palpation of a central
column4: hard
column5: poorly demarcated hypogastric mass measuring approximately 10 x 8 cm. Laboratory tests
column6: including acute phase reactants and digestive and gynaecological tumour markers
column7: as well as gynaecological ultrasound
column8: were normal. An abdominopelvic CT scan was performed
column9: showing a giant dilatation of the rectum and left colon
column10: occupied in the entire lumen by compacted faecal debris
column11: causing displacement of all the abdominal organs and bilateral hydronephrosis without associated renal insufficiency. Colonoscopy up to the cecum with biopsies and pelvic MRI were normal. Anorectal manometry was performed
column12: which showed preservation of the inhibitory rectoanal reflex. Treatment was started with oral polyethylene glycol and lactulose enemas
column13: with notable clinical improvement
column14: and she is currently on maintenance therapy with oral lactulose at high doses with weight gain and a bowel movement every 24-48 hours.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient is a 12-year-old male born at term with the use of forceps for stationary dilatation. Apgar and other postpartum examinations were normal. Rest was indicated during the last trimester of pregnancy due to threatened labour. During the postnatal period she presented delayed psychomotor development. At 3 years of age
column2: she presented with absence seizures without subsequent epileptic seizures or need for treatment. Currently
column3: she presents moderate mental retardation
column4: learning difficulties
column5: severe behavioural alterations in the autism spectrum
column6: sphincter control deficit and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
column7: treated first with methylphenidate without improvement and
column8: subsequently and up to the present
column9: with antioxidants and improvement of the disorder. He also has social anxiety and extreme phobias to noises and animals
column10: hypersensitivity to sounds
column11: textures and certain foods
column12: as well as chewing difficulties and secondary vomiting
column13: generalised hypotonia
column14: lax joints
column15: valgus feet that have required surgery
column16: and a significant sleep disturbance treated with melatonin. He has no cardiological or dysautonomic alterations or characteristic facial features. The patient has an older healthy brother
column17: but has a second cousin on the maternal side
column18: aged 33 years
column19: diagnosed at the age of 13 years with FXS after genetic testing. At that time the entire maternal side of the family was genetically tested and it was reported orally
column20: without a written report
column21: that both the patient's mother and her sisters were healthy carriers. This condition was not sufficiently appreciated by the family in the face of successive healthy children of the case patient's sisters and healthy brother. The case patient's mother did not receive genetic counselling or prenatal diagnosis indications in either of her two pregnancies. Only at her request was genetic analysis performed in the postnatal period in both cases.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 57-year-old woman came to the dentist's office for treatment of a caries on the occlusal surface of the lower right 2nd molar (47). With the patient semi-recumbent
column2: without cervical extension
column3: local anaesthesia was infiltrated and no abnormal reactions were observed. Subsequently
column4: the caries was reamed with the turbine. During the drilling
column5: the patient developed rotational vertigo. The vertigo subsided as soon as work with the turbine was stopped. When the drilling was restarted
column6: the patient again presented rotatory vertigo
column7: which was milder on this occasion
column8: which allowed the filling to be completed without any further problems. The patient was referred to the Otolaryngologist to study her vertigo in response to intense sound (Tullio's phenomenon). The anamnesis
column9: audiological tests (audiometry and impedance audiometry)
column10: vestibular tests (recording of vertic-rotatory nystagmus in response to high intensity sound stimuli)
column11: neurophysiological tests (recording of abnormal vestibular myogenic evoked myogenic potentials) and computed tomography demonstrated the existence of a dehiscence of the right superior semicircular canal.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male infant born at 40 weeks gestation with vaginal delivery and cephalic presentation. Birth weight was 3
column2: 700 g and height 47 cm. Urological assessment was requested due to the existence of a large bilateral scrotal enlargement. Physical examination revealed a tension hydrocele in the right hemiscrotal and a mild hydrocele on the left side
column3: with positive transillumination. The left teste was normal in terms of morphology and consistency
column4: but palpation of the right testicle was difficult due to the presence of a tension hydrocele.  Blood tests showed moderate leukocytosis. Urine sediment was normal. Doppler ultrasound was performed by adjusting both the pulse rate and the wall filter to the lowest levels of the ultrasound machine. The findings were bilateral hydrocele
column5: being large on the right side
column6: with the right teste showing preserved arterial Doppler flow
column7: although with an elevated resistance index (RI) (RI=0.82; Normal: 0.48-0.75)
column8: absence of venous flow and heterogeneous echogenicity
column9: suggesting areas of destructuring. The left testicle is normal ultrasonographically
column10: presenting a peak systolic velocity of 11 cm/s and diastolic velocity of 5 cm/s
column11: with an IR of 0.55. Given the suspicion of testicular vascular compromise
column12: surgical exploration was decided eighteen hours after birth. We observed a tension hydrocele with no evidence of cord torsion
column13: and the teste had a purplish colour and a necrotic appearance
column14: so orchiectomy was performed.  The postoperative course was without immediate complications. The pathological anatomy of the specimen showed testicular haemorrhagic infarction.  After eight months of follow-up the patient is asymptomatic and the left hydrocele has disappeared.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 75-year-old woman with a history of type II DM under insulin treatment with chronic complications such as polyneuropathy
column2: HTN under treatment and obese
column3: who is scheduled for PTR (total knee replacement) surgery. The anaesthetic technique was a combined epidural/intradural procedure at L3-L4 level
column4: 3 ml of bupivacaine 0.5% without vasoconstrictor was administered through the intradural needle and an epidural catheter was left in place for postoperative analgesia. The postoperative period was uneventful and she went upstairs with a PCAE (epidural PCA) loaded with bupivacaine 0.125 and fentanyl 4 micrograms per ml
column5: with a schedule of 3 ml.h-1
column6: 3 ml boluses every 30 minutes. At approximately 4 a.m. the PCA was changed
column7: causing the error and administering via epidural a PCA with medication and programming for i.v. (in 100 ml
column8: 50 mg of fentanyl every 30 minutes). (in 100 ml
column9: 50 mg of morphine plus 10 g of metamizole). At the time of the daily visit to the PACU
column10: the nurse of the PACU detects the error. The patient is conscious and oriented with excellent analgesia
column11: with no evidence of respiratory depression
column12: neurological alterations or other side effects. The amount of drug administered was 4 mg morphine and 160 mg metamizole. The PCA and catheter were removed and the patient was admitted to the Resuscitation Unit for control and follow-up
column13: where she did not present any side effects and remained stable at all times. 24 hours later
column14: she was discharged to the ward and 2 weeks later she was discharged home
column15: after a review by the anaesthesiologist. Periodic follow-up was carried out for up to 18 months without any incidence.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 52-year-old woman came to the emergency department for sudden and painless loss of vision in the left eye (OI). She had no relevant personal or family history. On ophthalmological examination
column2: her best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) in the right eye (RA) was 0.9 and in the LA 0.6. Intraocular pressure (IOP) and biomicroscopy (BMC) of the anterior pole showed no significant alterations. Fundus visualisation (FO) showed a brownish mottling
column3: more prominent temporal to the fovea
column4: corresponding to the typical "orange peel fundus" image. There were also characteristic angioid striae (AE)
column5: as well as colloid bodies in both eyes (AO). In his OI
column6: there were striking drusen of the optic nerve and a subfoveal greyish lesion within an elevated AE
column7: bordered by haemorrhages
column8: compatible with CNV.  A series of complementary tests were therefore performed
column9: showing diffuse hyperautofluorescent mottling (hyper-FA) and irregular linear hypoautofluorescent lesions (hypo-FA) with hyper-FA mottling in their bed in the fundus autofluorescence (FA) of the AO. In the OI
column10: optic nerve drusen and colloid bodies with intense hyper-FA were prominent. Fluorescein angiography (FAG) revealed a hyper- and hypofluorescent lattice due to alteration of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and a hyperfluorescent lesion with late diffusion in the LA compatible with CNV. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) showed a destructuring of the EPR-choriocapillary hyperreflective band in the AO
column11: and in the OI a dense cupuliform lesion (CNV)
column12: bordered by a small detachment of neuroepithelium. After ophthalmological diagnosis
column13: she was referred to the elastic pseudoxanthoma unit of our hospital
column14: where the disease was confirmed. Treatment was prescribed with monthly intravitreal injections of 0.05ml of ranibizumab (Lucentis) for 3 months in her OI
column15: with measurement of the MAVC and OCT one month after each injection
column16: and control AFG at 3 months. Periodic follow-up OCT scans were performed for a follow-up period of one year. At 3 months
column17: a clear improvement in the condition was observed
column18: as the MAVC improved to 0.7
column19: subretinal haemorrhages disappeared and macular thickness decreased on OCT.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient is a 50-year-old woman who is an occasional smoker. Her personal history of interest included a nine-day tourist trip to the Mayan Riviera (Mexican Caribbean)
column2: fifteen days before the onset of symptoms. During the trip
column3: the patient reported numerous mosquito bites. In the 48 hours prior to consultation
column4: the patient self-treated with acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) as an antipyretic and symptomatic treatment for headache. On physical examination the patient was conscious
column5: oriented and febrile (37.6ºC)
column6: BP=110/70. There was facial flushing and bilateral conjunctival injection as well as the presence of a haemorrhagic
column7: symmetrical
column8: maculo-papular rash on the trunk and extremities
column9: especially on the lower limbs
column10: where it was confluent
column11: and which did not change on vitropressure. In the rest of the examination by apparatus
column12: only the presence of numerous latero- and retrocervical adenopathies and preauricular adenopathies was identified. There was no evidence of meningismus or hepatosplenomegaly.  The Rumpell-Leade loop test showed more than 30 petechiae in the right antecubital fossa. A haematological examination showed: red blood cells 4.90x106/microL with haematocrit of 43% and normal platelets. The white blood count showed 7
column13: 700 leukocytes with relative lymphopenia (22%) and the presence of numerous activated lymphocytes. The ESR was 28 mm at 1 hour
column14: with CRP=6.62 mg/dL. Coagulation tests were normal for both tracts. Biochemistry showed a creatinine of 1.28 mg/dL with ALT=78 U/L transaminitis. Gross gout and blood smear were negative. Finally
column15: the immunological analysis determined: negative MgIgAc against CMV
column16: negative HBcAc
column17: HBsAgAg and HBsAgAg
column18: negative MgIgAc against P. falciparum and positive MgIgAc against dengue (IFA). Blood smear and blood smear did not detect the presence of blood parasites. The patient was diagnosed with classical dengue with probable criteria for ASA-induced dengue haemorrhagic fever grade 1. After withdrawal
column19: the patient recovered completely within 10 days.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 30 year old man
column2: who after suffering an assault was taken to the emergency department of the Hospital Universitario La Paz due to multiple incised wounds to the face
column3: neck
column4: scalp and left hand. On arrival he was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit for marked hypothermia
column5: Glasgow 10
column6: severe metabolic acidosis
column7: hypokalaemia and acute renal failure
column8: requiring mechanical ventilation for 24 hours. After resolution of the acute organic symptoms and primary suturing of the wounds
column9: the patient was transferred to the ward after 48 hours
column10: and was discharged from hospital one week after admission.  Six days after discharge
column11: the patient returned to the emergency department for pain and swelling in the left preauricular region
column12: underlying the surgical scar of one of the facial wounds. Symptoms included tinnitus and physical examination revealed limited oral opening and a left preauricular lump measuring 2 × 2 cm
column13: soft and pulsatile on palpation and inspection. Auscultation of the mass revealed a murmur synchronous with arterial systolic flow. A parotid ultrasound was performed
column14: showing an image compatible with a high-flow left intraparotid arteriovenous fistula. The cervicofacial and cervical computed tomography (CT) scan showed an image suggestive of a vascular pocket measuring 36 × 25 × 24 cm
column15: located behind the left mandibular vertical branch
column16: between the deep and superficial lobe of the parotid gland
column17: at the level of the retromandibular vein. There is a probable arterial afferent image coming from branches of the external carotid artery
column18: with venous drainage towards the external jugular vein.  With a view to a diagnosis of certainty
column19: an angiography was carried out showing a vascular lesion whose fundamental afferent is the proximal portion of the internal maxillary artery and whose venous drainage is directed superiorly towards the pterygoid plexus and descending towards the external jugular vein. There is also retrograde flow from the facial artery into the pouch. Treatment is carried out on the spot by embolisation via microcatheterisation of the internal maxillary artery and occlusion with a 3 × 8 mm platinum coil. However
column20: the final angiographic control showed late retrograde filling from the left facial artery.  The patient was discharged with outpatient follow-up
column21: with evident clinical improvement. Angio-CT revealed occlusion of the internal maxillary artery with closure and thrombosis of the fistulous pocket. Outpatient follow-up at 1 and 6 months showed no complications or recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 58-year-old patient with a personal history of obesity
column2: hypertension
column3: fibromyalgia and D3-D4 disc herniation. She was admitted to another hospital due to clinical symptoms of several months' evolution consisting of lumbosciatica refusing the usual analgesic treatment
column4: a feeling of retrosternal knot
column5: progressive dysphagia and weight loss
column6: where she underwent: - Cervicothoracoabdominal CT scan: a mass effect was observed in the upper third of the oesophagus
column7: and its exact nature could not be defined. - Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy: a brownish-black mass was observed in the upper third of the oesophagus
column8: submucosal
column9: non-ulcerated
column10: with an intense vascular network. - Dorsal CT and MRI: multiple vertebral lesions (in D7 and from D9 to D12) compatible with osteoporotic vertebral crushing. - Bone scan and tumour markers: negative. Diagnosed with lumbosciatica due to multiple vertebral lesions of osteoporotic origin in the dorsal spine and oesophageal mass
column11: she was referred to our department to complete the study. On arrival
column12: the patient presented with low back pain that made ambulation impossible
column13: not yielding to opioid treatment and dysphagia with liquids. On examination she was in very poor general condition

column1: A 52-year-old woman with arterial hypertension as the only history of interest. She consulted the gynaecology department for metrorrhagia accompanied by abdominal pain. She did not report haematuria or renal pit pain. Vaginal ultrasound was performed
column2: which showed a left adnexal mass 7 cm in diameter and very vascularised
column3: with a large uterus and normal right ovary. With the suspicion of primary ovarian carcinoma
column4: the staging study was completed with an abdominal-pelvic CT scan
column5: which identified a complex mass in the lower pole of the right kidney
column6: 64 x 65 mm in diameter
column7: with intense contrast uptake and central hypodense areas. Two other small nodules measuring 17 and 10 mm were also reported in the upper pole of the same kidney with similar characteristics to the previous lesions. The left adnexa presented a solid-cystic lesion measuring 90 x 65 mm
column8: with intense contrast uptake. No regional adenopathy or peritoneal metastatic implants were observed.  With the diagnostic suspicion of primary ovarian carcinoma and secondary renal metastasis
column9: total hysterectomy and double adnexectomy were performed
column10: and radical right nephrectomy was performed in the same surgical act. The intraoperative histological study of the ovarian structure was reported as metastasis of renal cell carcinoma in the ovary. The definitive renal histological diagnosis was Fuhrman grade I renal cell carcinoma extending to perirenal fat
column11: without infiltrating the renal vein.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 49-year-old man with a personal history of multiple paragangliomas. In 2005 he underwent surgery for right jugular paraganglioma by infratemporal approach with good postoperative evolution. In 2014
column2: surgical treatment was decided for a right vagal paraganglioma due to tumour progression
column3: and the paraganglioma was excised laterocervically. Postoperatively
column4: the patient presented right facial paralysis grade II on the House-Brackmann scale
column5: cophosis and paralysis of the right cranial nerves IX
column6: X
column7: XI and XII. In successive check-ups at the clinic
column8: the patient presented dysphagia
column9: dysphonia
column10: and also reported very intense pain in the infra- and preauricular region that appeared with the start of chewing at all meals
column11: and which progressively subsided. It was decided to inject hyaluronic acid into the right vocal cord
column12: botulinum toxin into the right cricopharyngeus muscle and
column13: given the suspicion of PMS
column14: it was decided to inject botulinum toxin into the right parotid region. Five units were infiltrated in 12 points for a total of 60 units. After 15 days the patient noticed a notable improvement in his dysphonia and complete disappearance of the pain.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 65-year-old male patient
column2: smoker of 20-40 cigarettes/day and with a history of duodenal ulcus. He had undergone surgery 5 years previously for stenosing neoplasia of the rectosigmoid junction (Dukes stage B adenocarcinoma
column3: T3N0M0
column4: stage III-A AJCC)
column5: and underwent anterior resection followed by end-to-end anastomosis by mechanical suture using the double stapling technique. The postoperative course of the operation was uneventful and the patient was followed up in consultation every 6 months
column6: with colonoscopy and ultrasound being performed annually. The endoscopic image of the perianastomotic region was normal in all revisions
column7: including the last one performed the previous year (4 years after the operation). Five years after the operation
column8: the patient began to have soft stools
column9: intermittent abdominal pain in the hypogastrium and later rectorrhagia. He was admitted to the internal medicine department and underwent an abdominal CT scan
column10: which revealed no pathological findings
column11: and colonoscopy
column12: which revealed a stricture 10 cm from the anal margin that prevented the passage of the endoscope. A biopsy was performed which showed no histopathological signs of malignant disease and was reported as a non-specific ulcer.  Given that serum tumour markers were at normal levels
column13: and in the absence of other signs of neoplasia
column14: it was decided to repeat the endoscopy and perform an opaque enema. The new endoscopy and biopsy showed identical findings to the previous ones. The barium enema showed a colon stenosis of irregular appearance and 8 cm in length
column15: and the possibility of malignant stenosis could not be ruled out with this image. In the absence of conclusive evidence of tumour recurrence
column16: a period of treatment with corticosteroid enemas (budesonide
column17: 2 mg enema
column18: twice a day) was decided upon in order to reduce inflammation and thus complete the endoscopic examination.  After a month
column19: with the patient asymptomatic
column20: the endoscopy was repeated
column21: finding an inflammatory and ulcerated mucosa
column22: covering a 6-8 cm long stricture that could be passed through with the endoscope
column23: with no signs of neoplasia and the rest of the colon appearing normal. The biopsies taken showed non-specific inflammatory signs. The stricture was judged to be of ischaemic origin and
column24: given that the patient was totally asymptomatic
column25: periodic follow-up was decided. After 6 months of follow-up
column26: electrocardiographic alterations were detected
column27: for which the cardiologist was consulted. Ergometry and coronary angiography revealed irregularities in the middle proximal anterior descending artery
column28: severe involvement of the ostium of the diagonal branch
column29: 80% stenosis of the obtuse marginal branch and 80% stenosis in the middle right coronary artery. Dilatation and implantation of a double coronary stent was decided
column30: after which the electrocardiographic alterations disappeared. After 16 months of follow-up
column31: the patient has normal transit and is asymptomatic.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 40-year-old woman was referred to our department for persistence for about eight months of a picture of anterior blepharitis of indolent appearance with the appearance of an indurated nodule in the right upper eyelid classified as "chalazion refractory to triamcinolone injection"
column2: associated with ipsilateral preauricular lymphadenopathy. A biopsy of the palpebral nodule was performed and reported after histopathological analysis as sebaceous carcinoma.  The right upper eyelid was then completely excised
column3: including the tarsus
column4: and reconstructed with a free graft of palatal mucosa and covered with a pedicled frontal glabellar flap. Border involvement was ruled out in the resected surgical specimen. At the same time
column5: a radical cervical removal was performed due to the presence of necrotic lymphadenopathies in various lymphatic territories. In the same surgical procedure
column6: the conjunctiva was biopsied in all four quadrants as well as the lower eyelid. The anatomopathological study showed no conjunctival infiltration
column7: but tumoural changes in the lower eyelid
column8: so brachytherapy was used for a total of 94 sessions with the isotope iridium 192 at a dose of 0.67 Gy for each session (total dose of 63.8 Gy). External radiotherapy was also associated with the cervical region in order to complete the surgical treatment carried out on the cervical region.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: LTR. Male patient
column2: 32 years of age
column3: with no medical history of interest
column4: who came for consultation for implant treatment due to loss of the upper right central incisor. The radiological examination (orthopantomography) showed a residual root cyst at the level of the lost tooth. The patient was recommended the possibility of a treatment plan consisting of the removal of the cyst
column5: bone regeneration of the bone defect and insertion of an implant in the same operating session. Subsequently
column6: after a healing period
column7: rehabilitation with an implant-supported cemented crown is carried out. The patient is informed of the surgical technique and the prosthodontic aspects (provisional and definitive prosthesis)
column8: timing (duration of treatment
column9: number of visits) and follow-up (clinical and radiological check-ups)
column10: and of the possibility of complications and loss of implants. The patient authorises the implant treatment by means of an informed consent form. Surgery The day before surgery
column11: the patient starts a preventive antibiotic regimen (amoxicillin + clavulanic acid) for one week
column12: and in case of pain or inflammation
column13: ibuprofen is prescribed. In addition
column14: a daily chlorhexidine rinse is recommended for the first 30 days. The root cyst is removed with curettage and the implant bed is made
column15: inserting a universal external connection implant with Nanoblast® nanosurface (Galimplant
column16: Sarria
column17: Spain) submerged. The entire bone defect is filled with KeraOs® tricalcium beta-phosphate (Keramat
column18: Coruña
column19: Spain) and covered with a BioGide® resorbable collagen membrane (Geistlich
column20: Wolhusen
column21: Switzerland). 8 months after implant insertion
column22: the second surgery is performed with placement of a healing screw.  Prosthodontics 2 weeks after the second surgery
column23: the implant was functionally loaded by placing the corresponding implant-supported prosthesis
column24: a porcelain crown cemented on a machined hexagonal metal abutment.  Clinical follow-up The time elapsed since the implant was functionally loaded was 12 months. There have been no complications during this period.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Ten-year-old boy presented to the emergency department for testicular pain of four hours' duration. He reported that
column2: although previously well
column3: he began to experience progressive discomfort in the left testicle. He reported no fever
column4: previous trauma or micturition syndrome. He had no family or personal history of interest. Clinical examination was normal
column5: except for the left testicle
column6: which showed a slight increase in size
column7: erythematous and uncomfortable on palpation
column8: but with relief of pain with testicular ascent. The cremasteric reflex was present. Both testicles were palpated in a normal position
column9: normal shape
column10: with no skin lesions. In view of the acute scrotal pain
column11: testicular Doppler ultrasound was requested to complete the study
column12: and images compatible with left epididymitis were observed
column13: ruling out testicular torsion. As a chance finding
column14: a 1.5 mm image of right intratesticular calcification was observed.  Analgesia measures were prescribed and recommendations were made to minimise discomfort (scrotal elevation and rest)
column15: explaining the warning signs for further consultation. The patient progressed favourably. Given the image of intratesticular calcification
column16: he was referred to paediatrics for follow-up. In the first two years of follow-up the patient has remained asymptomatic and no changes have been observed in the number or distribution of testicular microcalcifications
column17: nor have changes been reported in the echogenicity of the testicular parenchyma. We will continue to carry out periodic clinical and ultrasound check-ups to assess his evolution. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 65-year-old man who consulted the emergency department in August 2005
column2: presenting with urinary pain in the hypochondrium and right inguinal region of 72 hours' evolution
column3: fever
column4: general malaise and irritative urinary symptoms. She had a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus 2 under treatment
column5: her mother had breast cancer
column6: her father had coronary heart disease and her sister had a brain tumour. On admission to the emergency department she had blood pressure (BP): 130/80
column7: heart rate (HR): 80 beats per minute
column8: respiratory rate (RR): 18 breaths per minute
column9: temperature (T): 38.7 degrees Celsius (oC)
column10: with no signs of respiratory distress. In the neck there was a thyroid mass measuring 4 x 6 cm
column11: indurated
column12: not very mobile
column13: not painful on palpation
column14: with no inflammatory changes. Physical examination revealed a large mass in the right flank and iliac fossa which continued to the inguinoscrotal region
column15: displacing the left hemiscrotal and penis
column16: with no evidence of inguinal adenopathy or local inflammatory changes
column17: the mass had a firm
column18: hard consistency
column19: non-mobile
column20: with negative transillumination; the right testicle was not palpable due to the mass effect
column21: the left testicle was present
column22: rectal examination was unremarkable. The patient presented with pain on right lumbar percussion and urinary tract infection was confirmed by urine culture; intravenous antibiotic treatment was started. Lactate dehydrogenase dehydrogenase (LDH) levels were measured and the result was 300 U/L. During her hospitalisation she presented hyperglycaemia (259 mg/dl)
column23: normal creatinine (0.8 mg/dl)
column24: leucocytes 17850 neutrophils 86% haemoglobin 16 platelets 275 000. After antibiotic management
column25: signs of systemic inflammatory response decreased. A contrasted abdominal tomography (CT) scan (September 2005) showed the presence of a large mass in the right iliac fossa that displaced the bladder to the contralateral side and continued to the right hemiscrotal
column26: solid in appearance
column27: with well-defined borders
column28: diffusely involving the ipsilateral testicle. There was no evidence of locoregional adenopathy. The tumour was excised together with a radical orchidectomy on the same side of a semi-ovoid
column29: lobulated
column30: yellowish
column31: smooth-surfaced mass measuring 34 x 22 x 17 cm and weighing 5786 grams. Complete removal was achieved without complications
column32: the patient presented good clinical evolution post-surgery and it was therefore decided to discharge the patient on the 5th day post-surgery.  The pathology report confirms that the tumour lesion corresponds to a malignant neoplasm of mesenchymal and sarcomatous origin formed by well-differentiated adipose cells in the middle of which some bizarre pleomorphic cells are observed
column33: constituting a dominant picture of well-differentiated liposarcoma
column34: lobulations of cartilage-like tissue are observed
column35: which corresponds to a component of the divergent tumour
column36: where there is cartilage-like tissue with a malignant hyaline tumoural appearance that oscillates between a grade II and III chondrosarcoma component. The tumour corresponds to a dedifferentiated liposarcoma in which the adipose component is a classic well-differentiated lipoma-like liposarcoma from which islands of high-grade chondrosarcoma component emerge
column37: such findings corresponding to dedifferentiated liposarcoma of the spermatic cord with tumour-free resection margins. Local radiotherapy was suggested but the patient refused
column38: accepting only periodic clinical check-ups. During the follow-up
column39: an aspiration cytology of the cervical mass was performed and the pathology report showed papillary thyroid carcinoma
column40: which is currently being followed up by oncology. Forty-eight months after excision of the inguinoscrotal mass
column41: the patient is asymptomatic
column42: with no clinical or paraclinical signs of tumour recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 45-year-old man resuscitated from CRA after acute coronary syndrome in the street and transferred to hospital with absence of reflexes except for coughing and spontaneous breathing. After the hypothermia protocol
column2: the same examination persisted
column3: with generalised cerebral oedema seen in the cranial CT scan. On the third day of admission
column4: the relatives were informed of the poor prognosis and spontaneously suggested donation. They were informed of the need to wait until the patient progressed to encephalic death
column5: which they accepted. On the fifth day of admission
column6: the same neurological examination continued. The family expressed their wish not to wait for encephalic death
column7: requesting the withdrawal of life support. Donation through the LSTL and controlled asystole protocol was proposed to them
column8: and they gave their consent. He was transferred to the operating theatre for terminal extubation. Asystole occurred 9 minutes after extubation and once death was certified
column9: rapid laparotomy
column10: cannulation and intraoperative cold perfusion were performed. ICT was 23 minutes. Both kidneys were explanted
column11: the lungs were discarded by bronchoaspiration and the liver by TIC at the limit.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 42-year-old woman at the time of undergoing a liver transplant. Her personal history prior to the transplant included appendectomy in 1978
column2: liver cirrhosis of probable alcoholic origin diagnosed in 1989
column3: ADH secondary to grade II oesophageal varices in 1996 together with portal hypertension and ascites. In February 1998 she was diagnosed with hepatocarcinoma. The patient received an uneventful liver transplant in October 1998 and was discharged on treatment with tacrolimus. Eighteen months after the transplant
column4: the patient reported for the first time weakness of the lower limbs and loss of sensation in them
column5: evolving within two months to complete paraplegia affecting the urinary bladder. Physical examination revealed paraparesis with amyotrophy due to disuse of the lower limbs
column6: greater subjective hypoaesthesia in DID with level D8-D10
column7: more intense deep sensory impairment in DID
column8: especially at the vibratory level. ROT present
column9: the patellar ones alive and the Achilles hypoactive. Bilateral extensor CPR. The following diagnostic tests were also performed in this case: Brain MRI: involvement of the medullary cord from C2 to D10
column10: also presenting hyperintense supratentorial lacunar lesions mainly at the subcortical level of the left frontal lobe and also the right frontal
column11: parietal and occipital lobes. PEES: pathological at posterior tibial level CSF: sexological determination for HTLV-I positive
column12: rest normal. Blood test for antibodies (ELISA) and for the existence of the virus (HTLV-I)
column13: positive. The patient was diagnosed with tropical spastic paraparesis and treated with Interferon-á
column14: initially presenting discreet improvement
column15: especially at the distal level of the EEII
column16: although in the last few days the treatment regimen had to be reduced due to an increase in transaminase values. Despite the initial good response
column17: the symptoms have progressively worsened and she is now dependent for daily life and has a permanent bladder catheter after an attempt at bladder re-education by intermittent catheterisation failed. The liver transplant is currently functioning. In all three cases
column18: transplantectomy was not indicated given the spread of the virus to the blood and nervous systems and the impossibility
column19: given the measures available

column1: A 13-year-old boy was referred for evaluation after suffering ocular trauma to his left eye with a slingshot. Visual acuity was 20/20 in both eyes. Examination of the right eye was normal and
column2: in the left eye
column3: microhyphema and anterior uveitis were noted. Fundus examination under dilation showed equatorial rounded retinal haemorrhages in the left eye. Intraocular pressure values were normal (15 mmHg and 12 mmHg respectively). The patient developed inferior peripheral retinal ischaemia (demonstrated by AFG) three weeks after the trauma (at this time the patient reported a superior temporal peripheral scotoma) with subsequent development
column4: twelve months later
column5: of retinal neovascularisation in the inferior nasal quadrant. The complete haematological study and blood coagulation tests were normal. In addition
column6: the sickle cell disease test was negative. The microhyphema and retinal haemorrhages resolved with medical treatment (atropine sulphate 1% and topical corticosteroids
column7: eye protection for one week
column8: bed rest for the first four days with gradual resumption of activity
column9: and restriction of salicylates and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
column10: oral administration of aminocaproic acid). Due to the complete resolution of microhyphema in the first week and in the absence of rebleeding
column11: no further studies of less common coagulation disorders
column12: such as factor VIII and XI deficiency or vitamin K deficiency
column13: were performed. Retinal ischaemia was treated with argon laser photocoagulation. After 15 months of follow-up
column14: her final visual acuity remains at 20/20 with no other ocular complications.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 37-year-old hyperopic male who
column2: on routine examination
column3: was found to have an intraocular pressure (IOP) of 34 mmHg in the right eye (OD) and 32 mmHg in the left eye (OI). Gonioscopy showed signs of angular closure in both eyes leading to bilateral Nd:YAG laser iridotomies. At two weeks signs of angular closure continued despite the iridotomies being patent and the IOP was 33 mmHg (OD) and 36 mmHg (OI). Ultrasonic biomicroscopy (UBB) was performed and detected an iris-plateau configuration with angular closure secondary to multiple iridociliary cysts. The cysts had thin hyperreflective walls with hyporeflective fluid content
column4: suggesting the diagnosis of primary neuroepithelial cysts.  It was decided to treat the RO by argon laser iridoplasty (impact size 500 µm
column5: 0.5 seconds exposure and 500 mW power). The same approach was offered for the OD
column6: but the patient preferred conservative treatment with hypotensive medication (timolol 0.5% every 12 hours) until the response to laser treatment could be seen. After iridoplasty
column7: BMU was repeated
column8: showing a change in the configuration of the iris root from convex to concave
column9: as well as the disappearance of the cysts. The IOP was reduced to 17 mmHg without treatment.  At one month IOP remained at 18 mmHg in the OI without medication and 14 mmHg in the OD with Timolol. In the BMU
column10: the cysts reappeared in the laser-treated eye
column11: without producing a secondary angular block. This situation persisted for 6 months
column12: after which the iris plateau configuration of the OI reappeared and the IOP rose to 28 mmHg. At this point
column13: it was decided to treat this eye with hypotensive medication like the right eye
column14: as it maintained an adequate intraocular pressure (14 mmHg). The patient declined any other non-medical treatment
column15: as he tolerated the medication very well and adequate blood pressure control was achieved.  Currently
column16: after 12 months of follow-up
column17: the patient shows an IOP of 14 mmHg in both eyes with Timolol 0.5% every 12 hours. The BMU still shows multiple neuroepithelial cysts in both eyes
column18: with no increase in size or number and no clinical signs of angular closure.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 70-year-old patient came to our department due to a decrease in visual acuity in the left eye. His personal history included type 2 diabetes mellitus
column2: dyslipidaemia
column3: hypertension and allergy to pyrazolones. On examination
column4: corrected visual acuity was 0.5 in the right eye and 0.1 in the left eye. Examination of the anterior pole revealed incipient lens opacity in both eyes. Intraocular pressure was 16 mm Hg in both eyes. Fundus examination showed peripapillary chorioretinal atrophy with a yellowish-white discolouration affecting the nasal retina and temporal vascular arcades in both eyes
column5: affecting the macula in the left eye. There was no vitritis.  FFA showed early hypofluorescence and variable late hyperfluorescence of the lesions in both eyes with macular involvement in the left eye.  The patient was diagnosed with serpiginous choroiditis
column6: and treatment was started with oral corticosteroids in the form of oral prednisone at a dose of 1mg/kg/day until 2 weeks after a therapeutic response had been obtained
column7: at which point the dose was reduced to 0.5mg/kg/day. Subsequently at 4 weeks it was reduced every other day and at 8 weeks it was reduced to 0.1mg/kg/day
column8: and visual acuity remained stable. The patient was referred to the Internal Medicine Department for adjustment of the insulin doses due to the start of corticosteroid treatment. Six months later
column9: the patient consulted the gynaecology department for metrorrhagia
column10: which revealed an advanced carcinoma of the uterine cervix with involvement of the lower third of the vagina.  The patient was referred to the Oncology Department
column11: which began treatment with 40mg of intramuscular methylprednisolone for 3 days a week associated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy for 5 weeks. Two months later
column12: given the imminent macular involvement of the second eye
column13: azathioprine was added to the treatment at a dose of 1.5mg/kg/day
column14: which was reduced to 1mg/kg/day after two months and oral prednisone was reduced according to protocol4. The patient died one year later due to multi-organ failure.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 76-year-old woman with a history of ischaemic heart disease
column2: diagnosed with seronegative rheumatoid arthritis in 1992 due to chronic
column3: symmetrical
column4: erosive polyarthritis which fulfilled five of the criteria of the American College of Rheumatology. Chloroquine and parenteral methotrexate had been used as background medication. In 2000 she underwent total right knee arthroplasty with a satisfactory result. In 2002 she developed normocytic anaemia
column5: fatigue
column6: sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy and splenomegaly. A haematological study revealed a monoclonal IgM component of 3.1 g/dl and after a bone marrow biopsy she was diagnosed with Waldenström's macroglobulinemia. Since the patient remained stable and oligosymptomatic with low doses of prednisone (7.5 mg/day) and oral methotrexate (7.5 mg/week)
column7: the haematology department decided to maintain a wait-and-see attitude
column8: deferring therapy with alkylating agents or nucleoside analogues. During the first three days of August 2005
column9: he presented with self-limited febrile diarrhoea. After a week's improvement
column10: he began to experience fever
column11: pain
column12: swelling and progressive limitation of mobility in the right knee
column13: symptoms that persisted and led to consultation and admission to our centre on 25 August. Examination revealed an axillary temperature of 37.5ºC
column14: swelling and tension effusion in the right knee
column15: patchy hypoaesthesia in the lower limbs and abolition of the Achilles reflexes. Arthrocentesis revealed a cream-coloured purulent fluid with 75
column16: 000 leukocytes/mm3 (> 95% polymorphonuclear). Gram stain failed to visualise microorganisms
column17: but aerobic cultures recovered L. monocytogenes sensitive to penicillin
column18: ampicillin
column19: co-trimoxazole and rifampicin. ESR was 120 mm/1 hour. C-reactive protein: 51.7 mg/L. CBC showed 6.5 x 109 leukocytes/L (47% neutrophils
column20: 25% lymphocytes
column21: 14% monocytes)
column22: Hb: 99 g/L
column23: haematocrit: 28.7 L/L
column24: platelets: 442 x 109/L. Immuglobulin levels: IgA (25 mg/dl)
column25: IgG (405 mg/dl)
column26: IgM (2300 mg/dl; VN < 230); light chains: lambda (44 mg/dl; VN: 90-210)
column27: kappa (276 mg/dl; VN 170-370). The following parameters were normal or negative: biochemistry (glucose
column28: creatinine
column29: urea
column30: total cholesterol
column31: triglycerides
column32: lacticodehydrogenase
column33: creatinine kinase
column34: transaminases
column35: bilirubin
column36: alkaline phosphatase
column37: gamma-glutamyltranspeptidase
column38: calcium
column39: phosphorus
column40: sodium
column41: potassium and chloride)
column42: urinalysis
column43: serology for Salmonella
column44: Shigella and Yersinia
column45: complement dosage (C3 and C4) and antinuclear antibodies. Rheumatoid factor by latex was 54 IU/ml. Chest X-ray showed no abnormalities. X-ray of the right knee showed periprosthetic radiolucencies. Abdominal ultrasound showed signs of hepatic steatosis and mild splenomegaly. In addition to drainage and saline lavage of the joint
column46: 2 g of ampicillin every 6 h and gentamicin (3 mg/kg/8 hours; maintaining a concentration between 4 and 9 mg/ml) were administered intravenously for 5 weeks. At the time of writing this clinical note
column47: three months after discharge from hospital
column48: the patient is progressing favourably and is receiving treatment with co-trimoxazole and rifampicin
column49: which will be continued for a total of 6 months.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 30-year-old woman
column2: smoker of about six cigarettes a day
column3: with a history of miscarriage two and a half years before being examined in the Gynaecology Department for infertility. In this context
column4: during a vaginal ultrasound scan
column5: an exophytic intravesical lesion of approximately 24 mm in diameter was found
column6: located on the right posterolateral wall
column7: with septations inside.  She was referred to the Urology Department
column8: referring certain micturition discomfort coinciding with menstruation
column9: without macroscopic haematuria or other accompanying manifestations. Blood tests showed normal values
column10: while in the elemental urine only 18 red blood cells/mcL were present. Intravenous urography was requested
column11: with no other significant findings; cystoscopy was also performed
column12: which revealed an exophytic lesion
column13: approximately one endoscopic field in size
column14: located at the bottom of the bladder
column15: with a pseudocystic surface. Transurethral resection of the lesion described was indicated and was achieved completely
column16: with good postoperative evolution. The result of the histopathological study revealed a bladder wall lined by focally hyperplastic endothelium
column17: with glandular formations of predominantly tubal morphology in the lamina propria and muscular tissue
column18: with associated endometrial and endocervical components
column19: all compatible with a diagnosis of bladder mullerianosis.  After one year of follow-up
column20: the patient has remained asymptomatic
column21: with no evidence of endoscopic recurrence at check-ups.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 9-year-old girl was admitted to the paediatric department from the emergency department for the second episode of macroscopic haematuria in 20 days. No family history of interest
column2: personal history of facial haemihypertrophy due to congenital torticollis
column3: chickenpox
column4: infectious mononucleosis
column5: nocturnal enuresis until the age of 7
column6: pneumonia at 9 months and trauma to the coccyx. Physical examination: slight skin pallor
column7: weight within the 25-50 percentile and height within the 50-75 percentile. No other findings. Complementary examinations: complete blood count
column8: biochemistry
column9: coagulation
column10: urine culture
column11: renal function
column12: enolase
column13: alpha-fetoprotein
column14: chest X-ray and ECG were normal. Urinary sediment: macroscopic haematuria. Abdominal ultrasound: 5cm diameter mass in the left kidney
column15: complex with cystic/necrotic areas. The paediatrics department consulted our department and decided to perform an abdominal CT scan with contrast after ultrasound findings
column16: with the finding of a mass depending on the left kidney
column17: in the anterior face
column18: with cystic content and irregular endoluminal thickening. It presents a thick and irregular septum of similar density to that obtained in the internal irregularities described. No inter-cavo-aortic or periaortic adenomegaly was observed. The mass is compatible with Wilms' tumour or adeno-carcinoma. It was decided to perform a left nephrectomy: the mass measured 4.5 cm in diameter.  The anatomopathological diagnosis was cystic mesoblastic nephroma (multilocular renal cyst).   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 51-year-old male. Unrelated aetiology ACKD
column2: hypertensive and on haemodialysis since 2005
column3: with first kidney transplant immediately failed due to non-immunological arterial thrombosis in October 2007
column4: receiving a transfusion of 2 red blood cell units on admission. Sporadic increase in transaminases in 2009
column5: becoming persistent since December 2010 (maximum figure 28/40 IU/l GOT/GPT). Occult HCV was diagnosed as 14
column6: 700 copies/µg total RNA in CMSP (RNA in serum by ultracentrifugation and high-sensitivity anti-HCV core antibody
column7: negative). Normal ultrasound and FibroScan®. There was no external possibility of contagion
column8: and PCR and viral serology was performed on the rest of the patients in the unit
column9: as well as on the healthcare staff
column10: without detecting new cases of classic HCV infection. She received a second kidney transplant in October 2013
column11: and was treated with thymoglobulin (TG)
column12: tacrolimus (FK)
column13: mycophenolate (MMF) and corticosteroids. Seventeen months after the transplant
column14: the viral load in PBSC is undetectable
column15: and the serum ultracentrifugation RNA and the highly sensitive anti-HCV core antibody remain negative.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 42-year-old woman consulted for a history of headache of 10 days' duration accompanied by gait instability. History of migraine
column2: peripheral facial paralysis "a frigore" 20 years ago and episodes of depression. The neurological examination showed a right dysmetria and a positive Romberg's manoeuvre and sequelae of his facial paralysis. Cranial CT scan showed an expansive process occupying the right posterior hemifosa. The lesion had a solid component that was enhanced by contrast material and a cystic component. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain confirmed the findings of the CT scan. A lesion of about 4 cm in diameter was found with a solid and a cystic component
column3: surrounded by oedema
column4: located in the right cerebellar hemisphere. This mass was heterogeneous and hypointense in relation to the cerebellar tissue on T1 and hyperintense on T2. It was enhanced with Gadolinium. It was not accompanied by hydrocephalus.  The tumour was excised almost completely by means of a craniectomy of the right posterior hemifosa. Postoperative evolution was satisfactory and the patient remained completely asymptomatic. A control brain MRI scan showed a wide resection of the tumour with a minimal remnant in the most cranial portion of the right cerebellar hemisphere next to the brainstem. The anatomo-pathological study diagnosed a Glioblastoma multiforme (WHO grade IV) with extensive areas of necrosis and abscessation. The tumour cells showed nuclear immunohistochemical positivity for p53.  Subsequently the patient was treated with focal radiotherapy in the posterior fossa 60 Gy
column5: 2 Gy/d ICRU (International Commission on Radiation Units) concomitant with Temozolomide 75 mg/m2 according to the EORTC 22981 (European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer) scheme. Eight months after the intervention
column6: the patient remained asymptomatic
column7: although the control brain MRI showed the onset of tumour recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Patient diagnosed at 38 years of age with multifocal infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the left breast. She underwent surgery at our institution
column2: a second level hospital
column3: with modified left radical mastectomy on reduction pattern
column4: homolateral axillary lymphadenectomy and immediate reconstruction with latissimus dorsi flap and 475cc textured anatomical prosthesis (model 20636 Polytech®
column5: Polytech Healthand Aesthetics
column6: Dieburg
column7: Germany) in retromuscular position in a pocket formed by the junction of the pectoralis muscle with the latissimus dorsi. A right reduction mammoplasty designed in the same pattern with inferior pedicle for the nipple-areola complex was also performed for symmetry.  As postoperative adjuvant treatment she underwent chemotherapy
column8: as planned at the time of diagnosis of the carcinoma
column9: and radiotherapy as 3 metastatic axillary lymph nodes were found during surgery. The patient completed radiotherapy 8 months after surgery and 2 months later
column10: the radiation received led to severe radiodermatitis and a spontaneous seroma which
column11: after several attempts at drainage
column12: led to explantation of the prosthesis one year after the initial surgery. The genetic counselling diagnosis recommended prophylactic right mastectomy as it was considered a high risk because the biopsy of the reduction specimen showed ductal hyperplasia with atypia.  Due to the impossibility of using the latissimus dorsi flap and the sequelae of radiotherapy
column13: after assessing the reconstructive possibilities
column14: we referred the patient to a tertiary hospital as our second level institution is not qualified for vascular microsurgery techniques. The indication was to perform breast reconstruction with a bilateral DIEP microsurgical flap. One year after the explantation
column15: the indicated prophylactic mastectomy of the right breast and microsurgical reconstruction with bilateral DIEP flap was performed. The evolution
column16: after a postoperative pulmonary infection that required admission to the Intensive Care Unit
column17: was unfavourable
column18: and total necrosis of both DIEP flaps occurred. After a year had passed and the scars had stabilised
column19: we assessed whether there was really any possibility of reconstruction given the patient's age and the severity of the sequelae (radiodermatitis and skin adhesions to the ribcage). We decided to try to improve the skin cover with an autotransplant of fat in order to be able to support tissue expanders in the future and achieve moderate-sized breasts.  Two sessions of autologous fat grafting were performed at an interval of 6 months and on an outpatient basis. In the first session
column20: fat was obtained from the abdomen and after processing with centrifugation
column21: 240cc of autologous fat was injected in the right thoracic region and 200cc in the left thoracic region. In the second session
column22: fat was obtained from the flanks and crotch and 160cc. was transferred to the left breast. We achieved clinical improvement in terms of tissue thickness
column23: release of soft tissue adhesions of the left thoracic radiodermatitis and
column24: at the same time
column25: we achieved a discreet increase in volume.  At 6 months we decided to place tissue expanders. We chose anatomically shaped tissue expanders (Mentor®
column26: Johnson & Johnson
column27: New Jersey
column28: USA)
column29: 350cc. In the right hemithorax
column30: the expander was implanted in a retropectoral plane without any technical difficulties. We had the additional problem of the precariousness of the tissues and the previous radiodermatitis in the left hemithorax. To prevent extrusion
column31: we proceeded with the surgery by suturing with Vycril® 3/0 a sheet of Strattice® dermal matrix 8 x 16cm from a fibrous remnant found at the site of the inferior border of the pectoralis major to the submammary sulcus. The role of the matrix was to protect the lower pole of the expander which was located in a subpectoral plane in the upper part and covered by the Strattice® sheet in the lower half. The postoperative period was uneventful. Filling sessions of the expanders occurred normally from 2 weeks postoperatively. The amount of filling per session ranged from 20 to 60cc per expander to a total volume of 360cc spread over 7 sessions and with an average interval of 3 weeks. The great elasticity and the low resistance to expansion of the left breast
column32: contrary to what was expected due to the previous radiotherapy
column33: should be highlighted
column34: so that after 4 months the process had been satisfactorily completed.  At 5 months we proceeded to replace the expanders with definitive 380cc
column35: anatomical
column36: textured prostheses (Polytech® model 20737). We observed a total integration of the dermal matrix which contributed to the thickening of the soft tissue. Three months later
column37: given the favourable evolution of the patient
column38: with no evidence of capsular contracture
column39: we reconstructed the nipples with local fleur de Lys flaps. The flap of the breast that had previously undergone radiotherapy suffered partial necrosis. At the time of writing this article
column40: we are performing micropigmentation technique for the areola. Eight months after the last intervention the patient is satisfied with the result and has been able to fully reincorporate into her social and working life.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
