column1: Male infant aged one month
column2: with no personal history of interest
column3: who came to the emergency department for the third time in the last week with a partially consolable crying episode. He had been diagnosed with infant colic and the usual measures were recommended. He is exclusively breastfed. In the last 48 hours his feeding has been worse
column4: his crying
column5: which was initially in the evening
column6: has continued all day and the mother has not been able to calm him in her arms since yesterday. He remains afebrile and in excellent general condition
column7: with adequate weight gain
column8: currently weighing 4 kg. Physical examination reveals abdominal distension and palpation of a periumbilical mass extending to the right flank
column9: with no obvious defence. She frankly refused breastfeeding in the emergency department and presented with vomiting of food. With suspicion of intestinal obstruction

column11: which appeared as a large space-occupying focal lesion with cystic characteristics and no vascular flow on colour Doppler and multiloculated and multitabulated. column12: which revealed a voluminous intra-abdominal cystic mass measuring 90 x 60 x 65 mm
column13: located mainly in the right flank and the central abdominal region. It extends from the lower edge of the liver

column15: displacing the intestinal structures to the left. It is a multilocular mass with well-defined borders and thin walls

The patient underwent mid laparotomy and a multicystic mass containing whitish liquid was excised from the mesentery of a loop of the middle ileum. column17: the first 24 hours in the Paediatric Intensive Care Unit (PICU) and the rest on the ward
column18: was uneventful and in eight days the patient was sent home with adequate enteral tolerance and no complications. The pathological anatomy confirms the diagnosis of mesenteric cystic lymphagioma with a multiseptate cystic mass of approximately 5 cm in diameter with a smooth whitish wall and a thickness of 0.1 cm.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present a six-year-old girl who consulted the health centre for right-sided gonalgia with no inflammatory signs or history of trauma. She was treated with ibuprofen and three months later returned to the clinic with pain and inflammation of the fifth metatarsal of the right foot
column2: of a progressive nature
column3: which limited her ambulation. Subsequently
column4: pain and swelling appeared on the dorsum of the right hand. None of the symptoms were accompanied by previous influenza
column5: gastrointestinal infection or urinary symptoms
column6: and she was afebrile at all times. One week later
column7: she visited the clinic for persistent symptoms and functional impotence to stand upright. Her personal and family history and pregnancy were of no clinical interest. Her psychomotor development was normal. The patient's weight was 23.5 kg
column8: height 122 cm
column9: heart rate 74 bpm and general condition was acceptable. Examination revealed right knee with pain
column10: swelling and limited flexion mobility due to pain at 90°
column11: patellar balling and mild swelling with pain in the fifth metacarpophalangeal joint of the right hand
column12: and right foot with increased sensitivity to pressure at the base of the fifth metatarsal and local swelling with pain
column13: without deformity or crepitus. No vasculonervous deficit. The physical examination was normal
column14: with no rash
column15: lymphadenopathy or visceromegaly. X-rays were normal at all times. Laboratory tests: mild thrombocytosis (425 000/µl)
column16: no leukocytosis or neutrophilia
column17: C-reactive protein 13 mg/ml
column18: erythrocyte sedimentation rate 52
column19: antinuclear antibodies (ANA) positive at 1/160
column20: rheumatoid factor negative
column21: anti-DNA negative. Arthrocentesis was performed (biochemistry and culture) obtaining inflammatory fluid with 5360 cells/ml
column22: glucose 69 mg/dl
column23: protein 5.4 g/dl and negative culture. Treatment was started with ibuprofen at a dose of 200 mg every eight hours
column24: pending assessment by the specialist
column25: with a slight improvement. Paediatric Rheumatology requested an assessment
column26: which extended the blood tests
column27: performed an ophthalmological study and started treatment with deflazacort. The extended laboratory tests were negative for anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies
column28: ENA
column29: HLA B27 and hepatitis B and C serology. Thyroid
column30: urinalysis and coagulation tests were also normal. One month later
column31: she was reviewed by Paediatric Rheumatology and was diagnosed with right knee arthritis ANA(+) and probable JIA
column32: due to persistent swelling and pain in the right knee and tarsus. The study was completed with foot ultrasound and corticosteroid infiltration. The ultrasound was normal and the patient progressed well after the infiltration.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male infant aged 6 months (affected) and heterozygous in his mother who was seen in our clinic for presenting divergent strabismus with absence of fixation in the left eye. Both pregnancy and delivery had passed without complications. As personal history
column2: the infant had been involved in a traffic accident the previous month. On examination the anterior pole was normal in both eyes. In the left fundus there was an inferior retinal detachment associated with a vitreous veil with retinal traction up to the papilla.   No retinal changes were observed in the right fundus. Retinoscopy showed a neutral point of +3.00 -2.00 at 10o in the right eye and +3.50 +0.50 at 7o in the left eye. Given the history of the traffic accident
column3: a traumatic origin was attributed to the retinal detachment in the left eye. Periodic check-ups were carried out. The retinal detachment evolved towards complete resorption
column4: with a demarcation line appearing in the temporal retina. The macula adapted
column5: presenting an alteration at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium.   After a few months
column6: vitreous flanges were observed in the inferior temporal arcade in the right eye. This led to the possibility of peripheral retinoschisis as the origin of the retinal detachment in the left eye. Both macular OCT and ERG were performed
column7: but the results could not be assessed in both tests due to the patient's poor cooperation given his young age. A DNA study was therefore performed on a peripheral blood sample. A mutation (Q154R) was observed in exon 5 of the XLRS gene responsible for X-linked retinoschisis. The mutation was present in hemizygosis in the patient (affected) and in heterozygosis in his mother (carrier). At the age of 6 years
column8: visual acuity was 20/20 in the right eye and 20/400 in the left eye
column9: despite prolonged treatment with hourly occlusions of the right eye. Examination revealed inferior temporal vitreous condensation in the right eye and inferior temporal peripheral retinoschisis in the left eye
column10: associated with residual fibrosis of the inferior temporal arcade.   The absence of foveal schisis was noted by OCT in both eyes.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 70-year-old man admitted for deterioration in general condition
column2: asthenia
column3: anorexia and weight loss of 1 month's duration. He had undergone surgery for adenocarcinoma of the prostate and had subsequently received several sessions of radiotherapy (total dose 70 Gy)
column4: the last of which was 12 months before his admission
column5: in treatment with hormone therapy. Since starting radiotherapy treatment
column6: the patient reports a change in intestinal rhythm
column7: with alternating diarrhoea and constipation and frequent colicky pain
column8: accompanied by urgency and tenesmus of defecation. Physical examination revealed only a soft
column9: depressible
column10: non-painful abdomen
column11: with increased
column12: non-pathological sounds
column13: without obstructive signs
column14: masses or megaliths. There were no adenopathies
column15: fever or other noteworthy findings. Laboratory tests showed leukocytosis of 21
column16: 720 /mm3 (17.2% neutrophils
column17: 4.1% lymphocytes
column18: 2.4% monocytes and 75.3% eosinophils)
column19: ESR 60 mm in the first hour
column20: CRP 38.80 mg/L
column21: ferritin 481 ng/mL
column22: rheumatoid factor 800 as acute phase reactants
column23: hypoalbuminaemia of 2.2 g/dL without alteration of other markers of malabsorption. Transaminases and cholestasis enzymes were normal. Anti-nuclear
column24: anti-mitochondrial and anti-smooth muscle antibodies were negative and PSA was 0 ng/mL. Stool parasitology in 3 conveniently collected samples was also negative. Chest X-ray showed no significant alterations. Colonoscopy was performed and the mucosa of the 30 cm explored showed a tubular fibrotic appearance with erythematous stippling
column25: with regular fibrotic stenosis at this level that prevented progression. Multiple biopsies were taken showing acute and chronic non-specific inflammation
column26: with no evidence of eosinophils at any level
column27: and the presumptive diagnosis was actinic colitis.  Abdominopelvic CT scan with intravenous contrast showed diffuse thickening of small bowel loops at the level of the distal jejunum and ileum
column28: with no other alterations. There was no evidence of lymphadenopathy at any level or abdominal masses
column29: with radical prostatectomy and thickening of the perirectal fat
column30: bladder wall and rectum
column31: probably related to previous radiotherapy. Due to the alterations in the loops
column32: an intestinal transit was performed which showed a discrete thickening of the connivent valves at the level of the jejunum
column33: with loops of pelvic ileum of reduced calibre
column34: with separation from both the jejunum and the rest of the ileum due to parietal thickening
column35: all compatible as a first possibility with actinic enteritis
column36: and the last ileal loop being of normal calibre with preserved folds.  Given that the scans performed pointed to radiotherapy as the origin of the abdominal symptoms
column37: and other causes of secondary peripheral eosinophilia having been reasonably ruled out
column38: empirical treatment was prescribed with corticosteroids (methylprednisolone 1 mg/kg/day for 1 week
column39: with a subsequent tapering regimen for 3 months) and parenteral nutrition
column40: given the progressive deterioration of the patient's general condition. This treatment completely resolved both the clinical picture and the analytical alterations
column41: which ruled out the central origin of the eosinophilia. One week after starting treatment
column42: the patient was discharged with a CBC showing 5
column43: 280 leukocytes/mm3 with 1% eosinophils
column44: ESR 27 mm in the first hour and CRP 0.76 mg/L
column45: with the diagnosis by exclusion of actinic enteritis and secondary peripheral eosinophilia. He remained asymptomatic and with normal laboratory tests.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 73-year-old male patient with a history of brucellosis
column2: hyperuricaemia and hypercholesterolaemia was admitted to our department for scheduled surgery for benign prostatic hyperplasia. In the diagnostic study
column3: a rectal examination revealed a prostate with adenomatous characteristics
column4: very enlarged (G III/IV). A retropubic adenomectomy was performed according to the T. Millin technique
column5: enucleating a large adenoma weighing 170 grams. Six days later
column6: the catheter was removed
column7: the patient resumed comfortable urination and was discharged. Eleven days after the operation
column8: and barely four days after discharge
column9: the patient was readmitted to our department for abdominal pain (hypogastric)
column10: pain in the right testicle and thigh root on the same side
column11: and a non-specific general malaise in the last 24 hours. A small amount of sero-purulent liquid drained from the orifice where the adenomectomy drainage was performed. The surgical wound was minimally impacted. He was admitted to the urology department with a diagnosis of surgical wound infection and empirical antibiotic treatment was started. The general and urological examination was within normal limits. Orchiepididymitis was ruled out. Laboratory tests showed a marked decrease in red blood count
column12: but no leukocytosis. The patient is treated symptomatically but does not improve. The pain in the pubic area is accentuated
column13: so bone scintigraphy is performed
column14: which reports the finding of pathological hypercaptation of the radiotracer in the upper third of both pubis in relation to possible pubic osteopathy
column15: as the only data of interest. The patient continues without improvement
column16: the treatments (based on empirical antibiotherapy and analgesia) fail to reduce the pain
column17: which is now located in the root of the thigh
column18: and the general deterioration is accentuated. The patient presented severe anaemia
column19: elevated ESR
column20: fibrinogen and CRP. Examination of the thigh was unremarkable
column21: with non-specific pain on pressure on the inner thigh. The pain was attributed to neurological involvement
column22: as the examination was normal
column23: and the pain also extended to the inguinal area and right testicle. With the diagnosis of a suspected pelvic abscess (the septic picture seemed unquestionable to us) in relation to the surgical history
column24: an abdominal CT scan was requested. This showed absolute normality of the abdominal organs... but cuts made below the symphysis pubis at the level of the right thigh revealed a large abscess in the area of the adductor muscles. In view of this finding
column25: the traumatology department was called in and noted that the inner aspect of the right thigh was now slightly reddened
column26: swollen
column27: painful on palpation but without clear fluctuation. The coxofemoral joint was free. Seven days after admission and as a matter of urgency
column28: surgery was performed: a wide longitudinal incision was made on the inner side of the proximal third of the thigh and by means of blunt digital dissection
column29: a deep penetration was made through the abductor musculature until a large purulent collection was reached
column30: which was directed proximally towards the pubis. An abundance of foul-smelling pus is obtained (samples are taken for microbiological examination). After washing the cavity with abundant saline and oxygenated water
column31: the surgical wound is partially closed and Penrose drains are left in place. Examination of the surgical wound of the adenomectomy and the area where the drain had been at the present time were absolutely normal and no cavities or collections were identified. Drains were placed and the operation was concluded. The patient required intensive care
column32: transfusion of blood products
column33: a long period of hospitalisation
column34: meticulous local dressings
column35: etc. The patient made a slow but excellent progress towards complete recovery. All subsequent controls (analytical
column36: radiological
column37: ultrasound...) corroborate the good evolution. The microbiology department informs us that the following results were obtained in the cultures taken: pure culture of seropurulent fluid from the adenomectomy wound: coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (without being able to specify the species). Culture of pus obtained during the operation to drain the thigh abscess: two strains of coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (identified as Staphylococcus epidermidis and Streptococcus alpha haemolyticus).   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 42-year-old woman attended the Maxillofacial Surgery Department of the Marqués de Valdecilla University Hospital in Santander (Spain) for several days of discomfort in the right temporomandibular joint (TMJ). The patient reported clicking of the right TMJ for several years with no other accompanying symptoms. Physical examination revealed no dento-skeletal abnormalities. She presented a maximum painless oral opening (MAO) of 45 mm
column2: reciprocal TMJ clicking (at the beginning of opening and at the end of closing)
column3: posterior deviation and protrusion greater than 10 mm. Selective pain on palpation of the right masseter and pterygoids. A panoramic radiograph was taken showing left condylar duplication.  Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of both TMJ showed the presence of anterior displacement of the disc
column4: which was reduced to the opening in the right TMJ. In the left TMJ
column5: the morphology of the condyle was striking: anteroposterior bifidity and the presence of a grade II joint effusion. To complete the imaging study
column6: a computerised tomography (CT) scan of both TMJs was requested
column7: which confirmed the existence of an anteroposterior bifid left condyle with no evidence of degenerative changes.  The patient was treated conservatively with an unloading splint
column8: muscle relaxants
column9: anti-inflammatory drugs
column10: local heat and a soft diet. With this treatment she improved clinically and is currently followed up in routine check-ups in our outpatient department.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 49-year-old male cirrhotic enolic patient associated with Child stage B7 HCV infection was admitted due to altered level of consciousness. Ammonium levels remained persistently elevated during admission. An abdominal ultrasound scan showed a very dilated and tortuous peripancreatic collateral vessel
column2: heterogeneous liver parenchyma without space-occupying lesions and a homogeneous 15 cm splenomegaly. Subsequently
column3: an angio-CT scan was performed
column4: which showed abundant collateral circulation associated with a spleno-renal portosystemic shunt.  Using interventional radiology techniques
column5: the shunt was partially embolised with microcoils. Post-embolisation abdominal ultrasound showed the disappearance of the spleno-renal shunt. After embolisation
column6: the patient showed rapid clinical improvement (disappearance of somnolence) and analytical improvement (normalisation of ammonium levels). He did not develop gastro-oesophageal varices or ascites. He did not require hospital admission during the 10 months of follow-up.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present a case of an 18-year-old male referred to Hospital 12 de Octubre by SAMUR
column2: after suffering a bull horn injury to the left cervicofacial region during the running of the bulls in San Sebastián de Los Reyes in August 2005. He was immediately transferred to the operating theatre
column3: where the correct orotracheal intubation
column4: which had been carried out in situ by the medical staff in the bullring
column5: was confirmed. The absence of respiratory and cardiovascular alterations was verified
column6: as well as a stable haemodynamic situation. Then
column7: under general anaesthesia
column8: a regular tracheotomy and cannulation of the corresponding central and peripheral airways were performed. Subsequently
column9: an initial and diagnostic examination was carried out
column10: where an incised and anfractuous wound was observed from the upper left supraclavicular region to the ipsilateral labial commissure. A fracture of the right mandibular body
column11: comminuted fracture of the left mandibular angle
column12: dental avulsion of the incisal sector of the upper jaw
column13: as well as severe laceration of the lingual musculature and floor of the mouth were observed. In addition
column14: an exposure of the left jugulo-carotid bundle was observed
column15: which was found to be completely intact. Interdental suturing was performed at the fracture sites and adjacent soft tissue in order to provisionally restore the anatomy
column16: and the patient was transferred to the Radiology Department for a diagnostic craniofacial CT scan in order to rule out the existence of associated central nervous system and cervical lesions. Subsequently
column17: once in the operating theatre
column18: direct laryngoscopy was performed to exclude the presence of laryngo-oesophageal lesions. The entire oral cavity and affected tissues are meticulously washed with a surgical brush and antiseptic solution. Tetanus vaccine and gamma globulin are administered
column19: and systemic intravenous treatment with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and metronidazole is started.  After correct exposure of the fracture sites at the level of the right mandibular body and left mandibular angle
column20: favoured by the characteristics of the wound itself
column21: reduction and osteosynthesis is performed using 2.4 Synthes® mandibular reconstruction plates
column22: given the presence of comminution in one of them and the high potential for infection of the surgical site. The remaining root debris in the upper incisal sector was exodonticated and the corresponding bone regularisation was carried out. Suture and anatomical restoration of the cervical musculature
column23: floor of the mouth and tongue. Microsurgical anastomosis of the right mentonian and left lingual nerves. The skin and oral mucosa are sutured. The patient was subsequently transferred to the ICU-Polytrauma Department where he remained for 36 hours
column24: presenting no neurological or systemic complications during this time. After referral to the ward
column25: antibiotic treatment was continued for 10 days
column26: and the wound was treated daily with antiseptic solution
column27: both intraoral and cutaneous. There was no evidence of infectious pathology in this area
column28: and the patient progressed favourably
column29: being discharged on the eleventh day.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 32-year-old male (78 kg
column3: without drug allergies
column4: with a history of inguinal herniorrhaphy and without any treatment
column5: military
column6: who during his working day suffered a crushing after an unexpected fall from a metal structure weighing approximately 1
column7: 500 kg. He was evacuated by land ambulance with advanced life support capability to the Hospital Universitario Central de la Defensa "Gómez Ulla" without loss of consciousness and with both respiratory and haemodynamic stability. In the Emergency Department
column8: a secondary assessment was carried out
column9: a blood sample was taken (CPK 2.295 U/l and myoglobin 469 ng/ml with the rest of the haemogram
column10: biochemistry and haemostasis parameters within normal limits)
column11: a chest X-ray compatible with mild pulmonary contusion without pelvic rib fractures and cervical and abdominopelvic CT scan showing a fracture of the left ischiopubic branch without displacement
column12: 10 mm diastasis in the upper portion of the right sacroiliac joint with small bony avulsion of the superomedial iliac border
column13: and decreased thickness of the intersomatic spaces at L4-L5 and L5-S1 accompanied by small diffuse disc prominence at L4-L5.  Diagnosed as polycontused
column14: he was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit with GCS of 15 points
column15: symmetrical reactive pupils
column16: without neurological focality
column17: with good respiratory dynamics
column18: oxygen saturation within the normal range
column19: perfused
column20: normotensive and normocardiac
column21: without signs of peritoneal irritation and absence of macroscopic haematuria
column22: so that after 24 hours it was decided to discharge him to the hospital ward. On the hospital ward
column23: the patient evolved satisfactorily
column24: with a blood test on the sixth day of admission showing elevated liver enzymes (GOT 134 U/l
column25: GPT 91 U/l
column26: BT 1.2 mg/dl
column27: BD 0.5 mg/dl) which was diagnosed by the Gastroenterology Department as probable acute toxic hepatopathy without liver failure
column28: not accompanied by hepatomegaly or jaundice. Fifteen days after the accident and after clinical improvement and recovery of normal laboratory values
column29: the patient was discharged from hospital with the recommendation of periodic check-ups by the Traumatology Department. During his admission
column30: the patient presented pain of variable intensity (VAS 2/10
column32: 7/10 and 1/10 during his stay in the emergency room
column33: ICU
column34: hospital ward and at discharge
column35: respectively)
column36: with stabbing characteristics
column37: located in the right thoracic region
column38: right pelvis and buttocks
column39: non-radiating
column40: which increased with sitting and decreased in the supine position without causing vegetative symptomatology. She slept satisfactorily and slept without interruption for approximately 8 hours a day. She presented slight dysthymia
column41: probably due to not being able to be with her family living in Colombia. The analgesic treatment administered during the evacuation to the hospital was: fentanyl 100 µg
column42: in the ICU: paracetamol 1 g/8 h i.v. and dexketoprofen-tromethamol 50 mg/8 h i.v.
column43: during the first 6 days in the ward: paracetamol 1 g/8 h i.v. and dexketoprofen-tromethamol 50 mg/8 h i.v. and finally until discharge: dexketoprofen-tromethamol 50mg/8 h i.v. and fentanyl 400 µg transmucosal 30 minutes before any potentially painful movement (showering
column44: standing x-ray...).  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 69-year-old man with a personal history of M1 AML (myeloblastic without differentiation)
column2: in complete remission (CR) for 11 months after chemotherapy treatment according to the PETHEMA-LAM 99 protocol. In February 2008 he was admitted for catarrhal respiratory symptoms
column3: with severe nasal congestion
column4: with no response to antibiotics. He also presented erythematous papules on his back
column5: supraclavicular and submaxillary adenopathies. The patient was referred by the haematologist for presenting red eye of two days' evolution
column6: with no other ocular symptoms. On examination he had a corrected visual acuity of 20/20 in OD and 18/20 in OI. Ocular reflexes
column7: motility and tonometry were normal. Anterior pole biomicroscopy showed a salmon-coloured raised fleshy lesion on the upper and lower tarsus in OD. In the OI
column8: a similar lesion was found in the inferior tarsal conjunctiva. No alterations were observed in the fundus.  The possibility of leukaemic involvement of the conjunctiva was considered and a biopsy of the lesion was performed. Histology showed a diffuse proliferation of myeloid cells arranged under the conjunctival epithelium
column9: which were immunohistochemically positive for myeloperoxidase and CD43
column10: negative for B and T cell markers (CD20
column11: CD3
column12: CD5)
column13: as well as for TdT
column14: CD34 and CD117
column15: and the case was diagnosed as a granulocytic sarcoma.  New biopsies confirmed the involvement of the nasal mucosa and skin. Based on these findings
column16: the diagnosis was SM affecting conjunctiva
column17: skin and nasal mucosa. However
column18: no relapse was observed in peripheral blood and bone marrow smears
column19: so it was considered that CR persisted at this level. Lumbar puncture and all other examinations were normal. Following the diagnosis of extramedullary recurrence in the form of SM of AML
column20: second-line treatment was started according to the FLAG-IDA protocol with a good response of the infiltrative lesions. The patient died in May 2008
column21: three months after the diagnosis of SM
column22: due to multi-organ failure.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This was an 11-year-old patient (weight 35 kg) scheduled for bilateral knee tenotomy to correct a knee "flexion" that prevented him from resting in the supine position. He had been diagnosed with DMD at 3 years of age by genetic study
column2: and due to the progression of the disease he needed a wheelchair from the age of eight. Preoperatively
column3: he had elevated transaminases (AST 131 mU.ml-1
column4: ALT 187 mU.ml-1) and CPK 4226 UI/l. The rest of the biochemical control
column5: haemogram and coagulation were within normal limits. Chest X-ray showed increased bronchovascular tract in the bases. A functional respiratory study could not be performed due to the patient's lack of cooperation
column6: but the last one available (at 8 years of age) showed a severe restrictive disorder. The electrocardiogram (ECG) showed deep Q waves in the left precordial leads
column7: with no repolarisation alterations. The patient was premedicated with 7 mg midazolam orally. Anaesthetic induction was performed after cannulation of a peripheral line with propofol (2 mg/kg-1) and 0.5 µg/kg-1 slow bolus remifentanil. Endotracheal intubation was performed with a 6.5 Fr calibre flexometallic tube with pneumotap after neuromuscular blockade with mivacurium (0.2 mg/kg-1). Anaesthetic maintenance was performed with propofol (10-4 mg.kg-1) to achieve a bispectral index (BIS) of 40-60
column8: remifentanil (0.25 µg.kg-1.min-1) and mivacurium (0.6 mg.kg-1.h-1) with the patient mechanically ventilated with O2-air. With the patient in lateral decubitus
column9: before being placed in prone position for surgery
column10: epidural anaesthesia was performed at L4-L5 level with an 18G-gauge Tuohy needle
column11: through which a catheter (20G) was placed for post-surgical analgesia. Two ml of bupivacaine 0.25% with vasoconstrictor was administered as a test dose and 12 ml of ropivacaine 0.2%. The operation was uneventful and the patient could be extubated at the end of surgery
column12: with good ventilatory mechanics. Recovery from the mivacurium muscle block
column13: monitored with a neurostimulator
column14: was not prolonged and reversal of the muscle block was not necessary. The patient was admitted to the ward under the care of traumatology and monitored by the Pain Unit of our hospital. As post-surgical analgesia
column15: 7 ml.h-1 of ropivacaine 0.18% with 1 µg.ml-1 of fentanyl through the lumbar epidural catheter
column16: achieving adequate analgesia (0 out of 10 on the visual analogue scale). However
column17: eight hours after surgery
column18: the ward was notified because the patient presented complete motor block (Bromage grade 3) with a sensitive level at T10
column19: which reversed three hours after reducing the local anaesthetic (LA) concentration by half. No other adverse events were recorded. Epidural analgesia was effective (VAS < 2) with the new LA concentration. The epidural catheter was removed on postoperative day 5. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 25-year-old Colombian woman was admitted to our obstetrics department for presenting with rupture of membranes at 24 weeks and 5 days gestation. She had no family or personal history of interest. Gynaecological history: menarche at 14 years of age; M.F.: 3-4/32. In a routine pregnancy examination performed at 20 weeks' gestation
column2: she was diagnosed with vaginal condylomatosis. Examination on admission: patient was apyretic. Inspection of the external genitalia revealed multiple vulvoperineal condylomas. TV: cervix formed
column3: posterior and closed. There was abundant clear water flowing. Ultrasound: foetus in cephalic longitudinal. Posterior placenta
column4: ILA 8 (amniotic fluid index). F.C.F. positive. Estimated foetal weight: 641 g.  Treatment with intravenous antibiotics was started and a series of complementary tests were performed (complete CBC
column5: serology
column6: vaginal
column7: rectal and amniotic fluid cultures
column8: and hybridisation test for HPV)
column9: the results of which are shown in table 1
column10: and which led to the diagnosis of chorioamnionitis.  Labour was triggered one week later and due to the presence of chorioamnionitis and foetal immaturity was allowed to progress. Delivery was spontaneous
column11: with a live male foetus of 690 g
column12: pH of artery 7.24 and pH of vein 7.48. Apgar test at 1 and 5.5. Placenta of 167 g
column13: hypermature with signs of chorioamnionitis. After delivery
column14: biopsies of the vagina and perineum were performed
column15: the results of which were: condyloma acuminatum of the vagina and condyloma acuminatum of the perineum respecting the edges. The neonate died at 40 days of life.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 25-year-old male patient was admitted to the Internal Medicine Department for an afternoon fever of 3 days' duration and an ultrasound scan revealed an incidental tumour in the right testicle. As personal history
column2: he reported no drug allergies. Bilateral inguinal herniorrhaphy. He reported a painless tumour that had been present for a year and had been progressively increasing. Physical examination revealed an enlarged right testicle with a painless tumour in the upper pole. In view of the suspicion of a testicular tumour
column3: various complementary tests were performed. A testicular ultrasound scan showed a heterogeneous
column4: solid tumour in the right testicle measuring 78 mm x 57 mm x 61 mm
column5: compatible with a primary testicular tumour. The left testicle was normal. Computerised axial tomography (CAT): right testicular tumour with retrocaval and para-aortic adenopathies > 2 and <5 cm. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): 1890 IU/I; alpha-fetoprotein (AFP): 51 ng/ml; beta-chorionic gonadotropin (Beta-HCG): 23 mIU/ml. He underwent right inguinal orchiectomy with anatomical pathology report of 7 cm embryonal carcinoma replacing parenchyma and epididymis with implants in the cord and reaching the albuginea. Diagnosed with embryonal carcinoma of the right testicle T3N2M0
column6: stage II with intermediate risk due to elevated LDH
column7: he completed treatment with chemotherapy according to the BEP scheme (bleomicina
column8: etoposide and cisplatin) for 4 cycles. At the age of 4 years
column9: and being free of disease in the control check-ups
column10: he came to the emergency department for a painful tumour in the left testicle. Physical examination revealed a left monorchid
column11: indurated tumour at the level of the lower pole of the left epididymis. Complementary examinations included: Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): 347 IU/I; alpha-fetoprotein (AFP): 2.4 ng/ml; beta-chorionic gonadotropin (Beta-HCG): 0.1 mIU/ml. Chest X-ray: No pathological findings. Testicular ultrasound: Testicular tumour measuring 51x19x22 mm in size
column12: with heterogeneous echostructure and colour Doppler flow
column13: also affecting the body and tail of the epididymis. Calcification in the anteroinferior aspect of the testicle. Computerised Axial Tomography thoraco-abdominal-pelvic: Liver
column14: spleen and pancreas normal. Kidneys of normal morphology and density. No adenopathy or lymph node chains. On suspicion of a second germ cell tumour
column15: a radical orchiectomy was performed on the left inguinal route
column16: and the pathological anatomy revealed a classic seminoma of 3.2 cm in diameter infiltrating the testicular parenchyma and extending to the epididymis and spermatic cord. The postoperative period was uneventful. He was referred to the Oncology Department for assessment of adjuvant treatment and monitoring. Given that the maximum diameter of the tumour was 3.2 cm and that it did not affect the rete testis
column17: conservative control treatment was chosen. Three months later
column18: a control CAT scan revealed enlarged left retroperitoneal adenopathy (3.5 cm)
column19: with a poor plane of separation with the psoas that trapped the middle third of the ureter
column20: causing grade I hydronephrosis. In the control blood tests: haemogram
column21: biochemistry and haemostasis within normal parameters except for creatinine of 1.2 mg/dl; lactate dehydrogenase = 552 IU/I
column22: alpha-fetoprotein and chorionic beta-gonadotropin within normal parameters. He was diagnosed with retroperitoneal recurrence and underwent treatment with chemotherapy (etoposide and cisplatin for 4 cycles). The patient has currently been disease-free for 3 years in the periodic check-ups carried out in the Urology and Oncology Departments.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 43-year-old man
column2: with a history of diabetes
column3: who was admitted for moderate acute pancreatitis. Two weeks later
column4: he reported acute pain in the left hemiabdomen and nausea
column5: with no other symptoms. On examination
column6: a large occupation of the left hemiabdomen was palpated without peritoneal irritation. Laboratory tests: elevated triglycerides and lipase
column7: other biochemistry
column8: haemogram and coagulation normal. During the examination
column9: the patient suffered syncope and his haematocrit dropped from 40 to 21%
column10: requiring transfusion of 6 red blood cell concentrates
column11: and he remained stable. Imaging tests revealed a haemorrhagic pancreatic pseudocyst measuring 17 x 27 cm in diameter. The patient was admitted to the ICU where he remained stable. One week later
column12: the patient was scheduled for surgery with a cysto-jejunostomy. The postoperative period was uneventful and the patient was discharged one week after the operation.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 59-year-old man with a personal history of chronic alcoholism and smoking for years
column2: who had suffered an episode of upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage secondary to anti-inflammatory analgesics as complications. His urological history included a prostate syndrome of two years' evolution with no secondary complications. She came to the emergency department for intermittent febrile syndrome of four days' evolution
column3: associated with urinary incontinence in the last 48 hours
column4: together with dysuria and sacral pain radiating to both lower limbs and worsening with movement. Rectal tenesmus of recent onset was also associated. On arrival at the emergency department
column5: fever of up to 39ºC was observed
column6: the patient was haemodynamically stable
column7: confused
column8: drowsy and sweaty. On physical examination
column9: the abdomen was globular
column10: soft and depressible
column11: not peritonitised. Painful on palpation in the bilateral lumbar area at L5-S1
column12: as well as in the hypogastric area and perineal region. There is no impression of a bladder balloon. The genital examination was normal
column13: and the rectal examination showed a slightly painful rectal volume I adenomatosis. The neurological examination shows decreased strength in both lower limbs in the upper third and sensitivity is preserved. Patellar and Achilles reflexes are present. Urgent blood and biochemistry tests showed: haemoglobin 14.2 g/dl
column14: haematocrit 41.5%
column15: leucocytes 20
column16: 300 (neutrophils 72.9%)
column17: glucose 212 mg/dl
column18: creatinine 1.11 mg/dl
column19: sodium 135 mEq/l
column20: potassium 3.8 mEq/l
column21: sedimentation rate 100 mm/h. Urinalysis with negative leucocytes
column22: negative nitrites and normal sediment. The analysis was completed with a coagulation study which showed a prothrombin activity of 83%
column23: a cephalin time of 27.2 sg
column24: and fibrinogen of 574 mg/dl. An urgent abdomino-pelvic CT scan was requested at the outset
column25: showing multiple simple cysts in the kidneys and left renal lithiasis. No dilatation of the urinary tract. The prostate was enlarged
column26: with two hypodense lesions in both lateral lobes measuring 3.3 cm and 3 cm
column27: compatible with prostatic abscess.  Empirical antibiotic treatment with Ceftriaxone 1 g/12 h
column28: Ampicillin 1 g/6 h and Gentamicin 240 mg/24 h was then started. With the diagnosis of prostatic abscess
column29: we decided to drain the collection under control with ECTR and urinary diversion. In the operating theatre
column30: a lumbar puncture was performed prior to intradural anaesthesia. A cloudy-yellowish cerebrospinal fluid was observed and a sample was sent to microbiology and biochemistry
column31: 1070 leukocytes were isolated (85% polymorphonuclear). On the other hand
column32: the diagnosis of prostatic abscess was confirmed in the TCPR
column33: which showed two collections of 30 and 28 mm affecting the left and right lobe respectively
column34: the rest of the prostate being heterogeneous with no clear abscessed areas. By means of perineal puncture-drainage we evacuated 10 cc of pus from the collections described
column35: leaving a cystostomy tube in place for drainage. We diverted the urine via suprapubic cystostomy.  From the culture of the samples (prostatic and lumbar puncture)
column36: sensitive S. aureus oxicilin was isolated
column37: so we started treatment with Cloxacillin 2 g/24 and Rifampicin 300 mg/12h
column38: and requested an urgent lumbar MRI which was reported as a subdural empyema
column39: with no signs of spondylodiscitis.  Subsequent control based on new ECTR showed a clear improvement
column40: although it was necessary to drain again a hyperechogenic area in the right prostatic lobe
column41: evacuating 4 cc of purulent material. Subsequent check-ups did not reveal any new suspicious areas. A transesophageal echography was also performed
column42: which ruled out secondary endocarditis
column43: and a new lumbar MRI scan was performed after six weeks of antibiotic treatment
column44: which showed complete resolution of the subdural empyema.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 70-year-old woman
column2: whose personal history included a breast cancer operation 14 years earlier
column3: came to the emergency department of another hospital because of severe pain in the lower lip accompanied by swelling and oedema in the lip
column4: chin and submandibular area that had awakened her suddenly at night. She was initially treated with iv corticosteroids and analgesia
column5: and referred home. Four days later
column6: the patient came to the emergency department of our hospital describing that the lesion had become "blackish and yellowish". The lesion was not painful and there was no fever or other accompanying symptoms. On questioning
column7: the patient reported having recently seen spiders in her home. This was in the context of an epidemic of bites by the Loxosceles reclusa spider in the same geographical area. In the previous 15 days
column8: 7 cases of upper and lower limb bites had been diagnosed in the emergency department. Examination revealed a single lesion of about 2 cm
column9: necrotic in appearance and well demarcated
column10: occupying the lateral third of the skin
column11: vermilion and commissure of the left lower hemilabium
column12: surrounded by a white and purplish halo. Intraorally
column13: a pale mucosal lesion with signs of necrosis and fibrinous exudate was observed in continuity and did not dislodge on scraping. Laboratory tests were ordered
column14: a biopsy was taken and treatment with amoxicillin/clavulanic acid by mouth was started. The infectious diseases department was consulted on suspicion of a spider bite. The differential diagnosis was made with necrotic cutaneous-mucosal lesions
column15: such as cellulitis
column16: vasculitis
column17: diabetic ulcers
column18: vascular insufficiency
column19: drug reactions
column20: thermal or chemical burns
column21: infectious or traumatic
column22: all of which were ruled out. After 7 days
column23: the necrotic tissue was debrided under local anaesthesia. The suggestive clinical and epidemiological context
column24: together with the laboratory and pathological anatomy results and the differential diagnosis
column25: led to the probable diagnosis. At 2 months
column26: given the low aesthetic and functional impact of the scar defect
column27: lip reconstruction was not necessary.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient is a 22 year old male
column2: asthenic
column3: asthenic
column4: slim and thin
column5: who has been coming to our health centre repeatedly in the last month due to stabbing epigastric pain associated with nausea and postprandial vomiting that relieves the pain. The episodes have been occurring for 7 years
column6: for which reason she has consulted the emergency services on multiple occasions
column7: but no acute pathology has ever been found. She was admitted 3 years ago for one of these episodes
column8: undergoing gastroscopy with gastric biopsy which was positive for H. pylori; she underwent eradication treatment with current triple therapy (omeprazole
column9: amoxicillin and clarithromycin)
column10: with a subsequent negative breath test for H. pylori infection. Due to persistent symptoms
column11: treatment was started with antiemetics and multiple proton pump inhibitors
column12: with no long-term response. On admission
column13: he was assessed by the Mental Health Service
column14: as the symptoms of acute pain persisted
column15: which subsided with vomiting
column16: and he was diagnosed with an anxious-depressive syndrome with poor follow-up and non-compliance with treatment. He had no food or drug allergies. Currently
column17: the pain subsided in the genupectoral position and with cannabis consumption. On examination we found a patient with stable vitals
column18: with a BMI of 17.7. The abdomen was excavated
column19: tympanic
column20: soft and slightly painful on deep palpation in the epigastrium
column21: with no palpable masses
column22: adenopathies or megaliths. Laboratory tests showed no abnormalities; no anaemia
column23: negative inflammatory response markers
column24: no liver or electrolyte abnormalities
column25: total protein 5.8 g/dL (normal value 6.4 to 8.3 g/dL). The abdominal X-ray showed no signs of intestinal obstruction. A total abdominal ultrasound was performed in the supine decubitus position
column26: with no evidence of relevant findings
column27: for which reason we decided to consult the Digestive Service
column28: where
column29: after being assessed
column30: a barium bowel transit was requested
column31: with a delay of more than 8 hours due to slow gastric emptying due to a permanent decrease in calibre in the 3rd duodenal portion
column32: suggestive of extrinsic compression
column33: which did not prevent the distal passage of contrast
column34: all compatible with vascular compression. In view of this finding
column35: a CT angiography of the abdomen was performed
column36: with the result of a vascular clamp that produced compression of the 3rd portion of the duodenum. The mesenteric clamp affected the duodenum and the left renal vein
column37: producing compression and pre- and post-compression dilatation.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Female
column2: 42 years old. She presented 8 months with recurrent herpes in the mouth. Admitted for 2 months with a dry cough and rapidly progressive dyspnoea. In addition
column3: bilateral chest pain
column4: fever up to 39oC and weight loss of 14kg. The recurrence of the herpetic lesion caused dysphagia and odynophagia. Physical examination revealed whitish plaques in the oropharynx; chest examination revealed decreased breath sounds and fine rales. On room air
column5: oxygen saturation was 86%. The arterial blood gas report with 70% supplemental oxygen was: pH 7.30
column6: pCO2 40.5mmHg
column7: pO2 132mmHg
column8: HCO3 19.5mmol/l
column9: base excess -5.8mmol/l
column10: oxygen saturation 97.9%. Oxygenation index (OI) of 188. Laboratory tests on admission showed: lymphopenia of 600 cells/mm3
column11: Hb 11.8g/dl
column12: lactate dehydrogenase 971IU/l and albumin 3.3g/dl. Chest X-ray showed bilateral patchy opacities with ground glass and pneumomediastinum
column13: so the differential diagnosis included HIV-associated immunosuppression and P. jirovecii pneumonia (PJP). The ELISA test for HIV was POSITIVE
column14: confirmed by Western Blot. Bronchoscopy with transbronchial biopsy and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) was performed. The histopathological study is reported in figure 1. He received treatment with Trimethoprim/Sulfamethoxasol and Prednisone in reduction doses for 21 days.  On the 7th day of treatment he presented respiratory deterioration and the OI dropped to 110
column15: for which he was admitted to intensive care in shock and supported with invasive mechanical ventilation. On admission
column16: laboratory tests showed leukocytes of 24
column17: 300 cells/mm3
column18: Hb 10.8g/dl
column19: lactate dehydrogenase 2033 IUI/l and albumin 2.26g/dl. Imipenem was added on suspicion of hospital-acquired pneumonia and after 12 days the leukocyte count improved to 5800 cells/mm3
column20: Hb 8.7g/dl
column21: lactate dehydrogenase 879 IUI/l
column22: albumin 2.41g/dl and OI 243.5
column23: and extubation was achieved. In the following 24h
column24: he presented massive haemoptysis (volume 250ml). Hb decreased to 6g/dl
column25: OI decreased to 106 and he was supported with invasive mechanical ventilation. Swan-Ganz measured a POAP of 10mmHg. Chest X-ray is shown in figure 2A. He underwent LBA whose pathology study confirmed the presence of recent and active alveolar haemorrhage. In addition
column26: rt-PCR documented CMV infection and he started treatment with Ganciclovir 350mg/d for 14 days.  He had a good evolution
column27: improving the OI to 277 and withdrawing from invasive mechanical ventilation 9 days after the event. After 37 days he was discharged home. At follow-up
column28: the CD4 count was 109 cells/µL and the viral load <40 cells/µL.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A four-year-old girl came to the emergency department with a palpable purpuric rash on the lower limbs and buttocks
column2: pain and swelling in the left ankle and on the second finger of the right hand. As a background
column3: the week prior to the onset of the clinical picture she had acute pharyngitis.  Additional tests:  Microbiology: rapid detection of group A β-hemolytic streptococcus negative
column4: sterile urine culture
column5: negative blood culture. Blood count: leukocytes 8320/mm3
column6: haemoglobin 13 g/dl
column7: platelets 276 000/mm3
column8: erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) in the first hour of 18 mm/h. Coagulation tests: prothrombin time 13.9 seconds (range 10-14)
column9: Quick's index 69% (range 70-150)
column10: international normalised ratio (INR) 1.25 (range 0.85-1.15)
column11: activated partial thromboplastin time 31.4 seconds (range 26-36)
column12: fibrinogen 429 ng/ml (range 200-400). Biochemistry: glucose 82 mg/dl
column13: urea 20 mg/dl
column14: creatinine 0.40 mg/dl
column15: total/direct bilirubin 0.4/0.2 mg/dl
column16: total protein 7.5 g/dl
column17: albumin 3.5 g/dl
column18: total calcium 8.6 mg/dl
column19: GOT/GPT 23/15 IU/l
column20: GGT 15 IU/l
column21: lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) 254 IU/l
column22: FA 127 IU/l. Ions: Na 130 mEq/l
column23: K 3.5 mEq/l
column24: Cl 103 mEq/l. C-reactive protein 1.05 mg/dl. Urine sediment: no significant proteinuria or haematuria.  Due to the clinical characteristics
column25: the case suggests Schönlein-Henoch purpura with joint involvement as a first possibility. The case evolved satisfactorily with oral non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and rest.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 61 year old male patient
column2: who is being assessed for clinical pain due to grade III obliterating arteriopathy with involvement of the lower limbs. He has been prescribed Durogesic® Matrix 50 μg/h as analgesic treatment for 18 months with acceptable pain control (VAS
column3: 3-4). As rescue medication she is using paracetamol 1 g
column4: (maximum 1 or 2 per day). She came for an emergency visit to the pain unit because for the last 15 days she has had an increased pain threshold with a certain state of agitation and nervousness. All this occurred after seeing his GP for medication
column5: who prescribed generic transdermal fentanyl 50 μg/h
column6: requiring paracetamol 1 g every 6 h as a rescue
column7: with little pain relief
column8: increasing the VAS to 7-8. After anamnesis with the patient
column9: we again prescribe Durogesic® Matrix 50 μg/h. When the patient was reviewed after 2 weeks
column10: he again presented better pain relief
column11: with VAS of 3-4 again
column12: and the nervousness that he had previously presented disappeared. Currently
column13: 3 months after the last visit
column14: the patient continues with Durogesic® Matrix 50 μg/h and
column15: sporadically
column16: paracetamol 1g.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O

column1: A 35-year-old man consulted for sudden loss of central vision in his left eye. His personal history included having had a common cold for 10 days prior to the episode. Clinical examination revealed an uncorrected visual acuity of 0.9 in the right eye and 0.1 in the left eye
column2: with metamorphopsia in the latter. No inflammatory signs or anterior segment abnormalities were observed. The left fundus showed macular thickening of approximately 2 papillary diameters (PD) with small intraretinal haemorrhages. The right fundus showed a yellowish-white lesion with a papillary diameter temporally inferior to the macula. Additional examinations included fluorescein angiography (FFA) and indocyanine green angiography (IGA)
column3: optical coherence tomography (OCT)
column4: B-mode ultrasound and a complete blood test.  The FFA of the IO shows a pattern of patchy hypofluorescence at very early times
column5: followed by diffuse hyperfluorescence of the posterior pole with a better demarcated subfoveal hyperfluorescent area of 1 PD. AVI shows a hypofluorescent area with poorly demarcated borders in the posterior pole that is maintained with angiographic times.  OCT shows a loss of foveal thickness due to the existence of a subfoveal intraretinal cyst accompanied by small areas of perifoveal neurosensory retinal detachment (DRNS).  Both the ultrasound and the analytical study did not reveal any findings of interest. Given this bilateral
column6: albeit asymmetrical
column7: yellowish-white lesion of inflammatory origin located in the chorioretinal interface
column8: the probable diagnosis was acute posterior placoid epitheliopathy with an atypical presentation. Due to the severe loss of VA
column9: treatment was started with oral systemic corticosteroids administering 1mg/kg body weight of prednisone; a daily omeprazole tablet was also prescribed. After 2 weeks
column10: the patient came for a check-up and reported a very slight improvement in his LAA. The AVSC is 0.9 and 0.15 respectively. Fundus examination showed an increase in pigmentation of the lesions without any other signs of interest. The OCT shows alteration of the subfoveal RPE in the OI
column11: with no evidence of the small perifoveal DRNS described above. The corticosteroid regimen was then tapered.  At 5 weeks the patient showed significant improvement with an AVSC of 0.9 in the OD and 0.6 in the OI. Fig. 5A shows the healing of the lesions corroborated by a control FFA. At the last check-up performed one year after the onset of the episode
column12: the patient's visual acuity recovered completely
column13: with 0.9 in both eyes without correction. The fundus examination showed hyperpigmentation of the lesions corresponding to their scarring.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present a clinical case of chronic bladder dysfunction (detrusor hyperactivity)
column2: associated with intense refractory pain
column3: secondary to bladder spasms
column4: in a patient requiring continuous bladder lavage. A 58-year-old man was admitted to hospital with macroscopic haematuria
column5: accompanied by suprapubic pain
column6: and had been wearing a urethral catheter for 72 hours prior to admission due to acute urinary retention. His personal history included right lumbosciatica due to lumbar disc protrusions
column7: remote urolithiasis treated with extracorporeal lithotripsy and a long-standing chronic voiding syndrome
column8: in the context of benign prostatic hypertrophy according to prostate biopsy
column9: chronically treated with oral tamsulosin (vo)
column10: after two previous transurethral prostate resections. The patient was admitted to the hospital's Urology Department and underwent imaging tests. An abdominopelvic ultrasound scan showed signs of "wrestling bladder"
column11: with no evidence of obstructive uropathy
column12: and an abdominopelvic CT scan with contrast revealed prostatic hypertrophy and diffuse parietal bladder thickening
column13: compatible with detrusor hypertrophy. The urethral catheter was replaced with a catheter adapted for continuous bladder lavage to dissolve intravesical clots. During the establishment of bladder lavage
column14: episodes of suprapubic colic pain appeared
column15: accompanied by intense neurovegetative cramping and reflux of haematuric bladder fluid
column16: against gravity
column17: from the bladder lavage serum
column18: located about sixty centimetres above the patient's level. After ruling out obstructive problems and urethral catheter positioning
column19: a diagnosis of bladder spasm due to detrusor hyperactivity was made and treatment was started with intravenous (IV) hyoscine butylbromide
column20: metamizole and dexketoprofen
column21: tolterodine and alprazolam
column22: both by IV
column23: and subcutaneous morphine chloride
column24: without success. Given the persistence of the painful symptoms and intolerance to bladder lavage therapy
column25: it was decided to place a lumbar epidural catheter in the L3-L4 intervertebral space
column26: through which a bolus of 80 mg of lidocaine 2% with 50 μg of fentanyl was administered
column27: followed by a perfusion of levobupivacaine 0.125% with fentanyl
column28: at a rate of 5 mg/hour and 4 μg/hour respectively. After the introduction of the epidural block
column29: excellent control was achieved of the painful symptoms and the urodynamic manifestations of bladder spasm
column30: with a level of sensory block at the level of the T12 dermatome and a motor block at grade 0 on the Bromage scale. She was maintained on the aforementioned perfusion until the accidental explantation of the epidural catheter
column31: which occurred seven days later
column32: and iv analgesia was started with morphine chloride at 0.96 mg/hour. On the tenth day of admission
column33: the patient underwent scheduled surgery under intradural anaesthesia for retropubic prostatic adenomectomy
column34: according to Millin's technique
column35: and postoperative analgesia was maintained with iv morphine chloride
column36: associated with iv paracetamol. In addition
column37: tolterodine by mouth was maintained. At 48 h postoperatively
column38: and still under continuous bladder lavage therapy
column39: the episodes of painful bladder spasms reappeared
column40: with similar characteristics to the previous ones
column41: requiring an increase in the morphine chloride infusion rate to 1.8 mg/hour. Placement of a new epidural catheter was ruled out
column42: due to postoperative prophylactic heparinisation. After withdrawal of continuous postoperative bladder lavage due to cessation of haematuria
column43: the clinical picture disappeared completely. The patient reported greater pain relief with epidural block compared to the therapeutic combination of spasmolytics
