column1: Female patient
column2: aged 23 years
column3: non-smoker
column4: with no relevant medical or surgical history or known drug allergies. She came to the clinic because of an increase in the volume of the lower vestibular gum
column5: adjacent to the left mental orifice
column6: of 2 months' evolution
column7: with active growth. It was not related to traumatic causes. Clinical examination revealed a nodule 0.5 cm in diameter
column8: of fibroelastic consistency on palpation
column9: similar in colour to normal mucosa
column10: partially adherent to deep planes and painless. On radiological examination
column11: no particularities were observed in the area of the lesion.  Under local anaesthesia
column12: an excisional biopsy of the lesion was performed. Pathological examination revealed a proliferation of spindle cells arranged in short swirling fascicles
column13: with abundant vascular structures of myxomatous appearance
column14: isolated collagen deposits and foci of lymphocytic infiltrate with extravasated red blood cells. Immunohistochemical studies were also performed and were positive for vimentin and smooth muscle actin and negative for alk-protein 1
column15: beta catenin
column16: CD 34
column17: desmin
column18: S-100. Ki67 expression was 5-6% of labelled nuclei. This picture corresponds to the diagnosis of nodular fasciitis. The patient was followed up for 18 months and no recurrence was observed.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Three-year-old girl diagnosed a year ago with neurofibromatosis type 1 by the paediatrics department. She was referred to ophthalmology for assessment
column2: in the context of screening for other pathologies carried out in these patients. For this reason
column3: a cranial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan was also requested. At this time the patient had no symptoms and the examination was as follows: uncorrected visual acuity in the right eye 0.9 and in the left eye 1. Biomicroscopic examination of the anterior segment was normal
column4: as was funduscopy in both eyes. Intraocular pressure was normal in both eyes. External eye movements without pathological findings. No proptosis or exophthalmos. Isochoric and normoreactive pupils. In the neuroimaging study with MRI
column5: the presence of an optic nerve glioma of the left eye was detected. It was decided not to treat
column6: but to follow the patient with periodic check-ups every three months. During this follow-up
column7: a slight proptosis progressively appeared and the patient's vision decreased to 0.9 in the left eye.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 53-year-old woman with a history of migraines. She presented with sciatica refractory to treatment and a herniated disc L5-S1. After informed consent and preoperative study without contraindications
column2: L5-S1 microdiscectomy was performed. The operative technique
column3: including preparation and positioning
column4: was as follows: - Anaesthesia General anaesthesia was performed
column5: with orotracheal intubation. Induction was performed with Propofol
column6: analgesia with Renifentanil (m opioid receptor agonist
column7: with analgesic potency similar to fentanyl)
column8: and relaxation with Atracurium Besylate (competitive or non-depolarising neuromuscular blocking agent). Sevofluorane was used as a volatile anaesthetic. During the procedure
column9: 100 mg Tramadol (centrally acting analgesic
column10: pure non-selective µ
column11: delta and kappa opioid receptor agonist) and 25 mg dexketoprofen trometamol were administered. The duration of anaesthesia was 1 hour 50 minutes without any complications of any kind during the anaesthesia. - Placement The patient was placed in the Mohammedan position
column12: with the pectoral region and iliac crests supported on special pillows
column13: with central recesses to avoid decubitus of the abdomen and breasts.  The head was supported on a cushioned system in the form of a cranially open donut. To avoid ocular support
column14: the eyes were protected with lubricant and eye pads held in place by a bandage placed circularly over the head at the level of both eyes. The lower extremities were padded in the decubitus regions (both knees). Pedial and posterior tibial pulses were checked on both sides. The position of the patient's back was parallel to the ground. - Surgical technique It was performed by conventional microsurgery with a two-finger midline incision
column15: section of the common sacro-lumbar aponeurosis
column16: retraction of the paravertebral musculature
column17: flavectomy
column18: root dissection and excision of the extracted disc herniation. Blood loss was minimal and no blood was administered. A small amount of hydrogen peroxide was used as a haemostatic (about 5 cc). - Immediate postoperative period Upon awakening from anaesthesia
column19: the patient reported that she could not see anything at all in either eye. Ophthalmology was requested and no pathology was found. Ocular tension was normal. The photomotor and consensual reflexes were preserved. An emergency brain CT scan was performed
column20: which showed an image in the right intraventricular choroidal circulation compatible with a gas bubble. Another right occipital occipital juxta-osseous image was considered doubtful.  A cranial MRI was performed
column21: which showed a diffuse signal increase in T2 sequences in posterior areas of both occipital lobes. The MRI angiography was normal.  The picture was interpreted as being of vascular origin
column22: either positional or derived from the patient's migraine history
column23: and she was empirically treated with dexamethasone and vasodilators. After 6 hours
column24: she reported perceiving indistinguishable and faint chromatic shapes
column25: with the appearance of a threat reflex. The following morning (12 hours after the operation)
column26: he reported having recovered his vision
column27: although he perceived chromatic halos around the figures presented to him. These dyschromatopsias disappeared within 24 hours. A follow-up MRI showed significant improvement of the occipital images seen on the previous MRI.  Subsequent controls (one month after surgery) showed visual normality.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 26-year-old woman
column2: with no previous history of interest
column3: who
column4: although previously well
column5: began with mild odynophagia
column6: an afternoon fever of up to 38.5º which resolved well with paracetamol
column7: and general malaise. No accompanying chills or sweating crises. 4-5 days later
column8: she noticed the appearance of lymph nodes in both laterocervical areas and started treatment with amoxicillin
column10: on her own without observing any improvement. Physical examination revealed the presence of lymph nodes in both laterocervical chains
column11: of medium consistency
column12: rolling
column13: non-adherent
column14: 1-2 cm in diameter and painless. There were no palpable lymphadenopathies at other levels or organomegaly. No goitre or pain on pressure over the thyroid region. The analytical study showed leukocytosis with lymphocyte predominance
column15: with an ESR of 22 mm/h. Liver function was preserved
column16: there was no hypergammaglobulinaemia and mantoux was negative. Chest X-ray was normal. Serology for the viruses studied was negative (anti-EBV
column17: CMV
column18: HIV
column19: HTLV-1
column20: HV-6
column21: toxoplasma and syphilis). In the immunological study: ANA: 1/40 (80)
column22: antiDNA: 13.4 IU/ml (50)
column23: antiRNA: negative
column24: ENA-RNP: 0.45 and anticardiolipin: negative. Thyroid function was assessed: T3: 1.31 mg/L (0.6-1.6)
column26: TSH: 6.3 mU/L (<7)
column27: TGB (antithyroglobulin): 20.17 U/mL (<60)
column28: TPO (antiperoxidase): 1071 U/mL. Thyroid scan was normal. The fever disappeared after 12 days
column29: but the lymph nodes remained unchanged
column30: so a biopsy of two lymph nodes in the middle area of the right latero-cervical chain was performed
column31: which was diagnostic. Histological examination was compatible with non-lymphocytic histiocytic necrotising lymphadenitis or Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease. In the evolutionary control of thyroid function 5 months after the onset of the disease
column32: a decrease in the titre of antithyroid antibodies was observed (TGB: 7.6 U/mL; TPO: 870 U/mL)
column33: maintaining normal thyroid hormone and TSH levels (2.95 mU/L). Our diagnosis was subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis associated with Kikuchi's disease.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 64-year-old man with known HIV infection for 22 years
column2: on treatment with didanosine
column3: tenofovir and lopinavir/ritonavir. During the last two years
column4: during outpatient examinations
column5: he reported asthenia and diffuse bone pain. Several tests showed elevated total and bone alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25-HCC)
column6: total and ionic calcium and other routine serum biochemical parameters
column7: and urine elemental and sediment were normal. A plain spine X-ray showed degenerative signs
column8: and a Tc99 scintigraphy was normal.  During the last month her condition worsened
column9: with increased asthenia
column10: decreased strength
column11: difficulty walking and a 7 kg weight loss
column12: and she was admitted to hospital. Physical examination was unremarkable
column13: except for proximal muscle weakness. Laboratory findings included mild hyperglycaemia (154 mg/dl)
column14: marked glycosuria (4+)
column15: hypophosphataemia
column16: inappropriately high phosphaturia
column17: hypouricemia (2 mg/dl)
column18: mild metabolic acidosis (bicarbonate 19 mmol/l) and proteinuria (945 mg/24h). In addition
column19: moderate aminoaciduria
column20: with increased values of glycine (x2)
column21: valine (x2)
column22: serine (x4) and threonine (x4). Serum FGF23 was 6 pg/ml. Other parameters are shown in table 1. From these results a diagnosis of incomplete Fanconi syndrome with severe hypophosphataemia and probable osteomalacia was established in association with TDF. TDF was withdrawn and treatment was started with raltegravir and ritonavir-boosted darunavir. In addition
column23: phosphorus supplements
column24: 25-HCC and 1
column25: 25-dihydroxyvitamin D (1
column26: 25 DHCC) were administered. As a result
column27: his condition progressively improved. Six months after TDF withdrawal
column28: bone pain and muscle weakness had disappeared
column29: the patient had regained baseline weight and serum analytical abnormalities had normalised
column30: although phosphate reabsorption remained slightly low.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO B-FARMACO B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male
column2: 34 years old
column3: smoker of 15 cigarettes a day
column4: with a history of peptic oesophagitis
column5: hiatus hernia and non-allergic bronchial asthma. Diabetic father. He presented with severe abdominal pain in the left flank
column6: pasty stools and increased abdominal sounds
column7: and was assessed in primary care
column8: initially interpreting the symptoms as possible acute gastroenteritis. Examination revealed slight pain on palpation in the left abdomen and a slight increase in peristalsis. Given the persistence of the pain
column9: various complementary tests were requested. While awaiting further assessment
column10: 10 days after his visit to primary care
column11: he came to the hospital emergency department for a new episode of intense abdominal pain in the left flank
column12: this time accompanied by diaphoresis
column13: nervousness and skin pallor. He was assessed three times in the emergency department
column14: diagnosed and treated as renal colic. Blood pressure: 136/95 mm Hg; heart rate: 89 l/min; temperature: 37.7o; sweating. Abdominal examination revealed left flank pain with positive left renal suction. The rest of the physical examination was normal. Chest and abdominal X-rays were normal. There was minimal leukocytosis (10
column16: mild hyponatraemia and CRP=13. As there was no clinical improvement with symptomatic treatment
column17: an abdomino-pelvic ultrasound scan was performed showing a tumour in the left adrenal gland. Following this result
column18: a CT scan was requested
column19: showing a mass of 6.5 cm in diameter depending on the left adrenal gland
column20: which led to a differential diagnosis of pheochromocytoma or adrenal carcinoma.  Following this result
column21: the patient was referred to the Urology Department and from there to the Internal Medicine Department for a functional study in an attempt to rule out pheochromocytoma. The determination of urinary metanephrines and catecholamines showed a reading of more than five times the normal value for total urinary metanephrines and urinary free catecholamines. A diagnosis of a functioning left adrenal mass is made
column22: with marked elevation of metanephrines due to probable pheochromocytoma. Once the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma was established
column23: it was decided to perform a laparoscopic total left adrenalectomy after blockade with dosazoxin 4 mg/day. The anatomopathological analysis of the surgical findings showed that it was a malignant pheochromocytoma of 130 g and 6 x 6 cm
column24: with extensive necrosis
column25: marked cellular pleomorphism
column26: abundant atypical mitoses (<50 x 10 cga)
column27: capsular invasion and a tumour thrombus in a large-calibre vein (the clamped vein)
column28: with no extra-adrenal extension. The trans-operative period passed without complications. During the whole process the patient presents normal blood pressure figures with good general condition
column29: and no treatment is carried out.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 82-year-old woman with a history of breast neoplasia treated with surgery and hormone therapy 20 years ago
column2: hypertensive cardiomyopathy in sinus rhythm
column3: hypercholesterolemia and moderate chronic hyponatremia around 133 mmol/L. He was treated with torasemide 5 mg/24h
column4: isosorbide mononitrate 50 mg/24h
column5: acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg/24h
column6: pravastatin 20 mg/24h
column7: candesartan 32 mg/24h
column8: hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg/24h
column9: atenolol 50 mg/24h and spironolactone 25 mg/24h. She started treatment with sertraline 50 mg/24h
column10: with her usual natraemia figures
column11: for suspected depressive syndrome
column12: six weeks before admission. After two weeks
column13: his general condition worsened
column14: with nausea
column15: vomiting
column16: needing help with daily activities and behavioural alterations. One month later
column17: hyponatraemia of 119 mmol/L was detected
column18: sertraline was discontinued and water restriction was started at home for three days
column19: with no improvement in symptoms. She was admitted to Internal Medicine with a diagnosis of confusional syndrome secondary to urinary tract infection and/or hyponatraemia. A diagnosis of hyponatraemia was made
column20: probably secondary to sertraline. Laboratory tests on admission were compatible with SIADH. Thyroid hormone values (TSH: 4.04 mIU/L
column21: free T4: 1.72 ng/dL
column22: free T3: 3.13 pg/mL) and cortisol (19.7 μg/dL) were within the normal range. Hyponatraemia was treated on the first day with discontinuation of sertraline

column1: A 42-year-old man
column2: drinker of more than 100 g of ethanol per day
column3: with no other history of interest
column4: reported a 3-day history (coinciding with an increase in habitual alcohol intake) of fever
column5: jaundice
column6: abdominal pain in the right hypochondrium and abdominal distension. Physical examination revealed frank muco-cutaneous jaundice
column7: grade I encephalopathy and ascites. No enlargement of the liver or spleen was observed. Cardiorespiratory auscultation was normal. Laboratory tests on admission showed the following results: leukocytes 26
column8: 820 per µl (neutrophils
column10: prothrombin activity 40%
column11: plasma creatinine 1.9 mg/dl; urea 91mg/dl; total bilirubin 21mg/dl; AST 164 U/l; ALT 103 U/l; GGT 152 UI/dl. Hepatic viral markers were negative. Chest X-ray showed a right basal alveolar infiltrate and abdominal ultrasound showed a small liver with increased echogenicity and homogeneous structure; normal bile duct; patent portal vein
column12: splenomegaly
column13: abundant ascites. Computed axial tomography (CT) of the abdomen showed a small liver with lobulated contour. With the clinical diagnosis of acute alcoholic hepatitis on chronic liver disease with severity criteria and a Maddrey score of 71

column22: with heparin Na 5U/kg/hour or with both. The patient was haemodynamically stable during the sessions

column1: A 72-year-old male patient suffered a severe traumatic brain injury due to a traffic accident
column2: presenting on admission with a score of 8 on the Glasgow Coma Scale. Clinically
column3: he was associated with severe thoracic and pelvic trauma requiring orotracheal intubation and thoracic drainage. Cranial CT showed intraventricular bleeding and a slight right frontoparietal frontoparietal subarachnoid haemorrhage
column4: which evolved as subdural hygromas. There were no lesions in the posterior fossa. The facial CT scan showed a multiple fracture of the facial mass including the roof and medial wall of the left orbit. When the patient left the ICU and was clinically stable
column5: the ophthalmological study revealed a VA of 0.7 in both eyes. Biomicroscopy showed moderate phacosclerosis with no other abnormalities. Funduscopy revealed myelinated nerve fibres in both eyes
column6: normal papillae and no posterior pole abnormalities or peripheral lesions. The study of intrinsic ocular motility revealed anisocoria with mydriasis in the left eye. Extrinsic motility showed complete paralysis of both abducens nerves and the left common ocular motor (including ptosis). Clinically it manifested with torticollis as well as diplopia in all positions
column7: which was disabling. Since none of the lesions described radiologically justified the clinical findings
column8: nor were they amenable to surgical treatment
column9: it was decided to complete the study by means of a cranial MRI in order to find a pathophysiological explanation for the clinical findings. This examination revealed the existence of subcortical petechiae and focal lesions of the corpus callosum
column10: all compatible with the diagnosis of diffuse axonal damage. No structural lesions were found in the brainstem. After four months of evolution
column11: the patient presented a combined paralysis that had not improved clinically. As a therapeutic procedure
column12: botulinum toxin (5 IU Botox) was injected into both medial rectus. The clinical improvement was maintained for three months
column13: after which the symptoms reappeared.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 66-year-old man was referred by the Gastroenterology Department due to the finding of a 25 cm retroperitoneal mass on abdominal ultrasound performed for dyspepsia. His personal history included: old pulmonary tuberculosis and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Physical inspection revealed a large mass deforming the right anterior hemiabdomen
column2: extending from the subcostal area to the pubis. On palpation
column3: the mass was painless
column4: firm in consistency
column5: with no signs of peritoneal irritation and dull to percussion. Rectal palpation revealed a prostate of size II/V
column6: adenomatous
column7: smooth and well-defined. Blood tests
column8: urine sediment and urine culture were normal
column9: and the PSA level was 1.2 ng/ml. Abdominal ultrasound showed a cystic lesion 25 cm in diameter
column10: with abundant internal echoes
column11: extending from the lower edge of the liver to the groin. IV urography (IVU) showed distortion of the right renal silhouette and pelvis
column12: with significant displacement of the lumbo-iliac segment of the right ureter
column13: extending beyond the abdominal midline
column14: as well as slight ectasia of the ipsilateral upper urinary tract.  The abdomino-pelvic CT scan performed with oral and intravenous contrast showed a right retroperitoneal polylobulated cystic retroperitoneal mass of 25 cm in cranial-caudal diameter
column15: extending from the subhepatic region to the groin
column16: compressing and displacing the right kidney
column17: the psoas iliacus muscle and the ascending colon
column18: posteriorly and medially. Punctate calcifications were also observed in the cystic wall. In the medial and inferior portion of the mass there was a tubular structure of 2 cm in diameter and 7 cm in length
column19: with progressive tapering in a caudal direction
column20: ending in a complete stop. The right kidney was functionally normal. The CT findings were interpreted as a possible dysplastic right lower kidney with partial agenesis of the ureter.  Given the existing diagnostic doubts with the radiological studies performed
column21: it was decided to perform a percutaneous puncture-biopsy
column22: which was reported as a cystic lesion wall
column23: and urine cytology
column24: which showed no evidence of malignant cells. Subsequently
column25: surgery was performed via a right pararectal approach
column26: showing a cystic mass related at its cranial end to the right hepatic lobe and the lower pole of the kidney
column27: and at its caudal end to the space of Retzius and the internal inguinal orifice. No intra-abdominal organ infiltration was observed. Careful resection of the cystic mass and the cecal appendix
column28: which was in close relation to the caudal portion of the cystic mass
column29: was performed.  Pathological examination of the specimen revealed a dilated appendix
column30: lined by a cytologically benign mucinous epithelium
column31: which formed papillary-like structures. These findings were diagnostic of mucinous cystadenoma of the appendix.  The postoperative course was normal. The IVUS performed three months after surgery showed good bilateral renal function
column32: with lateral hypercorrection of the right ureteral tract and disappearance of the right renal distortion.  At the 20-month check-up
column33: the patient was asymptomatic from the urological point of view
column34: and the control CT scan showed no abdominal lesions suggestive of peritoneal pseudomyxoma.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 43-year-old man
column2: active smoker of about 15 cigarettes a day. He came to the emergency department with continuous epigastric pain of sudden onset accompanied by nausea and dizziness. Normal bowel habits. She reported similar episodes of lesser intensity that she related to ingestion and that subsided with fasting. Asthenia and moderate anorexia
column3: with weight loss of about 15 kg in the last three months. On examination she was afebrile
column5: cutaneous-mucosal pallor and the abdomen was soft
column6: depressible
column7: without defence or signs of peritoneal irritation
column8: although painful on palpation in the epigastrium with discreetly increased peristalsis. The CBC showed a Ht° of 30% with a Hb of 11.1 g/dl
column9: the rest being normal. The abdominal X-ray showed dilated jejunal loops with hydroaerial levels. Abdominal ultrasound revealed a "pseudorenon or sandwich" image in the sagittal view and a "bull's eye or doughnut" image in the axial view. The inner layer was hyperechoic and the outer layer hypoechoic
column10: suspicious of intestinal invagination. Surgical intervention was decided and after anaesthetic induction an abdominal mass located in the mesogastrium was palpated
column11: smooth and mobile. A supraumbilical laparotomy was performed
column12: revealing an intussusception of a jejunal loop that was impossible to reduce
column13: so segmental resection of 30 cm of jejunum was performed
column14: containing a tumour measuring 4 x 4 x 2.5 cm that was reported as anaplastic carcinoma
column15: with a rhabdoid phenotype that invaded the entire wall and infiltrated the subserosal layer. Immunohistochemistry showed high positivity for cytokeratins AE-1/AE-3
column16: cytokeratin 7
column17: cytokeratins 5/6/8/18 and vimentin. Cytokeratin 20
column18: CD-30
column19: CD-31
column20: actin
column21: desmin
column23: MELAN-A/M arp-1 and TTF-1 were negative
column24: suggesting a pulmonary origin.  Chest CT confirmed the presence of a right hilar mass of about 4 cm
column25: polylobulated and with spiculated contours
column26: encompassing the upper lobar bronchus but without significant stenosis. Bronchoscopy revealed a thickening of the carina at its separation from the right upper lobar bronchus
column27: with endobronchial tumour that prevented passage of the bronchoscope to the posterior segment. Biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of an undifferentiated carcinoma with the same immunohistochemical pattern as the intestinal mass.  The postoperative period was uneventful and the patient was discharged in good clinical condition. She was subsequently treated with carboplatin AUC 5 day 1
column28: and gemcitabine 1250 mg/m2/day days 1 and 8
column29: every 21 days
column30: with partial response after the fourth cycle of chemotherapy. Six months after diagnosis
column31: she was admitted for progressive cognitive deterioration secondary to multiple right frontoparietal brain metastases
column32: and died fifteen days later.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column21: compatible with optic neuropathy. Visual acuity: 0.5 in the left eye
