In OI there is a total reduction in sensitivity. Corticosteroids (prednisone) at a dose of 1 mg/kg/day for 30 days were prescribed as treatment. The patient progresses with increased papillary oedema in both eyes and clinically with bulging vision in the OD and amaurosis of the OI. Fundus examination at 2 months showed almost total atrophy of the right optic nerve with dilatation and venous tortuosity and total atrophy of the left optic nerve.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 47-year-old man
column2: with no past history of interest
column3: who was diagnosed with a right renal mass by ultrasound accidentally during a routine study due to abdominal pain. Abdomino-pelvic CT scan confirmed the presence of a solid heterogeneous mass of approximately 6 cm
column4: located in the upper pole of the right kidney with a permeable renal vein.  Radical right nephrectomy was performed by subcostal laparotomy
column5: with no lymphadenopathies. The anatomopathological diagnosis was clear cell renal carcinoma of 8.4 centimetres
column6: stage pT3aNoMo
column7: Robson stage II and Fuhrman nuclear grade IV. The patient was discharged five days after surgery. Approximately three months later and before being seen in the consultation room for follow-up of his neoplasm
column8: the patient came to the emergency department for pain in the right hypochondrium of recent onset. On examination
column9: a painful mass was palpable in the right hypochondrium
column10: for which reason a new CT scan was performed which revealed a tumour recurrence in the surgical site
column11: infiltrating the right posterior diaphragmatic pillar and liver; peritoneal implants were also found
column12: the largest measuring four centimetres
column13: adjacent to the hepatic hilum.  It was decided to remove the tumour masses
column14: resecting the mass adjacent to the liver as well as several peritoneal and retroperitoneal implants
column15: and the intraoperative biopsy was compatible in all cases with high-grade clear cell carcinoma. The paravertebral retroperitoneal mass was inaccessible due to its close contact with the great vessels. In view of these findings
column16: it was decided to contact the Oncology Department and treatment was started with interferon (Intron A)
column17: which was poorly tolerated and the dose had to be reduced. At check-ups
column18: the patient reported non-specific abdominal discomfort that responded to mild analgesics
column19: but a control CT scan of the abdomen 5 months after the second surgery revealed multiple liver lesions suggestive of metastasis
column20: as well as growth of the recurrence in the surgical bed and several peritoneal implants in the omentum.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 57-year-old patient referred to the emergency department of our hospital by his general practitioner for presenting with pain in the glans penis for a week
column2: with progressive appearance of a reddened lesion affecting the distal portion
column3: covered with fibrin
column4: necrotic appearance
column5: with a large exudative component
column6: which seems to be a thrombotic process. His personal history included venous insufficiency with trophic alterations in the lower limbs. A smoker of 40 cigarettes a day for many years
column7: he was diagnosed three months ago in the urology department with benign prostatic hyperplasia requiring medical treatment. During the diagnostic work-up of BPH
column8: the patient underwent a TR
column9: determination of PSA
column10: ultrasound scans
column11: etc.
column12: but these studies did not reveal any abnormalities worth mentioning. The current examination showed that the anterior two thirds of the glans were swollen
column13: hardened
column14: with a necrotic appearance and abundant exudate and fibrin covering the area.  In view of the normal urological studies and the total lack of information about the morbid process
column15: a minimal biopsy of the lesion was taken. We were informed of necrosis phenomena
column16: dense acute and chronic inflammatory infiltrate and thrombosis of the dermis. In this situation of ignorance of the morbid process
column17: but in the face of a necrotic process that did not improve with the symptomatic treatments established
column18: partial amputation of the penis was indicated. The glans penis was removed along with a small portion of the corpora cavernosa. The pathological anatomy service informed us of the presence of a tumour thrombosis of the corpora cavernosa compatible with metastasis from an epidermoid carcinoma.  In view of this unusual situation
column19: we proceeded to locate the primitive tumour and study its extension. The abdominal CT scan revealed small subcentimetric para-aortic
column20: interaorto-caval and mesenteric root adenopathies in the retroperitoneum. The rest was within normal limits. Complementary studies were continued in search of the primitive neoplasm
column21: at the same time as an assessment was requested by the Traumatology Department of a sudden onset and severe intensity of pain in the shoulder. The referred pain is explained by the existence of a pathological fracture at the level of the upper third of the right humerus due to a radiological lesion typical of bone metastasis. The bone scan corroborates the diagnosis of bone metastasis at the level of the proximal third of the humerus
column22: with no other distant pathological deposits. Further studies are carried out and the evaluation by the Otorhinolaryngology Department is absolutely normal. The Digestive Service came into play and performed an endoscopic study and discovered a mameloned and ulcerated mass of 3 centimetres in diameter at the level of the cardia
column23: which corresponded to gastric infiltration by a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the oesophagus.  Polychemotherapy treatment was started but the patient's condition progressively worsened and he died a few months later.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 61-year-old woman with a history of pharmacologically controlled arterial hypertension and two episodes of right maxillary sinusitis treated medically four and two years prior to the current problem. No known allergies and no previous surgical interventions. In April 1999
column2: he presented with a right laterocervical subcutaneous tumour at the level of the angle of the mandible
column3: which was initially related to a case of acute otitis that had occurred two months earlier. Since the appearance of the lump
column4: he has reported moderate cervical pain which is accentuated by rotational movements. In June of the same year
column5: she reported dysaesthesia in the shoulder and right upper limb associated with cervical pain
column6: as well as ipsilateral C2 neuralgia. Examination: a well-defined rubbery tumour was observed in the right mandibular angle adhering to deep planes and moderately painful on palpation. There is no alteration of the long pathways and the cranial nerves are bilaterally preserved. Investigations: a complete blood test revealed no abnormalities. A cervical MRI was performed
column7: showing a space-occupying lesion occupying the right conjunctival foramen of C2-C3 with enlargement and erosion of the lateral mass of the axis
column8: as well as the right posterior interapophyseal joint. Occupation of the anterolateral recess of the spinal canal is observed
column9: but without distortion of the spinal cord. Anteriorly it distorts
column10: displaces and collapses the right vertebral artery and contacts the carotid bifurcation and the internal jugular vein without affecting them. It also distorts the laterocervical musculature
column11: but without infiltrating it.  A CT scan was then performed
column12: showing more clearly an erosion of the lateral mass of C2. Finally
column13: an angiography of the supra-aortic trunks demonstrates occlusion of the right vertebral inflow.  Management: in April 2000
column14: in conjunction with the ENT department
column15: a subtotal resection of the tumour was performed via the lateral cervical approach in order to obtain a histological diagnosis and reduce the tumour mass. The procedure passed without incident and the patient was discharged five days later. The patient remained asymptomatic. Once the diagnosis of a well-differentiated grade I chondrosarcoma had been obtained
column16: the patient was readmitted one month later to attempt to complete the resection via the posterior approach and to stabilise the upper cervical spine by means of occipito-cervical instrumented fixation. During the procedure
column17: which was successful
column18: a tumour was observed that eroded
column19: insufflated and invaded the articular massifs of C2 and C3 on the right and their respective haemilamina. Invasion of the right hemibody of the axis is also observed. The vertebral artery is thrombosed. The roots of the right C2 and C3 are undamaged and the dural sac is free. The instrumentation performed consisted of transpedicular screwing of left C2 electively
column20: according to the Goel4 technique
column21: with cranial extension by anchoring three screws in the occipital scala bilaterally
column22: and with caudal extension with screwing in the lateral mass of left C3 and right lateral mass of C4. Subtotal excision is achieved. The postoperative course was completely satisfactory
column23: with the postoperative control X-ray showing correct fixation. The patient was discharged home nine days later and referred to the radiotherapy department
column24: where a course of 50 Gy was administered as adjuvant treatment.  Evolution: in April 2002 the presence of a right laterocervical adenopathy was noted. A new MRI study confirmed tumour recurrence. The lymphadenopathy was excised and histological analysis confirmed the presence of recurrence
column25: and brachytherapy with 40 Gy was carried out. In March 2003 a new tumour increase was observed; a new surgical intervention was decided
column26: after demonstrating the absence of distant disease. On this occasion a transcervical lateral suprahyoid approach was performed with subtotal resection. Elective tracheostomy was also performed. Both procedures were uneventful. Unfortunately
column27: three months later new tumour growth was confirmed again
column28: coinciding with pain in the left hemifacial region radiating to the left upper extremity
column29: and symptomatic treatment was decided. In December 2003
column30: coinciding with the presence of motor difficulties in both upper limbs
column31: new tumour growth was confirmed radiologically. On this occasion a new surgical intervention was rejected and it was decided to administer chemotherapy following a scheme of adriamycin + ifosfamide. After two cycles
column32: treatment was abandoned due to poor response and high toxicity. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 27-year-old male patient
column2: also a native of Senegal and with no previous history of interest
column3: who consulted for vomiting and abdominal pain. The patient reported asthenia and anorexia of one month's duration
column4: with diffuse abdominal discomfort from the onset. In view of the progression of the symptoms and the appearance of vomiting
column5: he went to the emergency department. Physical examination showed an acceptable general state of health
column6: with only a great pain on palpation in the epigastrium and right hypochondrium
column7: with palpation of an area of impaction compatible with a mass at this level. There were no signs of peritoneal irritation
column8: although there was voluntary defence. Laboratory tests showed moderate hypertransaminasemia and mild coagulopathy. Ultrasonography revealed the presence of a large hepatic mass (approximately 12 cm in diameter) with numerous satellite nodules. MRI confirmed the hypervascular nature of these lesions. Finally
column9: viral serology revealed chronic HBV infection and the alpha-fetoprotein was 12
column10: 687 ng/ml
column11: so the patient was diagnosed with giant HCC with satellites and HBV infection. Symptomatic palliative treatment was started and he died a few months later.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Female patient aged 62 years
column2: obese
column3: diabetic and hypertensive for a year. For the last 6 months she has been complaining of sporadic
column4: low-intensity right lumbar pain. Physical examination was normal. An abdominal ultrasound was performed
column5: which showed a hypoechogenic right adrenal mass of 80mm
column6: compressing the upper pole of the right kidney. A descending urogram showed an expansive process in the right adrenal gland
column7: the upper pole of the right kidney was displaced downwards. On helical CT scan
column8: tumour mass with a larger diameter of 8.7x76 cm with irregular contours
column9: heterogeneous density of 100 - 37 HU
column10: septate
column11: compatible with adrenal tumour of fatty density. Figure 1  The hormonal study for cortisol determination was normal. The patient underwent surgery via lumbar approach. Trans-operative findings were a tumour located in the right adrenal gland
column12: well demarcated with irregular borders and lobulations. Right adrenalectomy was performed without complications. The patient's postoperative evolution was favourable and she remained asymptomatic. The pathologist reported the specimen weighing 171.4 g
column13: measuring 9 x 8 x 6 cm
column14: with yellow-orange areas and other areas of haemorrhage and adipose tissue alternating with areas of calcifications. Histopathological examination: myelolipoma of the adrenal gland with extensive areas of calcifications.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 46-year-old woman underwent radical left mastectomy with axillary lymphadenectomy in October 2005 due to hormone receptor-positive infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the upper outer quadrant and lymph node metastasis in 1 of 13 isolated nodes. In the same surgical procedure
column2: immediate reconstruction was performed by placing an expander prosthesis (anatomical Becker) with a 300 cc. volume textured silicone gel layer
column3: starting expansion 2 weeks after surgery and reaching the maximum expansion volume 1 month later. As a complementary treatment
column4: chemotherapy was established according to a sequential scheme of adriamycin-cyclophosphamide and taxane
column5: receiving a total of 24 sessions during the period from November 2005 to May 2007
column6: followed by trastuzumab. Complementary hormonal treatment with letrozole was maintained for a period of approximately 3 years. The second stage of reconstruction was performed in July 2006
column7: by replacing the expander prosthesis with a 320 cc textured silicone gel breast implant in the same subpectoral location. In the follow-up clinical controls
column8: a depression was observed at the medial edge of the mastectomy scar
column9: in the form of a hatchet
column10: which displeased both the patient and the surgical team
column11: so it was decided to remodel it in March 2007 by means of a fat graft of adipose tissue obtained from the abdominal area and processed using the Coleman technique
column12: after infiltration of the scar with 3 cc of local anaesthetic (lidocaine). The scar was infiltrated with 3 cc. of local anaesthetic (lidocaine 1% with adrenaline); it was performed without incident and a total of 5 cc. of fatty tissue was infiltrated in the area of the defect. The patient continued to be monitored by the Gynaeco-Oncology Department
column13: and follow-up imaging tests were carried out in accordance with our hospital's guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of malignant tumours. Specifically
column14: 4 annual mammograms and 2 breast ultrasound scans were performed between May 2006 and April 2009
column15: with no evidence of alterations suggesting damage to the integrity of the prosthesis. In March 2010 a new breast ultrasound was performed in which a previously unreported cystic ovoid image was visualised on the anterior surface of the interior of the breast prosthesis
column16: so the radiologist decided to perform an MRI. This procedure was carried out one month later and a nodular image was observed in the prosthesis
column17: located in the internal interquadrant area
column18: about 2.5cm in diameter
column19: which appeared as an image of liquid content
column20: with no inflammatory signs or signs of prosthetic rupture. In different sections it appeared as if an elongated hook-shaped structure was introduced into the prosthesis
column21: similar to the way a finger is introduced into a half-inflated balloon. The patient did not report any symptoms.  In view of these images
column22: we decided to perform a surgical exploration
column23: taking into account the possibility of having to remove the breast prosthesis. At first it was thought that the fatty infiltrate might have entered the prosthetic capsule and pushed the prosthesis
column24: without breaking it
column25: creating a deep concavity inside it
column26: like a tunnel. During the operation
column27: it was found that the prosthesis appeared to be intact and that there was no tissue inside the capsule that could alter the shape of the implant. There were no alterations in the area of the capsule that was in contact with the site of fat infiltration
column28: but we nevertheless decided to take a biopsy of the area of injected fatty tissue; this biopsy corresponded in the histological study with fibrous tissue with no signs of malignancy. When we removed the prosthesis for examination
column29: we were struck by the fact that there were several opaque spots scattered in different places inside it
column30: with no linear distribution
column31: which might lead us to believe that these were needle punctures. However
column32: at a point close to the largest of these
column33: after applying strong compression to the prosthesis
column34: we saw that the cohesive silicone of the implant was slightly herniated. We then decided
column35: once the implant had been removed
column36: to open it and send samples of the material inside. The removed implant was replaced with another of the same characteristics.  The anatomopathological study reported the sample analysed from inside the prosthesis as haematic material.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 39-year-old woman diagnosed with complex regional pain syndrome type I of the right upper extremity
column2: with a previous history of two arthroscopic surgeries on that shoulder. The last surgery presented as a complication an infection caused by pseudomonas which was successfully treated. The patient complained of moderate to severe burning pain every day in her right upper extremity
column3: which did not respond to conventional analgesic treatments. Associated with this she presented oedema
column4: colour changes and trophic changes in this extremity. Apart from CRPS
column5: the patient was in good general health
column6: neurologically normal
column7: without hypertension or diabetes. It was decided to perform a stellate ganglion block
column8: for which intravenous access was established and the patient was monitored with electrocardiogram
column9: blood pressure and O2 saturation. The block was performed by paratracheal approach using a 3.5 cm long needle with 10 ml of procaine 1% without epinephrine; the cricoid cartilage was palpated to discern the C6 level. The transverse process of the sixth vertebra was palpated between the trachea and the carotid sheath. Prior to the injection
column10: aspiration was performed in order to rule out puncture of any vascular structure; the aspiration was negative. After the block
column11: the patient presented Horner's syndrome. Five minutes after the block
column12: the patient manifested malaise
column13: dizziness and severe headache. The patient's blood pressure increased from 135/80 to 235/135 mmHg
column14: with sinus tachycardia. The hypertension was relieved by administration of intravenous metoprolol in fractional doses
column15: bringing the blood pressure down to 140/90 mmHg. After vital signs were restored to normal levels
column16: the patient complained of dizziness and fatigue accompanied by headache and hiccups
column17: for which she was hospitalised. An ECG
column18: neurological examination and a cranial CT scan were performed and revealed no abnormalities. Thyroid tests were also performed to exclude thyrotoxicosis
column19: which were normal. A few days later the patient returned to the clinic and reported weakness and a 'back and forth movement of the head' which had no medical explanation. The 'movement' disappeared two months later without the need for medication.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 37-year-old man
column2: with no medical history of interest
column3: came to the emergency department under police custody from the airport due to suspicion of ingestion and intra-abdominal transport of drug wrappers (BP). During a scheduled flight
column4: the patient had a convulsive episode and subsequently expelled three foreign bodies orally. On arrival
column5: the patient presented: blood pressure 157/88 mmHg
column6: heart rate 108 bpm
column7: temperature 37°C and O2 saturation 94%. On examination
column8: the abdomen was distended and matt to percussion
column9: non-painful
column10: with palpation of multiple foreign bodies in the mesogastrium and no peritonism. Neurological examination showed slightly mydriatic pupils
column11: Glasgow 15 and no neurological focality. Abdominal radiography confirmed the presence of multiple intra-abdominal radio-opaque foreign bodies. The most relevant analytical findings were: leucocytes 14.1 x 109/l (neutrophils: 86%)
column12: creatinine 1.7 mg/dl and glucose 131 mg/dl. The electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia. Urinalysis was positive for cocaine and its metabolites and benzodiazepines. Evacuation treatment with polyethylene glycol solution (Casenglicol®) and strict clinical observation was started. Two hours after admission
column13: the patient experienced an episode of psychomotor agitation and tachycardia (120 beats/min)
column14: followed by a decreased level of consciousness
column15: motor incoordination
column16: mydriasis and tonic-clonic crisis
column17: and was transferred to an intensive care unit. Clonazepam (1 mg) and diazepam (10 mg) e.v. were administered and it was decided to perform an emergency laparotomy. After accessing the abdominal cavity
column18: multiple hard foreign bodies were palpated along the entire digestive tract. A transverse gastrotomy at the antral level
column19: a longitudinal ileotomy 15 cm from the ileocaecal valve and two longitudinal colotomies (at the level of the transverse colon and sigma) were performed
column20: with removal of multiple foreign bodies. An anterograde lavage of the rectum-sigma was performed with physiological saline solution through a colotomy
column21: and another four packets were evacuated distal to the promontory. A total of 96 cylindrical foreign bodies of 5 cm in length with multilayer latex wrapping
column22: smooth
column23: compact and of apparently resistant manufacture were extracted. None of the packages showed visible signs of breakage. The patient was observed for 24 hours in an intensive care unit. Peristalsis and oral diet were started on the second postoperative day. The patient progressed well and was discharged from hospital on the fourth postoperative day.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 30-year-old woman with no personal history of interest was admitted to our department with a diagnosis of obstructive jaundice secondary to possible choledocholithiasis. Laboratory tests showed bilirubin of 4.6 mg/dl
column2: GOT 406 UI/l
column3: GPT 512 UI/l
column4: amylase 50 UI/l. Abdominal ultrasound: cholelithiasis. Bile duct not dilated. ERCP showed a dilated duct without choledocholithiasis and sphincterotomy was performed. After the test
column5: the patient began with pain in the epigastrium and CDH radiating to the shoulder and a feeling of nausea. On examination
column6: the patient was agitated
column7: hypotensive
column8: tachypnoeic with intense pain in the CDH with significant voluntary defence that made examination difficult. Laboratory tests: bilirubin 1.6 mg/dl
column9: GOT 101 IU/l
column10: GPT 311 IU/l
column11: amylase 71 IU/l
column12: haemoglobin 11.6 g/dl
column13: leucocytes 8
column14: 800 µ/l. Abdominopelvic CT scan: collection of 4.7 x 10 x 11 cm with a denser area inside (probably clots and gas bubbles
column15: suggestive of infection) adjacent to the right hepatic lobe. Aerobic in extrahepatic bile duct. No free fluid or pneumoperitoneum.  Based on the poor clinical condition of the patient
column16: who did not respond to any analgesic regimen and the CT findings suggestive of abscess adjacent to the liver with signs of bleeding and infection
column17: and without being able to rule out duodenal perforation
column18: it was decided to perform surgery. During surgery
column19: a subcapsular haematoma was observed in the right hepatic lobe measuring about 10 cm with bubbles inside. Intraoperative cholangiography was performed in which no alteration in the biliary tract was visualised
column20: as well as cholecystectomy and evacuation of the abscess
column21: leaving a drain in the right subphrenic space. The patient was taken to the ward and broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment was started. Liquid culture: E. coli. Sterile blood cultures. Following an episode of anaemia
column22: 4 red blood cell concentrates were transfused. Ultrasound scans and serial scans showed persistent haematoma
column23: so it was decided to place a pig-tail. The evolution was satisfactory and she was discharged after 4 weeks of hospitalisation.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 27-year-old woman
column2: who has been monitored in our unit since February 2004
column3: when she was referred by her traumatologist at the age of 18. History - Fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva. Diagnosis at 6 years of age. Fusion at the level of the vertebral bodies of the cervical spine
column4: multiple ossifications at the level of the cervical
column5: dorsal and lumbar paravertebral musculature
column6: bilateral shoulder girdle
column7: coxofemoral joints
column8: thighs
column9: knees and abdomen
column10: resulting in intense pain and inability to ambulate
column11: requiring a wheelchair to move around.  - Surgical intervention of exostosis at the level of the right knee
column12: and bilaterally in the first metatarsophalangeal joint. - Bilateral otosclerosis operated on at the age of 6. She is a hearing aid wearer. - Iron deficiency anaemia probably secondary to chronic gastric bleeding due to treatment with NSAIDs and corticoids. On treatment with oral iron. - Obesity
column13: cushingoid appearance. - Intolerance to metamizole. - Reactive anxious-depressive syndrome. - Episodes of hypercapnic respiratory failure secondary to restrictive ventilatory disorder due to her underlying disease
column14: which have occasionally merited treatment with home NIV since 2004. The latest complementary explorations performed were: - Thoracic CT scan (February 2010): gross calcifications in soft tissue in the thoracic cavity in relation to the patient's underlying pathology. Cardiomegaly. - Abdominal CT scan (April 2010): multiple muscle calcifications were seen in the pectoral
column15: periscapular
column16: dorsal
column17: paravertebral and mainly in the left buttock area
column18: suggestive of corresponding to her underlying disease. - PFR (March 2011) FVC 1.57 (40 %); FEV1 1.36 (42 %); FEV1 86 %
column19: GSA: (March 2011) P02 70
column20: PC02 55. Socio-functional status: Lives with parents. Student of business administration. She uses a wheelchair. At her first visit she was prescribed a slow-release oral morphine
column21: plus a permanent prednisone regimen. Previously
column22: various NSAID and paracetamol regimens had been established
column23: which were progressively ineffective
column24: alternating between different types of opioids and different forms of presentation. Since February 2004
column25: she has been monitored periodically
column26: both for her baseline pain caused by the multiple heterotopic ossifications she presents
column27: and also and fundamentally
column28: for her painful thrusts secondary to inflammatory conditions in soft parts that give rise to new bone formations
column29: thrusts caused by mild trauma
column30: abnormal postures
column31: viral conditions
column32: etc. We progressively withdrew the corticoids
column33: leaving them confined only to the painful episodes due to neo-ossification
column34: largely improving the cushingoid elements that he presented. Baseline control with transdermal fentanyl plus sublingual fentanyl for breakthrough pain. Lately
column35: with transdermal fentanyl 100 mcg/h every 3 days
column36: the pain was under control. A few weeks ago she presented her most severe pain thrust since we attended her: due to a change of address
column37: 2 days of family holidays
column38: and with no other apparent cause
column39: she started severe pain at the level of the left scapula
column40: without fever and without any parallel respiratory symptoms. She went to the nearest hospital where she was examined and was found to have no respiratory or diffuse infectious component
column41: attributing the symptoms to her underlying illness. She was given NSAIDs
column42: pyrazolones and morphine
column43: all by IV. After 24 hours
column44: as no improvement was noted
column45: she was referred to our centre. On arrival
column46: VAS of 100 mm. The X-ray showed bone neoformation in the form of a bridge between the left scapula and costal grill
column47: as well as accentuation of the right paracervical bone neoformation. We started a regimen of IV dexamethasone 4 mg c/6 hours + IV morphine 5 mg c/6 hours + desketoprofen 50 mg IV c/8 hours + oral diazepam 10 mg hour 22. Coverage with omeprazole
column48: 40 mg/day. After 24 hours
column49: the patient remained practically unchanged
column50: so we increased the dosage of dexamethasone to 12 mg c/6 hours. After 24 hours there was improvement
column51: VAS of 40 mm
column52: we increased the dosage of dexamethasone in the morning to 20 mg
column53: leaving the other 3 administrations at 12 mg. In addition
column54: as she reported some dysaesthesia and paraesthesia on mobilisation of the painful region
column55: we added oral pregabalin: 75mg-5mg-150 mg. Progressive improvement. After 3 days of this last regimen
column56: VAS 0 mm. We began to reduce the dosage of dexamethasone
column57: switching to oral administration
column58: and morphine. Five days later
column60: with an oral regimen of paracetamol 1 gram c/8 hours + naproxen 500 mg 1-0-0 + pregabalin 75 1-0-2 + diazepam 10 mg 0-0-1 + montelukast 5 mg 0-0-1. Six days after starting the corticosteroids
column61: the blood tests were normal.  From the time of discharge we carried out telephone follow-up
column62: showing good evolution. No pain. She has resumed her university studies at a distance.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Female newborn with normal pregnancy and delivery. Clinical examination revealed a tumour 1 cm in diameter in the introitus
column2: hard on palpation
column3: located slightly to the right of the urethral meatus
column4: displacing the latter as well as the vaginal introitus. The lesion had a cystic appearance with a slightly yellowish colour. With the diagnosis of suspected ureterocele
column5: an ultrasound scan was requested: neither duplicity nor urinary dilatation was found. The perineal ultrasound confirmed the cystic nature of the lesion
column6: confirming the diagnosis of a paraurethral cyst of Skene. A wait-and-see approach was adopted
column7: and the lesion gradually decreased in size during follow-up
column8: reaching a size of 5 mm at 2 weeks
column9: with the tumour disappearing completely by one month of age. No sequelae were described in the patient.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 75-year-old man with a history of moderate COPD and no other medical history of interest. Among the toxic habits
column2: he was a smoker (20 packs/year) and a non-drinker. No environmental risk factors or family history. The patient presented with urethrorrhagia and inability to urinate
column3: for which reason he went to the Emergency Department. Given the impossibility of urinary catheterisation
column4: a suprapubic size was placed and the patient was subsequently examined. An ultrasound scan was performed showing a large bladder balloon with an apparent single diverticulum similar in size to the bladder (greater than 13 cm maximum diameter) with several parietal polypoid images smaller than 2-3 cm in both the bladder and the diverticulum
column5: findings suggestive of bladder neoplasia. In view of the ultrasound findings and urethral stricture
column6: a ureterotomy and cystoscopy were performed
column7: where a solid tumour measuring almost 7 cm was observed
column8: calcified on the lateral side
column9: and a transurethral resection was performed at the same time
column10: with residual disease being observed on the spot. The anatomopathological result was inconclusive
column11: but immunohistochemical analysis of the sample showed negative results for epithelial markers and positive results for fibroblastic markers: vimentin and actin
column12: all compatible with reactive fibroblastic proliferation or solitary fibrous tumour. With the results obtained
column13: it was decided to complete the surgery
column14: and at that time
column15: it was decided to perform a partial cystectomy and diverticulectomy
column16: with the following anatomopathological result: low-grade leiomyosarcoma (mitosis =3 X10 high magnification fields). Marked cellular pleomorphism. Foci of intratumoral necrosis and multiple images of isolated cell necrosis. Extensive areas of myxoid change. Intense intra- and peritumoural inflammation. Infiltration of the entire thickness of the diverticular wall down to the peridiverticular adipose tissue causing peritumoural fibrotic reaction. Surgical margins free of tumour. Immunohistochemistry The tumour cells expressed positivity for markers of muscle differentiation (vimentin and actin) and were negative for desmin and epithelial markers (EMA and High Molecular Weight Cytokerqatins). With the result obtained of low-grade leiomyosarcoma with infiltration of all layers
column17: the case was presented to the clinical committee
column18: opting to administer complementary treatment to the patient given the high risk of the patient. In addition
column19: the extension study was completed by performing a thoracoabdominal CT scan
column20: a bone scan and a pelvic MRI
column21: which did not show distant disease. It was decided to administer locoregional radiotherapy and complementary chemotherapy. The patient received locoregional radiotherapy at a dose of 57 Gy. The chemotherapy administered consisted of the combination ifosfamide-adriamycin at the usual doses
column22: with the patient receiving three cycles of this treatment. Once treatment was completed
column23: the patient continued to undergo strict check-ups with periodic cystoscopies
column24: urinary cytology and periodic thoraco-abdomino-pelvic CT scans. After a period of 22 months
column25: the patient continues to be disease-free and undergoes regular check-ups and is asymptomatic and has an excellent quality of life.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 69-year-old man
column2: a heavy drinker and smoker
column3: operated on in 1985 for squamous cell carcinoma of the floor of the mouth and tongue
column4: and underwent haemimandibulectomy with radical dissection of the left neck. In 1996 he underwent reconstruction with free iliac crest graft and titanium rod. In 1999 he underwent a total suprahyoid laryngectomy for a new squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx with left supraclavicular metastasis (T4N1M0). Closure of the pharyngostoma was performed using a dermo-placial-fascial Herrmann flap. She subsequently received radiotherapy treatment with cobalt-60 over the surgical site and bilateral supraclavicular cervical chains. In July 2006 she presented a recurrence of her oral cavity carcinoma
column5: which was surgically treated with resection of the tongue base stump and reconstruction with a left pectoral myocutaneous flap. In November 2006
column6: she was admitted due to the appearance of dysphagia
column7: which resulted in a total inability to eat orally and
column8: secondarily
column9: severe malnutrition. Repeated attempts were made to place a nasogastric tube
column10: without success. A nasofibroscopy was performed which revealed an impassable pharyngo-oesophageal stricture of benign appearance. An oral endoscopy was then requested
column11: which showed a fibrous-looking stenotic area at the pharyngo-oesophageal junction
column12: associated with significant hair growth in the pharynx due to inversion of the skin in the previous surgery
column13: but with no evidence of local tumour recurrence. The oesophageal stricture proved impassable to the endoscope
column14: so a surgical gastrostomy was performed according to the Witzel technique. The patient is currently in an adequate nutritional state and there is no evidence of new tumour recurrence.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A patient came to our clinic with a large cervical tumour on the left side of the neck. He had undergone surgery for a gill cyst in the same location 18 years ago. He explained the slow and painless growth of the mass
column2: which had been growing for approximately 10 years. The limits of the tumour include the left greater body of the hyoid bone at the anterior level
column3: the mastoid region at the superior level
column4: the clavicle at the inferior part and the external occipital protuberance as the posterior limit.  The consistency of the mass is soft and it is not attached to deep planes. No lymph nodes or other masses were palpable and the intraoral examination was normal. The rest of the physical examination was completely unremarkable. It was decided to perform cervicofacial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
column5: which revealed a homogeneous
column6: well-defined mass that did not invade neighbouring structures and with a fatty density.  A sample was taken by fine needle puncture aspiration (FNA) which confirmed the initial suspicions of lipoma. It was decided to perform surgical excision of the tumour. An approach was made at the level of the posterior hairline
column7: resecting a 5*10cm skin spindle to improve direct closure.  During the operation
column8: a specimen weighing 459.5g and measuring 25*16*4.8cm was obtained. On the first postoperative day the patient showed a rapidly growing haematoma at the level of the posterior suture
column9: which required emergency evacuation and haemostasis of a small vessel at the level of the left trapezius muscle. After the seventh postoperative day the patient was discharged. Pathological studies confirmed the diagnosis of lipoma without atypia He is currently progressing satisfactorily and is being monitored in our outpatient clinic.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 29-year-old man who came to our clinic with a case of one month's evolution consisting of a daily fever of 39º-40º
column2: intense pleuritic pain in the left hemithorax and cough with abundant blackish expectoration. He had no medical or surgical history of interest. He had been a smoker of 20 cigarettes/day for 10 years. Physical examination was strictly normal
column3: except for pulmonary auscultation in which there was an overall decrease in vesicular murmur with isolated areas of echophonia. Various analytical studies were performed
column4: including: haemogram
column5: general biochemistry
column6: baseline arterial blood gases
column7: creatinine clearance
column8: calciuria
column9: proteinogram

column14: all results being normal. Spirometry showed a restrictive pattern. A pulmonary diffusion test showed decreased diffusion (65%)
column15: compatible with a reduction of the exchange surface. The plain chest X-ray showed a bilateral interstitial pattern. A chest CT scan showed multiple cystic lung lesions
column16: none larger than 2 cm
column17: distributed in both lungs
column18: especially in the upper and middle lobes. A lytic lesion was also observed at the level of the left fourth costal arch. The Thoracic Surgery Department was asked to perform an open lung biopsy. Samples were taken from the upper and lower lobes of the left lung. The histopathological study showed infiltration of the lung parenchyma by eosinophils and mononuclear cells with aryronucleated nuclei typical of Langerhans cells. S-100 and CD1a immunohistochemical stains were positive. Electron microscopy was performed and the characteristic Langerhans cells with polylobed nuclei and deep indentations were observed. Structures formed by two double bet membranes were also seen
column19: separated by a dense structure that fulfils the characteristics of a Birbeck granule in its tubular portion. With the diagnosis of LCPH
column20: the patient was advised to stop smoking and an appointment was made for a follow-up chest CT scan at 6 months. In this study
column21: the cystic lesions disappeared almost completely
column22: with the costal lytic image persisting. Clinically
column23: the patient showed a significant improvement and was asymptomatic except for the persistence of a slight costal pain in the left hemithorax that corresponded to the bony lesion observed in the CT scan.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 54-year-old man was referred to our department in May 2003 for odontalgia related to an erupted lower right third molar. On oral inspection
column2: a swelling expanding the vestibulo-lingual cortices was observed in the region of the right mandibular third molar
column3: decayed distally. The oral mucosa was intact
column4: and no cervical adenomegaly was palpable. The patient reported the existence of hypoaesthesia in the distribution territory of the mentonian nerve
column5: which had been present for fifteen days. The orthopantomography revealed the presence of a radiolucent image of poorly defined contours in the right mandibular body. Two days later
column6: under local anaesthesia
column7: the third molar was exodonticated and the underlying tissue was curettage-biopsied. During the operative procedure
column8: heavy bleeding occurred
column9: which could be contained with the use of Surgicel (Johnson & Johnson
column10: New Brunswick
column11: NJ) and by packing the alveolar bed with bone wax.  Postoperative haemogram and coagulation study showed no significant alterations. The histopathological diagnosis of the submitted material was: mandibular metastasis from well-differentiated hepatocarcinoma. The neoplastic cells did not stain with cytokeratins 19 and 20
column12: nor with alpha-fetoprotein
column13: but did show intense cytoplasmic granular staining with the hepatocyte N marker.  The patient's personal history included a history of type II diabetes for 8 years
column14: controlled with oral hypoglycaemic agents. He was a drinker of 130 g. ethanol/day since the age of 30
column15: and a smoker of 2 packs of cigarettes/day since the age of 20. One year before our assessment
column16: the patient had been diagnosed with cirrhosis of the liver (Child Pugh stage A: 5/15) and multicentric hepatocarcinoma with involvement of segments II
column17: III and IV
column18: and underwent partial liver resection one month after diagnosis. He had previously undergone a complete study that included bone scintigraphy with technetium 99-MDP and computed tomography of the skull
column19: lung
column20: abdomen and pelvis
column21: without finding the presence of metastases. Postoperative serum alpha-fetoprotein values were normal (3.6 ng/ml). Fifteen days after surgery
column22: there was a marked increase in alpha-fetoprotein levels (221 ng/ml)
column23: and bone scintigraphy and magnetic resonance imaging revealed the existence of multiple metastases affecting the left occipital
column24: sternal body
column25: pelvis and multiple vertebrae. The patient underwent palliative radiotherapy on the vertebral lesions (10 Gy at one week after Co 60) without improvement
column26: and exited six months after our biopsy.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 31-year-old patient with traumatic spinal cord injury at the age of 20 and a history of repeated urinary tract infections related to neurogenic bladder (self-catheterisation) and episodes of urinary obstruction. In 2009
column2: he was referred to the nephrology department for stage 2 chronic kidney disease
column3: with proteinuria in the nephrotic range (creatinine 1.3mg/dl
column4: proteinuria 20g/24h). The patient refused to undergo a renal biopsy and in the same year stopped attending nephrology consultations. In January 2012
column5: he began to experience episodes of decreased level of consciousness. Cranial computed axial tomography and lumbar puncture were performed
column6: both of which were normal. Electroencephalogram with diffuse slowing. Creatinine at that time was 3.3mg/dl. The symptoms were diagnosed as secondary to urinary tract infection. In April 2012
column7: the same symptoms recurred
column8: accompanied by temporo-spatial disorientation. She presented a new episode in the same month
column9: but this time with behavioural changes (infantilism
column10: nervousness
column11: aggressiveness). Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain was performed with no findings of interest. Following this episode
column12: treatment was started with clonazepam. In May 2012

column14: haemodialysis was started via a temporary catheter in the right jugular vein. The patient presented
column15: approximately once a month
column16: in the first two hours after starting haemodialysis
column17: episodes of decreased level of consciousness
column18: and on other occasions psychomotor agitation. In November 2012
column19: he was assessed by Neurology and Psychiatry
column20: with no relevant findings. They classified the symptoms as secondary to hypoxic-metabolic encephalopathy. Despite presenting with correct KT and Kt/V
column21: we increased the number of dialysis sessions to 4/week
column22: with no clinical improvement. In January 2013
column23: we decided to discontinue treatment with baclofen (Lioresal®)
column24: replacing it with tinazidine and diazepam. After two weeks of treatment with tinazidine
column25: the patient discontinued the drug due to drowsiness
column26: and the spasticity was only controlled with diazepam. Ten months after drug withdrawal
column27: the patient had no further neurological symptoms.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 59-year-old man who was admitted in September 2008 with a diagnosis of post-surgical chylothorax. He had a history of sigmoid cancer
column2: having undergone a liver metastasectomy in July 2008
column3: and since then several thoracentesis to evacuate the chylothorax (approximate volume extracted: 9
column4: 000 mL). On admission
column5: he reported asthenia
column6: discomfort in the right hemithorax and mild respiratory distress. A pleural effusion occupying two thirds of the right hemithorax was radiologically observed. After placement of a pleural drain
column7: 500 mL of milky fluid were obtained in the first 24 hours
column8: the analysis of which was compatible with chylothorax3: cholesterol (COL) 60 mg/dL
column9: triglycerides (TG) 515 mg/dL
column10: COL pleural fluid/serum ratio: 0.28; TG pleural fluid/serum ratio: 3.18. Conservative treatment with absolute diet and thoracic drainage was decided
column11: and the Nutrition Department was consulted to initiate parenteral nutritional support.  The nutritional assessment showed a weight loss of 4% in the last two months (usual 74 kg; current 71 kg)
column12: albumin 2.6 g/dL
column13: transferrin 154 mg/dL
column14: C-reactive protein (CRP) 16.6 mg/dL. Slight loss of subcutaneous fat and muscle mass
column15: together with reduced functional capacity at home in recent weeks; absence of malleolar oedema and signs or symptoms of specific vitamin deficiencies. Dietary history with no recent changes. The nutritional situation was compatible with mild protein-energy malnutrition
column16: and the following nutritional care plan was proposed: - Objectives: To maintain the gastrointestinal tract at rest and prevent further malnutrition in a patient with high nutrient losses through pleural drainage - Nutritional requirements: Calorie requirements estimated by Harris-Benedict equation (correction factor 1.4) of 2
column17: 200 kcal/day; protein requirements 1.5-1.7 g/kg/day of amino acids; standard micronutrient requirements. - Composition of parenteral nutrition (PN) formula: Volume 2500 ml; 120 g amino acids; 300 g glucose; 60 g lipids (MCT/LCT); 2280 kcal total; vitamins and trace elements according to AMA-ASPEN recommendations. Despite treatment
column18: pleural drainage remained stable in the first few days
column19: with a chylous appearance persisting. Ultrasound showed loculated pleural effusion
column20: and 200
column21: 000 IU of urokinase was administered for two consecutive days through the thoracentesis tube. Given the persistence of abundant chylous drainage

column23: at a dose of 100 mcg/8 h subcutaneously. The drainage progressively reduced over the following days
column24: changing to a serous appearance. At the same time
column25: the patient's general condition worsened
column26: with abdominal distension
column27: oliguria and hyperglycaemia. On suspicion of an adverse reaction to octreotide

column29: leucopenia (2
column30: 390 leucocytes/microlitres)
column31: thrombocytopenia (48.000/microlitres)
column32: urea 59 mg/dL
column33: creatinine 0.6 mg/dL
column34: total bilirubin 1.4 mg/dL (direct 1.2 mg/dL)
column35: GOT 76 IU/L
column36: GPT 61 IU/L
column37: gGT 502 IU/L
column38: FA 136 IU/L
column39: CRP 29.8 mg/dL.  After discontinuation of octreotide

column42: mixed feeding was started using oral enteral nutrition (EN) with a fat-free formula (Clinutren Fruit®; 1.25 kcal/mL; 13% protein
column43: 87% carbohydrates; 600 mL/day)

column45: natural fruit
column46: fruit juice or compote
column47: infusions). On subsequent days

column50: boiled or grilled white fish
column51: salad and skimmed milk
column52: and supplemented with MCT oil (up to 60 g/day

column56: the thoracentesis tube and PN were removed. Nutritional evolution was favourable

column1: 84-year-old female patient with a history of hypertension
column2: hyperthyroidism
column3: type II diabetes mellitus and anxiety syndrome. She was referred to the Urology Outpatient Department from the Emergency Department for a picture of monosymptomatic frank haematuria of several weeks' evolution with no other associated symptoms or alteration in general condition. Physical examination revealed the presence of a palpable mass in the right lumbar fossa. The abdomen was soft and depressible. The requested ultrasound study showed a large heterogeneous solid mass in the lower pole of the right kidney
column4: the contralateral kidney being normal. The bladder showed internal echoes compatible with clots. The cystoscopic study was unremarkable. Abdomino-pelvic CT scan
column5: chest X-ray
column6: blood biochemistry and haemogram were also performed. The CT scan showed a large right tumour mass measuring 9x10 cm
column7: heterogeneous and with hypodense areas (areas of necrosis) with distortion of the renal parenchyma and its contour
column8: located in the lower pole and with attenuation values lower than those of the healthy parenchyma. The renal vein was thrombosed and there were retroperitoneal locoregional adenopathies.  Laboratory tests showed the presence of iron deficiency anaemia
column9: increased ESR and normocalcaemia. Radical surgery was proposed
column10: which the patient and her family rejected
column11: and selective embolisation was accepted as an alternative. By puncture of the right common femoral artery
column12: arteriography of the abdominal aorta was performed and subsequently the right renal artery was selectively catheterised with a 5 Fr Cobra 2 visceral angiographic catheter (Angiodinamics®). The artery supplying the tumour is then embolised with 355-500 micron polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) particles (Contour®
column13: Boston Scientific)
column14: totally occluding the flow of the artery without immediate complications.  After 24 hours of hospitalisation
column15: given the good evolution of the patient
column16: it was decided to discharge her from the hospital pending further check-ups. Two weeks after the onset of anticoagulation
column17: the patient consulted for a headache and a brain CT scan was performed
column18: which showed no findings of pathological significance. After 28 months of follow-up
column19: there have been no further episodes of haematuria and the only notable symptomatology is insomnia and musculoskeletal pain
column20: both controlled with symptomatic treatment. Blood pressure values have not been modified
column21: maintaining acceptable figures with IECAS and calcium antagonists. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 30-year-old man
column2: who one month before admission presented with cough
column3: headache and progressive dyspnoea on exertion. Two weeks later the patient presented with mucopurulent expectoration and fever of 38ºC. He consulted his doctor who prescribed treatment with amoxicillin and later moxifloxacin and tiotropium bromide. He consulted the emergency department for dyspnoea at rest
column4: severe retrosternal pain and palpitations. He was a non-smoker and had a history of bronchial asthma
column5: which he treated with inhaled salbutamol. On physical examination he presented with A.T.: 110/70 mmHg
column7: he was conscious
column8: tachypnoeic
column9: sweating
column10: with no jugular ingurgitation. Pulmonary auscultation showed diffuse bilateral crackles and cardiac auscultation showed rhythmic
column11: rapid tones without murmurs or extratonos. The abdomen was soft and depressible with no organomegaly. There was no oedema in the extremities and peripheral pulses were preserved. Laboratory tests showed 18
column12: 500 leukocytes with left shift
column13: haemoglobin 16.3 grams/dl
column15: 000 platelets
column16: prothrombin activity 73%. D-dimer 920 mg/dl. Baseline arterial blood gases: pH 7.53
column17: pO2 47 mmHg
column18: pCO2 23 mmHg
column19: CO3H 19.2 mmol/l. Normal biochemistry including troponin and CPK. Chest X-ray showed severe cardiomegaly and a bilateral interstitial pattern. In view of these findings
column20: a transthoracic echocardiogram was performed showing severe pericardial effusion
column21: with no evidence of tamponade and a left ventricle of normal dimensions. Admission to the intensive care unit
column22: with treatment with furosemide
column23: levofloxacin
column24: acetylsalicylic acid and non-invasive mechanical ventilation. A new echocardiogram showed signs of tamponade
column25: so a pericardiocentesis was performed
column26: obtaining one litre of serohaematic fluid
column27: with the following biochemical characteristics: LDH 2353 U/l
column28: protein 5.3 gr
column29: 9855 cells with 98% polymorphonuclear. Seven days later
column30: he was transferred to the Internal Medicine Department where the study to determine the aetiology of the pericardial effusion and the interstitial pattern was initiated
column31: and the following tests were performed: antinuclear antibodies
column32: rheumatoid factor
column33: Mantoux
column34: negative. The thyroid profile was normal. Pericardial fluid culture was negative
column35: as were three blood cultures. Pathological anatomy of the pericardial fluid was reported as intense acute inflammation and clusters of mesothelial cells with reactive-looking atypia
column36: being negative for malignant cells. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) was found to be elevated 21.53 ng/ml. In addition
column37: serologies for human immunodeficiency virus
column38: Mycoplasma pneumoniae
column39: cytomegalovirus
column40: Epstein Barr and Chlamydia pneumoniae were negative except for IgM to cytomegalovirus which was positive. A chest CT scan showed two pathologically sized mediastinal adenopathies of pretracheal location measuring approximately 19 x 15 mm and 18 x 17 mm respectively
column41: and a slightly larger bilateral pleural effusion on the right side. A pulmonary window showed bilateral and diffuse alterations of the lung parenchyma with an interstitial pattern of nodular septal reticulum and lobular centre with areas of patchy alveolar condensation predominantly distributed in the apical segment of the lower lobes and both upper lobes.  Bronchoscopy was performed

column1: A 56-year-old woman
column2: hypertensive
column3: with a history of poliomyelitis at one year of age and sequelae in the left lower limb that required multiple interventions to enable her to walk properly
column4: as well as lumbar spine surgery at 42 years of age. Diagnosed with spinal pathology of D11-D12 and L3-L4
column5: she underwent L1-L5 pósterolateral arthrodesis plus lamina graft and bone substitute
column6: presenting poor evolution
column7: with infection of the surgical wound and necrosis of the paravertebral musculature that required 3 new interventions to debride the non-viable tissue. After the third operation
column8: she was fitted with a vacuum therapy system and was referred to our department
column9: a reference centre for reconstructive surgery. The time between the first spinal surgery and the time of referral to our department was approximately 18 days. The patient was transferred on a stretcher as she was unable to ambulate and had significant atrophy in both lower limbs
column10: as well as a defect in the dorso-lumbar area measuring approximately 20 x 5 cm in diameter
column11: with exposure of the spinal column and osteosynthesis material. There were no signs of infection.  We performed a study of the extent of the defect by means of computerised axial tomography (CT)
column12: which reported an instrumented arthrodesis from L1-S1 with resection of posterior elements and posterior soft tissue augmentation in the surgical site
column13: with traces of air and soft tissue mass suggesting post-surgical changes
column14: with no evidence of abscesses. We also performed dorsal-lumbar CT angiography to determine the viability of the paravertebral muscle-cutaneous perforators.  We maintained the vacuum therapy system in the surgical wound for 20 days
column15: while imaging and pre-anaesthetic studies were completed
column16: to assist in cleansing the lesion. Planning of the surgical procedure included debridement of the scar tissue
column17: coverage of the deep bony structures with well-vascularised tissue and closure of the skin defect without tension. Under general anaesthesia
column18: with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position
column19: we performed excisional debridement of the inverted skin edges and fibrous scar tissue in the lumbar region. We designed and raised a reverse latissimus dorsi muscle flap based on the secondary pedicles
column20: transposed it to the lumbar defect by tunnelling and fixed it to the healthy perilesional muscle tissue. We placed 4 spiral drains
column21: 2 in the donor area and 2 in the recipient area
column22: one in the submuscular plane and the other in the subcutaneous plane. The donor site was closed directly
column23: in planes
column24: without tension. The skin of the recipient site was closed after Friedrich of the edges
column25: without tension and without compressing the muscle flap.  Five days postoperatively
column26: we observed an increase in the right paravertebral volume after abrupt mobilisation of the patient in bed. Ultrasonography revealed a right paravertebral intramuscular haematoma measuring 15 x 2 cm in size. Under general anaesthesia
column27: we evacuated a coagulated haematoma and checked the viability of the muscle flap
column28: re-closing the wound. After 18 days
column29: the patient began to walk with the aid of a walker
column30: recovering the functionality of the lower limbs and was discharged on postoperative day 22. During the 2-year follow-up after surgery
column31: the patient showed normal deambulation and an excellent local evolution of the flap.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 94-year-old woman presented with chalazion and unilateral blepharitis of the left eye of 8 months' duration
column2: having been treated topically with antibiotic ointment and eyelid washes. Examination revealed erythematous swelling of the left upper eyelid
column3: hard in consistency
column4: mainly affecting the pretarsal area
column5: with thickening of the affected area and madarosis of the area. Biomicroscopy showed an unaltered ocular surface
column6: with no evidence of conjunctival or corneal involvement. There was ipsilateral preauricular adenopathy. An incisional biopsy of the lesion was performed and the pathologist reported it to be a sebaceous carcinoma palpebrae.
