column7: without infiltration of bone or retroorbital fat. The patient was referred to oncology for further investigation. No distant metastases were found. Given the patient's age and the presence of lymph nodes
column8: palliative radiotherapy was indicated. The local tumour diminished but radiotherapy proved intolerable for the patient and she stopped treatment. One year later the patient died of heart failure.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male
column2: 3 months old

column5: not consanguineous. History of maternal aunt with epilepsy and older brother of 6 years with autism. Normal pregnancy and term birth by caesarean section due to pelvic presentation

column1: A 64-year-old man with a personal history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus
column2: dyslipidaemia and recurrent renal colic. He reported diarrhoea
column3: with episodes of steatorrhoea
column4: constitutional syndrome and epigastralgia for two months. The patient was admitted through the emergency department for jaundice
column5: choluria and progressive acholia. Physical examination showed good general condition
column6: afebrile
column7: normohydrated and with cutaneous-mucosal jaundice. On abdominal examination
column8: the gallbladder was palpable
column9: with discomfort at that level and no signs of peritonism; the rest of the abdomen was unremarkable. Laboratory tests showed hyperbilirubinaemia of 17 mg/dl
column10: with increased FFAA (2522 U/l) and γGT (107 U/l). No leukocytosis. Viral hepatitis markers were negative and there was an elevated CEA (7.6 ng/dl). AFP and CA19.9 were normal. Ultrasonography showed minimal dilatation of the intrahepatic bile duct and discrete dilatation of the common bile duct; the gallbladder was hydropic and without lithiasis. A rounded hypoechoic mass in the head of the pancreas of approximately 2 cm was seen
column11: which was not confirmed by CT scan
column12: which additionally showed dilatation of the duct of Wirsung and no adenopathy. Cholangioresonance showed similar findings with clinical suspicion of ampuloma which was not evident in the gastroscopy
column13: which was strictly normal. With the diagnosis of obstructive jaundice of probable malignant origin
column14: surgery was performed a week after admission
column15: revealing a mass in the head of the pancreas with a neoplastic appearance
column16: for which a cephalic duodenopancreatectomy with pyloric preservation and pancreatogastrostomy was performed. In the anatomopathological study
column17: the surgical specimen showed two clearly differentiated areas of tumour appearance. One of 1 cm and with well-defined limits in the duodenal wall
column18: and another with undefined borders of 3 cm in the pancreatic head.  On microscopic examination
column19: the duodenal tumour consisted of cords of polyhedral
column20: uniform cells infiltrating the muscular fascicles of the wall. They showed nuclei with a low degree of atypicality and very low mitotic activity. The pancreatic tumour consisted of atypical glandular structures that infiltrated the duodenal wall and were lined by columnar cells with very atypical nuclei and a high mitotic index.  Once the diagnosis had been made. To confirm the different nature of the two tumours
column21: immunohistochemical techniques were applied. The resulting immunophenotype clearly differentiated the two tumours
column22: as the duodenal tumour was negative for CEA and positive for chromogranin

column1: We present the case of a 41-year-old patient who consulted for pain and dorsal induration of the proximal third of the penis

column3: except for the painful palpation of the nodule described. Doppler ultrasound was performed

column7: which showed no evidence of lesions suggesting thrombosis or any other type of pathology in the location of the dorsal penile vein.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 47-year-old married male patient attended the Oral Medicine Department of the Hospital de Clínicas in Porto Alegre and reported having painful lesions in the oral cavity with the appearance of bleeding blisters that rupture easily and leave an ulcerated surface for approximately 4 months. column2: the patient states that he is a non-smoker and works in a car battery factory
column3: which has also caused him chronic intoxication (saturnism). He also claims to have had an ulcer on his right leg for 20 years. Physical examination reveals swollen cervical and submaxillary lymph nodes on the left side
column4: as well as several ulcer-like lesions on the labial mucosa
column5: palate
column6: jugal mucosa
column7: floor of the mouth and larynx. The lesion on the right leg is confirmed

column11: right leg and oral cavity

column15: C3
column16: C1q and fibrinogen deposits. Treatment with prednisone was started with gradually increasing doses up to 100 mg daily. The patient responded favourably to treatment and left the hospital with a marked improvement.  After hospitalisation

column18: 40 mg Omeprazole
column19: 400 mg calcium carbonate
column20: vitamin D4 and Nystatin rinses
column21: the latter 4 times a day. After one month of treatment

The patient is still under medical supervision.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 60-year-old man with a history of repeated urinary tract infections attended the emergency department for presenting a mass in the lower abdomen
column2: of about six months' duration
column3: which bled spontaneously and caused intense pain. Physical examination revealed a bladder exstrophy plaque in the hypogastrium and a complete epispadic penis
column4: which had not been surgically corrected during childhood. There was an exophytic formation in the sinus of the plaque
column5: 10 cm in diameter and hard in consistency
column6: with a friable surface that bled at the slightest friction. No inguinal lymph nodes were palpable and the rest of the examination revealed no other findings.  Blood tests showed a creatinine level of 2.2 mg/dL
column7: with all other parameters being normal. After admission to hospital to complete the study
column8: bilateral renal ultrasound was performed
column9: showing grade III/IV dilatation of both pyelocaliceal systems. Intravenous urography showed functional annulment of the right kidney
column10: with delayed elimination of the left kidney. The suspicious mass was biopsied and the histopathological result was bladder adenocarcinoma. The thoraco-abdomino-pelvic CT scan and bone scan showed no evidence of metastasis. The patient underwent surgery
column11: with radical cystoprostatectomy with lymphadenectomy plus Indiana shunt and closure of the abdominal wall defect with fascia lata. Histopathological analysis of the surgical specimen revealed the existence of an intestinal adenocarcinoma with some signet ring cells. The margins of the specimen were infiltrated
column12: with extensive involvement of adjacent soft tissue and peritoneum
column13: and two iliac adenopathies infiltrated by the tumour were isolated. The tumour stage corresponded to T4bN2M0. The medical oncology department rejected adjuvant treatment
column14: considering that it would not increase the patient's survival. At the check-up 6 months after surgery
column15: a painless left inguinal lymphadenopathy of increased consistency was palpated
column16: together with induration of the edges of the surgical wound
column17: a finding compatible with local recurrence of the tumour that was confirmed by biopsy of the suspicious area. Bone scanning at this time remained negative and CT scan showed a heterogeneous mass with poorly defined borders in the surgical site. The patient died 2 months later from sepsis of urinary origin.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 41-year-old male patient was referred to our clinic for a recurrent tumour lesion on the left side of the base of the neck
column2: 10 cm in diameter
column3: with a central ulcerated area
column4: bleeding and adhering to deep planes. The patient had been diagnosed with solitary neurofibroma for 30 years and was treated on three occasions with partial resection and coverage with an acromial flap and graft. He developed a retractable keloid scar on the left lateral neck area and was treated with 15 sessions of radiotherapy
column5: which caused significant limitation of lateral movements in the cervical area.  We proceeded to perform an imaging study of the lesion by magnetic resonance imaging with coronal and sagittal axial slices in Fast Spin Echo sequence
column6: enhanced in T1
column7: T2
column8: GRE and T1 with gadolinium
column9: finding a solid mass of neoplastic type
column10: with well-defined borders of 10.4x5.8x12. 4 cm in its longitudinal
column11: anteroposterior and transverse axes respectively
column12: occupying the left anterior region of the base of the neck
column13: superior to the sternoclavicular joint
column14: with origin in the upper and medial area of the left pectoral muscle and at the insertion level of the sternocleidomastoid muscle in the clavicular area. No involvement of vascular structures of the neck or intrathoracic extension was observed. After gadolinium administration
column15: moderate enhancement of the tumour was observed. The patient underwent surgery by the Oncology Department in conjunction with the Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery Department
column16: with preoperative marking for complete resection of the neurofibroma and immediate reconstruction.  The Oncology team carried out the en bloc resection of the neurofibroma
column17: generating a soft tissue defect of 20x10 cm in diameter with exposure of the pectoral muscle
column18: left parasternal area
column19: medial area of the first costal arch and clavicle.  The Plastic Surgery team was in charge of the restoration of the defect by subfascial dissection
column20: with 2.5 x magnification loupes
column21: of an anterolateral free flap of the left thigh based on 2 perforating vessels of the descending branch of the lateral circumflex femoral artery
column22: with dimensions of 24x11 cm
column23: and pedicle of 12 cm in length
column24: performing termino-terminal anastomosis with nylon 9-0 to superior thyroid vessels contralateral to the lesion and transposition of the acromial flap previously performed to its native location. The donor area of the anterolateral thigh flap was closed by first intention without complications. The coordination of work in 2 teams by Oncology and Plastic Surgery facilitated a total operative time of 5 hours
column25: with the patient not requiring transfusions or a stay in the Intensive Care Unit. Adequate planning
column26: by locating 2 perforating vessels in the left thigh area with a manual 8 MhZ acoustic doppler
column27: ensured that a flap with the necessary dimensions for coverage could be obtained. The histopathological report of the resection piece corroborated the diagnosis of neurofibroma
column28: with dimensions of 16x10.5x6.5 cm
column29: showing mesenchymal cells
column30: fibroblasts
column31: Schwann cells
column32: perineural tissue and mast cells
column33: and with deep surgical margins free of lesion.  The patient spent 6 days in hospital
column34: with intravenous antibiotic therapy with cefazolin 1 g every 8 hours
column35: acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg once a day orally
column36: and anti-inflammatory/analgesic treatment with ketoprofen 25 mg every 8 hours. We did not immobilise either the recipient or the donor site
column37: and only left open Penrose drainage in the recipient site for 48 hours. We monitored the flap by clinically assessing capillary filling
column38: colour and local temperature every hour for the first 24 hours
column39: and then every 2 hours for a further 48 hours. We also used 8MhZ manual Doppler to assess the patency and permeability of the venous and arterial anastomosis. During the hospital stay there was no evidence of venous congestion or arterial insufficiency
column40: with adequate coverage of the defect created by the resection. We started neck physiotherapy 6 weeks after the operation
column41: based on flexion-extension and lateral neck movements. We followed up the patient in the outpatient clinic every 3 weeks for a period of 18 months
column42: during which time the neck area improved in contour and mobility
column43: with a better aesthetic-functional result and without the need for secondary surgical treatment.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 56-year-old man

column14: initially without achieving a sustained viral response
column15: and subsequently in its pegylated form for 48 weeks
column16: achieving a negative viral load. Four months after the end of treatment
column17: he presented an episode of acute pericarditis with HCV in the pericardial fluid coinciding with a new increase in viral load. The patient had had poor clinical tolerance to both previous treatments and it was decided not to start new therapies. Other complications included inflammatory arthritis of large joints. From the renal point of view
column18: antiproteinuric treatment with renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system blockade was started
column19: despite which the patient developed progressive renal failure and finally started haemodialysis in 2007. In November 2009
column20: he received his first deceased donor kidney transplant due to a spontaneous cerebral haemorrhage. The donor had HLA typing: DR1
column21: DRX
column25: A30 and a history of enolism
column26: with creatinine at the time of extraction of 1 mg/dl and negative proteinuria. Immunosuppression with corticosteroids
column27: mycophenolic acid and tacrolimus was performed. Renal evolution was excellent and renal function was immediate. Thirteen months after transplantation
column28: the patient developed non-nephrotic proteinuria and microhaematuria with haematic casts
column29: but maintained normal renal function. An autoimmunity study
column30: donor-specific antibodies
column31: as well as antigenemia for cytomegalovirus and serum PCR (polymerase enzyme chain reaction) for BK virus were negative
column32: and renal Doppler ultrasound was normal. Given the suspicion of recurrence of the underlying disease
column33: it was decided to perform a renal biopsy. Light microscopy showed renal parenchyma with ten glomeruli with marked mesangial enlargement
column34: mild fibrosis and tubular atrophy. Immunofluorescence showed granular mesangial deposits of IgA and C3
column35: and electron microscopy showed mesangial enlargement of cells and matrix with abundant homogeneous electrodense deposits. Immunohistochemistry for C4d was negative. A diagnosis of de novo IgA mesangial GN in the graft was made
column36: and the dose of corticosteroids and mycophenolic acid was increased without clinical-biochemical improvement. After starting antiproteinuric treatment
column37: with blockade of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system by means of an angiotensin II receptor antagonist (ARA II) and the subsequent association of spironolactone
column38: proteinuria became negative
column39: although with a slight deterioration of renal function
column40: currently stabilised.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 35-year-old man who was referred to the clinic for evaluation of a radiological alteration of the chest. He had no drug allergies
column2: he was allergic to pollen. He worked as a plasterboard worker. He had smoked 10 cigarettes/day since the age of 14 (10.5 packs/year) and 8 joints of marijuana/day. He consumed alcohol occasionally. He had no family history of interest. During the last year
column3: he reported coughing predominantly in the evening and at night when lying on his back
column4: accompanied by white expectoration. He also had associated wheezing that improved with bronchodilators. He also reported dyspnoea on exertion. He had lost about 5 kg in weight. She reported asthenia which she related to work. She had a dog at home. He had not travelled recently nor had he had any known contact with tuberculosis patients. On physical examination he was in good general condition
column5: eupneic with a baseline oxygen saturation of 98%. There were no adenopathies or acropacities. Cardiopulmonary auscultation was normal. Chest X-ray (CXR) showed a diffuse linear interstitial pattern predominantly on the right. The study was completed with several complementary explorations: blood tests with all parameters within normality
column6: including autoimmunity and negative serology
column7: respiratory function tests (RFT) within normality
column8: negative Mantoux
column9: computed tomography (CT) of the chest showing the lung parenchyma occupied by multiple small cavitary-cystic lesions
column10: widely distributed in both lung fields
column11: with involvement of both upper and lower fields.  Based on these findings
column12: bronchoscopy was performed and no mucosal alterations or lesions were observed. Three BAL scans were performed in the right upper lobe
column13: which were sent for cytology
column14: smear microscopy and lymphocyte subpopulations. In addition
column15: four bronchoaspirate secretions (BAS) were performed for fungi
column16: Pneumocystis
column17: culture and Koch's bacillus. All results were negative. The bronchoaspirate pathology report revealed minimal inflammatory component
column18: with no abnormal histiocytes or atypical cells. Immunohistochemistry was negative for S100 and CD1a. Given this result
column19: a biopsy of the right upper lung lobe was performed by thoracotomy. Pathology was compatible with Langerhans' histiocytosis in the proliferative or cellular phase. The patient was advised to stop smoking. He was seen 3 months later and reported being asymptomatic with a gain of 6 kg. However
column20: in the control chest X-ray the interstitial pattern remained.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 68-year-old woman with headache of one year's duration and frontal protrusion. She had a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus
column2: hypertension
column3: extrinsic bronchial asthma and osteoporosis. The symptoms began with localised headache in the face and right hemicranium
column4: and increased ESR and anaemia were detected
column5: so empirical treatment with glucocorticoids was started on suspicion of temporal arteritis. At that time no biopsy of the temporal artery was performed. Four months later the patient suffered bilateral loss of vision. Ophthalmoscopic examination showed signs of intracranial hypertension. An MRI scan of the brain showed diffuse thickening of the calvarium and meninges. Analyses showed persistent anaemia
column6: with a tendency to macrocytosis. CSF analysis showed hyperproteinorrachia (he was still on corticosteroid treatment) and no malignant cells were found. After a biopsy of the temporal artery
column7: arteritis was ruled out and she was referred to our hospital for further investigation. The aforementioned clinical manifestations were associated with jerking crises in the right hemibody that subsided with clonazepam
column8: complex visual hallucinations
column9: changes in character with increased irritability and loss of recent memory. The general physical examination showed an apyretic patient
column10: with cutaneous-mucosal pallor
column11: right frontal protrusion and cutaneous signs of cranial hypervascularisation. She had oedema of both eyelids and right eyelid ptosis. No lymph nodes were palpable. Cardiopulmonary auscultation was normal. Neurologically she was temporarily disoriented and apathetic. Muscle fatigue was present. She scored 19 out of 30 in the Mini-mental test. There was a decrease in visual acuity in both eyes
column12: to a greater extent in the left eye (with the right eye she counted fingers at one metre
column13: with the left eye at half a metre). Fundus examination showed papillary oedema and bilateral cotton wool exudates
column14: more marked in the left eye. Motor balance was symmetrical. He was walking with short strides and decreased brachiation.  Blood tests showed GGT 85 IU/l; LDH 779 IU/l; hypoproteinaemia (total protein 5.61 g/dl
column15: albumin 3.4 g/dl); other biochemical parameters were normal. The haemogram showed anaemia (Hb 8.6 g/dl) with an inflammatory iron pattern
column16: platelets 106
column17: 000/mm3 and normal leukocytes. Normal haemostasis. Elevated ESR (53 mm/h). Primary hypothyrodism was detected (TSH 1.1 mIU/l
column18: free T4 0.6 ng/dl) and increased PTH (170 pg/ml). Proteinogram and FSR without pathological findings. Among the tumour markers only CA 15.3 was elevated (67.4 IU/ml). Cranial CT showed diffuse calcification suggestive of hyperostosis with scattered meningeal-dural thickening more marked in the left frontal region. Lumbar puncture showed clear cerebrospinal fluid with mild hyperproteinuria (48 mg/dl)
column19: glucose 74 mg/dl and 0 cells. No malignant cells were found. CSF cultures were negative. EEG study showed diffuse slowing with intermittent frontal slow activities and lesion-irritative signs in the left temporal area. Brain MRI detected diffuse hyperostosis of the cranial calvarium with diffuse abnormal meningeal enhancement more prominent in the left frontal region. Mammography was normal. Metastatic bone series showed generalised osteosclerosis. Bone scan showed increased activity in the skull
column20: especially at the fronto-parietal level
column21: compatible with hyperostosis. The iliac crest biopsy showed artefacted trabeculae without haematopoietic activity. The thoraco-abdominal-pelvic CT scan found no alterations.  In the presence of pachymeningitis with secondary hyperostosis
column22: with no malignant cells detected in CSF in serial lumbar punctures and without knowledge of the existence of a primary cancer
column23: a biopsy of the cranial bone and meninges was performed with the following anatomo-pathological result: calotte with hyperostosis
column24: bone marrow and dura mater with extensive infiltration by metastatic adenocarcinoma. The immunohistochemical profile did not indicate the origin of the primary tumour. Cranial radiotherapy treatment was indicated
column25: which the patient refused
column26: and palliative treatment with tamoxifen was started due to the suspicion of a breast tumour. In fact
column27: a few months after the biopsy
column28: a new thoraco-abdomino-pelvic CT scan was performed
column29: which showed an irregular right axillary nodule. The patient refused aggressive treatment and died at home two months after discharge
column30: so no post-mortem examination was performed. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A common case of dizziness
column2: with unusual diagnosis An 11-year-old girl with no family or personal history of interest
column3: who attended the health centre as an emergency patient
column4: reporting a sensation of movement of objects around her since the previous night
column5: with fear and anxiety. Physical examination was normal; otoscopy without alterations. Blood pressure and glycaemia were normal. The absence of vegetative component
column6: instability
column7: pallor or other symptoms such as tinnitus or tinnitus is noteworthy. No neurological focality
column8: balance or gait disturbances
column9: ataxia or other cerebellar signs were found. The patient had a history of taking Romilar® (dextromethorphan) the previous night and a positive family history. Based on these data and a normal physical examination
column10: she was sent home for observation
column11: and was scheduled to be seen the following morning.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 13-year-old boy with no past history of interest consulted for frontal headache and nocturia in the previous months. On examination he presented normal height and weight for his age
column2: bilateral gynaecomastia of 2 cm in diameter
column3: pubarche and testicles of 3 ml. Ophthalmological examination was normal. Computed tomography (CT) revealed an intrasellar expansive process (emerging from within the sella turcica) with a well-defined suprasellar growth
column4: about 3 cm in maximum diameter
column5: isodense with respect to the parenchyma
column6: cystic in appearance with a solid pole and peripheral ring that were hyperintense after contrast injection. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) defined the suprasellar cystic portion with proteinaceous content (slightly hyperintense in T1 and hypointense in T2) and the intrasellar solid portion isointense to the grey matter in both sequences and intensely enhanced after gadolinium. With the radiological diagnosis of craniopharyngioma
column7: surgical treatment was indicated (the prolactin level had not been determined)
column8: and a macroscopically complete excision was performed via the right transciliary approach. Pathological anatomy diagnosed a pituitary adenoma with positive immunohistochemistry for prolactin and chromogranin A.  After surgery
column9: the patient presented bitemporal haemianopsia with increased extension in the right visual field and panhypopituitarism
column10: and was referred to endocrinology. Postoperative prolactin levels were 83 ng/ml
column11: with no adenoma remnants on MRI
column12: and treatment with cabergoline was started. Calcaemia was normal (9.5 and 8.8 mg/dl)
column13: so there is no suspicion of hyperparathyroidism or other tumours typical of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN 1).   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 65-year-old patient with a personal history of alcoholism and chronic alcoholic liver disease. He underwent surgery in January 2008 for stenosing adenocarcinoma of the sigma
column2: performing a subtotal colectomy and terminal ileostomy in the right iliac fossa. Eight months later
column3: reconstruction of the intestinal transit with end-to-end anastomosis and closure of the ileostomy was performed. Shortly afterwards (November 2008) the patient was admitted for faecaloid peritonitis
column4: and a resection of 1.5 metres of small intestine was performed
column5: leaving a definitive terminal ileostomy with a rectal stump left in the pelvis
column6: with no possibility of subsequent reconstruction. Two months after the second operation (January 2009) the patient was admitted to hospital again due to acute renal failure and secondary hydroelectrolytic alterations
column7: together with ileostomy debit greater than 1500 ml/day. At that time he was being treated with Tramadol
column8: Paracetamol
column9: oral iron and a loop diuretic (Furosemide) due to the presence of oedema in the lower limbs. Subsequently
column10: he returned to the hospital on several occasions and was treated in the emergency department
column11: with renal failure and dehydration
column12: together with water and electrolyte disorders
column13: which were resolved in the department itself and did not require hospital admission. In July 2009
column14: she returned to the emergency department due to worsening general condition
column15: with significant asthenia
column16: prostration
column17: difficulty in ambulation and oliguria. Laboratory tests performed in the ED showed: Creatinine: 4 mg/dl (LN 0.6-1.40); Sodium: 113 meq (LN 135-145)
column18: Potassium: 6.7 mEq/l (LN 3.5-5)
column19: Albumin: 3.1 g/dl (LN 3.4-4); Plasma calcium: 6.7 mg/dl (LN 8.5-10.5); Calcium corrected with albumin: 7.4 mg/dl; Magnesium: 0.5 mg/dl (LN 1.5-10.5); Calcium corrected with albumin: 7.4 mg/dl; Magnesium: 0. 5 mg/dl (LN 1.7-2.5); Phosphate: 2.8 mg/dl (LN 2.5-4.5); Venous pH: 7.17 (LN 7.33-7.43); Bicarbonate: 18 mmol/l (LN 22-28); The patient was admitted to Internal Medicine for acute renal failure with hyperlactacidemic metabolic acidosis and electrolyte disturbances secondary to ileostomy losses and diuretic treatment. After several days of parenteral rehydration he was discharged. The diuretic was then discontinued and treatment was started with oral rehydration salts
column20: Loperamide (2 mg/8 hours) and magnesium salts (Magnesium Lactate: 500 mg per tablet = 2 mmol = 4 meq of Mg element) at a dose of 8 meq/8 hours/vo). One week later
column21: the patient suffered syncope at home with a fall to the floor and mild craniocerebral trauma to the right frontal region. On arrival at the emergency department
column22: he had two convulsive episodes of tonic-clonic seizures that subsided with iv diazepam. A few minutes later he suffered a third seizure
column23: for which reason treatment was started with IV phenytoin and he was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). A cranial CT scan was performed showing minimal subarachnoid haemorrhage in the left suprasylvian region secondary to the CT scan. ECG and chest X-ray with no significant alterations. Laboratory tests showed ionic Ca: 2.3 mg/dl (LN 3.9-5.2); 25-hydroxyvitamin D: 10 ng/ml (LN 11-40)
column24: Magnesium 0.5 mg/dl; Sodium 125 meq
column25: Potassium 2.8 meq. IV treatment was started with serum therapy for rehydration
column26: as well as IV treatment with magnesium sulphate
column27: calcium gluconate and potassium chloride to correct the electrolyte deficits. During his stay in the ICU he did not present new episodes of seizures or neurological focality
column28: and on discharge from this department his magnesium
column29: calcium and potassium levels had normalised. A referral to the Nutrition Unit was then requested and the physical examination revealed a weight of 63 kg (usual weight one year earlier: 74 kg)
column30: height 1.68 m; BMI 22.3 kg/m2
column31: together with signs of a decrease in lean mass and fat mass. During the 3 weeks that the patient was hospitalised
column32: he was treated with dietary measures such as: astringent diet
column33: low in fat and simple sugars
column34: 30 minutes rest after meals
column35: fluid intake outside meals. In addition
column36: treatment was started with oral rehydration salts (Sueroral®)
column37: Loperamide (14 mg/day)
column38: Codeine (90 mg/day)
column39: oral magnesium supplements (up to 60 meq/day
column40: divided into 4 intakes)
column41: calcium carbonate (500 mg) + Cholecalciferol (400 IU) every 8 hours. The Ileostomy debit was 1500-2000 ml/day at baseline and 800-1000 ml/day at discharge. Her nutritional status improved with normalisation of nutritional parameters: cholesterol
column42: albumin
column43: Prealbumin and Retinol Binding Protein. Weight decreased from 63 to 61 kg
column44: and malleolar and pretibial oedema disappeared. At discharge
column45: Mg levels were below normal
column46: although relatively "safe" (Mg 1.3); with magnesiuria of 14.7 (LN 50-150)
column47: sodium
column48: potassium
column49: total calcium
column50: ionic calcium and chlorine within normal range. In the last days of admission
column51: it was decided to change the Cholecalciferol for Calcitriol (0.25 micrograms/day)
column52: in order to favour and improve magnesium absorption
column53: maintaining the doses of oral calcium (1500 mg/day). PTH levels at discharge were normalised (38pg/ml)
column54: as were vitamin D levels (20ng/ml). The patient is currently undergoing check-ups at the Nutrition Clinic
column55: presenting good general condition
column56: ileostomy debits of 1000 + 200 ml/day; with Mg levels within normal range (1.9 mg/dl)
column57: as well as the rest of the electrolytes
column58: having been able to progressively reduce the doses of magnesium lactate to 9 comp/day (36 meq/day of elemental Mg) and the doses of calcitriol to 0.25 μg/48 hours.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: A 60-year-old male patient
column2: smoker
column3: severe alcoholism
column4: with a history of arterial hypertension and an episode of acute enolic pancreatitis in November 2003. On admission
column5: an abdominal CT scan was performed which showed diffuse pancreatic inflammation with exudates
column6: as well as the presence of two tumours in the anterior leaflet of the left kidney
column7: one of them with tomodensitometric characteristics suggesting a haemorrhagic cyst or with a high protein content
column8: without being able to rule out a solid tumour. After recovery from the acute inflammatory symptoms
column9: the case was discussed with us
column10: and we continued the study of the tumour by performing a new control abdominal CT scan in February 2004

column14: characteristic of fat necrosis secondary to pancreatitis.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 41-year-old man diagnosed with a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma implanted on short segment Barrett's oesophagus
column2: detected during routine endoscopy carried out in the context of a long-standing gastro-oesophageal reflux disease. The patient underwent surgery
column3: with total transhiatal oesophagectomy with cervical anastomosis
column4: creating a tubulised gastric conduit
column5: associated with vagotomy
column6: without pyloroplasty. Postoperatively
column7: the patient presented with copious and persistent vomiting that did not improve after a week of conservative treatment
column8: including metoclopramide and i.v. erythromycin. Oral endoscopy demonstrated abundant retention in the gastric conduit and a markedly stenosed pylorus. Pyloric dilatation with an 18 mm balloon (CRE™ Wireguided Balloon Dilator; Boston Scientific Corporation) was performed
column9: followed by easy passage of a 10 mm gastroscope through the pyloric channel. However
column10: after a few days
column11: the patient did not experience any improvement. A barium study revealed an almost complete and persistent stop in the pylorus
column12: allowing only a filiform passage of contrast.  One week after dilatation
column13: a new pyloric dilatation
column14: in this case forced
column15: was performed with a 35 mm balloon (Rigiflex®; Microvasive
column16: Boston Scientific
column17: USA)
column18: with the patient's informed consent. The procedure was performed under deep sedation
column19: with anaesthetist
column20: endoscopic and fluoroscopic control. The endoscope was advanced into the descending duodenum
column21: leaving a radio-opaque guide. The pylorus was marked by submucosal contrast injections at several points. With the endoscope withdrawn
column22: the balloon was advanced over the guidewire until it was correctly positioned
column23: under fluoroscopic control. At that point
column24: the balloon was inflated with air at 300 mmHg
column25: with manometric control
column26: to 300 mmHg for two minutes. After the procedure
column27: the pylorus was widely dilated. After dilatation
column28: plain abdominal radiology was performed and the patient was monitored for signs and symptoms of perforation or bleeding. No complications occurred. The patient was able to drink fluids without problems after 24 hours. In the following days
column29: progressive oral tolerance was satisfactory. A new radiological control with barium showed good passage of contrast into the duodenum. The patient was discharged a few days later and is asymptomatic 3 months later.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column9: oval

column1: We present the case of a 35-year-old female patient. She was referred to our unit after her third hospital admission in the previous 18 months for recurrent chylous ascites. With no previous history of interest
column2: she was admitted for the first time with ascites and mild oedema in the lower limbs for a month and a half
column3: and underwent an exploratory laparotomy on suspicion of ovarian neoplasia. Twelve litres of ascitic fluid with chylous characteristics were evacuated
column4: with no ovarian abnormalities or peritoneal carcinomatosis. She was discharged with diuretic treatment with spironolactone 100 mg and prednisone 40 mg in descending doses
column5: after 5 months she was readmitted
column6: and 9 litres of chylous fluid were extracted by evacuating paracentesis. On a new admission 6 months later
column7: during which time the symptoms had progressively reappeared
column8: 14 more litres of peritoneal fluid were evacuated. Throughout his hospital stay
column9: the following complementary tests were performed: blood count
column10: with discrete leukocytosis and normal formula
column11: iron study without alterations; biochemical profile
column12: with hypoproteinaemia and hypoalbuminaemia
column13: hypocalcaemia. Celiac profile
column14: HBsAg
column15: HCV-Ac
column16: tumour markers and Mantoux tests were negative. ASLO
column17: C-reactive protein and serum a-1 antitrypsin levels were normal. Thyroid function study was normal. The serum proteinogram showed decreased values of albumin and gamma globulins. The ascitic fluid extracted showed exudate characteristics and a chylous appearance. His culture was negative. Thoracoabdominal CT showed normal thorax
column18: ascites in all peritoneal compartments
column19: oedema in small bowel loops. Abdominal ultrasound showed abundant peritoneal ascitic fluid
column20: with normal liver
column21: portal
column22: great vessels
column23: gall bladder and spleen. Fibroenteroscopy
column24: reaching the cecum
column25: showed from the bulb to the sections of jejunum explored
column26: irregularity in the villous pattern
column27: oedema of folds and numerous punctate lymphangiectasias. Ileoscopy was performed and the terminal ileum showed an extremely irregular mucosa
column28: with whitish
column29: friable plaques on biopsy. The capsuloendoscopy showed diffuse involvement of the small intestine
column30: with punctiform "millet grain" formations and oedematous and congestive folds. Biopsy of the intestinal mucosa was reported as lymphoid follicular hyperplasia
column31: focal lymphangiectasia; and gastric
column32: duodenal and jejunal mucosa biopsy showed no significant alterations. Treatment was started with diuretics and intravenous albumin
column33: presenting a favourable clinical evolution
column34: being discharged with the diagnosis of primary intestinal lymphangiectasia
column35: with home treatment with Furosemide 40 mg
column36: Spironolactone 100 mg and Prednisone 30 mg
column37: being referred to the Clinical Nutrition and Dietetics Unit for assessment and follow-up. Examination in the consulting room showed a height of 1.65 m
column38: weight 53.5 kg
column39: BMI 19.3 kg/m2
column40: after evacuation of 14 L of ascitic fluid during her admission; subjectively she was thinner than before the onset of symptoms. Skin pallor
column41: long-lined fingers
column42: discrete symmetrical malleolar oedema. The rest of the physical examination was normal. No usual gastrointestinal symptoms
column43: except for 1-2 bowel movements per day with a somewhat greasy appearance. She has a varied diet
column44: always avoiding excessively fatty foods due to intolerance. She denies toxic habits. Nuligesta. Laboratory tests showed serum values of total protein 3.4 g/dL
column45: albumin 2.1 g/dL
column46: calcium 7.3 mg/dL. The rest of the basic biochemistry
column47: lipidogram and haemogram were normal. We decided to start dietary treatment. A personalised diet of 2
column48: 200 kcal in 24 hours and the following distribution of nutrients was established: 52% carbohydrates
column49: 30% lipids
column50: 18% proteins. The intake of fats from food is restricted
column51: and lipids are provided in the form of MCT oil
column52: using 85 ml per day
column53: introduced into the diet progressively to avoid intolerances. The protein intake of the diet is supplemented with 400 ml of hyperprotein formula for enteral nutrition and 20 g of powdered protein module. A vitamin-mineral supplement is also added. The patient is cooperative and shows strict compliance with the recommended guidelines
column54: with good adaptation and excellent tolerance. After 11 months of follow-up
column55: she has achieved weight gain
column56: with a weight of 59.3 kg and BMI 21.4. The analytical parameters have improved significantly
column57: with serum values of total protein 5.2 g/L
column58: albumin 3.7 g/L
column59: calcium 8.5 mg/dL. There are no gastrointestinal symptoms. Waist circumference was 78 cm
column60: and no free fluid was observed in the abdomen on abdominal ultrasound. She has not presented new episodes of ascites and has not required hospital admission during this period.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 74-year-old woman was admitted to our centre for a week presenting with a sensation of rotatory vertigo with nausea and vomiting
column2: gait instability
column3: horizontal binocular diplopia and speech disturbances. Her personal history included an allergy to iodinated contrast dye and infiltrating ductal breast carcinoma with positive oestrogen and progesterone receptors and negative nodes three years earlier. She underwent surgical treatment and radiotherapy of the residual breast. She was currently in remission and was being treated with anastrozole. Physical examination revealed slurred speech
column4: nystagmus with a rapid rotatory component in all directions of gaze
column5: paresis of the right fourth cranial nerve
column6: disabling truncal ataxia with inability to walk and dysmetria in all four limbs. Upper cortical functions were preserved. General tests showed: normal haemogram
column7: general biochemistry and haemostasis. The usual tumour markers (CA 125
column10: alpha-fetoprotein and carcinoembryonic antigen) were normal. A neuroimaging study with computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain was performed and was normal. FCD was suspected and anti-Yo antibodies were determined and were positive at high titres in serum and CSF. While the study of occult neoplasia was being performed
column11: treatment with immunoglobulins
column12: cyclophosphamide and methylprednisolone was started without evident clinical improvement. Thoracic-abdominal CT
column13: mammography
column14: breast MRI and bone scintigraphy showed no evidence of tumour pathology. Positron emission tomography (PET) showed two 15 mm nodular lesions located behind the pancreatic head compatible with mesenteric adenopathy of malignant aetiology. No other foci suspicious for malignancy were observed. Laparotomy and biopsy were performed. The anatomopathological study showed the presence of metastases of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. The diagnosis of metastasis of breast carcinoma was considered and the Medical Oncology Department started treatment with epirubicin and cyclophosphamide. The clinical evolution of the patient was towards stabilisation without improvement of signs and symptoms
column15: the patient was not able to perform activities of daily living on her own and needed a wheelchair to move around.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 50-year-old female patient with no medical history of interest was referred by her dentist to the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Department of the Virgen del Rocío University Hospital in Seville for the extraction of an included upper left canine. The patient reported that 6 months ago the deciduous upper canine had been exfoliated spontaneously. After taking a panoramic radiograph and a lateral radiograph
column2: the situation of the included canine was verified in the upper left quadrant
column3: impacted between the lateral and central incisor
column4: with complete root development and apical foramen. Intraoral examination revealed the absence of the upper right second premolar and the lower left first molar
column5: which had been missing for a long time. There were diastemas in the anterior sector and a distance from the edentulous section of less than 5 mm. After assessing the different therapeutic options
column6: the patient was offered orthodontic treatment in order to provide the necessary space for prosthetic replacement in the canine region
column7: and secondly
column8: after insertion of an osseointegrated implant in the same surgical time as the extraction of the included canine
column9: to proceed with the prosthetic restoration.  In the first phase
column10: orthodontic treatment was carried out to achieve a mesiodistal space of 7 mm and closure of diastemas. Once this was completed
column11: the extraction of the impacted canine and the insertion of an implant were planned. Under local anaesthesia
column12: a mucoperiosteal flap was raised palatally to gain access to the impacted canine. After performing the minimal osteotomy
column13: the tooth was odontosected
column14: extracted and curetted. A vestibular mucoperiosteal flap was then raised to expose the vestibular cortex and ridge. A cylindrical hydroxyapatite implant 3.25 mm in diameter and 15 mm in length was placed
column15: ensuring crestal anchorage to the floor of the nostrils
column16: achieving very good fixation of the implant. A resorbable collagen membrane was placed and guided bone regeneration of the defect was carried out with demineralised bank bone. Also at the same session
column17: implants were conventionally inserted in the position of the upper right second premolar and lower left first molar. The postoperative course was uneventful. After an osseointegration period of 6 months
column18: the second surgery and placement of the transepithelial abutment was carried out without incident. The prosthetic reconstruction was performed with a cemented implant-supported crown. The patient was then referred to the orthodontist to complete the orthodontic treatment. After seven years of evolution
column19: the evolution is favourable with no peri-implant bone loss and maintenance of aesthetics and functionality.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The first case is that of a 9-year-old girl who reported blurred vision. Her visual acuity was 0.2 and 0.3 according to the Snellen optotype
column2: respectively. Her refraction was determined under cycloplegia to rule out refractive defects and was +0.75 in both eyes. The rest of the ophthalmological examination was normal
column3: with a stereopsis of 60"-40". Further anamnesis revealed that the patient was a girl adopted at the age of 7 years. While she was drawing in the consulting room
column4: it was observed that she had no difficulty in handling herself
column5: even dilated
column6: so that the symptoms seemed disproportionate and a simulation was suspected. A mirror test was used
column7: and the result was that the 0.4 line was seen with both eyes. Considering that flat mirrors have the property of doubling distances
column8: her real acuity would correspond to 0.8. The case was discussed with the parents and it was decided to carry out regular check-ups. His acuity improved to unity with both eyes at 3 months.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Girl aged 11 years and 10 months. Normal female karyotype
column2: normal gestation and delivery. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) shows agenesis of the corpus callosum together with extensive neuronal migration abnormalities. This patient presents with epilepsy in infancy with the first seizure episodes at 2 years of age. Electroencephalographic (EEG) recordings demonstrate an asymmetrical hypsarrhythmia. Funduscopic examination shows a complete papilla in the right eye
column3: peripapillary pigment and areas of peripapillary hypopigmented chorioretinal lacunae extending into the retinal vascular arcades. However
column4: there is no macular involvement. The left fundus shows a colobomatous optic disc and small chorioretinal hypopigmented areas. There are no other renal or vertebral malformations. The patient is characterised by a long survival
column5: with a current age of 11 years and 10 months
column6: but presenting a very severe psychomotor retardation.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Female patient who at birth presented with a bluish spot in the right naso-orbital region
column2: which grew rapidly over the following month. When she was seen by us at the age of 6 months
column3: she presented a 4 cm pedunculated mass
column4: which involved the nasoorbital sulcus and nasal dorsum

column7: and after four sessions at four-week intervals
column8: the fibrous haemangioma was excised using a supraciliary incision.
