column1: A 64-year-old woman diagnosed with chronic open-angle glaucoma whose left eye was operated on by viscocanalostomy. Her best corrected visual acuity was 0.7 and 0.8 in the right eye (OD) and left eye (OI) respectively. Preoperative intraocular pressure (IOP) in the LA was 26 mmHg despite treatment with the combination of timolol maleate and dorzolamide twice daily together with latanoprost once daily. In the OD
column2: with the same regimen
column3: IOP was 17 mmHg. Both in the study of the optic papillae and in the follow-up of the visual field
column4: a progressive deterioration was observed in the OI. It was decided to perform a viscocanalostomy according to the usual Stegmann technique1. We performed the conjunctival dissection with a fornix base and after dissection of a scleral flap that went beyond Schwalbe's line
column5: we created a second
column6: deeper scleral flap
column7: which was removed
column8: where we proceeded to locate Schlemm's canal and carefully canalised it inwards by injecting the viscoelastic. Finally
column9: we proceeded to suture the superficial scleral flap tightly with 10-0 nylon. Twenty-four hours after surgery
column10: the patient had a Descemet's membrane detachment (DMD) in the inferior temporal quadrant measuring 5.0 x 5.0 mm. The space between Descemet's membrane and the corneal stroma had significant haematic and viscoelastic filling. Visual acuity (VA) at this time was 0.5 and IOP 16 mmHg. Treatment was prescribed with mydriatics (cyclopentolate) and topical steroids (dexamethasone) and serial controls were carried out with VA control
column11: biomicroscopy
column12: gonioscopy and intraocular pressure measurement.  Two weeks after the operation
column13: the state of the corneal inclusion remained practically unchanged
column14: with moderate corneal oedema causing a decrease in VA to 0.05
column15: so surgical reapplication was decided using the following technique: A myringotome was used to make an intentional break in the lower part of the descematic detachment and by repeated introduction of air and balanced saline into the anterior chamber
column16: both the viscoelastic and the haematoma were drained through the surgical opening of the descematic detachment. Subsequently SF6 was injected to keep the corneal endothelium in place.  One week after this procedure the DMD was completely reapplied
column17: with radiated folds from the affected area
column18: but with complete disappearance of the corneal oedema
column19: and recovery of VA to 0.8. His unmedicated IOP was 16 mmHg.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Three-year-old girl attended the emergency department after accidental ingestion three hours earlier of approximately 45 ml of an antitussive syrup made up of a combination of dextromethorphan hydrochloride (2 mg/ml) and pseudoephedrine hydrochloride (6 mg/ml). On arrival
column2: blood pressure 125/89 mmHg
column3: heart rate 97 bpm
column4: respiratory rate 28 rpm
column5: oxygen saturation 100% and temperature 36.5 °C. Weight: 13 kg. Physical examination was normal. The estimated ingested dose of dextromethorphan was 90 mg (6.9 mg/kg) and 270 mg (20.7 mg/kg) of pseudoephedrine. The patient was admitted for observation in the Intensive Care Unit because of the risk of possible cardiovascular
column6: anticholinergic and central nervous system side effects. During the first 12 hours
column7: the patient presented mild sinus tachycardia (maximum 130 bpm)
column8: associated with blood pressure > P95
column9: with no other cardiac rhythm abnormalities. She did not show any alteration in the level of consciousness at any time. She was discharged after 24 hours.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 34-year-old male patient diagnosed with chickenpox three weeks previously
column2: which had resolved without complications. He came to the emergency department with a decrease in visual acuity in his left eye. Ophthalmological examination showed a corrected visual acuity of 1 in the right eye (OD) and 0.6 in the left eye (OI). The slit-lamp study showed a cellular tyndall of 4+ in the OI
column3: keratic precipitates (3+) and no fluorescein staining of the cornea
column4: the OD being normal. Intraocular pressure was 16mmHg in both eyes. Initial fundoscopic examination of the OI revealed mild vitritis (1+) with no foci of retinitis. Topical treatment with corticosteroids and mydriatics was started. Two days later
column5: a slight decrease in cellular tyndall (3+) was observed in the anterior chamber
column6: but fundus examination revealed a peripheral focus of necrotising retinitis in the temporal area associated with retinal vasculitis. The patient was admitted and treatment was started with intravenous acyclovir (10 mgr/kg/8 hours)
column7: antiplatelet therapy (acetylsalicylic acid 150 mgr/24 hours) and topical treatment was maintained. Prophylactic argon laser photocoagulation was also performed around the area of retinal necrosis.  After 48 hours and after verifying a good response with a decrease in the retinal focus
column8: systemic corticosteroids were introduced at a dose of 1 mg/kg/d
column9: showing a rapid improvement in visual acuity
column10: with a decrease in vitritis and a smaller retinal focus. After 2 weeks
column11: antiviral treatment (famciclovir 500 mgr/12 hours) was switched to oral therapy and a gradual decrease in corticosteroids was started at a rate of 10 mgr each week. Antiviral treatment was continued at maintenance doses for 6 weeks
column12: with regular blood and biochemistry tests to detect renal involvement. Six months after the onset of the disease
column13: the patient remained asymptomatic
column14: with a visual acuity of unity in the left eye
column15: healing of the retinal lesions and complete absence of ocular inflammatory activity in both eyes. During admission
column16: recent varicella zoster virus infection was confirmed by seroconversion.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 34-year-old man consulted for pain with paraesthesia on the ulnar border of the right hand and fourth and fifth fingers for two weeks after a tennis tournament. He presented diffuse oedema in the volar aspect of the ulnar area of the wrist and hand
column2: with positive Tinnel over the pisiform. Radiology and ultrasound were normal. After infiltration of a corticoid with local anaesthetic
column3: he was immobilised with a wrist brace in neutral position. The neurophysiological study showed a compressive neuropathy of the ulnar nerve in Guyon's canal. The patient received symptomatic treatment with cryotherapy
column4: orthosis
column5: analgesics
column6: vitamin B complex and physiotherapy. Computerised Axial Tomography (CAT) of the wrist
column7: requested due to persistent pain at nine months
column8: showed a pseudarthrosis of the unciform process of the hooked bone
column9: with a large fragment. He underwent surgery by palmar approach
column10: dissection of the ulnar neurovascular bundle
column11: cross-linking of the pseudarthrosis bed and osteosynthesis with two 1.5mm diameter Compact Hand titanium screws (Synhes®).  He maintained an antebrachial splint
column12: including the fingers
column13: for three weeks
column14: after which he began physiotherapy. Four months after surgery
column15: the patient was symptom-free
column16: except for hypoaesthesia of the fourth finger
column17: with full mobility
column18: recovered strength and returned to work (strength) and sporting activities. The CT scan at two months and the X-ray at three months showed a partial fusion. A new CT scan at four months showed complete union.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: T. I. is a 38-year-old woman who came to our unit
column2: referred from the burns unit of another hospital in Barcelona
column3: with a psychotic condition. The patient suffered burns following a fire at her home which required a month's stay in the unit. The patient reported no personal or family history of mental illness. She also denied the use of toxic substances. The only somatic antecedents that stood out were: delivery by caesarean section five months ago
column4: infection of the surgical wound
column5: and second and third degree burns from the aforementioned fire. In the patient's psychobiography
column6: she was from Casablanca (Morocco) and the sixth of nine siblings (five boys and four girls). She attended school until the age of twenty with good performance (school and high school
column7: plus 2 years of complementary education). Her socio-occupational adjustment in her country was good (various temporary jobs as a hostess
column8: shop assistant
column9: sports instructor
column10: etc.). She got married in her country a year and a half ago by family agreement (she had never had a partner or male friends before) and a month later she moved to live in the province of Girona (Spain)
column11: where she lived with her husband
column12: her brother-in-law and his wife. Since her marriage
column13: the patient has been a housewife. Her first child (a boy) was born five months ago in a complicated delivery. Two months ago
column14: a fire broke out in her home in unclear circumstances
column15: which led to her admission to the burns unit of a hospital. On admission to our unit
column16: the patient was vigilant
column17: conscious and temporo-spatially disoriented. Contact with the patient was psychotic; her speech was sparse
column18: in a low voice and with a monotonous tone of voice. She referred to a delirium of prejudice and paranoid delusions that she did not specify. She was suspicious. She reported hypothymia
column19: dysthymia of fear
column20: as well as auditory hallucinations in the form of "noises". The examination revealed a poor fixation memory. In subsequent interviews with the patient (several of them with the help of a translator)
column21: she reported that about two months after the birth she began to experience a mood disorder that oscillated between sadness or crying and elevated mood. She progressively developed delusions of harm towards herself and her child
column22: as well as auditory hallucinations in the form of voices criticising her and giving her orders. In relation to these psychotic symptoms
column23: the patient explained anguish and intense fear of being harmed (herself or her child) as well as her voluntary isolation as a protective measure. On examination in the hours prior to the fire
column24: during the fire and during her stay in the burns unit
column25: the patient explained fluctuations in her level of consciousness and memory loss
column26: so that the suspicion of an extended suicide in the context of the hallucinatory-delusional symptoms could not be ruled out. During his stay in the acute unit
column27: pharmacological treatment was started with Haloperidol up to 11.5 mg/d (with progressive reduction of the dose)
column28: Amisulpride (up to 800 mg/d) and Clonacepam. A few hours after admission she was alert
column29: conscious and oriented. For the first few days the patient was still fearful and suspicious
column30: hardly leaving her room. Slowly
column31: contact
column32: affection and psychotic symptoms improved; the hallucinations gradually disappeared and she gradually distanced herself from the delusional content until she was able to criticise it. He gradually adapted to the dynamics of the unit. Facilitating early and continuous contact with her son and leave from the family home was considered key to the patient's treatment and recovery; in fact
column33: early mother-child contact was an important factor that accelerated the patient's recovery. The leaves were uneventful and the family was very cooperative at all times. On discharge the patient was euthymic
column34: calm
column35: free of positive psychotic psychopathology and able to take care of her child (although the amnesia secondary to the confusional disorder persisted). The patient and her family raised the possibility of her convalescence in Morocco
column36: which we considered beneficial as she would be cared for by professionals with the same language and culture and would have the support of her family of origin; but we stressed the importance of moving with her son for the transfer to be truly therapeutic.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 59 year old patient who has had difficulty walking for about a month. She presents weakness and pain in the lower limbs
column2: which improves after stopping
column3: sometimes accompanied by non-radiating back pain. She has noticed changes in her voice
column4: becoming more dysphonic
column5: which she relates to her work. In the anamnesis she did not report weakness in her hands or upper limbs. There was no eye or sphincter control disorder
column6: nor was there any sensory disorder. No emotional lability was noted
column7: although the patient already had an adjustment disorder after the death of his wife. He reports occasional cramps in twins. Personal history: hypertension and type 2 diabetes. Family history: paternal uncle died with a diagnosis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). In the neurological examination he presented with hypophonic speech
column8: centred facial expression. Normal internal and external ocular motility. Tongue twitching. No cervical weakness. Motor: lower limbs (lower limbs): paraparesis of proximal predominance 4/5. Dorsiflexion of both feet 5/5. No upper limb weakness. No sensory deficit. Osteo-tendon reflex (ROT) +++/+++ with bilateral Hoffmann positive and right cutaneous-plantar reflex indifferent
column9: left preserved. Fasciculations in deltoid
column10: pectoral and diffusely in MMII. Muscle atrophy in both quadriceps. General examination was unremarkable. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) was performed: right 1.18; left 1.29. Laboratory tests were requested
column11: with a CK of 232
column12: immunological study and normal serology. Chest and lumbosacral X-ray normal. Following suspicion of motor neurone disease
column13: the Internal Medicine department was consulted and requested an electromyogram (EMG)/electroneurography (ENG) suggestive of a neurogenic pattern with active denervation in both MMII
column14: right upper limb (fibrillations and positive waves)
column15: compatible with motor neurone disease
column16: probably ALS. With these results
column17: the patient was referred to Neurology. After assessment of the patient and with a diagnosis of probable ALS
column18: according to the revised El Escorial criteria
column19: and pending completion of the study with cranial-medullary magnetic resonance imaging and a new neurolophysiological study
column20: treatment was started with Riluzole 50 mg
column21: one tablet every 12 hours. Due to the clinical evolution of the patient with proximal paraparesis in MMII
column22: with significant muscle atrophy of both thighs
column23: dysphagia for solids
column24: without involvement of the upper limbs (MMSS) and correlated with the latest neurophysiological study
column25: another possible diagnosis was considered
column26: specifically myopathy. The EMG suggested myopathy with bulbar and pelvic girdle involvement (inclusion body myopathy)
column27: so a muscle biopsy was performed
column28: the results of which were conclusive
column29: ruling out the possibility of primary skeletal muscle disease and only showing changes secondary to denervation. The patient subsequently presented with a progression of symptoms
column30: showing weakness in dorsal flexion of the left foot (4/5). Incipient atrophy at the level of the fifth interosseous space of the left hand. Diffuse fasciculations in different body segments
column31: as well as mild aphonia. Finally
column32: a diagnosis of motor neuron disease was suggested
column33: probably ALS. Treatment was continued with Riluzole 50 mg. Speech therapy and physical and respiratory rehabilitation at home were recommended. Five months after the definitive diagnosis
column34: the patient developed septic shock of urinary origin and subsequent complications
column35: requiring invasive mechanical ventilation (tracheotomy)
column36: percutaneous gastrostomy feeding (PEG) and secondary adaptive disorder
column37: and was discharged home. Two months later
column38: he presented with an exitus.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A six-year-old patient consulted for periumbilical abdominal pain of 12 hours' duration accompanied by vomiting and a liquid stool. She presented with a low-grade fever
column2: intense skin pallor and general malaise. Examination revealed a distended abdomen that was painful on palpation
column3: with more intense defence in the right iliac fossa. Suspicion of acute appendicitis led to a normal haemogram and emergency biochemistry. The abdominal X-ray showed marked dilatation of the small bowel loops in the left hemiabdomen and scant right gas
column4: findings compatible with reflex ileus. Ultrasound showed great distension of the right colic frame with liquid content that displaced the rest of the small bowel loops to the left and the presence of a small amount of free liquid in the interassoid and Morrison's space
column5: in relation to probable intestinal under-occlusion or occlusion
column6: although the possible cause could not be determined.  Laparotomy revealed the presence of a large ileal lymphatic malformation occupying practically the entire abdominal cavity
column7: multiple moderate-sized cysts (5 cm in diameter) and a larger cyst (15-20 cm in diameter). The loops of the ileum adjacent to the malformation show some degree of volvulus and moderate ischaemic involvement that completely reverses after devolvulation. Ileal resection is performed
column8: completely including the malformation
column9: with end-to-end anastomosis. The pathological anatomy confirms the diagnosis of mesenteric cystic lymphangioma with a cystic mass of approximately 17 cm in diameter
column10: with a smooth external surface and a vascular pattern on the wall corresponding to a single
column11: multiseptate cavity filled with a slightly thick
column12: cloudy yellow liquid. The wall is smooth internally and of a maximum thickness of 0.1 cm.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 14-year-old male patient
column2: resident of the city of Medellín
column3: previously asymptomatic
column4: was referred to the urology department of the Hospital Pablo Tobón Uribe with a diagnosis of a left testicular mass. The patient incidentally palpated a painless testicular mass in the left scrotal area
column5: without noting its growth over time
column6: unrelated to local trauma or associated with other symptoms. He initially consulted his local doctor and an ultrasound study was ordered
column7: which showed two rounded
column8: well-defined images of similar size
column9: shape and echogenicity in the left scrotal sac
column10: measuring an average of 9 x 11 mm
column11: which also showed a similar Doppler pattern. This study ruled out lesions in the epididymis. With this result
column12: they suggested ruling out a testicular mass or supernumerary testicle and referred him to the internist
column13: who ordered a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
column14: which reported the presence of three well-defined oval-shaped structures in the scrotal sac
column15: compatible with two testicles and one additional one (see Fig. 2)
column16: without masses or adenopathies. Because of these findings he was referred to urology. The patient had a negative personal history. On physical examination
column17: the patient was found to be in good general condition
column18: with vital signs within normal parameters for his age and with adequate development of the upper abdomen; there were no palpable masses or hernias in the abdomen and no inguinal lymphadenopathies. In the external genitalia
column19: the penis was normal
column20: and two healthy testicles were palpated
column21: as well as a spherical adenomatous mass
column22: located in the upper (proximal) area of the left hemiscrotal
column23: mobile
column24: non-painful
column25: easily detachable with the fingers
column26: with no nodulations or signs of local inflammation.  Based on the clinical history
column27: complementary studies and physical examination findings
column28: a diagnostic impression of paratesticular mass or PQ is made. With this clinical approach and prior review of the subject
column29: it is decided to perform surgery for exploration and resection of the lesion
column30: with the prior informed consent of the patient and his family. Under general anaesthesia
column31: a transverse scrotal incision was made
column32: with subsequent dissection by planes up to the albuginea on the left side
column33: observing the presence of two structures of equal size
column34: appearance and consistency compatible with testicles
column35: being joined by a common epididymis and each with a vascular bundle
column36: where only one
column37: this led us to think that it corresponded in its embryological origin to the superior testicular pole
column38: while the other
column39: located proximally or superiorly
column40: had a very dilated and unique venous bundle. The latter was sectioned
column41: ligated with exhaustive haemostasis and cut; a rounded carmelite-coloured structure of firm consistency
column42: approximately 1.2 cm in its largest diameter
column43: was obtained and sent for anatomopathological study. A pocket is then made in the subdarthrodial space where the healthy testicle is placed and fixed with Vicryl® 4-0 (Ethicon
column44: Johnson & Johnson) absorbable organic suture material (polyglactin). A plane closure is performed and a left ilioinguinal nerve block is made on the left side. The patient was discharged immediately postoperatively and progressed satisfactorily
column45: without complications. Two fragments were processed for the pathology report and histological sections showed a normal testicle. No seminal intratubular neoplasia.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male patient
column2: 33 years old
column3: with a history of chronic end-stage renal failure secondary to polycystic disease. He was transplanted from a deceased donor at another institution in 2007. He received immunosuppressive treatment with prednisone
column4: tacrolimus and mycophenolate mofetil. In March 2012 he underwent a renal biopsy that reported acute cellular rejection Banff IA. He received treatment with methylprednisolone 1500 mg
column5: prednisone 50 mg per day
column6: mycophenolate 3000 mg per day and tacrolimus XL 7 mg per day. One month later
column7: the patient presented with fever
column8: frontal and retro-ocular headache
column9: with decreased sensitivity in the right hemiface. He was evaluated and diagnosed with acute sinusitis and was started on treatment with amoxicillin. The patient did not improve and began to present ocular proptosis
column10: oedema of the right upper jaw
column11: greenish rhinorrhoea
column12: diplopia
column13: epiphora
column14: ulcer in the palate
column15: convulsions and azotemia. For this reason he was referred to our institution. On admission he was feverish
column16: with oedema in the right hemicara
column17: extensive ulcer on the hard palate
column18: ocular proptosis
column19: ophthalmoplegia
column20: loss of vision in the right eye and altered renal function. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain showed involvement of the paranasal sinuses
column21: right orbit
column22: frontal lobe
column23: cavernous sinuses
column24: right basal ganglia and ipsilateral area of the thalamus. With these findings
column25: a diagnosis of MROC was made
column26: so liposomal amphotericin B was started
column27: immunosuppression was suspended and the patient underwent radical multidisciplinary surgery
column28: where sinusitis drainage
column29: drainage of the right frontal brain abscess
column30: extensive resection of the soft and bony tissues of the right hemiface
column31: enucleation
column32: tracheostomy and gastrostomy were performed. Cultures and pathology confirmed Mucor infection. Additionally E. cloacae
column33: C. sedlakii
column34: K pneumoniae BLEE (β-lactamase extended spectrum enzyme-lactamase) positive were isolated.  A magnetic resonance imaging check still shows involvement of the disease in the brain. However
column35: given the extent and serious sequelae of more radical surgery
column36: it was decided to continue medical management. For this reason
column37: treatment was completed for 6 weeks after radical surgery with liposomal amphotericin B
column38: meropenem
column39: linezolid and posaconazole plus twice-weekly dressings. Subsequently he was discharged with posaconazole 400 mg every 12 hours
column40: cyclosporine 50 mg every 12 hours
column41: prednisone 5 mg daily and nutrition by gastrostomy. Six months later the patient was in good general condition
column42: with no signs of active infection and with acceptable renal graft function (creatinine 1.5 mg/dl). He underwent successful surgical reconstruction. Six months after reconstruction the patient is in good general condition and is currently planning to complete his facial reconstruction process.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 73-year-old male patient
column2: smoker of 55 packets of cigarettes a year
column3: with no known drug allergies and no previous treatment. He was admitted for ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (STEMI)
column4: complicated 72 hours later by post-infarction angina. A haemodynamic study revealed 90% obstruction in the right coronary artery (RCA)
column5: 70% in the anterior descending (AD)
column6: 90% in the first diagonal
column7: 70% in the bisector and 70% in the circumflex (CX). Catheterisation showed an ejection fraction of 75% with normal left ventricular end-diastolic pressure. At the medical-surgical session
column8: the patient was accepted for surgery
column9: and treatment was started with carvedilol
column10: captopril
column11: amlodipine
column12: simvastatin and acetylsalicylic acid. After 30 days
column13: a planned myocardial revascularisation was performed using saphenous vein to CD and diagonal vein and mammary artery to DA grafts. During the procedure
column14: an ECC time of 112 minutes
column15: an ischaemia time of 76 minutes and a hypothermia of 29°C was achieved. Anaesthesia was induced with etomidate and cisatracurium and maintained with midazolam (5-7.5 mg/hour)
column16: cisatracurium (2.5-5 mg/hour)
column17: and remifentanil (0.01-0.02 µg. kg-1. min-1). Standard cardiopulmonary bypass with pulsatile flow was used. Heparin activity was antagonised with protamine. Pump output was normal
column18: and there were no intraoperative incidents. On admission to the Intensive Care Unit
column19: he showed the following haemodynamic parameters: mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 77 mmHg
column20: with dobutamine perfusion at 4.5 µg kg-1 min-1
column21: heart rate of 80 l/min
column22: pulmonary artery pressure of 31/20 mmHg
column23: PVC of 18 mmHg and PCP of 16 mmHg. Cardiac output (CO) was 6.8 l/min
column24: with a cardiac index (CI) of 3.35 l/min/m2. Within 2 hours of evolution
column25: the patient developed haemodynamic deterioration
column26: with marked hypotension despite adding noradrenaline perfusion at 0.4 µg kg-1.min-1 and increasing the dose of dobutamine to 8 µg kg-1.min-1. He maintained diuresis
column27: remained afebrile and well adapted to maximal ventilation. Mediastinal drains were scanty. Plain chest X-ray showed no evidence of parenchymal condensation
column28: the Swan-Ganz catheter was in the correct position and there were no changes in the electrocardiogram (ECG). A total of 2
column29: 200 cc of crystalloids and colloids were administered in one hour
column30: i.e. about 30 ml/kg (weight: 70 kg) and noradrenaline perfusion was increased above 0.5 µg kg-1 min-1 without any response. Dobutamine infusion was maintained at the same doses. Sedation was performed with low doses of midazolam. Echocardiographic monitoring ruled out other complications. Core temperature was 35°C and there was no early rewarming
column31: according to the usual pattern. In the presence of data compatible with postoperative vasoplegia refractory to treatment
column32: it was decided to use methylene blue. However
column33: blood cultures were taken and were negative. In addition to requesting the corresponding consents
column34: the relatives were informed of the use of this medication. The haemodynamic parameters measured with the pulmonary artery catheter before and at various times after methylene blue infusion are shown in table 1. A dramatic haemodynamic response was observed at the time of infusion
column35: which was sustained over time. It allowed withdrawal of noradrenaline
column36: normalised MAT and increased systemic vascular resistance (SVR) and pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR). No changes in arterial blood gases were recorded.  Methylene blue was administered at a dose of 2 mg/kg diluted in 250 cc of 5% glucose solution
column37: to be given over 60 minutes. No adverse effects of interest were observed
column38: except for urine staining. There was no renal failure
column39: maintaining normal urea and creatinine values and preserved diuresis. Haemoglobin levels were unchanged and there were no alterations in coagulation or liver failure. The level of methaemoglobinaemia was not determined
column40: although this adverse effect
column41: like the others
column42: has been described with the use of doses much higher than those used in our case. After stabilisation
column43: the patient was extubated 24 hours after admission
column44: and discharge was extended preventively until 72 hours
column45: with no new complications arising. Hospital discharge occurred 11 days later and no late complications were observed.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 53-year-old man
column2: who until 1992
column3: when he was 41 years old
column4: had a small hiatus hernia as his only personal history of interest. Since that date and as a consequence of a traffic accident
column5: he began to experience discomfort in both the cervical and lumbar spine
column6: with the pain radiating to the shoulders
column7: arms and legs. The painful symptomatology increased in intensity
column8: and under the diagnosis of lumbar disc herniation L4-L5
column9: a lumbar discectomy and laminectomy were performed
column10: with a worsening of her symptoms appearing after the operation. Months later
column11: due to lumbar instability
column12: he underwent a new operation to fix the lumbar vertebrae
column13: and as a consequence of this operation his symptoms worsened even more
column14: with the appearance of paraesthesia and neuropathic pain accompanied by urination disorders
column15: constipation and erectile difficulties
column16: which led to the diagnosis of post-surgical epidural fibrosis or post-laminectomy syndrome. In 1997 he underwent two further operations. The first time
column17: to remove the osteosynthesis material; and the second time
column18: to perform a cervical discectomy with laminectomy at C3-C4
column19: which also failed
column20: as the pain increased in intensity and acquired neuropathic characteristics. Given the severity of the condition and the poor evolution of the patient
column21: he was referred to the Pain Unit of our hospital where
column22: after the initial assessment
column23: it was decided to opt for the placement of a spinal neurostimulator
column24: which also failed to achieve satisfactory results. On the other hand
column25: as a consequence of the continuous analgesic and anti-inflammatory treatments used to try to control the pain
column26: the patient developed a duodenal ulcer which aggravated the pre-existing hiatus hernia
column27: and anxiety and depression. Recently
column28: after an accidental fall
column29: he fractured both calcaneus
column30: adding a new component of pain to those already reflected
column31: and which has ended up plunging the patient into moderate depression. The calcaneal fracture is leading to a sympathetic-reflex dystrophy of both legs. He is currently diagnosed with cervical and lumbar postlaminectomy syndrome
column32: and presents continuous pain
column33: of moderate-severe intensity
column34: with frequent exacerbations that increases with sitting and throughout the day
column35: and becomes unbearable in the afternoon
column36: being forced to use crutches due to the degree of disability
column37: and due to the marked limitation of mobility
column38: especially in the cervical and lumbar regions. Examination revealed a positive bilateral Lasegue's sign at 30 degrees; severe sensory impairment
column39: which
column40: in addition to the pain
column41: caused hypoaesthetic and spastic areas in both lower limbs; and marked motor and sphincteric difficulties that significantly limited the patient's daily life. The pain has been treated with numerous drugs
column42: ranging from non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs to morphine
column43: anti-competitive drugs
column44: anxiolytics and antidepressants. Since three years ago
column45: oral fentanyl citrate therapy was introduced to accompany the use of transdermal fentanyl. Since then
column46: his pain and quality of life have improved substantially
column47: although the results are still far from optimal
column48: as he needs two 400 µg tablets almost every day to control his painful exacerbations. As the most significant fact to be highlighted
column49: the patient states that months after starting continuous treatment with oral fentanyl citrate
column50: he has developed multiple caries
column51: which have caused the loss of a total of ten teeth
column52: and he blames this on the use of this drug. His dental hygiene is defective but existing
column53: and he performs it occasionally
column54: almost every day. In the group of 77 patients who also receive chronic oral treatment with fentanyl citrate for various pathologies in our Pain Unit
column55: and whom we reviewed as a result of the case in question
column56: no other cases of significant dental disorders were found. The mean age of these patients was 63 ± 8.2 years and the duration of fentanyl treatment was 36 ± 8 months. Dental hygiene behaviour in this group has not changed with the introduction of the new drug
column57: and the prevalence of caries can be extrapolated to that of the general adult population
column58: where it is around 85-99%
column59: depending on age and different studies (5). |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 37-year-old male patient under psychiatric treatment for psychotic disorder
column2: paranoid schizophrenia
column3: who consulted for decreased visual acuity. The anamnesis reveals that in the context of an episode of non-systematised delirium of interpretation
column4: i.e. reading a book on iridology
column5: the patient interpreted that sunlight could change the colour of the iris of his eyes
column6: which was not stated in the text. The patient injured both eyes by concentrating the sun's rays with the help of a magnifying glass during several consecutive sessions for aesthetic purposes. He also self-induced second and third degree burns on the skin of his face and arms in order to make alleged cysts disappear. As a result
column7: the lesions he presented in his eyes were as follows: massive atrophy of the iris with destruction of the sphincter function
column8: solar maculopathy
column9: with abundant subretinal fluid in the macular area and peripheral chorioretinal atrophy with pigment deposition
column10: which is equivalent to photocoagulative lesions. Over a period of eight weeks the macular lesions resolved spontaneously
column11: although the loss of visual acuity has been permanent. Visual acuity was 0.5 in the right eye and 0.6 in the left eye. Both iris and peripheral retinal lesions have remained stable.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A term newborn girl was referred for ophthalmological assessment at 20 days of life due to the appearance of occasional nystagmus. Her mother
column2: with no significant history during pregnancy
column3: had undergone glaucoma surgery at 20 years of age with bilateral trabeculectomy and reconstructive surgery for syndactyly of the hands. Ophthalmological examination revealed microcorneas with discreetly veiled appearance
column4: occasional horizontal nystagmus
column5: bilaterally increased digital ocular tone and fundus with preserved papillae; and general physical examination revealed a narrow nasal pyramid with narrow nostrils and thin nasal wings
column6: mild micrognathia and syndactyly of the fourth and fifth fingers of both hands. Under sedation
column7: tonometry revealed intraocular pressure (IOP) of 35 and 40mm Hg in the right and left eyes
column8: respectively
column9: and epithelial oedema and superficial corneal clouding.  Bilateral trabeculectomy was performed with good postoperative IOP control
column10: without the need for additional topical drugs. At the last ophthalmological examination
column11: at 14 months of age
column12: the patient was in orthotropia
column13: with good fixation and light tracking
column14: refractive defect of -4 dioptres in both eyes
column15: diffuse blisters and no inflammatory signs
column16: and good IOP control was confirmed. No alterations of interest were found in the FO.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 73-year-old ex-smoker with a history of hyperlipidaemia and triple aorto-coronary by-pass surgery eleven years earlier
column2: who was admitted for clinical symptoms of one month's evolution with dyspnoea and angina on slight exertion. For this reason
column3: a coronary angiography by cardiac catheterisation was performed
column4: which showed a three-vessel coronary artery disease with non-revascularisable obstruction of the saphenous bridge to obtuse marginal. Prior to the procedure
column5: the patient was being treated with an antiplatelet agent and had moderate renal insufficiency (creatinine 3.7 mg/dl)
column6: which did not contraindicate the study. Since the catheterisation
column7: the patient presented a general syndrome with asthenia and anorexia
column8: and a blood test two weeks later showed a worsening of his renal function
column9: with creatinine of 7.5 mg/dl and eosinophilia of 13%
column10: for which he was admitted on suspicion of acute renal failure due to CES after cardiac catheterisation. Due to the progressive increase in creatinine
column11: he required haemodialysis
column12: and new signs included purple spots on the lateral area of the foot (livid reticularis)
column13: a biopsy of which did not reveal cholesterol emboli. Referred to ophthalmology 40 days later for fundus examination
column14: he presented the following ophthalmological examination: visual acuity (VA) was 0.8 in both eyes
column15: intraocular pressure (IOP) was 13 mm Hg and in the right eye fundus (OD) a microhaemorrhage was observed above the papilla and four cholesterol emboli and in the left eye fundus (OI) another two emboli located in the temporal and nasal branch. Subsequently
column16: the patient went into heart failure
column17: accompanied by signs and symptoms of acute peripheral ischaemia
column18: with worsening general condition and progressive obnubilation until his death 73 days after coronary angiography. Necropsy revealed numerous cholesterol emboli in the vascular structures of the thyroid
column19: pancreas
column20: heart
column21: spleen
column22: liver and kidneys.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 19-year-old male who was admitted with clinical manifestations consisting of intermittent localised pain in the left hemothorax accompanied by cough and febrile fever of one month's duration. In the general laboratory tests performed
column2: the only notable findings were a leukocytosis of 16
column3: 500 x 109/l and an ESR of 24 mm in 1h
column4: the rest of the complementary tests
column5: including microbiological tests
column6: were negative. The chest X-ray showed a mass with irregular borders that blurred the contour of the left pulmonary hilum. A chest CT scan confirmed the existence of a mass with sharper borders and hypodense areas in its interior located in the anterior mediastinum and in intimate contact with cardiac structures measuring 10 x 6 cm in diameter. The biopsy obtained by videothoracoscopy of the mass showed that it consisted of a proliferation of Langerhans cells with abundant eosinophils
column7: histochemical stains showed positivity for S-100 and CD1a
column8: being negative for lymphoid markers
column9: all these findings were compatible with the diagnosis of LCH. After receiving 2 lines of chemotherapy treatment and without obtaining an evident response
column10: it was necessary to initiate radiotherapy therapy
column11: during which a lymphadenopathy appeared in the supraclavicular location
column12: which after being biopsied showed evidence of nodular sclerosis-type Hodgkin's disease associated with LCH; after no response was observed to conventional treatment
column13: autotransplantation of peripheral blood haematopoietic precursors was carried out
column14: achieving complete remission of both diseases to date.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 43-year-old man infected with HCV genotype 1a and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
column2: with liver fibrosis grade F4 (cirrhosis)
column3: FibroScan of 27 kPa and Child-Pugh grade A. On HIV treatment since February 2010 (tenofovir + emtricitabine + raltegravir). The patient presented RP below normal levels (<120 x 109/L) since diagnosis of HCC (December 2008). Prior to initiation of antiviral therapy for HCC
column4: the patient had grade III thrombocytopenia (PR = 42 x 109/L)
column5: grade III neutropenia (neutrophils = 0.66 x 109/L) and haemoglobin (Hb) values within normal range (Hb = 14.1 g/dL). Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) values were within normal range (35 and 36 IU/mL
column6: respectively) and gamma-glutamyltranspeptidase (GGT) was found slightly elevated (62 IU/mL). HCV viral load (CVVHC) was 180

column1: Patient: YSS Age: 32 years Race: Black. Personal history: No associated pathologies. HEA: Patient who presented with progressive enlargement of the external genital organs
column2: lymph transudation and sexual impotence for the last two years. Positive findings on physical examination at the time of admission: External genitalia: marked oedema of the penis and scrotum with erythema and pain. Painless inguinal lymphadenopathy.  Complementary studies were performed to demonstrate possible aetiology: Complete blood count: normal figures. Serology: non-reactive. Mantoux test: Negative Total and fractionated proteins: Normal X-ray of the hip: No bone lesion. Abdominal U/S: Thickened right psoas of 48 mm Simple CT scan of the hypogastrium and pelvis: Aseptic necrosis of the femoral head with hypertrophy of the psoas at that level. Various surgical procedures were performed: -Right retroperitoneal exploration. -Adenectomy of the right iliac and cava. -Needle lymphangioplasty. -Fasciotomy of the root of the penis. At no time did this patient present any symptoms of chyluria or oedema of the lower limbs
column3: nor was he found to have a varicocele or hydrocele. Based on the clinical manifestations
column4: as well as the findings and ruling out other possible causes of lymphoedema of the penis and scrotum in this patient
column5: the following diagnosis was made: -Primary local inflammatory lymphoedema of the penis and scrotum. -Aseptic necosis of the femoral head. The patient was then assessed by a multidisciplinary team comprising urologists
column6: angiologists and plastic surgeons. It was decided to perform a lymphangiectomy. Surgical anatomy It is distorted by the condition
column7: which prevents the normal evacuation of the lymph
column8: due to the distortion and trapping of the lymphatic ducts as a result of the increased fibrous connective tissue and reduction of the elastic fibres
column9: essential in these organs

column13: arteries and nerves are located
column14: are found forming a block which is difficult to distinguish in layers and which must be excised in its entirety while respecting the thin penile fascia attached to the erectile
column15: spongy and cavernous organs containing the urethra and dorsally the penile artery. In the pockets of the six sheaths that make up the lining of the testis: the scrotum
column16: the muscular dartos
column17: the cellulose

column19: the second muscular tunic called the erythroid
column20: also form a block that must be removed in its entirety
column21: leaving the vaginal layer covering the testis

column1: A 42-year-old man consulted for a right testicular mass and pain
column2: of 2 months' evolution
column3: which progressively increased. He denied any other pathological history or other symptoms. Testicular ultrasound showed a diffuse increase in the size of the right testicle
column4: measuring 6.2x5.8x4.2 cm
column5: with diffuse alteration of its echogenicity. Therefore

column7: rubbery
column8: whitish testicle. The histopathological study showed diffuse infiltration of the testicular parenchyma by a malignant haematolymphoid neoplasm composed of small

column1: A 72-year-old male patient was referred from another centre for a short-standing right thyroid nodule
column2: with signs of airway compression. Ultrasound showed images typical of multinodular goitre with the presence of a solid nodule in the right lobe and scintigraphy detected a cold area at this level. Prior to admission
column3: a FNA had been performed which was insufficient for diagnosis and its subsequent repetition showed signs of follicular hyperplasia
column4: so it was decided to perform a right hemithyroidectomy
column5: with intraoperative control. A brownish
column6: pale
column7: 2.6 cm nodule was detected in the specimen and processed for histological study (see below). After the diagnosis
column8: the patient's history was investigated at other centres and it was discovered that 17 years earlier he had undergone a right radical nephrectomy for renal carcinoma. After 9 months the patient showed cervical swelling and multiple cervical adenopathies were detected by imaging techniques
