column1: A 61-year-old woman transferred from a regional hospital due to acute renal failure. The patient reported severe diarrhoea and vomiting for a week. Her history included arterial hypertension and DM treated with irbesartan
column2: amlodipine and metformin (850 mg/12 h). Examination revealed severe dehydration
column3: tachypnoea and bradypsychia
column4: although he was responsive to commands. The abdomen was soft and non-painful. Blood pressure was 90/40 mmHg
column5: heart rate 70 beats/minute and temperature 35.8ºC. Table 2 shows the main analytical data. Serum amylase was 94 U/l. Fluid intake normalised blood pressure and the administration of 165 mEq of bicarbonate raised pH to 7.06 and bicarbonate to 4 mEq/l. The patient underwent urgent haemodialysis and metformin treatment was discontinued. Twelve hours after admission
column6: creatinine was 2.2 mg/dl and pH 7.43
column7: but amylase rose to 1
column9: with normal ionic calcium and triglycerides. An abdominal CT scan revealed peripancreatic fatty infiltration with free abdominal fluid compatible with acute pancreatitis. No known causes of pancreatitis were found
column10: including hypertriglyceridaemia
column11: hypercalcaemia
column12: alcoholism
column13: biliary lithiasis or trauma. The patient progressed favourably and was transferred to the ward 72 hours after admission.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 28-year-old male patient came to our department presenting with left hemimandibular pain and fever. He had no pathological history of interest. Physical examination showed no specific signs
column2: but there was pain on palpation of the pericoronary tissues of the lower left third molar. A blood test was carried out in the emergency department showing a slight increase in the number of leukocytes
column3: with no other notable alterations. The orthopantomography (OPG) showed both third molars included
column4: in mesioangular position
column5: with follicular sacs
column6: the right one being larger.  With the suspicion of a possible infection of odontogenic cause (pericoronaritis) antibiotic treatment was started
column7: with complete resolution of the symptoms. Exodontia of both lower wisdom teeth was recommended. Histological examination confirmed the presence of a follicular sac associated with the wisdom tooth
column8: formed by non-keratinised polystratified epithelium. After the extraction of the lower left third molar
column9: the patient did not return to complete the treatment. After 20 months he consulted again for pain at the level of the lower right third molar. The OPG showed a large radiolucent image around the crown of the right lower third molar.  With the diagnostic suspicion of a dentigerous cyst associated with the third molar
column10: surgery was performed with exodontia of the tooth and cystectomy. The anatomopathological study confirmed the presumptive diagnosis as a lesion with a connective tissue wall lined on the inside by a stratified epithelium of keratinised ciliated cells and cells with abundant mucin. At the three-month check-up
column11: the residual cavity created by the cyst was found to have undergone active ossification (with the formation of bone trabeculae).   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Eight-year-old boy with diffuse intermittent abdominal complaints in recent years
column2: attributed to acute banal processes. No personal or family history of interest. No urinary infections or other urinary symptoms. Coinciding with an episode of abdominal pain in the right hemiabdomen
column3: an abdominal ultrasound was performed
column4: which revealed mesenteric adenitis and mild dilatation of the right renal pelvis
column5: with suspected stenosis of the UPU. Urine sediment and urine culture were normal.  The abdominal pain disappeared spontaneously
column6: but the patient was referred to Paediatric Nephrology for follow-up. In the control ultrasound
column7: while asymptomatic
column8: dilatation of the urinary tract with mild-moderate dilatation of the right renal pelvis was still visible
column9: so an isotopic renogram was requested (suspicion of pyeloureteral junction stenosis). The renogram confirmed obstructive ectasia in the right kidney. The renal scintigraphy study showed an increase in right renal size
column10: with evident hypocaptation along the medial border
column11: signs of dilatation of the tract
column12: with a renal function of 58.8% in the left kidney and 41.2% in the right kidney. Given the dilatation of the urinary tract due to obstructive causes
column13: the patient was referred to paediatric urology for surgery. A nephrostomy catheter was placed for a few months to recover and prevent deterioration of renal function5
column14: 6. After removal of the nephrostomy catheter
column15: imaging
column16: clinical and analytical controls continued to be carried out
column17: with progressive normalisation.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: at the age of 40
column3: she underwent mastectomy with axillary dissection in another city. The histological report was infiltrating lobular carcinoma. The maximum diameter of the primary tumour was 3 cm (T2). Fourteen nodes were isolated from the axilla
column4: four of which were infiltrated by the tumour; further data on hormone receptors were not available. After the operation she received complementary chemotherapy with six cycles of FEC. In 2000 she began to suffer epigastric pain accompanied by a weight loss of more than 10 kg. In November 2000
column5: gastroscopy revealed a tumour-like mass in the gastric body. The biopsy was reported as diffuse adenocarcinoma with signet ring cells. In January 2001
column6: a laparotomy was performed
column7: in which ascites and an unresectable gastric neoplasm through the stomach wall and infiltrating the head of the pancreas were found. Ascitic fluid cytology was compatible with signet ring cell invasion. He then started cytostatic treatment with chemotherapy. In December 2001
column8: she began to suffer from back pain; bone scintigraphy showed multiple uptakes compatible with bone metastases
column9: which were confirmed by magnetic resonance imaging. Since then she has been treated with analgesic radiotherapy and has also received various lines of chemotherapy and hormonal treatment
column10: which she is still undergoing. The patient's prolonged survival encouraged further gastric biopsy studies which confirmed the presence of oestrogen and progesterone receptors in signet ring cells.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 45-year-old woman presented to the urology department with voiding syndrome and recurrent urinary tract infections. The patient had a history of hypothyroidism
column2: arterial hypertension on regular treatment with atenolol and enalapril
column3: smoked 10 cigarettes a day and had undergone cholecystectomy. Physical examination revealed no pathological findings. Renal and bladder ultrasound was performed
column4: showing irregular thickening of the bladder wall.  Cystoscopy was subsequently performed and revealed a small bladder with a neoformation of approximately 5 centimetres in diameter with a solid appearance on the left lateral side towards the back and anterior side
column5: with an inflammatory appearance and poorly defined limits. In the abdomino-pelvic CT scan
column6: a diffuse thickening of the bladder wall was observed
column7: which was more significant on the left side. After contrast administration
column8: diffuse uptake of the entire bladder wall was observed with marked enhancement of the left parietal mucosa. No mesenteric or retroperitoneal adenomegaly was observed. Urine cytology was negative on two occasions for tumour cells.  In view of these findings
column9: transurethral resection of the bladder neoformation and random bladder biopsies were performed. The samples obtained were sent for anatomo-pathological analysis
column10: which showed diffuse proliferation of spindle-shaped and elongated cells at the level of the lamina propria
column11: with large vascular neoformation; nodular structures consisting of an acellular eosinophilic material whose fibres are arranged in a swirling manner
column12: constituting Wagner-Meissner bodies
column13: in a concentric arrangement simulating nerve structures
column14: were also observed. Immunohistochemistry confirmed that the spindle cells and Wagner-Meissner bodies were strongly positive for antiserum S-100
column15: confirming the diagnosis of diffuse neurofibromatosis of the bladder wall. The patient was referred to the internal medicine department for further investigation to rule out other manifestations of neurofibromatosis in other organs. In the same way
column16: the patient is periodically followed up by the urology department to monitor the appearance of new neoformations.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male aged one year and five months
column2: referred by his paediatrician for strabismus. He had endotropia (15 degrees) and small hypertropia in the right eye (OD)
column3: the left eye (OI) was dominant. The visual acuity (VA) is low in the right eye (the eye is disturbed by occluding the left eye) and acceptable in the left eye (the eye fixes the gaze and picks up small objects). The light reflex on the cornea leads us to suspect eccentric fixation in both eyes. The child had suffered from febrile convulsions. Among the family history
column4: the mother had chickenpox while pregnant (between 16 and 18 weeks)
column5: and a maternal uncle has Alport syndrome. The anterior pole is normal. On schiascopy the neutral point is +2 in both eyes. Indirect ophthalmoscopy shows oval lesions in both maculae
column6: predominantly in the temporal half
column7: suggestive of old retinochoroiditis
column8: with normal periphery. In the OD the macula is larger
column9: highly pigmented and with whitish glial tissue in the centre; the temporal arches are curved towards the pathological area
column10: and there is temporal parapapillary atrophy. In the OI there is well-defined chorioretinal atrophy with pigmented borders
column11: normal retinal vessels and some choroidal vessels over the sclera with pigment clusters; scleral ectasia is seen under the retina. The child has no nystagmus
column12: no other ocular or systemic lesions. The skull X-ray is normal. Suspecting intrauterine ocular infection
column13: serology for TORCH (Toxoplasma
column14: Rubella
column15: Cytomegalovirus and Herpes)
column16: syphilis and lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus is requested for the child and the mother. Both are negative for toxoplasma (both IgG 0.14 IU/ml
column17: by enzyme immunoassay
column18: EIA). Cytomegalovirus
column19: child negative
column20: mother positive with low titres (Ig G 2.1 Index
column21: by EIA). Herpes type I
column22: child negative
column23: mother positive with low titres (IgG 2 Index
column24: by EIA). Herpes type II
column25: child negative
column26: mother positive with low titres (IgG 2.39 Index
column27: by EIA). Varicella-zoster virus
column28: child negative
column29: mother positive with high titres (IgG 2.68 Index and IgM negative
column30: by EIA). Syphilis
column31: mother and child RPR negative. Rubella
column32: both positive as vaccinated (boy IgG 59.3 IU/ml
column33: mother IgG 113.7 IU/ml
column34: by EIA). Lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus
column35: both positive
column36: but with low titres that are not significant (IgG 1/32
column37: by indirect immunofluorescence). This rules out an infectious aetiology
column38: as the child's antibodies are not elevated
column39: and suggests that it is a bilateral atypical macular coloboma. As there are hereditary cases (1)
column40: the fundus examination of the child's parents and siblings was performed
column41: and all were normal. It can also be associated with hypercalciuria and hypomagnesaemia (2)
column42: but in this case the calcium/creatinine index and magnesaemia are within normal limits. Subsequently we have followed the evolution until the age of three years
column43: the VA in the OD is light perception and projection
column44: and in the OI it is 0.2. In the visual evoked potentials
column45: by stimulation with luminous glasses and checkerboard
column46: there is a clear asymmetry
column47: with a detriment in OD. Penalisation with patching was not considered due to the large size of the coloboma in the OD. It would be interesting to carry out an ocular ultrasound scan
column48: but it was decided to wait until the patient was older and cooperated in carrying it out.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 45-year-old man with stage 5 CKD secondary to hepatorenal polycystic kidney disease with a history of arterial hypertension and hyperuricaemia. Given the progressive deterioration of renal function with the need for renal replacement therapy
column2: and after explanation of the different techniques
column3: a 1 cuff non-self-positioning straight peritoneal catheter was inserted. One month later
column4: after starting CAPD at home with 4 exchanges of 2 litres of 1.36% glucose
column5: the patient came to the Peritoneal Dialysis Unit
column6: reporting inguino-scrotal oedema of 48 hours' evolution. After ruling out orchiepididymitis
column7: CT-peritoneography was performed
column8: as in the previous case
column9: confirming the passage of contrast to the testicles through a permeable vaginal process. Peritoneal rest and transfer to haemodialysis was decided. One month later
column10: the peritoneovaginal duct was surgically closed
column11: and CAPD was restarted in June 2009 without incident or recurrence of the leak.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 30-year-old man with legal blindness since childhood
column2: affiliated to the ONCE
column3: who came to the clinic diagnosed with an intraocular tumour. His medical history included hypoacusis; there was no evidence of neurofibromatosis. He had undergone cataract surgery in both eyes and glaucoma in the left eye (OI) 10 years previously. On ophthalmological examination
column4: visual acuity was finger-counting in the right eye (OD) and amaurosis in the OI. He had a pendular nystagmus. In the study of the anterior segment
column5: there was a coloboma of the iris in the right eye
column6: pseudophakia and in the left eye
column7: pupillary seclusion and the bleb of filtration from the previous trabeculectomy. Intraocular pressure was 14 in the OD and 45 mm Hg in the OI. Fundus examination showed a retinal and optic nerve coloboma (NO) in the right eye; fundus imaging was not possible in the left eye
column8: ultrasound showed a retinal detachment and the presence of a mass in the inferior temporal region. An MRI was requested and reported as an increase in the diameter of the eyeball in the OD 32 x 26 mm and dilatation of the exit of the NO; The OI had a size of 23 x 22 mm
column9: and a polypoid lesion was detected in the inferior temporal region of the globe
column10: isointense in T1 and hypointense in T2 with enhancement after contrast
column11: possibly related to amelanotic melanoma
column12: associated with a slight thickening of the covers; in addition there was an extraocular lesion at the exit of the NO cystic
column13: hyperintense in T2 sequence without contrast uptake. With the suspicion of an intraocular and NW tumour
column14: enucleation was performed
column15: which required lateral orbitotomy. Microscopically
column16: an eyeball was observed with a greyish tumour of soft consistency and thickened NO at one of its poles. The pathology study described a proliferation inside the globe and under the retina formed by enlarged cells with ovoid nuclei and fibrous stroma with thick-walled vessels
column17: abundant glial fibres
column18: Rosenthal fibres and microsquamous areas. An image of similar morphology with cystic changes and calcifications was also found in the optic fillet. Immunohistochemistry was positive for S100
column19: neuronal specific enolase
column20: vimentin and GFAP
column21: Ki67 was low positive.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 58-year-old woman was seen by the gastrointestinal department for pain in the right hypochondrium of 6 months' duration
column2: accompanied by alterations in bowel habits. She had no general syndrome or urological symptoms. Physical examination revealed a good general state of health
column3: normal hydration
column4: normal colour and moderate obesity. There is no cushingoid habitus or stigmata of virilisation. Blood pressure is normal. Cardiopulmonary auscultation is normal. The abdomen was globular
column5: soft and depressible
column6: making palpation of possible masses or organomegaly difficult
column7: showing slight pain on deep pressure in the right hypochondrium
column8: with no Murphy's sign. As for the complementary examinations
column9: the routine biochemical and haematological analysis
column10: as well as the adrenal function tests were within normal ranges. Ultrasonography shows the presence of a tumour in the right adrenal area measuring approximately 6x6 cm. No liver metastases are observed. The CT scan confirms the mass in close contact with the wall of the inferior vena cava
column11: which it apparently displaces
column12: and infiltration of the latter cannot be ruled out. There is no evidence of retroperitoneal lymph node involvement or metastasis elsewhere. There was also no evidence of tumour thrombosis. In view of these findings
column13: it was decided to perform MRI for a correct definition of the involvement of neighbouring tissues
column14: reporting identical CT findings and without being able to definitively predict parietal infiltration.  With the diagnosis of an adrenal mass
column15: the decision was made to intervene
column16: which was carried out through a transperitoneal right subcostal incision. The right adrenal region was approached
column17: revealing a large tumour at this level. Dissection of the tumour was begun
column18: but no plane of separation was found in the area of contact with the lateral and posterior wall of the vena cava
column19: so it was decided to excise it after venous control proximal and distal to the mass and suturing with polypropylene of the wall of the inferior vena cava. The patient followed a favourable postoperative course
column20: without developing complications. She was discharged on the seventh postoperative day. The macroscopic histological study showed a 6 x 8 cm piece of elastic consistency
column21: easy to cut
column22: with a fleshy appearance and greyish-brown colouring. Remains of adrenal tissue can be seen in the periphery
column23: of apparently normal appearance. Microscopy reveals a proliferation of cellular elements of stromal lineage
column24: with large pleomorphic nuclei
column25: with multinucleated cells adopting a fascicular pattern. The mitotic index is high (7 m/10 high-magnification fields). There are areas of intratumoral necrosis and invasion of adrenal tissue present in the peripheral area. The definitive diagnosis is LEIOMIOSARCOMA OF CAVA. With regard to the evolution
column26: both analytical and imaging tests performed in the early post-surgical period showed normality. The case was referred to the Oncology Department
column27: which decided on consolidation radiotherapy treatment on the surgical site
column28: which began 40 days after the operation. Further check-ups were carried out at six
column29: nine
column30: twelve and twenty-four months
column31: all of which were normal.  The patient is currently alive and free of disease
column32: after 28 months of follow-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 25-year-old woman
column2: smoker of about 10 cigarettes/day
column3: with no other history of interest. She was admitted for symptoms of > 5 diarrhoeal stools
column4: sometimes accompanied by blood and weight loss. Colonoscopy was performed and normal colonic mucosa was observed. In the terminal ileum
column5: three irregularly shaped ulcerations with a fibrinous background were seen. Biopsies were taken
column6: confirming the diagnosis of Crohn's disease. Laboratory tests showed an albumin level of 2
column7: 890 mg/dl with no other findings. She was referred to the Nutrition Department
column8: where no protein catabolism
column9: reduced intake or other causes of malnutrition were observed. A1AT in blood: 159 mg/dl; A1AT in stool: 1.28 mg/g; stool weight in 24h: 182.84 g. A1AT clearance was 147.19 ml/day (> 56 ml/day)
column10: confirming the diagnosis of PLE. After treatment with azathioprine and hyperprotein nutritional supplements
column11: the patient improved clinically
column12: with serum albumin rising to 3
column13: 270 mg/dl.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 24-year-old white male with a non-painful mass in the right testicle
column2: which the patient noticed by self-palpation. Serum beta-HCG and alpha-FP levels were normal. Ultrasonography was performed and the images were interpreted as a solid testicular tumour. The patient underwent a right inguinal radical orchiectomy
column3: with normal postoperative course. Pathological findings: Macroscopic examination revealed an orchiectomy specimen measuring 5.5 x 4 x 4 cm and weighing 51 g
column4: which
column5: at the upper pole and located in the thickness of the testicular pulp
column6: contained a cystic lesion measuring 1.4 cm
column7: circumscribed by a capsule
column8: with a keratotic content
column9: crumbly consistency and whitish colouring; the surrounding testicular parenchyma retained a spongy and soft appearance. The only relevant finding in the rest of the specimen was a cystic formation in the spermatic cord
column10: 1.2 cm in diameter
column11: with a smooth
column12: translucent wall and a watery content.  Microscopically
column13: the intraparenchymatous lesion was represented by a cystic formation covered by a thin stratified squamous epithelium with a granular layer
column14: peripherally delimited by a thin fibrous band
column15: with no evidence of cutaneous appendages
column16: whose lumen was occupied by abundant keratotic material
column17: laminated and compact. The adjacent testicular parenchyma reflected normal characteristics
column18: with an adequate maturational gradient of tubular germ cellularity. The cystic lesion of the spermatic cord corresponded to a spermatocele.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 78-year-old woman with a history of hypertension
column2: type 2 diabetes mellitus
column3: generalised osteoarthritis
column4: NYHA stage II congestive heart failure and chronic atrial fibrillation. She was being treated with metformin (850 mg/8 hours)
column5: glipizide (5 mg/day)
column6: lercanidipine (10 mg/day)
column7: lisinopril-hydrochlorothiazide (20/12.5 mg/day)
column8: acenocoumarol and occasionally ibuprofen. Two days before admission due to increased bone pain
column9: she received ibuprofen (600 mg/8 hours)
column10: and subsequently began to show general deterioration
column11: vomiting and decreased level of consciousness. In the emergency department she was hypotensive and poorly prefused in coma (Glasgow 6/15) and blood tests showed plasma creatinine of 1.79 mg/dl
column12: glycaemia of 215 mg/dl and prothrombin time of 7%. Arterial blood gases had a pH of 7.03 with bicarbonate of 10 mEq/l and plasma lactic acid of 14 mmol/l. Chest X-ray revealed a left base infiltrate.  She was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) and underwent orotracheal intubation with mechanical ventilation and administration of vasoactive drugs and antibiotics. A lumbar puncture was indicated
column13: the result of which was compatible with pneumococcal meningitis. Haemodialysis with a bicarbonate bath was performed
column14: and the patient's blood tests subsequently improved
column15: with plasma creatinine (Cr) of 1.2 mg/dl and serum bicarbonate of 22 mEq/l. However
column16: the patient remained in coma
column17: with EEG with low voltage waves
column18: and died 72 hours after admission.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The present case is that of a 62-year-old man suffering from central thoracic pain
column2: tingling sensation in the hands and nausea. A week earlier he had had a similar episode without requiring medical assistance. Forty-five minutes after the onset of symptoms
column3: he was attended at the local hospital
column4: diagnosed as having an inferior infarction
column5: and started fibrinolysis with Streptokinase 1
column7: 000 IU. He was also treated with Solinitrin
column8: Aspirin and Zantac
column9: and was subsequently referred to the Regional Hospital as there were no beds available in the Coronary Unit. Half an hour after admission to the Hospital Comarcal (around 4.30 hours after the onset of symptoms)
column10: he began to experience pain in both lower limbs
column11: accompanied by intense pallor and no pulse. Computerised Axial Tomography (CAT) was performed
column12: which ruled out aortic dissection and
column13: suspecting embolism
column14: he was referred to the Provincial Hospital. At the referral centre
column15: a CT scan of the chest showed no pathology in the thoracic aorta and an ultrasound scan of the lower limbs showed bilateral occlusion at the popliteal level. He underwent surgery and bilateral embolectomy
column16: recovering the colour
column17: but the coldness persisted. The histopathological study showed fibrohaematic thrombotic material. After the first few hours the patient showed haemodynamic instability
column18: with the appearance of lividity in the lower limbs
column19: renal failure and shock
column20: with death finally occurring 24 hours after the onset of symptoms. The external examination of the corpse revealed a purplish-red colouring in the lower third of the thighs
column21: knees
column22: genital area and lower abdomen. The lungs were increased in size and consistency
column23: crepitus was perceived on pressure
column24: the fingerprint remained after pressure (fovea) and when cut
column25: after compression
column26: foam spurted out. The right lung weighed 850 grams and the left lung weighed 640 grams. After incising the pericardial sac
column27: a slight cardiomegaly weighing 390 grams was observed. The left ventricle was hypertrophic with a maximum free wall thickness of 2 cm. Histopathological analysis of the heart showed chronic ischaemic heart disease
column28: with an old infarct and a recent infarct
column29: 1-3 weeks old
column30: on the posterior aspect of the left ventricle. The thoracic aorta has a large ruptured atherosclerotic plaque with intraplaque haemorrhage and thrombotic material adhering below the arch. The endothelium of the abdominal aorta is occupied by reddish coagulated haematic material. The liver exhibited a steatotic appearance. Examination of the liver and lung confirms the macroscopic diagnoses of steatosis and pulmonary oedema.  In the arterioles supplying the skeletal muscles of the legs
column31: there were numerous emboli from ruptured atheroma plaques causing ischaemic necrosis of the muscle fibres.  Histologically
column32: the kidneys show acute tubular necrosis
column33: myoglobin pigment in tubules and emboli in arterioles from ruptured atheroma plaques.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 21-year-old male patient
column2: with no known allergies or other history
column3: who came to the emergency department for a 6-month clinical picture of asthenia
column4: increased fatigue with moderate exercise and accompanied by a general syndrome with a weight loss of about 10 kg during these months. Due to episodes of abdominal pain during this period
column5: he visited the emergency department twice and underwent gastroscopy
column6: reported as minimal hiatus hernia with grade I oesophagitis and duodeno-gastric bile reflux. In the last 5 days
column7: his symptoms worsened
column8: with vomiting
column9: more intense diffuse abdominal pain and liquid stools with no increase in the number of stools. Physical examination showed blood pressure of 120/60 mmHg
column10: heart rate of 110 pm
column11: afebrile
column12: conscious and oriented
column13: without neurological focality
column14: eupneic
column15: cardiac auscultation was rhythmic
column16: tachycardic
column17: without murmurs
column18: the abdomen was soft and depressible
column19: diffusely painful
column20: without defence on palpation
column21: no masses or megaliths were palpated. There was generalised skin hyperpigmentation
column22: accentuated in the nipples
column23: genital area and with melanic spots on the palate and gingival borders. Blood tests on admission showed blood glucose 59 mg/dL
column24: creatinine 4.32 mg/dL
column25: urea 214 mg/dL
column26: Na 123 mg/dL
column27: K 8.0 mg/dL
column28: Ca 8.2 mg/dL
column29: arterial blood gas with pH 7.24
column30: pCO2 35.6 mmHg
column31: pO2 107 mmHg (with O2 at 4 litres/minute)
column32: bicarbonate 14.4 mmol/L
column33: EB - 11.3 mmol/L and SatO2 97.2%. Haemoglobin 13.4 g/dl
column34: haematocrit 39.5%
column35: MCV 83 fL
column36: leucocytes 12
column37: 800 (45% neutrophils
column38: 32% lymphocytes
column39: 12% monocytes and 10.5% eosinophils). Coagulation without alterations. The electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia at 110 bpm with RSR' configuration and QT prolongation (487 ms). Chest X-ray was normal. During his stay in the ED
column40: measures were initiated to correct the hyperkalaemia but the patient became progressively sweatier
column41: tachycardic and hypotensive (BP 85/46 mmHg) and
column42: with the suspicion of an Addisonian crisis
column43: admission to the ICU was decided and volume replacement with saline solution was initiated (4. 500 cc in the first 24 hours)
column44: glucose
column45: actocortin (100 mg i.v. bolus followed by 400 mg in continuous intravenous infusion in the following 24 hours); initially requiring vasopressor amine perfusion (dopamine at 10 mcg/kg/min)
column46: which could be withdrawn in 36 hours. Blood samples taken prior to the start of corticosteroid treatment to determine adrenal function showed a basal cortisol 4.0 mg/dL and plasma ACTH 264 pg/ml. Determination of serum anti-adrenal capsule antibodies by indirect immunofluorescence was positive with a titre of 1/80. The determination of thyrotropin
column47: free thyroxine
column48: FSH and LH
column49: as well as anti-thyroglobulin and anti-microsomal peroxidase antibodies were within normal ranges. Abdominal CT: presence of morphologically normal adrenal glands. The patient was discharged from the Intensive Care Unit 3 days after admission and from the hospital 7 days later with renal function and ion parameters within normal range and with treatment with hydroaltresone 20 mg vo/8 h.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O

column1: A 14-month-old boy presented to the HUCA with desquamative skin lesions on the scalp and exudative lesions in the folds and perianal region. A skin biopsy was performed and the diagnosis was LCH. The condition was limited to the skin only and topical treatment was carried out locally. On further examination
column2: localised gingivitis was diagnosed at the level of 83.84.  In order to determine if there was a relationship with the previous skin process
column3: the corresponding biopsy of the marginal gum of 84 was carried out with processing of the sample with haematoxylin-eosin
column4: according to standard technique
column5: for histopathological study. At the same time
column6: an immunohistochemical study is carried out using CD1a markers (surface antigen) and S-100 protein specific to Langerhans cells. The result of the anatomopathological study determined the presence of a squamous epithelium with an infiltrate of polynuclear cells and eosinophils. At the level of the chorion
column7: nodules composed of cells of histiocytic structure with vesicular
column8: clear
column9: dented nuclei
column10: some with an irregular "coffee bean" shape
column11: were evident.  Immunohistochemistry showed evidence of positivity for CD1a surface antigen and S-100 protein
column12: effectively determining the oral involvement of the disease.  The patient was classified within the pathology type of multifocal Langerhans cell histiocytosis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 54-year-old man with the following personal history: ex-alcoholic
column2: ex-smoker
column3: chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) classified as moderate-severe mixed respiratory disability
column4: liver disease
column5: polyarthrosis
column6: polymyalgia rheumatica and Barret's oesophagus. Due to chronic corticosteroid treatment
column7: in May 2010 he suffered an osteoporotic vertebral crushing for which he underwent surgery consisting of vertebral fusion D2-D7 and vertebroplasty D4-D5. One month later
column8: he was transferred to our hospital with a diagnosis of D4 ASIA C transverse spinal cord injury syndrome for evaluation and rehabilitation treatment; the latter was impossible from the outset due to the instability of the vertebral injury. In addition
column9: it was necessary to perform daily local dressings and every 2-3 days regular dressings in the operating theatre due to the presence of an open
column10: infected and sphacelated wound in the upper dorsal vertebral region. In this way
column11: an attempt was made to maintain the osteosynthesis material and prevent the clinical evolution of his spinal injury. Finally
column12: given the impossibility of reducing the bacterial load of the wound and proceeding to close it
column13: we decided to remove all the osteosynthesis material in October. We prescribed cures with local antiseptics until a suitable bed was achieved in order to perform
column14: in January 2011
column15: a trapezius flap with a skin paddle to cover the existing defect. In the immediate postoperative period following this operation
column16: untimely postural manoeuvres were performed
column17: which iatrogenically caused venous congestion of the described flap. One month later
column18: we proceeded to debride the affected tissues and placed 2 portable VAC® systems for one month: one to manage the exudate generated in the area of the muscle detachment and the other in the cranial and caudal part of the skin flap. We chose the black foam dressing modality (granufoam: polyurethane 400-600 micrometre pore size) for the dressing because it was a relatively small residual wound (4 x 5 cm)
column19: with few signs of infection
column20: and because of the need to improve local blood flow to limit tissue loss and thus promote the generation of granulation tissue. Therapy was instituted continuously at -125mmHg for the first 48 hours and then lowered to -75mmHg until the end of treatment.  In March 2011 we covered the 3 previously described areas with autografts
column21: already granulated
column22: and fixed them with a state-of-the-art portable VAC® system (VIA®) for a further week at -75 mmHg
column23: and the patient was then transferred to the Rehabilitation Service to continue with his gait recovery programme.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 76-year-old patient underwent emergency surgery for a perforated cecum tumour obstructing the terminal ileum. His personal history included ischaemic heart disease with an AMI and coronary artery bypass grafting 13 and 6 years ago respectively. He underwent a right hemicolectomy and resection of 15 cm of ileum with reconstruction of the transit by means of an ileocolic anastomosis. A liver metastasis was observed in segment 8 with a size of 4 cm. A second operation was required 4 days later due to intra-abdominal abscess. The anatomopathological study was of well-differentiated adenocarcinoma with 17 lymph nodes free of tumour infiltration (T4N0M1). Postoperative CT scan showed a 3.5 cm solid nodular lesion in segment 8 of the liver. Postoperative MQ with FOLFOX was performed and the lesion decreased in size to 2.5 cm. Six months after the intervention of the primary tumour
column2: it was decided to perform a laparoscopic RF of the liver metastasis
column3: given the high surgical risk of the patient.  The procedure was performed under general anaesthesia with the patient in supine decubitus. The access trocar to the abdominal cavity and for the optic was placed at epigastric level. An 11 mm trocar was used and placed below the costal ridge. The portable 7.5 Mhz laparoscopic ultrasound transducer was placed through the 11 mm trocar. No other metastatic lesions were observed on intraoperative ultrasound. Under ultrasound and laparoscopic control
column4: the electrode was inserted in the centre of the lesion and ablated with a target temperature of 105°C
column5: a treatment time of 6 minutes
column6: an achieved power of 150 W and a successful ablation of the intrahepatic path. The RF electrode used was 25 cm long and had an ablation diameter of 4 cm. The lesion became hyperechogenic after ablation and no residual lesion was observed. There were no postoperative complications and the hospital stay was one day. One month after RF treatment
column7: a helical CT scan was performed
column8: showing a hypodense lesion with absence of uptake
column9: compatible with complete necrosis of the tumour lesion.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 67-year-old male patient
column2: active smoker
column3: with no personal history of interest
column4: who came for endoscopic examination due to progressive dysphagia of solids and liquids of one year's evolution
column5: with occasional odynophagia
column6: without weight loss
column7: hyporexia or fever. Gastroscopy revealed an irregular
column8: pearly mucosa in the supracardial region
column9: with circular eroded areas and other ulcerated areas covered with fibrin
column10: producing partial stenosis of the oesophageal lumen
column11: which made it difficult for the endoscope to pass through
column12: and was highly suggestive of oesophageal carcinoma. The rest of the examination was normal.  Six biopsies were taken from the lesion described. Histologically
column13: the samples correspond to thick strips of flat polystratified oesophageal epithelium
column14: partially furrowed by connective-vascular axes
column15: which conserve a normal maturational gradient and stratification
column16: including small foci of oedema and leukocyte exocytosis
column17: one of them also shows phenomena of superficial parakeratinisation
column18: associated with eosinophilic masses with a fibrino-necrotic appearance
column19: and bi- and multinucleated cells

column1: Male patient
column2: black
column3: 21 years of age
column4: who consulted the Maxillofacial Surgery Department of the Hospital Universitario San Vicente Fundación de Medellín attached to the Universidad de Antioquia
column5: referred by a dentist from a public health institution for presenting an asymptomatic increase in the volume of the mandible
column6: with unknown evolution. Intraorally
column7: excellent dental integrity and good dental occlusion were observed
column8: but there was an increase in volume in the vestibular region involving the body and the symphysis
column9: while lingually
column10: the expansion of the table was only in the area of the lower right canine and bicuspids. The initial panoramic X-ray showed a radiolucent image 10 cm long
column11: multiloculated
column12: located from distal tooth 46 to mesial tooth 33. The mesial root of tooth 46 and the root of tooth 45 showed rhizolysis
column13: with possible pulp necrosis. Teeth 46
column14: 45 and 44 had minimal mobility; the other teeth had normal vitality and the lower dental canal was rejected. There is no alteration in the sensitivity of the mentonian nerve.  The patient consented to the entire treatment by signing the informed consent form. Prior to the initial biopsy an aspirate was taken producing a citrine fluid and the first histopathological study found a lax connective tissue
column15: some multinucleated giant cells with few nuclei and a thin band of keratin; there was no evidence of epithelial tissue but it was considered as insufficient sample. Nevertheless
column16: a diagnosis of keratocystic odontogenic tumour was made
column17: due to the presence of a keratin band. After this procedure
column18: the lesion became superinfected and the patient had to be hospitalised due to the severity of the clinical picture; this condition was used to perform a second biopsy under general anaesthesia 8 days later
column19: in which a capsule made up of connective tissue with an intense inflammatory infiltrate and epithelial tissue with several layers of cells was found
column20: which gave the diagnosis: inflammatory root cyst. Given the ambiguity of the diagnosis and the aggressiveness of the lesion
column21: it was decided to perform the intervention with the first diagnosis (keratocystic odontogenic tumour -exkeratocyst-). With this diagnosis it was decided to plan an aggressive surgical treatment and it was decided to order endodontic treatment from 46 to 33 (9 teeth) prior to the surgical procedure
column22: as the dental apices were immersed in the cavity and the curettage itself would cause amputation of the pulp vascular bundles
column23: in addition
column24: according to the diagnosis
column25: it is a very recurrent lesion. This endodontic treatment lasted 3 months due to the difficulty of sealing the canals due to the presence of an amber-coloured liquid draining through the pulp chambers. After this time
column26: the production of liquid content ceased and the endodontic treatment was completed.  The surgical phase was performed under general anaesthesia. A trapezoidal flap was raised from distal 46 to distal 33. When the flap was reflected
column27: it was found to be expanded in its entire length and perforated in the bicuspid area (teeth 44 and 45)
column28: where the biopsies had previously been taken. We proceeded to remove all the expanded vestibular cortex until we had complete access to the cystic cavity. The thick fibrous capsule covering the osseous defect was found and removed. The bone cavity is reamed with rotary cutting instruments and the entire bone defect is brushed with Carnoy's solution. Some perforations of the lingual cortex are visible
column29: which are cauterised with an electroscalpel due to the risk of invasion of the tumour lesion into the lingual soft tissues. Due to the weakening of the mandibular basilar border
column30: a reconstruction plate is placed to avoid intra- or postoperative fracture. Before suturing the flap
column31: the bone defect is filled with fibrillar collagen and medicated with analgesics and antibiotics. The tissue obtained is sent to pathology. The histopathological report of the surgical specimen shows fibroconnective tissue devoid of epithelium and a post-surgical diagnosis of an aneurysmal bone cyst was obtained. Because the second biopsy showed an epithelium
column32: the diagnosis was misleading but
column33: evaluating the three histopathological samples
column34: it was considered that the epithelial tissue of the second biopsy was the product of the inflammatory reaction
column35: while the initial biopsy and the surgical specimen showed no epithelial component; it was decided to consider it an aneurysmal bone cyst. The patient was evaluated at 8 and 15 days and then at 2 months
column36: 10 months and 2 years. At the follow-up appointment at 2 months pulp necrosis and fistula were found at the level of 47
column37: which was adjacent to the lesion and the mesial root apex had been amputated during the surgical procedure. Endodontics was performed and the infection resolved. He also presented with right mentonian nerve paraesthesia and was prescribed B-complex tablets for one month. A new post-surgical assessment was carried out 10 months later and adequate bone healing was found
column38: but there was an occlusal sequela
column39: as the teeth that were left without bone support due to being immersed in the bone defect (teeth 44 to 33) were intruded and produced an open bite. Two years later a new clinical and radiographic check-up was carried out where it was found that: teeth 44 to 33 remained in open bite
column40: tooth 44 was also slightly vestibularised. The panoramic radiograph shows good bone filling
column41: but the three-dimensional tomography shows that there is a defect of about 6 mm in diameter that compromises the apex of 44 and 43
column42: and that the bone has yet to regenerate
column43: and the paraesthesia still persists two years later. The intraoral image shows that the enlargement produced by the expansion of the lesion of the lingual plate at the level of teeth 43
column44: 44 and 45 still persists.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: A seven-year-old girl born in Spain with no previous pathology was referred to the Paediatric Infectious Diseases Unit for painful left submandibular lymphadenopathy of one month's duration
column2: with no response to treatment with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and oral anti-inflammatory drugs. The patient had no fever
column3: night sweats or weight loss. She was not vaccinated with BCG. For one month a year she visits Morocco
column4: where she has contact with animals (sheep
column5: lambs) and consumes unpasteurised dairy products. Physical examination revealed a left submandibular conglomerate of lymphadenopathies
column6: painful on palpation
column7: hard
column8: non-rolling and non-adherent
column9: the largest lymph node measuring 2 × 2 cm. The rest of the physical examination and anamnesis by apparatus showed no pathological findings. Given the lack of response to treatment and taking into account the epidemiological data

column11: which was positive
column12: with a 10 mm induration with vesicular pattern at 72 hours. Chest X-ray and abdominal ultrasound were normal.  Brucella
column13: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and cytomegalovirus (CMV) serologies were negative. CBC showed normal haemogram

column15: whitish material. Culture and cytology revealed a pattern of necrotising granulomatous lymphadenitis. Given the limited involvement of the patient and the suspicion of tuberculous adenitis
column16: initial home treatment with isoniazid
column17: rifampicin and pyrazinamide was prescribed
column18: pending culture of the sample obtained by FNA. The culture was positive for M. bovis

column21: isoniazid and rifampicin. For this reason

column24: the patient attended regular check-ups at the Paediatric Infectious Diseases Department

column1: A 54 year old woman attended the emergency department for 5 days with progressive pain starting in the right iliac fossa
column2: associated with hyporexia and without alterations in intestinal transit
column3: micturition symptoms or previous local trauma. History of arterial hypertension and non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus treated with enalapril and acetylsalicylic acid. On examination
column4: the abdomen was distended
column5: painful at the level of the right iliac fossa with no signs of peritoneal irritation. Laboratory tests showed no abnormalities except for elevated acute phase reactants (fibrinogen 811 mg/dl and CRP 12 mg/dl). Computed tomography (CT) showed a 4 x 3 x 5 cm mass adjacent to the cecal pole with an 8 mm appendix
column6: which suggested acute appendicitis versus a complicated neoformative process. A laparoscopic approach was initially used
column7: finding a haematoma with mass effect at the level of the cecum and free bloody fluid
column8: so it was decided to convert and perform a right hemicolectomy with an uneventful postoperative period. column1: This is a 54 year old female patient diagnosed with partial edentulism of both arches and severe Seibert class III alveolar atrophy1 in the edentulous premaxilla region.  The treatment plan consisted of the placement of 2 autoclaved hydrogel beads for tissue expansion of the premaxilla and a subsequent en bloc bone allograft at the same site. column2: they were exposed and removed

column5: the dental implants were placed
column6: initially planned in a suitable position
column7: with very good bone and soft tissue for their rehabilitation.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 15-year-old female patient

column5: of erythematous lesions on the pretibial surface of both legs
column6: symmetrical in shape
column7: which have increased in number and size and some have begun to change colour
column8: with a certain yellowish colour.  The patient reported a mild upper airway infection the previous week with no other symptoms. She denies taking any medication. Physical examination revealed no fever. Blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg
column9: heart rate: 60 beats per minute and normal cardiorespiratory auscultation. The lesions appeared as erythematous skin nodules
column10: slightly hyperthermic and painful on palpation
column11: ranging in diameter from 1 to 3 cm on the pretibial surface
column12: with no lesions observed at other sites. The patient was recommended rest and analgesia with paracetamol or NSAIDs
column13: and was referred to the dermatology department for a confirmatory biopsy. Given that the patient's physical examination was normal
column14: the following complementary tests were requested to reach an aetiological diagnosis: haematology
column15: formula
column16: blood count and ESR; biochemistry with liver
column17: kidney and thyroid function tests; proteinogram; calcium and phosphorus; rheumatoid factor
column18: C-reactive protein (CRP) and antinuclear antibodies (ANA). All values were within the normal range. A chest X-ray was also requested
column19: with no pathological findings; Mantoux was negative; ASLO was negative and Epstein Barr virus (EBV) serology was positive for IgG
column20: negative for IgM; pregnancy test was negative. After 15 days the lesions had practically disappeared. The biopsy gave the definitive diagnosis. Given the results of the complementary tests and the patient's evolution
column21: it was labelled as erythema nodosum of idiopathic aetiology.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Six-month-old female infant. Controlled pregnancy of normal course and no family history of interest. Programmed caesarean delivery due to breech presentation. Artificial lactation without incident. Correct vaccination schedule. Beginning of complementary feeding at five months of age (fruit and gluten-free cereals). Her parents consult because they have noticed
column2: since the introduction of fruit porridge
column3: the appearance of erythema on both temples a few minutes after starting to eat. They report that the symptoms are reproduced with any type of fruit intake and that the erythema increases in intensity as the amount of fruit ingested increases. The child does not refuse fruit and even eats it with a certain avidity. The erythema usually disappears after about ten minutes and is not accompanied by any other symptoms. As the patient was asymptomatic at the time of the examination
column4: it was decided to carry out a controlled provocation test in the consulting room. A few seconds after starting to eat
column5: erythematous
column6: faint red plaques with poorly defined limits suddenly appeared on the bilateral temporal region
column7: being more evident on the right side.  Based on the anamnesis
column8: physical examination and provocation test
column9: Frey's syndrome was suspected and the parents were informed of its benign and self-limiting nature. An expectant attitude was maintained
column10: with no need for complementary tests or treatment
column11: and the usual complementary feeding regime was maintained. After a month
column12: the clinical symptoms subside
column13: although the erythema reappears after 12 months with the consumption of natural yoghurt
column14: which is also acidic
column15: and disappears definitively after several weeks.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 58-year-old woman presented to hospital with pain in the popliteal fossa and vomiting of 48 hours' duration. Her history included DM
column2: hypertension
column3: dyslipidaemia
column4: hyperuricaemia
column5: congestive heart failure and depression. On admission
column6: vital signs were normal and examination showed signs of deep vein thrombosis. Blood tests showed normal ionic
column7: haematological
column8: renal and hepatic function. The patient was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis of the lower extremities by ultrasound and was treated with NPH insulin
column9: metformin (850 mg/12 hours)
column10: enoxaparin
column11: torasemide
column12: enalapril
column13: dipotassium clorazepate
column14: allopurinol
column15: mirtazapine and digoxin. During the first two days
column16: the patient continued to vomit and hardly ingested any liquids
column17: and 24 hours later
column18: she reported abdominal pain with asthenia
column19: vomiting
column20: visual disturbances and oliguria. On the fifth day of admission
column21: the patient suffered cardiac arrest due to ventricular fibrillation and
column22: after being resuscitated by the intensivist
column23: she was mydriatic
column24: anauric and with a Glasgow scale score of 3. Blood pressure was 120/45 mmHg (with noradrenaline)
column25: heart rate was 115 beats/minute and temperature was 36°C. The most significant analytical data are shown in table 2. During the first hours he received fluids
column26: 500 mEq of sodium bicarbonate and noradrenaline
column27: which restarted diuresis
column28: but arterial blood gas did not improve (pH 6.90 and bicarbonate 7.1 mEq/l). A haemodialysis session improved metabolic acidosis (pH 7.28 and bicarbonate 16 mEq/l) and hyperkalaemia (5.2 mEq/l). After overcoming aspiration pneumonia
column29: the patient was transferred to the ward in a vegetative state and died on the 19th day of admission.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 28 year old woman
column2: nursing assistant
column3: attended the emergency trauma department because she reported that for two days she had been experiencing pain in the subpatellar region of the right knee which had been worsening and she was currently having difficulty moving the joint. Physical examination revealed an erythematous lesion in the right subpatellar region
column4: with pain on palpation and a small incised-contuse wound a few millimetres long. Active and passive mobilisation is partially limited by the pain
column5: with no other accompanying symptoms. The worker refers that in childhood she had an osteochondroma in the same knee
column6: currently cured and without sequelae
column7: with the last control X-ray taken two months ago
column8: which was completely normal. The worker relates this episode to a work-related accident suffered two days ago
column9: in which she slipped and fell to the floor while carrying a box of 32 mercury thermometers in her hand. Some of the mercury thermometers fell on her right knee and caused an incised-contuse wound
column10: which we observed on examination still healing. The nursing assistant acknowledges that she was overworked at her workplace. The box in which she was transporting the thermometers was not closed
column11: the worker was not wearing gloves and the work clothes were not removed after the accident at work. Subsequently
column12: no hygienic-sanitary measures were taken and no appropriate action was taken to deal with the mercury spillage. In the emergency department
column13: the next step was to take an X-ray of the knee
column14: which revealed a metallic foreign body in the patellar bursa
column15: corresponding to mercury.  After the diagnosis of chemical bursitis due to mercury
column16: and taking into account the toxicity of the metal
column17: the patellar bursa was removed urgently in the operating theatre under scopia
column18: in order to avoid mercury remains in the worker's joint. Currently
column19: the auxiliary has no sequelae and has fully recovered from her injury.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a five-month-old female infant who consulted for progressive irritability over a ten-day period. She presented with isolated vomiting
column2: without fever or changes in urine or stools. In the last few days she began to have abdominal distension and on the same day of the consultation she presented with an expulsion of purulent exudate through the umbilicus
column3: for which reason she was referred from the Primary Care Department to the Emergency Department. She was a full-term newborn with an appropriate weight for gestational age. She had a controlled pregnancy
column4: with no infectious risk factors. The neonatal period was uneventful. Of note was omphalorhexis at 14 days of life
column5: with a small residual granuloma that required cauterisation with silver nitrate on two occasions. There was no history of wet umbilicus. On arrival at the emergency department
column6: the physical examination revealed a red tumour with spontaneous expulsion of pus in the umbilicus. The adjacent area was shiny and distended
column7: with no erythema or other inflammatory signs. The rest of the examination was compatible with normality. Vital signs were: temperature 36.1 °C
column8: heart rate 139 bpm
column9: blood pressure 98/51 mmHg and oxygen saturation 100% on room air.  An analytical control was carried out with a haemogram
column10: showing leukocytosis with normal formula and biochemistry with C-reactive protein (CRP) of 44 mg/l. A sample of umbilical exudate was collected for culture and intravenous antibiotic treatment was started with cloxacillin and gentamicin. Twenty-four hours after admission
column11: an ultrasound scan of the abdomen showed a heterogeneous collection measuring 5.5 × 2.5 × 2.4 cm adjacent to the upper area of the bladder towards the umbilicus
column12: with a diagnosis of a probable infected urachal cyst. Subsequently
column13: Staphycoccus aureus was isolated in exudate culture
column14: and treatment with cloxacillin was maintained
column15: with good evolution
column16: disappearance of inflammatory signs and purulent secretion. She was discharged six days after admission
column17: with follow-up by Paediatric Surgery.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 44-year-old woman with a history of ex-smoking
column2: hypertension
column3: type 2 DM
