column1: A 25 year old patient was referred to our clinic after an ultrasound study revealed a hypoechoic mass suggestive of neoplasia in the left teste. The patient consulted the speciality centre because he had noticed a painless enlargement of the left testicle for some days. His personal history included having suffered from a right testicular lift in childhood. At the age of 9 months
column2: he suffered a case of meningitis that left him with a permanent neurological deficit and residual seizures. In addition
column3: appendectomy and tenotomy of the Achilles in infancy. At our clinic
column4: she was asked for a new ultrasound scan
column5: tumour markers and an extension study using computerised axial tomography. The results of the tests showed a beta-HCG of 5.7 mIU/ml
column6: with normal lactate dehydrogenase and alpha-fetoprotein. Ultrasound showed an 8 cm mass in the left teste with multiple hypoechoic nodules compatible with a testicular tumour
column7: as well as microcalcifications in the right testicle. No adenopathies or metastases were seen in the thoraco-abdomino-pelvic CT scan. He underwent radical left orchiectomy via the inguinal route and the pathological anatomy analysis reported classic seminoma that did not infiltrate the albuginea or the cord
column8: nor was there any vascular or lymphatic invasion. With the diagnosis of classic Stage I Seminoma
column9: conservative treatment was chosen. At 10 months
column10: a control ultrasound study revealed a hypoechoic nodule in the right testicle suspicious of neoplasia. Physical examination and tumour markers were normal. A radical right orchiectomy was performed and the pathological anatomy study reported a classic type of seminoma with foci of Intratubular Germ Cell Neoplasia measuring approximately 4.5 cm. Vascular tracts
column11: albuginea and spermatic cord free of tumour. Hormone replacement therapy was also started. Three months later
column12: an increase in beta-HCG of up to 4.5 mIU/ml was detected
column13: with the rest of the tumour markers normal
column14: and a new thoraco-abdominal-pelvic CT scan was requested
column15: which revealed a retroperitoneal mass measuring 3 cm x 8 cm para-aortic below the left renal artery
column16: extending to the iliac bifurcation. Another 2 cm x 2 cm nodular image with a necrotic centre and peripheral contrast uptake is also seen more anteriorly. With the diagnosis of abdominal adenopathic relapse of classic seminoma
column17: treatment began with 4 cycles of Etoposide and Cisplatin. He has now been disease-free for approximately 7 years.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 31-year-old woman was admitted to the Internal Medicine Department of our hospital in 2008 for unquantified weight loss and vomiting of uncertain duration. The patient did not report any other device-related symptoms. During admission
column2: a complete biochemical study
column3: complete blood count and thyroid function were normal. Infectious pathology was ruled out
column4: with various serological tests
column5: determination of parasites in faeces
column6: etc.
column7: all of which were negative. The presence of digestive pathology was also ruled out
column8: specifically malabsorptive symptoms (upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (EDA)
column9: anti-gliadin and anti-endomysial antibodies
column10: duodenal biopsy: normal). The gastro-oesophagoduodenal study showed dilatation of the second duodenal portion in relation to extrinsic compression
column11: suggestive of aorto-mesenteric clamp; the diagnosis was confirmed by performing a CT angiography of the mesenteric artery. The patient was also assessed by psychiatry
column12: ruling out the presence of an eating disorder.  With the diagnosis of Wilkie syndrome
column13: she was referred to the Nutrition Department in November 2009. She reported a normal weight of 56 kg. At that time she weighed 43.9 kg and her body mass index (BMI) was 16.7 kg/m2. Initially
column14: nutritional management was attempted with dietary modifications
column15: postural measures and prescription of supplements
column16: without improvement; although at no time in the evolution of the patient did she present with retention stomach or hydroelectrolyte alterations. In January 2010
column17: at 42.6 kg
column18: a feeding tube was provisionally placed in order to attempt nutritional recovery through the administration of enteral nutrition (EN). Digestive tolerance was good and she did not present refeeding syndrome
column19: increasing her weight to 50 kg (BMI: 19). At that time
column20: an attempt was made to reintroduce natural foods
column21: but the vomiting reappeared
column22: so a new oesophagogastroduodenal study was performed
column23: with similar findings to the diagnosis. In view of this situation
column24: in agreement with the patient
column25: the General Surgery Department was consulted and surgical treatment was proposed. A duodenojejunostomy was performed. Oral tolerance after surgery was initially problematic in relation to gastric hypotonia
column26: and treatment with prokinetics was necessary. Two months after the operation the patient was completely asymptomatic
column27: with a weight of 50 kg
column28: oral tolerance was good and the barium study showed a stomach with normal morphology and emptying and good passage of contrast through the duodenojejunostomy. To date
column29: the patient has lost weight again (45 kg). She denies the existence of digestive symptoms
column30: and states that she feels thin and wishes to regain her lost weight; but refuses to take nutritional supplements
column31: as well as any medical tests and re-evaluation by the Psychiatry Service.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 44-year-old woman with a medical history of chronic renal failure on haemodialysis since 2005. In April 2010 she underwent a renal transplant from a cadaver donor
column2: following immunosuppressive treatment. On the fourth postoperative day
column3: the patient presented with fever
column4: worsening general condition and erythematous lesions on the right flank
column5: which rapidly evolved with the appearance of phlyctenas and skin necrosis. The Nephrology Department performed a biopsy and culture of the lesions and requested the collaboration of our department.  Given the clinical suspicion of necrotising fasciitis
column6: it was decided to start intravenous (IV) antibiotic therapy and perform immediate surgical debridement up to the muscular plane
column7: without including it
column8: covering an area of approximately 25 X 25 cm in the right flank and ribcage. We adjusted the immunosuppressive treatment
column9: maintaining only Prograf (Tacrolimus) and suspending Mycophenolate and Dacortin
column10: and started broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotic treatment with Ciprofloxacin (400 mg/12 hours)
column11: Teicoplanin (400 mg/12 hours)
column12: Clindamycin (600 mg/6 hours) and Tobramycin (50 mg/12 hours). Samples obtained for culture were positive for Escherichia coli. After debridement
column13: treatment was started with negative pressure therapy with VAC® system for 13 days at 125 mmHg and cures every 48 hours.  Once the problem area was clean
column14: granulated and free of infection (13 days after debridement)
column15: it was covered with autologous partial-thickness skin grafts again associated with VAC® therapy with Granofoam dressing at 125 mmHg for 10 days
column16: with the first dressing on the fourth day and then every 48 hours. In the first treatment after grafting
column17: we found that the graft was properly attached and with no signs of acute complications such as haematoma or infection
column18: which led us to withdraw antibiotic treatment and restart the suspended immunosuppressant treatment
column19: as recommended by the Nephrology Department.  After 24 days of hospitalisation
column20: the patient was discharged by our department and continued under a regime of outpatient occlusive dressings using antibiotic tulgrase and gauze impregnated with povidone iodine. The first outpatient plastic surgery appointment was made 2 weeks after hospital discharge (18 days post-grafting)
column21: at which time the problem area was found to be healed. At 6 months
column22: we performed an evolutionary control.  The therapeutic combination of IV antibiotics
column23: the suppression of 2 of the 3 immunosuppressants that the patient was taking due to her kidney transplant
column24: surgical debridement and VAC® therapy accelerated the wound cleaning and contraction process
column25: as well as helping the autologous partial skin grafts to take hold quickly and completely
column26: and the patient had acceptable skin coverage. The patient was offered the possibility of implanting 2 skin expanders and performing a more aesthetic reconstruction later

column1: We present the case of a seven-year-old girl who came to the emergency department for right palpebral ptosis and periorbital pain of 24 hours' duration
column2: which did not subside with the usual analgesics
column3: being afebrile
column4: with sporadic nausea and vomiting and without intercurrent infectious process. The patient had no personal or family history of interest
column5: except for an episode similar to the one described in the previous two years
column6: lasting two weeks
column7: which subsided spontaneously without medication. Physical examination revealed paralysis of the supraduction and adduction of the gaze of the right eye
column8: with eyelid ptosis
column9: without pupillary involvement or alteration of other cranial nerves. A complete blood count and general biochemistry
column10: erythrocyte sedimentation rate
column11: C-reactive protein
column12: glycosylated haemoglobin
column13: anti-DNA antibodies
column14: antinuclear antibodies (ANA)
column15: extractable nucleus antibodies (ENA)
column16: anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA)
column17: and cranial magnetic resonance imaging were performed
column18: all results being normal. Tolosa-Hunt syndrome was diagnosed and oral prednisone 1 mg/kg/day for five days was prescribed. Within 48 hours
column19: the patient was re-evaluated and presented complete resolution of ophthalmoplegia and pain
column20: with persistence of mild palpebral ptosis
column21: which was maintained for the next six months.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 80-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a painless left submandibular tumour that has been present for 2 months and has experienced progressive growth and increased consistency. It is not accompanied by constitutional syndrome. The patient's only history was renal lithiasis and arterial hypertension. Physical examination revealed a left submandibular mass approximately 4 cm in diameter
column2: hard in consistency
column3: adherent to deep planes
column4: which did not cause pain on palpation. There were no alterations in cervical mobility or facial expression. In the intraoral examination there was no inflammation of the floor of the mouth or Wharton's canal. An ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration puncture-fine needle aspiration (FNA) was performed
column5: which was reported as a carcinoma of undetermined nature. An MRI scan was requested and the report was compatible with a heterogeneous left submaxillary mass
column6: with internal necrosis
column7: measuring 3 × 4 × 3 cm
column8: which had imprinted on the floor of the mouth
column9: with no conclusive signs of infiltration of the supra-hyoid musculature and which respected the mandibular bone cortex.  With the diagnosis of malignant tumour of the submaxillary gland
column10: a type III left functional cervical dissection was performed
column11: including the hypoglossal nerve
column12: the digastric muscle and the marginal branch of the left facial nerve
column13: with a reaming of the left mandibular medial aspect. Histological analysis of the specimen shows a neoplastic proliferation with infiltrative borders
column14: growing in nests and cords
column15: consisting of cells with large cytoplasm and plasmacytoid and epithelioid morphology. The nuclei are atypical with moderate pleomorphism
column16: prominent nucleolus and 11 mitoses/10 high magnification fields. The cells are arranged within a hyalinised stroma. Extensive areas of necrosis and foci of squamous differentiation are seen. No ductal structures are seen. The immunohistochemical study shows that the neoplastic cells are positive for CKAE1/AE3
column17: actin
column18: calponin
column20: S-100 protein and GFAP
column21: and negative for CEA. The proliferative index (Ki67) is 25%. The tumour is completely resected and the distance to the nearest resection margin is less than 1 mm. The lymph nodes are negative for malignancy. This report is compatible with the diagnosis of myoepithelial carcinoma of the submaxillary gland pT3-N0
column22: MX. Following a multidisciplinary consensus
column23: postoperative radiotherapy was decided. The total dose of radiotherapy received was 60 Gy
column24: divided into 30 sessions. The patient is being followed up in outpatient clinics 3 years after the surgery and
column25: after serial control MRI and CT scans
column26: no signs of tumour recurrence or metastasis were observed.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 56-year-old woman was initially evaluated for intestinal disorders. Initial physical examination and routine laboratory workup were normal. An abdominal ultrasound revealed a 12 cm solid mass behind the left kidney with abnormal vascularity. Computed tomography showed a well-circumscribed mass behind the left kidney that enhanced after intravenous contrast administration and had a clear fatty plane between the left kidney and the mass. A fine needle puncture was performed to obtain histology. The pathology report was of a benign or low malignant potential mesenchymal tumour. Laparoscopic exploration was decided.  Surgical technique: Under general anaesthesia the patient was positioned in right lateral decubitus after placement of an orogastric and bladder catheter. A single dose of cephalothin 2gr was administered intravenously. Pneumoperitoneum was performed with a Veress needle at 12 mmHg. Two trocars of 1 2 mm and 5 mm respectively were placed forming a rhombus as shown in Figure 3. The colon and spleen were widely mobilised towards the midline. After opening Gerota's fascia the mass was clearly visualised over the outer edge of the kidney. Preserving the tumour borders
column2: the mass was released from its contact with the renal capsule. An area of 2cm was observed firmly adhered to the renal capsule requiring resection and subsequent argon laser fulguration of the cruciate bed. The surgical specimen was removed in a plastic bag by oblique extension of the left flank trocar incision. A Blake drain was left through the 5 mm trocar opening. The operative time was 135 minutes with an estimated bleeding of 200 ml. The patient progressed favourably and was discharged on the third postoperative day. The final pathological analysis revealed a very low grade leiomyosarcoma. After a follow-up of 6 months the patient has recovered completely with no evidence of her underlying disease.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present a case with complex lithiasic pathology in which the stone sweeper was used as a bilateral internal urinary diversion. The patient was a 54-year-old male patient with 3 right renal lithiasis
column2: the largest of which was 1.2 cm in the lower calyx
column3: with moderate pyelocaliceal and ureteral dilatation up to the junction with the iliac vessels
column4: where a ureteral lithiasis of 1.1 cm was located; a stone sweeper catheter was placed in this renal unit prior to ESWL treatment. On the left side
column5: a 1 cm lithiasis was found in the lower pole
column6: which had previously been treated with ESWL
column7: achieving partial fragmentation; a stone sweeper catheter was also placed in this renal unit prior to a second ESWL session. The calibre of this catheter is 6.5 Fr and was maintained for a period of one month.  During the two stone sweeper catheters the patient reported no upper or lower urinary tract related symptoms indicating good tolerance. The removal of the catheters was easy
column8: without anaesthesia and small lithiasis fragments were observed inside the baskets.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 29-year-old man with a history of two admissions for febrile syndrome in the last two years. On one occasion
column2: in June 1999
column3: he was diagnosed with infectious mononucleosis with positive serology for EBV (positive VCA IgG
column4: VCA IgM and EBNA). On the other
column5: in September 2000
column6: after presenting with a 10-day clinical picture of fever with chills
column7: asthenia and general malaise with persistent positive serology for EBV
column8: and an abdominal ultrasound scan revealed splenomegaly with a hypoechoic lesion which
column9: after responding favourably to antibiotic treatment (broad-spectrum coverage)
column10: he was discharged with a diagnosis of splenic abscess. Since then
column11: he remained asymptomatic until he was readmitted in June 2001 with a fever of one week's duration
column12: accompanied by chills
column13: headache
column14: odynophagia and weight loss
column15: with no other accompanying symptoms. Physical examination revealed a temperature of 39ºC
column16: general malaise
column17: cutaneous and mucosal pallor and splenomegaly. Laboratory tests showed normocytic anaemia (Hb 11.9 g/dl
column18: Ht 35.8% and MCV 91.8 fl)
column19: thrombopenia (44
column20: 000 platelets/mm3)
column21: normal white blood cells (7
column22: 440/mm3) with neutrophilia (77%) and left deviation (7%Cay)
column23: slightly elevated transaminases (GPT 48 IU/L) and cholestasis enzymes (GGT 88 IU/L
column24: FA 232 IU/L). The rest of the biochemical parameters
column25: the coagulation study and the elemental urinalysis were normal. Proteinogram
column26: immunoglobulin determination and immunological study were normal. Various microbiological studies were performed
column27: including serology for hepatitis viruses (A
column28: B and C)
column29: retroviruses (HIV-1 and 2)
column30: typhoid
column31: brucella
column32: mycoplasma
column33: legionella (with determination of urine antigen)
column34: herpes
column35: CMV
column36: and toxoplasma
column37: which were negative. The results of EBV serology were IgG anti-VCA IgG and IgG anti-EBNA positive and IgM anti-VCA negative. The rest of the microbiological studies (blood cultures
column38: sputum cultures and urine cultures
column39: which included the study of mycobacteria) were negative. Imaging tests
column40: specifically the abdominal CT scan
column41: showed a focal splenic lesion (which was related to abscess or infarction)
column42: enlarged lymph nodes at the para-aortic level and mesenteric adenopathies. In other studies
column43: the results (microbiological and histopathological) obtained from liver and bone marrow biopsy were negative. Given the initial diagnostic suspicion of intra-abdominal abscess
column44: antibiotic treatment was started with ceftazidime
column45: metronidazole and vancomycin
column46: with a slight clinical improvement. Subsequently
column47: given the aforementioned history and clinical picture
column48: and in order to rule out
column49: among other diagnostic possibilities
column50: a lymphoproliferative process
column51: a diagnostic laparotomy was performed under general anaesthesia. In this intervention
column52: a significant splenomegaly
column53: focal thickening of the hepatic capsule of the left hepatic lobe
column54: a small peritoneal nodule in the mesentery of the distal ileum and multiple small lymphadenopathies at the same level were found
column55: samples were obtained from all of them and a splenectomy was performed. Histological study of the lymph nodes indicated reactive lymphadenitis in the lymph nodes
column56: calcified granuloma in the peritoneal nodule and no relevant findings in the sample from the left hepatic lobe. The splenectomy specimen
column57: which weighed 442 grams and measured 15 x 11 cm in greatest diameter
column58: had a subcapsular nodule of 2 cm in greatest diameter
column59: homogeneous and whitish. The remaining splenic tissue was congestive in appearance and showed no pathology. Microscopic analysis revealed a proliferation of spindle and myofibroblastic cells
column60: with positive immunohistochemical studies for actin and negative for ALK 1 and EBV
column61: and the pathological diagnosis was inflammatory pseudotumour of the spleen. The patient evolved favourably and has remained asymptomatic ever since.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 45-year-old male patient with a history of smoking and hypercholesterolemia
column2: suffering from severe acute coronary artery disease who underwent quadruple coronary artery bypass grafting with extracoronary circulation. Transesophageal echocardiography showed an ejection fraction of 8-10%. The patient was intubated and kept on mechanical ventilation for 9 days in the intensive care unit (ICU). After extubation
column3: he began to experience increased respiratory frequency
column4: reduced oxygen saturation and oxyhaemoglobin values
column5: so he was reintubated and reconnected to the mechanical ventilator
column6: which was maintained until the twelfth day
column7: when it could be definitively withdrawn. Once the patient's condition stabilised
column8: he was transferred to the cardiology department. On the eighth day on the ward he began to experience dyspnoea
column9: stridor
column10: intense respiratory work and tachypnoea
column11: for which he was again transferred to the ICU. Given the symptoms of upper airway obstruction
column12: an urgent fibrobronchoscopy was performed
column13: which revealed complex tracheal stenosis. A cervical computed tomography (CT) scan showed tracheal stenosis at the proximal end of 66% at approximately 2 cm from the glottis with peritracheal fibrosis and a 5 mm lumen.  It was decided to perform rigid bronchoscopy to place a tracheal prosthesis. Rigid bronchoscopy was combined with Nd-YAG laser therapy on the lesion and subsequent mechanical resection with a rigid bronchoscope. After tracheal recanalisation
column14: a silicone prosthesis (Dumon 14/40) is placed
column15: which is correctly anchored and permeable with the proximal end about 2.5 cm from the cords and the distal end about 7 cm from the carina. At the 7-day check-up
column16: the prosthesis is still fully permeable and the respiratory symptoms have been definitively resolved.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 13-year-old female patient
column2: with no personal history of interest
column3: consulted for bilateral palpebral oedema of three days' evolution. In the subsequent anamnesis she reported accompanying headache with slight odynophagia
column4: without associated fever. Physical examination revealed bilateral eyelid oedema with no other ocular involvement
column5: no oedema in other locations and tonsillar hypertrophy 2/4 with no exudates. In the following days he consulted again up to three times due to persistent and increased eyelid oedema
column6: with no other symptoms. A urine dipstick was performed on several occasions without detecting proteinuria and a culture of pharyngeal exudate was negative. In view of the clinical findings and the negative results of the tests performed to date
column7: a blood count
column8: blood biochemistry
column9: liver profile and urine sediment were requested
column10: with normal results except for leukocytosis (18
column11: 460/µl) with lymphocyte predominance (61.8%) and increased transaminases (GOT 139 IU/l
column12: GPT 184 IU/l). Ten days after the onset of the disease
column13: the eyelid oedema resolved
column14: with no evidence of fever
column15: lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly. A blood test was performed three weeks later and the haemogram showed no abnormalities and transaminases decreased to normal values (GOT 22 IU/l
column16: GPT 16 IU/l). Suspecting mononucleosis syndrome
column17: serology for EBV and cytomegalovirus (CMV) was requested
column18: obtaining positive IgM against EBV
column19: which allowed the diagnosis to be confirmed.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 74 year old woman was admitted to hospital for obnubilation and anuria after presenting for 5 days with abdominal pain and vomiting. Her history included DM treated with metformin (850 mg/8 h) and glibenclamide. Blood pressure was 105/60 mmHg
column2: heart rate was 155 beats/minute and temperature 36.7ºC. Examination revealed severe dehydration
column3: disorientation
column4: Kussmaul's respiration
column5: abdominal pain with weak peristalsis and absence of abdominal defence. Table 2 shows the main analytical data
column6: highlighting in addition a hyperamylasaemia of 2
column7: 605 U/l. An abdominal CT scan revealed an enlarged pancreatic head suggestive of acute pancreatitis. After discontinuation of metformin administration
column8: the patient was intubated orotracheally and connected to a mechanical ventilator. She also received fluid therapy with potassium supplementation
column9: noradrenaline
column10: bicarbonate
column11: insulin
column12: amiodarone
column13: imipen and furosemide. On the second day of admission
column14: after administering 750 mEq of bicarbonate and 140 mEq of potassium
column15: acid-base balance (pH 7.41 and bicarbonate 20 mEq/l) and water-electrolyte balance (sodium 147 mEq/l
column16: potassium 3.5 mEq/l) normalised and creatinine decreased to 5.5 mg/dl. On the third day of admission
column17: due to the presence of repeated mucous stools
column18: a colonoscopy was performed which revealed a sessile polypoid formation located next to the anal sphincter and measuring 14 cm in length. The endoscopic specimen was reported as a villous adenoma of the rectum. On the seventh day of admission the patient was extubated
column19: and two days later she was transferred to the ward for removal of the adenoma.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 77-year-old man with a history of chronic atrial fibrillation who suffered massive intestinal ischaemia with resection of the jejunum
column2: ileum
column3: ascending colon and half of the transverse colon and underwent jejuno-colic anastomosis. After a hospital stay of two months he was sent home with NPD seven days a week
column4: infusing for 10 hours. His usual caregiver was his 72-year-old wife
column5: who had incipient Parkinson's disease. He also had a very involved close family. NPD was maintained for 11 years
column6: being discontinued following clinical deterioration caused by community-acquired pneumonia. The total duration was 3
column7: 940 days. During this period she had 5 catheter-associated infections (infection rate: 1.3 episodes per 1
column8: 000 days of NPD) and 1 accidental catheter exit. The catheter needed to be replaced 4 times (catheter half-life: 788 days). He had mild
column9: non-progressive hepatic steatosis since two years after the onset of NPD. He was hospitalised on four occasions due to complications of the technique. His functional status at the start of NPD was that of an active independent life and he became sedentary but autonomous at the end of NPD. During the first eight years of NPD he travelled once or twice a year for a few days' holiday at the beach.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 66-year-old male
column2: active smoker
column3: with a history of partial gastrectomy for ulcer disease and chronic hepatopathy due to HCV under regular follow-up. He was admitted for digestive haemorrhage in the form of melaena accompanied by pain in the right hip of several weeks' evolution
column4: radiating down the antero-lateral side of the thigh to the knee; he also reported constitutional syndrome with a weight loss of 6 kg. Physical examination revealed pain on palpation in the right femoral head and discrete hepatomegaly of 2 cm
column5: while basic biochemical and haemocyte data were normal
column6: except for discrete anaemia; serum levels of αFP were 4.4 ng/ml. Abdominal CT scan showed an 8 x 7 x 5 cm mass in the right hepatic lobe with heterogeneous contrast uptake
column7: suggestive of HCC; conventional radiology of the pelvis and hip revealed a lytic image with a moth-eaten pattern at the level of the neck and right femoral head. Bone scintigraphy (99mTc) showed a pathological accumulation of radiotracer at this level
column8: as well as in the left supraorbital region. Finally
column9: the histological study by biopsy of the lesion in the femoral neck confirmed the diagnosis of HCC metastasis. Chemoembolisation of the primary tumour was performed
column10: associated with palliative radiotherapy on the coxofemoral joint (total dose of 2
column11: 400 cGy)
column12: with evident symptomatic improvement. Six months later
column13: the patient presented a pathological subtrochanteric fracture that required ostesynthesis using a PFN nail
column14: and died 20 weeks after the intervention.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 32-year-old man
column2: with no pathological history of interest and no previous treatment
column3: operated on for tearing of the splenic hilum
column4: mesentery of the root of the jejunum and superior mesenteric artery (SMA) due to trauma. Resection of the right colon
column5: ileum and 2/3 of the jejunum with jejunostomy and splenectomy was performed. After the postoperative period and undergoing TPN
column6: progressive oral tolerance was started with sugar infusions
column7: defatted broths
column8: alkaline lemonade (WHO formula) to introduce small and frequent oral intakes of elemental enteral formula (Elemental 0.28 Extra liquid®) and 3 intakes of 5 grams of glutamine (Adamín G®) in order to stimulate trophism and adaptation of the enterocyte. At 6 months
column9: the 12 cm of jejunum is anastomosed with the left colon and cholecystectomy is performed to avoid further choleretic diarrhoea. From this point on
column10: the objective is to maintain a stable nutritional status
column11: a diuresis of more than 1 litre/day and control of diarrhoea
column12: assessing daily balances and determining haematological and biochemical parameters twice a week. Nutritional management It is structured as follows: a) Parenteral nutrition: TPN is replaced by 2 litres of Isoplasmar G® with the addition of an ampoule of 10 mEq of potassium/litre and the vitamin module (Addamel®) on alternate days with the trace element module (Cernevit®). b) Oral enteral nutrition: 4-5 intakes of "Elemental 0.28 Extra Liquid" and 3 intakes of 5 g of "Adamín G®" are maintained interspersed with food. c) Oral hydration: "alkaline lemonade" is given on demand and between meals. d) Feeding: with progressive criteria
column13: starting with easily digestible and easily absorbed foods and with less secretory stimulus to continue with those of greater difficulty. From a diet of simple carbohydrates and cooked starches
column14: depending on the rhythm
column15: volume and characteristics of the faeces
column16: protein foods (skimmed dairy products
column17: egg whites
column18: fish and lean meats) are included
column19: followed by the addition of oil
column20: to then assess tolerance to cooked vegetables and pulses. In all cases
column21: small
column22: frequent and easy-to-prepare intakes are recommended. e) Medication: to reduce chlorhydropeptide secretion and stimulate the secretion of water and pancreatic bicarbonate
column23: omeprazole (40 mg/day) is combined with 2 capsules of pancreatic enzymes (Kreon 10
column24: 000®) with food intake to facilitate the digestibility of natural foods and their absorption. The appearance of abdominal distention due to fermentation resulting from the excess HC in the first phase accelerated the transition to a normal
column25: highly fractionated diet free of fried foods
column26: animal fats and moderate HC
column27: and the aerocolia was controlled. Three months after jejunocolic anastomosis
column28: nutritional stability
column29: diuresis and 4-6 liquid-pasty stools were maintained. He was discharged from hospital with the aforementioned treatment and with a reservoir for nocturnal fluid therapy of 1-2 litres of Isoplasmar G depending on diuresis. He was evaluated by the intestinal transplant unit of the Ramón y Cajal Hospital in Madrid and 14 months after starting enteral nutrition
column30: the indication for transplant was rejected due to his good nutritional status. Fluid therapy was suspended
column31: maintaining diuresis above 1
column32: 200 mL/day
column33: 3-5 stools of pasty or formed consistency (depending on the type of intake) and stable anthropometric and analytical parameters with hypolipaemia. The rapid loss of 7-8 kg after withdrawal of fluid therapy is noteworthy
column34: finally stabilising at 64 kg
column35: for a height of 175 cm and a usual weight of 70 kg. She is independent and maintains moderate physical activity. She follows a free diet with frequent small meals
column36: limited only by specific intolerances
column37: and frequently drinks mineralised beverages. He has been prescribed: "Elemental 0.28 Extra Liquid" (800 kcal/day)
column38: 2 capsules of "Kreon 10.000®" with each meal
column39: 2 tablets of "Supradyn®" (double the RDA for micronutrients) and 1.000 mcg of vitamin B12 im per month. During the course of the evolution
column40: a depletion of vitamins D
column41: B12 and folic acid was detected
column42: which was corrected with the corresponding shock dose. Tables I
column43: II and III show the analytical determinations of nutrients carried out during the period from 6 months after the intervention to the last one carried out
column44: where a stable and progressive nutritional state within normality is observed.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 25-year-old man was stung by a stingray while fishing on the inner surface of the right ankle
column2: with intense
column3: burning pain
column4: initially treated at a local hospital with treatment and administration of systemic antibiotics; as he did not show an adequate clinical response
column5: he was referred to our health institution. On admission to hospital
column6: the patient presented with a very painful
column7: deep lesion in the posterior region of the internal malleolus of the right foot
column8: with necrosis of the overlying skin and abundant discharge of purulent and fetid material. We diagnosed soft tissue infection and he was hospitalised for surgical debridement and antibiotic treatment (Clindamycin 600 mg every 8 hours and Amikacin 1 g daily). X-rays were taken of the right ankle in which soft tissue oedema was observed
column9: with no evidence of radio-opaque fragments that might correspond to the remains of the venomous sting. In the operating theatre
column10: drainage of the collection of purulent material and debridement of the necrotic tissue were performed
column11: creating a 7 x 5 cm tissue defect on the internal malleolus of the right ankle
column12: with exposure of the Achilles tendon and the posterior edge of the tibia; soft tissue culture was also performed.  Laboratory tests showed: leucocytes 7200/ul
column13: with 60% neutrophils
column14: haemoglobin 10.7g/dL
column15: haematocrit 31.8%
column16: creatinine 0.9 mg/dL
column17: C-reactive protein 3.13mg/dL and erythrocyte sedimentation rate 81 mm. We performed two additional debridements due to persistent discharge and residual necrotic tissue on the third and fifth day of hospitalisation. The culture result detected the presence of Proteus vulgaris
column18: sensitive to Amikacin. On the 9th day
column19: we decided to cover the remaining defect with a reverse-flow saphenous-internal fasciocutaneous saphenous-internal flap. We debrided the edges of the defect
column20: leaving a final loss of substance of 8x3 cm; for the coverage we designed a skin island with the same dimensions and then we closed the donor area of the flap in a primary way.  The patient's evolution was satisfactory
column21: with adequate infection control and successful healing.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 74-year-old female patient was admitted with diffuse abdominal pain
column2: hyporexia and asthenia of 2 weeks' duration. She had been vomiting coffee grounds and melenic stools for 2 days. Her personal history included hypertension under treatment with amiloride/hydrochlorothiazide and dyslipidaemia controlled with lovastatin. She was a non-smoker and denied taking NSAIDs
column3: alcohol or oral contraceptives. Her family history was: mother died of gastric cancer
column4: brother with liver cirrhosis of unknown aetiology and sister with hepatocellular carcinoma. - Physical examination: haemodynamic stability. Diffuse pain on abdominal palpation
column5: with no signs of peritonism. - Laboratory tests on admission: haemoglobin: 13.5 mg/dl; haematocrit: 37.6%; platelets: 120
column6: 000 platelets/ml; bilirubin: 247 mg/dl; alkaline phosphatase: 220 UI/l; aspartate aminotransferase: 59 UI/l; alanine aminotransferase: 28 UI/l and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase: 129 UI/l. An emergency gastroscopy showed medium-sized oesophageal varices with no warning signs of imminent bleeding [F2 RC(-) according to the classification of the Japanese Society for the Study of Portal Hypertension] and multiple erosions with fibrin at gastric and duodenal level with no signs of recent haemostasis. On computed tomography and abdominal ultrasound
column7: the liver was of normal size
column8: with slightly undulating borders and a slightly heterogeneous parenchyma
column9: with no space-occupying lesions. Splenomegaly
column10: ascites and a small left pleural effusion were also observed. On the other hand
column11: there was a complete non-occlusive portal thrombosis at the level of the hepatic hilum and its branches
column12: as well as another thrombus at the level of the superior mesenteric vein with the presence of collateral circulation in the gastrohepatic and periesplenic ligaments. The aetiological study of the different causes of chronic liver disease included: hepatotropic viruses (HBV
column13: HCV) and HIV
column14: study of autoimmunity
column15: ceruloplasmin
column16: ferritin and porphyrins in urine
column17: all results being negative. Subsequently
column18: a percutaneous liver biopsy was performed with a haemodynamic study showing a portal pressure gradient of 12 mmHg with normal phlebography. The biopsy showed altered liver architecture due to hepatocyte hyperplasia in zone 1 of some of the acini
column19: with a tendency to be nodular but without perinodular fibrosis septa. The portal tracts showed the usual duct-artery-vein triad
column20: although the vein was sometimes inconspicuous and some paraportal vein was observed. They showed mild fibrous enlargement and contained a mild lymphoplasmacytic inflammatory infiltrate with focal overflow through the periportal interface. Some inflammatory foci were also observed in the lobule
column21: although there were no acidophilic bodies or other relevant findings. These mild fibroinflammatory changes
column22: the irregular nodular hyperplasia and the absence of perinodular fibrosis rule out the presence of cirrhosis and are compatible with non-cirrhotic portal hypertension. Given the possibility that all hepatic changes were secondary to primary portal thrombosis
column23: a hypercoagulability study was performed.  This study showed an antigenic free protein S (pS)
column24: total antigenic pS and anticoagulant free pS of 56
column25: 107 and 44% respectively
column26: which was suggestive of a type I protein S deficiency. All other coagulation parameters (including fibrinogen
column27: antithrombin
column28: protein C
column29: anticardiolipin antibodies
column30: activated protein C resistance
column31: factor V Leyden
column32: factor II G 20210A and homocysteine) were in the normal range. This result was confirmed in a subsequent control. The patient was placed on anticoagulant treatment with acenocoumarol and diuretics indefinitely. No new decompensations have been observed in the patient's follow-up.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: a 33-year-old patient was taken to the emergency department for a bleeding cut on his neck caused by falling over a shop window. In the emergency department an incised trauma was seen in the right antero-lateral region of the neck with a clean dissection involving only the superficial tissues and no apparent damage to the rest of the structures
column3: so the suture was made in planes. On 4-09-06 she attended the emergency department of our hospital for examination of the wound
column4: reporting headache and blurred vision in the right eye (OD). In the ophthalmological examination the uncorrected visual acuity with the OD was 1 and with the left eye (LA) 1. The intraocular pressure was 12 mm Hg in the OD and 13 mm Hg in the LA. Extrinsic ocular motility was normal except for a right palpebral ptosis of 3 mm with good levator function. The pupil of the OD measured 2.0 mm and that of the OI 4.0 mm. The external examination and palpation of the neck
column5: except for the trauma findings
column6: were normal. A cervical CT scan showed a large haematoma with internal growth that was significantly compressing the trachea
column7: so it was decided to perform an intraoperative exploration and evacuation
column8: where a solution of continuity was observed in the external jugular vein that was leaking into deep planes. Five months later
column9: Horner's syndrome had disappeared.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 80-year-old woman reported the presence of a lump in her left breast for sixteen years which she had been reluctant to consult for fear of the diagnosis and possible treatments. Although she reported that at first the growth had been slow and indolent
column2: in the last two years it had progressed to the point of self-amputation of the breast. She had finally come to the clinic encouraged by her relatives after presenting with progressive back pain and dyspnoea
column3: more evident in the previous weeks. At that time she had ipsilateral axillary and supraclavicular lymphadenopathies. Chest X-ray showed signs of pleural effusion and probable carcinomatous lymphangitis. Bone scintigraphy showed multiple uptakes. The clinical diagnosis was confirmed by puncture of a nodule protruding above the breast bed; cytology was compatible with infiltrating ductal carcinoma. The patient started treatment with tamoxifen. Two days later she suddenly presented with a significant worsening of her back pain
column4: which necessitated an increase in analgesia. Over the next two weeks
column5: the patient herself gradually withdrew the analgesics until they were discontinued. After a transient elevation
column6: both CA153 and alkaline phosphatase decreased to normal levels. After six months
column7: the lymphadenopathies had completely resolved
column8: although a small remnant remained in the breast bed; the scintigraphy showed some attenuation of the hypercaptured areas and there was a clear improvement in the pulmonary involvement. The patient remained responsive for 22 months. After progression she received several lines of hormonal treatment. She died 56 months after diagnosis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 69-year-old man came to us for a check-up for prostatic syndrome in treatment with an alpha-blocker. He had undergone surgery on the right hip
column2: hypoacusis and repeated angina. He had an episode of left costolumbar trauma some 30 years ago. Urological history of haematuria on two occasions
column3: the last time a year ago. On examination
column4: the prostate had fibroadenomatous characteristics
column5: volume II/IV
column6: with no nodulation. On abdominal palpation
column7: there was a large mass located in the left hypochondrium and left void
column8: painful on palpation. Laboratory tests: Hb 14.6 g/dl
column9: Hcto. 43.1%
column10: ESR 9 mm/h and biochemistry within normal limits. PSA: 3.1 ng/ml. Simple X-ray: large mass effect located in the left hypochondrium and left void
column11: ovoid in shape
column12: totally calcified.  In view of these findings
column13: a differential diagnosis with any mass located in the retroperitoneum with this type of calcification is considered: - Primitive retroperitoneal tumours - Adrenal tumours - Renal tumours - Metastatic tumours - Infectious pathology Blood determinations of plasma renin activity before and after ambulation
column14: as well as aldosterone and cortisol at 8 and 20 hours are performed
column15: the results being within normal range. Urine levels of 17-ketosteroids and corticosteroids
column16: as well as catecholamines
column17: metanephrines and vanillylmandelate were normal. All of the above ruled out a functioning adrenal tumour. Stains for acid fast bacilli in urine and sputum were also negative
column18: as was the Mantoux test. The possibility of a calcified hydatid cyst was raised
column19: but serology was negative. The previously suffered left costolumbar trauma was also considered as a possible cause of the calcified adrenal mass. With the diagnosis of a retroperitoneal mass without filiation
column20: exploratory laparotomy was performed
column21: finding a protruding lesion in the left hypochondrium
column22: hard to palpation
column23: with fixation to deep planes and diffuse lesions distributed throughout the peritoneum
column24: with the intraoperative anatomopathological report of peritoneal fat infiltrated by a malignant tumour of probable mesenchymal origin. It was decided to close the abdominal cavity as it was a disseminated malignant process. The definitive pathological report was pleomorphic liposarcoma
column25: with immunohistochemical techniques of: S100: positive; Oil-Red: positive; vimentin: positive; PS 3: positive; desmin: negative.  The patient was discharged on the seventh day after the operation and died two weeks later at home.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A four year old male child was referred from the diagnostic service of the Universidad Mayor to the Dr. Luis Calvo Mackenna Paediatric Hospital for evaluation of an increase in volume in the right mandibular area
column2: asymptomatic and of undetermined evolution. The mother reported that she had not noticed the increase in volume until the time of referral
column3: and that the child never complained of pain or functional impotence. The patient had no relevant morbid or surgical history. Extraoral examination revealed an enlargement involving the body and right mandibular ramus
column4: firm and painless on palpation
column5: with no skin involvement. There were no adenopathies. There was also no associated sensory involvement and the mandibular functional examination was normal.  On intraoral examination
column6: the patient had complete primary dentition and a large increase in volume involving the body and the right side ramus
column7: the mucosa covering it was undamaged
column8: painless on palpation and hard in consistency.  In the panoramic Cone Beam view
column9: an extensive well-defined unilocular radiolucent lesion could be observed
column10: with variable content of radiopacities similar to dental structures
column11: extending from the distal root of the second temporal molar to the upper area of the right mandibular ramus
column12: equivalent to 45mm in the mesiodistal direction
column13: 30mm in the vestibulo-lingual direction and 35mm in the cephalo-caudal direction. The lesion produced displacement towards the basilar edge of the first permanent molar germ
column14: while the second permanent molar was not observed. The anterior border of the ramus
column15: the alveolar ridge and the basilar border were involved. In the coronal section
column16: the expansion of the vestibular bone table and the inferior displacement of the lower dental canal were particularly visible.  An incisional biopsy of the lesion was performed. Histopathological examination with haematoxylin-eosin staining showed fibrous connective tissue with areas of dental tissue with varying degrees of calcification similar to dentine or dentinoid tissue
column17: all in relation to odontogenic epithelium. In addition
column18: areas similar to dental papilla were observed with epithelial proliferation arranged in cords and islets with periphery similar to ameloblasts
column19: and towards the centre tissue reminiscent of stellate reticulum. The histopathological diagnosis was FOA.  With this diagnosis
column20: definitive surgery was planned. Under general anaesthesia
column21: the approach was performed at the level of the anterior border of the right mandibular ramus. Bone exposure showed a significant expansion of the mandibular vestibular bone table
column22: over which an osteotomy was performed to allow access and subsequent complete enucleation
column23: followed by conditioning of the cavity and suturing with Vycril 4.0.  Postoperative management of the patient involved antibiotic therapy and conventional analgesia in conjunction with revulsives and a soft diet. The latter was prolonged for one month. The patient is maintained with periodic controls in the immediate and late postoperative period and
column24: currently
column25: after one year postoperatively

column1: A 64-year-old male patient attended the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Department of the Hospital Universitario Central de Asturias with squamous cell carcinoma affecting the lingual border
column2: the lateral oropharyngeal wall
column3: the tonsillar area and the left soft hemipalate. There were also large metastatic adenopathies in the vascular axes and in the submaxillary regions on both sides of the neck. In a first surgical step
column4: the tumour was resected
column5: a classic left cervical radical resection and a reconstruction of the defect with a microvascularised anterolateral fasciocutaneous microfasciocutaneous thigh flap. Three weeks later
column6: a classic right radical cervical resection was performed. Due to the magnitude of the surgery and in anticipation of possible postoperative complications
column7: an elective rule tracheotomy was also performed in the first operation
column8: using the Björk flap as a means of opening the trachea. The tracheostomy was maintained until several days after the second operation
column9: with spontaneous closure of the tracheostoma occurring after decannulation of the patient and release of the tracheal flap attachment to the skin.  Subsequently
column10: the patient received complementary radiotherapy treatment of the oral cavity
column11: the oropharynx and cervical lymph node levels I to VI. A control cervicothoracic CT scan
column12: requested 4 months after surgery
column13: revealed the existence of a small mass compatible with a neoplastic process in the right middle lobe of the lung
column14: for which reason he was referred to the Pneumology Department. A bronchoscopy was then performed

column16: black in colour
column17: about 2.5 cm long
column18: inserted at one end into the anterior tracheal wall. An attempt was made to remove it
column19: but when it was found to be firmly fixed
column20: and to avoid possible tears in the tracheal wall
column21: it was decided not to do so. Finally
column22: the lung mass turned out to be inflammatory in nature and resolved spontaneously.  In relation to the tracheal suture thread
column23: the only symptomatology reported by the patient was an occasional foreign body sensation

column2: after ultrastructural examination and IHC

column4: complete remission at one year and after three years there was no evidence of local or distant recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 61-year-old male patient was referred to our clinic for an incidental ultrasound finding of a renal mass following a study of epigastralgia. His personal history included cholelithiasis and right hydrocelectomy. In the anamnesis
column2: the patient did not report pain in the renal fossa
column3: haematuria
column4: episodes of urinary infection
column5: asthenia
column6: anorexia or weight loss. Physical examination revealed no abdominal masses or megaliths. Ultrasound showed an exophytic nodule measuring 4 x 2 cm in diameter at the level of the upper pole of the right kidney with solid and cystic areas
column7: with vascularised areas (Doppler ultrasound). Given the diagnosis of a complex renal mass
column8: an abdomino-pelvic CT scan was requested
column9: which showed a complex cystic lesion at renal level
column10: and it was impossible to definitively determine its benign nature. We performed an abdominal MRI which identified the mass measuring 4.2 x 3.3 x 3 cm
column11: hypointense in T1 sequences and markedly hyperintense in T2 sequences
column12: with several linear septa inside
column13: linear enhancement of the walls of the cyst and the internal septa after administering gadolinium
column14: making it diagnostic of a minimally complicated cystic mass.  Given the diagnostic uncertainty of the CT scan and the ultrasound findings (Bosniak grade III renal cyst)
column15: we decided to perform a surgical exploration and by means of an incision in the flank we performed a lumpectomy. Subsequent evolution was satisfactory and the histological study confirmed the presence of a Fuhrman grade I multilocular cystic clear cell renal cell carcinoma
column16: with negative resection margins. In the control CT scan 6 months after the operation
column17: we can observe the post-surgical changes at the level of the renal cortex and adjacent fat
column18: with no evidence of local recurrence. The patient is currently asymptomatic
column19: being reviewed every 6 months with ultrasound and annually with CT.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 77-year-old woman with a single history of arterial hypertension. She presented with a clinical picture consisting of gait ataxia
column2: sphincter incontinence and disturbance of higher functions. Neuroimaging studies showed dilatation of the ventricular system
column3: so
column4: with the suspicion of CAH
column5: a DLE was placed. Thirty hours after placement
column6: the patient suddenly began to present headaches and vomiting not associated with orthostatism. There was no deterioration in the level of consciousness. The drainage bag contained 510 ml of CSF. A cranial CT scan showed a haematoma in the left cerebellar hemisphere
column7: transversely arranged
