column1: An 84-year-old man with a personal history of allergy to procaine and streptomycin
column2: who had undergone surgery for a left hip replacement and bilateral inguinal hernia. In August 2010
column3: he was diagnosed with RP and treatment with prednisone 30 mg/day was indicated. The patient was independent for activities of daily living and had no cognitive impairment. At the time of consulting the Nephrology Department (8 months after the diagnosis of RP)
column4: he was on therapy with prednisone 5 mg
column5: omeprazole 20 mg/day
column6: enalapril 5 mg every 12 hours
column7: levothyroxine 25 mg/day
column8: chlorthalidone 12.5 mg/day. The patient was admitted to the Nephrology Department for an increase in volume in the lower limbs and in the abdominal-scrotal region of four days' duration. On interrogation
column9: he only reported a slight decrease in the diuresis rhythm and nocturia at one time. Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 150/80 mmHg
column10: heart rate of 80 bpm
column11: globular abdomen with dullness in the mesogastrium and oedema with pitting in the lower limbs
column12: the rest of the examination being unremarkable. Blood tests on admission showed: creatinine: 0.8 mg/dl; cholesterol: 354 mg/dl; triglycerides: 104 mg/dl; albumin: 2.2 g/dl; total protein: 5 mg/dl. Blood count and coagulation were normal. Serology for hepatitis B
column13: C and human immunodeficiency virus: negative. In the immunological study
column14: antinuclear antibodies and anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies were negative
column15: and complement was normal. IgG was 450 mg/dl (normal range: 751-1560) and IgM and IgA were normal. Blood electrophoresis showed a percentage decrease in albumin without monoclonal peaks. Tumour markers (carcinoembryonic antigen [CEA]
column17: alpha-fetoprotein and prostate-specific antigen [PSA]) were within normal values. CA125 was 136 IU/ml (normal value: 0-35). The 24-hour urine protein quantification was 9.51 g/24h. Creatinine clearance was 77 ml/min. Urine electrophoresis also ruled out the presence of monoclonal peaks and Bence-Jones proteinuria was negative. Chest X-ray showed a right pleural effusion. In the renal ultrasound
column18: the kidneys were 11 cm in size and there was no lithiasis or dilatation. An abdominal CT scan was performed
column19: which revealed a thickening of the gastric folds. For this reason
column20: a gastroscopy was requested
column21: which confirmed the existence of a thickened pyloric fold
column22: but without evidence of malignancy in the anatomopathological study. In the presence of florid nephrotic syndrome
column23: a percutaneous ultrasound-guided renal biopsy was performed with the following findings: "5 glomeruli per slice plane
column24: all with the usual histological characteristics. Immunofluorescence was negative for the markers studied (IgG
column25: IgA
column26: IgM and C3). The interstitium
column27: tubules and vascular component were free of lesions. The final diagnosis was minimal change nephropathy (MCN). Based on the biopsy findings
column28: the prednisone dose was increased to 1 mg/kg/day. One month later
column29: the clinical and biochemical remission of the nephrotic syndrome was confirmed at the outpatient clinic
column30: and a tapering prednisone regimen was indicated. Seven months later
column31: when the patient was on maintenance therapy with prednisone 5 mg/day
column32: a relapse of the nephrotic syndrome was observed
column33: which made it necessary to increase the prednisone dose to 50 mg/day. After the nephrotic syndrome disappeared
column34: prednisone was tapered to a dose of 2.5 mg/day. One month after maintaining prednisone at a dose of 2.5 mg/dl
column35: the patient consulted his general practitioner for oedema. Laboratory tests showed the appearance of proteinuria of 1.66 g/day
column36: so it was decided to increase the prednisone dose to 10 mg/day
column37: and the proteinuria disappeared. At the last nephrology review
column38: on maintenance with prednisone 10 mg/day
column39: the patient was asymptomatic and without proteinuria.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 46-year-old man
column2: with no relevant pathological history
column3: non-smoker. He underwent a fixed restoration on a single-tooth implant (ITI® SLA. Straumann. Walderburg-Switzerland) placed in the 3.6 zone. Six months after the crown was cemented
column4: he attended a check-up without reporting any associated symptoms. Clinical examination revealed a slight reddening of the mucosa adjacent to the implant and a peri-implant pocket 6 mm deep
column5: with slight bleeding on probing. The articulating paper showed premature contact on the prosthetic crown. The panoramic radiograph showed a radiolucent area in the marginal bone at 3.6. Occlusal grinding of the prosthetic crown was performed. Subsequently
column6: a mucoperiosteal flap was raised from 3.5 to 3.7
column7: revealing a fibrous soft tissue surround occupying a marginal peri-implant bone defect at 3.6. The pathological tissue was removed with plastic curettes and sent for pathological examination. The implant surface was decontaminated with 0.2% chlorhexidine gel for 2 minutes and irrigated with physiological saline. The flap was enlarged to access a lingual mandibular torus in the ipsilateral premolar area
column8: which was extracted and particulated to serve as an autograft. The flap was repositioned and sutured with 3.0 silk. The patient was re-instructed in oral hygiene
column9: ibuprofen 600 mg every 8 hrs x 4 days and mouthwash with chlorhexidine digluconate 0.12% twice daily x 2 weeks. Histopathological analysis showed epithelio-connective tissue with abundant lymphoplasmacytic and juxtaepithelial infiltrate. Under the superficial area
column10: a dense fibro-connective tissue with few inflammatory cells was observed. Twelve months after surgical treatment
column11: an X-ray showed marginal bone healing and a normal clinical appearance with no symptoms.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 43-year-old woman diagnosed with cervical cancer in 2007 and treated with brachytherapy and radiotherapy. After presenting with actinic sigmoiditis and intestinal obstruction at the end of 2009
column2: she underwent a Hartman intestinal resection with the result of an unloading colostomy. At that time the patient weighed 41.5 kg
column3: 165 cm (BMI = 15). During the subsequent period her weight fluctuated between 38 and 42 kg despite nutritional monitoring
column4: and she was admitted five times
column5: one of them for intrabadominal abscess and ureteroenteral fistula
column6: for which a left nephrostomy was performed. In November 2011 she underwent ileocaecal resection with laterolateral anastomosis due to intestinal fistula. In the postoperative period
column7: she developed a coma secondary to imipenem
column8: which led to admission to the ICU. He required parenteral nutritional support for 20 days. In January 2012 he was admitted again for multifactorial grade III chronic renal failure and nutritional treatment with a renal protection diet was established. The clinical situation required new PN for 10 days due to incoercible vomiting and inability to eat orally. In September 2012
column9: she was readmitted due to a suprapubic fistula
column10: starting PN again with the aim of renourishing the patient to face a new surgical intervention
column11: at which time she had a BMI = 13 (37 kg
column12: 169 cm). On the thirteenth day
column13: after a weight gain of 4 kg
column14: the patient developed an allergic condition that started with erythema and pruritus. Antibiotics were discontinued (9 days with meropenem) and treatment with corticosteroids and antihistamines was administered. The evolution continued to be torpid in the following hours
column15: with oedema and difficulty breathing. At this point it was decided to discontinue PN
column16: and an improvement in symptoms was observed. Given the essential need for preoperative nutrition
column17: a protocol was drawn up for the reintroduction of PN: 1. Initiation of TPN with exclusive supply of amino acids
column18: glucose and electrolytes
column19: using a different source of amino acids to that of the previous preparation. Always start in the morning with close monitoring of the patient. 2. After 48 hours
column20: if there have been no signs of recurrence of allergy
column21: add increasing amounts of lipids to the parenteral diet over the next 72 hours. 3. In case of good tolerance
column22: assess the need to add vitamins and trace elements to the mixture. PN is restarted with good tolerance and without complications
column23: providing complete PN with macro and micronutrients according to the patient's needs around the 4th day. Following nutritional recovery
column24: surgery was decided with poor postoperative evolution and the need for admission to the Intensive Care Unit due to the development of septic shock of abdominal origin and multi-organ failure
column25: which ended in the patient's death.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 44-year-old male admitted for facial trauma. Radiographic examination revealed a large radiolucent lesion and a displaced angle fracture.  Enucleation of the lesion

Bone healing was observed radiographically two months later.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 7-year-old girl
column2: with no relevant pathological or neonatal history
column3: who presented for consultation with a clinical picture of 8 months' evolution consisting of a right upper gingival nodular lesion of approximately 3 x 3 cm in diameter
column4: and who reported slow growth for 8 months
column5: which accelerated in the 2 months prior to consultation. A computerised tomography (CT) scan was requested which showed a right maxillary tumour with infiltration towards the antrum and nasal cavity measuring 3 x 3 cm in diameter. In view of this diagnosis
column6: the Paediatric Surgery Department indicated marginal resection of the maxillary tumour using a sublabial approach and the histopathological report of the resection specimen showed a 3 cm maxillary chondrosarcoma with grade II differentiation. The patient was subsequently sent for complementary treatment with adjuvant radiotherapy
column7: which she did not attend. One year later she was readmitted to hospital with a recurrence of the tumour after 2 months of evolution. The tumour now showed accelerated growth
column8: measuring 9 x 6 cm in diameter on CT scan and occupying the entire right maxilla and partially the left maxilla. Chemotherapy treatment was indicated at that time for tumour reduction and the patient received 9 cycles of Doxurrubicin 30 mg per m2 of body surface area; Vincristine 1.5 mg per m2; Mesna 300 mg per m2 and Cyclophosphamide 300 mg per m2
column9: for 5 months
column10: without achieving the desired effect. In view of this
column11: the Plastic Surgery
column12: Oncological Surgery and Head and Neck Surgery Departments were asked to assess the patient and decided to submit her to a new surgical intervention in which
column13: after a tracheostomy
column14: we performed a bilateral subtotal maxillectomy with palatectomy
column15: including the tumour in its entirety and preserving the soft palate. The resection specimen was 10 x 8 cm
column16: greyish
column17: firm
column18: with reddish mucosa
column19: haemorrhagic and with areas of necrosis of 30%. The histopathological study performed with light microphotography and haematoxylin/eosin staining confirmed the diagnosis of grade II chondrosarcoma
column20: cellular pleomorphism with 2 mitotic figures per field and with surgical edges free of tumour and without vascular permeation.  In the same surgical procedure we carried out partial and temporary maxillary reconstruction with titanium mini-plates and alloplastic prosthesis.  After 8 months of follow-up after radical surgery
column21: the patient is in good general condition
column22: with an adequate scarring process
column23: with no evidence of local or distant tumour activity as evidenced by both clinical and CT scans.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 32-year-old woman. She reported habitual constipation
column2: which had increased over the last few months. Physical examination was unremarkable except for a rectal examination
column3: in which a rounded
column4: soft
column5: non-painful protrusion was palpated at the fingertip on the right lateral aspect of the rectal wall. An abdominal ultrasound was requested
column6: revealing a mass of cystic appearance and doubtful aetiology of right pararectal location
column7: with a longitudinal diameter of about 34 mm. An MRI of the lower pelvis was requested to identify the cystic lesion found on the ultrasound scan

column1: A 43-year-old man was admitted to hospital with severe precordial pain lasting one hour. The ECG showed mild inferior E-ST
column2: prominent J wave in V1-V2 and marked D-ST in leads V1 to V5. Diagnosed with inferoposterior AMI
column3: the patient received thrombolytic treatment with reteplase. One hour later the ECG revealed an incomplete BRD
column4: an overt J wave (R') in leads V1-V2 and no ST-segment deviations. There were also high R-waves affecting the initial part of the QRS complex and acuminate T-waves in leads V2-V3
column5: suggesting the diagnosis of subsequent superimposed AMI. Eight hours after admission the ECG revealed a T-wave inversion in leads III and aVF
column6: a J-wave in leads V1-V2 and a concave E-ST with positive T-wave in leads V1 to V4. Three days later the ECG revealed a J-wave
column7: a concave E-ST and a positive T-wave in leads V2 to V5 suggestive of PRRS. Creatinine kinase rose to 4
column8: 999 U/l (with a MB fraction of 254). An echocardiogram revealed inferobasal and apical akinesia. Coronary arteriography revealed a 90% stenosis in the middle third of the right coronary artery and 60% stenosis in the proximal portion of the circumflex artery. Following stenting of the right coronary artery
column9: the patient has been asymptomatic for three years.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 19-year-old patient who had undergone caesarean section two years previously due to suspected chorioamnionitis. She then began with fever and night sweats without affecting her general condition
column2: and a large mediastinal mass was found on chest X-ray. Following mediastinoscopy and biopsy
column3: a diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma nodular sclerosis type
column4: stage III-IV due to infradiaphragmatic adenopathic involvement and hepatosplenomegaly was made. Chemotherapy was started according to the ABVD scheme to complete nine cycles
column5: followed by radiotherapy on the mediastinum. One year later
column6: disease was again detected in the mediastinum and lung parenchyma together with hepatosplenomegaly. For the last month he has been suffering moderate pain treated with paracetamol
column8: 000 mg/day-1 and metamizol 1
column9: 500 mg/day-1. It was decided to start a new line of chemotherapy with ESCHAP. Systematically
column10: at the beginning of the chemotherapy cycles and during the following 5-7 days
column11: the patient suffered intense mediastinal and dorsal interscapular pain that did not subside with oral morphine or fentanyl TD
column12: relieved only with parenteral morphine
column13: 10 mg s.c.
column14: which provided her with analgesia of irregular duration
column15: between 4 and 12 hours. This occurred during the previous cycle of chemotherapy and after a first cycle of the ESCHAP scheme. In view of the poor peripheral routes
column16: vascular portal placement was proposed
column17: which was approached via the right subclavian route. We took advantage of this circumstance to plan PCA with an external pump during and after the chemotherapy cycles
column18: through the vascular portal. Monitoring consisted of continuous EKG in DII lead
column19: pulse oximetry and blood pressure measurement by oscillometry every five minutes. The procedure was performed under local anaesthesia and sedation with 2 mg intravenous midazolam
column20: using the Seldinger technique. The right subclavian vein was approached below the junction between the distal third and the midclavicular third with satisfactory progression of the guidewire and subsequent blood aspiration. Antero-posterior (A-P) radiological control was carried out to verify correct placement. Chemotherapy was then started. Twenty-four hours after starting chemotherapy
column21: the patient reported chest pain and intense dyspnoea
column22: with tachycardia
column23: tachypnoea and abolition of vesicular murmur in the right hemithorax on examination. Chest X-ray showed massive right pleural effusion
column24: with a catheter tip outside the right atrium in the pleural cavity.  In view of the suspected extravasation of a chemotherapy substance in the pleura
column25: a diagnostic puncture was performed
column26: obtaining serous pleural fluid with the same biochemical characteristics as the chemotherapy used. The patient's radiological series was reviewed and the tip of the venous catheter was observed to migrate until it was located at pleural level
column27: possibly between the two blades
column28: resulting in secondary drainage of the infused liquid into the pleural space.  It was decided to place an endopleural drainage after evacuating thoracentesis by thoracic surgery
column29: extracting 2
column30: 000 cc of serous content. Clinical improvement was immediate. Seventy-two hours later
column31: the pleural drain was removed and a new central venous access was placed via the left subclavian approach
column32: without incident
column33: through which chemotherapy treatment was resumed.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 66 year old woman underwent hysterectomy plus bilateral adnexectomy and lymphadenectomy for endometrial adenocarcinoma. Background: myotonic dystrophy type I (DM type I) or Steinert's disease
column2: pacemaker for complete AVB

column8: FEV1/FVC = 0.76. - Arterial blood gases: pH 7.44
column9: PO2 53 mmHg
column10: PCO2 51 mmHg
column11: HCO3 34.6 mmol/l. - Haemogram: Hb 11.4 g/dl
column13: Platelets 85x1000/μl
column14: Leukocytes 4.6x1000/μl - Coagulation: prothrombin activity 80%

He came to the emergency department with three months of clinical manifestations of gait instability and generalised weakness (he had previously been admitted to another centre for these symptoms). On physical examination
column4: the patient was dehydrated
column5: confused
column6: bradypsychic and with distal tremor. The analytical data are summarised in (table 1)
column7: highlighting significant deterioration of renal function
column8: severe hypercalcaemia and marked elevation of PTH (twenty times the laboratory reference value). Serum therapy
column9: perfusion of furosemide and intravenous corticosteroids
column10: bisphosphonates and calcitonin were started. Due to the severity of the neurological symptoms
column11: urgent renal replacement therapy by haemodialysis with low calcium concentration in the dialysate was simultaneously indicated. There was a transitory clinical improvement
column12: but due to persistent renal failure and rebound of hypercalcaemia (increase in calcaemia > 2 mg/dl 24 hours post-hemodialysis)
column13: daily sessions were required.  As part of the aetiological study
column14: myeloproliferative processes and other neoplasms (no monoclonal component in the proteinogram
column15: negative Bence-Jones proteinuria)
column16: infectious pathology (negative serologies) and autoimmune diseases were ruled out. Urinary ultrasound showed kidneys of normal size and adequate cortico-medullary differentiation. Thoracic-abdominal CT scan showed a retroesophageal mass measuring 5.6 × 3.2 × 6.8 cm
column17: suspicious for parathyroid tumour
column18: and the image was confirmed by parathyroid scintigraphy
column19: as well as bilateral hypodense adrenal nodules: right 27 × 18 mm and left 15 × 11 mm. With these findings
column20: the patient consulted Endocrinology
column21: which ruled out pheochromocytoma (negative urine catecholamines and metanephrines). In a joint session with General Surgery it was decided to perform surgery
column22: resecting an 8 cm parathyroid tumour. Anatomical pathology reports parathyroid adenoma without capsular or vascular invasion.  In the immediate postoperative period
column23: "hungry bone syndrome" occurred and the patient required intravenous and oral calcium supplementation due to severe hypocalcaemia
column24: and daily haemodialysis sessions for nine days after surgery. Nine months later
column25: the patient is asymptomatic
column26: with calcaemia in range without the need for supplementation
column27: and with partial recovery of renal function (creatinine 2.7 mg/dl). It is noteworthy that renal function remains impaired one year after surgery
column28: despite normalisation of calcaemia.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 77-year-old man
column2: with no toxic habits
column3: with a personal history of allergy to iodinated contrast
column4: prostate adenocarcinoma with vertebral metastasis in 1998
column5: treated with radiotherapy and hormone therapy. Arterial hypertension
column6: hypercholesterolemia
column7: ischaemic heart disease
column8: repeated nephritic colic and intention tremor. In the computerised axial tomography (CAT) scan to monitor his prostate pathology
column9: a right parspinal mass was detected. A biopsy revealed the presence of a myxoid soft tissue sarcoma
column10: 16 x 6 cm in diameter
column11: extending from T12 to L3
column12: without infiltration of subcutaneous tissue. The patient was operated on by the Traumatology and Orthopaedics Department in conjunction with the Plastic Surgery Department
column13: performing en bloc exeresis of the erector spinae muscle compartment affected
column14: leaving a residual defect as shown in Fig. 1. The tumour did not microscopically affect the skin or subcutaneous tissue. Preoperative imaging tests also suggested that the tumour respected superficial planes
column15: so we opted for the placement of a rectangular tissue expander
column16: 20 x 7 cm in diameter
column17: model SRV2007 (Allergan®
column18: Irvine
column19: California
column20: USA)
column21: 750 cc in volume. The closure was made in planes (subcutaneous cellular tissue and skin). We tunneled the reservoir to fill the expander in a subcutaneous plane
column22: cranially and laterally to its final location in the right axillary midline.  Intraoperative filling of the expander with physiological saline until the skin was brought into plane with respect to the adjacent regions
column23: with a total of 680 cc.  Perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis was carried out with intravenous cefuroxime
column24: then maintained for 5 days in the postoperative period
column25: which was uneventful except for postoperative anaemia in the immediate phase
column26: which required transfusion of 2 red blood cell concentrates. Hospitalisation lasted 20 days
column27: and the patient was able to ambulate independently on discharge
column28: with support from a brace as the only orthopaedic measure. After the operation
column29: the Orthopaedic Service carried out periodic follow-ups
column30: with no back pain
column31: scoliosis or neurological deficits being observed during the first 10 months. We also carried out weekly check-ups in the Plastic Surgery outpatient clinic until 2 months after surgery
column32: then once a month for 3 months
column33: and then every 3 months thereafter. We were able to verify a good quality of the scar
column34: without significant functional deficits. There was no extrusion of the expander
column35: and the imaging tests showed no migration or volume depletion of the expander. The control X-rays 4 months after surgery showed minimal right lumbar convexity
column36: without clinical repercussions
column37: with excellent functional recovery of the patient and a good aesthetic result
column38: without any depression in the resection area.  The anatomopathological study reported the resected tumour as a low-grade neural sheath sarcoma
column39: with incomplete resection of the deep border. We decided
column40: in a joint session of the Tumour Committee of our hospital centre
column41: not to carry out a surgical reintervention given the patient's age and
column42: above all
column43: his general condition and previous pathologies. We indicated the follow-up of periodic controls by means of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and serial CT scans.  The patient was free of disease for 9 months. Thereafter
column44: we detected local progression of the disease affecting the psoas iliacus and quadratus lumborum muscles
column45: and regional lymphatic dissemination
column46: with poor clinical tolerance to chemotherapy treatment. The patient died of this process 2 years after surgery.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Eight-year-old girl
column2: of Bolivian origin
column3: consulted our health centre for intermittent vaginal bleeding and mucopurulent
column4: foul-smelling vaginal discharge for the last two months. Physical examination revealed severe congestion and oedema of the hymen and vulvar introitus. The girl lives with her parents and a paternal uncle and his partner at the same address and they deny any evidence of sexual abuse. Given this florid clinical picture
column5: she was referred to the emergency department for differential diagnosis of vaginal foreign body and to rule out sexual abuse. A gynaecological examination was performed
column6: where a vaginal foreign body was ruled out and a vaginal exudate sample was collected. In turn
column7: she was assessed by the on-call forensic doctor
column8: who issued a judicial report ruling out signs of sexual abuse. The culture of the vaginal exudate was positive for Shigella sonnei resistant according to the antibiogram to amoxicillin/clavulanic acid
column9: ampicillin and the combination trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole
column10: and sensitive to cefuroxime axetil
column11: cefixime and gentamicin. A stool culture
column12: perianal exudate culture and urine culture were also requested and were negative. It was decided to prescribe antibiotic treatment with cefuroxime axetil for ten days
column13: showing great clinical improvement
column14: but without complete resolution of the symptoms
column15: so the same treatment regimen was repeated
column16: with the clinical symptoms disappearing.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the clinical case of a 50-year-old woman
column2: a tightrope walker by profession
column3: with no personal history of interest
column4: who progressively developed
column5: over a period of about 10 years
column6: a malformation of the scalp consisting of a left frontal irregular mass
column7: approximately 12x11 cm in its main axes
column8: pulsatile
column9: with significant development of the vascular network of the cranial calotte
column10: in charge of the superficial temporal arteries and their venous return branches. In the anamnesis
column11: the patient recalls a traumatic history 12 years ago
column12: with frontal contusion
column13: after which she suffered a large bifrontal subgaleal haematoma
column14: which resolved conservatively over the course of approximately two months. Apart from this incident
column15: he reported no other symptoms and the physical and neurological examination was normal. In view of the suspicion of a traumatic arteriovenous malformation
column16: imaging tests were requested. Cerebral MRI showed no significant alterations and cerebral angiography of the internal and external carotid artery territories showed a left frontal epicranial vascular nidus
column17: with extracranial vascular contributions from both superficial temporal arteries
column18: and contributions from the intracranial circulation by transosseous meningeal branches coming from the ethmoidal arteries and dependent in turn on the two ophthalmic arteries
column19: left and right. Neither the embolisation of the intracranial branches due to the high risk of amaurosis of one or both eyes
column20: nor of the extracranial branches was carried out
column21: as it was considered possible to resect the AVM by surgical intervention alone. A bicoronal incision was made behind the nidus
column22: bilaterally accessing the nourishing branches of the AVM
column23: in order to first ligate and section them and thus reduce the blood supply to the lesion and make resection of the lesion possible with controlled bleeding. The nidus was located outside the pericranium and under the subcutaneous cellular tissue
column24: and showed irrigation through the calotte from the intracranial branches as evidenced by the previous angiography. Radiofrequency coagulation
column25: both mono and bipolar
column26: and bone wax were used to control haemorrhage. All subcutaneous blood vessels were resected
column27: and hair follicles were evident only in a few isolated areas. During surgery it was necessary to transfuse with two red blood cell concentrates
column28: and a blood salvager (ORTHOPAT HAEMONETICS) was used to better control blood loss. The scalp was sutured in the usual way by planes and the skin was sutured with agrafes. Postoperatively
column29: there were no neurological complications and the wound healed adequately
column30: with no areas of necrosis or alopecia developing. The cosmetic result was excellent. After one year she has shown no recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 26-year-old woman diagnosed at 18 years of age with ulcerative colitis without requiring treatment. In October 2002 she presented new episodes of diarrhoea of 3-4 stools/day with red blood. Anamnesis by apparatus with no notable alterations. Rectal examination revealed an excrescent lesion 3-5 cm from the anal margin. HIV
column2: lues
column3: Epstein-Barr virus and cytomegalovirus serology were negative. Several colonoscopies were performed which revealed a rectal formation 2-3 cm from the anus with an ulcerated surface (anatomopathological report of an ulcerated lesion with signs of dysplasia in the epithelium covered by fibrinous-leukocytic material
column4: inconclusive) and treatment was therefore instituted with dietary hygiene measures
column5: corticosteroid enemas and even 5-ASA suppositories. A new colonoscopy revealed a mixed hyperplastic polyp-tubular adenoma of the rectum and the patient was referred for surgery
column6: which was carried out in January 2004 with transanal resection of the lesion and the anatomopathological report of chronic non-specific inflammation. After re-analysing the patient's history
column7: given the discordance between the clinical and histological features of the lesion and its evolution over time
column8: it was decided to review all the biopsy specimens by the same anatomopathologist
column9: who found no evidence of villous adenoma or inflammatory bowel disease in any of the samples
column10: and together with him
column11: a diagnosis of "cap polyposis" was made.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 42-year-old male with aggressive periodontal disease
column2: with no other pathology of interest. The intervention followed the following sequence: - Supracrestal incision with posterior and medial discharges to avoid flap tension and to adequately locate the mentonians. - Intense curettage of post-extraction alveoli if present. - Identification of mentonians. - Regularisation of the ridge
column3: trying to ensure that all implants are at the same occlusogingival height. - Central osteotomy with a 2 mm drill to a depth of 10 mm; confirm with a direction indicator that the osteotomy is perpendicular to the bipupillary line.  - Positioning of the "all-on-4 guide": this is a guide (Nobelbiocare®) which
column4: thanks to its markings and references
column5: allows the insertion of the implants at the right angle (about 30º) while keeping the tongue away from the surgical field.  - Preparation of the distal implant sites with 30º inclination. Note the presence of the right distal molar which was used by the patient to retain the removable prosthesis and which we will remove in the same session.  - Note also the presence on the left side of an unsightly diapneusis in the lower labial commissure which we will subsequently remove by conventional surgical excision. - We can also see that the preparation bed of the right distal implant is in the vertical of the exit of the mentonian. - We drill and insert the right distal implant (Nobelbiocare® Brånemark implant
column6: Ti-Unite Groovy 3.75 x 15)
column7: of the same dimensions as the other three fixations used in the case. - Care should be taken not to use an excessive number of drills so that we achieve a minimum insertion torque of 35 N cm. - We always use countersink drills on the distal implants
column8: so that they are submerged (infraosseous) distally
column9: so that there are no exposed loops mesially
column10: given the inclination of these fixations. - Once the first distal implant is in place
column11: we insert its corresponding 30º angled multi-unit abutment. As can be seen in figure 4
column12: the 30º inclination of the implant
column13: corrected with an abutment with the same angulation
column14: results in a perpendicular to the ridge and
column15: as we intend
column16: to the bipupillary line.  - We repeat the procedure with the distal left implant/abutment. - Next
column17: we prepare the beds for the mesial implants
column18: trying to maintain parallelism and equidistance between them and with the distal implants.  - We place straight multi-unit abutments on the mesial implants already inserted. - Next
column19: we apply the appropriate torque (15 N cm on the posterior implants and 35 on the anterior implants) as these abutments will never be removed again (the provisional and definitive prostheses will be fabricated on them). - We then screw in the temporary titanium cylinders that will later be embedded in the temporary prosthesis and suture the wound around them with resorbable suture. - Once the entire incision has been sutured
column20: we unscrew the cylinders and use a circular scalpel around the multi-unit abutments so that the gingiva does not get in the way during intraoperative screwing and unscrewing in the next few minutes. - We check the passive seating of the prosthesis
column21: lowering it if necessary. - We reline the prosthesis with dense silicone and have the patient bite down. Once it has set
column22: the marks of the multi-unit abutments on it will mark the points where the prosthesis must be drilled
column23: a manoeuvre which we then carry out. - We screw the titanium cylinders back in. - We check the passive seating of the perforated prosthesis and see if the cylinders allow maximum intercuspidation; if not
column24: we trim the cylinders to allow it. - We place a rubber dam to isolate the surgical field during subsequent manoeuvres.  - We put cotton wools in the chimneys of the cylinders and close the perforations of the prosthesis with soft wax. - We dry the prosthesis well and we fill it with self-curing resin and have the patient bite into position.  - We remove the wax "plugs" and fill with more resin occlusally
column25: leaving only the access to the screws uncovered. - We let it set completely
column26: unscrew and check the stability of the cylinders already embedded in the prosthesis.  - Fill the holes (pores) with more resin and cut the cylinders flush with the prosthesis. - We cut the fins and the distal ends of the prosthesis (in the provisional prosthesis we leave practically no cantilever); we remove the rubber dam. - We also remove any resin in contact with the flange; for this we use the GC Fit-checker® used as a reline
column27: which shows us the area that exerts pressure on the flange.  - We polish the prosthesis
column28: screw it in definitively at 15 N cm and adjust the occlusion.  - After 15 days
column29: the patient comes for a check-up and we remove the suture to which we have access; the rest
column30: as it is resorbable
column31: is of no concern to us  - At this point we train the patient in the handling of Superfloss® so that hygiene is optimal (it is quite simple as there are only four implants). - We carry out regular check-ups until after 5-6 months we proceed to manufacture the definitive prosthesis. During this period it is not necessary to unscrew the provisional prosthesis.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 54-year-old woman
column2: cholecystectomised at 23 years of age and with several episodes of residual choledocholithiasis resolved endoscopically as background of interest. The patient was admitted for epigastric pain radiating to the back
column3: accompanied by nausea and vomiting
column4: of hours' duration
column5: without fever or dysthermic sensation. The patient had been discharged the previous day for residual choledocholithiasis that had resolved endoscopically
column6: with no other pathological findings on endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). On examination
column7: he presented pain in the right hypochondrium and epigastrium on palpation
column8: with no signs of peritonism
column9: and with a slightly distended abdomen. Laboratory tests showed leukocytosis with neutrophilia
column10: hyperbilirubinaemia and mild elevation of transaminases
column11: with normal amylase
column12: as well as a marked elevation of 1 hour ESR. Parietal cell antibodies were positive and serum IgG4 was negative. Blood cultures were taken on admission and no microorganisms were isolated. An ultrasound scan showed several space-occupying lesions suggestive of liver abscesses
column13: so it was decided to complete the study with a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan. This showed multiple lesions in both hepatic lobes
column14: between 1 and 7 centimetres in diameter
column15: hyperintensely ill-defined in T2-weighted sequences with fat suppression
column16: and with homogeneous or peripheral enhancement during the dynamic study with intravenous contrast
column17: thus being compatible with hepatic abscesses. Dilatation of the main bile duct with repletion defects at the level of the distal common bile duct and common hepatic duct
column18: together with a stenosis at the level of the hilar confluence
column19: with no apparent cause and which had not been seen previously
column20: was also observed. Ultrasound-guided percutaneous drainage was attempted
column21: but was not possible due to the absence of significant liquefaction. With intravenous antibiotic treatment
column22: the patient became asymptomatic and remained afebrile. A new follow-up MRI scan was performed
column23: showing a significant reduction in liver lesions
column24: but without being able to rule out a neoplastic origin
column25: as well as an irregularity in the origin of the left hepatic branch
column26: which raises the doubt of an inflammatory or tumoural origin
column27: in addition to choledocholithiasis. An ERCP was performed
column28: from which two microcalcifications were extracted
column29: confirming stenosis of the left hepatic branch
column30: and samples were taken for cytological study
column31: which were negative for malignancy. Finally
column32: it was decided to perform an ultrasound-guided biopsy of the lesions
column33: without incident. Histological examination of the lesion revealed a proliferation of myofibroblastic cells with elongated nuclei and cytoplasm
column34: positive for actin and desmin by immunohistochemical techniques. There was also an increased population of IgG4-positive plasma cells
column35: in some areas exceeding 30 per high-magnification field
column36: with an IgG4/IgG ratio greater than 40%. All these findings were suggestive of inflammatory liver pseudotumour of the lymphoplasmacytic type
column37: probably related to IgG4-related systemic disease. In addition
column38: damage to the bile duct and some concentric periductal fibrosis without IgG4 cells at that level were seen in the non-injured liver.  The patient
column39: after receiving antibiotic treatment for possible superinfection of the lesions given the history of ERCP
column40: was discharged with steroid treatment in a descending regimen
column41: with a good clinical-radiological evolution.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A patient aged 5 years and 7 months
column2: with no personal or family history of interest
column3: was admitted to our hospital on 12 June 2002 for a 10-day history of headache
column4: predominantly in the evening
column5: followed by convergent strabismus of the left eye and diplopia. Neurological examination revealed an awake
column6: cooperative and environmentally connected child
column7: with convergent strabismus of the left eye with preserved ocular motility and horizontal nystagmus on forced gaze to the right. Blood tests
column8: biochemistry and chest X-ray were normal. Cranial CT and MRI showed a well-defined mass located inside the right lateral ventricle at the level of the atrium and temporal horn
column9: of homogeneous density and measuring 6 by 2.5 cm
column10: with significant perilesional oedema and showing intense uptake after administration of intravenous contrast.  The patient underwent a transtemporal approach through the medial temporal gyrus with macroscopically complete excision of the tumour. The histopathological study showed a neoplastic meningothelial proliferation with a predominantly meningotheliomatous pattern and high cellularity
column11: classifying the tumour as an atypical meningioma. The presence of high mitotic activity was striking
column12: in some areas reaching 2-3 mitoses in 10 high-magnification fields
column13: with the proliferating cells having larger nuclei and prominent nucleoli. The Ki-67 antibody activity
column14: measured randomly in the whole tumour
column15: ranged from 18-20%.  The girl's clinical evolution was favourable and she was discharged from hospital ten days after surgery with minimal convergent strabismus of the right eye. Despite not having undergone complementary treatment
column16: the patient is currently asymptomatic and no signs of recurrence have been detected in follow-up imaging studies.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 27-year-old man shot in the skull during a police chase. He was taken to a medical centre and died after 24 hours as a result of the encephalic injury. Among the autopsy findings were two holes in the scalp (right frontal and parietal) and a single bony entry wound in the right parietal bone with no bony exit wound. The cutaneous entry wound
column2: without tattooing or smoking
column3: is classified as "far" or "long distance". The scalp was removed and a bone entry wound was observed in the right parietal region
column4: elongated
column5: with external bevelling limited to the most posterior area of the wound
column6: with a fracture trace. A fragment of the projectile was recovered in the right occipital region
column7: deformed
column8: made of bare lead
column9: .38 calibre
column10: with a sector of its surface "mirrored". The rest of the projectile produces a cutaneous exit wound in the right parietal region
column11: almost superimposed on the bony entry wound. Histological examination confirms the nature of the cutaneous orifices.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 26-year-old woman with no previous neurological history
column2: asthmatic and on treatment with oral contraceptives
column3: presented with a picture of very intense holocranial headache accompanied by photophobia
column4: nausea and vomiting without fever for about 24 hours of evolution
column5: which was suddenly complicated the following morning with gait instability and diplopia. The neurological examination revealed mild nuchal rigidity
column6: right internuclear ophthalmoplegia
column7: staggering Romberg and left lateropulsion in gait
column8: the rest being normal. A computerised axial tomography was performed
column9: showing a lesion with negative density (-20 to -67 Hounsfield Units) located in the temporal region as well as multiple oval images scattered throughout the right suprasellar cisterns
column10: bilateral quadrigeminae
column11: pontocerebellar angle and frontal horn of the left lateral ventricle
column12: which were interpreted as fat particles. With suspicion of chemical meningitis due to rupture of a dermoid cyst
column13: treatment was started with dexamethasone at a dose of 4 milligrams every 12 hours. A brain MRI scan six days after the onset of symptoms showed an extraparenchymal mass corresponding to the cyst in the medial region of the left temporal pole
column14: ascending to occupy the anterior area of the left perimesencephalic cistern
column15: and dissemination of fat in the subarachnoid space; In addition
column16: a hyperintense image is observed in the paramedial region of the midbrain in the T2-weighted sequences
column17: which is hyperintense in the diffusion sequences and hypointense in the ADC map
column18: compatible with an ischaemic infarction. The MRI is completed with T1 and EGD sequences with fat suppression after gadolinium administration
column19: showing small fat particles scattered in the subarachnoid space; the fat accumulation in the interpeduncular cistern in close contact with the distal part of the basilar and the theoretical exit of the mesencephalic medial perforating branches
column20: superior cerebellar arteries and posterior cerebral arteries is striking. Figure 1 shows a composition with the most representative neuroimaging of the case. Following the results of this test
column21: treatment was started with acetylsalicylic acid at a dose of 100 mg per day and the aetiological study of the stroke was completed with blood tests
column22: haemogram
column23: lipidogram
column24: autoimmunity study
column25: serology
column26: thyroid hormones
column27: homocysteine
column28: anticardiolipin antibodies
column29: B2-microglobulin
column30: antiphospholipid
column31: cerebrospinal fluid study
column32: electrocardiogram
column33: supra-aortic trunk duplex
column34: transcranial Doppler
column35: bubble test
column36: transthoracic echocardiography
column37: arrhythmia holter and angioresonance of Willis polygon; all with normal or negative results. The headache responded to dexamethasone administration in less than 48 hours and the ophthalmoparesis and instability resolved after 10 days
column38: leaving the patient asymptomatic. The patient was diagnosed with isolated anteromedial mesencephalic infarction possibly secondary to vasospasm of paramedian mesencephalic perforating arteries in relation to subarachnoid dissemination of the fatty content of a ruptured temporal dermoid cyst. In agreement with the patient
column39: the neurosurgery department decided on a wait-and-see attitude and serial neuroimaging controls
column40: leaving elective surgery for the case of the appearance of symptomatology due to tumour compression.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of an eight-month-old female patient admitted for a seven-day course of symptoms consisting of fever up to 40oC
column2: refusal of food intake and vomiting. She had no family or personal pathological history of interest
column3: and no known allergies. Physical examination revealed only small rounded laterocervical lymphadenopathies and pharyngeal hyperemia. In the complementary study requested
column4: he had a haemogram with normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate; C-reactive protein
column5: 4.48 mg/dl; and normal sodium
column6: potassium
column7: chloride
column8: magnesium
column9: calcium (Ca)
column10: phosphorus (P)
column11: bilirubin
column12: protein and blood gases. Blood
column13: urine and stool cultures were negative and a pharyngeal swab isolated Parainfuenzavirus 3. An analytical finding that attracted attention was an AF level of 5252 IU/l. The parents were again asked about the cause of this elevated AF
column14: with particular emphasis on the consumption of drugs
column15: history of fractures or previous illnesses
column16: both in the patient and in her relatives
column17: but no new data were obtained. A new determination of AF was requested to check that it was not a laboratory error
column18: as well as GGT
column19: vitamin D
column20: parathyroid hormone (PTH) and AF isoenzymes. This analysis confirmed elevated AF (6070 IU/l)
column21: with the rest of the requested parameters (GGT
column22: AF isoenzymes
column23: vitamin D and PTH) being normal. On the seventh day of admission
column24: once the febrile process had resolved
column25: the patient was discharged with a diagnosis of Parainfuenzavirus 3 infection and hyperphosphataemia under study. He was monitored clinically and with periodic AF tests in outpatient clinics. Subsequent controls showed a progressive decrease in AF
column26: she remained asymptomatic and with a strictly normal physical examination
column27: so she was definitively discharged after six months
column28: after presenting two AF determinations within normal values for her age
column29: with the diagnosis of transient benign hyperphosphataemia of infancy (HTBI).   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 67-year-old woman consulted our department for swelling in the posterior region of the right hemipalate. A biopsy was performed under local anaesthesia with the diagnosis of PLGA. The cervical examination revealed a right submandibular lymphadenopathy. The most relevant antecedent was a radiotherapy treatment in childhood for an unclassified pathology in the head and neck region. The orthopantomography was normal. A cervicofacial computerised tomography was requested
column2: which showed a stage IV lesion at the level of the right nostril (T4N2CMx). A cytological puncture of the submandibular adenopathy was performed and reported as probable PLGA. MRI showed a well-defined lesion at the level of the nasal fossa with extension towards the pterygoid region.  Surgical intervention under general anaesthesia was decided. The tumour was approached by means of a Lefort I type maxillotomy. A unilateral suprahomohyoid cervical ganglionic cervical emptying was also performed. Tumour resection and bone repositioning of the maxilla was performed using 1.5 mm preformed mini-plates.  The definitive result of the pathological anatomy confirmed the diagnosis of PLGA
column3: with invasion of surgical margins at the level of the right pterygomaxillary area. Metastatic adenopathies (2/16) were detected on the right side (5).  The patient was presented at the Maxillofacial Surgery-Oncology session
column4: and it was decided to perform adjuvant radiotherapy in the right pterygomaxillary region and to follow imaging controls by means of resonance imaging. Given the persistence of tumour remains
column5: it was decided to extend the surgical margins in the right pterygomaxillary region and reconstruct the defect using a buccal adipose Bichat ball. Two years later
column6: the patient is still undergoing periodic check-ups and is free of disease.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 61-year-old woman with multiple previous hospital admissions for episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding
column2: with a history of mitral valve disease with prosthetic valve replacement and on treatment with acenocoumarol. In April 2011
column3: she was admitted for intestinal bleeding of unaffiliated origin and severe iron deficiency anaemia
column4: a gastroscopy and capsule endoscopy were performed without significant findings
column5: after which it was decided to reduce the INR range to 2.5-3. Two months later
column6: he presented a new episode of intestinal bleeding
column7: after which a capsule endoscopy was performed again
column8: showing the existence of intestinal angiodysplasias in the duodenal antrum
column9: proximal jejunum and terminal ileum
column10: with no evidence of bleeding from any other cause. He was subsequently admitted three times for the same reason
column11: requiring multiple units (U) of red blood cell concentrates. Enteroscopy was performed orally up to the middle jejunum
column12: during which no angiodysplasias were found
column13: and it was impossible to assess the existence of ileal angiodysplasias. At the last admission she had a haemoglobin of 10.5 g
column14: with a haematocrit of 0.340 L/L and a mean corpuscular volume of 25.7 pg. After this new episode
column15: and the episodes of bleeding persisted
column16: with no clear lesions to perform other measures such as electrofulguration or surgery
column17: it was decided to use thalidomide
column18: at a dose of 50 mg daily
column19: as a drug for compassionate use
column20: following the patient's handwritten authorisation. The patient was asymptomatic for three months
column21: with haemoglobin levels of 124 g/L and a negative faecal occult blood test over time. After this period
column22: she was admitted for a significant deterioration of her general condition
column23: with dyspnoea on minimal effort
column24: orthopnoea
column25: malleolar oedema and no chest pain. Urgent echocardiography was requested and was reported as severe pulmonary hypertension with a PSAP (pulmonary artery systolic pressure) of 100mmHg
column26: (prior to the start of thalidomide treatment
column27: the patient had a PSAP of 26mmHg measured by ultrasound) and a study was performed to rule out pulmonary thromboembolism
column28: with negative D-dimer and angiographic tomography. There was no evidence of other causes for the elevated PSAP
column29: so the drug was discontinued and treatment was started with monthly lanreotide.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O

column1: A 64-year-old man was transferred to the Internal Medicine Department from the Cardiology Department due to a fever of over 38.3 °C
column2: of more than 3 weeks' evolution with no source of origin after 5 weeks of studies. On admission
column3: the patient was being treated with gliclazide (1-1-1) and acarbose (1-1-1) to control type 2 diabetes mellitus
column4: Atorvastatin (0-0-20 mg) to control hypercholesterolemia
column5: quinapril (5 mg-0-5 mg) to control arterial hypertension and
column6: finally
column7: acetylsalicylic acid (0-150 mg-0) as vascular accident prophylaxis. In addition to these pathologies
column8: the patient had severe aortic valve stenosis together with moderate aortic insufficiency
column9: which required valve replacement with Mitroflow bioprosthesis no. 23 in March of the year of admission. When the patient was admitted to the Cardiology Department
column10: a five-week febrile condition was detected in a patient with a prosthetic valve; a transesophageal echocardiogram ruled out the presence of endocarditis or functional valvular alterations
column11: and empirical intravenous treatment with Vancomycin was started (given the existence of a prosthetic valve despite not clearly demonstrating vegetation)
column12: improving until he was asymptomatic and afebrile when discharged from Cardiology a week later. During discharge
column13: the patient underwent periodic body temperature controls
column14: and 4 weeks later a new elevation was detected
column15: which led him to our hospital and he was admitted for the second time to the Cardiology Department
column16: where endocarditis was again ruled out by transesophageal echocardiography
column17: so he was transferred to the Internal Medicine Department
column18: with a diagnosis of Classical fever of unknown origin to be studied. After admission
column19: fever of over 38.3°C
column20: with peaks of up to 39°C
column21: blood pressure of 150/70 mm of mercury
column22: and a heart rate of 104 beats per minute were confirmed. On physical examination the patient was normal colour and normal depth
column23: cardiac auscultation showed no murmurs
column24: pulmonary auscultation showed preserved vesicular murmur with no evidence of rhonchi
column25: crackles or wheezing; the abdomen was not painful and there was no evidence of splenomegaly; ENT examination showed no evidence of infectious foci; neurological examination showed no evidence of meningismus
column26: strength or sensitivity deficit
column27: or alteration of cranial nerves or osteotendinous reflexes; the examination also showed no evidence of lymphadenopathy. Complementary tests were performed for the study of fever of unknown origin according to protocol7 with a haemogram showing 14
column28: 000 leukocytes (70% neutrophils and 5% cayates) and 1371 g/dl haemoglobin. Biochemistry showed normal renal and hepatic function with normal glycaemia. A peripheral blood smear was performed which confirmed the haemogram data with no other pathological findings. Chest X-ray showed no pathological findings or changes with respect to previous admissions. A paranasal sinus X-ray showed hypoplasia of the left frontal sinus. The transesophageal echocardiogram showed no evidence of endocarditis
column29: abscesses or fistulas
column30: together with a normofunctioning aortic prosthesis. Subsequently
column31: a Ga67 scintigraphy was performed
column32: with no tracer deposits in the thoracoabdominal region. To complete the study of fever of unknown origin
column33: tumour markers (alpha-fetoprotein
column34: CEA-II
column35: Ca 19.9n Ca 125II
column37: total PSA
column39: specific neutrophil enolase
column40: Ca 72. 4) which were normal and the study of immunological markers (ENA antinuclear antibodies
column41: rheumatoid factor
column42: C-reactive protein
column43: ASLO
column44: anti-DNA antibodies
column45: ANCA
column46: anticardiolipin antibodies
column47: anti-smooth muscle antibodies
column48: antimitochondrial antibodies
column49: ANA and LKM) which were negative. On admission
column50: blood cultures were taken after taking body temperature above 37.5 °C
column51: and all four were positive for Leuconostoc spp. and the antibiogram showed sensitivity to amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and tobramycin
column52: antibiotherapy that was started from that moment onwards. Due to the existence of the bioprosthesis
column53: the patient was treated for 8 weeks as if it were endocarditis
column54: despite there being no evident lesions on transesophageal echocardiography. Periodic check-ups were carried out for 1 year after discharge without any febrile or clinical findings that would lead to any new suspicion of complications or valve complications.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 4-year-old patient came to the clinic for consultation due to tiredness
column2: the examination being normal; 5 days later
column3: she had an urticarial rash on the lower limbs which disappeared on arrival at the clinic. Two days after the last visit
column4: she developed a fever of 38.5oC
column5: it appears that she has a cold and her tiredness has increased
column6: and the macular rash persists
column7: now affecting the lower and upper limbs and face
column8: although we cannot visualise it at the time of the examination either. Physical examination: periorbital and eyelid oedema
column9: more accentuated in the morning for the last 3 days. Mouth breathing with nasal obstruction
column10: conspicuous sub-maxillary and laterocervical lymphadenopathy
column11: congestive tonsils and on abdominal palpation splenomegaly and hepatomegaly measuring 4 cm. Conspicuous inguinal adenopathies of 2 cm in diameter. Abotarated facies. No exanthema. Neurological normal. Axillary temperature of 38 oC. The rest of the examination and cardiopulmonary auscultation is normal with no signs of respiratory failure. Laboratory results - CBC: red blood cells 4
column14: haemoglobin 10.9 g/dl
column15: haematocrit 31.6%
column16: MCV 78.4. Leukocytes: 21
column17: 200 (neutrophils 2%
column18: segmented 31%
column19: lymphocytes 50%

column21: reactive lymphocytes 9%

column1: Female patient
column2: aged 26 years
column3: diagnosed with coeliac disease with anti-transglutaminase antibodies 73 U (normal value up to 10) and duodenal biopsy with enteropathy with severe villous atrophy (grade III). She progressed well on a gluten-free diet
