column1: A 52-year-old man
column2: with no past history of interest
column3: was studied after an abdominal ultrasound scan for a urological study revealed an intrahepatic cystic tumour which at first appeared to be an uncomplicated complex hepatic cyst. An abdominal CT scan was requested in which a cystic image of about 5 centimetres (cm) in diameter was found located between segments V and VIII in the shape of a bunch of grapes
column4: with septa in its interior
column5: some of which were thick and attracted significant contrast in some areas. Tumour markers were negative. Given the asymptomatic nature of the picture
column6: it was decided to follow up. In the radiological control carried out one year later
column7: the lesion increased in size (9 x 7 x 7 x 7 cm) and was located in the porto-biliary confluence
column8: without compressing it. Given the growth of the lesion
column9: it was decided to operate on the patient given the possibility of malignancy of the lesion.  During surgery
column10: a cystic
column11: polylobulated tumour was observed at the junction of segments IV and V
column12: bulging towards the hilum. The intraoperative biopsy was reported as a mucinous tumour without being able to rule out malignancy. Given the possibility of a cystadenocarcinoma
column13: a radical excision of the specimen was decided
column14: and complete resection could not be performed. Dissection revealed fistulisation of the tumour to the right hepatic duct
column15: outflow of mucinous content and intracystic polypoid lesions. The definitive histological diagnosis was mucosecretory cystadenocarcinoma which
column16: as it occurred in a male patient
column17: was more aggressive. The evolution has been favourable
column18: with adjuvant chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil and no recurrence at one year follow-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O

column1: 18-year-old woman with a history of syncope one month before the fatal event
column2: having not consulted a doctor. She was sitting with her family on the bank of a river when she suddenly felt unwell
column3: lost consciousness and fell into the water. She was immediately recovered from the water but died a few minutes later. Initially it was suspected that it could have been an accidental submersion. The autopsy was performed with a postmortem delay of 16 hours. The corpse was an athletic female of a height of 1.65 m and weight of approximately 54.5 kg (BMI 20 kg/m2)
column4: with no external signs of violence or marfanoid habitus. On opening the thoracic cavity
column5: a massive left haemothorax of 3
column6: 000 cc was found due to rupture of a saccular aneurysm of the terminal portion of the aortic arch
column7: slightly distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery. The aneurysm measured 4.2 x 4.6 cm and its markedly thinned wall was barely 1 mm thick. The rupture line measured 2 mm in length and was located in the infero-anterior region of the aneurysmal sac.  The heart weighed 200 g
column8: the expected weight being 199 g according to Kitzman's tables. At the level of the subaortic endocardium there was a clear
column9: slightly thickened area. Both the atrioventricular and semilunar valves were normal
column10: as was the origin of the coronary arteries. Histopathological examination of the aneurysm wall showed thinning of the aortic wall at the expense of rupture and loss of elastic fibres and reduction of muscle tissue which was replaced by a non-fibrillar basophilic matrix.  Given the suspicion of the existence of an atypical collagenopathy
column11: i.e. without phenotypic expression
column12: genetic screening for Marfan Syndrome was performed on the younger sister of the deceased - after genetic counselling at the Children's Hospital. The technique used was molecular genetic research of the FBN1 marker
column13: which was amplified by standard PCR protocol
column14: sequenced and quantified by electropherograms (capillary electrophoresis)
column15: analysed and compared with reference sequences. The study was negative. Other diseases were not screened due to the lack of genetic markers at that time.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 55-year-old man
column2: allergic to tetracyclines and beta-lactams with a history of arterial hypertension being followed up by the Chronic Pain Unit due to a clinical picture of low back pain and left lumbosciatica of spondyloarthrosis origin with an associated myofascial component. Medical treatment was started with tramadol
column3: pregabalin and duloxetine at the usual doses and diagnostic-therapeutic infiltration with local anaesthetic and corticoids of deep muscles (left psoas and quadratus lumborum). After a clinical improvement of more than 50%
column4: a new infiltration was scheduled
column5: according to hospital protocol
column6: of the psoas and left quadratus lumborum muscles
column7: with botulinum toxin serotype A (Dysport®) 200 IU per muscle in the same session and without incident. Four months later
column8: the patient presented a self-limited episode of eyelid ptosis without consulting for it. Since then
column9: he reported episodes of ptosis
column10: which improved after infiltration with local anaesthetic and corticosteroids of trigger points in the shoulder girdle. Six months later
column11: he presented with an episode of palpebral ptosis associated with diplopia and mandibular weakness
column12: for which he consulted the Neurology Department of the hospital and was diagnosed with myasthenia gravis (MG)

column1: A 67-year-old hypertensive patient with no history of gastroduodenal ulcus or intake of gastrolesive drugs
column2: who consulted the emergency department for melena and progressive fatigue of about two weeks' duration. Laboratory tests showed a Hb of 9.8
column3: with pallor on physical examination
column4: normotensive and acceptable general condition with negative rectal examination. An upper endoscopy showed a large submucosal lesion in the gastric fundus
column5: excavated in the centre by a fibrinous ulceration with no signs of current or recent active bleeding. It was interpreted as an ulcerated gastric submucosal lesion
column6: most probably leiomyomatous
column7: responsible for the gastrointestinal bleeding.  Radial echoendoscopy confirmed the submucosal nature of the lesion
column8: which was dependent on the fourth layer of the gastric wall (muscularis propria)
column9: hypoechogenic
column10: homogenous
column11: with delimited borders and a maximum diameter of 4.6 x 3.4 cm. Its border on the face of the gastric lumen showed an excavation secondary to an ulcer of about 2 cm in size. No perilesional or celiac trunk lymphadenopathy was observed. An echoendoscopic diagnosis was made of a gastric submucosal stromal tumour (GIST tumour) of probable muscular lineage. With this diagnosis and due to the echoendoscopic criteria of size (greater than 4 cm) and haemorrhagic complication
column12: elective surgical treatment was performed by resection and enucleation of the lesion. Histological study of the resected specimen yielded a gastric schwannoma.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 38-year-old man
column2: with hepatitis B as the only personal history of interest
column3: presented with a picture of pollakiuria and bladder urgency of 11 months' duration accompanied by terminal haematuria without clots. On physical examination
column4: the abdomen was soft and depressible with no visceromegaly or other abnormalities. On rectal examination
column5: the prostate had a volume of I/IV
column6: was elastic
column7: ill-defined and almost flat. Genitalia were normal. Blood tests with haemogram
column8: biochemistry
column9: coagulation and PSA within normal parameters. Urinalysis with pH 5.5. Urine sediment with 15-20 leucocytes/field and abundant mucus. Urine culture was sterile. Urine cytology was negative for malignant tumour cells and renal
column10: bladder and prostate ultrasound found no alterations
column11: the prostate being homogeneous
column12: with well-defined contours
column13: measuring 17 x 20 mm. Intravenous urography showed normal kidneys and ureters
column14: and a displacement of the bladder to the left and above by a subvesical pelvic mass (with no appreciable bladder filling defects). Cystourethrography showed extrinsic bladder compression.  Cystoscopy showed no endovesical changes. The abdominal-pelvic CT scan showed a large pelvic mass anterior to the bladder
column15: measuring 12 cm in diameter
column16: with well-defined contours
column17: which displaced the bladder backwards and to the left
column18: and the bowel loops cranially
column19: with a fatty plane separating the mass from the bladder. After contrast administration the mass became denser.  Since its origin was not clear
column20: MRI was performed
column21: confirming that it measured 8x12x13cm
column22: well defined
column23: located in front of the bladder and rejecting the bladder to the back and to the left. The mass formed lobulations and was delimited by a thin capsule. The diagnostic suspicion on MRI was fibroadenoma of the urachus due to its lobulated appearance and the presence of fibrous tissue with nodular areas that were enhanced by the injection of IV contrast.  The FNA diagnosis was 'morphologically benign tumour
column24: probably adenomatoid'. In view of the findings described above
column25: it was decided to remove the tumour. On bimanual palpation
column26: the mass was mobile on prostatic compression. Through a median infraumbilical incision and extraperitoneal access
column27: a pelvic mass was identified to the right of the bladder
column28: which appeared to be dependent on the anterior prostatic aspect. After opening the endopelvic fascia
column29: the thin prostatic pedicle on which the mass was dependent was sectioned. Intraoperative biopsy was reported as malignant epithelial tumour with intense reactive fibrosis. Prostatectomy was not performed pending a definitive diagnosis
column30: as macroscopically it appeared benign.  The histopathological study described
column31: macroscopically
column32: a nodular tumour with a smooth surface measuring 12.5 x 12.5 x 7 cm
column33: weighing 50 g. One of its edges was covered by a small
column34: irregularly shaped lump. On one of its edges there was a thin pedicle 0.7 mm long. Microscopically it was composed of a proliferation of spindle cells without atypia in variable numbers
column35: adopting in some areas a haemangiopericytoid-like pattern
column36: associated with a large differentiation of thick collagen bundles predominating in the tumour. There were very isolated foci of atypical cells with <4 mitoses/10 high magnification fields. The pedicle had arterial and venous structures surrounded by connective tissue within which nests with fibroblastic differentiation were identified. Immunohistochemistry showed positivity for CD34
column37: D99 and vimentin
column38: focally positive anti-desmin and broad spectrum keratins
column39: negative cytokeratin 7
column40: EMA
column41: actin
column42: enolase
column44: chromogranin and p53. The tumour proliferation index expressed by Ki67 was less than 1%. The definitive diagnosis was solitary fibrous tumour. After three years of follow-up the patient has no recurrence of the disease on MRI and is asymptomatic.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 31-year-old male with a history of post-traumatic splenectomy 14 years earlier and overweight. He presented with pneumococcal sepsis that caused multiple organ failure (renal
column2: respiratory
column3: haematological and haemodynamic) and admission to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). He remained intubated for 11 days and was subsequently transferred to the Internal Medicine ward. Due to poor perfusion secondary to sepsis
column4: necrotic lesions appeared in the upper and mainly distal lower extremities. Initially assessed by Vascular Surgery
column5: treatment with prostaglandins was indicated for 21 days. After improvement in general condition and disappearance of vital risk
column6: and after 7 weeks admitted to Internal Medicine
column7: he was transferred to Plastic Surgery for treatment of the residual necrotic lesions. On admission to our department he presented multiple small lesions on the forearms
column8: hands and thighs that epithelialised adequately with topical treatment. The most relevant complication was left plantar necrosis with extensive eschar in the plantar moulting area which was debrided in the hospital ward
column9: left plantar anaesthesia
column10: dry necrosis of the 3rd
column11: 4th and 5th toes of the right foot and a right pretibial ulcer measuring 10 x 5 cm.  We performed surgical intervention for left plantar and right pretibial debridement and daily debridements on the ward to reduce most of the slough and bedsores. After 20 days of daily debridements in the patient's room
column12: without local anaesthesia (no pain due to plantar anaesthesia and necrotic tissue)
column13: V.A.C.® therapy was started on the sole of the left foot to promote granulation
column14: avoid superinfection and allow subsequent coverage of the defect. Polyurethane sponges (VAC GranuFoam®) were applied with continuous negative pressure of 125 mmHg for the first 48h and then continued with intermittent negative pressure (5 minutes with suction and 2 minutes without suction). Silver sponges (VAC GranuFoam Silver® ) were used for the first week to improve the antibacterial effect due to the persistence of sloughing. The VAC® container collected abundant exudate during treatment. We used the VAC ATS® Therapy System. The entire treatment lasted 20 days and sponge changes were performed 3 times a week.  The patient was able to continue doing physiotherapy exercises during the treatment
column15: comfortably carrying his VAC® System in his hand
column16: when he went to the sessions in a wheelchair. The evolution was very favourable
column17: with disappearance of residual slough
column18: formation of bright red granulation tissue
column19: without the appearance of superinfection and obtaining a suitable bed to receive a skin graft.  One week after withdrawal of VAC® therapy
column20: the patient underwent surgery to cover the left plantar defect with a partial thickness skin graft taken from the thigh on the same side
column21: amputation of the 3rd
column22: 4th and 5th toes of the right foot and skin grafting on the residual right pretibial defect. The grafts attached adequately and the wounds healed well.  The patient was discharged after 4 and a half months of hospitalisation and 2 weeks after the skin graft coverage procedure. At discharge he was ambulating with the aid of crutches. Six weeks after discharge he was walking independently with the aid of a special insole fitted by the podiatrist
column23: although he requires regular care by the podiatrist due to the plantar anaesthesia which requires strict monitoring of the skin in this area.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 51-year-old woman came to the emergency department with headache of 2 months' duration. The scan showed a lytic lesion measuring 38 x 21 mm involving the left temporal calvarium immediately above the mastoid. The patient's personal history included thermocoagulation of a skin lesion in the same region in another hospital
column2: currently without apparent involvement of the skin. After performing a full body bone extension study and computed tomography (CT) of the thorax
column3: abdomen and pelvis
column4: which were negative
column5: we proceeded to surgical excision of the lesion in collaboration with the Neurosurgery Department. The lesion was removed by circumferential en bloc craniectomy including the temporalis muscle and its fascia
column6: with a macroscopic margin of 1 cm. The underlying dura mater had an apparently preserved appearance
column7: without infiltration. A 5 cm acrylic plasty was cast for the bony defect and direct scalp closure was performed.  The excised mass was soft and whitish in consistency and eroded the external and internal table of the temporal bone.  Pathological examination showed a neoplasm in multiple well-defined solid nests separated by fibrous tissue. Inside these nests
column8: atypical epithelium with frequent mitoses was found arranged around central areas formed by keratic material. All these characteristics represent a malignant tumour originating in the hair follicle and specifically a trichofollicular carcinoma.  As a consequence of the most probable origin of the tumour
column9: the history of skin lesion and the fact that the scalp had not been removed in the first operation
column10: we decided to extend the surgery and perform a revision of the bed and resection of the scalp island. The operation was scheduled by the Plastic Surgery Department 2 months after the first operation
column11: but the day before the scheduled date the patient was admitted to the Pneumology Department for haemoptysis
column12: with negative fibrobronchoscopy and CT scan showing pleural thickening
column13: and therefore a follow-up examination was recommended. Given the time that had elapsed
column14: a new control cranial CT scan was performed
column15: which revealed the presence of post-surgical changes with no signs suggestive of local recurrence or lymph node dissemination. Finally
column16: 3 months after the first operation
column17: the patient underwent another operation with extensive resection of the scalp and exposure of the previous surgical site. Intraoperatively we observed the presence of a new lesion of small size
column18: 1 cm
column19: located 1 cm from the posterior edge of the craniectomy and without contiguity with the previous one
column20: with preserved external table but eroding internal table and with apparent dural infiltration. We removed the acrylic plasty
column21: extended the craniectomy
column22: performed circumferential dural resection with margins and repaired the meninx with Neuropatch® plasty. The final bone and skin defect
column23: 12 x 7 cm in diameter
column24: was reconstructed by Plastic Surgery with a free flap of rectus abdominis muscle based on the inferior epigastric artery (TRAM) and free skin grafting of partial skin over the muscle. The location of the tumour at the junction of the middle and posterior third of the skull base made the availability of recipient vessels for the flap more complex. Finally
column25: the anastomoses were made end-to-end to the superior thyroid artery
column26: which was subsequently rotated to reach the pedicle of the flap and the external jugular vein. The anatomopathological study of the excised piece showed infiltration by a tumour with the same characteristics as the primitive one
column27: i.e. a trichofollicular carcinoma in the internal table
column28: diploe and dura mater
column29: with free borders
column30: which curiously did not infiltrate the scalp
column31: epidural tissue or local ganglia. A third surgical intervention was necessary because a new antero-superior parietal lesion without continuity with the previous craniectomy was detected in the control scan in less than 1 month of evolution. We were able to access the upper edge of the previous craniectomy through the incision of the upper edge of the TRAM flap and its extension towards the scalp on the upper temporal line. We extended the craniectomy 4x5 cm antero-superiorly to include the new lesion and the underlying dura with free margins. Closure was performed with another Neuropatch® plasty and acrylic cranioplasty only on the new bone defect (the previous bone defect was completely covered by the TRAM flap).  Both diploe and dura were infiltrated by trichofollicular carcinoma
column32: with negative resection margins. The control cranial and thoracic scan 3 months after the last operation showed no recurrence of local disease and detected the presence of 2 apical pulmonary nodules which were removed by videothoracoscopy. The anatomopathological report was of pulmonary metastases with histological image similar to that of the previous biopsies. In view of this

column36: 600 cGy. He also received adjuvant chemotherapy: 6 cycles of CDDP-5FU (cisplatin with fluorouracil) and another 4 cycles of carboplatin-taxol with a good response. Two and a half years after the diagnosis of the primary tumour
column37: and having finished this last cycle of chemotherapy

column1: A 37-year-old man
column2: with no personal or urological history of interest
column3: who came to our surgery referred from the emergency department for pain and swelling of the left testicle. He referred a picture of progressive left testicular swelling of two months' evolution. He reported no fever
column4: no accompanying urological symptoms
column5: and no general malaise. On palpation

column1: A 72-year-old man with a personal history of hypertension
column2: chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
column3: ex-smoker and diagnosed with papillary urothelial carcinoma of the bladder (T1G2). Transurethral resection of the tumour was performed and 3 weeks later treatment was started with a long course of endovesical instillations of BCG (Connaught strain

column1: Patient aged 45 years assessed in September 2000 for left hemiparesis. His medical history included smoking
column2: hypertension
column3: hypercholesterolemia
column4: peritonitis at the age of 18 and myocardial infarction in 1999. After CT and MRI

column6: with signs of dissection on MRI.  Contralateral supply was found to be present. Using the right common femoral approach
column7: a monorail metallic stent (Carotid wallstent
column8: Boston Scientific Co.) was implanted in the area of the stenosis that also extended over the pseudoaneurysmal area of the cervical course of the left internal carotid artery.  A microcatheter was introduced through the stent mesh and GDC coils (Boston Scientific Co.) were released without risk of migration. A post-procedural angiographic control showed the recovery of the lumen in the stenotic zone and the absence of filling of the pseudoaneurysm. During the procedure
column9: 5000 IU of sodium heparin was administered. Sequential anticoagulation therapy was performed in the acute phase with sodium heparin in continuous perfusion
column10: followed by dicoumarinics and
column11: subsequently
column12: antiplatelet agents.  After three years of evolution

column1: A 47-year-old woman visited the urology department after right-sided renal colic accompanied by haematuria. She was being treated with diclofenac for osteoarthritis and low back pain. X-ray and ultrasound showed a lithiasis in the middle calcific group of the right kidney and a giant renal cyst. A CT scan showed the presence of a simple renal cyst (Bosniak I)
column2: measuring 17 centimetres and distorting the right kidney
column3: and ipsilateral lithiasis measuring 8 millimetres. Hydatidosis serology was negative. Haemogram within the normal range.  The patient had lumbar discomfort and wanted to be treated for the cyst. She was informed of the different possibilities. Percutaneous drainage and sclerosis of the cyst was pending. Subsequently
column4: the patient presented with cystitis
column5: and a few days later went to the emergency department for high fever and right lumbar pain. Antibiotic treatment was prescribed at home. Two months later
column6: when percutaneous drainage was scheduled
column7: the cyst was found to have reduced in size. It measured 6.4 centimetres. In addition
column8: its wall was calcified. It was confirmed by late-slice CT scan that the cyst was communicating with the pyelocaliceal system. Microhaematuria and leucocyturia were present. column9: which was treated twice
column10: first with Amoxicillin-Clavulanic acid
column11: and then with Trimetropin-Sulfamethoxazole. Finally the infection was cured and the lithiasis was treated by extracorporeal lithotripsy. Since then the patient has been asymptomatic. One year after the cyst rupture

column13: showing that the lesion measured 2.9 centimetres in diameter
column14: with thick
column15: nodular calcifications and no contrast uptake. Bosniak IIF.  Subsequently
column16: 2 more years have elapsed. Control ultrasound scans
column17: IVUS and CT scan confirm that the appearance of the lesion has not changed. No further communication with the urinary tract has been demonstrated. The patient remains asymptomatic.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 74-year-old male patient consulted for recurrent episodes of painful red eye in the inner eye
column2: associated with progressive loss of vision over several months. He reported no relevant systemic personal history. His ophthalmic history included accidental exposure to a cleaning product 15 years earlier. Ophthalmological examination showed visual acuity (VA) of 8/10 in the right eye (RA) and 1/10 in the left eye (LO). The biomicroscopic examination revealed an area of approximately 210º of corneal conjunctivalisation affecting the visual axis
column3: with superficial vascularisation and mixed hyperemia. There was a sector of limbus of approximately 5 hours extension that preserved the normal architecture of Vogt's palisades and an absence of dye staining. The rest of the examination showed no relevant findings.  With the clinical diagnosis of partial IL with visual axis involvement
column4: an ECS of the fibrovascular tissue invading the corneal surface was performed
column5: including the affected limbar area
column6: and respecting the sector of the nasal limbus with normal characteristics. An amniotic membrane (AM) graft was placed in the denuded area and sutured with the epithelium facing upwards and then another 15 mm diameter circular fragment of AM was sutured as a patch
column7: with the epithelium facing downwards. During follow-up there was progressive re-epithelialisation with a corneal-like epithelium over the MA graft which was integrated under the MA graft. At 3 weeks after surgery there was a smooth and regular corneal epithelial surface and a significant reduction of the associated mixed hyperemia. The VA of the OI improved to 4/10. With a follow-up of 8 months no recurrences have been observed.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A child was admitted to hospital in cardiorespiratory arrest
column2: apparently due to a gunshot wound to the oropharynx
column3: according to the relatives
column4: without a first inspection showing any injuries of this nature. The court was informed and a forensic autopsy was carried out. Beforehand
column5: a radiological study of the cranial extremity and the cervical spine was carried out
column6: showing the existence of a foreign body of metallic density lodged in the spinal canal at the level of C2
column7: compatible with a firearm projectile
column8: as well as a smaller fragment in C3-C4.  Post-mortem examination Male subject
column9: 11 years old
column10: totally naked
column11: with a bloodied face. He presented as signs of medical action stitches in both wrists and left forearm and adhesive discs for electrocardiographic recording.  After cleaning the blood from his face
column12: a small crescent-shaped excoriation with a discrete loss of substance was observed on the supero-internal ridge of the right nostril.  The first step was an autopsy of the spine
column13: separating the skin coverings and muscle masses
column14: with no haemorrhagic areas visible. After sectioning the transverse processes and the skull
column15: the spinal cord is removed together with the brain
column16: and a deformed firearm projectile is found in the vertebral canal at the level of the 2nd dorsal vertebra
column17: which has partially severed the spinal cord
column18: 35 mm from the bulb.  The cervical block was then removed
column19: revealing an excoriation at the base of the tongue
column20: a large retropharyngeal haematoma and the intraosseous trajectory of the projectile. The rest of the structures and organs examined were uncharacteristic. After the operations performed
column21: it was concluded that death was caused by a single gunshot wound penetrating through a natural orifice
column22: specifically the right nostril
column23: producing at this level a small crescent-shaped wound with slight loss of substance. It follows a front-to-back and slightly up-and-down path
column24: pierces the hard palate
column25: grazes the surface of the tongue
column26: crosses the retropharyngeal space and
column27: after passing through the intervertebral disc
column28: lodges in the anterior wall of the spinal canal
column29: injuring the spinal cord.  The morphological characteristics indicated a long-distance shot
column30: possibly of a medico-legal aetiology of an accidental nature
column31: which was confirmed during the police investigation.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 53-year-old man with no past history of interest who was admitted from the emergency department with pulmonary thromboembolism. Given the suspicion of occult neoplasia and the presence of haematuria not previously evident
column2: an abdominal ultrasound scan was carried out which revealed a right renal mass and the study was completed with CT and MRI.  Both studies confirmed the presence of a heterogeneous tumour infiltrating the lower two thirds of the right kidney measuring approximately 10x10 cms. with involvement of the renal sinus and hilum
column3: also showing tumour thrombosis of the right renal vein and infrahepatic cava. No adenopathies or metastases were evident. He underwent an anterior radical nephrectomy with cavotomy to remove the thrombus and an extensive right aorto-caval lymphadenectomy. The anatomo-pathological result was Fuhrman grade 2 clear renal cell carcinoma of 9 cm with invasion of the renal hilum
column4: perinephric fat and renal vein
column5: without metastatic involvement of lymph nodes or the edges of the fat or the hilum
column6: as well as free ureter. (Stage III
column7: T3N0M0). The patient was discharged from hospital on the sixth day. Three months after the operation
column8: the patient reported slight pain and induration in the penis of recent onset. Palpation revealed an indurated mass. An MRI of the pelvis was performed
column9: which revealed the existence of a mass occupying and expanding the left corpus cavernosum
column10: compatible with metastasis of previous renal carcinoma.  A biopsy was taken of the lesion
column11: the result of which confirmed our suspicion
column12: showing isolated nests of tumour cells in the histological sections compatible with metastasis of clear cell carcinoma. Given this diagnosis
column13: we considered the best therapeutic approach for the patient
column14: taking into account the progressive increase in local pain
column15: the patient's age and his good general condition. We therefore opted for a total penectomy until a disease-free surgical border could be confirmed intraoperatively. One week after discharge
column16: the patient was admitted to the oncology department with a picture of obnubilation and motor and sensory alteration
column17: and showed lesions in the cerebellum and right cerebral hemisphere compatible with metastasis in the cranial CT scan. A CT scan of the chest also revealed multiple pulmonary nodules and bilateral paratracheal microadenopathies related to metastasis. The patient died nine months after the first operation for his renal carcinoma
column18: i.e. six months after the diagnosis of metastases in the penis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 38-year-old man
column2: with no past history of interest
column3: came to the urology clinic requesting a vasectomy. The physical examination revealed a normal male subject
column4: with penis
column5: testicles and epididymis of normal size and consistency. The right vas deferens was clearly palpable. This was not the case with the left vas deferens which could not be palpated within the spermatic cord. Rectal examination was unremarkable. In view of the suspicion of vas deferens agenesis
column6: a transrectal ultrasound was performed
column7: in which the left seminal vesicle was not visualised. IVUS revealed the complete absence of the left kidney. Subsequently
column8: an MRI confirmed the absence of the left seminal vesicle
column9: vas deferens and ureter. The patient was scheduled for vasectomy which was performed uneventfully on the right side. Control seminograms performed three months after the operation revealed complete azoospermia
column10: confirming the clinical suspicion of deferential agenesis associated with renal and homolateral seminal vesicle agenesis. The patient's first-degree relatives (two sons

column12: given the potential autosomal dominant transmission of renal agenesis
column13: and both kidneys were found to be present in all of them. column22: prior to surgery

column24: who
column25: reviewing the clinical history from admission
