column52: with no intra-abdominal lymphadenopathy. Diagnosis: Given the presence of constitutional syndrome
column53: fever
column54: pancytopenia with evidence of bone marrow infiltration
column55: myeloptysis (leukoerythroblastic reaction and dacryocytes in peripheral blood smears)
column56: and the presence of space-occupying lesions in the liver
column57: it was decided to perform a bone marrow aspirate and biopsy. However
column58: before obtaining the definitive result of the bone marrow examination
column61: evolved unfavourably and died 9 days after admission. An autopsy was not performed due to the express wishes of the family. The bone marrow examination revealed the following data: -Bone marrow aspirate: dry aspirate (suggestive of myelofibrosis). -Bone marrow biopsy: hypercellular bone marrow parenchyma (5/5)
column62: with massive and diffuse infiltration of neoplastic cells of haematopoietic appearance
column63: with myelofibrosis and necrosis phenomena. The tumour cells are large
column64: with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and bulky
column66: with prominent central nucleolus and abundant mitotic figures. No haemophagocytosis is evident. Immunohistochemistry: -CD45/ EMA/ LISOZYME (Golgi pattern)/ CD68: positive. -CD79a/ CD10/ CD23/ CD43/ IgS/ CD15/ CD30/ CD45RO/ CD1a/ CD2/ CD3/ CD4/ CD8/ CD57/ CD 34/ MPX/ FACTOR VIII/ LMP1 (EBV)/ BCL2/ P53: negative. -Cell proliferation rate (Ki 67) >80%. Tumour cells are accompanied by reactive lymphoid T cells (CD45RO/ CD2/CD3/CD8/CD57 positive) and histiocytes (CD68 positive). The definitive diagnosis on bone marrow examination was compatible with histiocytic sarcoma according to the World Health Organisation classification. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 29-year-old man consulted for several weeks for peripheral vision disturbances associated with manifestations of pituitary hypofunction. On examination he had a visual acuity (VA) of 1 in both eyes (AO)
column2: with normal anterior pole
column3: intraocular pressure and fundus (FO). The visual field (VF) (Octopus 1-2-3 programme G1X) showed a superior arcuate defect with some peripheral changes in the right eye (RA) and a superior altitudinal defect and peripheral defects in the left eye (LO).  Urinalysis revealed hypodensity of practically water and hormone function studies showed undetectable FSH and LH
column4: testosterone and growth hormone at below normal levels. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed dilatation of the left lateral ventricle
column5: periventricular involvement of the third ventricle
column6: the hypothalamus
column7: as well as the region of the chiasm and contrast-enhancing optic nerves
column8: compatible with granulomas in the aforementioned locations.  In the thoraco-abdomino-pelvic computed axial tomography (CT) with contrast
column9: numerous lymph nodes were observed at the cervical
column10: bilateral supraclavicular
column11: bilateral axillary and also at the thoracic and pelvic levels. A deep axillary adenopathy was biopsied and was found to be compatible with sarcoidosis. The patient was diagnosed with systemic sarcoidosis with central nervous system involvement
column12: involvement of the chiasm
column13: optic nerve
column14: hypothalamic-pituitary axis with panhypopituitarism (hypogonadism
column15: hypocorticism
column16: decreased growth and antidiuretic hormones). Treatment was started with methylprednisolone pulses 1g/d for 3 days
column17: and vasopressin. At one and four years the patient was stable and hormonally controlled. The CV alterations were permanent but stable and non-progressive.  VA was 1 in AO and the fundus showed a slightly verticalised papilla with pallor in the temporal region accompanied by peripapillary atrophy in OD and total pallor and temporal peripapillary atrophy in OI
column18: physiological AO excavation. OCT showed a decrease in the nerve fibre layer in the upper
column19: nasal and lower quadrant in OD and in all sectors of the OI. The visual evoked potentials with damer (PVE-pattern) showed a decrease in all recorded responses and a slight increase in latencies when stimulating the RO.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 11-year-old male patient consulted for left coxalgia of 2 years' evolution with mechanical characteristics that improved with rest. His personal history included Arnold-Chiari malformation
column2: hydrocephalus associated with Dandy Walker malformation treated with ventriculo-peritoneal shunt valve and epilepsy with partial seizures. Physical examination revealed gait dysfunction with an antalgic limp and limb adduction and lumbar hyperlordosis. The hip had 20o flexion with a range of motion of 90o flexion
column3: 20o external rotation
column4: 10o internal rotation
column5: and 20o abduction. Plain radiography showed discrete regional osteopenia ;. CT scan showed oedema and discontinuity of articular cartilage with synovial hypertrophy.  Arthrocentesis was performed under fluoroscopic control under general anaesthesia
column6: but no synovial fluid sample was obtained. The study was complemented with arthrography which confirmed the existence of severe chondrolysis. With a presumptive diagnosis of idiopathic chondrolysis
column7: rest
column8: unloading of the limb with the use of canes and physical rehabilitation were prescribed. One month later
column9: the hip was infiltrated with hyaluronic acid under radioscopic control. The evolution was torpid with persistence of symptoms despite treatment. Ten months after diagnosis
column10: gentle joint mobilisation was performed under general anaesthesia
column11: confirming movement of the femoral head en bloc with the pelvis
column12: which was assessed as fibrous ankylosis. Due to joint stiffness
column13: the option of periarticular tenotomy was ruled out. A year after diagnosis
column14: joint stiffness improved slightly
column15: so treatment was supplemented with soft tissue traction
column16: with a favourable response in terms of pain control and flexion. The patient used outpatient traction for nocturnal periods
column17: walking with English canes and continued with rehabilitation treatment for 6 months. After this treatment
column18: the flexion attitude disappeared and he was able to lead a normal life without physical activity or prolonged walking
column19: which caused episodes of pain and lameness. Four years later
column20: concentric loss of 50% of the joint space with effacement of the medial line and local osteopenia was evident. The clinical evolution was favourable with disappearance of pain and almost complete spontaneous progressive recovery of function and mobility over a period of 6 years
column21: as well as partial recovery of joint space. The MRI then showed joint narrowing with subchondral lesions in the femoral head and acetabulum
column22: without signal changes in the medullary on both sides of the joint
column23: with a destructive process of the articular cartilage. MRI was not previously performed due to lack of availability at the centre
column24: but it would have been more appropriate to perform it to make a differential diagnosis. The range of joint movement at the end of clinical follow-up was -10o for abduction
column25: internal rotation and external rotation with a dysmetry due to a 1 cm shortening of the affected limb. Currently
column26: after 14 years of follow-up since the onset of symptomatology
column27: the patient is living a normal life
column28: asymptomatic
column29: Trendelenburg (-)
column30: symmetrical and painless mobility of both hips (RI 30o
column31: RE 65o)
column32: with incomplete recovery of joint space.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 24-year-old male suffered a severe crush injury to the left upper limb. After initial care
column2: the patient presented with exposure of the osteosynthesis plate in the distal third of the radius and thrombosis of the radial and ulnar revascularisation anastomoses at the carpal level. The absence of reverse flow in the posterior interosseous artery was confirmed by Ultrasound Doppler. After debridement
column3: a radial-ulnar bypass with saphenous vein graft was performed to revascularise the limb. As a means of covering the osteosynthesis material and the distal anastomosis of the by-pass
column4: a 15x7.5 cm posterior interosseous perforator helix flap was placed on the dorsal aspect of the forearm. The skin perforator was located 4 cm proximal to the distal joint. Once the flap could be pivoted on the cutaneous perforator vessels of the posterior interosseous artery
column5: it was rotated 90 degrees along the ulnar border of the forearm until it reached the volar aspect of the carpus. The donor site was covered with a partial skin graft. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 69-year-old female patient with a history of arterial hypertension and hypercholesterolemia
column2: with end-stage chronic renal failure of unidentified aetiology
column3: nephrogenic anaemia treated with erythropoiesis-stimulating factors and secondary hyperparathyroidism. Residual diuresis was around 200 ml. per day. In 2004 she started renal replacement therapy with haemodialysis
column4: and was subsequently placed on the waiting list for a renal transplant. In January 2008 she received a cadaver donor kidney transplant in the right iliac fossa. The postoperative period was satisfactory except for two medical complications: development of diabetes mellitus requiring insulin administration and toxicity due to calcineurin inhibitors
column5: which meant that the graft was initially non-functional. She was discharged in the fifth week after the operation with creatinine of 0.9 mg/dl and diuresis of around 2000 ml per day
column6: receiving triple immunosuppressive therapy with prednisone
column7: tacrolimus and mycophenolate mofetil. He was readmitted two weeks later for a condition consisting of significant oedema in the right lower limb and deterioration of renal function
column8: with a decrease in diuresis and an increase in plasma creatinine concentration to 2 mg/dl. He was in good general condition
column9: with fever and haemodynamic manifestations absent. ECHO showed a large peri-graft collection
column10: later studied with CT
column11: extending from a level slightly more cranial than the aortic bifurcation to the rectum
column12: causing compression of the iliac vessels and displacement of the bladder.  Percutaneous puncture and pig-tail placement to drain the collection is followed by a great improvement in symptoms and biochemical analysis of the fluid obtained (creatinine 1.67 mg/dl
column13: Na 146 mEq/l
column14: K 4.3 mEq/l) confirms the clinical suspicion of lymphocele. Surgical treatment was indicated
column15: and once infection had been ruled out
column16: the lymphocele was marsupialised into the peritoneal cavity laparoscopically. The patient was discharged from surgery on the third postoperative day
column17: with normal renal function and asymptomatic. A follow-up CT scan at 14 days showed resolution of the lymphocele.    |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 75-year-old patient with moderate Alzheimer's disease who presented with abdominal pain of three days' duration
column2: with fever. On examination she presented with diffuse abdominal pain and peritonism. A computerised tomography (CT) scan was requested
column3: which revealed the presence of free fluid
column4: pneumoperitoneum
column5: with infiltration and thickening of the entire colon wall with the presence of calcified faeces inside. The location of the perforation was not visualised (image). The patient underwent urgent surgery and was found to have diffuse faecaloid peritonitis with a perforation at the level of the sigma. A Hartmann's operation was performed
column6: with a left hemicolectomy due to the finding of a new perforation at the level of the splenic angle of the colon.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 40-year-old woman attended the primary care clinic for pain in both wrists
column2: loss of strength in the hands and paraesthesia in all fingers
column3: with greater frequency and intensity in the right hand. The patient presented with chronic pain of five months' evolution with mechanical characteristics and progressive worsening
column4: associated with deformity of the wrists. There had been no previous trauma to justify the presence of the aforementioned symptoms. She has no pathological history of interest. She is right-handed and works caring for the elderly. Physical examination of both wrists revealed the presence of a deformity on the dorsal side at the level of the ulnar styloid
column5: associated with ulnar deviation. In addition
column6: there was increased sweating and reddening of the hands. The joint balance (BA) of the wrists was symmetrical: dorsal flexion: 40o. Palmar flexion: 55o. Radial deviation: 20o. ulnar deviation: 30o. Supination: last degrees missing. Pronation: complete. Pain on palpation at the level of the distal radiocarpal joint and discomfort on palpation of the radial head. He has a complete elbow AB. Muscle balance (BM) flexion-extension of the wrists is 4/5. Moreover
column7: the grip-fist-grip is complete. Opposition of the thumb is preserved. The metacarpo-phalangeal
column8: proximal interphalangeal and distal interphalangeal joints are free. There is a negative median Tinnel's sign and a doubtful median Phalen's sign. In view of the clinical findings described above
column9: an anteroposterior and lateral radiograph of both wrists is requested.  After observing the presence of deformity on the X-ray
column10: the patient was referred to the Traumatology outpatient department for assessment
column11: where a diagnosis of Madelung deformity and bilateral distal ulnar dislocation was made. Surgical treatment of carpal reconstruction was proposed
column12: but the patient refused
column13: so a referral was made to Rehabilitation. A bilateral nocturnal positional splint was prescribed
column14: plus physiotherapy treatment (toning of intrinsic hand muscles and analgesic electrotherapy).  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 57-year-old man with a history of chronic active alcoholism and secondary alcoholic liver disease
column2: who had previously been admitted to the Acute Psychiatric Unit for manic symptoms related to alcohol intake. He was admitted to Neurology from the emergency department due to clinical symptoms of progressive deterioration over a week's time
column3: with the impossibility of bipe-destation and a decrease in the level of consciousness in the last 24 hours. The patient was afebrile
column4: with a BP of 120/75 mmHg
column5: tachycardic
column6: tachypneic and icteric. Cardiopulmonary auscultation was normal. Neurologically
column7: he presented somnolence
column8: mild bilateral mydriasis
column9: bilateral facial weakness with the rest of the cranial nerves normal
column10: muscle weakness in all four limbs (lack of cooperation for balance) and generalised hyporeflexia. No tremor or agitation was observed. Emergency laboratory tests showed elevated blood glucose (233 mg/dL)
column11: normal renal function
column12: hypokalaemia
column13: metabolic acidosis with normal lactate and respiratory alkalosis (pH: 7.3
column14: bicarbonate: 11.9 mmol/L
column15: base excess: -14.4 mmol/L
column16: pO2: 104 mmHg
column17: pCO2: 24 mmHg
column18: lactate: 2.8 mmol/L). Treatment was started with intravenous hydration (5% dextrose and saline)
column19: potassium (K) replacement
column20: parenteral thiamine administration and hepatic anti-encephalopathy measures. On the hospital ward
column21: the patient's neurological condition was similar. Laboratory tests showed worsening hypokalaemia
column22: severe hypo-phosphataemia
column23: mild hypomagnesaemia
column24: hypernatraemia
column25: persistent acid-base balance disturbances and the presence of methylketone in urine. We do not have chlorine levels on admission to calculate the GAP anion
column26: nor ketone bodies in the blood. The electrocardiogram corresponded to sinus rhythm and showed no alterations associated with electrolyte deficits. At that time
column27: the Nutrition Unit was consulted to assist in the management of the patient. Hydration was continued with 5% dextrose only
column28: without saline solution
column29: the administration of parenteral thiamine already started in the ED was maintained at a dose of 100 mg/day and aggressive replacement of the different deficits was carried out intravenously. Initially
column30: 40 mmol of monopotassium phosphate was administered in 6 hours (corresponding in our case to about 0.55 mmol of P/kg body weight)
column31: after which a 5% glucose perfusion with 140 mEq of potassium chloride (2 mEq of K/kg body weight) and 24 mEq of Mg (3 g of magnesium sulphate) was prescribed over the following 24 hours. By the end of this period the acid-base balance abnormalities and hypernatraemia had been corrected. However
column32: it was necessary to maintain this high replacement rate of P (0.55 mmol P/kg/day) and K (2 mEq K/kg/day between potassium chloride and monopotassium phosphate) for 72 hours to achieve normalisation. Figure 1 shows the daily evolution of serum K
column33: P and Mg levels until complete correction. The analytical improvement was accompanied by clinical improvement
column34: which allowed oral supplementation with progressive withdrawal of parenteral intake.  Simultaneously
column35: the Neurology Department continued to carry out diagnostic studies. Computerised axial tomography showed no evidence of acute endocranial pathology
column36: although there were clear signs of corticosubcortical atrophy. The cerebrospinal fluid had a slightly xanthochromic appearance
column37: without cells
column38: with glucose 101 mg/dL
column39: protein 95 mg/dL
column40: and Adenosine deaminase 5.5 IU/L. The electroencephalogram showed rapid low-voltage baseline activity
column41: without asymmetries
column42: focality or triphasic components; and the electromyogram suggested severe axonal predominant polyradicular sensory-motor involvement of the lower extremities (LES) and mild involvement of the upper extremities (EESS). At the time of discharge the patient was fully alert
column43: with weakness 4/5 in EESS and EEII. Definitive diagnoses were: alcoholic ketoacidosis (AKA)
column44: severe hypophosphataemia and hypokalaemia
column45: mild hypomagnesaemia
column46: and confusional syndrome and acute axonal sensory-motor polyradiculoneuritis secondary to severe hypophosphataemia.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 21-year-old woman
column2: with no previous history of interest
column3: who initially consulted the emergency department of her health centre due to odynophagia and fever
column4: was diagnosed with acute pharyngitis
column5: and was prescribed treatment with oral amoxicillin for a week. Once the treatment was completed
column6: the patient visited her primary care physician
column7: reporting a remission of fever but persistent odynophagia
column8: which she related to a lesion on the left lateral edge of the tongue. Examination revealed an ulcerated lesion
column9: whitish in colour
column10: approximately 1 cm in diameter
column11: on the lateral edge of the tongue
column12: about 3.4 cm from the tip. No lymphadenopathy or other oropharyngeal lesions were found. The lesion was labelled as a lingual aphthous ulcer
column13: in the context of a post-infectious condition
column14: and symptomatic treatment was prescribed to alleviate the discomfort. After 15 days
column15: the lesion did not improve
column16: and on re-interrogation of the patient it was found that the lesion may have preceded the infectious condition
column17: with these data the patient was referred for a biopsy of the lesion. The intraoperative biopsy diagnosed squamous cell carcinoma that reached the surgical edge. The microscopic description showed an ulcerated neoformation that infiltrated deep to the vicinity of the deep resection edge without reaching it. The neoformation consists of epithelial cells arranged in nests or cords. These cells have a low mitotic index and have a tendency to form horny globes. The diagnosis is well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma infiltrating to the vicinity of the surgical resection margin. Subsequently
column18: a biopsy of a cervical fibroadipose fragment containing 25 lymph nodes was performed and all 25 were negative for tumour cells. The patient underwent surgery where a functional neck dissection and a left hemiglossectomy was performed using CO2 laser. The evolution was satisfactory
column19: being asymptomatic up to the present time and with no signs of recurrence.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 65-year-old man
column2: with a history of transurethral resection (TUR) for high-grade superficial transitional cell bladder neoplasia (pT1 G3)
column3: with subsequent low-grade recurrence
column4: with the following history of interest: smoker of more than 1 pack/day
column5: AHT
column6: severe COPD and dilated cardiomyopathy. During follow-up for his bladder neoplasia
column7: an abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan was performed without intravenous (IV) contrast
column8: in which a heterogeneous nodular lesion with fatty content (hypodense)
column9: 2 cm in diameter
column10: well-defined borders and retroperitoneal location
column11: posterior to the inferior vena cava
column12: was observed as a casual finding. The study was completed with an abdominal ultrasound scan showing a retroperitoneal hyperechoic lesion in contact with the right lateral aspect of the inferior vena cava.  A wait-and-see approach was adopted and a follow-up CT scan was performed one year later
column13: showing an enlargement of the mass (4 cm maximum diameter) which displaced and compressed the inferior vena cava medially without showing signs of invasion. In view of the suspicion of retroperitoneal liposarcoma
column14: magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with IV gadolinium was performed
column15: confirming the fat content of the lesion and a discrete heterogeneous contrast uptake. The T1 sequences showed a hyperintense lesion
column16: although slightly inferior to the retroperitoneal
column17: mesenteric and subcutaneous fat
column18: with an area of lower intensity in the upper pole of the lesion. The fat suppression technique showed a discrete hyperintensity compared to perilesional fat mainly in the upper half.  In the opposite phase images the lesion was hypointense with a nodular area at its upper pole of higher signal intensity corresponding to the area of lower intensity in the T1 sequence and higher intensity in the fat suppression. After gadolinium administration
column19: a discrete gadolinium uptake was observed. With the radiological diagnosis of a fatty tumour
column20: probably liposarcoma (given its predominant frequency among retroperitoneal masses)
column21: surgery was decided. A reniform mass was surgically removed
column22: posterior to the inferior vena cava and anchored in the retroperitoneum to the anterior vertebral ligament
column23: 2 cm from the right renal vein at its lower edge. The lesion had no vascular pedicle
column24: showing only small peripheral lymphatics. A pseudoencapsulated lobular tumour measuring 6 x 5 cm
column25: with an adipose consistency and a greyish-yellowish colour was referred for pathological examination. Histology of the specimen revealed a well-demarcated adipose tumour
column26: showing extensive haematopoietic islets with the presence of the 3 series together with rounded lymphoid aggregates
column27: diagnostic of lumbar prevertebral myelolipoma
column28: although a bone marrow study was recommended in order to rule out its primary pathology (extramedullary haematopoiesis in the context of a myelodysplastic-myeloproliferative syndrome). The latter possibility was ruled out by analysis of the bone marrow
column29: confirming the diagnosis of retroperitoneal extra-adrenal myelolipoma.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 40-year-old female patient who presented to her general practitioner with daytime sleepiness and frequent nocturnal awakenings over a period of months
column2: to which was now added a significant tension headache in the occipital and temporal regions. The patient was referred to the pulmonologist with the suspicion of sleep apnoea syndrome
column3: which was ruled out by the relevant tests
column4: including polysomnography. As the pain component was increasing
column5: the patient was referred to our Orofacial Pain Unit. The clinical examination revealed an Angle class 2 occlusion
column6: with slight occlusal wear
column7: as well as signs and symptoms of masticatory muscle pain due to myofascial syndrome with trigger points in the masseter and sterno-cleido-mastoid muscles on both sides. The patient also reported back pain
column8: heavy digestion and meteorism. Treatment was started with NSAIDs and muscle relaxants
column9: as well as a Michigan type flat occlusal splint. After 3 months
column10: the patient came for consultation showing a clear improvement in facial pain
column11: although she reported a poor night's rest with frequent awakenings. On examining the splint
column12: a dark green staining-impregnation reminiscent of gastric contents (juice) was observed...  Suspecting gastro-oesophageal reflux
column13: the patient was referred to the gastroenterologist
column14: who after performing the relevant tests (Ph-metry and endoscopy) confirmed the diagnosis. The patient was treated with diet
column15: postural measures and proton pump inhibitors (Omeprazole). At the next review
column16: after 6 months
column17: the symptoms had almost completely subsided and the patient continued with the treatment protocol for her myofascial syndrome.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 47-year-old woman came to our department 3 months after discovering a tumour in the left preauricular region. The patient reported that the lesion was of sudden onset and progressive growth. She complained of pain in the temporal
column2: cervical and left periocular region. Her medical history included only essential arterial hypertension and treatment with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
column3: with no other relevant systemic alterations. Physical examination revealed a nodule approximately 1.5 cm in diameter in the left preauricular region. On palpation
column4: the tumour was soft
column5: mobile and slightly tender to the touch. The maximum oral opening is 45 mm and there is joint popping in both joints. The rest of the head and neck examination is unremarkable. Computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) reveal an image suggestive of a cystic lesion measuring 1.8 × 1.7 × 1.4 cm adjacent to the upper border of the parotid gland. The MRI shows a left TMJ-dependent pedicle
column6: with the position of the articular meniscus and displacement of the mandibular condyle with open and closed mouth being normal.  A fine needle aspiration puncture was performed
column7: which was reported as a sample consisting entirely of proteinaceous material and histiocytes
column8: compatible with a cystic lesion. In view of the findings obtained
column9: surgical treatment was carried out using a preauricular approach
column10: identifying the trunk of the facial nerve and its respective branches. After dissection of the facial nerve
column11: it was decided to perform a superficial parotidectomy of the upper portion as multiple adhesions to the lesion were found
column12: isolating the synovial cyst above the frontal branch of the facial nerve. Subsequently
column13: the pedicle that communicates the cyst with the temporomandibular joint was visualised
column14: proceeding to its ligation and subsequent resection. The wound was sutured in planes.  The surgical specimen obtained was fixed with 10% formalin. Histological sections stained with haematoxylin and eosin revealed a multilocular cystic lesion. To establish with certainty the presence of synoviocytes in the cyst lining
column15: immunohistochemical analysis confirmed their existence.  During the outpatient follow-up of the patient after 9 months of evolution
column16: she has shown no postoperative complications or signs of recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A healthy 24-year-old woman presented with gingival bleeding in the right upper right posterior teeth during the last 6 months. The patient also reported episodes of mild pain and a gradual deviation of the teeth. There were no signs of fever or pus. A general systemic examination of the patient revealed no abnormalities. Local examination revealed a diffuse swelling of 1 x 3 cm in the alveolus corresponding to the upper right molars. The swelling was more prominent on the vestibular side. The surface appeared rough and erythematous. There were no visible pulsations in the lesion. The aforementioned teeth were deviated towards the palate. On palpation
column2: the swelling showed a hard consistency. The three affected teeth did not respond to heat
column3: cold or electrical pulp stimulation. Orthopantomography was inconclusive. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan showed a soft tissue mass in the right maxillary alveolus
column4: without bone erosion. Radiological examinations and routine haematological examinations
column5: including coagulation tests
column6: revealed no abnormalities.  Based on clinical
column7: radiological and CT findings
column8: a provisional diagnosis of giant cell lesion was made
column9: and an incisional biopsy of the vestibular gingiva was performed. Marginally increased intraoperative bleeding was evident
column10: but was attributed to inflammation. The pathology report of the specimen revealed fibrovascular connective tissue with aggregates of numerous dilated endothelial capillaries and venules suggestive of AVM. After consultation with an interventional radiologist
column11: resection of the lesion was decided and performed under general anaesthesia. The single specimen included vestibular and palatal gingivae
column12: alveoli
column13: and the affected teeth. Haemostasis was achieved and the defect was closed by first intention by advancement of the palate and buccal mucosa. The perioperative period and recovery was uneventful and comfortable for the patient. Pathological analysis of the specimen was very similar to that of the incisional biopsy and revealed numerous arterioles and venules interspersed between the bony trabeculae
column14: extending into the gingiva suggesting arterio-venous malformation.  The patient was followed up for a period of 1 year without recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 30-year-old male suffered an accident while loading a speargun at home. The emergency services were notified. After protocol "A
column2: B
column3: C" the clinical examination of the patient showed only a penetrating wound at the level of the submandibular region. The approximate size of the spear was 80 cm long and 1 cm in diameter with an intracranial trajectory of about 15 cm. The firefighters carefully cut the harpoon to facilitate the transfer of the patient to hospital. The patient was haemodynamically stable
column4: alert and oriented (Glasgow 15)
column5: with no neurological deficit and no active bleeding. There were blood clots in the left ear canal. There was no cerebrospinal fluid leaking from the entry wound or the external auditory canal. The lateral skull X-ray showed the trajectory
column6: direction and the existence of a beard mechanism in the harpoon. An emergency CT scan was performed which showed the direction of the arrow. The entry orifice was in the left submaxillary region and penetrated to the carotid siphon of the left temporal bone crest
column7: passing very close to the petrosal sinus. The flap of the harpoon was located at the level of the left mandibular condyle on its inner side. Under general anaesthesia and nasotracheal intubation
column8: the patient was placed in a supine and neutral head position. The position of the harpoon
column9: adjacent to the left mandibular condyle
column10: made oral opening difficult. Despite this
column11: access was made intraorally at the level of the left tonsillar pillar. A 4 cm incision was made. Through this approach
column12: the harpoon was exposed at the level of the flipper mechanism. Subsequently
column13: the barba mechanism of the harpoon was inactivated by means of a steel wire ligature.  Finally
column14: under intraoral control
column15: the harpoon was extracted in the opposite direction to its entry.  No cerebrospinal fluid was observed to leak from the entry wound or from the intraoral access. The intraoral wound was sutured with 3/0 vicryl
column16: the subcutaneous with 4/0 vicryl and the submandibular wound with 4/0 prolene. Immediately after the operation
column17: a follow-up CT scan was performed
column18: showing only a small pneumocephalus.  The patient was kept under observation for 24 hours without showing neurological focality. Subsequently
column19: he went to the ward and was discharged on postoperative day 3 without any neurological disorder. No complications were reported. One month later
column20: an audiometry was performed which revealed a conductive hearing loss of 60% in the left ear. The patient is now living a normal life and is only waiting for a hearing aid.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male patient
column2: aged 37 years
column3: who came to the clinic with a right paramandibular nodule
column4: 6 years old
column5: which has increased in size in the last year. He reported that the lesion appeared after the exodontia of a lower molar.46 On examination
column6: the patient presented a nodule 1.5 cm in diameter
column7: at the bottom of the vestibule
column8: at the level of 45 and theoretical 46. The lesion was mobile
column9: well demarcated
column10: elastic in consistency and painful on palpation. The overlying mucosa was normal. An orthopantomography was performed and no mandibular pathology was observed. Resection of the lesion was performed under local anaesthesia
column11: previously locating the exit of the mentonian nerve to preserve it.1  Macroscopically
column12: the lesion was a well-demarcated
column13: whitish
column14: nodular lesion measuring 2 x 1.5 x 1 cm in size. Microscopically the lesion consisted of uniform spindle-shaped cells with poorly defined cytoplasmic boundaries
column15: oval or round nuclei
column16: without mitosis or nuclear pleomorphism. The cells were randomly arranged interspersed with collagen fibres and isolated blood vessels. There were no areas of necrosis
column17: no haemangiopericytoid pattern. At the periphery the lesion was delimited by a connective tissue border.  Immunohistochemically the lesion cells were: strongly positive for: vimentin
column18: CD34 and bcl2 ; weakly positive for: factor XIIIa and muscle specific actin (1A4); and negative for: S-100 protein
column19: cytokeratins (CAM 5
column21: desmin and muscle actin (HHF35).  The postoperative course was uneventful
column22: and one year after surgery there are no signs of local or regional recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: FP
column2: a 22-year-old black woman
column3: who consulted in November 2000
column4: due to facial asymmetry
column5: pain and a sensation of crepitus at the left infraorbital level. She presented a tumour of progressive growth in the left hemimaxillary region of 5 months of evolution. On facial examination
column6: an increase in volume was observed in the left infraorbital region
column7: which markedly raised the lower eyelid
column8: making it difficult for the patient to look down and to the right. There was deformation of the nasal pyramid and obstruction of the left nostril due to reduced permeability as a result of the elevation of the nasal floor and deformation of the nasal intersinus septum.  The patient did not present ocular alterations
column9: she reported that she felt the lesion growing and that she presented anterior nasal corrsion which was not objectified. The oral examination showed a stable and repeatable occlusion
column10: caries in tooth 24 and mobility and displacement of tooth 22. A large mass of diffuse limits
column11: covered by healthy and erythematous mucosa
column12: deformed the left upper labial vestibule and the palatal vault. On palpation
column13: the lesion had crepitant and soft areas
column14: was asymptomatic
column15: and had clear boundaries. Orthopantomography showed a unilocular homogeneous radiolucent mass of approximately 5.5 cm in greatest diameter
column16: located in a shape corresponding to a lesion in a maxillary globular position20
column17: displacing the roots of teeth 22 and 23 and with rhizolysis of both roots. It also displaced the maxillary sinus and reached the infraorbital rim
column18: with clear boundaries but no corticalisation. In the CT scan
column19: axial and coronal slices showed a radiolucent mass with trabeculations inside
column20: extending from the alveolar ridge to the infraorbital rim
column21: raising the left floor and destroying the intersinuso-nasal wall at the bottom
column22: coming into contact with the nasal septum. It expanded and thinned the cortices and in some areas perforated them.  The protocol described above for the treatment of GCL was implemented. A series of infiltrations were performed between December 2000 and January 2001. At the end of this period
column23: the patient informed that she was pregnant and all treatment was suspended until the end of the pregnancy. In October 2001
column24: almost a month after delivery
column25: the patient returned
column26: reporting that she no longer felt the crepitus. On physical examination the lesion was more localised and on palpation the entire lesion was bony in consistency. On CT scan
column27: axial and coronal slices showed an image which
column28: unlike the lesion on the initial CT scans
column29: was radiopaque with a radiolucent central nucleus. Its boundaries were indistinguishable from healthy bone.  In view of these findings
column30: 11 months after the start of treatment
column31: it was decided to perform surgical enucleation. Under general anaesthesia and through a buccal approach
column32: the lesion was accessed. As in case 1
column33: an increase in bone volume was found without clear boundaries with the normal bone structure. Surgical remodelling of the lesion was performed with drills. It was necessary to reshape the infraorbital rim and the piriform notch.  Clinically and radiographically
column34: at 22 months follow-up there is no evidence of residual lesion or recurrence. Root canal treatment was not performed on the 22nd and 23rd teeth
column35: which are healthy. Currently
column36: the patient is clinically cured 28 months after the start of treatment and 17 months after surgical remodelling.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 34-year-old woman
column2: 18 weeks pregnant
column3: attended the emergency department because during an episode of hyperemesis gravidarum with projectile vomiting she suddenly presented with right supraorbital swelling with ocular proptosis and visual alterations of the right eye. The patient had no personal history of interest
column4: was not taking any regular medication and had not previously suffered any trauma. Ophthalmological examination revealed exophthalmos with hypophthalmos of the right eye
column5: right mydriasis of 7 mm with decreased pupillary reactivity
column6: limited supraduction and supraversion with diplopia
column7: myodesopsia and painful upper eyelid oedema on palpation. Fundus examination was normal with intraocular pressure of 24 mmHg. No oedema or vascular abnormalities were observed in the conjunctiva.  As the patient was pregnant
column8: an urgent orbital magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan was requested and the findings were compatible with a diagnosis of right extraconal intraorbital right intraorbital haematoma. A blood test based on routine haemogram
column9: biochemistry and coagulation showed no abnormalities that could have precipitated the picture. Given the clinical repercussions and the increasingly evident changes in the patient's vision
column10: it was decided to perform urgent surgery to evacuate the haematoma and decompress the orbit under general anaesthesia. A right upper blepharoplasty approach was performed
column11: dissecting the orbicularis oculi muscle and the periosteum
column12: until reaching the orbital supero-external bony rim. When the periosteum was incised at the level of the orbital aspect of the frontal bone
column13: blood and clots from the extraconal haematoma were released under pressure. After evacuation of the haematoma there were no bleeding spots from any vessels in the region. A fine Penrose drain was placed and treatment for hyperemesis gravidarum was started with pyridoxine 10 mg/8 h iv + thiamine 100 mg/24 h iv + metoclopramide 10 mg/8 h iv.  The patient evolved favourably after surgery
column14: with mydriasis and visual alterations disappearing in the first postoperative hours
column15: and the drainage was removed after 48 h. Currently
column16: 3 months after surgery

column1: A 62-year-old man with long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus secondary to chronic calcific pancreatitis with a tendency to hypoglycaemia due to the administration of rapid insulin
column2: multiple admissions for urinary infectious conditions and functional deterioration. On admission
column3: he suffered from neglect of personal hygiene with uncontrolled elimination habits
column4: malnutrition
column5: chronic renal failure

Culture of the ulcer exudate showed that it was positive for MRSA and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and the antibiogram showed that MRSA was sensitive only to colistin (MIC < 2) and intermediate to amikacin (MIC = 16). MRSA was sensitive to co-trimoxazole (MIC < 1/19) and intermediate to clindamycin (MIC = 1.9). Treatment was initiated with colistin cream 0.1% with daily application to the dressing and oral cotrimoxazole 800/160 mg every 12 hours for MRSA treatment. After one month of treatment
column7: a favourable clinical evolution of the ulcer was observed
column8: with growth of edges and granulation tissue
column9: which had not been observed prior to topical treatment. The patient died due to chronic renal failure exacerbated by urinary sepsis
column10: for which reason a post-treatment culture was not available.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 39-year-old man with no toxic habits
column2: allergic to acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) and diclofenac. He initially consulted for soft tissue swelling associated with palpable purpura in both lower limbs in April 2001. Immunological tests revealed positive cryoglobulinaemia with a cryocrit of 9.2% (IgM kappa monoclonal IgM and IgG component). Serologies for hepatotropic viruses and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) were negative
column3: as were antiphospholipid antibodies. Physical examination revealed palpable purpura in the lower extremities; the rest of the examination was unremarkable. A thoracoabdominal computed tomography (CT) scan showed no lymphadenopathy or visceromegaly. With the suggestion of cutaneous vasculitis
column4: treatment was started with prednisone at a dose of 1 mg/kg/day
column5: with an initial favourable evolution and disappearance of the lesions. One year after the first consultation
column6: the patient reported paresthesia in the lower limbs
column7: again associated with petechiae in the same location
column8: this time presenting with nephritic syndrome. Laboratory tests showed hypocomplementemia
column9: a cryocrit of 17% and a proteinogram with a faint abnormal band in the gamma zone. Serum immunoelectrophoresis: restricted mobility component IgM kappa (there was no evidence of monoclonality in the urine). Renal function showed creatinine 1.2 mg/dl
column10: sediment with red blood cells +++ and proteinuria 2.8 g/day. Renal biopsy confirmed the presence of glomerulonephritis with mesangiocapillary pattern. Azathioprine was added to the treatment
column11: with maintenance of renal function and proteinuria of around 1g.  After six years of follow-up
column12: an analytical control revealed a peripheral blood immunophenotype compatible with LLP. This finding was later corroborated with a bone marrow aspirate in which bone marrow infiltration by chronic small B-cell lymphoproliferative syndrome was observed
column13: compatible with quiescent LLP
column14: so at that time he did not require chemotherapy treatment. One year later
column15: the patient presented persistent proteinuria of 4.7 g/24 h
column16: so it was decided to perform a new renal biopsy that confirmed the presence of cryoglobulinemic glomerulonephritis and also showed lymphocytic infiltration compatible with low-grade B lymphoma. Given the renal involvement by the lymphoma
column17: it was decided to start treatment with rituximab at a dose of 375 mg/m2 subcutaneous (s.c.) x 4 and plasma exchange.  Two years after anti-CD20 treatment
column18: the patient has lymphoproliferative syndrome in remission and renal involvement is maintained in the form of residual proteinuria (4 g/day) with preserved renal function (Cr 0.8 mg/dl
column19: GFR: 100 ml/min) under treatment with double blockade of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 71-year-old woman with no past history of interest who
column2: after 6 months of dermatitis on the face
column3: trunk and extremities
column4: was diagnosed in July 2013 by skin biopsy as having DM with skin involvement
column5: without reporting muscle weakness. Muscle enzymes CK and aldolase were normal. ANA positive (1:320) and Mi-1:Mi-2 positive (1:320) with anti-P155/140 negative. Tumour markers and a complete CT scan do not demonstrate the presence of neoplasia. Acute phase reactants are elevated
column6: CRP 44.2 mg/L [0 - 5] and ESR 73 mm/h [0 - 19]. He was treated with prednisone at a dose of 30 mg/24 h in various descending doses for 4 months. During this period
column7: she progressively began to experience myalgia and muscle weakness that forced her to be bedridden
column8: with fever
column9: dysphagia and weight loss of 10 kg. In December 2013
column10: she was admitted on suspicion of DM with the appearance of myopathy. An electromyogram (EMG)
column11: magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and muscle biopsy confirmed inflammatory myopathy in the proximal muscles of the extremities. An oesophagogram confirmed significant oesophageal motor impairment and delayed gastric emptying. She was diagnosed with MD with muscular and digestive involvement
column12: as well as skin involvement. The pulmonary study and echocardiogram were normal. For the first 8 days
column13: corticosteroid therapy prior to admission was maintained. Cinitapride was prescribed as a prokinetic. On the ninth day
column14: after confirming the myopathy
column15: azathioprine 50 mg/24h was started. Intravenous (IV) methylprednisolone pulses were added for 3 days
column16: followed by prednisone 30 mg/24h for 2 weeks (then a tapering schedule). On the seventh day after starting azathioprine
column17: GOT/AST 160 U/L [2 - 35] and GPT/ALT 313 U/L [2 - 35] were detected
column18: the previous levels being normal. It was decided to discontinue azathioprine due to hepatotoxicity and the pharmacist reported the suspected adverse reaction to the Pharmacovigilance Centre. Mycophenolate 500 mg/24h is started
column19: for which the patient signs an informed consent form and the documentation for the use of drugs in special situations is completed. The dose was increased to 1 g/12h.  After 6 weeks of treatment
column20: she reported improvement in muscle strength
column21: increased physical activity
column22: significant reduction in dysphagia and dermatitis
column23: with normalisation of acute phase reactants and transaminases
column24: continuing with normal CK and aldolase. It was decided to discontinue cinitapride and continue with a tapering prednisone regimen. After 9 weeks of therapy
column25: she reported hair loss and paresthesia in the lower limbs
column26: which are described as frequent adverse reactions in the mycophenolate data sheet. At week 12 the prednisone dose was lowered from 10 mg to 7.5 mg /24h. At the 14-week follow-up
column27: the patient described a 10-cm pruritic erythematous plaque similar to those seen at the onset of the disease. The only change observed in the laboratory tests was an increase in CRP to 29.2 mg/L. The alopecia stabilised
column28: the paraesthesia disappeared and it was decided to return to 10 mg of prednisone every 24 hours. At week 16
column29: CRP normalised to 4.1 mg/L and the skin condition disappeared
column30: returning to a dose of 7.5 mg /24h of prednisone. At week 20
column31: CRP remained in range and there were no signs of dermatitis
column32: and prednisone 7.5 mg /24h plus 1 g /12h of mycophenolate therapy was considered safe and effective in controlling the disease in this patient.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present a 38-year-old male patient with no past history of interest who came to the emergency department with syncopal symptoms accompanied by a melanic-rectorrhagic stool. Examination: conscious and oriented
column2: BP 106/68 mmHg
column3: abdomen soft and depressible
column4: positive rectal examination for haematic debris. The blood test showed a CBC of 30%
column5: then 23% and a urea level of 67 mg/dl. A gastroscopy was performed
column6: which was normal
column7: and a colonoscopy up to the cecum and terminal ileum showed incipient angiodysplastic lesions of the colon and rectum. A capsule endoscopy was requested
column8: which showed no pathological findings
column9: and subsequently a Tc99m-pertechnetate scan showed the existence of a focal hyperactive area in the right iliac fossa adjacent to the right iliac artery suggestive of the existence of ectopic gastric mucosa compatible with Meckel's diverticulum in that location. It was decided to operate under general anaesthesia with a Mc Burney incision
column10: observing a Meckel's diverticulum 60 cm from the ileocaecal valve with a wide base (> 50% of the surface of the intestinal diameter) and inflammatory signs. Intestinal resection was performed
column11: including the diverticulum and a mechanical latero-lateral anastomosis plus prophylactic appendectomy. The postoperative period was uneventful and he was discharged on the 5th day. No blood transfusion was required. The pathological anatomy reported Meckel's diverticulum with heterotopic gastric mucosa.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 60-year-old woman diagnosed in January 2010 with BCR-ABL positive CML. From diagnosis until April 2011 she received treatment with imatinib 400mg/day with acceptable tolerance (moderate symptoms of tiredness
column2: pain
column3: burning and swelling in the legs
column4: oedema of the eyelids and appearance of whitish lesions in the nail bed) and a very rapid haematological response
column5: with normalisation of the haemogram within a week. In April 2011
column6: due to the progression of the molecular signal and the acquisition of the Y253F mutation in peripheral blood (PB) and bone marrow (BM)
column7: imatinib was replaced by dasatinib 100mg/day. The Y253F mutation confers resistance to imatinib
column8: intermediate sensitivity to nilotinib and sensitivity to dasatinib. The patient presented good clinical tolerance during treatment with dasatinib
column9: except for the appearance of a persistent cough and asthenia
column10: achieving a major molecular response. During treatment with dasatinib
column11: the patient developed pancytopenia with blast infiltration of the BM
column12: a diagnosis of lymphoid blast crisis was made and the T315I mutation in the ABL kinase domain was detected. Once morphological remission of the blast crisis was achieved after the administration of induction chemotherapy with vincristine
column13: daunorubicin
column14: steroids and intrathecal prophylaxis and given the previous exposure to imatinib and dasatinib
column15: the haematology department decided to start treatment with ponatinib in September 2012. Initially
column16: the dose administered was 45mg per day
column17: which had to be reduced to 30mg per day due to clinical intolerance
column18: mainly osteomuscular pain
column19: asthenia and elevated blood pressure
column20: which required adjustment of the antihypertensive treatment. Currently
column21: the patient maintains a complete haematological and molecular response with acceptable tolerance. She has recently been assessed in the pre-transplant consultation of the Haematology Department for the possibility of consolidation with allogeneic HSCT from an unrelated donor
column22: as she does not have an HLA-matched sibling.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A boy aged 9 years and 8 months
column2: with no past history of interest
column3: was referred to the paediatric emergency department from his health centre for headache and proptosis. Onset of symptoms 4 days earlier
column4: with fever
column5: vomiting
column6: headache and nasal congestion; diagnosed at his health centre with sinusitis and on antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid for 48 hours
column7: with no improvement in symptoms. He reported severe right frontotemporal headache and right eyelid oedema that had evolved into proptosis in the last few hours. Physical examination revealed slight proptosis of the right eye
column8: with slight eyelid swelling
column9: as well as obstruction of the nostril on the same side. The neurological examination revealed only a slight difficulty in conjugate gaze. Given the poor clinical course of the sinusitis and the appearance of neurological symptoms
column10: an emergency cranial CT scan was performed with the clinical suspicion of a possible intracranial complication. The CT scan showed pansinusitis
column11: a subperiosteal phlegmon on the medial wall of the right orbit and a small right frontal subdural empyema (1.8 x 1.8 x 0.6 cm).   After a joint assessment with professionals from the neurosurgery department
column12: it was decided to maintain a wait-and-see attitude. Empirical intravenous treatment was started with cefotaxime
column13: vancomycin and metronidazole. The primary focus (pansinusitis) was drained and the sinuses were evacuated via a nasal approach. All cultures were negative. The clinical course was favourable
column14: with disappearance of the symptoms a few days after the start of treatment. The patient underwent serial imaging tests (MRI)
column15: which showed a gradual decrease until complete disappearance eighteen days after treatment. Blood tests showed normalisation of the infectious parameters
column16: with leukopenia and hypertransaminasemia secondary to the antibiotic treatment.   Antibiotic treatment was discontinued twenty-six days after the start of treatment and the patient was discharged. Subsequently
column17: he was monitored on an outpatient basis
column18: with no evidence of neurological sequelae
column19: and with absolute normalisation of the analytical parameters.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 26-year-old man with a decrease in visual acuity (VA) in the left eye (LA) of two years' evolution. Carrier of the causal mutation of VHL disease
column2: father and brother with systemic manifestations of the syndrome. On examination
column3: the VA of the LA is 0.4. The left fundus showed an orange endophytic tumour of two papillary diameters in the superior temporal arcade with dilated nutrient vessels. A systemic study was requested
column4: which also showed multiple solid nodules in both kidneys suggestive of bilateral hypernephroma (later confirmed after radical left nephrectomy)
column5: a hypercapillary nodule in the right adrenal gland
column6: a probable pancreatic neuroendocrine tumour and multiple haemangioblastomas in the pons and spinal cord
column7: with mild associated medullary oedema.  Argon laser photocoagulation was started in two sessions during which subretinal haemorrhage along the vascular arcade and vitreous haemorrhage (VH) occurred. Two months later
column8: in the absence of reabsorption of the VH
column9: a 23G vitrectomy was performed
column10: during which treatment of the lesion was completed using an endolaser. Three months after surgery
column11: VA was 0.6. OCT reveals a good foveal profile
column12: with resolution of macular oedema. The AFG confirms the closure of the nutritional vessels
column13: the lesion has a cicatricial appearance
column14: and although it captures early on
column15: there is no leakage
column16: with replacement vessels being seen in the periphery of the lesion.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 45-year-old man
column2: quarry worker for 23 years
column3: diagnosed with complicated silicosis (PMF). Ex-smoker for 10 years (15 packets/year) and pulmonary tuberculosis (TBP) in 2000
column4: correctly treated with recurrence in 2003. He had required frequent courses of steroids in the last 2 years. She presented to the emergency department for dyspnoea and haemoptotic expectoration of 5 months' duration. Physical examination showed febrile fever (37.3oC). Pulmonary auscultation showed rhonchi and bilateral wheezing. Blood tests showed haemoglobin 11.9 g/l; platelets: 515
column5: 000 / mm3; sedimentation rate 79 mm/h and C-reactive protein 50 mg/l. Arterial blood gases showed respiratory failure (pH 7.45
column6: arterial oxygen pressure 59 mm Hg and arterial carbon dioxide pressure 35 mm Hg). Chest X-ray showed a bilateral micronodular pattern with clusters in both upper lobes. Computerised axial tomography (CT) revealed extensive bilateral interstitial involvement in relation to silicosis complicated by the formation of large masses of progressive massive fibrosis (PMF)
column7: which showed cavitation in their interior not present in the CT 9 months earlier
column8: with mamelon formations in their interior at the level of the right upper lobe (LSD). Fibrobronchoscopy showed no significant findings and bronchoaspirate cytology showed no malignancy. Sputum lowestein culture was negative and fungal culture was positive for Aspergillus fumigatus. A CT scan showed that the cavitated lesion had shrunk in size after 7 months of treatment with voriconazole. The patient is currently being evaluated for lung transplantation.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male patient
column2: aged 64 years
column3: with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for 20 years
column4: poorly treated
column5: systemic arterial hypertension diagnosed 6 months previously without treatment
column6: heart failure diagnosed 6 months previously and diagnosis of chronic renal failure
column7: also made 6 months previously
column8: treated with peritoneal dialysis. He presented with symptoms of 2 weeks' evolution
column9: following hospitalisation for metabolic decompensation
column10: where a transurethral catheter was placed for 2 weeks; he reported abdominal pain in the hypogastrium
column11: of moderate intensity and oppressive type
column12: radiating to the glans penis
column13: and the use of self-prescribed topical treatments without improvement. The pain intensified to the point of being incapacitating 3 days prior to admission
column14: so he came to our department. She denied fever or other accompanying symptoms. Physical examination revealed an unaltered abdomen
column15: a penis with necrosis on the glans penis and purulent discharge through the urethral meatus
column16: as well as areas of necrosis on the first and second ortex of both feet. Laboratory tests showed: haemoglobin 9.9 g/dl
column17: leucocytes 11
column19: platelets 304
column21: glucose 138 mg/dl
column22: BUN 143.8 mg/dl
column23: creatinine 7.71 mg/dl
column24: calcium 7.79 mmol/l
column25: phosphorus 7.08 mmol/l
column26: potassium 5.75 mmol/l
column28: pCO2 47 mmHg and HCO3 17.1 mmol/l. He underwent phalectomy
column29: firstly partial
column30: but in the trans-operative period it was decided to perform a total phalectomy due to lack of vascularity up to the base of the penis; in addition

column32: resection edges with dystrophic calcification of the arterial media. The result of secretion culture was Escherichia coli
column33: for which he received antibiotic therapy for 7 days.
