column1: We present the case of an 11-year-old boy from Gambia who consulted for macroscopic haematuria predominantly at the end of micturition and dysuria of one year's duration; there was no history of fever. On taking the medical history
column2: the patient reported a recent trip to his country of origin and several baths in lakes in the region. Physical examination was unremarkable. In view of the clinical suspicion of bilharzhiasis
column3: the Microbiology Department of the referral hospital was contacted
column4: where they indicated urine collection on three consecutive days
column5: preferably at midday and at the end of urination (when egg excretion is at its peak) and a renovesical ultrasound examination was requested. The microbiological study showed Schistosoma haematobium eggs.  The bladder ultrasound revealed a parietal thickening that reached a maximum thickness of 9 mm in a radius of 20 mm
column6: suggesting schistosomiasis
column7: for which treatment with praziquantel was prescribed.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O

column1: A 29-day-old newborn weighing 4
column2: 100 kg was brought by his parents to the health centre for evaluation for facial rash. On examination
column3: his paediatrician observed tachycardia and tachypnoea
column4: and pulse oximetry showed a heart rate of 255 bpm and O2 Sat: 97%
column5: so he was referred to hospital. Until then
column6: he tolerated feeding well and showed good weight gain. Pregnancy and delivery were normal
column7: being full term with Apgar 8/9
column8: birth weight 3
column10: length 51.5 cm and head circumference 31.8 cm. No family history of interest was noted. On arrival at the emergency department
column11: he had a good general appearance with good colour
column12: tachypnoea and subcostal tugging
column13: a heart rate of over 250 beats per minute (bpm) with an O2 Sat of 97%. A few minutes later he presented with worsening general condition
column14: coldness and acral cyanosis and facial pallor. The ECG showed supraventricular tachycardia morphology with narrow QRS complexes
column15: retrograde P waves and a heart rate of 288 bpm.  Vagal manoeuvres were performed (ice on the face) with no effect
column16: so 1 intravenous (IV) bolus of 50 µg/kg of adenosine was administered without response and 3 minutes later a second bolus of 100 µg/kg was administered
column17: the tachycardia subsided and reverted to sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 168 bpm
column18: with improvement in skin colouring and general appearance. Since we have 2 ml ampoules of Adenocor® with 6 mg of drug available in our environment
column19: dilutions were necessary. In our case
column20: we took 0.5 ml (1.5 mg) diluted with 14.5 ml of saline
column21: obtaining a concentration of 100 µg/ml. An initial dose of 2 ml (50 µg/kg) is then administered and in the absence of response a second dose of 4 ml (100 µg/kg) is administered. After resolution of the tachycardia
column22: the patient was transferred to the paediatric intensive care unit (PICU) of the referral hospital for follow-up and evaluation. During the following 24 hours
column23: he presented a new episode of supraventricular tachycardia
column24: also resolved with adenosine
column25: and subsequently remained asymptomatic. Normal echocardiography was reported. To date
column26: he has not presented any recurrence
column27: maintaining prophylactic treatment with propranolol.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O

column1: A 20-year-old man
column2: fisherman
column3: with no medical history of interest
column4: presented with pain and swelling in the index finger of 2 days' evolution

column6: pain on palpation over the flexor tendon path of the second finger and pain on passive extension of the finger. Ultrasonography revealed a hypoechogenic area around the flexor tendon of the index finger and marked synovial hypervascularisation. On surgical exploration
column7: a small amount of pus was evacuated into the synovial sheath by drainage with opening of the A1 and A5 pulleys and irrigation system.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male
column2: 57 years old. With a history of right nephroureterectomy for transitional cell carcinoma in 1991 and radical cystoprostatectomy with Bricker-type urinary diversion in 1995 (pTis No Mo
column3: performed due to BCG-refractory bladder carcinoma in situ). He came to our clinic to assess the possibility of converting his urinary diversion
column4: as he presented stoma prolapse and reported that his life was very limited by the external self-adhesive device. A thoraco-abdominal CT scan was requested as a restaging study
column5: and no signs of tumour activity were found. His baseline creatinine was 1.5 mg/dl. An exploratory laparoscopy was performed in May 2003
column6: with complete dissection of the pelvis
column7: identifying the urethral stump with a Benique. The urethral stump was resected and intraoperative biopsy ruled out tumour infiltration. The neobladder (Studer) was constructed after exteriorising 45 cm of terminal ileum through the stoma orifice. The urethra-neobladder anastomosis was performed laparoscopically. The total operative time was 480 minutes
column8: with an estimated bleeding of 100 cc. The patient was discharged on the sixth postoperative day without complications.  The evolution since then (29 months) has been favourable
column9: with no evidence of metabolic alterations or signs of recurrence of the baseline disease.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 67-year-old woman with multiple risk factors: hypertension
column2: hypercholesterolemia
column3: dysglycosis
column4: obesity
column5: acute coronary syndrome
column6: etc. She had a single left kidney with stenosis due to stage 3 chronic kidney disease (K/DOQUI Guidelines) secondary to ischaemic nephropathy with preserved diuresis. Angiographically
column7: he presented critical stenosis of the left renal artery and uncontrolled hypertension despite drug treatment with quintuple therapy (angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
column8: beta-blockers
column9: calcium antagonists
column10: diuretics and alpha-blockers). Previous tests showed a creatinine level of 1.9-2.4 mg % and a rebellious blood pressure (BP). Her anaesthetic risk is moderate
column11: and she underwent scheduled surgery to place a stent in the left renal artery under locoregional anaesthesia with continuous blood pressure monitoring. During surgery she is haemodynamically stable
column12: with maintained diuresis. During the postoperative period
column13: he began with sudden intense pain in the left renal fossa accompanied by hypotension
column14: vegetative symptoms and sudden oligoanuria. Subsequently
column15: he began with chest pain
column16: radiating to the back
column17: with no changes in the electrocardiogram or elevation of cardiac markers. However
column18: treatment for ischaemic heart disease was started. Given the suspicion of stent thrombosis
column19: an arteriography was performed via the left femoral artery confirming renal artery thrombosis (thrombolysis was attempted without success) and migration of the stent
column20: which was unsuccessfully repositioned. During the procedure he was haemodynamically unstable and required vasoactive drugs and blood transfusion; in anuria
column21: with increased urea and creatinine levels
column22: so a dialysis catheter was implanted. He required high doses of vasoactive drugs to maintain BP
column23: haemodiafiltration due to anuria with rising urea and creatinine levels and echocardiography which ruled out cardiogenic component. He presented coagulation alterations with no evidence of active bleeding and rapid clinical deterioration with respiratory failure dependent on mechanical ventilation. Abdominal computed axial tomography showed the presence of a retroperitoneal haematoma
column24: and urgent laparotomy was performed. The situation was complicated by the presence of distributive shock refractory to vasoactive drugs
column25: systemic inflammatory response syndrome and anuric renal failure
column26: and led to a situation of multi-organ failure secondary to complications of vascular surgery on renal ischaemia in a single patient who was finally exhaled
column27: the immediate cause of which was shock refractory to treatment.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 47-year-old male patient
column2: with no toxic habits or pathological history of interest
column3: came to the andrology clinic for prolonged
column4: non-painful erections of approximately 4 years' duration after blunt perineal trauma with the handlebars of a bicycle. Physical examination revealed enlarged corpora cavernosa
column5: not painful on palpation
column6: with no palpable abnormal pulses. Penile sensitivity was preserved. Mobile testicles in both scrotal pouches without alterations. As complementary explorations
column7: penile Doppler ultrasound was performed: right cavernous vascularisation apparently preserved; in the most proximal portion of the left corpus cavernosum an anechoic formation was observed (2x1.8x1.5cm) with turbulent flow in its interior
column8: compatible with a long-standing arteriovenous fistula (AVF).  With the diagnosis of high flow Priapism
column9: it was decided to perform pudendal arteriography under local anaesthesia confirming AVF and subsequent embolisation of the same by means of 2 coil 3x5.  After embolisation the patient evolves favourably with complete penile detumecence and normal erections. He is currently asymptomatic.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 88-year-old woman admitted for painless obstructive jaundice. Her personal history included deep vein thrombosis
column2: duodenal ulcer with upper gastrointestinal bleeding and ischaemic heart disease under treatment. She began with colicky pain in the right hypochondrium for a week
column3: associated with fever
column4: jaundice (choluria and acholia)
column5: nausea and vomiting. On examination
column6: the patient had a painful abdomen in the right hypochondrium. Abdominal ultrasound revealed a homogeneous liver with dilatation of the intra-extrahepatic bile duct
column7: a very dilated common bile duct
column8: 22 mm to its most distal portion at its mouth in the papilla. No lithiasis or possible obstructive cause was observed. The pancreatic area had a normal ultrasound appearance. Doubtful hypoechogenicity and increased volume of the pancreatic head. Wirsung at the limit of normality and distended gallbladder. Laboratory tests showed: total bilirubin 11 mg/dl; 8.23 mg/dl of direct mg/dl
column9: amylase 1
column10: 435 mU/ml and haemoglobin 11 g/l. Transparihepatic cholangiography was performed as a diagnostic and therapeutic measure. This showed moderate dilatation of the intrahepatic bile duct with moderate dilatation of the common bile duct secondary to obstruction at the level of the distal portion of the duodenum. Passage through the obstruction was achieved and an internal-external drainage catheter was left in place
column11: and its proper placement and functioning was confirmed by cholangiography. During the following days she developed haemobilia with catheter obstruction that self-limited
column12: with a fall in haemoglobin levels and no haemodynamic repercussions. Given the age of the patient and the diagnosis of pancreatic head neoplasia
column13: palliative treatment was chosen with placement of a stent (biliary wall stent 10 x 70 mm in length) which was lodged from the proximal common bile duct to the interior of the duodenal lumen. After placement of the stent
column14: she developed episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding with haemodynamic repercussions in the following days
column15: requiring transfusion. There was no previous diagnostic method because it seemed difficult to suspect the cause. Selective arteriography was chosen to diagnose the location of the active bleeding. Selective arteriography of the celiac trunk and hepatic artery was performed
column16: and a 1 cm pseudoaneurysm was visualised in the right hepatic artery branch. Selective catheterisation was attempted to introduce a metallic coil
column17: which was technically unsuccessful due to tortuosity of the celiac trunk and hepatic artery that expelled the catheter. A new selective splenic and hepatic arteriography was performed
column18: visualising permeability of the splenoportal axis and pseudoaneurysm of the intrahepatic branch of the hepatic artery
column19: achieving selective catheterisation of the branch with pseudoaneurysm and introduction of a metallic coil 3-5 mm in diameter
column20: achieving closure of the bleeding vessel. The evolution was satisfactory with control of the bleeding
column21: as well as good drainage of the biliary tract with normalisation of bilirubin levels.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 62-year-old man
column2: partially edentulous and not wearing prostheses
column3: smoker since the age of 12 (20 cigarettes a day). He consulted for a painful tumour measuring 5 x 3 cm on the tongue
column4: which had developed over a month
column5: and a weight loss of approximately 6 kg in two months. The tumour was located on the right free edge
column6: extending towards the base of the tongue. There was an ulcer unrelated to chronic dental or prosthetic trauma.  A biopsy of the ulcerated area was taken and histology suggested a differential diagnosis between pseudosarcomatous carcinoma and epithelioid-fusocellular sarcoma. One month later
column7: pulmonary metastases were seen on chest X-ray
column8: osteolytic images in the dorsal-lumbar spine and two subcutaneous nodules on the dorsum. Biopsy of a dorsal nodule showed the same diagnosis as in the tongue. No treatment was given and the patient was admitted to palliative care and died 6 months later. Pathological anatomy: tongue biopsy (haematoxylin-eosin): infiltrating and ulcerated epithelioid and fusocellular neoplastic proliferation
column9: with a high mitotic index. Differential diagnosis between pseudosarcomatous carcinoma and epithelioid and spindle cell sarcoma.  Immunohistochemistry: negative pankeratin (AE1-AE3)
column10: positive vimentin
column11: negative desmin (positive in non-tumour muscle)
column12: negative CD34 and positive actin in spindle cell component (positive intrinsic control in vessels and non-invaded muscle). Immunohistochemical diagnosis: infiltrating leiomyosarcoma of the tongue.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 67 year old female patient was referred to the Maxillofacial Surgery Department of our hospital
column2: presenting with a circumscribed tumour in the left parotid region. On palpation it had a pasty consistency
column3: easily movable
column4: with no signs of infection or skin alterations. No palpable adenopathy was found in the lymph node chains of the neck. There was no pain in the area of the tumour. No alterations were observed on intraoral examination. The time of evolution was 3 years. The patient had no other relevant systemic alterations.  A CT scan was requested
column5: which showed that the tumour involved the superficial lobe of the left parotid gland. There was no evidence of alterations in the surrounding tissues. Given the clinical picture
column6: the presumptive diagnosis is a benign salivary gland tumour.  Under general anaesthesia and through an extraoral approach
column7: the tumour was removed
column8: performing a superficial lobectomy of the parotid gland with preservation of the facial nerve.  Pathological anatomy confirmed the diagnosis of benign myoepithelioma. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals typical markers for clear myoepithelial cells: actin
column9: S- 100 protein and vimentin.8 The postoperative course is uneventful. Only a paresis of the peribuccal muscles is evident on the operated side
column10: which completely resolves after 3 months. After one year of follow-up
column11: no signs of recurrence were detected.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Five-year-old male patient who
column2: after suffering an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) attack in a public place
column3: was evacuated to a local health care centre and was first diagnosed with a diaphyseal fracture of the left femur. The fracture was not adequately reduced and he was immobilised in a splint. He was evacuated to the second Spanish military surgical echelon ROLE 2 in Herat
column4: Afghanistan for definitive treatment.  After noting the unacceptable fracture reduction
column5: it was decided to carry out a surgical procedure of Damage Control Orthopaedics consisting of a reduction and immobilisation by external fixation. In the absence of TENS-type elastic endomedullary rods or external fixators for the paediatric age group
column6: external fixation by means of an external wrist fixator (used as a circumstantial method) on the left femoral diaphysis was decided upon. In the operating theatre and after anaesthetic optimisation
column7: the surgical procedure is performed
column8: which involves debridement of the necrotic soft tissues with profuse pulsatile lavage. Scopy confirmed the presence of a transverse and unstable femoral diaphysis fracture. Closed reduction with scopic control of the fracture was performed
column9: and an external fixation technique was carried out by implanting a Stryker™ TRIAX external fixator (wrist and small fragment external fixator used here as a method of circumstance) in a monoplane and monotube configuration. Two proximal pins and two distal pins and check under scopia for correct pin placement.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 50-year-old male patient with a crisis of profuse sweating
column2: loss of 10% of body weight and pain in the left knee
column3: without fever
column4: of six months' evolution
column5: who consulted for pain and enlargement of the left thigh. His laboratory tests (including LDH) showed no abnormal values and
column6: clinically
column7: he was diagnosed with osteomyelitis of the left trochanter. Radiology of the pelvis showed a single lytic lesion in the left femoral head confirmed by CT
column8: 99Tc and 67Ga scintigraphy. Bone biopsy was reported as lymphoproliferative bone involvement with the possibility of HL. One month later
column9: referred to our Oncology Unit
column10: the physical examination revealed an adenopathic mass of 7 cm in diameter in the left axilla and bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathies of months of evolution. Previous symptomatology was interpreted as B symptoms and new laboratory data showed a b2µglobulin of 5 mg/l
column11: LDH 670 and negative serology for HIV and hepatovirus. The axillary mass was biopsied and reported as nodular sclerosis type HL. The lymph node architecture was distorted by fibrous tracts between nodules of lymphocytes
column12: plasma cells
column13: neutrophils
column14: histiocytes and CD-30+ cells
column15: with clear cytoplasm and lobulated nuclei. There was focal positivity for CD-15 and EMA and almost all tumour cells were Ki-67+. Bone marrow biopsy was reported as fibrosis associated with LH infiltration. CT scan showed lymphadenopathy in the left axilla
column16: supraclavicular
column17: mediastinum
column18: retroperitoneum
column19: pelvis and groin. From 24-2-2000 to 29-9-2000
column20: the patient received seven cycles of QT in ABVD regimen. By the second cycle
column21: the B symptoms and peripheral adenopathies had disappeared. By the fourth
column22: the ß2µglobulin (1.7 mg/l) and LDH (398) values were normal
column23: and by the sixth
column24: the CT scan showed only sclerosis of the left iliac blade
column25: the bone marrow biopsy showed no LH infiltration and the 67Gallium scan was negative. On 15-1-2001
column26: the response was consolidated with 3 cycles of QT in MOPP regimen and RT (36 Gy) on the left femur. To date
column27: the patient is free of relapse. QT regimens used in the treatment ABVD (every 2 weeks): Doxorubicin 25 mg/m2 + Bleomycin 10 mg/m2 + Vinblastine 6 mg/m2 + Dacarbazine 375 mg/m2. COPP (every 4 weeks): Day 1: Cyclophosphamide 650 mg/m2 + Vincristine 1.4 mg/m2 + Procarbazine 100 mg/m2. Day 8: Cyclophosphamide 650 mg/m2 + Vincristine 1.4 mg/m2. Days 1-14: Prednisone 40 mg/m2.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 66-year-old male patient with a history of hyperglycaemia on dietary treatment
column2: epididymal tuberculosis (TBC)
column3: vocal cord decortication and a smoker of 40 cigarettes/day
column4: who came to the outpatient clinic for an episode of haematuria. Physical examination: good general condition. Rectal examination: grade I-II/IV prostate
column5: elastic consistency
column6: preserved limits. No suspicious areas were observed. Blood tests were performed (haemogram: red blood cells 5.09 million/mm; haemoglobin 15.8 g/dl; haematocrit 47.35%; platelets 250.0 thousand/mm; leukocytes 10.67 thousand/mm (neutrophils 47.10%
column7: lymphocytes 44.9%
column8: eosinophils 1.20%
column9: basophils 0.8%). Coagulation study: no alterations. Biochemistry: no alterations; PSA 2.9) and urine (urine systemic: density 1015; pH 6.5; leucocytes 500/microl; nitrites negative; erythrocytes 10/field. Sediment: abundant leukocytes)
column10: with negative urine cytology (intense acute inflammatory component)
column11: simple abdominal X-ray showing lithiasis in the lower pole of the left kidney and abdominal ultrasound with normal right kidney
column12: lithiasis in the lower pole of the left kidney and irregular dilatation of the ureter on the same side. At the bladder level
column13: a mass of approximately 1 cm in maximum diameter was observed on the left lateral side. IVUS was performed
column14: showing a left kidney with calyceal dilatation and irregularities all around
column15: dilatation of the ureter on the same side
column16: with tortuous and irregular contours
column17: up to the iliac ureter. In its last 8-10 cm up to the bladder
column18: the ureter has a normal appearance. Cystogram with contour irregularities in its upper portion. Cystoscopy was carried out and a tumour was observed on the left lateral side of the bladder
column19: with a solid appearance and whitish colouring
column20: which prevented the left ureteral orifice from being seen. A Löwenstein urine culture was requested and TUR of the bladder mass was performed. The postoperative course was uneventful. PA report: granulomatous tuberculoid cystitis
column21: compatible with TB. Lowenstein urine test: positive for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Diagnosis of genitourinary tuberculosis with bladder tuberculoma and left renoureteral involvement and tuberculostatic treatment was started (Isoniazid 5 mg/kg/day + Pyrazinamide 30 mg/kg/day + Rifampicin 10 mg/kg/day for 2 months. Isoniazid + Rifampicin at the same doses for the following 4 months). During his follow-up (14 months after diagnosis and after treatment was completed)
column22: he developed a fistula with exudate in the left teste
column23: the staining of which did not show any BAAR
column24: with negative Lowenstein. It closed with local dressings. A control testicular ultrasound was performed
column25: showing chronic changes in both epididymides with small bilateral hydrocele. Control IVUS was carried out and showed good evolution
column26: improving the function and morphology of the urinary tract (left). In the last IVU performed (4 years after diagnosis)
column27: an alteration in the morphology of the lower pole of the left kidney was observed
column28: with a decrease in the cortical area and associated variegated calcification in the parenchyma
column29: all in relation to her diagnosis of TB. Ureters of normal calibre and morphology. Stress bladder and prostatic hypertrophy. Negative Löwenstein urine cultures were maintained at the end of medical treatment.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We refer the case of a 73-year-old female patient who consulted for jaundice and constitutional syndrome of less than 2 months' duration. In the emergency department there was evidence of a large painful hepatomegaly and analytical tests showed leukocytosis with neutrophilia and mixed alteration of the liver profile
column2: predominantly cholestatic (alkaline phosphatase and GGT more than 10 times the normal value and ALT and AST less than 3 times the normal value)
column3: without hepatic insufficiency.  Twenty-four hours after admission
column4: he began with confusional symptoms that rapidly progressed to coma and fever of over 39ºC. An abdominal ultrasound and CT scan were performed
column5: showing multiple space-occupying
column6: hypodense
column7: solid liver lesions distributed in both lobes and occupying practically the entire organ
column8: suggestive of MTS. No infectious focus was found
column9: several blood cultures were sterile and
column10: by CT
column11: the presence of brain lesions had been ruled out.  Analytically
column12: the liver profile deteriorated
column13: presenting a significant elevation of transaminases in the range of acute hepatitis (ALT and AST greater than 20 times the normal value with a significant increase in LDH) and signs of liver failure with progressive deterioration of renal function. Despite intensive treatment with anti-encephalopathy measures
column14: vasoactive drugs
column15: broad-spectrum antibiotics at high doses (to cover the CNS as a possible focus) and transfusion of fresh frozen plasma
column16: the patient died 5 days after admission as a result of multi-organ failure
column17: without establishing the nature of the liver lesions or their origin due to the rapid evolution. For this reason
column18: a clinical autopsy was performed. The necropsy confirmed the existence of extensive hepatic MTS. The primary tumour was a caecal adenocarcinoma 3 x 2 cm in diameter
column19: Dukes stage D and Astler-Coller stage IV. It had serous and perivascular fatty infiltration and lymphatic and venular infiltration. MTS in locoregional infradiaphragmatic lymph nodes and lung parenchyma. In addition
column20: lesions of associated ischaemic hepatitis and cholangiolitis and extensive pancreatic and peripancreatic autolysis were observed.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 58-year-old patient with a history of venous thrombosis in MMII. Rest of the patient was of no interest. She presented with an ulcerated lesion at the level of the left jugal mucosa
column2: approximately 3 cm in diameter
column3: compatible with squamous cell carcinoma. A 2 cm diameter lymphadenopathy was also palpable at cervical level I.  Surgery was performed and the tumour lesion was resected with a safety margin and unilateral functional cervical dissection. The defect was reconstructed using a medial brachial graft from the left arm. The pedicle of the flap was taken from the ACCS
column4: which was anastomosed with the facial artery
column5: and the thyrolinguinguofacial venous trunk (TVTLF)
column6: which was joined to one of the concomitant veins of the ACCS
column7: as no blood refluxed through the basilic vein. The length of the pedicle was about 6 cm
column8: the diameter of the artery 1.5 mm and the diameter of the vein 1 mm.  The intraoral defect was completely covered
column9: providing sufficient volume
column10: and the arm skin closure was performed directly without the need for a free graft.  The patient was discharged 10 days after the operation and the graft was found to be viable.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 57-year-old male patient with a history of type II diabetes mellitus
column2: hypertension and ischaemic heart disease was studied in our clinic for proliferative diabetic retinopathy. His visual acuity was 20/50 in the right eye (OD) and 20/25 in the left eye (OI). He had previously been treated with argon laser panretino-photocoagulation in both eyes
column3: as well as pars plana vitrectomy and stripping of the internal limiting membrane with intravitreal triamcinolone injection in OD due to vitreous haemorrhage and chronic diffuse macular oedema. There were no residual neovascular membranes on fundus examination
column4: but microaneurysms and haemorrhages in the posterior pole of both eyes. In the left eye
column5: there were some AMIR in the temporal macular area. Fluorescein angiography was performed using 5 ml of 10% sodium fluorescein. Equatorial ischaemic areas and diffuse macular oedema and AMIR were observed in the left eye
column6: but no neovascular membranes were observed. In this eye and after 8 minutes of angiogram
column7: active bleeding from the AMIR occurred. Eye movement left different traces of blood in the vitreous cavity. The bleeding was brief and self-limited
column8: with no symptoms initially. Shortly afterwards the patient began to notice myodesopsias. Two weeks later
column9: the vitreous haemorrhage resolved without consequences.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 60-year-old smoker diagnosed with hypothyroidism after thyroid ablation with radioactive iodine and severe OG with bilateral optic neuropathy
column2: classified according to the Clinical Activity Criteria (CAS) with a score of 5 out of 7: pseudophakia in both eyes
column3: inferior punctata OD
column4: palpebral oedema
column5: conjunctival hyperemia and chemosis and caruncle hyperemia and oedema. Visual acuity (VA) was also measured
column6: despite not being included in the CAS criteria for evaluating the capacity of the visual system
column7: obtaining a VA of 0.4 in the right eye (R.O.) and VA of 0.5 in the left eye (L.O.). Normal VA is equal to 1. He started with ocular symptoms 1 year before diagnosis. The aim of treatment was to restore euthyroidism
column8: smoking cessation and disease control by intermittent high-dose intravenous corticosteroids (6 doses of methylprednisolone 500 mg/week
column9: followed by 6 doses of methylprednisolone 250 mg/week). Despite this
column10: little response was obtained and bilateral orbital decompression was necessary due to worsening VA. However
column11: the orbitopathy continued to progress to a VA of finger count in OD and VA less than 0.05 in OI
column12: necessitating a second orbital decompression. Having exhausted all therapeutic possibilities
column13: authorisation for the use of Tocilizumab "off-label" in this patient was requested from the Pharmacy and Therapeutics Committee of our hospital. After obtaining authorisation and informed consent
column14: treatment was started with intravenous Tocilizumab at a dose of 8 mg/kg body weight
column15: once every 4 weeks
column16: for a total of 5 doses. After 2 weeks from the start of treatment
column17: the patient began to show an improvement in the signs and symptoms of the pathology
column18: both subjective and objective
column19: with the VA in the OI at this time being equal to 0.05. At 9 weeks the improvement continued
column20: showing a VA in the LAA equal to 0.1
column21: with almost no signs of oedema and conjunctival and palpebral erythema. At 18 weeks the VA in the LA was equal to 0.6 and after 20 weeks of treatment the VA in the LA reached a value of 1 (normal VA). In the OD
column22: the improvement could not be quantified at that time due to the strabismus present after the decompressions performed
column23: and surgical intervention was pending to resolve this pathology. After 5 sessions with Tocilizumab
column24: the patient has no inflammatory activity and a VA of 0.1 in the OD and VA of 1 in the OI with no adverse effects
column25: with a CAS score of 0 out of 7.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 29-year-old woman who underwent a follow-up pelvic ultrasound examination after laparoscopic tubal ligation. During the study
column2: a 20 mm tumour was detected on the right lateral aspect of the bladder
column3: well defined and hypoechoic. The patient had no micturition symptoms
column4: as she mentioned in the subsequent interrogation.  Intravenous urography was performed
column5: which did not detect any alteration of the upper urinary tract. The cystogram showed a rounded
column6: smooth-surfaced repletion defect located in the right bladder wall. Blood and urine tests were within normal limits. The patient underwent cystoscopy
column7: which revealed the presence of a "hump-shaped" tumour with a smooth surface and preserved mucosa on the right lateral aspect of the bladder
column8: immediately above and in front of the ipsilateral ureteral meatus.  With the presumptive diagnosis of bladder leiomyoma
column9: transurethral resection of the tumour was performed. The resected fragments had a whitish
column10: solid and compact appearance
column11: similar to that of a prostatic adenoma
column12: with little bleeding. The material obtained from the transurethral resection consisted of a proliferation of spindle cells with elongated cytoplasm
column13: like the nucleus
column14: and slightly eosinophilic. No mitoses or atypia were observed. Immunohistochemistry showed positivity for muscle-specific actin (DAKO
column15: clone HHF35 ) in the proliferating cells.  Three months after transurethral resection
column16: a control cystoscopy was performed
column17: showing a raised calcareous plaque over the area of previous resection
column18: compatible with encrusting cystopathy
column19: which was treated by transurethral resection of this and leiomyomatous debris and subsequent urinary acidification.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 27-year-old woman
column2: 27 weeks pregnant
column3: wearing a seat belt
column4: driver
column5: who had a head-on collision with another vehicle during an overtaking manoeuvre
column6: presented with cranioencephalic trauma with loss of consciousness. In the emergency department she presented with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15; 90 minutes after the accident she developed dysarthria and aphasia
column7: with no obstetric involvement. She was admitted to the ICU 2h 15min after the accident
column8: with motor aphasia
column9: right proximal hemiplegia and right extensor plantar cutaneous reflex
column10: cutaneous mark of the seat belt in the abdominal area and in the left lateral cervical region. A cranial CT scan and an extracranial Doppler ultrasound were performed without pathological findings. At 18h
column11: a cranial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine and an angio-MRI of the supra-aortic trunks and intracranial vessels were performed
column12: These showed an acute infarction in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery affecting the corpus striatum and the left frontoparietal corticosubcortical region
column13: as well as a diffuse decrease in the calibre of the left ICA with severe stenosis of the C6-C7 supraclinoid segment
column14: secondary to arterial dissection. Platelet antiplatelet therapy was started with 200mg of ASA. Subsequently a dead foetus was detected by ultrasound; a caesarean section was performed 24h later.  At hospital discharge
column15: 2 weeks after the accident
column16: she presented with minimal predominantly motor dysphasia
column17: and 3/5 proximal hemiparesis in the right upper extremity and 0/5 distal hemiparesis in the right lower extremity.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 24-year-old woman with a history of congenital endotropia and medial rectus surgery at the age of 3 years. On examination she had residual endotropia and DVD. Surgery was performed according to the technique of lateral rectus resection and retoinsertion of both superior rectus loops. Four months after surgery
column2: she presented a cystic conjunctival lesion with signs of inflammation in the upper nasal sector of her left eye. Drainage was performed and a mucopurulent liquid was obtained
column3: which led to a diagnosis of subconjunctival abscess. Treatment was started with topical ciprofloxacin and dexamethasone and systemic ciprofloxacin. After one month the lesion recurred without inflammatory signs and progressive growth was observed. Complete surgical excision of the lesion
column4: which is adjacent to the primitive insertion of the upper rectum
column5: was performed. The histopathological diagnosis was a benign cystic lesion. The study revealed the existence of a cystic formation with a fibrous wall including vessels and some lymphoid aggregates
column6: partially lined on the inner surface by a flat stratified epithelium
column7: with no significant atypia or mitoses. After surgery the lesion did not recur.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 74-year-old male who had undergone surgery for a left frontal parasagittal transitional meningioma (WHO grade I). One month after this surgery
column2: he consulted for infection of the surgical wound
column3: which had a central dehiscent area from which purulent material was coming out. The patient had had no fever
column4: his general condition was good and he had a normal neurological examination. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) performed at that time showed
column5: adjacent to the craniectomy site
column6: a hypodense subdural collection
column7: with bubbles inside
column8: which was peripherally enhanced after gadolinium administration. The craniotomy was reopened and a purulent epidural collection emerged
column9: which was evacuated and sent for microbiological study. Empirical antibiotic therapy was started with intravenous ceftazidime and vancomycin. Bacterial cultures were negative. The patient was discharged with oral treatment with ciprofloxacin and cotrimoxazole for two weeks.  One and a half months after discharge
column10: the patient was brought to the emergency department for a generalised tonic-clonic seizure. He had been febrile for the previous days with no other clinical data of interest. On physical examination he was in good general condition
column11: afebrile
column12: had a Glasgow Glasgow of 15/15
column13: showed no neurological focality and the surgical wound showed no evidence of infection. Anticonvulsant treatment was started and a CT scan was performed
column14: which revealed a predominantly hypodense subdural collection
column15: with peripheral enhancement after contrast administration and a convex internal margin towards the brain parenchyma. Air persisted within the collection. Empirical antibiotic treatment was started with ceftazidime and vancomycin. With the diagnostic suspicion of recurrence of subdural empyema
column16: a third craniectomy was performed which revealed a subdural collection with a purulent appearance that was evacuated. Samples were sent for microbiology from the drained material and from a craniectomy specimen adjacent to the collection which was removed for therapeutic purposes due to possible infection and embedded in thioglycollate broth for processing.  After 5 days of incubation
column17: growth of Proprionibacterium acnes (P. acnes) was observed after subculture in solid medium and in anaerobic atmosphere of the enrichment broth. An antibiogram by E-test was performed
column18: showing resistance to metronidazole and sensitivity to penicillin
column19: amoxicillin-clavulanate
column20: ceftazidime
column21: clindamycin and vancomycin. Treatment with vancomycin and ceftazidime was discontinued and amoxicillin-clavulanic acid was started. column1: A 13-year-old boy with no personal history of interest. His relevant family history included a brother who had died of Wilms' tumour. He consulted for micturition symptoms (dysuria
column2: pollakiuria) with no other symptoms. The urine dipstick was negative. Treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole was started until the urine culture result was reported as sterile. In the absence of improvement after one week
column3: the patient visited the emergency department. The anamnesis was associated with micturition symptoms and anuria of 18 hours' duration
column4: together with abdominal pain located in the hypogastrium and right iliac fossa. There was no history of surgery or fever since the onset of the symptoms. On examination
column5: she was in good general condition with no signs of dehydration
column6: and her vitals were within normal values. Cardiopulmonary auscultation was normal. On abdominal examination
column7: palpation was painful in the hypogastrium and right iliac fossa
column8: with local signs of peritoneal irritation. There was no bladder balloon. The rest of the examination showed no relevant findings. Laboratory tests showed no findings of interest: leukocytes 5400 μl
column9: neutrophils 2370 μl (44%)
column10: haemoglobin 13.9 mg/dl
column11: C-reactive protein <2.9 mg/l. An abdominal X-ray was performed
column12: which showed no abnormalities
column13: and an abdominal ultrasound with no findings in the urinary tract
column14: with a virtually empty bladder. However
column15: an 8 mm thickened appendix with periappendicular free fluid and thickening of the adjacent fat was visualised; findings compatible with acute appendicitis.  Intravenous fluid infusion was performed in an expansion regime
column16: obtaining adequate diuresis in a short time. Given the diagnosis of acute appendicitis
column17: he underwent surgery under general anaesthesia
column18: identifying phlegmonous appendicitis and performing an appendectomy. The subsequent evolution was favourable
column19: with no postoperative complications.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 58-year-old man with a body surface area of 2.02 m_ with ischaemic heart disease and chronic renal failure secondary to nephroangiosclerosis. Informed about dialysis techniques
column2: he opted for PD as he wanted home treatment. On 23-Jan-2004
column3: a self-positioning PD catheter was surgically implanted without incident. A preoperative chest X-ray showed no pleural effusion or other notable alterations.  On 30-March-2004 continuous ambulatory PD (CAPD) was started with 3 daily exchanges of 2
column4: 000 cc at 1.36%. After 48 hours
column5: the patient reported drainage of 2
column6: 500 cc after 8 h. of stay
column7: and so the pattern was modified to 2 daily exchanges with the same volume and glucose to minimise the negative effect of excessive ultrafiltration on residual renal function (RRF). After 1 week on CAPD
column8: on 6-April-2004 he consulted for medium effort dyspnoea with orthopnoea of 48 hours' evolution. He had abundant diuresis
column9: drainage of 2
column11: 400 cc per exchange and stable weight. Examination revealed a decrease in vesicular murmur in the right lung base
column12: compatible with the existence of pleural effusion at that level
column13: which was confirmed by a chest X-ray. With a diagnosis of suspected hydrothorax on CAPD
column14: diagnostic thoracentesis was performed on the right
column15: which showed a clear yellow fluid with protein < 1 g/dl
column16: 17 leu/mm3
column17: 40 haem/mm3 and 197 mg/dl glucose for a glycaemia of 108 mg/dl. Upon diagnostic confirmation of hydrothorax
column18: CAPD was discontinued and the patient was kept on an outpatient basis without dialysis due to his good RRF. Symptoms improved the following day and a check-up a week later showed no pleural effusion. On 20-April-2004
column19: after 2 weeks without PD
column20: the patient was admitted and CAPD was restarted in decubitus with 6 exchanges/day of 1
column21: 000 cc at 1.36% to minimise intraperitoneal pressure
column22: without initial recurrence of the hydrothorax. After 4 days without problems
column23: the infusion volume was increased to 1
column24: 500 cc and ambulation was allowed. On 27-April-2004 he was discharged. After 3 days at home and 10 days after restarting CAPD
column25: he returned to the hospital with a recurrence of the right hydrothorax. On this occasion
column26: and after immediate discontinuation of CAPD
column27: a haemodialysis (HD) catheter was implanted in the right femoral vein. The good evolution of the case during the first few days after restarting CAPD encouraged us to try again to solve the problem by means of peritoneal rest
column28: this time for a longer period of time. On 31-May-2004
column29: after a month of peritoneal rest
column30: he restarted CAPD again with 5 daily exchanges of 1
column31: 000 cc at 1.36% and absolute bed rest
column32: this time with a recurrence of hydrothorax only 48 hours later. CAPD was again suspended and HD was restarted. Given the ineffectiveness of conservative treatment
column33: and in agreement with the patient
column34: pleurodesis with talc was indicated
column35: which the thoracic surgeons performed on 18 June 2004 with no further incidents or problems. A chest X-ray taken 4 days after thoracentesis showed no pleural effusion. After keeping the patient on HD for a further 5 weeks as recommended by the thoracic surgeons
column36: on 26 July 2004
column37: CAPD was restarted with 4 exchanges/day of 1500 cc at 1.36%
column38: this time without incident. Currently
column39: 15 months after restarting CAPD after pleurodesis
column40: the patient is still on CAPD with no recurrence of the hydrothorax
column41: using 4 exchanges/day of 2 litres at 1.36% and is really satisfied to be able to remain on the type of dialysis he had chosen.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 54 year old patient who came to the clinic with elevated PSA levels
column2: antibiotic treatment was recommended and a new analysis was carried out. After a result of 8 ng/ml
column3: a prostate biopsy was recommended. The anatomopathological result was prostate adenocarcinoma Gleason 3+3= 6
column4: confirming localised disease with a nuclear magnetic resonance. The patient's past history included previous appendectomy and inguinal herniorrhaphy. Surgical treatment was proposed by means of radical prostatectomy
column5: with access via the retropubic and extraperitoneal route using the Walsh technique
column6: and the operation was carried out without incident. During the first few days he presented with fever peaks of up to 38.1oC
column7: symptoms of postoperative paralytic ileus with abundant vomiting on the second day
column8: suspending the oral tolerance started on the first day. On the fourth day
column9: an abdominal X-ray was performed with the presence of gas in the colic frame and hydro-aerial levels in the right colon. Discharge was planned for the eighth day
column10: given the satisfactory evolution. On the seventh day she presented with pain in the right flank and reddening of the area with fever up to 39oC. A CT scan of the abdomen showed a liquid collection with abundant gas in the retroperitoneum
column11: behind the second and third duodenal portions
column12: accompanied by minimal pneumoperitoneum
column13: as well as diverticulosis at the level of the descending colon and sigma.   In view of these findings
column14: the existence of duodenal perforation in the retroperitoneal portion and an infectious condition was suspected
column15: and conservative treatment was chosen. Drainage was placed in the collection by ultrasound
column16: obtaining cultures of the liquid
column17: with growth of Staphylococcus haemolyticus and Candida albicans after a few days. He remained on empirical antibiotic treatment during the entire admission
column18: based on the cultures. A nasogastric tube was placed and oral feeding was replaced by parenteral feeding. Follow-up of the collection was done by ultrasound
column19: confirming intestinal sealing with the use of contrast in a gastroduodenal transit 30 days after placement of the drain
column20: subsequently initiating oral tolerance. After good tolerance to ingestion and apyretic state
column21: the drainage tube was removed and the patient was discharged 45 days after the operation. At 26 months he remains asymptomatic and with undetectable PSA.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 57-year-old man
column2: with no past history of interest
column3: attended the hospital emergency department for chest pain. Acute coronary syndrome with ST-segment elevation in the anterior aspect of the heart was diagnosed and percutaneous coronary angiography was performed. The patient had a lesion in the middle portion of the anterior descending coronary artery
column4: so angioplasty was performed and a stent was placed
column5: without complications
column6: after administering 300 mg of acetylsalicylic acid
column7: 300 mg of clopidogrel and 5
column8: 000 IU of intravenous heparin sodium. At the end of the procedure the patient was in Killip III and presented with massive haematemesis. Arterial O2 saturation was 92%
column9: with a Ventimask at 50% 10 bpm. Digestive endoscopy was performed with respiratory support with CPAP-B
column10: as per protocol described
column11: and a Mallory Weiss lesion was observed. Haemoglobin dropped from 15.1 to 13g/dl and haematocrit from 43.6 to 39.1%. At the end of the procedure
column12: the patient was 100% saturated and CPAP-B could be removed (arterial blood gas was not performed due to the risk of bleeding after administration of anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents).   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 47-year-old male with no family history of SCD who had been seen in our outpatient clinic since 2002 for proteinuria. In 2006
column2: abdominal ultrasound and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed poor cortico-medullary differentiation and the presence of multiple bilateral parapelvic cysts. In 2007
column3: due to deterioration of renal function with serum creatinine levels of 1.6 mg/dl and proteinuria of 1 g/24 h
column4: it was decided to perform an ultrasound-guided renal biopsy
column5: which revealed changes consistent with moderate-severe chronic interstitial nephritis. In 2009
column6: the patient was admitted due to oedema and dyspnoea on exertion. Examination showed no skin lesions suggestive of skin angiokeratomas. The admission blood test showed a serum creatinine of 1.7 mg/dl and proteinuria of 2.4 g/24 h. Echocardiogram and cardiac MRI findings showed probable cardiomyopathy due to deposition disease. Electromyography showed signs of small fibre neuropathy
column7: with impaired autonomic function. A sweat test failed to pick up sweat after pilocarpine stimulation
column8: and an ophthalmological examination revealed cornea verticillata.  In clinical suspicion of FS
column9: the level of alpha-galactosidase activity in leukocytes and plasma was determined using a fluorogenic substrate 4-methyilumbelliferyl α-D-galactosidase. GLA activity was 0.5 nmol/h/ml (2% of normal) in plasma
column10: and /4.2 nmol/h/mg protein (10.7% of normal) in leukocytes
column11: confirming the diagnosis of EF. Enzyme activity was normal in the patient's relatives studied (mother and sister). Genetic study was performed
column12: genomic deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) was extracted from dried blood spot and coding gene fragments were amplified by PCR. Direct sequencing of the 7 exons of the GLA gene was performed using a capillary sequencer (ABI PRISM® 310 Genetic Analyzer). The analysis determined that the patient was homozygous for a novel c.1182del (single nucleotide deletion) mutation in exon 7 of the alpha-GLA A gene. The patient's mother and sister were investigated and were negative for this mutation. The remaining siblings were not available for study
column13: but none of them have manifested clinical symptoms associated with the disease to date. The patient has one male child
column14: so the mutation is not transmitted to offspring. Hormone replacement therapy with agalsidase alfa (Replagal®) was initiated. During follow-up
column15: oedema and neuropathic pain improved
column16: but renal function progressively worsened to end-stage renal failure
column17: over a period of 3 years. The patient started haemodialysis
column18: and one year later
column19: he received a living donor kidney graft from his wife. The patient
column20: during post-transplant follow-up
column21: has remained with stable renal function with an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 45 ml/min/1.73 m2
column22: with proteinuria of 200 mg/24 h. Follow-up biopsies were performed at 3 months and 1 year
column23: which showed no Gb3 deposits in the renal tissue. Regarding cardiac evolution
column24: clinically
column25: he presented with the appearance of dyspnoea on exertion
column26: in addition to worsening myocardial fibrosis
column27: assessed by cardiac MRI performed in February 2014. It was decided to change treatment to agalsidase beta (Fabrazyme®)
column28: since then.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O

column1: The present case corresponds to a 30-year-old woman with no relevant personal history
column2: who consulted for an initial picture of a pulsating right hemicranial headache of two months' duration which progressed to become holocranial. The headache had organic features and was resistant to conventional treatment (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and triptans). In addition
column3: it was accompanied by blurred vision
column4: more pronounced in the left eye
column5: two episodes of self-limited diplopia and occasional episodes of left eyelid ptosis. The neurological examination revealed an afferent pupillary defect in the left eye with a decrease in visual acuity of 0.1 and 0.25 in the right eye. The rest of the cranial nerves showed no alterations on examination. The hormonal study did not reveal any functional alterations. Cranial computed tomography (CT) scan showed a non-calcified cystic lesion eroding the sphenoid sinus and the lateral walls of the sella turcica. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain confirmed the existence of a 4 x 3 x 3 cm tumour in the region of the sphenoid sinus
column6: which was destroying
column7: eroding and expanding the walls of the sinus and the clivus itself. The lesion caused compression and cranial displacement of the pituitary gland and the chiasm. It was isointense on T1-weighted sequences and hyperintense on T2-weighted sequences
column8: with fluid-liquid levels inside
column9: septate appearance and peripheral enhancement on post-contrast sequences. In addition
column10: there was sclerosis of the surrounding sphenoid bone.  Under general anaesthesia
column11: a transsphenoidal sublabial approach was performed
column12: partially resecting the lesion in its central part
column13: with the intention of decompressing the optic chiasm. The anatomopathological analysis confirmed the presence of a benign tissue with a partially mineralised appearance
column14: with the presence of osteoblasts and irregular trabeculae forming large venous lakes
column15: compatible with an aneurysmal bone cyst. Post-surgical control MRI showed adequate decompression of the optic chiasm with residual lesion in both lateral regions and ethmoidal cells. The neuro-ophthalmological examination performed at three months confirmed that the patient's visual acuity was practically normal (O.D.: 1 and O.I.: 0.9).  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 68-year-old patient with absence of hair on the scalp
column2: with a history of right inguinal hernia that had not been operated on and with actinic keratosis that had been present for years
column3: initially treated with retinoids and cryotherapy. Two years later the patient reported the appearance of several crusty lesions in the parieto-occipital region. Biopsies of the lesions were taken and reported as moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The lesions were excised
column4: leaving one of the margins of the resection affected by the tumour. The patient was given maximum dose radiotherapy to the scalp. Six months later the patient reported the appearance of several lesions similar to the previous ones in the same area. New biopsies were taken and reported as squamous cell carcinoma. The patient was then referred to our department to assess the therapeutic possibilities. On arrival the patient presented two crusty lesions of approximately 2 and 3 cm in diameter respectively and other smaller lesions suspicious of malignancy. Likewise
column5: as a consequence of the radiotherapy
column6: there was fibrosis and complete retraction of the scalp which prevented any type of reconstruction by means of local flaps. During the clinical session
column7: it was decided to perform a wide scalp resection and immediate reconstruction of the defect with a free omentum flap
column8: as well as a herniorrhaphy to reduce the inguinal hernia that the patient presented.   The patient is operated on together with the General Surgery Service and a two-team approach is performed simultaneously. On the one hand
column9: a wide scalp excision is performed together with a bilateral preauricular approach to identify and isolate the superficial temporal vessels. On the other hand
column10: a median laparotomy is performed. Once the abdominal cavity has been explored
column11: the omentum is tractioned and dissected from the transverse mesocolon upwards. The vascular pedicle corresponding to the right gastroepiploic vessels is then identified and the small vascular branches leading to the posterior and anterior area of the greater curvature of the stomach are exposed and ligated. Once the vascular pedicle of the greater curvature of the stomach is freed
column12: the pedicle of the left gastroepiploic artery is ligated
column13: leaving the omentum pediculated to the right gastroepiploic artery and ready to be transferred to the defect area. The omentum is then sutured to the remaining scalp and anastomoses are performed. Some authors use both vascular pedicles with double anastomoses to the facial and superficial temporal vessels.8 In our case we performed the anastomoses using only the right gastroepiploic pedicle and the superficial temporal artery and vein as recipient vessels. Finally
column14: the entire omentum flap is covered with a meshed dermoepidermal graft and a compressive bandage is applied for 1 week. The surgical specimen reported as moderately differentiated epidermoid carcinomas and two carcinomas in situ
column15: all with disease-free resection margins. The postoperative period was uneventful and the patient was discharged 12 days after surgery. The patient is followed up in multiple revisions and
column16: 2 years after surgery
column17: shows no signs of local recurrence. From an aesthetic point of view
