column1: We present the case of a 4-year-old girl who consulted for a painful erythrotic rash in the cervical region of 12 hours' duration. The patient had general malaise
column2: no fever
column3: respiratory symptoms or other additional symptoms. She had been assessed 6 hours earlier as a possible prurigo
column4: having started treatment with corticosteroids and systemic antihistamines. Physical examination revealed skin erythema on the neck
column5: armpits
column6: chest and buttocks
column7: with areas of skin peeling in the axillary and cervical areas and some yellowish crusty lesions in the cervical region. He also showed erythema and palpebral and conjunctival inflammation
column8: and the rest of the physical examination was normal. The heart rate
column9: respiratory rate and blood pressure were normal. Blood tests showed leukocytosis (12
column10: 300 leukocytes/µL
column11: normal formula) without elevation of acute phase reactants.  With a presumptive diagnosis of SPEE
column12: he was admitted and started treatment with i.v. cloxacillin
column13: topical mupirocin
column14: i.v. antihistamine
column15: i.v. fluid therapy and analgesia. The evolution was initially unfavourable
column16: with generalisation of the lesions and extension of the erythroderma. On the third day
column17: IV clindamycin was added empirically to the treatment
column18: with a very favourable evolution of the lesions after 24 hours. Subsequently
column19: the blood culture was negative and the skin and nasal smear culture was positive for S. aureus (penicillin-resistant
column20: sensitive to cloxacillin
column21: amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and clindamycin). After six days of admission with parenteral treatment
column22: discharge was decided to continue antibiotic treatment on an outpatient basis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was 59 years old and was admitted with a gunshot wound with an entry wound in the buttock
column2: about 4 millimetres in diameter and no exit wound. He also had another gunshot wound to the right thigh with an entry wound to the back and exit wound to the front
column3: without affecting important structures. The patient is conscious
column4: oriented and with a slight abdominal defence. The plain abdominal X-ray shows a bullet located at the level of the symphysis pubis
column5: as well as a fracture of the right descending branch of the pubis. The patient arrived in retention
column6: and catheterisation was impossible
column7: so a suprapubic catheter was inserted. A laparotomy was then performed
column8: but no other lesions were found
column9: and a left colostomy was performed. The following day
column10: a urethrography was performed
column11: and it was found that contrast was passing from the urethra to the rectum
column12: causing high fever with chills that lasted for a few days. Subsequently
column13: five days after the first operation
column14: the patient is taken to the operating theatre and a colonoscopy is performed
column15: revealing rectal perforation. An endoscopic urethrotome was then introduced into the prostatic urethra and the apparently large orifice that joins the urethra to the rectum was visualised. Despite this
column16: the path to the bladder is found and an eighteenth catheter is left in place.  Then
column17: in the same surgical act
column18: a laparotomy is performed up to the symphysis pubis
column19: the abdomen is checked again and no lesions are found. The Retzius space is then dissected and the anterior aspect of the prostate
column20: which is hyperplastic
column21: is palpated by radiological control until the projectile is touched. The bullet is then grasped and removed with a ring forceps under radiological control. The postoperative period is uneventful and the patient is discharged a few days later with the probe in place.  After three months the patient was asymptomatic
column22: a new colonoscopy was performed
column23: the rectal orifice was found to have disappeared and the colostomy was closed without incident. However
column24: the tube is left in place for a further three months
column25: i.e. a total of six months. At the end of this time
column26: a urethrogram is performed again
column27: the gap is found to have closed and the catheter is removed. Six months later
column28: the patient returns for a follow-up
column29: is asymptomatic and with normal sexual function; this time only an ultrasound is performed
column30: which is normal
column31: and he is definitively discharged.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 77-year-old male patient (HC 53.296/3)
column2: ex-smoker of 60 cigarettes/day
column3: with a history of: - Myocardial infarction. - Infrarenal abdominal aneurysm surgery. - Right renal lithiasis. - Arterial hypertension. He consulted for presenting monosymptomatic macroscopic haematuria in 1999. He was diagnosed with transitional carcinoma of the bladder showing very focal micropapillary areas (G3-pT1) and areas of carcinoma in situ.  Subsequently he presented tumour recurrence in 2000 and 2004 diagnosed as carcinoma in situ and was treated with intravesical chemotherapy (BCG). In January 2005 she came to our hospital with a tumour in the abdominal wall
column4: at the level of the right iliac fossa
column5: for which reason an abdominal CAT scan (computerised axial tomography) was performed which showed a solid mass measuring 7 x 6 cm in the musculature of the right anterior abdominal wall. Laparotomy was performed with en bloc resection of the abdominal wall. An irregular fragment weighing 180 g and measuring 9 x 9 x 7 cm was received at the pathology department. Serial sections identified a firm
column6: whitish nodular lesion measuring 6 x 6 x 5 cm and not in contact with the resection edge
column7: although it was focally close to it. The anatomopathological study showed a poorly differentiated carcinoma of high histological grade that frequently showed a micropapillary pattern and frequent permeation of lymphatic vessels
column8: suggesting a metastatic origin. Immunohistochemistry was performed showing positivity for keratin (AE1-AE3) and cytokeratin (CK) 7 and negativity for CK20
column9: TTF-1
column10: N-Cam
column11: Chromogranin and Synaptophysin. The final diagnosis was metastasis in the abdominal wall due to micropapillary bladder carcinoma.  Subsequently
column12: PET (positron emission tomography) was performed
column13: and a hypermetabolic focal deposit was observed in the right hemipelvis
column14: in the path of the iliac
column15: compatible with lymph node metastasis
column16: a finding that was confirmed in a subsequent abdominopelvic CAT scan. However
column17: no recurrence was detected in the bladder and urine cytology was negative. Four cycles of chemotherapy were administered according to the Carboplatin-Gemcitabine protocol and a complete response was observed on review. The patient is alive and disease-free 12 months after the initial diagnosis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 31-year-old male who was involved in a motorbike accident. Chest X-ray showed mediastinal widening. CTHT on admission showed a pseudoaneurysm of the thoracic aorta distal to the left subclavian artery outlet with significant periaortic and mediastinal haematoma associated with bilateral haemothorax.  He was admitted to the ICU
column2: where strict blood pressure control was achieved. Eight hours after the trauma
column3: a stent was placed in the descending thoracic aorta via the left iliac route. The left subclavian artery was partially occluded without clinical repercussions. After 24 hours he was discharged to the ward and a week later he was discharged from hospital
column4: as he was asymptomatic.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 7-year-old boy presented with severe facial asymmetry due to marked right facial hypoplasia. MRI confirmed mandibular ankylosis accompanied by large secondary tissue retraction and microretrognathia
column2: allowing only a maximum interincisal opening of 4 mm
column3: in addition to class II malocclusion. The ankylotic block of the right temporomandibular joint was surgically resected by means of osteotomy at the level of the condylar neck and right coronoidectomy
column4: followed by reconstruction with an interposition chondrocostal graft. At the time of final discharge
column5: the patient maintained a mouth opening of 3 cm.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 42-year-old married woman
column2: singleton (twins)
column3: with a 20-year history of repeated infections in the genital area. At the age of 22 she contracted HPV; for years she was treated with laser
column4: without success. She suffered from Candida albicans infections at least once a month. At the age of 34 she developed genital herpes. Episodes of candidiasis worsened
column5: alternating with herpes. Constant vaginal pain made it impossible for her to maintain regular sexual activity. At the age of 36 she underwent in vitro fertilisation (IVF) treatment
column6: resulting in a twin pregnancy carried to term. At the age of 38
column7: she underwent a new vaginal laser cauterisation
column8: which evolved with repeated ulcerations
column9: mainly in two locations
column10: always very difficult to heal. Her vagina was permanently dry and she could not wear trousers due to constant pain. Faced with the dissatisfaction caused by conventional and unsuccessful treatments
column11: with her intimate life at an unacceptable level
column12: the patient was looking for an alternative. Taking into account the knowledge acquired about wound treatment and the good evolution of chronic ulcers treated with lipoaspirate graft (which contains most of the VEFs and ADSCs (1))
column13: we proposed an innovative solution for her case. This proposal consisted of: 1. Resection of the vaginal areas with recurrent wounds
column14: and coverage with local rotation flaps.  2. Lipografting of the labia majora to increase their volume and thus close the vulvar orifice and retain the natural moisture. 3. Lamellar lipograft placed under the vaginal mucosa
column15: in all its posterior hemisphere
column16: in order to increase the inflammatory response capacity
column17: improve the healing power and give resistance to the tissues. Once the proposal was accepted by the patient
column18: the surgery was performed under general anaesthesia. Although the fat donor areas with the highest production of stem cells are those of the trunk of the body (3)
column19: in this case we opted to aspirate from the hips
column20: using tumescent technique with physiological saline and adrenaline at 1 /500
column22: following the usual practice of our group (4). We used 4 mm diameter cannulas for liposuction and 3 mm diameter cannulas for grafting. From the aspirate column (approximately 400 cc. Fig. 1)
column23: after waiting 40 minutes for sedimentation
column24: we discarded the oil layer on the surface
column25: resulting from the rupture of the adipocytes
column26: and the residual liquid at the bottom
column27: mostly the product of infiltration. We grafted 10 cc of fat in each labium majus
column28: tunneled in layers
column29: and 4 cc in the posterior submucosa of the vagina following the retroinjection technique
column30: in a parallel and laminar fashion; we had previously performed resection of two vaginal ulcers and approximation of the superficial transverse muscle of the perineum
column31: with a small posterior perineoplasty for closure. The patient was discharged from hospital the day after the operation. She removed two internal stitches of polyglycolic acid suture thread at three and four weeks.  As for recovery
column32: she resumed her professional activities three days after surgery
column33: her sporting activities after three weeks and
column34: out of misgivings
column35: did not resume sexual relations until two months after surgery. Due to restriction of the perineum
column36: she presented a small fissure next to the posterior vaginal commissure after sexual intercourse
column37: which healed quickly.  So far
column38: after 9 months of follow-up
column39: there has been no recurrence of herpes or any other type of infection; the vagina is permanently moist
column40: something she was unaware of as she had always lived with local dryness. The vaginal introitus remains closed
column41: the labia have a youthful and turgid appearance and the patient can wear any type of clothing. Her only complaints are related to the occasional appearance of fissures in the posterior commissure after sexual intercourse
column42: and a small wound of 3 x 1 cm
column43: painful
column44: which occasionally appears at the point where an irreabsorbable stitch was placed in depth
column45: but which does not coincide with the area where the ulcers caused by the laser therapy were previously located. These problems are caused by mechanical action and can be corrected; they are due to a small excess in the closure of the perineum and a reaction to the suture thread
column46: and not due to a lack of resistance of the tissues
column47: which was the main objective of the treatment and which was fully successful
column48: as we know from MRI carried out 2 months after the surgery
column49: that the liposuctioned material had already stabilised in its new bed (2)
column50: as well as the angiogenesis induced by the EVF
column51: which was already fully active
column52: allowing an improvement in the resistance of the mucosa and restoring it to normality. After this period
column53: the critical moment for this type of surgery is considered to have passed.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 59-year-old woman with no previous history of interest presented with haematuria and pain in the right renal fossa and right hypochondrium of 6 hours' duration. She was accompanied by nausea and hypotension with 90/50. Laboratory tests showed leukocytosis with neutrophilia. An abdominal ultrasound scan showed a heterogeneous image measuring 15 x 14.5 cm depending on the right kidney. Several hours later his general condition worsened
column2: with a greater tendency to hypotension and an increase in abdominal mass. An abdominal CT scan was performed showing a large renal mass occupying the entire right hemiabdomen with the appearance of intratumoural bleeding and free intra-abdominal fluid. Surgical intervention was decided due to haemodynamic instability
column3: and a right nephrectomy was performed. The anatomopathological study was reported as clear cell renal adenocarcinoma 10 cm in diameter in the medial area of the kidney infiltrating the renal capsule without affecting the sinus
column4: vascular and hilar structures; stage G II
column5: T2.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 72-year-old man
column2: with a history of ex-smoker (for 17 years)
column3: moderate drinker and COPD under treatment; referred from the Digestive Service for a study of dysphagia to solids and liquids with anorexia and progressive weight loss. An oral endoscopic study was performed
column4: reporting the existence of a mameloned and stenosing mass from 32 cm to the oesophagogastric junction
column5: in which a fistulous orifice was observed
column6: the trajectory and distal end being unknown; in the biopsy only the moderately differentiated
column7: ulcerated and infiltrating epidermoid component of the neoplasm was found. The thoraco-abdominal CT scan showed thickening of the oesophageal wall in the lower third and oesophageal-gastric junction
column8: in the caudal portion of which there was a small filiform lumen
column9: without identifying the fistulous tract described; no mediastinal or abdominal organ involvement. The barium oesophagogastroduodenal study revealed a stenosis of 1-5 cm in length in the lower third of the oesophagus
column10: with no other relevant findings. Echoendoscopy showed a lesion affecting all the layers of the oesophageal wall
column11: starting immediately at the subcarinal level
column12: extending towards the left edge where some points exceeded the adventitia
column13: penetrating minimally into the periesophageal fat
column14: contacting the aorta and right pleura
column15: without invading it; from the lymph node point of view
column16: only a small subcarinal lymphadenopathy with an inflammatory appearance was observed (T3N0).  Oesophagectomy
column17: intrathoracic gastroplasty and feeding jejunostomy were performed. The anatomopathological study of the surgical specimen showed a 5 cm infiltrating cancer with a well-differentiated epidermoid and microcytic component
column18: with 2 isolated adenopathies with a clear predominance of the microcytic component and involvement of the circumferential border. He subsequently underwent adjuvant chemotherapy (carboplatin
column19: etoposide) and radiotherapy (60 Gy). Ten months after diagnosis
column20: the CT scan was repeated and showed images compatible with liver metastases
column21: which led to the initiation of palliative chemotherapy with etoposide
column22: which he continues to receive today.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O

column1: A 65-year-old woman with a previous diagnosis of bipolar affective disorder type II treated with lithium and olanzapine attended the emergency department for behavioural alterations of four days' duration. The patient has a long history of several admissions to psychiatric services. She lives alone and is independent in her activities of daily living
column2: although she receives home help. The family reports initial symptoms of mood swings and extravagant dress
column3: which later evolved into dysarthria
column4: difficulty in walking and temporo-spatial disorientation. In the study performed in the Emergency Department
column5: arterial hypertension (174/110 mmHg)
column6: hypokalaemia (3.09 mEq/l)
column7: fever (38.4ºC) and abdominal distension were observed
column8: which was attributed to urinary retention
column9: and 2 litres of urine were extracted after bladder catheterisation. Lithemia
column10: ECG
column11: CK and cranial CT scan were normal
column12: as were plain abdominal and chest X-rays. Lumbar puncture was performed with normal cell count. The patient was admitted to the Internal Medicine Department with a diagnosis of confusional syndrome with no known aetiology. She was treated with antipyretics
column13: broad-spectrum antibiotics and venous thrombosis prophylaxis with heparin. The study was extended with a new lumbar puncture
column14: cranial MRI
column15: thoracic and abdominal-pelvic CT scan
column16: blood and urine cultures
column17: which showed no abnormalities that could justify the symptoms. Within two days
column18: the patient developed mutism
column19: akinesia
column20: rigidity
column21: distal tremor and decreased blinking. Fever and arterial hypertension (AHT) persist
column22: with hypernatraemia (150mEq/l). Electrolyte disturbances are interpreted in the context of diaphoresis and no fluid and food intake. After deterioration of the level of consciousness
column23: admission to the Resuscitation Unit was assessed and a nasogastric tube was placed for the patient's nutrition. Psychiatric assessment was requested and electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) was prescribed urgently for the following day with the diagnostic impression of malignant catatonia. Two days after the first session
column24: the patient was found to have coherent spontaneous speech and was feeding. Two more sessions of ECT were administered and lithium was reintroduced. Fever
column25: diaphoresis
column26: hypertension
column27: electrolyte disturbances and disorientation have subsided. The culture for Herpes Simplex Virus was negative
column28: ruling out encephalitis due to this cause. The patient was discharged in 30 days with a diagnosis of TAB type II and malignant catatonia. column1: A 69 year old woman with a personal history of chronic renal failure (CRF) without affiliation
column2: rheumatoid arthritis (RA) of 20 years' evolution
column3: on chronic treatment with corticoids. The patient presented with a sudden onset of total anaemic haematuria
column4: haemodynamic compromise
column5: accompanied by significant deterioration of renal function (creatinine 6.9); after orthopaedic knee surgery. The urological ultrasound scan showed normal kidneys
column6: with no alterations in the parenchyma or collecting system; a large bladder clot was observed. After failure of conservative management with saline solution
column7: the patient presented haemodynamic destabilisation
column8: and endoscopic exploration was performed
column9: but it was impossible to extract the clot; given the situation
column10: open surgery was decided
column11: opening the bladder
column12: extracting the clot
column13: and the bladder mucosa was found to be thinned with bleeding in a sheet
column14: with no macroscopic bladder lesions. Random biopsies of the bladder mucosa were taken and reported as bladder amyloidosis with extensive vessel involvement. Treatment with perfused corticosteroids and colchicine. The patient was discharged without haematuria and renal function improved (creatinine 2.3).   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 29-year-old single woman
column2: living with her parents
column3: with no history of organic or psychiatric pathology or drug abuse
column4: admitted to neurology for behavioural alterations
column5: disorientation and lack of connection with the environment. The family reported that it was the first episode of these characteristics
column6: that for the last 2 weeks they had seen the patient discouraged
column7: not very communicative (they did not identify any trigger or decompensating factor
column8: the relationship with the patient was good
column9: she had a good social support network
column10: good job performance
column11: etc.)
column12: she sometimes looked lost
column13: even spoke incoherently ("the veins in her head were dry")
column14: there was no alteration in her biological rhythms. All this was a cause for great family anxiety
column15: so the family doctor was consulted
column16: and she was treated as depressed and prescribed sertraline 50 mg/day (1 week before admission). The evolution was torpid
column17: with episodes of psychomotor agitation and disorientation
column18: which is why the family decided to take the patient to the emergency department. There was no family history of significant psychiatric or organic disease. On examination
column19: apart from the spatio-temporal disorientation and agitation
column20: nothing remarkable was found
column21: and there was no neurological focality. Laboratory tests (haemogram
column22: coagulation
column23: liver function tests
column24: renal
column25: thyroid
column26: urine
column27: folic acid and vitamin B12) and brain tomography were normal. Urine toxins were negative. Lumbar puncture (LP) showed 26 leukocytes/mm3. In the ED she presented with a generalised tonic-clonic seizure and was admitted with a presumptive diagnosis of viral encephalitis
column28: and treatment was started with acyclovir and valproic acid. During her admission she was assessed by psychiatry. The family again reported that the patient had been listless for 2 weeks
column29: repeating that she had "dry veins in her head". She was classified as psychotic depression and venlafaxine 75 mg/day was prescribed. Serology for HIV
column30: Brucella
column31: Cytomegalovirus
column32: Herpes Simplex
column33: Syphilis
column34: Toxoplasmosis and Epstein Barr were negative. During the first week of hospitalisation the patient was confused
column35: presented with soliloquies and unmotivated laughter. LP was repeated (34 leucocytes/mm3
column36: lymphocytes 100%
column37: serology and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) culture for Brucella
column38: Lúes and Borrellia were negative). Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was normal. The antidepressant was discontinued and tiapride was prescribed. During the second week
column39: electroencephalogram (EEG) showed signs of moderate diffuse slow encephalopathy. The patient was unresponsive to simple commands
column40: mutative
column41: stuporous
column42: so tiapride was discontinued
column43: leaving her on intramuscular haloperidol in case of agitation. Due to the torpid evolution
column44: she was admitted to the ICU
column45: discontinuing valproic acid and starting levetirazepam. The patient started to present involuntary movements and dystonia. Transthoracic echocardiography was normal. Megadoses of corticosteroids and haemin were added (suspected acute intermittent porphyria). Due to the most frequent complex tonic seizures
column46: sedation and endotracheal intubation were decided. No uroporphyrins were detected
column47: coproporphyrins and zinc were within normal limits (so haemin was discontinued). LP was repeated
column48: with polymerase chain reaction for mycoplasma and mycobacteria being normal. During the fourth week
column49: sedation was withdrawn: he responded to simple commands
column50: had facial myoclonus and buccolingual movements
column51: and extubation was performed. EEG continued to show signs of diffuse encephalopathy. Prion disease was ruled out (negative for CSF protein). The gynaecological ultrasound showed a slightly enlarged ovary. During the sixth week
column52: ceruloplasmin
column53: serum copper and abdominal ultrasound were normal. The patient was more conscious and reactive. The possibility of encephalitis was raised in relation to a teratoma that was not found. LP was repeated looking for the presence of paraneoplastic antibodies (anti-Hu
column54: anti-Yo
column55: anti-Ri
column56: anti-CV2
column57: anti-fysin
column58: anti-Tr and anti-calcium channel)
column60: except for anti-NMDA antibodies. Psychiatry was called again due to psychomotor agitation and self-referential delusions
column62: reaching up to 160 mg/day with progressive improvement. The final diagnosis was encephalitis against N-methyl-D-aspartate receptors (ECR-NMDA) and psychotic disorder secondary to organic pathology (ECR-NMDA).   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 77-year-old man with no history of interest. He consulted for reddening of the skin in the upper third of the chest and proximal part of both limbs together with proximal muscle weakness in the arms and legs
column2: heliotrope erythema on the eyelids and purplish papules on the knuckles of both hands
column3: of one month's evolution. Laboratory tests showed creatinkinase 736 IU
column4: LDH 545 IU
column5: urea 63 mg/dl
column6: CA 19.9 64.1 U/ml. Electromyogram: findings compatible with inflammatory myopathic process. Muscle biopsy: inflammatory changes compatible with dermatomyositis. With the diagnosis of dermatomyositis
column7: treatment was started with prednisone 60 mg/day and study: thoracoabdominal CT scan: 6 cm pancreatic mass and hypodense hepatic lesions. Hepatic puncture-biopsy: Adenocarcinoma. Referred to Oncology. After 8 weeks of corticoids
column8: with no improvement in the skin lesions or muscle weakness
column9: and in view of the diagnosis of stage IVB pancreatic adenocarcinoma due to liver metastases
column10: we started treatment with gemcitabine 1250 mg/m2 on days 1 and 8 every 21 days. After 2 cycles of treatment
column11: complete resolution of the skin lesions
column12: normalisation of muscle enzymes and recovery of strength were documented. Currently the patient remains asymptomatic after 6 cycles of treatment and with less than 50% response to his baseline disease.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 62-year-old male
column2: ex-smoker with no other history of interest
column3: was admitted to the ICU of our centre for convulsive status. According to his family
column4: in recent weeks he had been irritable and childish
column5: and in the last few days he had complained of heaviness and numbness in his right limbs. The seizures were controlled with i.v. phenytoin. There were no notable findings in the tests (laboratory tests
column6: ECG
column7: brain CT) performed in the emergency
column8: except for right basal atelectasis in the chest X-ray. A lumbar puncture showed acellular CSF but with hyperproteinorrache (72 mg/dl protein) and EEG with left temporal irritative activity. A brain MRI study showed a hypersignal lesion on the left temporal lobe (FLAIR and diffusion sequences)
column9: which did not change after administration of paramagnetic contrast
column10: nor did it present foci of haemorrhage in the evolution.  Treatment with phenytoin
column11: acyclovir (pending PCR for herpes simplex) and antibiotherapy (pneumonia) with Tazocel and Teicoplanin was added. He did not present seizures again and remained afebrile
column12: and was transferred to the Internal Medicine ward. On admission there were no notable findings in the physical examination and in the neurological examination he was conscious
column13: with nominal dysphasia
column14: inappropriate mood
column15: attention deficit and tendency to fabulate and slight right hemiparesis. In the following days he improved (he recovered paresis and his language normalised) although he persisted with moria and Korsakoff's syndrome. Treatment was completed with acyclovir (on the sixth day he received a negative PCR for HSV) and antibiotherapy. Laboratory studies were irrelevant
column16: except for mild elevation of CEA (3.9 ng/ml). Anti-Hu antibodies
column17: antithyroid antibodies
column18: serology (lupus
column19: HIV
column20: neurotropic virus) were negative. Screening for occult neoplasia began with thoracoabdominal CT (normal except for atelectasis/ILD pneumonia)
column21: bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (negative)
column22: upper and lower gastrointestinal endoscopy
column23: intestinal transit
column24: urological assessment
column25: bone scintigraphy and bone marrow biopsy. Given the normality of these studies
column26: and with the diagnosis of ELP
column27: a whole-body PET scan was requested
column28: which revealed the presence of fluoroglucose hyperuptake at the pharyngolaryngeal level
column29: as well as small satellite lymphadenopathies. The finding of PET was confirmed with a CT scan of the neck and an anatomo-pathological study of the lesion
column30: which was diagnostic of epidermoid carcinoma of the pyriform sinus.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 41-year-old male
column2: referred for evaluation due to the finding of proteinuria. Diagnosis of PNH in the context of haemolytic anaemia. He did not require blood transfusions and had no thrombotic events. Laboratory tests showed persistent haemolytic activity
column3: elevated LDH (1
column5: 000 U/l) and undetectable haptoglobin
column6: haemoglobin 8.5 mg/dl
column7: mild leukopenia and thrombocytopenia
column8: normal ferritin 25 ng/ml. He presented recurrent haemolytic crises with fatigue
column9: dysphagia
column10: abdominal pain and dark urine. Episodes usually lasted 1-3 days
column11: every 2-3 months. Renal function was normal
column12: serum creatinine 0.9 mg/dl and GFR (MDRD) > 60 ml/min. Persistent haemoglobinuria with normal urine sediment
column13: and proteinuria of 1.3 g/day with albuminuria 170 mg/day and non-selective aminoaciduria
column14: indicating DTP. Acid-base status
column15: phosphate and uric acid were normal. The possibility of DTP due to haemosiderin deposition was considered
column16: so an MRI was performed with the finding of bilateral renal cortical hypointensity compatible with iron deposition. Initiation of therapy with eculizumab was considered
column17: but was rejected due to the lack of transfusion requirement and normal GFR.  Two years later
column18: he presented a severe haemolytic crisis with acute renal failure
column19: which was attributed to haemoglobinuria. The patient was treated with conservative measures
column20: with recovery of renal function in 18 days. Following this episode
column21: treatment with eculizumab was started. Within a few weeks
column22: LDH and haemoglobin almost normalised
column23: maintaining low haptoglobin levels. In the following months
column24: tubular proteinuria progressively normalised. Fourteen months after initiation of eculizumab
column25: a new MRI showed an improvement in signal hypointensity in the renal cortex of 34 and 51% in the left and right kidneys
column26: respectively
column27: indicating partial removal of iron deposits in the kidney.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 68-year-old woman with no past history of interest came to the emergency department due to bleeding from a tumour on the left arm. The tumour is large (21x15 cm) and occupies the entire distal half of the arm; it is ulcerated
column2: with necrotic areas
column3: very fragile skin and bleeding. He reports having noticed a small diameter tumour that had been progressively increasing in size over the last 2 years and for which he had never consulted.  In the emergency department
column4: electrocoagulation of the bleeding spot was performed under local anaesthesia and a tissue sample was taken for pathological examination. She was admitted to hospital and underwent tests. Preoperative tests were performed
column5: as well as diagnostic imaging tests and a tumour extension study. The X-ray of the arm showed a soft tissue mass without bone invasion. The extension study (thoracic-abdomino-pelvic CT scan) showed a pulmonary nodule with well-defined borders and juxtapleural location
column6: located in the upper segment of the left lower lobe
column7: measuring about 6 mm
column8: suggestive of metastasis; it also showed ipsilateral axillary adenopathies.  Biopsy of the tumour reveals an area with massive infiltration of the entire dermis by a fibrohistiocytic proliferation that appears to be low-grade and another necrotic area
column9: suggesting a high-grade proliferation. Malignant fibrohistiocytoma
column10: fibromyxoid sarcoma or myxofibrosarcoma are suggested as differential diagnoses. Once the studies had been completed
column11: the patient was assessed in a joint clinical session by the Plastic Surgery
column12: Oncology and Thoracic Surgery Departments to decide on the therapeutic approach to be taken. Surgical treatment of the tumour and the application of adjuvant chemotherapy to the pulmonary nodule
column13: which was not considered to require surgical removal
column14: were decided upon. The intervention consisted of complete resection of the tumour with wide margins and direct closure of the underlying defect. The adjuvant chemotherapy treatment consisted of 6 cycles of Ifosmamide
column15: Mesna
column16: Adriamycin and Dacarbazine.  The anatomopathological study of the excised tumour revealed macroscopically a 21x16x15cm piece
column17: partially lined by skin with important areas of deep ulceration and expansive growth border; on section it presented extensive central areas of necrosis
column18: firm elastic consistency and whitish colouring in the non-necrotic areas and a myxoid appearance in other areas. Microscopic examination revealed an overall nodular pattern
column19: although in many areas it was lost due to the large size of the nodules. Histologically there were highly variable aspects
column20: predominantly areas of sarcomatoid appearance with elongated cells with ovoid nuclei and discreetly acidophilic cytoplasm; in other areas there were variable amounts of mucoid material
column21: areas of myxoid predominance and even clear cartilaginous appearance; the other clearly identified component was epithelial
column22: glanduliform and often cylindromatous. Immunohistochemistry was positive for cytokeratins (AE1-AE3) in epithelial areas and negative in sarcomatoid areas
column23: Vimentin positive in sarcomatous areas and negative in pure epithelial areas
column24: s-100 protein positive in sarcomatoid areas and negative in epithelial areas
column25: EMA positive in epithelial areas
column26: MIB I (proliferation index) very high (50%)
column27: Actin and Desmin negative
column28: C-Kit negative. The definitive histological diagnosis was a tumour of epithelial origin with a high degree of malignancy
column29: called malignant chondroid syringoma.  The patient was followed up in the Plastic Surgery outpatient clinic
column30: presenting good scar evolution
column31: with no evidence of recurrence after 2 years. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the arm showed no evidence of local recurrence. Thoracic-abdominal imaging studies showed a decrease in axillary lymphadenopathy and a pulmonary nodule (4mm). Quarterly check-ups by the Plastic Surgery and Oncology Departments continue to be carried out.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 45-year-old woman was referred from the neurosurgery department for sudden bilateral loss of vision after ventriculoperitoneal bypass surgery for a temporal subdural hygroma and cranial occipital abscess. This was the result of a subacute post-surgical complication. A fortnight earlier she had undergone preventive spinal decompression surgery for Arnold-Chiari I malformation. The patient had a clinical history of 16 years
column2: with mild headaches
column3: unsteadiness
column4: rotatory dizziness
column5: self-limited vomiting of variable duration and mild vertical nystagmus for a year. The latter led to the suspicion and diagnosis of congenital malformation
column6: as the rest of his symptoms were related to the ulcerative colitis he had been suffering from for years. Visual acuity (VA) at the first examination was hand movement in both eyes. Pupillary reactions were 2+ with no relative afferent pupillary defect. There was a high-frequency
column7: medium-amplitude downward twitching nystagmus. Fundus examination showed bilateral retrohyaloid premacular and vitreous haemorrhage
column8: confirmed by optical coherence tomography (OCT) and ocular ultrasound. All these findings were compatible with TS.  A posterior hyaloidectomy was performed in his right eye (OD) after instillation of anaesthetic eye drops and use of Nd:YAG laser 15 pulses (range 4-7 mJ/pulse) in the most inferior part of the haematoma. The posterior hyaloid ruptured and immediately drained blood into the vitreous cavity. A watchful waiting approach was chosen for his left eye (OI). The VA at one year
column9: after several revisions with marked improvement
column10: was 0.6 in the OD and 0.1 in the OI. OCT revealed a premacular epiretinal membrane of recent appearance in his OI. The frequency of nystagmus decreased and the amplitude became mild. Bilateral haemovitreal was still slowly and progressively resorbing. The patient refused any ocular surgery and was satisfied with the visual result achieved.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 27-year-old man came to an internal medicine clinic referred by his primary care doctor for: asthenia of three months' duration
column2: non-specific dizziness and intermittent epigastralgia of moderate intensity. Relevant personal history: allergic rhinoconjunctivitis. His usual treatment consisted of ebastine 10 mg once daily during the seasonal allergy period. Examination revealed marked pallor of the skin and mucous membranes. Blood tests showed haemoglobin 6.5 g/dL (13-18 g/dL)
column3: mean corpuscular volume 125 fl (80-100 fl)
column4: leucocytes 6
column8: platelets 280

column1: 73-year-old woman with arterial hypertension
column2: osteoarthritis of both hips
column3: chronic lymphoid leukaemia
column4: operated meningioma of the left cerebellopontine angle
column5: segmental resection of the sigmoid colon due to diverticulitis and peritonitis
column6: paroxysmal atrial fibrillation
column7: aortic stenosis and hypertensive heart disease treated with Manidon retard®
column8: Ameride® and Sintrom®. He presented with numerous recurrent episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding in the form of melena and rectorrhagia since April 2006. There were no significant abnormalities in platelet numbers or function. Sintrom was withdrawn in September 2006. The haemorrhages involved: 9 hospital admissions
column9: 4 colonoscopies
column10: 4 gastroscopies
column11: 2 capsule endoscopic examinations and 1 double-balloon enteroscopy with oral and anal access. These endoscopic examinations led to the diagnosis of xanthomas and petechial red spots in the jejunum and ileum treated with argon
column12: small hyperplastic gastric polyp removed and small angiodysplasias in the ascending colon also treated with argon. The patient received subcutaneous octreotide at a dose of 0.1 mg every 12 hours which was not well tolerated and was discontinued. Hormonal treatment was discarded because of the increased risk of inducing vascular thrombosis given the patient's lymphoproliferative disease. Despite endoscopic and medical treatment
column13: the gastrointestinal bleeding persisted and 24 red blood cell concentrates were required until March 2008. The use of thalidomide at a dose of 300 mg per day in two doses was then considered. After assessment of the patient by haematologists and neurologists and an electromyogram and explanation to the patient of the precautionary measures to be taken (regarding the exclusive personal use of thalidomide)
column14: an application was made to the Ministry of Health for its compassionate use. In the first 2 months of treatment the patient had occasional rectorrhagia and it was necessary to transfuse 3 more red blood cell concentrates. In the following 4 months
column15: no further transfusions or admissions due to new episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding have been necessary. Thalidomide has been well tolerated. Since receiving treatment
column16: the patient has presented blurred vision due to cataracts and oedema in the lower limbs related to her heart disease
column17: both unrelated to the thalidomide.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O

column1: 53-year-old woman diagnosed with tuberous sclerosis at the age of 29 due to the presence of multiple facial lesions (sebaceous adenoma). History of fibrocystic breast mastopathy and colloid goitre. Her parents and children showed no signs of the disease. She reported two palpebral lesions two years earlier that caused itching and tearing in the right eye. On examination
column2: she presented multiple facial lesions with a butterfly wing distribution
column3: flat in appearance
column4: well demarcated (some overlapping)
column5: reddish and non desquamative
column6: measuring approximately 0.4 to 0.8 cm in the longest axis. On the periungual area of both the fingers and toes there are fibromas (Koeman's tumours)
column7: and a hypopigmented patch on the chest. On the left lower eyelid there were two lesions affecting the free edge of the eyelid
column8: nodular
column9: cystic in appearance and yellowish-white in colour
column10: located on the middle 1/3 and outer 1/3 of the eyelid
column11: measuring 0.5 and 0.3 cm in diameter. The clinical diagnosis was epidermal inclusion cysts. The rest of the ophthalmological examination (ocular fundus) and systemic examination (cranial
column12: thoracic and abdominal CT) were normal. Surgical treatment consisted of resection of the two palpebral tumours using two wedges that encompassed the lesions
column13: with good cosmetic and functional results. The histopathological diagnosis was angiofibroma due to the presence of a pronounced collagenous proliferation associated with angiomatous hyperplasia. After 18 months of follow-up there was no evidence of recurrence.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 71-year-old man was admitted to the internal medicine department for a study of constitutional syndrome. Over the previous 6 months he had experienced progressive deterioration manifested by asthenia
column2: anorexia
column3: loss of about 20 kg of weight and inability to ambulate. His personal history included having been a smoker and heavy drinker up to 23 years previously and presenting type 2 diabetes mellitus and prostatism of approximately 5 years of evolution. Physical examination revealed a patient who appeared to be chronically ill and bradypsychic
column4: with pale skin and mucous membranes and generalised loss of strength in all 4 limbs. No adenopathies. Crackles in the left lung base. Pain on percussion of the spine
column5: more intense at the cervical and dorsal levels. Soft and depressible abdomen
column6: painful on palpation in the right hypochondrium and periumbilical area
column7: where on inspection and palpation there is a hard nodule
column8: fixed to deep planes and measuring approximately 3 x 3 cm
column9: covered with skin of normal characteristics. No visceromegaly. Rectal examination revealed a slightly enlarged prostate
column10: with no irregularities
column11: and the rest of the physical examination was normal. Laboratory tests were normal: ALT: 47 U/l; GGT: 259 U/l; Alkaline phosphatase: 277 U/l; Urates 2.29 mg/dl. Moderate leukocytosis and thrombocytosis. ESR 41 mm at 1 hour. Rest of the general protocol including TSH within normality. Ferritin: 515 ng/ml; absence of M component in the proteinogram; normal alpha-fetoprotein; PSA: 11.5 ng/ml (normal values from 0.4 to 4); Carcinoembryonic antigen: 221 ng/ml (normal values up to 5); and Ca 19.9 of 188 U/ml (normal values up to 37). No 24-hour uricosuria was performed. FNA of the periumbilical nodule showed the presence of malignant cells suggestive of adenocarcinoma and the primary tumour was then searched for: Chest X-ray showed an alveolar infiltrate in the left lower lobe; abdominal ultrasound: poorly assessable due to abdominal air distension
column12: although the periumbilical nodule was visible. Bone scintigraphy showed multiple hypercapillary accumulations in the axial and peripheral skeleton. Thoracic-abdominal CT revealed a nodule measuring 1.4 x 1.6 cm in the right upper lobe
column13: in contact with the visceral pleura
column14: which appeared thickened and with lytic lesions in the posterior costal arch. Lytic metastases at the level of the dorsal spine and sternum. Minimal bilateral pleural effusion. Multiple focal hepatic lesions in segment III with vascular pattern compatible with haemangiomas. Lesion of 1.1 cm in segment IV probably metastatic. Nodule of 1.4 cm in left adrenal gland suggestive of adenoma. Hypodense lesion in the tail of the pancreas measuring 1.7 x 1 cm possibly related to primary tumour. Tumour implants in soft tissues
column15: one of them at periumbilical level
column16: compatible with the nodule of the sister María José
column17: and another in the right iliac muscle
column18: with metastatic bone infiltration in the pelvis
column19: sacrum and lumbar vertebrae. After performing the aforementioned imaging techniques
column20: which did not define a clear origin of her carcinomatosis
column21: after 2 weeks in hospital she was transferred to the Palliative Medicine unit
column22: where she died. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 25-year-old man with macular haemorrhage secondary to ocular trauma. His VA is 0.4 and his intraocular pressure is 15 mmHg. As the size of the haemorrhage was not very large
column2: it was decided to start treatment with topical and oral corticosteroids and cycloplegic. The following week the VA decreased to 0.1 and the haemorrhage increased
column3: so a subsequent vitrectomy was performed
column4: an attempt was made to displace the haemorrhage with perfluoropropane without success and 0.1 ml of rt-PA at a concentration of 50 µg/0.1 ml was administered directly onto the retina and the eyeball was filled with gas (SF6 at 30%) in prone position for 1 week. Four weeks after the operation
column5: the VA was 0.8
column6: the macular haemorrhage had disappeared
column7: but once the blood was reabsorbed
column8: a juxtafoveolar choroidal rupture was observed. At 6 months the VA is 1.0.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 67-year-old patient with a history of depressive syndrome and prostatism
column2: who was diagnosed at the beginning of 2004 with descending colon carcinoma. In March of the same year he underwent a left subtotal colectomy with ileosigmoid anastomosis. The anatomopathological study of the colectomy specimen showed a tumour measuring 4x2 centimetres compatible with a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon
column3: infiltrating down to the subserosal fat
column4: with no lymph node involvement and with free surgical edges (pT3NoMo). Postoperatively
column5: he required drainage of an abscess in the abdominal wall
column6: and the rest of the postoperative period was without further complications. Preoperative blood tests showed a haematocrit of 47.7
column7: haemoglobin of 15.6
column8: creatinine of 0.91
column9: normal urinalysis
column10: PSA < 4 and a Carcino Embryonic Antigen (CEA) of 91.45 (Normal < 5.00). Preoperative CT was reported as a mass in the descending colon compatible with colon carcinoma with small retroperitoneal adenopathies less than 1 centimetre in diameter
column11: not significant
column12: as well as chronic fibrocicatricial lesions in the chest. Four months after the colectomy
column13: the patient began to notice a painful nodular mass in the right testicle. A testicular ultrasound scan was performed which detected a heterogeneous lesion
column14: with solid and cystic areas
column15: at the level of the right epididymal body and which could be affecting the testicle
column16: and the Urology Department was consulted for assessment.  The examination revealed that the patient had a painful tumour measuring 1-2 centimetres in the right epididymis
column17: as well as another smaller tumour in the right spermatic cord. The lesions were scheduled for surgical exploration under spinal anaesthesia with oncological criteria: inguinal incision
column18: extraction of the right teste and spermatic cord and clamping of the same. Macroscopically we observed
column19: in the middle third of the right epididymis
column20: a nodular lesion of about 2 centimetres in diameter
column21: yellowish in colour and elastic in consistency
column22: firmly attached to the right testicle
column23: from which we detached with difficulty. The testicle appeared macroscopically normal and without infiltration. In the right spermatic cord we palpated another lesion of similar characteristics
column24: which appeared to encompass the cord circumferentially. Intraoperative biopsy was performed and reported as adenocarcinoma
column25: so we decided - after informing the patient who gave his consent - to perform a radical right orchiectomy
column26: including the spermatic cord. After studying the surgical specimen
column27: the Pathological Anatomy Service confirmed that it was a tumour measuring 2 centimetres in diameter in the middle third of the right epididymis and another tumour in the right spermatic cord measuring 1.5 centimetres in diameter
column28: corresponding to malignant epithelial neoformations with glandular structures compatible with metastasis of an adenocarcinoma
column29: possibly of the colon. The surgical edges and the right testicle were free of tumour.  The postoperative period was uneventful
column30: and the patient was discharged by the Urology Department the day after the operation and transferred to the Oncology Department for complementary treatment with chemotherapy. In the postoperative controls
column31: control CT scans and analyses were performed
column32: and 12 weeks after the orchiectomy a significant elevation of the CEA was detected
column33: which corresponded with the appearance in the imaging tests (CT) of retroperitoneal adenopathies larger than 1 centimetre
column34: pulmonary nodules and a thickening of the colon wall near the anastomosis. The patient is currently alive
column35: although the imaging studies carried out after the operation showed that the evolution is unfavourable despite chemotherapy treatment
column36: with the appearance of multiple mesenteric and hepatic implants and an increase in the number and size of the pulmonary nodules.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 64-year-old man with right mandibular swelling of 6 months' duration. The plain X-ray showed a well-demarcated
column2: osteolytic
column3: multiloculated

column1: This is a 70-year-old patient who reported lower urinary tract symptoms in the form of an increase in nocturnal urinary frequency
column2: slight dysuria and a slight decrease in voiding calibre. Given these incipient prostate symptoms
column3: he was referred to his local urologist
column4: who performed a digital rectal examination (adenoma II)
column5: and requested a PSA determination and an abdominal ultrasound for the next consultation. The patient's only previous history was an operation on the left eye as a result of trauma
column6: and in urological terms

column8: by means of a lumbotomy. At the next consultation
column9: and the patient being totally asymptomatic
