column1: We present the case of a 24-year-old man who came to the emergency department with bilateral decreased VA and headache of two days' duration. The patient's personal history included a case of influenza the previous week treated with ibuprofen 600 mg. On examination the VA of the right eye was bulging and the VA of the left eye was 0.05. Pupils were isochoric and normoreactive and biomicroscopy of the anterior pole was normal. Ophthalmoscopy revealed greyish-white confluent lesions in the posterior pole of both eyes affecting the fovea. Suspecting AMPE
column2: fluorescein angiography (FFA) was performed
column3: showing areas of marked hypofluorescence at early times
column4: which became areas of hyperfluorescence at late times. Indocyanine green angiography (ICG) shows areas of hypofluorescence in the choroid corresponding to the placoid lesions that are related to the choroidal hypoperfusion that accompanies this pathology. Optical coherence tomography showed retinal thickening with hyperreflectivity in the outer retinal layers. Oral corticosteroid treatment (prednisone 60 mg) was started and continued for one week.  On the other hand
column5: the patient reported a severe headache that improved with corticosteroid treatment and reappeared when the medication was discontinued. Therefore
column6: given the suspicion of cerebral vasculitis
column7: which is sometimes associated with this condition
column8: a nuclear magnetic resonance angiography (NMRA) was performed
column9: in which no signs of vasculitis were observed. A histocompatibility study was requested for HLA B-7 and HLA DR2
column10: which was positive. The patient's visual acuity improved gradually
column11: but at one month's follow-up the patient reported diplopia in distant vision. Examination revealed paralysis of the right sixth cranial nerve
column12: with slight limitation of abduction of the right eye
column13: which was confirmed by the Hess-Lancaster test. An injection of botulinum toxin was made in the medial rectus of the right eye and after a week the diplopia disappeared. At present the diplopia has disappeared and the VA is 0.7 in the right eye and 0.8 in the left eye. OCT shows a recovery of the foveal architecture
column14: but with an increase in retinal reflectivity in both eyes.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 64-year-old man came to the PC clinic for a dry cough of two months' duration and an occasional sensation described by the patient: as if his pylorus was "closing up" and he was unable to eat. His family history included the death of his mother and father from tuberculosis (TB). His personal history included: poliomyelitis in childhood
column2: which left a slight deformity in both lower limbs
column3: duodenal ulcus at the age of 35 with no subsequent peptic symptoms
column4: and inguinal herniorrhaphy in 1997. He had been an ex-smoker for 9 years. In the anamnesis
column5: he initially reported occasional retrosternal heartburn lasting minutes
column6: which subsided spontaneously or with antacids
column7: and also a feeling of gastric fullness. Physical examination revealed an asthenic habitus. He was afebrile
column8: eupnoeic and normal colour. Examination of the head
column9: neck
column10: chest and abdomen was normal. At the first visit
column11: his family doctor ordered basic laboratory tests (haemogram and biochemistry) and a chest X-ray and prescribed empirical treatment with omeprazole 20 mg/day. The results of the complementary tests were strictly normal and the empirical treatment was not effective. Simultaneously
column12: the patient consulted an otorhinolaryngologist on his own initiative
column13: who requested an X-ray of the paranasal sinuses
column14: which revealed findings compatible with sinusitis that was treated by the specialist with a course of Cefuroxime-axetil 500 mg/12 h (6 days). Subsequently
column15: one month later
column16: given the persistence of the cough and the recent appearance of a discreet weight loss
column17: her family doctor requested an interconsultation with the pulmonologist
column18: who performed an extended analytical analysis and a faecal occult blood test
column19: looking for pulmonary and digestive pathology. The pulmonologist performed the following complementary tests: mantoux test
column20: which was positive (12 mm) with sputum and urine Ziehl's test repeatedly negative
column21: baseline arterial blood gases
column22: pulmonary function tests (PFT) and methacholine challenge test
column23: fibrobronchoscopy
column24: and thoracic computed tomography (CT). All these tests yielded no pathological findings. Empirical treatment with bronchodilators prescribed by the pulmonologist was also ineffective. The new complementary tests performed by the family doctor showed mild anaemia (Hb: 11.7 g/dl)
column25: normochromic normochromic normocytic anaemia with high red blood cell distribution index
column26: thrombocytosis
column27: increased globulins
column28: decreased albumin and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 88 mm/hour. The faecal occult blood test was positive. With this new finding
column29: her family doctor requested a consecutive consultation with the gastroenterologist
column30: who performed a colonoscopy and an opaque enema in which the only significant finding was colonic diverticulosis
column31: with no evidence of other digestive pathology. Simultaneously with the follow-up of the digestive symptoms
column32: 3 weeks after the consultation with the pulmonologist
column33: the patient began to suffer from asthenia and his family doctor requested a consultation with the hospital's Internal Medicine Department. At this department
column34: an abdominal CT scan was performed showing a large abdominal tumour with probable gastric organ-dependence and local involvement
column35: which was confirmed by gastroscopy and biopsy. During oral panendoscopy
column36: a pre-pyloric gastric ulcer of benign appearance was found
column37: which was later confirmed by pathological anatomy of a biopsy specimen. The General and Digestive Surgery Department performed an exploratory laparotomy and found a large tumour
column38: probably retroperitoneal
column39: attached to the posterior gastric wall at the level of the fundus and multiple extraperitoneal nodules. Several of these nodules were removed for biopsy and a partial gastrectomy with gastrojejunostomy was performed. The biopsy was reported as an intermediate grade spindle cell sarcoma (grade II)
column40: which could be classified as a stromal sarcoma of the gastrointestinal wall. With this diagnosis
column41: he was referred to the internal medicine department for evaluation of adjuvant treatment
column42: which was rejected. After discharge from hospital
column43: the patient received home care with palliative treatment by his family doctor until his death
column44: fourteen months after diagnosis.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 65-year-old male patient diagnosed with OI following a study of a daughter who was also affected. He had no previous family history of the disease.  He reported a history of several fractures (approximately 6-7) during childhood and adolescence following minimal trauma
column2: the first of the humerus at the age of 2 years. During adulthood he had had two new fractures in the elbow and shoulder. All had been treated conservatively. He received calcium treatment during childhood. He had also had multiple sprains and several muscle ruptures throughout his life. Diagnosed with otosclerosis
column3: he had undergone surgery for stapedectomy of both ears. He was referred to our clinic for osteoporosis detected in bone densitometry (DXA)
column4: which showed T-scores of -3.4 in the lumbar spine (L1-L4)
column5: -3 in the femoral neck and -2.8 in the total femur. He was asymptomatic. Physical examination revealed a height of 162 cm
column6: blue sclerae and the presence of dentinogenesis imperfecta. There were no thoracic deformities
column7: nor in the dorsolumbar spine or limbs
column8: except for the right elbow (postfracture). No hyperlaxity was observed. The calcium-phosphorus metabolism study showed normal levels of calcium
column9: phosphorus
column10: calciuria
column11: and parathormone (iPTH). 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25OHCC) levels were in the range of insufficiency: 22 ng/ml (desirable values >30 ng/ml). Bone remodelling markers were in the normal range. Other endocrine causes of osteoporosis were ruled out. As part of our protocol for the study of patients with OI
column12: a cervical spine X-ray ruled out basilar impression
column13: and a chest X-ray showed degenerative changes in the spine; the echocardiogram showed minimal dilatation of the ascending aorta; respiratory function tests were normal
column14: and the abdominal ultrasound ruled out renal lithiasis. A genetic study was performed by massive sequencing by NGS (Next-Generation Sequencing) of the COL1A1
column15: COL1A2
column16: CRTAP and LEPRE1 genes
column17: detecting a heterozygous deletion of a Guanine (c.3524delG) in the COL1A1 gene. This mutation results in a change in the reading pattern
column18: which
column19: at the level of the collagen protein
column20: causes a premature stop codon (p.Gly1175Valfs*64) and is therefore likely to be a pathogenic change. Other changes were detected and considered polymorphisms. Treatment with weekly alendronate associated with daily calcium and vitamin D supplements was recommended
column21: showing a discrete densitometric improvement after 1 year of treatment (T-scores of -3.2 in the lumbar spine
column22: -2.9 in the femoral neck and -2.4 in the total femur).   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient
column2: aged 28 years
column3: with no past history of interest
column4: came to the urology department for a testicular nodule that he had detected three months ago and which
column5: according to the patient
column6: had not increased in size. On examination
column7: a hard
column8: mobile and painful nodule was observed on palpation at the level of the right spermatic cord. Tumour markers and hormone levels were normal. Ultrasound imaging showed an oval
column9: hypoechoic image of mixed echogenicity
column10: with a maximum longitudinal axis of 2.8 cm
column11: which appeared to be related to the spermatic cord. The MRI study shows a low signal T2 image at the level of the right spermatic cord
column12: indicating that it is a tissue with low water content
column13: possibly fibrous or scar tissue
column14: with a maximum diameter of 43 mm.  With the diagnosis of a right paratesticular tumour
column15: it was surgically excised and the tumour was separated from the vas deferens without difficulty. The patient is currently asymptomatic and has been treated without incident. Macroscopic examination of the specimen revealed a rounded formation of brownish colour and elastic consistency
column16: well delimited
column17: with a maximum diameter of 5 cm
column18: with a whitish
column19: homogeneous surface with a fibrous appearance when cut. Microscopic examination revealed a well-circumscribed lesion consisting of cells with extensive eosinophilic cytoplasm with the presence of transverse striations in some of them
column20: immersed in a fibroblastic stroma
column21: with occasional vacuolated cells and multinucleated cells
column22: with no mitotic activity. In the immunohistochemical study
column23: the neoplastic cells showed intense and generalised expression of desmin and vimentin
column24: and focal expression of specific smooth muscle actin (Master Diagnostic. Granada. Spain).  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 64-year-old man reported bilateral
column2: progressive and painless loss of vision affecting the left eye (OI) for 7 days and which in the last 48 hours had also started to affect the right eye (OD). The patient had a history of heavy smoking and the death of a brother due to pulmonary neoplasia. Ophthalmological examination revealed corrected visual acuity of 0.4 in the right eye and hand movement in the left eye. Intraocular pressure and anterior segment were normal
column3: and funduscopy revealed moderate vitritis in both eyes
column4: with slight hyperemia of the papilla in the OD
column5: and papillary pallor in the OI. It was decided to admit the patient for further investigation
column6: with the initial diagnosis of papillitis with bilateral vitritis.  The neurological examination
column7: blood count and biochemistry were normal. The chest X-ray showed a slight thickening of the right pulmonary hilum
column8: and the cranial CT scan was normal. Lumbar puncture showed only a discrete elevation of proteins. Based on these findings
column9: it was decided to start treatment with corticosteroid boluses and antiplatelet therapy.  Angiofluoresceinography showed hypercapitation in the papilla with no signs of vasculitis. Evoked potentials were normal in OD and compatible with axonal neuropathy in OI. Electroretinogram and brain MRI were normal. Serology
column10: immunology and usual tumour markers were negative. Based on the tests obtained
column11: an infectious
column12: vascular or demyelinating aetiology was ruled out
column13: so an infiltrative aetiology or a paraneoplastic syndrome was assessed. A thoracic-abdominal CT scan was requested
column14: which showed a 3 cm image in the right hilum
column15: compatible with adenopathy. Bronchoscopy showed a widening of the carina
column16: and cytology was negative for malignancy. A PET study was proposed to better assess the lymphadenopathy and a referral to thoracic surgery for mediastinoscopy. In addition
column17: samples of cerebrospinal fluid
column18: plasma and aqueous humour were taken to study the CRMP-5-IgG autoantibody
column19: which was positive in the first two samples. CRMP-5-IgG positivity and the presence of neuritis is associated in 62.5% of cases with the existence of a small cell lung carcinoma (2
column20: 3).  Based on these data
column21: it was decided to cancel the PET study and perform a mediastinoscopy
column22: which was reported as a microcytic lung carcinoma. The oncology department classified it as limited-stage microcytic carcinoma and started treatment with chemotherapy and radiotherapy. The initial response to corticosteroid treatment was good
column23: improving vision to 0.7-0.3 at 15 days and reaching a final visual acuity at six months
column24: when we considered the study closed
column25: of 0.8 in OD and 0.6 in OI
column26: with an ad integrum restitution of the funduscopic image.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 22-year-old woman
column2: bipulmonary transplanted in March 2014 due to cystic fibrosis. The donor had positive serology for CMV
column3: while the recipient was negative. A few days after transplantation
column4: ganciclovir prophylaxis was started
column5: and later
column6: when the patient tolerated the oral route
column7: valganciclovir was switched to valganciclovir. Viral load controls during prophylaxis were negative in the recipient until the 6th month after transplantation
column8: when viral load was detected in the controls (2
column9: 090 IU/ml) without stopping prophylaxis. The patient was admitted to our hospital and started intravenous treatment with ganciclovir; however
column10: one month after starting intravenous therapy
column11: the positive viral load persisted and even increased to 42
column12: 400 IU/ml. Due to this
column13: a resistance study was carried out
column14: and it was found to be resistant to ganciclovir
column15: so he was switched to foscarnet. With this drug
column16: the viral load was negatived
column17: but not without certain adverse effects such as hypomagnesaemia. This meant that the immunosuppressive treatment had to be modified
column18: changing cyclosporine for everolimus
column19: as the former can produce the same alteration8. When the viral load became negative with foscarnet
column20: treatment was suspended
column21: with fortnightly check-ups. After two months without treatment
column22: the viral load had increased to 13
column23: 665 IU/ml
column24: at which point a request was made to the Pharmacy Service for compassionate use of maribavir
column25: with the intention that the patient would receive oral therapy instead of intravenous therapy. While arrangements were being made to obtain maribavir
column26: the patient started treatment again with oral valganciclovir. Because of the expected delay in obtaining maribavir
column27: and given the urgency of the case
column28: the physicians in charge of the patient considered the off-label use of leflunomide. This request was reported by the Pharmacy Department to the Hospital's Medical Directorate
column29: which authorised the use of leflunomide in this patient. Once leflunomide was available to start treatment
column30: valganciclovir was discontinued. At this time (March 2015) the patient had a viral load of 17
column31: 344 IU/mL. The initial regimen was 100 mg daily for the first five days
column32: followed by 20 mg every 12 hours. Fifteen days after starting treatment the viral load had decreased to 531 IU/mL
column33: becoming undetectable within a month. Six months after starting leflunomide the patient maintained an undetectable viral load with no adverse drug effects.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 16-year-old male with a personal history of adenoidectomy at age 4
column2: factor VII and X deficiency (detected at age 4)
column3: unconjugated hyperbilirubinaemia (detected at age 15). Maternal uncle
column4: 37 years old
column5: mentally retarded
column6: died of status convulsus. He was admitted for asthenia
column7: hypotension (100/70 mmHg)
column8: anorexia and dizziness coinciding with a decrease in the dose of dexamethasone (Dacortin 60 mg/day) prescribed for peripheral facial paralysis. On suspicion of adrenal insufficiency
column9: he was admitted to the hospital ward. A progressive tendency to sleep
column10: slight disorientation and hallucinations with hyperbilirubinaemia and hyperammonaemia were detected
column11: and he was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit. On arrival he presented the following findings: height 1.85 m
column12: weight 75 kg
column13: blood pressure 130/70 mmHg; heart rate 100 bpm; temperature 36.5o
column14: O2 saturation 100%; conscious but disoriented; jaundiced; rest of examination normal. CBC on admission: Hb 16 g/dl (13-17.4)
column15: leukocytes 10
column17: platelets 196.000 mil/mm3 (150-400)
column18: fibrinogen 287 mg/dL (200-450)
column19: total bilirubin 7.1 mgr/dL (0-0.3)
column20: direct bilirubin 0.47 mgr/dL (0.3-1.9)
column23: GGT 16 IU/L (5-40)
column24: ammonia 424 mgr/dL (15-45)
column27: creatinine 0.7 mg/dL (0.5-1)
column32: CO3H 25.78 mEq/L (21-29). The following imaging tests were performed: CT scan of the brain with no notable findings and good differentiation of white and grey matter. Abdominal ultrasound: no sign of thrombosis
column33: homogeneous liver without alterations
column34: kidneys and spleen normal. Abdominal Doppler ultrasound: no alterations in liver
column35: spleen
column36: bladder or kidneys. No ascites
column37: masses or thrombosis. Hepatic artery and splenic vein normal. At 24 h of admission
column38: ammonia elevation up to 602 mg/dL and prothrombin activity 44% (75-130) (control of 3 months before Act. Pr. 45%). The following day
column39: gradual decrease in ammonia to 67 mg/dL with an increase in BT to 10.3 mgr/dL and BD 0.3 mgr/dL and 24 hours later
column40: intense psychomotor agitation
column41: followed by coma with GCS 7. Ammonia at this time was 575 mg/dL
column42: BT 12.7 mg/dL and BD 0.3 mg/dL. Eight hours later
column43: coma crisis and ammonia of 1
column44: 723 mg/dL
column45: at which time we started empirical treatment on suspicion of a urea metabolism disorder
column46: with Benzoate Na 12 g in 30 min and 15 g/24h pc
column47: Carbaglu 1.5 g/6h IV
column48: L carnitine 3 mg every 5 h IV
column49: plasmapheresis and continuous venovenous haemodiafiltration. Twelve hours later we achieved a decrease in BT to 5.4 mg/dL but ammonia rose to 4
column50: 535 mg/dL
column51: dropping to 4
column52: 004 mg/dL 12 hours later. At this time the patient presented CT scan with signs of cerebral oedema
column53: neurological examination and transcranial Doppler compatible with encephalic death
column54: confirmed by brain scintigraphy. Necropsy was refused
column55: but a postmortem liver biopsy was performed
column56: which showed liver with preserved architecture
column57: ischaemic centrolobulillar necrosis and changes suggestive of metabolic pathology. Subsequent blood and urine tests (at the reference centre) showed ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency. The family study identified the mother as a carrier and one of the siblings and a maternal aunt as affected.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 22 year old male patient came to the maxillofacial surgery department of the Hospital San José referred by his dentist for a painless increase in volume in relation to the body and left mandibular branch of undetermined evolution. The patient had no previous morbid or surgical history. On extraoral examination there was an increase in volume involving the body and left mandibular ramus that had not previously been detected by the patient. There was no skin involvement and no adenopathy. There was also no associated sensory involvement and the mandibular functional examination was normal.  On intraoral examination the patient presented partial edentulousness due to the absence of the lower left canine and molars
column2: and an increase in volume with a dented surface involving the body and ramus on the same side. The overlying mucosa had whitish areas
column3: was painless to palpation and hard in consistency.  A panoramic radiograph was requested
column4: showing a well-defined
column5: bilocular
column6: radio-opaque
column7: mixed lesion
column8: extending from the root of the lower right lateral incisor to the middle of the left mandibular ramus
column9: with a diameter of 12cm in its largest diameter and 4cm in its smallest diameter. Included in the lesion were the tooth germs of the left lower canine
column10: first and second molar. The anterior border of the ramus
column11: alveolar ridge and basilar border were expanded.  A CT scan was requested which showed thinning of the bony cortices
column12: mainly of the vestibular cortical bone. Based on this
column13: a stereolithographic model was requested to plan the definitive surgery.  An incisional biopsy of the lesion was performed. Histopathological examination stained with haematoxylin-eosin showed a lesion consisting mainly of fibroblastic stroma with variable cellularity
column14: containing multiple calcified structures of different sizes and irregular distribution. The histopathological diagnosis was FO.  With this diagnosis
column15: definitive surgery was planned. A 2.4 reconstruction plate was modelled on the stereolithographic model and extended at the level of the basilar border from the right lower first molar to the upper area of the left mandibular ramus. The mandible was exposed via a cervical approach and the mandibular segment involved was resected en bloc
column16: taking the tumour borders as the limits. Subsequently
column17: mandibular reconstruction was performed using a microvascularised fibula graft
column18: which was adapted to the reconstruction plate and sectioned into three parts to facilitate its adaptation to the plate.  Post-operative management of the patient involved antibiotic therapy and conventional analgesia together with revulsives and a soft diet. The latter was prolonged for one month. After one year postoperatively
column19: the patient underwent oral rehabilitation with the placement of osseointegrated implants on which a hybrid prosthesis was made.  The patient continues to have regular clinical and radiographic check-ups. Currently
column20: after 5 years

column1: A 68-year-old woman
column2: whose only history of interest was iron deficiency anaemia studied by Gastroenterology since May 2013
column3: with no history of nephrological problems. After progressive anaemia (haemoglobin 6.5g/dl)

column5: with a post-transfusion reaction and progressive deterioration of renal function
column6: reaching maximum creatinine levels of 7.67mg/dl
column7: urea 171mg/dl and oligoanuria. Admission to the Nephrology Department was decided
column8: where a complete work-up was performed and haemoglobin values of up to 4.2mg/dl
column9: LDH of 997IU/l
column10: indirect bilirubin of 1.1mg/dl
column11: reticulocytes 2.9%
column12: haptoglobin of 36.40mg/dl and in the blood smear: anisopoikilocytosis with polychromasia were observed. A urine dipstick showed haematuria and pyuria. The data suggested intravascular haemolytic anaemia of autoimmune origin due to blood incompatibility. The haematology department was consulted and reported the presence of irregular antibodies with anti-Tja specificity at a titre of 1/16. These results are compatible with the absence of an antigen of high incidence in the general population
column13: the P antigen. During admission
column14: renal function improved. He required several sessions of haemodialysis

column16: and treatment for his anaemia with erythropoietin and intravenous iron
column17: transfusion of four red blood cell concentrates. column1: A 77-year-old male patient

column3: ex-smoker
column4: with a personal history of dilated cardiomyopathy of enolic origin
column5: for which he underwent orthotopic cardiac transplantation nine years ago. In NYHA functional class I since the last annual check-up. The electrocardiogram showed normal sinus rhythm at 95 beats per minute (bpm)
column6: signs of left atrial dilatation and bifascicular block with right bundle branch block and left bundle branch hemiblock. Chest X-ray showed median sternotomy sutures
column7: atheromatosis at the level of the atrial arch and cardiovascular silhouette within normal limits. column8: EF: 0.61). An end-diastolic volume (EDV) of 73 ml

column11: 350 mAs effective for each tube
column12: CTDIvol= 41 mGy. Seventy ml of iodinated contrast (Iomeron 400
column13: 400 mgI/ml
column14: Bracco
column15: Milan
column16: Italy) was administered through a right antecubital vein. During the scan the subject's mean heart rate was 80 bpm (range 78-83 bpm). The duration of apnoea was eight seconds. This examination showed left dominance with normal coronary arteries

column19: VTD 61 ml
column20: VTS 24 ml and myocardial mass of 88 grams. No regional contractility abnormalities were observed. Since stress echocardiography was negative for myocardial ischaemia and non-invasive FDCT coronary angiography showed normal epicardial coronary arteries

column1: A 74-year-old woman with HCV cirrhosis associated with Child stage B8 haemochromatosis with multiple admissions with the diagnosis of recurrent severe hepatic encephalopathy (17 admissions in 20 months). Conventional abdominal ultrasound showed a heterogeneous liver parenchyma with no space-occupying lesions compatible with chronic liver disease
column2: a 13 mm patent portal vein and a homogeneous
column3: slightly enlarged spleen (13 cm). On the other hand
column4: the doppler study showed reversal of flow in the portal and splenic veins
column5: without a clear portal-systemic shunt. AngioCT was then performed
column6: revealing a marked collateral circulation and an associated spleno-renal shunt. The patient maintained persistently elevated ammonium levels. Partial embolisation of the shunt with microcoils was performed using interventional radiology
column7: resulting in a marked slowing of blood flow through the shunt. Post-embolisation abdominal ultrasound showed hepatopetal portal flow with persistent hepatopoietic flow in the splenic vein and decreased perisplenic collateral circulation. After embolisation the patient experienced immediate clinical improvement and ammonium levels normalised. In the 18 months following shunt embolisation
column8: she required hospital admission on three occasions
column9: in relation to mild hydropic decompensation
column10: hepatorenal syndrome and grade I hepatic encephalopathy. Post-embolisation oral endoscopy was performed and no oesophago-gastric varices were observed.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 31-year-old male
column2: smoker of 30 cigarettes a day with no other history of interest
column3: who was admitted to the Emergency Department reporting weight loss (approximately 10 kg)
column4: asthenia and dry cough for the last 6 months. Ten days prior to admission
column5: he had a fever of up to 39ºC
column6: generalised myalgia and dyspnoea on moderate exertion. The admission blood test showed a baseline arterial oxygen pressure (PaO2) of 63 mmHg; erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 92 mm/h; white blood cell count of 9300 l/mm3 (73% neutrophils); lactic dehydrogenase (LDH): 957 mg/dl
column7: and fibrinogen: 954 mg/dl. Chest X-ray showed bilateral diffuse interstitial-alveolar infiltrate over the lung parenchyma. Chest CT showed extensive involvement of the lung parenchyma with areas of alveolar involvement
column8: symmetrical and bilateral areas of ground-glass opacity and adenopathies in the pulmonary hilum
column9: paratracheal and below the carina. The patient underwent a transbronchial biopsy
column10: which was non-specific. A lung biopsy was performed in the operating theatre and the histological study showed alveolar proteinosis. The microbiological study of the biopsy isolated Nocardia sp. Fifteen days after admission
column11: the patient presented clinical worsening with a large increase in dyspnoea
column12: hypoxia and worsening of the alveolar-arterial gradient. Given the clinical situation
column13: it was decided to perform bilateral bronchoalveolar lavage. Prior to orotracheal intubation
column14: the patient was sedated with propofol
column15: analgesiated with fentanyl and relaxed with succinylcholine. Intubation was performed with a left Mallinckrodt 39F double-lumen tube. We checked the location of the tube by means of a paediatric fibrobronchoscope. The patient was then kept sedated and relaxed with continuous perfusion of propofol and cisatracurium. We initially ventilated the patient for 30 minutes in pressure control
column16: with inspired oxygen fraction (FiO2) of 100%
column17: positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 6 cm H2O
column18: peak pressure of 30 cm H2O and respiratory rate of 12. The patient had tidal volumes of 800 ml (volume/minute of 10 lpm) and his oxygenation was 96%. We then measured the static compliance of each lung (25 ml/cm H2O in the right lung and 15 ml/cm H2O in the left lung)
column19: so we decided to start lavage in the left lung (the one with the worst static compliance) with the patient in the supine position. The lavage was performed with isotonic saline solution heated to 37ºC. We infused one litre from a height of 30-40 cm above the patient and drained the patient by gravity. The same operation was carried out until the lavage fluid had cleared. Thirteen litres were necessary in this first phase. To achieve a better result and drainage
column20: thoracic percussion was performed on the lavaged lung. At the end of the lavage in the supine position
column21: we observed an improvement in the static compliance of the left lung of up to 53 ml/cm H2O and an improvement in saturation of up to 98%. The patient was then placed in prone position. We performed the same procedure as in the supine position
column22: in this case 15 litres of saline solution at 37°C were necessary to obtain a clear drainage. The total time taken to lavage the left lung was 2 hours and 45 minutes. After completion of the left lung lavage
column23: we ventilated both lungs in pressure control mode with FiO2 100%
column24: PEEP 10 cm H2O and peak pressure of 35 cm H2O for 45 minutes. The measured static compliance was 39 ml/cm H2O and oxygen saturation was 96%. We decided to ventilate the left lung alone
column25: to check that he could tolerate right lung lavage. The patient was well tolerated with an oxygen saturation of 96%. We decided to start the lavage of the right lung starting in prone position. In this position the drain started to clear with 20 litres of saline solution in one hour and 35 minutes. We changed to the supine position
column26: and in this position only 4 litres were needed in 14 minutes to obtain a clear drainage. After 30 minutes of mechanical ventilation the static compliance of both lungs was 64 ml/cm H2O and the oxygen saturation was 98%. Finally we changed the double lumen tube to a standard number 8 tube and started disconnecting the patient. The patient was extubated two hours after completion of the lavage. The control chest X-ray showed a bilateral fine interstitial pattern. When the patient was discharged from the intensive care unit he had a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 453.8 (193.8 on admission). Sequential lavage had to be repeated twice during the following year due to worsening of his disease with good tolerance.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 84-year-old woman diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis was admitted urgently for abdominal pain and distension. With a diagnosis of subocclusive ileus
column2: medical treatment was initially started. With no urological history
column3: she began a few hours after urethral catheterisation with haematuria
column4: which became very intense
column5: evolving into the formation of a large bladder clot occupying the entire cavity
column6: and perivesical fluid and gas were also observed on computed axial tomography. Urgent surgery was performed
column7: revealing a section of ileum 1.5 m long up to 10 cm from the ileocaecal valve
column8: with a violaceous oedematous appearance
column9: which recovered and acquired a normal appearance
column10: colour and peristalsis; The patient had a small fissure in the bladder wall
column11: so a cystotomy was performed to drain the large clot
column12: observing bleeding in the wall sheet and great friability of the wall
column13: taking multiple biopsies and subsequently performing ligation of both hypogastric tubes. In the immediate postoperative period
column14: after anuria and severe haemodynamic alteration
column15: the patient died (09/05/2000). column1: Male
column2: 45 years old
column3: quarry worker for 15 years. Diagnosed with complicated silicosis in FMP. Ex-smoker for two years
column4: 25 packs/year. Pulmonary tuberculosis in 2007. He attended the Emergency Department in March 2009 with threatening haemoptysis
column5: preceded by cough and brownish expectoration of 4 weeks of evolution. Physical examination showed normal vital signs and bilateral rhonchi on pulmonary auscultation. Serum tests showed leukocytosis (11
column6: 280 cells/μl with 80% neutrophils) with no other abnormalities. Fibrobronchoscopy revealed a large clot in the right upper lobe bronchus. CT showed bilateral and diffuse micronodular interstitial involvement
column7: some calcified nodules
column8: predominantly in the upper lobes and conglomerates that had increased with respect to previous studies
column9: with the appearance of material inside them
column10: as well as nodular and diffuse pleural thickening. Culture was positive for Aspergillus fumigatus in sputum and bronchial aspirate. column1: A 26-day-old boy with no relevant family
column2: prenatal or perinatal history. At around three weeks of age
column3: he began to present vomiting
column4: which increased
column5: and the day before his admission he began to vomit with each feed
column6: abundantly and in projectile form. The patient was eager to eat and was in good general condition. On presentation to the Emergency Department
column7: a clinical suspicion of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis was raised
column8: supported by a blood gas analysis showing metabolic alkalosis and an ultrasound with a characteristic target image. The patient underwent open surgery using the Ramstedt technique without incident. Prior to the procedure the patient was intubated without complications. At 14 hours after surgery
column9: inspiratory stridor was heard for the first time
column10: which did not change with sleep
column11: position or feeding. The mother was re-interviewed and denied having heard it before. The patient had no evidence of respiratory distress or oxygen desaturation on pulse oximetry. As this was a previously healthy patient who had not heard stridor before
column12: it was suspected that the operative intubation and associated post-traumatic oedema might be the cause. Adrenaline nebulisation and a dose of intravenous dexamethasone were administered. After two hours
column13: the stridor had not changed
column14: and as the patient continued without signs of respiratory distress
column15: this problem was started to be addressed. A plain chest X-ray showed no abnormalities in the lung parenchyma
column16: neck structures or tracheal air column. Subsequently
column17: a flexible nasolaryngoendoscopy showed the supraglottic structures and the vocal cords to be intact
column18: without morphological alterations or abnormal movements. The next step was a fluoroscopic series with oral contrast
column19: which showed a notch in the posterior wall of the upper third of the oesophagus. During this time the patient showed no change in his symptoms. After the pylorus surgery
column20: he had not presented vomiting again. At no time did he present signs of respiratory distress associated with stridor. A few days later
column21: a bronchoscopy was performed
column22: in which an extrinsic compression 2 cm above the carina was observed
column23: pulsatile
column24: obstructing more than 50% of the tracheal lumen and unchanged by positive pressure. Given the strong suspicion of a vascular malformation responsible for the decrease in tracheal calibre
column25: computed tomography angiography (CT angiography) was performed
column26: which identified a complete double aortic arch
column27: with predominance of the right arch as the cause of the tracheal constriction. Echocardiography was normal.  The patient underwent surgery via a left lateral thoracic approach
column28: which was performed without mishap.  In the first hours after surgery
column29: a significant decrease in the intensity of inspiratory noise was noted. He was discharged and during the following weeks the residual stridor continued to decrease. He had no further respiratory or digestive symptoms
column30: and at a follow-up consultation two months after surgery the stridor eventually disappeared completely. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 34-year-old male
column2: diagnosed with Klinefelter's syndrome
column3: came to the emergency department for loss of visual acuity in the left eye (LO) of 2 days' evolution. Visual acuity in the right eye (OD) was 1 and in the OI 0.2. The anterior pole was unchanged and the angle was open grade IV 360o with little pigmentation. The intraocular pressure (IOP) in the OD was 34mmHg and in the OI 30mmHg. The central corneal thickness in OD was 516 microns and in OI 520 microns. Funduscopic examination showed a marked increase in papillary excavation in both eyes with an excavation/vertical disc ratio of 0.8. In the OI there was an oval depression corresponding to a congenital optic nerve pit in the temporal sector with an area of peripapillary atrophy associated with a serous macular detachment. Study of the retinal nerve fibre layer by optical coherence tomography (OCT) (Stratus OCT Carl Zeiss Ophthalmic Systems
column4: Inc) showed significant thinning in both eyes
column5: more marked in the OD
column6: although it should be noted that the actual thickness of the left optic nerve fibre layer may be increased by the serous macular detachment. Computerised campimetry (Humphrey 24-2) showed a superior arcuate defect in the OD and a central defect in the OI due to maculopathy. Characteristically
column7: fluorescein angiography showed an initial hypofluorescence of the fovea. OCT over the macula revealed separation of the inner retinal layers in communication with the fovea and a macular neurosensory detachment with no connection to the fovea. We also see a macular lamellar hole in the outer retinal layers.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Female
column2: 44 years old
column3: with a history of excision of nodular malignant cutaneous melanoma on the left shoulder (Breslow: 3.9 mm; Clark level IV; pT3bN0M0) in 1998. She was treated with interferon for one year. Controls every 6 months were negative. At 5 years of age
column4: she was admitted to the surgical department for an episode of intestinal occlusion. Abdominal CT scan: invagination of the small intestine. Treatment: urgent surgical intervention: segmental resection of the ileum due to an intraluminal tumour affecting the serosa. More polypoid tumours were palpated but not resected
column5: as no perioperative diagnosis was available during emergency surgery. The postoperative course was correct and without complications. Macroscopic examination: smooth
column6: rosy serous surface
column7: preserved folds and two tumours partially occupying the lumen (3.5 x 1.5 x 1.5 x 4 cm and 1.2 x 1 x 1 x 1 cm). When cut
column8: the surface was solid
column9: homogeneous
column10: brownish with blackish areas and the consistency was soft.  Microscopically: cells with large
column11: eosinophilic or clear cytoplasm with a vesicular nucleus and prominent nucleolus. Focally there was melanin in the cytoplasm. Abundant mitoses were observed. The tumour cells ulcerated the mucosa and diffusely infiltrated the entire intestinal wall and focally the mesentery and in other areas occupied vascular lumina. The tumour cells were positive for the monoclonal antibodies HMB 45 and S-100 protein. Based on the clinical information
column12: the histological image and the result of immunohistochemistry
column13: the definitive diagnosis was metastasis in the small intestine of known cutaneous melanoma. A study was started to assess the surgical option for salvage: small bowel transit
column14: which revealed at least two more lesions in the jejuno-ileal junction
column15: and a PET scan showing uptake in the abdominal midline
column16: with the rest of the study being normal. The patient was readmitted. Intestinal resection of two segments of jejunum and ileum respectively was performed
column17: leaving the patient macroscopically free of disease. The pathological study showed that the tumours had the same histological characteristics as described above.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 13-year-old girl with CRPS of the right lower limb
column2: also secondary to an ankle sprain that had occurred six months before her arrival at the unit. The approach was to place an octopolar electrode (Octrode) in the posterior medullary cords at T9-T12 level under general anaesthesia in the operating theatre and connect to an external electrical impulse generator. Once recovered from anaesthesia
column3: programming of the system was carried out with very good localisation of the paraesthesias over the affected area. It was reviewed a week later in the unit
column4: observing a good response to both pain and oedema and other signs. It was reviewed again a week later
column5: in which it was verified that the pain and allodynia control situation had been maintained
column6: which had allowed the patient to start the rehabilitation exercises that she had had to suspend due to the severe pain that the mobilisation of the limb triggered. In view of this situation
column7: and in agreement with the parents
column8: it was decided to connect the patient
column9: in the operating theatre and under general anaesthesia
column10: to a Genesis programmable electrical impulse generator. The patient was evaluated 15 and 30 days after the implantation of the generator
column11: and continued in the same situation of pain relief and accompanying symptomatology. Six months later
column12: the patient came to the Unit for consultation
column13: with pain relief and the rest of the symptoms still being maintained
column14: the allodynia and a large part of the oedema and the rest of the accompanying symptoms having disappeared
column15: the patient could now support her foot and continued with rehabilitation
column16: and the family informed us that they had not used the generator for two months and had kept it disconnected
column17: and neither the pain nor the accompanying symptoms had appeared. In view of this situation
column18: it was decided to review the patient within four weeks
column19: continuing with the rehabilitation exercises during that time. The patient was evaluated four weeks later and in view of the persistence of the previous situation
column20: it was decided
column21: by mutual agreement with the family
column22: to explant both the generator and the spinal cord electrode
column23: which was done again in the operating theatre under general anaesthesia. The patient is currently asymptomatic and continues to lead a normal life.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 32-year-old man presented with long-standing low back pain that worsened in the last few days
column2: as well as a loss of thirty pounds of body weight over a period of approximately three months. No symptoms and signs of adrenal hyperfunction were detected. On abdominal examination
column3: a hard tumour was palpated in the left hypochondrium reaching the mesogastrium and left iliac fossa. The imaging studies performed were: abdominal ultrasound
column4: chest X-ray
column5: descending urogram and computed axial tomography. No metastases were detected in the chest X-ray. The findings obtained in the other imaging studies indicated the presence of an extensive
column6: well-demarcated mass with regular contours and heterogeneous signs suggestive of haemorrhagic and necrotic areas. There was displacement of neighbouring structures with infiltration. No infiltration of the liver or inferior vena cava was demonstrated. Treatment consisted of surgical excision via the thoraco-abdominal route with clamping of the thoracic aorta to control transoperative haemorrhage. In addition to resection of the tumour
column7: a left nephrectomy and en bloc splenectomy with hilar adenopathy bundles were performed.  The excised tumour was well encapsulated
column8: weighing 4350 g and with a maximum diameter of 24 cm. Macroscopic examination showed a solid mass with haemorrhagic areas. The tumour infiltrated the capsule and the perirenal fat of the entire upper pole of the left kidney as well as the spleen. Histological examination revealed a diagnosis of adrenal gland carcinoma. The postoperative course was satisfactory and the patient was discharged on the tenth day after surgery. Survival was six months. Death occurred due to disease progression.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 65-year-old man with mediastinitis caused by Staphylococcus aureus. After aortic reconstruction surgery with a Dacron® prosthesis
column2: the prosthesis was exposed 12 days after surgery
column3: with a high risk of dissemination of local infection and the possibility of rupture due to desiccation. Since it was decided to open the surgical wound
column4: the patient was washed with physiological saline solution every 8 hours and treated with silver Sulfadiazine. The patient required continuous intubation from the day of surgery
column5: maintaining haemodynamic stability thanks to the use of vasoactive drugs. It was decided to restitute the chest wall with pectoral muscle flaps. After curettage of the sternum in the midline
column6: a window was made in the upper end of the sternum (left margin)
column7: at the level of ribs 3a and 4a
column8: to wrap the aortic prosthesis with the left pectoral muscle. The right pectoralis muscle was advanced over the sternum after further osteosynthesis with wires and then direct closure of the skin flaps. The patient remained in the ICU for 2 days with antibiotic treatment
column9: and was then discharged to the ward without incident. Two years later he remains asymptomatic.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 62-year-old woman reported multiple episodes of blurred vision in both eyes over the last 13 years
column2: with subsequent complete recovery of visual acuity. The various outbreaks were treated with oral corticotherapy
column3: which was discontinued after the respective remissions. She was diagnosed with serpiginous choroiditis based on clinical and angiographic findings. Her family history includes a twin sister of her mother with a similar condition. She has no personal history of interest. At the last ophthalmological examination
column4: the disease remained inactive and visual acuity (VA) was unity in both eyes despite significant chorioretinal atrophy and scarring in the posterior pole
column5: including the macula. The anterior segment showed no relevant findings and intraocular pressure was 14 mmHg in both eyes. The fundus showed multiple geographically shaped cicatricial lesions
column6: with atrophy and variable hypertrophy of the RPE throughout the posterior pole.  Fluorescein angiography showed multiple mottled lesions due to atrophy and hyperpigmentation
column7: with late stage staining.  Four months earlier
column8: she had begun to suffer from flatulent dyspepsia
column9: vomiting and pruritus. Laboratory tests showed an increase in transaminases (GOT 110 and GPT 90)
column10: GGT (gamma-glutamyltranspeptidase) 110
column11: hypergamma-globulinaemia (IgG 1620)
column12: ANA (antinuclear antibodies) 1/320
column13: negative AMA (antimitochondrial antibodies). HBV surface antigen
column14: anti-HBs antibody
column15: anti-HBc antibody and anti-HCV antibody were negative. A liver ultrasound was performed and was normal. The picture had a good response to calculolytic bile acids. The suspected diagnosis was autoimmune hepatitis. It was decided not to perform aggressive diagnostic tests such as a liver biopsy due to the mild activity of the digestive symptoms.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 66-year-old woman was referred to our department for uveitis in the right eye which had been present for a year. The patient reported decreased vision in this eye but no myodesopsia or metamorphopsia. Her medical history included an intracranial haemorrhage twelve years ago
column2: which required surgery and transfusion of two units of red blood cell concentrate. In the ophthalmological examination
column3: the best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was 8/20 in the right eye and 10/20 in the left eye. Slit-lamp examination showed cellular debris in the vitreous with no signs of activity. Fundus examination showed epimacular membrane in both eyes
column4: no signs of retinal vasculitis
column5: snowballs or snowbanks. Optical coherence tomography confirmed the epimacular membrane. Intermediate uveitis of unknown aetiology was diagnosed.  In the following months the patient developed progressive weakness in the lower limbs and became unable to walk. She also consulted for an episode of vitritis ++ that subsided with transseptal triamcinolone (TRIGON depot). In the aetiological study
column6: after ruling out other causes of the neurological symptoms
column7: with normal MRI
column8: given the association of uveitis and idiopathic myelopathy with patellar hyperreflexia
column9: serology was requested for VLHT-1
column10: which was positive by enzyme immunoassay (EIA) for the detection of antibodies against VLHT-1 (ABBOTT HTLV-1/HTLV-2
column11: Innogenetics N.V.). EIA samples were tested by strip immunoblot (INNO-LIATM HTLV I/II
column12: Innogenetics N.V.) which confirmed the presence of antibodies to HTLV-1. The diagnosis of tropical spastic paraparesis and intermediate uveitis due to HTLV-1 was then established. Treatment with oral prednisone was prescribed
column13: improving his neurological symptoms as well as his CVAM
column14: reaching a vision of 14/20 in the right eye and 18/20 in the left eye.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a four-year-old boy with no history of interest
column2: correctly vaccinated
column3: who started a fever of 38.5 oC of 12 hours (h) of evolution
column4: painful submaxillary adenopathies
column5: erythematous pharynx with exudate
column6: without catarrhal symptoms. In addition
column7: he presented with raised micropapular exanthema in "goose bumps" affecting the trunk and the inguinal and axillary folds
column8: slightly pruritic and slightly painful on palpation. Given the clinical suspicion of scarlet fever
column9: a rapid test for Streptococcus pyogenes was performed
column10: which was negative
column11: so expectant management and a clinical check-up in 24-48 h was decided. At 24 h
column12: the general condition had worsened with fever up to 39oC and persistent exanthema
column13: so
column14: given the high suspicion of scarlet fever

column16: the result of the pharyngeal swab was positive for Staphylococcus aureus (abundant growth) and sensitive to amoxicillin/clavulanic acid. At that time

column18: afebrile and the rash had subsided
column19: so it was decided to complete treatment with amoxicillin/clavulanic acid for eight days. Two weeks after the onset of fever
