column1: 45-year-old male
column2: with no known drug allergies. Personal history: ex-smoker (more than 30 packs/year)
column3: type 2 diabetes mellitus
column4: hypercholesterolemia
column5: a history of circulating antiphospholipid antibody with a history of two deep vein thrombosis. Within his pre-admission vascular history: in October 2004 he had a left iliac stent plus a left-right femoral-femoral by-pass. In February 2005 he underwent dilatation with cryotherapy of the left iliac
column6: which was not effective
column7: so he underwent a femoro-popliteal by-pass to the first portion of the left lower limb. In February 2006 he was admitted again to the vascular surgery department due to short claudication. In a first operation
column8: a bilateral femoral-ileal by-pass was performed with placement of an epidural catheter for post-surgical analgesia. The postoperative period was not satisfactory
column9: so three days later
column10: a new operation was performed: common femoral by-pass with internal saphenous vein in the left leg. After 24 hours of evolution
column11: the epidural catheter was lost and intravenous analgesia was prescribed at that time. Four days later the evolution was not adequate
column12: with an ischaemic foot
column13: cold toes
column14: signs of prenecrosis
column15: together with intense pain requiring treatment with transdermal fentanyl
column16: rescue with 5 mg boluses of subcutaneous morphic chloride every hour and oral corticoids (prednisone 60 mg/day)
column17: suspecting the possibility of small vessel micro-infarcts and considering the possibility of amputation of the anterior third of the foot
column18: given the bad situation. Consultation with the anaesthesiology department (Pain Unit) was requested
column19: which rejected the placement of a new epidural catheter
column20: as the patient was on therapy with oral anticoagulants. It was decided to place a sciatic catheter (Stimulong-plus Plexos Cateter set 19 G-100 mm by Pajunk®)
column21: which was performed in the operating theatre
column22: with neurostimulation and via the proximal posterior gluteal route (Labat technique). Perfusion with bupivacaine 0.37 % at 3-5 ml/hour is then started. Two days later the foot looks much better. Six days after catheter placement she began to walk
column23: losing the sciatic catheter three days later
column24: at which point she was switched to intravenous analgesia. She was discharged 2 days later with a satisfactory evolution.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We describe the case of a 91-year-old woman
column2: type 2 diabetic treated with oral hypoglycaemic agents
column3: hypertensive
column4: and previously dependent for physical activities of daily living after an ischaemic stroke. The family reports that the patient has presented with vomiting
column5: hypogastric pain and haematuria in the last 15 days. Initially treated with fosfomycin-trometamol on an outpatient basis
column6: the condition worsened in the last 48 hours with jaundice and generalised abdominal pain
column7: and the patient was brought to the Emergency Department. The patient was conscious
column8: oriented
column9: afebrile and normotensive. Physical examination revealed jaundice and abdominal pain on palpation in the hypogastrium and right hypochondrium
column10: with no evidence of associated peritoneal irritation. Biochemistry showed poor glycaemic control (glucose: 571 mg/dL)
column11: cholestasis and cytolysis (total bilirubin: 10.9 mg/dL; direct bilirubin: 9.3 mg/dL; GOT: 57 U/L; GPT: 134 U/L; GGT: 806 U/L; alkaline phosphatase: 657 U/L) and acute renal failure (creatinine: 2.8 mg/dL). The haemogram is practically normal (white blood cells: 11
column12: 990/mm3 with 75.9% neutrophils; haemoglobin: 15.5 g/dL; platelets: 217
column13: 000/mm3). Systematic urinalysis shows glycosuria
column14: microhaematuria and negative nitrites. The urine sediment was clearly pathological
column15: with abundant leukocytes and germs. Additional tests included a simple abdominal X-ray
column16: which revealed the presence of ectopic air in the lower pelvis
column17: probably in the bladder wall
column18: suggestive of emphysematous cystitis
column19: and an abdominal ultrasound
column20: which confirmed the presence of gas bordering the bladder wall. In addition
column21: there was evidence of a large dilatation of the gallbladder and the intra- and extrahepatic biliary tract
column22: with suspicion of choledocholithiasis. Urine culture isolated more than 100
column23: 000 CFU/ml of Escherichia coli sensitive to amoxicillin-clavulanic acid
column24: cefuroxime-axetil
column25: cefotaxime
column26: piperacillin-tazobactam
column27: gentamicin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.  With a diagnosis of obstructive jaundice and emphysematous cystitis
column28: admission was decided. Intravenous antibiotic treatment was initially started with piperacillin-tazobactam
column29: urinary catheterisation and strict control of blood glucose levels. An abdominal-pelvic CT scan was requested which confirmed the diagnosis of emphysematous cystitis. The obstructive jaundice resolved after retrograde cholangiopancreatography and endoscopic sphincterotomy
column30: and no bile duct stones or bile duct dilatation were found in the control ultrasound.  After 5 days of intravenous antibiotic treatment
column31: given the patient's good general condition
column32: it was decided to discharge her from hospital with oral antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid for 14 days
column33: maintaining the urinary catheter. The control urine culture after treatment was negative. A follow-up abdominal-pelvic CT scan showed no evidence of residual lesions.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 49-year-old male patient; 4 months before admission to our hospital he underwent vascular surgery with aorto-biliac replacement for infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. One week prior to admission to the Intensive Care Unit
column2: he presented episodes of proctorrhagia with increasing volumes. After secondary haemodynamic decompensation
column3: admission to the Intensive Care Unit was indicated. She also reported the presence of severe periumbilical and hypogastric colic pain
column4: haematocrit of 13% and incoercible bleeding
column5: so emergency abdominal surgery was indicated on suspicion of AFE
column6: since the abdominal ultrasound performed hours earlier reported a linear image above the umbilical scar compatible with vascular prosthesis
column7: with a hypoechogenic area of 87 x 67 x 71 mm surrounding it. An exploratory laparotomy was performed
column8: revealing a retroperitoneal haematoma surrounding the previous prosthesis and FAE with jejunum 60 cm from the fixed loop and sigmoid colon. He presented cardiorespiratory arrest and died in the operating theatre.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 46-year-old male patient with no past history of interest
column2: who presented with a sudden loss of strength in the lower limbs. This condition presented repeatedly and episodically
column3: self-limiting in a few hours. It generally affects the lower limbs
column4: although it can be generalised. She refers to previous episodes that have increased in frequency and intensity over the last year. During the interrogation
column5: she reported a weight loss of 20 kilos in the last four months
column6: with no decrease in intake
column7: occasional trembling
column8: irritability and nervousness. Physical examination revealed no decrease in limb strength or alterations in the osteotendinous reflexes. He had a stable
column9: non-pathological gait
column10: with no dysmetria. According to the patient
column11: he reported a progressive recovery of muscle strength a few minutes ago. A fine distal tremor was found
column12: without exophthalmos. The heart rate was 120 beats per minute
column13: with an enlarged thyroid on palpation
column14: with no palpable nodules. The patient underwent an emergency blood test
column15: which showed creatinine 0.59 mg/dl (normal 0.60-1.35)
column16: sodium 142 mEq/L (135-145)
column17: potassium 2.07 mEq/l (3.5-5)
column18: magnesium 1.64 mg/dl (1.7-2.5)
column20: ionic calcium 3.95 mg/dl (4.1-5.3)
column21: total protein 6.47 mg/dl (6.00-8.50). A loss of strength coinciding with hypokalaemia led us to diagnose periodic paralysis. Given the presence of characteristic semiology of thyroid pathology
column22: a hormonal study was requested
column23: finding primary hyperthyroidism of autoimmune origin with the following parameters: T4L 4.07 ng/dl (0.9-1.7)
column26: antithyroglobulin antibodies 62.7 IU/ml (0-60)
column27: antiperoxidase antibodies 1269 IU/ml (0-60)
column28: TSI 5.7 IU/l (0-1.75). Vitamin D and PTH were normal (28 ng/mL [20-55] and 26 pg/mL [11-80]
column29: respectively). The first complementary test that should be requested in the presence of hyperthyroidism is a thyroid scan
column30: which in our case showed diffuse hyperthyroidism. All these data suggested Graves' disease as the cause of the symptoms. In the acute phase
column31: treatment was started with 40 mEq of intravenous potassium
column32: achieving normalisation of the figures (4.1 mEq/L)
column33: and propranolol 10 mg and methimazole 30 mg daily at home
column34: with a progressive decrease in dose. At the present time
column35: she is being treated with methimazole 5 mg daily with partial remission of symptoms and normal thyroid function
column36: with no new episodes of paralysis.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 60-year-old man came to hospital with precordial pain lasting two hours. The ECG revealed a subepicardial lesion current compatible with an inferior AMI
column2: a pronounced J-point depression together with a descending D-ST in leads V1-V2 and a horizontal D-ST in V3 to V5. Fibrinolytic treatment with tenecteplase and lidocaine was administered for extrasystolic ventricular tachycardia. One and a half hours later the ECG
column3: recorded without pain
column4: revealed a marked J wave in leads V1-V2 and no ST segment shift. One day later the ECG revealed an inferior T-wave inversion
column5: a J-wave in leads V1-V2 and a concave E-ST with positive T-waves in leads V2 to V4. Creatinine kinase rose to 1
column6: 143 U/l (with a MB fraction of 102). An echocardiogram revealed inferobasal akinesia. The clinical course in hospital was uneventful. Four years after discharge the ECG showed a J wave in inferior and anterior leads
column7: and a concave E-ST with positive T wave in leads V2 to V4 suggestive of a PRRS.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 16-year-old male undergoing chemotherapy treatment for recurrent Hodgkin's disease. During the course of this treatment
column2: the patient showed signs of digestive haemorrhage (melenas)
column3: accompanied by an intense elevation of transaminases and a significant alteration in blood coagulation tests (protombin activity). The patient died a few days later due to acute liver failure
column4: with signs of encephalopathy and massive gastrointestinal haemorrhage. At necropsy
column5: diffuse liver damage was observed
column6: accompanied by focal lesions in the lower third of the oesophagus. The histological study showed
column7: in both organs
column8: an inflammatory lesion of necrotising character
column9: showing cytopathic changes typical of herpetic infection
column10: consisting of images of multinucleation and presence of Cowdry type A bodies.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male patient
column2: 63 years old
column3: of mixed race
column4: diabetic and inveterate smoker. He presented to the outpatient clinic for pain in the right hypochondrium and low obstructive urinary symptoms consisting of nocturnal frequency of 2-3 times
column5: weak urinary stream and postvoid dribbling. Total PSA was 2µg/mL
column6: haemoglobin
column7: ESR
column8: haemochemistry and cyturia were normal. The general physical examination and abdominal examination were negative. Rectal examination revealed the presence of a slightly enlarged prostate with an irregular surface and a stony consistency. A prostate biopsy was performed
column9: which revealed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. Abdominal ultrasound revealed a 6 cm diameter
column10: heterogeneous and complex tumour in the lower pole and middle part of the right kidney and another of similar size and ultrasound characteristics in the upper pole and middle portion of the left kidney. A simple and contrasted renal CT scan was performed which confirmed the images reported in the ultrasound
column11: being hypodense
column12: well delimited and both showing enhancement with the administration of iodinated contrast. No abdominal adenopathy or tumour lesions in neighbouring organs were detected. Chest X-ray and bone scintigraphy were negative for metastases.  To establish the diagnosis of renal tumours
column13: laparoscopy was considered
column14: but the patient had a large right supra- and infra-umbilical paramedian scar
column15: sequelae of laparotomy for acute perforated appendicitis with generalised peritonitis
column16: and this procedure was avoided in order to prevent possible complications. It was then decided to perform a fine needle aspiration biopsy on the right kidney lesion and
column17: after two attempts
column18: the samples were not useful for diagnosis. Subsequently
column19: the patient refused to undergo any further investigative or therapeutic procedures for his renal disease. He was treated for prostate cancer with LHRH analogues and anti-androgens. After three months of prostate cancer treatment
column20: the evolving renal CT scan shows no changes from the initial one. The patient is currently asymptomatic and is in good general condition.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 20-month-old girl was admitted with a prolonged febrile syndrome of 5 months' duration
column2: intermittent in the first months and constant in the following 2 months
column3: with a maximum temperature of less than 39°C and intermittent in the last two months. The patient presented with maculopapuloerythematous
column4: evanescent exanthema on the trunk and proximal extremities
column5: lymphadenopathy since the age of 13 months
column6: affecting the cervical
column7: axillary and inguinal nodes
column8: and hepatomegaly. Laboratory tests showed anaemia (9.3 g/dL)
column9: leukocytosis (27
column10: 340/mm3) and increased ESR. The clinical and laboratory manifestations were suggestive of JIA
column11: and treatment was started with oral prednisone at 2 mg/kg/day (10 mg every 12 hours). After one month
column12: the dose was reduced and an interleukin 1 receptor antagonist (Anakinra) was added at 1 mg/kg/day subcutaneously. After 2 weeks of treatment
column13: the patient developed hypertransaminemia of probable viral aetiology
column14: and the anakinra was withdrawn
column15: causing a clinical worsening with recurrence of skin lesions
column16: arthralgias and fever
column17: requiring high doses of corticosteroids to control the disease
column18: and the Hospital's Pharmacy and Therapeutics Committee (CFT) was asked to approve the off-label use of canakinumab. Canakinumab is a fully human monoclonal antibody that binds with high affinity to human interleukin-1 beta
column19: neutralising its biological activity4. At the time of application canakinumab was indicated for the treatment of Cryopyrin Associated Periodic Syndromes (CAPS) in adults
column20: adolescents and children aged 2 years and older
column21: but a recently published study5 is available with results of this drug in JIA in children over 4 years administered at 4mg/kg subcutaneously every 4 weeks. The PTC agrees to approve it and treatment is started at 2mg/kg every 4 weeks to test tolerance. Given the patient's weight
column22: the Pharmacy Service reformulated the vial to allow for multiple doses and to be more efficient. Adequate tolerance and good response to the biologic was observed at a dose of 2 mg/kg/4 weeks
column23: with symptoms disappearing
column24: which allowed the corticosteroid dose to be reduced to 8 mg/day
column25: and the patient continued to progress well. The dose of canakinumab was increased to 3 mg/kg/4 weeks and the corticosteroid was withdrawn until discontinuation. After 6 months of treatment
column26: she suffered a new relapse with sustained febrile fever
column27: irritability and some skin lesions
column28: so the dose of canakinumab was increased to the optimal dose of 4 mg/kg/4 weeks
column29: reintroducing corticosteroids. The disease remained stable despite an infectious process that subsided without secondary complications
column30: during which time the biologic was discontinued. After 7 months of treatment
column31: methotrexate 7.5 mg/week subcutaneous was added together with calcium folinate
column32: 7 mg/week
column33: due to the development of joint manifestations in elbows and carpals that appeared painful and inflamed. Eight weeks later
column34: the patient developed coagulation disorders and hypertrasaminemia
column35: probably secondary to methotrexate treatment
column36: and monocytosis
column37: which led to her admission and discontinuation of methotrexate and canakinumab. During admission
column38: the patient progressed favourably and was diagnosed with active polyarticular JIA
column39: so it was decided to start etanercept 0.4 mg/kg/week subcutaneously to treat the joint manifestations. Although the clinical response to the new biologic was satisfactory
column40: its administration was suspended for 15 days due to a new elevation of transaminases until its resolution. two months later
column41: the patient was admitted for arthrocentesis in both knees. From then on
column42: the patient continued treatment with etanercept 0.4mg/week
column43: continuing to improve without skin lesions or fever and allowing corticosteroids to be reduced to 4 mg/day.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 53-year-old Negroid woman aged 53 years
column2: morbidly obese: body mass index (BMI) 41kg/m2
column3: and marked asymmetry of volume of the lower limbs
column4: with an exuberant volume of the right leg in which the presence of amphractuosities in the cutaneous-adipose tissue of the dorsum of the right foot stands out.  We proposed a diagnosis of secondary chronic lymphoedema of probable infectious aetiology due to filaria
column5: given that the patient had previously resided in Guinea Bissau where filariasis is endemic
column6: and we classified it as stage IV according to the clinical staging system of Campisi-Michelini et al (6). The patient was admitted for treatment by elevation of the limb and optimisation of skin hygiene
column7: and then underwent surgery
column8: the Charles technique being performed with excision of the affected area of the dorsum of the foot over an area of 16 x 11 cm and coverage with a partial skin graft taken from the inner side of the same leg. It is important to note that we preserved the skin of the interdigital space to prevent the later appearance of scar flanges.  Postoperatively
column9: the patient presented lymphatic drainage in the operated area without loss of the net graft
column10: with drainage occurring through the fenestrations. She remained in hospital for a period of 15 days
column11: with the limb elevated and with daily dressings until the lymphatic exudation ceased. During admission she completed a 15-day course of antibiotic therapy
column12: which we continued prophylactically on an outpatient basis for a further 2 weeks until healing was complete. After 2 weeks she began to wear elastic stocking compression for 24 hours during the first 3 months and then only during the day for her daily activities to prevent recurrence.  The patient showed a reduction in the volume of the foot as well as an improvement in mobility and skin hygiene. She was followed up in consultation every 3 months in the first year and every 6 months in the second year
column13: until definitive discharge 2 years postoperatively.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 67-year-old man with no personal history of interest. He reported that while walking he suddenly noticed double vision and slight eyelid ptosis in the OD
column2: which became total in the following hours. She had no ophthalmological history. She did not report weight loss
column3: fever
column4: jaw claudication or decreased vision. Visual acuity in both eyes was 1. Extraocular motility in the OI was normal. In the OD there was total ptosis with limitation of gaze in all positions except abduction. Pupillary motility was normal in both eyes. Intraocular pressure was 16 mmHg in the OD and 18 mmHg in the OI. Anterior and posterior biomicroscopic studies were normal. Laboratory tests were non-significant with ESR of 21 mm/h
column5: protein C of 0.3 mg/dl and platelets of 125
column6: 000/ml3. Definitive diagnosis was made with biopsy of the temporal artery where temporal artery occlusion was found with giant cells around the internal elastic
column7: which appeared ruptured and reduplicated.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A nine year old paediatric patient
column2: with no clinical history of interest
column3: was referred to the paediatric maxillofacial surgery unit for presenting dental inclusion. The radiological study showed an inclusion of the lower left canine
column4: with a radiolucent area around 33
column5: and she was admitted for surgical correction
column6: with a preoperative diagnosis of follicular cyst. The surgical treatment carried out consisted of the removal of the "follicular cyst" with curettage of the bone cavity and extraction of the included canine
column7: with subsequent filling with "Bio-oss" bone
column8: the post-surgical evolution being satisfactory. The surgical specimen obtained through curettage comprised several irregular fragments of greyish colour and low consistency that together measured 0.8 x 0.7 cms and a canine (0.9 x 0.5 cms) resulting from the exodontia. The histological study showed an unaltered tooth structure
column9: accompanied by fragments of fibrous tissue inside which there were numerous solid nests of odontogenic epithelial elements arranged in compact micronodular formations with a swirling cellular arrangement. The elements forming these structures were basaloid in morphology
column10: with monomorphous
column11: oval or fusiform nuclei
column12: somewhat hyperchromatic
column13: although without evidence of divisional activity. Mixed with these structures were glanduliform formations
column14: sometimes tubular in appearance
column15: with a lining of cylindrical
column16: homogeneous cells and nuclei often polarised towards their base. At intercellular level and in a scattered manner
column17: small calcified basophilic spherules appeared as well as areas of irregular contour of amorphous and hyaline deposit
column18: PAS + diastase resistant
column19: positive to Congo Red although green refringence to polarised light was not observed. In view of these data
column20: a diagnosis of follicular adenomatoid odontogenic tumour associated with retention of the canine dental structure was made.  From the resected soft tissue material
column21: an immunohistochemical study was carried out
column22: which firstly showed a reactivity of the proliferating elements
column23: both in the nodular and adenomatoid areas
column24: against the AE1-3 keratin cocktail. Nuclear positivity for the p63 protein (a marker of basal or progenitor cells) was also observed
column25: this nuclear reactivity being present in both the glanduliform areas and in the swirling nests of spindle cells.  The proliferation marker Ki-67 marks only 2-3% of the constituent cells of the tumour lesion
column26: with positivity often appearing in clusters of spindle cell nodules. Detection of the melanin differentiation markers HMB45 and Melan-A was negative as was detection of the hormone receptors oestrogen (ER) and progesterone (PRg) and beta-2-microglobulin.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a three-month-old infant with a history of refusal of feedings
column2: nausea
column3: regurgitation and vomiting of one month's evolution. For this reason he was referred from Primary Care to the Emergency Department. He was a full-term newborn of appropriate weight for gestational age
column4: with a normal pregnancy course in which no polyhydramnios was observed. The neonatal period was uneventful
column5: with adequate psychomotor and weight and weight-related development until two months of age
column6: when he began to show the symptoms described above. On arrival at the emergency department
column7: he appeared to be in poor general condition
column8: with dry mucous membranes
column9: haggard
column10: capillary refill greater than 2 seconds and skin pallor
column11: with the rest of the physical examination being normal. Vital signs were: temperature
column12: 36.6°C; heart rate
column13: 137 bpm; blood pressure
column14: 88/55 mmHg (p75); O2 saturation
column15: 100%; respiratory rate
column16: 52 rpm; blood glucose
column17: 90 mg/dl. Weight 5.995 kg (P10)
column18: height 60.5 cm (P10). He was expanded with physiological saline solution and blood tests were performed
column19: with a normal haemogram and biochemistry showing: Na 151 mEq/l; K 2.2 mEq/l; Cl 130 mEq/l and in the venous blood gas analysis: pH 7.29
column20: pCO2 27 mmHg
column21: bicarbonate 13 mmol/l and ionic calcium 1.74 mg/dl. Findings compatible with metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap. A urine dipstick was performed on urine from one urination with pH 7
column22: density 1015 and negative remainder. The patient required intravenous serum therapy with maximum potassium (80 mEq/l) and bicarbonate (3 mEq/kg/day)
column23: and was discharged after a week
column24: maintaining oral treatment with sodium bicarbonate and potassium citrate. Renal ultrasound showed bilateral papillary hyperechogenicity
column25: compatible with the onset of nephrocalcinosis. Ophthalmological assessment
column26: bone series and auditory potentials were normal. During follow-up until nine months of age
column27: the patient was asymptomatic
column28: with improvement in weight-for-nature development (p25 for weight and p50 for height)
column29: and treatment doses were adjusted according to the change in weight. The blood tests six months after discharge are shown in Table 2. In the control ultrasound performed six months after discharge
column30: the findings compatible with nephrocalcinosis persisted.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 36-year-old emmetropic woman came to our emergency department for blurred vision without a previous episode of influenza in January 1992. On examination she had visual acuity (VA) in the right eye (RA) 20/30 and in the left eye (LA) 20/60
column2: anterior chamber cells of 1+ in both eyes (AO) and multiple white dots of 100-200 microns
column3: more numerous in the area temporal to the macula in the AO. Angiofluoresceinography (AFG) showed multiple hyperfluorescent spots. Treatment was started with 40 mg per day of methylprednisolone IM (Urbason® soluble 40 mg
column4: Aventis Pharma S.A.
column5: Madrid)
column6: atropine sulphate 10 mg/ml topical (Atropina® 1%
column7: Alcon Cusí S.A.
column8: Barcelona) every 12 hours and dexamethasone 1 mg/ml topical (Maxidex®
column9: Alcon Cusí S.A.
column10: Barcelona) every 6 hours. After two weeks of treatment he achieved a VA of 20/20 in AO. The systemic tests requested (basic laboratory tests
column11: chest X-ray
column12: luetic serology
column13: angiotensin converting enzyme and Mantoux) were negative.  Four years later he presented a new relapse
column14: more marked in the OD
column15: with visual loss at 20/60 OD and 20/30 OI
column16: with no evidence of campimetric alterations. The same systemic regimen was started as in the previous episode with complete visual recovery after one month of treatment
column17: although some white patches and upper temporal peripapillary pigment persisted in the OD. In September 2001 he presented a new
column18: milder flare-up. VA was 20/25 OD and 20/20 OI
column19: and funduscopic examination revealed yellowish-white spots distributed over the posterior pole and alteration of the macular retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) AO. Topical and systemic corticosteroid treatment was started as in the first episode. Three weeks after the onset of the flare
column20: VA decreased to 20/40 OD and 20/60 OI
column21: so it was decided to add oral methotrexate (Methotrexate Lederle®
column22: Whyeth
column23: Madrid) at low doses. An HLA A29 study was requested
column24: which was negative. In April 2005
column25: the patient remained asymptomatic
column26: with VA at 20/30 OD and 20/25 OI. Fundus examination showed a nasal juxtafoveolar neuroepithelium lifting in the OD; optical coherence tomography confirmed the suspected diagnosis of ARVCM. The patient refused treatment
column27: but five months later
column28: with a VA in the RA of 20/60
column29: treatment of the SNVRS was started with photodynamic therapy (Visudyne®
column30: Novartis Farmacéutica S.A.
column31: Barcelona) and intravitreal triamcinolone acetonide 4 mg in 0.1 ml (Trigon depot® 40 mg/ml
column32: Bristol-Myers Squibb
column33: Madrid). VA in the OD improved to 20/40".  Currently
column34: the patient has VA 20/40 OD and 20/25 OI
column35: faint yellowish-white spots in the posterior pole of both eyes
column36: AO peripapillary atrophy lesions
column37: with involvement of the papillomacular bundle in the OD and several inactive whitish lesions
column38: inferior to the macula in the OI.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 27-year-old woman who was seen in the emergency department complaining of metamorphopsia in her OD. Her VA was 0.6 in the OD and 1.0 in the OI and on funduscopic examination she had several rounded whitish foci scattered in the posterior pole of both eyes
column2: one of them juxtafoveal in the OD and of a more greyish colour with a perilesional neurosensory detachment
column3: microhaemorrhages and hard exudation that raised suspicion of the existence of a subretinal membrane. No inflammatory signs were found in the anterior chamber or vitreous.  FFA (fluorescein angiography) showed a very early block of fluorescence in all foci
column4: which rapidly changed to frank hyperfluorescence
column5: more noticeable in late stages in the focus suspected of having an associated membrane (NVSR). In some foci
column6: a small area of central block persisted. In the AVI (indocyanine green angiography)
column7: fluorescence block was observed from early stages and throughout the angiogram
column8: except in the case of the suspected NVSR focus
column9: where a hot spot appeared in early stages within a hypofluorescent plaque
column10: which in late stages gave rise to plaque hyperfluorescence
column11: confirming the diagnosis of NVSR.  In both FFA and AVI we found more foci of activity than those seen in the fundus. A complete blood work-up was carried out
column12: including biochemistry and a blood bank
column13: an HLA study was requested (B7 and DR2: for PHOS and AMPPE
column14: A29 for Birdshot)
column15: which was negative; a radiological study of the chest was also carried out to rule out tuberculosis and serology to rule out syphilis and Lyme disease
column16: which was normal in all cases. Corticosteroid treatment was started at a dose of 1.5 mg/kg body weight/day. VA improved to 0.8 and remained stable until the last check-up 3 months later. The foci progressively evolved towards pigmentation.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 42-year-old man with a personal history of alcoholism
column2: cocaine abuse and fracture of the right tibial plateau in January 2011 which was treated surgically (osteosynthesis-plate with iliac crest graft). There was an infection of the surgical wound that led to right tibial osteomyelitis after 4 months
column3: requiring several surgical interventions for the removal of osteosynthesis material
column4: debridement and cleaning. The patient has been hospitalised since 4. He has been treated with the latest generation of intravenous antibiotics administered via a central line
column5: and orally with 2 tablets of distraneurine and bromazepam/12 h since admission (to prevent delirium due to alcohol deprivation); as analgesia: pregabalin 75-0-150
column6: paracetamol 1 g/8 h intravenous
column7: metamizole 2 g/8 h intravenous
column8: tramadol 100 mg/8 h intravenous
column9: Enantyun® 25/8 h orally and morphine 5 mg/6 h intravenous (a total of 20 mg intravenous per day). At the 8th month of evolution of the process
column10: the patient was referred to the Pain Unit for poor pain control.  On assessing the patient
column11: he was in a depressed mood and in unbearable pain
column12: with an 8 on the visual analogue scale (VAS 8)
column13: of a neuropathic type - intense burning and prickling in the right lower limb (DID) - which made it difficult for him to rest at night and even woke him up. At this time he also had fever peaks of up to 39 oC recorded in the nursing chart
column14: with no organic repercussions. The pain management of this patient was initially straightforward
column15: as he presented mainly with neuropathic pain. We planned to discontinue distraneurine and bromazepam in stages. We switched from intravenous analgesia to oral analgesia
column16: achieving a decrease in symptoms: adding and increasing antineuropathic drugs (1
column17: 2): pregabalin (up to 150 mg-0-150 mg) associated with amitriptyline (0-0-25 mg). Discontinuing intravenous morphine and switching to Oxycontin® at equianalgesic doses with morphine (10-0-10 mg) and paracetamol 1 g/8 h
column18: requiring occasional resuscitation with Oxynorm® 5 mg. On the fourth day of follow-up
column19: the patient started with a significant stupor at night and the following day
column20: without responding to stimuli or obeying orders. After ruling out exogenous opioid consumption
column21: the total opioid dose was reduced to MST® 10-0-10 and Adolonta® 100 mg rescue if pain (requiring one before bedtime at the start of treatment and occasionally throughout the day
column22: and no longer required after 10 days). On the fifth day
column23: the patient showed significant psychomotor agitation
column24: incoherent speech and disconnection from the environment
column25: compatible with the diagnosis of withdrawal syndrome. We were forced to make a differential diagnosis. Having ruled out the metabolic origin of the confusional picture (normal blood tests)
column26: we thought it was an overdose/abstinence syndrome
column27: for some due to the dose of opioid prescribed and for us due to possible substance abuse (the urine toxicity profile is not conclusive in this regard
column28: The patient was therefore referred to psychiatry to assess the patient and confirm whether there was a pattern of substance abuse (the family denies any drug use by the patient
column29: but they are not always with him) or another origin.  The psychiatrist's diagnostic impression was polymedication
column30: especially opioids
column31: and suggested a short half-life benzodiazepine to control the psychomotor agitation (alprazolam 4 mg v.o./8 h
column32: which was progressively reduced as the symptoms subsided). In this regard
column33: as the opioid had already been tapered
column34: no further action was taken. In terms of pain control
column35: over the next 15 days
column36: the antineuropathic treatment was very effective
column37: except for a persistence of "shooting" pain
column38: which required a gradual increase of amitriptyline (1.2) to 75 mg at night. This measure achieved a VAS2
column39: with a significant improvement in night-time rest and mood. In addition
column40: the patient no longer requires rescue
column41: as mentioned above. We could therefore have considered reducing the opioid medication
column42: but the patient continued to present alterations in behaviour and level of consciousness ranging from stupor to psychomotor agitation
column43: with the first repercussion being that the nursing staff did not administer the prescribed opioid
column44: for fear of an opioid overdose leading to respiratory depression
column45: and secondly
column46: he required mechanical restraint after falling and dislocating the spacer placed in the femur. We insisted that all the prescribed medication should be administered and the total dose of opioid (MST® 10-0-10 and Adolonta® 100 mg rescue) was maintained
column47: so as not to relapse into possible withdrawal syndromes. Although the patient presented with febrile peaks
column48: the infectologists following the patient did not consider the fever or any other possible complication arising from the osteomyelitis
column49: such as endocarditis or brain abscess
column50: to be responsible for the condition. As it seemed unlikely that an overdose/abstinence of the prescribed opioids was the origin of the confusional syndrome suffered by this patient for more than 2 weeks
column51: it was decided to rule out organicity by ordering a cranial CT scan after 3 weeks of follow-up. The cranial CT scan showed a subacute right parietal cerebral infarction.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: 76-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus
column2: dyslipidaemia and depressive syndrome. She was being treated with metformin 850 mg/8 hours
column3: escitalopram 20 mg/24h
column4: mirtazapine 30 mg/24h and simvastatin 40 mg/24h. In a blood test carried out six months earlier he had a Cr of 0.81 mg/dl. Two weeks before admission
column5: he started treatment with ibuprofen (600 mg/8 hours) for low back pain. A week earlier she had experienced nausea
column6: vomiting and diarrhoea
column7: for which she went to the emergency department. On examination she had dry skin and mucous membranes and her blood tests showed plasma Cr was 9 mg/dl
column8: glucose 189 mg/dl
column9: urea 196 mg/dl
column10: haemoglobin 10.9 g/dl
column11: sodium 125 mEq/l
column12: potassium 8.6 mEq/l and lactic acid 6.3 mmol/l. Arterial blood gas analysis showed a pH of 7.23 and bicarbonate of 15 mEq/l. An abdominal ultrasound showed bilateral ureterohydronephrosis due to bladder neoplasia. Given the patient's haemodynamic instability
column13: haemodialysis was performed for two hours
column14: with a subsequent Cr of 5.9 mg/dl
column15: potassium of 6.1 mEq/l
column16: pH of 7.39 and bicarbonate of 22 mEq/l. Subsequently
column17: bilateral nephrostomy was performed with improvement of the clinical picture and normalisation of the analytical figures with Cr of 1.1 mg/dl
column18: pH of 7.31 and bicarbonate of 23 mEq/l.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 60-year-old male patient with a history of several episodes of acute pancreatitis of enolic origin. He presented with fever
column2: general malaise
column3: abdominal pain
column4: nausea and vomiting of food. He was admitted to the Emergency Department where haemodynamic instability was observed with sinus tachycardia at 130x' and arterial hypotension (BP: 80/50 mmHg)
column5: for which reason he was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). Physical examination on arrival at the ICU revealed a large abdominal distension
column6: with a diffuse painful abdomen and palpation of a mass at the epigastric level extending towards the left hypochondrium. Blood tests showed leukocytosis with significant left shift
column7: hyperglycaemia
column8: and a discrete elevation of both bilirubin and liver enzymes. After stabilisation
column9: an abdominal CT scan showed a pancreatic pseudocyst measuring 17 x 8 centimetres in diameter that displaced the intestinal loops and compressed the stomach.  Transgastric drainage was attempted by means of endoscopic ultrasound but was not possible as the compression exerted by the mass made it impossible for the endoscope to progress. Several percutaneous drainage attempts were also made
column10: all of which were unsuccessful. For this reason
column11: it was decided to perform a surgical evacuation by marsupialisation of the pseudocyst by means of cystogastrostomy
column12: obtaining a total of 4 litres of purulent material. Subsequent evolution was satisfactory and he was discharged from the ICU 6 days after admission.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Girl aged 3 years and 8 months. Gestational diabetes and mother Rh - grade A
column2: gestation of 38 weeks and normal delivery. Normal female karyotype 46 XX. Prenatal ultrasound diagnosis of this girl shows agenesis of the corpus callosum and multicystic dysplastic right kidney. In the central nervous system she has a choroid plexus cyst and a cyst in the deep interhemispheric region. On MRI examination
column3: no abnormalities of neuronal migration are detected. Electroencephalographic (EEG) recordings were normal. Cognitive studies show a normal psychomotor development quotient. Fundus examination showed a practically normal appearance of the right fundus
column4: with a normal optic papilla
column5: two small hypopigmented chorioretinal lacunae and absence of macular involvement. However
column6: we observed in the left fundus a colobomatous malformation of the optic nerve and a larger number of chorioretinal lacunae without macular involvement.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient is a 30 year old female patient who comes to the emergency department of CBMF-HGO in general condition presenting with dyspnoea
column2: dysphagia
column3: odynophagia
column4: tachypnoea
column5: dysphonia
column6: limitation of mouth opening to 15 mm
column7: increased volume in the submandibular region extending to the anterior cervical and right supraclavicular region
column8: painful on palpation and with local hyperthermia.  Intraoral clinical examination showed maxillomandibular partial edentulism
column9: unit 4.8 with advanced caries
column10: poor oral hygiene and moderate enlargement of the floor of the mouth leading to glossoptosis. The admission paraclinical reports leukocytosis with 22
column11: 800 U/mm3 at the expense of neutrophils (80%)
column12: haemoglobin 12 g/dl
column13: haematocrit 35.3% and glycaemia 123 g/dl. The CT scan showed multiple hypodense images at the level of the sublingual
column14: bilateral submandibular and submentonian space connected to the right supraclavicular and retrosternal region
column15: decreased airway lumen in the cervical and thoracic region with mediastinal displacement to the left.  Definitive diagnosis: Ludwig's angina complicated with mediastinitis. In consultation with the Infectious Diseases and Internal Medicine departments
column16: intravenous antibiotic treatment was started with vancomycin 1 g every 12 hours
column17: clindamycin 600 mg every 8 hours and meropenem 1 g every 8 hours. Surgical drainage of the submandibular
column18: bilateral sublingual and submentonian spaces was performed
column19: communicating them and proceeding to the placement of a passive penrose-type drain. Given the cervicothoracic extension
column20: the General Surgery team complemented the surgical drainage in the right supraclavicular region
column21: leaving a penrose drain in the same way. Three daily lavages were performed with 1
column22: 000 cc of saline solution. Following the surgical procedure and the therapy implemented
column23: the patient improved clinically

column25: on presenting laboratory values of white blood cells with 6
column27: haemoglobin of 12.8 g/dl
column28: haematocrit of 39.6% and clinical improvement of the initial symptoms
column29: discharge from the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Unit was decided.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 78-year-old woman
column2: referred from the general surgery department to the pain clinic for chronic abdominal pain secondary to intestinal angina. No history of chronic degenerative diseases. She underwent 2 laparotomies in 6 months and 1 diagnostic laparoscopy for episodes of mesenteric ischaemia. - Diagnosis: mesenteric ischaemia corroborated by computed tomography with venous and arterial contrast. - Present illness: patient with chronic
column3: generalised
column4: severe abdominal pain
column5: of 6 months' duration
column6: which does not subside with the usual analgesics. Colicky pain
column8: severe EVERA
column9: disabling
column10: episodic
column11: sometimes accompanied by nausea and vomiting
column12: with no factors that increase or decrease it. - Physical examination: weight 45 kg; height 1.50 m; blood pressure 90/50 mmHg; heart rate 65; respiratory rate 18. Conscious
column13: oriented
column14: hydrated
column15: with pallor of mucous membranes and integuments
column16: cachectic. Face
column17: head and neck without alterations
column18: cardiopulmonary without compromise
column19: abdomen with generalised pain in all quadrants
column20: severe
column21: on superficial and deep palpation
column22: peristalsis present and of normal characteristics
column23: without palpable masses. The rest of the physical examination was normal. - Algaeological diagnosis: severe visceral chronic abdominal pain. - Aetiological diagnosis: intestinal angina (mesenteric ischaemia).  Clinical course Therapy with potent opioids (hydromorphone
column24: methadone
column25: oxycodone
column26: morphine and transdermal fentanyl) and adjuvants
column27: such as calcium antagonists
column28: nitrates
column29: etc.
column30: with different rotations and management schemes according to her clinical evolution. Not a candidate for intervention due to clinical status and anticoagulation with acenocoumarin
column31: and due to the use of antiplatelet agents.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 6-year-old female patient with a diagnosis of cloacal exstrophy who had undergone surgery on several occasions in different institutions; at the time of consultation she presented with multiple fistulas and scars on the abdominal wall with a significant deficit of antero-superior abdominal tissue. Due to the previous failure in the creation of a bladder reservoir
column2: reconstruction is programmed
column3: operating as a team with the Paediatric Urology Service.  1st surgical stage: Consisted in the placement of 2 rectangular expanders of 1000cc. and 15
column4: 2cm. long x 7
column5: 3cm wide with remote valve (Silimed®) below the abdominal cellulo-fatty tissue and above the aponeurosis of the greater oblique muscle in subcostal and lateral position. Between 50 to 100cc of physiological saline were infiltrated at intervals of 1 week to 20 days
column6: according to the patient's tolerance
column7: until a volume of 1150cc was reached.  2nd Surgical time: Once the expansion was completed
column8: the expanders were removed and the ileocecal urinary reservoir was reconstructed
column9: after which the abdominal defect was reconstructed by lifting and cross-linking two major oblique flaps
column10: with a rotation axis in the lower ribs
column11: which were covered with the expanded fascio-cutaneous tissues.  The patient evolved favourably without complications. .   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present a case of cervical myoclonias probably associated with Etanercept. A 16-year-old woman
column2: diagnosed with severe plaque psoriasis
column3: under dermatological follow-up and on treatment with Etanercept 25 mg twice a week. She consulted for abnormal cervical movements in March 2013. She had started treatment with etanercept 25 mg twice weekly in May 2012 for a flare-up of severe plaque psoriasis that did not respond to topical (clobetasol
column4: calcipotriol
column5: betamethasone + calcipotriol) and oral (ciclosporin and mycophenolate mofetil) treatments. After 12 weeks of treatment
column6: a complete clinical response was achieved and the drug was withdrawn. One week after the last dose of etanercept
column7: administered on 29 June 2012
column8: he developed granulomatous interstitial dermatitis of the extremities
column9: which was attributed to the withdrawal of etanercept6. In November 2012
column10: she had a new flare-up of psoriasis
column11: and the severity was assessed using the Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) calculation
column12: with a PASI of 18.60. Etanercept 25 mg twice weekly was restarted and clinical improvement was achieved after 15 weeks of treatment. On 5 March 2013
column13: the patient was admitted to Internal Medicine for a 48-hour history of sudden
column14: involuntary
column15: repetitive
column16: arrhythmic and sustained movements of the head to the left during sleep. He had received the last dose of etanercept on 27 February 2013. The condition was not accompanied by any other systemic symptoms. The movements caused twitching of the left upper limb
column17: were painless and associated with hypoaesthesia in the hemiface and anterior portion from D4 to L2. She did not report similar previous episodes or movement alterations at these or other levels suggesting a personal history of myoclonus
column18: dystonia or any other type of involuntary movement. On physical examination he was afebrile and haemodynamically stable. The neurological examination revealed nociceptive hypoaesthesia in the left hemiface and anterolateral part of the trunk from D2 to L2
column19: and D2 to D8 in the back. Among the complementary tests
column20: an electroencephalogram was performed
column21: showing myoclonic movements of left cervical flexion and elevation of the left shoulder
column22: presenting over the temporoparietal region of the same hemisphere a graphoelement with a spike morphology that precedes the movement by 200-400 ms
column23: interpreted as an artefact due to muscle contraction. In view of the clinical suspicion of AMR due to Etanercept
column24: the drug was withdrawn and an exhaustive search was requested from the hospital's Pharmacy Service on the reactions described with Etanercept. Treatment was started with carbamazepine 100 mg for suspected paroxysmal dyskinesias
column25: which was discontinued due to dizziness and nausea. Subsequently
column26: treatment was prescribed with clonacepam 0.5 mg 1-1-2
column27: levitiracetam 250 mg c/12 h
column28: valproic acid 500 mg c/8 h and diazepam 2.5 mg 0-1-2 without improvement. A differential diagnosis was made between spinal myoclonias
column29: although without long tract involvement
column30: paroxysmal non-kinesiogenic dyskinesias or dystonia-myoclonias. One week after admission
column31: the clinical picture began to respond with diazepam at doses of 2.5 mg 1-1-2
column32: clonazepam 0.5 mg 1-1-2
column33: valproic 500 mg c/8 h
column34: levetiracetam 1000 mg c/12 h and biperidene 2 mg c/8 h. On the tenth day
column35: the patient was discharged from the hospital. On the tenth day she was discharged with clinical improvement and treatment with clonazepam 0.5 mg 1-1-2
column36: biperiden 4 mg c/24 h and levetiracetam 1000 mg c/12 h in a descending regimen.   |O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 19-year-old female in her first intrauterine pregnancy was diagnosed with brain death following a suicide attempt by means of a gunshot wound to the right occipital level. Ultrasonography confirmed the presence of a live product of 19.6 weeks' gestation with no macroscopic malformations. The patient's family requested to continue advanced life support manoeuvres in order to save the product and eventually consider the mother as a potential organ donor. The ethics committee of the institution decides to continue with basic and somatic life support. Once haemodynamic stability was achieved
column2: management was initiated by the Nutrition Service
column3: emphasising the importance of nutritional support to promote the growth and development of the product. At 20.3 weeks of gestation
column4: mixed nutritional and metabolic support was started
column5: both enteral and parenteral. Resting Energy Expenditure (REE) was estimated using the Harris-Benedict prediction formula
column6: adding the theoretical energy and protein component established for gestational age. The energy and protein intake was increased gradually and gradually according to biochemical monitoring in order to prevent refeeding syndrome behaviour. After 5 days of mixed feeding and once tolerance and nutritional adequacy by enteral route had been established
column7: parenteral support was discontinued. Enteral intake was maintained at total macro- and micronutrient requirements using a mixture of standard polymeric formula
column8: high protein formula and modular trace element formula. A minimum gestational age of 24-26 weeks was established to consider the possibility of extrauterine life according to previous reports in the literature. Gestational weight was monitored serially by weekly ultrasound and fetal well-being was monitored by biophysical profile measurement. The relationship between ultrasound weight gain and energy intake is shown in figure 1.  Haemodynamic
column9: ventilatory and metabolic stability was maintained with the usual management measures without evidence of uterine activity or foetal distress by tocographic monitoring for 22 days. Suddenly
column10: on the 23rd day of ICU stay (22.4 weeks gestation
column11: 12th day of nutritional support)
column12: she presented hypertensive dyscontrol with uterine activity and transvaginal bleeding. Obstetric ultrasound showed placental abruption and foetal death. With the loss of the product and in accordance with the purposes established for continuing vital and somatic management in the ICU
column13: the mother's organs were explanted for donation (liver
column14: heart
column15: kidney and cornea). The foetal autopsy showed a male product weighing 450g. Macroscopic age of 23 weeks of gestation
column16: with no evidence of malformations.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 80-year-old man with a history of TURP 3 years earlier consulted for pollakiuria
column2: hypogastric pain and fever of 48 hours' evolution one month after undergoing surgery for incarcerated right inguinal hernia. On questioning
column3: he reported a progressive worsening of his urinary stream in recent months. Physical examination revealed bladder ballooning
column4: minimal serous discharge from the inguinal wound and painful induration of the penile base. A cystostomy catheter was placed due to the impossibility of urethral catheterisation
column5: and with blood tests showing leukocytosis with a left shift and urine sediment positive for gram-negative bacilli
column6: he was admitted for intravenous antibiotic treatment and study. After presenting clinical and analytical improvement
column7: an abdominal ultrasound was performed
column8: which showed a subcicatricial seroma at the right inguinal level and cystography by cystostomy catheter where an extravasation was observed in the proximal penile urethra.  Once the febrile UTI was treated with a positive urine culture for multisensitive E.coli
column9: the patient was discharged. At the follow-up visit
column10: the patient reported significant perineal pain that he had been treating with anti-inflammatory drugs and provided the anatomo-pathological report from the surgery department where he had undergone surgery for inguinal hernia
column11: stating that the resected material was a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma lymphadenopathy. At that time
column12: the patient was diagnosed as a possible squamous cell carcinoma of the urethra with inguinal adenopathy and an extension study was performed. Pelvic MRI showed a 3 cm collection between the urethra and corpora cavernosa as well as right inguinal lymphadenopathy.  Thoracic-abdominal CT scan showed a single subpleural lesion in the upper lobe of the right lung suggestive of metastasis
column13: with no adenopathy. The patient was admitted for poor control of perineal pain and the appearance of several nodular skin lesions on the pubis and right thigh.  Biopsy of one of these lesions was positive for squamous cell carcinoma. The patient underwent 6 cycles of palliative polychemotherapy with cisplatin + 5-fluorouracil (CDDP 137 mg-5FU 6839 mg) with good tolerance and good initial clinical response with improvement of asthenia
column14: partial regression of the lethargy and disappearance of the pulmonary lesion. One month after the end of chemotherapy
column15: he presented early progression of the disease with the appearance of a greater number of skin lesions. She then underwent palliative radiotherapy
column16: achieving better control of perineal pain and little response of the lethal lesions. She is currently being treated with morphine and monitored by a palliative care team at home
column17: 9 months after the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 54-year-old male patient with no personal history of interest. He attended the Emergency Department of our hospital in September 2005 due to right frontoparietal headache and lateral gaze diplopia of 2 weeks' duration
column2: as well as right eyelid oedema for the last week. He was initially assessed by the Ophthalmology Department
column3: which found moderate exophthalmos in the right eye
column4: inflammation
column5: hyperemia and moderate upper and lower right eyelid swelling
column6: limitation in all gaze positions and diplopia. Visual acuity was not impaired. The intraocular pressure (IOP) of the right eye was 20 mmHg
column7: the IOP of the left eye was 10 mmHg. Fundus examination was normal. An orbital CT scan was requested
column8: showing an enlargement of the sphenoid bone with a permeative pattern and hyperostosis of the orbital face with a soft tissue mass bulging the lateral rectus muscle. There was also occupation of the ethmoid cells.  The patient was admitted to the neurosurgery department and a cranial MRI was requested
column9: which was reported as a possible hyperostosis meningioma in the right periorbital plate of the greater wing of the sphenoid
column10: without being able to rule out fibro-osseous sphenoid lesions. Surgical biopsy of these lesions was scheduled. The anatomopathological result of the biopsy was connective tissue
column11: striated skeletal muscle and isolated bony trabeculae with nests and cords of epithelial cells with ample cytoplasm that focally formed glandular lumina
column12: in the bone there was metastasis of adenocarcinoma with immunohistochemical positivity for Prostate Specific Antigen (PSA). In view of these findings
column13: the Urology Department was consulted. A directed anamnesis revealed alterations in urination in recent months (pollakiuria and nocturia) and haemospermia. Physical examination Rectal examination: prostate volume II/IV
column14: stony consistency in both lobes
column15: fixed
column16: suspicious for prostate cancer. Complementary tests PSA: 389 ng/ml Transrectal prostate biopsy: prostatic adenocarcinoma Gleason 4+4=8
column17: extensively affecting both lobes. Tc99m bone scan: imaging showed multiple areas of hyperenhancement involving the right zygomatic region and right internal orbital region
column18: both costal ribs
column19: dorsolumbar spine
column20: iliac spine
column21: right acetabular and ischiopubic region
column22: left iliac spine and acetabular region and middle third of left femoral diaphysis.  Diagnosis Adenocarcinoma of the prostate Gleason 4+4=8 with multiple bone metastases. Treatment Treatment with complete hormonal blockade (Bicalutamide 50 mg/24h and Goserelin 10.8 mg/12 weeks) and bisphosphonates (Zoledronic acid 4 mg iv /4 weeks). Evolution After the establishment of the androgen blockade
column23: there was a progressive improvement of the ocular symptoms. During the first 7 months of follow-up the patient remained asymptomatic. At 8 months the patient was admitted to the Urology Department with haematuria
column24: which did not improve with continuous bladder lavage and required bladder TUR
column25: which revealed a large prostatic neoformative process invading the bladder floor. Pathological anatomy of the resection fragments: foci of prostatic adenocarcinoma with involutive changes secondary to hormone treatment. Nine months after the initial diagnosis
column26: the patient was admitted to our department again due to obstructive voiding syndrome
column27: decreased diuresis
column28: deterioration of renal function and dyspnoea. A thoracoabdominal-pelvic CT scan was performed
column29: showing right pleural effusion with compressive atelectasis
column30: multiple mediastinal adenopathies
column31: multiple pulmonary metastases
column32: ureteropielocaliceal dilatation of the left kidney and the already known multiple metastatic bone lesions of the blastoma type. Right pleurocentesis was performed (pleural fluid cytology was positive for malignant tumour cells). Percutaneous nephrostomy was not considered. The patient was monitored by the Palliative Care Unit. He died 10 months after the initial diagnosis.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 8-day-old female neonate
column2: preterm at 36 weeks
column3: high birth weight (3
column5: suffering from peripartum asphyxia with moderate-severe neonatal encephalopathy. Due to peripartum asphyxia
