column6: she was treated at the regional hospital of origin with systemic hypothermia using the CritiCool® system (MTRE
column7: Mennen Medical Corp
column8: USA). Eight days after admission
column9: he was transferred to the Paediatric Monitoring Unit of the Hospital 12 de Octubre. During his stay in this unit he was referred to the Plastic Surgery Department for an early onset dorsal skin lesion. During the assessment we observed a tumour on the back
column10: in the midline
column11: measuring 11x13x4 cm
column12: partially fluctuant
column13: with a central blackish eschar measuring approximately 5 cm in diameter. A soft tissue ultrasound was requested to try to establish the diagnosis
column14: which revealed liquefactive fat necrosis. We performed 2 punctures to evacuate the contents without success
column15: so we decided to perform surgical debridement and application of vacuum therapy (Renasys®
column16: Smith&Nephew®
column17: London
column18: UK)
column19: on the 11th day of admission. The therapy was set at a pressure of 100 mmHg
column20: with continuous cycles and dressing changes every 72 hours.  The patient underwent surgery after 21 days of treatment with vacuum therapy. At the time of surgery
column21: the wound had a good appearance
column22: with a background of granulation tissue and no exudate. Tissue advancement was performed
column23: leaving a central cruciate area of 1 cm2. The patient was admitted to the Neonatology Department of our hospital and was finally discharged 5 days postoperatively
column24: at the age of 45 days. After 8 months of evolution
column25: the patient has a stable wound
column26: without pain
column27: which allows her to lead a normal life
column28: scoring 2 points on the Vancouver Scar Scale.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: JL
column2: a 46-year-old white female
column3: consulted in February 2000 for facial asymmetry and difficulty using her lower prosthesis. She presented with an enlargement of the left parasymphyseal volume of 1 year's duration
column4: of slow growth
column5: which had stabilised in recent months
column6: and she did not recall any history of trauma in the area. The oral examination revealed a complete upper and lower edentulous patient. In the left anterior mandibular area there was a mass expanding the vestibular and lingual cortex
column7: covered by healthy mucosa in which telangectasias were observed. On palpation
column8: the borders were clear
column9: there was crepitation of the vestibular cortex and perforation of the lingual cortex. The objective and subjective neurological examination confirmed that there was no involvement of the inferior alveolar nerve
column10: Vincent's sign (-).  Imaging examination revealed a radiolucent lesion with radiopaque areas within
column11: unilocular
column12: approximately 6 cm in greatest diameter
column13: with defined boundaries and no corticalisation. The lesion extended from approximately the left premolar area to the right incisor area across the midline. It deformed and thinned the mandibular basal and displaced the inferior alveolar canal.  The protocol described above for the treatment of LCG was implemented. Two series of intralesional corticosteroids were performed. The first series was performed between March and April 2000 and the 2nd series started in September 2000
column14: 5 months after the completion of the 1st series. Fifteen months after the start of treatment
column15: in May 2001
column16: because the lesion had not disappeared and the bone cortices did not allow passage of the needle to attempt a new series of infiltrations
column17: it was decided to perform surgical enucleation. Under general anaesthesia and through a buccal approach the lesion was accessed. Contrary to expectations
column18: we did not find a bleeding
column19: friable lesion corresponding to the macroscopic characteristics of LCGs
column20: but rather an increase in bone volume without clear limits with the normal bone structure. Surgical remodelling of the lesion with drills was performed.  The patient is now clinically cured 39 months after initiation of treatment and 24 months after surgical remodelling
column21: with no midfacial midline deviation and a lower alveolar ridge suitable for prosthetic use.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 65-year-old man with a history of two sessions of photodynamic therapy with Verteporfin (PDT) and proposed for a third
column2: came for assessment. His current visual acuity is 0.7 in the right eye (OD). This is a single eye as the left eye (OI) is in ptisis bulbi due to a traumatic antecedent that occurred in his childhood. The patient reported no changes since the onset of the condition
column3: nor had he noticed any change in his visual acuity prior to the PDT sessions. Funduscopic imaging revealed a raised vitelliform lesion in the foveal area with hard drusen in the posterior pole. Fluorescein angiography (FFA) shows a progressive and intense ring hyperfluorescence at late times with a hypofluorescent central zone. Indocyanine green angiography (IVGA) shows no alterations of interest. OCT showed the presence of a medium-high reflectivity wedge-shaped structure between the pigmented epithelium and the neurosensory retina with a detachment of the neurosensory retina bordering the lesion. An electrooculogram was performed and the result was within normal limits. The patient was diagnosed with DFVA and it was decided to carry out regular check-ups. At the 3-
column4: 6- and 12-month check-ups
column5: the test results showed no variation with respect to the first visit and his visual acuity remained stable. At the 24-month check-up her visual acuity was 0.02. The fundus examination did not show the vitelliform lesion but a rounded orange lesion in the foveal area. In both FFA and AVI there is intense hypofluorescence maintained throughout the angiographic period. OCT shows a normal foveal depression with absence of the mid-reflective mass seen at the first visit and an increase in posterior reflectivity at the level of the pigment-coriocapillary epithelium complex.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 23-year-old male diagnosed with hyperrefléxic bladder secondary to myelomeningocele. He had a ventriculo-peritoneal shunt due to hydrocephalus. Despite medical treatment
column2: the patient presented with symptoms of total urinary incontinence
column3: with the need to use a penile collector
column4: as well as recurrent pyelonephritis predominantly on the right side. The cystography showed the presence of a scalloped bladder with a low capacity and a right grade III passive and left grade I active vesicoureteral reflux. The cystography data were confirmed by the urodynamic study. Laparoscopic enlargement enterocystoplasty was performed with a 15 cm detubularised ileal segment. The duration of surgery was 6 hours. Haemorrhage was about 100 cc. The postoperative period was uneventful and the patient was discharged from hospital on the ninth postoperative day. After 18 months of follow up
column5: the patient is in a continent state and has not had any new episodes of pyelonephritis. The cystography performed 6 months after surgery showed disappearance of the right passive and left active reflux. Only the persistence of a right grade I active reflux was evidenced.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a three year old girl who came to the primary care clinic for three days presenting with toothache and discrete dental phlegmon
column2: without fever.  The examination revealed a caries in the lower right second molar
column3: with discrete inflammation and mandibular pain. It was decided to start antibiotic treatment with high-dose amoxicillin and anti-inflammatory drugs
column4: and the patient was referred to the dentist3. The patient was seen at the dentist's office four days later. The phlegmon and regional adenopathy persisted
column5: but there was no pain. It was decided to continue with treatment and monitoring. After a week of treatment
column6: the phlegmon was more defined and painful
column7: and the patient was referred to maxillofacial surgery. That same afternoon he presented with fever and was referred to the Emergency Department
column8: where it was decided to treat with amoxicillin plus clavulanic acid and to see a dentist. Twenty days later
column9: at the primary care clinic
column10: he presented with a red
column11: painful and suppurative abscess on the right submaxillary border. She was again referred to the emergency department for drainage. There it was drained and samples were taken for culture and pathological anatomy of the ulcerated cervical lesion. Treatment was started with azithromycin and ciprofloxacin.  The result of the pathological anatomy describes granulation tissue with acute and chronic inflammation and central necrosis
column12: with no microorganisms observed (with Grocot
column13: Gram and Ziehl-Neelsen techniques) and no traces of lymph node are identified. The evolution of the ulcer was torpid
column14: with treatment every two days at the health centre. One month after drainage
column15: exodontia was performed
column16: with definitive improvement after two months of evolution. The large scar on the face begins to involute.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 38-year-old patient diagnosed with ulcerative pancolitis since 2004
column2: corticodependent. That same year he presented with inflammatory bowel disease with bloodless diarrhoea
column3: significant general condition and weight loss of 15 kg in one month
column4: as well as digestive intolerance to treatment with azathioprine (Imurel®). During the last 3 years he has required several admissions due to severe bouts of diarrhoea (5-6 stools per day) with red blood. In June 2007
column5: he presented a prolonged flare-up of ulcerative colitis with moderate-severe activation and poor response to drug treatment with criteria of cortirrefractoriness
column6: at which point cytapheresis was initiated
column7: receiving a session every 7 days for 5 weeks. The access routes were the antecubital veins of the arms
column8: and during the sessions there were no complications or adverse reactions. From the second session onwards
column9: she showed a notable clinical improvement and is currently receiving oral mycophenolate-mofetil (CellCe®) treatment.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O

column1: This is a 35-year-old woman
column2: with a family history of Crohn's disease and no pathological history of interest or toxic habits
column3: who started with abdominal pain in FID plus weight loss. She was studied on an outpatient basis and was diagnosed with Crohn's disease with ileal and ileocaecal valve involvement (A1L1B2
column4: Vienna 1998)
column5: according to clinical
column6: endoscopic and histological criteria. Treatment with mesalazine and steroids was started with good response. Due to corticodependence
column7: treatment with azathioprine was started
column8: and the patient remained steroid-free and in complete clinical remission
column9: but symptomatology returned two years later. Infliximab was indicated and two doses were administered. Antinuclear antibodies
column10: chest X-ray and viral serology were negative. Two weeks later
column11: the patient was admitted with a fever of 39°C
column12: pain and difficulty in moving the neck. The previous week he had presented with general malaise and fever
column13: and had been treated for three days with azithromycin on an outpatient basis. Physical examination revealed thinness (BMI 17)
column14: temperature 37 ºC
column15: blood pressure 105/60
column16: she was conscious and oriented
column17: with complete normal neurological examination
column18: oral thrush and normal cardiorespiratory and abdominal examination. Tests showed normocytic anaemia (9.9 g/dl Hb)
column19: leukocytes 6
column20: 700 with 84% segmented
column21: platelets 363
column22: 000. Blood biochemical parameters were normal except for GOT 87
column23: GPT 51
column24: gamma-GT 67 and total proteins were 5.8 g/dl with albumin 1
column25: 400 mg/dl. Urinalysis and sediment were normal
column26: as were chest and abdominal X-rays on admission. A lumbar puncture was performed
column27: detecting normal glycorrhachia
column28: proteinorrachia of 102 mg/dl
column29: 960 cells/mm3
column30: 90% of which corresponded to polynuclear cells
column31: Gram stain in which no germs were observed and positive culture for Listeria monocytogenes
column32: leading to the diagnosis of Listeria meningitis
column33: initiating antibiotic treatment and suspending all immunosuppressive medication. Five days after hospitalisation
column34: the patient presented with acute abdominal symptoms
column35: with intestinal peritonitis secondary to perforation of the preterminal ileum and ileal stenosis
column36: with the rest of the small intestine and colon remaining normal. Ileocecal resection and terminal ileostomy with mucosal fistula of the ascending colon were performed. Pathological anatomical pathology confirmed granulomatous inflammation compatible with Crohn's disease. The evolution was favourable
column37: completing antibiotic therapy with ampicillin and gentamicin for three weeks
column38: with negative CSF at discharge. Azathioprine was reinstituted once stable and the infectious condition was overcome
column39: and she was discharged 21 days after admission.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Patient Y. V. L.
column2: 30 years old. Eight years ago she had her first child; pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Three years ago
column3: she had an unwanted pregnancy terminated by endometrial curettage
column4: at which time she was fitted with a copper T-cup as a method of contraception. Approximately one year later
column5: she began to present with irritative urinary symptoms
column6: consisting of postvoid urethral burning
column7: urethral and lower abdominal pain
column8: frequency of urination and urinary urgency. She attended medical consultation
column9: Escherichia coli was detected in urine cultures and she was treated with several courses of different antibiotics with the diagnosis of infectious cystitis. The previous symptoms subsided
column10: but within weeks of completing the aforementioned treatments
column11: they returned
column12: with greater intensity. Finally
column13: sudden interruption of the urinary stream and dyspareunia were added to the symptoms described above. In the midst of this situation
column14: the patient became pregnant again
column15: presumably with the copper T placed in utero
column16: and decided to carry to term. During the nine months of gestation
column17: the above-mentioned urinary symptoms continued in a similar form and intensity. She gave birth without difficulty
column18: this time a boy. Two months after the birth
column19: and due to the persistence of the urinary symptoms
column20: she decided to go to the urology clinic. Ultrasound of the urinary tract was ordered and it was reported that both kidneys were normal in position and morphology and that there was a large lithiasis in the bladder
column21: approximately five centimetres in diameter
column22: which moved with changes in the patient's position. An antero-posterior X-ray of the pelvis was performed
column23: showing the presence of a lithiasis measuring approximately five by three centimetres in size
column24: in the projection of the small pelvis and with a copper T inside it.  It was decided to perform a suprapubic cystolithotomy. During the cystolithotomy
column25: the bladder mucosa was found to be very erythematous and bleeding easily. The lithiasis
column26: located at the bottom of the bladder
column27: was fragmented during the extraction manoeuvre with the forceps
column28: revealing the copper T with lithiasic incrustations inside. The foreign body was then stripped of its lining and was found to be intact.  The patient was maintained with a urethral catheter for two weeks
column29: and was treated with oral Ciprofloxacin
column30: 500 milligrams every 12 hours for three weeks. The evolution was satisfactory and total cessation of symptoms was achieved.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Woman born at term by vaginal delivery. First child of non-consanguineous parents. Intrauterine detection of mild bilateral ventriculomegaly in the 21st week of gestation
column2: which persisted in successive check-ups. No other incidents were observed during pregnancy. The Apgar test score was 3/10
column4: 10 and 20 minutes respectively
column5: requiring endotracheal intubation in the delivery room. Birth weight was 3480 grams
column6: length 55 cm and head circumference 39.5 cm. At birth the baby had dysmorphic features: coarse fascia
column7: hypertelorism
column8: anteverted nostrils
column9: microretrognathia and frontal asymmetry with left prominence. Generalised hypotonia progressing to generalised hypertonia with vivid reflexes
column10: clonus and generalised convulsive episodes. There is no visual monitoring. During the neonatal period
column11: an electroencephalogram was performed showing a discrete diffuse slowing. Brain ultrasound showed asymmetric ventriculomegaly with left ventriculomegaly and hemispheric asymmetry in favour of the left side. Cranial computed tomography showed prominence of the ventricular system. Magnetic resonance imaging showed cortical dysplasia with foci of nodular heterotopia.  Metabolic and infectious screening is normal. Karyotype 46XX. At 7 months of age she was referred to the ophthalmology department for esotropia of the right eye of 15º. She presented with left eye dominance
column12: abduction nystagmus in both eyes. The retina had a dystrophic appearance with diffuse disorganisation and retinal pigmentary abnormalities. Optic nerve hypoplasia.  Myopia of -13.00 dioptres (-2 to 90º) in the right eye and -14.00 dioptres (-2 to 180º) in the left eye. Optical correction is prescribed. Visual evoked potentials are pathological with an increased latency period. An electroretinogram could not be performed due to lack of cooperation. At 14 months
column13: the large left hemicranial hypertophy made it impossible to wear glasses
column14: and contact lenses were prescribed
column15: which were well tolerated.  At 10 months of age
column16: there was significant psychomotor retardation
column17: hypertonia of the extremities and cervico-axial hypotonia. There is no head control or sitting. Eye contact improves with increased interaction with the environment and social smile. Electroencephalographic controls show an interhemispheric asymmetry of the tracing
column18: without irritative paroxysms. There is a progressive enlargement of the left hemibody
column19: plagiocephaly and lowering of the ipsilateral orbit. Progressive appearance of deformities: tibia vara
column20: coxa valga and bilateral femoral thinning. At 15 months
column21: macrocephalic appearance with involvement of the craniofacial massif. Epidermal nevus and scattered haemangiomas
column22: predominantly on the left side. Spasticity in response to stimuli. At 16 months of age
column23: tracheostomy was performed due to laryngotracheomalacia. He died on the sixth postoperative day due to pneumonia.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: In June 2003
column2: a 40-year-old female patient from and resident of a town near Guatemala City presented for consultation referred by her general dentist with an asymptomatic dark brown pigmented macule
column3: discovered during a routine clinical examination. The lesion was located on the anterior mucosa of the hard palate
column4: measuring 0.5 cm in diameter. The patient had no relevant medical history and was in good health. She reported not taking any medication. The patient had lost her upper incisors through exodontia and was wearing a removable partial denture made of acrylic
column5: inadequately designed
column6: which caused pressure erythema of the underlying mucosa
column7: candidiasis was ruled out by exfoliative cytology.  An excisional biopsy was performed under local anaesthesia using the punch technique with a 0.6 cm diameter instrument. The surgical site healed by second intention without complications. The tissue obtained from the biopsy was fixed in 10% buffered formalin and processed routinely. Microscopic examination with haematoxylin-eosin stain revealed a mucosal fragment lined by mildly acanthotic stratified squamous epithelium with spongiosis
column8: containing numerous dendritic melanocytes. The underlying connective tissue showed the presence of melanin pigment admixed with a mild lymphocyte-predominant inflammatory infiltrate. The definitive diagnosis was melanoacanthosis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 64-year-old patient
column2: allergic to penicillin and with aortic valve replacement due to endocarditis
column3: consulted for the appearance of a penile mass of progressive growth in recent weeks. Physical examination revealed an excrescent and variegated formation on the glans penis
column4: which deformed the meatus
column5: with ulcerated areas covered with fibrin. Hard
column6: fixed lymph nodes were palpable in both inguinal regions. Chest X-ray and abdomino-pelvic CT confirmed the presence of large pulmonary and inguinal adenopathies. With the diagnosis of penile neoplasia
column7: partial penectomy with safety margin was performed. Pathological anatomy showed a pleomorphic penile sarcoma with osteosarcomatous differentiation and margins free of involvement. Treatment with two lines of chemotherapy consisting of adriamycin and ifosfamide was decided but there was no response. He was admitted again with a large and rapidly growing local bleeding recurrence that caused obstruction of the meatus with acute renal failure. A cystostomy tube was placed and treatment with serum therapy was started
column8: improving renal function
column9: but with progressive worsening of the general condition until he died 6 months after diagnosis.   |O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 25-year-old man operated on for a left varicocele six months previously
column2: who consulted for a problem of repeated urinary tract infections without sexual pathology. Retrograde urethrography and voiding cystourethrography showed the presence of an incomplete urethral duplicity originating in the bulbar urethra and running along the ventral side. The accessory tract was surgically resected via the perineal route. Subsequent imaging controls showed the existence of a normal bulbar urethra. Voiding symptoms have not recurred in the two years since the operation.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 14-year-old male adolescent attended his paediatrician without an appointment due to chest pain in the left anterior hemithorax radiating to the neck. The pain started the previous day
column2: began as mild and has been increasing
column3: and the patient has observed that the discomfort worsens in decubitus and with deep breathing
column4: and improves when he sits up and tilts his trunk forward. He denies fever or other symptoms
column5: and has no medical or surgical history of interest. The physical examination is completely normal; however
column6: the paediatrician performs an electrocardiogram (ECG) and decides
column7: in view of the test findings
column8: to refer the patient to hospital. Before reading on
column9: take a close look at the ECG.  Following the routine reading1
column10: the ECG shows a sinus rhythm at 100 beats per minute. There are no abnormalities in the P wave or PR segment
column11: and the QRS complex presents an axis within the lower left quadrant (between 0 and +90o
column12: being positive in I and aVF) without morphological alterations. So far
column13: we have not detected any unusual data. On analysing the repolarisation
column14: we observed a QTc interval of normal duration
column15: although the presence of negative T waves in leads V3-V6 is striking. We observed a marked decrease in the ST segment in V4 and slightly less in V5
column16: without pathological Q waves or signs of ventricular hypertrophy. Given the patient's clinical and electrocardiographic findings
column17: the paediatrician diagnosed acute pericarditis and referred the patient to hospital.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 50-year-old man with a history of lumbar spine fixation due to herniated discs
column2: who presented with coralliform lithiasis in the right renal pelvis
column3: scarcely radiopaque
column4: with pyelocaliceal dilatation and delayed elimination in the IVUS. Alkalinising treatment was administered with potassium citrate (Acalka) at a dose of one tablet every 8 hours for 3 months and a double J catheter was placed on the right. Subsequently
column5: three sessions of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy were scheduled and IVUS was requested after the treatment
column6: showing a functional annulment of the affected renal unit despite the placement of the double J catheter.  To assess the functional status of the right kidney
column7: an isotopic renogram and renal scintigraphy were performed with low isotopic uptake in the right kidney and a flat
column8: obstructive curve after administration of the diuretic in the renogram. Total renal function of the right kidney was 9%. A right ureteroscopy was performed under anaesthesia in an attempt to identify the origin of the renal annulment. During the procedure
column9: a long lumbar and iliac ureteral stenosis (8-10 cm) with no appreciable lithiasis was observed. A standard guide wire (Cordis
column10: 150 cm long and 0.90 mm wide with a polytetrafluoroethylene coating) was advanced to the kidney and repeatedly dilated with a high-pressure pneumatic balloon (18 atmospheres) without resolving the ureteral stricture
column11: given that during the dilatations the working guide wire was dragged with the balloon to a more distal position
column12: a safety guide wire was also placed and advanced to the renal pelvis to prevent its displacement. Once the attempts at ureteral dilatation had been completed
column13: it was decided to place a double J catheter
column14: which ascended without any problems through the working guide. However
column15: on attempting to remove the guidewire
column16: it was observed that the intrapyelic loop had formed a knot that prevented it from being removed.  At this point
column17: the patient was presented with two therapeutic options: percutaneous approach to remove the loop or nephrectomy
column18: given the limited functionality of the right kidney and the long ureteral stricture
column19: which was difficult to resolve with conservative measures. The patient opted for the second option
column20: performing a right nephrectomy without significant operative incidences
column21: and the patient was asymptomatic in successive visits to the outpatient clinic.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We describe the case of a 47-year-old patient being followed up for psoriatic spondyloarthritis and fibromyalgia
column2: on treatment with leflunomide
column3: celecoxib and gabapentin
column4: with no history of interest and with regular menstrual cycles. She reported no toxic habits and her body mass index (BMI) was normal. During a routine check-up
column5: she reported pain in her feet and ankles
column6: with no history of trauma
column7: of a mechanical rhythm
column8: which progressively increased until it caused claudication on walking
column9: with modification of the statics of her feet due to the pain. On examination
column10: there was swelling of the ankles and feet
column11: with pain on pressure and bilateral fovea. An ultrasound scan was performed in consultation
column12: which revealed very marked inflammation of the subcutaneous cellular tissue (TCS) with no signs of synovitis or Doppler signal. A foot X-ray was requested
column13: which showed no pathological findings. Due to the significant SCT oedema
column14: the patient was referred to Angiology for assessment. Angiology requested a lymphography scan which confirmed severe bilateral lymphatic insufficiency. As the clinical manifestations of intense pain with claudication persisted
column15: an MRI of the feet was ordered
column16: which showed a fracture callus in the right foot in the 3rd and 4th MTT and oedema in the 2nd MTT; and in the left foot a fracture line in the 1st MTT
column17: and oedema in the 3rd and 4th MTT and in the surrounding tissue. Given the findings of the MRI
column18: the patient was assessed by the Traumatology Department
column19: which indicated conservative treatment with unloading and rehabilitation (magnetotherapy). Due to the finding of multiple stress fractures
column20: a study was carried out in our consulting rooms
column21: and analyses were performed with renal function
column22: serum and urinary calcium
column23: ionic calcium
column24: magnesium and PTH
column25: which were normal. Only a vitamin D level of 19.5 ng/ml was found
column26: and supplementation was indicated.  Assessing the case of this patient as a whole
column27: we considered
column28: as a predisposing factor for the appearance of stress fractures
column29: the significant alteration of the antalgic foot statics that she had developed due to the pain caused by the severe lymphatic insufficiency that she suffered.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the clinical case of a 42 year old male
column2: with no drug allergies
column3: with a personal history of infectious mononucleosis in childhood
column4: fracture of the left arm 5 years ago
column5: morbid obesity with hepatic steatosis treated by bariatric surgery. He came to the Otorrolaryngology department for a few weeks of left nasal obstruction
column6: with repeated episodes of purulent rhinorrhoea
column7: with a sensation of left nasal packing
column8: accompanied by an intranasal mass and a left submandibular tumour. Simultaneously
column9: the patient was referred to the haematology department for repeated asymptomatic thrombocytosis in the blood tests. He was seen in the haematology department and
column10: with the suspicion of essential thrombocythemia
column11: a bone marrow aspirate/biopsy was performed
column12: showing a platelet count of 487
column13: 000/ul in the haemogram. The patient underwent a biopsy of the intranasal mass
column14: which was completed with an incisional biopsy of the left submandibular tumour. The cervico-facial CT scan showed a mass of soft tissue in the left submaxillary cell
column15: with areas of necrosis or abscessation
column16: 3 cm in greatest diameter; accompanied by an adjacent locoregional adenopathic component of probably inflammatory nature. There was also a second lesion in discontinuity with the previous one
column17: corresponding to a left paralateronasal cyst. Biopsy of the intranasal lesion consisted of an infiltrate of lymphoid neoplastic cells with a diffuse growth pattern
column18: no 'starry sky' images
column19: and a moderate mitosis rate. The neoplastic cells are of intermediate size
column20: with discretely irregular nuclei and moderate pleomorphism. The immunophenotype of the neoplastic cells determined by immunohistochemistry was: CD45+/cCD3+/Granzime B+/CD56+
column21: CD20-/CD4-/CD8-/LMP1(EBV)-/Perforin-. Biopsy of the submandibular tumour showed massive infiltration by intermediate to large lymphoid neoplastic cells with nuclear irregularities and coarse
column22: irregular and sparse azurophilic granulation. The immunophenotype is identical to that of the intranasal lesion. The EBER(EBV) determination was positive
column23: there was polyclonal re-enhancer of T-lymphocyte receptor gamma chain (TCR) genes and immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) genes. This was compatible with a diagnosis of extranodal nasal type NK lymphoma. The patient was immediately sent to the medical oncology department for evaluation. The patient was in very good general condition with a performance status of 0
column24: with no B symptoms and asymptomatic
column25: except for the symptoms of left nasal obstruction. The extension study was completed with thoraco-abdominal computed tomography
column26: which showed no evidence of distant dissemination
column27: bone marrow biopsy already requested due to suspicion of essential thrombocythemia
column28: biochemistry with renal and hepatic profile
column29: proteinogram
column30: LDH and serum beta-2-microglobulin. Bone marrow examination showed normocellular parenchyma (3/5)
column31: with moderate megakaryocytic hyperplasia with elements in all maturational stages
column32: some of them with hypertrophic appearance
column33: with the remaining series preserved. There was no evidence of myelofibrosis
column34: parasites or granulomas. There was also no lymphomatous infiltration. The bone marrow study does not support (nor does it absolutely rule out) the diagnosis of essential thrombocythemia. LDH and beta-2-microglobulin
column35: as well as the rest of the biochemical parameters were in the normal range. Serology for HIV
column36: HBV and HCV were negative. Haemoglobin and leukocyte counts were normal
column37: with an unaltered leukocyte formula
column38: with only a thrombocytosis of 487
column39: 000/ul standing out. With the diagnosis of extranodal NK lymphoma nasal type in localised stage with reactive thrombocytosis
column40: the patient immediately started treatment with polychemotherapy followed by sequential radiotherapy
column41: deciding to carry out an autologous bone marrow transplant as the first line of treatment.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 34-year-old patient consulted for penile deformity secondary to repeated thickening treatment. He reports that in the space of 8 months he underwent 3 sessions of fat transfer carried out in his country by a specialised professional. Four months after the last infiltration
column2: he began to experience spontaneous pain that increased during erection
column3: making it impossible for him to have sexual intercourse.  On physical examination
column4: the penis had an exaggerated horizontal dimension (girth)
column5: with visible irregularities that could be seen on palpation and were painful. Soft
column6: mobile tumours between 1 and 3 cm in diameter are palpated. The clinical examination and the patient's history of fat inclusion provide us with an indication of the diagnosis and aetiology of the problem. As a complementary study we requested a radioisotopic lymphography to rule out possible lymphoedema. The report tells us that the lymphatic vessels and regional lymph nodes are intact (10
column7: 11). Surgical treatment We plan to remove the tumours causing the deformity. In a surgical environment and under general anaesthesia
column8: we place a Foley catheter no. 16 in order to control by touch the course of the urethra and therefore also the corpus spongiosum that houses it. We incised the penis in its ventral midline and proceeded to dissect and remove each of the tumours that could be identified
column9: taking care not to damage the noble structures of the penis. Once complete resection of the tumours has been achieved
column10: careful haemostasis is carried out and the incision is closed in planes
column11: taking into account the different layers of the penile integument. Drainage is left in place. At the end of the operation
column12: the changes achieved are already visible.  The pathological examination revealed that the lesions were made up of fat globules and that some of them showed foci of cytosteatonecrosis.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A girl aged three years and ten months was seen for recurrent episodes of muscle weakness in the lower limbs
column2: which recovered spontaneously within minutes. Personal history of no interest. Controlled pregnancy without incident; vaginal birth. Artificial lactation. Normal perinatal and psychomotor development. No muscle weakness or cramps reported up to six months previously. Family history included hyperkalemic paralysis in several relatives on the paternal side (father
column3: paternal uncle and aunt
column4: paternal grandmother) without providing further details and without being able to specify the genetic study. The clinical picture began about six months before coming to the clinic
column5: being previously asymptomatic; they reported 3-4 intermittent episodes
column6: on separate days
column7: of muscle cramps and a feeling of numbness in the lower limbs while sleeping
column8: from which she recovered spontaneously in a few minutes. She showed no other clinical manifestations or involvement of other limbs. Since these episodes the patient remained asymptomatic. Clinical and neurological examination was normal at the time of examination
column9: with normal strength
column10: sensitivity and osteotendinous reflexes. In view of the suspicion of familial hyperkalemic paralysis
column11: an analytical study was requested with a haemogram and biochemistry
column12: which were normal. Blood count was normal
column13: electrolytes in blood and urine normal
column14: K 4.5 mEq/l with fractional potassium excretion (FEK) of 13%. It was not possible to perform blood tests coinciding with the clinical presentation. Electromyography (EMG)
column15: creatine phosphokinase (CPK) and electrocardiogram (ECG) could not be performed at the same time as the clinical examination
column16: as the patient had no new symptoms. The electromyography (EMG)
column17: without coinciding with the clinical picture
column18: was normal. In view of the clinical suspicion
column19: given the family history
column20: despite the fact that the clinical manifestations were not very evident
column21: a genetic study of the SCN4A gene (OMIM +603967) was requested
column22: detecting a heterozygous p.Thr704Met mutation. At the time of diagnosis
column23: treatment with oral acetazolamide was not started as the episodes of muscle weakness have not recurred and serum potassium values were normal in the controls performed. Periodic clinical and analytical controls will be carried out to assess whether
column24: at some point
column25: medical treatment is required. A diet not rich in potassium was prescribed.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 59-year-old man who consulted for intellectual deficit
column2: convulsions
column3: bradypsychia
column4: disorientation and stupor in the previous days. CT scan without contrast showed a peripheral left frontal lesion of 3.5 cm in diameter
column5: with a broad base and mass effect
column6: accompanied by trans-subzyphoidal herniation
column7: collapse of the third ventricle and dilatation of the lateral ventricles. These findings were interpreted as the presence of a left frontal lobe menigioma and a resection was performed in December 2000. The pathological anatomy was reported as meningeal osteosarcoma (Macroscopy: 5.2x4.5 cm partially calcified mass. Microscopy: Well demarcated osteogenic tumour
column8: without parenchymal infiltration. Irregular bone trabeculae containing atypical areas
column9: well-differentiated areas with osteoclastic cells
column10: necrosis and haemorrhage). The 99mTecnetium scan was positive in the surgical field
column11: laboratory tests were normal and the body CT scan showed paralysis of the left hemidiaphragm and hydrothorax. Referred to our unit and having ruled out metastatic involvement
column12: the patient started an adjuvant QT programme
column13: but after a first cycle of cisplatin and adriamycin
column14: the MRI showed the persistence of a frontal meningeal neoplasm surrounded by a collection of blood
column15: with mass effect and ventricular collapse. A second resection with wide margins was performed and the pathologist reported in the specimen the persistence of an osteosarcoma of the dural meninx
column16: with infiltration of brain tissue and bone. An adjuvant QT regimen was scheduled with cyclophosphamide 600 mg/m2
column17: bleomycin 15 mg/m2 and actinomycin-D 0.6 mg/m2 (day 1/21 days) and weekly methotrexate
column18: which the patient discontinued of his own volition after the first cycle. For this reason
column19: adjuvant RT was administered from March to May 2000
column20: 50 + 14 Gy (5x2 Gy/weekly) of 60Cobalt. The patient continued to undergo check-ups until May 2003
column21: when a local relapse was discovered by MRI
column22: and he was sent to the neurosurgery department of the Carlos Haya Hospital in Malaga. On 11-05-2003
column23: referring intellectual deficit and urinary incontinence
column24: he underwent a new CMRI which showed an expansive frontoparietal process
column25: extending to the right frontal lobe and corpus callosum
column26: and a thoracic CT scan which showed multiple metastatic nodules in both lungs. Treatment with surgery
column27: QT and RT was ruled out
column28: and high-dose corticosteroids were administered
column29: achieving an initial improvement. However
column30: on August 30
column32: the patient came to the emergency room of our centre
column33: presenting severe deterioration of consciousness
column34: with a Karnoffsky index of 30%
column35: dyspnoea and thrombosis of the left femoral system
column36: with multiple pulmonary metastases seen in the chest X-ray. Once stabilisation was achieved
column37: active oncological treatment was ruled out and the patient was referred to our Palliative Care Unit.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 75-year-old woman with a history of obstructive pulmonary disease
column2: hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. She consulted our department due to the incidental ultrasound finding of a renal lesion. Ultrasound: complex cystic lesion
column3: multiseptate
column4: with polylobulated contours
column5: 11 cm in diameter and with peripheral punctate calcifications
column6: occupying almost the entire kidney. Abdominal-pelvic CT scan: left renal lesion 11 x 7 cm in diameter
column7: multiseptate and with punctate calcifications. Absence of retroperitoneal adenopathy.  A differential diagnosis was made between cystic multilocular nephroma
column8: as a first option
column9: and cystic renal cell carcinoma. We performed an isotopic renogram with Tc-99m. Left kidney with lower uptake and functionalism
column10: with a cold central image that could correspond to an occupying lesion. I.R. function: 25%. Bone scintigraphy: No alterations. With the diagnosis of Bosniak III renal lesion
column11: surgical intervention was decided and a nephrectomy was performed. Pathology report: multilocular cystic nephroma
column12: without atypia. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 29-year-old woman diagnosed with multiple cavernomas in 1996
column2: the year in which she underwent surgery following a frontal haemorrhage of a right frontal cavernous angioma
column3: with evacuation of the haematoma and resection of the vascular lesion. In the same year
column4: a small left protuberancial angioma of 3 mm in diameter was detected. The patient remained asymptomatic until January 2004
column5: when she was admitted for headache and vomiting associated with haemihypoaesthesia with paraesthesia of the right hemibody and right hemiparesis 4/5. Examination revealed a vertical nystagmus
column6: right hemiparesis 4/5 and right hemihypoaesthesia with sensory extinction. The cranial CT scan performed on admission showed a right posterior protruberancial haematoma of 20 mm in diameter
column7: related to the known location of the cavernoma.  Brain MRI confirmed the presence of a protuberancial cavernous angioma with the presence of perilesional haemosiderin defining the growth and bleeding of the lesion
column8: which deformed the IV ventricle in the rhomboid fossa at the level of the left facial colliculus without emerging into the ventricle or any other part of the surface of the brainstem.  Given the clinical and radiological progression of the lesion
column9: it was decided to intervene surgically
column10: using intraoperative monitoring consisting of stimulation of the surface of the rhomboid fossa
column11: to determine the location of the nuclei of the left cranial nerves VII X and XII. Intraoperative auditory potentials were also performed. To stimulate the nuclei located in the rhomboid fossa
column12: we used the NIM-Response® System (Medtronic
column13: XOMED) nerve monitoring system
column14: applying a monopolar stimulus at constant voltage with a rectangular monophasic pulse. The maximum intensity applied was 2 mA. The stimulus duration was 100 µseconds and the frequency was 10 Hz. Electromyographic reading was performed with electrodes placed 5 mm apart in a bipolar arrangement to cover the representative muscle area. Electrodes to monitor the facial nerve were placed on the orbicularis oculi muscles of the mouth and eye. To record the cranial nerve XII the electrodes were placed on the genioglossus muscle. The recording of the Xth pair was performed with vocal cord sensors located in the anaesthesia tube. The patient was placed in prone position and a suboccipital craniectomy and excision of the posterior arch of C1 was performed. After dural and arachnoid opening and under microscopic control
column15: asymmetry was observed at the level of the left facial colliculus. After anatomical identification of nuclei X and XII
column16: their functionality was confirmed by intraoperative stimulation with positive electromyographic response. The facial nucleus was located only by stimulation and was found to be very lateral
column17: on the border between the angle of the rhomboid fossa and the middle cerebellar peduncle. The nucleus was probably displaced laterally due to the mass effect of the haematoma
column18: which was not visible on the surface. A pial incision was made
column19: the haematoma was located and evacuated
column20: as well as the cavernoma causing the haematoma. At the end of the resection
column21: the monitoring of the nuclei involved was repeated
column22: obtaining electromyographic response in all of them
column23: although the intensity of the facial
column24: especially of the orbicularis oris of the lips
column25: had decreased. The auditory potentials were maintained with the same response as in the preoperative period. Postoperatively
column26: the patient presented transient X and XII paresis
column27: which recovered completely after 48 hours and which we suspect was due to the block produced by the repeated electrical stimulus. She also presented an internuclear ophthalmoplegia with one-and-a-half syndrome
column28: which has partially recovered
column29: with a persistent nuclear paresis of the left VI pair
column30: as well as a nuclear facial paresis which has progressively improved. No motor deficits were observed in the long pathways
column31: although he is unstable when walking
column32: although he can ambulate unaided
column33: autonomously. The level of consciousness is good
column34: with preserved higher cognitive functions.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 10-year-old boy with no past history of interest
column2: with bilateral gonalgia
column3: back pain and low back pain after a fall from a bicycle 4 days ago. On examination he had preserved active and passive mobility with pain in both lower limbs (MMII). There were no signs of fractures or neurological alterations. Rest
column4: local cold and anti-inflammatory treatment was prescribed. After 48 hours
column5: the patient returned for persistent pain
column6: loss of strength
column7: paresthesia in the lower limbs
column8: difficulty in standing and walking and urinary incontinence. Physical examination revealed a decrease in strength and altered sensation in both LMMII. Suspecting transverse myelitis
column9: the patient was referred to the hospital emergency department. On admission
column10: blood tests were normal
column11: the cerebrospinal fluid study revealed moderate pleocytosis
column12: without the presence of oligoclonal IgG bands; the electroencephalogram showed no alterations and the evoked potentials showed paralysis and spasticity of MMII
column13: hyporeflexia and bilateral Babinsky
column14: absence of abdominal and cremasteric reflexes
column15: hyperalgesia and dysaesthesia of the trunk and MMII. Electromyogram revealed impaired medullary somatosensory sensation through the posterior cords
column16: with no conduction through the right cord and partial impairment of the left cord. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain was normal
column17: however
column18: spinal MRI showed an expansive lesion at spinal cord level from D1 to D6 compatible with transverse myelitis.  Twenty-four hours after admission
column19: the patient presented intense pain in the right eye with sudden loss of visual acuity. He was assessed by ophthalmology and a diagnosis of right optic neuritis was made. In view of the presence of transverse myelitis and optic neuritis
column20: with brain MRI that did not meet multiple sclerosis criteria and spinal MRI showing a lesion of three or more spinal segments (D1 to D6)
column21: an anti-acuoporin-4 antibody test was performed
column22: which was negative. Based on the clinical manifestations
column23: evolution and despite the negative antibody
column24: the patient was diagnosed with neuromyelitis optica or Devic's disease (see diagnostic criteria table 1).  The patient was initially treated with intravenous methylprednisolone at a dose of 1 g/day without improvement
column25: so plasmapheresis was performed with good clinical evolution. The patient was followed up by neurology
column26: ophthalmology and urology with progressive improvement and progressive decrease of corticotherapy. Fourteen months later
column27: the patient presented complete recovery of strength and sensitivity of the lower limbs
column28: normal gait
column29: normal reflexes
column30: absence of spasticity
column31: ataxia or dysmetria; occasionally he presented painful lumbar hyperaesthesia of a self-limited nature. In the right eye
column32: he maintained blurred near vision
column33: with attenuation of colour perception
column34: although he managed to recover 70% of visual acuity. Nocturnal enuresis persists due to bladder spasticity
column35: which continues to be treated with desmopressin.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O

column1: 36-year-old patient admitted for cerebral haemorrhage
column2: open to the ventricles. Neurosurgical evacuation was ruled out. Initial ICP was higher than 20mmHg; sedoanalgesia
column3: relaxation and osmotics were started. At 72h she started progressive respiratory deterioration
column4: attributed to neurogenic pulmonary oedema. After 48h with FiO2 of 1
column5: PD was tried on the eighth day of admission. There was no significant respiratory improvement and the ICP rose to 20mmHg. After 12h
column6: the patient was switched back to SD. After a further 12 hours
column7: respiratory improvement began
column8: which allowed a decrease in FiO2 to be initiated. On the twelfth day
column9: coinciding with a transfer to the CT room
column10: ICP monitoring was lost and a new sensor was placed
column11: which gave values below 20mmHg with a CPP above 65mmHg
column12: which remained similar on the following days. Two days later
column13: respiratory deterioration resumed. He was placed early on PD
column14: which allowed a decrease in FiO2 in 3h. After 12h on PD
column15: he was placed on SD and continued to improve. No deterioration in ICP or CPP was observed. Subsequent evolution was favourable until recovery of a normal level of consciousness
column16: with left hemiparesis.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Patient 3 years old (94 cm
column2: 10 kg)
column3: girl
column4: Afghan
column5: with signs of malnutrition
column6: who presented with second degree burns in the anterior and posterior region of the right thigh
column7: right flank and mesogastrium (25% of the body surface burned) secondary to an explosion 4 days ago. Topical treatment was applied but proved ineffective. Due to the torpid evolution of the lesion
column8: local mechanical debridement and application of argentic sulphadiazine and Tulgrasum® healing dressing impregnated with antibiotic (bacitracin-zinc
column9: neomycin
column10: polymyxin B sulphate) was decided. To allow the procedure to proceed
column11: midazolam (1 mg i.m.) was administered beforehand and ketamine (60 mg i.m.) after 5 minutes. Analgesia (grade 0 on the verbal pain scale) and sedation was achieved after 10 minutes (score 4 on the Ramsay scale)
column12: allowing the procedure to be performed without incident for 22 minutes. The patient recovered sensation and wakefulness 120 minutes after treatment. The degree of amnesia of the surgical procedure assessed by the Korttila and Linnolia scale was total.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 52-year-old woman with erosive seropositive RA
column2: high titres of rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies (anti-CCP) for 12 years
column3: with secondary failure to infliximab and adalimumab. He presented with red eye
column4: pain and photophobia. Examination: peripheral corneal infiltrate in crescents associated with scleritis. Negative culture of the corneal scraping. We started treatment with prednisone 1mg/kg/day orally and decided to change the therapeutic target to rituximab at the usual dose in RA with methotrexate 25mg/week. After the first cycle of rituximab the patient experienced great improvement with cure of the QUP and went into clinical remission of RA. After 10 months
column5: a corneal infiltrate and mild scleritis reappeared
column6: as well as the onset of joint symptoms. We decided to continue treatment with i.v. rituximab every 8 months with good clinical control of both ocular and systemic symptoms.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 49-year-old female patient (weight: 60 kilos; height: 1.63 metres) consulted the emergency department for 5 days of left lumbar pain
column2: burning and electric type
column3: intensity 10/10 on a verbal analogue scale. The pain is episodic
column4: exacerbated by movement and does not improve with the administration of tramadol and diclofenac. Physical examination revealed erythematous
column5: vesicular lesions with dermatomatous distribution on the skin of the lumbar region and left buttock. The rest of the physical examination was normal. She has a history of lumbar disc disease
column6: arterial hypertension and hypothyroidism under medical treatment. The patient denies any history of renal disease. The patient was assessed by the infectious diseases department
column7: who considered it to be a case of herpetic neuritis and decided to hospitalise the patient due to the severity of the symptoms. During the first day and prior to the hydration protocol (500 ml of 0.9% saline solution)
column8: an infusion of intravenous acyclovir 10 mg/kg every 8 hours (600 mg) was started. Consultation with the pain clinic was requested
column9: who started an analgesic programme with acetaminophen + codeine (500 + 30 mg orally every 6 h)
column10: morphine in case of severe pain (2 mg per dose) and pregabalin (150 mg/12 h). The patient initially presented adequate analgesia with no side effects
column11: rating her pain at 4/10. On the second day of hospitalisation she presented dizziness
column12: nausea
column13: emesis
column14: somnolence and dysarthria. The symptoms were considered to be a side effect of the analgesics and it was decided to discontinue the acetaminophen with codeine and pregabalin. Morphine doses of 2 mg were prescribed in case of severe pain after assessment of consciousness. On the third day of hospitalisation
column15: without receiving any opioid dose
column16: the patient persisted with deterioration of her general condition
column17: with progression to stupor
column18: tachypnoea
column19: desaturation and respiratory distress. She was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit. The picture is compatible with acute pulmonary oedema and renal failure with serum potassium at 5.7 mEq/L
column20: BUN 50 mg/dl (admission value of 17.2)
column21: creatinine 5.01 mg/dl (admission value of 0.66) and arterial blood gases with metabolic acidosis. Nephrology confirmed the diagnosis of acute renal failure secondary to administration of acyclovir
column22: with the need for haemodialysis. The patient required a single session of haemodialysis with improvement in azo levels. Analgesic management continued with acetaminophen 500 mg and codeine 30 mg; the patient did not require new doses of morphine. She was discharged on the sixth day of hospitalisation with controlled pain and normal renal function tests.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 9-year-old girl
column2: with no history of pathology of interest
column3: presented with a pruritic rash
column4: with small papulo-erythematous lesions that in some areas became confluent
column5: affecting the palms and soles of the feet. There was no enanthema and the patient was afebrile. As a history
column6: the patient had been taking amoxicillin for 9 days due to LII pneumonia diagnosed at the referral hospital. The differential diagnosis initially included: Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection
column7: viral exanthema (probably infectious mononucleosis)
column8: drug allergy to amoxicillin and toxicoderma. In view of the patient's clinical picture
column9: it was decided to discontinue antibiotic treatment
column10: an antihistamine was prescribed to calm the itching and a blood test was requested. The results of the first analysis were: ESR 31; Hb 14.1 g/dl; Ht 41; leukocytes 8
column12: 000; GOT 91 U/L; GPT 220 U/L; ferritin 445; IgE 25.13 U/L; RAST to amoxicillin negative; serology for Mycoplasma pneumoniae IgG and IgM negative. After this first analysis
column13: the possible viral aetiology
column14: probably a mononucleosis syndrome
column15: became stronger
column16: and after 2 weeks a control analysis was carried out with the following results: GOT 130 U/L; GPT 363 U/L; GGT 310 U/L; alkaline phosphatase 352 U/L; ESR 8; ferritin 138; Paul Bunnell negative; hepatitis A
column17: B and C serology negative; toxoplasma serology IgG and IgM negative; CMV serology IgG positive and IgM negative; EBV serology IgG positive and IgM negative. At this point it was decided to repeat the analysis after one month
column18: extending the study and ruling out the most frequent causes of transaminitis. The results were: GOT 228 U/L; GPT 483U/L; GGT 257U/L; CPK 87 U/L; alpha-1-antitrypsin 147 mg/dl; ceruloplasmin 3.23 mg/dl (22-58); plasma copper 43 mcg/dl (80-160); antinuclear antibodies
column19: anti-DNA
column20: anti-LKM negative; IgA antitransglutaminase negative; alpha-fetoprotein negative; brucella serology negative
column21: parvovirus B19 serology negative. After this analysis
column22: the suspicion was centred on Wilson's disease. To complete the study
column23: copper in urine was requested
column24: with a result of 170 mcg/24 h (normal: 0-60) and a liver ultrasound scan showed mild steatosis. With suspicion of Wilson's disease
column25: he was sent to the paediatric hepatology unit of the referral hospital where they confirmed the diagnosis and started treatment with D-penicillamine.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O

column1: A 35 year old patient with skin phototype I according to the Fitzpatrick classification presented to the Plastic Surgery Department of our hospital with a clinical history of fibrocystic mastopathy
column2: intracanalicular papillomatosis and cancerophobia due to a family history of breast neoplasia. Mammography showed well-distributed micronodular tissue that was classified as a BIRADS 3 mammographic pattern. Nevertheless
column3: she was admitted for prophylactic breast cancer surgery. At the time of surgery she had no palpable axillary lymph nodes.  We performed a bilateral skin-sparing mastectomy
column4: with the intraoperative finding of a left axillary lymphadenopathy
column5: close to the subcutaneous tissue
column6: black in colour. Given the possibility of the intraoperative discovery of a melanoma metastasis
column7: we decided to refer the sample for deferred anatomopathological study. No other clinical signs suggestive of tumour pathology were found
column8: so the surgery was completed with bilateral placement of breast prostheses.  An exhaustive examination of the patient during postoperative admission revealed no skin lesions compatible with melanoma
column9: but did reveal the presence of a 10-year-old tattoo in the left pectoral region. The patient was discharged from hospital pending the results of the anatomical pathology study.  The deferred histological study of the surgical specimen described the adenopathy as a purplish-coloured
