column10: bilobed fragment measuring 1.6 x 1.3 x 0.5 cm
column11: with a purplish tinge. Microscopy showed reactive lymphoid hyperplasia. The structure of the lymph node was preserved
column12: without the presence of melanocytic cells and with a deposit of a dark granular artificial pigment.  Once again in the consultation room
column13: the clinical examination together with the histological study of the lesion made it possible to attribute the cause of the clinical changes of the lymphadenopathy to the patient's tattooing
column14: with the consequent result of a benign prognosis and without the need for further treatment or follow-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 46-year-old woman was admitted to hospital in March 2005 for a painful mass in the outer third of the left upper eyelid of 6 months' duration
column2: accompanied by a decrease in ipsilateral visual acuity (VA). The patient reported the development of a similar mass 15 years prior to her admission
column3: which was successfully managed with unspecified medical treatment. The rest of the history was not relevant to the current condition. Ophthalmological examination revealed a VA of 0.7 in the right eye (OD) and 0.2 in the left eye (OI). In the outer third of the left upper eyelid there was a 4 ¥ 3.5 cm painful mass accompanied by ptosis
column4: inferior displacement of the eyeball on the same side. There was a limitation to levosupraversion of the left eye. Exophthalmometry with base 100 was 17 mm for both eyes. The palpebral aperture was 10 mm in the OD and 4 mm in the OI. Left levator muscle function was limited. A CT scan of both orbits with axial and coronal slices was requested and showed a cystic looking temporal mass with bony destruction
column5: invading the orbit and displacing the left eyeball downwards
column6: apparently dependent on the frontal sinus. An aspiration of the mass was performed
column7: from which a dense yellowish liquid was obtained. A smear of the contents showed few Gram-positive cocci in pairs and chains
column8: accompanied by numerous polymorphonuclear leukocytes and abundant mucus. Treatment with oral ampicillin
column9: dicloxacillin and naproxen and topical sulfacetamide was started. The patient underwent drainage of the paranasal sinus contents with removal of the sinus wall. Microscopically
column10: haematoxylin and eosin stained slides demonstrated fragments lined by respiratory-type epithelium. Below the epithelium
column11: the wall consisted of a dense connective tissue stroma with areas of haemorrhage mixed with variable clusters of inflammatory infiltrate consisting of mature lymphocytes
column12: plasma cells
column13: polymorphonuclear leukocytes and numerous eosinophils. The diagnosis of frontal sinus mucocele was established. The presence of large numbers of eosinophils as part of the inflammatory infiltrate suggested a probable allergic or hypersensitivity etiology.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 35-year-old man diagnosed with HLA B27-positive ankylosing spondylitis in 2011. An abdominal ultrasound showed multiple hepatic and renal cysts. Right kidney 18cm and left kidney 19cm. In the absence of a family history of cystic disease
column2: a diagnosis of polycystic disease due to de novo mutation was made. In March 2011 she started treatment with adalimumab (Humira®) 40mg every 15 days. At that time he presented: haemoglobin (Hb) 12.4g/dl
column3: creatinine (Cr) 2.3mg/dl
column4: estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) MDRD (Modification of Diet in Renal Disease) 34ml/min/1.73m2
column5: proteinuria of 10mg/dl. In September 2011: Cr 3.24mg/dl
column6: eGFR MDRD 23ml/min/1.73m2
column7: proteinuria 1.78g/24h. Treatment was discontinued in January 2012 due to the development of polyneuropathy and purpura. In February 2012 a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan showed 18cm right kidney (volume 2450ml) and 18cm left kidney (2250ml). In April 2012 Golimumab (Simponi®) 50mg every five weeks is started. Six doses were administered and discontinued in September 2012
column8: when the patient reported a marked increase in abdominal diameter and umbilical hernia directly related to the administration of the drug. A final dose was administered in December 2012. In March 2013

column1: A 26-year-old woman
column2: with no family history of breast cancer and a personal history of resection of fibroadenoma in the right breast 4 months before coming to our department. With this sole history
column3: bilateral subcutaneous mastectomy was proposed to her as "preventive treatment" for possible cancer. The patient had not been sufficiently informed about the repercussions of this procedure. She did not undergo complementary ultrasound or mammography studies
column4: nor BRCA 1 or 2 genetic studies. Two months after removal of the fibroadenoma
column5: a bilateral subcutaneous mastectomy was performed in a private hospital by a medical oncologist in collaboration with a plastic surgeon. During the same operation
column6: 400 cc round
column7: textured
column8: subcutaneous
column9: saline solution breast implants were placed in the subcutaneous plane. When the stitches were removed
column10: she presented wound dehiscence in both breasts
column11: several secondary closures were performed without result
column12: and she also suffered from erythema
column13: increased temperature in both breasts and whitish material leaking from the wounds. In this situation she came to our department; 2 months had passed since the mastectomy. The patient reported that she had not requested such "large" implants
column14: as her breast volume after the operation was almost one cup larger than previously.  Oral antibiotic treatment was given for 48 hours and on the third day
column15: surgical lavage and removal of the implants with regularisation of the wound edges
column16: suturing and placement of closed-circuit drains that were maintained for 3 days. Three months later
column17: round
column18: textured
column19: 300 cc breast expanders with integrated valve were placed in the retromuscular plane. A final expansion of 320 cc was achieved and maintained for 18 months; although replacement of the expanders with prostheses was planned after 6 months
column20: the patient refused further surgery. During this time
column21: she began to experience stabbing pain in both breasts
column22: so she finally agreed to the removal of the expanders and the placement of 295 cc silicone gel implants
column23: round and textured
column24: through a periareolar approach; at this time
column25: the lower mammary poles were also freed
column26: the size of the nipple-areola complex was reduced and bilateral radial capsulotomy was performed.  Postoperatively
column27: antibiotic and anti-inflammatory treatment was administered; one month after surgery
column28: manual massage and ultrasound application was started and continued during the 2nd and 3rd month
column29: followed by Endermology during the 4th month. As the patient reported persistent stabbing pain
column30: Colchicine treatment was added for 5 months at a dose of 1 mg/day
column31: which was reduced to 0.5 mg/day due to intestinal intolerance. The following 4 months
column32: she was treated with Thalidomide at a dose of 50 mg/day. Eighteen months after implant placement
column33: the patient continued to report painful discomfort
column34: however
column35: clinically the breasts were soft and the ultrasound study showed no data suggestive of prosthetic rupture or the presence of capsular contracture.  After 3 years
column36: the patient presented frank capsular contracture and significant pain
column37: but did not accept further surgical treatment due to a change of residence to the interior of the country. One year later
column38: she returned requesting surgical treatment
column39: at which time we proceeded to remove the implants and perform breast reconstruction with bilateral pedicled TRAM. Microsurgical treatment had been proposed to reduce the morbidity of the abdominal wall by preserving more of the rectus abdominis muscle
column40: but the patient refused. No implants were used in the reconstruction and it was necessary to place a Marlex® mesh to cover the defect in the anterior abdominal wall once the two pedicled flaps had been raised.  We present images of the postoperative result 2.5 years after reconstruction
column41: 8 years after the initial mastectomy.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 68 year old male patient with a personal history of TUR of the prostate for benign prostatic hyperplasia in another centre
column2: whose pathological study revealed the presence of a Gleason 6 adenocarcinoma with PSA values within the normal range and who was subsequently treated with radiotherapy with radical intent and is currently in a disease-free interval. He consulted for pain in the right groin for more than 2 years
column3: which increased with standing and decreased with decubitus. Diagnosed with a direct right inguinal hernia
column4: he underwent an inguinal herniorrhaphy and correction of a concomitant right hydrocele. At the same time
column5: a mameloned fleshy tumour was observed attached to the upper pole of the testicle
column6: measuring 2 centimetres in diameter. Right radical orchiectomy via the inguinal route and excision of the spermatic cord above the internal inguinal ring was performed. There was no evidence of lymphadenopathy. The anatomopathological study revealed a leiomyosarcoma with positive immunohistochemistry for Actin and Vimentin and negative for Prostate Specific Antigen.  The extension study was normal. Complementary radiotherapy was considered. After 9 months he noted the appearance of an outgrowth lesion measuring 3 x 2.5 centimetres in the herniorrhaphy scar which was resected
column7: reporting a recurrence of leiomyosarcoma with increased mitotic activity. She did not receive adjuvant treatment. After 6 months he noticed the appearance of a new nodular lesion on the right flank with progressive increase in size. The C.A.T. showed a nodule that infiltrated the subcutaneous fat and the iliopsoas muscle in depth. The tumour was resected together with fibres of the lesser oblique
column8: transverse muscle and iliopsoas muscle. The pathology report is compatible with infiltration by leiomyosarcoma. At this point
column9: adjuvant therapy with adriamycin and ifosfamide for six cycles was proposed. After 12 months
column10: the patient underwent surgery again for local recurrence
column11: stony to the touch
column12: which trapped arterial and venous vessels in the groin area. The report concludes recurrence of high-grade leiomyosarcoma. column14: the patient presented an episode of haematuria
column15: which was confirmed by ultrasound scanning and confirmed by cystoscopy
column16: and showed the existence of an excrescent lesion in the right bladder wall measuring 3 centimetres. column1: This is a 68-year-old male referred from his outpatient clinic for bilateral obstructive uropathy
column2: in intravenous urography
column3: performed for the study of haematuria. His past history included dyslipidaemia
column4: benign prostatic hyperplasia
column5: acute myocardial infarction and non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. He reported three episodes of haematuria in December 2001
column6: August 2002 and January 2003
column7: self-limited
column8: asymptomatic and without clots. Physical examination showed the patient to be in good general condition
column9: with a globular
column10: soft
column11: depressible abdomen
column12: without masses or megaliths
column13: not painful on palpation. Rectal examination revealed a palpable prostate compatible with benign hyperplasia grade III/IV. Complementary analytical tests Blood count: parameters within normal limits. Blood biochemistry: glucose 145 mg/dl. The rest of the parameters were within the limits of normality. PSA 9.09 PSAl 1.43 index 15.73. Systematic urine study: pH6.5
column14: density 1
column16: negative for proteins
column17: ketone bodies
column18: bilirubin
column19: nitrites
column20: urobilinogen and leukocytes

column26: showing a repletion defect at the level of the pelvic ureter
column27: about 5 cm from the bladder.  Abdominal-pelvic CT scan: Moderate bilateral hydronephrosis (26 cm in the right renal pelvis and approximately 29 cm in the left
column28: in the transverse axis). In both distal ureters
column29: approximately 5 cm away from the urinary bladder
column30: intraureteral content is observed
column31: with soft tissue density
column32: suggestive of bilateral urothelioma
column33: occupying practically the entire lumen of the ureters
column34: although without totally occluding them
column35: and occupying an approximate length of 2 cm. The rest of the abdomino-pelvic structures showed no apparent alterations.  Pelvic MRI: Dilatation of the left kidney without being able to identify the exact cause of the stenosis. Treatment By means of a transperitoneal midline laparotomy

column37: revealing two intraureteral masses
column38: mobile
column39: approximately 2 cm in length
column40: with periureteral tissues of normal appearance. A bilateral longitudinal ureterotomy was performed
column41: revealing two papillary neoformations with a pedunculated implantation base
column42: and it was decided to remove them. Placement of pig-tail and closure of the urethrotomy. Pathological anatomy Macroscopic description: Irregular white-pinkish fragment measuring 3x2.5x1.2 cm on the left and 3x2.5x1.2 cm on the right. When cut
column43: a central axis can be seen in both. Microscopic description: The tumours in both ureters have a similar appearance. They correspond to papillary urothelial carcinoma
column44: of low cytological grade
column45: with connective-vascular axes lined by multiple rows of urothelium with slight pleomorphism and exceptional mitoses. Both have a centred muscle-vascular axis
column46: free of tumour infiltration
column47: although in some areas the tumour contacts the muscle apparently without underlying chorion. The resection base with signs of fulguration
column48: free. At the level of the left tumour
column49: there is papillary proliferation on one of its edges
column50: while the opposite one preserves urothelium without significant dysplasia. On the right side
column51: both edges appear to be free
column52: although in one of them there is a remaining papillary fulgurated tumour attached. Final diagnosis Papillary urothelial carcinoma G1 stage difficult to assess
column53: probably T1. Clinical course The patient was discharged after 14 days of hospitalisation

column55: which recovered after the application of conservative measures. She attended 10 days later for pig-tail removal without any complications. At his first check-up after surgery
column56: three months later

column1: An 82-year-old patient
column2: diagnosed after a study of normocytic-normochromic anaemia by colonoscopy of neoplasia of the right colon. Both the histological and cytological studies diagnosed MM. After an exhaustive extension study
column3: which included a thoracoabdominal CT scan
column4: abdominal ultrasound
column5: dermatological examination (including exeresis and study of two nevi that ruled out MM)
column6: fundus study and anorectal examination
column7: the patient underwent surgery and a right hemicolectomy. The anatomopathological study of the resection specimen confirmed the presence of a polypoid and ulcerated MM measuring 11 cm in diameter at the level of the ascending colon
column8: which invaded the submucosa and focally the muscular layer. Numerous tumour cells contained melanin and immunohistochemistry was positive for S-100 protein and HMB45. Of the 30 lymph nodes resected
column9: 2 had metastases. The patient followed a good postoperative course
column10: being alive with no evidence of disease 4

column1: A 67-year-old woman with a personal history of appendectomy
column2: herniated disc and hiatus hernia
column3: fracture of the tibia and fibula
column4: as well as right renal colic attended urology for a check-up. In the ultrasound study

column6: measuring approximately 5 cm
column7: with lobulated external borders
column8: which did not appear to affect the perirenal space
column9: with no adenopathy or dilatation of the renal excretory tract. With the diagnosis of probable hypernephroma
column10: a radical right nephrectomy was performed laparoscopically.  Macroscopic examination revealed a cortical neoformation with a maximum diameter of 5 cm
column11: well-defined but not encapsulated

column13: with a yellowish cut surface with areas of haemorrhagic appearance and cystic areas. Microscopically

column16: cytokeratin 7

column18: CD34

column1: Three and a half year old boy with severe neurological damage secondary to perinatal ischaemic acute cerebrovascular accident (CVA). He came to the clinic with his mother
column2: who reported unusual crying for some weeks and the suspicion that the child had pain in his hands. She also told us that the child had been receiving treatment with oral steroids for some weeks
column3: as during the follow-up of his neurological damage
column4: when consulting for locomotor system symptoms
column5: chronic idiopathic arthritis was suspected
column6: with normal X-rays of the hands and wrists. He is an only child of non-consanguineous parents. The father has had a bone problem in his wrists since childhood; he recalls having suffered pain in his wrists as a child and tells us that he has no wrist bones
column7: that he retains normal mobility and that this does not cause him any problems in his profession as a car driver. The physical examination of the child is conditioned by his neurological damage (he shouts
column8: without any other type of language and listens and attends when spoken to
column9: smiling when caressed); he is not capable of ambulation without assistance; a left hemiplegia derived from his perinatal stroke and the typical signs of spasticity. Somatometry shows a head circumference of 46 cm (< P3)
column10: a length of 104 cm (P25-50) and a weight of 16.5 kg (P50). Blood pressure values are normal (111/66 mmHg). There are no dysmorphic features. The child's repeated attempts to bite his right wrist are striking. There are no inflammatory signs and the child expresses himself with groans on repeated mobilisation of the right wrist. No other joints were found to be affected. The father is 180 cm tall
column11: but his wingspan is reduced to 164 cm. His hand is 18.7 cm long (shortened by 4 cm for his height) with a third finger of 8.3 cm (normal). The paternal radiograph shows bilateral absence of the carpus.  The child's X-ray shows carpal lesions compatible with carpal osteolysis and unilateral tarsal scaphoid lesions.  The genetics service was consulted and the diagnosis of multicentric carpotarsal osteolysis of autosomal dominant transmission without nephropathy was studied and confirmed.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 65-year-old male
column2: referred from Nephrology to the Vascular Surgery Department for presenting a voluminous pulsatile mass on the left forearm
column3: of several years' evolution
column4: with accelerated and progressive growth in recent months. Personal history of arterial hypertension
column5: dyslipidaemia
column6: left radiocephalic fistula for haemodialysis performed twenty years earlier due to terminal chronic renal failure
column7: and six years after being transplanted
column8: the fistula was ligated. On physical examination
column9: on the anterior aspect of the left forearm
column10: there was a huge pulsating tumour
column11: with no murmur or thrill. His hands were well perfused
column12: with radial and ulnar pulses present.  Firstly
column13: an echo-Doppler was performed
column14: which showed intense flow within the tumour
column15: without being able to define whether it was an aneurysm or a pseudoaneurysm
column16: an axial computed tomography angiography (angio-CT) was therefore requested
column17: showing an ectatic and elongated humeral artery
column18: and in the radial region an aneurysm or pseudoaneurysm of 62 millimetres in diameter
column19: with the ulnar and interosseous arteries permeable and the distal radial artery obstructed. With the diagnostic suspicion of aneurysm or pseudoaneurysm of the radial artery secondary to radiocephalic AVF ligated in a transplant patient
column20: surgical treatment was indicated. Through incisions at the level of the flexure of the arm and distally at the radial level
column21: the humeral
column22: radial and ulnar artery was dissected and controlled
column23: revealing a large true aneurysm along the entire course of the radial artery. Complete resection of the aneurysm was performed
column24: ligating the radial artery proximally and distally
column25: as it was found to be chronically thrombosed and the vascularisation of the hand was ensured by the ulnar and interosseous arteries.  The postoperative period was uneventful; on discharge he had humeral and ulnar pulses and good perfusion of the hand. Pathological anatomy confirmed that it was a true radial artery aneurysm. One year after treatment
column26: the patient is asymptomatic and without complications.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 82 year old man came to the Emergency Department for: dyspnoea
column2: increased expectoration and somnolence. Relevant personal history: hypertension
column3: diabetes mellitus
column4: paroxysmal atrial fibrillation
column5: Guillen-Barré syndrome and oropharyngeal epidermoid carcinoma T3N0M0 with associated paraneoplastic syndrome of inadequate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH)
column6: pending the start of radical radiotherapy. His usual treatment consists of acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg
column7: lorazepam 1 mg
column8: silidosin 8 mg and omeprazole 20 mg
column9: all taken once a day; (tolvaptan discontinued after the last admission). The patient was diagnosed with bilo-bar pneumonia due to bronchoaspiration associated with hypoosmolar hyponatraemia (sodium: 101 meq/L (normal range (R.N.) 135-145 meq/L)
column10: Osmolality 210 mOsm/kg (R.N. 280-300 mOsm/kg). He presented with severe dysphagia and bleeding associated with pharyngeal tumour
column11: planning gastrostomy and initiating parenteral nutrition via peripheral route
column12: empirical antibiotic treatment with meropenem 1000 mg/8 h and natraemia replacement by serum therapy (252 meq of sodium in 500 mL of 0.9% physiological saline solution every 12 hours); he had normal renal function (MDRD-4 IDMS: > 60 ml/min/1.73m2). On admission to Internal Medicine
column13: clinical and analytical improvement was observed (sodium: 130 meq/L)
column14: and the Nephrology Department assessed paraneoplastic SIADH with good response to natraemic replacement by means of serum therapy
column15: which was suspended. Treatment was restarted at low doses of tolvaptan to avoid overcorrection (7.5 mg/24 h) and subsequently increased to the usual dose of 15 mg/24 h. The patient presented with febrile syndrome without a clear focus
column16: and empirical treatment was started with cefepime 2000 mg/12 h
column17: vancomycin 1000 mg/12 h and oseltamivir 75 mg/12 h. Blood cultures were requested
column18: and the results were positive. Blood cultures were requested and were positive for methicillin-resistant Streptococcus epidermidis
column19: sensitive to vancomycin (MIC = 2 mg/L)
column20: so antibiotic treatment was maintained
column21: considering bacteraemia due to catheter
column22: which was withdrawn. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed
column23: ruling out endocarditis. Subsequent blood cultures were negative. Three days after starting treatment
column24: the dose of vancomycin was increased to 1250 mg/12 h due to persistent febrile peaks
column25: CRP: 9.6 mg/dL (R.N: 0.0-0.5 mg/dL) and procalcitonin: 4.01 mcg/L (R.N: 0.0-0.5 mcg/L). After two days
column26: new plasma concentrations were extracted and were still lower (8.4 μg/mL) (the possibility of error in the extraction of the sample or in the accuracy and precision of the measurement was assessed)
column27: so a pharmacokinetic study was performed to predict the dose by Bayesian estimation
column28: using the PKS® programme (Abbott Base Pharmacokinetic System
column29: Abbott Diagnostics)
column30: calculating a t1/2 of 6.4 h and increasing the dose to 1000 mg/8 h. Oral metronidazole 500 mg/8 h was added to the treatment due to persistent Clostridium difficile diarrhoea
column31: and two days later
column32: worsening renal function was observed due to digestive losses
column33: causing pre-renal failure with hyponatraemia (sodium: 115 meq/L)
column34: which preceded the elevation of creatinine levels to 2.46 mg/dL and elevation of pre-dose plasma concentrations of vancomycin to 43.1 μg/mL
column35: for which treatment was discontinued. Acute renal failure develops and creatinine values of 5.07 mg/dL are reached in the days following discontinuation of intravenous vancomycin treatment. Nine days after discontinuation
column36: elimination remains very slow
column37: with a t1/2 of 132 h and reaching a plasma concentration of 25.5 μg/mL. Concentrations below the therapeutic range are not reached until 15 days after discontinuation of antibiotic treatment. The Nephrology Department suspended enteral nutrition to avoid promoting diarrhoea
column38: and performed a new natraemic correction by suspending treatment with tolvaptan
column39: increasing serum therapy and forcing diuresis (approximately 3000 mL/day) to eliminate plasma vancomycin. Vancomycin was administered via gastrostomy due to persistent Clostridium difficile diarrhoea despite treatment with oral metronidazole. Subsequently
column40: the patient presented hypertension
column41: with very abundant diuresis and very positive free water producing hypernatraemia (sodium: 157 meq/L) despite suspension of tolvaptan
column42: so saline solutions were reduced to increase free water. He also presented metabolic acidosis
column43: which was corrected with bicarbonate
column44: and respiratory alkalosis
column45: and a chest X-ray was performed due to suspected left pleural effusion. Due to persistent high plasma concentrations of vancomycin and hypernatremia
column46: serum therapy was readjusted and desmopressin was added. Finally
column47: resolution of the bacteraemia associated with methicillin-resistant Streptococcus epidermidis
column48: normal haematological formula and afebrile after resolution of the vancomycin intoxication
column49: gradual resolution of the episode of diarrhoea
column50: recovery of renal function and natraemia
column51: reintroduction of enteral diet by gastrostomy and radiotherapy (36 sessions)
column52: discontinuation of metronidazole and oral vancomycin.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO column1: This is a 76-year-old woman who was admitted to the vascular surgery department for postphlebitic syndrome. During her stay on the ward she showed clinical deterioration and was transferred to the ICU on 10/5/03 with severe sepsis. His past history of interest included high blood pressure
column2: obesity
column3: arthrosis and resection of a tubular adenoma of the colon. In August 2000 he underwent cholecystectomy for lithiasic cholecystitis with significant subhepatic inflammatory plastron that required subtotal resection of the gallbladder. On admission
column4: he developed DVT of IBD with subsequent PTE and atrial fibrillation
column5: starting treatment with amiodarone and dicoumarin. During the last month he was in outpatient care due to non-specific digestive symptoms
column6: with elevated GGT and AF observed in analytical control. On examination in the ICU she was stuporous
column7: icteric and with arterial hypotension. O2 saturation was preserved with a mask. Cardiac auscultation rhythmic at 80 bpm
column8: without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation was normal. The abdomen was globular
column9: painful on palpation in the right hemiabdomen
column10: although without signs of peritoneal irritation and the IBD showed good evolution of its thrombosis. Laboratory tests showed leukocytosis (37
column11: 000/mm3) with neutrophilia
column12: urea 1.83 g/l
column13: creatinine 4.2 mg/dl total bilirubin 8.6 mg/dl
column14: with a direct fraction of 5.7 mg/dl
column15: AST 312 U/l
column16: ALT 106 U/l
column17: GGT 416 U/l. With the diagnosis of sepsis of biliary origin
column18: treatment was started with fluid therapy
column19: dopamine and empirical antibiotics with piperacillin/tazobactam
column20: obtaining a good initial response. Complementary tests performed: CT scan of the abdomen (11/5/03) showing multiple hypodense images in the hepatic parenchyma suggesting abscesses. Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiogram
column21: which confirmed the existence of endocarditis at the mitral subvalvular level leading to grade II insufficiency. Following this finding
column22: vancomycin and gentamicin were added to the antibiotic treatment. FNA of a liver lesion. ERCP did not show dilatation of the biliary tract
column23: although papillotomy was performed to ensure biliary drainage. Subsequent evolution was unfavourable with the establishment of refractory BMDS and exitus 96 hours after admission to the ICU. We requested a necropsy
column24: which revealed multicentric cholangiocarcinoma
column25: with multiple nodules throughout the organ
column26: local extension to the gallbladder bed and extrahepatic bile ducts
column27: regional metastases to lymph nodes in the hepatic hilum and distant metastases
column28: manifested by microscopic foci in the lung.  There was also extensive intratumoral necrosis with superinfection by Enterobacter cloacae
column29: also isolated in blood and FNA sample
column30: which leads us to suppose that it was the germ responsible for the septic picture.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 69-year-old woman came to the clinic with repeated respiratory infections. The patient reported no allergies or toxic habits
column2: she was hypertensive treated with amlodipine and presented hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine. She had undergone hysterectomy with double adnexectomy 20 years earlier. She reported a clinical history of 10 years of frequent respiratory infections
column3: predominantly in winter although also present in summer
column4: consisting of cough
column5: dyspnoea
column6: wheezing and purulent expectoration. He also reported orthopnoea. Physical examination revealed rhythmic cardiac auscultation
column7: without murmurs or extratonos and pulmonary auscultation with isolated rhonchi. Perimalleolar oedema was observed in the extremities. Spirometry was performed with the following result: FVC 67%; FEV1 56%; PEF 73%; FEV1/FVC 68%
column8: positive bronchodilator test. Lung gas diffusion is slightly reduced
column9: being 72.6% of the reference value. Chest X-ray showed kyphoscoliosis with no other abnormalities. The CT scan showed areas of emphysema and bronchiectasis in both bases
column10: more evident in the middle lobe. Blood tests showed only a deficit of AAT (30 mg/dl). Fibrobronchoscopy was performed with no significant findings. With these results
column11: an AAT phenotype was performed
column12: which showed the ZZ type. Diagnosed with asthma and D-AAT
column13: asthma treatment was started with significant improvement. Initially
column14: D-AAT replacement therapy was not carried out
column15: as she maintained acceptable lung function.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 39-year-old woman with a history of a diffuse normofunctioning goitre
column2: calcified uterine myoma
column3: normal menstrual periods
column4: an uneventful pregnancy and vaginal delivery
column5: who came to the emergency department for colicky abdominal pain together with abdominal distension and several liquid stools over 48 hours. The patient reported two similar episodes in the last year
column6: which resolved spontaneously within a few hours
column7: with no other accompanying symptoms. Physical examination showed good general condition
column8: with haemodynamic stability
column9: abdomen without scars
column10: distended and tympanised
column11: painful on palpation in the right hemiabdomen
column12: especially in the right lower quadrant
column13: with no signs of peritoneal irritation and no palpable masses or visceromegaly
column14: decreased peristalsis. The requested blood test showed discrete leukocytosis with a predominance of granulocytes and CRP 3.7mg/dl
column15: with the rest of the tests (glucose
column16: ions
column17: renal function
column18: liver enzymes
column19: amylase
column20: urine system
column21: etc.) being normal. An abdominal X-ray showed dilatation of the small intestine loops (ID)
column22: with hydro-aerial levels and absence of gas in the colon and rectal ampulla
column23: uterine calcifications suggestive of myoma. Abdominal ultrasound showed abundant gas and hyperperistalsis in the ID and minimal free fluid between the intestinal loops. The abdominal CT scan showed marked dilatation of the loops of the ID
column24: which respected the terminal ileum
column25: with a change in calibre in the preterminal ileum at the level of the FID
column26: a non-dilated colon with opacification with oral contrast
column27: accumulation of free fluid at the level of the pouch of Douglas
column28: and a myomatous uterus with lumpy calcifications.  Initially
column29: conservative treatment was applied with nasogastric tube
column30: fluid therapy and analgesia
column31: with no clinical or radiological improvement in the following hours
column32: so surgery was decided. The approach was performed via infraumbilical midline laparotomy
column33: revealing a moderate amount of free serous fluid
column34: dilation of the loops of ID and stenosing thickening in the terminal ileum
column35: about 10 cm from the ileocaecal valve
column36: with a tumour appearance
column37: retraction of the serosal surface and mesenteric lymphadenopathies. Pelvic examination revealed a myomatous uterus. Ileocaecal resection and mechanical latero-lateral anastomosis were performed
column38: as well as drainage of the fluid from the cul-de-sac of Douglas. Samples were sent to Anatomical Pathology for histological study
column39: and it was reported that abundant adhesions and fibrosis were observed in the wall of the terminal ileum and cecum. In depth
column40: islets and nests of endometrioid glandular epithelium and endometrial stroma were observed. Focally there is an increased inflammatory infiltrate and fibrosis. The intestinal wall shows hypertrophy of the muscle layers
column41: lymph nodes without histologically evident lesions. With the diagnosis of ileocecal endometriosis
column42: and after a favourable postoperative course without complications
column43: the patient was referred to the gynaecology and obstetrics department to assess the start of treatment with gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues and follow-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 57-year-old man
column2: with no medical history of interest
column3: presented with an asymptomatic tumour of nine years' evolution at the level of the left jugal mucosa
column4: coinciding with the edentulous area of the second upper molar. The lesion grew slowly and never ulcerated. Intraoral examination showed an exophytic mass of nodular appearance and well delimited
column5: 2 X 2 cm in diameter located in the middle third of the left jugal mucosa that included the caruncle of the mouth of the Stenon duct; the tumour had a pale pink colour and a firm consistency on palpation. After manipulating the left parotid gland to provoke saliva to flow out
column6: we found that the duct was permeable and the saliva was clean and fluid.  Treatment consisted of locating and cannulating the Stenon's duct through its caruncle
column7: using a paediatric intravenous catheter
column8: followed by biopsy-excision of the tumour mass with a cold scalpel
column9: respecting both the path of the duct and its drainage caruncle. We then left an active intraoral drain through the caruncle for one week and applied external pressure to the parotid gland every 48 hours.  Histopathological examination showed fibrosocolagenised tissue oriented in bundles in all planes of the space
column10: without atypia and lined by flat stratified epithelium
column11: compatible with fibrous hyperplasia.   One month after surgery
column12: the patient's upper jaw was rehabilitated with a removable metal-resin prosthesis. After one year of evolution
column13: there have been no recurrences and the drainage of the left parotid gland is normal.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 20-year-old female patient who came to the Faculty of Dentistry in Seville referred by her orthodontist. Given the inadequate position of the lower left canine (included in horizontal position)
column2: the temporary canine was used by the orthodontist during orthodontic treatment as a permanent tooth
column3: not considering it appropriate to rescue the permanent tooth. He informed the patient of the existence of the dental inclusion and the need for its extraction or at least its monitoring. In the radiological examination (orthopantomography) we found the inclusion of the lower left canine in a horizontal position under the apices of the contralateral lower premolars and canines (Mupparapu transmigration pattern 4 (8)). Given the evidence of transmigration of the canine
column4: we indicated its extraction. If we were to continue to monitor the case
column5: bringing the impacted tooth closer to the mentonian foramen would unnecessarily increase the risks of the intervention
column6: and would almost certainly result in clinical symptoms due to irritation of the lower dental nerve by the impacted tooth (9
column7: 10).  The extraction was performed through a partial Neuman incision
column8: with extraction at the level of the left lateral incisor. Discharge was not performed in the fourth quadrant due to the proximity of the mentonian foramen
column9: identifying and protecting the right mentonian nerve during the operation. The tooth was extracted by coronal osteotomy and double odontosection
column10: also eliminating the pericoronal sac.  Finally
column11: the wound was sutured and analgesic
column12: anti-inflammatory (Ibuprofen 600 mg
column13: 1 tablet / 8 hours for one week) and antibiotic (Amoxicillin 875 mg / Clavulanic acid 125 mg
column14: 1 tablet / 8 hours for one week) treatment was prescribed during the postoperative period
column15: which passed without incident. The stitches were removed after ten days. The evolution was favourable and no complications were detected.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The first case is a 25-year-old woman diagnosed with Laurence-Moon-Biell syndrome manifesting hypogonadism with obesity
column2: mental retardation
column3: polydactyly
column4: retinitis pigmentosa and renal failure. He started HD treatment at the age of 11
column5: received his first renal transplant the following year
column6: which failed due to venous thrombosis
column7: so he returned to HD and required transplantectomy 9 months later. Due to vascular access difficulties
column8: she needed to be referred to PD. During her evolution
column9: the patient suffered several episodes of peritonitis and severe hyperparathyroidism. Her peritoneal membrane was classified as medium-high transporter. After 12 years on PD
column10: the patient showed a poor general condition and peritonitis
column11: caused by two germs (Staphylococcus epidermidis and Pseudomonas aeruginosa)
column12: together with staphylococcal tunnel infection. The examination revealed a "mass effect" in the area of the subcutaneous tunnel
column13: non-fluctuant
column14: without inflammatory signs
column15: of hard consistency and mamelon-shaped contour
column16: producing a peritoneal eventration at the catheter orifice. Radiological imaging showed sclerosis and calcification of the entire peritoneal membrane
column17: compressing all abdominal visceral structures. Specific antibiotic treatment was administered
column18: the PD catheter was removed
column19: and the patient was transferred to HD. Later
column20: the patient had difficulty in swallowing due to vomiting. Once on HD
column21: she developed two new episodes of ascites
column22: secondary to peritonitis due to Echerichia coli
column23: which required evacuation by paracentesis. Subsequently
column24: he presented acute ischaemia in the right lower limb
column25: due to femoropopliteal obstruction.  Surgical treatment of the peritoneal calcification and amputation of the ischaemic limb were ruled out. The evolution was unsatisfactory and he died shortly afterwards.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 41-year-old male
column2: with a personal history of treated pulmonary tuberculosis
column3: with no other personal history of interest except moderate alcoholic drinker. He was referred to our centre due to a gradual increase in abdominal circumference since the previous month
column4: together with oedema in the lower limbs. No other accompanying symptoms. Laboratory tests showed altered coagulation (prothrombin time 43%)
column5: creatinine 0.58 mg/dl
column6: cholesterol 77 mg/dl
column7: albumin 1
column8: 610 mg/dl. An abdominal ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis of hepatic steatosis and portal hypertension
column9: together with collateral circulation and ascites
column10: all probably related to excessive consumption of alcoholic beverages (virological study for hepatitis was negative). Gastroscopy revealed grade III oesophageal varices
column11: a small hiatus hernia and gastropathy secondary to portal hypertension. Given the clinical and analytical findings
column12: protein-losing disease was suspected
column13: so A1AT clearance was performed and was 45 ml/day (> 24 ml/day) [A1AT in blood: 190 mg/dl; A1AT in stool: 0.38 mg/g; stool weight in 24h: 225 g]
column14: and he was diagnosed with the same
column15: in relation to his portal hypertension. He was treated with alcohol abstinence
column16: oral hyperproteic nutritional supplements and diuretics
column17: improving clinically and analytically
column18: and was discharged for outpatient follow-up at his reference centre.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 39-year-old man was referred to our Echoendoscopy Unit to determine the nature of a submucosal lesion located on the gastric side of the oesophago-gastric junction. The patient began his medical examination in the Otorhinolaryngology Department
column2: where he consulted for pharyngeal discomfort. After the examinations carried out by this department
column3: it was decided to perform an upper endoscopy
column4: where a rounded lesion with preserved mucosa of approximately 1.5 cm in diameter was found at 36 cm from the dental arch. Endoscopic biopsies were taken and the histological results were inconclusive. In the presence of a submucosal lesion
column5: the nature of which could not be identified by endoscopic imaging or after histological study of the biopsies
column6: the patient was referred to our centre for endoscopic ultrasound examination (EUS). EUS is performed on an outpatient basis
column7: under vital signs monitoring and conscious sedation based on midazolam and pethidine. A Pentax EG3830UX linear echoendoscope coupled to a Hitachi 8500 ultrasound machine was used. At 36 cm from the dental arch
column8: a small
column9: well-defined
column10: anechoic lesion with a cystic appearance was identified
column11: which appeared to be submucosally dependent
column12: measuring 14 x 6 mm in maximum diameter. The ultrasonographic study did not identify the presence of abdominal or mediastinal adenopathies and demonstrated the integrity of the vascular axis. Once the lesion to be punctured has been identified
column13: a colour Doppler ultrasound study is performed to avoid vascular formations and to identify the most suitable route for the puncture. The Echotip Wilson-Cook 19 G needle is used for the puncture. First
column14: the needle sheath is extracted a few centimetres through the working channel until it is visualised either gastroscopically or echoendoscopically; the lesion is then punctured using the needle located inside the sheath. Once its position inside the lesion has been verified
column15: the stylet is removed (which is used to prevent possible contamination of the sample) and the needle is advanced in order to extract as much material as possible from the lesion. In our case we have used an aspiration syringe to increase the cellularity of the sample. Two passes are made over the lesion until the pathologist
column16: present in the examination room
column17: confirms the sufficiency of the sample.  The Diff-Quick stain (Merck) is used to evaluate the sample in the examination room and the cytological study is completed with the Papanicolau stain (Merck). The cytological examination revealed abundant foamy histiocytes and scant cylindrical epithelium indicative of a benign cyst compatible with a gastric duplication cyst.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 45-year-old man who came to the emergency department with a sudden decrease in vision in his left eye. As recent history
column2: the patient had suffered an episode of influenza a few days earlier. A complete ophthalmological examination was performed
column3: which determined a visual acuity of unity in the right eye
column4: the examination data being compatible with normality
column5: including the fundus. The examination of the left eye
column6: however
column7: showed a visual acuity of 0.800 and the fundus showed lesions in the macular and central foveolar area with a rounded orange appearance. Given the history of influenza and the patient's clinical picture
column8: treatment with NSAIDs (ibuprofen 600 mg/12 hours) was prescribed and a FFA and EOG were requested.  The EOG showed a slight alteration in the left eye
column9: being compatible with normality in the right eye. FFA in the right eye was compatible with normality
column10: but in the left eye there were hyperfluorescent areas with a central hypofluorescent spot
column11: without contrast diffusion at late times.  Complementary tests confirmed the diagnosis of suspected ARD and
column12: given that the evolution of the disease was likely to resolve spontaneously
column13: treatment with NSAIDs was suspended. The patient evolved favourably
column14: recovering unit vision in his left eye between the 3rd and 4th week after the onset of the clinical picture.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 58-year-old woman. Calcific calcific lithiasis of the left kidney. Personal history: severe hypertension difficult to control
column2: as on a previous occasion Leoch had to be suspended until the blood pressure figures were stabilised with study and treatment by the Nephrology Department. Moderate obesity. First Leoch. Number and intensity of waves: 4
column3: 500 to 4. Clinical: Admitted two days after Leoch of the left kidney with left lumboabdominal pain and hypovolemic shock with Hb of 7 and Hto 24. Four units of red blood cell concentrate were transfused over the days of admission to stabilise the Hb between 9 and 9.5. CT scan showed the existence of a subcapsular haematoma with lithiasic fragments and pleural effusion on the left.  In IVUS a few days later
column4: there was functional delay of the left kidney and poor visualisation of the calyces and infundibula due to compression of the same with normal ureter.  Thoracentesis was performed with evacuation of 200 cc of haematic fluid. Twelve days after the haematoma
column5: it was drained by lumbotomy; four days later she was discharged in good general condition. Subsequent radiological and analytical controls confirmed normal bilateral renal function.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 35-year-old male patient with a tumour in the upper pole of the right testicle found by chance during self-exploration
column2: for which reason he attended a urology consultation where a physical examination was performed
column3: revealing a mass of approximately 1cm in diameter depending on the epididymis
column4: and a testicular ultrasound scan
column5: which was reported as a solid nodular lesion in the head of the right epididymis. MRI was performed. Confirming nodular mass
column6: with adenomatoid tumour of the epididymis being the first diagnostic possibility.  It was decided
column7: in both cases
column8: to surgically resect the nodular tumour in the right epididymal tail
column9: without performing a subsequent orchiectomy. In both cases an anatomopathological examination of the surgical specimen was performed. Macroscopic histological findings: nodular formation of 1.5 cm (case 1) and 1.2 cm (case 2) of firm consistency
column10: whitish colour and well demarcated. Microscopically
column11: tumour proliferation was observed
column12: consisting of tubular structures in which the cellularity showed rounded and elongated nuclei without cytological atypia and occasionally showed vacuolated cytoplasm
column13: all compatible with adenomatoid tumour of the epididymis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 42-year-old patient diagnosed with ulcerative pancolitis in 2003
column2: corticodependent
column3: with a first cortico-refractory episode in August 2003 and with cytomegalovirus superinfection
column4: which was treated with ganciclovir iv. In May 2004
column5: he presented a moderate flare-up with diarrhoea with red blood (2 stools per day) and since then chronic iron deficiency anaemia
column6: which he has been treated with ferrotherapy. Endoscopic examination showed ulcerative pancolitis with severe involvement. He was treated with corticosteroids and immunosuppressants. In June 2007 she presented with a new flare-up of disease activity with 10-12 liquid stools per day
column7: abdominal pain and fever. Due to the progressive clinical and analytical worsening presented by the patient and the poor response to conventional treatment
column8: it was decided to start treatment with granulocytoapheresis associated with cyclosporine iv. While the patient was hospitalised
column9: 4 sessions were carried out
column10: requiring the placement of a double-lumen catheter in the right jugular vein. A central catheter had to be changed due to infection (MARSA
column11: contact isolation was performed)
column12: and the remaining 3 sessions were received on an outpatient basis. During these months
column13: the patient has shown a rapid clinical and endoscopic improvement. He is currently receiving treatment with azathioprine (Imurel®).  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O

column1: A 33-year-old woman came to the emergency department with asthenia
column2: a history of unknown allergies
column3: cutaneous lupus with malar erythema untreated for 8 years and under follow-up by rheumatology. Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Appendectomy. Ex-smoker for 7 years. Non-drinker. No toxic habits
column4: except for quinine drinks (tonic). Episodes of anaemia after 2 births. Caesarean section and tubal ligation in the 3rd. Current illness: Consultation for intense asthenia and presyncope (of one week's evolution)
column5: making it difficult to ambulate
column6: together with anorexia without weight loss. Menstruation very long-lasting (8 days) and abundant. No melenic stools
column7: pale skin and mucous membranes. Epistaxis and gingivorrhagia. Laboratory tests showed anaemia with 6.7 g/dl haemoglobin
column8: thrombopenia with platelets of 6
column9: 000/mm3. LDH 1696 IU/l. Blood smear with presence of schistocytes. Other tests were normal. Diagnosis: According to the clinical and laboratory data
column10: the patient presented a compatible picture of TTP in the context of SLE. On admission
column11: a red blood cell concentrate and a platelet concentrate were transfused. One hour after transfusing the platelets
column12: the patient began with a picture of global aphasia and deviation of the oral commissure to the left with no other neurological focality. Subsequently
column13: she speaks with normal speech without obvious focality. Given the added neurological symptom
column14: the patient was admitted to haematology for further investigation. As the patient presented thrombotic microangiopathy and seizures
column15: the department requested plasmapheresis. Due to the clinical worsening of the patient
column16: she was admitted to the ICU. Plasmapheresis session plan: The exchange volume should be between 1-1.5 times the plasma volume. Treatment will be prolonged until 48 hours after response is achieved. The patient weighs 75 kg
column17: and according to the ratio tables
column18: a total of 3
column19: 500 cc. of volume to be reinfused corresponds to her
column20: so the following is programmed: 1
column21: 750 cc. of fresh plasma + 350 cc. of 20% human albumin + 1
column22: 400 cc. of Dianeal® 1.36% peritoneal dialysis solution. Incidence of the sessions: For the performance of the 1st plasmapheresis in ICU
column23: an attempt was made to implant a catheter in the right jugular vein
column24: but due to its difficulty and excessive bleeding
column25: a double-lumen catheter was placed in the left femoral vein. The monitor used for the technique was a PRISMA CRRT-TPE (Hospal®)
column26: with PTE-2000 filter. The heparin dose was 15-5-5-5-5 mgr
column27: the duration of the sessions was about 210 minutes
column28: with an average infusion of 980 ml/h
column29: blood flows between 120-140 ml/min and pressures of (BP. - 85 to -170 mmHg
column30: and PV of 70 to 90 mmHg
column31: maintaining a MTP between 25-55 mmHg). The patient in the ICU presented a poor general condition (sedated)
column32: with the constants maintained. A total of 17 sessions were performed. Incidence of the same: She was very agitated during the 1st session. In the 5th and 6th sessions she suffered hypotension and major convulsions
column33: which subsided with diazepam and physiological saline
column34: ending the treatment. On the 16th there was an increase in TMP to 55 mm Hg with 50 minutes to go
column35: ending the session. In the 17th
column36: there was a failure of the air test with 90 minutes to go
column37: so the SET had to be changed. The rest of the sessions were carried out without problems
column38: being well tolerated by the patient.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 19-year-old male patient admitted from the emergency department for a gunshot wound (hunting shotgun) after an attempt at autolysis (impact distance less than one metre). He presented with a wound in the lower third of the lateral region with significant bone loss from the left first premolar to the left mandibular angle. Significant cutaneous and mucosal loss of the left jugal region and left cheek. Tracheotomy
column2: debridement of devitalised tissues
column3: splinting of teeth
column4: intermaxillary block and placement of a mandibular reconstruction plate. Direct intraoral closure and skin closure with a cervicofacial advancement flap were carried out during this first surgical stage. In the immediate postoperative period
column5: there was suffering and loss of the cervicofacial advancement flap
column6: leaving a significant left facial granulating area. Scar retraction of the oral mucosal tissue results in severe limitation of the oral opening (0.8 cm). There are orofacial communications and salivary fistulas. Secondary intervention is decided by means of a scapular-parascapular osteomyocutaneous flap of the left arm
column7: non-dominant
column8: but with a history of recurrent dislocation. The operation began with a new tracheotomy and preparation of the recipient vessels: facial artery and branch of the thyrolinguinguofacial venous trunk. It is necessary to remove a large amount of cellular-ganglionic tissue from level I and III
column9: in order to reach the recipient vessels. The osteocutaneous scapular-parascapular flap is then dissected and the donor area is closed
column10: leaving suction drainage and immobilising the left upper limb with a sling.  The bony part of the flap is then adapted to the mandibular defect with ostosynthesis using the reconstruction plate placed in the initial operation. The cutaneous part of the flap is folded like a book
column11: leaving one of the cutaneous lobes intraoral and one extraoral (cervical facial). The back of the so-called book is de-epithelialised and sutured to the remaining lower lip. The intraoral part reconstructs the entire jugal mucosa up to the anterior pillar of the soft palate. The external part reconstructs the mandibular and left submandibular skin area. The posterosuperior region of the skin defect is left for dermoepidermal grafting. The block and the dental splint are removed and the mouth is left "open".  Adaptation of the flap required submaxillectomy and removal of some of the posteroinferior subcutaneous tissue. The anastomosis was made end-to-end from the scapular circumflex artery to the facial artery; and from the greater of the scapular circumflex veins to the thyroinguinguofacial trunk. The duration of the operation was 14 hours
column12: with an ischaemia time of 2.45 hours. Satisfactory evolution regarding the vitality of the scapular flap. Local complications: parotid salivary fistula in the posterosuperior area due to loss of the dermoepidermal graft over the maseterine region.  Complications in the donor area: disinsertion of the long arm of the triceps and wound dehiscence. To treat this dehiscence
column13: the patient underwent a local transposition graft. Postural complication: paralysis of the radial nerve on the contralateral (right) side.  The patient is undergoing rehabilitation treatment to regain mobility of the left arm.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 61-year-old patient with a history of radical prostatectomy with staging obturator lymphadenectomy for moderately differentiated prostate carcinoma (Gleason score 5)
column2: with limited microscopic involvement of the resection margins. Three months after prostate surgery
column3: he consulted for an increase in right testicular volume
column4: with negative testicular tumour markers
column5: a mass with irregular areas on ultrasound and decreased vascular flow on Doppler study. The preoperative evaluation had included an abdominal CT scan with no findings. Post-orchiectomy CT scan detected retroperitoneal adenopathies from the inguinal area to the renal bifurcation. After performing an inguinal orchiectomy
column6: he was diagnosed with diffuse large B-cell testicular lymphoma.  He was given an initial course of cytoreductive chemotherapy according to the R-CHOPx8 schedule
column7: with complete remission after induction. He presented an early relapse treated in second line with IFOVM / DHAP
column8: with initial remission after three cycles and then a new relapse
column9: dying 14 months after diagnosis.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 72-year-old male patient whose personal history included a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
column2: arterial hypertension
column3: type II diabetes mellitus and chronic ischaemia of the lower limbs. He was being treated with metformin
column4: acarbose and glinclazide. He presented with a 72-hour history of diffuse abdominal pain accompanied by diarrhoea and anorexia
column5: with subsequent deterioration of the level of consciousness. He was seen at a secondary hospital where he was found to have acute renal failure
column6: significant metabolic acidosis and haemodynamic instability
column7: which led to the decision to transfer him to the ICU of our hospital. On arrival at our unit
column8: the patient was conscious but sleepy
column9: tachycardic (heart rate 120 beats per minute in sinus rhythm)
column10: hypotensive (blood pressure 80/40 mmHg) and with indirect signs of low cardiac output on physical examination. Among the analytical determinations made on admission
column11: acute renal failure with creatinine and urea levels of 6.6 mg/dl and 197 mg/dl respectively and severe lactic acidosis with pH: 6.8
column12: base deficit -29 mmol/l
column13: GAP anion of 41 and lactate level of 176 mg/dl stood out. Given the suspicion of acute metformin intoxication
column14: a blood sample was taken to determine the plasma levels of metformin and treatment was started consisting of water and electrolyte replacement
column15: haemodynamic stabilisation using noradrenaline at a dose of 0.4 mcg/kg/minute and dobutamine at a dose of 10 mcg/kg/minute and correction of the acidosis by intravenous administration of 1 M bicarbonate. In agreement with the Nephrology Department
column16: haemodialysis was also decided. The patient's evolution was favourable
column17: with progressive disappearance of acidosis and normalisation of renal function parameters that allowed the patient to be discharged on the ninth day of admission to the ICU. The determination of metformin levels was 70.40 mg/l at plasma level and 53.10 mg/l at erythrocyte level.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 42-year-old man came to the emergency department with a bilateral and progressive decrease in vision of several weeks' duration. His personal history included chronic hepatopathy due to virus C and an autoimmune Evans syndrome (autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura with anaemia) of long evolution
column2: which had required splenectomy 20 years earlier. Maintenance treatment was 30 mg oral prednisone every other day. On ophthalmological examination
column3: best corrected visual acuity in OD was 0.3 and in OS 0.2. Biomicroscopically
column4: there was a posterior subcapsular cataract 1+ in OD and 2+ in OS. Funduscopy revealed multiple areas of neurosensory and retinal pigment epithelium detachment (RPE) in the posterior pole of both eyes
column5: as well as small
column6: rounded
column7: discrete and sparse whitish lesions in the equatorial retina of both eyes. In addition
column8: other peripheral pigmented cicatricial lesions were present in OS. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) revealed detachments involving the macula in both eyes.  Angiofluoresceingraphy was indicated
column9: but was not performed because 2 days later the patient was admitted with a high fever
column10: laterocervical lymphadenopathies and persistent diarrhoea. He was treated empirically with cefotaxime and corticotherapy
column11: but evolved unfavourably
column12: presenting respiratory difficulty with progressive deterioration of his general condition. CT scan showed a large mediastinal enlargement
column13: and biopsy of the cervical lymph nodes revealed a diffuse large B-cell lymphoma with CD20+ marker. With the diagnosis of stage II E diffuse large B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
column14: he received 6 cycles of CHOP chemotherapy and rituximab. Throughout the chemotherapy treatment (especially from the 3rd cycle onwards)
column15: the patient already experienced a clear visual improvement
column16: with progressive reapplication of all the foci of sensory detachment and RPE
column17: leaving retinochoroidal scars with pigment redistribution. Six months after chemotherapy
column18: complete remission of the lymphoma was confirmed by CT and scintigraphy
column19: and the retinas were applied and the old exudative lesions had a cicatricial and inactive appearance. OCT confirmed resolution of the detachments. VA was 0.7 in OD and 0.6 in OS and the patient is awaiting cataract surgery.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 58-year-old man who presented to the emergency department with severe ocular pain accompanied by progressive visual loss in his left eye.
