Ophthalmological examination revealed a pigmented mass in the iridocorneal angle that protruded into the anterior chamber and affected the iris. The patient's symptoms were compatible with acute glaucoma secondary to this mass in the anterior chamber. Ophthalmoscopy showed a large pigmented mass with an irregular appearance
column2: with more raised areas. Ocular ultrasound findings were compatible with a large
column3: diffusely spreading ocular melanoma. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed a mass with a base of 17 mm
column4: slightly hyperintense in T1 and hypointense in T2
column5: compatible with the diagnosis of choroidal melanoma (1). The oncology department performed an extension study which ruled out metastatic dissemination. Given the extent of the tumour
column6: the patient's symptoms and the absence of any possibility of visual recovery
column7: treatment by enucleation was considered (1
column8: 3).  Macroscopic visual examination of the eyeball after removal revealed the presence of scleral invasion. The patient evolved favourably
column9: retaining ocular motility and a satisfactory appearance with the external ocular prosthesis
column10: maintaining a good quality of life
column11: presenting only difficulty in performing daily tasks requiring good binocular vision. Macroscopic examination of serial sections of the eyeball showed a circumferential mass of endophytic growth covering practically the entire choroid extending to the ciliary body and iris
column12: corresponding histologically to a proliferation of spindle and epithelioid cells with large
column13: pigmented cytoplasm
column14: oval nuclei with prominent nucleoli with a significant degree of atypia. The number of mitoses was high
column15: with evidence of haemorrhagic and necrotic foci. These anatomopathological data confirmed the diagnosis of diffuse uveal melanoma
column16: with perforation of the scleral wall reaching the external surface of the sclera.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 33-year-old man
column2: with no known pathological history
column3: was admitted to a hospital emergency department at 7.43 am
column4: from his home
column5: with the diagnosis of "cranial traumatism causing ischaemic stroke". The previous evening he had been hit in the neck by a ball while playing a football match as a goalkeeper. During his admission
column6: a cranial CAT scan was performed
column7: which revealed an ischaemic infarction in the territory of the right middle cerebral artery as a consequence of a traumatic dissection of the right internal carotid artery. He presented endocranial hypertension and cerebral herniation with evolution towards encephalic death
column8: for which he entered the organ donation programme and died 10 days after his admission.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 24-year-old male referred to the maxillofacial surgery department of our institution for evaluation of cleft lip and palate. The patient had no history of interest except for unspecified surgery for his underlying disease years before
column2: and with secondary malar hypoplasia. On physical examination the patient had dysmorphia of the nasal pyramid. Cephalometric analysis and imaging studies including multidetector computed tomography (MDCT) confirmed the presence of maxillary hypoplasia. A 2-phase surgical management was planned based on clinical and radiological findings. In the first phase a LeFort type 1 osteotomy with placement of internal maxillary distractors was performed. After correction of the maxillomandibular relationship
column3: a second phase would probably include extraction of teeth and rehabilitation with dental implants. The first phase of treatment was carried out without immediate surgical complications. The patient presented 27 days later to the emergency department for epistaxis for which bilateral anterior packing and admission were indicated. It was decided to perform MDCT after intravenous contrast injection (IVC) for vascular study of the facial mass
column4: which revealed a pseudoaneurysm of approximately 8 × 9 × 8 mm (anteroposterior
column5: transverse and craniocaudal diameter) in the right pterygo-palatine fossa with probable origin in the ipsilateral internal maxillary artery.  During admission
column6: the patient presented significant episodes of oral and nasal bleeding with important haemodynamic consequences
column7: for which a subsequent tamponade with Foley catheters was performed. One day later
column8: selective arteriography of the right external carotid artery was performed with therapeutic intent
column9: which confirmed the presence of the pseudoaneurysm and its dependence on the internal maxillary artery. It was decided to perform embolisation in the same intervention with 50% cyanoacrylate glue. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the maxillofacial surgery ward. As there were no new bleeding episodes or haemodynamic alterations
column10: 6 days after embolisation
column11: the patient was discharged.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 60-year-old woman diagnosed with antral stenosing gastric neoplasia. Subtotal gastrectomy with Roux-en-Y reconstruction was performed. On day +7 the patient deteriorated abruptly with the appearance of peritonitis
column2: so she underwent urgent laparotomy
column3: showing necrosis of the gastric lesser curvature and of the anterior face of the distal oesophagus. Transection and closure of the abdominal oesophagus and gastric stump
column4: oesophageal exclusion with cervical oesophagostomy and feeding jejunostomy were performed
column5: starting EN on day +1. The patient was discharged with NED by jejunostomy. Three months later
column6: she was readmitted for reconstruction of the digestive tract
column7: after colonoscopy and computed axial tomography
column8: in which no data suggestive of tumour recurrence were observed. During surgery
column9: multiple micronodules were observed in the transverse colon and in the region corresponding to the gastrohepatic omentum
column10: with intraoperative pathology compatible with signet ring cells
column11: so reconstruction was suspended and NED was maintained by jejunostomy indefinitely.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 68-year-old man
column2: with no known drug allergies
column3: with a history of hypertension
column4: mild chronic renal failure
column5: chronic atrial fibrillation
column6: antithrombin III deficiency leading to intestinal ischaemia due to mesenteric venous thrombosis nine years earlier
column7: with resection of 150 cm of jejunum and ileum. In March 2005
column8: she came to the emergency department after presenting at home with two melenic stools. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was performed
column9: showing a depapillated mucosal portion of the duodenum with no active bleeding. Colonoscopy revealed multiple teleangiectatic lesions with no active bleeding. Subsequently
column10: capsule endoscopic examination revealed multiple ecchymoses in the duodenum
column11: jejunum
column12: ileum and cecum. After several similar episodes of HDB requiring transfusions
column13: capsule and endoscopy were repeated
column14: with no new findings. Scintigraphy with labelled red blood cells was also performed and was compatible with small bowel angiodysplasia. During one of the episodes
column15: a mesenteric angiography was performed
column16: showing extravasation at the level of the arteriovenous fistula and performing embolisation with coils
column17: after which she presented with acute abdominal symptoms and persistent bleeding
column18: performing a laparotomy and finding ischaemia of the previous anastomosis
column19: possibly related to the embolisation. A new resection of the ileum was performed
column20: leaving about 80 cm with the ileocaecal valve intact. Despite the intervention
column21: the patient continued to suffer from HDB
column22: and treatment with somatostatin was tried
column23: but without response. In the 28 months following the first episode
column24: the patient required a total of 132 red blood cell concentrates. Given the failure of all previous therapies and the lack of relevance of new surgical treatments
column25: treatment with thalidomide at a dose of 100 mg per day was started at the beginning of July 2007. Eight months later
column26: the patient has had no new episodes of HDB and has not required any transfusions. The patient is currently followed up monthly in outpatient clinics and is asymptomatic except for occasional mild paresthesia in the lower limbs
column27: with a normal electromyogram. The patient has had one episode of bilateral PTE that resolved with anticoagulant treatment. Given the history of antithrombin III deficiency and the fact that thrombophilia is not described among the possible side effects of thalidomide
column28: we believe that this event is not attributable to the use of thalidomide.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O

column1: A 33-year-old man diagnosed with KS and with a history of bilateral sinusitis
column2: bronchiectasis and retinal detachment of the right eye consulted for testicular enlargement and induration. The patient reported no other accompanying symptoms except lumbar pain radiating to the left testicle. Examination revealed an increase in testicular volume
column3: painless and with a stony consistency suggestive of neoplasia. No lymph nodes were palpable.  The ultrasound showed signs compatible with a seminoma-type testicular tumour with no locoregional lymph nodes. Chest X-ray showed situs inversus
column4: evidenced by the apex of the cardiac silhouette and the gastric gas chamber to the right and some scarring with probable bronchiectasis in the left lower lobe.  Laboratory tests showed LDH: 340 (230-460); GOT: 44 (2-37); GPT: 44 (2-40). Tumour markers: a-fetoprotein: 1.1 ng/ml (1-7) and b-HCG <5.0 mIU/ml. Inguinal orchiectomy was performed under spinal anaesthesia at L3-L4 level with hyperbaric bupivacaine and testicular prosthesis was placed. The anatomopathological result was a classic seminoma of 2.5 cms in diameter that affected the albuginea (without exceeding it) and respected the epididymis
column5: the rete testis
column6: the spermatic cord and the surgical edges. There is no evidence of vascular invasion. Intratubular germinal neoplasia. Fibrosis and tubular hyalinisation of the non-tumour testicle. With the diagnosis of grade I seminoma without poor prognosis criteria and in agreement with the Oncology Department
column7: it was decided not to apply additional treatment
column8: observing after one year of follow-up normal biochemical normality of the tumour parameters and with negative physical examination and imaging tests. After orchiectomy
column9: two spermiograms were performed
column10: both of which showed azoospermia.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A female patient
column2: seen for the first time at the ophthalmology department of our hospital in 1992 (aged 33) due to a decrease in the visual acuity of her right eye. The initial ophthalmological examination showed a visual acuity (VA) of 0.2 in the right eye (RA) and 0.6 in the left eye (LO)
column3: with -5.0 and -4.0 spherical dioptres respectively. Biomicroscopic examination of the anterior pole showed a marked posterior embryotoxon and intraocular pressure was 12 mmHg in both eyes. The patient's fundus showed the following features OD: Circumpapillary geographic atrophy of the RPE and choroid with precise boundaries encompassing the entire macular area and allowing visualisation of the underlying choroidal vessels. OI: Diffuse lesions with similar characteristics to those in the OD
column4: with a crescent of atrophy partially affecting the macular area. In this situation
column5: fluorescein angiography (FAG) was performed
column6: showing the atrophy of the RPE and choriocapillaris already described
column7: without clear signs of activity. Given the possibility of serpiginous choroiditis
column8: immunosuppressive treatment was started with corticosteroids and cyclosporine
column9: as well as vitamin supplements for possible nutritional deficiency
column10: but no favourable response was observed. Subsequently
column11: and due to the unfavourable evolution
column12: immunosuppressive treatment with Azathioprine and Methotrexate was reinstated without any sign of improvement. In 2003
column13: and due to her family history (2 nephews genetically diagnosed with Alagille Syndrome without associated ophthalmological manifestations)
column14: a genetic study was performed on the patient
column15: discovering the 2785+3 mutation of AAGT in intron 19 of the Jagged 1 gene and thus confirming the suspicion of Alagille Syndrome. At present
column16: and after 14 years of follow-up
column17: the patient has a visual acuity of light perception in OD and 0.1 with eccentric fixation in OI. The fundus examination showed the growth of atrophic chorioretinal lesions that completely covered the macular area without showing any evidence of angiographic signs of activity in the periodic check-ups carried out throughout the follow-up in our department.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: History and onset of Capgras Delirium after Subarachnoid Haemorrhage (SAH) 59-year-old female patient with a degree in exact sciences and former high school teacher. She is the eldest of three siblings. She describes her happy childhood
column2: was very close to her father
column3: was an outgoing
column4: sociable and independent child. Intellectually brilliant
column5: she soon lived independently
column6: moving several times from city to city according to professional requirements. She had a psychotic break with paranoid ideation at the age of 30 after her planned wedding was called off. The manic and depressive episodes alternated
column7: some of them requiring hospital admission
column8: although she was able to lead a normal life without work-related problems between periods until the third of her admissions in 2005
column9: motivated by a depressive episode and coinciding with the recent death of her father
column10: at which time the patient applied for work incapacity (absolute ILP granted in 2006). The relapses were always related to the abandonment of lithium treatment. Alcohol abuse was also observed during this time. Diagnosis until December 2009: "Bipolar disorder with congruent and non-congruent psychotic symptoms
column11: with remission" and "Alcohol abuse". Since she became independent she has hardly any relationship with her parents and siblings
column12: because of her lifestyle and manic symptomatology she is considered the "black sheep" of the family. In 2009 she suffered a subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH). The CT scan revealed left temporoparietal involvement surrounded by extensive oedema; mass effect on the ipsilateral ventricular system and acute left parietal haematoma with severe involvement of the level of consciousness
column13: sensitivity
column14: motor skills and speech. On waking up from the coma
column15: he says that the first thing he sees is the face of a former teacher colleague with whom he had an affectionate relationship. After this he says that his siblings "are not his siblings"
column16: attributing the change to the teacher friend. The CD extends to friends and acquaintances. Abandoned by her partner at the time
column17: it is the brother who takes responsibility for her care. Evolution of the case after SAH. Subsequently
column18: she required several hospital admissions due to decompensation of psychiatric symptoms; asymptomatic periods practically ceased. In the acute unit prior to admission to the EMU he presented: potomania
column19: psychotic decompensation with paranoid-type delirious ideation
column20: kinaesthetic hallucinations
column21: social isolation and disorganised thinking
column22: hyperthymic mood
column23: insomnia
column24: and slight disinhibition. Lithium salts were withdrawn due to nephropathy secondary to diabetes insipidus
column25: and valproic acid was introduced. Diagnosis: "Mixed schizoaffective disorder
column26: with congruent and non-congruent psychotic symptoms"; "Alcohol abuse". In February 2012 he was admitted to the EMU to start an "individualised rehabilitation plan". - The medical-nurse assessment found moderate functional limitation with generalised hypotonia. History of hypothyroidism and NIDDM
column27: both in remission. Potomania and enuresis secondary to episodes of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus that were corrected with self-registration and thiazides. - The neuropsychological examination (WAIS IV) showed cognitive impairment in both working memory and processing speed
column28: although the levels reflect a "normal" level
column29: around an IQ of 100
column30: which was previously assumed to be much higher given his academic and professional history. He exhibits socially inappropriate verbal behaviour suggesting frontal involvement
column31: perhaps as a result of his long history of alcohol abuse. - Psychopathological evaluation: Presence of several delusions of bodily influence
column32: telepathy and DC
column33: and some simple hallucinatory phenomena. The same teacher who causes impersonation also throws things at him and pushes him. He communicates telepathically with him through the numbers on the TV and the clicks he hears in the windows. The characteristics of the CD are shown in table 1. It should be noted that although at the beginning he showed some hostility towards the "brother's double"
column34: his feelings became positive
column35: in fact he now gets along much better with him than before the SAH episode. Psychopathological stabilisation is achieved with Depakine 1300 mg/day
column36: Olanzapine 20 mg/day
column37: Risperidone 6 mg/day
column38: Vitamin B Complex. He participates in the "treatment adherence group". Discharged in December 2012. Residual positive psychotic symptomatology and partial insight.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 40-year-old man was followed up by the dermatology department for presenting painful nodular gluteal lesions with purulent drainage. He was histologically diagnosed with deep suppurative cystic folliculitis
column2: compatible with acne conglobata
column3: with positive culture for Staphylococcus aureus. He was treated with prednisone (15 mg/day)
column4: isotetricin and rifampicin without improvement. In addition
column5: he had a one-year history of 25 kg weight loss and abdominal pain
column6: with onset of fever in recent weeks. The patient was referred for admission. On physical examination he was cachectic
column7: with multiple nodular lesions in the gluteal and perianal region with scarring between them
column8: draining purulent material. Laboratory tests showed severe iron deficiency anaemia (Hb: 7.2 g/dl)
column9: increased acute phase reactants (CRP:13) and signs of malnutrition (albumin: 2.49 g/dl
column10: cholesterol: 8.3 mg/dl). A colonoscopy was performed
column11: showing pseudopolyps
column12: ulcers and a mucous cobblestone appearance in the rectum and transverse colon
column13: as well as two fistulous orifices; the histological diagnosis was inflammatory bowel disease of the Crohn's disease (CD) type. A pelvic MRI showed a left perianal fistula with extension to the left thigh root. Treatment was prescribed with high-dose steroids
column14: 5-ASA
column15: antibiotics and azathioprine
column16: with a notable clinical and analytical improvement and practical resolution of the skin lesions. In this case
column17: the existence of another diagnosis (acne conglobata) together with the presentation of CD as perianal disease (EPA) led to a delay in diagnosis
column18: which may have been a determining factor in the development of these severe lesions.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 53-year-old male patient came to the urology department for a left testicular mass. Physical examination revealed a palpation of a lesion in the upper pole of the left testicle
column2: firm in consistency and not painful. A testicular ultrasound scan was performed showing an area measuring 2 x 2 cm
column3: of heterogeneous echogenicity
column4: with multiple cystic areas
column5: suggestive of a possible neoplasm. Tumour markers were negative. Given the high suspicion of testicular tumour
column6: we decided to perform a radical left orchiectomy. In the histological study of the surgical specimen
column7: macroscopically there was a well-defined tumour
column8: 1.8 cm in diameter
column9: yellowish in colour and with a stony consistency. Microscopically it is made up of horny scales and nests of squamous epithelium in which "shadow" epithelial cells are recognisable. Most of this material is calcified and ossified
column10: and a fibrous reaction is observed around the lesion
column11: leading to the formation of a pseudocapsule that delimits the tumour. In this fibrous pseudocapsule
column12: bundles of smooth muscle are focally identified. The testicular parenchyma shows moderate interstitial oedema. The epididymis and spermatic cord show no relevant histological alterations. The anatomo-pathological diagnosis was testicular dermoid cyst (mature testicular teratoma)
column13: pseudopilomatrixoma variant.  After orchiectomy
column14: an extension study was carried out by chest X-ray and abdominopelvic CT scan
column15: with no evidence of systemic extension of the disease. Testicular tumour markers (alpha-fetoprotein
column16: beta-HCG and LDH) were negative. The patient is asymptomatic and free of disease at present after 6 months of follow-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 33 year old male patient
column2: who was referred from another hospital centre for presenting a large right hemimandibular tumour
column3: 6 months old
column4: which had experienced progressive growth
column5: and which he reported after exodontia of a molar in the fourth quadrant
column6: with no mention of significant pain at that level. Physical examination and orthopantomography revealed a bone-dependent tumour 5-6 cm in diameter
column7: with involvement of both bony cortices
column8: extending from the region of the second premolar to the middle of the right mandibular ramus
column9: with involvement of the ipsilateral internal pterygoid muscle.  A facial computed tomography (CT) scan showed a mandibular tumour lesion measuring 5.5 × 4.8 × 3 cm
column10: destroying the internal mandibular cortex
column11: displacing the musculature and structures of the base of the tongue
column12: and involving most of the right mandibular body and ramus
column13: with preservation of the condyle. A diagnostic biopsy was performed
column14: with the result of a myxoid lesion with a reactive lymphoplasmacytic inflammatory component
column15: with positivity for vimentin
column16: CD138
column17: Kappa
column18: Lambda and partial positivity for actin. Immunohistochemistry showed negativity for S-100
column19: CD31 and CD68. The diagnosis was mandibular odontogenic myxoma.  Under general anaesthesia and nasotracheal intubation
column20: surgical excision of the lesion with margins was performed using a combined intraoral and extraoral approach
column21: with segmental haemimandibulectomy from the canine region to the ipsilateral mandibular ramus and coronoid process
column22: preserving the mandibular condyle. The patient had a serrated contralateral hemimandible. Primary reconstruction was performed using a microvascularised free fibula graft. The maximum thickness of the fibula was 14 mm. The flap was preformed in situ
column23: with carving of the new hemimandible using a reconstruction bar modelled on the original mandible
column24: and subsequent osteotomy of the peroneal bone and fixation with miniplates. Vascular anastomosis was performed between the right peroneal and facial arteries
column25: and between the concomitant right peroneal veins and right thyrolinguofacial venous trunk. The histological study of the specimen was reported as a mandibular odontogenic myxoma without involvement of the surgical edges. The postoperative period was uneventful. One year after the operation
column26: on observing a height discrepancy of 17 mm between the fibula and the alveolar ridge of the contralateral hemimandible
column27: it was decided to perform vertical osteogenic distraction of the fibula by placing an intraoral alveolar distractor.  Distractor placement was performed under general anaesthesia. The fibula graft was exposed through an incision in the vestibular oral mucosa
column28: after which a subperiosteal dissection was performed to adequately visualise the underlying bone
column29: taking extreme care to preserve the periosteum of the lingual aspect of the fibula. The intraoral alveolar distractor (MODUS ARS 1.5; Medartis®
column30: Basel
column31: Switzerland) was placed on the vestibular surface of the fibula to correctly design the osteotomies. The osteotomies were performed on the vestibular surface of the fibula
column32: using an oscillating saw
column33: with saline irrigation. A trapezoidal bone segment was obtained
column34: with the lingual periosteum remaining intact. The alveolar distractor was fixed with screws on both sides of the horizontal osteotomy. Once the perfect functioning of the distractor had been checked
column35: the distractor was placed in its starting position
column36: so that both bone fragments were in perfect apposition. This is essential to initiate bone formation from the position of maximum contact between fragments and to achieve adequate post-osteotomy haemostasis. The vestibular incision was closed leaving part of the distractor through the incision to facilitate activation of the distractor.  Distractor activation was not performed during the latency period (10 days). After this
column37: activation was performed at a rate of 0.5 mm per day. Serial orthopantomographic controls (obtained weekly) showed vertical distraction of the peroneal bone and the formation of bony trabeculae at the interface at the end of stabilisation. 17 mm of bone was obtained in 34 days
column38: so that the fibula graft reached the same level as the contralateral alveolar ridge
column39: with optimal correction of the initial height discrepancy between the two.  The consolidation period lasted three months
column40: during which the distractor was maintained in its initial fixation site. Orthopantomography at three months confirmed excellent ossification between the basilar and the distracted fragment. Subsequently
column41: in a second operation
column42: the distractor was removed using the same intraoral approach. The quality of the newly formed bone
column43: ascertained macroscopically
column44: was excellent. In the same operation
column45: three 3.75 × 15 mm threaded titanium implants (Mozo-Grau®) were placed in the distracted area. Good primary stability was achieved in all implants. The postoperative period was uneventful. Prosthetic rehabilitation
column46: using an implant-supported prosthesis
column47: was successfully completed after three months of osseointegration. The results obtained
column48: both aesthetic and functional
column49: were satisfactory for both the patient and the surgeon after 18 months of follow-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Patient aged 15 years with no previous history of interest. He was seen in the emergency department for vomiting and epigastric pain of three days' evolution
column2: and reported a weight loss of 7 kg in the previous two months. Physical examination revealed moderate mucocutaneous pallor
column3: hepatosplenomegaly of two finger widths and epigastric pain on deep palpation. Scrotal examination revealed an enlarged left teste (three to four times larger than normal) with a hard consistency
column4: irregular surface and non-painful. On cross-examination
column5: the patient confirmed that he had noticed a progressive and painless enlargement of the teste for about a year. The ED blood test showed only a haematocrit of 35%
column6: haemoglobin 11.3 g/dl and LDH 2802 U/L. The abdominal and testicular ultrasound showed the existence of a very enlarged left teste with heterogeneous echogenicity
column7: with foci of necrosis and liquid areas; and at the hepatic level there were extensive images suggestive of metastasis.  Chest X-ray revealed multiple pulmonary metastases and discrete pleural effusion
column8: which after thoracentesis revealed haematic pleural fluid. Twelve hours after admission
column9: a thoracoabdominal CT scan showed extensive metastatic involvement
column10: with multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules
column11: right pleural effusion
column12: mediastinal and retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy
column13: hepatomegaly with massive metastatic involvement
column14: and possibly splenic and pancreatic metastases. There was no intraperitoneal free fluid.  Blood samples were obtained for testicular markers: alpha-fetoprotein 15000 ng/ml and betaHCG of 200
column15: 000 mIU/ml
column16: and orchiectomy was scheduled for the following day. Thirty-six hours after admission
column17: rapidly onset hypovolaemic shock with pain and abdominal bulging occurred
column18: requiring urgent laparotomy after abdominal ultrasound
column19: which showed a large amount of intraperitoneal fluid. During laparotomy
column20: extensive metastatic involvement was found in the tail of the pancreas
column21: spleen and liver with rupture of splenic and hepatic metastases and massive haemoperitoneum due to active bleeding and diffuse hepatic haematoma. Splenectomy was performed with suture and surgicel tamponade of the bleeding liver areas; at the same time
column22: radical left orchiectomy was performed. The macroscopic anatomopathology describes: "piece of radical orchiectomy
column23: weighing 233 grams and measuring 8x9x5 cm
column24: accompanied by 7 cm of cord; on serial sections the testicular parenchyma shows an almost total replacement by a whitish tumour
column25: with areas of necrosis and haemorrhage that does not appear to go beyond the testicular coverings". Microscopic histopathology of the testicle showed a mixed germinal malignant neoplasm with areas of embryonal carcinoma
column26: endodermal sinus tumour
column27: choriocarcinoma and teratoma.  The spleen measured 15x7x3 cm and weighed 180 g. Serial sections showed six nodular
column28: rounded
column29: whitish formations with central necrosis. Microscopy confirmed that the splenic lesions were metastases of the testicular neoplasm.  Forty-eight hours after the operation
column30: the patient suffered a new episode of hypovolemic shock with evident signs of intra-abdominal bleeding
column31: so a new laparotomy was performed
column32: verifying the existence of a hepatic burst at the level of the right and left lobe
column33: with incoercible haemorrhage and death shortly afterwards.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 28-year-old woman with no previous history of interest consulted for voiding syndrome with predominantly daytime frequency of urinary frequency and a certain degree of urgency without urinary leakage. Urine culture was negative and treatment with anticholinergics was indicated. Given the lack of response to treatment
column2: cystography was performed
column3: which was normal
column4: and renovesical ultrasound showed cystic parapipelic images
column5: some of them with internal septa and bladder without lesions. In order to determine the nature of these cysts
column6: an abdominal CT scan was requested
column7: which revealed a large parapelvic cyst in the right kidney with no repercussions on the duct and a right adrenal hypodense mass. MRI showed a normal adrenal gland and a lobulated cystic lesion containing numerous septa in its interior surrounding the right kidney; in the left renal cell there was a lesion of similar characteristics but smaller in size. The findings were compatible with bilateral renal lymphangioma. After three years of follow-up the patient continues with mild micturition symptomatology under treatment
column8: but has not presented symptoms derived from her renal lesion.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 60-year-old male patient with Alport syndrome
column2: microhaematuria and proteinuria of 4 g/day
column3: creatinine 2 mg/dl
column4: urea 123 mg/dl
column5: moderate hearing loss
column6: arterial hypertension treated with enalapril 20 mg
column7: obesity with BMI = 36.26 (P 120 kg
column9: altered fasting blood glucose (less than 126 mg/dl)
column10: normal glycosylated Hb
column11: dyslipidaemia and hyperuricaemia under treatment. Ex-smoker of one pack a day. Normothyroid. Renal biopsy (performed in 1995): MO (12 glomeruli) focal and segmental glomerular sclerosis evolving to sclerosing glomerulopathy
column12: IF with mild intensity Ig M in mesangium and IgA and M in tubular cylinders. ME 2 glomeruli. Capillary MB with irregular thickening and focal unfolding of the lamina densa. Podocytes with total fusion of pedicels. In one sector
column13: effacement of the glomerular structure with deposition of abundant amorphous material
column14: electron dense. The alterations of the lamina densa are compatible with Alport's disease
column15: the rest of the findings with focal sclerosing glomerulonephritis. Renal ultrasound: RD 95.6 x 52 x 53
column16: RI 99 x 51 x 52. Renal Doppler without alterations. A low-protein
column17: low-calorie diet was indicated and losartan was added to the treatment at a dose of 75 mg/day (maximum tolerated by the patient). A very slight reduction in proteinuria to 3.6 g/day was observed. Gastric by-pass surgery was performed
column18: and the patient's overall weight decreased by 35 kg
column19: reaching a BMI of 25.6. Nephrological control: creatinine 1.56 mg/dl
column20: proteinuria 0.3 g/day
column21: urea 65 mg/dl and normotension with enalapril 5 mg/d; minimum dose of lipid-lowering agents
column22: normouricemia and normoglycaemia were maintained. Three years after surgery
column23: the patient's good evolution is related to compliance with treatment (diet)
column24: aerobic exercise and clinical-psychological support.  L. Roberto León Instituto de Nefrología Sa Buenos Aires. (Buenos Aires)   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 42-year-old woman with a personal history of umbilical hernia surgery and hypertension. She presented with pain in the FII of 2 years' evolution
column2: rectal tenesmus and flat stools. Physical examination revealed diffuse pain on deep palpation in the FII. Blood tests showed 16
column3: 000 leukocytes and 91% neutrophils. A barium enema and colonoscopy were performed
column4: both of which revealed a stenosing image at the level of the sigma. Histological study of the biopsies was inconclusive. Resection of the stenosis area with end-to-end anastomosis was performed. The histological study confirmed the lesion of endometriosis of the colon with transmural involvement causing areas of fibrosis and haemorrhage.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 65-year-old patient diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the prostate Gleason 6/10 in both prostatic lobes (TNM Stage 2003 T1c). PSA at the time of diagnosis was 9.43 ng/ml. In January 2006 the patient underwent a radical retorpubic prostatectomy (Anatomical pathology report: Gleason 6/10 pT2c prostate adenocarcinoma with tumour-free margins). During dissection of the posterior aspect of the prostate 2 cm opening in the anterior aspect of the rectum. Direct closure of the rectal wall with loose stitches. No other intraoperative complications. On the fifth postoperative day
column2: the patient presented fever (37.6ºC)
column3: abdominal pain
column4: urinary fistula
column5: faecaluria and signs of peritonitis on physical examination. An abdominal CT scan was performed showing free retrohepatic fluid and an urgent laparotomy was performed
column6: showing faecaloid peritonitis secondary to perforation of the sigma and abundant urine and faeces in the pelvis. A new vesico-urethral suture
column7: resection of the perforated segment of the sigma and discharge colostomy were performed. After emergency surgery
column8: the patient developed septic symptoms and was admitted to the ICU for respiratory support. During the septic condition
column9: the patient presented urinary fistula with abundant urine leakage through the drainage and infection of the surgical wound. After respiratory and haemodynamic stabilisation
column10: the patient was discharged from the ICU with a permeable colostomy. Clear urine. Subsequently
column11: disappearance of urinary fistula and fat necrosis in the distal third of the surgical wound
column12: observing abdominal musculature as a background of the ulcer. In March 2006
column13: cystography was performed
column14: showing passage of contrast from the urethrovesical junction to the rectal ampulla. With a diagnosis of vesico-rectal fistula
column15: conservative treatment was indicated with bladder catheterisation until resolution of the surgical wound infection and closure by secondary intention.  In October 2006
column16: given the persistence of the fistulous orifice
column17: closure of the urethro-rectal fistula and transanal mucosal advancement plasty was performed. One month after surgery
column18: cystography was performed and no contrast leakage was observed outside the urinary tract
column19: so the bladder catheter was removed.  In March 2007 colostomy closure and eventroplasty of the abdominal wall with mesh was performed. In June 2007 the patient had comfortable spontaneous urination and normal bowel movements. Absence of urinary incontinence.
