column1: The patient was a 27-year-old man who had suffered from pneumonia as a child and was a non-smoker and non-smoker. He was diagnosed with extrinsic bronchial asthma and allergic rhinoconjunctivitis with hypersensitivity to grasses and olive trees. He needed inhaled corticosteroids sporadically. After significant physical exertion (he was a costalero in a procession during a local festival and had slept very little) in the summer of 2003
column2: he began to experience pain in the right hemithorax that sometimes radiated to the right upper limb and increased with deep breathing. Subsequently
column3: he developed a fever and a feeling of dyspnoea
column4: for which he went to the hospital emergency department. Clinical examination on admission revealed a poor general condition and a lesion in the scar phase on the abdominal wall that could correspond to a boil. Vesicular murmur was diminished at the right base. Cardiac and neurological examinations were normal. There were no organomegalies. There was leukocytosis (from 12
column5: 000/cubic mm to 18
column6: 700/cubic mm) with neutrophilia
column7: the rest of the haematological parameters being within normal limits. There was no eosinophilia. Creatinine increased during admission to 1.6 mg/dl and urea to 61 mg/dl. Other biochemical values were: total bilirubin: 2.19 mg/dl
column8: direct fraction: 1.33 mg/dl
column9: LDH: 687 IU/l
column10: GOT: 61 IU/l; GPT: 111 IU/l
column11: GGT: 521 IU/l
column12: alkaline phosphatase 509 IU/l. Sedimentation rate reached 71 mm in the first hour. Serology for HIV and hepatitis B and C viruses were negative. Serial blood cultures were performed and were positive for susceptible Staphylococcus aureus methicillin. Transthoracic echocardiography showed normal images without pericardial effusion. Ten days after admission
column13: a warm
column14: erythematous lesion appeared in the right parasternal region that disappeared on digitopressure and was about 5 x 5 cm. Fluid was aspirated from the lesion
column15: the culture of which was also positive for methicillin-sensitive S. aureus. Ultrasound of the abdomen was normal. Chest CT scan showed a left pleural effusion with interstitial prominence. There were three small nodular images in the right upper lobe
column16: left upper lobe and another subpleural image of less than one centimetre in size compatible with small staphylococcal abscesses (Fig. 1). The CT scan of the abdomen was normal
column17: with no presence of adenopathy or fluid in the free cavity. The bone scan showed intensely increased osteogenic activity at the level of the sternal joint compatible with arthritis at that level. An MRI of the sternum was performed. There was gadolinium uptake at the joint of the manubrium with the sternal body
column18: extending to the middle of the manubrium and the proximal third of the sternal body
column19: with enlargement and uptake in the adjacent soft tissues
column20: both anterior and posterior. These findings were compatible with arthritis at that level and highly suggestive of osteomyelitis. There were no signs of bone destruction. The clinical course was good with antibiotic treatment consisting of intravenous (IV) cloxacillin for 15 days at a dose of 2 g/6 hours and IV gentamicin for 7 days at a dose of 5 mg/kg/24 hours. He did not require intensive care at any time during his evolution. Subsequently
column21: oral treatment with rifampicin (dose of 600 mg/24 h) and levofloxacin (dose of 500 mg
column22: every 24 h) was continued for two months. The parasternal dermal lesion took five weeks to disappear. To rule out primary immunodeficiency
column23: the patient underwent a screening test with the following results: normal complement levels
column24: lymphocyte subpopulations and markers
column25: granulocyte oxidative capacity and lymphocyte function (the latter with expression of activation markers in response to different stimuli). Protective levels for specific IgG against tetanus toxoid
column26: Haemophilus By pneumococcal capsular polysaccharide. Slightly elevated levels of IgE and IgG4 with normality in the remaining immunoglobulins and IgG subclasses (IgE = 170 IU/l
column27: normal range: 0-100 IU/l; Ig G4 = 3
column28: 910 mg/l
column29: normal range: 80-1
column30: 400 mg/l). Isohemagglutinin titres could not be assessed due to lack of samples. This study was performed when the patient was discharged and two months after the onset of the disease.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 78-year-old woman
column2: weighing 40 kg and 1.65 m tall
column3: with a history of gastrectomy for gastric ulcer with Billroth II reconstruction more than 30 years ago
column4: which was subsequently converted to Roux-en-Y due to alkaline reflux. One year later
column5: he began to suffer from subocclusive symptoms
column6: requiring surgery for intestinal obstruction. Secondary malnutrition with severe hypoalbuminaemia
column7: severe chronic anaemia
column8: pressure ulcers in the sacral region and heels
column9: urinary incontinence and immobility syndrome. He also had renal TB more than 20 years ago
column10: with repeated pyelonephritis
column11: which required surgery due to ureteral stenosis. He was admitted for anaemia with a haemoglobin of 4.8 g/dl (VN: 12-18 g/dl) secondary to gastrointestinal bleeding. He presented severe protein-calorie malnutrition (BMI: 14.7 kg/m2)
column12: with albumin of 2.48 g/dl (VN: 3.30-5.20 g/dl). On admission she had a urinary catheter with urine in a purple collection bag. Three months earlier
column13: she had been admitted for anasarca symptoms related to malnutrition due to malabsorptive syndrome
column14: and at that time she was started on hypercaloric/hyperproteic nutritional supplements (Fortimel® 1 every 8 hours). Table I shows the improvement in the biochemical nutritional markers from this first admission and the start of the nutritional supplements until discharge from hospital. During the first admission
column15: the patient required bladder catheterisation for diuresis control
column16: which was subsequently maintained to promote healing of the ulcers in the sacral region. Shortly before discharge
column17: purple urine was observed in the bladder catheter bag
column18: so fosfomycin was empirically administered in a long regimen due to suspicion of urinary tract infection. On admission
column19: the persistence of the purple colour of the urine in the bladder catheter bag was observed despite antibiotic treatment. The patient describes having noticed this change in colour since previous discharge and that it persists when the catheter is changed
column20: reappearing three or four days after each change. She did not present fever or leukocytosis at any time. The biochemical analysis of the urine shows an alkaline pH (8.5)
column21: which can also be observed in the analyses of previous months. In addition
column22: the sediment shows magnesium ammonium phosphate crystals
column23: 10-25 red blood cells per field
column24: 10-25 leukocytes per field and abundant bacteriuria. The nitrite reaction was negative. Urine culture isolated Proteus vulgaris
column25: resistant to fosfomycin. Treatment was started with ciprofloxacin (sensitive according to the antibiogram) and the bladder catheter was changed. After 48 hours the urine was normal in colour.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 79-year-old woman with no past history of interest consulted for diarrhoea and general syndrome of one year's duration. Physical examination revealed a palpable mass in the right iliac fossa which was confirmed by simple abdominal X-ray. An abdominal CT scan revealed the presence of a large hepatic mass with exophytic growth towards the right iliac fossa suggestive of hepatocarcinoma. The pancreas
column2: spleen
column3: kidneys
column4: uterus and ovaries were normal. Hepatotropic virus serologies were negative and serum alpha-fetoprotein levels were within normal limits. A fine needle puncture-aspiration of the lesion yielded material
column5: histological examination of which showed a well-differentiated hepatocarcinoma. Once surgical resection was ruled out due to the size of the tumour and suspicion of vascular invasion
column6: treatment with chemoembolisation was started with good results. At present
column7: after six months of follow-up
column8: the patient is asymptomatic.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 54-year-old man
column2: smoker of 30 cigarettes a day. He first consulted the urology department in May 2000 for lower urinary tract infection and left renal colic. Rectal examination revealed a fixed
column3: stony
column4: irregular prostate in both lobes. Ultrasonography shows no alterations of interest
column5: except for an enlarged prostate for his age (prostate weighing approximately 65 grams). The PSA is 223. Prostate biopsy revealed 6 markedly infiltrated cylinders of adenocarcinoma Gleason VII. A staging bone scan was performed
column6: which showed no evidence of bone pathology
column7: and complete androgen blockade with antiandrogens and LH-RH analogues was initiated (August 2000). During follow-up
column8: PSA levels gradually increased (January 2001: 0.5
column9: August 2001: 0.7
column10: February 2002: 6.4
column12: without the patient noticing any worsening of his general condition. In February and April 2002
column13: he visited the emergency department for two episodes of haematuria and urinary retention
column14: requiring bladder catheterisation for a month. His obstructive symptoms progressively worsened over two months
column15: reaching the point of almost dribbling urine in June 2002. The urine flow study in May 2002 showed a peak flow of 2 ml/sec
column16: with a residual of 80 ml. Due to this clearly obstructive worsening of his disease
column17: transurethral resection of the prostate was proposed. In July 2002
column18: when the resector was introduced to perform the resection of the prostate
column19: a penile urethra full of 0.5-1 cm polypoid mamelon formations was observed
column20: which made entry into the bladder difficult
column21: as they reduced the urethral calibre and bled when rubbed. The rest of the bulbar and prostatic urethra is normal
column22: the latter being somewhat unstructured. T.U.R. was not performed because it was difficult to see.  In July 2002
column23: after finding a PSA of 22
column24: antiandrogens were withdrawn
column25: keeping the analogues and including the patient in a trial with Atrasentan (M00- 244). The persistence of severe obstructive symptoms justified a resection of the urethral mamelons and the prostate
column26: and both samples were sent separately to the anatomical pathology department to obtain histological affiliation of the urethral mamelons. Bladder catheterisation was maintained for 3 weeks. The histological diagnosis of the urethral tissue was: masses formed exclusively by a Gleason X adenocarcinoma. Regarding the prostate tissue itself
column27: the diagnosis was the same. At present
column28: the patient is in excellent general condition
column29: attending the relevant consultations according to the trial protocol
column30: with no symptoms derived from his illness.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 52-year-old man
column2: weighing 240 kg and with a BMI of 74 kg/m2
column3: was admitted to hospital with a diagnosis of ischaemic stroke. As pathological history of interest
column4: the patient had presented in the past with deep vein thromboembolism
column5: for which reason he was prescribed anticoagulant therapy at home with Rivaroxaban. The Emergency Department suggested the possibility of fibrinolytic treatment with alteplase. However
column6: after examination
column7: this intervention was rejected
column8: as the patient was at the limit of the time interval
column9: had 23 points on the NIHSS (National Institute of Health Stroke Scale) and the time of the last intake of Rivaroxaban was unknown. After admission to the ICU for monitoring and neurological surveillance
column10: it was decided to start treatment with enoxaparin as anticoagulant therapy. For this purpose
column11: the Intensive Care Medicine Department contacted the Pharmacy Department to find out the most appropriate dosage given the patient's extreme obesity2 (BMI > 40 kg/m2). For safety reasons
column12: given the scarcity of data on the subject
column13: it was decided to start treatment at a dose of 0.7 mg/kg/12 h subcutaneously (enoxaparin 160 mg/12 h) to avoid bleeding and as this was the maximum dose evaluated in various clinical trials3-5. 3-5 In addition
column14: monitoring of anti-Xa factor was established to establish the final dose.  Four hours after administration of the third dose
column15: the anti-Xa factor concentration in blood was 0.37 IU/mL. When it was between 0.35-0.49 IU/mL
column16: the dose was increased by ≈10% (170 mg/12 h). Four hours after the next dose
column17: the anti-Xa factor concentration was 0.59 IU/mL
column18: and at 24 hours it was 0.48 IU/mL. In view of this result
column19: the dose was increased
column20: reaching 180 mg/12 h. Finally
column21: the next determination obtained a value of 0.84 IU/mL
column22: placing us within the therapeutic range and setting the optimal dose for our patient at 0.75 mg/kg/12 h.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 56 year old patient
column2: treated for cancer of the left lingual border by left glossectomy and left cervical lymphadenectomy
column3: pT4N2bM0 positive surgical border
column4: receiving concurrent adjuvant radiochemotherapy (cisplatin
column5: three-dimensional conformal radiotherapy) (66Gy tumour bed
column6: 54Gy cervical chains) which ended in March 2006. In November 2007 (18 months) we observed a right laterocervical mass
column7: level II
column8: 4cm and 29mm in CT. Negative extension study. Pathological anatomy: carcinoma. Considered unresectable by the Head and Neck Tumour Committee (CTCC) due to doubts about infiltration of the sternocleidomastoid muscle
column9: we decided on chemotherapy (cisplatin six cycles) and re-evaluation. In May 2008 cervical MRI showed partial remission (24mm). After CTCC assessment
column10: we decided to perform a right modified functional cervical lymphadenectomy with resection of the jugular vein and spinal nerve encompassed by the tumour mass
column11: followed by interstitial HDRBT (June 2008)
column12: placing the vectors in the surgical procedure. After total excision
column13: the tumour bed and organs at risk (carotid artery
column14: brachial plexus) were identified by the surgeon and oncologist. We used a single-plane implant with five plastic tubes (separated by 1cm to minimise the risk of vascular toxicity) and Nucletron® comfort buttons (catheter-skin fixation). We used helical CT slices (5mm) for therapeutic simulation. Pathology showed metastasis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in 4 of 7 resected nodes
column15: all with extranodal infiltration. The HDRBT planning volume was defined as 5mm from the centre of the catheter. The total dose of 34Gy (10 fractions of 3.4Gy
column16: 2 per day [6 hours apart]
column17: five consecutive days)
column18: was started five days after surgery.  As a multidisciplinary follow-up we evaluated: functional status
column19: physical examination
column20: toxicity
column21: TSH value
column22: and cervical CT scan. In February 2011
column23: the patient is free of disease
column24: in good general condition
column25: without pain
column26: as chronic toxicity: grade I soft tissue fibrosis (National Cancer Institute criteria [version 3.0]).   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 50-year-old man underwent a Scopinaro biliopancreatic diversion in January 2004 due to morbid obesity. The patient presents with hepatic steatosis and malabsorptive syndrome. He is being treated with vitamin B12 for chronic anaemia and vitamin K for decreased prothrombin activity. In January 2006 he underwent pyeloinfundibulonephrolithotomy with postoperative urinary fistula. In April 2006
column2: the patient was referred to the ophthalmology department for night blindness progressive over 3 months. The patient also reported a foreign body sensation and red eye. On examination the visual acuity was unity in both eyes. Slit lamp examination showed a very decreased BUT
column3: conjunctival xerosis and Bitot spots in both eyes. Fine corneal conjunctival epithelial stippling could also be seen on fluorescein staining. In the Schirmer I test under anaesthesia
column4: values greater than 15 mm were observed. Ophthalmoscopically
column5: there was whitish mottling in the mid-periphery without macular involvement. The plasma retinol level was 0.07 mg/l (normal level 0.30-0.8 mg/l).  Given the potential severity of the condition
column6: oral treatment with vitamin A and pancreatic enzymes was started to promote its absorption while awaiting intramuscular treatment
column7: with little improvement. Concomitantly
column8: due to complicated nephrolithiasis (intrarenal abscess)
column9: the patient underwent a nephrectomy with severe bleeding
column10: requiring five red blood cell concentrates. After this procedure
column11: the patient reported a slight improvement in his symptoms
column12: despite having stopped oral treatment due to post-surgical fasting. Finally
column14: 000 IU of intramuscular vitamin A was administered
column15: achieving an immediate improvement in the subjective symptoms
column16: although the ophthalmoscopic manifestations took three months to disappear.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Patient aged 86 years
column2: retired construction worker
column3: with no previous medical or surgical history
column4: who consulted for occasional episodes of dizziness. Physical examination revealed an irregular pulse rate of 92 per minute
column5: blood pressure of 110 / 80
column6: normal cardio-pulmonary examination and a BMI (Body Mass Index) of 26. Abdominal examination revealed a painless mass in the right flank
column7: which moved with respiratory movements. Preoperative evaluation shows an electrocardiogram with a complete arrhythmia due to atrial fibrillation
column8: normal haemogram with a sedimentation rate of 36 mm/hr
column9: Creatinine of 1.03 mg/dl
column10: normal albumin and total protein
column11: and normal liver function. A CT scan of the abdomen showed a multilocular cystic mass 12 cm in diameter in the lower pole of the right kidney.  With the diagnosis of a right renal tumour
column12: the risks of surgery were discussed with the patient and family
column13: who agreed to the procedure. Three weeks after diagnosis
column14: a laparoscopic hand-assisted radical nephrectomy was performed
column15: indicated by the size of the tumour mass. The surgical procedure was performed with the placement of 4 trocars. Two 10 mm trocars
column16: one right subcostal and one right pararectal at the level of the umbilicus
column17: the latter for insertion of the camera. Two 5 mm trocars are also placed in the epigastrium to separate the liver. The surgeon's hand is introduced through an oblique incision in the right iliac fossa. Radical nephrectomy is performed in the usual way preserving the adrenal gland. The kidney is placed in a polyethylene bag and removed through the iliac fossa incision.  Surgical time was 100 minutes
column18: with estimated bleeding of less than 100 ml. There were no intraoperative or postoperative haemodynamic alterations.  The immediate postoperative period evolved without complications
column19: requiring non-steroidal analgesics (Ketorolac) for pain control. Medical discharge was indicated 36 hours after surgery. In the outpatient control 9 days after surgery the patient was asymptomatic and his tests showed a haemoglobin of 13.7 mg/dl
column20: creatinine of 1.74 mg/dl and urea nitrogen of 23.0 mg/dl. The biopsy was reported as kidney and perirenal adipose tissue which together weighed 1
column21: 400 g. Towards the lower pole and in intimate contact with the kidney there was a 9.5 cm tumour
column22: firm in consistency
column23: which on section showed extensive cystic areas
column24: yellow-orange
column25: softened
column26: necrotic
column27: with haemorrhagic content and which did not penetrate the renal capsule. On the periphery of the tumour there were well-defined
column28: pale yellow
column29: adipose-like tumour areas
column30: which together constituted a tumour measuring 15 cm in diameter and which were in close contact with the surgical section
column31: separated from it by a thin sheet of fibrous tissue 0.1 cm thick.  On histological examination the renal parenchyma showed preserved architecture. The central tumoural portion showed a hypercellular neoplastic proliferation of spindle-shaped
column32: stellate
column33: epitheloid cells
column34: some giant
column35: with scanty
column36: poorly demarcated cytoplasm
column37: irregular nuclei with prominent nucleoli and high mitotic rate; the cells were arranged in sheets amidst a moderately abundant myxoid stroma in some areas with G3 myxofibrosarcoma (myxoid variant malignant fibrohistiocytoma). In the peripheral portions
column38: the tumour had a clearly better differentiated adipose appearance with G1-2 myxoliposarcoma features. The adipose tumour was separated from the surgical section by a thin sheet of fibrous tissue 1 mm thick. The pathology report concluded that it was a perirenal myxoliposarcoma with indifferentiation towards a G3 myxofibrosarcoma (malignant fibrohistiocytoma myxoid variant). The patient is currently asymptomatic and with stable renal function 9 months after surgery.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 78-year-old man
column2: carpenter
column3: ex-smoker for 22 years
column4: with a history of hypertension
column5: dyslipidaemia and ischaemic heart disease due to acute myocardial infarction that required double coronary bypass surgery. The patient underwent surgery for colon neoplasia with the anatomopathological result of stage III adenocarcinoma (pT3pN2M0). Given the patient's pathological history
column6: the use of fluoropyrimidines is not recommended. For this reason
column7: adjuvant chemotherapy treatment was started according to the TOMOX scheme at adjusted doses (raltitrexed 2.5 mg/m2 and oxaliplatin 100 mg/m2 every 3 weeks). A total of 8 cycles are planned. Tolerance is good. At the follow-up visit prior to the seventh cycle
column8: the patient reported having received antibiotic treatment the previous days for a lower respiratory tract infection diagnosed by his family doctor. He was afebrile
column9: with grade II asthenia and mild deterioration of renal function
column10: so it was decided to postpone the cycle. At that time
column11: the total accumulated doses of raltitrexed and oxaliplatin were 26 mg and 1
column12: 040 mg respectively. Forty-eight hours after this last visit
column13: the patient came to the emergency department with a fever of 38.5oC and dyspnoea on minimal effort. Arterial blood gas analysis showed parameters compatible with severe respiratory failure. Chest X-ray showed bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and dubious condensation in the right lower lobe. The patient was admitted on suspicion of severe pneumonia
column14: and empirical broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy and non-invasive mechanical ventilation were started. Echocardiography ruled out pulmonary thromboembolism. After 48h
column15: due to respiratory worsening
column16: the patient was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU)
column17: requiring endotracheal intubation. The patient was classified as severe respiratory failure secondary to community-acquired pneumonia without isolated germ vs. pulmonary toxicity due to cytostatics associated with adult respiratory distress syndrome. Interactions with the patient's chronic medication were ruled out. The results of microbiological studies (blood and sputum) as well as serology for atypical microorganisms were all negative. Chest CT scan showed a diffuse interstitial pneumonitis component. In view of these results
column18: and given the patient's clinical course
column19: it was decided to initiate high-dose corticosteroid treatment (prednisone 1mg/kg/day)
column20: on suspicion of pulmonary toxicity to cytostatics. The patient's evolution was torpid
column21: and he died after 17 days in the ICU.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 51-year-old man with ileocolic Crohn's disease of long evolution
column2: with multiple complications due to flares
column3: who required intestinal resection surgery and was left with a terminal ileostomy in 2009. This year NPD was started using a fully implanted intravascular device. He was being treated with Infliximab and corticosteroids. The following year he was admitted on several occasions for febrile syndrome associated with abdominal pain
column4: without an obvious source and the disease itself was considered to be the origin. During these hospitalisations
column5: Staphylococcus epidermidis was isolated in several blood cultures. The catheter was also replaced due to breakage
column6: removing only the reservoir and the proximal portion of the catheter as the distal portion was fixed to the tissue
column7: so that a fragment remained lodged inside the superior vena cava. In February 2011
column8: she presented with a similar condition with fever for 11 days and abdominal pain that progressed to septic shock and she was admitted to the ICU. A chest X-ray showed that the abandoned fragment of the catheter was located from the superior vena cava to the right ventricle. The study was completed with an echocardiogram which showed vegetations over the catheter protruding from the atrium into the ventricle. With the diagnosis of catheter endocarditis
column9: antibiotic treatment with Daptomycin and Rifampicin was started
column10: taking into account previous isolations of Staphylococcus epidermidis
column11: and cardiac surgery was performed to remove both catheters.  Initially the patient developed multi-organ dysfunction with no control of the septic picture despite antibiotic treatment. A cranial and thoraco-abdominal CT scan was performed to look for other foci of infection with the following findings: subarachnoid haemorrhage
column12: patchy condensations in the right lung and several splenic infarctions
column13: all compatible with multiple septic emboli. Several isolates were found in the surgical specimen: Staphylococcus epidermidis in the functioning catheter and polymicrobial growth in the catheter with vegetation. In this case
column14: Staphylococcus epidermidis
column15: Ochrobactrum anthropi and a fungus identified at the National Microbiology Centre in Majadahonda as Trichorderma longibrachiatum were isolated. With these results
column16: the antibiotic treatment was modified to Linezolid
column17: Imipenem and Caspofungin
column18: and the septic picture was finally controlled. The patient had a torpid evolution with the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation and tracheostomy
column19: pneumonia associated with mechanical ventilation due to Acinetobacter baumannii and polyneuropathy of the critical patient. After an ICU stay of 45 days
column20: all these processes were resolved and he was transferred to the ward where he completed his recovery.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the clinical case of a 25-year-old male patient who came for consultation due to repeated episodes of pain and inflammation around the lower left semi-included third molar. The medical history does not include any medical history of interest
column2: the patient does not take any daily medication except antibiotics and anti-inflammatory drugs for the current problem
column3: he is not a smoker and is in perfect health.  After the clinical examination
column4: we requested an orthopantomography as the first diagnostic test. In it we can see how the wisdom tooth in question (38) is in close contact with the NDI canal
column5: detecting radiological signs determined as clear indicators of high risk of injury to the nerve during extraction manoeuvres. Thus
column6: curvatures are observed in the roots
column7: darkening around the apices (mesial root) and an effacement of the upper cortex of the canal in contact with the distal root. Although the orthopantomography showed a fairly clear image
column8: we decided to request a CT scan in order to plan the case correctly before deciding on the therapeutic procedure. In the CT images we verified that the contact between the wisdom tooth and the NDI is real and that
column9: therefore
column10: the risk of damaging it during extraction is high.  In this situation
column11: we inform the patient of the possibility of performing a coronectomy or partial extraction of the symptomatic third molar. With this technique we aim to eliminate the clinical symptoms caused by pericoronaritis
column12: as we achieve a direct closure of the wound and the roots are included
column13: preserving the integrity of the NDI. The patient was informed of the possibility of an infectious complication of pulpal cause
column14: which would force us to re-enter to complete the extraction. Re-entry would also be necessary if
column15: in the long term
column16: root migration were to occur
column17: and the roots were to return to generate clinical pericoronaritis due to exposure. Only
column18: if this occurs
column19: the relationship of the roots to the NDI would probably no longer be as clear
column20: and the extraction
column21: therefore
column22: not as compromised. After obtaining the patient's informed consent
column23: we decided to perform the coronectomy using the following surgical technique: Administration of antibiotic prophylaxis. Bayonet incision and lifting of a full-thickness flap similar to the one used for complete extraction of a wisdom tooth. Cutting of the crown with a fissure drill from the buccal table
column24: following an angulation of approximately 45°. This section is complete so as not to exert force on the roots with the drills
column25: which requires being very careful when approaching the lingual table so as not to injure the lingual nerve. Subsequently
column26: further tooth tissue is removed
column27: either with the same fissure bur or with a round bur from above. The latter is slightly easier than with the fissure drill. In this way
column28: the section is at least 3 mm below the bone ridges. The aim is to allow the bone to regenerate over the roots and to enclose them in the jaw. The exposed root surface should not be treated. Finally
column29: the remains of the follicle are removed
column30: without mobilising the roots
column31: the remaining tooth and the wound is sutured with loose stitches that are removed in one or two weeks. Radiological check-ups should be carried out at one month
column32: six months and annually.  All these steps were carried out in our case
column33: and the patient has not presented any complications in one year after the intervention.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 42 year old female patient
column2: with no personal history of interest
column3: was referred by her GP to the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Department of the Hospital Universitario Virgen de las Nieves in Granada for presenting multiple papillomatous lesions on the upper lip which
column4: according to the patient
column5: had been present for approximately fifteen years. The patient's intraoral examination also revealed the presence of a scrotal tongue. Under local anaesthesia and in two surgical procedures
column6: the lesions were completely excised. Pathological examination of the lesions classified them as fibropapillomas.  Due to the characteristic cobblestone appearance of the mucosal lesions
column7: accompanied in the systemic exploration by cutaneous trichilemmomas in acral regions
column8: the long period of evolution of the lesions and the presence of a direct family history (mother who died of thyroid neoplasia at the age of 49 with the presence of the same type of lesions on the labial mucosa
column9: sister with non-filial mammary pathology
column10: and sister with a non-filial mammary pathology)
column11: the patient was diagnosed with fibropapillomas
column12: sister with unaffiliated breast pathology and daughter operated on for papillary thyroid carcinoma) it was decided to refer the patient to the Gynaecology Department for screening for neoplastic breast pathology
column13: given the strong suspicion
column14: among the differential diagnoses proposed
column15: of Cowden's syndrome.  At the gynaecology department of our hospital
column16: the patient was diagnosed with bilateral fibrocystic breast disease and infiltrating ductal carcinoma grade GII of the left breast
column17: requiring lumpectomy plus homolateral axillary emptying and complementary treatment with postoperative chemo-radiotherapy. Given the clinical diagnosis of multiple hamartoma genodermatosis (the patient had one pathognomonic lesion
column18: one major criterion and three minor criteria)
column19: a complete systemic tumour screening process was initiated. The patient was evaluated in the Digestive Service
column20: where the presence of asymptomatic polyps in the rectal and colonic mucosa was detected and she was referred to the Endocrinology Service for evaluation of progressive thyroid enlargement associated with clinical hyperthyroidism. After ruling out malignancy by cytohistological study
column21: the patient was operated on by the Endocrine Surgery Service and underwent total thyroidectomy. The conclusive anatomopathological result diagnosed the lesion as a multinodular colloid goitre. Five months after the thyroid surgery and after a routine abdominopelvic ultrasound scan
column22: a mass was detected in the right kidney which
column23: after a CT scan
column24: showed radiological characteristics of malignancy. Referred to the Urology Department
column25: it was decided to perform a radical right nephrectomy plus supracaval lymphadenectomy. Histological study of the surgical specimen diagnosed the lesion as clear cell and granular renal carcinoma with a mainly tubular component. No additional post-surgical treatment was required. At present
column26: the patient has a progressive decrease in visual acuity which is not being studied by the Ophthalmology Department. All the neoplastic processes diagnosed and treated were detected in early stages. At the moment the patient is in complete remission of all the tumour pathology diagnosed and treated. Despite having a clear clinical diagnosis almost from the beginning
column27: the patient has been studied at the National Centre for Oncological Research [Department of Human Genetics]
column28: confirming definitively that she is a carrier of the c1093lnaGGAT mutation in the PTEN gene
column29: which ratifies the genetic diagnosis of Cowden Syndrome. The study has been extended to the rest of the first-degree relatives in order to carry out an adequate screening and initiate a close clinical follow-up if necessary.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 69-year-old man with a history of stage D2 prostate adenocarcinoma with multiple bone metastases who had received a month and a half earlier chemotherapy treatment with mitoxontrone and prednisone with clinical and analytical response. His personal history included surgery for a pulmonary hydatid cyst 50 years ago that required transfusion of blood products
column2: left iliofemoral bypass in 1991 due to chronic arterial ischaemia and a 3 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm under follow-up. He was admitted for asthenia
column3: anorexia
column4: pruritus and mucocutaneous jaundice
column5: with choluria and acholia of two weeks' evolution. Physical examination revealed mucocutaneous jaundice
column6: hepatomegaly at about 23 cm of the right costal margin
column7: painful on deep palpation
column8: without peritonism. Blood tests showed: Hb 13.5
column9: leukocytes 3
column10: 900 (lymphocytes 53%)
column11: platelets 159.000
column12: prothrombin activity 53%
column13: INR 1.58
column14: fibrinogen 221
column15: cephalin time 42.9
column16: urea 38
column17: creatinine 0.8
column18: glucose 110
column19: total protein 6.3
column20: GOT 904
column21: GPT 990
column22: total bilirubin 10.7 (direct 7.2)
column23: GGT 399
column24: alkaline phosphatase 349
column25: LDH 905. HIV serology negative. HAV IgM negative
column26: HBsAg+
column27: antiHBs-
column28: lgM anticore+
column29: HBeAg+ and antiHBe-. HCV markers negative. HBV DNA positive.  Abdominal ultrasound showed no relevant findings except for a normal sized liver with diffusely increased echogenicity without focal lesions
column30: vascular permeability or signs of portal hypertension. An uncomplicated transjugular liver biopsy was performed and the diagnosis was acute hepatitis of viral aetiology
column31: with regenerative changes and mild portal fibrosis. There were areas of hepatocyte collapse and bridging necrosis. Given the high probability of fulminant hepatic failure due to his underlying disease
column32: it was decided to administer adefovir dipivoxil on a compassionate use basis for the control of acute viral hepatitis. After initiation of treatment
column33: the patient experienced a favourable clinical course with progressive normalisation of liver function. HBV DNA was negative two months after the start of treatment. Three months after treatment
column34: the control analysis showed a total bilirubin of 1.1
column35: GOT 36
column36: GPT 25
column37: GGT 72 FA 426
column38: and second-line chemotherapy treatment with docetaxel could begin due to elevated PSA and reappearance of pain in the dorsal spine and right shoulder.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 35-year-old woman
column2: with no previous history of interest
column3: presented with abdominal pain
column4: diarrhoea and constitutional syndrome
column5: which appeared a few weeks after her first birth; the previous pregnancy had passed without complications. She was studied in the Digestive System Section and was diagnosed with CD as she met the diagnostic criteria: 1) high titre of anti-transglutaminase antibodies; and 2) intestinal biopsy with villous atrophy in the duodenum and crypt hyperplasia. Shortly after the aforementioned clinical manifestations
column6: she presented with polyarthralgia of medium-sized joints
column7: predominantly in the carpus and tarsus
column8: together with paraesthesia and skin lesions with pruritic micropapules. She was referred to the nephrology department for detecting proteinuria of +++. Physical examination: blood pressure 104/76 mmHg
column9: BMI 27
column10: minimal oedema in the lower limbs and papules on the elbows and arms. Blood tests: normal haemogram and coagulation
column11: creatinine 0.9 mg/dl
column12: total cholesterol 238 mg/dl
column13: triglycerides 104 mg/dl
column14: total protein 6.5 g/dl and albumin 3.6 g/dl. In the immunological study: ANA
column15: anti-DNA
column16: ANCAS
column17: C3
column18: C4
column19: anticardiolipin antibodies
column20: lupus anticoagulant and cryoglobulins were negative or normal. Serology against HBV
column21: HCV and HIV negative. Anti-tissue transglutaminase IgA antibodies positive to titre 800 U/ml (normal <7 U/ml). Urine: protein 4.4 g/day and sediment with 5 red blood cells per field. Renal ultrasound was normal. Given the persistence of nephrotic proteinuria for several weeks
column22: a percutaneous renal biopsy was performed
column23: the result of which was stage 2 NM
column24: without vascular or interstitial lesions. He received treatment with a gluten-free diet and other conservative measures with statin
column25: aspirin at antiplatelet doses
column26: enalapril and losartan
column27: with no initial response. However
column28: after 12 months of follow-up
column29: simultaneous negativation of anti-transglutaminase antibodies and complete remission of proteinuria was observed
column30: as shown in figure 1. During this time
column31: there were no other signs of systemic disease
column32: except for an increase in TSH levels of 6.6 µU/ml

column1: A 32 year old man came to the emergency department for a recent decrease in vision in the eye of the left eye coinciding with the appearance of a brownish lesion in this eye. His ophthalmological history included a penetrating trauma to the eye three years earlier
column2: which had been sutured in our centre. On examination
column3: visual acuity was 0.1
column4: which improved to 0.5 with steno-opia. Biomicroscopy of the anterior segment showed an iris cyst occupying half of the anterior chamber
column5: the anterior wall of which contacts the corneal endothelium
column6: a 6 mm linear corneal scar that respects the visual axis and a clear lens. The intraocular pressure (IOP) is 14 mmHg in both eyes. The fundus as far as the lesion can be explored is normal
column7: as is the B-mode ocular ultrasound of the posterior segment. The Stratus OCT image shows a thin anterior wall in discontinuous contact with the corneal endothelium and clear contents of the cyst. The lesion was clinically diagnosed as an epithelial iris cyst. The patient was operated by aspiration puncture of the cyst with a 30g needle
column8: viscodissection of the cyst to separate it from the corneal endothelium and reformation of the anterior chamber followed by ab externo photocoagulation in the same surgical act of its collapsed walls using non-confluent
column9: high power
column10: long term impacts until tissue retraction was observed. No intense burns were performed and no confluent treatment was applied to avoid extensive atrophy of the underlying iris. Postoperatively
column11: the patient had moderate intraocular inflammation that responded to hourly topical corticosteroids and formation of a wide posterior synechia at XII h without cataract development and with significant visual improvement. Six months after the operation
column12: the visual acuity was 0.8 and the biomicroscopic examination showed a vertical oval pupil with posterior synechiae from X to II h as the only sequelae. There are no signs of recurrence of the lesion.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 39-year-old woman with a personal history of pulmonary tuberculosis
column2: repeated renal colic and stress urinary incontinence. She attended the emergency department for low back pain and pollakiuria. Abdominal ultrasound showed bilateral ureterohydronephrosis with preserved left renal parenchyma and right kidney with thin
column3: unstructured cortical tissue
column4: as well as renal function with serum creatinine of 1.98 mg/dl. Therefore
column5: a urinary diversion by percutaneous nephrostomy of the left kidney was decided.  A diagnosis of genitourinary tuberculosis was made due to a positive Lowestein culture in the urine evacuated by the nephrostomy and medical treatment was started with Rifampicin
column6: Isoniazid and Pyrazinamide for 2 months and Isoniazid and Rifampicin for a further 4 months. During the outpatient follow-up
column7: a renal scan was performed showing a non-functioning right kidney and the left kidney with preserved morphology and discrete ectasia of the upper calyceal system. An abdominal ultrasound was also obtained which corroborated the findings of the renal scan. The patient discontinued antibiotic treatment and follow-up consultations after 6 months
column8: due to social problems
column9: despite persistent disease in the cultures. One year after diagnosis
column10: medical treatment was restarted and continued for one year with adequate clinical follow-up. Intravenous urography was performed
column11: with a diagnosis of right mastic kidney and stenosis of the last few cms of the left ureter. A right nephrectomy was performed and left uretero-vesical reimplantation was attempted
column12: during which the left ureter was disinserted 1 cm below the pyeloureteral junction
column13: so a permanent left urinary diversion (racket nephrostomy) was decided.  For three years he maintained good renal function and periodic changes of racquet nephrostomy with the evident limitation and affectation of his quality of life. After this time and given the patient's good physical condition and age
column14: reconstruction of the excretory tract with ileum was considered. The preoperative evaluation confirmed complete bladder retraction
column15: so simultaneous replacement of this organ was considered.  The surgical technique consisted of freeing and defunctionalising 60 cm of ileum with opening of the left mesocolon to allow anastomosis of the proximal end of the ileum to the pelvis of the left kidney
column16: with loose sutures and a double J tutor catheter. Subsequently
column17: cystectomy and hysterectomy of the myomatous uterus was performed because the anastomosis between the neobladder and urethra was difficult
column18: with detubulation of 30 cm of distal ileum in isoperistaltic position
column19: forming a "U" shaped neobladder with modified Camey type folding of the final 20 cm.  The postoperative period was uneventful with good clinical evolution and removal of the ureteral tutor 21 days after surgery. Cystogram showing that the bladder suture was watertight
column20: although the presence of vesico-ureteral reflux was observed
column21: with high pressure. After removal of the nephrostomy and bladder catheter
column22: the patient was discharged from hospital with hourly urination and leaks between micturitions
column23: requiring compresses and the Credé manoeuvre to empty the bladder.  Six months later
column24: cystography showed a larger bladder capacity and little reflux
column25: but night-time incontinence persisted.  During the periodic check-ups performed every 6 months
column26: the patient expressed her satisfaction with the results obtained after surgery and her improved quality of life
column27: as she no longer has urinary diversion and urine leaks are scarce and nocturnal. At present
column28: 4 years after the last surgery
column29: she has urination every 2-3 hours with daytime continence and a night-time pad
column30: bladder emptying at the expense of the Credé and Valsalva manoeuvre without subsequent residue
column31: requiring 1 g daily of oral bicarbonate for adequate metabolic control and a plasma Creatinine of 1.1 mg/dl7.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A white female patient aged 66 with a history of gastrointestinal haemorrhage due to peptic ulcer at the age of 42
column2: menopause at the age of 50
column3: osteoporosis
column4: dorsal-lumbar arthrosis
column5: dyslipidaemia
column6: appendectomy. She was usually treated with rabeprazole 10 mg/24 hours
column7: almagate on demand. She consulted for pain and stiffness in proximal areas of the limbs of 1 year of evolution
column8: which in the last 3 months was accompanied by fever
column9: asthenia
column10: anorexia
column11: loss of about 8 kg of weight and a depressive syndrome associated with organic pathology. Physical examination showed a good general condition with a temperature of 37.5ºC
column12: blood pressure was normal

column15: ESR 75 mm

column17: and D-dimers 400 ug/l. On biochemical examination GGT 139 U/L

Chest X-ray showed a fibrous tract with residual appearance in the right lower lobe. Gastroduodenal transit was normal. Abdominal ultrasound and abdominal CT scan were normal. Gastroscopy was normal. Temporal artery biopsy was performed and showed only signs of arteriosclerosis. With the diagnosis of polymyalgia rheumatica
column34: treatment was started with deflazacort 30 mg/24 hours
column35: with improvement and normalisation of haemoglobin
column36: CRP and ESR. Deflazacort was progressively reduced and 7 months after starting treatment the patient was asymptomatic and was on a dose of 6 mg deflazacort per day. When the patient was 69 years old

column38: paroxetine 20 mg/24
column39: gabapentin 400 mg/12 h
column40: omeprazole 20 mg/24
column41: lormetazepam 1 mg/24. A routine check-up had been performed 6 months earlier
column42: the patient was asymptomatic and haemoglobin
column43: ESR and CRP were normal. She consulted for febrile fever and occasionally fever of 38.5 ºC predominantly in the evening with no apparent source
column44: dry cough
column45: anorexia
column46: and diffuse abdominal pain. Physical examination was normal. Blood tests showed haemoglobin 10.4 g/dL
column47: Ht 31.9% (normal MCV
column48: MCH and RDW). ESR 109 mm
column49: and CRP 93 mg/dL. Biochemical analysis showed GGT 220 U/L
column50: GPT 45 U/L
column51: GOT 44 U/L
column52: and ALP 153 U/L
column53: iron 20 ug/dL
column54: and ferritin 441.6 ng/ml. CK. Proteinogram normal. Normal thyroid hormones. Normal folate and cobalamin
column55: normal haptoglobin. Negative direct Coombs' test. Urine sediment. Negative blood cultures

column58: Epstein Barr
column67: hepatitis B and C virus serology negative. Sputum ZN negative. Mantoux test was negative. CEA and beta-2-microglobulin were normal. Ig G 10.60

column72: ANCA and anti LKM negative. Faecal occult blood was negative. Chest X-ray showed cardiomegaly. The spine X-ray showed an area of sclerosis at L4
column73: which in the lumbar spine CT scan corresponded to a bone infarction at L4. There were no significant findings on abdominal ultrasound. Thoracic-abdominal CT showed only a pericardial effusion. Gastroscopy was normal and colonoscopy showed diverticula and internal haemorrhoids.  The ECG showed sinus rhythm Fc 90 x' q in DIII and AVF and lack of septal vector activation. An echocardiogram showed severe anteroposterior pericardial effusion associated with a pattern of poor ventricular relaxation
column74: without haemodynamic compromise. Pericardiocentesis was performed and approximately 200 cc of yellowish serous-fibrinous fluid was obtained
column75: with a gelatinous character that solidified at rest; pericardial fluid analysis showed red blood cells 680/mm3
column80: ADA 18 U/L; pericardial fluid culture was sterile
column81: ZN stain negative; cytology was negative for malignant cells
column83: some inflammatory and mesothelial cells without atypia. The cardiac study was completed with myocardial perfusion scintigraphy which showed no perfusion abnormalities suggestive of myocardial ischaemia or necrosis. A temporal artery biopsy showed a transmural inflammatory infiltrate consisting of a mixture of polymorphonuclear
column84: lymphocytes and giant cells; the infiltrate was accompanied by fracture of the internal elastic band. Treatment with deflazacort at 60 mg/day was started
column85: improving the symptoms in a few days
column86: and the pericardial effusion resolved in 3 months.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O column1: A 40-year-old man attended the emergency department due to the appearance of oedema. He had a family history of a mother with unrelated renal amyloidosis. The mother's renal biopsy report refers to permanganate resistance
column2: which seems to rule out AA amyloidosis
column3: and leads us to consider
column4: at the time the diagnosis was made
column5: the possibility of AL amyloidosis. The patient is not receiving any pharmacological treatment. Physical examination revealed blood pressure of 135/75 mmHg and bimalleolar oedema
column6: with no other data of interest. Laboratory tests confirmed the presence of nephrotic syndrome (serum albumin 2.5 g/dl
column7: cholesterolaemia 275 mg/dl and proteinuria 6 g/24 h)
column8: with no alterations in the sediment and normal glomerular filtration rate. The electrophoretic spectrum in blood and urine
column9: the immunological study and renal ultrasound were normal. A renal biopsy was performed
column10: showing 19 glomeruli with a totally distorted structure due to a nodular hyaline deposit
column11: with positivity for Congo red and thioflavin; the tubules and vessels showed no significant alterations
column12: the result being compatible with amyloidosis. In the study on the paraffin sample
column13: there was marked positivity for AP protein
column14: which is a part of the amyloid substance common in all types of amyloidosis
column15: with negativity for light chains and AA
column16: B2 microglobulin and transthyretin proteins. A complementary study was performed with antibodies against fibrinogen and lysozyme
column17: and the amyloid substance deposits were positive for the A alpha chain of fibrinogen (Afib). However
column18: the genetic study found no mutation in the Afib chain gene
column19: but demonstrated a previously undescribed mutation in the apolipoprotein AI (apo AI) gene. In view of this discrepancy
column20: the biopsy of the mother was analysed and showed glomerular deposition in the cortex and massive deposition at the medullary level. Deposition at the medullary level is not described in Afib amyloidosis
column21: being very characteristic of apo AI. It is concluded that the initial results of immunohistochemistry are not reliable because they were not performed under the appropriate conditions
column22: and the presence of apo AI was subsequently confirmed by the same technique. An extension study was performed
column23: with echocardiography and electromyography
column24: with no evidence of cardiac involvement or autonomic neuropathy. A progressive increase in transaminases was detected
column25: suggestive of liver involvement. These results are consistent with this type of familial amyloidosis
column26: with preferential renal and hepatic involvement. Despite the initial normality
column27: renal function progressively deteriorated to the point of requiring renal replacement therapy within 2 years. The patient was treated with peritoneal dialysis for 4 years until he underwent surgery and a cadaver donor kidney transplant. He had a complicated postoperative period with splenic rupture
column28: in the context of his disease
column29: with amyloid deposition in the spleen
column30: requiring an urgent splenectomy. Finally
column31: the patient was discharged in stable condition.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 5-year-old female patient referred to our department with a diagnosis of oronasal fistula. Her history included bilateral cheiloplasty and palatoplasty of the soft palate at the age of 6 months and palatoplasty of the hard palate at the age of 4 years
column2: with the latter procedure presenting a dehiscence (oronasal fistula) that caused rhinophonia and nasal reflux of food. On intraoral examination we observed an oronasal fistula at the junction of the primary and secondary palate on the left side measuring approximately 12mm x 25mm.  It was planned to close the fistula with an anteriorly based lingual flap due to the size of the defect. Technique Under general anaesthesia with nasotracheal intubation the palatal defect is contoured by taking a tissue margin of approximately 8mm. The mucosa overlying and surrounding the fistula is unfolded and its edges are faced to create a nasal floor. An aluminium template is made with the dimensions of the fistula
column3: from which a slightly larger flap is designed. The lateral edges of the tongue are sutured to a horseshoe-shaped acrylic plate
column4: which is intended to stabilise and support the tongue to facilitate taking the flap.  Once the tongue flap has been obtained
column5: the primary closure of the lingual cruciate area is performed. The flap is then positioned over the oronasal fistula and suturing is started from back to front.  Twenty-one days after surgery a perfusion test was performed
column6: no evidence of ischaemia was observed and the pedicle was removed under local anaesthesia. Satisfactory closure of the fistula was achieved
column7: a small dehiscence occurred in the immediate postoperative period
column8: which closed spontaneously after three months.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 58-year-old man presented with sudden loss of vision in his left eye. The patient had been under follow-up by Internal Medicine and Dermatology for 12 years due to PXE. His MAVC in the OD was 0.6 and in the OI 0.4. No alterations were found in IOP or anterior pole CMB. The FO examination revealed bilateral AEs. In the OD
column2: there was a raised yellowish-grey gliotic lesion and
column3: in the OI
column4: a pigmented triradiate image bordered by orange areas in the macular area
column5: together with a small juxtafoveal lesion
column6: somewhat greyish and slightly raised
column7: surrounded by abundant subretinal haemorrhages
column8: mainly nasal. Suspicion of CNV membrane within a "reticular pattern" retinal dystrophy led us to perform an AFG
column9: where a gliotic eschar was observed in the OD and
column10: in the OI
column11: a hypofluorescent image in the form of a reticulum
column12: in the upper area of which there was a hyperfluorescent lesion with lacy borders that increased in intensity and size in the late stages
column13: thus confirming the previous suspicion. OCT corroborated the diagnosis
column14: showing a discrete elevation of the EPR-choriocapillary band.  The FA of the LA revealed a curious image
column15: as the dystrophy in pattern appeared as the negative of the angiographic image; in other words
column16: the reticulum
column17: which angiographically appeared hypofluorescent
column18: was intensely hyper-FA in FA due to the alteration of the EPR at that level. In this case
column19: the same treatment as in the previous patient was applied according to the protocol described above. A higher VA was achieved
column20: reaching 0.7. Progressive OCT scans showed a progressive decrease in macular thickness and the control AFG showed an improvement in the condition.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 62-year-old woman
column2: hypertensive and hypercholesterolaemic on pharmacological treatment. Diagnosed with stage IV adenocarcinoma of the colon with multiple liver metastases. Under chemotherapy treatment with mFOLFOX 6 + Bevacizumab (oxaliplatin 85 mg/m2 i.v. day 1
column3: leucovorin 200 mg/m2 i.v. day 1

column1: A 58-year-old man presented to his referral hospital in 1999 with a history of chronic intractable diarrhoea accompanied by weight loss. The patient was diagnosed with CD and was placed on a gluten-free diet. He reported no other history of interest and the physical examination was negative. column2: with a good response to the gluten-free diet. The patient's haematological and biochemical analyses

column11: with slight impairment of visual memory. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and positron emission tomography (PET) were normal. column11: which showed a tumour at the right parotid level involving both the superficial and deep lobes
column12: measuring 2.6*3.4*3.4cm and compatible with a metastatic tumour.  The positron emission tomography (PET) scan showed a hypermetabolic lesion at the right parotid level compatible with a metastatic process. After the study by our tumour committee
column13: it was decided that the treatment of choice was radical parotidectomy due to the involvement of both parotid lobes.  The pathological anatomy revealed a mass with a morphological and immunohistochemical pattern compatible with metastasis of renal clear cell carcinoma. For this characterisation it was necessary to use cytokeratins

column18: which resolved without complications. The postoperative evolution was favourable and the patient was discharged from the hospital
column19: and the wounds were monitored in outpatient clinics.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present a 21-year-old homosexual male with no pathological history of interest
column2: who was referred to the gastroenterology department for "anal pruritus of 9 months' duration resistant to the usual treatment". During this time
column3: his doctor had prescribed local treatment with various corticoid creams and hygienic-dietary measures without improvement. Anal examination revealed the presence of a pigmented lesion with slightly verrucous borders in the posterior perianal region. Rectal examination and anuscopy were normal.  A skin biopsy was performed and histology revealed the presence of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis with altered cell maturation
column4: affecting the entire thickness of the dermis. This was compatible with bowenoid papillomatosis (anal intraepithelial neoplasia grade 1). Antibodies to human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) were negative and other immunodeficiencies were ruled out.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 63-year-old man with no past history of interest. He consulted for presenting a nodular lesion in the right dorso-lumbar quadrant of one month's evolution and rapid growth
column2: associated with asthenia and anorexia for the last three months
column3: with a weight loss of 10 kg. He reported no other symptoms. Physical examination revealed only a slight hepatomegaly. On the right dorsal-lumbar region there was a nodular lesion measuring 5x3 cm
column4: purplish in colour
column5: not adhering to deep layers but painful when rubbed or moved.  Laboratory tests showed urea 74 mg/dl
column6: creatinine 1.93 mg/dl and GGT 83 IU/L with normal GOT/GPT. A chest X-ray showed an elevated left diaphragm and aortic elongation
column7: with no other findings. A biopsy of the skin lesion was performed with an anatomopathological diagnosis of adenocarcinoma metastasis. In view of these findings
