column9: which revealed thickening of the oesophago-gastric junction
column10: with left gastric adenopathy >1cm in diameter and liver lesions suggestive of metastasis. Gastroscopy showed a lesion compatible with neoplasia of the cardia. Biopsy revealed adenocarcinoma. Given the diagnosis of metastatic gastric adenocarcinoma
column11: the patient started chemotherapy treatment with cisplatin (70mg/m2 every 21 days) and 5-fluorouracil in a 48-hour continuous infusion every week (3 gr/m2
column12: days 1
column14: 15). This regimen is one of the first-line treatments for this tumour and is included in the guidelines of the Spanish group for the treatment of tumours of the gastrointestinal tract (TTD). After the second cycle
column15: he developed haematological toxicity with febrile neutropenia. He developed septic shock and died in that context.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 76-year-old woman came to our hospital as an emergency patient with a sudden decrease in the visual acuity of her left eye over a 24-hour period. Her personal history included the presence of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis that had required treatment with methotrexate and which had been treated with Infliximab (Remicade®) for 20 months. She had no ophthalmological history of interest. The initial ophthalmological examination was as follows: corrected visual acuity in the right eye (OD): 1.0 and in the left eye (L): 0.15; relative afferent pupillary defect in the left eye; biomicroscopy of the anterior segment showed bilateral cortico-nuclear cataracts; and the fundus showed hard drusen over vascular arcades as well as a normal macula and optic nerve. In view of these findings
column2: laboratory tests and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) were requested
column3: which were normal
column4: and Humphrey 30-2 campimetry was performed
column5: showing generalised depression of sensitivity in the left eye
column6: while the right visual field was normal. The Farnsworth-Munsell colour test of the left eye showed an alteration in the blue-yellow axis.  Suspecting a lesion affecting the left prechiasmatic visual pathway
column7: a cranio-orbital magnetic resonance imaging scan was requested
column8: which showed multiple demyelinating lesions of the subcortical and periventricular white matter with involvement of the callosal-septal junction. Taking into account the irregular morphology of the lesions and their characteristic location
column9: and despite the criterion against age
column10: multiple sclerosis was the first possibility to be considered. However
column11: after consultation with neurology
column12: the possibility of retrobulbar optic neuritis of demyelinating aetiology in relation to treatment with Infliximab was raised. It was decided to discontinue treatment with Infliximab and start treatment with 1g pulses of methylprednisolone for 3 days
column13: with a clear recovery of visual acuity (1.0) and disappearance of the campimetric scotoma in successive check-ups and up to the present time.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 41-year-old man with no toxic habits and a history of lactose intolerance
column2: diagnosed in 2003 with Crohn's disease with an inflammatory pattern and ileal involvement
column3: which had started two years earlier with an episode of uveitis. He is currently in clinical remission without any maintenance treatment. For the last two months he has had an upper respiratory tract cold
column4: accompanied in the last few days by cough
column5: whitish expectoration and fever of 38ºC. Initially diagnosed with right basal pneumonia
column6: he was treated with antibiotics and mucolytics with little improvement. He subsequently presented with dyspnoea
column7: purulent expectoration
column8: asthenia and loss of 8-10 kg. After failing to improve
column9: he was referred to hospital and admitted to the pneumology department. Physical examination revealed pale skin
column10: temperature: 37.2 ºC and pulmonary auscultation with crackles in the right base. -Complementary examinations: - Systematic: ESR: 66 mm 1 hour
column11: leukocytes: 6
column12: 900/ul with normal formula
column13: red blood cells: 4
column15: 000/ul; Hb: 11.9 g/dl; Ht: 35.6%; platelets: 366
column16: 000/ul. Biochemistry: no significant findings. Coagulation: normal. O2 sat: 95%. - Blood cultures negative for anaerobes and aerobes. HIV serology: negative. Sputum bacteriology negative. Urine bacterial Ag: negative for pneumococcus and legionella. - Chest X-ray on admission: alveolar infiltrates in the right base and minimal infiltrates in the left base
column17: which in subsequent radiological controls became migratory to segment 6
column18: also affecting the right middle lobe. Days later
column19: condensation was observed in the right upper lobe
column20: reducing the basal infiltrates. - Spirometry: FVC: 2.52 l (56%); FEV1: 2.23 l (60%); FEV1/VC: 78%; MMEF25-75: 1.96 l (46%): non-obstructive ventilatory failure. - Thoracic CT: extensive parenchymal consolidation in the right upper lobe; resolution consolidation and volume loss in the right middle lobe; partial resolution consolidation in the right lower lobe with image of alveolar infiltrate and partial resolution image in the posterior segment of the left upper lobe.  - Following the results
column21: fibrobronchoscopy was performed with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) and transbronchial biopsy (BTB): no endoluminal lesions or mucosal alteration were observed. BAL microbiology: normal upper airway flora with negative culture of Legionella
column22: Gram
column23: BAAR and fungi. BAL: 80 cells/mm3
column24: 65% macrophages
column25: 25% lymphocytes (increased)
column26: 5% eosinophils and 5% PMN. Lymphocyte populations: CD4/CD8 ratio: 0.87. Transbronchial biopsy: widened interalveolar septa due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis. Alveolar cell hyperplasia with pneumocyte desquamation at the lumen and PAS-negative granular exudate. Myxoid granulation tissue emerging from terminal bronchi into the lumen. No granulomatous lesions or hyaline membranes. All of the above is compatible with organised pneumonia with bronchiolitis obliterans. Treatment with prednisone at a dose of 1 mg/kg/day was started
column27: and the fever subsided and the rest of the symptoms improved. At one month and three months the patient was asymptomatic and radiological controls were normal.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 46-year-old man reported constipation and pain in the upper abdomen of 7 days' duration. Abdominal computed tomography (CT) showed a mass measuring 11 x 12 x 7 cm depending on the descending colon and a left hemicolectomy was performed. Pathology showed a spindle cell tumour with low mitotic activity which
column2: after ultrastructural and immunohistochemical (IHC) examination
column3: was diagnosed as GANT. At 5 months he presented a double recurrence located in the transcavity of the omentum and adjacent to the wall of the cecum which was completely resected. Adjuvant treatment with imatinib 400 mg per day orally was performed. After 24 months of follow-up there have been no recurrences or metastases.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 33-year-old woman
column2: 34 weeks pregnant (third pregnancy) with a controlled pregnancy and no history of interest
column3: was admitted to the emergency department for headaches

column5: with fovea. Laboratory data showed elevated transaminases and bilirubin
column6: and a slight decrease in platelets: red blood cells 4.52; haemoglobin 12 g/dl; haematocrit 4.52; haemoglobin 12 g/dl; haemoglobin 12 g/dl. /dl; haematocrit 35% (these data in a pregnant woman suggest haemoconcentration); platelets 150; coagulation study: normal; creatinine 1.48 mg/dl; aspartate amino transferase (A.S.T.): 885.2 international units (I.U.); alanine amino transferase (A.L.T.): 334 I.U.; total bilirubin: 4.41 mg/dl; proteinuria was 500 mg/dl. column7: affecting both maculae

column11: 800 grams was obtained. After the caesarean section the patient suffered oliguria from which she subsequently recovered. Transaminases
column12: bilirubin
column13: platelets and diuresis normalised

Fundus examination showed persistent but flat macular serous detachments. Optic disc oedema and peripapillary exudative detachment persisted in both eyes. In the right eye there was a bullous detachment with level
column16: located between the inferior vascular arcades

column18: initially bullous. In the early stages of fluorescein angiography

column20: very evident at the peripapillary level. The later stages showed progressive diffusion foci in the subpigmentary and subretinal space

column22: the vessels had a normal appearance

column25: with a visual acuity of 1.0 in both eyes. In the fundus examination only the presence of focal hyper- and hypopigmentation where the retina had been detached was remarkable.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The clinical case is presented of a medical specialist in microbiology
column2: with many years of experience
column3: who accidentally inoculated himself
column4: when performing the antibiogram by the BACTEC MGIT 960 method
column5: with a pure strain of Mycobacterium tuberculosis
column6: isolated from a sputum sample from an ambulant patient of Spanish origin; he pricked himself on the external lateral side of the distal phalanx of the index finger
column7: piercing the glove with the contaminated needle. At the time of inoculation
column8: he immediately treated the wound (washing with soap and water)
column9: and later reported it to the Occupational Risk Prevention Service (SPRL)
column10: where the inoculation was recorded as an occupational accident. At the SPRL
column11: the medical-work history of the injured worker was reviewed and it was noted that she had a positive Mantoux test; analyses and serologies were requested for HCV
column12: HIV and quantified post-vaccination antibodies for hepatitis B; the worker was also informed that if any signs or symptoms compatible with tuberculosis or with problems at the site of inoculation
column13: she should consult the SPRL. Three weeks later
column14: an erythematous papule appeared at the inoculation site
column15: slightly painful on pressure
column16: which grew to a size of 1.5-2 cm
column17: without axillary lymphadenopathy or general symptoms. (Image 3)  Image 3. Biopsy of the lesion  When the worker observed that the lesion did not improve
column18: she made an informal consultation with the Plastic Surgery Department
column19: which requested a biopsy and excision of the lesion. The anatomical and pathological findings were granulomatous dermatitis with occasional necrosis
column20: highly suggestive of tuberculous dermatitis. (Image 4)  Pathological anatomy: granulomatous dermatitis
column21: suggestive of tuberculous dermatitis.  In the microbiological study
column22: dubious acid fast bacilli were observed
column23: and when cultured in BACTEC MGIT 960
column24: the growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis was confirmed. Subsequently
column25: both isolates (from the source and from the injured worker) were studied by MIRU (Mycobacterial interspersed repetitive units)
column26: confirming the identity of both strains. (Image 5)  Image 5. Microbiological study  The diagnosis of cutaneous tuberculosis was confirmed and the worker was referred to the Internal Medicine Department
column27: where
column28: after being assessed
column29: she began anti-tuberculosis treatment with rifampicin 600 mg
column30: 250 mg of isoniazid and 1500 mg of pyrazinamide on an empty stomach for two months
column31: continuing for a further four months with rifampicin 600 mg and isoniazid 300 mg per day. This service also monitored the patient with monthly analyses in which no alterations were detected
column32: good tolerance to the medication was observed
column33: and she was discharged from the hospital 7 months after starting treatment. The SPRL reports the occupational disease in accordance with RD 1299/2006
column34: of 10 November
column35: which approves the list of occupational diseases in the Social Security system and establishes criteria for their notification and registration.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Patient aged 13 years and 11 months with a personal history of thyroglossal cyst operated on at the age of 2 years
column2: obesity under study
column3: who manifested since 2 months before admission: asthenia
column4: headache
column5: anorexia
column6: frequent epistaxis and tachycardia after physical exercise. Examination revealed cutaneous and mucosal pallor
column7: laterocervical and submandibular lymphadenopathy
column8: splenomegaly measuring 6 cm and hepatomegaly measuring 2 cm. Various complementary examinations were requested
column9: including the following: Ht: 28.3%; Hb: 7.2 g/dl; leukocytes: 235
column14: B 7.9%); platelets: 24
column15: 000 mm3; ESR: 70 mm/h; LDH: 1
column16: 686 U/l; uric acid: 8.3 mg/dl; ferritin: 151 ng/dl. In view of the patient's clinical and analytical evolution
column17: a haematological neoplastic process was suspected and a bone marrow aspirate was performed in which 97% of blasts were observed
column18: with marrow infiltration of blast elements. After completing the cytogenetic
column19: molecular
column20: serological
column21: microbiological and immunological studies
column22: a diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)
column23: FAB type L2 was made. Chemotherapy was started according to the SHOP 99 protocol for very high-risk patients
column24: obtaining complete remission at the end of the induction phase. Four months after the consolidation phase
column25: the patient relapses
column26: and the fourth phase of treatment
column27: maintenance therapy
column28: is required to keep the child in remission. The treatment of ALL is carried out according to established protocols (4)
column29: with the child often having to undergo multiple lumbar punctures for chemotherapy administration and spinal cord aspiration for disease control throughout the disease treatment process (5). After obtaining parental consent and explanation of the treatment to the child
column30: sites for lumbar puncture and bone marrow aspiration were chosen. The patient was premedicated with midazolam (Dormicum®) 5 mg v.o. and OTFC transmucosal oral fentanyl citrate (Actiq®) 400 mcg v.o.
column31: and an EMLA® cream dressing was placed on the puncture sites. Oxygen was administered through nasal goggles at 4 l/m
column32: and the electrocardiogram
column33: capnography

column1: An 83-year-old man with advanced Alzheimer's disease
column2: insulin-dependent diabetic of 35 years' duration
column3: who attended our emergency department for ocular pain in the right eye of 2 days' duration. VA could not be measured due to lack of cooperation. column4: with no concomitant infectious or inflammatory process. The patient had no history of trauma. With the diagnosis of a sterile non-traumatic corneal perforation

column7: the active part (yellow part) was immediately applied to the corneal defect
column8: pressing and gently moulding the sponge for 3 minutes with forceps to ensure that it was firmly attached to the lesion.  Without removing the excess material
column9: the eye was occluded. On uncovering
column10: after about 36 hours of occlusion
column11: it was observed that there were no sponge remnants in the area of application and a fibrinoid material occluded the perforating endothelial pore. No sponge debris was found to be displaced or in the conjunctival fornices. A therapeutic lens was applied for safety and topical antibiotic
column12: cycloplegic and medroxyprogesterone treatment was started. Seventy-two hours after application
column13: corneal thinning persisted over the perforation area
column14: with complete closure and good anterior chamber depth. column2: a 73-year-old man was admitted to the internal medicine department with a provisional diagnosis of bone metastasis from an unknown primary tumour. He had lost 15 kg in 18 months and manifested anorexia

column4: left thigh pain and elevated blood concentrations of calcium

column1: An 81-year-old man was referred from the outpatient clinic to our urology department for symptoms of the lower urinary tract. He had a personal history of arterial hypertension treated with angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors
column2: surgery for duodenal ulcus in 1961 and cholecystectomy in 2002. An infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm was diagnosed by chance during the abdomino-pelvic ultrasound scan. The CT scan revealed that it did not affect the iliac bifurcation. The examination also showed that the kidneys had a morphology compatible with horseshoe kidneys
column3: with an isthmus located at the level of the infrarenal abdominal aorta. Our case reveals the most favourable situation
column4: in principle
column5: for the surgical approach
column6: since the aneurysm originates distal
column7: 4 cm from the exit of the main renal arteries
column8: which are two
column9: one for each renal half. There is no additional artery at the level of the isthmus. In successive controls
column10: a progressive increase in the aortic diameter was observed
column11: which
column12: in a control CT scan
column13: had reached a maximum diameter of 8 cm.  In view of these findings
column14: the vascular surgery department decided to consider surgical treatment of the aneurysm. On physical examination
column15: the patient preserved pulses and an expansive abdominal heartbeat was palpated. The rest of the examination was of no interest. As part of the preoperative protocol for aneurysms
column16: a baseline echocardiogram and respiratory function tests were performed
column17: all without significant alterations. A retroperitoneal approach was chosen with resection of the infrarenal aortic aneurysm and aorto-aortic bypass with a 16 mm Hemashield prosthesis
column18: without intraoperative complications. And no lumbar or polar arteries were visualised. The postoperative course was normal
column19: with no complications arising from the procedure
column20: and the patient maintained adequate renal function. At discharge
column21: all pulses were present. The patient was asymptomatic in terms of vascular alteration; he maintained all pulses in the lower extremities
column22: with preserved renal function parameters and a control CT angiography 6 months after the operation showed aorto-aortic bypass without leaks or evidence of areas of aneurysmal dilatation.  An intravenous urography was also performed
column23: showing the kidneys with horseshoe morphology
column24: pyeloureteral junction in the anterior plane without significant alterations
column25: as well as in the collecting systems.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 72-year-old woman with a history of smoking (50 pack-years)
column2: alcoholism and extrinsic asthma who consulted for fever
column3: productive cough and an increase in her usual dyspnoea. Physical examination revealed fever (37.9º C)
column4: tachypnoea and hypoventilation with expiratory wheezing. No visceromegaly or adenopathies were palpable. Laboratory tests showed a mild neutrophilia and mild thrombocytopenia
column5: and sputum culture and Gram and Ziehl-Neelsen stains were negative. Chest X-ray showed a left paracardiac condensation
column6: with air bronchogram
column7: blurring the cardiac silhouette and computed axial tomography (CT) confirmed the existence of a left pulmonary infiltrate
column8: with pleural involvement. With the suspected diagnosis of lingula pneumonia
column9: treatment was started with bronchodilators
column10: oxygen therapy and amoxicillin-clavulanic acid
column11: with clinical improvement and disappearance of the febrile fever. The patient was discharged for follow-up in the pneumology department where
column12: given the persistence of the condensation image
column13: the study was continued. CT-guided fine needle aspiration (FNA) showed a monomorphous lymphoid proliferation
column14: suspicious for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL). A lung biopsy by mini-thoracotomy confirmed the diagnosis of CD 20 positive
column15: bcl-2 positive
column16: p-53 negative small B-cell lymphocytic lymphoma (SBCL).  Biological studies showed a discrete increase in ESR

column18: homogeneous
column19: 5x7 cm
column20: triangular-shaped lung mass with peripheral base and pericardial apex
column21: involving the lingula and left upper lobe

column23: oral treatment was started with pulsed chlorambucil
column24: 40 mg orally on day 1
column25: and prednisone
column26: 100 mg/day for 4 days
column27: every 4 weeks. At the first re-evaluation
column28: after four cycles of chemotherapy
column29: the size of the tumour mass had not changed
column30: so treatment with intravenous polychemotherapy was proposed to the patient
column31: which she refused. Continuous chlorambucil was then started at a dose of 3 mg/day. column32: both WHO grade I
column33: and the dose of chlorambucil was reduced to 1 mg/day. After two years of continued treatment

column1: A 51-year-old woman consulted for a painless
column2: painless and firm tumour on the left upper eyelid that was recurrent and perceptible to the touch. She was also found to have associated blepharochalasis and eyelid bags.  The patient reported a history of transconjunctival excision of a chalazion 2 years earlier
column3: with recurrence of the lesion shortly afterwards. The ocular functional examination was normal. We requested a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the facial mass
column4: in which we found a solid formation in the supero-external region of the orbit
column5: without involvement of the eyeball
column6: with the diagnosis of a presumed lacrimal gland tumour.  We decided
column7: in agreement with the patient
column8: to carry out surgical resection of the tumour and at the same time perform an associated upper and lower cosmetic blepharoplasty. The intraoperative finding of the lesion was a left palpebral formation measuring 1 x 0.8 x 0.5 cm in diameter
column9: with a smooth surface and elastic consistency
column10: which did not invade ocular structures and which we were able to remove completely. The upper blepharoplasty was performed according to the classic technique and the lower blepharoplasty was performed transconjunctivally
column11: with removal of both the upper and lower palpebral bags.  The patient's postoperative evolution was good
column12: without complications

column14: non-infiltrative

column1: Eight-day-old infant whose parents consulted for a poorly healed umbilicus. Personal history: first child born to healthy parents. Born at 39 weeks of gestation by euthecological delivery; Apgar 9/10
column2: weight 2830 grams. No history of interest was reported
column3: nor was the hospital report provided. Examination revealed a wide implantation of the umbilical cord
column4: which had a mucous appearance
column5: and a small tear at the base of the cord
column6: with no signs of local infection. The rest of the physical examination was normal. She reported no accompanying clinical manifestations. Silver nitrate was applied and an appointment was made for a check-up in 48 hours. At the follow-up visit
column7: she was given a discharge report after birth. It shows that the umbilical cord had a cyst
column8: diagnosed in the second trimester prenatal ultrasound and described as a Wharton's jelly cyst measuring 49 x 39 mm. At birth she was assessed by a surgeon
column9: who placed a clamp proximal to the cyst
column10: which was resected. At two days of life
column11: an abdominal ultrasound was performed
column12: which was normal. During admission she remained asymptomatic and was discharged with normal clinical symptoms
column13: except for a small tear at the base of the cord
column14: which did not present complications. At the outpatient follow-up visit
column15: an abundant discharge of clear fluid from the centre of the umbilicus was observed
column16: with no signs of infection. She was referred for assessment by paediatric surgery. The surgeon ligated the umbilical cord
column17: which was almost detached and appeared moist. A fistulous tract was found to be present. A new abdominal ultrasound revealed a tortuous tubular structure communicating with the upper bladder wall and a diagnosis of persistent urachus (permeable urachus type) was made and observation and subsequent re-evaluation was decided. At eight months of life
column18: spontaneous closure had occurred
column19: and subsequent check-ups revealed the absence of urachal stricture. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 28-year-old male patient
column2: with no past history of interest
column3: consulted for a progressive
column4: non-painful left malar tumour that had been noticed for 15 days. He had no history of local trauma. On examination
column5: a hard lesion was palpable on the inferoexternal rim of the left orbit
column6: approximately 1 cm in diameter
column7: with no apparent pulsatility.  Doppler ultrasound reported an expansive
column8: polylobulated malar lesion with partial calcification and no vascular signal. Orbital computed tomography (CT) detected a rounded
column9: well-defined medullary lesion with trabeculated internal structure and cortical expansion without infiltration or periosteal reaction. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) described an expansive malar osteolytic malar lesion measuring 16x10x13mm
column10: with well-defined sclerotic margins
column11: absence of perilesional soft tissue infiltration and intense contrast uptake.  Given the presumptive diagnosis of a low-flow vascular lesion
column12: and given the progressive characteristics of the lesion
column13: it was decided to excise the lesion under general anaesthesia. The lesion was exposed through a left subciliary approach with tail enlargement towards the malar and dissection in planes. After a box osteotomy including a peripheral safety margin of 0.5cm
column14: the defect was reconstructed with chin graft and arched titanium plate. The intercortical gaps were filled with cancellous bone obtained from the donor site. Postoperative radiological controls showed an anatomical reconstruction with good bone consolidation.  Pathological examination revealed dilated vascular spaces lined with endothelium without atypia
column15: concluding an "intraosseous haemangioma". However
column16: the immunohistochemical study was negative for GLUT-1. Therefore
column17: we consider that the correct clinical and immunohistochemical diagnosis is intraosseous venous malformation. After 5 months of follow-up
column18: the patient is completely asymptomatic
column19: with an excellent cosmetic result.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present a 24 year old female patient who consulted the Maxillofacial Surgery Department of the San José Hospital Complex in October 2006
column2: referred from the Dermatology Department of the same centre with a diagnosis of SMR due to an increase in the volume of the lower lip which had not responded to treatment with intralesional and oral corticoids. The patient reports that the enlargement of the lower lip dates back to 2004
column3: which was biopsied in the same year and histopathologically diagnosed as a GCS associated with MDS. Initial treatment consisted of intralesional infiltrations performed in the dermatology department with betamethasone 4 mg and prednisone 0.5 mg without positive results. In her medical history
column4: she reported a history of morbid epilepsy under treatment
column5: mild mental retardation
column6: hypothyroidism
column7: insulin resistance and allergy to iodine. The drugs he uses regularly are Levothyroxine 100 mg 1 tablet/day
column8: Carbamazepine 200 mg 1.5 tablets/day
column9: Metformin 850 mg 1 tablet/day. Physical examination revealed a large increase in the volume of the lower lip
column10: which was everted
column11: associated with a depapillated tongue and the presence of transverse furrows on the dorsum of the tongue compatible with a fissured tongue
column12: as well as a discrete macroglossia.  Treatment consisted of 3 intralesional infiltrations of 1 ml of Kenacort®-A 40 mg (Triamcinolone acetonide) diluted in 1 ml of 2% lidocaine in the lower lip to control post-infiltration pain
column13: at one-week intervals. The patient was monitored for three months
column14: where a marked reduction in the size of the lower lip was observed
column15: but still without achieving an aesthetic size
column16: so a fourth infiltration was performed without improvement. Then a lower lip reduction cheiloplasty was scheduled under general anaesthesia to improve the aesthetics of the patient's lip
column17: with good results that were controlled at one month postoperatively.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 87-year-old woman suffered a right frontal TBI when she accidentally fell in a nursing home. Her known medical history included mitral valve disease
column2: episodes of paroxysmal atrial flutter and haemodynamic angina
column3: and deep vein thrombosis with pulmonary thromboembolism. He was receiving drug treatment with Sintrom®
column4: Acuprel®
column5: Nitroplast®
column6: Trangorex® and Diluton®. As a result of the TBI there was a contused wound in the right ciliary region which was repaired with sutures. The following day
column7: in a period of less than twelve hours
column8: after starting her usual activities (toileting and breakfast)
column9: she experienced a progressive deterioration in her level of consciousness and anisocoria with mydriatic right pupil
column10: for which she was transferred to the emergency department of the local hospital. On admission
column11: Glasgow Glasgow 8-9 and anisocoria were noted. A cranial CT scan was performed (without contrast) which was reported as "chronic DHS with rebleeding" covering the right frontal
column12: temporal and parietal regions; supracallosal and transstentorial herniation; and subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) in the right hemisphere. After her neurosurgical assessment
column13: it was decided not to intervene and to transfer her back to her home
column14: where she died fourteen hours later.  During the examination of the body we found the body of a woman of the aforementioned age. Numerous contusions at different stages of development were observed. The presence of a sutured wound with four stitches in the right ciliary region together with multiple contusions of different colours (reddish and bluish) close to it stands out due to its relation to the facts. A judicial autopsy was carried out thirty-one hours after death. In the internal habitus
column15: at the thoracoabdominal level
column16: various macroscopic findings of interest were observed. The heart weighs 250 g and shows calcified atheroma plaques in the anterior descending and circumflex coronary arteries that reduce the lumen by > 90%
column17: scars from old infarctions in the posterior wall of the left ventricle and papillary muscle
column18: and calcification of the mitral annulus. In the cranial cavity there is right frontotemporoparietal SDH consisting of dark coagulated blood with no evidence of associated fractures. The brain was fixed in formalin for 24 days before completing its macroscopic study
column19: with the following findings: weight 1018 g and in addition to the described DHS
column20: there was an external right subarachnoid haemorrhage; right trans-stentorial herniation furrow and haemorrhage in the midbrain. Coronal sections showed flattening of the right hemisphere
column21: especially the frontal lobe
column22: associated with a 15 mm thick subdural haematoma with a gelatinous appearance in the centre
column23: with no evidence of neomembrane; midline deviation to the left
column24: with collapse of the right lateral ventricle and dilatation of the left; supracallosal herniation and foci of haemorrhage in the right frontal white matter
column25: corpus callosum
column26: right thalamus and right frontal cortex. The midbrain shows extensive haemorrhage in the midline
column27: right paramedial portion and dorsolateral quadrants and
column28: in the pons
column29: foci of haemorrhage can be seen in the floor of the fourth ventricle and cerebellar peduncles.  Samples of subdural haematoma
column30: cortex and white matter from the right parasagittal frontal region
column31: lenticular nucleus
column32: internal capsule
column33: thalamus
column34: corpus callosum
column35: hippocampus
column36: midbrain
column37: cerebellar peduncles
column38: pons and bulb were taken for microscopic analysis. Microscopic examination of the subdural haematoma shows that it consists of well-preserved red blood cells in the periphery and acellular proteinaceous material in the central areas. No haemosiderophages (Perls' stain is negative) and no signs of organisation on the arachnoid side (the dura mater was strongly adherent to the cranial calotte and was not removed for microscopic examination). Given the diagnostic disparity between the CT scan and the autopsy regarding the date of the HSD
column39: the preparations corresponding to the haematoma were re-examined and arachnoid lining around the haematoma was identified in some areas.  In the brain parenchyma adjacent to the haematoma
column40: glial cells with early reactive changes (globoid morphology with eosinophilic cytoplasm) were identified and oedema was observed around the foci of haemorrhage described. In the trunk
column41: occasional axonal beads and spongiosis are observed around the haemorrhages.  Other neuropathological findings
column42: compatible with the patient's age
column43: were the presence of numerous senile plaques throughout the cortex
column44: microcalcifications in the basal ganglia and hippocampus
column45: and neurons with granulovacuolar and neurofibrillary degeneration in the hippocampus. The chemical-toxicological analysis carried out at the INTCF (Dpto. of Madrid) on blood samples was negative for the toxins investigated (barbiturates
column46: benzodiazepines
column47: analgesics -paracetamol
column48: metamizol
column49: tramadol
column50: salicylates-
column51: antidepressants
column52: phenothiazines and analogues
column53: sulphonylurea-type antidiabetics
column54: non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
column55: non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
column56: diuretics
column57: xanthine bases
column58: antiparkinsonian drugs
column63: morphine-derived opioids and ethyl alcohol). Thus
column64: we consider that the sequence of the lesions or pathology found would be as follows: an elderly person with a history of heart disease referred to above
column66: suffers a slight right frontoparietal trauma
column67: which generates a rupture of a pre-existing arachnoid cyst and therefore an acute SDH
column69: entrapment and death. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 25-year-old female patient from Ukraine
column2: diagnosed with diabetes secondary to pancreatic agenesis 5 years ago
column3: admitted to our department from the emergency department for non-acidotic hyperglycaemic ketotic decompensation. Since diagnosis
column4: the patient has had acceptable metabolic control with HbA1c below 7% with dietary treatment and exercise. Her family history includes a diabetic great-grandfather and healthy parents and siblings. In the anamnesis
column5: on admission the patient reported poor metabolic control for the last two months
column6: coinciding with the onset of frequent episodes of urinary tract infections
column7: and recently aggravated by vulvovaginal candidiasis and paronychia on the fingers
column8: with symptoms of polydipsia
column9: intense polyuria and weight loss of 6.4 kg during this period. Physical examination revealed: height 167 cm; weight 38.6 kg; BMI 13.4 kg/m2; BP 120/80 mmHg; HR 116 bpm; saturation 97%. Mandible in lantern jaw. Thyroid grade 0. Normal AC and AP. Abdomen soft and depressible
column10: non-painful
column11: without masses or megaliths. MMII without oedema and preserved peripheral pulses. Vibratory sensitivity
column12: with preserved monofilament and osteotendinous reflexes. Erythematous and pruritic lesions in the vulvar and perianal region suggestive of candidiasis. Paronychia on the fourth finger of the right hand. Extensive diabetic dermopathy on legs and arms. Complementary tests: normal haemogram
column13: ESR 35 mm/h
column14: glucose 552 mg/dL
column15: Cr 0.8 mg/mL
column16: total cholesterol 205 mg/dL
column17: LDL-C 125 mg/dL
column18: HDL-C 58 mg/dL. Normal liver profile except for GOT 54 IU (7-32)
column19: GPT 63 IU (5-31) and GGT 59 (7-32). Albumin/creatinine ratio: 0.6µg/mg. Glucose urine 5567 mg/dL. Urine methylketone 50 mg/dL. HbA1c 16.2%. Basal C-peptide 166 pmol/L (298-2350). Anti-GAD 0.2 KU/L (0-0.9)
column20: anti-IA2 0.2 KU/L (0-1) and anti-insulin (IAA) 77.2 nU/mL (N<40). IgA anti-transglutaminase antibodies 0.82 KU/L (0-10). Anti-TG 149 (0-40) and anti-TPO 13.3 (0-35). TSH 3.1 Gynaecological examination: bicornuate uterus. Fundus examination and normal retinography. Abdominopelvic CT scan with contrast: dorsal agenesis of the pancreas. Abdominal ECHO: multiple cortical cysts of less than 1 cm in the left kidney
column21: diffuse throughout the left renal parenchyma with no evidence of dilatation of the pyelocaliceal system or other findings. Normal right kidney. Absence of pancreatic body and tail. Culture of exudate from the panadizo grew Klebsiella oxytoca and vulvovaginal culture was positive for Candida albicans. With the suspicion of MODY type diabetes
column22: a genetic study was requested by semiquantitative fluorescent PCR
column23: detecting heterozygous deletion of at least exons 1 to 8 of the HNF1 β gene
column24: which is associated with type 5. Treatment was started with insulin glargine and insulin aspart 1.3 U/kg. Fluconazole was administered orally 100 mg/day (10 days) and a vaginal vaginal ovule in a single dose of clotrimazole 400 mg
column25: and the fungal lesions disappeared. Subsequent check-ups showed HbA1c levels of less than 6% with a progressive decrease in insulin to 0.5 U/kg 6 months after admission. Eight months after admission
column26: the diabetic dermopathy disappeared and 18 months after admission
column27: the patient had regained her initial weight and insulin requirements were maintained at 0.5 U/kg. Renal function has remained within normal limits and microalbuminuria is negative. There was only a slight increase in transaminases.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Female patient
column2: 37 years old
column3: black
column4: with a history of sickle cell anaemia and end-stage chronic renal failure
column5: on haemodialysis for 6 years. She had previously presented several episodes of sickle cell crises with the need for multiple transfusions. In November 2010 she underwent renal transplantation from a deceased donor
column6: sharing a RD and an A
column7: with a cold ischaemia time of 15 hours. Induction with alemtuzumab and methylprednisolone boluses was performed. During the transoperative period
column8: the patient was hypotensive
column9: requiring dopamine. Perfusion of the renal graft was slow
column10: with recovery during surgery. Postoperatively
column11: the patient became anuric
column12: with elevated azooses and metabolic acidosis; the peripheral blood smear reported hypochromia
column13: anisocytosis
column14: microcytosis and dianocytosis
column15: high density lipoproteins 677
column16: leukocytes 17
column18: neutrophils 90 %
column19: lymphocytes 8 %
column20: haemoglobin 7.1
column21: haematocrit 21 %
column22: platelets 179
column24: corrected reticulocytes 5.2 %. Graft Doppler reported good vascular perfusion
column25: but high resistance indices. A vaso-occlusive graft crisis was suspected and management with transfusions
column26: hydroxyurea and haemodialysis was initiated. On the fifth day
column27: a biopsy of the renal graft was performed; the most important findings were areas of infarction in peritubular capillaries with the presence of neutrophils and erythrocyte trapping
column28: some of which were sickle-shaped
column29: and positive C4d in 100% of the peritubular capillaries. With these findings
column30: a diagnosis of acute humoral rejection and sickle cell crisis of the graft was made; treatment was carried out with methylprednisolone pulses
column31: plasmapheresis
column32: tacrolimus
column33: mycophenolate and exchange transfusion
column34: the latter as management of the sickle cell crisis. Ten days after transplantation
column35: renal function improved and renal replacement therapy was discontinued. The last control creatinine
column36: four months later
column37: was 1.3 mg/dl.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 58-year-old woman referred for abdominal discomfort. She was operated on for breast carcinoma in 1996. One year later
column2: in a control ultrasound and abdominal CT scan
column3: a multicystic pancreatic mass was discovered
column4: with negative biopsy aspiration puncture for malignant cells. She was asymptomatic until 2000
column5: when she began to experience dull abdominal pain. Physical examination and laboratory tests were rigorously normal. Blood tumour markers (CEA
column6: Ca 125 and Ca 19.9) were negative. Abdominal ultrasound: multiple cystic formations throughout the pancreatic cell
column7: multitabulated
column8: with a solid component and some with microcalcifications
column9: of varying size
column10: the largest being 3 cm
column11: and with no flow inside. All this was compatible with giant pancreatic cystadenoma. Abdominal CT and MRI with contrast confirmed these findings. Fine needle aspiration of one of the cysts was performed and no malignant cells were observed. Tumour markers in the cystic fluid showed Ca 125: 786 IU/ml (vn: 0-35)
column13: and normal CEA. A diagnosis of giant cystadenoma of the pancreas
column14: probably serous
column15: was made. The patient has not presented any clinical or radiological changes since the first imaging study 6 years ago. After discussing this with the patient and with the Surgery Department
column16: both refused surgical treatment for the moment.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A one-and-a-half-month-old girl presented with fever (38°C) of 48 hours' evolution and irritability
column2: associated nasal mucus; on examination she had a small erythematous rash and the rest of the examination was normal. Initial CBC: leukocytes 6310/µl (67% segmented
column3: 6% lancets
column4: 19% lymphocytes
column5: 8% monocytes)
column6: haemoglobin (Hb) 10.9 g/dl
column7: haematocrit (Hto) 29.6%
column8: platelets 492 000/µl
column9: C-reactive protein (CRP) 8.9 mg/l. Lumbar puncture: glucose 51.3 mg/dl
column10: protein 133.9 mg/dl (haemorrhagic fluid). Given the suspicion of severe bacterial infection
column11: she was admitted for intravenous antibiotic treatment with cefotaxime and ampicillin (200 mg/kg/day)
column12: adding acyclovir (60 mg/kg/day) in the following 24 hours to cover the herpes simplex virus. Febrile after 48 hours. On the fourth day he presented irritability
column13: poor colour and general condition
column14: with persistent evanescent rash
column15: and respiratory distress; a control blood test was performed with the following findings: leukocytes 2670/µl (segmented 31%
column16: keys 3%
column17: lymphocytes 47%
column18: atypical lymphocytes 5%
column19: monocytes 11%)
column20: reticulocytes 0.66%
column21: Hb 8.0 g/dl
column23: platelets 131 000/µl. Capillary blood gases: pH 7.32
column24: PCO2 43.3 and HCO3 21.8 mmol/l. Chest X-ray: bilateral alveolar interstitial infiltrates
column25: more striking on the left side
column26: suggestive of acute pulmonary oedema. Given the finding of pancytopenia
column27: samples were taken for parvovirus and enterovirus serology
column28: as well as influenza A serology. High-flow oxygen therapy was started and he was transferred to the paediatric intensive care unit of a tertiary hospital
column29: where he remained for five days.  Immunoglobluin M (IgM) antibodies for parvovirus B19 were positive and IgG negative
column30: leading to a diagnosis of parvovirus B19 infection
column31: respiratory failure and associated pancytopenia. The patient showed progressive improvement on the fifth day of admission
column32: and was discharged on the twelfth day without further complications. The girl's brother subsequently presented with fifth-day erythema infectiosum.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 36-year-old man
column2: with no personal history of interest
column3: who in an ultrasound scan performed due to colicky pain over the right renal fossa
column4: was reported as an intrarenal mass measuring 8-10 cm with echogenic material inside
column5: located in the lower pole of the right kidney
column6: suggesting a complicated renal cyst. Subsequent CT scan showed a solid mass in the lower pole of the right kidney with a maximum diameter of 10 cm
column7: which caused compression of the excretory tract
column8: with no evidence of tumour thrombus in the renal vein or in the cava
column9: suggestive of hypernephroma. Bone scintigraphy with Tc99m-MDP was performed and no pathological bone accumulations were observed.  Based on the data obtained
column10: a radical right nephrectomy was performed
column11: revealing an intraoperative finding of a mass attached to the lower pole of the right kidney (the tumour and the kidney
column12: although close together
column13: were clearly independent on dissection). The anatomo-pathological report of the specimen was a solitary fibrous tumour. The tumour was well demarcated but not encapsulated
column14: without infiltrating the kidney or the renal vessels which were displaced by the large tumour mass. The immunohistochemical study showed positivity for CD34
column15: CD99 and Vimentin
column16: while it was negative for Desmin
column17: Protein S-100
column18: and CAM5.2.  The patient underwent surgery in November 2001. Since then
column19: he has been undergoing outpatient controls in our clinic with biannual ultrasound scans and annual CT scans
column20: with no recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 40-year-old woman
column2: with no relevant pathological history. She attended the primary care clinic for dyspepsia with epigastralgia and retrosternal pyrosis of 10 days' evolution. The anamnesis ruled out dietary transgressions
column3: intake of drugs or gastrolesive substances
column4: and the presence of organic symptoms or clinical alarm data. Physical examination was normal. The patient was diagnosed with dyspepsia that was not investigated. Treatment was started with hygienic-dietary measures and omeprazole 20 mg/day for 4 weeks
column5: and the patient was scheduled for a check-up. The patient reported a slight clinical improvement. The dose of omeprazole was increased to full doses and a prokinetic drug was added. The patient was recalled in 4 weeks for a further review
column6: where the presence of mechanical oropharyngeal dysphagia was noted as an alarm sign. An EDA was requested as a matter of preference
column7: which revealed the presence of an oesophageal exudate in the proximal 2/3 of the esophagus. Samples of the lesions were taken by brushing for pathological examination and culture
column8: which confirmed the diagnosis: candidal oesophagitis.  The patient was treated with fluconazole 100 mg/day for 21 days and pantoprazole 40 mg/day orally
column9: achieving complete remission. Given the diagnosis of CD
column10: the study of its possible causes and associated entities (neurological
column11: neoplastic
column12: metabolic
column13: systemic
column14: immunosuppression
column15: etc.) was completed by means of anamnesis
column16: physical examination
column17: complete blood tests (with thyroid
column18: hepatic and renal function
column19: diabetic profile
column20: immunological status of the patient
column21: serological study
column22: etc.) and chest and abdominal X-rays. The results of all the complementary tests were negative. After completing the study
column23: the only risk factor found was treatment with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). The patient was finally diagnosed with CD in an immunocompetent patient. In the literature reviewed
column24: patients with CD related to taking PPIs had taken this treatment for at least 2 months6-8 (like our patient). We decided to discontinue such treatment after clinical resolution
column25: and subsequently performed a follow-up EDA
column26: which was normal.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 76-year-old patient attended the emergency department for right frontal TBI with loss of consciousness
column2: caused by a casual fall at home. The patient reported loss of vision in the right eye (OD) when she regained consciousness. Her medical history included type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with oral antidiabetics and osteoarthritis. There was no other personal or family history of interest. Examination revealed an infraciliary incised-contuse wound and a diffuse right fronto-orbital haematoma. Visual acuity (VA) was no light perception with a relative afferent pupillary defect (ARPD) in the OD and 0.6 in the left eye. The anterior pole was within normal
column3: as were intraocular pressure and fundus. Computed tomography (CT) of the skull with orbital slices was normal and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed increased perineural fluid in the right NW sheath. Given the persistence of symptoms
column4: a sagittal reconstruction of the optic canal of the helical CT scan was performed
column5: showing a linear fracture of the roof of the right orbit extending to the lesser wing of the right sphenoid
column6: in the region of the OC
column7: with minimal subsidence of the lateral fragment that reduced the internal diameter of the OC. Visual evoked potentials were performed using monocular stimulus (Medelec® Synergy. Oxford. Instruments
column8: England) with Googles at 2 cycles per second
column9: showing a great asymmetry in the morphology of the responses to stimulation of both eyes
column10: suggesting an absence of conduction of the visual stimulus in the right NW. The patient was diagnosed with traumatic optic neuropathy (TON) with a mixed mechanism of production due to a closed frontal trauma that was transmitted indirectly to the OC and a direct lesion of the NO when the lesser wing of the sphenoid was displaced inside the OC. Treatment with megadoses of corticosteroids (1 g of methylprednisolone followed by 250 mg every 6 hours for 48 hours) was started
column11: without improvement.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 4-year-old patient referred to the ophthalmology department in June 2008 from paediatrics
column2: with a diagnosis of congenital ptosis of the left eye
column3: which according to the parents had been evident since the age of two. The parents report that she tends to rub that eye a lot. Normal pregnancy
column4: at term by caesarean section. Only the mother's coagulation problems during pregnancy
column5: treated with subcutaneous heparin
column6: stand out. Examination revealed a slight asymmetry between the upper eyelids
column7: with the inner third of the left upper eyelid slightly lowered. No masses were palpable in this area. Visual acuity was 0.8 in both eyes with Snellen's E test. Ocular motility normal
column8: Cover test negative. Fundus examination was unaltered. The patient was seen again five months later
column9: reporting itching in the left eye. The new examination revealed a discreet bulge in the inner third of the upper eyelid of the left eye. There was no clear limitation of the motility of the left eye
column10: but it appeared to be slightly hypotropic. The rest of the examination was normal. A differential diagnosis of motility disorder or orbital mass was suggested. An assessment by paediatric ophthalmology was decided and an imaging technique was requested.  In the consultation with the paediatric ophthalmology department a week later
column11: uncorrected visual acuity of 1 in the right eye and 0.7 in the left eye was observed
column12: which at 1.25 at 40o reached unity. Negative cover test in primary position with discrete limitation to adduction and elevation
column13: normal stereopsis and fundus without alterations. Palpation revealed a mass in the inner third of the upper eyelid. During the waiting period until the magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed
column14: the astigmatism increased. The MRI showed a tumour in the superointernal angle of the left orbit
column15: compressing the eyeball
column16: compatible with a dermoid cyst
column17: and surgical treatment was indicated. An anterior orbitomy was performed through the inner third of the palpebral fold. Intraoperatively
column18: a well-defined lesion was detected in the superointernal orbital quadrant
column19: which was removed in its entirety. One week after the operation
column20: symmetry between both upper eyelids and eye position were restored.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 72-year-old man diagnosed with primary open angle glaucoma and underwent trabeculectomy of both eyes in February 2001 with good blood pressure control. One year later
column2: the patient underwent cataract surgery by phacoemulsification plus posterior chamber intraocular lens implantation
column3: which took place without complications
column4: preserving the posterior capsule intact and achieving a visual acuity (VA) of 0.6 in the OD and 0.5 in the OI. Two years after the filtering surgery
column5: the visual field showed progression in the OD and an intraocular pressure of 23 mmHg
column6: so treatment was started with travoprost 0.004% (Travatan®
column7: Alcon
column8: Fort Worth
column9: Texas). One month after starting treatment
column10: the patient reported a decrease in VA in his OD
column11: and the examination was compatible with the development of cystic macular oedema that had reduced VA to 0.2. The diagnosis was confirmed by OCT (OCT 3000
column12: Humphrey Zeiss Instruments
column13: Dublin
column14: CA) which revealed the existence in the retinal thickness of low intensity spaces corresponding to cystic spaces
column15: and an accumulation of underlying subretinal fluid
column16: reaching a thickness at the foveal level of 437 SD 21 microns. Travoprost was discontinued and treatment with oral acetazolamide (edemox®
column17: Chiesi wassermann
column18: Madrid
column19: Spain) 125 mg every 6 hours
column20: ketorolac (acular®
column21: Allergan
column22: Madrid
column23: Spain) 1 drop every 6 hours and timolol maleate 0.5% (timoftol 0.5%®
column24: Madrid
column25: Spain) twice daily. At two weeks
column26: VA had improved to 0.6
column27: and OCT showed normal macular thickness (213 OD 9 microns)
column28: with disappearance of the cysts and recovery of the foveal depression.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 21-year-old woman presented to the maxillofacial surgery department with a painless tumour on the left parotid gland that had been present for about 8 months. Physical examination revealed a solid lesion at the level of the parotid gland
column2: not attached to deep planes. An ultrasound with fine needle aspiration (FNA) was requested
column3: which revealed a well-defined parotid nodule of about 25mm in maximum diameter
column4: predominantly cystic
column5: with a solid pole inside of 9mm. It showed no vascularisation on colour Doppler; the FNA was inconclusive. In view of these ultrasound findings
column6: the study was completed with a computed tomography (CT) scan of the neck with intravenous contrast. The CT scan showed a well-defined tumour of about 22mm
column7: located in the superficial lobe of the left parotid
column8: containing fat inside
column9: and an 8mm rounded solid nodule on its posterior wall. All of this was compatible by imaging with parotid cystic teratoma.  In view of these findings
column10: surgery was proposed to the patient
column11: which she accepted. A facial nerve-sparing suprafacial parotidectomy was performed with en bloc resection of the lesion. At the end of the surgery
column12: all branches of the facial nerve were monitored to check their integrity and function. The surgical specimen obtained after resection showed a fragment of epidermis with hair follicles. The pathological findings confirmed the definitive diagnosis of a benign mature cystic teratoma of the left parotid gland
column13: in which epidermal cells
column14: mesenchymal cells
column15: adipocytes
column16: sebaceous glands and mature chondrocytes were found. No atypia were observed.  Postoperatively
column17: the patient presented with mild paresis
column18: recovering full facial mimicry 4 months postoperatively. Currently
column19: 14 months after surgery
column20: there is no recurrence of the lesion. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 37-year-old patient
column2: whose only medical history was extrinsic asthma. She had received epidural analgesia 1 month earlier for a euthecological delivery in another hospital. The hospital discharge report noted an accidental dural puncture during the epidural technique and occipital headache during the first 12 h postpartum
column3: which had subsided with medical treatment (caffeine
column4: paracetamol) and rest. However
column5: once at home
column6: the patient again began to experience occipital pain
column7: which she treated daily with analgesics; after 1 month of recurrent pain
column8: she consulted the emergency department of our hospital. The patient presented with occipital pain that worsened with standing and Valsalva manoeuvres. She was afebrile. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain revealed Chiari malformation type I (caudal displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum) and diffuse thickening of the meninges. The patient was referred to the anaesthesia department for an epidural blood patch
column9: but refused the technique for fear of a new epidural. Treatment with dexamethasone and analgesics was started and the pain subsided after 4 days. After 6 months
column10: the patient was reviewed at the neurology outpatient clinic and a new MRI scan was performed
column11: showing the persistence of the anatomical abnormality corresponding to Chiari I syndrome
column12: but noting that the meningeal thickening had disappeared. Clinically
column13: the patient did not report pain at baseline
column14: but she did report pain in relation to Valsalva manoeuvres or coughing; according to her
column15: this symptom was prior to this process. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 27-year-old man was admitted for polytraumatism after falling from a height of 15 metres. He was treated at the scene of the accident with a Glasgow Coma Scale of 6 points and haemodynamic stability was achieved. In the TACHT a pseudoaneurysm of the thoracic aorta in the isthmus and accompanying periaortic haematoma were diagnosed. The associated lesions in all cases are described in table 1. The patient was treated with labetalol for strict blood pressure control. The 24-hour and one-week follow-up TTE scans of the aortic lesion were unchanged. On the ninth day he was discharged from the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) and on the 28th day after the accident a stent was placed in the descending thoracic aorta via the left primitive iliac artery with asymptomatic occlusion of the left subclavian artery.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

A 50-year-old patient with a history of recurrent renal lithiasis consulted for recurrent haematuria and a feeling of discomfort. Serial cytological examination of urine showed the presence of atypical cells suspicious for malignancy. Imaging studies revealed a heterogeneous lesion occupying almost the entire right renal pelvis. Total nephrectomy and partial ureterectomy were performed
column2: revealing a kidney measuring a maximum of 10.5 x 5 cm with an irregular
column3: heterogeneous brownish lesion in the renal pelvis with haemorrhagic areas and other slightly yellowish
column4: shiny areas with an extremely soft consistency when cut. This lesion
column5: relatively well delimited
column6: did not invade the renal parenchyma or the renal sinus and was limited to the pyelocaliceal system
column7: although it compressed the cortex with expansive margins at one of the renal poles. Histological examination showed that the lesion consisted of well-demarcated tumour nests with no evidence of invasion of the renal parenchyma
column8: encompassing a central mucinous matrix which constituted more than 50% of the tumour volume. Loose neoplastic cells and nests of smaller size than those located at the peripheral level were found floating within this matrix. The tumour cells showed polygonal morphology with central nuclei without apparent nucleoli and little atypia as well as eosinophilic and clear cytoplasm. In the areas bordering the mucinous matrix
column9: a shy glandular differentiation was observed
column10: coinciding with the observation of some nucleoli and a slight increase in nuclear atypia. The tumour cells showed intense immunopositivity for EMA
column11: CK 7 and mild immunopositivity for CK20; this
column12: together with the morphology
column13: confirmed the urothelial nature of the neoplasm. With all the above data
