column14: the diagnosis of low-grade transitional cell carcinoma with intense mucinous differentiation of the renal pelvis (colloid carcinoma) was made.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 46-year-old male patient
column2: diagnosed with classical Hodgkin's lymphoma
column3: mixed cellularity variety
column4: stage IV-B with medullary
column5: hepatic and splenic involvement
column6: undergoing treatment with chemotherapy (escalated BEACOPP). In the induction phase of chemotherapy (day 11) he began with fever
column7: chills and melena. Laboratory tests showed neutropenia (100 leukocytes/mm3) and platelets. He was admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure and during admission suffered lower gastrointestinal bleeding with hypovolemic shock
column8: which required intubation and transfusion of blood products. Upper endoscopy identified a large ulceration in the proximal jejunum measuring 2-3 cm
column9: with smooth edges and a necrotic background
column10: with no active bleeding. The pathology study of the biopsy taken from the edges of the ulcer showed several fragments of small intestine mucosa
column11: some ulcerated
column12: with a dense mixed inflammatory infiltrate
column13: with numerous foreign body giant cells
column14: identifying abundant thick non-septate hyphae in their cytoplasm and among the infiltrate
column15: compatible with mucormycosis. CT scan identified a thickening of the intestinal wall in jejunum
column16: 4.5 cm in diameter
column17: and multiple hypodense lesions in both hepatic lobes and lytic involvement in vertebral bodies at dorsal and lumbar level. Treatment was started with amphotericin B
column18: with glycaemic control
column19: and eradicatory surgery was considered. The patient underwent surgery
column20: which revealed a plastron located in the jejunum with involvement of the transverse mesocolon
column21: with double perforation covering the jejunum. The anatomopathological study of the jejunum and ileum resection specimen showed ulceration and intense acute and chronic inflammation with double perforation and adhesion of loops
column22: secondary to infection by Zygomycetes of the mucor type
column23: with extensive fibrinoid necrosis of the medium-sized vessels of the subserosal fat. The hyphae are thick
column24: of variable diameter
column25: branching at different angles and in coronal sections show a clear
column26: reinforced membrane. The hyphae were PAS and methanamine silver positive for fungi. The patient had no complications from the surgery. At one year follow-up the patient is still alive and his lymphoma is in remission.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 41-year-old man with a history of allergy to penicillins
column2: arterial hypertension under medical treatment and psoriasis came to our clinic for haematuria. Urine cytology was performed with atypia suggestive of malignancy and an abdominal ultrasound scan showed a bladder mass on the left lateral side measuring 65x46 mm producing a left ureterohydronephrosis. In view of these findings
column3: the patient underwent TUR of the bladder and an infiltrative mass was resected
column4: occupying the entire left lateral aspect and obscuring the ureteral orifice. A left nephrostomy was also performed. The pathological anatomy of the mass was undifferentiated undifferentiated undifferentiated urothelial carcinoma of the bladder. In view of this
column5: an extension study was performed with a normal thoracoabdominal CT scan
column6: normal bone scintigraphy and left retrograde pyelography
column7: which revealed ureterohydronephrosis up to its entry into the bladder
column8: with no mass visible within the ureteral lumen. As the extension study was negative
column9: a radical cystoprostatectomy with Bricker shunt was performed. The pathological anatomy showed high-grade solid urothelial carcinoma infiltrating the perivesical fat
column10: prostate and urethra with tumour-free surgical edges. Neoplastic cells in the vascular lumen were visualised in peritumoral vessels. In the left iliobturator chain
column11: lymph nodes infiltrated by urothelial carcinoma (pT4aN1M0). Postoperatively
column12: the patient presented recurrent episodes of anaemia and thrombopenia that did not improve despite transfusion of red blood cells and platelets. Renal function remained normal and the bricker function was correct from the beginning. After 5 days
column13: the patient was successfully tolerated. Given the isolated signs of anaemia (around 7 g/dl haemoglobin) and thrombocytopenia (around 20
column14: 000 platelets/ml)
column15: an abdominal CT scan was performed where no haematomas were observed and the drainage debit was low from the outset
column16: ruling out active bleeding. Enoxaparin was withdrawn to avoid pharmacological causes of thrombopenia. Coagulation was always normal and there were no signs of bleeding
column17: ruling out disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). A haemolytic picture was also ruled out as bilirubin was normal and the direct Coombs' test was negative. As the cause of the recurrent episodes of anaemia and thrombopenia was not found
column18: a sternal bone marrow aspiration-puncture was performed and metastatic urothelial carcinoma cells were obtained. On discovering the infiltration of the bone marrow by the bladder tumour
column19: haemotherapy substitution treatment was carried out and chemotherapy treatment was started
column20: and the patient died 3 weeks later.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Patient aged 67 years
column2: smoker of 6 cigarettes/day. Previously diagnosed with breast cancer (T2 N0 M0) treated by surgery associated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Due to metastatic progression of the breast carcinoma
column3: treatment was started with bisphosphonates (pamidronate at a dose of 90 mg e.v. 20 cycles). After the first 9 cycles of pamidronate
column4: the patient was referred to our Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Department by her oncologist due to a burning sensation and diffuse gingival pain with habitual gingivorrhoea
column5: presenting an ulcerous lesion 5 mm in diameter on the lateral edge of the right hemilengua
column6: which was very painful. Exodontia of the molar associated with the lingual decubitus lesion and four other non-viable teeth were indicated
column7: with a bone exposure lesion appearing approximately one month after each exodontia at the site of the extractions. Limited debridement of the bone necrosis was performed
column8: supplemented with antibiotherapy (amoxicillin-clavulanic acid
column9: clarithromycin) and chlorhexidine gel. The evolution was favourable in all areas except for the mandibular molar
column10: where the exposure of the bone perpetuated the lingual decubitus
column11: requiring a second
column12: more aggressive ostectomy. Although this exposure did not completely disappear
column13: the patient's pain was well controlled as the lingual lesion disappeared.    |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 38-year-old woman sought dental care for treatment of decay of tooth #37 (left mandibular second molar). At that time she had no medical or dental history of note
column2: was not taking any medication and had no other restorations in her mouth. After intraoral examination and analysis of the periapical X-ray of the tooth in question
column3: the tissue affected by the caries was removed and a class I cavity preparation of Black was made and filled with silver amalgam. No postoperative problems occurred. After 19 months
column4: the patient returned to the dental office as she suspected caries in other teeth. Intraoral examination revealed an atrophic
column5: slightly erythematous area on the left jugal mucosa
column6: precisely in the region of the mucosa in contact with the molar restored with silver amalgam. The right jugal mucosa had a normal appearance. When asked about the lesion
column7: the patient informed us that she had not noticed it
column8: although recently she had sometimes felt a strange sensation in that area when eating spicy food. She also informed us that she had not received any type of treatment since the previous visit
column9: when the amalgam restoration was performed. When asked about any history of allergy
column10: she had no previous history of allergic reactions. Careful examination of the lesion shows that it projects onto the silver amalgam restoration
column11: coming into intimate contact with it during certain oral movements
column12: making it necessary to separate the mucosa with the mirror in order to be able to see the lesion properly.  To confirm the nature of the lesion histologically
column13: a biopsy of the lesion is taken. The pathology study of the biopsy of the lesion showed squamous epithelium with irregular acanthosis and foci of parakeratosis
column14: with marked spongiosis and the presence of exocytosis of lymphocytic elements in the stratum corneum. The underlying stroma showed a chronic lymphocyte-like inflammatory infiltrate distributed discretely in a band
column15: with involvement of the stratum basale. In depth
column16: fibroconnective and adipose tissue was observed with some thin-walled vascular structures
column17: without relevant alterations. The anatomopathological diagnosis was compatible with oral lichen planus
column18: the histological picture observed in the mucosa being equivalent in the skin to an acute-subacute dermatitis.  Once the nature of the lesion was explained to the patient and the possibility of it disappearing by removing the silver amalgam restoration
column19: she decided not to replace the restoration as she felt that she had no significant discomfort and did not wish to undergo the treatment again. Restorations of other teeth were made with composite resin
column20: without any mucosal reaction.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 67-year-old woman who came to the emergency department for bilateral conjunctival oedema of 3 weeks' evolution
column2: after having been treated with artificial tears and topical antibiotic-corticoid ointment during this period of time without improvement. The patient's personal history included arterial hypertension under pharmacological treatment
column3: diabetes mellitus that was difficult to control and recently diagnosed oral candidiasis. Ophthalmological examination revealed bilateral conjunctival chemosis with intense tearing
column4: and the rest of the ophthalmological examination was normal. The patient reported having lost 5 kg in the last 2 weeks
column5: a feeling of generalised swelling
column6: especially in the face
column7: together with asthenia and generalised pruritus.  After a systemic examination she was diagnosed with suspected Cushing's syndrome. Hormonal tests revealed an ACTH of 3 pg/mL (normal 10-55)
column8: basal plasma cortisol of 35.3 mcg/dL and urinary free cortisol (UFC) of 632 mcg/24h (normal < 180). Chest X-ray and computed tomography (CT) were normal. Abdominal CT scan showed a left adrenal mass measuring 8.2×5.4cm
column9: suggestive of adrenal carcinoma
column10: with no locoregional adenopathies.  Given the clinical evolution
column11: it was decided to start treatment with ketoconazole 400mg/day prior to surgery in order to inhibit adrenal cortisol secretion
column12: and the adrenal tumour was excised together with dissection of the surrounding fat
column13: with complete resolution of the chemosis.  The histology of the adrenal tumour was reported as "adrenocortical carcinoma with extensive zone of necrosis with proliferative activity
column14: infiltrating the surrounding capsule and invading the pericapsular lymphatic vessels". After an initial course of chemotherapy with cisplatin-etoposide
column15: he was diagnosed 3 months later with multiple bilateral pulmonary metastases in both hemithoraxes and a local recurrence at the left adrenal level by means of a thoraco-abdomino-pelvic CT scan
column16: for which he received three cycles of chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide
column17: adriamycin and vincristine
column18: without improvement
column19: with progression of respiratory and cardiac insufficiency
column20: starting treatment with weekly taxol for 2 months (antineoplastic chemotherapy)
column21: dying due to the progressive respiratory insufficiency he presented.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male
column2: 53 years old. Calcium lithiasis. Location of the lithiasis and size: multiple calcific stones between 1-1.5 cm; left kidney. Personal history: undergoing nephrology check-ups for AHT and mild CRF. Right pyohydronephrosis secondary to distal ureteral lithiasis that required percutaneous nephrostomy
column3: partially recovering the function of the right kidney. Nine lithotripsies
column4: five on the right side (two ureteral and three renal) and three on the left kidney
column5: although the haematoma occurred after the first one on this kidney. Number of waves and intensity: 3
column6: 500 impacts
column7: intensity 3-4. Immediate post-Leoch symptoms: intense pain a few hours after the procedure. CT scan: left subcapsular haematoma of 15 cm.  Subsequent treatment: analgesia and analytical controls. Ht decreased to 32 and Hb 10. No haemodynamic alterations. No transfusions were required. Admitted to hospital for 8 days. Evolution of the haematoma: No intense pain except for the first 4-5 days
column8: so together with haemodynamic stability and maintenance of Hb
column9: conservative treatment was decided
column10: and the haematoma was almost completely reabsorbed in 18 months; ultrasound and CT scan at one and a half years showed small remains of the haematoma.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 62 year old patient consulted for pain in the right hemiscroct of three months' evolution. On physical examination
column2: a grade IV right varicocele was found
column3: and a large mass was also palpated at the level of the right renal area. An abdominal ultrasound scan was performed
column4: which revealed a heterogeneous mass of approximately 10 cm in the right kidney and no pathological findings in the left kidney. A computed axial tomography of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast showed a heterogeneous right renal formation measuring 110 x 120 mm in diameter
column5: with no retroperitoneal adenomegaly. Difficult evaluation of the right renal pedicle.  An MRI was requested which confirmed the right renal heterogeneous formation in the upper pole of 12 cm. in diameter
column6: without involvement of the renal vein or the inferior vena cava.  A radical right nephrectomy was performed. Good progress
column7: the patient was discharged on the fifth postoperative day. Pathological anatomy revealed: Undifferentiated malignant tumour of lineage to be differentiated by immunohistochemistry (IHC). Tumour size 13 cm. Local invasion: the tumour extends through the renal capsule
column8: causing focal infiltration of the perisuprarenal fat. Renal hilum free of lesion. Vascular embolisms present
column9: surgical margins free of tumour lesion. Non neoplastic kidney: chronic pyelonephritis. Arterio- and arteriolonephrosclerosis and retention cyst 4 cm. in diameter. Adrenal gland free of lesion. IHQ:WT1 +++
column12: P53 -.  Diagnosis: Nephroblastoma (Wilms' tumour)
column13: stage II of the NWTS classification. CT scan one month postoperatively showed tumour recurrence at the level of the nephrectomy bed. He started chemotherapy with vincristine
column14: dactinomycin and doxorubicin. During the course of chemotherapy
column15: she developed pneumonia with deterioration of general condition
column16: sepsis and months of nephrectomy.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 56-year-old woman with a history of residual pulmonary tuberculosis
column2: bladder carcinoma operated on twice and currently treated with local instillation of mitomycin
column3: diabetes mellitus
column4: arterial hypertension and hyperuricaemia
column5: for the last month on treatment with allopurinol
column6: has attended the emergency department on several occasions over the last 10 days
column7: for attacks of dyspnoea together with skin rash and has been treated from the beginning with high-dose corticosteroids
column8: antihistamines and aerosol therapy. She was admitted to the ICU with suspected NET
column9: presenting an erythematous maculopapular and blistering rash over 70% of the body surface
column10: positive Nikolsky's sign
column11: type I respiratory failure
column12: mild renal failure and a tendency to hypotension. Supportive treatment and ciclosporin A were started. The patient has evolved favourably
column13: the skin lesions have completely re-epithelialised 21 days after admission to the ICU
column14: and she has been discharged to the ward.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of an 85-year-old man with a history of prostate adenocarcinoma treated with LHRH analogues
column2: maintaining adequate biochemical control of the disease
column3: who consulted for a picture of 2 months' evolution consisting of an enlarged left hemiscrotal
column4: in the absence of pain
column5: fever or other symptoms. Physical examination revealed a larger than normal left hemiscrotal
column6: under tension
column7: with a mass that prevented identification of the left testicle. Blood tests were requested
column8: confirming beta-HCG and alpha-fetoprotein within the reference ranges
column9: and scrotal ultrasound
column10: reported as: "large cystic mass in the left scrotum
column11: measuring 10x8.3 cm
column12: compressing and displacing the testicle
column13: compatible with a large cyst dependent on the epididymis
column14: although other possibilities
column15: such as cystadenoma
column16: cannot be ruled out". Based on the clinical data
column17: and assessing the differential diagnoses and the patient's situation
column18: he was offered a bilateral orchiectomy
column19: the right subalbuginea and the left inguinal
column20: which he accepted.  The surgical specimen weighed 550 g
column21: measured 11x11x9 cm and had a brownish-haemorrhagic colouring; when cut
column22: a cystic cavity compressing the testicular parenchyma was evident. Microscopic pathological study
column23: including sections of the cyst wall and the rest of the teste
column24: revealed a cystic lesion lined with flat epithelium
column25: with areas of ulceration
column26: haemorrhage and necrotic tissue; the testicular parenchyma showed intense signs of atrophy
column27: fibrosis and vascular congestion
column28: with an almost total absence of germ cells in the seminiferous tubules.  The anatomopathological diagnosis was: benign testicular cyst compatible with cystic dilatation of the rete testis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 53-year-old male
column2: veteran road cyclist
column3: with no medical or surgical history of interest
column4: toxic habits or known allergic reaction to medication
column5: who consulted our emergency department for fracture of the middle third of the right clavicle and fracture of the right costal arches caused in an accident with a fall on the road. On admission he was in good general condition
column6: haemodynamically stable
column7: without dyspnoea
column8: suffering from pain in the right clavicle and costal wall with no symptoms or signs of neurovascular involvement of the right upper limb. The simple radiological study showed fracture of the fourth and fifth right costal arches without evidence of haemothorax or pneumothorax
column9: and fracture of the middle third of the right clavicle with third fragment
column10: confirmed by computerised axial tomography (a
column11: 1b).  The patient was initially treated with analgesia
column12: non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and a bandage of eight. Three days later
column13: the patient consulted the same department for swelling of the right upper limb with no loss of sensation and with preserved peripheral pulses
column14: normal vital signs and cardiorespiratory auscultation with normal heart sounds at normal frequency without murmurs or extratonos
column15: and preserved vesicular murmur in both lung fields
column16: without rales or other pathological findings. Spirometry
column17: electrocardiogram and echocardiogram were normal; blood tests showed abnormal values of MCHC=31.4g/dl
column18: neutrophils=76.6%
column19: lymphocytes=16.4%
column20: eosinophils=0.9%
column21: fibrinogen=645mg/dl
column22: GGT=52U/l and positive D-Dimer. Venous echo-Doppler study revealed venous thrombosis of the axillary
column23: cephalic and basilic veins with compression of the ulnar branch of the medial brachial cutaneous nerve at the level of the basilic hiatus (a
column24: 2b).  The bandage in eight was replaced by a simple sling
column25: which was maintained until the start of functional rehabilitation
column26: and treatment with Tinzapain sodium was carried out
column27: with radiographs and serial Doppler utrasonography for control until the clavicle fracture was consolidated and the thrombosed veins were completely recanalised. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the clinical case of a 13-year-old boy with no previous history of interest
column2: who
column3: after a kick against resistance while playing football
column4: suffered pain and functional impotence in the groin and right thigh. The patient was in good general condition
column5: without fever
column6: and reported no infectious diseases in the previous days. He had no rotational alterations or shortening of the limbs
column7: reported pain that increased with local palpation of the EIAI
column8: the hip was free to passive mobilisation
column9: but active movements were limited by pain. An anteroposterior X-ray of the pelvis and an axial X-ray of the right hip showed a fracture-avulsion of the EIAI. Joint rest
column10: partial weight bearing with crutches and analgesia with ibuprofen 400 mg every eight hours orally was indicated. After three weeks
column11: an appointment was made for an ultrasound examination
column12: which showed a correct evolution of the injury. Following physiotherapy
column13: after two months he gradually returned to sporting activity and was discharged three months after the initial injury.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 63 year old patient who reported a visual acuity (VA) deficit in the right eye (OD) of several months' evolution. His personal history included post-traumatic epilepsy of ten years' duration
column2: arterial hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He had been treated with 1.5 g vigabatrin and 200 mg carbamazepine daily since the trauma. VA was 0.3 in the OD and 0.8 in the left eye with correction. Anterior biomicroscopy and tonometry were normal. Ophthalmoscopy revealed pallor of both papillae and a macular epiretinal membrane in the OD.  Computerised Humphrey 30/2 white-white and blue-yellow perimetry showed severe concentric campimetric reductions in both eyes (Humphrey instruments
column3: model 745
column4: Carl Zeiss Inc).  She had no family history of interest
column5: so hereditary optic neuropathy was ruled out. The anamnesis and analytical determinations of mean corpuscular volume
column6: vitamins B1
column7: B6
column8: B12 and folic acid ruled out nutritional aetiology. A diagnosis of retinotoxicity due to vigabatrin was established and the patient was referred to the neurology department. At one year of follow-up
column9: the loss of campimetry and VA persisted.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Seven-year-old girl who attended the emergency department in springtime for an episode of complex generalised seizure with disconnection from the environment and falling to the ground while walking
column2: together with hypertonia
column3: sialorrhoea and movements of the corner of the mouth lasting about three minutes
column4: with spontaneous recovery. In the previous days the child had presented with myalgia
column5: headache and fever up to 39°C
column6: but had been afebrile for 24 hours. She had no relevant physiological history: pregnancy
column7: childbirth and perinatal period were of no interest
column8: nor did she have any pathological history of interest
column9: and her only family history was her mother's treatment with lithium for bipolar disorder that had been going on for years. On arrival at the ED
column10: the patient presented a post-critical state with a Glasgow Glasgow score of 10
column11: but the rest of the examination
column12: both neurological and by systems
column13: was normal. The blood tests were outstanding in the biochemistry and haemogram: - Biochemistry: - Glutamic-oxalacetic transaminase (GOT): 93 UI/l. - Glutamic-pyruvic transaminase (GPT): 44 IU/l. - C-reactive protein (CRP): 2 mg/l. - Haemogram: - Leukocytes activated aspect: 6000 (N: 30% L: 66% M: 4%). - Platelets 125 000. - Normal red blood count. In view of the afebrile seizure
column14: it was decided to admit him to complete the study. Two hours after admission
column15: he had a new seizure that ceased with the administration of intravenous midazolam at 0.15 mg/kg
column16: but he suffered respiratory arrest requiring T-piece ventilation and was admitted to intensive care for close monitoring and surveillance. On arrival at the intensive care unit
column17: he presented post-critical state
column18: with a Glasgow Glasgow of 7 and all other vital signs normal except for an axillary temperature of 38°C in this case. Neurological examination revealed marked hyperreflexia of the lower limbs
column19: with negative meningeal signs. Urgent cranial computed tomography (CT)
column20: lumbar puncture
column21: urine toxicity and lithemia (due to maternal history) were performed
column22: with normal results. An urgent electroencephalogram (EEG) was performed
column23: reporting global slowing of activity compatible with meningoencephalitis. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) serology was obtained for enterovirus and herpes virus
column24: both negative. Serology was also obtained for multiple agents such as toxoplasma
column25: rubella
column26: lupus
column27: herpes simplex 1 and 2
column28: varicella-zoster virus
column29: Mycoplasma
column30: adenovirus
column31: mumps
column32: parvovirus
column33: measles
column34: Coxsackie
column35: ECHO virus and Borrelia
column36: also negative. In the following hours after admission
column37: the patient presented episodes of agitation with somnolence and again presented two generalised convulsive episodes
column38: so maintenance levetiracetam was started at 40 mg/kg/day
column39: with a previous bolus of 20 mg/kg
column40: together with prophylactic acyclovir at 60 mg/kg/day
column41: despite the negative serology. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain was requested urgently
column42: with normal results and no evidence of bleeding or hyperdensity lesions. Given the history of myalgia and fever in the previous days and the poor recovery of the neurological symptoms
column43: it was decided to determine influenza A antigens in the nasal exudate
column44: which was positive
column45: so treatment was started with oseltamivir 5 mg/kg/day for a total of five days
column46: and acyclovir was discontinued. The patient progressively improved
column47: but suffered a new convulsive episode and it was decided to extend serology for cytomegalovirus (CMV)
column48: Ebstein-Barr virus (EBV)
column49: herpes and influenza A negative
column50: and a repeat MRI of the brain was performed
column51: which remained normal. CSF oligoclonal bands were requested
column52: which were negative
column53: and the autoimmunity study with anti-DNA
column54: anti-Ro
column55: anti-La
column56: anti-histone
column57: anti-Sm
column58: anti-RNP
column61: and anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) were negative. Valproic acid was administered at a dose of 40 mg/kg/day
column62: with complete cessation of seizures. The patient had a total of five seizure episodes and on discharge the EEG improved
column63: although not completely normal. Treatment was continued with valproic acid 40 mg/kg/day and levetiracepam 60 mg/kg/day. Currently
column64: the patient continues to be monitored at Neuropaediatrics consultations
column67: with normal EEG at the last visit.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 41-year-old smoker diagnosed with lipoma on the right thigh underwent an abdominal ultrasound scan following an elevation of catecholamines in the blood (noradrenaline and dopamine) without accompanying hypertension. A hypoanechoic nodular lesion of approximately 3 cm in maximum dimension compatible with a solid lesion with cystic degeneration
column2: multitabic
column3: was observed at the adrenal level. The lesion was confirmed by CT scan and scintigraphy. The patient underwent surgery with the clinical findings of pheochromocytoma versus adrenal gland adenoma. A 9 cm irregular adipose tissue fragment was received with serial sections showing a 1.2 cm yellowish-orange tissue together with a thin-walled
column4: whitish multilocular cystic formation with no papillary formations or outgrowths inside. Histological examination showed a large cystic formation without haematic content lined by flat cells with central spindle-shaped nuclei sometimes protruding intraluminally
column5: with immunohistochemical positivity for CD 31 and CD 34 and negativity for calrretinin (endothelium). Cystic formations with similar characteristics to the one described
column6: although smaller in size
column7: were observed both adjacent to the main formation and randomly distributed within the adrenal parenchyma. Based on these findings
column8: the diagnosis of cystic lymphangioma was made.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 18-year-old woman was referred from the emergency department by the Internal Medicine service for blurred vision in both eyes of 5 days' evolution. Her only history was hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine 100 micrograms/day
column2: and headaches for which treatment with nadolol 40 mg/night and topiramate 25 mg in the mornings had recently been prescribed. He provides a recent analytical study
column3: prior to treatment
column4: within the normal range. His ophthalmological clinical history showed a previous visual acuity
column5: 6 months earlier
column6: of unity (10/10) in both eyes with a correction of +0.50 sphere -0.75 cylinder at 100° in the right eye and +0.75 sphere -0.75 cylinder at 75° in the left eye. A new refractive study was performed which determined a myopic change in both eyes with -4.25 sphere -0.50 cylinder at 110o in the right eye and -3.75 sphere -1.00 cylinder at 60o in the left eye
column7: a correction with which he achieved visual acuity equal to 0.6 (6/10) in the right eye and 0.7 (7/10) in the left eye.  The biomicroscopic study showed mild hyperemia and conjunctival congestion in both eyes
column8: narrow anterior chambers with a positive eclipse sign and transparent corneas and crystalline lenses
column9: with no signs of inflammation or seclusion. Pupils are isochoric and normoreactive. Normal ocular motility. Intraocular pressure measured with applanation tonometer was 32 mmHg in the right eye and 29 mmHg in the left eye. Papillae and posterior pole examination were normal.  On suspicion of acute angular closure
column10: oral treatment was started with carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (acetazolamide 250 mg)
column11: ½ cp every 8 hours
column12: and topical treatment with bimatoprost and timolol maleate in eye drops
column13: with discontinuation of the recently introduced medications (nadolol and topiramate). At 24 hours he showed blood pressure of 23 mmHg in both eyes
column14: and 13 mmHg in the right eye and 12 mmHg in the left eye at 48 hours
column15: with normalisation of anterior chamber depth
column16: so acetazolamide treatment was progressively reduced at 48 hours
column17: third and fourth day until total suppression and topical treatment was withdrawn after 7 days
column18: maintaining normal blood pressure of 17-18 mmHg in both eyes at 3
column19: 6 and 12 weeks
column20: without treatment.  Vision was completely normalised at 72 hours
column21: with visual acuity equal to unity in both eyes and refraction similar to that prior to the episode. A final diagnosis of myopisation and ocular hypertension due to acute angular closure secondary to treatment with topiramate was made
column22: which was communicated to the patient
column23: family and Internal Medicine service as the prescriber of the drug.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 61-year-old man diagnosed
column2: operated and treated for rectal adenocarcinoma 18 months previously. He consulted for a painful increase in penile size
column3: together with the appearance of erythematous
column4: excrescent and bleeding lesions on the preputial skin when rubbed. At the same time
column5: hypogastric lymphoedema of the penile skin and scrotum was observed on examination.  The lymphoedema was excised by circumcision. Pathological examination revealed preputial subcutaneous metastases secondary to intestinal adenocarcinoma. The macromicroscopic image showed tumour infiltration of the squamous flat lining epithelium giving rise to a carcinomatous excrescence. There was little inflammatory component. At high magnification
column6: the infiltrating tumour was a moderately differentiated
column7: high-grade adenocarcinoma with a high mitotic index.  Despite oncological treatment
column8: the patient died 4 months after diagnosis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 13-year-old girl
column2: with no past history of interest
column3: came to the clinic with severe vomiting and abdominal pain of five days' duration. She was in fair general condition
column4: with no signs of dehydration

column1: A 47-year-old woman
column2: with no past history of interest
column3: consulted for persistent pain in the right iliac fossa following an oesophagogastroduodenal study with barium a year earlier due to symptoms of gastro-oesophageal reflux. Laboratory tests were strictly normal. A colonoscopy was performed up to the terminal ileum
column4: with normal mucosa and calibre; an abdominal X-ray and ultrasound nine months after the barium study showed the presence of barium inside the appendix
column5: with no evidence of acute appendicitis. Due to the persistence of the symptoms

column1: A 47-year-old patient with a history of gastric ulcus
column2: smoker of 10 cigarettes/day
column3: vasectomised
column4: who consults for moderate increase in left scrotal volume for years but with an increase over the last month
column5: accompanied by dull discomfort
column6: without acute pain. No micturition symptoms or fever. Physical examination revealed the presence of a medium-sized hydrocele that prevented exploration of the testicle and epididymis. column1: This is a 59-year-old man
column2: diagnosed with T2N2b squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx
column3: who was initially treated with three cycles of chemotherapy without remission
column4: so that three months later a supraglottic laryngectomy was performed
column5: with modified incomplete radical emptying of the left side. Pathology showed an infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma in the left hemiepiglottis with 8 of 11 positive lymph nodes of the internal jugular
column6: subdigastric and left supraclavicular chain. He subsequently received chemotherapy and radiotherapy on supraglottis and hypopharynx and bilateral lymph node areas. Nine months after surgery
column7: she consulted for a three-week headache associated with binocular diplopia and blurred vision in the right eye
column8: with evidence of ophthalmoparesis of the third
column9: fourth and sixth right cranial nerves. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain showed a mass in the posterior and lateral portion of the right cavernous sinus
column10: with protrusion towards the prepontine cistern
column11: well demarcated
column12: with homogeneous gadolinium uptake and dimensions of 11x14.4x12.2 mm. The CT bone window showed no lytic lesions or invasion of the sphenoid wing or sinus. The thoraco-abdomino-pelvic CT scan was negative. The radiological differential diagnosis was schwannoma
column13: meningioma or metastasis.  An open biopsy was performed with a transylvian approach to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus where tumour invasion of the intradural space was observed. The anatomopathological result was squamous cell carcinoma. Subsequently
column14: radiotherapy was administered as palliative treatment. Three weeks after surgery the patient consulted for dorsal pain without neurological symptoms. An MRI study of the spine showed focal lesions in the D4
column15: D6 and D10 bodies suspicious for metastatic implants. Radiotherapy treatment relieved the headache
column16: but he developed ophthalmoplegia
column17: retaining only right eye abduction. column1: A 72-year-old man came to the ophthalmology department for loss of vision in the left eye (LO) that had been present for one month. By way of background
column2: the patient had been treated for prostate carcinoma 10 years earlier with radiotherapy without relapse at the time of the study. Visual acuity in the right eye (OD) was 5/10 and no light perception in the OI. Intraocular pressure was 18 mmHg in OD and 12 mmHg in OI. Slit-lamp examination showed a ++ nuclear cataract in both eyes. The fundus examination in the OD showed no alterations
column3: but in the OI it was not visible due to a haemovitreous. Ultrasound showed a lobulated lesion occupying 4/5 of the vitreous chamber. The hypothesis of CM or metastatic lesion was put forward
column4: so a search for a primary lesion was performed. Thoracic-abdominal CT scan and liver tests were normal. Given the suspicion of a malignant lesion
column5: a PET/CT scan was performed
column6: which was positive in the eye (SUVmax: 7.2)
column7: liver (SUVmax: 5.7) and right pulmonary hilum (SUVmax: 3.5). After the PET/CT scan we reviewed the abdominal CT scan
column8: without identifying liver lesions
column9: only a dubious nodular alteration of poorly delimited density and difficult to interpret due to its small size
column10: not accessible for biopsy by ultrasound or CT scan. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the liver was considered
column11: but was rejected due to the small size of the lesion. Enucleation was decided because of the need for pathological anatomy to confirm the diagnosis prior to chemotherapy. The severity of the pathology
column12: type of surgery and no possibility of visual recovery in the affected eye were reported. The pathological anatomy showed a large spindle cell MC (17*17 mm) and in the immunohistochemical study intense cytoplasmic positivity for MELAM-A and HMB45.  The patient
column13: who at the end of the diagnostic process had an ECOG-1 (quality of life according to the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group scale) due to vision loss
column14: started palliative treatment with dacarbazine at a dose of 850 mg/m2 every 3 weeks in April 2011
column15: with excellent tolerance. In June 2011
column16: he was re-evaluated and presented radiological progression of the liver
column17: not detected in CT
column18: but detected in PET/CT. In June 2011
column19: she started 2nd line treatment with ipilimumab (3 mg/kg every 3 weeks - 4 doses)
column20: with preservation of general condition (ECOG1)
column21: completing treatment without side effects. Hepatic progression was again detected (at week 12 and 16 of treatment
column22: as stipulated in the ipilimumab evaluation protocol)
column23: identified on CT and PET/CT scans. In November 2011
column24: he started 3rd line of treatment with fotemustine at 75 mg/m2 with induction dose
column25: due to preservation of general condition
column26: without completing the planned treatment until the planned radiological evaluation
column27: due to general deterioration. She died in February 2012 (11 months after diagnosis).  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 72-year-old male patient with a personal history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypercholesterolaemia under pharmacological treatment
column2: with no family history of interest or previous surgery. He was referred by his primary care physician for a three-week history of general malaise
column3: a feeling of dizziness and dull pain in the right hypochondrium. There were no recent alterations in intestinal transit
column4: rectorrhagia or melaenic stools. Physical examination revealed only a mildly painful abdominal palpation in the right hypochondrium
column5: with no visceromegaly. Laboratory tests showed: leukocytes: 14.3 x 109/L (85% neutrophils); haemoglobin: 11.7 g/dL (MCV: 89.7 fL

column1: The patient was a 40-year-old male who was involved in a car accident. CT scan on admission showed a pseudoaneurysm of the thoracic aorta at the exit of the left subclavian artery with a periaortic haematoma extending into the posterior mediastinum. The patient was admitted to the ICU in spontaneous respiration with systolic blood pressure (SBP) below 120 mmHg. Conservative treatment of the associated lesions was carried out. Ten hours after admission to the ICU
column2: a stent was placed in the descending thoracic aorta via the left femoral artery
column3: with partial occlusion of the left subclavian artery. He was discharged to the ward after 48 hours. He was monitored with TACHT at 7 days
column4: at one month and at 45 days.  Two months after the accident he presented acute pericarditis and absence of left radial pulse without clinical repercussions. The TACHT showed correct localisation of the stent.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 27-year-old female patient with juvenile arthritis of 12 years of evolution affecting the knees
column2: right ankle and 1st right MTCF. In the study she was HLA B-27 positive
column3: ANAS negative and RF negative. There was no axial or extra-articular involvement. In treatment with medium-high doses of corticoids
column4: 10-30 mg/day of prednisone with incomplete response
column5: after no response to salazopyrin
column6: methotrexate
column7: hydroxychloroquine and corticoids at low doses
column8: as well as infiltrations in both knees and ankle with corticoids and isotopic synoviorthesis of both knees with Yttrium-90. After proposing treatment with etanercept
column9: the patient was started at full doses accepted for juvenile arthritis
column10: rheumatoid arthritis and ankylopoietic spondylitis
column11: with a complete and sustained response. In view of the desire to become a mother reported by the patient and her husband
column12: we indicated the lack of experience with this type of drug and advised against pregnancy. In December 2005
column13: after 3 years of asymptomatic treatment without requiring NSAIDs or corticosteroids
column14: she came for consultation because she was two weeks pregnant (last menstrual period 26/11/2005) and so
column15: in agreement with the patient
column16: we withdrew etanercept and started treatment with prednisone in the event of a flare-up. Two weeks later
column17: the patient came to the clinic reporting an incapacitating oligoarticular flare-up
column18: for which she started treatment with etanercept
column19: at a dose of 25 mg twice a week. We again pointed out the lack of experience and
column20: in agreement with the patient
column21: her husband and the health authorities
column22: we continued the treatment with strict monitoring. We added ASA 50 mg/day
column23: iron and folic acid to the treatment. The due date is 23/08/2006. The pregnancy passed without complications and without arthritis activity
column24: with anaemia and maintained elevation of acute phase reactants
column25: which were completely normalised after delivery
column26: which took place without complications
column27: with a normal term newborn. Artificial lactation is advised and accepted. Treatment with etanercept is maintained in the pre and postpartum period
column28: and the patient is asymptomatic and has normal blood tests with no inflammatory data or anaemia. column1: An 11-year-old girl presented with asthenia

column1: A woman diagnosed with AHT at the age of 14
column2: when she was first admitted to a paediatric hospital
column3: with blood pressure (BP) of 210/120mmHg
column4: headaches and hypokalaemia. Suspecting secondary hypertension
column5: she underwent several tests. Renal ultrasound
column6: echocardiogram and catheterisation of the aorta and renal arteries showed no abnormalities. Plasma renin activity (PRA) and plasma aldosterone (PA) levels were elevated on two occasions. Urinary vanillylmandelic acid and plasma TSH
column7: free T4 and T3 levels were normal. She was discharged from hospital on angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and calcium channel blockers
column8: but did not return for follow-up. At 19 years of age
column9: she consulted another hospital for hypertension and was eight weeks pregnant
column10: for which she was hospitalised in intensive care. Good foetal health
column11: BP 200/110mmHg and hypokalaemia were determined
column12: and treatment with clonidine and alpha methyl dopa was started. Renal ultrasound showed a regular nodular formation of 45mm in diameter in the lower pole of the left kidney
column13: ultrasonographically compatible with angiomyolipoma. PRA and AP levels were elevated. She continued on outpatient treatment with labetalol and nifedipine. At 19 weeks' gestation she was admitted to the emergency room with a diagnosis of missed abortion
column14: and a curettage was performed. Four days later she requested voluntary discharge and did not return for follow-up. Two years later
column15: while on medication with enalapril
column16: losartan and amlodipine
column17: she was admitted to our hospital ward with occipital headache and muscle weakness of several days' duration. BP was found to be 220/140mmHg. Initial studies showed hypokalaemia of 2mEq/l
column18: plasma creatinine of 0.6mg/dl and plasma urea of 25mg/dl. Renal ultrasound showed a solid nodular image
column19: corroborated by contrasted abdominal computed tomography
column20: where a voluminous space-occupying formation was observed
column21: solid
column22: in the interpolar sector and lower pole of the left kidney
column23: 65mm in diameter
column24: hypovascularised. The Doppler of the renal arteries and the echocardiogram showed no alterations.  Given the presumptive diagnosis of HTN secondary to renal tumour
column25: due to high renin levels
column26: and having ruled out other secondary causes of HTN in previous studies
column27: it was decided to perform a nephrectomy of the affected kidney
column28: having previously controlled BP with the addition of spironolactone at a dose of 100mg/day to his usual medication. Pathological examination revealed a 5.5x4.5cm encapsulated tumour
column29: haemorrhagic in appearance
column30: with whitish fibrous areas. Microscopically
column31: the tumour lesion was found to consist of medium-sized cells
column32: with medium-sized
column33: vesicular nuclei
column34: with irregular chromatin
column35: some with inconspicuous nucleoli and eosinophilic cytoplasm
column36: others with clear cytoplasm
column37: arranged in a diffuse pattern with extensive haemorrhage and mild mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate
column38: without invasion of the renal capsule. No cellular atypia
column39: mitosis or necrosis was found. The tumour cells were positive for vimentin and showed strong and diffuse positivity for CD34. Ultrastructural observation revealed cells with intracytoplasmic granules with different degrees of electrolucency
column40: surrounded by membranes. In terms of morphology
column41: they varied from round to elongated
column42: acquiring some shapes with rectilinear edges
column43: and in some of them a crystalloid rhomboid shape stood out
column44: which at high magnification showed a zigzag structure of marked electrodensity. These findings could be linked to juxtaglomerular cell tumour (JCT)
column45: confirming the clinical suspicion.  After surgery
column46: the patient's BP gradually decreased and antihypertensive drugs were simultaneously withdrawn
column47: and she evolved asymptomatic
column48: normotensive
column49: with normal levels of plasma renin
column50: aldosterone and serum potassium
column51: without pharmacological treatment.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 28-year-old male patient suffered blunt trauma to his left eye during an assault. In the initial emergency examination
column2: a significant reduction in VA was observed in this eye due to hyphema
column3: the IOP was 8 mmHg and Berlin oedema was seen in the ocular fundus. The patient was treated with relative rest
column4: cycloplegia
column5: topical and systemic corticosteroids. After resorption of the hyphema
column6: VA improved to 1
column7: but IOP was 4 mmHg
column8: so treatment was continued with restriction of physical effort
column9: atropine 1% and topical corticosteroids
column10: despite which ocular hypotony persisted (4-6 mmHg)
column11: VA was reduced to 0.4 and retinochoroidal folds and papillary oedema developed. The discontinuation of topical corticosteroids did not improve the clinical picture either. The gonioscopic study showed a grade IV open angle without other alterations. Ten months after the trauma
column12: an ultrasound biomicroscopy (UBM) was performed
column13: which revealed a tear of the iris root in the nasal area with 360° ciliochoroidal detachment. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) showed foveal thickening (326 microns).  Given the lack of response to conservative treatment
column14: it was decided to perform a transscleral contact diode laser cyclopexy using the G probe of the Oculight SLx diode laser (Iris Medical Instruments
column15: Mountain View
column16: California). The procedure was performed under retrobulbar anaesthesia and 2 rows of 10 impacts each (power 3 watts
column17: exposure time 3 seconds) were applied over the area of cyclodialysis described with the BMU. In the first 24 hours no changes in VA or IOP were observed
column18: but from one week onwards a gradual rise in IOP was observed
column19: reaching 12 mmHg by the 6th month
column20: which was accompanied by improvement in VA and progressive reduction in papilla oedema
column21: chorioretinal folds and foveal thickness. BMU showed closure of the cyclodialysis by means of a peripheral anterior synechia and disappearance of the choroidal detachment
column22: justifying normalisation of IOP. At one year follow-up VA was 1 and IOP 14 mmHg.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 65-year-old man consulted for an infravesical obstructive syndrome together with a soft tumour in the right hemiscrotal
column2: which decreased in size during urination. Physical examination revealed the presence of an enlarged right scrotal pouch and a reducible inguinal hernia. Rectal examination revealed a medium-sized
column3: bilobed
column4: adenomatous prostate. The complementary examinations included a total PSA
column5: which was normal
column6: a vesico-prostatic ultrasound that revealed a 57-gram prostate and a testicular ultrasound with an image suggestive of vesical herniation.  Finally
column7: retrograde cystography showed the presence of a massive bladder hernia in the right hemiscrotal.  Treatment was surgical and consisted of resection of the herniated portion of the bladder which was peritoneal and correction of the inguinal hernia with marlex mesh. In a second stage a TUR of the prostate was performed. Controlled after six months the patient remains asymptomatic.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: tricuspid and aortic insufficiency

column11: simvastatin (20 mg/day v.o.)
column12: simvastatin (20 mg/day v.o.) and omeprazole (20 mg/day v.o.). )

column15: vitamin D (1 ampoule v.o./month)
column16: domperidone (10 ml/8 hours v.o.) and home oxygen therapy. In January 2016
column17: she was admitted to the hospital emergency department for an episode of haematochezia
column18: where she was diagnosed with bilateral pulmonary pathology. A computed axial tomography (CT) scan of the chest revealed extensive bilateral parenchymal pulmonary infiltrates
column19: a calcified granuloma in the middle lobe of the lung and subcarinal lymphadenopathy (15x20 mm). On suspicion of bilateral multi-lobar community-acquired pneumonia
column20: she was prescribed clarithromycin (500 mg/day v.o.) and was discharged from hospital. In February 2016
column21: the patient was admitted to the internal medicine department for dyspnoea and for the study of pulmonary infiltrates that had not subsided since hospital discharge despite antibiotic treatment. During admission
column22: a Mantoux test and bronchoscopy were performed
column23: both with negative results
column24: in addition to a CT scan showing bilateral airspace condensation
column25: an interlobular adenopathy (15 mm) of possible malignant origin
column26: several irregular nodules and a calcified nodule (6.2 mm). It was decided to withdraw treatment with sertraline and clarithromycin and the tests were repeated two weeks later
column27: with results showing a decrease in pulmonary infiltrates and less air condensation. The patient experienced both objective and subjective clinical improvement and was discharged from the hospital. Five days after discharge
column28: the patient restarted treatment with sertraline on the advice of her primary care physician in the event of a possible recurrence of the depressive symptoms. The patient returned to the emergency department in March 2016 for dyspnoea on slight exertion and oppressive central thoracic pain that increased with deep inspiration. Pulmonary auscultation revealed a vesicular murmur with crackles in the right base. He was readmitted to internal medicine
column29: where a chest X-ray revealed the presence of smaller pulmonary infiltrates than in the previous admission. It was decided to withdraw sertraline for a second time
column30: and the patient recovered her autonomous capacity
column31: her dyspnoea and chest pain disappeared
column32: and her oxygen saturation increased to 93%. Two weeks after discontinuation of sertraline treatment
column33: a control chest X-ray was performed
column34: confirming the decrease in the extent of pulmonary infiltrates. It should be noted that during the whole period the patient had eosinophil levels within the normal range. The patient's clinical evolution allowed definitive discontinuation of treatment with sertraline

column1: Triamcinolone-assisted PPV was performed in a patient presenting with dislocation of a lens quadrant into the vitreous cavity with secondary macular oedema in her left eye (LO). Following phacofragmentation
column2: a peeling of the internal limiting membrane revealed marked macular oedema. Due to this oedema
column3: 5 mg/0.1 ml of triamcinolone acetonide (Trigon depot® Bristol-Myers Squibb SL
column4: Anagni Frosinone
column5: Italy) was injected at the end of the operation. After a good immediate postoperative evolution
column6: he came to the clinic four days later with painless visual acuity (VA) loss and a foreign body sensation in the LAA. VA was less than 0.05
column7: with a 3.4 mm hypopyon formed by the deposition of fine crystalline opacities with no signs of inflammation
column8: intraocular pressure of 10 mmHg and a well-positioned anterior chamber lens. The fundus showed marked vitreous haze. The patient's clinical picture suggested infectious
column9: toxic or pseudoendophthalmitis. Given the early onset
column10: the absence of inflammatory signs except for the large pseudohypopyon
column11: its crystalline nature and the fact that the patient had an anterior chamber lens that facilitated the diffusion of the triamcinolone
column12: the symptoms were oriented towards pseudoendophthalmitis and it was decided to monitor her closely with ciprofloxacin eye drops every 2 hours (Oftacilox®
column13: Alcon Cusi
column14: El Masnou
column15: Barcelona
column16: Spain) and Poly-pred eye drops every 8 hours (Allergan
column17: Wesport
column18: Co. Mayo
column19: Ireland). After four days

column23: her best corrected visual acuity was 0.3
column24: and the cornea was clear with no traces of triamcinolone in the anterior chamber.  |B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O
