column1: A 38-year-old patient
column2: with no past history of interest
column3: diagnosed with depressive syndrome and on treatment with venlafaxine (75 mg - 150 mg - 150 mg v.o.) and alprazolam (1-2 mg v.o. /8 h). She consulted her primary care physician after an episode of oppressive chest pain
column4: non-radiating and without vegetative cortex
column5: which fluctuated in intensity during the day but did not subside despite rest. An electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed showing sinus tachycardia at around 120 bpm with repolarisation alterations. He was transferred to hospital and admitted to the Intensive Care Unit
column6: where a new ECG confirmed persistent sinus tachycardia with very diffuse repolarisation alterations
column7: as well as negative T waves in the anterior face and a prolongation of the QT space of around 500 msg. He was diagnosed as having Acute Coronary Syndrome and conventional treatment was started with double antiplatelet therapy (acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg v.o./24 h and clopidogrel 75 mg v.o./24 h)
column8: anticoagulation (enoxaparin 80 mg s.c./24 h) and intravenous infusion of nitroglycerin at 10 ml/hour. When sinus tachycardia continued
column9: treatment with low doses of beta-blockers (atenolol 25 mg v.o./12 h) was started.  The absence of alterations in cardiac markers prompted a new ECG which indicated regional alterations in contractility. A coronary angiographic study showed a normal left ventricle with an ejection fraction of 65% and a normal segmental analysis
column10: showing epicardial coronary arteries without significant angiographic stenosis
column11: ruling out the existence of active coronary artery disease. Given the suspicion that the cardiovascular effects could be caused by venlafaxine
column12: the drug was withdrawn and treatment was started with sertraline 50 mg v.o./day
column13: decreasing the dose of nitroglycerine to 5 ml/h until its subsequent discontinuation. The patient progressed adequately and continued treatment with sertraline and atenolol
column14: shortening the QT interval and maintaining heart rates of around 80 bpm
column15: with ECG evolution towards normalisation of repolarisation.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 18-year-old patient who 5 months earlier had been the victim of a severe 13
column2: 800 volt electrical burn to the face while trying to save a co-worker. He presented an extensive injury with loss of both lips and nose. Extensive scarring of the perioral and adjacent areas made it impossible to use any type of local flap for reconstruction of the area. In the nasal region there was loss of skin substance and nasal lining
column3: as well as part of the cartilaginous covering of the dorsum
column4: tip
column5: tail and nasal wings. He had undergone surgical reconstruction with a frontal flap 4 months earlier in another department
column6: but this had progressed to necrosis.  Reconstruction was scheduled using a bipedicled flap from the anterior cervical region
column7: described by Tsur (3)
column8: for lip reconstruction and a right supratrochlear flap for reconstruction of the nasal lining and a left supratrochlear flap for nasal coverage. There was a partial loss of the left supratrochlear coverage flap and a small partial loss of the right supratrochlear flap for the nasal lining
column9: which were observed at 3 days postoperatively. On the fifteenth day
column10: one of the cervical flap pedicles was released and on the 30th day
column11: the other was released after complete integration of the flap to the upper lip. Thereafter
column12: several flaps were performed under local anaesthesia
column13: every 2 months
column14: for the reconstruction of the lower lip
column15: the tailbone and the nasal tip
column16: and thinning by defatting of the main flaps was also performed. A total of 7 complementary procedures were performed. Persistent residual oedema of the cervical flap
column17: keloids and hypertrophic scars appeared in the donor areas
column18: which were treated with intralesional corticosteroids. The final reconstruction
column19: 2 years after the Tsur flap was made
column20: made it possible to create an emotionally expressive structure although with limited functionality; touch-ups and refinements improved the final result
column21: achieving a satisfactory aesthetic appearance and food continence
column22: which sufficiently pleased the patient. At present
column23: 4 years after the initial surgery
column24: no further surgical treatments have been scheduled.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Female patient aged 8 years with left hemimandibular enlargement
column2: 5 months of evolution
column3: rapid growth
column4: painful. Intraorally
column5: expansion of the vestibular cortex with displacement of dental organs. Radiographically
column6: lesion destroying part of the body and left mandibular ramus
column7: but preserving condyle and coronoid process. Result of incisional biopsy
column8: mandibular plexiform ameloblastoma. Taking into account the aggressive local clinical behaviour of the lesion
column9: en bloc excision was performed. A reconstruction prosthesis was placed
column10: preserving the condyle and coronoid process. Postoperative period was uneventful. Nerve (lower dentition) and motor structures were preserved. Good mouth opening
column11: and adequate facial appearance. Three months after the initial surgery
column12: bone matrix mixed with medullary aspirate was placed in the surgical bed in an attempt to stimulate bone growth in the surgical bed
column13: observing adequate bone neoformation to date with acceptable dental occlusion. Good oral opening
column14: facial aesthetics
column15: as well as preservation of sensitivity and motor skills. Five years of control without complications.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 61-year-old Caucasian woman
column2: diagnosed 13 years previously
column3: by transbronchial lung biopsy
column4: with IPF. The patient had been treated with corticosteroids up to two years earlier. She had been receiving continuous home oxygen therapy for 20 months. Six years earlier she had been diagnosed with duodenal ulcus and had no other history of interest. In the week prior to her admission she presented with frequent and severe coughing attacks
column5: without expectoration
column6: fever or increase in her usual dyspnoea. On the day of admission
column7: she presented to the emergency department with sudden swelling in the left cervical region
column8: intermittent central thoracic pain
column9: which increased with coughing and respiratory movements
column10: and dyspnoea at rest. Physical examination revealed tachypnoea (32 breaths/minute)
column11: tachycardia (120 beats/minute)
column12: swelling and crackles in the left cervical region
column13: fine crackles in both lung fields and crackles on cardiac auscultation (Hamman's sign)
column14: with no paradoxical pulse. The most relevant analytical data were: leucocytes 23.9x109/l (80% neutrophils)
column15: haemoglobin 132 g/l
column16: haematocrit 39.4%
column17: LDH 342 U/l and creatine kinase 123 U/l. Baseline arterial blood gas values were: pH 7.47
column18: PO2 54 torr
column19: PCO2 36 torr
column20: HCO3- 27.1 mmol/l and oxygen saturation 90%. Electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm at 120 beats per minute
column21: the rest of the tracing being normal. A neck X-ray showed cervical emphysema predominantly on the left. A chest X-ray revealed a bilateral pulmonary fibrosis pattern more marked in the lower fields
column22: with an anterior pneumomediastinum evident in the lateral projection. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest showed a marked pattern of bilateral pulmonary fibrosis
column23: a pneumomediastinum and large air bullae in the left upper lobe
column24: with no evidence of pneumothorax.  The evolution was favourable with symptomatic treatment
column25: with subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum disappearing after 14 days in radiological controls.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 60-year-old man diagnosed in another hospital in 2000 with extracapillary glomerulonephritis type III associated with C-ANCA. He was treated with 5 intravenous boluses of 6-methylprednisolone followed by oral corticosteroids in a descending pattern associated with oral cyclophosphamide (we were unable to obtain the exact dosage). Cyclophosphamide was discontinued at the time due to myelotoxicity. In 2002 he was included in a periodic haemodialysis programme. In September 2006
column2: in another transplant centre
column3: he received a cadaveric kidney graft. The patient was receiving tacrolinus monotherapy
column4: although we cannot be sure whether he had previously received any other combination of immunosuppressants. His serum creatinine levels ranged between 1.5 and 1.7 mg/dl. In December 2013
column5: on the occasion of the implantation of a percutaneous aortic valve in our hospital
column6: a pre- and post-intervention assessment was performed in our department. At that time
column7: his clinical condition was good
column8: with serum creatinine of 1.5 mg/dl and proteinuria of 0.3 g/day
column9: with normal urinary sediment. In October 2014
column10: due to the appearance of respiratory symptoms with fever and deterioration of renal function
column11: the patient decided to transfer to our hospital for clinical monitoring. The fever and respiratory symptoms
column12: without microbiological or radiological evidence
column13: improved with empirical treatment with levofloxacin. However
column14: renal function worsened in a few days
column15: reaching serum creatinine levels of 4 mg/dl
column16: with proteinuria of 6.8 g/day and haematuria. C-ANCA determination was 74.2 IU/ml (normal values: 0-5 IU/ml) and P-ANCA 8.4 IU/ml (normal values: 0-6 IU/ml). All other autoimmunity parameters (ANA
column17: anti-GBM antibodies
column18: complement
column19: cryoglobulins
column20: etc.) were negative. HIV
column21: HCV
column22: HBV serology and CMV and BK viraemia were also negative. A biopsy of the renal graft was performed in which the most relevant findings were: of the 19 assessable glomeruli
column23: 3 showed global glomerular sclerosis
column24: 12 glomeruli showed cellular crescents. Some of them showed disruption of Bowman's capsule causing pseudogranulomatous inflammatory reaction of mononuclear cells. In 2 glomeruli there were lesions compatible with fibrinoid necrosis. We found tubular necrosis in 15%
column25: tubular atrophy in 20% and some haematic casts
column26: as well as interstitial infiltrate in 25% with some eosinophils and foci of recent interstitial haemorrhage and arteriolar hyalinosis
column27: with some images of mucoid degeneration of the wall without transmural infiltrate. The immunofluorescence study was negative. The immunohistochemical study for C4d was negative.  Given the evidence of a recurrence of the underlying disease
column28: the patient received 3 intravenous boluses of 500 mg of 6-methylprednisolone (the patient was diabetic) on consecutive days
column29: followed by oral prednisone at a dose of 0.5 mg/kg/day in a descending pattern. He also underwent 8 sessions of plasmapheresis and was started on treatment with mycophenolate mofetil (1 g/12 h
column30: oral) associated with tacrolimus. Twelve days after admission
column31: the patient was discharged with a serum creatinine of 2.9 mg/dl. At an outpatient follow-up one month later
column32: creatinine was 2.3 mg/dl and proteinuria was 3.6 g/day. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 37-year-old single man
column2: a farm worker
column3: who was sent to our department from another hospital because it did not have the necessary experience to treat the type of lesion he was suffering from; at that time he presented a penoscrotal lesion for which he had been urgently admitted 15 days earlier to the Urology Department of his hospital of origin with a diagnosis of suspected infected sarcoma or lymphogranuloma venereum. He had not previously been seen or treated in any other medical centre. During the 10 days he was admitted to the urology department
column4: he was initially treated with Metronidazole and Ceftazidime
column5: and once the antibiogram had been performed
column6: with Amikacin
column7: Trimethoprim/Sulfamethoxazole and Cefotaxime. The biopsy diagnosis was Buscke-Lowenstein warty carcinoma. On admission
column8: he presented with an exophytic tumour lesion on the penis measuring about 15 cm in diameter. The patient reported that it had started 6 months earlier as a small ulceration in the balanopreputial sulcus that progressively grew in the shape of a cauliflower and eventually infiltrated the surrounding tissues. In the penis
column9: it affected the skin
column10: dartos
column11: Buck's fascia and albuginea
column12: invaded the interior of the corpora cavernosa
column13: destroyed the urethra and its spongiosa but respected the glans
column14: and also infiltrated the pubic tissues
column15: the scrotum and its contents. The boundaries between the affected tissues and healthy tissues were not well defined; in the affected tissues there was a deformed
column16: soft
column17: fungal
column18: ulcerated
column19: purplish mass
column20: foul-smelling and bleeding in some areas; the peripheral tissues were oedematous and there were palpable bilateral iliac and inguinal adenopathies. The patient urinated through an inconspicuous fistulous orifice located between the mass and the remains of the destroyed urethra. Clinical tests were normal; serological tests for brucellosis
column21: lupus and HIV were negative; bacteriological culture was positive for bacteroides caccae
column22: proteus mirabilis and staphylococcus aureus. Pathological examination of the biopsy indicated giant Buschke-Lowenstein condyloma acuminatum. Craniocaudal axial sections from the upper edge of the symphysis pubis to the root of the penis were performed using computerised axial tomography (CAT). The images showed bilateral lymphadenopathies in the internal and external iliac and inguinal chains; some of these lymphadenopathies exceeded one centimetre in diameter. The solid mass infiltrated the penis and scrotum and also appeared to infiltrate the fascia of the left adductor muscle
column23: but no infiltration of the fat of the subcutaneous cellular tissue of the inner wall of the thighs or the fat of the perineum was observed
column24: nor were there any bony lesions in the ischio-ileo-pubic branches suggestive of metastatic infiltration.  Given the characteristics of the tumour
column25: the involvement of the lymph node chains and the possibility of malignancy
column26: it was decided to perform radical surgical treatment
column27: which was carried out 3 days after admission to Plastic Surgery. Under general anaesthesia
column28: with the patient in the supine position and the lower limbs apart
column29: we made a perilesional incision through the pubis
column30: inguinal folds and perineum
column31: excising the tumour lesion en bloc; we then performed a lymphadenectomy of the affected chains
column32: thus completing the emasculinisation of the patient. The incisions of the lymphadenectomies were closed in planes and the perineum-inguino-pubic area was covered with a skin graft taken from the left thigh.   Intraoperative study of an irregular biopsy specimen measuring 3 x 2 cm revealed a nodular formation with the appearance of a lymph node
column33: suspicious for carcinoma metastasis due to the existence of non-conclusive atypical cells. The anatomopathological study of the excised piece described: an irregular piece of warty appearance
column34: which on one side shows the penile glans penis
column35: measuring 18 x 15 x 12 cm of larger dimensions. The tumour occupies most of the piece
column36: encompasses the penis circumferentially and affects the skin of the pubis
column37: scrotum and perineum. When cut
column38: the tumour is friable
column39: with vegetative growth on the surface and papillomatous growth in depth
column40: which also deeply affects the glans and perineal tissues; the testicles are engulfed by fibrosis and the tumour mass
column41: although not infiltrated. The lymph nodes of the lymphatic chains sent for analysis are reactive
column42: but free of tumour metastases. After surgery
column43: the patient was admitted to the resuscitation unit for 2 hours and then to the hospital ward for 25 days. A second operation was necessary due to partial necrosis of a small area of the wound of the left lymphadenectomy incision and the loss of approximately 25% of the skin graft used for the perineo-inguino-pubic closure. During hospital admission
column44: the usual postoperative medical treatment was administered and no blood transfusion was necessary. The patient remained catheterised since the operation and was discharged from hospital with the catheter
column45: which he kept for a further month at home. As a result of the operation
column46: a small stump was left with a hole in the perineal region
column47: where the urethra ends and through which urination takes place. Despite having been explained to the patient the different types of surgical procedures available for penile reconstruction (5)
column48: with their advantages and disadvantages
column49: he has always refused to undergo reconstructive surgery.    As a consequence of emasculinisation
column50: he developed hypergonadotropic hypogonadism
column51: which is why he has been treated with testosterone since the operation (12 years to the present). On the other hand
column52: as it is a benign tumour
column53: no postoperative medical treatment of any kind has been carried out
column54: nor radio or chemotherapy as they are not indicated.    |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: 48-year-old male
column2: with no history of medical interest or toxic habits
column3: and no known allergies. While working in the warehouse of a nuclear power plant
column4: he was required to unload a lorry carrying 55% hydrazine hydrate. One of the drums accidentally fell to the ground
column5: causing a spillage of about 25 litres
column6: and the company's own emergency services were notified and diluted the 3 m2 area where the spillage had occurred with water. The patient actively participated in the collection of the waste
column7: without using any personal protective equipment; at the end of the task he did not change his clothes or take a shower. Several hours after the accident
column8: he began to notice a reddening of the mouth with cheilitis of the lower lip
column9: oral aphthae and diffuse abdominal pain. He was seen by a medical service
column10: where he was prescribed symptomatic treatment. Six days after the accident
column11: he developed erythematous scaly lesions on his face and arms (areas that were not covered during the accident). He therefore went to a hospital where he underwent a general blood test and simple chest and abdominal X-rays
column12: which were normal
column13: and was prescribed treatment with antihistamines. Two weeks later
column14: he visited the Toxicology Unit of the Hospital Clinic of Barcelona on his own initiative
column15: due to persistence of the erythema-squamous lesions
column16: abdominal discomfort and dysgeusia. The physical examination was normal and the blood and urine tests showed only a total bilirubin of 2.5 mg/dl (VN: up to 1.2 mg/dl) with an indirect bilirubin of 2.1 mg/dl. The abdominal ultrasound was normal. He was checked after one and three months and was found to be asymptomatic
column17: although bilirubin remained slightly elevated
column18: and he was discharged from the hospital.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 68-year-old male
column2: with no history of interest and asymptomatic from a digestive point of view. He was referred to the outpatient gastroenterology department for presenting normocytic anaemia and a positive faecal occult blood test (FOBT). The rest of the blood tests and the physical examination showed no findings of interest. Colonoscopy showed an ulcerated lesion at the level of the cecum
column3: in front of the ileocaecal valve
column4: compatible with malignant neoplasia
column5: from which multiple biopsies were taken. These showed ulcerated tissue with no tumour cells visible. In view of the suspected diagnosis
column6: the study was completed with a CT scan
column7: which showed thickening of the wall of the cecum and ascending colon with no evidence of lymph node or distant involvement. Tumour markers were normal. Given the negativity found in the samples
column8: it was decided to repeat the colonoscopy
column9: and biopsies were taken again
column10: which were also negative for malignancy. The biopsies taken at the first colonoscopy were reviewed and showed granulomas with the presence of multinucleated giant cells and mycobacterial bacilli with Ziehl Nielsen staining.  The patient was referred to the outpatient pulmonology department
column11: although he had no respiratory symptoms. Mantoux test was negative
column12: but Quantiferon® was positive (value: 5.12). Chest X-ray showed a reticulonodular infiltrate in both upper fields. Sputum was collected
column13: which was not bacilliferous
column14: and samples were sent for culture
column15: which were negative. PCR of the colon samples was also negative. Standard antituberculosis treatment was started and the clinical course was good. Six months after the end of treatment
column16: a follow-up colonoscopy was performed
column17: which was normal.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 46-year-old man with no history of interest presented with recent onset iron deficiency anaemia (Hb 11.3g/dL; MCV 79.8 µ3; Urea 29 mg/dL; Creatine 0.95 mg/dL; Iron 29 µg/dL
column2: Ferritin 12 µg/L) at a routine check-up at work. The patient denied ingestion of gastro-lesive drugs and digestive externalisation of the bleeding
column3: so conventional endoscopic examination was indicated (gastroscopy and ileo-colonoscopy)
column4: which was negative. After 30 days
column5: the study was completed with an ECE
column6: which was also negative
column7: and the study was terminated and symptomatic treatment with oral iron supplements was indicated. After 3 months
column8: the patient attended the emergency department for asthenia and melena in the last 48 hours. On physical examination he was pale and sweaty. His blood pressure was 90/60 mm Hg and heart rate was 105 beats per minute
column9: and a rectal examination revealed the presence of melena stools. Laboratory tests in the emergency department (Hb 7 g/dL; MCV 77.2 µ3; Urea 57 mg/dL; Creatine 0.74 mg/dL) confirmed the suspicion of gastrointestinal bleeding
column10: and the patient was admitted for observation. In the first 24 hours
column12: 000 ml of fluid therapy was administered and 4 red blood cell concentrates were transfused
column13: with post-transfusion haemoglobin of 9.5 g/dL. Once the patient was stabilised
column14: and given the suspicion of an upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage
column15: an urgent gastroscopy was performed
column16: which was negative
column17: and a new ECE was repeated at that time. In this last examination
column18: the origin of the bleeding was identified from a gastric lesion of submucosal origin and ulcerated on its surface that was hidden between the gastric folds. The diagnosis of certainty was obtained after a new gastroscopy and after ruling out metastatic disease
column19: the lesion was resected. The histopathological study confirmed the submucosal origin of the lesion (gastric GIST).   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: As part of the activity of the Basic Prevention Unit of the Osakidetza Alav University Hospital
column2: medical consultations are carried out at the request of the workers. The worker
column3: a 41-year-old administrative assistant
column4: first came to our Unit on 4 December 2013. The symptoms she presented with were a cough
column5: especially at night
column6: sneezing
column7: a feeling of fatigue
column8: with no fever or accompanying expectoration. She also reported a frontal headache with tension features. The cough and feeling of fatigue had been present for several weeks. Personal history: allergy to mites
column9: grasses and animal epithelium. She smoked 20 cigarettes/day
column10: with a high level of dependence (according to the Fagerstrom test). She did not take any medication
column11: nor did she have any other additional pathology
column12: except that a few years ago she had presented papular
column13: pinkish lesions on her fingers
column14: which were assessed by Dermatology as Granuloma annulare and treated with topical corticoids. It should be noted that she had a pet cat
column15: which she could not do without. On examination
column16: cardiopulmonary auscultation was normal
column17: with no signs of neurological involvement. Initially
column18: it was thought to be an allergic condition
column19: probably related to the cat's epithelium. Treatment was prescribed with inhaled bronchodilators and analgesics for her headache
column20: and she was scheduled for a follow-up appointment in 10 days. The worker improved substantially with the bronchodilator and did not attend a check-up. When she stopped the bronchodilators on her own initiative
column21: she again presented with coughing and a more pronounced sensation of dyspnoea. She returned to our clinic one month after the initial visit
column22: with similar coughing symptoms and a feeling of fatigue
column23: with a normal cardiopulmonary examination
column24: so spirometry and chest X-ray were requested. The spirometry performed on the worker was strictly normal. The chest X-ray requested showed images of millimetric nodules predominantly in both upper fields
column25: which were not present in the patient's chest X-ray of February 2012. A high-resolution CAT scan (HRCT) was requested
column26: and at the same time a consultation was made with Pneumology
column27: completing the study with CO2 diffusion tests and pulmonary flow curve.  The CAT scan showed bilateral pulmonary involvement
column28: predominantly in the upper fields
column29: with thickening of the bronchial walls. Scattered nodules
column30: some cavitated inside
column31: giving rise to cystic images.  The CO2 diffusion tests and pulmonary flow curve were within normal parameters. Complete blood tests were carried out and ANCA and ANA were negative. Given the radiological findings described in the CT scan and the smoking habit
column32: the initial diagnostic suspicion was of Histiocytosis X
column33: so it was decided to refer for confirmation by lung biopsy
column34: for which a bronchoscopy was performed and samples were taken using the cryobiopsy technique. The cryobiopsy probe is located 1-2 cm from the pleura using fluoroscopy.  The cryoprobe used is a flexible probe with a diameter of 2.4mm
column35: which is connected to the cryotherapy equipment. The freezing of the tissue to which the probe is applied results from the decompression of the gas (nitrous oxide) at the end of the probe
column36: which allows the extraction of a traction-stable sample. As with transbronchial biopsies
column37: the probe is introduced through the bronchoscope and cold is applied for 3 seconds. The difference to the traditional clamp technique is that in this case sedation of the patient is required
column38: which on the other hand provides greater comfort and better tolerance. Emphysema changes and intra-alveolar accumulations of histiocytes with fine brownish cytoplasmic pigmentation associated with hyperplastic pneumocytes are described.  Immunohistochemistry showed nodular clusters of CD1-positive cells
column39: compatible with Langerhans cell histiocytosis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 38-year-old patient with amputation of the left forefoot due to arteriopathy caused by Buerger's disease. In January 2008
column2: Durogesic® 100 μg/h plus transmucosal fentanyl 400 μg rescue was prescribed for pain in the affected leg of 8/10 on the visual analogue scale (VAS). In one of the prescriptions for this drug
column3: in September 2008
column4: a pharmacy dispensed another commercial brand
column5: after which he began at 4 h with pain 7/10 on the VAS
column6: which he had not experienced for months
column7: nausea and gastralgia
column8: which were treated favourably with metoclopramide
column9: improving gastric pain
column10: and pantoprazole 40 mg every 12 h
column11: and increasing the dose of oral transmucosal fentanyl from 400 to 600 μg. After 2 days
column12: the patient was prescribed Durogesic® 100 μg/h
column13: with a favourable resolution of the patient's allergic pathology. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 70-year-old woman with a history of arterial hypertension
column2: hiatus hernia
column3: constipation and hysterectomy who consulted for irritative voiding syndrome for 8 months
column4: consisting of intense dysuria and pollakiuria with occasional urinary urges without other urological symptoms. In the last 6 months she had presented 3 episodes of lower urinary tract infection with positive urine cultures for E. coli treated by her general practitioner. Initial work-up included blood biochemistry which was normal
column5: urine and urine sediment study which showed intense leukocyturia
column6: urine culture which was again positive for E.coli and urine cytology by spontaneous urination which showed urothelial cells without atypia and abundant neutrophilic polymorphonuclear leukocytes. Treatment was prescribed with antibioteparia and anticholinergic (tolterodine). After 3 months
column7: the patient was reviewed in the outpatient clinic
column8: with persistent symptoms based on dysuria and pollakiuria
column9: although she had improved considerably from the emergencies with the anticholinergic drug
column10: and even days before the review she had had a new episode of urinary tract infection. Given the poor response
column11: a more advanced study was initiated
column12: requesting intravenous urography to rule out a urothelial tumour of the upper urinary tract
column13: which was strictly normal
column14: and urological ultrasound
column15: which was also normal
column16: so cystoscopy was performed in consultation
column17: finding nodular lesions
column18: raised
column19: solid in appearance
column20: slightly reddened
column21: with adjacent areas of oedema
column22: located in the trigone and lower part of both lateral sides. Due to this finding
column23: despite the fact that the patient had no risk factors for TB and the urography was strictly normal
column24: urine smear microscopy and Lowenstein-Jensen culture of 6 samples of the first morning urine on consecutive days were performed
column25: as the bladder lesions macroscopically could be tuberculomas
column26: and these studies were negative for Koch's bacillus
column27: so endoscopic resection of the lesions described was performed under anaesthesia. The anatomopathological study revealed ulceration of the mucosa with significant chronic inflammatory infiltrate and vascular congestion
column28: as well as the presence of plasma cells and lymphocytes constituting lymphoid follicles
column29: These are divided into a central zone with abundant lymphoblasts and immunoblasts
column30: called the clear germinative centre
column31: and a peripheral zone formed by mature cells (lymphocytes and plasma cells) giving rise to mantle lymphocytes or corona radiata
column32: as they are also called.  The patient was prescribed hygienic-dietary measures and long-term antibiotic prophylaxis with a single daily nocturnal dose for 3 months and then every other day for 6 months with ciprofloxacin
column33: vitamin A in a single daily dose for 6 months
column34: prednisone 30mg for 45 days and then every other day for another 45 days until its definitive suspension
column35: and finally digestive protection with omeprazole. The patient experienced clear improvement with progressive disappearance of the symptoms
column36: especially after the third month of treatment. Currently (one year after the end of treatment)
column37: she is asymptomatic with normal control cystoscopy and negative urine cultures.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 35-year-old woman consulted for terminal dribbling or "drooling micturition"
column2: dyspareunia and repeated urinary tract infections. Intravenous urography and voiding cystography showed findings compatible with urethral diverticulum. The patient had urinary frequency and nocturia 3 to 4 times. Occasionally she had had isolated episodes of stress urinary incontinence
column3: for which she used a daily protective pad. She had urinary urgency and occasional urge incontinence. There was no urinary voiding
column4: no sensation of bladder pressure or incomplete emptying. No haematuria or symptoms or signs of genitourinary cancer. Normal bowel rhythm. No previous female sexual dysfunction until the present dyspareunia affecting her sex life. No neurological pathological history. Medical and surgical history: High blood pressure. Asthma in childhood. Occasional lumbosacral pain. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy 2 years ago. Two caesarean sections
column5: the last one 12 years ago. On antihypertensive treatment with atenolol
column6: chlorthalidone and amlodipine. No known allergies. No diabetes. No smoking or drinking. Physical examination: Morbid obesity. Good general health. Examination of the head
column7: neck and cardio-pulmonary system with no pathological findings. Blood pressure: 140/100. Abdomen soft
column8: obese
column9: not painful
column10: no hepatosplenomegaly. Pelvic examination in dorsal lithotomy position: relatively narrow vaginal introitus; bulge in the suburethral area near the bladder neck and mid urethra approximately 2.5 cm in diameter
column11: fluctuant
column12: compatible with a urethral diverticulum. No pus was obtained on pressure. No stress incontinence was observed.  Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the pelvis was performed on axial T1
column13: axial T2
column14: fatty T2 sequences in both right and left images. Two liquid formations were found in the pelvis. The larger one measured 3.4 cm in its longitudinal axis
column15: in the right parasagittal area
column16: the second collection measured 1 cm in its longitudinal axis. The one cm diameter formation had the same characteristics and was located between the parasagittal and mid-sagittal area. A relationship to the urethra could not be documented in the other sequences. The impression was of a large urethral diverticulum
column17: at least 3.5 x 2.5 cm
column18: however
column19: it could not be ruled out that the smaller collection was a Bartholin's gland cyst.  Flexible cystourethroscopy under anaesthesia revealed a large urethral diverticulum 10 mm from the bladder neck. On compression
column20: there was no drainage from the urethra. At cystourethroscopy with 12 and 70 degree optics
column21: two ostia were found in the mid urethra at 7 o'clock cystoscopic time. The ostia were within a few millimetres of each other. The rest of the urethra was unaltered. Macroscopically
column22: the diverticulum did not involve the bladder neck
column23: nor did it deform the trigone. Cystoscopy showed both ureteral orifices to be normal and orthotopic. No alterations were found in the rest of the bladder. The diagnostic impression was of complex urethral diverticulum with two ostia at 7 o'clock cystoscopic time in the middle urethra. A urethral diverticulectomy was indicated. The patient was previously informed of the risks of the procedure
column24: including urethrovaginal fistula
column25: urethral stricture
column26: urinary incontinence and possible subsequent reconstructive surgery. Procedure  General anaesthesia. Lithotomy position. Sterilisation and preparation of the external genitalia field in the usual way. Silk fixation stitches in the labia minora to expose the anterior vaginal wall. Antegrade placement of a 16 French suprapubic cystostomy tube using the Lowsley retractor. The balloon of this catheter was inflated with 7 ml of sterile water and left as a gravity drain for the duration of the operation. Placement of a 16 Fr Foley urethral catheter into the urinary bladder. Cystoscopy was performed confirming the preoperative diagnosis. The anterior vaginal wall was infiltrated with a total of 15 ml of saline containing lidocaine and epinephrine. An inverted U-shaped incision was made and a flap of the anterior vaginal wall was dissected until the periurethral fascia was exposed. A horizontal incision was made in the periurethral fascia and a plane between the urethral diverticulum and the periurethral fascia was carefully dissected. It should be noted that the wall of the diverticulum was very thick and indurated. The diverticulum was dissected down to the level of its own neck. The diverticular neck was sectioned just flush with the urethra
column27: exposing the previously placed Foley urethral catheter. The edges of the urethra were approximated by suturing the urethral mucosa continuously with 3-0 Vycril. In the horizontal plane the periurethral fascia was reapproximated with loose Vicryl stitches. The anterior vaginal flap was used as the final layer. As there was excess anterior vaginal wall tissue overlying the diverticulum
column28: the excess was trimmed and the anterior vaginal incision was closed with continuous 2-0 Vicryl suture. The Foley urethral catheter was left in place and the suprapubic cystotomy was left draining under gravity. It should be noted that dissection of the diverticulum
column29: which was 4 cm in length
column30: was very difficult
column31: mainly due to the difficulty of dissecting the entire length of the diverticulum up to the neck of the diverticulum. Pathology report: Tissue fragment measuring 4.0 x 2.0 x 0.5 cm and another tissue fragment measuring 2.0 x 1.0 x 0.5 cm compatible with complex urethral diverticulum
column32: with chronic inflammation covering dense connective tissue.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: A 56-year-old Caucasian woman was referred to the oral and maxillofacial surgery department with progressive dysphagia of 6 months' duration. She also reported an accentuated foreign body sensation on swallowing. His personal history includes psychomotor retardation with borderline IQ and functional limitation of the right lower limb. She was short in stature and hypothyroidism
column2: which had never been assessed. The intraoral examination revealed a vaguely purplish
column3: vascularised
column4: hard and non-painful tumour on palpation in the lingual midline behind the foramen caecum. The visible tumour surface is not ulcerated. No cervical lymph nodes were palpated. An MRI scan was requested showing a uniform mass at the base of the tongue measuring approximately 5 x 4 cm compatible with lingual thyroid with severe obstruction of the airway. The study was completed with an isotopic scintigraphy with Tc99 which showed accentuated uptake at the base of the tongue with no uptake in the usual pre-laryngeal hyoid position. The patient was referred to an endocrinologist to check his thyroid function and with the diagnosis of lingual thyroid
column5: surgery was decided given the progressive obstructive dysphagia.  Under general anaesthesia
column6: a tracheostomy was initially performed to adequately secure the airway given the large size and posterior location of the tumour at the base of the tongue. A suprahyoid mid cervicotomy is performed
column7: combined with deperiostealisation of the mandibular lingual table and posterior lingual pull-through to increase surgical control at the time of resection. Given the deep posterior location of the tumour
column8: an exsanguinating median glossotomy is required
column9: which allows complete tumour excision under direct control without associated injury to vital adjacent structures. Finally
column10: the approach routes are closed in planes.  The patient had an excellent evolution and was decannulated in the immediate postoperative period. The pathological anatomy confirms the diagnosis of lingual thyroid. The follow-up MRI showed an absence of lingual thyroid tissue.  She was followed up by us and by the endocrinologist for regular check-ups to monitor her baseline hypothyroidism.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 18-month-old female was brought to the emergency department because she presented with a 48-hour history of fever of 38.5o C maximum axillary temperature
column2: limping
column3: an antalgic attitude
column4: pain and limitation to passive and active mobilisation of the left hip. Blood tests were completed with elevated acute phase reactants (17
column5: 800 leukocytes with 53% neutrophils
column7: 000 platelets
column8: ESR 55 mm/hour
column9: CRP 9.56 mg/dL and PCT 1.5 ng/mL)
column10: negative blood culture
column11: bone x-ray without alterations and ultrasound of the hips with distension of the joint capsule and intra-articular echogenic content. Given the suspicion of septic arthritis of the left hip

column13: given that the patient was correctly vaccinated for her age
column14: a sample was sent to the reference hospital for typing of the bacteria
column15: which turned out to be type f sensitive to cefotaxime. After a week in hospital
column16: blood tests were performed with normal haemogram
column17: white blood count and immunoglobulins. In view of the results of the culture and antibiogram
column18: intravenous cloxacillin was discontinued and the patient was given only parenteral cefotaxime at the same initial doses and the condition was monitored. After completing 10 days of intravenous antibiotherapy and 14 days of oral antibiotherapy (with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid)

column20: no pain
column21: no limp when walking and no sequelae in imaging techniques performed after treatment was completed). column1: A 65 year old man with a spinal cord stimulation electrode (MES) system to control pain secondary to ischaemia due to peripheral artery disease and induction of vasodilatation. Despite therapeutic efforts
column2: the poor evolution of the disease led to the amputation of the right lower limb in November 1998. The following month
column3: the patient began to report symptoms compatible with phantom limb pain. Double anticonvulsant therapy
column4: antidepressants and minor analgesics and adjustment of EEM parameters were started. The pain was partially controlled
column5: but episodes of lancinating pain persisted with visual analogue scale (VAS) = 8. In 2005
column6: the patient was preferentially referred to the gastrointestinal medicine department for consultation
column7: as he had MES and the possible implication for scalpel management with diathermy for endoscopic polypectomy. Following the supplier's specifications
column8: the digestive medicine department was informed of the impossibility of using shortwave diathermy and microwave diathermy
column9: as this could cause heating of the electrode interface in the tissue
column10: which could cause tissue damage. Therefore
column11: the use of bipolar electrocoagulation was recommended. The digestive service commented that endoscopic polypectomy with bipolar electrocautery could not be performed; furthermore
column12: after consultation with the general surgery service
column13: it was considered that only a total colectomy should be performed after biopsy and anatomopathological diagnosis of the lesions. In view of this clinical situation
column14: it was decided to assess the real effectiveness of the EEM after 7 years of operation and
column15: if ineffective
column16: to remove it in order to be able to perform endoscopic polypectomy using standard diathermy. To this end
column17: the EEM was switched off and the patient was scheduled for assessment after 1 month. At this appointment the patient assessed his baseline pain with a VAS = 4 with episodes of paroxysmal pain of VAS = 7. His degree of disability was similar whether the electrode was on or off. After 6 months of follow-up with the electrode off and no change in the clinical situation
column18: it was decided to remove the EEM and proceed with endoscopic polypectomy. The phantom limb pain worsened over the years with partial response to anticonvulsants and antidepressants. The patient continued to have a baseline VAS of 4 and increasingly frequent episodes of lancinating pain of 10. With regard to his quality of life
column19: the Lattinen index had a value of 12 and
column20: in addition
column21: the patient was depressed and his family life was affected. In view of this situation
column22: it was decided
column23: after reviewing the bibliography
column24: to schedule him for continuous perfusion of ketamine at a dose of 0.4 mg/kg in 60 min
column25: in daily sessions for 1 week. Midazolam 1 mg was administered as premedication. The only adverse effects reported by the patient during the infusions were dizziness and drowsiness. The patient was evaluated at 1
column26: 3 and 6 months
column27: with a VAS at 6 months of 0 at rest and a decrease in lancinating pain episodes of less than 2 per week
column28: with a VAS in these episodes of 6 and lasting a maximum of 10 s
column29: Lattinen of 5 and a very significant improvement in mood. He was discharged from the unit after one year of follow-up
column30: given the almost complete abolition of the picture without medication.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 35-year-old man
column2: working in the maintenance of electrical installations
column3: went to the company medical service for a routine check-up. He was asymptomatic. He had been a smoker of 10 cigarettes/day for 8 years. He was not a consumer of alcoholic beverages
column4: had no toxic habits and did not regularly take any medication. He had no family history of sudden death and had no personal history of syncope
column5: lipothymia
column6: convulsions
column7: agonal nocturnal breathing or palpitations. The medical examination revealed no abnormalities in the physical examination or in the routine complementary examinations
column8: with the exception of his baseline ECG.  Suspecting Brugada syndrome
column9: he was referred to the Arrhythmia Unit of Hospital Clínic de Barcelona. After clinical and electrocardiographic assessment and a flecainide test
column10: a diagnosis of BS was made. To complete the risk stratification
column11: an electrophysiological study was also performed
column12: which showed A-H intervals of 128 msec and HV of 44 msec. A ventricular pacing protocol was performed
column13: without induction of sustained ventricular arrhythmias
column14: and therefore
column15: in conjunction with the patient's clinical data
column16: it was concluded that BS was of low arrhythmic risk. Avoidance of the drugs and medications listed in Table 1 and vigorous treatment of any febrile symptoms were recommended
column17: as it has been shown that fever can trigger ventricular arrhythmias in patients with BS6
column18: and a genetic study was also scheduled. Six months later
column19: the patient remains asymptomatic.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 56-year-old man with a history of laryngeal neoplasia
column2: type 2 diabetes mellitus
column3: ex-smoker and ex-drinker
column4: diagnosed with hyperthyroid crisis. At that time he presented exophthalmos of 23 and 25 mm without limitation of eye movements

column22: TO of 18 mmHg
column23: and mild-moderate diabetic retinopathy. column1: Patient with cleft lip and bilateral cleft palate. The premaxilla was protruded and rotated to the right
column2: and the lateral segments had collapsed. This protrusion made lip surgery difficult because it increased soft tissue tension.  After impression taking

column1: A 63-year-old heterosexual male was admitted in November 2013 for progressive dyspnoea of one month's duration

column3: cumulative rate of 80 packs/year

column5: and had unprotected sex with different partners. He reported no previous liver disease

column9: and was treated with sun protection creams. In addition to the respiratory difficulty

column1: A 44-year-old male from Mali came to the emergency department with fever of six hours' duration and general malaise. column2: BP 122/71 and HR 137 l/min. A grade 1a goitre was palpated. In the mouth

column4: with the rest of the examination being unremarkable. Blood tests showed 500 leukocytes/mm3 (0% neutrophils) with the rest of the series normal
column5: CRP 321 mg/dL
column6: normal thyroid function and no other data of interest. Urine
column7: sputum and blood samples were taken for microbiological study and broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment was started (amikacin 20 mg/kg/day and cefepime 2 g/8 hours). The bone marrow study performed the following day detected hypercellularity with maturation arrest in myeloid series
column8: with no other data of interest

column1: A 32-year-old primigravida
column2: 38 weeks' gestation
column3: admitted to hospital for rupture of membranes. Her personal history included Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome
column4: with involvement of the right lower limb
column5: in which an increase in diameter and length could be observed
column6: with the presence of a flat angioma on the anteroexternal side of the thigh
column7: striking venous varicosities
column8: both on the thigh and right leg
column9: and trophic skin disorders that mainly affected the distal area of the leg. Followed up by the vascular surgery service
column10: she did not receive any medical treatment
column11: except for local topical products for the care of the skin disorders on her right leg. She provided a report describing the lesions that the patient presented; it also excluded the involvement of the contralateral lower limb
column12: as well as the existence of vascular malformations at other levels. She had not presented any complications as a consequence of her underlying disease
column13: with the exception of skin involvement due to circulatory stasis. The patient requested epidural analgesia for labour; at that time she had 3 cm of cervical dilatation
column14: there was effective uterine dynamics and the foetus was reactive
column15: with no evidence of foetal distress. Laboratory data showed a haemogram with platelets 136
column17: haemoglobin 10.9
column18: with the rest of the parameters being normal; the coagulation study and basic biochemistry were normal. After signing the consent form and explanation of the procedure
column19: it was decided to place a 20G epidural catheter using an 18G Tuohy needle at the level of the L3-L4 space
column20: and the technique was performed without incident. Test doses of 5 ml of bupivacaine 0.25% with epinephrine and an initial bolus of 8 ml of bupivacaine 0.25% without vasoconstrictor and 100 mg of fentanyl were administered without incident. Bupivacaine 0.0625% was perfused with 2 µg.ml-1 of fentanyl
column21: between 15-20 ml.h-1
column22: achieving very satisfactory analgesia until the end of labour. Euthocic delivery was achieved
column23: which required episiotomy
column24: and the product of gestation was a male newborn weighing 2
column26: with an Apgar test of 9-10. In the immediate postpartum period
column27: the epidural catheter was removed without incident. At 12 h after delivery

column29: low molecular weight heparin was administered s.c.
column30: prophylactically as indicated by obstetrics
column31: without incident. This treatment was maintained until the patient was discharged on the 3rd postpartum day. The patient was assessed 24 hours after delivery and telephoned one week after hospital discharge
column32: without any incident and/or complication related to epidural analgesia. The degree of satisfaction with the analgesic technique used was optimal.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 77-year-old man was referred to the hospital emergency department from his health centre for assessment of haematemesis. The patient's personal history included high gastrointestinal bleeding two years earlier
column2: in the context of taking aspirin due to a catarrhal process
column3: as well as repeated renoureteral crises (CRU) and asthma. No further information was available at the time regarding his personal history. He was taking anti-inflammatory-bronchodilator inhalation treatment; of his own volition the patient had recently discontinued his usual treatment with omeprazole. Diagnosed three days before with CRU at his health centre for colicky low back pain radiating to the left lower quadrant (LQ)
column4: he had received intramuscular diclofenac and aspirin on demand
column5: with partial relief. On presentation of haematemesis
column6: he was referred for assessment. In the emergency department
column7: the patient reported
column8: in addition to this radiating lumbar pain
column9: which he recognised as having similar characteristics to previous CRU
column10: the presentation in the last eight hours of heartburn
column11: as well as trembling when getting out of bed and instability
column12: which had led to a fall and nasal trauma. He had also presented three vomits of bloody content during this period. Physical examination revealed good general condition
column13: BP 70/50 mm Hg with normal capillary refill
column14: HR 90 bpm
column15: tachycardia 36º C; nauseous
column16: with pallor concomitant with nausea
column17: but basically normal colour; wound in nasal bridge with traces of bleeding in nostrils and "coffee grounds" in labial commissures; abdomen painful to deep palpation in CII
column18: with no signs of peritoneal irritation or apparent masses and negative rectal examination for blood and melena. Samples were taken for laboratory and cross-matching tests and serum therapy was started via two peripheral venous lines
column19: which managed to raise the blood pressure without normalising it. Blood tests showed Hb
column22: leukocytes 27
column23: 500/µL with 87% neutrophils
column24: platelets and coagulation normal; urea 52 mg/dL
column25: creatinine 2.86 g/dL; the rest normal. Given this situation of haemodynamic instability and haematemesis in a patient with a history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding and current treatment with potentially gastrolesive drugs
column26: an urgent endoscopy was requested. Immediate endoscopy revealed an oesophagus with clearly ischaemic mucosa from 30 cm and necrotic up to 38 cm
column27: as well as a normal fundus
column28: gastric body
column29: incisura and antrum
column30: with some minimal haematic debris. During endoscopy the patient went into cardiorespiratory arrest due to pulseless electrical activity. Resuscitation manoeuvres were unsuccessful and the patient died. Necropsy revealed acute necrotising erosive oesophagitis in the distal 14 cm and aortic arteriosclerosis
column31: predominantly abdominal and iliac bifurcation
column32: with saccular aneurysm in the abdominal aorta 13 cm long and 8 cm in diameter ruptured
column33: massive retroperitoneal haemorrhage of approximately 3
column34: 000 cc and extension to the peritoneal cavity.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 36-year-old woman with no medical or epidemiological history of interest was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit for sepsis and meningitis due to type B meningococcus isolated in blood and cerebrospinal fluid cultures. She received fluid therapy support
column2: ceftriaxone and vancomycin for 10 days with disappearance of clinical and analytical parameters of sepsis although with persistence of daily fever of 38o in the evening
column3: well tolerated
column4: with no other infectious focality in the complementary tests which included: serial blood cultures
column5: urine culture
column6: chest X-ray
column7: abdominal ultrasound and cranial CT scan. He was admitted to the internal medicine ward to complete the study and evolution; he remained haemodynamically stable and in good general condition
column8: fever of up to 38.5oC well tolerated
column9: right subclavian central venous access with no evidence of infection
column10: few petechiae in the lower limbs in a phase of regression
column11: with the rest of the general and neurological examination being normal. The haemogram
column12: haemostasis
column13: renal
column14: hepatic
column15: thyroid and lipid profile were normal
column16: with a ferritin value of 775 µg/dl
column17: ESR 90 mm1 per hour
column18: CRP at 23.8 mg/dl (VN <0.3 mg/dl) and procalcitonin at 0.22 ng/ml. Serology for hepatitis B and C virus
column19: HIV
column20: EBV
column21: CMV
column22: HSV types 1 and 2
column23: Coxiella burnetti and Rickettsiae was negative; autoimmunity with ANA
column24: ANCA
column25: rheumatoid factor
column26: immunoglobulins and complement were normal or negative. Mantoux reaction was negative; blood cultures via central catheter
column27: peripheral blood and urine cultures were repeatedly negative; control cerebrospinal fluid was normal except for proteinuria of 65 mg/dl with negative smear microscopy and culture. Fundus examination
column28: electrocardiogram
column29: echocardiography and thoraco-abdominal CT with contrast were also normal. A cranial MRI with contrast was requested
column30: showing a discrete generalised meningeal uptake and multiple lesions between 7-10 mm
column31: hypointense in T1 and hyperintense in T2 and Flair
column32: in the temporal white matter
column33: in the left external capsule
column34: right periventricular
column35: frontal and bilateral anterior parietal with marked peripheral uptake of contrast in a ring and associated perilesional oedema. Given the findings compatible with multiple brain abscesses secondary to meningococcaemia
column36: an extensive literature search was performed (clinical practice guidelines
column37: systematic reviews
column38: bibliographic databases
column39: meta-search engines and related non-indexed journals) which confirmed the scarce data reported regarding this complication. At this point it was decided to perform a PET-CT scan in order to rule out other possible findings/foci that could justify the persistence of the fever
column40: which corroborated the hypermetabolic uptake of the brain lesions described
column41: and the absence of uptake at other body levels.  Ruling out another infectious/inflammatory focus
column42: treatment with parenteral ceftriaxone was maintained for 8 weeks
column43: with slow but progressive disappearance of fever
column44: gradual decrease until CRP and ESR normalised
column45: as well as disappearance of brain abscesses in MRI control after finishing treatment
column46: with no complications or recurrence of the condition in the subsequent outpatient follow-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 40-year-old patient
column2: polydrug addict since adolescence
column3: with a first admission to prison at the age of 20
column4: and with repeated admissions thereafter. In 1993
column5: co-infection with HIV and HCV was detected. His medical history includes the prescription of the first ART in 1998

column8: and probably oesophageal
column9: candidiasis - Pulmonary TB and brain lesions due to toxoplasmosis and/or TB - almost constant seborrhoeic dermatitis In August 2009
column10: he presented with crusty
column11: scaly
column12: non-pruritic lesions initially on the scalp
column13: ears and armpits. Subsequently
column14: these lesions spread to the trunk and extremities
column15: including soles and palms of the hands and feet. Similar lesions also appeared on the intergluteal fold and genitalia. The dermatologist diagnosed psoriasis and prescribed treatment with calcipotriol plus betamethasone
column16: salicylic petrolatum and tracolimus 0.1%. This treatment was not started until a new admission to prison at the beginning of 2010. In recent weeks
column17: a slight improvement has been observed. At the beginning of the case
column18: the CD4+ cell count was 64 with an HIV CV of 1
column20: 000 copies/ml (6.04 log). He also had significant cachexia (BMI < 16) and anaemia (Hbina 10 g/dl; Htcto. 30%). The patient has refused ART. column1: A 58-year-old woman diagnosed with seropositive
column2: erosive and nodular rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with high titres of rheumatoid factor for 15 years. She had received previous treatment with different disease-modifying drugs (DMARDs): hydroxychloroquine
column3: sulfasalazine
column4: cyclosporine and leflunomide
column5: which were withdrawn due to ineffectiveness. He followed background treatment with methotrexate 25mg/weekly/sc
column6: prednisone 5-10mg/day variable and infliximab 5mg/kg/IV/8 weeks with acceptable disease control in the last 2 years with low activity without reaching complete remission. He developed septic arthritis of the right ankle with synovial fluid culture positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Infliximab was withdrawn and treatment was started with intravenous antibiotherapy. After 3 months she consulted for red eye
column7: intense periorbital pain and photophobia. The patient presented with an upper peripheral corneal infiltrate in a crescent shape with extreme stromal thinning associated with scleritis. The culture of the corneal scraping was negative. On suspicion of severe QUP
column8: treatment was started with prednisone 1mg/kg/day orally with no response. Megadoses of methylprednisolone 1g/IV/3 days were prescribed. In addition
column9: surgical resection of the conjunctival tissue adjacent to the QUP and cyanoacrylate adhesive was performed to prevent ocular perforation. The patient responded poorly to treatment
column10: with persistent pain
column11: scleritis and corneal infiltrate. As there was not optimal control of her underlying disease
column12: we decided to start an infusion of rituximab 1g/i.v. two infusions 15 days apart. Three weeks after the start of treatment
column13: there was significant clinical improvement
column14: with an inactive corneal leukoma without scleritis. column1: A 68-year-old woman
column2: with a personal history of interest
column3: reported smoking 20 cigarettes/day for the last 40 years
column4: and as surgical interventions: cholecystectomy
column5: tonsillectomy and bilateral adnexectomy (due to uterine polymyomatosis). Two years earlier
column6: she was seen at a gastrointestinal clinic for moderate to solid dysphagia
column7: with no other accompanying symptoms. An upper endoscopy was performed and a hiatal hernia was found
column8: and treatment with proton pump inhibitors was recommended
column9: with considerable improvement in symptoms. Subsequently
column10: during the consultation period
column11: the patient presented with severe epigastric pain of several months' duration
column12: and a second endoscopy was repeated
column13: revealing a lesion in the middle third of the oesophagus
column14: biopsied and reported as an ulcerated and infiltrating small cell carcinoma of the oat-cell type. In view of these findings
column15: the patient underwent further studies and different explorations with the fundamental objective of finding the primary tumour (thinking of a pulmonary origin given the histological species of the neoplasm) and staging the disease. On examination
column16: the patient was in good general condition
column17: afebrile
column18: with no findings of adenopathies or relevant data on cardiopulmonary auscultation
column19: with a normal abdomen except for the right subcostal and infraumbilical scar and no neurological alterations. Laboratory tests showed no relevant alterations. The barium oesophagogastroduodenal study showed a flat
column20: ulcerated lesion 5 cm from the oesophagogastric junction
column21: about 5 cm long
column22: which discreetly reduced the lumen of the esophagogastric junction
column23: the rest of the study being normal.  The thoraco-abdominal CT scan showed a neoplasm in the middle third of the oesophagus
column24: causing a reduction in its lumen
column25: with lymphadenopathy in the subcarinal area
column26: left supraclavicular (1.5 cm); in the abdomen
column27: lymphadenopathy in the retroperitoneum
column28: retrocrural area and right iliac chain; images suggestive of bilobular liver metastases and a large splenic cyst. There was no evidence of a space-occupying lesion in the lung. Fibrobronchoscopy revealed no pathological findings. A transthoracic puncture aspirate was positive for oat-cell carcinoma
column29: which could indicate pleural invasion.  Echoendoscopy showed a vegetating and ulcerated oesophageal tumour
column30: extending from 30 to 35 cm and infiltrating 2/3 of its sides
column31: but allowing passage of the endoscope. Between 28 and 32 cm there was a well-demarcated retrocardiac extrinsic mass which did not infiltrate the oesophagus. column6: metformin
column7: omega-3 fatty acids

column12: she had not presented any outbreak of UC. He reported 2-3 semi-soft stools and denied vomiting or food intolerances. He had discontinued his antidiabetic treatment and was in remission according to the American Diabetes Association. On physical examination

column14: blood pressure 99/62

column1: A 44 year old male patient
column2: whose personal history included testicular trauma in childhood which did not require surgery.
