column3: a left teste of normal size
column4: mobility and consistency
column5: and an enlarged right hemiscroctum with a normal teste and an adjacent structure in the upper pole separate from the theoretical right teste
column6: not indurated or painful to the touch. In order to make a first approximation to the diagnosis
column7: germinal tumour markers were requested
column8: with normal results
column9: and a testicular ultrasound scan showed a structure adjacent to the right teste in its upper pole that was differentiated from it
column10: smaller in size and ultrasonographically similar to the teste
column11: associated with a right hydrocele
column12: so that the initial suspicion was of polyorchidism with associated hydrocele.  A CT scan was also performed
column13: showing two structures of similar appearance in the right hemiscrotal area
column14: one of which was smaller than the other
column15: with no other exploratory findings of interest.  An exploratory scrototomy was performed
column16: showing a right hydrocele and two interrelated structures
column17: compatible with teste
column18: sharing epididymis and deferens. A biopsy was taken of the smaller structure and eversion of the vagina was performed to resolve the hydrocele. column1: This is a 73 year old female patient who came for gynaecological consultation due to metrorrhagia. On examination
column2: no gynaecological pathology was observed and she was referred to the urology department for examination. The patient has a personal history of previous hysterectomy 20 years ago for leiomyomas
column3: and has been consulting a urologist for four years due to pain
column4: haematuria and repeated urinary tract infections
column5: having undergone a urological examination in the first consultations
column6: which included cystoscopy with multiple biopsy with the anatomopathological result of inflammation and urothelial dysplasia. Subsequently
column7: she underwent periodic check-ups
column8: including cytology and control cystoscopies with cold biopsy
column9: with no evidence of neoplasia. When she was referred by the gynaecology department
column10: an ultrasound study was performed in which a hypoechoic image was observed adjacent to the bladder
column11: and a CT scan was recommended. The pelvic CT scan showed an oval tumour
column12: with well-defined contours
column13: soft tissue density
column14: slightly heterogeneous
column15: with a maximum diameter of about 5 cm
column16: located adjacent to the left anterior margin of the bladder without communication with the bladder lumen
column17: presenting poorly defined margins with apparent infiltration of the perivesical fat
column18: and which on the anterior and inferior margin presents a linear image of soft tissue density that appears to contact the abdominal wall.  With the diagnosis of a prevesical mass suspicious of a desmoid cyst or persistent urachal tumour
column19: surgery was performed. A median laparotomy incision was performed with resection of the prevesical neoplastic process associated with partial cystectomy. Macroscopic examination of the specimen revealed an oval formation of elastic consistency measuring 8x4 cm
column20: which
column21: when cut
column22: appeared to correspond to a cystic formation filled with greyish
column23: friable material. Microscopic examination shows that the wall of the cavity is made up of fibromuscular tissue and from it a grade III papillary neoplasm of transitional epithelium can be observed
column24: which presents a fundamentally exophytic growth towards the lumen of the duct
column25: without infiltrating the whole of the wall. The tumour infiltrates the muscular wall of the bladder
column26: included in one of the resection ends
column27: without reaching the mucosa
column28: and no urothelial neoplasia is observed in the bladder lining epithelium.  The patient was discharged from hospital and remains asymptomatic at the present time.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We offer a case of a complicated crown and root fracture
column2: in which intraalveolar transplantation was used using Ledermix paste mixed with calcium hydroxide as a provisional intraconduit medication
column3: following its evolution for four years. Description of the case:. In 1996 a thirteen year old boy came for consultation with a fracture of the upper right central incisor
column4: of one week's evolution
column5: without having received dental treatment. On examination
column6: a complicated fracture of the crown-root was observed
column7: reaching up to two millimetres below the marginal gingival margin. Surgical extrusion of the root was chosen. After anaesthesia with 4% Mepivacaine
column8: an incision was made in the periodontal ligament and the root was luxated with an elevator
column9: placed on the mesiopalatal and dystopalatal sides
column10: respectively. The root was extracted and inspected for additional fractures. The apical fragment was repositioned
column11: ensuring that the tooth was stabilised and the fracture was optimally exposed with minimal extrusion. The tooth was rotated to a position 90° from the original
column12: which was considered the most stable
column13: and then splinted to the adjacent teeth. To avoid interference during occlusion
column14: part of the crown was removed.  One week after the initial treatment
column15: the pulp was removed and filled with equal parts Ledermix and calcium hydroxide
column16: and the crown was provisionally restored with composite. After six months
column17: in the absence of signs of root resorption
column18: the canal was definitively filled with gutta-percha
column19: but the crown had discoloured
column20: acquiring an intense grey colour. The non-vital teeth were bleached using a mixture of carbamide peroxide and glycerine (Endoperox®
column21: Septodont France). The patient has been monitored for four years
column22: with no signs of root resorption evident over this period of time.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 81-year-old man with a history of chronic atrial fibrillation came to our hospital with progressive dyspnoea of 2 months' duration
column2: accompanied by asthenia and unquantified weight loss. The patient was afebrile
column3: with semiology of right pleural effusion. Chest X-ray confirmed pleural effusion and mediastinal enlargement without lung parenchymal involvement. Blood tests were normal. Thoracentesis showed thick milky fluid with 1400 leukocytes/mm3 with 10% neutrophils and 90% lymphocytes
column4: protein 49 g/L (pleuroplasmic ratio: 0.66)
column5: LDH 262 U/L (pleuroplasmic ratio: 0.75)
column6: glucose 10.2 mmol/L
column7: ADA 16 U/L
column8: cholesterol 1.75 mmol/L and triglycerides 12.8 mmol/L. Cytology and conventional culture were negative. Intradermal Mantoux test was negative. Fibrobronchoscopy showed no endobronchial lesions. Ziehl-Neelsen staining and Löwenstein-Jensen medium culture of bronchoalveolar lavage were negative. A thoracoabdominal CT scan showed multiple adenopathic masses in the mediastinum and bilateral right predominant pleural effusion. A CT-guided fine needle puncture-aspiration of the mediastinal mass was performed
column9: without being able to collect adenopathic tissue. Thoracoscopy with pleural and lung biopsy and placement of a pleural drainage tube was performed. Pathology showed chronic granulomatous lesions compatible with tuberculosis in both pleura and lung. PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis was positive in the lung biopsy and negative in the pleura. Treatment was started with Isoniazid 300 mg/day
column10: Rifampicin 600 mg/day and Pyrazinamide 1250 mg/day. Despite the treatment
column11: the patient presented a clinical worsening and respiratory failure
column12: and died. A necropsy was performed
column13: which revealed bilateral chylothorax
column14: chronic granulomatous caseating lymphadenitis compatible with tuberculosis of mediastinal lymph nodes and bilateral pleuropulmonary
column15: hepatic
column16: left adrenal and renal miliary dissemination. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 62-year-old man presented with a painless decrease in visual acuity (VA) in the left eye (LA) of 2 days' duration. He had been seen 2 months previously for red eye
column2: diagnosed with conjunctivitis
column3: and treated with a fixed combination of dexamethasone and tobramycin. At that time VA was 1 and IOP 14mmHg in both eyes. Personal history was diabetes mellitus
column4: hypertension
column5: obesity
column6: hepatic steatosis
column7: hyperthyroidism
column8: ischaemic heart disease and renal transplantation for chronic renal failure secondary to chronic pyelonephritis. His systemic medical treatment included prednisone 5mg/24h (Prednisone Alonga®
column9: Sanofi Aventis)
column10: tacrolimus (Prograf®
column11: MSD) and mycophenolate mofetil (Cellcept®
column12: Roche). Initial examination was VA of 1 in the right eye (RA) and 0.1 in the LA
column13: normal biomicroscopy in the RA
column14: in the LA there was intense conjunctival injection and central predominantly tarnished cornea with mild oedema and negative fluorescein staining
column15: without Tyndall
column16: synechiae
column17: keratic precipitates or secretion. IOP was 18mmHg in OD and 46mmHg in OI. The fundus was difficult to visualise due to corneal oedema
column18: but the papilla and macula were normal
column19: with an applied retina and no peripheral lesions. On gonioscopy the angle was open
column20: with no synechiae or neovessels. During the examination
column21: the patient's somnolence and some respiratory difficulty were striking. He was also short
column22: moderately obese and had a short neck. The initial diagnosis was ocular hypertension in OI
column23: and treatment was started with the fixed combination of brimonidine 0.2% and timolol maleate 0.5% (Combigan®
column24: Allergan). He was referred to the glaucoma clinic and the pulmonology department
column25: which subsequently diagnosed severe apnoea-hypopnoea syndrome. One week later
column26: VA was still 0.1 and conjunctival hyperemia
column27: mild corneal oedema
column28: mild superficial punctate keratitis
column29: with IOP of 40mmHg persisted. Pachymetry was 512µm in OD and 574µm in OI (increase justified by corneal oedema). A differential diagnosis with a carotid-cavernous fistula or an orbital apex syndrome was suggested
column30: and a computerised axial tomography (CAT) scan was requested. Treatment was changed to brinzolamide (Azopt®
column31: Alcon Cusi)
column32: tafluprost (Saflutan®
column33: MSD) and diclofenac sodium (Diclofenac-lepori®
column34: Angelini Farmaceutica). Two days later
column35: IOP was still at 30mmHg
column36: so acetazolamide (Edemox®
column37: Chiesi-Spain) and prednisone 60 mg (Prednisone Alonga®
column38: Sanofi Aventis) were added orally.  Hyperemia progressively decreased
column39: and corticosteroids were gradually reduced
column40: but IOP remained above 26mmHg. CT ruled out any orbital and/or cranial disease. At 5 weeks
column41: a peripheral ulcer of pseudodendritic appearance with positive fluorescein staining and infiltration of the edges appeared; corneal scraping was performed for culture and detection of C-reactive protein of herpes virus and treatment was started with topical (Zovirax®
column42: Glaxo Smith Kline) and oral (Virex®
column43: Biogen) acyclovir. Microbiological analysis confirmed positivity for HVS. With this treatment
column44: the corneal lesion healed leaving a small peripheral leukoma
column45: IOP normalised and visual acuity reached 0.8.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 41-year-old woman with no past history of interest presented with diffuse abdominal pain
column2: more intense in the epigastrium
column3: of 1 week's duration
column4: together with nausea
column5: bilious vomiting and poor general condition. The pain increases with coughing and inspiration. No fever or dysthermic sensation. No choluria or acholia. On physical examination the patient is conscious and oriented
column6: affected by pain and appears serious. Mucocutaneous pallor. The patient is afebrile and normotensive. Cardiopulmonary auscultation with no findings. Abdomen without masses or megaliths
column7: with generalised abdominal pain on palpation
column8: more intense in the epigastrium
column9: with no signs of peritoneal irritation (Murphy negative). No signs of collateral circulation. No oedema in the lower limbs. No signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Laboratory tests showed normal biochemistry with increased transaminases (GOT: 146 U/L
column10: GPT: 171 U/L). Haemoglobin: 11.4 g/dL
column11: haematocrit: 34%
column12: leucocytes: 12700 without neutrophilia and platelets: 291000. Haemostasis with INR: 1.3 and cephalin time 53.3 sec. A CT scan was performed showing a thrombus with fatty density extending from the left kidney to the left renal vein (LRV)
column13: inferior vena cava (IVC) and right atrial ostium. Free suprahepatic veins. No complete occlusion of the IVC lumen. Non-specific abnormality of the pancreatic head.  Due to this last data from the CT scan together with the intense epigastralgia
column14: it was decided to perform an abdominal-pelvic ultrasound
column15: finding: liver and intra- and extrahepatic biliary tract normal. Lipoma in IVC. Ultrasound signs of cholecystitis
column16: probably perforated and possible pancreatitis. Free fluid in the pelvis
column17: perihepatic
column18: perisplenic and right perirenal spaces (more than in the previous CT scan). A differential diagnosis of bilio-pancreatic pathology vs. Budd-Chiari Syndrome was suggested
column19: so it was decided to perform a second CT scan showing bilateral pleural effusion
column20: thickening of gastric folds with increased contrast uptake and angiomyolipoma (AML) vs. renal lipoma extending towards the IVC and ostium of the right atrium
column21: with passage of contrast throughout the venous structures
column22: with portal vein and suprahepatic veins permeable. There are images suggestive of hepatic congestion: hepatomegaly
column23: increased calibre of the portal vein and suprahepatic veins with delayed arrival of contrast to them
column24: periportal oedema
column25: spleen and pancreas with blue colour and abundant free fluid.  With a presumptive diagnosis of Budd-Chiari syndrome secondary to thrombus in the cava
column26: paracentesis was performed under ultrasound control
column27: in order to exclude with greater certainty an infectious/tumoral peritoneal process as the cause of the symptom. An analytical result of transudate was obtained
column28: ruling out a peritoneal process. Transesophageal echography showed good ventricular function with no intracavitary thrombus
column29: the tricuspid valve was free and there was pericardial effusion. Finally
column30: with a diagnosis of Budd-Chiari Syndrome secondary to cava thrombus (LMA vs. Lipoma)
column31: and in view of the patient's worsening clinical condition with poor general condition
column32: urgent surgery was decided 48 hours after her arrival at the Emergency Department. SURGICAL INTERVENTION. It was a thrombus with surgical level IV as it presented a supradiaphragmatic situation reaching the ostium of the right atrium. A chevron incision was made and access to the retroperitoneum by opening from the fixed loop to Winslow's hiatus to allow complete ascending release of the intestinal package
column33: including ligation of the inferior mesenteric vein. Hepatic mobilisation is achieved by sectioning the round
column34: coronary
column35: right and left triangular and falciform ligaments. The left kidney and its corresponding hilum are then released
column36: starting with the release of the vena cava
column37: beginning at the infrarenal level and ascending to the suprahepatic level with control of the right renal vein (RKV) and section of the remaining branches except for the suprahepatic veins
column38: which are found to be free of tumour thrombus and are the only ones that attach the vena cava to the liver. The diaphragmatic hiatus is widened and the thrombus is squeezed out up to the infradiaphragmatic level. Clamping of the hepatic pedicle (Pringle manoeuvre)
column39: proximal and distal IVC and RVD with subsequent cavotomy and opening of the IVR
column40: complete removal of the thrombus and left nephrectomy.  PATHOLOGICAL ANATOMY: predominantly lipomatous angiomyolipoma of the renal sinus with vascular infiltration.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present a 66-year-old patient with a medical history of subtotal gastrectomy for gastric adenocarcinoma four years ago and arterial hypertension on treatment with spironolactone. The patient was referred by the Digestive Service for a long-standing condition characterised by: anorexia
column2: loss of 12 kilos in 6 months (current weight 42 kilos)
column3: hypochromic anaemia and constipation. Physical examination revealed a large
column4: firm
column5: painless
column6: mobile tumour that occupied three quarters of the abdomen.  Given the history of gastric adenocarcinoma
column7: the severe deterioration of the general condition
column8: the constipation and the anaemia
column9: the first clinical suspicion suggested was: ascites due to carcinomatosis
column10: tumoural intestinal obstruction or abdominal tumour. The analytical data showed haemoglobin 7.5 g/dl
column11: 3.35 million haematitis
column12: 27% haematocrit
column13: MCV 71.3
column14: RDW 18
column15: ESR 37 mm/h
column16: CRP 0.7
column17: PSA 2.6 ng/ml
column18: creatinine 0.89 and urea 24. Liver and digestive tumour markers were unremarkable. Gastroscopy revealed an inflammatory polyp in the gastric stump
column19: with no evidence of tumour recurrence. Colonoscopy was impossible due to intestinal displacement and intolerance of the patient. The abdominopelvic ultrasound revealed the presence of a cystic tumour with incomplete septa
column20: of mixed anechoic content
column21: which occupied the entire abdominal cavity. The left kidney was identified as normal
column22: with no evidence of the presence of the right kidney. In view of the finding of a voluminous intra-abdominal cystic lesion
column23: the patient was referred to our clinic where intravenous urography was performed with the result of right functional annulment
column24: contralateral normofunction and a large mass effect that displaced the digestive lumen towards the left hypochondrium and impressed the right lateral wall of the cystogram. The CT scan showed a large cystic mass measuring 29.5 cm x 27.5 cm x 16 cm
column25: with multiple septa and well-defined walls occupying almost the entire abdomen. A calcific image was identified in the theoretical renal pelvis area of the hydronephrotic kidney with compression and displacement of all abdominal structures.  Given the diagnostic suspicion of giant hydronephrosis secondary to obstructive lithiasic uropathy
column26: the possibility of percutaneous drainage and subsequent nephrectomy was evaluated. Simple right nephrectomy was performed by subcostal lumbotomy
column27: evacuating 7
column28: 800 millilitres of serohaematic content. An extended hilar lymphadenectomy was performed due to the finding of lymphadenopathies at this level. The fluid culture was negative and cytology was not performed as there was no clinical or radiological suspicion of urothelial tumour. Histological examination revealed the presence of a multicystic kidney
column29: with marked dilatation of the pyelocaliceal system and severe parenchymal atrophy (thickness 0.5 cm). The epithelial lining showed changes of dysplasia of different degrees
column30: with areas of papillary pattern and areas of infiltration of the renal parenchyma.  In other areas
column31: solid nests of cells with large
column32: clear cytoplasm and high nuclear grade (Fuhrman grade 3) were identified
column33: as well as nodal infiltration of clear cell type renal cell carcinoma.  The subsequent evolution was unfavourable
column34: with the appearance of liver metastases and the eventual death of the patient two months later.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 20-year-old male diagnosed in September 2003 with pre-B acute lymphoblastic leukaemia
column2: who received intravenous induction chemotherapy and prophylactic intrathecal chemotherapy using PL. After applying various treatment regimens for 8 months
column3: complete remission of the disease was not achieved. Four lumbar punctures for intrathecal chemoprophylaxis were performed during this period without complications. Repeated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analyses were normal on all occasions. Platelet counts prior to these punctures were 34
column9: 000 platelets/mm3 respectively. Prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) were normal
column10: and no platelet transfusion was performed prior to LP. In May 2004
column11: the patient was readmitted to hospital for a new cycle of chemotherapy and subsequently scheduled for a bone marrow transplant. A new LP was performed without incident
column12: but on this occasion several platelet concentrates had to be trans-fused beforehand as the patient had thrombocytopenia of 26
column13: 000/mm3. In the previous 2 months he had also required several transfusions due to a progressive tendency to thrombocytopenia (below 20
column14: 000/mm3). PT and APTT were normal. A few hours after the last LP
column15: the patient required attention for isolated right sciatica. After about 48 hours
column16: radicular pain was associated with loss of strength in both MMII
column17: which rapidly evolved into bilateral paraparesis
column18: with only partial motor strength (3/5) in flexion-extension of the feet. No sensory or sphincter disturbances were observed. An emergency dorsolumbar MRI was performed
column19: which showed an image suggestive of ventral intradural extraparenchymal haematoma compressing conus medullaris and cauda equina from D12 to L4. After intravenous gadolinium administration
column20: no contrast uptake suggestive of an underlying lesion was observed. Subsequently
column21: a decompressive laminectomy was performed from L1 to L4 and a longitudinal durotomy
column22: after which the cauda equina was observed under high tension
column23: contained by the intact arachnoid membrane. A small amount of subarachnoid blood clot compressed the conus medullaris dorsally. Exploration of the lateral areas showed the presence of a large ventral haematoma also contained by the arachnoid membrane. The arachnoid was then incised longitudinally and after separation of the dorsal roots of the cauda equina the clot was accessed. It was only possible to achieve a subtotal removal of the clot
column24: as it was partially organised and adhered to the nerve roots. No macroscopic lesions were observed that could be the origin of the haematoma. The surgical procedure was completed with the closure of the dural plane using a lyophilised plastia to widen the space. The postoperative course was uneventful. The patient achieved a progressive recovery of strength and was able to ambulate on the fourth day
column25: without sphincteric alterations or radicular pain
column26: and reported only a slight residual cramping in the lower limbs. In the following weeks
column27: oncological treatment and bone marrow transplant were continued
column28: but the patient developed a series of systemic complications that finally led to multi-organ failure and his death one month after the surgery. A post-surgical lumbar MRI could not be performed due to the patient's poor clinical condition.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 70-year-old woman presented to her referral hospital with a tumour on the right lateral aspect of the tongue with clinical stage T2N0M0. The biopsy was reported as squamous cell carcinoma.  The therapeutic modality decided at her hospital was external radiotherapy divided into 30 fractions (2 Gy/fraction)
column2: a total of 60 Gy for both cervical fields. The treatment was completed with brachytherapy with four Iridium 196 needles
column3: a total of 50 Gy. The disease completely subsided and the patient was free of the disease for one year
column4: at which time she returned to the specialist when she presented with inflammatory symptoms in the irradiated area
column5: with pain and fistula in the right mandibular angle. The physical examination and the orthopantomography image were diagnostic of ORN of the right mandibular body
column6: and it was decided to refer the patient to the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Department of the Hospital Universitario La Paz.  Initial treatment consisted of curettage
column7: bone remodelling and hyperbaric oxygen treatment (Hospital Militar de Zaragoza
column8: 17 sessions with 100% hyperbaric oxygen: 2.5 ATA-60 minutes). Despite attempts at resolution with conservative treatment
column9: the patient eventually developed a pathological fracture
column10: leading to a right segmental mandibulectomy and reconstruction with a microvascularised fibula free flap.  The limits of the bone resection were determined from the radiological changes showing necrotic bone together with the intraoperative macroscopic image. The affected tissue was resected with a bone margin of 0.5-1 cm to bleeding bone
column11: with en bloc removal of the intraoral mucosa and skin circumscribed to the extraoral fistula. The bone defect after mandibulectomy was 8 cm. In the postoperative follow-up
column12: 33 to 38 carious teeth with periodontal and periapical disease
column13: which caused pain and recurrent local infections
column14: were exodonticated. After an asymptomatic period of 8 months
column15: the patient consulted for a fistulised inflammatory episode in the left hemimandible
column16: which radiologically corresponded to ORN of the left mandibular body.  After attempts at conservative treatment of the new condition
column17: the symptoms persisted and the poor evolution of the disease led to a second operation with a left mandibulectomy and a second microvascularised fibula with a cutaneous island.  In the early evolution the patient developed a midline fistula
column18: which was resolved by removing the osteosynthesis plate that joined the anterior end of the transplanted first fibula with the right parasymphysis region. The final evolution of the disease has been satisfactory
column19: with adequate intra- and extraoral healing and resolution to date.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Recently
column2: we attended a 46-year-old man in our hospital
column3: with a history of Down's syndrome and severe mental retardation
column4: who came to the emergency department of our hospital presenting with diffuse abdominal pain and progressive abdominal distension of 24 hours' duration. He presented a history of constipation and absence of bowel movements in the last 2 days. As a background of interest
column5: the patient had presented
column6: 13 years earlier
column7: with a gastric volvulus that was operated on urgently
column8: and a surgical gastropexy was performed. During the operation
column9: a dolichocolon was observed
column10: with absence of fixation ligaments
column11: but no procedure was performed on it. In the current physical examination
column12: the only findings were abdominal distension and tympanism
column13: accompanied by diffuse abdominal pain. Rectal examination failed to demonstrate stool in rectal ampulla. Haemogram and biochemistry were normal. Plain abdominal X-ray showed massive dilatation of the proximal colon. This distension could also be seen on computed tomography (CT). Subsequent barium enema demonstrated the typical "bird's beak" image. Although with difficulty
column14: the barium passed into the dilated segment of the splenic angle. A therapeutic colonoscopy was performed
column15: which succeeded in untwisting the colonic segment. The patient passed a large amount of stool and gas
column16: remained asymptomatic after 24-48 hours
column17: and was discharged from the hospital and referred to the surgical department. Two days later
column18: his symptoms reappeared and he was diagnosed with recurrence of volvulus of the splenic flexure of the colon. The colonoscopy was repeated and the urgent process was again resolved. The patient underwent scheduled surgery and resection of the redundant segment of the colon was performed. The postoperative period was uneventful.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 76-year-old woman with GCCA was referred for surgical treatment. After an early failed trabeculectomy it was decided to perform a combined procedure of valve implantation and phacoemulsification. Twenty-four hours after surgery the patient showed atalamy with peripheral iridoendothelial contact with an IOP of 40 mmHg. After ruling out other possible causes of atalamy with hypertonia (choroidal detachment
column2: annular ciliochoroidal detachment and pupillary block)
column3: a diagnosis of malignant glaucoma was made and the same treatment as in the previous case (capsulotomy and hyaloidotomy through the pupil) was performed. One year after surgery
column4: IOP was 12 mmHg with timolol maleate 0.5% (Timoftol® 0.5%
column5: Merck Sharp & Dohme de España SA
column6: Madrid) every 12 hours.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 64-year-old woman with a personal history of diabetes mellitus
column2: arterial hypertension and atrial fibrillation anticoagulated with acenocoumarol. She was seen at the outpatient clinic for a clinical picture of inability to ambulate and occasional urinary incontinence
column3: with impairment of higher functions and emotional lability. Neuroimaging studies showed tetraventricular hydrocephalus. Suspicion of CAH led to the placement of a DLE as a diagnostic test. After replacing acenocoumarol with low molecular weight heparin a few weeks earlier
column4: the DLE was placed. During the transfer of the patient from the operating theatre to the hospital ward
column5: the drain was accidentally kept open. Six hours after placement
column6: after draining 240 ml of CSF
column7: the patient began to experience headaches
column8: nausea
column9: vomiting and sweating
column10: which were initially attributed to intracranial hypotension. At no time did the level of consciousness deteriorate. In view of the intensity of the symptoms
column11: an urgent cranial CT scan was performed which showed the presence of a haematoma in the left cerebellar vermis and hemisphere
column12: with subarachnoid bleeding on the upper surface of the cerebellum and in the cerebellar folia. The DLE was removed immediately and
column13: given the patient's good clinical condition
column14: it was decided to follow conservative treatment
column15: with good clinical evolution. Neuroimaging studies (MRI and cerebral angiography) ruled out the existence of underlying pathology.  The patient recovered to her previous state. Subsequently
column16: a ventriculoperitoneal shunt was implanted
column17: with great clinical improvement.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 73-year-old patient with a history of arterial hypertension and polyarthrosis presented to the emergency department with abdominal distension and pain associated with constipation and febrile fever. The symptoms had started three weeks earlier and worsened during the four days prior to admission. During this period
column2: an upper gastrointestinal fibroendoscopy (oesophagus
column3: stomach and duodenum) and a colonoscopy (up to the splenic angle) were performed
column4: but no abnormalities were found. Physical examination revealed a low-grade fever (37.6º C)
column5: a distended abdomen
column6: diffusely painful on palpation
column7: tympanised on percussion
column8: with scant borborygmi but no evidence of peritonism
column9: pulmonary auscultation with decreased ventilation in the lower half of the right hemithorax and the onset of intense pain on palpation and percussion of the last three dorsal spinous processes. Analyses showed 8.2 x 109 leukocytes / L
column10: haemoglobin 136 g / L
column11: platelets 186 x 109 / L. Except for glycaemia (123 mg/dl)
column12: the following laboratory parameters were normal or negative: urea
column13: creatinine
column14: bilirubin
column15: transaminases
column16: gamma-glutamyltranspeptidase
column17: sodium
column18: potassium
column19: chlorine
column20: calcium
column21: phosphorus
column22: creatine phosphokinase
column23: amylase
column24: lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
column25: proteinogram
column26: immunoglobulin dosage
column27: alpha-fetoprotein
column28: CA 19 antigens. 9 and CA 125 antigens
column29: as well as general urinalysis. ESR and C-reactive protein were elevated
column30: with values of 85 mm / 1 h and 133 mg / L (normal < 5 mg / L)
column31: respectively. Mantoux intradermal reaction (10 IU RT-23) was positive
column32: with an induration of 25 mm. Chest X-ray showed an image compatible with right lower lobe atelectasis in the context of an ipsilateral pleural effusion. There were no signs suggestive of adenopathy or alterations in the cardiopericardial silhouette. A thoracoabdominal CT scan confirmed the existence of a right pleural effusion and identified prominent degenerative changes along the dorsolumbar spine but
column33: above all
column34: erosions in the vertebral plates adjacent to the D10-D11 disc space. A lumbar MRI showed hyposignal on T1-weighted sequences and hypersignal on T2-weighted sequences in these vertebrae and their corresponding disc
column35: with morphological alterations typical of infectious spondylodiscitis D10-D11. Three serial blood cultures were negative. Samples obtained by aspiration of the D10-D11 space showed gram-positive cocci chains
column36: which were subsequently recovered and typed as penicillin-sensitive Streptococcus pneumoniae. Pleural fluid analysis showed pH: 7.55; leucocytes: 8.4 x 109/L (58% neutrophils
column37: 26% eosinophils
column38: 16% lymphocytes)
column39: protein: 48 g/L (ratio to serum protein: 0.65)
column40: glucose: 125 mg/dl
column41: ADA: 25.92 IU/ml
column42: LDH: 362 U/L (pleural LDH/serum LDH ratio: 0.8). Both auramine-rhodamine staining and Löwenstein-Jensen medium culture of pleural fluid were negative and cytology showed no evidence of neoplastic cells.  The patient was initially treated intravenously with amoxicillin + clavulanic acid (1 g / 200 mg
column43: every 8 hours). After 21 days
column44: she was switched to the oral route (875 / 125 mg
column45: every 8 hours) for 6 weeks. The evolution was favourable and she was able to start walking with a dorsolumbar corset after the fourth week. One month after the end of antibiotic therapy
column46: a control chest CT scan still showed a discrete pleural effusion
column47: but the patient had only mild mechanical dorsalgia
column48: her ESR had decreased to 21 mm / 1 h and her CRP was 2.4 mg/L. Outpatient follow-up continued for a further three years
column49: during which time the evolution was favourable and a D10-D11 vertebral block was formed.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 45-year-old patient admitted to the haematology department for Ig G Kappa stage III-A MM IgG with hepatic infiltration. He had no personal or family history of interest. The patient was referred to the Ophthalmology Department for a red right eye (OD) of 24 hours' evolution with no other visual or ocular symptoms. Visual acuity was equal in both eyes and the slit lamp showed a painless
column2: vascularised
column3: upper nasal subconjunctival mass in the right eye. The rest of the examination
column4: including the fundus examination
column5: was normal. The lesion progressed in 48 hours
column6: infiltrating the upper eyelid and causing ophthalmoplegia of the OD. A computed tomography (CT) scan was performed showing soft tissue enlargement without bony lesions. Biopsy of the lesion showed plasma cell infiltration. The patient was undergoing QT with Vincristine
column7: Uracil
column8: Cyclophosphamide
column9: Melphalan and Prednisone followed by Vincristine
column10: Uracil
column11: Adriamycin and Dexamethasone. On biopsy confirmation local RT was added. Despite treatment with QT and RT the infiltration continued to progress through the eyelids and conjunctiva
column12: developing acute post-rabecular glaucoma with intraocular pressure (IOP) of 50 mm Hg which did not respond to oral (carbonic anhydrase inhibitors) and topical (beta-blockers and prostaglandins) treatment. RT was discontinued and QT was replaced by Cyclophosphamide
column13: Dexamethasone
column14: Bortezomid and Adriamycin
column15: followed by Methotrexate
column16: Cytarabine and Methylprednisolane. This second line of QT resulted in remission of the infiltration within two weeks
column17: normalisation of IOP with normal visual fields
column18: although with residual ptosis and restriction of ocular motility. Despite remission of the ocular symptoms
column19: the patient died after six months.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 21-year-old male was admitted to the Neurosurgery Department for presenting nodules in the left parietal region that had increased in volume over the last 7 months. Relevant personal history included: moderate haemophilia A and surgery for scaphocephaly in childhood (craniectomy + silicone bands + bone fixation with haemoclips). She presented spontaneous intraparenchymal cerebral haematoma which was treated conservatively. There were no known episodes of trauma. Physical examination revealed a painless
column2: non-pulsatile
column3: elastic tumour with a smooth surface
column4: covered with normal scalp and measuring 5x3x3 cm in the left parietal region. The neurological examination was normal.  Laboratory findings were: haemoglobin
column5: 16g/dl; haematocrit
column6: 50%; leucocytes
column8: with a normal differential count; platelets
column9: 211000; prothrombin activity
column10: 97%; APTT: 59sec. Factor VIII: 19%. Plain X-ray and CT scan of the skull showed an osteolytic lesion of sclerotic margins at the left parietal level with erosion of the external and internal table and expansion of the diploe. MRI revealed a parietal nodule on the same side
column11: well demarcated
column12: with different signal areas inside
column13: with haemoglobin in different stages of evolution: high signal density for methaemoglobin and low signal density for deoxyhaemoglobin.  CT scan of the chest
column14: abdomen and pelvis
column15: as well as bone scintigraphy
column16: ruled out tumour or bone metastasis. The patient received 50U/kg/d Factor VIII prior to surgery which increased his Factor VIII level to 89% of normal. Throughout the operation he received a continuous intravenous infusion of 5U/kg/h of Factor VIII.  Surgical intervention Under local anaesthesia
column17: the scalp was incised over the tumour and subperiosteal dissection revealed elevation and erosion of the external table
column18: containing zygatricial fibrous tissue around a haematoma in various stages of organisation and
column19: in addition
column20: plastic tissue (silicone bands). The inner table was thinned
column21: with irregular beading and a bony defect. The haematoma
column22: granular tissue and foreign body (silicone) as well as the thinned and elevated outer table were removed to normal bone thickness and appearance by bone curettage. Histological examination confirmed the presence of old haematoma and granulation tissue. After surgery
column23: Factor VIII remained at 80% of normal activity until the suture material was removed.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 78-year-old man diagnosed in January 2012 with SS stage III-B/IV-A1 (T4N0M0) with extensive skin involvement
column2: whose personal history was a smoker of 20 cigarettes a day
column3: type 2 diabetes mellitus
column4: hypertension
column5: atrial fibrillation and benign prostatic hyperplasia. He was diagnosed with lichen planus in 2010 by the dermatology department
column6: presenting with pruritus that was controlled with corticosteroids and systemic antihistamines
column7: PUVA therapy and acitretin. When he was diagnosed with SS
column8: oral chlorambucil was added to the therapy. After 10 months
column9: in November 2012
column10: loss of response was observed starting 2nd line treatment with bexarotene together with gabapentin 300 mg daily with the aim of improving pruritus control. Skin progression after 2 months of treatment
column11: as well as insomnia and depression
column12: associated with uncontrollable pruritus
column13: led to start with a 3rd line of treatment
column14: administering polychemotherapy according to the CVP scheme (cyclophosphamide
column15: vincristine and prednisone)
column16: without doxorubicin due to the comorbidities he presented. Unfortunately
column17: after two cycles of treatment
column18: the patient continued to show no response and no improvement in pruritus. The next available option
column19: extracorporeal photopheresis
column20: was rejected by the reference centre
column21: and in this situation it was decided to administer aprepitant as antipruritic therapy
column22: a use outside the authorised indications. The Pharmacy Department
column23: together with the Haematology Department
column24: reviewed the literature and compared the doses used in the different published case series
column25: starting with a dose of 80 mg daily for 10 days and continuing with 80 mg every 48 hours. Since this was an off-label indication
column26: the patient was asked for informed consent. Each pack of Emend® (aprepitant) contains one 125 mg and two 80 mg doses. Since the dose to be used in this case was 80 mg
column27: in order to make use of the 125 mg capsule
column28: it was decided to prepare a suspension of aprepitant. To this end
column29: the contents of the aprepitant4 capsules (125 mg +80 mg +80 mg +80 mg) were extracted and 7 mL of Ora-Plus® vehicle and another 7 mL of Ora-Sweet® were added
column30: resulting in a 20 mg/mL suspension
column31: which was repacked into 4 mL oral syringes (80 mg). The suspension was given a stability of 90 days
column32: stored in a refrigerator. The patient was given both oral and written information about the days on which to take the treatment
column33: the need for refrigeration and the most common adverse effects. Fifteen days after starting treatment with aprepitant
column34: the patient reported significant improvement in pruritus. So far
column35: pruritus had always been assessed subjectively. It was decided to assess the patient's pruritus using the visual analogue scale (VAS) (0 = no pruritus and 10 = worst imaginable pruritus)
column36: and the patient was given a VAS of 5. Given the effectiveness of the treatment and the absence of adverse effects
column37: it was decided to continue with the regimen of 80 mg every 48 hours. After one week
column38: the patient was admitted for vesicular lesions and pain in the right hemithorax. During admission
column39: pruritus was well controlled. Gabapentin was also discontinued due to treatment-associated tremors and a 4th line treatment for CTCL (pegylated liposomal doxorubicin) was administered. When the patient was discharged from the hospital
column40: he did not take the aprepitant syringes with him by mistake and was off treatment for approximately 1 week. When he returned to the clinic
column41: he reported a worsening of itching
column42: so he restarted treatment with aprepitant. After 3 cycles of chemotherapy
column43: it was decided to discontinue doxorubicin given the progression at cutaneous level. As a last option
column44: weekly gemcitabine was administered
column45: but had to be withdrawn due to poor tolerance. Finally
column46: with a VAS of 9
column47: it was decided to discontinue all chemotherapy and to maintain the best supportive therapy
column48: continuing treatment with aprepitant until the end of the disease.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O

column1: A 70-year-old male smoker with pulmonary emphysema and vitiligo underwent colonoscopy in May 2001 due to diarrhoea
column2: abdominal pain
column3: general deterioration with weight loss
column4: anaemia and hypoalbuminaemia. The colonoscopy showed a polypoid mass in the sigma that produced stenosis preventing the passage of the endoscope. Although biopsies did not confirm the malignancy of the lesion
column5: resection was performed with latero-lateral colonic anastomosis. The report of the surgical specimen was: colectomy specimen with an extensive ulcer of 6.5 cm
column6: with raised edges penetrating the colon wall down to the pericolic fat with extensive reparative inflammatory reaction and mucosal inclusions with hyperproduction of mucus forming lakes at the mural level within the ulcer. The diagnosis was: deep cystic colitis. The patient improved after surgery but returned six months later with anal pain and discharge. There was a fistulous orifice in the right anal margin with no clear inflammatory signs but painful to the touch with spontaneous discharge of white fluid and an ulcer of the anal canal extending proximally. Colonoscopy confirmed that the ulcer extended 3 cm into the rectum
column7: with regular and nodular borders. At the colonic anastomosis there was another ulceration with pseudonodular formations and a large amount of mucus
column8: and at 30 cm there was another similar mucosal excavation with a possible fistulous orifice. Biopsies were non-specific. During admission he presented haematemesis and gastroscopy showed severe distal oesophagitis
column9: erosive gastritis and diffuse ulceration of the mucosa of the bulbar and postbulbar duodenum. A gastrin determination was requested and was: 817 pg/ml (normal value up to 100 pg/ml). Biopsies of the duodenal ulcers were also non-specific. The patient improved with omeprazole 40 mg per day
column10: plantago ovata and analgesics. A CT scan of the abdomen confirmed the presence of a 3 cm mass in a vascularised pancreatic tail-body. A laparotomy was performed and no pancreatic tumour was found
column11: but a mass in the transverse colon was resected. Histological examination showed: 21 cm of transverse colon with an irregular mucosal area with a variegated aspect of 7 cm in extension
column12: areas of linear ulceration with inflammatory infiltrate with microabscesses affecting the entire thickness of the piece. At two months the gastrin value was 529 pg/ml. The patient did not agree to further examinations and remained in good general condition for two and a half years
column13: having one or two bowel movements a day with some anal incontinence. He received iron due to iron deficiency anaemia
column14: plantago ovata and omeprazole 20 mg a day. In October 2004 a colonoscopy was performed for diarrhoea which showed segmental colitis from 15 cm anal margin to 35 cm with pseudopolyps and friability
column15: which looked like ulcerative colitis. The rectum was free of lesions. Colon biopsies suggested active ulcerative colitis. The patient was treated with oral mesalazine and then steroids from November 2004 to February 2005. The patient was admitted several times for worsening pulmonary emphysema and suffered a bilateral pneumothorax. He was followed up only in pulmonology consultations until April 2006.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 56-year-old male
column2: with no personal history of interest
column3: who consulted for self-limited episodes of monosymptomatic macroscopic haematuria of 2 months' duration. On rectal examination
column4: the prostate was well-defined and adenomatous in consistency (grade II/IV). The following complementary examinations were performed: - Blood count
column5: biochemistry
column6: urine culture
column7: urine cytology and sediment: within normal limits. PSA: 1.46 ng/ml. - Urological ultrasound: bilateral renal sinus cysts. Normal bladder. - Intravenous urography: pyelocaliceal distortion due to the aforementioned cysts. Patent ureters. Normal bladder. Post-myocardial film showed the presence of a 'contrast leakage' into the abdominal cavity. - Cystoscopy: small solid mass located in the bladder dome.  In view of these findings
column8: transurethral resection (TUR) of the lesion was performed
column9: with the histopathological result of adenocarcinoma infiltrating the bladder wall. Following this diagnosis
column10: an extension study was performed using chest X-ray (which was reported as normal) and abdominopelvic CT scan
column11: showing a tubular structure extending from the bladder dome to the umbilicus with a thick wall
column12: especially near the bladder (persistent urachus with possible infiltration of the wall by the tumour) and a moderate amount of free fluid in the peritoneal cavity.  One week before definitive surgical treatment
column13: the patient was admitted with a high fever accompanied by micturition symptoms
column14: abdominal pain
column15: vomiting and anorexia. On physical examination
column16: the patient showed abdominal distension with some degree of peritoneal irritation. Laboratory tests showed leukocytosis with neutrophilia. After initiating broad-spectrum parenteral antibiotic treatment
column17: the patient's symptoms improved
column18: except for the abdominal distension. Abdominal ultrasound showed a large amount of ascitic fluid with septa. With a suspected diagnosis of urachal adenocarcinoma
column19: a wide partial cystectomy was performed
column20: including the bladder dome
column21: a large mass at the level of the urachus and umbilicus
column22: as well as a pelvic lymphadenectomy. During surgery
column23: we observed a large amount of mucoid material infiltrating the entire peritoneal cavity (several samples were taken from different locations for histological study). The anatomopathological diagnosis of the surgical specimen was mucinous adenocarcinoma of the urachus with extension to the urinary bladder and peritoneum. The histological report of the mucoid material sent was pseudomyxoma peritonei.  At present
column24: after 1 year of follow-up

column1: A 19-year-old male in military uniform was found in the dorsal decubitus position with both upper limbs on the sides of the body
column2: in an open night scene. A weapon of military manufacture and use was identified on the left forearm: the Light Automatic Rifle - FAL
column3: model PARA Nº 50-63
column4: super-compact with folding stock and flame-retardant muzzle
column5: calibre 7.62 x 51 mm NATO
column6: velocity 810 m/s. The stock was found resting on the left hand (which was in a firing spasm) with the rifle in a position parallel to the body with the muzzle about 30 cm from the head
column7: magazine and firing pin facing outwards. The scene and the victim's clothes were found without signs of violence. The deceased presented blunt injuries of a tearing type in his oral cavity
column8: abundant epistaxis
column9: otorrhagia and a large blood stain under his head.  Once the protocols for fixing the scene of the crime had been carried out
column10: the body was turned to corroborate the existence of a presumed exit wound in relation to the large blood stain under the head
column11: and a small circular wound with regular edges was identified at the cervical level. The presence of a cavity in the ground was found to correspond perfectly with the cranial cavity and a perforation in the ground in direct connection with the presumed exit wound. The probing of this perforation allowed us to establish its depth at about 20 cm with an angulation of the trajectory coinciding with that estimated between the buccal cavity and the cervical orifice
column12: in a right-left
column13: bottom-up direction. The excavation of this perforation favoured the recovery of the projectile
column14: embedded in its depth.  During the autopsy procedure in the morgue and given the lesions of maxillofacial and maxillofacial involvement
column15: the lesions were described as follows: 1. Large contused lesion in the oral cavity with periorificial tearing on both margins and stellate shape
column16: with accentuated destruction towards the right side of the individual. Deposit of greyish-blackish pigments throughout the oral mucosal lining
column17: more marked in the left jugal mucosa. A large tear was identified throughout the lingual body with identical presence of pigment. In the most posterior and left lateral sector at the level of the junction of the hard and soft palate and the isthmus of the fauces
column18: a circular perforation of 1.5 cm in diameter and intense haemorrhage were observed. In terms of hard structures
column19: maxillary and mandibular fractures were observed at the junction of the respective central and lateral incisors
column20: with displacement and significant mobility of fracture ends towards the right side. No direct or indirect dentoperiodontal lesions were found in maxillary teeth. Regarding the mandibular teeth
column21: the lower right central incisor was intact but avulsed and displaced towards the mandibular basal at the depth of the fracture line
column22: while the lateral incisor on the same side showed a longitudinal amelo-cemento-dentine fracture with loss of substance. The missing tooth fragment was identified at the depth of the mandibular fracture line
column23: on the same side as the avulsed central incisor.  2. Circular perforating lesion with regular borders
column24: 1.5 cm in diameter
column25: located in the midline slightly to the left at the posterior cervical level about 3 cm below the occipital eminence
column26: partially hidden by the hair. Macroscopic examination verified the absence of metallic particles.  3. Passive probing of the trajectory established communication between the perforation described in the depth of the oral cavity
column27: in the left posterior sector
column28: with the orifice at cervical level
column29: establishing a rectilinear direction slightly right-left
column30: front-back
column31: down-up
column32: involving the musculature of the pharynx
column33: the soft palate and the tongue. On examination
column34: no metallic debris was identified along this path. Given the atypical morphology of both orifices
column35: a tongue wedge was obtained
column36: fixed in 10% formalin and processed with the routine technique of paraffin embedding and haematoxylin-eosin staining at the Laboratorio de Pericias en Odontología Forense
column37: Córdoba (Argentina). The identification of powder deflagration particles embedded between the lingual striated muscle bundles and the absence of these particles in the exit wound confirmed the oral cavity as the point of entry of the projectile.  Toxicological tests were negative for both alcohol and drugs. The absence of signs of a struggle (both at the scene and on the subject's clothing)
column38: the location and number of wounds
column39: the direction and distance of the shot and the spasm in the left hand
column40: compatible with the position of the weapon (reconstruction of the event was performed)
column41: all elements listed in the literature as characteristic of suicide [7
column44: and the collection of personal information that revealed a recent history potentially indicative of self-harm
column45: determined the medico-legal aetiology of suicide.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 60-year-old male patient with no history of pathology of interest came to the emergency department for gastrointestinal bleeding in the form of haematochezia
column2: without haematemesis
column3: with haemodynamic stability (blood pressure 101/61 mmHg
column4: heart rate 83 beats/min
column5: temperature 36.8 ºC) and normal physical examination. Laboratory tests on admission: Hb 11.3 g/dl
column7: MCV 89 fL
column8: urea 11 mmol/L and creatinine 67 µmol/L. Initially
column9: fibrogastroscopy and colonoscopy were performed
column10: but no lesion responsible for the bleeding was found. During admission
column11: the patient became progressively anaemic (up to Hb 7 g/dl)
column12: requiring transfusion of 5 red blood cell concentrates. On the fourth day of admission he presented several episodes of haematochezia with transient haemodynamic instability. A new fibrogastroscopy and colonoscopy were performed
column13: without locating the cause of the haemorrhage. Given the persistence of the bleeding (which required volume expansion with crystalloids and transfusion of 11 additional red blood cell concentrates)
column14: transfemoral arteriography of the celiac trunk and superior and inferior mesenteric artery was performed
column15: revealing intraluminal extravasation of contrast depending on a proximal jejunal artery. Selective catheterisation and embolisation with microcoils was performed and the supraselective microcatheter (2.7 Fr) was kept in situ for subsequent identification of the pathological jejunal segment by intraoperative administration of methylene blue through it. An urgent exploratory laparotomy was performed
column16: which revealed multiple jejunal diverticula. Methylene blue (0.5 ml) was administered through the microcatheter
column17: identifying a segment of jejunum stained blue 1 metre from the angle of Treitz that included the lesion responsible for the haemorrhage (jejunal diverticulum). A segmental bowel resection of 20 centimetres of jejunum was performed
column18: as well as a lateral-lateral anastomosis. A plain X-ray of the surgical specimen showed the presence of multiple diverticulosis and microcoils close to the diverticulum responsible for the bleeding. The patient presented with respiratory distress in the immediate postoperative period (secondary to polytransfusion and hypovolemic shock)
column19: and remained in the Intensive Care Unit for 10 days. Subsequent course was uneventful
column20: and he was discharged from hospital 17 days later. Pathological anatomy confirmed the diagnosis of jejunal diverticulosis with focal ulceration.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 64-year-old male patient diagnosed in May 2014 with subcardial gastric adenocarcinoma with involvement of the oesophagogastric junction in stage IV (following ascitic fluid cytology that was positive for malignancy). The first line of treatment was EOX: epirubicin 91.5 mg (50 mg/m2) + oxaliplatin 237.9 mg (130 mg/m2) every 21 days intravenously + oral capecitabine (650 mg/12 h). After the administration of four cycles of chemotherapy
column2: a clinical improvement was observed which
column3: after radiological confirmation
column4: led to surgery. He underwent a total gastrectomy
column5: with excision of a liver cyst and cholecystectomy. One month later he required a second operation for biliary leakage and one month later he needed a transparietal drainage due to a collection in the right hypochondrium. The patient suffered a recurrence three months after undergoing gastrectomy (four and a half months after completing neoadjuvant chemotherapy)
column6: so it was requested
column7: in the context of an expanded use programme

column9: every 14 days
column10: of paclitaxel 137 mg (80 mg/m2) on days 1 and 8 + ramucirumab 496 mg (8 mg/kg) on day 1

column12: she was admitted to hospital with fever of unknown origin

column15: he evolved torpidly due to several adjacent intra-abdominal collections and bilateral pleural effusion

column17: 500 mg per day

column21: transfer to the Palliative Care Hospital was requested
