column1: We present a case of leiomyosarcoma of the colon whose first manifestation was a pulmonary metastasis. The patient was a 74-year-old woman with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and hysterectomy with double adnexectomy and subsequent brachytherapy for endometrial adenocarcinoma 5 years ago. She consulted for dyspnoea of 2 months' evolution
column2: without associated cough
column3: haemoptysis or general syndrome. Blood tests were normal. Chest X-ray and chest CT scan revealed a right parahilar mass measuring 5 x 3 cm. A biopsy of the mass was taken by bronchoscopy showing a mesenchymal tumour with positive imnunohistochemistry for vimentin and negative for c-KIT compatible with leiomyosarcoma.  An extension study was performed with gastroscopy
column4: colonoscopy and abdominopelvic CT scan
column5: which was negative. With a diagnosis of primary leiomyosarcoma of the right lung
column6: a right pneumonectomy was performed
column7: confirming the histology of leiomyosarcoma in the surgical specimen. One month after the right pneumonectomy
column8: the patient presented with abdominal pain with nausea
column9: vomiting and episodes of rectorrhagia. Colonoscopy showed a polylobulated mass with a neoplastic appearance in the ascending-blind colon and abdominal CT scan with dilatation of the small bowel loops showing a doughnut-shaped image at the level of the terminal ileum-blind ileum compatible with intestinal invagination with a probable underlying tumour lesion.  Emergency surgery was performed
column10: revealing small bowel obstruction due to invagination of the terminal ileum at the level of the tumour in the cecum. A right hemicolectomy was performed. Histopathological study of the surgical specimen showed that it was a leiomyosarcoma measuring 6 x 4 x 2.8 cm
column11: affecting the mucosa
column12: submucosa
column13: muscle and serosa with a high number of mitoses (more than 10 mitoses per 10 high magnification fields) and immunohistochemistry positive for actin and vimentin and negative for c-KIT. This finding demonstrates that the LMS had its origin in the colon and the lung tumour was metastatic. During this second postoperative period
column14: the patient again presented respiratory complications and died one month after abdominal surgery.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

The patient presented depressive symptoms with high levels of anxiety and intense hypochondriacal fears. Both the patient and his family demanded another antidepressant treatment
column41: as in recent years there had been a clear clinical worsening in the periods in which he had been without treatment. It was decided to start treatment with mirtazapine 15 mg/day with an increase to 30 mg/day after the first week of treatment and to carry out weekly controls of plasma sodium levels during the first 3-4 weeks and then more frequently. At discharge
column42: antihypertensive treatment with enalapril is also recommended
column43: avoiding combinations with thiazide diuretics.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: A 39-year-old black male patient aged 39 years with a history of recurrent oral aphthous lesions and vision disorders (progressive loss)
column2: who presented with painful ulcerative lesions in the genital region (penis and scrotum)
column3: with a diameter of 3 and 10 mm
column4: with trimmed edges and a yellowish background
column5: covered with a pseudomembrane. We carried out complementary tests
column6: thinking that it was a sexually transmitted disease
column7: but everything was within normal limits. We then decided to perform excision and biopsy of the lesions. The results showed a leukocytic infiltrate in the superficial dermis
column8: epidermal necrosis and the presence of polymorphonuclear leukocytes (no tumour lesion).  When she returned to the clinic
column9: she presented with total loss of vision and arthralgias. The case is discussed in conjunction with Urology
column10: Dermatology and Ophthalmology
column11: and the criteria are as follows: - Recurrent oral aphthosis. - Signs of uveitis (loss of vision). - Genital ulcers. And performing the cutaneous patergia test
column12: which consists of injecting 1 cc of physiological saline solution intradermally into the patient's forearm. Where it was considered 'positive' (he developed a pustule on an erythematous base)
column13: we concluded that this patient had Behcet's disease.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 24-year-old patient with a twin brother who in December 2005 underwent surgery for a combined neoplasm (mucinous adenocarcinoma and goblet cell carcinoid
column2: T4N2M1) infiltrating the appendicular wall and meso
column3: with multiple peritoneal implants and involvement of 8 of the 29 isolated lymph nodes. He underwent right hemicolectomy
column4: peritonectomy and resection of macroscopic visceral peritoneal implants. Subsequently
column5: adjuvant chemotherapy with mFOLFOX4 was started for 12 cycles
column6: with episodes of diarrhoea after the second and third cycle and a hurticarial reaction after the 7th cycle. At the start of chemotherapy
column7: 5HIAA in 24-hour urine was within normal parameters and body scanning with In.111 pentreotide and SPECT showed no alterations. Ten months after surgery
column8: he presented with acute testicular pain. On physical examination
column9: the right testicle was horinzontalised
column10: enlarged
column11: hard and irregular in the upper pole
column12: as well as thickening of the spermatic cord. In the testicular Doppler ultrasound
column13: the right testicle showed increased calibre of the vascular structures
column14: thickened epididymis
column15: hypoechoic and with peripheral vascularisation. Anechoic scrotal content was observed with mobile echogenic content
column16: compatible with complicated hydrocele (pyocele and haematocele...). An urgent surgical exploration was decided
column17: in which haematocele and thickening with induration of the testicular vagina were observed. Intraoperative pathology revealed infiltration by mucinous adenocarcinoma. Radical right orchiectomy with ligation of the cord at the root of the scrotum was performed. Definitive pathology analysis showed a neoplasm of the testicular vagina consisting of mucinous lakes and clusters of epithelial cells
column18: mostly in signet ring morphology
column19: with no involvement of the epididymis or testis.  After testicular surgery
column20: chemotherapy was administered with FOLFIRI plus BEVACIZUMAB in the 3rd cycle. Nine months after the orchiectomy
column21: the patient presented hepatic
column22: pancreatic and regional adenopathic progression
column23: presenting subocclusive pictures. He died 21 months after diagnosis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 64-year-old male patient was referred to the Ophthalmology emergency department for double vision and dizziness
column2: with apparently no other noteworthy symptoms; however
column3: an instability when standing upright was observed that could not be justified by the diplopia alone. The only history of interest was that the patient reported having been vaccinated against influenza five days earlier. Visual acuity was 0.7 in both eyes (AO)
column4: and both pupils were dilated and areflexic
column5: with no previous contact with mydriatics. There was a limitation in the abduction of the AO
column6: greater in the left eye (OI)
column7: in the supraduction of the AO
column8: and difficulty in the rest of the eye movements
column9: reporting horizontal diplopia. The rest of the ophthalmological examination was normal.  In view of the suspected diagnosis of Miller Fisher syndrome
column10: the patient was referred to the neurology department
column11: which detected an ataxic gait
column12: hyporeflexia
column13: and ruled out limb weakness
column14: deciding to admit him for follow-up and a complete study. The results of the blood tests and the computerised axial tomography (CAT) performed in the emergency department were normal. Twenty-four hours after admission
column15: respiratory distress appeared
column16: requiring oxygen and physiotherapy
column17: and in the following weeks he developed new neurological symptoms: facial paralysis
column18: dysphonia and dysphagia. During admission
column19: a lumbar puncture was performed
column20: which detected albuminocyte dissociation
column21: and a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) definitely ruled out space-occupying lesion or demyelination. Electromyographic study did not provide additional information. The immunological study was positive for anti-GQ-1b antibody
column22: definitively confirming the initial diagnosis. The patient's symptoms improved two weeks after admission
column23: having received two cycles of immunoglobulins. The clinical evolution was slow and polysymptomatic
column24: with diplopia persisting with prolonged limitation of bilateral abduction.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 68-year-old patient with a history of severe mental retardation and deaf-mutism secondary to meningitis in childhood. She consulted our emergency department due to pain and inflammation in the left hemiscrotal for more than 3 weeks
column2: which did not subside despite antibiotic and anti-inflammatory treatment. Examination revealed a generalised increase in scrotal contents
column3: more marked on the left side
column4: with a painful testicle on palpation
column5: firm consistency
column6: smooth surface and thickened epididymis. The right testicle was normal. Urine sediment revealed the presence of pyuria. Ultrasonography revealed an enlarged
column7: heterogeneous left testicle
column8: with a medial area with multiple cystic cavities
column9: some of which were hypoechogenic. Diagnosed as advanced orchitis
column10: the patient was discharged with analgesic-anti-inflammatory treatment. Eight days later
column11: the patient attended the urology department for a check-up
column12: where palpation clearly delimited a nodule
column13: which suggested a differential diagnosis of testicular neoplasia. A radical left orchiectomy was performed
column14: after determination of tumour markers (b-HCG
column15: alpha-fetoprotein and LDH)
column16: which were normal. Macroscopically
column17: the section surface of the orchiectomy specimen showed thickening of the tunica albuginea
column18: with haemorrhagic areas. The testicular parenchyma was increased in consistency
column19: with the presence of whitish fibrous tracts and yellowish plaques on section. Microscopic examination revealed marked hypospermatogenesis with hyalinisation of the seminiferous tubules
column20: as well as a chronic inflammatory process
column21: consisting of histiocytes
column22: abundant plasma cells and giant cells. Within some of these cells
column23: characteristic Michaelis-Gutmann bodies with an owl's eye appearance were recognised
column24: which were positive for Von Kossa staining
column25: demonstrating their calcium composition and thus suggesting the diagnosis of MLP. These inflammatory changes also partially affected the epididymis. With the diagnosis of testicular and epididymal PML
column26: treatment was completed with a course of fluoroquinolones for 3 months
column27: after which the evolution is satisfactory and the patient is asymptomatic.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the clinical case of a 67-year-old male
column2: with a history of moderate-severe enolism
column3: arterial hypertension and ischaemic heart disease
column4: who was transferred to the Emergency Department from another centre where he had come 4 hours after ingestion of an OP (Metasystox®: oxydemeton-methyl) in an attempt at autolysis. At the centre of origin
column5: he underwent gastric lavage and was given a dose of activated charcoal. On arrival at the ED
column6: the patient was conscious and oriented
column7: hypotensive and bradycardic
column8: with clear muscarinic manifestations: profuse sweating
column9: sialorrhoea
column10: abundant tear secretion
column11: and diffuse colicky pain with nausea and vomiting. At the nicotinic level
column12: there were no motor deficits but there was some perceptible fasciculation in both thighs. During his stay in the Emergency Department
column13: the patient presented generalised myoclonus
column14: miosis and desaturation with peripheral cyanosis
column15: probably secondary to the fasciculations of the peripheral muscles and the diaphragm. In view of the symptoms
column16: joint treatment with atropine and pralidoxime (1 g over 30 minutes) was started
column17: achieving an improvement in the peripheral symptoms
column18: with a decrease in the number of fasciculations and disappearance of the abdominal cramps. A second dose of 25 g of activated charcoal and a bolus of intravenous diazepam were administered to control the convulsions. Given the refractory nature of the seizures
column19: orotracheal intubation was performed to protect the airway and treatment was started with pralidoxime (12 g/day) and atropine (20 mg/day)
column20: both in continuous infusion. Under these conditions he was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU)
column21: where he remained for 12 days. During the first 10 days post-intoxication
column22: he continued with the treatment given in the emergency department
column23: according to the doses specified in table I. Until day 6 post-intoxication
column24: the patient presented miosis and high peristalsis
column25: and from this day onwards he manifested mydriasis and impaired tolerance to enteral nutrition as a consequence of the absence of peristalsis. This improves as the dose of atropine is reduced. However
column26: reactive mydriasis persisted until discharge to the ward. Another symptomatology of the patient
column27: characteristic of OP poisoning
column28: is generalised myoclonus and thoracic muscle weakness. This weakness could also be a consequence of the sedation to which he is subjected due to his agitated state. By day 5 post-intoxication
column29: isolated facial myoclonus is noticeable
column30: still in the context of neurological symptoms. Progressive recovery of limb strength begins on day 6 post-intoxication
column31: and is complete by day 9. However
column32: between these days
column33: even under treatment with pralidoxime in continuous perfusion
column34: the patient develops an IS with proximal and facial muscle weakness. This led to hypoventilation due to muscle fatigue. As for the respiratory symptoms
column35: which are critical in patients with OP poisoning
column36: there is an episode of initial respiratory failure
column37: which is subsequently corrected by keeping the patient on mechanical ventilation (MV) until 5 days after the poisoning. From this day on
column38: gradual disconnections from MV begin
column39: with the patient tending towards hypoventilation due to muscle fatigue. Improvement in respiratory function
column40: although hampered by nosocomial tracheobronchiolitis due to H. influenzae
column41: became apparent around day 8 post-intoxication. Despite psychomotor agitation
column42: he tolerates MV disconnections allowing extubation one day after initiation. However
column43: a tendency to hypoventilation persists throughout his stay in the ICU. As a biomarker of exposure to the toxicant
column44: plasma cholinesterase levels were assessed. The first measurement
column45: carried out at 16 hours post-ingestion
column46: showed a level of 13 ukat/L (reference range: 89-215 ukat/L). Its evolution can be seen in figure 1.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We reviewed in our clinic a young male patient aged 40 years with visual acuity loss in the left eye (OI) of 2 weeks' evolution and metamorphopsia for two years. The patient's best corrected visual acuity was 0.3 and
column2: in addition to myelin fibres in the superior temporal arcade
column3: a MER centred on the macular region producing an image of a macular pseudo-hole was observed in the fundus. A marked distortion of the retinal blood vessels around the macula could be seen. There was no evidence of DPV. The right eye was normal. Flurescein angiography was performed and no macular oedema or diffusion of the retinal vessels was observed. The patient reported no trauma or previous pathology in this eye
column4: and was therefore diagnosed with idiopathic MER and included on the waiting list for pars plana vitrectomy. One month later
column5: he came for consultation reporting a marked improvement in visual acuity and disappearance of metamorphopsia. The corrected visual acuity of the unit improved and in the fundus there was an absence of MER
column6: disappearance of the distortion of the retinal vessels and a dense prepapillary DPV.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 58-year-old woman with a personal history of depressive syndrome and lumbar canal stenosis. Diagnosed with B27-positive ankylosing spondylitis in 2005 and on treatment with adalimumab since 2008. Before starting treatment
column2: a positive tuberculin skin test required isoniazid prophylaxis for nine months. His regular medications included non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
column3: tramadol
column4: antidepressants and proton pump inhibitors. At a routine rheumatology check-up
column5: a significant deterioration of her renal function was noted and she was requested to undergo a nephrology assessment. The patient was asymptomatic. On initial physical examination
column6: there was no oedema
column7: no palpable laterocervical or retroauricular lymphadenopathy and cardiopulmonary auscultation was normal. In view of the analytical findings
column8: a renal ultrasound was performed
column9: showing kidneys measuring 10 and 12 cm
column10: respectively
column11: with good corticomedullary differentiation. There was no evidence of renal lithiasis or pyelocaliceal dilatation. The hypodense lesions in the spleen suggested possible lymphomatous involvement
column12: at which point the patient was admitted for further studies.  The thoraco-abdomino-pelvic computed tomography (CT) scan showed multiple pulmonary nodules (predominantly in the upper lobes with a peribronchovascular pattern) and mediastinal adenopathies. No splenic lesions were observed. A cervical adenopathy was biopsied
column13: showing granulomatous epithelioid inflammation with extensive caseous necrosis. Ziehl-Nielsen staining showed few bacilli.  In view of these findings
column14: it was decided to perform fibrobronchoscopy
column15: in which no macroscopic lesions were observed in the airway. Bronchoalveolar lavage showed a moderate number of lymphocytes
column16: bronchial lavage was negative and a transbronchial fine needle aspiration of a mediastinal adenopathy identified the existence of granulomas. Ziehl's staining was initially reported as negative
column17: with a second observation revealing a single acid-fast bacillus. Following fibrobronchoscopy
column18: an interferon gamma release assay for tuberculosis (quantiFERON) was performed
column19: which was positive. Based on these tests
column20: it was decided to start anti-tuberculosis treatment. As part of the nephrological work-up
column21: antinuclear antibody (ANA)
column22: anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA)
column23: anti-DNA and anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies were negative. Viral serology was negative for human immunodeficiency virus and hepatitis B and C viruses. Complement was normal. Urine analysis initially showed a microalbuminuria/creatininuria index of 261.9 mg/g and proteinuria/creatininuria 1.1 without nephrotic syndrome. The only notable finding in the proteinogram was a monoclonal IgM peak
column24: with a serum concentration of 305 mg/dl and a negative urine light chain concentration. During her evolution on the ward
column25: the patient presented sustained arterial hypertension with no evidence of water overload or other symptoms of note. Given the clinical findings (severe renal failure)
column26: radiological findings (kidneys of normal size and echostructure) and analytical findings (anaemia
column27: proteinuria and microhaematuria)
column28: a renal biopsy was performed in which interstitial inflammation was detected at the expense of lymphocytes
column29: accompanied by histiocytes that formed granulomas at several points. Multinucleated Langhans-type giant cells were present in one of them. The glomeruli were normal. In the tubules
column30: the lumen was occupied with granular material and flattening of the epithelium. No microorganisms were observed in PAS and Ziehl-Nielsen staining.  After the renal biopsy
column31: the patient was discharged on treatment with prednisone at a dose of 40 mg/day
column32: erythropoietin and complete antituberculosis treatment (rifampicin
column33: isoniazid
column34: ethambutol and pyrazinamide). The patient progressed towards slow but progressive improvement of renal function. She persisted with anaemia and high erythropoietin requirements

column1: This is a 66-year-old diabetic woman with a history of hepatitis C virus of post-transfusion aetiology. In January 2006 she presented with a persistent voiding syndrome which did not respond to treatment and she underwent cystoscopy with subsequent TUR. She was diagnosed with pTa G3 bladder carcinoma and started treatment with intravesical BCG. The follow-up TUR at the end of BCG treatment detected the presence of multiple foci of carcinoma in the bladder
column2: confirming the diagnosis of urothelial carcinoma invading the muscular layer (pT2 G3). In July 2006 she underwent a radical cystectomy with urinary diversion by means of a Mainz II type ureterosigmoidostomy. The pathological anatomy showed a high-grade urothelial carcinoma with invasion of the muscular layer and involvement of one of the resected lymph nodes
column3: a pT2a N1. No distant metastases were detected. Two weeks after the operation
column4: he presented with disorientation and a tendency to sleep in the context of a condition compatible with a urinary tract infection. After 24 hours of observation
column5: intravenous hydration and antibiotic therapy
column6: she recovered and was discharged on oral antibiotics. Ten days later she returned to the hospital with the appearance of dyspraxia
column7: a tendency to sleep
column8: incoherent speech and drowsiness. During the episode she also presented a febrile peak of 38.5ºC. Biochemistry and haemogram were normal (no leukocytosis or neutrophilia). An abdominal ultrasound scan identified moderate bilateral hydronephrosis and a CT scan of the brain was normal. During her admission
column9: and after initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment and fluid therapy
column10: the confusional picture gradually resolved until complete recovery. A few days later
column11: the patient again presented cognitive deterioration. On this occasion
column12: the onset of the central symptoms had been similar
column13: with dyspraxia
column14: sudden difficulty in performing daily tasks
column15: somnolence and obtundation
column16: but on this occasion she came to the hospital in a coma
column17: with a Glasgow Glasgow Glasgow score of 8. Laboratory tests showed only moderate hyperglycaemia and slightly elevated transaminases. An electroencephalogram showed slow waves over areas of both hemispheres
column18: characteristic findings of metabolic encephalopathy. A CT scan of the brain showed no structural abnormalities. Similar to the previous admission
column19: after several days in hospital with supportive fluid therapy and absolute diet
column20: the patient experienced a progressive improvement with complete clinical recovery. Three weeks later
column21: the patient again noticed symptoms of dyspraxia and a tendency to sleep with progressive onset. She went to the emergency department where she was evaluated without finding any alterations in the examination or in the analytical or imaging tests
column22: so she was sent home; there was no fever or any other symptoms suggestive of infection. Twenty-four hours later
column23: she presented with a severely altered level of consciousness with a Glasgow score of 6. On this occasion
column24: the patient had started a first cycle of adjuvant chemotherapy 15 days earlier
column25: with taxol 175 mg/m2 and carboplatin AUC 5. All other electrolyte parameters
column26: including calcaemia
column27: were strictly normal. Venous blood gas analysis showed a pH of 7.44. Brain CT and chest X-ray were normal. Given the presence of repeated episodes of confusional syndrome of probable metabolic cause
column28: all within 3 months of the cystectomy
column29: it was considered that this could be a metabolic complication of the shunt. After ruling out metabolic acidosis
column30: it was decided to request blood ammonium levels
column31: which showed an ammonaemia of 400 micrograms/dl (normal between 17-80). Given the diagnosis of hyperammonaemic encephalopathy of non-hepatic cause
column32: fluid therapy
column33: absolute diet
column34: lactulose enemas were started and
column35: given the clinical severity
column36: haemodialysis was started. After 3 haemodialysis sessions
column37: the patient experienced a neurological recovery parallel to the correction of ammonium levels
column38: which decreased to normal. Subsequently
column39: the ureterosigmoidostomy was surgically converted to an ileal conduit. Currently the patient continues with adjuvant chemotherapy treatment and has not had any new confusional episodes.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: at the age of 47

column1: A 69-year-old woman was admitted for asthenia and fatigue in the course of an outbreak of temporal arteritis on maintenance treatment with glucocorticoids. She consulted the ophthalmologist urgently due to decreased visual acuity (VA)
column2: pain
column3: tearing and difficulty opening the eyelids of the right eye (OD)
column4: associated with ipsilateral exophthalmos of uncertain onset. VA was 0.3 in the OD and 0.6 in the left eye (LA) with a relative afferent pupillary defect of 3+/4+ in the OD. There was mild conjunctival hyperemia
column5: restriction of suprathreshold translations in the OD with vertical diplopia and mild ipsilateral exophthalmos with oedematous eyelids under tension. Intraocular pressure (IOP) was 15 mmHg and 17 mmHg in OD suprathreshold and 14 mmHg in OI. The macula was normal and the papilla had no oedema or pallor.  Two months earlier
column6: the VA was 0.8 in both eyes with incipient cataracts. In view of this clinical picture
column7: an urgent orbital CT scan was requested
column8: showing thickening without a clear spindle shape of the inferior rectus and lateral rectus muscles of the right eye
column9: especially in the distal two thirds
column10: with a slight increase in orbital fat
column11: as well as occupation of the posterior ethmoidal cells and the pterygomaxillary fossa.  It was decided to start treatment with methylprednisolone 250 mg intravenous every 6 hours for 3 days. The patient was evaluated 2 days later and reported significant improvement. A concentric reduction in the visual field was observed
column12: which subsequently returned to normal.  After eight months
column13: the VA of the OD after cataract surgery is unity
column14: with normal pupillary reflexes and no papillary pallor. CT and MRI showed a non-specific occupation of the pterygopalatine fossa and orbital apex with slight distal thickening of the inferior rectus and lateral rectus muscles compatible with orbital pseudotumour.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 60-year-old man came for consultation in January 2009 due to episodes of occasional macroscopic haematuria over two years. Ten months after the first episode
column2: he began to have pollakiuria and dysuria
column3: and 2 months later an ultrasound study was performed which revealed thickening of the right bladder wall
column4: leading to ureterohydronephrosis. A thoraco-abdominal CT scan and bone scintigraphy were performed to determine the extent of the lesions and confirmed the ultrasound findings. In February 2009
column5: she received surgical treatment by bladder TUR with a diagnosis of plasmacytoid carcinoma of the bladder with invasion of the muscularis propria and the presence of foci of lymphovascular embolisation
column6: for which a radical cysto-prostatectomy with ileal diversion was indicated
column7: which was performed without incident on 27 March 2009. The anatomopathological report revealed an atypical epithelial neoformation of diffuse growth with some nests or cords
column8: consisting of small cells
column9: scanty cytoplasm and large
column10: pleomorphic and polylobulated nuclei. In addition
column11: some areas were observed where the nuclei were more pleomorphic
column12: polylobulated
column13: large and very hyperchromatic than the rest of the tumour population. Both typical and atypical mitoses and apoptosis were frequent. The neoplastic cells infiltrated the bladder wall and reached the muscularis propria. Cytoplasmic immunohistochemistry was 100% positive for cytokeratin-7 and 70% positive for cytokeratin-20 and diffuse high molecular weight cytokeratin. The definitive diagnosis was poorly differentiated
column14: high-grade
column15: plasmacytoid cell variant urothelial carcinoma.  The patient was then referred to the Oncology department and started adjuvant chemotherapy treatment with Cisplatin and Gemcitabine (4 cycles)
column16: which concluded in August 2009. In March 2010
column17: during a follow-up examination and while the patient was asymptomatic
column18: lesions suggestive of metastasis in the spine were observed
column19: so an MRI of the spine was performed
column20: which revealed possible metastasis at D3
column21: D8
column22: D9
column23: D10 and L1. Bone scintigraphy and PET-CT scans were performed
column24: which were inconclusive
column25: so a follow-up examination in three months was recommended. At this check-up
column26: growth of the known bone lesions was observed
column27: which were biopsied and were inconclusive for malignancy. In September 2010
column28: the PET-CT scan was repeated
column29: showing no signs of pathological bone uptake
column30: but multiple lymph nodes in the left axillary
column31: perivascular mediastinal
column32: subcarinal and internal mammary regions
column33: as well as in the retroperitoneal region. Another fine needle puncture of the spine was performed and reported as a metastatic lesion compatible with a plasmacytoid urothelial tumour. In addition
column34: a biopsy of the mammary lymph nodes was performed
column35: which were also reported to be compatible with metastatic lesions originating from the plasmacytoid urothelial tumour. At that time
column36: a new line of chemotherapy treatment was started with Paclitaxel and Carboplatin
column37: in a three-weekly schedule with a total of 6 cycles
column38: which concluded in January 2011. Halfway through the chemotherapy treatment
column39: a new control CT scan was performed in which the disease remained stabilised. On 17 February 2011
column40: a re-evaluation CT scan showed moderate-severe right ureterohydronephrosis at the expense of a nodular image protruding into the ureteral lumen suggestive of a new tumour lesion. In addition
column41: there was functional atrophy of the contralateral kidney with an increase in plasma creatinine up to 2.9 ng/mL. It was decided to perform a right percutaneous nephrostomy with placement of a double J ureteral catheter via the antegrade route. During this admission
column42: he suffered an inferoposterior and right ventricular AMI
column43: which was effectively treated by primary angioplasty. The patient finally died in mid-March 2011.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 39-year-old HIV-positive patient
column2: category C3
column3: consulted in the emergency department of our hospital due to abdominal pain. He presented bilateral cervical adenopathies due to Mycobacterium infection
column4: for which he was under treatment. The abdominal pain had started eight hours earlier in the epigastrium and was subsequently located in the right iliac fossa. Physical examination revealed mild abdominal distension with signs of peritoneal irritation. The only alteration found in the blood test was a mild leukocytosis (11.70 x 103/mL) with neutrophilia (78%). Bilirubin
column5: amylase
column6: and liver enzymes were normal. Abdominal ultrasound showed hepatomegaly
column7: splenomegaly and peripancreatic
column8: para-aortic and celiac lymphadenopathy. The appendix and free peritoneal fluid were not visualised. The patient underwent surgery with a clinical diagnosis of acute appendicitis. On surgical examination the appendix was macroscopically normal
column9: no adenopathy was observed and an appendectomy was performed. The immediate postoperative period was uneventful and the patient was discharged 48 hours later. Histopathological examination of the specimen showed the presence of leishmaniasis in the appendix and in two nodes of the mesoappendix. With this result
column10: medical treatment for leishmaniasis was started.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 36-year-old man
column2: with no medical history of interest
column3: attended the Emergency Department
column4: presenting with paraesthesia in both upper limbs
column5: accompanied by drowsiness. Two hours before admission
column6: he referred the application of 270 g (9 bottles of 30 g) of EMLA® anaesthetic cream (lidocaine 2.5%
column7: prilocaine 2.5%) for laser depilation on the back
column8: upper and lower limbs. The patient was conscious and oriented
column9: sleepy and cyanosed. Blood pressure was 144/83 mmHg
column10: heart rate 82 bpm and a baseline SaO2 of 91%
column11: so oxygen therapy was started until SaO2 94% was reached. The rest of the examination was normal. Complementary tests (chest X-ray and electrocardiogram) showed no significant pathological alterations. The admission blood test (4 hours after application of EMLA®
column12: see Table 1) showed a methaemoglobin level of 10.1%
column13: and he was diagnosed with severe methaemoglobinaemia secondary to topical administration of EMLA® (lidocaine 2.5%
column14: prilocaine 2.5%). Administration of 100 mg methylene blue was started intravenously within 10 minutes. One hour after administration of the antidote
column15: his methaemoglobin level remained elevated (2.7%)
column16: and he also presented alkalosis
column17: so he was assessed by the Intensive Care Unit. After transfer to this unit
column18: he continued high-flow mask oxygen therapy
column19: improving the cutaneous-mucosal discolouration and recovering SaO2 to 96%. Twenty-four hours after the application of EMLA®
column20: the patient remained haemodynamically stable and the methaemoglobin level dropped to 0.2%
column21: so it was decided to transfer him to the Internal Medicine Department
column22: where
column23: given his favourable evolution
column24: it was decided to discharge him three days after his admission.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 30-year-old woman
column2: smoker of 20 cigarettes/day and with no other personal history of interest. The patient reported repeated urinary tract infections. An abdominal ultrasound scan was indicated and an intravesical nodular lesion was observed
column3: for which she was referred to the urology department. Cystoscopy showed an exophytic tumour measuring 3x3 cm on the right lateral side with intact bladder mucosa
column4: and no alterations were found in the rest of the bladder. Examination under anaesthesia (EBA) and transurethral resection of the lesion (TUR) were performed. The pathological anatomy report described macroscopically fragments of bladder wall with preserved urothelium without dysplasia
column5: highlighting in the muscular layer itself and in continuity with the muscle tissue of the same
column6: a spindle cell tumour with cells showing large nuclei
column7: pleomorphic
column8: vesicular in appearance and large eosinophilic cytoplasm. This cellularity is arranged in ill-defined fascicles and among it there is abundant cellularity consisting mainly of numerous plasma cells and eosinophilic polymorphonuclear leukocytes. A high mitotic index is not observed
column9: although the proliferation index measured as nuclear positivity with antibodies against MIB-1 is between 10 and 25% of the tumour cellularity. No areas of necrosis were observed. Immunohistochemistry showed marked positivity against cytokeratins (AE1/AE3) and CAM5.2 at the cytoplasmic level
column10: as well as marked cytoplasmic positivity with antibodies against p80 (ALK protein). The cellularity described was negative for smooth muscle antibodies (smooth muscle actin
column11: MyO D1 and Calretininin)
column12: as well as for CEA and high molecular weight cytokeratins
column13: with only focal and isolated positivity for EMA. FISH on paraffin-embedded material showed no evidence of translocation in the ALK gene. The definitive anatomopathological diagnosis is inflammatory myofibroblastic bladder tumour.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 38 year old male patient
column2: who reports limitation of oral opening which he noticed started at the age of 18 and has been progressing. Totally asymptomatic
column3: he already has difficulty feeding. In addition
column4: he suffers from various intraoral carious foci that the dentists he has visited have declared impossible to treat due to the reduced oral opening. The patient refers to multiple treatments with different specialists trying to improve this oral opening
column5: with physical therapies and jaw exercises
column6: which have been totally ineffective. At the time of the first examination
column7: the patient had a maximum oral opening of 16 mm
column8: which did not change when forced
column9: and the patient had a panoramic X-ray and computerised tomography in which an evident elongation of the coronoid processes above the level of the zygomatic arch was observed. Once diagnosed as HPC
column10: it was decided to perform the bilateral coronoidectomy by means of an intraoral approach
column11: with a maximum oral opening of 40 mm during the trans-operative period.  Three days after surgery
column12: physical therapy was started with oral opening exercises and support with tongue depressors
column13: with good progress during the first week (maximum oral opening of 21 mm). Subsequently
column14: his oral opening became critical (6 mm of maximum oral opening). It was decided to use functional orthopaedic appliances
column15: with the use of the Spring-Bite
column16: with an interval of 10 minutes
column17: 4 to 5 times a day
column18: obtaining an oral opening of 30 mm 30 days after its use. The use of the appliance was continued for 6 months.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 78-year-old male patient
column2: diabetic on treatment with oral antidiabetics
column3: with a history of renal lithiasis and repeated nephritic colic
column4: and with malignant neoplasia of the neck treated with RT two months earlier
column5: who came to the emergency department for an irritative micturition syndrome with pollakiuria
column6: bladder tenesmus and dysuria of two months' evolution. Two days earlier he had been in the emergency department where he was diagnosed with UTI and antibiotic treatment with Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid was started without improvement. Physical examination showed an axillary temperature of 38.2º C. The rest of the examination was completely normal
column7: including a rectal examination which revealed a prostate of size III/IV
column8: not indurated and slightly painful on palpation. The blood test showed a significant leukocytosis of 41800 with neutrophilia (93%)
column9: a blood glucose of 337 mg/dl
column10: a platelet count of 394000
column11: a fibrinogen of 771 and a decrease in Quick's Index (68%). Urine sediment showed pyuria and microhaematuria and plain chest and abdominal X-rays showed no pathology. An ultrasound scan of the abdomen was also performed at the emergency department and showed no pathology. With suspicion of UTI
column12: she was admitted to the Urology Department and intravenous antibiotic treatment was started after obtaining a urine culture. The treatment regimen chosen in this case was a combination of ceftriaxone 1 g plus tobramycin 100 mg every 12 hours. On the third day of admission and in view of the patient's clinical and analytical improvement
column13: it was decided to switch from intravenous to oral antibiotherapy
column14: continuing with cefuroxime-axetil. On the seventh day
column15: coinciding with the arrival of the blood and urine cultures taken on admission
column16: which were reported as negative
column17: the patient presented a fever peak of 39ºC and a new rise in the leukocyte count. We decided to reinstate intravenous antibiotherapy and to perform a vesico-prostatic ultrasound scan in which the patient's large prostate (400 cc) was striking.  In view of the suspicion that it could be an acute prostatitis in the context of BPH
column18: it was decided to continue with intravenous antibiotherapy and to schedule a Millin-type adenomectomy when the infectious symptoms had subsided. Despite antibiotic therapy
column19: the evolution continued to be unfavourable
column20: with persistent febrile peaks
column21: so the treatment regimen was changed and levofloxacin i.v. was introduced instead of ceftriaxone
column22: and a fractionated urine culture was requested. Despite the change in antibiotic treatment
column23: the patient continued to present fever and worsening general condition
column24: so it was decided to perform a transrectal ultrasound to rule out the presence of any complications
column25: in which a poorly defined area appeared in the medial and cranial periphery of the right lobe
column26: with heterogeneous echogenicity
column27: although predominantly hypoechogenic
column28: and with an absence of flow in the Doppler method suggestive of prostatic abscess.  In view of the ultrasound findings
column29: it was decided to perform a transrectal ultrasound-guided puncture of the abscess
column30: obtaining about 20 ml of purulent material which was sent to microbiology. The culture of the prostatic exudate and pus were positive for E. coli. Despite the puncture
column31: the patient continued with septic symptoms and reported no improvement
column32: so it was decided to perform a CT scan to confirm the diagnosis and rule out complications of the abscess. The CT scan showed an increase in the size of the prostate gland with a multi-tabular liquid collection
column33: located caudally to the gland itself.  In view of the CT findings
column34: and transrectal puncture having failed
column35: it was decided to perform a transvesical prostatectomy. During the operation
column36: after opening the capsule
column37: we were able to appreciate the total destructuring of the gland
column38: with the presence of multiloculations and purulent material inside it
column39: as well as extensive areas of tissue necrosis involving the entire prostatic urethra at the apical level. Pathological anatomy showed two small foci of microacinar adenocarcinoma
column40: far from the limits of resection
column41: with a Gleason 2 + 3 and chronic and acute abscessed prostatitis with extensive areas of necrosis together with nodular hyperplasia.  The postoperative evolution was satisfactory
column42: with a rapid clinical and analytical improvement
column43: and the patient was discharged from hospital 21 days after the operation. Fifteen days after discharge
column44: the patient was seen in our outpatient clinic with stress urinary incontinence. Six months after the operation
column45: the patient continues to have mild to moderate incontinence and requires absorbent pads for daily hygiene. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 47-year-old patient whose only pathological history is ankylosing spondylitis with significant loss of mobility of the spine
column2: especially at the cervical level. From the urological point of view
column3: the first contact with the patient was due to the study in August 2001 of a monosymptomatic and capricious haematuria
column4: which after a urographic and ultrasound study led to the diagnosis of a 13 mm papillary neoformation on the left lateral side of the bladder. Based on these findings
column5: an endoscopic resection of the neoformation was performed in November of the same year
column6: with the anatomopathological diagnosis of pTa G1 transitional carcinoma. The patient continued with outpatient follow-up with ultrasound studies and negative urinary cytology. In December 2003
column7: a control cystoscopy was performed and the patient was found to be asymptomatic
column8: with a diagnosis of papillary tumour recurrence
column9: superficial in appearance
column10: in the bladder floor. The preoperative study was normal
column11: with a urine sediment of 35 red blood cells/field and 100 leukocytes/field
column12: with a urinary pH of 7 and a negative culture for usual germs. Three months later
column13: endoscopic resection of the recurrence was performed
column14: which was multifocal
column15: with a diagnosis of pTaG1 transitional carcinoma. Given the age of the patient
column16: the recurrence in less than two years
column17: and the multifocal nature of the recurrence
column18: it was decided
column19: despite the low tumour grade
column20: to complete the treatment with intravesical instillation of Mitomycin C. A weekly instillation of 40 mg of Mitomycin C was scheduled for six weeks
column21: after instillation of an early dose within 48 hours of surgery. Tolerance to the instillations was good and the patient was followed up again in the consultation room. As the patient was asymptomatic
column22: he was seen for a check-up in September 2004 with suspicious but not malignant cytology and the ultrasound finding of a significant thickening of the anterior bladder wall
column23: with abscessation
column24: suggestive of cystitis. In addition
column25: in the area of the last tumour resection there is also a hyperechogenic area with a relief of 1.5 cm at the base of the implantation
column26: highly suggestive of tumour recurrence. Image 1 The urine culture was negative at that time
column27: with a urinary pH of 8
column28: and in the sediment 40 red blood cells/field and 120 leukocytes/field. In October 2004 an endoscopic revision was performed under general anaesthesia. The surgical findings were as follows: - Normal bladder capacity - Deflected area with granulation tissue on the anterior aspect of the bladder
column29: the abscessed image of the ultrasound disappeared. - On the left lateral side of the bladder floor there is a pseudomembrane with a necrotic appearance that detaches when it rubs against the resector. - Under the pseudomembrane there is a very thickened
column30: deflected and very hard mucosa with a feeling of calcification over an area of 2 cm. The lesion described was resected to its full extent with the suspicion that it was an infiltrative neoplasm with areas of necrosis due to its endoscopic appearance. The pathological examination revealed fragments of the bladder wall with intense inflammation
column31: areas of necrosis and deposits of inorganic salts intermingled with necrotic tissue and fibrin
column32: with no evidence of tumour tissue. Smooth muscle fibres with intense inflammation and areas of haemorrhage and necrosis were also observed
column33: but no tumour infiltration was evident. Image 2 The postoperative period was uneventful
column34: and with the diagnosis of encrusting cystitis
column35: the patient was discharged three days after the operation for periodic follow-up in consultation.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Female patient
column2: 62 years old
column3: poorly controlled diabetic
column4: obese
column5: with a history of unresolved left chorioriform lithiasis. She consulted for fever and left lumbalgia of 7 days' evolution
column6: with oral mycosis and frank deterioration of general condition. She presented leukocytosis with marked neutrophilia
column7: hyperglycaemia with ketoacidosis and elevated urea and creatinine levels. Physical examination revealed a soft abdomen
column8: with pain in the left flank and positive left renal percussion. Abdominal ultrasound and direct abdominal X-ray were performed
column9: which led to the diagnosis by identifying air in the left renal fossa. Abdominal and pelvic CT scan showed air in the left kidney and perirenal tissues
column10: which infiltrated the abdominal wall. Due to the rapid deterioration of his general condition
column11: drainage of the renal fossa was performed by lumbotomy to avoid contamination of the peritoneal cavity
column12: evacuating the gas and debriding necrotic tissue. After an initial improvement
column13: signs of sepsis reappeared and simple nephrectomy was performed a week later. Good postoperative evolution
column14: 14 days later new sepsis of respiratory origin. He started with purulent secretion through the wound
column15: a toilette was performed
column16: but he died 48 hours later due to multiple organ dysfunction with nosocomial pneumonia.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 51 year old male presented to the dermatology department for 6-7 days with nodular
column2: erythematous-violaceous
column3: painful lesions on the legs and dorsum of the feet
column4: accompanied by swelling of the ankles.  The patient was in good general health
column5: with no other accompanying symptoms. His personal history included three episodes of acute pancreatitis secondary to chronic ethylism
column6: the last one a year ago. The magnetic resonance cholangiography performed at that time had detected chronic pancreatitis
column7: as well as two pancreatic pseudocysts
column8: for which he was being monitored by the Digestive Service. A skin biopsy and analytical study were performed and treatment was started with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and omeprazole. Histopathology of one of the skin lesions showed an intense inflammatory infiltrate in the fatty lobule consisting of neutrophilic polymorphonuclear cells
column9: soaps secondary to fat necrosis and areas of haemorrhage.  The analytical study showed pancreatic amylase values of 469 IU/L. In view of these findings
column10: compatible with the diagnosis of pancreatic panniculitis
column11: the patient was admitted to the hospital to be studied and monitored for a possible exacerbation of his chronic pancreatitis. The evolution of the skin lesions was good
column12: despite the fact that the patient had discontinued anti-inflammatory treatment due to epigastralgia. However
column13: the epigastralgia did not subside and even became more continuous and intense
column14: and was subsequently accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The clinical manifestations and amylase levels were controlled during admission by conservative measures
column15: but the control CT scan showed an enlargement of the pancreatic head
column16: with dilatation of the duct of Wirsung
column17: partial destruction of the pancreatic gland
column18: peripancreatic
column19: celiac and gastrohepatic ligament adenopathies
column20: together with portal vein thrombosis
column21: which required anticoagulant treatment. Five months after the diagnosis of pancreatic panniculitis
column22: the control CT scan reported resolution of the pancreatic pathology
column23: with portal cavernomatous transformation and persistence of small lymphadenopathies with no clear pathological significance
column24: so that the picture was finally interpreted as an exacerbation of his chronic pancreatitis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 37-year-old woman diagnosed with LAM in 2003 as a result of spontaneous right haemopneumothorax requiring surgery with evacuation of the haemothorax and resection of bullous dystrophy. He was followed up as an outpatient without incident until 2009 when he presented with chylous ascites and a large retroperitoneal cystic lymphangioma was detected on abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan. In February 2011
column2: he was admitted for exertional dyspnoea and extensive right pleural effusion. The pleural fluid showed characteristics of chylothorax: pH 7.43; triglycerides 1
column3: 216 mg/dl; cholesterol 73 mg/dl
column4: leukocytes 2
column5: 700 cells/μl (mononuclear 92%)
column6: protein 4.5 g/dl
column7: LDH 142 U/l. The patient had a weight of 57 kg
column8: height 169 cm
column9: BMI: 19.2 and had normal blood protein and lymphocyte values. Initially
column10: conservative treatment with evacuating thoracentesis
column11: fat-free diet and oral nutritional supplements (ONS) rich in medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) was performed. After one week
column12: the patient presented respiratory worsening and a right thoracic drainage tube was placed
column13: obtaining 2
column15: 000 ml/day of pleural fluid. Given the amount of pleural fluid
column16: parenteral nutrition (PN) was started and treatment with octeotride was started at increasing doses up to 100 μg/8 h
column17: which was discontinued a few days later due to digestive intolerance and severe water and electrolyte disturbance. Despite digestive rest
column18: pleural effusion increased and became bilateral
column19: requiring bilateral thoracic drainage. Three pleurodesis with talc were performed
column20: which were partially effective and did not allow removal of the drainage. Despite treatment
column21: the patient's nutritional status deteriorated
column22: with a weight loss of 5 kg
column23: hypoalbuminaemia of 1.8 g/dL and lymphopenia of 700 cells/μl. During treatment with PN
column24: she developed a catheter-associated infection that required withdrawal of the central line and suspension of the catheter. The fat-free oral diet was progressively reintroduced with MCT-rich ODS. The debit of both thoracic drains decreased progressively and after two and a half months of hospitalisation the patient was discharged from hospital with both thoracic drainage tubes and bowel movements every 3 days with a debit of 500 ml/day
column25: with an albumin of 2 g/dl and lymphocytes of 700 cells/μl. Subsequent evolution was good and the pleural drains were removed 4 and 6 months after discharge
column26: with a progressive improvement in the patient's nutritional status. At present
column27: there is still minimal bilateral pleural effusion
column28: predominantly on the right
column29: which has not changed in the last 4 months
column30: the patient has no dyspnoea at rest although she requires home oxygen therapy and has a BMI of 18.7
column31: with normal nutritional parameters.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 63 year old woman with no previous history of importance consulted for a mass of soft consistency measuring 3 cm in diameter in the left parotid region with a history of 4 months
column2: accompanied by peripheral paralysis of the cervical branch of the facial nerve with deviation of the homolateral labial commissure. The tumour
column3: mobile and painless
column4: was easily revealed by bimanual palpation and was predominantly intraoral. The patient had no significant palpable lymph nodes in the neck and the rest of the physical examination was unremarkable. Consultation with neurology ruled out the possibility of central facial palsy by means of a CT scan of the brain. Soft tissue ultrasound was reported as a solid heterogeneous mass with soft tissue density in the parotid region and no adenomegalic rank nodes in the neck. Fine needle aspiration puncture under ultrasound control was reported as negative with haematic material on 2 occasions. It was then decided to perform a freezing biopsy under general anaesthesia with an intraoral approach whereby the tumour was accessible and protruded under the oral mucosa next to the ostium of the Stenon's duct. After incising the mucosa
column5: a lax
column6: wine-red tumour with a vascular appearance was found
column7: which was removed without difficulty through the same incision
column8: and its continuity with the parotid tissue of normal characteristics was verified. Freeze biopsy revealed a lesion compatible with a benign vascular tumour. The mucosa was closed with separate stitches of polyglycolic acid and the procedure was terminated. The evolution was favourable with hospital discharge at 24 h and complete recovery of facial paralysis at 10 d postoperatively. There is no evidence of disease after 5 years of follow-up. The deferred histological report was parotid capillary haemangioma....   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 73-year-old woman attended the emergency department after an accidental fall due to tripping on the stairs at home. The left limb presented with the knee in fixed flexion of 40º and external rotation of the hip. The femoral condyles were clearly palpable
column2: with a 'pseudo-hip impingement' proximal to the patella. The attitude in flexion was not changed by pain when attempting to change the position. The patella was fixed and tight. Any attempt at flexion-extension resulted in severe pain and tightness of the quadricipital tendon and goose foot. The radiological study showed a low patella with its proximal pole in contact with the intercondylar area
column3: compatible with lower horizontal dislocation of the patella.  Reduction by manipulation was unsuccessful
column4: so epidural anaesthesia was performed
column5: producing a sonorous audible 'clunk' or patellar snap when performing patellar traction and knee extension
column6: after which the patella was anatomically arranged. The patellar and quadricipital tendons were found to be undamaged and functional
column7: without haematoma
column8: with correct gliding and tension. The anterior tibial tuberosity was also found to be in normal condition. The joint was stable in both varus and valgus in extension and 30° semi-flexion
column9: with no haemorrhagic focus in LLE
column10: LLI or goose foot. External arthrotomy was performed with extraction of 30 cc of sero-haematic synovial fluid
column11: where the anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments were found to be normal. There was evident femoro-patellar arthrosis with chondyle and patellar osteophytosis (Ahlbach grade III). We performed excision of the patellar osteophytes and the intercondylar groove. The patient was immobilised with a knee orthosis in extension for 2 weeks with support
column12: after which physiotherapy was started for 2 weeks. One month after the trauma he presented flexion of -30º and full extension
column13: with absence of pain. Two months after the accident she presented full flexion-extension. The radiological study at that time showed knee with predominantly femoro-patellar arthrosis (Ahlbach grade III).  A characteristic of the patient that helps to explain the injury is that the patient had generalised hyperelasticity. Four years later
column14: she has suffered no recurrence and only reports discomfort in the anterior area of both knees when descending stairs
column15: compatible with her femoro-patellar osteoarthritis. This symptomatology was already present before the dislocation.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 32-year-old woman
column2: diagnosed with SLE and antiphospholipid syndrome 6 years ago
column3: monitored in the outpatient rheumatology department
column4: on treatment with prednisone (15 mg a day)
column5: ASA (100 mg a day)
column6: calcium (1 g)
column7: vitamin D (800 u) and omeprazole (20 mg a day). The patient reported fever (40 ºC)
column8: predominantly in the evening
column9: of one week's duration
column10: with no other accompanying symptoms. Physical examination revealed only hepatosplenomegaly
column11: with no palpable lymphadenopathy. Blood cultures

column13: except for hepatosplenomegaly with no apparent focal lesions. Laboratory tests showed Hb 6.7
column14: leukocytes 1
column15: 000 (400 neutrophils

column17: platelets 60
column19: ANA 1/1
