column1: A 54-year-old man with recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis
column2: with a personal history of hyperlipidaemia under treatment and a previous fistulotomy. Six years earlier
column3: he had had an episode of moderate-severe acute pancreatitis that required hospitalisation. Ten months ago
column4: he presented a new episode requiring ERCP
column5: which led to a recurrence of acute pancreatitis (interval of 5 days). As complementary tests
column6: a magnetic resonance cholangiography showed chronic pancreatitis on pancreas divisum and atrophy of the hepatic parenchyma
column7: and an ERCP also showed signs of chronic pancreatitis and pancreas divisum.  Surgical intervention was decided
column8: performing caudal pancreatectomy and pancreatico-jejunal bypass. A tumour was found on the anterior gastric wall
column9: which was reported intraoperatively as GIST and was removed. After surgery
column10: the patient was admitted to the ICU
column11: where he progressed satisfactorily. On the 5th postoperative day he was transferred to the ward
column12: where the drainage became purulent. After treatment with antibiotic therapy
column13: the patient's evolution was satisfactory and he was discharged on the 19th day.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 44-year-old single male
column2: living with his mother and working in sheltered employment. Diagnosis of Residual Schizophrenia (F20.5
column3: ICD-10) (11) in follow-up at his Mental Health Centre and with psychopharmacological treatment with 400 mg of amisulpi-ride
column4: 10 mg of olanzapine and 10 mg of diazepam. Non-daily but sustained use of tramadol
column5: cannabis
column6: alcohol and cocaine. As somatic antecedents
column7: he has difficulty in walking
column8: he walks with a crutch
column9: as a consequence of a polytraumatism after a precipitation in the context of a psychotic episode 14 years ago. The patient was found unconscious at home by his mother
column10: unresponsive to stimuli and unable to say for how long he had been in this state. Self-intoxication with an undetermined amount of tramadol
column11: benzodiazepines
column12: alcohol and cocaine. He was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit for 6 days. Complications included rhabdomyolysis
column13: acute renal failure and pneumonic process. Normal cranial CAT scan. Stabilisation and transfer to the Internal Medicine ward
column14: one week of admission
column15: somatic overcoming of the episode. Transfer to the Psychiatry Department
column16: voluntary admission. During the first five days of admission to the Psychiatry Unit
column17: the patient remained psychopathologically stable. No psychotic decompensation
column18: critical of the episode which he defines as a "high" and of which he states that he cannot remember the specific conditions but he does remember a previous discussion with his mother. Adapted to the rhythms of the unit
column19: participates in occupational therapy activities. Euthymic
column20: within the previous defectuality
column21: concrete plans for the future
column22: outings with the family with adequate response
column23: possibility of discharge and follow-up at his Mental Health Centre. However
column24: after these first asymptomatic days
column25: the patient began to progressively present episodes of temporo-spatial disorientation accompanied by marked bradypsychia
column26: ataxia (from crutch to walker) and generalised motor slowing. Mnesic failures accompanied by an effort to remember
column27: aphasia and apraxia. However
column28: the patient is calm and placid. No anxiety
column29: sustained sleep. No changes in previous psychiatric treatment. Despite the family's insistence on pointing to "a psychotic break" (...) the picture is framed within a cognitive deterioration of cortical characteristics with marked impairment of the attentional system
column30: executive function
column31: memory and linguistic function. The EEG showed marked lenification and diffuse attenuation of the background rhythm. After assessment by Internal Medicine and Neurology
column32: she was transferred to the Neurology Department. The initial cranial MRI showed a supratentorial diffuse leukodystrophy pattern
column33: predominantly fronto-parietal
column34: hyperintense in T2 and with a discrete component of restriction in the diffusion sequences. (MRI-T2
column35: image 1; MRI-T2-FLAIR
column36: image 2).  Ten days later
column37: in comparison with the previous MRI
column38: greater signal alteration was observed in the diffusion sequences with progression of the picture in T2 and T2-FLAIR at bilateral parieto-occipital level and regression in T2-FLAIR in frontal and temporal poles. During the twenty days of admission to the Neurology Department
column39: no infectious symptoms or analytical alterations were observed and serology and antibody tests were normal. It was concluded that the clinical and neuroimaging alterations were compatible with late hypoxic encephalopathy
column40: leaving the possibility of previous leukodystrophic lesions in the white matter in doubt. However
column41: there was no family history of interest and there was no previous history suggesting the presence of leukodystrophy. During his stay in Neurology
column42: the patient slowly improved spontaneously
column43: maintaining the previous psychiatric treatment. On admission he was only able to walk with a walker and needed to be guided. On discharge he is able to move around with walking sticks without difficulty
column44: he is able to throw coins into the coffee machine
column45: his bradypsychia and memory have improved significantly
column46: but he still has moments of disorientation. He attends the Rehabilitation Service on a daily basis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 70-year-old man with a history of gastrectomy for gastric adenocarcinoma 12 years ago and Gleason VII prostate carcinoma (2 cylinders of 6 affected by the tumour)
column2: treated surgically by radical prostatectomy ten years ago
column3: with a lymph node affected by the tumour and androgen blockage to date
column4: with a PSA of 0.06 at the last check-up. He came to the Emergency Department of our hospital with a non-painful exophytic lesion on the glans penis of about five weeks' duration. He did not remember having had any previous injury or trauma in the area
column5: and reported some episodes of bleeding with friction since the appearance of the lesion.  Examination of the patient revealed a round
column6: dark reddish exophytic lesion on the dorsum of the glans penis
column7: approximately two centimetres in diameter
column8: with a tendency to bleed
column9: elastic and non-painful consistency. No lymphadenectomy was palpable and the rest of the physical examination of the patient was normal A biopsy of the lesion was performed and during the operation it was observed that it was a tumour with a macroscopic
column10: non-infiltrating appearance
column11: located in the mucosa of the glans penis
column12: with areas of a thrombosed appearance and easily friable.  The intraoperative anatomopathological analysis was reported as a lesion composed of undifferentiated cells with nuclear hyperchromatism
column13: pleomorphism and a large number of mitoses and blackish pigment
column14: which would be compatible with the diagnosis of melanoma. The resection was completed with a subtotal penectomy with a four-centimetre safety margin from the edge of the lesion and a bilateral superficial inguinal lymphadenectomy with nodes unaffected by the tumour. A thoracoabdominal CT scan was performed
column15: which showed no metastatic disease. Pathological examination of the penectomy specimen showed a maximum depth of invasion of 1.5 mm. Immunohistochemical analysis with S-100 and HMB 45 confirmed the diagnosis of melanoma (1).  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 13-year-old girl
column2: diagnosed in May 2003 with intermediate uveitis and treated with topical
column3: peribulbar and oral glucocorticoids
column4: with persistent cystic macular oedema (CMO) in both eyes and visual acuity (VA) of 0.2 in the right eye (RA) and 0.4 in the left eye (LO). In February 2004
column5: 4 mg of intravitreal triamcinolone (Trigon Depot®
column6: Bristol-Myers Squibb) was injected into the RA. One month later
column7: the CME had resolved with VA of 0.7
column8: so treatment was repeated in the LA with VA of 0.7. One year later
column9: intraocular pressure (IOP) of 26 mmHg OD and 23 mmHg OI were detected and controlled with topical timolol 0.5% (Timoftol® 0.5%
column10: MSD). By July 2005
column11: she had developed posterior subcapsular cataracts
column12: with VA of 0.2 OD and 0.5 OI. She is currently awaiting phacoextraction surgery.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 83-year-old woman with a history of non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus
column2: arterial hypertension
column3: dyslipidaemia and chronic atrial fibrillation consulted for progressive abdominal pain and constitutional syndrome of one month's duration. On physical examination
column4: the patient was afebrile and haemodynamically stable
column5: with a globular
column6: soft
column7: depressible abdomen
column8: painful on palpation and a tumour on the left flank. Blood tests showed haemoglobin 9.3 g/dl
column9: leukocytes 11
column11: urea 109 mg/dl
column12: creatinine 1 mg/dl
column13: total bilirubin 2.6
column14: alkaline phosphatase 139 U/l
column15: with the rest of the liver function normal. Abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan showed a mass measuring 20 x 20 x 15 centimetres of heterogeneous density that caused displacement of the renal vessels and pyelocaliceal system without causing obstructive uropathy or metastatic involvement. Surgery involved a radical left nephrectomy with complete excision of the mass. The patient died one month after surgery due to acute pulmonary oedema. Pathological anatomy showed a 3.5 kg tumour of mucoid appearance with areas of haemorrhage affecting 30%
column16: and in its centre the rejected nephrectomy specimen but without parenchymal infiltration
column17: compatible with a mixed liposarcoma (dedifferentiated and myxoid)
column18: with a mitotic index of 2/10 high magnification fields.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 32-year-old man with colon neoplasia with hepatic
column2: retroperitoneal and mediastinal metastases
column3: with a rapid evolution on a background of ulcerative colitis. A week after diagnosis
column4: despite presenting an advanced stage
column5: he was admitted for surgery with partial tumour resection
column6: and postoperative chemotherapy treatment was started with different consecutive lines of therapy: oxaliplatin+folinic acid+fluorouracil
column7: capecitabine+oxaliplatin
column8: and capecitabine+irinotecan
column9: with no response. The K-ras gene was even determined for possible treatment with cetuximab or panitumumab
column10: which was negative and therefore ruled out this therapeutic alternative. Furthermore
column11: treatment with bevacizumab was not advisable as the patient presented with drainage in the abdominal cavity
column12: with production of purulent material. Fifteen days after surgery
column13: the patient reported moderate pain in the left eye
column14: for which reason he requested a consultation with our department. On ophthalmological examination
column15: the patient presented moderate eyelid oedema
column16: conjunctival chemosis
column17: severe non-reducible exophthalmos
column18: complete ptosis in the left eye
column19: and limited ocular motility in all gaze positions
column20: but especially in lateral gaze and supraversion. Cranial and orbital magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was requested
column21: with T1-weighted images and axial diffusion-weighted and FLAIR images. Two nodular lesions were observed in the left orbit
column22: one of them measuring 2×1cm
column23: located in the superior region
column24: with involvement of the superior rectus and levator muscles; and the second
column25: located at the level of the apex
column26: with involvement of the external rectus
column27: all highly suggestive of metastasis of the extrinsic ocular musculature.  Due to the patient's poor general condition
column28: palliative radiotherapy was ruled out
column29: and methylprednisolone boluses were started at a dose of 1g/day
column30: with partial relief of pain. However
column31: 48 hours after the second bolus of corticotherapy
column32: the patient presented extreme abdominal and ocular pain
column33: so palliative sedation was decided
column34: and the patient died.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 64-year-old Italian man was admitted in March 2005 for severe headache
column2: continuous fever and pancytopenia. His history showed that he was suffering from NHL type B grade II (Real) already treated with chemotherapy according to the CHOP-R scheme and then with high doses of cyclophosphamide in order to mobilise the stem cells in anticipation of an autologous transplant
column3: which was never carried out. A recent total body CT scan showed remission of the lymphomatous disease
column4: while the osteomedullary biopsy revealed secondary myelodysplasia in the absence of neoplastic infiltration. On admission to hospital
column5: the physical examination revealed a fever of 39°C
column6: cutaneous and mucosal pallor and splenomegaly
column7: BP 110/70 mmHg
column8: heart rate 128 beats per minute. The rest of the initial physical examination is compatible with normality. Complementary examinations. Initial tests showed
column9: among other things
column10: pancytopenia with neutropenia of 830/ul. Virological examinations (negative) and serial blood cultures were performed. A CT scan of the skull showed no acute focal lesions or signs of cerebral hypertension. The patient was treated with supportive therapy
column11: granulocyte growth factors
column12: antifungals and broad-spectrum antibiotics
column13: with remission of the haematological picture and resolution of fever. Due to the persistence of headache and the successive appearance of meningeal signs
column14: a diagnostic lumbar puncture was performed. Microscopic analysis of the CSF showed an increase in the total number of cells
column15: consisting of a large number of neutrophils
column16: megakaryocytes and myeloid cells with intermediate maturation; a picture representative of a medullary population. Immunohistochemical cytological analysis was compatible with myeloid metaplasia: factor VIII and myeloperoxidase positive in morphologically compatible elements. The repeated analysis of CSF compared to peripheral blood and the fact that no spinal tap was traumatic or difficult to perform excludes contamination. In the meantime
column17: the blood culture was positive for Sterotrophomonas maltophilia
column18: which was sensitive to antibiotic treatment. Two weeks after admission
column19: the patient's neurological condition worsened
column20: he went into a cerebral coma and died.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 28-year-old man was admitted to the emergency department of a regional hospital presenting
column2: as a result of a car accident
column3: with polytrauma with fracture of the 6th costal arch and right pulmonary contusion
column4: renal laceration with right subcapsular and suprarenal haematoma
column5: haematoma of the abdominal wall
column6: dislocation of the right elbow and ligament injury in the knee on the same side
column7: injuries with loss of substance in both lower limbs
column8: and no signs of TBI. The patient required orotracheal intubation and assisted ventilation due to respiratory failure
column9: and blood transfusions due to acute anaemia
column10: and was admitted to the ICU. Extubated after 48 hours without incident
column11: he was transferred to the hospital ward 24 hours later
column12: where he remained for ten days
column13: and a plaster cast was placed on the right lower limb. Since being discharged from hospital
column14: 13 days after the traumatism
column15: the patient presents pain at dorsal-lumbar level
column16: initially attributed to the renal traumatism
column17: which in the last 7 days is associated with a subjective sensation of loss of strength with paresthesia-dysesthesia in both lower limbs
column18: more pronounced when lying down
column19: and in the last 72 hours
column20: difficulty in starting urination and constipation. One month after the trauma
column21: the patient attended the regional hospital where an X-ray of the thoracic and lumbar spine was performed
column22: showing an increase in the interspinous distance in the anteroposterior projection
column23: and in the lateral projection an anterior displacement of the vertebral body of T11 on T12
column24: with a possible dislocation of the articular facets at this level
column25: and a minimal fracture of the most anterior portion of the vertebral body of T12. An MRI of the area was performed in which the existence of haematomas in the canal was ruled out
column26: confirming the findings of the X-ray
column27: and with a doubtful image of spinal cord contusion. Blood was also observed at the level of the interspinous ligament. The patient was referred to our department. On admission
column28: the patient presented mild paraparesis (4+/5)
column29: predominantly proximal
column30: with no sensory deficits
column31: mild symmetrical bilateral patellar hyperreflexia
column32: with no signs of pyramidal release. A CT scan was performed
column33: which in axial sections revealed the existence of an abnormal arrangement of the T11-T12 facets
column34: with stenosis of the canal at that level
column35: the existence of a sign of the naked facet
column36: and the sagittal and three-dimensional reconstruction confirmed dislocation and blockage of the articular facets at the T11-T12 level bilaterally. The patient underwent surgery through a posterior approach
column37: with excision of a scar magma at both joints
column38: curettage of the veneers of the upper FA of T12
column39: and open reduction of the dislocation by means of distraction-extension manoeuvres
column40: achieving almost complete reduction after performing a bilateral partial laminectomy
column41: which facilitated reduction
column42: followed by T11-T12 fixation with pedicle screws
column43: bars and autologous graft. The patient evolved favourably
column44: his neurological symptoms disappearing in the first week
column45: and he was discharged pain-free and ambulating normally.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Patient with a history of hiatal hernia and two caesarean sections at 22 and 24 years of age. At 31 years of age
column2: she consulted because since the second caesarean section and with increasing intensity
column3: she complained of micturition syndrome
column4: accompanied by pelvic and perineal pain
column5: in the days before
column6: during and after menstruation. She reported no haematuria or fever. Examination of the external genitalia and abdomen showed no abnormalities. She was treated on multiple occasions with urinary antiseptics
column7: although positive urocultures were never demonstrated. The renal ultrasound was normal and the bladder showed a 1.5 cm hyperechogenic
column8: excremental image on the posterior aspect of the bladder. Cystoscopy was performed in the middle of the menstrual cycle
column9: describing the existence of a small area
column10: minimally raised
column11: blurred
column12: retrotrigonal
column13: which on contact with the cystoscope produced faint ecchymosis
column14: not being identified at that time as the image of endometriosis. The patient was lost for check-ups for 3 years
column15: during which time she continued with the same symptoms
column16: and was treated by her gynaecologist who performed diagnostic laparoscopy
column17: finding no pelvic endometriotic foci
column18: but an adhesion to the pelvic walls and bladder in solidarity with the uterine body. The patient returned to our department and underwent an ultrasound and CT scan. Abdominal and transvaginal ultrasound showed an echogenic formation in the bladder floor 2 x 1.5x2.7.  An abdominopelvic CT scan showed no pathology in the abdominal organs
column19: but in the bladder there was a mass measuring 2x3 cm on the posterior side with no clear differentiation plane with the uterus.  At the age of 34 and with the suspicion of possible endometriosis
column20: bladder endoscopy was performed under anaesthesia a few days before menstruation
column21: and a morular mass of about 3 cm
column22: retrotrigonal
column23: with somewhat oedematous mucosa
column24: intact and with areas of bluish colour was observed. TUR was performed
column25: showing small cavities when sectioned with the snare
column26: which corresponded to cystified endometrial glands
column27: from which retained blood in the form of blackish fluid flowed when cut. The histopathological study confirmed the presence of intramuscular nests of endometrial-type glands
column28: surrounded by oedematous endometrial stroma
column29: with no signs of malignancy; all compatible with the diagnosis of endometriosis.  The patient was treated for 6 months with LH-RH analogues. Five years later she is completely asymptomatic and has had several bladder ultrasound scans and two cystoscopies during this period with no evidence of recurrence.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 33-year-old male smoker of a packet of cigarettes a day with no other history of interest came to the emergency department for ten days with penile induration at the base of the penis. Examination revealed an indurated longitudinal cord at the base of the penis in a dorsal location
column2: mobile and painful. No inguinal lymphadenopathy was palpable. The patient was afebrile. Penile Doppler ultrasound was performed and showed an induration corresponding to segmental thrombosis of the superficial dorsal vein of the penis. Coagulation study was normal. Diagnostic Judgement: Mondor's disease. The patient received anti-inflammatory treatment. He did not attend the check-up.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 48-year-old man from Argentina with no personal history of interest with progressive enlargement and pain in the left testicle of 2 months' evolution; no urinary symptoms
column2: no fever. He was treated with various antibiotics without improvement. Physical examination revealed a hard tumour on the left testicle that was painless and without signs of fluctuation. Complementary tests: Haemogram: Lymphocytosis
column3: the rest normal. Urine sediment: pyuria. Urine culture: sterile. Semen cultures: E. coli (1st)
column4: S. Sprophiticus (2nd)
column5: P. Mirabilis (3rd). Tumour markers: CEA
column6: alpha foetus and BHCG normal. Urinary ultrasound: normal. Testicular ultrasound: Heterogeneous left testicular tumour without liquid areas inside. Positive Mantoux test with ulceration. In the absence of clinical and radiological improvement
column7: radical orchiectomy was performed and the pathological study reported non-specific orchitis.  A sample was sent to microbiology
column8: consisting of purulent exudate obtained intraoperatively from the testicular tissue. Auramine staining for mycobacteria was negative. Gram staining showed polymorphonuclear leukocytes and few Gram(+) bacilli
column9: some of them filamentous
column10: with irregular staining and with bulging bacillary ends in the form of maces. Genomic amplification (PCR) for M.tuberculosis was negative. Chlamydia antigen detection was also negative. Culture for usual bacteria
column11: including Neiseria and Haemophilus
column12: were negative at 72 hours of incubation. At 96 hours
column13: growth was detected in the culture of a micro-organism very adherent to the medium
column14: difficult to emulsify
column15: which on Gram staining showed a Gram(+) bacillus morphology of coryneform appearance
column16: sometimes with irregular staining and some with club-shaped terminations. Phenotypic identification did not provide significant data
column17: so genetic study by 16SrRNA sequencing was performed and the strain was identified as Corynebacterium thomsseni. Cultures for Nocardia
column18: mycobacteria and fungi were negative. The isolated strain was highly sensitive to Penicillin
column19: Ampicillin
column20: Amoxicillin with clavulanic acid
column21: Cefotaxime
column22: Gentamicin
column23: Amikacin
column24: Erythromycin
column25: Tetracycline
column26: Trimethoprim sullfamethoxazole
column27: Rifampicin and Imipenem.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O

column1: A girl aged 18 months and 10 kg was transferred from her hospital of origin due to septic shock (maximum noradrenaline 1.5 µg/kg/min
column2: mechanical ventilation 21 days
column3: DIC); APD was started 40 hours after admission due to anuria
column4: increase in creatinine (baseline 0.7 mg/dl
column5: later 2.3 mg/dl) and balance of +2
column6: 360 ml. DPA was started on day 2 with 1.36% fluid
column7: 10 ml/kg per hour
column8: 20 minutes
column9: with D/P ratios of urea
column10: creatinine and Dt/Do glucose of 0.91
column12: respectively
column13: with effective ultrafiltration between 405 and 700 ml/day. To obtain a negative net balance we had to increase the dialysate concentration to 3.27%. We observed that with a volume of 15 ml/kg and 10 minutes dwell time at 3.27%
column14: the value of the ratios was 0.51
column15: 0.47 and 0.41 (the clearance of substances was not excessive
column16: but we still had sufficient osmotic gradient)
column17: so we increased the dwell time to 15 and then to 20 minutes with the following D/P ratios for urea
column18: creatinine and Dt/Do glucose: 0.65
column21: and 0.75
column23: 0.35 respectively
column24: with stabilisation of the upward trend of creatinine at 4 mg/dl. On day 21
column25: cloudy dialysate was observed with low cellularity and increased protein
column26: so we reduced the concentration of the liquid to 2.27% and left it for 4 hours with 15 ml/kg per pass and 4 passes per day (in peritonitis it is recommended to increase the time of permanence and reduce the concentration of the infused solution4). In these circumstances
column27: the values of the D/P ratios of urea
column28: creatinine and Dt/Do glucose were 1.04
column29: 0.85 and 0.14 respectively
column30: so we reduced the duration to 2 hours
column31: 6 daily passes with the same volume and type of liquid
column32: obtaining ratios of 1.01
column33: 0.76 and 0.23 with a decrease in 36 h of creatinine from 4.2 mg/dl to 3.3 mg/dl (renal function of 6.6 ml/min/1.73 m2 by urinary creatinine clearance and 9 ml/min/1.73 m2 by Schwarz formula). On day 27 with 6 daily passes with 1.36% glucose at 15 ml/kg and 2 hours dwell time the ratios were 1.04
column35: so we reduced to 90 minutes dwell time and then 60 minutes
column36: being able to increase the number of daily passes to 9
column37: obtaining ratios of 0.98
column38: 0.88 and 0.38 (with 60 minutes dwell time we obtained the same clearance as with 120 minutes dwell time); by being able to make more passes we would improve clearance and ultrafiltration)
column39: and a decrease in creatinine from 2.7 to 1.8 mg/dl (renal function of 15 ml/min/1.73 m2 by urinary creatinine clearance and 19 ml/min/1.73 m2 by Schwarz formula)
column40: which made it possible to suspend DPA.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We describe the case of a 58-year-old female patient. She refers to a hysterectomy at 42 years of age due to metrorrhagia secondary to fibroids. Two years earlier she had been assessed in gynaecology for lumbar densitometric osteoporosis (T-score at L1-L4 of -3
column2: with normal figures in the femoral neck)
column3: treated with denosumab and vitamin D supplements. She reported no toxic habits
column4: no personal or family history of fracture
column5: and her BMI was normal. She consulted for mechanical pain in the left foot
column6: of acute onset
column7: without inflammation or triggering cause
column8: which had been increasing in intensity until it became refractory to NSAIDs. On examination
column9: there were no striking findings
column10: except for pain on mobilisation of the left forefoot. No alterations in foot statics were observed. The patient provided a foot X-ray which showed no pathological findings. An MRI of the left foot was requested
column11: which revealed a stress fracture in the 2nd MTT with periosteal callus and soft tissue oedema. An analytical study was performed
column12: highlighting increased levels of PTH and vitamin D (103.7 pg/ml and 272 ng/ml
column13: respectively)
column14: attributed to excess vitamin D supplementation. Renal function
column15: serum and urinary calcium were normal. Treatment with vitamin D supplementation and denosumab was discontinued. The patient was assessed by the traumatology department and conservative treatment with unloading
column16: relative rest
column17: NSAIDs and magnet therapy was indicated
column18: with progressive improvement. Due to the patient's age
column19: 58 years
column20: and the predominance of osteoporosis at lumbar level
column21: she was considered a suitable candidate for treatment with SERMS (bazedoxifene)
column22: associated with calcium supplementation with vitamin D. One year later
column23: in the same month in which she started with pain in the previous episode
column24: she again reported the same symptoms in the left foot
column25: with no triggering cause. An X-ray was requested which showed an old fracture callus in the 2nd MTT due to a previous stress fracture
column26: with no other findings. An MRI of the left foot was performed to complete the study
column27: which showed oedema of the 1st and 3rd MTT
column28: of the cuneiform
column29: scaphoid and talus bones
column30: and tenosynovitis of the posterior tibialis. A new bone densitometry was requested
column31: which showed a T-score in the lumbar spine of -3.5. The patient had not taken bazedoxifene and vitamin D continuously
column32: so the importance of resuming them was insisted upon
column33: given the bone mineral density figures
column34: which had worsened. The fractures were treated with rehabilitation and unloading with progressive improvement.  Evaluating the case globally
column35: we considered osteoporosis as a predisposing factor
column36: as the patient was not obese
column37: nor had she had trauma or other risk factors. The fact that the two episodes of pain began in the same month (coinciding with the change of season)
column38: a year apart
column39: was striking. The patient did not report any change in her habits or physical activity (sedentary) at that time
column40: so we believe that perhaps the change in the type of footwear may have led to an overload of the left foot
column41: favouring the appearance of new stress fractures.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Three-year-old boy
column2: with no family history of congenital deformities or pathology detected during pregnancy. Physical examination revealed hypoplasia of the right forearm with absence of the third
column3: fourth and fifth digital rays and ulnar deviation of the hand by 60 degrees. Mobility of the thumb and index finger was adequate with good prehensile strength. Sensitivity was considered normal in the two-point discrimination test. Radiologically there was ulnar and radial hypoplasia at the expense of the distal third
column4: with radiohumeral synostosis
column5: absence of early carpal bones and absence of the third
column6: fourth and fifth rays. The total length of the radius was 5.8 cm and 3.0 cm for the ulna
column7: while in the healthy forearm it was 12.0 cm for the radius and 12.4 cm for the ulna
column8: which comparatively corresponded to a deficiency of 48.3% for the radius and 24.1% for the ulna. The humerus on the affected side had a length of 15.5 cm and on the healthy side 17 cm. A diagnosis of right upper limb longitudinal formation failure
column9: postaxial
column10: Bayne's grade IV
column11: with moderate humeral longitudinal shortening was established.  We decided to perform bone elongation of the forearm bones by placing a uniplanar transfixion distractor designed by JMY México® according to the characteristics proposed by Matev (13). Although the lengths of the radius and ulna were different
column12: the distraction of both bones was performed simultaneously. In the first surgical stage
column13: two parallel pins were placed proximal and two distal to the site chosen in the diaphysis of both bones for osteotomy
column14: leaving only the posterior cortex and with a margin between the proximal and distal pins of 3 cm. An incomplete circular osteotomy covering 300 degrees of the circumference was performed and the rest of the cortex was left intact. The postoperative course was uneventful. On the fourth postoperative day we started the distraction phase at a rate of 2 mm per day for the first 15 days and then at 1 mm per day for 45 days until a total elongation of 7.5 cm was achieved in 60 days. The total length achieved for the radius was 13.3 cm and for the ulna 10.5 cm. Four weeks after completion of distraction we observed adequate longitudinal bone formation radiologically. However
column15: we left the distractor in place until 8 weeks after stopping distraction
column16: at which time we found that there was excellent bone structure in the gap.  The second surgical time was performed at this time to remove the distractor and to perform centralisation of the hand over the distal radial epiphysis. To facilitate this procedure it was necessary to perform a diaphyseal resection of the radius. The new bony fixation was performed with Kischner pins. No osteotomy of the ulna was necessary because its elongation was in the direction of the vector traction and no deviation was observed.  The postoperative evolution was satisfactory
column17: with discrete oedema of the hand that subsided after a short time; the patient recovered the mobility of the fingers and did not suffer any alteration of sensibility. Six months after completion of the forearm procedure
column18: we placed the distractor in the humerus diaphysis with the same technical procedure as previously described
column19: although it is important to note the anatomical risk points of the nerves and vessels in order to perform the technique meticulously and avoid injury to these structures. In the semicircular corticotomy
column20: we preserved the posterior portion of the periosteum to save the radial nerve; the pins were placed in parallel
column21: two proximal and two distal
column22: with a 3 cm margin between them to perform the corticotomy. Four days later
column23: we started the elongation process at a rate of 1 mm per day
column24: until a gain of 6 cm was achieved. We decided to overcorrect the bone to balance it with the growth of the contralateral arm. At the end of the procedure
column25: we left the distractor in place for 8 weeks
column26: during which time we verified by radiology the adequate bony healing of the gap created for humeral longitudinal growth.  Finally
column27: 8 weeks after completion of the humeral distraction
column28: the time chosen to remove the distractor
column29: we performed the elbow arthrodesis
column30: leaving the elbow joint in a functional position.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 27-year-old pregnant woman
column2: blood group A positive
column3: with a personal history of meningitis at the age of 3
column4: curettage for molar pregnancy (G1P0A1) in her first pregnancy in 2005 and smoker of 10-20 cigarettes/day. No previous history of transfusions. In the ultrasound performed at 35 weeks' gestation
column5: bilateral foetal hydrocephalus and oligohydramnios were detected
column6: so a caesarean section was scheduled for 36 weeks' gestation. The previous analytical study showed a positive serology (IgM) for Parvovirus B19. Examination of the newborn after caesarean section revealed a good general condition
column7: with an Apgar test of 8 and 9 points in the first and fifth minute
column8: respectively
column9: small haematomas on the left shoulder and buttock
column10: macrocephaly with anterior fontanel under tension and prominence of the cephalic veins. The haemogram showed severe tombocytopenia (9 x 109/L). Given the clinical suspicion of NAFLD
column11: an aliquot of irradiated apheresis platelet concentrate of unknown HPA-1a phenotype was transfused and treatment was started with intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIG) at a dose of 1 g/kg x 2 days
column12: with a very good response (platelets > 100 x 109/L

column1: 28-year-old woman admitted for abdominal tumour and constitutional syndrome. She reported regular discomfort in the left void that increased in intensity weeks before her admission. column2: heterogeneous tumour

column1: A 33-year-old woman consulted for abdominal pain of two months' duration located in the right iliac fossa with no other accompanying symptoms. The patient visited several hospitals

column7: which did not detect any other lesions.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 46-year-old woman with a history of ovarian endometriosis

column1: A 56-year-old male patient with a history of positive serology for HIV and Hepatitis B presented with acute cholecystitis for which he underwent emergency laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the late postoperative period

column1: The patient is a 79-year-old woman with a history of arterial hypertension and cardiac arrhythmia
column2: who comes to our centre after noticing a non-painful tumour in the left breast
column3: which she refers to as having developed approximately one month ago. On examination
column4: a solid
column5: hard
column6: poorly demarcated
column7: fixed tumour of approximately 4 cm in diameter adhering to deep planes was palpated in the inner-inner quadrant of the left breast. A mammographic study of both breasts was performed without being able to clearly appreciate the mass as it was in a deep plane. The ultrasound study revealed a hypoechogenic and heterogeneous mass measuring approximately 28 x 30 mm with signs of malignancy
column8: irregular borders and posterior acoustic shadow. A clinical tru-cut microbiopsy of the lesion was performed and histology showed a malignant infiltrative neoformation of fusocellular character surrounding non-neoplastic acinar ductal structures.  Malignant spindle cell neoplasms of the breast raise the differential diagnosis mainly between metaplastic spindle cell carcinomas and sarcomas
column9: so complete excision of the lesion is indicated and the definitive diagnosis is deferred to histological study of the lesion. Given the patient's age and after assessing her wishes and the therapeutic possibilities
column10: surgical treatment was decided
column11: and an infero-medial quadrantectomy was performed without axillary lymphadenectomy. The histological size of the neoplasm is 5 x 4.8 x 3.5 cm
column12: with infiltration of the skin and skeletal muscle and microscopically shows an infiltrating neoplastic proliferation made up of spindle cells arranged in irregular fascicles with abundant areas of necrosis and variable cell density. The neoplastic cells show marked nuclear atypia
column13: hyperchromasia and abundant mitoses. In none of the areas studied is neoplastic ductolobulillar epithelium visible or forming part of the lesion and the few ducts observed appear to correspond to non-neoplastic structures infiltrated by the tumour.  In the immunohistochemical study the neoplastic cells are strongly positive for keratins AE1-AE3
column14: cytokeratin 22
column15: vimentin
column16: smooth muscle actin
column17: Cerb-2 and CD10 and negative for keratin 903
column18: EMA
column19: cytokeratin 7
column20: CD31
column21: CD34
column23: total actin
column24: desmin
column25: myosin
column26: CD68
column27: protein S-100 and HMB45. Hormone receptors for oestrogen and progesterone are negative.  Based on all these data
column28: a diagnosis of metaplastic spindle cell carcinoma was established. The patient showed no signs of residual tumour and adjuvant radiotherapy treatment was decided at a dose of 60 Gy
column29: at 2 Gy per fraction
column30: in 5 fractions per week. The patient is currently asymptomatic
column31: two months after the end of treatment.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 77 year old male patient with multiple cardiopathogenic factors
column2: and the only urological history was benign prostatic hypertrophy. He was admitted to the Internal Medicine Department for the study of constitutional symptoms of 4 months' evolution with anorexia and loss of about 15 kg of weight
column3: accompanied by generalised weakness and epigastric cramping pain lasting minutes. She had no other accompanying symptoms. A gastrointestinal examination (gastroscopy
column4: colonoscopy
column5: echoendoscopy) was performed and was normal. The physical examination was normal
column6: except for an increase in the size of the genitalia
column7: for which an ultrasound was performed
column8: with the result of a bilateral hydrocele
column9: more marked on the left side
column10: with multinodular morphology destructuring in the left teste
column11: which made it necessary to rule out an underlying malignant process. On examination

column19: multinodular

column24: lipidified cytoplasm. The mitotic index was high

The serum and imaging controls in relation to the testicular process remain within normal parameters.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 85 year old patient on treatment with moxifloxacin for a respiratory infection admitted for vomiting
