column1: A 69 year old man consulted the emergency department reporting a progressive and unexplained decrease in strength in the right lower limb of about fifteen days' duration. He also presented with paraesthesia in the distal areas of both feet. She did not report back pain and the symptoms began after pain in the knee. There was no history of interest except for hypertension
column2: which was treated and well controlled. Examination by the emergency physician revealed a step gait and a decrease in strength 4/5 for dorsiflexion of the right foot. He was diagnosed in the emergency department with possible neuropraxia of the right external popliteal sciatic nerve and was referred to the rehabilitation department
column3: where
column4: two months after the onset of the symptoms
column5: he was referred to the neurosurgery department after observing an intramedullary lesion at the level of L1
column6: rounded
column7: ill-defined
column8: 1x1 cm
column9: with an isointense centre and hypointense periphery in T1
column10: which after the administration of gadolinium enhanced in a diffuse manner and showed thickening of the diameter of the conus medullaris. As a first diagnosis
column11: the possibility of a conus medullaris ependymoma was reported
column12: without being able to rule out the possibility of an astrocytoma. There was no mention of any mass other than the one described above and no other process was evident on MRI. The patient was admitted to the neurosurgery department with hypoaesthesia in the tips of the toes of both feet
column13: together with a decrease in distal strength of 2/5 in the right lower limb and 3/5 in the left lower limb. On admission
column14: he retained sphincter control and the Karnofsky index was 70. Chest X-ray was reported as normal.  The patient underwent an osteoplastic laminotomy and total resection of a l x l cm mass
column15: easily resectable and not very haemorrhagic. Histological examination showed the presence of a metastasis of clear cell carcinoma of probable renal origin. This diagnosis was confirmed by a thoracic-abdominal CT scan
column16: which showed a giant renal mass (11 x 1 x 1 x 14 cm) and several abdominal and pulmonary metastases of less than 1 cm in size that were not evident on plain radiology. The patient recovered practically all of his paraparesis during his stay in the neurosurgery department. The control MRI study performed at 3 months showed no signs of recurrence. The patient evolved favourably
column17: with no neurological symptoms
column18: 14 months after the operation.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 53-year-old man consulted for the appearance of intense pain in the left iliac fossa with no other associated symptoms. He denied the existence of fever. He did not refer to usual home treatment or personal or family history of interest. Physical examination revealed slight overweight and painful palpation at the level of the left iliac fossa
column2: together with abdominal defence. Bowel sounds and the rest of the examination were normal. General laboratory tests showed a GGT of 88 U/l
column3: ferritin of 297.11 ng/ml and CRP of 7 mg/dl. All other parameters were normal. The clinical manifestations were suggestive of acute diverticulitis. Given the persistence and intensity of the pain
column4: as well as to confirm the suspected diagnosis
column5: a CT scan of the abdomen was performed
column6: which revealed sigmoid diverticulosis with no signs of diverticulitis. An upper abdominal section showed inflammation of the fat adjacent to the descending colon
column7: which corresponded to an epiploic appendix
column8: probably in the context of acute appendagitis secondary to twisting of the appendix.  The patient was diagnosed with "appendagitis" or "epiploic appendagitis" and received conservative treatment with oral anti-inflammatory drugs for 7 days
column9: with progressive improvement of symptoms and no complications. Antibiotics and hospitalisation were not necessary.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 71-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus was referred for a corneal ulceration of probable herpetic aetiology of the left eye of two months' evolution
column2: accompanied by mild ocular pain. The patient reported having suffered ocular inflammation associated with frontal dermatitis
column3: compatible with herpes zoster
column4: two years earlier. At the first visit
column5: she had a visual acuity of 0.4 in the right eye and a finger count at 1 metre in the left eye
column6: a mild bilateral cataract
column7: normal tonometry and fundus without significant alterations in both eyes. In the left eye
column8: a superficial and central corneal ulceration was observed
column9: with well-demarcated infiltrates at the edges
column10: associated with an inflammatory reaction in the anterior chamber (cellular tyndall 2+). Samples were taken for microbiological culture by corneal scraping
column11: and oral itraconazole 200 mg/24h associated with topical treatment with amphotericin B 0.15%
column12: cefazolin 50 mg/ml and tobramycin 15 mg/ml was prescribed
column13: based on the main suspicion of fungal keratitis. The culture showed growth of Candida albicans
column14: for which reason the same treatment was maintained. The keratitis rapidly worsened to corneal perforation within 6 days
column15: preceded by a significant increase in pain
column16: severe hyperemia
column17: extension of the corneal epithelial defect
column18: appearance of dense stromal infiltration (necrosis)
column19: hypopyon and ocular hypertension. An emergency amniotic membrane transplant (triple layer) was performed
column20: preceded intraoperatively by a new corneal scraping for microbiological culture. The result of this culture (aerobic and anaerobic) was negative for bacteria. Intravenous administration of voriconazole (200 mg/24 h) associated with oral aceclofenac
column21: preservative-free artificial tears and topical brimonidine was started as medical treatment. After 10 days
column22: intravenous voriconazole was replaced by oral voriconazole (200 mg/24 h) and continued for 6 weeks. The clinical picture responded favourably to treatment
column23: with inflammatory signs progressively disappearing during the first 15 days. The patient presented only blurred vision at the beginning of the treatment and a slight increase of LDH in the blood
column24: with no other side effects. Good integration of the amniotic membrane graft was observed
column25: although a penetrating keratoplasty was subsequently required due to residual corneal scarring (adherent leukoma).  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 68-year-old woman with a history of arterial hypertension and hypothyroidism came to the emergency department with acute pain in the left hypochondrium
column2: with no history of trauma
column3: of a constant nature
column4: radiating to the epigastrium with approximately 3 hours of evolution
column5: accompanied by dizziness and weakness. Physical examination revealed hypotension and tachycardia that was maintained despite the administration of intravenous fluids; the abdomen was painful
column6: predominantly in the hypochondrium and left lumbar fossa
column7: with no signs of peritoneal irritation. Ultrasound and computed tomography (CT) showed the presence of a rounded retroperitoneal tumour measuring approximately 10 x 12 cm in front of the upper pole of the left kidney
column8: vascularised
column9: with irregular contrast uptake and small calcifications inside; in addition
column10: there was an increase in the density of the retroperitoneal space compatible with bleeding. With the aforementioned findings
column11: surgery was performed
column12: revealing a large left retroperitoneal haematoma extending to the midline and the left iliac fossa and a tumour approximately 12 cm in diameter above the upper pole of the left kidney
column13: encapsulated
column14: with active bleeding due to a fissure in it
column15: which was removed
column16: preserving part of the adrenal gland and the left kidney. The evolution is satisfactory. Subsequent evaluation revealed the absence of arterial hypertension and abdominal ultrasound showed no pathological findings. The biopsy described a nodular tumour 10 cm in diameter and weighing 457 grams
column17: reddish in colour with a yellowish peripheral margin
column18: with a microscopic diagnosis of adrenal endothelial pseudocyst.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 24-year-old woman
column2: with reactive serology for HIV since 5 years ago
column3: without antiretroviral treatment or clinical controls
column4: who reported starting approximately one month ago with pain in the lower right maxillary region. He consulted a dentistry department where tumefaction was found in the right lower maxillary region
column5: at the level of the third lower molar. Treatment with antibiotics and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs was indicated. Two weeks later
column6: she consulted again with no improvement in her symptoms
column7: reporting increased pain and swelling. The symptoms were interpreted as a dental phlegmon and amoxicillin/clavulanic acid and corticosteroids were prescribed. One week before hospitalisation
column8: and due to the increase in size of the described tumour
column9: surgical drainage was performed
column10: obtaining haematic material. Analgesics were prescribed and the same antibiotic regimen was maintained. Five days after this procedure she was admitted to our hospital. As epidemiological antecedents
column11: she reported addiction to inhalation cocaine
column12: marijuana and smoking. On admission she was lucid
column13: afebrile
column14: oriented in time and space; the physical examination revealed the existence of a tumour formation in the right lower maxillary region extending to the submental area
column15: measuring approximately 10 × 10 cm
column16: red-violet in colour
column17: indurated
column18: painful on pressure
column19: which prevented the closure of the mouth
column20: chewing
column21: swallowing and speech. It involved the gum
column22: including dental pieces
column23: the peribuccal soft tissues and the right lower jaw. Homolateral submandibular adenomegaly was palpable
column24: indurated
column25: painless
column26: adherent to skin and deep planes. The rest of the physical examination showed no alterations of clinical relevance. Chest X-ray was normal. The admission laboratory showed: Ht: 35%
column31: L: 21%); ESR: 21 mm 1 hour; TGO: 41U/l
column32: TGP: 31 U/l
column33: FAL: 153 U/l
column34: glycaemia: 138 mg/dl
column35: urea: 27 mg/dl
column36: creatinine: 0.56 mg/dl
column37: Na+: 136 mEq/l
column38: K+: 4.1 mEq/l
column39: prothrombin concentration 98%
column40: KPTT: 30.6"
column41: pregnancy test: negative
column42: VRDL: non-reactive. Serologies for Chagas and hepatitis B and C virus were negative and for toxoplasmosis: IgM: negative and IgG: positive 1/64. CD4+ T-cell count was 235 cells/ml (16.3%)
column43: CD8: 872/mm3 (60.5%) and HIV viral load was 154
column44: 263 copies/ml (log10 4.74).  An abdominal ultrasound revealed mild heterogeneous splenomegaly; the rest of the patient had no abnormalities. An excisional biopsy was performed for diagnostic purposes; histopathological examination of the material obtained showed a proliferation of atypical
column45: medium to large lymphoid cells with regular nuclei
column46: lax chromatin
column47: presence of nucleoli attached to the cell membrane and amphophilic cytoplasm. Numerous mitoses and apoptosis phenomena were also observed. Immunohistochemistry revealed positivity for CD45
column48: CD3
column49: CD20
column50: CD10 and Bcl-6 in the neoplastic cells
column51: and negativity for CD138
column52: MUM-1 and Bcl-2. The Ki67 cell proliferation index was 99%. Microbiological studies of the biopsy material were negative for BAAR
column53: fungi and common germs. The definitive histopathological diagnosis was primary LB of the oral cavity. Bone marrow biopsy showed no infiltration by atypical lymphoid cells. Gram
column54: Grocott and Ziehl Neelsen stains were negative.  The patient received 6 cycles of chemotherapy based on the EPOCH-R schedule (etoposide
column55: prednisone
column56: vincristine
column57: cyclophosphamide
column58: doxorubicin
column59: with rituximab and intrathecal methotrexate). Episodes of neutropenia were treated with granulocyte colony-stimulating factor. After treatment
column60: complete disappearance of the gum lesion was observed. Four years later
column62: with no evidence of neoplastic disease
column63: undetectable viral load and CD4 362 cells/ml.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 18-year-old female patient who had undergone surgery for cloacal exstrophy (reconstruction of the intestinal and urinary tracts) in another care centre
column2: and who came to our department presenting with absence of the anterior abdominal wall
column3: unstable skin
column4: pubic eventration
column5: numerous scar sequelae and an incontinent urinary reservoir.  Wall reconstruction
column6: eventroplasty and urinary ostoma plasty are scheduled
column7: working as a team with the Surgery and Paediatric Urology Service. 1st surgical stage: Consisted of the placement of 2 rectangular expanders of 1000cc. (with expansion capacity up to 1500cc) and 15.2 cm. long x 7.3 cm. wide with remote valve (Silimed®) below the abdominal cellulo-fatty tissue and above the aponeurosis of the greater oblique muscle in subcostal and lateral position. Expansion was performed at a rate of between 50 and 100 cc of physiological solution at intervals of 1 week to 20 days
column8: depending on the patient's tolerance
column9: until reaching 1300 cc.  2nd Surgical time: Once the expansion is complete
column10: the urinary wall and ostoma surgery is scheduled. The paediatric plastic surgery team removed the expanders and the urological surgeon performed the urinary ostoma plasty. Both surgical teams then proceeded to reconstruct the upper and middle thirds of the wall using the remaining tissues of the rectus abdominis sheath
column11: rectus abdominis muscle and remaining scar tissue. In the lower third and pubis
column12: due to the absence of tissue
column13: it was decided to use a 15 x 10 cm polypropylene (Prolene®) prosthetic mesh over the lax scar tissue covering the eventration
column14: anchoring it to the pubic bones and the greater oblique muscle on both sides. Reconstruction of the skin and cellulo-fatty tissues is achieved by advancing the expanded lateral tissues.  The patient evolved favourably without complications and vaginal reconstructive surgery was performed one year later.  Despite the pubic diastasis of almost 17cm
column15: the patient has no gait disturbance and has not undergone any treatment by her own decision.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 20-year-old male who consulted for hypertensive crises of one year's duration
column2: accompanied by profuse sweating
column3: generalised flushing
column4: headache and
column5: occasionally
column6: lumbar pain. Blood pressure levels reached 230/110 mmHg
column7: often triggered by physical exertion. Physical examination revealed malar and palmar erythema
column8: which disappeared with acupressure. Laboratory tests showed elevated 24-hour urinary catecholamines and metanephrines: noradrenaline excretion 7515.77 nmol/24 h (< 504)
column9: dopamine 4298.84 nmol/24 h (< 3237) and normetanephrines 39676 nmol/24 h (< 2424). An abdominal ultrasound was performed
column10: showing a retroperitoneal mass of about 8 cm
column11: with heterogeneous echogenicity and marked vascularisation. In view of this finding
column12: abdominal-pelvic computed axial tomography (CT) was performed
column13: confirming the existence of a retroperitoneal mass measuring 8 x 4 cm above the aortic bifurcation
column14: which infiltrated the inferior vena cava and bordered the aorta at 180o
column15: encompassing the inferior mesenteric artery. Given the CT findings
column16: cavography was performed to assess resectability
column17: and an infrarenal intracaval repletion defect of 2 cm in diameter was observed.  Given the suspicion of paraganglioma of the organ of Zuckerkandl
column18: beta and alpha-adrenergic blockade was performed
column19: followed by surgical intervention with en bloc resection of the tumour; the anterior aspect of the cava was partially sectioned to remove the intracaval tumour. The postoperative period passed without complications
column20: the clinical symptoms disappeared and the plasma and urine levels of catecholamines and metanephrines normalised. The anatomopathological diagnosis confirmed the suspicion of a well-demarcated capsulated paraganglioma
column21: with a low proliferative index (ki 67: 5-7 %). He was referred to Medical Oncology
column22: where a 123I-MIBG scan was requested
column23: which showed no signs of residual or distant disease. In the absence of data justifying adjuvant chemotherapy treatment
column24: periodic follow-up was decided.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 26-year-old woman
column2: with no relevant past history or chronic treatment
column3: consulted Primary Care for general malaise
column4: cramps and paraesthesia in the hands and feet and
column5: for the past 2 days
column6: she had also been unable to raise her left eyelid. An analytical control was requested in Primary Care and a creatinine level of 4.6 mg/dl was detected (the only previous control recorded in our centre was 6 years earlier with a creatinine level of 1.5 mg/dl)
column7: for which reason the patient was referred to the Emergency Department. There was no family history of renal disease in any member of the family. Clinical course Her blood pressure was 135/67 mmHg
column8: heart rate 120 bpm and temperature 37.5°C
column9: with an unremarkable physical examination. Repeat blood work in the ED confirmed impaired renal function (creatinine 5.1 mg/dl and urea 245 mg/dl)
column10: together with sodium 124 mmol/l; potassium 3.5 mmol/l; pH 7.08; bicarbonate 5.9 mmol/l; pCO2 20 mmHg; corrected ionic calcium 0.69 mmol/l (normal 1.13-1.32); magnesium 1 mg/dl; leucocytes 14.060 and the rest of the haemogram and coagulation study were normal. Other deferred analytical determinations showed: calcium 7.4 mg/dl; phosphorus 5.6 mg/dl; iPTH 298 pg/ml; vitamin D 18.27 ng/ml and uric acid 8.8 mg/dl. The immunological study (immunoglobulins
column11: ANA) was normal. Blood electrophoresis: decreased gamma globulins. Serology for viruses B
column12: C and HIV was negative. Urine systemic analysis showed pH 6.0
column13: blood ++
column14: leucocytes +++. In 24 h urine
column15: proteinuria was 0.73 g
column16: creatinine clearance 12 ml/min
column17: uricosuria 600 mg
column18: calciuria < 4 mg/kg and oxaluria 10 mg (normal: 4-31). Electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm
column19: with ST elevation of 1 mm in all leads. Chest X-ray was normal. Plain abdominal X-ray showed extensive bilateral renal calcifications. After correction of hypocalcaemia
column20: hypomagnesaemia and metabolic acidosis
column21: the patient was discharged
column22: with no relevant incidents during admission. Laboratory values at discharge were creatinine 3.6 mg/dl; sodium 142 mmol/l; potassium 4.4 mmol/l; pH 7.43; bicarbonate 24.6 mmol/l; calcium 8.6 mg/dl; corrected ionic calcium 1.16 mmol/l; phosphorus 2.9
column23: iPTH 103 ng/ml and magnesium 1.9 mg/dl. Treatment at discharge was: calcium carbonate 2.5 g every 8 h; calcitriol 0.5 mcg/day; sodium bicarbonate 1 g/day and oral potassium and magnesium supplementation.  Some 48 hours after being discharged from the Nephrology Department
column24: she consulted the Emergency Department because she was unable to speak or perform tongue movements. In addition
column25: the patient reported that the previous night she had alterations in the control of her right hand movements. She also had difficulty swallowing and intense asthenia. She did not present fever or headache. On physical examination
column26: blood pressure was 102/72 mmHg
column27: heart rate 75 bpm
column28: baseline oxygen saturation 98% and the rest of the examination was normal. Blood tests were: creatinine 3.6 mg/dl; sodium 141 mmol/l; potassium 4.4 mmol/l; pH 7.43; bicarbonate 24.6 mmol/l; calcium 8.6 mg/dl; corrected ionic calcium 1.16 mmol/l and magnesium 1.9 mg/dl. The patient was assessed by the Neurology Department and was admitted to their care for further study. This department performed an edrophonium test (negative)
column29: brain CT scan without contrast (no significant findings)
column30: EEG (abundant outbreaks of paroxysmal activity [theta waves] in the left temporal region
column31: with propagation to the rest of the hemisphere
column32: as well as to the contralateral homologous region
column33: forming some bilateral paroxysmal outbreaks of sharp waves). Treatment was started with levetiracetam 250 mg/12 h
column34: which was insufficient to control the seizures. The patient progressed to focal status
column35: with no response to diazepam (up to 10 mg) or valproic acid boluses
column36: requiring transfer to the ICU. Comic activity was brought under control after the start of valproic acid perfusion (1 g/24 h)
column37: since when the patient has remained asymptomatic. Subsequently
column38: on the Neurology ward
column39: she was monitored with oral treatment: she remained asymptomatic and was discharged with 500 mg/12 h of valproic acid orally. Genetic study Given the absence of a family history of renal disease
column40: the current situation of advanced renal failure and
column41: therefore
column42: the diagnostic difficulties in performing specific studies to clarify the primary process that had led to the development of nephrocalcinosis
column43: it was decided to perform a genetic study. An analysis of all known genes associated with tubulointerstitial disease was requested http://nefrochus.villaweb.es/en/ which included analysis of the gene variants found in the known genes associated with forms of nephrocalcinosis (Nephrochus
column44: Santiago de Compostela). The study determined that the patient (II:1) was a carrier of a missense mutation in exon 14 of the SLC4A1 gene
column45: associated with autosomal dominant distal renal tubular acidosis (ATR-AD). This mutation (c.1766G > A
column46: fig. 2A) involves the substitution of a basic amino acid (p.R589H) arginine (Arg
column47: R) for an amino acid histidine (His
column48: H) not previously found in normal chromosomes of our cohort
column49: neither in the international 1000 genomes project
column50: nor in the dbSNP137 database
column51: but described in the literature5
column53: with a genomic code rs121912744 catalogued as CLINSIG = pathogenic and associated with families with autosomal dominant distal renal tubular acidosis. The functional study performed with various in silico prediction tools assigns pathogenicity criteria to the gene variant (SIFT: deleterious; polyphen2: deleterious; LRT: deleterious; MutationTaster: disease_causing_automatic; mutation assessor: medium; FATHMM: tolerated; RadialSVM: deleterious and LR: deleterious).  Co-segregation study In order to be able to decide on a possible live kidney transplant donation
column54: a cosegregation study is performed in both parents (I:1 and I:2). The fact that neither is a carrier of the R589H mutation indicates that this mutation is de novo or spontaneous
column55: and thus they can be candidates for donation. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
