column1: A 38-year-old man with a history of Crohn's disease of 3 years' evolution and admitted on two occasions for episodes of intestinal obstruction that were treated medically without the need for surgery. Since his last admission
column2: 6 months earlier
column3: the patient had remained asymptomatic and two weeks before admission
column4: the patient consulted his GP for fever and diarrhoea and was thought to be suffering from an exacerbation of Crohn's disease
column5: receiving treatment with corticosteroids without objective improvement. Given the persistence of fever
column6: he attended the emergency department with chills
column7: vomiting
column8: anorexia and pain in the right hypochondrium. On examination
column9: the patient was febrile (39°C) with poor general condition
column10: and a distended and painful abdomen in the right hypochondrium but without hepatomegaly. Cardiopulmonary examination was normal. The haemogram showed leukocytosis of 26
column11: 500/mm3 with a left shift
column12: haemoglobin 10.6 g/l
column13: haematocrit 36.3%
column14: platelets 490
column15: 000 and sedimentation rate of 50 mm/h. Serum biochemistry showed normal levels of transaminases and alkaline phosphatase
column16: creatinine and urea. Chest X-ray was normal. Abdominal CT revealed multiple abscesses in the right hepatic lobe. No other abdominal abscesses or abnormalities of the gallbladder
column17: bile duct or pancreas were identified. Empirical intravenous treatment with Gentamicin 80 mg every 8 hours and Clindamycin 600 mg every 8 hours was started. Before definitive treatment of the abscess
column18: a detailed study was performed to identify the cause of the liver abscess. On colonoscopy
column19: no abnormalities were observed and radiological evaluation of the small bowel revealed several strictures at the level of the jejunum and ileum but no evidence of fistulae or intestinal obstruction.  The liver abscess was drained under ultrasound control
column20: and samples of the abscess contents were taken for culture where Streptococcus milleri grew. Blood cultures were sterile. Intravenous antibiotherapy was continued for 6 weeks. Drainage was maintained for 21 days and removed when drainage was minimal. His recovery was satisfactory
column21: and he was discharged after completion of antibiotic treatment. An abdominal CT scan performed 4 months later showed collapse of the abscess cavities.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 57-year-old woman
column2: with no medical history of interest
column3: ex-smoker for 15 years
column4: referred from the Breast Cancer Early Detection Unit for a 3.5 cm nodule in the lower left quadrant of the left breast
column5: without palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. The diagnosis was made by biopsy
column6: MRI and axillary ultrasound of infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the left breast with axillary involvement. Neoadjuvant treatment with standard chemotherapy with FEC 75 (4 cycles) followed by docetaxel (4 cycles). After treatment
column7: there was no radiological response and surgery was performed
column8: with a left mastectomy and Berg level I and II lymphadenectomy. The definitive anatomopathological diagnosis was infiltrating ductal carcinoma
column9: grade III
column10: 2.6 cm
column11: Her2-neu negative. Oestrogen receptors 98%. Progesterone 38%. P53 29%. Ki 67 35%. Her-2 0%. Keratin 56 positive 1/3. EGFR negative. E-Caderin positive 3/3. Androgen negative. BCL2 positive 2/3. It is a luminal B-Ki67 pattern with metastasis in 1/ 19 lymph nodes. In the immediate postoperative period there was slight haemorrhage externalised by drainage
column12: and conservative treatment was carried out. On the seventh postoperative day
column13: a debit of 400 ml was observed through the axillary drainage
column14: with a milky appearance
column15: suggestive of chylous lymphorrhoea. The chylous fluid was confirmed by a biochemical study (triglycerides: 800 mg/dl
column16: total cholesterol: 47 mg/dl). A diet with fat restriction is indicated
column17: advising the ingestion of foods with medium-chain triglycerides and simultaneously administering subcutaneous somatostatin every 8 hours for 10 days. With these measures
column18: the quantity and appearance of the axillary drainage improved and normalised
column19: allowing its removal 20 days postoperatively. No further complications were observed in subsequent check-ups
column20: and the patient went on to complete oncological treatment. The patient is asymptomatic and free of disease after 37 months of follow-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 33-year-old patient with no past history of interest
column2: diagnosed with ileal Crohn's disease in early 2005. He had been treated with claversal 500 mg/8 h and azathioprine at a dose of 150 mg/day since December 2005 for corticodependence. He was also being treated with quarterly oral iron
column3: monthly intramuscular vitamin B12 and folic acid two days a week. Since then the patient was asymptomatic. In January 2007
column4: an increase in cholestasis enzymes over time was observed
column5: and it was decided to extend the study on an outpatient basis and withdraw azathioprine. Physical examination: Blood pressure: 100/60 mm/sec; Pulse: 70 bpm; Temperature: 36oC; Weight: 80 kg; Height: 180 cm; Good general condition. Conscious and oriented. Cardiopulmonary auscultation normal. Abdomen soft
column6: depressible
column7: not painful
column8: no masses or megaliths. Lower extremities without alterations. Given the persistence of cholestasis
column9: the following tests were performed: Blood tests. Blood count and coagulation normal. Platelets: 108
column10: 000/ml. Liver profile: Transaminases normal. FA: 248U/L. GGT: 390U/L. Ferric profile and autoimmunity negative. Hepatitis B and C virus serology negative. Abdominal ultrasound. Liver diffusely increased in size
column11: with smooth contour and diffusely coarse
column12: heterogeneous and hyperechogenic parenchyma
column13: without occupational lesions. Mild splenomegaly. Calibre and permeability of the portal portal normal. Rest of structures without alterations. Abdominal MRI. Liver diffusely increased in size
column14: smooth capsular contour and homogeneous parenchyma in mid-level T1 sequences
column15: in T2 sequences appears hypointense
column16: with diffuse patchy areas
column17: slightly hyperintense
column18: without occupational lesions. Slight splenomegaly. Rest of structures without alterations. Gastroscopy. In the lower third of the oesophagus 3 small varicose cords were observed
column19: which disappeared with insufflation. Given the persistence of dissociated cholestasis despite the withdrawal of azathioprine
column20: it was decided to perform a liver biopsy in which a preserved general architecture was observed. Some portal spaces are widened with incomplete porto-portal bridging. Isolated centrolobulillary veins. No cholestasis or haemosiderosis. No macrophages. PAS diastase positive. Some portal spaces have a slight infiltrate of round cells that does not overflow the limiting plate. The irregular hepatocyte trabeculae show a regenerative and pavement-like pattern in some areas. There are frequent binucleated cells
column21: vascular structures and dilated sinusoidal areas with a peliotic pattern. There is an irregular reticulin framework with areas of collapse. The histology described above is compatible with nodular regenerative hyperplasia.  The subsequent evolution
column22: both analytical and portal hypertension data
column23: was good with normal analytical normality and disappearance of the oesophageal varices.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male
column2: 63 years old. He consulted for monosymptomatic macroscopic haematuria. An ultrasound scan was requested
column3: showing a 5 cm mass on the left lateral aspect of the bladder that produced ureterohydronephrosis in the left kidney. A TUR-biopsy was performed
column4: revealing a high-grade infiltrating bladder tumour. The extension study was negative. The patient's creatinine was 2.5 mg/dl. A laparoscopic radical cystoprostatectomy with Bricker-type urinary diversion was performed in March 2005 (high-grade pT2b No Mo
column5: affecting the trigonal area and posterior aspect). The operative course evolved favourably. In the postoperative review one month after surgery
column6: the left ureterohydronephrosis was reduced while maintaining a certain degree of cortical atrophy
column7: and renal function improved (creatinine of 1.65 mg/dl).  The patient presented very poor tolerance to the stoma
column8: insisting on its conversion to a continent shunt. This situation was considered due to the improvement in his renal function. Two months later we performed an exploratory laparotomy
column9: achieving a good pelvic dissection and identification of the urethral stump. We constructed an ileal neobladder with 45 cm of ileum. Surgical time was 180 minutes
column10: with bleeding of less than 80 cc. The patient was discharged on the sixth postoperative day without complications. Five months after surgery
column11: he is continent during the day and night
column12: with good emptying of the reservoir. Both patients were thoroughly informed of the risks of surgery and its possible complications
column13: as well as the potential sequelae in terms of metabolic disorders
column14: persistent diarrhoea and incontinence and/or the need for self-catheterisation due to high post-micturition residual. In both cases
column15: the Bricker loop was released from the abdominal wall and after shortening it was anastomosed to the neobladder chimney
column16: requiring no ureteral reimplantation. The bladder catheter was removed after 3 weeks and both patients achieved continence in a short period of time. Both patients are very satisfied with the orthotopic shunt.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We describe the technique used in the case of a 23-year-old female patient who came to the clinic for primary amenorrhoea. Her phenotype was female
column2: with normal external genitalia and internal genitalia with absence of vagina. Abdomino-pelvic ultrasonography reported aplastic uterus and bilateral renal microlithiasis; excretory urography was normal; abdominal CT was also normal and pelvic CT showed the existence of a hypoplastic uterus. X-ray of the left hand showed an approximate bone age of 17 years. Simple radiology of the dorsal-lumbar spine showed right lumbar scoliosis and asymmetry of the iliac crests. The colon study by barium enema was normal and no internal genitalia were detected in the rectal examination. Complementary studies: hormonal profile with FSH
column3: LH
column4: oestradiol
column5: progesterone
column6: testosterone
column7: prolactin
column8: were normal. The patient was intensively studied and sent for medical evaluation to the Gynaecology
column9: Endocrinology and Psychology Departments
column10: until the final diagnosis of Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser Syndrome was completed and she was referred to Plastic Surgery for vaginal reconstruction.  The McIndoe technique was performed
column11: with the following modification: taking and applying partial thickness skin grafts from the gluteal regions
column12: which were manually cross-linked and fixed to a layer of haemostatic gel sponges in order to ensure intimate contact of the grafts with the newly formed vaginal walls. In total
column13: 2 rectangular 8 x 6 cm sheets of Gelfoam® haemostatic gel sponge were taken
column14: sutured together with 3-0 monocryl resorbable threads and placed on the silicone conformer to take its shape simulating a lining. The grafts were fixed to the conformer previously covered with Gelfoam® sponges
column15: also using resorbable sutures. The new vaginal tunnel was created by blunt dissection according to the technique described by the original author
column16: with a depth of 12 cm and a diameter of approximately 6 cm
column17: without intraoperative eventualities and with placement of the aforementioned device
column18: fixed to the vaginal neo-walls with non-absorbable 3-0 nylon suture. Finally
column19: we applied external compressive treatment with compresses and a layer of transparent adhesive and girdle-type suspensory tape.  The initial dressing was discovered 10 days postoperatively
column20: finding 100% integration of the grafts. We repositioned the conformer to hold it in place for 4 more weeks of continuous use and then 3 weeks of overnight conformer use was indicated. At 3 months postoperatively
column21: she was instructed to begin sexual intercourse
column22: which she had already agreed to schedule in order to obtain the best possible results from the technique
column23: avoiding vaginal stenosis. One year after the operation
column24: the patient has an active sexual life with satisfactory postoperative results.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 60-year-old man
column2: with no pathological history of interest
column3: who was referred to us from the Urology Department of our Centre with a diagnosis of stage IV prostate adenocarcinoma with multiple metastatic bone involvement and in a phase of hormone resistance. In February 2004
column4: due to prostatic syndrome (pollakiuria and urinary urgency)
column5: his Primary Care Physician (PCP) had performed a PSA test which showed a value of 12 ng/ml
column6: and for this reason he was referred to the specialist. He underwent transrectal ultrasound and ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy which was reported as: bilobular adenocarcinoma
column7: Gleason 7 (4+3). In the extension study (blood tests
column8: MRI and bone scintigraphy)
column9: retroperitoneal lymph node metastases and multiple foci of pathological hypercaptation (spine
column10: neck and femoral diaphysis
column11: bony pelvis) were observed. Complete androgen blockade with gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogue (A-LHRH) and antiandrogen was instituted. With this treatment
column12: the PSA level normalised within 4 months (June 04). The patient was receiving analgesic treatment for bone pain with NSAIDs and morphine. He was also treated with dorsolumbar vertebral irradiation with 30 Gy administered in 10 sessions. In April 2006
column13: and with the patient asymptomatic
column14: the PSA began to rise progressively to 7.3
column16: 21 ng/ml
column17: maintaining testosterone at castration levels. It was decided
column18: at this point
column19: to discontinue the antiandrogen. The biochemical response was good and normalisation was achieved in August 06. Unfortunately
column20: in November 06
column21: she attended the emergency department with intense generalised and incapacitating bone pain despite the increase in analgesic doses (EAV=8-9)
column22: for which she received treatment with strontium (St) in the Nuclear Medicine Department. In addition
column23: the clinical picture is accompanied by PSA figures of 850 ng/ml. In December 06 we decided
column24: with his informed consent
column25: to start palliative QT with Docetaxel and prednisone. We also started therapy with bone resorption inhibitors (zoledronic acid). The clinical response was satisfactory with analgesic control (VAS=2-3) and a reduction in PSA to 150 ng/ml. On 15-02-07
column26: she attended the emergency department and reported that for the last 15 days she had been noticing protrusion of the left eyeball and difficulty in fully separating the eyelids. Neurological examination Proptosis
column27: eyelid ptosis
column28: mydriasis with little reactivity secondary to involvement of the third pair. No orbital murmurs. Orbital MRI Metastatic replacement of the entire central segment of the cranial base
column29: the bone marrow of the vertebrae included in the study and part of the cranial diploe. Involvement of the roof and lateral wall of the left orbit which appear expanded and cause proptosis of the eyeball. The left greater sphenoid wing is replaced and thickened and there is a clear extension to the wall of the left cavernous sinus and the cleft. Similar changes are seen in the bones comprising the contralateral orbit
column30: but less advanced. The lesion of the roof of the left orbit is accompanied by a soft tissue lesion causing inferior displacement of the orbital musculature. Contrast sequences show heterogeneous hyperenhancement of all the lesions described.  He received palliative irradiation of the affected areas and presented a frank and rapid deterioration
column31: dying on 21-03-07.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 35-year-old male who was involved in a motorbike accident. CTHT on admission showed a 7 mm intimal laceration of the thoracic aorta after the brachiocephalic trunk exit. The patient underwent decompressive right parietal craniotomy and evacuation of a subdural haematoma as a matter of urgency. Treatment with intravenous labetalol was started for strict control of the TAS and management of the associated lesions was prioritised due to their severity. One week after admission
column2: the TTE showed an improvement compared to that at admission. 15 days later
column3: magnetic angiography (angio-MRI) showed a normal distribution of the outflow of the supra-aortic trunks with no images suggestive of traumatic rupture of the aorta. One month after admission he was discharged home.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 75-year-old male with a history of arterial hypertension
column2: type 2 diabetes mellitus
column3: transient ischaemic attack
column4: autoimmune hypothyroidism and mild cognitive impairment. He suffered a flame contact burn due to inflammation of his clothing by fanning a flame with diesel fuel
column5: as a result of which he had deep dermal and subdermal lesions on both lower extremities
column6: with a total body surface area burned of 20%. The burns were deep dermal on the posterior surface of both thighs and circumferential on both legs
column7: with a plaque of subdermal involvement on the anterior surface of the left leg
column8: as well as superficial dermal burns on the lateral thighs and face. Resuscitation in the first hours after the accident was carried out in a hospital in another region
column9: from where he was referred to the Intensive Care Unit of our hospital for further treatment of the injuries. On the day of admission
column10: we performed emergency escharotomies on both legs and completed initial resuscitation. During the first 3 weeks of hospitalisation we performed 4 sessions of serial debridement of the burned areas and coverage with meshed partial skin autografting of the anterior surface of the thighs in the defects caused by the exeresis of the deepest burns
column11: and with dermal substitutes (Biobrane®) in the debrided areas of superficial burns
column12: on the lateral thighs and in patchy areas of the legs One week postoperatively
column13: we observed the loss of the graft on the anterior surface of the left leg.  In a new surgical session we performed debridement of the left pretibial area
column14: with persistence under the graft of a burn that had not been eliminated during the previous surgeries. After adequate removal of this eschar
column15: we observed a 20 cm long pretibial defect
column16: with exposure of the tibia. The entire exposed periosteum was removed and vacuum therapy was started on the resulting defect. Vacuum therapy was applied using a VAC® device (KCI Clinic Spain SL)
column17: in continuous mode
column18: at 125 mmHg. Cures were performed every 72 hours with chlorhexidine soap. No further debridement procedures were necessary in the operating theatre. After 45 days of vacuum therapy we verified complete coverage of the bone by granulation tissue and performed definitive treatment with partial skin autografts taken from the buttocks
column19: after which we achieved complete closure of the wounds.  During the period of therapy
column20: microbiological cultures of the underlying granulation tissue were positive for multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa
column21: which the patient had previously also presented with in urine. We instituted systemic treatment with Imipenem and Cilastatin
column22: and performed partial debridement of the more superficial and hypertrophic granulation tissue during the dressing changes in the room. After completion of the vacuum therapy and grafting of the defect
column23: the patient showed no further signs of graft infection. He was discharged from hospital 100 days after admission
column24: with difficulty in ambulation and rehabilitation treatment on an outpatient basis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The case described in our study is that of a 76-year-old woman with a history of arterial hypertension and carcinoma of the rectum treated 15 years ago with radiotherapy
column2: surgery and chemotherapy
column3: in complete remission at that time. She was receiving outpatient treatment with opioid analgesics
column4: monitored by the Pain Unit
column5: for generalised osteoarthritis. In September 2013
column6: this patient attended the Emergency Department with acute chest pain that was diagnosed as NSTEACS-Killip III
column7: assessed by the Cardiology Department
column8: a loading dose of Prasugrel and acetylsalicylic acid was started
column9: and it was decided to perform primary percutaneous coronary intervention via the right radial artery
column10: with the placement of two stents. Two hours after her stay in the Intensive Care Unit
column11: the patient
column12: who was generally stable
column13: began to experience pain and haematoma formation on the volar aspect of the right forearm in relation to the catheter puncture site. The patient was assessed by the Traumatology Department and the physical findings of the examination were as follows: - Pain
column14: exacerbated by passive extension of the fingers (extension of the flexor muscles of the forearm). - Pallor. - Inability to detect radial or ulnar pulse. - Decrease in temperature with respect to the contralateral limb. - Anaesthesia and total paralysis of the affected limb. In view of the clinical findings
column15: a confirmatory diagnosis was made by measuring intra-compartmental pressure with the Stryker® "Intra-Compartmental pressure monitor system"
column16: obtaining a reading of 42mm Hg. The diagnosis of acute compartment syndrome in the right forearm was determined and urgent surgical treatment was proposed. The surgical procedure was performed under balanced general anaesthesia and airway control with a laryngeal mask. Antibiotic prophylaxis with 2 grams of intravenous Cefazolin. A skin incision was made over the midline of the volar side of the forearm
column17: from the elbow flexure to Kaplan's line. The subcutaneous cellular tissue was intensely infiltrated by haematoma. A longitudinal section of the forearm fascia was performed
column18: exposing the epitrochlear musculature of the forearm
column19: and decompression of the median nerve was performed by section of the carpal annular ligament. No vascular lesions with signs of active arterial bleeding were observed. For surgical closure
column20: the wound was covered with sterile compresses impregnated with Nitrofural
column21: and the wound was closed by means of mesh with vascular elastic vessel loops and a non-compressive bandage.  As soon as the fasciotomy was performed
column22: recovery of the colour and temperature of the affected limb was observed
column23: as well as recovery of the arterial pulse. Three hours after surgery
column24: the patient was re-evaluated
column25: with capillary refill of less than 2 seconds
column26: mobility and distal sensitivity
column27: and no pain. Nine hours later
column28: the patient presented absence of pain in the right forearm
column29: with good distal vasculonervous status.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male patient
column2: 17 years old
column3: referred to the Maxillofacial Surgery Service of the University of Talca
column4: for presenting a lesion at the level of the right mandibular angle
column5: revealed in a cervical lateral teleradiography control
column6: following a car accident. The patient reported no personal or family history. History of smoking
column7: alcohol and drugs were negative
column8: as were any medication intake or drug allergies. The general physical examination was not compromised. No aesthetic or functional alterations were observed on extraoral clinical examination. Intraoral palpation revealed a slight increase in volume in the posterior area of the mandibular vestibule.  In the conventional radiological study an extensive unilocular image of mixed density was observed
column9: with radiopaque predominance
column10: surrounded by a radiolucent band with net corticalised limits located in the area of tooth 48
column11: partially overprojected in the roots of tooth 47 with bulging of the bony slabs and with rejection of tooth 48 towards the distal and cephalic region. The mandibular canal was displaced towards the basilar edge in the segment corresponding to the mandibular body and rejected distally in the ascending branch.  The study was complemented with a computed axial tomography scan showing a hyperdense lesion
column12: with clear and corticalised limits
column13: with widening of the bony tables. Its dimensions were: antero-posterior 25.9 mm
column14: vestibulo-palatine 21 mm and 28.3 mm in greatest cephalo-caudal diameter.  The acquisition of the images was processed with Dentascan® software
column15: obtaining axial
column16: panorex and transversal reconstructions of the area of interest
column17: which confirmed the proximity to the mandibular canal
column18: as well as the involvement of both tables.  The differential diagnosis for this case was immature complex odontoma
column19: ameloblastic fibroodontoma
column20: calcifying epithelial odontogenic tumour and calcifying epithelial odontogenic cyst. After the radiological study
column21: an incisional biopsy was performed under local anaesthesia
column22: which included both soft and hard tissues
column23: showing calcified dentine-type tissue
column24: with areas of minor calcification and lax fibrous connective tissue that resembled the stellate reticulum of the dental organ. The periphery showed fibrous connective tissue and some small areas showing epithelium of odontogenic origin with the presence of peripheral cylindrical cells of the ameloblast type. The sample was irregular and showed no denticle structure. Accordingly
column25: the histological diagnosis was a lesion compatible with an odontoma in formation with the presence of ameloblastic changes. Enucleation of the lesion was performed under general anaesthesia
column26: using an extraoral approach at the level of the right mandibular angle to facilitate modelling and subsequent placement of a rigid osteosynthesis. In this way the affected area was accessed
column27: finding a very diminished vestibular table
column28: which was removed to make way for the exposure and complete elimination of the lesion
column29: concluding with a curettage of the surgical bed. The remnant of healthy bone tissue was very poor
column30: so the placement of a 2.4 reconstruction plate at the level of the mandibular angle and body was planned to provide greater strength and prevent a pathological fracture. Immediate grafting was not planned due to the possibility of recurrence.  Histopathological examination of the operative specimen revealed a greater amount of ameloblastic tissue and a diagnosis of ameloblastic fibroodontoma was made.  Healing went smoothly. Although this lesion has a low recurrence rate
column31: the patient is monitored regularly and there have been no signs of recurrence to date.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 34 year old female patient with a history of maternal grandfather who died of lung carcinoma. Sinusitis seven years earlier. She consulted her ENT specialist for a clinical history of 14 months with rapidly progressive rhinorrhoea and epistaxis. Rhinoscopy revealed a mass in the right nostril with a polypoid appearance
column2: very bloody on contact
column3: which occupied the entire right nostril and appeared to connect with the septum and middle turbinate
column4: extending to the choana and occupying the nasopharynx. The biopsy was positive for stesioneuroblastoma. A CT scan of the head and neck showed a 4-centimetre (cm) polypoid mass with a large pedicle in the right nostril and cavum. The MRI of the head and neck showed a space-occupying lesion that conspicuously obliterated the cavum and extended from the level of the nostrils towards the back
column5: coming into contact with the prevertebral musculature
column6: without infiltrating it
column7: and well delimited.  A CT scan of the thorax and a bone scan without pathology are performed as an extension study. She was classified as Kadish Stage C. She underwent functional endoscopic surgery and the pathological anatomy showed stesioneuroblastoma. The postoperative CT scan showed a polypoid thickening of the mucosa in the right maxillary sinus
column8: with no evidence of malignancy
column9: at the level of the right frontal sinus.  Adjuvant treatment with external radiotherapy was decided
column10: using a Linear Accelerator with 6 and 15 MV photons
column11: with tissue compensation wedges after virtual simulation and 3D planning on individualised helical CT. The tumour bed received a global dose of 60 Gy in 30 fractions
column12: with a schedule of 2 Gy/fraction
column13: 5 fractions per week. Tolerance was good
column14: with maximum cutaneous G1
column15: mucosal G2 and oropharyngeal G2 toxicity. Currently
column16: 6 months after irradiation
column17: the complete response has been maintained.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The third patient is a 25-month-old male
column2: who came directly to the emergency maxillofacial surgery department referred by his local paediatrician
column3: presenting with inability to close his mouth and drooling
column4: as well as refusal of breakfast. The previous day
column5: while playing in the swimming pool
column6: the child had fallen and hit his nose
column7: resulting in erosion of the nasal root. Based on the clinical presentation and this history
column8: the child was diagnosed with traumatic dislocation of the TMJ. In our examination we noted pain in the preauricular region on both sides that worsened when closing the mouth. However
column9: complete closure was possible without reduction manoeuvres
column10: and occlusion was good. Otoscopy was very painful
column11: the "swallow sign" was positive
column12: and the CAE was swollen with mild scaling and discharge. X-rays of both TMJs were normal. The patient was referred to the ENT department where
column13: after appropriate treatment
column14: the condition resolved.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Seven-year-old boy who came to the emergency department with pain in the right hip
column2: limping and fever. The symptoms had started abruptly seven days earlier. On the second day of illness he was assessed in the Traumatology Department and diagnosed with "hip synovitis"
column3: and prescribed rest and analgesics. The mother reported that during the following days the pain persisted at rest
column4: woke him up at night and improved
column5: but did not disappear
column6: with analgesia. She presented at all times with antalgic postures
column7: functional impotence and lameness. Fever persisted for seven days (maximum 38.5°C)
column8: accompanied by decreased appetite. In the last few days
column9: two skin lesions appeared
column10: one on the buttock and the other on the scalp. On general inspection
column11: we found a child in a wheelchair in fair general condition
column12: pale and in an antalgic position with complete flexion of the right hip and knee. During the physical examination
column13: the absence of swelling
column14: pain or limitation at any joint level was surprising
column15: and no bony tender points were found. Active mobilisation of the hip was reduced
column16: while passive mobilisation was normal. The gait was very cautious
column17: and in the standing position he did not bear weight on the right leg. Pediculosis infestation and a nodular
column18: inflamed lesion
column19: both on the scalp
column20: were also observed. Blood tests showed mild neutrophilia and increased acute phase reactants: fibrinogen 1008 mg/dl
column21: C-reactive protein 173 mg/l and erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 100 mm/hour. Ultrasound of the hip and abdominopelvic X-ray were normal
column22: except for an antalgic position in the latter.  During his stay in the ED
column23: and after administering intravenous analgesia
column24: abdominal pain appeared progressively on deep palpation in the hypogastrium and right iliac fossa without defence or other signs of peritoneal irritation. An abdominal ultrasound was performed
column25: which was normal
column26: and acute surgical pathology was ruled out. The study for fever without focus was completed with a chest X-ray and a urine test strip
column27: which were negative
column28: and it was decided to admit the patient to the Infectious Diseases Unit. The Paediatric Rheumatology Service was consulted and recommended a bone scan
column29: which was carried out in the following days
column30: with negative results. He was admitted with treatment with intravenous amoxicillin-clavulanic acid. Given the normality of the tests performed and the clinical suspicion of psoas abscess
column31: an abdominal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan was requested
column32: which showed an abscess in the right psoas muscle and osteomyelitis of the L4 vertebral body. The blood culture was sterile
column33: but the puncture of the scalp abscess isolated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus
column34: so antibiotherapy was modified to cover this germ
column35: with meropenem and linezolid. The patient evolved favourably
column36: without the need for surgical drainage.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 14-year-old male under haematology follow-up for thrombopenia was referred to Neuropaediatrics for presenting an increase in CPK (up to 1864 IU/L)
column2: lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) (up to 421 IU/l) and transaminases (aspartate transaminase [AST] up to 490 IU/l
column3: alanine aminotransferase [ALT] up to 280 IU/l) in serial analyses. The patient reported being previously asymptomatic
column4: except for a slight asthenia on moderate exercise
column5: such as running or climbing stairs
column6: occasionally associated with cramps and myalgia. Further anamnesis revealed an isolated episode of macroscopic haematuria following previous exercise. Examination was normal. An electroencephalogram
column7: electromyogram and muscle magnetic resonance imaging of the lower limbs were performed
column8: with no abnormalities in any of these complementary tests. A muscle biopsy was also performed
column9: which revealed myophosphorylase deficiency
column10: with no other additional alterations. The molecular study revealed the presence of p.R50X (c.148C>T) and p.R490W (c.1468C>T) mutations in compound heterozygosis
column11: confirming the diagnosis of suspected McArdle disease. The patient was referred to nutrition and dietetics
column12: presenting two episodes of rhabdomyolysis prior to dietary coupling that required admission to the paediatric intensive care unit. The patient is currently asymptomatic
column13: with normal CPK values
column14: following nutritional support guidelines and with outpatient controls in Neuropaediatrics and Paediatric Nutrition. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 30-year-old heterosexual male with a personal history of poor school performance and an overprotective upbringing pattern. He had been in a stable relationship for several years and had a daughter. At the time of the examination
column2: he was awaiting trial for two sexual assaults
column3: one week apart
column4: both of which involved the use of an intimidating instrument (knife) and the second victim had sustained injuries as a result of her resistance (dislocated shoulder). He had no previous criminal record. Accused acts In relation to these
column5: he recounts the introduction into his car
column6: under intimidation with a knife
column7: of a stranger "whom he liked"
column8: whom he groped and kissed after convincing her not to go any further for the sake of his daughter; he left her at the door of his house
column9: with threats of being able to locate her if she told him what had happened. After about a week
column10: he repeated the same sequence
column11: although this time the victim tried to run away from the car
column12: causing injuries to herself when she was held down by the victim. Both sexual assaults coincided with a period of deterioration in the couple's relationship
column13: and in the second one there was a clear precedent of frustration related to the non-fulfilment of the expectations of having a sexual relationship with a stranger with whom he had a telephone relationship
column14: and towards whom the victim had feelings of incipient infatuation. Relevant findings in the psychosexual sphere He highlighted the existence of a low level of sexual arousal
column15: as well as a high frequency in the practice of different sexual activities (coitus and masturbation). The expert witness presented various deviant sexual behaviours
column16: which began with practices with little interaction with the victims (voyeurism with masturbation)
column17: gradually leading to an increase in interaction
column18: both verbal (obscene compliments) and physical (touching without the possibility of a response from the victims)
column19: until the events with which he was charged. Habitual user of pornography and occasional prostitution. Psychopathological findings No significant alterations were found in axis I. Given that while he was in prison and prior to the forensic medical examination he was diagnosed with mild mental retardation by the psychologist of a non-governmental organisation
column20: he was referred to the forensic psychologist to support the diagnostic presumption of borderline intelligence with psychometric tests
column21: which were not valid with regard to the calculation of the intelligence quotient (IQ) due to the poor collaboration of the expert witness (he presented metasimulative behaviour according to the forensic psychological report)
column22: reaching the diagnostic conclusion of borderline intelligence on the basis of his adaptive abilities
column23: after clinical examination and application of the Intensity of Support Scale. With regard to Axis II
column24: the inmate showed typical features of the borderline personality disorder construct: verbalised cognitions related to fear of abandonment by his partner
column25: having developed crude strategies to avoid such abandonment
column26: such as prohibiting his partner from using the car to avoid abandonment
column27: or restricting access to family accounts; he showed feelings of low self-esteem
column28: identifying its origin in the rejection of his partner on a sexual level
column29: but also in the perception of actions on her part aimed at his undervaluation before other people; at the same time
column30: he showed an unstable self-image
column31: oscillating between feelings of high self-worth and feelings of inferiority; poor social environment
column32: with interpersonal relationships alternating between idealisation and devaluation. High impulsivity manifested in different areas of his private life
column33: as well as significant mood reactivity. In addition
column34: the inmate verbalised cognitive distortions aimed at minimising the use of violence against his partner and the victims
column35: even blaming his partner for the alleged acts due to her sexual rejection
column36: and the second victim for her injuries because she resisted the sexual activity by trying to flee; manifested other cognitive distortions about women and their role in society (female role related only to the care of the home and children
column37: without active participation in the decisions derived from living together as a couple)
column38: as well as about sexuality (justification of sexual activity with her partner with the mediation of violence in the absence of the latter's persistent refusal to have sexual relations). Functional analysis of reported sexual behaviours
column39: as well as sexual aggressions
column40: showed a consistent association between the practice of sexual behaviours and feelings of sexual frustration and associated cognitions (feelings of low self-worth and thoughts related to abandonment).  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 67-year-old man with visual acuity of 0.6 and 0.5 with grade 3 nuclear cataracts in both eyes. The left eye showed a grade I nasal pterygium and various lesions in the form of epithelial corneal islets with an inferior semicircular distribution
column2: not affecting the visual axis. There were no inflammatory signs in the anterior segment and the rest of the examination was normal. Treatment with Mitomycin-C 0.02% was started preoperatively (1)
column3: reducing the lesion to 1/3 of its size. Cataract surgery was performed on both eyes using the MICS technique
column4: excision of the pterygium in the left eye and excision of the corneal lesion
column5: and the patient was referred for pathological examination
column6: which revealed: conjunctival epithelium with foci of mild atypia of the cells of the basal layer
column7: the atypia occupying up to 2/3 of the total thickness at the limbus level
column8: with little pleomorphism. Actinic elastic degeneration of the chorion and scarce chronic subepithelial lymphocytic chronic inflammatory infiltrate. After 6 months
column9: the presence of isolated recurrent islets was observed
column10: which were treated again with Mitomycin-C
column11: the lesion regressed
column12: and no new recurrences were observed during the 1-year follow-up. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 67-year-old female patient was referred to our clinic by her general practitioner for an oral tumour that had been present for 20 years. The lesion was asymptomatic and had grown over the last year
column2: causing an aesthetic facial deformity and interfering with mastication. Her personal history included a hysterectomy and double anisectomy 10 years earlier. The intraoral examination revealed a pedunculated tumour on the left mandibular gingival ridge corresponding to the edentulous space of 37
column3: 6-8 cm in diameter
column4: well delimited
column5: partially covered by a whitish mucosa with a hard-elastic consistency. In addition
column6: there was mobility due to displacement of 35
column7: 36 and 38 and root remnants of 25
column8: 26 and 27. The radiological examination with orthopantomography revealed tooth displacement and the aforementioned root remnants. Under the presumptive diagnosis of cemento-ossifying fibroma

column10: with removal of the tumour
column11: curettage of the bone bed and avulsion of 35

column1: Male
column2: 57 years old
column3: history of no interest and smoker of 10-20 cigarettes/day. The patient presented with chronic hepatitis C genotype 1a/1c
column4: viral load 1
column6: 178 Ul/ml and a fibrosis grade F2-F3 (Fibroscan 9.9 Kilopascals) with an IL-28 CT polymorphism. It was decided to start his first treatment for hepatitis C with RBV 400mg/12h
column7: P-INF alpha 2a 180mcg/week and Telaprevir 750mg/8h (with meals). At the start of treatment the patient had a haemoglobin (Hb) of 157 g/L
column8: neutrophil count 4.2x109 no/L and 1 58x109 no/L platelets. Liver enzymes were slightly increased
column9: GPT 114 IU/L
column10: ALAT 115 IU/L and ASAT 80 IU/L. At week 4 the patient presented undetectable viral load
column11: Hb 136 g/L
column12: neutrophil count 2.0 x 109 no/L and platelets 110 x 109 no/L. He reported anorectal discomfort
column13: specifically haemorrhoids and anal itching
column14: mild anxiety that improved with Lorazepam and mild body itching that improved with the use of emollient creams. In week 8 of treatment she was admitted to hospital with epigastric pain that became more intense and radiated to both hypochondria during the last 36 hours. She had no fever
column15: chills
column16: nausea
column17: vomiting or choluria. Laboratory tests showed an amylase of 1888 IU/L
column18: Hb 107 g/L
column19: neutrophil count 2.7 x 109 no/L and platelet count 97x109 no/L. Absolute diet (except for taking Telaprevir
column20: with whole milk) and analgesic and antiemetic measures were instituted. The patient progressed favourably and was discharged after one week of hospitalisation with an amylase level of 173 IU/L. The following day he was admitted again with intense epigastric pain radiating to both hypochondria and an amylase level of 3406 IU/L. Acute pancreatitis was diagnosed. Given the recurrent course (two admissions)
column21: Telaprevir was discontinued (week 9 of treatment) due to the possibility that it was the cause and he continued with RBV and P-INF. The patient was discharged five days later with an amylase level of 365 IU/L. At week 12 post initiation of treatment
column22: viral load was undetectable
column23: Hb 109 g/L
column24: neutrophil count 1.1 x109 no/L and platelet count 1 58x109 no/L. He will continue treatment without Telaprevir until week 24.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O

column1: The patient was a 43-year-old man who consulted for a palpable lump
column2: painful on pressure in the right preauricular region. Physical examination revealed a poorly defined mass measuring 2 cm in the right parotid area
column3: with no other significant findings. The patient reported no personal or family history of interest
column4: only the aforementioned nodule which
column5: according to the patient
column6: had been present for more than five years. The imaging tests performed
column7: computerised axial tomography and ultrasound
column8: showed a well-defined tumour measuring 2.5 x 2 cm centred in the parotid gland
column9: which did not affect bone or muscle structures
column10: suggestive of a low-grade tumour.  Fine needle aspiration puncture of the lesion was performed
column11: using the routine method of 3 passes with a 23G needle
column12: with the help of the Cameco® (manual aspiration device) after which 2 slides were fixed in alcohol to be stained using the Papanicolaou technique and the rest (6 slides) were air-dried to use the Diff-Quick stain. Examination of the smears shows
column13: against a seroproteinaceous background
column14: abundant large cellularity
column15: with central and occasionally peripheral rounded nuclei
column16: little patent nucleolus and finely granular chromatin. The cytoplasm is very characteristic
column17: being abundant
column18: pale and foamy with vague borders
column19: vacuolated and containing abundant purplish granules. The cells are arranged in more or less compact clusters of large two-dimensional sheets
column20: sometimes adopting an acinar architectural pattern. Along with this predominant cellularity
column21: smaller cells with scant cytoplasm and small
column22: round or oval
column23: central nuclei are also present. The cytological image was therefore consistent with serous-type acinar cell pathology
column24: probably carcinoma
column25: and it was therefore proposed to perform DNA quantification by image cytometry on cytological smears. Given that the smears obtained in the first puncture did not allow an adequate assessment
column26: a second FNA was performed in order to process the material for cytometric determination
column27: for which purpose they were fixed in 99º methyl alcohol and subsequently stained with Gill's progressive haematoxylin.  Using TEXCAN® software and a video camera integrated into the microscope
column28: which captures grey scales
column29: the most relevant biological parameters are determined
column30: including ploidy
column31: S phase
column32: and percentage of cells above 5c (aneuploidy)
column33: expressed as a histogram (IMAGE 2)
column34: reveals an euploidy of 2.1 with no relevant S-phase activity and no cells above 5c
column35: thus indicating low aggressiveness (histogram type 1) according to Azúa's classification for static cytometry. With the cytological diagnosis of acinar cell carcinoma and the cytometric prognostic index of low grade
column36: conservative surgery was performed
column37: with excision of the parotid gland without cervical emptying and preserving the facial nerve. Macroscopically we found a whitish piece
column38: with a polylobulated morphology
column39: weighing 12 grams and measuring 8 x 4 x 3 cm in total. The cut showed a 1.5 cm nodular lesion that did not overflow the surgical resection ends
column40: apparently non-cystyphoid. Multiple parallel sections of the specimen were made and embedded in paraffin and then stained with conventional haematoxylin-eosin. Histopathological examination revealed a solid
column41: well-circumscribed
column42: microcystic neoformation composed mainly of acinar cells that did not overflow the glandular capsule. The multiple cystic spaces of very small size
column43: scattered between the solid sheets are formed by dilated lumina lined by intercalated ductal cells
column44: although acinar cells also occasionally participate. The acinar cells are serous secreting
column45: as demonstrated by PAS (periodic acid Schiff) staining which highlights intracytoplasmic zymogen granules as well as intracystic eosinophilic secretion. The neoplasm respects the resection edges and there is no evidence of vascular or nerve infiltration.  The definitive diagnosis is
column46: therefore
column47: low-grade acinar cell carcinoma
column48: well demarcated
column49: without invasion of the surgical edges.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 47-year-old man
column2: who quit smoking ten years ago
column3: smoked between 10-20 cigarettes/day for 15 years and was diagnosed 8 years ago with IgA mesangial glomerulonephritis. He had been working for 12 years as a welder in a company manufacturing steel discs with inserted cobalt and tungsten carbide "teeth" used to cut marble and granite. The welder used an autogenous welding system in which they used
column4: as filler metal
column5: metal rods based on: silver (39%)
column6: cadmium (25%)
column7: copper (22%) and zinc (14%). He consumed 1 kg/week; he did not use respiratory protective equipment and his workplace did not have a localised fume extraction system. Cadmium concentrations at her workplace were 52 μg/m3 (Environmental Limit Value (ELV) is 10 μg/m3). During the twelve years she had been working
column8: she had undergone an initial examination and two periodic non-specific examinations without monitoring exposure to cadmium and other chemical pollutants; the laboratory results were within normal limits (complete blood count
column9: blood glucose
column10: cholesterol
column11: liver transaminases
column12: serum creatinine and urine cytochemistry). In a general blood test carried out by your family doctor
column13: microhaematuria and proteinuria were detected. When his doctor took his medical history he detected exposure to cadmium fumes and was referred to the Toxicology Unit of our hospital. On admission
column14: the patient was asymptomatic
column15: had no personal or family history of nephrological problems
column16: no obesity or diabetes (blood glucose levels were normal)
column17: did not take any type of medication regularly and his blood pressure was 105/65 mm/Hg. Laboratory tests showed proteinuria of 2 g/24 h
column18: microhaematuria of 150 red blood cells/field
column19: blood cadmium of 20 μg/l (Biological Limit Value [BLV]: 5μg/l) and urine cadmium of 85 μg/g creatinine (BLV: 5 μg/g creatinine). Since the renal involvement was of the glomerular type
column20: and cadmium causes mainly tubular lesions
column21: a renal biopsy was recommended. Light microscopy showed five glomeruli
column22: one of which was completely sclerosed; the rest showed slight segmental hypercellularity; in two glomeruli there was an extracapillary segmental proliferation and foci of interstitial fibrosis with tubular atrophy. Immunofluorescence was positive for C3 (+++) and IgA (++) with mesangial pattern. The diagnosis was mesangial IgA focal glomerulonephritis and treatment with enalapril 10 mg/day was started. Due to the high concentrations of cadmium in biological fluids (blood and urine)
column23: which eight years after cessation of exposure are still above the maximum values allowed in Spain for workers exposed to cadmium
column24: the patient was taken off work; in addition
column25: he was considered a worker particularly sensitive to exposure to nephrotoxic substances and we advised him to avoid exposure in order to minimise the possibility of the patient progressing to chronic kidney disease as much as possible. He was followed up for 8 years (serum creatinine
column26: glomerular filtration rate
column27: proteinuria and urinary sediment values are shown in table 1) and repeated beta2-globulin and N-acetylglucosaminidase (NAG) controls were found to be within the normal range. At present
column28: blood cadmium concentrations are 7 μg/l (VLB: 5 μg/l) and urine cadmium is 18 μg/g (VLB: 5 μg/g).  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A one and a half month old girl is referred to the paediatric clinic for a right pelvic kidney and a white tuft of hair in the frontal region.  She is from the first pregnancy of a healthy mother. The pregnancy was controlled without incident
column2: with normal ultrasound scans except for the right pelvic kidney. Vaginal delivery
column3: instrumented at 38 weeks gestational age. Birth weight 2320 grams
column4: Apgar 10/10. Bilateral correct otoemissions. Family history: white parents
column5: healthy mother aged 25 years
column6: healthy father aged 36 years
column7: except for acromic spots in the middle third of both thighs
column8: without having been diagnosed with any disease. Other family history is unknown. The patient is asymptomatic; her bowel rhythm and diuresis are normal. Physical examination reveals a tuft of white frontal hair and a triangular-shaped acromic macule on the frontal region. There are no other skin lesions. The rest of the examination is normal
column9: with psychomotor development so far normal. Piebaldism is clinically suspected
column10: but additional tests are requested to check for ophthalmological anomalies and deafness
column11: which must be absent to confirm the clinical diagnosis of piebaldism. Ophthalmological assessment ruled out ocular lesions and auditory evoked potentials were performed
column12: which were normal. Abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of a right pelvic kidney with no other abnormalities. An analytical study (blood count and chemistry) was requested
column13: which was normal
column14: and a genetic study for mutation of the KIT gene (OMIM 164920) (4q12)
column15: which was negative. A heterozygous variant in the KIT gene of unknown clinical significance [c.2509G>A;(p.Ala837Thr)] was detected (also negative in the father).  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 77-year-old patient with a history of arterial hypertension and ischaemic heart disease who was under study due to non-specific abdominal discomfort and anaemia of recent onset. He attended our centre on a scheduled basis for colonoscopy after bowel preparation with Bohn's evacuating solution. During the procedure
column2: he suffered an intestinal perforation at the level of the sigmoid colon
column3: for which reason he underwent urgent surgery and was found to have a perforation 1 centimetre long with clean edges that was sutured by simple suture
column4: leaving a penrose drain. He was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) in the immediate postoperative period. On arrival at the ICU
column5: broad-spectrum antibiotics were administered and microbiological samples were taken. Among the complementary tests performed
column6: a serial quantification of PCT and C-reactive protein (CRP) was carried out
column7: with normal CRP values (0.25 mg/dl) and slightly elevated PCT values (0.6 ng/ml). Measurements taken 2 hours and 12 hours after the patient's admission to the ICU showed a significant increase in PCT values (12.73 and 220 ng/ml) while CRP values were only slightly elevated (0.8 and 15.5 mg/dl). The culture of the abdominal drainage isolated Enterobacter cloacae sensitive to the antibiotic regimen administered. Subsequent evolution was favourable and he was discharged 72 hours after admission to the ICU.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male patient
column2: 68 years old
column3: former textile industry worker
column4: referred for consultation due to complex renal cystic mass. History of rheumatoid arthritis
column5: controlled hypertension
column6: dyslipidaemia
column7: pulmonary tuberculosis 40 years ago
column8: medicated with indapamide
column9: sinvastatin and NSAIDs. He denied smoking habits or exposure to chemical agents. He reported exposure to sheep in his youth. He denied a known history of renal lithiasis. He had undergone left hip arthroplasty years ago. No history of abdominal or genitourinary surgery. For months he reported elimination of gelatinous material in the urine
column10: with no specific shape
column11: accompanied by episodes of total macroscopic haematuria
column12: without clots. No other accompanying symptoms
column13: such as back pain
column14: nausea or vomiting
column15: or lower urinary complaints. No anorexia
column16: asthenia or weight loss. No respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms. On physical examination there was a non-painful left flank/lumbar emplasia. No hepatomegaly
column17: no abnormal abdominal collateral circulation. Genitalia without clinical varicocele. Lower limbs without oedema. No peripheral adenopathies. Pulmonary auscultation without apparent alterations. In analytical terms he had mild anaemia (Hb 12.7 g/dL)
column18: without leukocytosis. Relative eosinophilia (2800/µL). SV 67 mm. Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL. Urea 77 mg/dL. Ultrasonography revealed a right kidney of somewhat reduced dimensions (10.8 cm) and with increased echogenicity of the parenchyma
column19: presenting a simple cyst in the upper pole. The left kidney showed a large complex cyst of the upper pole (70 x 68 x 67 mm)
column20: with evident solid content and associated regions with posterior acoustic shadowing. Subjected to abdominopelvic CT - voluminous complex cystic formation containing gross parietal and central calcifications
column21: occupying the upper two thirds of the left kidney
column22: as well as fine septa within it
column23: presenting attenuation values varying between 10 and 20 Housefield units. Subsequent to contrast administration
column24: there was evidence of contrast uptake by the walls. No lesions of solid abdominal organs
column25: presence of retroperitoneal adenopathies or morphological alteration of the suprarenal glands were evident. Chest X-ray without significant alterations
column26: such as cystic lesions or alterations compatible with lesions of metastatic nature or active tuberculosis. Negative Mantoux (tuberculin test). Acid-fast bacilli negative. Urine cultures (multiple samples) in Lowenstein's medium negative. Serology for Echinococcos granulosis and multilocularis negative.  With the diagnosis of Bosniak class IV complex cystic mass and in the absence of support for lesions of specific/parasitic infectious nature
column27: he underwent left radical nephrectomy by lumbotomy incision over the 12th rib bed. Pathological examination showed a neoplasm of 11.5 cm in greatest dimension
column28: consisting of glands of simple and complex structure
column29: the epithelium being moderately differentiated and centred by mucoid material in the form of large mucin pools with tumour fragments. The lesion invaded the renal parenchyma without affecting the capsule. The remaining parenchyma showed signs of pyelonephritis with mild atrophy. Surgical margins were free of tumour. Conclusion: mucinous adenocarcinoma of the renal pelvis PT3NxMx.  After histological results were available
column30: the patient underwent upper endoscopy and colonoscopy
column31: which showed no alterations. He was followed up for 10 months. The patient is totally asymptomatic and there is no evidence of recurrence of the disease
column32: locally or at a distance.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
