column1: A 73-year-old man on his first visit to our department
column2: with a history of diabetes mellitus
column3: ischaemic heart disease
column4: smoking until 1993
column5: with no known allergies to medication. In July 2001
column6: after several months of rectal discomfort
column7: a PSA level of 16.68 ng/ml was found in routine laboratory tests. Referred from Primary Care to Urology
column8: he was diagnosed by biopsy with Adenocarcinoma of the Prostate in the right lobe
column9: Gleason 3+3 (T1cNxMx
column10: Stage II). After establishing complete androgen blockade (CAB) with Bicalutamide and Leuprorelin
column11: he was referred to our department
column12: where a thoracic-abdominal CT scan was requested to complete the staging. Pending the results of this test
column13: due to the delay in performing it and taking into account the patient's age and the stage of the disease
column14: RT treatment was started. A dose of 70 Gy was programmed on the prostate and seminal vesicles
column15: using 18 MV photons
column16: 4-field box technique and fractionation of 2 Gy/day
column17: 5 days per week. Before the end of treatment
column18: a CT scan was received (11/10/01)
column19: which showed a 3 cm solid mediastinal mass
column20: left paraesophageal
column21: superior to the aortic arch
column22: and it could not be differentiated whether it was an adenopathic mass or a primitive neoplasm. In addition
column23: a solid right renal mass
column24: approximately 7 cm in diameter
column25: with central necrosis
column26: suggestive of hypernephroma
column27: was visualised. No vascular alterations
column28: retroperitoneal adenopathies or significant alterations in the pelvis were observed.  Following the results of the CT scan
column29: it was decided to continue irradiation of the prostate
column30: and treatment was completed on 26/11/01. In the meantime
column31: and given that the renal mass did not raise any diagnostic doubts
column32: it was decided to approach the thoracic lesion. On 15/11/01 a mediastinoscopy was performed with biopsies
column33: with the histological result of clear cell carcinoma
column34: compatible with metastasis of renal carcinoma. In agreement with Medical Oncology and Urology
column35: on 21/12/01 a Nephrectomy (NF) was performed
column36: with a definitive histological result of grade II-III renal cell carcinoma
column37: invading perirenal adipose tissue (T3aNxM1
column38: Stage IV). Given the possibility of surgery on the mediastinal metastasis
column39: a new CT scan was performed (30/01/02)
column40: in which the presence of the pulmonary mass was confirmed
column41: with an approximate size of 5 x 3 x 4 cm infiltrating the posterior mediastinal region
column42: with no cleavage plane with supra-aortic vascular structures or with the aortic arch
column43: being very close to the upper third of the oesophagus. The right NF was visualised in the abdomen with no signs of recurrence or tumour remnants.  On 27/02/02 an exploratory thoracotomy was performed
column44: with the finding of a 5 cm mediastinal tumour invading the pulmonary parenchyma and the upper face of the aortic arch at the level of an arteriosclerosis plaque that prevented lateral clamping
column45: and was therefore considered unresectable. A biopsy was taken and the diagnosis was confirmed. The possibility of radiotherapy treatment of the mediastinal lesion
column46: whether or not followed by immunotherapy
column47: was raised
column48: but the patient did not accept this possibility and
column49: considering his good general condition
column50: a wait-and-see attitude was adopted. The patient continues with CABG and symptomatic treatment. In June 2002 she received treatment with Megestrol Acetate for "hot flushes" secondary to CABG
column51: which was interrupted one month later when the CABG was discontinued. In September 2002 a bone scan was performed
column52: which showed no pathological deposits of the tracer
column53: as well as a PSA determination (0.10 ng/ml) and a new CT scan. This CT scan (12/09/02) showed a mass in the posterior mediastinum
column54: above the aortic arch
column55: measuring 6 x 4 x 4 cm
column56: infiltrating the left subclavian artery
column57: the aorta and the left lung
column58: as well as nodular images in the lingula and right lower lobe adjacent to the spinal column
column59: suggestive of pulmonary metastasis. In the abdomen there were multiple nodular images in the right renal fossa suggestive of recurrence
column60: with probable infiltration of the ipsilateral psoas muscle.  Therefore
column61: and as a conclusion after the last CT scan (9 months after NF)
column62: the patient showed clear progression of his disease
column63: with new metastases and local recurrence. In October 2002 he was admitted for clinical suspicion of pulmonary thromboembolism
column65: he was seen as an outpatient on several occasions
column66: showing a progressive improvement in his general condition.  In September 2003
column67: 21 months after the NF and the patient being asymptomatic

column69: which only showed several axillary lymphadenopathies of less than 1 cm and the right NF

column1: We present an 85-year-old female patient with angiosarcoma of the cecum. The patient was admitted to our hospital with rectorrhagia. On admission she presented hypotension and tachycardia and physical examination showed mucocutaneous pallor and abdominal distension. Rectal examination showed bright red blood without identifying any tumour. A blood test showed a haemoglobin of 4.3 g/dl and a lower gastrointestinal endoscopy was performed
column2: identifying a 1 cm reddish mass in the cecum with active bleeding
column3: which was initially controlled with haemostatic clips after biopsies had been taken. Twelve hours later the patient presented with a new episode of gastrointestinal bleeding with hypotension and an urgent laparoscopic right hemicolectomy was performed. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 5. The extension study performed after surgery was negative. On gross examination
column4: the cecum contained a 2 cm exophytic ulcer. Microscopic analysis showed multiple anastomotic vascular channels dissecting the collagen and smooth muscle laminae down to the lamina propria and muscularis propria. Immunohistochemistry showed high reactivity of tumour cells to CD31 and vimentin. Staining for CD34
column5: cytokeratin 20 and cytokeratin AE1-3 was negative. Based on these results
column6: a diagnosis of epithelioid angiosarcoma of the colon was made. The margins were free of tumour as were the 12 lymph nodes analysed. The patient did not receive adjuvant treatment and at subsequent follow-up she is still alive and without evidence of disease two years after surgery.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 22-year-old male patient
column2: with no history of interest apart from being a regular smoker of marijuana
column3: came to the emergency department reporting enlargement of the left scrotal sac after physical exertion 24 hours earlier

column1: A 14-year-old patient came to the clinic with tiredness or fatigue

column3: of 15 days' evolution. There was no history of fever

The child was born in New York and has lived in Spain for 6 years. Personal history not assessable. Correct vaccinations. No known drug allergies. No notable childhood illnesses. Menarche 2 years ago. Family history: relative with Berger's disease pending renal transplant. Physical examination: weight 51 kg; height 160 cm; BP 120/80 mmHg; heart rate 105 beats/minute; axillary temperature 36.8 oC. Good general condition
column5: pallor of skin and mucous membranes (blond)
column6: no skin lesions. Small submandibular adenopathies. Normal neurological examination; normal cardiorespiratory system; abdomen with no appreciable findings
column7: no visceromegaly
column8: negative lumbar percussion cuff; correct hydration. Laboratory results - Haemoglobin 10.3 g/dl; red blood cells 3
column10: 000; haematocrit 29.7; MCV 77; white blood cell count: 11
column11: 100 leukocytes with 63.2% neutrophils
column12: 25.1% lymphocytes

column1: A 35-year-old male patient with no pathological history of interest
column2: except for a significant smoking habit (20-30 cigarettes/day for more than 10 years). He came to the urologist referred by his general practitioner after suffering an episode of self-limited frank haematuria. Subsequently
column3: the patient presented with further episodes of small clots together with severe irritative voiding syndrome with repeatedly negative urine cultures. Initially
column4: ultrasound and intravenous urography showed a tumour at the level of the bladder trigone
column5: 3 cm in diameter
column6: with mild left ureteral ectasia. Renal function was normal (Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
column7: plasma urea: 42 mg/dL). Rectal examination revealed a certain increase in prostatic and bladder floor consistency. In view of the diagnosis of a primary bladder tumour
column8: the need for transurethral resection was suggested to the patient. Intraoperative cystoscopy confirmed the presence of a sessile bladder neoplasm
column9: measuring 2-3 cm
column10: with a bullous and ulcerated surface located over the trigonal area. The anatomopathological result reported the presence of a neoplasm consisting of small undifferentiated cells
column11: distributed in "single file"
column12: with some isolated foci of transitional carcinoma
column13: PSA (-) without being able to determine the precise origin of the tumour. The infiltration affected submucosa and muscle and the resection base was positive for tumour. Pending the results of complementary anatomopathology and extension studies in anticipation of a possible cystectomy
column14: 36 days after resection
column15: the patient was admitted for a severe constitutional syndrome
column16: with weight loss of 10-12 kg
column17: pain in both renal fossae with bilateral grade II/IV hydronephrosis due to ureteral trapping and obstructive renal failure (Creatinine 6.2 mg/dL
column18: Urea: 176 mg/dL
column19: K+:5.6 mEq/L). Urinary bypass was performed urgently
column20: percutaneous nephrostomy type
column21: with rapid restoration of renal function
column22: but during admission a new episode of macroscopic haematuria began. Cystoscopy revealed a large sessile tumour at the base of the bladder with infiltration of both ureteral meatus. Bimanual palpation revealed an irregular induration of the bladder floor that appeared to infiltrate the prostate. An extension study was requested with a simple chest X-ray
column23: abdomino-pelvic CT scan and bone scan. At this time no distant metastatic disease was observed
column24: only thickening of the bladder floor
column25: with bilateral uretero-pelvic-calyceal ectasia and absence of adenopathies.  In view of these findings
column26: a radical cystoprostatectomy with an Indiana-type continent reservoir was performed. During the operation
column27: it was difficult to free the bladder floor due to its infiltration by the tumour. The anatomopathological result confirmed the presence of an undifferentiated small cell carcinoma
column28: with immunohistochemical staining: cytokeratin (+)
column29: neuronal specific enolase (NSE) and Chromogranin (-)
column30: together with small foci of transitional carcinoma. The tumour affected the full thickness of the bladder wall
column31: right perivesical and periureteral fat
column32: rectal wall
column33: prostate
column34: seminal vesicles and 2 of the 8 nodes of the left common iliac (Stage:T4N2M0). The patient's postoperative course was uneventful and he was discharged one week after the operation.  Given the high risk of recurrence of the disease
column35: given the involvement of the surgical edges and the presence of adenopathies
column36: the tumour committee of our centre decided to carry out adjuvant chemo-radiotherapy. CDDP chemotherapy with concomitant radiotherapy on the pelvis with a dose of 50 Gy
column37: at a rate of 180 cGy per session
column38: 5 times a week
column39: and subsequent overimpression with another 14.4 Gy
column40: was established. The patient's tolerance to this treatment regimen was optimal. Three months after the operation and during the administration of the QT/RT
column41: he came to the clinic with discomfort in the right hemiabdomen radiating to the back with no other associated symptoms. The control abdomino-pelvic CT scan showed a reservoir with good capacity
column42: small dilatation of the right renal pelvis
column43: with no evidence of collections or signs of tumour recurrence. Three months later
column44: the patient presented epigastralgia with irradiation towards both hypochondria
column45: a feeling of immediate postprandial distension and heartburn. Physical examination revealed a mass at the level of the right hypochondrium-vacuum
column46: and ultrasound did not reveal a possible tumour recurrence at this level. A gastroscopy was requested
column47: which showed a retained stomach with extrinsic pyloro-duodenal stenosis
column48: raising the possibility of metastatic infiltration of the tumour versus possible stenosis secondary to radiotherapy. In view of these findings
column49: surgery was decided upon
column50: and during the course of the operation
column51: the presence of tumour recurrence in the right flank
column52: invasion of the duodenum by the tumour and multiple neoplastic implants in the omentum
column53: peritoneum and other serosae were observed
column54: and palliative gastrojejunostomy was performed. After the postoperative period
column55: the patient was sent home for palliative care and died one month after discharge (7 months after the cystectomy and 9 months after diagnosis).   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 78-year-old patient with a history of arterial hypertension
column2: type 2 diabetes mellitus
column3: osteoporosis and repeated nephritic colic who 6 days before admission began with pain in the right renal fossa with irradiation to the ipsilateral knee
column4: which was treated as an outpatient with dexametaxone
column5: lidocaine
column6: cyanocobalamin and thiamine without resolution. Subsequently
column7: the patient began to feel dystrophic with thermometric temperature above 38ºC
column8: poor general condition
column9: urinary symptoms and glycaemic decompensation
column10: for which he was admitted to hospital. Physical examination revealed marked general malaise
column11: fever
column12: pain in the sacral area with negative bilateral percussion fist and knees with signs of phlogosis. Laboratory tests showed mild leukocytosis without left shift (12
column13: 100x103/mm3 with N 65%)
column14: hyperbilirubinaemia with direct predominance (BT: 3.4 mg/dl
column15: BD: 2.7mg/dl)
column16: alkaline phosphatase 215 U/L (35-104). The rest of the laboratory tests showed no significant alterations. Complementary examinations included blood and urine cultures
column17: joint fluid puncture and cultures
column18: CT scan of the abdominal and lumbosacral spine
column19: magnetic resonance imaging of the lumbar spine and scintigraphy with Ga-67/MDP-Tc-99. The CT scan of the abdominal and lumbosacral spine shows air densities in the lumbar and right psoas muscles and in the intraspinal and dorsal location. Gas is also seen in the bony canal
column20: which could correspond to a ruptured L4-L5 disc.  The MRI of the lumbar spine confirmed images compatible with abscesses in the right paravertebral and psoas muscles
column21: and two collections suggesting epidural abscesses located at L4-L5 and D12-L4. An alteration of the signal of the body of D12 was observed after administration of gadolinium
column22: resulting in bone oedema compatible with spondylitis and probable spondylodiscitis.  In the combined body scan with Ga-67/MDP-Tc-99M there was pathological hyperfixation of both tracers in knees and shoulders suggesting an inflammatory-infectious process as well as greatly increased gallium uptake at L4-L5 and in paravertebral soft tissues compatible with spondylodiscitis with possible infection of adjacent soft tissues. On admission
column23: empirical antibiotic treatment was started with ciprofloxacin
column24: with subsequent microbiological confirmation (blood
column25: urine and joint fluid cultures) of the presence of Escherichia coli
column26: with a similar antibiogram. During the first few days of treatment
column27: the patient's symptoms improved slightly
column28: coinciding with the introduction of antibiotics and antipyretics. On the 10th day of admission
column29: the fever reappeared and the general condition progressively worsened. On the 12th day of admission
column30: the patient presented atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and cardiorespiratory arrest without response to resuscitation manoeuvres. The diagnosis was E. coli urinary tract infection complicated by polyarticular septic arthritis
column31: spondylodiscitis
column32: epidural abscesses
column33: psoas and dorso-lumbar musculature.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 26-year-old male professional sportsman (football player) with no other personal history of interest for the case in question. He suffered a fall from his own height while playing sport
column2: resting his left wrist and hyperextending it. As a result of the trauma
column3: he presented pain
column4: deformity and functional impotence
column5: with a normal distal neurovascular examination. Anteroposterior and lateral radiographs of the wrist showed a fracture of the radial styloid process
column6: a fracture of the lunate bone and a dislocation through the fracture line of the lunate. The dorsal fragment of the lunate is attached to the carpal bones and displaced dorsally
column7: while the volar fragment is in its anatomical position. In view of this image
column8: we diagnose a transstiloid radial-transmillunar fracture-dislocation.  We proceeded urgently to a closed reduction of the dislocation by means of traction and immobilisation
column9: verifying the instability of the injury. We also performed a post-reduction CT scan
column10: observing that the fracture of the lunate bone was coronal-oblique and comminuted.  72 hours after the trauma
column11: and after performing a supraclavicular block
column12: the patient underwent surgery using a dorsal approach with opening of the dorsal retinaculum at the level of the third slide and capsulotomy according to Berger's technique (8). We then proceeded to reduce the fracture of the lunate by stabilising it with a 2 mm diameter mini-screw
column13: and to repair the scapholunate ligament with a harpoon in the lunate. Total limb ischaemia time was 74 minutes.  After 6 weeks of cast immobilisation
column14: the patient was referred to rehabilitation until stabilisation of the condition with functional limitation: 35o flexion
column15: 25o extension
column16: full pronation-supination
column17: and no radiocarpal or midcarpal instability
column18: which allowed him to return to his previous sporting activity 5 months after the trauma. At the one-year check-up
column19: the process is stabilised
column20: with no worsening.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 54-year-old woman
column2: with no medical history of interest
column3: was referred to the plastic surgery department for a condition of 2 months' duration that started with pain and paraesthesia in the right leg. In the last few weeks she had worsened
column4: presenting with foot drop and difficulties in walking. The patient's symptoms were suggestive of right sciatic nerve neuropathy. Physical examination revealed an increase in size on the posterior aspect of the right thigh and palpation of a large
column5: deep
column6: soft and painful tumour. The patient's symptoms and physical examination suggested a neuropathy of the sciatic nerve
column7: probably due to extrinsic compression by the tumour. The following complementary studies were performed to confirm the diagnosis: - Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): a mass with maximum diameters of 14 x 9 x 5 cm (craniocaudal x transverse x anteroposterior) was visualised deep in the posterior compartment of the distal half of the right thigh
column8: mostly with a signal similar to fatty tissue
column9: although there were some septa and micronodular images with intermediate signal intensity in T1 and high in STIR and T2-SPIR. This mass subsequently displaced the sciatic nerve
column10: findings which
column11: although they could be related to a lipoma
column12: also suggest the need to rule out a low-grade liposarcoma.  - Electromyography (EMG): compatible with compression of the sciatic nerve at the level of the distal third of the right thigh. Given the patient's symptoms and the finding of a tumour in the MRI
column13: it was decided to carry out surgical treatment of the tumour. We performed surgery under spinal anaesthesia
column14: resecting the tumour and releasing the sciatic nerve at the level of the tumour. The patient did not present any postoperative complications.  The anatomopathological study of the surgical specimen revealed macroscopically a large tumour of lipomatous appearance
column15: yellow
column16: rounded
column17: well delimited
column18: 12 x 10 x 4 cm in size and weighing 266.7 g
column19: with no haemorrhagic or necrotic areas on section.  Microscopically it is mature adipose tissue
column20: separated into lobules by fine fibrous tracts and numerous small vessels at the periphery. The adipose cells show no atypia or mitosis. The patient's evolution was satisfactory
column21: with a gradual decrease in pain and paraesthesia and a gradual recovery of muscle strength to normal. After a postoperative follow-up of 15 months
column22: the patient is asymptomatic
column23: with no paresthesia
column24: no pain
column25: no gait disturbance and no evidence of recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 16 year old female referred to the ophthalmology clinic for visual difficulties
column2: "like a part of the waxed area that I can't see
column3: especially for the last 3 weeks". Her mother reports that "she has gone from being an active child to being slowed down
column4: with difficulty in thinking
column5: speaking and now she can't see properly". Since the age of 7 she has had epileptic seizures that are difficult to control. Her treatment was carbamazepine
column6: hydantoin and for 3 months Topamax 125 mg a day. The last ophthalmological examination performed a year earlier was normal. On examination
column7: spontaneous visual acuity (VA) was 1 in both eyes
column8: with normal anterior biomicroscopy. Pupils were isochoric and normoreactive. Funduscopic examination showed no abnormalities. Computerised campimetry showed a non-congruent left homonymous hemianopsia. The colour test showed no alterations in either eye. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with gadolinium was normal as well as diffusion MRI. The rest of the neurological examination was normal. In view of the suspicion of a Topamax toxic phenomenon
column9: Topamax was progressively discontinued
column10: with subjective improvement of the patient and partial recovery of the visual field.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 43-year-old man was admitted to the emergency department due to sudden left lumbar pain
column2: continuous and incapacitating
column3: without antalgic position or aggravating factors
column4: without irradiation
column5: with approximately 23 hours of evolution. No nausea or vomiting
column6: no macroscopic haematuria or lower urinary tract discomfort. Absence of precordial pain. Hypertension controlled with verapamil. He reported an episode
column7: interpreted as a transient ischaemic attack
column8: approximately eight weeks earlier (not confirmed). No history of cardiac arrhythmia or valvular heart disease. No other previous thromboembolic episodes. No known history of urinary lithiasis. No osteoarticular or respiratory complaints. No cocaine abuse. No history of hepatitis B or C. Medicated with 160 mg/day of verapamil. Physical examination showed diaphoretic
column9: BP 150 / 110 mmHg
column10: 80 beats per minute
column11: rhythmic and wide. Temperature 37.8 ºC. Abdomen painful on deep palpation in the left iliac fossa and flank
column12: with defence
column13: with no signs of peritoneal irritation. Decreased RHA. No abdominal murmurs. Negative bilateral renal Murphy. Existence of symmetrical arterial pulses. No perfusion deficit in the extremities. General neurological examination without alterations. Renal ultrasound showed no abnormalities
column14: especially dilatation of the urinary tract. Laboratory tests: Hb15.6 g/dL
column15: Leuc 13
column17: Neut 76.1%
column18: Creat 1.4 mg/dL
column19: TGO 104 UI/L
column20: TGP 74 UI/L
column21: LDH 1
column22: 890 UI/L. Coagulation parameters showed no alterations. The ECG showed sinus rhythm
column23: with no alterations compatible with acute myocardial ischaemia. An abdominal and pelvic CT scan was requested
column24: which showed the presence of multiple areas without contrast uptake in the left kidney
column25: without morpho-structural alterations
column26: compatible with multifocal areas of ischaemia
column27: with multisegmental distribution
column28: probably of embolic aetiology. No aortic dilatation or renal artery aneurysm. No intra-peritoneal alterations. Taking into account the multi-segmental distribution of the ischaemic process and the duration of discomfort
column29: we decided that there was no indication for invasive manoeuvres. The patient underwent systemic hypo-coagulation with heparin in an attempt to avoid future embolic episodes and appropriate analgesia.  He then underwent multiple examinations in an attempt to identify an embolic focus and the aetiological process. Echocardiography ruled out pathology of the cardiac valvular apparatus or the existence of valvular vegetations. Absence of areas of myocardial dyskinesia. Arteriography showed a perfusion deficit of the lower pole of the left kidney with multiple other less prominent areas showing perfusion deficits as well. No other alterations such as macro/microaneurysms or alterations of the main renal artery or aorta were detected. The study to rule out prothrombotic and vascular disease (lupus anticoagulant
column30: anti-cardiolipin
column31: ANCA's
column32: detection of cryoglobulins
column33: ANA's
column34: determination of immunoglobulins and complement fractions) was negative. After 15 months of follow-up
column35: we were left without an aetiological diagnosis. The patient remains asymptomatic
column36: with no new episodes of embolism or manifestations of systemic disease. Anti-coagulation therapy has been discontinued. He maintains controlled hypertension with the same dose of verapamil. The last analytical control had a serum creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL
column37: and GFR of 93 ml/min. column1: A 79-year-old man
column2: allergic to beta-lactams with a personal history of corticodependent COPD with several flare-ups a year and on treatment with home oxygen and bronchodilators at full doses (NYHA functional status III-IV). He came to the hospital with a 3-day history of cough with purulent expectoration
column3: increased respiratory distress and worsening level of consciousness. Physical examination revealed fever of 38°C
column4: central and peripheral cyanosis
column5: increased jugular venous pressure
column6: tachycardia at 120 bpm
column7: prolonged expiratory time
column8: wheezing and expiratory rhonchi in both lung fields
column9: especially in the right lung. In the abdomen
column10: painful hepatomegaly and oedema in both legs. Chest X-ray showed increased density in the right lower lobe
column11: with poorly defined borders. The haemogram showed 22
column12: 970 leukocytes/mm3 (93N
column14: Hb 13 g/dl
column15: HCT 37%
column16: MCV 90 fl

column18: 000/mm3. Blood gas results were pH 7.45
column19: pO257

column24: > 25 leukocytes 10-25 epithelial cells) showed only the usual respiratory tract flora. Empirical treatment was started with Levofloxacin iv. (500 mg/day)

column33: but after 48 hours
