column1: A 38-year-old man came to the emergency department of our hospital due to worsening voiding symptoms and fever of up to 38ºC. He had been on antibiotic treatment with levofloxacin for 5 days
column2: due to a diagnosis by pathological sediment and clinical picture of dysuria and pollakiuria of acute prostatitis
column3: without obtaining a urine culture. He came to the hospital due to poor clinical evolution with inability to urinate
column4: bilateral testicular and perineal pain and worsening general condition. Examination revealed a temperature of 38.6ºC
column5: vital signs were maintained and there was swelling in the perineal area with redness and local heat. Rectal examination was not possible due to the intense pain caused by the attempt.  Complementary tests showed leukocytosis: 18
column6: 000 leukocytes/mm3
column7: pyocytes in the urine sediment
column8: the rest of the parameters being within normal limits. The diagnostic imaging test performed was an abdominal and transperineal ultrasound
column9: which revealed the presence of urine in the bladder and a multiloculated prostatic abscess. Without prior general contraindication and under sedation
column10: percutaneous drainage of the abscess and placement of a suprapubic catheter were performed urgently. An ultrasound-guided transperineal puncture was performed
column11: obtaining purulent content and a 7 French pig-tail was left as drainage.  Cultures of the purulent content and urine were negative
column12: probably falsified by the antibiotic administered previously. The patient's evolution was favourable
column13: decreasing the pig-tail debit for 24 hours and subsequently withdrawing it. As he was afebrile and with normal urethral urination
column14: he was discharged and the prostate area was found to be normal ultrasonographically one month later.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 42-year-old woman was seen in the Gastroenterology Department since January 2005 for presenting with scant rectorrhagia at the end of bowel movements together with tenesmus and anal pain of two years' evolution. The patient had no family or personal history of interest and did not follow any regular medical treatment. Physical examination revealed only an indurated area on the left lateral wall of the rectum. A complete blood test was carried out
column2: which was strictly normal. In view of this finding
column3: it was decided to perform a colonoscopy
column4: finding two millimetric polyps in the rectal ampulla
column5: internal haemorrhoids (one of them prolapsed) and on the left lateral side of the rectal ampulla an erythematous and slightly raised area of approximately 2 x 2 cm
column6: with geographic borders and an indeterminate appearance
column7: from which biopsies were taken. The differential diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis)
column8: steroid ulcer and solitary rectal ulcer syndrome was initially raised. Pathological anatomy showed mucosal thickening
column9: with elongation and distortion of the glands and an oedematous lamina propria with a large amount of collagen and fibroblasts
column10: all compatible with the diagnosis of solitary rectal ulcer syndrome. Anorectal manometry was performed and showed a slightly reduced maximum tolerable rectal volume and a minimally prolonged balloon expulsion time.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 67-year-old man consulted an ophthalmologist for pain in the right eye in recent days with blurred vision
column2: incessant tearing and extreme gaze diplopia. Examination revealed marked ocular asymmetry with profusion of the right eye with generalised limitation of extrinsic mobility
column3: especially abduction
column4: and intense oedema of the conjunctiva which prolapsed through the parpebral fissure. After a CT scan of the orbit was performed and intraorbital involvement was ruled out
column5: the patient was referred to Internal Medicine. The patient was a male smoker of 30 cigarettes a day since his youth and had no other history of interest. In the anamnesis
column6: in addition to the ocular symptoms that were the reason for the consultation
column7: he reported some respiratory difficulty and dysphonia
column8: but without chest pain
column9: haemoptysis
column10: fever or other systemic symptoms. On physical examination
column11: his general condition was good and there were no signs of increased work of breathing. On physical examination
column12: in addition to the alterations of the right eye
column13: there was a striking increase in volume of the right side of the face and neck. The right jugular vein remained visible and continuously ingurgitated
column14: and dilatation of the superficial venous network was visible at the level of the right temple and the anterior thoracic plane. Palpation of the neck revealed a hard
column15: adherent and non-painful tumour in the right supraclavicular fossa. Vital signs
column16: palpation of the axillary hollows and pulmonary
column17: cardiac
column18: abdominal and lower limb examinations revealed no findings of interest. In the complementary examinations
column19: the haemogram
column20: coagulation study
column21: biochemical profile including tumour markers and arterial blood gases were normal. Chest X-ray showed mediastinal widening at the expense of the right hilum. The cervico-thoracic CT scan showed multiple nodular images in the upper lobe of the right lung
column22: adenopathic conglomerate occupying the anterior mediastinum and extending cranially to the right laterocervical region
column23: compressing the right jugular vein
column24: the left brachiocephalic trunk and the SVC. The cranio-orbital CT scan showed slight right exophthalmos
column25: with thickening of the superior ophthalmic vein and absence of orbital tumour. A fine needle aspiration of the right latero-cervical adenopathic mass was diagnostic of small cell carcinoma metastasis.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 18-year-old woman referred to the Emergency Department of the Hospital Universitario 12 de Octubre from another hospital centre after suffering a traffic accident with direct craniofacial impact. The patient reported no personal history of interest and on admission had a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 15. Physical examination revealed significant oedema and bilateral periorbital haematoma with crepitus
column2: right otorrhagia and rhinorrhoea from the left nostril. When assessed by the ophthalmology department
column3: no decrease in visual acuity
column4: diplopia or alterations in extrinsic ocular movements were observed
column5: although left macular oedema was observed. There were no initial alterations of cranial nerves except for paraesthesia in the V1 territory. Palpation revealed significant decalation in the left supraorbital rim. With the diagnosis of suspected skull base fracture with associated cerebrospinal fluid fistula
column6: a craniofacial CAT scan was requested
column7: showing a comminuted left frontobasal fracture-split with associated involvement of the ipsilateral temporal scale and pneumocephalus. Fracture of the right cranialmost portion of the cranial aspect of the right cerebellum lateral to the superior semicircular ducts. Fracture without displacement of the anterior wall of the right carotid canal. At the level of the brain there were multiple contusive haemorrhagic foci mainly located in both frontal lobes
column8: parieto-temporal endocranial bone fragments and minimal subarachnoid haemorrhage in the tentorium with right occipital epidural haematoma
column9: probably due to contrecoup injury.  After diagnostic confirmation of cerebrospinal fluid fistula (beta-2 transferrin test +) associated with complex frontobasal fracture
column10: it was decided
column11: together with the Neurosurgery Department
column12: to carry out surgical treatment: Left bicoronal and subcranial approach with excision of impacted frontobasal fragments. Repair of basal dural tears by means of duraplasty and fibrin adhesive after aspiration of the contused left frontal base. Obliteration of the frontal sinus after obturation of the duct with calotte bone chip and DBX (demineralised bone matrix) and curettage of the sinus mucosa. Reconstruction of the left orbital roof with titanium mesh and bone fragments fixed to it. Reduction and osteosynthesis of frontotemporal fractures and left supraorbital rim. Temporal muscle pectomy.  The patient was assessed at regular post-surgical check-ups without presenting any symptoms. Control imaging tests showed postoperative changes and complete frontal sinus obliteration.  Eighteen months after the operation
column13: the patient started again with occasional unilateral rhinorrhoea from the right nostril. After ordering imaging tests (high-resolution CT and MRI)
column14: a post-traumatic sphenoidal meningocele was observed with a paramedial cranial base defect measuring 1.5cm by 1.5cm. It was associated with a cystic cavity of right frontobasal cerebrospinal fluid.  Given the characteristics of the lesion
column15: transnasal endoscopic treatment was decided. Opening of the anterior wall of the sphenoid sinus with visualisation of the herniated meningocele. Intracranial dissection and monopolar coagulation until progressive intracranial reduction. The defect is delimited at the cranial base and fibrin adhesive is applied. The sphenoid sinus was obliterated with abdominal fat. Lumbar drainage was maintained until the 5th postoperative day and the anterior nasal packing was removed the same day without evidence of intranasal fluid leakage.  Postoperatively
column16: control MRI scans were performed
column17: showing the absence of a previous meningocele and adequate obliteration of the cranial defect with autogenous fat. The patient is currently in the third postoperative year after the last operation without recurrence of meningocele or clinical signs of cerebrospinal fluid fistula.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 40-year-old woman attended the emergency department of the health centre for right unilateral otalgia and headache of 3 days' duration. She was treated as otitis externa with beclomethasone drops + clioquinol. The following day she returned to the emergency department for headache which subsided almost completely with intravenous analgesic therapy
column2: adding dexketoprofen 25 mg/8 h to the previous treatment. Two days later he came to the consultation room reporting a throbbing headache
column3: oppressive sensation at the periorbital level and tinnitus in the right ear
column4: and the examination revealed no inflammation in the external auditory canal (EAC)
column5: selective hyperemia of the ossicular chain without tympanic alteration and discrete horizontal nystagmus
column6: indicating treatment with levofloxacin 500 mg/24 h
column7: betahistine and time off work. Two days later
column8: he attended for the temporary incapacity report
column9: reporting improvement of the ear pain
column10: but a certain sensation of instability
column11: and betahistine was replaced by sulpiride 50 mg/8h. Forty-eight hours later he consulted for "not feeling better"; he noted paresthesia in the right hemicara since that same morning
column12: ageusia in the right hemilanguage and during the interview we observed blepharospasm in the left eye
column13: confirming in the examination a right peripheral facial paralysis (facial asymmetry when smiling and blowing
column14: as well as a slight right ocular opening when told to close his eyes)
column15: for which he was referred to the hospital emergency department for otorhinolaryngological assessment. Audiometry showed a slight drop in acuity in the right ear. Cranial nerves were normal except for VII. There was no spontaneous nystagmus. Otoscopy showed hyperemia in the upper portion of the CAE and small vesicles were visualized in the right auricle
column16: so she was admitted with the diagnosis of "right Ramsay Hunt syndrome" to start treatment with intravenous acyclovir and evolutionary control.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O

column1: A 9 year old female patient who from the age of 3 years presented with protrusion at the level of the nasal root. In the last year
column2: prior to admission
column3: an increase in this deformity was detected
column4: which caused cosmetic alterations and anxiety with schooling problems. Physical examination revealed only a frontal bulge over the nasal root
column5: with no pain on palpation or other relevant pathological findings.  Cranial computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed deformity of the frontal sinus
column6: with no occupation of the sinus; sinus walls of normal thickness. No intracranial lesions were found. There was also a concomitant right parietal lesion compatible with fibrous dysplasia.  The hormonal study revealed levels within the normal range for her age. The patient underwent surgery and a coronal incision was made
column7: exposing the frontal bone and nasal root and revealing a bulging of the frontal sinus. Multifragmentation and remodelling of the anterior wall of the sinus was performed
column8: preserving the mucosa
column9: using an ultrasonic scalpel. The bone defect was reconstructed with resorbable mesh (polylactic and polyglycolic acids). In addition
column10: the parietal lesion was resected and remodelled
column11: replacing the internal cortex.  The patient had no postoperative complications and had a favourable evolution. The subsequent cosmetic result was optimal. The histological study of the parietal lesion was non-pathological. The patient was followed up clinically for only one year
column12: due to moving home for family reasons
column13: and there was no evidence of recurrence or discomfort in the region of the operation.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 60-year-old male patient with a Björk-Shilley type mitral metal prosthesis and tricuspid annuloplasty 20 years earlier due to rheumatic valve disease
column2: chronic atrial fibrillation (CAF)
column3: AHT
column4: congestive heart failure (CHF) with a NYHA Functional Grade I/IV. He was receiving treatment with acenocoumarol. He was admitted to our department due to fever
column5: chills
column6: and worsening of his usual dyspnoea
column7: with the appearance of orthopnoea and oedema in the lower limbs. The clinical examination was compatible with CHF (jugular veins ingurgitated
column8: arrhythmic pulse at 100 bpm
column9: gallop rhythm
column10: bilateral basal pulmonary crackles
column11: hepatomegaly of 2 crossings with positive hepatojugular reflex and pretibial oedema with fovea in MMII). Blood tests showed haemoglobin 12.4 g/L
column12: leukocytes 17
column14: with 87% neutrophils
column15: the rest of the usual parameters being within the normal range. Chest X-ray showed signs of CHF. Serial blood cultures were performed in which Neisseria Sicca was persistently isolated
column16: so treatment was started with intravenous Penicillin G sodium 24 million units in continuous perfusion and Gentamicin 80 mg I.V. every 8 hours (first 2 weeks)
column17: and the patient was afebrile on the third day of starting treatment. During admission
column18: reddish
column19: painful lesions appeared on the fingertips of both hands compatible with vasculitic phenomena
column20: and a diagnosis of Infective Endocarditis (IE) was made according to Durack's clinical criteria (4). Transthoracic Echocardiography (TTE) and Transesophageal Echocardiography (TEE) showed a normofunctioning mitral prosthesis and absence of vegetations. On the 9th day of treatment
column21: the patient presented an abrupt episode of loss of strength in the left hemibody
column22: and a cranial CT scan showed 3 hyperdense images at the temporal-parietal and occipital levels of both hemispheres compatible with haemorrhagic foci. At that time
column23: the NRI was 2.45
column24: in spite of which anticoagulation was suspended. Four days later
column25: and after stabilisation of the patient
column26: it was decided to restart anticoagulation with iv sodium heparin
column27: completing 6 weeks of antibiotic treatment and heparin. In the follow-up CT scan of the brain after treatment
column28: the occipitoparietal haematoma persisted
column29: the other haemorrhagic foci having disappeared. Given these findings and the possibility of rebleeding
column30: the patient was discharged with bemiparin 10
column31: 000 I.U. subcutaneously once a day for 3 months
column32: after which a new echocardiographic study and cranial CT scan were performed
column33: which showed the normality of the mitral valve and the practical resolution of the cerebral haematoma
column34: for which reason oral anticoagulation with acenocoumarol was started again
column35: and three months later he was found to be asymptomatic.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 90 year old patient went to his local urologist for progressive enlargement of the left hemiscrotal bone
column2: of approximately 2-3 years' evolution
column3: and possible interference with the micturition pattern. The only personal history of the patient was hypertension. Physical examination revealed a very large left hemiscrotal
column4: under tension
column5: with positive transillumination and in which the testicle could not be palpated. The right testicle
column6: which is lateralised due to the size of the left hemiscrotal
column7: and the epididymis were not altered on examination. The patient was in good general condition. In view of these exploratory findings
column8: a Doppler ultrasound was requested
column9: which was reported as a large left hydrocele
column10: heterogeneous left testicle with areas of increased Doppler flow and multiple calcifications
column11: suggesting chronic orchiepididymitis. Right testicle without alterations. It was decided to perform a left orchiectomy via the inguinal route and also to perform surgical treatment of the hydrocele
column12: from which 700 ml were evacuated. The macroscopic appearance of the specimen was reported as a testicle entirely occupied by a tumour measuring 8.7 x 6 cm which does not infiltrate the capsule. The tumour shows solid orange-coloured areas together with haemorrhagic microcystic areas. Macroscopically
column13: the tumour did not appear to reach the epididymal head or the tunica vaginalis. Histologically it was a Leydig cell tumour with malignant criteria (positive for vicentin
column14: focally for CK22 and AEI-AE3 and S-100
column15: negative for PLAP
column16: CD30
column17: CD117
column18: CD45
column19: CD20 and chromogramin). Nuclear pleomorphism
column20: mitotic activity
column21: foci of necrosis
column22: without vascular embolisation. The tumour focally infiltrates the capsule without extending beyond it. Rete testis
column23: epididymis and albuginea are not infiltrated. The extension study with chest X-ray and abdomino-pelvic CT scan was negative. Tumour markers showed normal values. Ten months after the operation
column24: the patient was in good general condition with negative markers and no radiological signs of distant metastasis. The possibility of complementary treatments was ruled out due to the age of the patient and the excellent evolution.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: In February 2000
column2: a 32 year old man came to the hospital emergency department for pain in the left shoulder and lumbar spine. Routine physical examination and laboratory tests were irrelevant. The radiological study showed generalised lytic bone lesions. Abdominal thoracic CT scan showed no images suggestive of visceral neoplasia. Gastroscopy
column3: barium enema
column4: abdominal
column5: testicular and prostate ultrasound were normal. In order to establish a diagnosis
column6: a bone marrow biopsy was taken from the iliac crest. Microscopically
column7: the bone marrow showed a partial replacement of its usual cellularity by a neoplasm consisting of epithelial nests in a fibrous stroma in some areas
column8: while in other areas these nests are surrounded by the usual bone marrow cellularity and are made up of polygonal cells with rounded or oval nuclei
column9: with a soft appearance without prominent nucleoli and very few mitoses. The immunohistochemical study showed negativity for oestrogen receptors
column10: S-100 protein
column11: HMB45
column13: bc1-2 and synaptophysin. Positivity in 25% of the nuclei with MIB-1 and in 90% of the nuclei with p27 and diffuse and strong positivity to progesterone receptors
column14: chromogranin A
column15: neuronal specific enolase
column16: carcinoembryonic antigen and in less than 50% of the cells to calcitonin
column17: amyloid was not detected with Congo Red staining. With these elements
column18: a diagnosis compatible with bone metastasis of medullary thyroid carcinoma was made. Serum calcitonin levels were 3
column19: 500 pg/ml (normal 15-100) and CEA 231 ng/ml (normal 0.01-5)
column20: with serum levels of Ca 125
column21: Ca 19.9 and PSA being normal.  Given the poor physical condition of the patient
column22: he was sent to the oncology department of our reference hospital in Jaén
column23: where a small solid thyroid nodule with calcium was found ultrasonographically in the left lobe
column24: which was not removed. After investigating the family
column25: no history of thyroid pathology was found. A first line of chemotherapy (CDDP-ADR-VP16) was administered for 6 months
column26: with no response. Palliative radiotherapy was also given to the dorsal lumbar spine. At the beginning of February 2001
column27: a second line of chemotherapy (CTX-DTIC) was started
column28: which was suspended a few days later due to the patient's poor condition
column29: progression of bone metastases and the appearance of pulmonary metastases. The patient died on 21 February 2001. The family did not authorise the autopsy.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Patient EJO
column2: brunette
column3: female
column4: 23 years old
column5: was referred to the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Service of the Piracicaba Dental School (FOP/UNICAMP) for removal of a lesion in the lingual region of the lower anterior teeth. The patient had a clinical diagnosis of neurofibromatosis. Physical examination revealed facial asymmetry and hundreds of skin nodules all over the body
column6: including the face and neck. Café-au-lait spots were present on the trunk and upper limbs.  Intraoral examination revealed malocclusion
column7: diastemas
column8: absent teeth and a neurofibromatous mass in the region of the lower alveolar ridge
column9: lingually to the incisors. The lesion was firm and painless to palpation
column10: of normal mucosal colouring
column11: non-ulcerated
column12: with a sessile base and about 2.5 cm in extension. Due to its size and its relationship with the teeth
column13: it did not allow adequate hygiene of the region
column14: favouring the accumulation of calculus. The tongue also showed an increase in volume
column15: with the presence of a neurofibromatous lesion with diffuse limits.  On radiographic examination
column16: the presence of retained element 23 was observed
column17: as well as right mandibular hypoplasia.  Surgical excision was performed for the neurofibromatous lesion in the lower anterior region. The lesion in the lingual region was not approached surgically due to the fact that it did not present any functional or aesthetic compromise for the patient. The diagnosis of neurofibromatosis was confirmed by anatomopathological analysis.  The patient is now six months post-operative follow-up
column18: with no complaints and no apparent sign of recurrence of the lesion. The patient is currently under periodontal treatment
column19: with significant improvement of the local supporting tissue conditions.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 29-year-old woman with a history of duodenal ulcus and constipation consulted for pain in the right renal fossa compatible with renoureteral crisis. No history of nephrolithiasis
column2: haematuria or urinary tract infections. Examination revealed only a positive right renal fist percussion. Ultrasound showed right renal pyelocaliceal ectasia with parenchymal thinning. IVUS shows a functional annulment of the right renal unit
column3: the rest of the examination being normal. Retrograde pyelography showed stenosis at the right pyeloureteral junction
column4: with negative selective urine cytology of the right ureter. Faced with the dilemma of whether to perform reconstructive surgery or exeresis
column5: renal scintigraphy was performed
column6: showing a relative uptake of 33% for the right kidney and 67% for the left kidney.  Right renal pyeloplasty was performed according to the Anderson-Hynes technique. Pathological examination of the urinary tract stenosis revealed a cavernous haemangioma as the cause of the obstruction
column7: which did not allow any cannula to pass. Postoperative urographic control at 3 months showed uptake and elimination of contrast in the right kidney with a slight delay compared to the left kidney.  The patient was discharged from the outpatient clinic three years after surgery after two more urographic controls; 7 years after pyeloplasty she has not consulted again for urological symptoms.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 73-year-old man diagnosed with infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma of the oropharynx G1
column2: cT4b cN2
column3: undergoing treatment with chemotherapy and radiotherapy until 3 months previously. He presented dysphagia secondary to radiotherapy for both solids and liquids
column4: with a weight loss of 10 kilograms (kg) in two months. She received enteral nutrition through NGUS for two years
column5: and was finally scheduled for PEG. During oral endoscopy
column6: bleeding occurred during dilation of a stricture in the upper oesophageal portion
column7: so the procedure was abandoned and the patient underwent RPG
column8: which was performed without incident.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 72-year-old man on HD programme since December 2002
column2: due to renal failure secondary to bilateral nephrectomy for renal neoplasia (1999 and 2002). History of arterial hypertension
column3: appendicectomy
column4: cholecystectomy and right inguinal herniorrhaphy. Splenectomy for spleen injury during right nephrectomy (2002). Venous thrombosis in the right lower limb due to femoral cannulation (dialysis catheter). Ischaemic colitis
column5: colon polyposis and lower gastrointestinal bleeding in 2007. In December 2008 a new episode of lower gastrointestinal haemorrhage due to angiodysplasia. Diagnosed in 2009 with moderate-severe aortic stenosis. History of vascular access: - Started treatment in December-02 via a right femoral catheter. It was withdrawn in February 2003 (venous thrombosis). - A left humero-cephalic AVF was performed in January 2003. It was started at 4 weeks. It developed an aneurysmal dilatation
column6: presenting partial thrombosis (December 2003)
column7: which allowed its use in unipuncture. - In December 2003
column8: a right humero-basilic AVF was performed
column9: which did not work. - In the same month a right humero-axillary PTFE graft was implanted
column10: with thrombosis after 24 hours. It had to be removed due to infection in January 2004. - Due to dysfunction of the left fistula
column11: a tunneled catheter was implanted in the left internal jugular vein in January 2004. It was used as a VA until July 2004
column12: and was removed due to infection refractory to antibiotic therapy. - On 22-7-04 there was an unsuccessful attempt to cannulate the right internal jugular vein
column13: and a catheter was placed in the right femoral vein: it was removed in Sep-04
column14: as a functioning AVF was available. - Again
column16: unsuccessful attempts were made to cannulate both the right and left internal jugular veins. - On 4-8-04 a PTFE prosthesis was implanted between the left femoral artery and vein. It was used from September until 22-10-04 (non-recoverable thrombosis). - On the same day 22-10-04 a tunneled catheter was implanted in the right internal jugular vein: - In October 2005 he presented an episode of bacteraemia due to E. coli
column17: resolved with antibiotherapy. - Subsequently
column18: the catheter gave problems of insufficient flow
column19: frequently requiring both local and systemic fibrinolytic treatment. - For this reason
column20: in November 2006
column21: anticoagulation with acenocoumarol (Sintrom®) was indicated
column22: with slight functional improvement. - In February 2007 she suffered an episode of lower gastrointestinal haemorrhage
column23: due to ischaemic colitis and colon polyps and conditioned by the anticoagulant treatment. - After withdrawal of acenocoumarol the catheter stopped giving flow. - On 22-2-07 an attempt was made to replace the catheter via the same venous line
column24: but it was impossible to insert the new catheter due to complete thrombosis of the superior cava. - On the same day
column26: a temporary catheter was placed in the left femoral vein. It was removed on 2-3-07 as a functioning central catheter was available. - On 28-2-07 a Split-Cath tunneled catheter was placed directly in the right atrium
column27: by means of a right anterior mini-thoracotomy. - From the first dialysis session
column28: there was minimal blood leakage through the junction of the catheter with the connection extensions. This did not prevent her from continuing to use the catheter. - Hospitalisation in October 2007 due to catheter infection
column29: resolved with antibiotic therapy. - In November 2007 the blood leakage increased significantly and was resolved by sealing with sterile silicone and placing a PTFE sheath around the leakage point. - In March 09
column30: the blood leakage was again present
column31: resolved with the same sealing procedure and PTFE sheath. - On 30-11-09 it leaked again
column32: and a new sealing attempt failed. - On 22-3-09 he required the insertion of a temporary catheter in the right femoral artery for a few days. - On 17-12-09 a new transthoracic replacement was performed by thoracotomy
column33: and another Split-Cath catheter was inserted. - As a complication
column34: he developed post-surgery cardiogenic shock
column35: and was diagnosed with moderate-severe aortic valve stenosis. - The catheter gave inadequate flow
column36: and it was shown that the distal ends were located in the suprahepatic vein. - On 25-3-10 the catheter was repositioned in haemodynamics
column37: the distal ends of the catheter being located in the inferior vena cava. - On 24-9-10
column38: again due to catheter dysfunction
column39: the catheter was repositioned in haemodynamics
column40: the distal ends remaining lodged in the right atrium. - On 22-3-10 he required the insertion of a temporary catheter in the right femoral artery for a few days. Since the last episode on 24-9-10 and until today (10-02-2012)
column41: the patient has been dialysed at his dialysis centre via the transthoracic catheter
column42: with no incidents and with adequate catheter function.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male patient referred in 2009 for monitoring to the Bone Metabolic Unit (BMU) at the age of 36 and diagnosed in a private centre with monostotic Paget's disease of the left radius. At the time
column2: the patient provided a biopsy and scintigraphy report carried out in 2007. He was treated with risedronate at the dose used for osteoporosis. On observing the good result in the levels of P1NP (procollagen type 1 amino-terminal propeptide)
column3: risedronate was discontinued that same year
column4: 2009. From then until November 2014
column5: he was periodically monitored for serum levels of bone remodelling markers
column6: and a new cycle of low-dose risedronate was prescribed for a few months when these increased. Also during this period of time
column7: a scan was performed without finding any significant alterations with respect to the previous scan. When the treatment was administered
column8: the patient's symptoms of local pain improved
column9: but in November 2014 he spontaneously came to the clinic with his arm in a sling
column10: reporting that two days earlier he had suffered a casual fall and presented intense pain in the area of the left carpus. Physical examination revealed a haematoma on the dorsum of the hand and distal third of the forearm
column11: oedema
column12: effacement of the tendon grooves on the dorsum of the hand
column13: functional impotence of the wrist and a local increase in temperature. Given the clinical suspicion of fracture
column14: the patient was referred from the Metabolic Unit to the Accident and Emergency Department where X-rays were taken; he was discharged with the diagnosis of contusion as no fracture was evident
column15: but a large hyperostotic lesion was observed on plain X-rays
column16: which is why the patient returned to the BMU. Despite the fact that the fracture was not visible on the X-rays
column17: but there was clinical evidence of it
column18: an urgent computerised axial tomography (CAT) scan and a nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) scan were requested for a deferred study of the hyperostotic lesion. The CT scan showed a fracture of the hooked and trapezius bones. The limb was immobilised with a posterior splint. Once the traumatic emergency had been resolved
column19: the radiological lesion of the radius was re-evaluated in the following days and the so-called "sliding wax melting" sign was identified. Given the possibility of melorheostosis
column20: this option was discussed with the Radiology and Nuclear Medicine departments for their consideration. Finally
column21: this was accepted as an alternative diagnosis to Paget's disease of bone
column22: being indistinguishable gammagraphically. Once the new diagnosis of melorheostosis had been confirmed and agreed
column23: we went back to the anamnesis
column24: which included a report of a fall at the age of 14 while practising sport. The patient reported having suffered intense pain in the radius
column25: but did not go to any health centre and hid it from his parents
column26: presenting a certain deformity since then. The pain subsided weeks after the fall. We deduce that the patient fractured his radius and as the fracture was not immobilised or reduced
column27: he was left with the deformity that can be seen in figure 1
column28: but which is not directly related to the hyperostosis. In addition to the striking central image
column29: there are other areas of hyperostosis on the inside of the distal end of the radius and in the proximal third.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A four-year-old boy who
column2: suddenly
column3: ten days ago
column4: presented with a speech disturbance consisting of repetition of syllables and prolongation of sounds. He has no other neurological symptoms. The parents relate it to a head injury suffered the day before the onset of the symptoms. Previously
column5: his language was slow and considered normal for his age. He showed adequate acquisition of language skills and other neurodevelopmental milestones up to the present. On examination
column6: the patient showed coherent speech with repetition of phonemes in sentences and prolonged pauses between phrases. Pronunciation is correct but the patient has to make an effort to control it. He organises sentences of three or four words without syntactic problems. He shows adequate oral comprehension. The rest of the neurological examination was normal. Given these data
column7: a diagnosis of developmental stuttering is made and assessment by a speech therapist is recommended.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 27-year-old woman
column2: active polydrug addict
column3: who 15 days before admission started with a dry cough
column4: dyspnoea of progressive intensity
column5: fever
column6: asthenia

column1: A 35-year-old male patient came to the emergency department with a severe bifrontoparietal headache lasting 8 hours

column1: A 48-year-old man who had been referred 9 years earlier for proteinuria. He had been treated with amlodipine
column2: atenolol and irbesartan for 2 years. In the general study he had proteinuria 1200 mg/day
column3: 448 red blood cells/μl in the sediment
column4: creatinine 1.05 mg/dl and negative immunology. In the renal biopsy: 5-10 glomeruli without striking cellularity
column5: without exudation
column6: 2-4 glomeruli with complete sclerosis
column7: discrete chronic lymphomonocytic infiltrates in the interstitium
column8: without vascular involvement
column9: without tubular atrophy; in the immunofluorescence IgM immunoglobulin deposits of focal and segmental distribution in 10 glomeruli
column10: with + and ++ intensity in the mesangial region. He was diagnosed as focal and segmental glomerulosclerosis with the addition of ramipril 2.5-5 mg/day
column11: observing a reduction in proteinuria to <400 mg/day. Three years ago he suffered an increase in proteinuria of 1.6 g/day
column12: albuminuria 895 mg/day and 250 red blood cells/μl
column13: with normoalbuminaemia and oedema. Treatment with prednisone and cyclophosphamide was tried
column14: with a decrease in proteinuria after 7 months of treatment to 1.1 g/day
column15: but with proximal muscle weakness that was interpreted as steroid myopathy. Prednisone was discontinued and changed to mycophenolate mofetil 1 g/day and amlodipine was withdrawn due to its possible influence on oedema
column16: adding 12.5 mg of hydrochlorothiazide due to poor blood pressure control. After 2 months
column17: mycophenolate was discontinued because the patient reported significant fatigue which he attributed to this drug. Cyclosporin A was then started at a dose of 150 mg/day (1.9 mg/kg/day) with good initial tolerance (levels 67.8 ng/ml). After 2 months
column18: the patient consulted for pain in the left breast accompanied by a retroareolar nodule the size of a chestnut that was tender to the touch. Cyclosporin A was discontinued
column19: and mammography and ultrasound were performed
