column22: so he discontinued as he presented proteinuria <250 mg/day. At the last review 5 months later
column23: proteinuria had risen to 650 mg/day and the glandular growth had subsided
column24: leaving him on treatment with doxazosin
column25: atenolol
column26: irbesartan and ramipril.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O

column1: A 33-year-old male patient was referred for consultation because he presented with a tumour in the basal mandibular region at the parasymphyseal level on the right side with several years of evolution and slow growth. His medical history included tuberous sclerosis and having undergone a kidney transplant after a nephrectomy for renal angiomyolipoma. Symptoms of the disease included Pringle's sebaceous adenoma of Pringle in the nasolabial region
column2: retinal hamartomas in the fundus and fibrotic lesions in the posterior cervical region. Clinical examination revealed a hard lesion adhering to the mandible
column3: approximately 2x2 cm in diameter
column4: with mild pain on palpation. On the skin of the lateral cervical region and on the nape of the neck
column5: multiple small excrescent lesions of dark colouring and fibrotic appearance were observed. Intraoral examination revealed gingival hyperplasia
column6: which was attributed to chronic anticonvulsant treatment with hydantoin to prevent the epileptic seizures typical of his underlying syndrome
column7: which the patient had previously suffered.  Panoramic X-ray showed increased bone density at the mandibular level in the parasymphyseal region
column8: and CT scan showed chondroid bone excrescence and erosion of the mandibular cortex at the right parasymphyseal level with no soft tissue mass component. The radiographic differential diagnosis included: ameloblastoma
column9: odontogenic myxoma
column10: aneurysmal cyst
column11: chondromyxoid fibroma
column12: central haemangioma or eosinophilic granuloma.  Under general anaesthesia and using a cutaneous approach
column13: the hard round lesion was excised with a safety margin in the mandible. In addition
column14: the cervical fibroids were excised in the same surgical procedure using a CO2 laser. The day after the operation the patient was discharged from the hospital. He has subsequently been seen in outpatient clinics without any signs or symptoms of recurrence of the mandibular lesion for three years.  Pathological examination of the excised mandibular bone lesion revealed a lesion consisting of a small number of fibroblasts and a stroma with a large amount of hyalinised collagen. Bone spicules were observed within the lesion without osteoid rim indicative of bone infiltration of the tumour. The lesion had spindle-shaped cells with elongated
column15: uniform nuclei with few mitoses and no atypia
column16: which made it benign. The study concluded that it was a desmoplastic fibroma.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 62-year-old patient with a personal history of chronic glaucoma and hysterectomy. She presented with a picture of loss of fixation memory
column2: of approximately one month's evolution
column3: initially labelled as a symptom of a depressive process. There was no neurological focality on physical examination. His family history is that both his mother and grandmother died of cerebral glioblastoma. The cranial computed tomography (CT) scan shows the presence of a left frontal cortico-subcortical intraaxial cortico-subcortical expansion process; the magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) findings of this lesion are considered compatible with a high-grade glioma
column4: located in the left hemispheric premotor region...  Surgical treatment was initially performed by means of a left frontal craniotomy
column5: with complete resection of the tumour
column6: whose histological report confirmed the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme. A control CT scan on the first postoperative day confirmed the absence of tumour remains. Subsequently
column7: he underwent adjuvant treatment with radiotherapy and chemotherapy
column8: according to the usual protocols
column9: with no morbidity derived from either of these treatments.  The patient's evolution was favourable
column10: remaining asymptomatic in successive check-ups. Thirteen months after surgery
column11: a control MRI scan revealed a right frontal cortico-subcortical lesion suggestive of a high-grade glioma
column12: with no apparent connection to the contralateral tumour and no signs of recurrence of the lesion. She was reoperated 14 months after the first surgery by means of a right frontal craniotomy with complete resection of the tumour. The histological report confirmed that it was a glioblastoma. The postoperative control CT scan showed complete resection of the right lesion. An assessment by Oncology ruled out adjuvant radiotherapy and treatment with chemotherapy was decided.  The patient remained asymptomatic. Three months after the second surgery and a control CT scan revealed a small right basal temporal nodule that captured contrast and was suggestive of a new focus of glioblastoma. The patient refused invasive treatment and underwent palliative conservative treatment. Subsequent imaging studies revealed new tumour lesions. The patient died 26 months after the first surgery.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 56-year-old patient was referred to our department due to an incidental finding of a renal mass of 5 cm maximum diameter
column2: left mesorenal on ultrasound during the study of a renoureteral crisis on the same side. The patient's only history was hyperuricaemia
column3: and he did not report any episodes of haematuria. At the centre where the diagnosis was made
column4: an extension study was performed with chest X-ray
column5: haemogram
column6: biochemistry and abdomino-pelvic computerised tomography
column7: which revealed a tumour thrombus extending through the renal vein to the retrohepatic vena cava. In this case
column8: the referring centre decided to place a filter in the inferior vena cava to prevent progression and embolisation of the thrombus. The patient was subsequently referred to our centre to assess surgical treatment
column9: as the sending centre did not have a cardiac surgery service. To complete the study
column10: we performed magnetic resonance urography (Uro-MRI) and angiographic study by computerised tomography (angio-CT) with cavography to assess as accurately as possible the extent of the thrombus and possible tumour vascular infiltration. Both scans report the retrohepatic extension of the thrombus
column11: the apparent absence of vascular infiltration and adenopathy
column12: as well as the presence of a metallic filter immediately above the thrombus
column13: responsible for the artefaction of the images.  With the diagnosis of stage T3bN0M0 renal neoformation with level II tumour thrombus
column14: it was decided to intervene
column15: together with the cardiac surgery department of our centre
column16: performing sternotomy and left subcostal laparotomy and
column17: after freeing the splenic angle of the colon by opening the retroperitoneum at the level of the mesentery
column18: left radical nephrectomy with the nephrectomy specimen remaining anchored by the thrombosed renal vein. Subsequently
column19: and under extracorporeal circulation with deep hypothermia and cerebral retroperfusion
column20: the filter is removed by closing it and traction under fluoroscopic control from its insertion point at jugular level
column21: with control by right auriculotomy of the possible dissemination to the lung of small thrombi during the removal manoeuvre
column22: followed by resection of the renal vein and its ostium due to suspicion of infiltration of the same and thrombectomy by traction to subsequently repair the defect with a Goretex® patch
column23: the patient requiring anticoagulation with dicoumarinic drugs for 3 months until endothelisation of the synthetic graft.  The pathological anatomy reveals the existence of renal adenocarcinoma
column24: Furhman grade III
column25: which infiltrates the renal capsule without going beyond it
column26: as well as the renal vein
column27: without infiltrating the vena cava (pT3bNoMo) with thrombus of exclusively tumour origin. The patient continued to undergo check-ups in our consultations until
column28: at the 12-month follow-up CT scan
column29: a lytic lesion was found in the posterior lamina of the L2 vertebra. After an extension study with scintigraphy and total-body CT confirmed that it was a single lesion
column30: he was referred to the neurosurgery department
column31: where he underwent surgery and resection of the lesion was carried out. Currently
column32: 20 months after the nephrectomy
column33: the patient is undergoing check-ups by our service and the medical oncology service
column34: and is asymptomatic and with no signs of recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 43-year-old male
column2: with no known drug allergies or medical or surgical history of interest
column3: with an abdominal gunshot wound (pistol with 9 mm parabellum projectile). The patient was admitted to the emergency department in haemodynamically stable condition
column4: with severe abdominal pain. Physical examination revealed the bullet entry wound in the left iliac fossa and exit through the left buttock
column5: with abdominal pain and signs of peritoneal irritation mainly in the hypogastrium and left iliac fossa. No involvement of the external genitalia or urethrorrhagia was observed. After urethro-vesical catheterisation
column6: intense macroscopic haematuria was observed. The only notable finding in the admission analysis was anaemia (Hb: 9.2 g/dl)
column7: with the rest of the biochemical parameters
column8: blood count and coagulation being normal. Given the patient's haemodynamic stability
column9: it was decided to complete the study by means of imaging tests prior to surgery. Given the theoretical trajectory of the projectile (once the entry and exit orifices were known)
column10: with the suspicion of bladder injury by firearm and given the possible involvement of other organs
column11: it was decided to perform abdominal-pelvic CT and CT-cystography (by gravity bladder repletion with 300 cc of diluted contrast material). - Abdominal-pelvic CT and cystographic CT: extraperitoneal
column12: left lateral-postero-lateral bladder rupture
column13: with extravasation of contrast after filling. Minimal dilatation of the left collecting system. Entry wound in the left iliac fossa with areas of haemorrhage in the mesosigm
column14: left lateral vesical side
column15: left seminal vesicle and left perirectal and ischiorectal areas.  With these findings
column16: exploratory laparotomy was decided. With the patient in the supine decubitus position
column17: a supra-infraumbilical midline laparotomy was performed. Initially
column18: a small perforation in the mesosigm was repaired without affecting the sigmoid loop and a minimal lesion was repaired at the level of the left primitive iliac vein
column19: subsequently verifying the indemnity of the rest of the iliac arterial and venous axis. An anterior longitudinal median cystotomy was then performed and a double bladder perforation was observed
column20: corresponding to the entrance (4 cm in the bottom of the bladder) and exit (1-2 cm
column21: in the left retromeatic region) of the projectile. After exploring the indemnity of the left distal ureter with a 5F ureteral catheter
column22: it was found that the intramural portion was completely disinserted and that the projectile had also severed the left vas deferens. It was decided to suture the double bladder perforation in two planes
column23: after debridement of the devitalised edges
column24: and to perform ureteral reimplantation with a transvesical technique and double J catheter (26 cm/6 F) in the posterior wall
column25: after distal ureteral release and section of the damaged end. After closure
column26: also in a double plane
column27: of the anterior longitudinal cystotomy
column28: a urethro-vesical catheter and double closed suction drainage were left: one intraperitoneal and the other extraperitoneal
column29: separated from the bladder suture line. Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotherapy was prescribed: Ceftriaxone 2 grams every 24 hours and Metronidazole 1.5 grams every 24 hours
column30: and the initial postoperative period was favourable. On the 5th day the patient presented deterioration of the general condition
column31: hypotension
column32: fever and leukocytosis with marked left deviation (31% of the keys). Empirical antibiotic therapy was replaced
column33: pending the results of the blood cultures
column34: with Imipenem 500 milligrams every 6 hours intravenously
column35: and the patient improved significantly both clinically and analytically. In the blood cultures
column36: an E. coli producing extended-spectrum b-lactamase
column37: sensitive to Imipenem
column38: grew. A new abdominal-pelvic CT scan was performed
column39: which only showed post-surgical changes
column40: ruling out the existence of liquid collections that could have caused the septic condition. The rest of the postoperative period was uneventful
column41: with initial removal of both drains and
column42: on the 10th day
column43: the urethro-vesical catheter. Finally
column44: the patient was discharged after completing 10 days of intravenous antibiotherapy. It was replaced by Ciprofloxacin 250 milligrams every 12 hours orally
column45: according to the previous antibiogram
column46: until the JJ catheter was removed. One month after the operation
column47: the patient returned to our department for urethro-cystoscopy and removal of the JJ catheter. It was observed that the double bladder wound was completely healed
column48: with the suture of the mucosal plane almost completely reabsorbed. The JJ catheter that was tutoring the ureteroneocystostomy is removed endoscopically without any problems. Currently
column49: three months after the operation
column50: the patient is urologically asymptomatic.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A girl aged two years and ten months with a history of atopic dermatitis attended the emergency department for skin lesions on the trunk and generalised pruritus of 12 hours' duration. She was afebrile
column2: with no other symptoms. Physical examination revealed erythematous
column3: non-confluent lesions on the trunk
column4: assessed as haematous and evanescent
column5: as well as the presence of tonsillar exudate. The rapid streptococcus test in the pharynx was negative. The patient was diagnosed with acute parainfectious urticaria and pharyngotonsillitis of probable viral aetiology. After 36 hours of evolution
column6: the patient returned due to progressive skin involvement
column7: with pruritic erythematodecamative lesions in the periocular and periorbital regions and in patchy plaques on the trunk and large folds
column8: together with areas of superinfection and scratching lesions on the trunk. The pharyngeal exudate persists
column9: she remains afebrile and complains of pain on picking her up. An outbreak of atopic dermatitis with superinfection was diagnosed and treatment was started with oral deflazacort.  Seventy-two hours later
column10: the patient presented again with worsening of the lesions
column11: associated with fever
column12: malaise and pain on palpation of the skin. The haemogram showed leukocytosis of 17500/mm3 without neutrophilia (neutrophils: 51%
column13: lymphocytes: 34.8%) and C-reactive protein of 4.3 mg/l. Finally
column14: the patient was diagnosed with scalded skin syndrome and was admitted for intravenous antibiotic treatment with clindamycin and cloxacillin. Foments with 2% sodium borate and antibiotic ointment were applied to the palpebral and perioral lesions. Methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus was isolated in the conjunctival and pharyngeal exudate and in a skin lesion; the blood culture was sterile. The patient progressed favourably and was discharged six days after admission.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 46-year-old woman with dyspepsia of several years' duration that did not improve with medical-dietary treatment. Endoscopy revealed a submucosal lesion 1 cm in diameter
column2: located on the posterior aspect of the gastric antrum with no signs of ulceration. The biopsy was suggestive of moderate congestion and focal oedema of the lamina propria. An antral gastrointestinal transit (GIT) and computed tomography (CT) scan showed a repletion defect with loss of mucosal folds compatible with the previously described tumour. During the follow-up
column3: several endoscopic ultrasound scans (EUS) were performed
column4: showing a hypoechoic
column5: homogeneous lesion with regular borders
column6: which appeared to depend on the muscular layer
column7: measuring 2 x 1.6 cm with a soft consistency
column8: compatible with a stromal tumour of the leiomyoma type
column9: with no ultrasound signs suggesting malignancy. No significant adenopathy. FNA: epithelial cellularity without malignancy.  The increase in size of the lesion
column10: the persistence of symptoms
column11: the absence of a definitive diagnosis and the impossibility of ruling out malignancy led us to consider surgical removal. Excision was performed laparoscopically
column12: identifying the lesion by means of intraoperative endoscopy and Chinese ink staining prior to surgery. An anterior gastrostomy is performed and the resection is carried out with a 45 mm linear endograft (Ethicon Endo-surgery). Subsequently
column13: the gastrostomy is closed with a continuous silk suture. Macroscopically
column14: the lesion has a solid consistency and the external surface is yellowish-whitish in colour. Microscopic examination identified heterotopic pancreatic tissue with a predominance of irregularly dilated ducts. The postoperative period was uneventful and oral intake was resumed on the 4th day and the patient was discharged on the 7th day. The patient is currently asymptomatic.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 57-year-old woman whose medical history included a history of paraganglioma of the carotid body in the patient's sister
column2: who was treated with surgical resection of the lesion. She came to the department with an increase in cervical volume on the left side anterior to the sternocleidomastoid of 5 years' evolution
column3: slow growth
column4: firm to palpation
column5: mobile in the anteroposterior direction
column6: with recent odynophagia and dysphonia. Computed tomography with contrast medium showed a hyperdense
column7: well-defined lobulated image measuring 29.7 × 33.3 mm
column8: located in the carotid bifurcation
column9: with no apparent airway involvement. Angiography shows a typical "lyre" image
column10: in which the ovoid lesion shows a homogeneous hyperenhancement of contrast
column11: as well as an opening of the carotid bifurcation.  Based on the clinical and imaging findings
column12: a diagnosis of carotid body paraganglioma is made. Due to the size of the lesion
column13: selective embolisation was performed with polidocanol foam and
column14: 48 hours later
column15: under general anaesthesia and orotracheal intubation
column16: surgical resection of the lesion was performed with a laterocervical approach anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle
column17: dissection by planes until the lesion was located
column18: which was completely resected with subadventitial dissection; collateral carotid branches were ligated for haemostatic purposes
column19: maintaining the integrity of the carotid arteries. The specimen obtained is sent for histopathological study
column20: in which the presence of clusters or nests of oval cells with uniform hyperchromatic nuclei surrounded by vascular stroma is observed
column21: forming the Zellballen pattern
column22: the classic pattern of carotid body paraganglioma.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 70-year-old woman underwent surgery by the Cardiac Surgery Department for a complex valve problem. She presented with multiple post-surgical complications that aggravated her general condition due to pump failure. After two weeks of hospitalisation
column2: she began to develop septic symptoms originating in the mediastinum. The surgical wound was opened
column3: with exposure of the heart
column4: and daily dressings with physiological saline solution. Two weeks after the first operation
column5: the cardiac surgery team performed an omentum flap to repair the defect
column6: without success. Two months after admission
column7: the patient was still in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with assisted ventilatory support
column8: drug-induced coma and had developed generalised polyneuropathy; extensive exposure of the heart
column9: with opening of the pleura in both hemithoraxes and herniation of a left pulmonary lobe with respiratory movements. It was decided to perform reconstruction using a latissimus dorsi flap and alloplastic material (Gore-tex®) to repair the central defect and pulmonary herniation. Part of the previously performed omentum flap was used to cover the defect. The patient evolved favourably
column10: her neurological condition improved gradually and she was transferred to the ward 18 days later
column11: to be discharged home one month after the operation. The patient died 6 months later from pneumonia affecting the right lung.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 89-year-old male patient with no pathological history of interest consulted for anorexia of one and a half months' duration accompanied by oedema of the hands and feet. He reported some episodes of rectorrhagia. Physical examination only revealed oedema with fovea limited to the metacarpophalangeal and metatarsophalangeal joints. With the diagnosis of suspected RS3PE
column2: therapy with prednisone 20 mg/24 hours was started
column3: and the oedema disappeared completely after 5 days of treatment. Given that this syndrome can appear in association with other pathologies
column4: the patient was studied.  In the complementary tests the haemoglobin was Hb 10.3 g/dL
column5: with MCV 94.5 fl. The biochemistry
column6: glucose
column7: urea
column8: creatinine
column9: uric acid
column10: total calcium
column11: phosphate
column12: cholesterol
column13: HDL-cholesterol
column14: LDL-cholesterol
column15: total proteins
column16: GPT
column17: LDH
column18: GGT
column19: Na
column20: K were normal. Cobalamins and folates were normal. Beta-2-microglobulin was normal. The proteinogram showed a monoclonal band to IgA lambda. C-reactive protein and ESR were normal. Interleukin 6 was normal. HIV serology was negative. Rheumatoid factor
column21: antinuclear antibodies and anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies were negative. PSA was normal. HLA-B27 phenotype was positive. Bence-Jones proteinuria was negative. Colonoscopy was normal. X-rays of the hands and feet showed no erosive lesions. Thoracic CT in the posterior segment of the LSD showed a pulmonary infiltrate adopting a branched (tree inbud) and nodular morphology; in the LM there was also an infiltrate of branched
column22: nodular morphology and a subsegmental condensation with air bronchogram; biapical pleuroparenchymal tracts with thin-walled cylindrical bronchiectasis in LII and thickening of lingula
column23: and pleura. Abdominal CT scan urinary bladder with thickening of the bladder floor
column24: multiple diverticula
column25: prostatic hypertrophy. Bronchoscopy showed a trachea and left bronchial tree with chronic inflammatory signs
column26: including diverticula and anthracosis plaques throughout the bronchial tree; at the level of the right bronchial tree
column27: in the bronchus intermedius a few mm before reaching the LM entrance
column28: mucous infiltration was observed and at the LM entrance there was a mass of necrotic and very friable appearance that totally obstructed the entrance; a bronchial biopsy was not performed due to bleeding. Cytological examination of the BAS revealed an acute inflammatory smear. The Löwestein culture of the BAS was positive for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The patient's progress showed that 5 days after starting corticosteroid treatment
column29: the oedema of the hands and feet disappeared
column30: and haemoglobin levels returned to normal one month later. Four months after starting prednisone
column31: Mycobacterium tuberculosis was identified and isoniazid
column32: rifampicin and pyrazinamide were prescribed
column33: and corticosteroid treatment was suspended due to suspicion of Poncet's disease. Three months after starting the tuberculostatics and withdrawing the corticosteroids
column34: the oedema in the hands and feet reappeared
column35: so corticosteroid treatment was reintroduced.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 86 year old aphakic patient after cataract extraction in 1999 complicated by capsular rupture and vitreous leakage. Three years later
column2: she came for consultation with a sensation of a foreign body and photophobia. She perceived light in the right eye and slit-lamp examination revealed corneal oedema in the peripheral 3 mm. Specular microscopy was performed. It was decided to perform penetrating keratoplasty due to the low density of central endothelial cells and the patient's discomfort. The patient's cornea was analysed histologically
column3: confirming the diagnosis of BML and showing detachment and rupture of Descemet's membrane and the endothelium in the peripheral zone
column4: the central zone being normal. At 18 months the corneal button remains transparent
column5: without oedema
column6: achieving corrected vision of 0.2 (due to cystic macular oedema).   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was admitted to our unit at 45 days of life (day 0) for moderate to severe dehydration due to acute gastroenteritis. Interesting data include: preterm newborn of 32 weeks gestational age with adequate birth weight (2
column2: 060 g) and Down's syndrome
column3: diagnosed in the first week of life of TF. Prior to admission he had not presented any hypoxic crisis. His weight curve was adequate. Ultrasound (Sonos 100 CF
column4: Hewlett Packard
column5: Massachusetts
column6: USA) showed a pulmonary stenosis gradient of 70 mmHg
column7: baseline O2 saturation was 92% with O2 at 0.5 bpm in nasal goggles
column8: non-invasive mean arterial pressure (MAP) ranged between 50 and 55 mmHg (50-90 percentile for his age). On the third day he presented acute hypovolaemic shock due to severe diarrhoea
column9: requiring volume expansion
column10: intubation and connection to mechanical ventilation (MV). After a good clinical response
column11: the patient was extubated after 6 hours with good clinical and gasometric tolerance. On the fifth day he started with progressive dyspnoea
column12: cyanosis
column13: bilateral crackles without wheezing
column14: requiring reintubation and connection to MV (Babylog 8000 plus
column15: Dräger Medizintechnik GMBH. Lübeck
column16: Germany). Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) testing in nasal mucus was negative. On day 8 he developed progressive oligoanuria with generalised oedema (maximum weight gain of 16% on day 9) and increased oxygen requirements (FiO2: 100%)
column17: with significant decrease in lung compliance and severe refractory hypoxaemia (transcutaneous saturation < 70%). Invasive MAT remained higher than 45 mmHg (5th percentile for her age: 43 mmHg): there was no pathological thermal gradient or coagulopathy. On auscultation
column18: the heart murmur changed characteristics
column19: becoming shorter and less intense (suggestive of suprasystemic PPH). Prone ventilation achieved only slight improvement for 2-3 hours (oxygenation index [OI] from 19 to 16) and the patient could not tolerate positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) increases greater than 8 cmH2O (desaturation and systemic hypotension). After ruling out infundibular spasm by ultrasound and verifying PPH (reversal of ventricular septal defect [VSD] shunt)
column20: treatment was started with ONI at 40 bpm. Subsequently
column21: after a good response
column22: it was maintained at 20 bpm. ONI and nitrous oxide (NOxPUMP plus
column23: Bedfont Scientific Ltd
column24: Upchurch Kent
column25: England) were continuously monitored
column26: the latter being maintained in ranges below 3 ppm.  The patient was also treated with dopamine perfusion at 8 µg/kg/minute. Chest X-ray showed bilateral alveolar infiltrates and mild pulmonary oligoperfusion. Bronchoalveolar lavage isolated Pseudomonas aeruginosa and antibiotic treatment was started. On day 12
column27: resolution of the acute renal failure and oedema was observed
column28: without having received treatment with renal function replacement agents. From day 30
column29: a progressive improvement in respiratory dynamics was observed
column30: tolerating the progressive weaning of ONI (previously it had not been possible to reduce it to less than 15 ppm because the patient could not tolerate it). On day 35 the patient was extubated.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male
column2: 58 years old at the time of transplantation on 5 October 1998. On peritoneal dialysis since January of the same year due to progressive CKD secondary to IgA glomerulonephritis with associated focal and segmental sclerosis diagnosed in 1984. Other antecedents of interest: arterial hypertension diagnosed in 1982
column3: under pharmacological treatment
column4: ischaemic heart disease due to coronary artery disease with transluminal angioplasty of the right coronary artery in 1994 (since then asymptomatic
column5: subsequent stress tests negative)
column6: type II dyslipidaemia. He underwent surgery for bilateral cryptorchidism and tonsillectomy in his youth. Renal transplant was uneventful (left kidney in right iliac fossa with 2 arteries in single patch and vein leading to external iliac)
column7: with immediate effective graft function
column8: no acute rejection and high levels of cyclosporine with no apparent clinical toxicity. The patient received treatment with cyclosporine 8mg/kg
column9: mycophenolate mofetil 2g/day
column10: and prednisone 1mg/kg
column11: with figures progressively decreasing in subsequent controls. In September 2000 (2 years after the transplant)
column12: the patient reported for the first time a feeling of instability when walking and trembling in his hands
column13: which progressively increased
column14: and a study was started by the neurology department. At the time of the study
column15: the patient had gait instability
column16: paraesthesia in both lower limbs (lower extremities) and hand tremors. Physical examination showed no motor deficit but decreased vibration sensitivity in both LES
column17: vivid osteotendinous reflexes (OTR) and cutaneoplantar reflex (CPR) in extension. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed no lesions at cerebral or spinal level
column18: cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis showed lymphocytic pleocytosis without oligoclonal bands
column19: evoked potentials were altered at tibial level and serological tests
column20: ELISA
column21: and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) were positive for HTLV-I in CSF and blood in the first case and PCR in blood. A high viral load was demonstrated. The patient was diagnosed with tropical spastic paraparesis (TSP)
column22: and despite repeated pulses of 6-Methyl-Prednisolone
column23: he is progressively evolving. He has refused treatment with interferon due to the possibility of transplant rejection
column24: and his renal function has always been correct
column25: with creatinine levels oscillating between 1-1-2. He was studied by our department due to urinary urgency with occasional leakage and dribbling. A radiographic and urodynamic study confirmed the existence of a hyperrefléxic bladder and a large bladder lithiasis which was removed by cystolithotomy without postoperative incidents in December 2003. column1: A 55-year-old man diagnosed in 2006 with CLL who received immunochemotherapy treatment in 2008 with Rituximab-Cyclophosphamide-Fludarabine
column2: achieving a partial response. In 2011
column3: there was evidence of disease progression and he started second-line treatment with Rituximab 375mg/m2 day 1 of the cycle and Bendamustine 90 mg/m2 days 1 and 2 every 28 days. Four hours after administration of day 1 of the second immunochemotherapy cycle
column4: the patient attended the emergency department with a dysthermic sensation
column5: fever of 38oC and an urticarial reaction with pruritus and scaly erythroderma over 50% of the body surface that persisted for 15 days. It was decided to perform skin tests with bendamustine because of the possibility of an allergic reaction to this cytostatic. The stock solution used was bendamustine 2.5mg/ml
column6: with 1/10
column8: 1/1000 and 1/10000 dilutions for intradermal administration. Given the previous good tolerance to rituximab for 6 cycles
column9: the skin reaction was associated with bendamustine. The toxicoderma was classified as grade 4 according to the Common Toxicity Criteria (version 4.0)9 and reported by yellow card to the Spanish Pharmacovigilance System. Skin tests were negative for all dilutions. However
column10: following the benefit/risk assessment between the severity of the toxicoderma and the potential benefit of bendamustine treatment
column11: it was decided to develop a PD for the administration of the next cycles of bendamustine. The PD consisted of 12 steps for the administration of the full dose of the drug (186.3mg). The protocol consisted of progressively increasing the infusion rate and drug concentration until the total therapeutic dose was reached. Three solutions A
column12: B
column13: and C were prepared from 1/100
column14: 1/10 and 1/1 dilutions respectively. Each of the solutions was used for four steps
column15: increasing the infusion rate every 15 minutes
column16: so that with each step twice as much drug was administered as in the previous step. In the last step
column17: the rate was kept constant until the total defined dose was administered. Table 1 summarises the solutions and the administration schedule of the desensitisation protocol.  The administration was performed on the haematology ward under medical supervision
column18: with a total duration of 5 hours and 37 minutes. The patient received 6 cycles of immunochemotherapy with bendamustine using this PD with mild skin pruritus but no serious complications.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 42-year-old male patient came to the emergency department after suffering a contusion to his left eye. The patient had previously undergone phacoemulsification of the crystalline lens
column2: with intraocular lens implantation; he subsequently underwent vitrectomy for retinal detachment. His post-surgery visual acuity was 2/10. On ophthalmological examination
column3: visual acuity in the right eye was 10/10 and light perception and projection in the left eye. Biomicroscopically
column4: the left eye showed moderate hyphema
column5: significant iris dialysis with pupillary involvement
column6: Descemet's folds and extreme hypotonia of the eyeball (later confirmed by applanation tonometry
column7: which showed ocular tension close to zero). Fundus examination revealed a massive haemovitreous hemovitreous that made it impossible to visualise the retina. After ruling out an anterior penetrating injury
column8: a diagnosis of suspected posterior scleral rupture was made and confirmed by orbital computerised axial tomography (CAT).  Given the condition of the globe
column9: the patient was admitted and observation was indicated due to the high risk of massive expulsive suprachoroidal haemorrhage if surgery was performed1 . Antibiotic and corticosteroid treatment was prescribed
column10: with close monitoring of the affected eye and the adelfus
column11: as there was a possibility of sympathetic ophthalmia developing. Two weeks later
column12: visual acuity improved from perceiving and projecting light to bulges
column13: with a recovery of the structure of the eyeball; this was confirmed with a new orbital CT scan
column14: showing a sealed posterior leakage point
column15: compatible with reconstitution. After a few months of monitoring
column16: there was progressive reabsorption of the haemovitreous tissue
column17: with a significant choroidal scar rupture
column18: which did not lead to an improvement in visual acuity due to macular and optic nerve involvement. In this case
column19: at first we thought it was a massive ocular burst due to the initial CT image
column20: but later
column21: we thought that what really happened was a massive hyperpressure that compressed the eyeball giving the tomographic image and later
column22: when the rupture was sealed
column23: its constitution was recovered; the fact that the eyeball was vitrectomised contributed to all of this.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column6: AlconCusí
column7: S.A.
column8: Barcelona
column9: Spain) and a topical quinolone (Chibroxín®
column10: Thea S.A.
column11: Barcelona
column12: Spain)

column14: Allergan S.A.)

column16: Novartis SA

column1: Female patient aged 13 years and 7 months who consulted for abdominal pain and vomiting of 2 days' duration. Family history: of no interest. Personal history: Bolivian origin. She arrived in Barcelona 3 weeks ago due to family reunification (her mother has been in Barcelona for 5 years). Menarche 4 months ago. No previous pathologies of relevance. Current illness: abdominal pain of 2-3 days' evolution
column2: diffuse
column3: radiating to the epigastrium
column4: sometimes accompanied by vomiting. No alteration in stool rhythm. She attended an emergency department where she was prescribed ranitidine and omeprazole. She came to the emergency department due to persistence of the symptoms. The patient reports that
column5: while in her country
column6: she has had 2 episodes of isolated abdominal pain in the last 2 months
column7: which she has related to menstruation. She is expecting her period in the next few days. It is therefore recurrent abdominal pain. Physical examination: afebrile

column9: good hydration of the skin and mucous membranes

column11: the tests will help us to eliminate or confirm the organic cause. In our case

column13: platelets 338

column21: creatinine 0.55 mg/dl

column1: A 46 year old woman
column2: hysterectomised for leiomyomas
column3: came to the emergency department for intense pain in the left renal fossa
column4: general malaise and repeated episodes of haematuria. Several urine cytological studies were negative for neoplastic cells. Imaging studies led to the patient's surgical intervention
column5: which revealed an atrophic left kidney and a large 'tumour mass' encompassing the theoretical exit of the left internal iliac artery
column6: left ureter
column7: pouch of Douglas
column8: rectum and lateral peritoneal surface. Due to the technical difficulties involved in enucleating such a lesion
column9: a ureteral sample was taken and submitted for histopathological diagnosis with the suspicion of ureteral carcinoma. The macroscopic study of the referred material showed an irregular whitish tissue with an elastic-firm consistency and fibrous appearance
column10: which on serial sections showed a fine reddish stippling that was difficult to appreciate. Histological examination revealed a ureteral segment with multiple intramuscular dilated glandular structures lined by endometrial epithelium whose immunohistochemical staining was strongly positive for cytokeratins
column11: oestrogen receptors and progesterone receptors. Enveloping the ureteral wall was abundant disordered fibrous tissue with signs of haemorrhage. With all these data
column12: the diagnosis of intrinsic ureteral endometriosis was made
column13: although the intense extra-ureteral tissue response and the clear signs of haemorrhage that accompanied it led us to think of an accompanying extrinsic component
column14: although no glandular structures were identified at that level.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 48-year-old woman with chronic renal failure secondary to tubulointerstitial nephropathy. The patient had received long-term HD replacement therapy and had undergone two renal transplants with transplantectomies: the first was due to acute humoral rejection and the second due to acute humoral and vascular rejection. She resumed haemodialysis treatment in March 2005. Serum intact parathyroid hormone (iPTH) values were intermittently high. Previously
column2: the patient had been treated with calcitriol for short periods of time
column3: as the administration caused hypercalcaemia and hyperphosphataemia. In January 2006
column4: she developed severe SHPTH (with higher iPTH levels than in previous months). Parathyroid ultrasound revealed a hyperechogenic pseudonodular image in the posteromedial area of the left thyroid lobe
column5: which was compatible with hypertrophy of the parathyroid gland. A radiological series showed signs of hyperparathyroidism in the bones of both hands and wrists and CV in the radial and interdigital arteries. Mammography showed multiple linear VC in both breasts.  The patient was treated with calcium carbonate alone. Subsequently
column6: oral calcitriol and sevelamer (800 mg with main meals)
column7: a phosphate (P)-chelating agent
column8: were added to the regimen and the dose of calcium carbonate was reduced. Figure 5 shows serum Ca
column9: P and iPTH levels. Hyperphosphataemia was brought under control after two months of treatment
column10: and the Ca-P product level was adequate
column11: but iPTH levels increased to 734 pg/ml
column12: so treatment was changed. Oral calcitriol was replaced by oral cinacalcet 30 mg once daily and intravenous alfacalcidol (2 µg) immediately after haemodialysis. The doses of calcium carbonate and sevelamer were not changed.  Two months later
column13: the calcimimetic dose was reduced due to hypocalcaemia levels (7.6 mg/dl). Treatment with intravenous vitamin D and calcium carbonate was maintained
column14: and the calcium in the dialysate was changed from 2.5 to 3 mEq/l. Over the next six months
column15: the levels of all parameters remained within the range recommended by the KDOQI guidelines. In November 2006
column16: excessive suppression of iPTH (138 pg/ml) and potential hypercalcaemia (9.4 mg/dl) were observed and treatment with calcium carbonate and alfacalcidol was discontinued. In January 2007
column17: treatment was continued with sevelamer (800 mg with main meals) and a minimal weekly dose of calcimimetic (30 mg cinacalcet on Mondays and Fridays)
column18: resulting in good control of mineral metabolism. During this period
column19: it could be observed that in the radiological series the calcifications of the interdigital artery had disappeared and the bone had a more structured appearance. Mammography also showed regression of the VCs. The initial linear calcifications were replaced by irregular calcifications.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 24-year-old woman from the United States
column2: weighing 70 kg and 175 cm
column3: with no past history of interest
column4: attended the emergency department with a dry cough
column5: precordial discomfort
column6: watery diarrhoea and fever. Examination revealed bilateral crackles and respiratory failure (baseline oxygen saturation 80%). Chest X-ray showed interstitial infiltrates and bilateral pneumothorax with pneumomediastinum. Laboratory tests showed leukocytosis with a left shift (11
column7: 700 - 109/L leukocytes
column8: 81% neutrophils)
column9: CRP = 15.93 mg/mL and LDH = 1
column10: 154 IU/L. The following microbiological studies were performed
column11: which were negative: two blood cultures
column12: urine culture
column13: antigenuria for Legionella and pneumococcus
column14: pharyngeal swab for detection of Adenovirus
column15: influenza A and B virus
column16: parainfluenza virus
column17: respiratory syncytial virus
column18: Coronavirus
column19: Rhinovirus and Enterovirus and blood sample for detection of HIV infection (anti-HIV antibodies and Ag p24). With suspicion of severe community-acquired pneumonia
column20: empirical intravenous (IV) treatment was started with ceftriaxone 2 g/24 h
column21: levofloxacin 500 mg/12 h for three days
column22: continuing with 500 mg/24 h and oxygen therapy. The patient was admitted to the ICU. In the first 48 hours the patient presented respiratory deterioration
column23: requiring orotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation
column24: so on day +2 the IV antibiotic spectrum was extended to meropenem 1 g/6 h
column25: linezolid 600 mg/12 h
column26: liposomal amphotericin B 300 mg/24 h (to cover histoplasmosis) and acyclovir 750 mg/8 h. The patient's diarrhoea was limited to diarrhoea
column27: which was limited to 2 days. Diarrhoea was limited. Due to progressive deterioration
column28: doxycycline 100 mg/12 h iv
column29: and methylprednisolone 60 mg/8 h iv were added on day +6 (due to the possibility of organisative pneumonia or vasculitis). The patient presented haemodynamic deterioration and progressive IR attributed to septic shock and nephrotoxicity
column30: with a 24 h urine CLcr of 9.4 mL/min (day +6)
column31: being 106.5 mL/min on admission (estimated with the Cockcroft-Gault formula from a serum creatinine of 0.9 mg/dL). The aetiological study was extended with the determination of autoantibodies to rule out an autoimmune renopulmonary syndrome (anti-neutrophil cytoplasm and anti-basal membrane antibodies were negative)
column32: determination of galactomannan antigen in blood (negative) and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL)
column33: where new bacterial and fungal cultures were requested (negative) and detection of viral antigens
column34: all negative except PCR for Adenovirus (result received on day +7). Given that this was the only microbiological isolation and given the plausibility of the aetiology
column35: it was classified as Adenovirus pneumonia with secondary acute respiratory distress syndrome. The serotype was not identified. Due to the patient's acute IR and the negativity of other isolates
column36: liposomal amphotericin B and acyclovir were discontinued
column37: the remaining antibiotic treatment was adjusted (meropenem 1 g/12 h iv and levofloxacin 250 mg/48 h iv)6
column38: and treatment was started with ganciclovir 200 mg/24 h iv (adjusted for renal function)
column39: awaiting improvement in CLcr before starting cidofovir. Given the presence of oligoanuria
column40: it was decided to start renal replacement support on day +11 in the form of HDFVVC due to haemodynamic instability (desired loss volume of 100-160 mL/h
column41: blood flow = 160 mL/min
column42: effluent flow = 2 L/h; acrylonitrile haemofilter with surface area = 0.9 m2) with the corresponding dose adjustment of antibiotic treatments (meropenem 500 mg/8 h iv and levofloxacin 250 mg/24 h iv)7. Three days later
column43: empirical treatment with doxycycline and linezolid was discontinued. After starting ganciclovir
column44: lymphopenia
column45: plateletopenia and progressive anaemia accompanied by intra-alveolar bleeding were observed
column46: and haematotoxicity may have been enhanced by previous linezolid treatment. Therefore
column47: treatment with cidofovir was considered
column48: even though renal function had not improved. Given the contraindication of its use in severe renal failure and the lack of references to its use in CVIDH in the technical data sheet
column49: a literature search was performed in Pubmed and Micromedex without finding any reference. It was finally decided
column50: taking into account the patient's renal function and the nephrotoxic effect of cidofovir
column51: to initiate therapy with a reduced dose according to the strategy of Brody et al. in patients undergoing high-flux haemodialysis
column52: and to consider empirically for our patient a CLcr of 40-50 mL/min (0.57-0.71 mL/kg/min). Thus
column53: after obtaining informed family consent
column54: an induction dose of 2.5 mg/kg (175 mg) was administered weekly for 2 weeks and every 15 days thereafter7. At the time of initiation of treatment (day +13) the patient had a residual diuresis of 300 mL/day. To prevent nephrotoxicity
column55: the usual treatment (hydration and probenecid) was carried out. Throughout cidofovir treatment
column56: the patient remained on haemodiafiltration and had no attributable adverse effects. On day +17
column57: a positive blood culture for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus was found and treatment with vancomycin 1 g/24 h (CLcr 40 mL/min) was started. After three doses of treatment
column58: plasma concentrations of this antibiotic were monitored
column59: obtaining a minimum concentration of 13 mg/dL
column60: in line with those expected with a CLcr of 40 mL/min
column61: and so the same dosage was continued. After four doses of cidofovir
column62: the PCR for Adenovirus was negative in LBA on day + 27. A lung biopsy was then performed where no signs suggestive of viral infection were found
column63: and antiviral treatment was suspended. Despite the treatment given
column65: with refractory respiratory failure secondary to acute respiratory distress syndrome requiring support with Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO)

column1: A 53-year-old male patient
column2: diagnosed with ankylopoietic spondylitis (HLA B27)
column3: secondary amyloidosis and terminal chronic renal failure on replacement treatment with haemodialysis. He presented with painless haematuria and cystoscopy revealed a bladder mass
column4: excrescent but not papillary and bleeding. Transurethral resection (TUR) was performed and the histological diagnosis was bladder amyloidosis. The patient evolved satisfactorily and after 11 months he was readmitted with intense
column5: epigastric and fixed abdominal pain
column6: to which was added two hours later a sudden
column7: abundant and haematic vomiting
column8: which was complicated by cardiorespiratory arrest
column9: leading to exitus (11/04/1995). Post-mortem anatomopathological diagnosis revealed ischaemic necrosis of the digestive tract in the territory irrigated by the superior mesenteric artery and amyloid deposits in the submucosal vessels. Organ and system involvement was widespread
column10: including bilateral renal atrophy due to amyloidosis. Bladder amyloidosis (AA)
column11: mostly perivascular and amyloidosis in prostatic vessels.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 43-year-old female patient previously treated for a deep lobe parotid tumour measuring 26 mm in greatest diameter and with previous FNA diagnosed as a basal cell adenoma. A conservative partial parotidectomy was performed and definitive histology showed an adenoid cystic carcinoma pT2N0M0
column2: with a variable histological pattern
column3: mostly tubular with solid areas
column4: others trabecular and few cribriform
column5: with foci of perineural and intraneural invasion
column6: contacting the surgical boundary. In the case of involvement of positive or close surgical margins in adenoid cystic carcinoma after surgery
column7: there is no standard approach; both margin widening and postoperative radiotherapy or margin widening followed by postoperative radiotherapy are valid3 . A PET-CT scan was performed
column8: showing a slight metabolic increase at the parotid level without being able to rule out malignant disease. The patient was referred to the Maxillofacial Surgery Department and a total parotidectomy was performed together with excision of the zygomatic
column9: buccal and marginal branches of the facial nerve
column10: which were included in the tumour mass. Immediate reconstruction with sural nerve graft and filling of the post-parotidectomy defect with temporo-parietal fascial flap was performed. Intraoperative biopsies of the resected nerve endings were negative for neoplasia
column11: definitive pathology of the parotidectomy demonstrated perineural and intraneural invasion adjacent to the tumour. Postoperative radiotherapy was administered because of the solid histological pattern
column12: perineural invasion and margin involvement at the first surgery. During clinical follow-up
column13: good resting function at eye closure and smiling was achieved
column14: with only a slight deficit at blowing one year after surgery. An electroneurophysiological study was carried out 6 months and 1 year after the operation
column15: the latter showing a quasi ad integrum restoration. The electroneurogram at 6 months showed an amplitude of 0.33 mV and a latency of 5.52 ms; and at one year the values were an amplitude of 1.6 mV and a latency of 2.85 ms. With regard to the electromyogram of both the orbicularis oculi and orbicularis labii muscles
column16: denervation-reinervation data were observed with a greater number of polyphasic motor units at one year after the intervention.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 47-year-old woman consulted the emergency department for an 8-hour history of continuous and diffuse abdominal pain
column2: together with vomiting
column3: first of food and then bilious vomiting. The patient's only personal history was two caesarean sections. In the ED she presented with a blood pressure of 122/85 mmHg
column4: a heart rate of 91 beats per minute and an axillary temperature of 35.9 oC. Abdominal examination reveals an infraumbilical mid-laparotomy scar
column5: the presence of diminished sounds
column6: and diffuse pain on palpation without clear signs of peritoneal irritation. There are no inguinal or crural hernias. Blood tests showed only a glycaemia of 122 mg/dL
column7: a leukocytosis of 15
column8: 240 uL
column9: together with neutrophilia of 93%
column10: with the rest of the parameters being normal. The simple abdominal X-ray was compatible with small bowel subocclusion and cholelithiasis. The emergency CT scan revealed the presence of dilated small bowel loops and suggested the possibility of intestinal torsion.  The findings in the complementary examinations
column11: together with the clinical worsening of the patient during the period of observation and study
column12: increasing vomiting and abdominal pain
column13: as well as the appearance of signs of peritoneal irritation in the lower hemiabdomen
column14: led to the proposal of an exploratory laparoscopy. The suspected diagnosis at that time was intestinal occlusion by flanges
column15: and the time elapsed since admission to the emergency department was 16 hours. Under general anaesthesia
column16: exploratory laparoscopy was performed
column17: identifying a strangulated and necrotic small bowel loop in the patient's pelvis. This loop occupies the right side of figure 3 (purple/black)
column18: which is an intraoperative photograph taken directly from the laparoscopic camera monitor. The left side of this image corresponds to the pre-herniary ileum (normal pink)
column19: between both ileum zones is the right fallopian tube which is attached to the anterior abdominal wall and below it is the broad ligament (not visible in the image) and which would have the orifice through which the herniation occurs
column20: in figure 4 the author represents a schematic drawing to better understand the anatomy of the intraoperative findings. The large dilatation of the small bowel loops greatly reduces the working space needed to manipulate the surgical instruments by laparoscopy. This fact
column21: together with the risk of perforation when manipulating the necrotic loop
column22: as well as the impossibility of identifying the anatomical structures with certainty
column23: make it necessary to convert to open surgery. The reconversion was performed by means of an iterative infra-umbilical laparotomy and it was found that the cause of the obstruction and strangulation of the ileum was an internal hernia through the right leaflet of the broad ligament of the uterus. The hernia was reduced
column24: 25 cm of necrotic ileum was resected and reconstructed with a manual end-to-end anastomosis. The hernial orifice is closed with a continuous 0/0 silk suture. The postoperative period passed normally and the patient was discharged with good clinical condition 11 days after admission. Postoperative control at one month is correct.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: currently asymptomatic untreated radicular proctitis
column3: hiatal hernia and asymptomatic gastroduodenal ulcus on maintenance treatment with omeprazole 20 mg/24 h
column4: chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and untreated pneumoconiosis
column5: after 40 years of evolution. He presented to the emergency department with continuous
column6: dull and non-pleuritic pain in the left hemithorax for 24 hours. He maintained his appetite
column7: oral tolerance and daily bowel habits. He reported no previous trauma

column11: haemogram

column1: Four-year-old female patient
column2: born in Mali and adopted at six months of age
column3: with no significant pathological history and correct immunisations. She consulted for the appearance of papular skin lesions and crusted nummular plaques with a tendency to coalesce on the anterior aspect of the right thigh. Topical fusidic acid was initially prescribed
column4: without clinical improvement and with the appearance of similar lesions on the trunk
column5: the root of the extremities and the face. There was no palmoplantar or mucosal involvement. The lesions were not pruritic.  On reinterrogation and re-exploration of the patient
column6: there was an isolated lesion on the dorsum of the right foot
column7: oval in shape
column8: hyperpigmented with perimarginal scaly collarette
column9: which had preceded the rest of the lesions and which was classified as a herald plaque. The final diagnosis was Gibert's pink pityrasis in a black patient

column1: We present the clinical case of a 28 year old male
column2: with no personal history of interest
column3: who came for consultation because he had been presenting for about 10 days with an indurated area on the penis close to the balanopreputial sulcus with the only associated symptomatology being discomfort during erections in the last few days. In the anamnesis
column4: the only interesting fact was the increase in sexual activity in the days preceding the appearance of the lesion
column5: without these relations having been with a risky partner or having received any trauma to the area in question. She did not report any micturition symptoms or fever. Physical examination revealed a subcutaneous indurated cord
column6: about 2 cm long
column7: close to the balanopreputial sulcus
column8: mobile
column9: non-painful and with no associated changes in the penile skin or signs of inflammation. There were also no palpable inguinal adenopathies. Among the complementary tests
column10: a urine and sediment study
column11: urine culture
column12: culture of prostatic secretion and post-prostate massage urine were requested
column13: all of which were strictly normal
column14: as well as serology tests for venereal diseases
column15: which were negative. An expectant attitude was maintained and sexual abstinence was recommended
column16: with spontaneous remission after 4 weeks.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 52-year-old woman reported a spontaneous decrease in visual acuity (VA) in her amblyopic left eye (LO). She had no history of premature birth or family history of ocular disease. At the first examination
column2: the best corrected VA was 1 in the right eye (OD) (-1 cylinder 150o +3 sphere; axial length 22.5mm) and 0.025 in the left eye (OI) (-0.75 cylinder 25o -13.25 sphere; axial length 25.3mm). Biomicroscopic study of the OI identified the Mittendorf's spot located in the lower nasal quadrant of the posterior lens capsule and the anterior end of the AHP with haematic content inside. The oleophilic eye was normal. Horizontal corneal diameters measured 12mm in both eyes (AO) and applanation tonometry was 18mm Hg in AO.  Indirect ophthalmoscopy of the OI showed diffuse mild intravitreal haemorrhage. The path of the AHP could be followed from the optic nerve to the posterior crystalloid. The artery
column3: fixed at both ends
column4: moved freely with eye movements. The posterior vitreous was partially detached from the retina. There were no peripheral retinal abnormalities
column5: no signs of vitreoretinal traction or retinal detachment. The fundus of the OD was normal.  The haemorrhage gradually resorbed over a week. The AHP could be distinguished more clearly allowing a better anatomical study. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) showed the morphological features of Bergmeister's papilla. From this
column6: the AHP emerged showing a tubular structure with a hyporeflective interior.  B-mode ultrasound showed a linear hyperechogenic image with respect to the vitreous corresponding to the AHP and a partial posterior vitreous detachment. Doppler ultrasound demonstrated normal blood flow in the central retinal artery and posterior ciliary arteries but no active blood flow in the AHP.  The haemogram and specific coagulation tests were normal. The haemovitreous was completely reabsorbed and the patient recovered the 0.2 vision she had before the haemorrhage due to anisometropic amblyopia. There was no recurrence of bleeding in 6 months of follow-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 38-year-old man was referred by his doctor to the emergency department for assessment of a lesion on his lower lip that had been present for a month and a half. He has a personal history of unaffiliated hepatitis
column2: tonsillectomy in childhood and a homosexual habit. One and a half months ago
column3: the patient noticed the appearance of a lesion on his lower lip that partially improved after treatment with acyclovir by his GP but worsened when he stopped taking it. The patient also reported lesions on the scrotum and left foot of recent onset. Physical examination revealed a 2 cm ulcerated lesion on the left side of the vermilion of the lower lip
column4: with an indurated base
column5: not painful on palpation. The neck was negative for adenopathy. No other lesions were observed in the head and neck area. Simultaneously
column6: on the left foot there was a 0.5 cm interdigital ulcerated lesion with a smooth surface and serous exudate and multiple smaller
column7: rounded
column8: copper-red
column9: painless to the touch macules on the sole of the same foot. Finally
column10: he had several small lesions on the scrotum (smaller than 0.5 cm) with an ulcerated appearance in different stages of resolution and painful to palpation. The rest of the physical examination was within normal limits.  A biopsy of the lip lesion was performed
column11: which was inconclusive
column12: and laboratory tests were requested to screen for HBV (HBsAg: negative
column13: Anti-HBc: positive
column14: quantitative Anti-HBs: >1000 mIU/ml -positive)
column15: HCV (G-ELISA: negative)
column16: HIV (Immunoblot: positive
column17: IgG ELISA: positive
column18: ELISA (2nd technique): positive
