column20: Lymphocyte population (CD 3+): CD 4: 43%
column22: CD 4/CD8 ratio: 0.77
column23: CD 4 absolute values: 762 cells/ul
column24: CD 8 absolute values: 992 cells/ul)
column25: syphilis (RPR: 1/64 Positive. HAART: Positive. ELISA capture G: Positive (treponemal test)) and tuberculosis (Mantoux: negative). No complementary CSF study was performed due to the absence of neurological symptoms and short evolution. With the diagnosis of syphilis in a patient with HIV

Serological control at 6 months confirmed the resolution of the picture.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 79-year-old woman with a history of hypertension
column2: osteoporosis and hysterectomy for myomatosis at the age of 50. She underwent transurethral resection of infiltrating bladder carcinoma in October 2006. She subsequently received radiotherapy sessions up to a total of 50 Gy due to persistence of an external tumour mass in the right angle of the bladder
column3: finishing this treatment in June 2007. In August 2007 she began chemotherapy treatment due to persistence of the bladder lesion and metastases in the spine detected by follow-up CT scan and bone scintigraphy. Her digestive history began in February 2008 when she was admitted for episodes of rectorrhagia
column4: initially scarce and distal
column5: but which soon became more frequent and profuse
column6: accompanied by symptoms of haemodynamic instability and severe anaemia with extensive transfusion requirements. Total colonoscopy was performed
column7: showing only changes typical of actinic proctitis with large friable and bleeding neovascular lesions; treatment was carried out with argon plasma (APC). The patient's clinical course was unfavourable: she received consecutive treatment with steroid enemas
column8: 5-aminosalicylic acid and sucralfate; in addition
column9: three more therapeutic rectoscopies were performed
column10: applying APC treatment
column11: despite which the episodes of profuse rectorrhagia with haemodynamic instability persisted
column12: requiring transfusion of a total of 21 red blood cell concentrates throughout the patient's hospitalisation period
column13: despite also receiving oral and intravenous ferrotherapy. In the absence of response to these treatments
column14: the case was discussed with the surgeon for topical treatment with formalin
column15: who
column16: using spinal anaesthesia and anal dilatation
column17: treated the rectal ampulla for 10 minutes with a 10% formalin solution 200 ml + 300 ml of water; The patient's tolerance to the procedure was excellent
column18: it was carried out without any complications and from that moment onwards the patient was completely asymptomatic without new episodes of haemorrhagic externalisation
column19: haemodynamic instability or new transfusion requirements; she was discharged and a follow-up colonoscopy was proposed after the treatment
column20: but she did not accept. Four months later
column21: she was admitted again for clinical signs of tumour progression
column22: and symptomatic treatment was decided by the Oncology Department
column23: and the patient died

column1: Female infant admitted at 7 months of age for a brief generalised tonic-clonic seizure
column2: without infectious process or associated fever
column3: which recurred with similar characteristics 23 hours after the first episode
column4: while she was admitted. No focal onset of the seizure was observed
column5: with maintained vital signs and a normal subsequent physical and neurological examination. The parents reported no personal history of note
column6: she attended regular health check-ups and her psychomotor and staturo-ponderal development was normal. On admission
column7: a complete blood count
column8: renal and liver function tests
column9: acute phase reactants
column10: brain ultrasound and electroencephalogram were performed
column11: with normal results. Given the observation of a conflictive socio-familial situation
column12: a search for toxins in urine was carried out
column13: which tested positive for cocaine in two successive samples. The first sample yielded a quantified level of cocaine metabolites in urine of 1.7 µg/ml and the second
column14: collected a few hours later
column15: 0.4 µg/ml (our laboratory cut-off point of 0.3 µg/ml)
column16: which were negative 48 hours after admission. The father is a regular cannabis smoker
column17: but the family members denied cocaine use at home or in their close social and family environment and pointed to the possibility of contact with environmental smoke in a closed room where they had been for hours before the onset of the seizures. column18: the patient has not presented again with seizures in the following six months and psychomotor development is proceeding normally.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 67-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hiatal hernia under medical treatment came to the urology department for monosymptomatic and self-limiting haematuria. Physical examination revealed no findings of interest. Blood tests showed that all parameters were within normal limits. Intravenous urography showed a repletion defect in the right renal pelvis
column2: which was later confirmed by abdominal computed tomography showing a mass in the pelvis amputating the middle calyx. Cytology was negative. Right nephroureterectomy was performed. Endoscopic ureteral deinsertion was first performed with the technical modification described below
column3: followed by nephroureterectomy through a right subcostal incision. The macroscopic description of the specimen shows a vegetative
column4: exophytic and papillary lesion that occupies the middle calyx and part of the renal pelvis without infiltrating parenchyma. Microscopically
column5: the tumour was reported as a high-grade urothelial carcinoma that did not invade the lamina propria (Ta G3). After four years of follow-up the patient is alive and free of disease.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was an 81-year-old man with a history of arterial hypertension under treatment

column4: but despite this he suffered from nausea and syncope

column1: A 12-year-old female was referred to the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery due to delayed eruption of the permanent lower incisors and permanent right-sided canine detected during orthodontic treatment. He also reported occasional pain and gingival swelling. Personal history included focal epilepsy and no allergies. On examination there was an absence of the lower right incisors and canine and a slight bulging of the vestibular cortex of the mandible at this location. Radiographic tests included an orthopantomography and a periapical radiograph
column2: where an intraosseous cystic lesion was observed
column3: measuring 20 x 30 millimetres and showing well-defined margins with some radiolucent and radiopaque images inside. In addition
column4: some radiopaque structures resembling a tooth could be identified inside the cyst together with a lateral displacement of the roots of the neighbouring teeth without apical resorption. With the diagnosis of suspected mandibular compound odontoma
column5: the patient underwent surgery under local anaesthesia
column6: although the cyst could not be completely removed due to lack of cooperation from the patient. Therefore
column7: a second surgery was performed under general anaesthesia in the Major Outpatient Surgery unit
column8: performing a complete removal of the tumour followed by curettage of the surgical site. Histological analysis revealed a composite odontoma with areas of proliferative ameloblastic cells. Microscopically
column9: a nested and banded proliferation of odontogenic palisaded epithelium together with stellate cells located in the centre of the nests could be observed. The stroma surrounding the epithelial nests showed areas of fibromyxoid tissue and areas of collagen with abundant cementum deposits surrounded by ameloblasts and scattered remnants of tooth enamel. Therefore
column10: regular check-ups by clinical examination and CT scans were performed without evidence of recurrence after 24 months of evolution. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 60-year-old patient diagnosed with multiple high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma (T1 G2-3) treated by bladder TUR on 12/01/05 and subsequent TUR for probable recurrence on 9/05/05 (AP: Chronic inflammatory tissue) for which complementary treatment was indicated with BCG instillations at a weekly dose
column2: for six weeks he came to our centre with a constitutional picture of deterioration of the general condition with marked asthenia
column3: fever of up to 39.5 ºC
column4: predominantly in the evening
column5: joint pain starting in the right foot
column6: with subsequent involvement of the left foot
column7: ankles
column8: wrists
column9: hands and fingers (symmetrical and cumulative involvement) together with conjunctivitis with marked ocular redness and purulent discharge. No aphthous ulcers or other oral or genital lesions reported. No other symptoms or signs of infectious locality. Laboratory tests showed marked leukocytosis (22
column10: 180 with 80% neutrophils)
column11: ESR 100 at the 2nd hour and CRP 49 mg/dl. In addition
column12: there was an alteration of liver enzymes. Serology for hepatitis was negative
column13: as well as for Yersinia and Chlamydia. Blood cultures
column14: urine cultures and stool cultures were negative. Culture of Koch's bacillus in urine with negative Kinyoun's stain. HLA B27 and RF negative. Subsequently
column15: arthrocentesis of the right ankle was performed with inflammatory fluid. Culture and crystals were negative. Given the negative results of the tests performed and the arthrocentesis
column16: as a differential diagnosis

We started treatment with indomethacin and corticosteroids (methylprednisolone 40 mg) with a good clinical and analytical response. On discharge the patient continued treatment with indomethacin 75 mg (1-0-1) for 21 days. The patient came back for a check-up after three months and was asymptomatic.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 76-year-old male patient came to the ophthalmology department for pain
column2: tearing and discharge in the left eye (OI) associated with severe red eye of 1 month's evolution. A month earlier
column3: the ENT department had clinically diagnosed a suspected mucous pemphigus vulgaris in the throat and mouth
column4: pending biopsy
column5: for which he was being treated with Prednisone 30 mg a day. His general history included hypercholesterolemia treated with torvastatin. Ophthalmological examination showed a visual acuity (VA) of 1.2 in the right eye (OD) and 1.0 in the OI. Biomicroscopy (BPA) revealed a large blister in the nasal sector of the bulbar conjunctiva
column6: associated with hyperemia
column7: which progressed to erosion within 24 hours; the rest of the examination was normal in both eyes. It was then decided to perform a conjunctival biopsy in the office under topical anaesthesia in the area of the lesion. Treatment with gentamicin ointment and fluorometholone eye drops every 8 hours was started. Histopathology revealed a suprabasal intraepithelial bulla while direct IF showed deposits of Immunoglobulin G (IgG) in the intercellular spaces of the conjunctival epithelium. Upon establishing the diagnosis of Pemphigus Vulgaris
column8: the dose of Prednisone was raised to 60 mg/day
column9: resulting in remission of ocular symptoms after two months.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present a 30-year-old man
column2: with no medical or surgical history of interest
column3: who consulted for a left latero-cervical tumour of several months' evolution; the patient reported night sweats in recent months as the only noteworthy finding in the anamnesis. Examination revealed a tumour measuring approximately 5x5cm in diameter medial to the lower third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM) with an elastic consistency
column4: poorly defined
column5: not adhered to deep planes or skin
column6: whose size did not vary with postural changes
column7: non-pulsatile
column8: and with negative auscultation. A computerised tomography (CT)-guided puncture was requested
column9: which was reported as lymph node cellularity with indeterminate changes that could not be cytologically typed
column10: recommending a viral serology study. The CT scan with intravenous contrast showed a homogeneous
column11: solid
column12: well-defined mass measuring 5x7 cm
column13: located in the left cervical vascular space
column14: compressing the left internal jugular vein
column15: behind the MCE
column16: with moderate contrast uptake and some adjacent lymphadenopathy. There was no hyperenhancement suggestive of carotid glomus. The radiological differential diagnosis included lymphoproliferative process
column17: neurogenic tumour or mesenchymal tumour.  Under general anaesthesia a left supraclavicular horizontal incision and section of the ECM muscle at this level was performed to obtain adequate exposure. A 5x7 cm tumour of congestive appearance was found
column18: hard with intense peripheral vascularisation that made its dissection difficult; the tumour presented a plane of separation with the vascular space. The clinical appearance at the time of surgery impressed the authors as a vascular tumour.  Pathological examination of the specimen revealed a lymph node with preserved architecture and a marked increase in the number of lymphoid follicles and positivity for immunohistochemical markers (CD20+CD10+
column19: bcl2-). Characteristically
column20: the germinal centres showed hyaline material
column21: some vessels and onion-layered arrangement of the lymphocyte crown.  The number of plasma cells (CD138) were in the normal range and showed no restriction for immunoglobulin light chains (kappa and lambda). The molecular study did not detect the presence of human herpes virus type 8 (HHV 8) by PCR. A thoraco-abdomino-pelvic CT scan was performed
column22: which was normal. Complete blood tests
column23: immunology and serology were normal. These findings represent the localised form of lymphoid angiofollicular hyperplasia or Castleman's disease
column24: hyaline-vascular variant.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 86-year-old patient consulted the maxillofacial surgery team at the San José Hospital Complex for an asymptomatic increase in volume
column2: of undetermined evolution in the anterior mandibular area. The patient had a personal history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes controlled by conventional medical treatment. She had no history of smoking or alcohol consumption. Physical examination revealed a large increase in volume in the anterior mandibular region of firm consistency and painful on palpation. The skin and mucosa overlying the lesion were normal
column3: with no associated lymphadenopathy. There was also no associated motor or sensory neurological involvement. A computed tomography (CT) scan was requested
column4: where axial images showed a hypodense lesion with a multilocular appearance extending from the region corresponding to the right canine area to the contralateral region corresponding to the left first molar
column5: which generated bulging
column6: thinning and perforation of bone tables. An incisional biopsy was scheduled and a drainage tube was installed in order to decompress the lesion.  Histopathological examination of the specimen revealed a cystic cavity lined by a parakeratinised poly-stratified epithelium with a basal stratum basale of ciliated cells with a hyperchromatic nucleus arranged in a palisade. Based on these findings the lesion was diagnosed as a keratocystic odontogenic tumour.  With this diagnosis it was decided to continue with decompressive therapy and to monitor the patient. After 2 weeks
column7: the patient presented pain and functional impotence that increased to the point of preventing her from eating 2 months after the drain had been installed. With this evolution
column8: a new CT scan was requested in which it was confirmed that the decompressive therapy was not fulfilling its objective
column9: as an increase in tissue involvement was observed as a result of the lesion
column10: in relation to the previous conditions
column11: presenting clear destruction of both vestibular and lingual bone tables. Three weeks after the decompression procedure
column12: and taking into account the new clinical and radiographic findings
column13: excision of the lesion was performed plus curettage and application of Carnoy's solution for 30 seconds on the operative site. The underlying bone defect was reconstructed using a mandibular reconstruction plate. The surgical specimen was sent for histopathological study
column14: which reported the presence of a cystic membrane with anaplastic epithelial tissue
column15: with loss of epithelial stratification
column16: cellular and nuclear pleomorphism
column17: loss of the nucleus/cytoplasm ratio
column18: prominent nucleoli
column19: among others. The neoplastic proliferation showed an infiltrative pattern towards the underlying connective tissue. In other areas of the sample
column20: nests and islets of epithelial proliferation were observed in the thickness of the cystic wall
column21: which showed the same anaplastic characteristics. Based on these histopathological findings
column22: a diagnosis of moderately differentiated intraosseous squamous cell carcinoma was made. In view of this diagnosis
column23: imaging tests were requested
column24: including chest X-ray
column25: total bone scan and bone scintigraphy
column26: which ruled out metastases and/or possible primary tumours. The patient was referred for oncological treatment and died of pneumonia.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 43-year-old woman from Bolivia who attended the Emergency Department of the Hospital de Navarra after presenting at home with a generalised convulsive seizure
column2: witnessed by family members
column3: with a subsequent confusional period and intense bilateral headache. Prior to the seizure
column4: one hour earlier
column5: she had had paresthesia in her right hand. She had no family history or personal history of interest. On physical examination
column6: he had normal pressure
column7: frequency and temperature constants and a Glasgow Glasgow Glasgow score of 15. No neurological focality was found. The patient was sweating
column8: with associated anxiety
column9: which was successfully resolved with 0.25 mg of alprazolam. The rest of the examination was normal and she did not present a new seizure. In the emergency department
column10: an ECG and chest X-ray were performed
column11: both of which were normal
column12: and blood tests with biochemistry
column13: haemogram and coagulation tests
column14: also within normal parameters. An urgent cranial CT scan was performed
column15: which revealed a 3 cm diameter cystic lesion in the left fronto-parietal region
column16: which did not capture contrast
column17: with nodular calcifications in its periphery. The patient was admitted to neurosurgery with a suspected diagnosis of NCC.  During his admission
column18: the study was completed with an electroencephalogram (EEG)
column19: which was normal
column20: a cranial MRI
column21: which confirmed the existence of cysticerci in the vesicular phase
column22: and an X-ray of the thigh
column23: with several small calcifications and morphology compatible with cysticerci. Treatment was started with dexamethasone
column24: albendazole and oxcarbazepine
column25: with good tolerance
column26: and he was discharged with the diagnosis of left rolandic epilepsy secondary to systemic cysticercosis and completed outpatient treatment for one month with albendazole
column27: maintaining the anti-epileptic treatment indefinitely
column28: without presenting new seizures.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 38-year-old woman
column2: primigravida at 40 weeks
column3: with a history of controlled gestational diabetes
column4: was admitted to hospital with arterial hypertension of 150/95 mmHg. She was treated with intravenous infusion of labetalol. After failure of induction of labour with prostaglandins
column5: she underwent caesarean section
column6: during which intense haemorrhage due to atony occurred
column7: leading to the decision to perform a subtotal hysterectomy. In a situation of intense haemodynamic instability and with signs of coagulopathy
column8: she was admitted to the intensive care unit
column9: where an abdomino-pelvic computerised tomography (CT) scan was performed
column10: which revealed a subcapsular hepatic haematoma measuring 6.7 × 15 × 19 cm with areas suggestive of recent bleeding
column11: compressing the right hepatic lobe. The patient's haemodynamics were stable
column12: with progressive reduction of the hepatic subcapsular haematoma according to the CT scan. A blood test revealed a decrease in haematocrit
column13: 18%; total bilirubin
column14: 5.1 mg/dl; GOT
column15: 815 U/l; and thrombocytopenia (55
column16: 000 platelets/ml)
column17: so a platelet transfusion was performed. Given the favourable clinical and ultrasound evolution
column18: it was decided to transfer the patient to the ward
column19: and the day before being discharged from the hospital
column20: 11 days after delivery
column21: while lying down and talking to her husband
column22: she began to feel unwell
column23: with a feeling of dyspnoea and loss of consciousness. After performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation manoeuvres
column24: the patient died and it was decided not to certify death due to sudden death in a stable patient. Autopsy findings The external examination revealed a very pale corpse with a slight lividity. The internal examination revealed - Haemoperitoneum of 950 cm3 of liquid blood. - Liver increased in size and weight
column25: weighing 2390 grams
column26: with a tear of Glisson's capsule in the upper portion of the anterior face of segments VII and VIII of the right lobe.  - Large subcapsular haematoma extending over almost the entire upper and posterior aspect of the right hepatic lobe
column27: measuring approximately 22 cm in longitudinal diameter
column28: 15 cm in transverse diameter and about 3 cm in maximum thickness. - Generalised visceral pallor. The entire liver was submitted for histopathological study
column29: revealing a very altered liver parenchyma with destruction of the normal architecture
column30: periportal and intraparenchymal necrosis
column31: and intrasinusoidal fibrin deposition. All findings are compatible with spontaneous liver rupture probably associated with HELLP syndrome.  The cause of death was therefore established as haemorrhagic shock secondary to spontaneous hepatic rupture caused by a subcapsular haematoma in the context of HELLP syndrome.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 80-year-old man came to the emergency department with a decrease in visual acuity (VA) in the right eye (OD) of 2 days' evolution. His medical history included: hypertension and dyslipidaemia under treatment
column2: chronic bronchitis and a transient ischaemic accident requiring antiplatelet therapy with aspirin. The ophthalmological examination in the emergency department was as follows. VA by OD: light perception (LP); by left eye (LO): 1; afferent pupillary defect of the LO 3+/4+; intraocular pressure of the LO: 16; LO: 17; biomicroscopy was normal and funduscopy showed a subretinal haemorrhage of 6 × 10 papillary diameters at the level of the posterior pole
column3: including the macular area.  An angiofluoresceingraphy (AFG) was performed
column4: confirming the subretinal location of this haemorrhage
column5: together with an inferior juxtafoveolar hyperfluorescent area at late times
column6: indicating the presence of a neovascular membrane (NVM) at that level.  Two days later
column7: 25 μg of r-TPA in a volume of 0.1 ml was injected intravitreally
column8: followed by a 0.3 ml injection of pure sulphur hexafluoride (SF6) and a 0.2 ml anterior chamber evacuation paracentesis. After 3 days
column9: he came for a check-up and it was observed that the blood had partially shifted from the posterior pole
column10: together with areas of fibrin.  One month after this procedure
column11: the patient was seen again with a VA of 0.05 and the funduscopy showed a decrease in the haemorrhage
column12: although the blood persisted in the macular area and fibrin in the lower area.  One month later
column13: the patient came for a check-up and funduscopy revealed a subretinal haemorrhage of similar extent to that seen at diagnosis
column14: so he was diagnosed with haemorrhagic AMD and a course of 3 doses of intravitreal ranibizumab was prescribed.  After the ranibizumab cycle
column15: he came to the hospital for a check-up and showed a VA of PL in the OD and 1 in the OI. Funduscopy revealed the presence of haemolithiasis that prevented adequate visualisation of the posterior pole structures. At the present time
column16: the patient is still under study to assess the next therapeutic step.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 25-year-old man
column2: with no personal history of interest
column3: consulted for a tumour in both testicles of two weeks' evolution. Physical examination: Hard mass occupying more than half of the left testicle. Right testicle increased in consistency
column4: especially in the posterior part. Complementary examinations: - Scrotal ultrasound: Solid tumour measuring 37x21 mm
column5: hypoechoic in the right testicle. Two solid lesions in the left teste measuring 32x17 mm and 7 mm with similar ultrasound characteristics to those found in the right teste. All compatible with bilateral multicentric testicular neoplasia. Left varicocele.  - Tumour markers: AFP: normal; ß-HCG: 6.15 mIU/ml (normal value: < 2.5 mIU/ml); LDH: normal. Surgical treatment: bilateral radical orchiectomy via the inguinal route. The patient ruled out the possibility of prosthesis placement. Histological diagnosis: seminoma with high mitotic index and vascular invasion (pT2) in both testicles (anaplastic seminoma).  Extension study (thoracoabdomino-pelvic CT): adenopathic growths at retroperitoneal level (N2) and hepatic metastatic lesions (M1). Complementary treatment: systemic chemotherapy with etoposide and cisplatin (4 cycles). Currently
column6: after 24 months of follow-up
column7: there are negative tumour markers with absence of retroperitoneal adenopathies and liver metastases (complete remission). The patient declined the possibility of semen freezing prior to radical surgery.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The forensic pathology department received the case of a 66-year-old woman with a history of arterial hypertension
column2: fibromyalgia and myasthenia gravis diagnosed 20 years previously. She was under chronic antihypertensive treatment with amlodipine (10 mg/24 h)
column3: furosemide (40 mg/24 h) and losartan postassium (50 mg/24 h)
column4: anxiolytic - antidepressant with duloxetine (30 mg/24 h) and amytriptyline hidorchloride (10 mg/24 h)
column5: treatment for osteoporosis with calcifediol (800 mg/24 h) and gastric protection with omeprazole (20 mg/24 h). One week before death
column6: she consulted the emergency department for catarrhal symptoms that were treated with ciprofloxacin and carbocisteine
column7: with improvement of the respiratory symptoms. Two days before his death
column8: he consulted the emergency department again because of general weakness
column9: which was attributed to the antibiotic treatment and the discontinuation of the treatment was indicated. There were no symptoms of headache and/or other symptoms of neurological focality in her clinical history. The patient died suddenly and her husband reported dyspnoea as the only symptom prior to death. During the autopsy the most remarkable findings were the following: Height of 149 cm
column10: weight of 80 kg and Body Mass Index of 36 kg/m2
column11: which corresponded to type II obesity. Other notable findings on external examination were hirsutism
column12: mid-thoracotomy scar as a consequence of thymectomy for the treatment of myasthenia gravis and oedema of the lower extremities. As external signs of violent cause
column13: a recent right buttock haematoma was found
column14: compatible with the fall she suffered during the perimortal period and with the sitting position on the floor in which she was found during the body removal. The most relevant findings of the internal examination were a coagulated haemopericardium of 200 g
column15: the heart weighed 400 g (expected weight 320 g) and we observed a 0.5 cm tear in the middle anterior part of the left ventricle due to transmural infarction secondary to coronary atheromatosis of the three vessels
column16: more marked in the middle third of the anterior descending artery where it obstructed the vascular lumen by more than 75%. In the skull
column17: the presence of internal frontal hyperostosis was notable
column18: less marked in the parietal area. The thickness of the unaffected diploe was 8 mm
column19: while in the areas of hyperostosis the thickness ranged from 1.5 mm to 2.3 mm. In addition
column20: multiple calcified meningiomas were found following the superior longitudinal sinus
column21: most of them nodular in shape and some of them smaller
column22: spiculated and plaque-like. At the cerebral level
column23: a slight depression of the surface of both frontal lobes was observed.  The rest of the autopsy findings were not significant and the results of the toxicological analysis were negative. The histopathological study was concordant with the macroscopic data of internal frontal hyperostosis and the meningiomas were calcified psammomatous.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 43-year-old mixed-race woman of mixed race with a history of augmentation mammoplasty performed in June 2009: periareolar incision
column2: transglandular dissection
column3: subfascial pocket
column4: placement of 290 cc anatomical textured cohesive gel implants (McGhan® Medical Corporation
column5: Santa Barbara
column6: California
column7: USA). Aspirative drains were placed and removed 24 hours after surgery. The postoperative period was uneventful and the result was satisfactory. One year after the procedure
column8: the patient presented discomfort and oedema in the right breast which subsided with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs at a dose of 120 mg per day for 7 days. The subsequent evolution was satisfactory until 2015
column9: i.e. 5 years after these symptoms and 6 years after the intervention
column10: when the patient again presented discomfort and oedema in the right breast
column11: as well as the appearance of galactorrhoea. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) studies were performed
column12: documenting the presence of abundant periprosthetic fluid in the affected breast.  In view of the situation
column13: an ultrasound-guided puncture was performed
column14: obtaining 270 cc of serous material
column15: without detritus inside
column16: dark yellow in colour and without characteristic odour. A sample was sent for cytological study
column17: which reported chronic mastitis with granulomatous reaction and negative culture. However
column18: the gradual enlargement of the breast continued in the following months
column19: and 2 new punctures were performed without success. In the second puncture
column20: fluid was again sent for malignancy study due to the suspicion of a possible ductal carcinoma. The patient was re-evaluated by ultrasound and MRI imaging studies
column21: but no abnormalities were found in the breast parenchyma
column22: so it was decided to remove the implant
column23: with capsulectomy and revision of the breast tissue by means of a trans-operative biopsy. The surgery was performed in conjunction with an oncological surgeon
column24: who examined the mammary gland and took samples from the different quadrants. The trans-operative and definitive study of both the sent breast tissue and the periprosthetic capsule was negative for malignancy. However
column25: the periprosthetic fluid evacuated during surgery was positive for neoplastic cells in the cytological study. This fluid was also studied by cell block preparation and processed by histology and immunohistochemistry. The latter obtained a positive result for LACG
column26: immunophenotype T
column27: positive for CD 45
column28: CD3
column29: CD 30 and EMA (epithelial membrane antigen)
column30: negative for CKAE1/AE3 (cytokeratin)
column31: CD 20 and ALK (anaplastic lymphocyte kinase) and a proliferation index of 80%.  The haematology department proposed a positron emission tomography (PET) scan
column32: but the patient decided not to continue with the staging studies despite the final diagnosis of lymphoma
column33: and to date has refused to follow any type of treatment
column34: not even the removal of the contralateral implant. She is currently (May 2016) asymptomatic.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 75-year-old man with a history of hyperuricaemia treated with Allopurinol was admitted for transurethral resection of the prostate. Immediate postoperative period was uneventful with treatment with Pantoprazole
column2: Ciprofloxacin
column3: Paracetamol
column4: Enantyum and Allopurinol. On the fourth postoperative day he presented dizziness
column5: tremor with a myoclonic component in the limbs and trunk and inability to walk
column6: with no laboratory alterations. In this situation
column7: Rivotril was prescribed and treatment with Ciprofloxacin was discontinued
column8: the myoclonic symptoms disappeared and the patient's condition improved
column9: and he was discharged from hospital.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 9-year-old male presented after a traffic accident with a complex post-traumatic defect in the left foot and ankle including a 7 x 10 cm loss of substance with exposure of the tibial malleolus
column2: talus and subtalar joint
column3: section of the posterior tibial tendon and long flexor tendon of the toes and avulsion of the tibial nerve and posterior tibial artery with a defect of 5 cm. The foot remains vascularised through the anterior tibial artery.  After the relevant debridement of devitalised tissue
column4: reconstruction of the defect was considered 5 days after the trauma
column5: by repairing the affected tendons
column6: reconstructing the tibial nerve with sural nerve grafts and covering the defect with an ALM perforator flap. Preoperatively a 7 x 10 cm flap is designed on the left thigh based on a localised perforator with Doppler. After a standard subfascial dissection of the flap following the description made by Wei et al. (4)
column7: we located a perforator with a very long intramuscular course and small diameter; it was then decided to explore proximally the transverse branch of the lateral femoral circumflex artery (LFA) in order to look for a better perforator. A larger caliber perforator is located at that level and the flap is redesigned to become a TFL perforator flap
column8: drawing a skin island more proximally with centre at the new perforator; the lateral femorocutaneous nerve of the thigh is included in the flap to provide sensation. After repair of the tibial nerve with 3 sural nerve grafts of 5cm each
column9: transfer and fixation of the flap is performed. Anastomoses are made termino-terminally to the posterior tibial artery and to two veins
column10: a posterior tibial comitant vein and the great saphenous vein. The lateral femorocutaneous nerve of the flap is connected termino-laterally to the proximal end of the tibial nerve. Finally
column11: a direct closure of the donor site is performed. The total operative time was 7 hours and 30 minutes. The postoperative period was uneventful and the patient was discharged from hospital 18 days after surgery.  The physiotherapy programme started from the first postoperative week
column12: with partial foot support (with the aid of crutches and a protective splint) one month after surgery and full foot support for ambulation at 6 weeks. At 4 months after surgery the foot contour was adequate
column13: allowing the patient to wear normal footwear
column14: with a range of ankle mobility of 45º of plantar flexion and 15º of dorsal flexion and a protective sensitivity (detected with monofilament test) of the plantar and flap.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 60-year-old male with a personal history of ischaemic heart disease (he suffered an acute myocardial infarction in 2004) and is a former smoker. The patient had no known drug or food allergies. In July 2008 he was diagnosed with primary amyloidosis and nephrotic syndrome. On discharge from hospital
column2: he received nutritional recommendations from the nephrology department to follow a low-sodium and low-fat diet and to exclude protein foods. To this end
column3: the patient had to cook all food
column4: not use table salt
column5: and could not use any other cooking techniques (frying
column6: grilling
column7: roasting
column8: microwaving
column9: etc.)
column10: as well as not eating the second courses (meat
column11: fish and eggs). The pharmacological treatment she is currently receiving is omeprazole
column12: candesartan
column13: enalapril
column14: atorvastatin
column15: acetylsalicylic acid
column16: ezetimibe
column17: furosemide
column18: barnidipine and spironolactone. She attended the diet therapy consultation to establish a diet adjusted to her nutritional needs. At the initial consultation
column19: a nutritional history was taken
column20: including a complete anthropometric assessment
column21: biochemistry and analysis of intake through a 3-day dietary survey analysed with the Dietsource 3.0 ®Nestlé Healthcare Nutrition software (2005 Edition). The baseline intake characteristics are shown in table I
column22: together with the nutritional recommendations for the patient with nephrotic syndrome: restrictive diet in protein
column23: salt and lipid profile rich in monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fatty acids3 . The following results were obtained in the initial examination:  - Anthropometry: weight 86.7 kg
column24: height 171 cm
column25: BMI 29.65 kg/m2. Body composition was measured by bioelectrical impedance (TANITA TBF 300®): 56.1 litres of water (64.7%)
column26: 76.6 kg of lean mass (88.4%) and 10.1 kg of fat mass (11.6%). The patient had oedema with pitting up to the knees. - CBC: Creatinine: 0.95 (normal values 0.5-1.1) mg/dL
column27: Glomerular Filtration: > 60 ml/min/1.72 m2
column28: P: 3.31 (normal values 2.5-4.5) mg/dL
column29: K: 4.23 (normal values 3.6-5) mmol/L
column30: Total Protein: 3.8 (normal values 6.2 - 8) gr/dL. Albumin: 1.74 (normal values 3.5-5) gr/dL and prealbumin: 20 (normal values 10-40) g/dL. Proteinuria: 14.55 g/24h. Total cholesterol: 180 (normal values 100-200) mg/dL
column31: Triglycerides: 110 (normal values 50-150) mg/dL
column32: HDL: 44 mg/dL (normal values 40-65)
column33: LDL: 68.8 mg/dL
column34: Uric acid: 7.23 mg/dL (normal values 2.4-7). A diet was prepared in accordance with the recommendations3
column35: according to the patient's characteristics
column36: tastes
column37: habits and schedules. The nutritional characteristics of the diet are shown in table I and the diet calibrated for the patient in table II.  After six months on the diet
column38: the patient presented the following data: Anthropometry: weight 79.4 kg
column39: BMI 27.15 kg/m2. Body composition measured with the same technique as at the initial visit indicated 46.5 litres of water (58.6%)
column40: 63.5 kg of lean mass (80.0%) and 15.9 kg of fat mass (20.0%). Oedema had decreased and was present only in the perimalleolar area. CBC: Creatinine: 1.58 mg/100
column41: Glomerular filtration rate: 48 ml/min/1.72 m2. P: 4.4 mg/dL and K: 5.37 mmol/L. Total protein: 4.8 g/L
column42: albumin: 3.15 mg/dL and prealbumin: 36.9 mg/dL. Proteinuria: 2.1 g/24h. Total cholesterol: 140 mg/dL
column43: Triglycerides: 88 mg/dL
column44: HDL: 64 mg/dL
column45: LDL: 58.4 mg/dL
column46: Uric acid: 10.75 mg/dL. Dietary adherence: Dietary intake was collected in a 24-hour recall and analysed with the same software as at the baseline visit. The data are shown in table I. At present the patient continues with the prescribed diet and continues to attend the diet therapy consultation bimonthly.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male patient aged 29 years. He was referred to our department to complete the study because
column2: after the appearance of a painless tumour in his left testicle for a month
column3: an ultrasound scan revealed a hypogenic left testicle of reduced size
column4: and a right testicle with heterogeneous parenchyma suspicious of neoplasia. He had no other urological symptoms
column5: no asthenia
column6: no weight loss. He also had no personal history of interest. Physical examination revealed a hypotrophic left teste and a slightly enlarged right teste. Both were painless
column7: of normal consistency and regular surface. Epididymis and cords with no pathological findings. Laboratory tests showed haemostasis
column8: biochemistry and haemogram within normal parameters
column9: and an alpha-fetoprotein of 2.7ng/ml with a beta-hCG of 4.2mIUI/ml. On admission
column10: a new Doppler flow ultrasound was performed and revealed: a right teste measuring 49mm x 36mm x 26mm with a hypoechoic lesion
column11: with lobulated edges
column12: heterogeneous
column13: occupying practically the entire testicle
column14: and with increased Doppler flow. And a 32mm x 22mm x 20mm hetrogenic left teste with a slightly hypoechoic focal lesion of approximately 9mm with subtle Doppler flow. In addition
column15: bilateral testicular microlithiasis. A chest X-ray was also performed
column16: which showed no pathological findings
column17: and a thoraco-abdominal-pelvic CT scan with contrast
column18: where no adenopathies or metastases were identified in any of the territories visualised. With the diagnosis of bilateral testicular tumour
column19: a bilateral orchiectomy via the inguinal route was performed and she was prescribed hormone replacement therapy. The pathological anatomy reported: atrophic left testicle with multiple microscopic foci of classic seminoma associated with large areas of intratubular germ cell neoplasia (IGCT) with no tumour infiltration in the albuginea
column20: rete testis
column21: epididymis or vascular infiltration. The right testicle presents tumour with characteristics of classic seminoma that occupies practically the entire parenchyma
column22: associated with foci of intratubular germ cell neoplasia (IGCT) and foci of atrophy in the remaining testicle. Tunica albuginea
column23: rete testis
column24: epididymis and surgical edge free of tumour. Treatment was completed with two cycles of chemotherapy with carboplatin according to hospital protocol. He has now been in complete remission for more than three years.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient is a 38-year-old male who came to the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Department of the Hospital Universitari Vall d'Hebron
column2: referred from another centre
column3: due to a mandibular tumour that had been present for 1 year.  His pathological history included being a former injecting drug addict
column4: HCV positive and HIV positive on antiretroviral treatment. On examination
column5: there was a right mandibular tumour approximately 5 cm in size
column6: fixed and hard in consistency
column7: and the oral mucosa remained intact. The orthopantomography showed a mixed lesion with calcifications in its interior affecting the right hemimandible.  The CT scan showed an expansive mixed lesion in the body of the right mandible that destroyed the cortices measuring 4.5x3x3.3 cm.  The biopsy performed showed a calcifying epithelial odontogenic tumour. The patient underwent a right hemimandibulectomy with microsurgical reconstruction with fibula.  Pathological anatomy revealed a mass measuring 4 x 2.5 cm with an irregular surface
column8: heterogeneous appearance
column9: congestive areas and remnants of teeth
column10: which confirmed the diagnosis of calcifying epithelial odontogenic tumour of the mandible infiltrating periosteal soft tissues. The mentonian nerve showed no invasion and the intraoperative biopsy of the left facial chain lymph node showed no metastasis.  Postoperative evolution was favourable and he was discharged on a tolerated diet and with wound control in outpatient clinics.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 55-year-old patient who was referred to our chronic pain unit for low back pain of more than 2 years' duration. The patient had undergone surgery 17 years earlier for the implantation of a mitral valve prosthesis and since then had presented periprosthetic leakage
column2: with mild haemolysis
column3: on treatment with iron
column4: folic acid and anticoagulated with anticoagulants. The subject reported continuous baseline pain in the lower back
column5: of mild intensity
column6: with a score of 3 on the visual analogue scale
column7: with exacerbations up to a score of 8
column8: predominantly at night and almost daily. The pain was located in the dorsolumbar area with irradiation towards the inguinogenital area
column9: more pronounced on the right side
column10: but affecting both sides. The duration of these episodes varied from minutes to hours
column11: with the patient comparing it to a burning sensation and stiffness. There was discrete improvement with exercise. He reported no other symptoms
column12: such as paresthesia or sleep disturbances. On examination
column13: he had no limitation of spinal mobility
column14: mild pain on flexion and negative arc sign
column15: and non-painful palpation of the spinous processes. Trigger points were identified in the paravertebral area
column16: most relevant in the musculature corresponding to the right quadratus lumborum muscle; tests for involvement of the psoas and the right sacroiliac joint were positive. There was no sensory impairment. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the dorsolumbar muscle spine reported "polydiscopathy with degenerative changes at L4-L5
column17: L5-S1 (decreased T2 signal intensity of the discs)
column18: no significant disc imprints over the spinal canal and signs of dorsolumbar interapophyseal arthrosis". Haemoglobin was 10 g/dl. The estimated clinical judgement was dorsalgia and low back pain secondary to a myofascial syndrome and degenerative polydiscopathy. Medical treatment was started with pregabalin
column19: tramadol and paracetamol; he received transcutaneous electrotherapy. Corticosteroid and local anaesthetic infiltration of the trigger points corresponding to the right lumbar quadratus lumborum muscle and bilateral lumbar facets was performed; none of the therapeutic measures improved the low back pain. He was then treated with transcutaneous fentanyl; the patient noted a slight improvement. The subject was re-evaluated after 3 months of treatment. Blood tests showed an increase in haemolysis parameters: decrease in haemoglobin (9.6 g/dl)
column20: haemoglobinuria 250 erythrocytes/field
column21: elevated lactodehydrogenase (LDH 4
column22: 806 U/l) and total bilirubin 4.38 mg/dl. Echocardiography showed ventricular dilatation and severe mitral stenosis with perivalvular leak and elevated pressure gradient. The patient was referred to the cardiovascular surgeon and underwent surgery to replace the malfunctioning prosthetic valve. After the operation
column23: one year later
column24: the patient remains free of low back pain.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 35-year-old woman consulted for poor visual acuity (VA) since childhood
column2: without treatment. Examination revealed yellowish hair
column3: eyebrows and eyelashes; reddish skin
column4: no nevi; corrected visual acuity of 20/400 (-9.50 -5.50 x 135º) in the right eye (OD) and 20/200 (-6.50 -5.50 x 20º) in the left eye (OI); exotropia of 50 dioptres
column5: horizontal nystagmus; both eyes (AO) with intraocular pressure of 12 mmHg
column6: normal conjunctiva
column7: cornea with some well circumscribed central and anterior whitish stromal deposits
column8: anterior chamber without cells or flare
column9: clear iris with transillumination
column10: clear crystalline lens and foveal hypoplasia. Based on the ocular and systemic clinical data
column11: the diagnoses of AOC and DG were established and the family was referred for clinical evaluation.  This is a family of nine members
column12: with parents aged 74 and 64 years. There is no consanguinity and they come from different localities. GD is present in the mother
column13: three siblings and their son
column14: while AOC is present in two of the siblings but with no GD data.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 15-year-old female patient presents at the Maxillofacial Surgery Department of the San Borja Arriarán Hospital Complex with painless right facial asymmetry
column2: which has progressively evolved over time without any other symptoms. During the interview
column3: the patient reported no history of morbidities or surgery. Nor does she report any habitual use of drugs or allergies. No type of parafunction was detected. On extraoral examination there is an increase in volume in the region of the right mandibular angle with poorly defined limits. On palpation it was firm
column4: painless and showed no signs of inflammation or submandibular or cervical lymph node involvement. No pathological signs or symptoms are detected in the TMJ examination.  The intraoral examination showed nothing relevant in relation to the soft tissues
column5: teeth and occlusion. Salivary secretion was normal
column6: especially in relation to the Stenon's ducts. A panoramic X-ray was requested
column7: showing a much more marked right mandibular angle. The lateral skull X-ray showed a double mandibular contour and the frontal teleradiography showed that the right mandibular sector was more developed
column8: with no impact on the occlusal plane. In addition
column9: bone scintigraphy was performed to rule out condylar hyperplasia and electromyography.  The diagnosis was unilateral right maseterine hypertrophy
column10: so it was decided to resect the right mandibular angle extraorally. Under general anaesthesia
column11: a right mandibular subangle access was performed until the ipsilateral angle was exposed. The angle and a portion of the masseter muscle were resected. A biopsy of the excised muscle was performed and the report did not reveal any pathological tissue condition. The patient was monitored immediately after the operation and showed no complications. After 6 years
column12: the patient is in good condition with no recurrence.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 57-year-old patient with repeated hospital admissions for epigastralgia accompanied by minimal elevations of amylase. The patient was diagnosed with prostatic adenoma. He reported epigastric pain and abdominal distension during meals that forced him to stop eating. On three occasions the patient attended the emergency department. Only a slight elevation of amylase (155 IU
column2: normal < 100) was observed. In an attempt to reach a diagnosis
column3: a trancutaneous abdominal ultrasound
column4: gastroscopy
column5: colonoscopy and abdominal CT scan were performed. All tests were normal. Finally
column6: a magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) was performed. Only the common bile duct and Wirsung's duodenum were found to lead separately into the duodenal wall. Initially it was interpreted as a variant of normality that can occur in up to 24% of normal subjects (1). However
column7: given the disabling symptoms (the patient reported epigastralgia with almost every meal)
column8: it was suggested that an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) be performed. There was a history of allergy to iodinated contrasts
column9: so glucocorticoid prophylaxis was performed. On endoscopic imaging the papilla had a flaccid appearance. The bile duct was deeply cannulated and a 0.025-inch guidewire was introduced to ensure access to the common bile duct. The introduction of contrast for cholangiopancreatography was performed from the same papillary orifice. During injection the papilla showed a distension visible on the endoscopic image and appeared as a cystic structure on cholangiography. The Wirsung was also drawn during the contrast injection but emptied immediately and was therefore not reflected on the radiographs. The diagnosis of choledochococele was made and it was sectioned by biliary sphincterotomy. The patient had no complications from the endoscopic intervention and the pain during swallowing has not reappeared after two years of follow-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 29 year old patient was referred to our clinic following pain in the right teste 3 months earlier
column2: which subsided with anti-inflammatory treatment. One month later he had a new episode of pain in the right testicle which was diagnosed as orchiepididymitis but which did not resolve with medical treatment. His only personal history was an allergy to sulphonamides. No urological history of interest. Physical examination revealed a painless tumour in the posteroinferior pole of the right teste. Suspicion of a testicular tumour led to a complete blood analysis with tumour markers and a testicular ultrasound scan
column3: the results of which showed AFP 36.4 ng/ml and Beta-hCG 4.2 mIU/ml. The ultrasound showed a 23 mm tumour in the lower pole of the right testicle with non-cystic characteristics suspicious of neoplasia. The patient underwent a radical right inguinal orchiectomy and the pathological anatomy revealed a 2 cm mixed germ cell tumour formed by embryonal carcinoma and foci of teratoma. No vascular or lymphatic invasion. Albuginea
column4: spermatic cord and epididymis free of tumour. As it was a Stage I Non Seminomatous Germinal Tumour
column5: it was decided by mutual agreement with the patient not to receive adjuvant treatment with chemotherapy and to follow a strict observational control. The patient underwent periodic check-ups according to our hospital protocol and remained free of disease in the imaging techniques
column6: clinically and analytically for 7 and a half years until a control ultrasound study detected microcalcifications in the left testicle with a single hypoechoic nodule measuring 7 mm x 9 mm
column7: also with calcifications and no increase in Doppler flow
column8: which was compatible with a testicular tumour. A left varicocele was also observed. Physical examination was unremarkable and tumour markers were normal. After left inguinal orchiectomy
column9: the pathological anatomy reports a 0.5 cm seminoma infiltrating the capsule of the atrophic testicle with extensive intratubular germ cell neoplasia. No vascular or lymphatic infiltration. Treatment was completed with chemotherapy and hormone replacement therapy. Currently she has been disease free for 4 years.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 74-year-old man presented to the emergency department with hypogastric pain
column2: fever and dysuria of 48 hours' duration. His personal history included hypertension treated with captopril
column3: hyperlipidaemia treated with atorvastatin and hyperuricaemia treated with allopurinol. Physical examination revealed a palpable
column4: painful
column5: large mass occupying the hypogastrium and both iliac fossae. Blood tests showed 25
column6: 930 leukocytes with a marked left shift and urinary sediment analysis showed 3-5 leukocytes/field
column7: microhaematuria with positive nitrites in the dipstick. An abdominal ultrasound was requested
column8: which revealed a possible abscess in the hypogastrium measuring 15 x 9.2 x 7.3 cm. The study was completed with an abdominal-pelvic CT scan showing an image with a liquid level measuring 15 x 9 x 9 x 8 cm in the hypogastrium
column9: above the bladder dome
column10: in close relation to the ileocecal area
column11: compatible with an abscess added to a benign or malignant neoformative process in the area.  With the diagnostic hypothesis of an infected urachal cyst
column12: percutaneous drainage was performed and samples were taken for microbiology and broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotic therapy was started. Serial cultures isolated Leuconostoc spp
column13: Streptococcus intermedius
column14: Clostridium perfringens
column15: Escherichia coli
column16: Bacteroides ovatus
column17: Corynebacterium spp. and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. During admission
column18: the study was completed with a new CT scan
column19: which provided no new information with respect to the previous one; opaque enema
column20: which provided no information on the origin of the symptoms; colonoscopy
column21: which showed no alteration at the colonic level; and cystoscopy
column22: in which the bladder mucosa was observed to be intact. Once the study was completed
column23: an exploratory laparotomy of the lesion was decided. After performing a median laparotomy
column24: an independent bladder mass was observed
column25: intensely adhered to the intestinal loops and cecum.  It was excised and accidentally opened
column26: with mucoid material coming out
column27: which was sent for intraoperative anatomical-pathological study
column28: ruling out malignancy. An ilio-ceco-appendicular lymphadenectomy was then performed (with an intraoperative freezing diagnosis of absence of malignancy) and segmental appendico-cecal resection. The final pathological diagnosis was appendicular mucinous cystadenoma (mucocele). The postoperative period was favourable
column29: except for infection of the surgical wound
column30: and the patient was discharged one month after the operation. The patient lived an independent life and was asymptomatic until one year after surgery
column31: when he died of sudden cardiac death.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 67-year-old man was admitted to the internal medicine department for constitutional syndrome
column2: anaemia and a mass on the right flank. Personal history of interest includes: cerebrovascular accident in the middle cerebral territory
column3: secondary to atrial fibrillation at 64 years of age; chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; regular treatment with oral dicoumarinics and amiodarone. The patient presented with anorexia
column4: asthenia
column5: and a weight loss of 12 kilograms in 4 months. Twenty days prior to admission
column6: sudden pain began in the flank and right renal fossa. The urological history was normal. Physical examination revealed a painful mass in the right hemiabdomen. The rest of the examination was unremarkable. Laboratory tests showed normocytic and normochromic anaemia (haemoglobin 10.6) and prolonged ESR; biochemical
column7: urinary and tumour marker tests were normal. Abdominal ultrasound showed a right renal mass with a mixed ultrasound pattern measuring 17 x 13 centimetres in diameter
column8: with an extraparenchymal area compatible with haematoma. The full body computed axial tomography (C.A.T.) showed a predominantly solid mixed mass in the upper pole of the right kidney
column9: with probable infiltration of the psoas muscle; no adenopathy or vascular thrombosis was observed. Prior to surgery
column10: and given the large size of the tumour mass
column11: arteriography was performed
column12: selectively embolising the renal artery by means of colis. Three days later
column13: radical nephrectomy was performed via the anterior approach
column14: revealing a large tumour mass dependent on the right kidney
column15: which did not affect the psoas muscle.  Histologically
column16: macroscopically
column17: a tumour mass of 10 centimetres in diameter was observed that affected perirenal fat without affecting the excretory or venous systems. Microscopically it is a very undifferentiated malignant renal spindle cell tumour
column18: Fuhrman grade 4 sarcomatoid type
column19: with perirenal infiltration but with no involvement of the excretory or venous systems; pT3 G3 N0 M0. After surgery
column20: the patient evolved favourably and was discharged on the tenth post-operative day.  At the first check-up
column21: six months after the operation
column22: the control CT scan showed two heterogeneous cystic masses in the retroperitoneal space; the first was adjacent to the psoas muscle and was about 12 centimetres in diameter
column23: with probable infiltration of the liver and ascending colon; the second was 10 centimetres in diameter adjacent to the psoas muscle. Fine needle aspiration puncture (F.N.A.P.) with ultrasound was performed and the result was renal carcinoma metastasis. The full-body bone scan showed no evidence of metastatic lesions.  72 hours after the P.A.A.A.F. the patient presented dizziness
column24: abdominal distension and anaemia
column25: and a blood test was carried out
column26: showing a loss of 5 g/dl of haemoglobin with respect to discharge. The CT scan at that time showed a large retroperitoneal mass
column27: with an intense haemorrhagic component. Exploratory laparotomy was performed
column28: evacuating the retroperitoneal haematoma
