column29: and excising the haemorrhagic cystic tumour
column30: adhered to the caudate lobe of the liver
column31: which in the intraoperative biopsy was reported as a high-grade malignant fusocellular tumour
column32: partially cystic
column33: compatible with recurrence of renal tumour
column34: the post-operative evolution of the patient presented a new retroperitoneal haematoma.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The second case is that of a 10-year-old girl who was referred from another centre for low vision with no apparent organic cause. The patient presented a report showing a visual acuity of 0.01 in both eyes with a refraction under cycloplegia of +1.00. All ophthalmological examinations were normal. The complementary tests presented visual evoked potentials (VEP)
column2: electroretinogram (ERG)
column3: angiofluoresceingraphy (AFG)
column4: computerised axial tomography (CAT)
column5: magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) also showed no alteration. Given the suspicion of simulation
column6: we investigated the patient's family
column7: school and social situation. She was the youngest of 4 siblings
column8: with a large age difference
column9: and in recent months she had begun to behave badly
column10: with low grades at school
column11: difficulty integrating with her classmates and
column12: in addition
column13: a sprain that forced her to use crutches. It was decided to carry out the lens confusion test: a +6.00 lens was placed in a trial frame and then progressively neutralised with negative lenses. Monocular VA was 0.8 and 0.6
column14: respectively; and 0.8 in binocular vision. Stereopsis values were normal
column15: 40". The parents were reassured about the child's condition and she was referred back to her referral centre for follow-up and monitoring.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 58-year-old patient of sub-Saharan origin came to the emergency department with sweating and fever with left lumbar pain
column2: heaviness in the left flank and dysuria for about 15 days. His personal history did not include any significant pathology: No DM. No hypertension. No known allergies. Former smoker for 8 years. No haematuria. No colic. No UTIs. He reports that in the last two weeks he has had occasional fever
column3: sweating
column4: heaviness in the left flank with lumbar pain on the same side and voiding symptoms with an acceptable urinary stream
column5: dysuria
column6: not shortness of breath
column7: no dribbling
column8: no urgency with night-time voiding once and daytime voiding every 3-4 hours with a feeling of complete emptiness. Physical examination revealed an abdominal mass effect in the left flank on deep palpation. Rectal examination showed a grade I-II prostate without suspicious lesions. Complementary tests showed: normal haemogram with signs of eosinophilia. Normal biochemistry. Other normal
column9: negative urine analysis. X-ray of the genito-urinary tract showed a mass effect in the left flank that blurred the psoas line on that side. Renal ultrasound: multiple cysts in the left kidney. Abdominopelvic CT scan: cystic lesions with daughter vesicles
column10: compatible with renal hydatid disease.  Echinococcus/Hemag antibody serology was requested
column11: which was POSITIVE at figures above 1/2.621.440. The study was completed with MRI to obtain a more complete iconography and to assess relations with adjacent structures. In view of the suspected diagnosis
column12: surgery was decided on the affected renal unit
column13: it being impossible to perform conservative surgery during the surgical procedure and the patient underwent a complete left nephroureterectomy due to suspicion of communication of the hydatid cyst with the duct due to the thickness of the duct. Prior to surgical treatment
column14: the patient received a course of Albendazole and another after surgery. After treatment
column15: the patient's antibody titration figures fell and three years after the procedure the patient is asymptomatic and analytically free of disease.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 9-year-old boy
column2: with no past history of interest
column3: reported myodesopsias of two days' evolution in the left eye. Ophthalmological examination in the emergency department revealed: visual acuity (VA) in the left eye (LA) 1. Biomicroscopy showed mild anterior uveitis and a funduscopic image of a focus of active chorioretinitis at a diameter of the papilla. Given the characteristics of the focus and its location
column4: a diagnosis of toxoplasmic chorioretinitis was made and treatment was prescribed with oral sulphadiazine
column5: pyrimethamine and folinic acid at doses adjusted per kg of body weight. After 9 days of treatment
column6: the patient returned to the emergency department with fever of 39º C
column7: papulo-erythematous rash on the chest
column8: back and face
column9: vesicles on the oral mucosa
column10: pneumonitis and balanitis. Ophthalmology showed bilateral upper hyposphagma
column11: membranous conjunctivitis with an exudative component and superficial keratopathy in both eyes. Blood culture
column12: hepato-renal profile
column13: oral mucosal smear for viruses
column14: herpes and mycoplasma serology were requested. All results were negative and serology for toxoplasma was IgG>500
column15: IgM negative. In view of the suspicion of JSS secondary to sulphadiazine
column16: all medication for ocular toxoplasmosis was immediately withdrawn and regular check-ups of the ocular fundus were performed
column17: which evolved towards spontaneous healing without complications. From the day of admission he required exhaustive skin and oral mucosal care
column18: parenteral nutrition and analgesia with intravenous (i.v.) morphine hydrochloride. Subsequently
column19: methylprednisolone 1 mg/kg/day i.v. was added
column20: decreasing the regimen until discharge. Ophthalmologically
column21: he was prescribed preservative-free artificial tears such as sodium hyaluronate every _ hour
column22: lubricating ointment at night
column23: rifamycin eye drops and dexamethasone every 4 hours to reduce mucosinequiant changes. Symblepharon-lysis is performed every 12 hours of initially very exudative
column24: abundant and easily extractable membranes and later more adherent
column25: fibrous and requiring scarification to remove them. After 3 weeks of treatment
column26: residual hyposphagma
column27: thickening of the semilunar fold of the inner canthus
column28: keratinisation with thickening of the free edge and slight shortening of the lower fornix were observed. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Patient H.V.P.D.
column2: 16 years old
column3: presented with the main complaint of difficulty in phonation. During the physical examination
column4: it was observed that the patient presented with tall stature
column5: facial pattern III
column6: with severe maxillary hypoplasia
column7: dental crowding
column8: Angle class III relationship
column9: anterior open bite
column10: bifid uvula and macroglossia. On collecting data during the anamnesis
column11: it was also revealed that
column12: at birth
column13: the patient had an abdominal wall defect which was subsequently corrected. All these findings contributed to the formation of the diagnosis of Beckwith-Wiedmann syndrome.  The patient was incorporated to orthosurgical treatment
column14: being observed swallowing problems
column15: phonation and breathing difficulties
column16: with strong correlation with macroglossia. Therefore
column17: a partial glossectomy surgical procedure was planned for this case
column18: prior to the orthognathic surgery procedure. The technique used was that proposed by Obwegeser et al. (1964)10
column19: in which the central segment and the apex of the tongue were resected
column20: thereby reducing its dimensions in the anteroposterior and transverse directions
column21: so that the problems related to speech were attenuated. For adequate control of transoperative bleeding and ease of execution
column22: the surgery was performed under general anaesthesia with orotracheal intubation
column23: due to the presence of hypertrophy of the nasal turbinates that prevented the passage of the nasotracheal tube. To make the incisions
column24: repair points were established with 2.0 cotton thread at the lateral and anterior extremities of the tongue and an Allis type tissue grasping forceps were used to assist in the dissection. After stabilisation
column25: demarcation of the incision with methylene blue and infiltrations of local anaesthetic (lidocaine 2% with epinephrine 1:200
column26: 000) were performed. Removal of the demarcated segment was performed with an electric surgical dissector (colrado needle
column27: Stryker Corporation®) in the apex-base direction
column28: preserving the lateral edges and minimising the risk of injury to the branches of the lingual nerve. The segment was removed and careful haemostasis was performed to minimise the risks of lingual haematoma and postoperative bleeding. After bleeding control
column29: the segments were approximated with resorbable thread (Vicryl 3.0-ETHICON) from the deepest to the superficial portion in a thorough base-to-apex approach. In the immediate postoperative period it was already possible to verify the anterior and transverse reduction of the tongue without compromising the airway
column30: and without any complications of a haemorrhagic or infectious nature. Ten days postoperatively
column31: the patient started speech therapy to help the return of tongue motility and phonation. Currently
column32: the patient is 3 years postoperative and has a considerable decrease in the size of the tongue in the transverse and longitudinal direction
column33: with no reports of sensory or gustatory loss in the region. He is undergoing phonoaudiological and orthodontic treatment with the aim of carrying out a surgical procedure to correct the maxillomandibular discrepancy.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This patient
column2: daughter of patient no. 3
column3: was the subject of a biochemical and radiological screening study at the age of 14 years. Hypocalcaemia
column4: hyperparathyroidism
column5: two maxillary tumours (second and fourth quadrants) and several renal cysts were found Right parathyroidectomy was performed to treat a parathyroid adenoma. Calcaemia remained normal for one year
column6: but started to increase thereafter. The patient underwent further surgery (left upper and lower parathyroidectomy and excision of half of the right upper parathyroid for a left upper parathyroid adenoma). The maxillary lesions continued to grow and a few months later the two ossifying fibromas were resected.  She subsequently had another episode of hyperparathyroidism and underwent surgery to resect the adenoma of the remaining gland. There is no evidence of recurrence or the development of new maxillary tumours.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 57-year-old woman
column2: under medication for depression and high blood pressure
column3: was found dead at home. Four days earlier
column4: she had consulted an emergency department for non-specific abdominal pain and started treatment with anti-inflammatory drugs. Autopsy findings: apart from obesity (BMI 34.9 kg/m2)
column5: the only significant finding was that the gallbladder was markedly distended and enlarged
column6: containing a large gallstone (4.5 x 2.5 cm) impacted in the gallbladder neck. The gallbladder wall was thickened and the mucosa hyperemic with focal haemorrhage. No purulent exudate
column7: perforation
column8: abscess
column9: fistula or peritonitis was observed. The cystic and common bile ducts were patent. Toxicological analysis detected benzodiazepines
column10: mianserin
column11: ibuprofen and ketoprofen at therapeutic concentrations. Microscopic findings: numerous positive biliary emboli were identified in the small bile arteries
column12: arterioles and alveolar capillaries of the lungs by Hall's technique. Biliary emboli were also identified in the liver (sinusoids and portal veins)
column13: in the gallbladder mucosa and in the spleen. Other microscopic findings of interest were the presence of numerous fibrin thrombi in the arterioles and alveolar capillaries of the lungs and in branches of the portal vein and in hepatic sinusoids; focal necrosis of hepatocytes
column14: leukocytosis in the hepatic sinusoids and in the small blood vessels of the lung; as well as the occasional presence of cholesterol emboli in the lungs. The gall bladder showed gangrenous cholecystitis. Bile aggregates and cholesterol crystals were observed adhering to its mucosa.  In view of these findings
column15: biliary embolism in association with disseminated intravascular coagulation and probable sepsis was established as the cause of death.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 64-year-old man consulted in May 2006 for facial dysaesthesia and left palpebral ptosis and proptosis of the eyeball on the same side. Personal history of arterial hypertension under medical treatment
column2: operated on for duodenal ulcus 20 years earlier
column3: and laryngeal polyposis on two occasions in 1993 and 1994. Diagnosed with prostatic adenocarcinoma by ultrasound biopsy in September 2005
column4: with PSA of 794
column5: alkaline phosphatase of 870
column6: and bone scan showing multiple bone metastases. At that time
column7: treatment was started with lh-rh analogues
column8: flutamide and zoledronic acid 4 mg every 21 days for 6 months. The nadir PSA was reached in January 2006 at 36-17 ng/ml. Days before admission
column9: he reported right facial numbness from the cheekbone to the upper lip
column10: and simultaneously left palpebral ptosis together with ocular protrusion. There was no diplopia
column11: facial or ocular pain. On physical examination
column12: the patient was conscious
column13: oriented and cooperative
column14: presenting left palpebral ptosis with protrusion of the eye on the same side
column15: with no apparent murmur
column16: with paresis of the left third and sixth pairs. He also presented alterations in the sensitivity of the right half of the face
column17: with the rest of the motor and sensory neurological examination being normal. Among the complementary tests
column18: blood tests showed GGT of 86
column19: alkaline phosphatase of 1145
column20: and a PSA of 121-02. Brain MRI and angio MRI were performed
column21: which showed supratentorial ischaemic lesions and an orbital mass of extraconal location attached to the left orbital roof that displaced and caudally engulfed the superior rectus muscle
column22: while the left frontal sinus was occupied by a mass with the same characteristics as the one described. The superior orbital rim remains intact with no apparent signs of infiltration. The obliteration of the fat of the upper extraconal fat leads to inferior displacement and ocular proptosis. There is also an expansive mass located in the right maxillary sinus that breaks the lateral wall and extends towards the soft tissues
column23: causing interruption of the floor of the right orbit and invasion of the inferior extraconal space
column24: displacing the inferior rectus muscle without invading it. The cavernous sinuses were free.  The thoraco-abdomino-pelvic computerised axial tomography diagnosed a bony pattern with vertebral blast-lytic infiltration
column25: without visceral alterations. Metastasis of prostatic adenocarcinoma was diagnosed in the right maxillary sinus and left frontal sinus
column26: with extraconal right inferior and left superior orbital involvement. Local radiotherapy was ruled out due to the risk of blindness. Flutamide was withdrawn as treatment
column27: and the lh-rh analogue was maintained. In June 2006
column28: treatment was started with docetaxel 70 mg/m2 every 21 days
column29: together with prednisone 10 mg per day. Six cycles were completed by the end of September 2006. A nadir PSA level of 6-8 ng/mL was reached in July 2006
column30: after the first two administrations of docetaxel. The patient reported a decrease in left ocular proptosis. Six cycles were completed
column31: with excellent tolerance. In October 2006 the PSA was 149 ng/ml
column32: with no change in the MRI images. Recently
column33: in January 2007
column34: treatment was restarted again with docetaxel and prednisone.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O

column1: A 23-year-old patient diagnosed with Crohn's disease of ileal location. She initially presented with an inflammatory pattern that evolved into stenosis (occasional subocclusive crises) and later into perforation
column2: leading to abdominal perforation with faecaloid peritonitis
column3: which led to 3 surgical interventions during a stay abroad. Due to numerous postoperative complications
column4: short bowel syndrome and enteroenteric and enterocutaneous fistula
column5: she was transferred to our hospital. On admission she presented with fever
column6: wound infection with skin dehiscence and severe malnutrition. She had a protective ileostomy
column7: directed fistulisation at the ileo-colic anastomosis with Petzer catheter and abdominal drains. She was started on Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) from the time of admission
column8: with gradual introduction of the new feeding. Throughout the entire period
column9: monitoring is carried out by the Nutrition Section of the Pharmacy Service. TPN is prepared on a daily basis
column10: adjusting the intake according to biochemical parameters and clinical evolution. After 7 days
column11: he developed cholestasis
column12: so it was decided to reduce and subsequently eliminate the lipid intake in the TPN. On day 68
column13: TPN was withdrawn due to the onset of oral tolerance
column14: being reintroduced 5 days later due to persistent enterocutaneous fistula that caused fever
column15: abdominal pain and significant weight loss. After removal of drains and Petzer tube and introduction of treatment with Infliximab
column16: she was discharged from hospital on day 85
column17: continuing with TPN at home until she recovered her nutritional state necessary to undergo intestinal reconstruction surgery. She is monitored on an outpatient basis by the Home Hospitalisation Unit (HADO) and the Parenteral Nutrition Section of the Pharmacy Service. The TPN is prepared daily in the Pharmacy Service
column18: and staff from the HADO Unit are in charge of its administration

column1: An 18-year-old male patient attended the emergency department for severe headache and headache referred by his GP due to the lack of improvement with conventional treatment for viral upper respiratory infections. His personal history included only a history of infectious mononucleosis. After a week of catarrhal symptoms
column2: with general malaise
column3: dry cough and fever (up to 38.5 ºC)
column4: he developed a global headache
column5: more intense at the frontal level
column6: in the last 48 hours
column7: initially without rhinorrhoea or nasal obstruction. Isolatedly
column8: he presented minimal purulent nasal discharge that was occasionally bloody in the last few days. He did not present loss of consciousness
column9: convulsions
column10: shivering or chills. Physical examination revealed: temperature: 37.5ºC; BP: 137/73 mmHg; P: 71 bpm. Good general appearance with correct hydration and muco-cutaneous perfusion. No signs of illness. Febrile facies. No painful spots on percussion of the paranasal sinuses. On the skin there was a macular and erythematous rash affecting the trunk and neck. There were no palpable larynocervical
column11: axillary or inguinal adenopathies. Cardiac auscultation was rhythmic
column12: with no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation shows a preserved vesicular murmur
column13: without the presence of rhonchi
column14: crackles or wheezing. The abdomen is soft
column15: depressible and there are no palpable masses or megaliths. The upper and lower extremities are free of pathological findings
column16: with distal pulses present. The neurological examination was strictly normal
column17: with no evidence of focality or meningismus. The corresponding complementary examinations were carried out
column18: with a rigorously normal chest X-ray
column19: non-pathological urine analysis and a haemogram showing leukocytosis with the presence of young forms (keys: 4%)
column20: making it necessary to consider the differential diagnosis between sinusitis and meningitis; therefore
column21: a lumbar puncture was performed with 3 predominantly lymphoid cells and 0.3 g/dl of protein and no glucose consumption. At the same time
column22: a radiographic study of the paranasal sinuses showed no data compatible with sinusitis; then
column23: to rule out intracranial complications (such as cavernous sinus thrombosis / encephalitis)
column24: a cranial CT scan was performed
column25: which showed occupation of the left sphenoid sinus
column26: which was related to acute sinusopathy.  Once the diagnosis of sphenoidal sinusitis was confirmed
column27: it was decided to admit the patient to hospital for proper monitoring of the patient's evolution and to start intravenous antibiotic treatment with third generation cephalosporins
column28: treatment with which the patient evolved correctly
column29: without complications
column30: with the headache and fever subsiding within 48 hours and being asymptomatic at the time of discharge from hospital.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 73-year-old woman with a personal history of bronchial asthma treated with bronchodilators on demand. She reported no cardiovascular risk factors. The patient came to the hospital with bronchial hyperresponsiveness secondary to respiratory infection. In the anamnesis she reported oppressive back pain with sweating and dyspnoea for 8 months
column2: triggered by moderate exertion
column3: which subsided with rest and had not changed during this time. Cardiac auscultation was rhythmic
column4: with a third sound
column5: a fluctuating systolic and diastolic murmur and signs of heart failure. Pulmonary auscultation revealed rhonchi and wheezing compatible with the bronchial hyperresponsiveness that led to admission. Laboratory tests showed anaemia with a slight increase in acute phase reactants. Cardiac biomarkers were negative. The ECG was normal and the chest X-ray showed cardiomegaly
column6: not present in a previous one a year earlier. With the initial suspicion of bronchial hyperresponsiveness
column7: stable exertional angina and secondary heart failure
column8: an echocardiogram was requested which showed a mass measuring 4 x 5 cm dependent on the left atrium and which protruded in diastole from the fossa ovalis into the ventricle
column9: producing mitral stenosis. Subsequently
column10: a cardiac catheterisation was performed in which no angiographically significant coronary lesions were observed. On suspicion of atrial myxoma
column11: the patient underwent surgery and the diagnosis was confirmed by histology. Four months after surgery the patient is asymptomatic and there is no evidence of recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 50-year-old man
column2: diagnosed with Crohn's disease with complex ileal and perianal involvement on immunosuppressant treatment
column3: who came to the emergency department with fever
column4: perianal suppuration and diarrhoea of 1 week's evolution. The patient had been on salicylates and azathioprine (2.5 mg/kg/day
column5: adjusted according to TPMT levels) for 2 years and had received 6 doses of infliximab
column6: a biological treatment that he discontinued 6 months before the current admission
column7: for work-related reasons. On physical examination
column8: the patient appeared in poor general condition
column9: being febrile (39 ºC)
column10: hypotensive (BP 80/40 mmHg)
column11: tachycardic (104 bpm) and tachypneic (22 rpm). In the right iliac fossa there was a palpable "mass effect" of increased consistency and a fistulous orifice in the left buttock over an indurated
column12: erythematous
column13: hot and painful area. Urgent laboratory tests showed anaemia (Hb 7.9 g/dl
column14: Hct 29%)
column15: renal failure (creatinine 4 mg/dl) and elevated acute phase reactants (CRP 127
column16: platelets 424
column17: 000/ml). With the probable diagnosis of sepsis and multifactorial renal failure (salicylates
column18: dehydration
column19: etc.)
column20: treatment was started with serum therapy and broad-spectrum antibiotics. During the following 24 hours
column21: the patient presented disorientation
column22: agitation and deterioration of renal function with evident metabolic and hydroelectrolyte alterations (urea 68 mmol/l
column23: creatinine 6.9 mg/dl
column24: sodium 138 mmol/l
column25: potassium 6 mmol/l
column26: total calcium 7.5 mmol/l
column27: inorganic phosphorus 5.1 mmol/l
column28: LDH 17
column30: urate 44 mg/dl). In view of these results
column31: a renal Doppler ultrasound was performed
column32: which was anodyne
column33: and the renal failure was interpreted as multifactorial in origin
column34: aggravated by the precipitation of uric acid crystals
column35: for which treatment was started with hyperhydration
column36: urine alkalinisation
column37: haemodialysis
column38: allopurinol and rasburicase
column39: with a marked decrease in urate levels (urate 1.8 mg/dl). However
column40: in view of the progressive clinical worsening of the patient's general condition
column41: an abdominopelvic CT scan was performed
column42: which showed a retroperitoneal mass measuring 13 x 10 cm and a lesion in the right flank measuring 15 x 8.6 cm
column43: which appeared to correspond to a conglomerate of fixed loops with a thickened wall
column44: without being able to rule out an underlying neoplasm. Multiple adenopathies in the mesenteric
column45: iliac and inguinal chains were also observed
column46: as well as a left perirectal lesion
column47: probably related to his history of abscess and perianal fistula. The latter lesion was the only radiological finding observed
column48: two months before the current episode
column49: in an abdomino-pelvic MRI to monitor his perianal disease. Despite supportive treatment
column50: the patient continued with fever
column51: decreased level of consciousness
column52: progressive dyspnoea and anuria
column53: and died three days after admission to the ward. The definitive diagnosis was obtained after necropsy: plasmoblastic plasmacytoma with a predominance of lamda-type light chains infiltrating terminal ileum and cecum
column54: root of the mesentery
column55: abdominal lymph nodes and bone marrow.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Seven-year-old patient in the first stage of mixed dentition
column2: with a digital sucking habit. She presented the following alterations: anterior open bite
column3: upper dentoalveolar protrusion
column4: increased protrusion
column5: bilateral posterior crossbite
column6: maxillary compression and rotation of the occlusal plane. The growth pattern had a vertical tendency. In the myofunctional assessment
column7: lip incompetence was observed.  Due to the unfavourable nature of the case
column8: a combined treatment including orthodontic devices (quad-helix with lingual grid cemented in the upper first molars to produce maxillary expansion) was chosen
column9: lingual arch cemented in the lower jaw to prevent the loss of the drift space and avoid extrusion of the lower molars and extraoral appliances (AEO) with high archwire to favour intrusion of the molars and thus allow the mandible to rotate forward and upward
column10: closing the open bite)
column11: together with myotherapy exercises to increase lip tone. The duration of treatment was one and a half years.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 37-year-old man
column2: former injecting drug addict
column3: was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis C virus genotype 4 with a low viral load (75
column4: 754 IU/ml). Treatment with pegylated IFN alpha-2b (100µg/week) and ribavirin (1g/day) was initiated. Two months after starting treatment
column5: the patient visited the clinic and reported blurred vision and "spots" in the visual field since approximately 10 days earlier. On ophthalmological examination she had a VA of 0.8 with correction in both eyes and multiple cotton wool exudates in the posterior pole. A diagnosis of IFN retinopathy was made and treatment was suspended. In successive check-ups the condition improved and at 3 months she presented a VA of 10/10 in both eyes and in the FO only a cottony exudate was seen in the inferior resorption of the left fovea.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 32-year-old man was referred to our department for presenting a pedunculated lesion with a clinical diagnosis of pyogenic granuloma
column2: 1 cm high and 0.6 cm in diameter at its base
column3: reddish in colour
column4: with vascular ingurgitation
column5: located on the free edge of the middle third of the right upper eyelid
column6: with no pain or bleeding
column7: and a year of evolution. The rest of the ophthalmological and systemic examination was normal.  The lesion was surgically excised by making a full-thickness pentagon that included the lesion. The histopathological diagnosis was pilomatricoma due to the description of a solid
column8: encapsulated mass consisting of a mass of pilomatric cells arranged in the periphery
column9: large masses of keratin and isolated areas of ghost cells
column10: with granulomatous reaction to adjacent foreign body. At higher magnification
column11: small basalioid cells without cytological atypia are identified. In the more central area
column12: the cells are larger
column13: with eosinophilic cytoplasm and loss of the nucleus (phantom). Between these two predominant cell types there are transitional cells.  After 4 years of follow-up no recurrence or malignancy has been observed.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Sixty-three year old woman with a personal history of kyphoscoliosis
column2: restrictive respiratory insufficiency and diverticulosis. The patient presented with peritonitis secondary to perforated diverticulitis
column3: treated with the Hart-mann technique. Postoperatively
column4: she developed an entero-cutaneous fistula
column5: treated with oral enteral nutrition. Given her refusal to undergo surgery
column6: she was discharged with this treatment
column7: when she presented a debit of 200 ml/day
column8: and periodic outpatient check-ups were scheduled
column9: which she did not attend. Three months later
column10: she went to the emergency department for presenting in the previous days with asthenia
column11: anorexia
column12: nausea
column13: dizziness
column14: abdominal pain
column15: decreased stool output through the colostomy and a significant increase in fistula output
column16: sometimes with a haematic appearance. He was afebrile
column17: with a BP of 85/50 mmHg and presented with diffuse pain on abdominal palpation. During his stay in the ED
column18: he presented a decreased level of consciousness that improved after administration of intravenous fluids. Laboratory tests showed: haemoglobin 12.3 g/dl; leucocytes 10
column19: 400/mm3; glycaemia 102 mg/dl; urea 426 mg/dl; creatinine 2.9 mg/dl; total protein 9.3 g/dl; Ca 10.5 mg/dl; Na 104 mEq/l; K 6.9 mEq/l; Cl 73 mEq/l; HCO3 17 mmol/l; urinary Na 6 mEq/l. She was diagnosed with dehydration
column20: acute renal failure
column21: metabolic acidosis
column22: severe hyponatraemia and hyperkalaemia. Given the suspicion of acute adrenal insufficiency
column23: treatment was started with hydrocortisone and continued with IV fluid replacement
column24: with good clinical and analytical response. Subsequent blood tests showed a drop in haemoglobin concentration to 7.6 g/dl and she received a transfusion of two red blood cell concentrates. She was admitted to internal medicine and subsequently transferred to surgery with a diagnosis of intestinal obstruction. On the sixth day of admission she was started on parenteral nutrition. The patient was fully conscious
column25: haemodynamically stable
column26: without oedema and renal function
column27: hyponatraemia and hyperkalaemia had normalised. She weighed 68 kg and was 145 cm tall (BMI 32 kg/m2). The composition of the TPN was: total volume 2500 ml
column28: 1500 kcal
column29: N 11 g
column30: glucose 200 g
column31: lipids 40 g
column32: Na 120 mEq
column33: K 60 mEq
column34: Mg 15 mEq
column35: P 15 mEq
column36: Zn 12 mg
column37: Ca 12 mEq. The following day the patient reported paresthesia in the hands and perioral region. Thiamine i.m. was administered empirically. A few hours later
column38: she began to present a picture of decreased level of consciousness and bradypsychia
column39: with preserved motility in the extremities. The clinical picture progressed during the following day
column40: presenting with a fluctuating level of consciousness deterioration
column41: with aphasia and paraparesis in MSI and becoming stuporous. She was afebrile and her blood pressure was 130/70 mmHg. NTP was discontinued
column42: she was maintained on serum therapy and empirical vitamin supplementation. Head CT scan was normal. She was transferred to the ICU and
column43: given the suspicion of metabolic encephalopathy
column44: an EEG was performed
column45: which showed non-convulsive status epilepticus
column46: and treatment with IV phenytoin was started. Laboratory tests showed: Hb 10.7 g/l; 12
column47: 800 leukocytes with 71.5% granulocytes; glycaemia 91 mg/dl; creatinine 0.5 mg/dl; Na 143 mEq/l; K 2.6 mEq/l; P 0.5 mg/dl; Mg 1.5 mg/dl; CPK 31 UI/l. The ECG showed no arrhythmias. Arterial blood gas analysis was similar to the previous one. She was diagnosed with severe hypophosphataemia with hypomagnesaemia and hypokalaemia. Phosphate salts were administered i.v.
column48: as well as magnesium and potassium
column49: with good clinical response
column50: progressively improving the neurological situation until normalisation. She was again transferred to surgery and parenteral nutrition was restarted
column51: progressively increasing the caloric intake and with a higher intake of phosphorus
column52: magnesium and potassium. During her admission she also presented several complications: phenytoin intoxication with neurological symptoms
column53: and sepsis due to Candida spp. related to the central catheter
column54: from which she recovered without sequelae. Oral enteral nutrition and modified oral diet were progressively introduced and TPN and IV fluids were discontinued. Since the diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency was not confirmed and there was significant dehydration on admission that could explain the analytical alterations
column55: corticosteroids were progressively decreased until they were discontinued
column56: without the appearance of symptoms or signs of adrenal insufficiency. Cortisol after ACTH stimulation (250 mg) was 43.9 µg/dl at 30 minutes
column57: reflecting a normal adrenal reserve. The patient refused intestinal transit reconstruction surgery. Enterocutaneous fistula persisted with a debit of approximately 300 cc/day. The patient was discharged with good clinical and analytical status. Table I shows the evolution of phosphorus
column58: magnesium and potassium levels during admission.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 42-year-old patient referred to the Colombian Pain Institute (INCODOL) with 11 months of neuropathic pain rated on the visual analogue scale (VAS) 10/10 and allodynia in the left groin
column2: following an ipsilateral inguinal herniorrhaphy
column3: irradiation to the testicle and thigh
column4: managed with acetaminophen. Staggered and multimodal pharmacological treatment was started with antiepileptics
column5: opioids
column6: lidocaine patches
column7: tricyclic and dual antidepressants
column8: in appropriate doses and schedules
column9: with no improvement of at least 50% after two months of follow-up
column10: and it was decided to perform an ultrasound-guided block of the left ilioinguinal
column11: iliohypogastric and genitofemoral nerves with local anaesthetic associated with steroid. Four months later
column12: the pain was rated 8/10
column13: with aggravation on movement
column14: hypersensitivity in the left inguinoscrotal region
column15: positive cremasteric reflex
column16: negative percussion on the anterosuperior iliac spine
column17: and a new block was performed
column18: with which the patient reported an improvement of more than 50%. In view of this evolution
column19: it was decided to perform a pulsed radiofrequency with a 10 mm active tip cannula on the left ilioinguinal
column20: iliohypogastric and genitofemoral nerves
column21: after a positive sensitive test at 0.2 mV
column22: with the following parameters: 2 Hz
column23: active phase of 20 milliseconds
column24: temperature control < 42oC
column25: for 10 minutes
column26: also applying a local anaesthetic and steroid on each nerve. At one week the pain was rated 2/10; at one month it was rated 1/10
column27: with no adverse effects
column28: and she returned to her work and family activities. Sustained improvement in the controls at 6 and 9 months (VAS 2-3/10).  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 92-year-old woman
column2: with no known drug allergies
column3: with a personal history of arterial hypertension
column4: type 2 diabetes mellitus
column5: chronic atrial fibrillation and Alzheimer's disease. She was admitted for vomiting in coffee grounds
column6: epigastralgia and weight loss in the last month. Physical examination was irrelevant. Laboratory tests showed: haemoglobin 7.1 g/dl
column7: haematocrit 23.8%
column8: MCV 77
column9: leukocytes 11
column11: ESR 40 mm. Glucose 206 mg/dl. Iron 28 ug/dl. An oral endoscopy showed a large hiatal hernia and a deep ulcer of approximately 2 cm in diameter in the distal third of the oesophagus with abundant whitish exudate in the crater. A biopsy and cytology of the lesion was performed. Histology showed esophageal squamous esophageal mucosa and numerous sulphide granules containing abundant hyphae consistent with actinomycosis.  Treatment was started with intravenous penicillin G for a few days and subsequently discharged with oral penicillin. The patient was lost to follow-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 60-year-old man with a history of arterial hypertension
column2: aortic and mitral valve disease
column3: left parietal haematoma
column4: left inguinal and umbilical herniorrhaphy
column5: diagnosed 3 years ago with stage A/O chronic lymphocytic leukaemia and under follow-up by the haematology department of our hospital
column6: without treatment. A control thoracoabdominal-pelvic CT scan showed lymphadenopathies in the cervical
column7: axillary
column8: mediastinal
column9: retroperitoneal and inguinal areas
column10: as well as a 3 cm hypodense image of the left prostate lobe
column11: with a poor plane of separation from the left levator ani muscle. The patient had no urological symptoms. Rectal examination revealed a poorly defined prostate at both bases
column12: with a diffuse increase in consistency in both lobes. PSA was 0.9 ng/ml. Transrectal ultrasound shows a prostate measuring 28.5 x 43.4 x 50.8 mm and 32.9 ml
column13: with heterogeneous parenchyma and several hyperechoic areas at both bases. The right vesiculoprostatic angle is effaced. Prostatic biopsies were taken by sextants.
