column1: The patient is a 71 year old woman
column2: who has been a former smoker for 25 years
column3: is diagnosed with hypertension
column4: polymyalgia rheumatica and temporal arteritis. In 1988
column5: following a study for metrorrhagia
column6: an endometrial tumour was detected and a hysterectomy and double adnexectomy were performed. The pathology study showed that it was a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma (grade I)
column7: with infiltration of the inner third of the myometrium
column8: without evidence of infiltration of blood or lymphatic vessels
column9: with a negative extension study
column10: therefore stage Ib. She subsequently received radiotherapy with cobalt-60 in the pelvis and brachytherapy in the vaginal vault. She underwent periodic check-ups with no evidence of relapse. In 2003
column11: she consulted for irritative cough and slight haemoptotic expectoration
column12: and a simple chest X-ray showed a mass in the left upper lobe. With the suspicion of a bronchogenic neoplasm
column13: the studies were completed and a thoracic-abdomino-pelvic CT scan was performed
column14: showing a necrotic mass measuring 8 cm in the LSI with atelectasis of this lobe with no other alterations. Bronchoscopy was performed which revealed a tumour in the anterior segment of the aforementioned lobe
column15: the BAS and bronchial biopsy being compatible with poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. With the clinical diagnosis of T2 N0 M0 squamous cell carcinoma of the lung
column16: it was decided to start neoadjuvant chemotherapy
column17: with the scheme Carboplatin (AUC 6) plus Paclitaxel (200mg/m2) every three weeks. After three cycles of treatment
column18: a partial response was observed in radiological studies and the patient underwent left upper lobectomy and lymphadenectomy. Analysis of the surgical specimen showed a tumour corresponding to adenocarcinoma with poorly differentiated areas
column19: with some squamous areas
column20: with positive immunohistochemical results for oestrogen and progesterone expression
column21: and negative for TTF-1 and CK20. These confirmatory results changed the initial approach
column22: as it was not a primary pulmonary tumour as previously thought
column23: but a pulmonary relapse of her endometrial tumour. The patient is being treated with megestrol acetate
column24: with good tolerance
column25: free of disease and is currently being followed up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male patient
column2: 40 years old
column3: with a medical history. He consulted the urology department for dysuria and 3 episodes of urethrorrhagia. On physical examination the mucous membranes were moist and normal-coloured
column4: cardio-respiratory auscultation was normal
column5: the abdomen was negative
column6: lumbar fossae were free
column7: rectal examination
column8: external genitalia and inguinal regions were normal. Urological ultrasound was normal. Cystourethroscopy was normal
column9: with only a slight protrusion when the cystoscope passed through the anterior urethra. A voiding urethrocystography X-ray showed a filling defect in the anterior urethra.  In view of the above
column10: we decided to carry out an endoscopic study under anaesthesia
column11: detecting a reddish
column12: well-defined polypoid tumour
column13: for which we decided to perform an endoscopic resection. The anatomopathological result of the surgical specimen was an inverted papilloma of the anterior urethra. The patient was discharged due to improvement
column14: evolving satisfactorily with disappearance of dysuria and urethrorrhagia.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 36-year-old man
column2: with no past history of interest
column3: was seen in the internal medicine department for presenting a painful left inguinoscrotal mass on palpation of two months' duration
column4: without weight loss or micturition syndrome. On examination
column5: the testicles were of normal size and consistency
column6: with an indurated and very painful left spermatic cord. Testicular ultrasound was normal. Abdomen-pelvis CT scan revealed a mass measuring 6 x 3 centimetres in the trajectory of the left spermatic cord
column7: with no evidence of retroperitoneal involvement. With the diagnosis of a left paratesticular tumour
column8: he underwent surgery
column9: a mass was found in the spermatic cord and an intraoperative biopsy was performed
column10: which was reported as a neoplastic proliferation of non-lymphomatous myofibroblastic appearance
column11: for which a radical left orchiectomy was performed. Pathology was pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma of the spermatic cord
column12: normal testis and epididymis and negative resection margins.  Subsequently
column13: the patient received several cycles of chemotherapy with adriamycin and ifosfamide + MESNA. In the control imaging tests four months after surgery
column14: no tumour recurrence was observed.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 27-year-old woman of Chinese nationality
column2: who did not understand Spanish
column3: had no known drug allergies
column4: no medical or surgical history of interest and had been correctly vaccinated as a child in her country of origin. The patient first came to the emergency department of the health centre for a pruritic urticariform reaction of 24 hours' duration. At this first consultation she was prescribed an intramuscular antihistamine and a delayed-release corticoid and was diagnosed with urticaria. One day later the patient returned to the emergency department with an increase in lesions
column5: reporting intense itching of the face
column6: scalp
column7: trunk
column8: upper limbs and genitals. Several polymorphous lesions with a widespread distribution were observed
column9: with haemorrhagic crusty lesions and other vesicular-pustular lesions two to five millimetres in diameter
column10: some of them umbilicated in the central area. In the central abdominal region there was a necrotic crusty lesion that the patient said she had handled. After examination
column11: she was diagnosed with chickenpox. She was referred home after taking a smear of the lesions
column12: explaining to her the respiratory isolation measures that should be taken with her non-immunised cohabitants. She was prescribed oral acyclovir 800 mg every four hours
column13: five times a day
column14: with nightly rest for seven days
column15: and antihistamines. Seven days later
column16: our patient attended the emergency department of our referral hospital for intense asthenia of 24 hours' duration with no other symptoms. Examination was completely normal
column17: so in the absence of any abnormalities in both laboratory and radiological tests
column18: it was decided to discharge her home. Twelve hours later
column19: the patient returned to the emergency department with suprapubic pain and asthenia. In the anamnesis she reported dysuria of two days' evolution and oligoanuria
column20: with no concomitant febrile process. Cardiopulmonary auscultation was completely normal. Abdominal examination revealed suprapubic pain with palpation of the bladder balloon with positive suction in both renal fossae. Suspecting acute urinary retention
column21: a bladder catheterisation was performed
column22: revealing an emptying of 1
column23: 200 cc. Blood and urine tests were performed with results within normal parameters. The abdominal X-ray showed the presence of abundant retained faecal debris. During re-evaluation in the observation room
column24: the companion-translator reported a clear improvement in abdominal pain and said that the patient had been suffering from progressive loss of strength and weakness in the lower limbs for four days. The patient was re-evaluated
column25: with marked cervical stiffness
column26: normal cranial nerves
column27: distal and proximal motor balance 5/5 in the upper limbs. In the lower extremities
column28: flaccid paraparesis with motor balance 3/5 proximal and 4/5 distal. Osteotendinous reflexes with bilateral patellar hyporeflexia and abolition of Achilles reflexes. Bilateral plantar cutaneous reflex in flexion. Hypo-sensitivity in metatarsals below D5 (breast). In view of the presence of neurological alterations
column29: a craniocerebral computerised axial tomography (CAT) scan was ordered
column30: where no focal intracranial lesions were observed and the cerebrospinal fluid spaces
column31: as well as the differentiation of grey matter and white matter
column32: were normal. Subsequently
column33: a lumbar puncture was performed where clear fluid was observed and samples were sent for laboratory studies
column34: and the patient was admitted to the neurology department with the diagnosis of suspected post-infectious incomplete transverse myelitis. During his admission
column35: a spinal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan was performed
column36: which showed an area of T2 hypersignal located at the level of the cervical spinal cord (C5-D1) with a small dilatation of the ependymal duct
column37: most likely related to infectious myelopathy. The lesion showed mild hypointensity in T1. This confirmed the diagnosis of infectious myelitis in the cervical spinal cord.  CSF serology results for Borrelia
column38: Brucella
column39: syphilis
column40: Epstein Barr virus (EBV)
column41: Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
column42: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) and Varicella zoster virus (VZV) were negative. Serum serology results were congruent with CSF
column43: except for Varicella zoster virus which was positive. Human Immunodeficiency Virus serology was also requested with negative results. Therefore
column44: her highly probable aetiological diagnosis was acute myelitis due to Varicella zoster virus (VZV) infection. Since her admission
column45: given the high suspicion of acute myelitis due to VZV
column46: treatment was started with i.v. acyclovir for the first ten days with the addition of i.v. corticosteroid. The patient experienced a slow but steady improvement
column47: and finally
column48: after a month of hospitalisation
column49: the catheter was removed without any episode of acute urinary retention in the following days. On discharge she continued rehabilitation treatment.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A seven-year-old boy came to the paediatric primary care clinic 30 minutes before and while walking
column2: presenting with a sensation of palpitations of sudden onset
column3: without accompanying chest pain or dyspnoea. He had not exercised previously. No personal history of heart disease
column4: nor family history of heart disease or sudden death. On arrival at the health centre
column5: the patient was conscious and oriented
column6: with no signs of respiratory distress. Cardiac auscultation shows rhythmic tones at 170-180 beats per minute (bpm)
column7: with no murmurs. Peripheral pulses are rhythmic and symmetrical. Good capillary refill. Blood pressure (BP) systolic: 90 mmHg
column8: 31st percentile (P31)
column9: diastolic: 65 mmHg (P76). An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed. Fig. 2 shows the measurement of the width of the QRS complex.  Given the electrocardiographic findings of wide QRS tachycardia without haemodynamic repercussions
column10: the paediatrician started an amiodarone infusion (5 mg/kg
column11: intravenous [IV])
column12: and referred the patient to hospital by medical transport. On arrival at the paediatric emergency department
column13: the patient was asymptomatic except for the sensation of palpitations. Physical examination was as follows: weight 22.5 kg (P21)
column14: height 119.5 cm (P14)
column15: systolic BP 88 mmHg (P25) and diastolic 63 (P71). Conscious and oriented. Good perfusion. Cardiac auscultation with tachycardia without murmurs. Normal peripheral pulses. Rest normal. After analysis of the ECG
column16: the possibility of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) conducted with aberrancy was considered
column17: so it was decided to try to reverse the tachycardia with vagal manoeuvres (gag reflex
column18: cold in the face)
column19: without success
column20: so a bolus of adenosine was administered at 0.1 mg/kg IV leaving in sinus rhythm. A baseline ECG was performed
column21: which showed no abnormalities. Blood tests showed ions and myocardial enzymes within the normal range.  The patient was admitted for 24 hours for observation
column22: with no new episodes
column23: an echocardiogram was performed
column24: which was normal
column25: and he was discharged with subsequent follow-up in Cardiology consultations
column26: with a diagnosis of paroxysmal SVT with aberrant conduction.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 47-year-old man
column2: referred to us from the Rehabilitation Department in February 2011
column3: for assessment of his obesity. The patient had a personal history of spinal cord injury following an accident at work in 2004
column4: with vertebral fracture and incomplete paraplegia at L1. He smoked more than 20 cigarettes a day and had arterial hypertension treated with enalapril 20/hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 every 24 hours and untreated hypertriglyceridaemia. In the directed anamnesis
column5: he reported great difficulty in daily life (he needs a wheelchair to get around and uses a standing position for transfers). She recognised that she had a strong appetite and snacking between meals. Since 2006 she had tried several times to lose weight
column6: without success. On examination she weighed 135 kg and was 1.72 cm tall
column7: BMI 46.62 kg/m2. tA 145/92. His blood tests showed cholesterol 222 mg/dL and triglycerides 260 mg/dL with HDL cholesterol 41 mg/dL. After being assessed by the multidisciplinary team at our hospital
column8: and ruling out contraindications for surgery
column9: his case was approved and he underwent laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass in January 2014. One month after surgery the patient is doing well
column10: had no complications in the immediate postoperative period; and denies vomiting at present. He has less appetite and is on a fractional liquid diet. His current weight is 120 kg. From the point of view of her cormobilities
column11: she has stopped hypotensive treatment and her BP control at home is optimal (110/90). Analytically
column12: she has no vitamin deficiency
column13: with daily supplementation of a vitamin complex.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 52 year old female patient
column2: with no previous history of interest
column3: referred to our department for surgical assessment. She had presented
column4: for four years
column5: with a small tumour on the right side of her forehead
column6: which had been slowly increasing in size. On examination
column7: a hard
column8: painless
column9: non-mobile mass was palpable under normal-appearing skin. Plain X-ray and CT scan of the skull showed a right frontal intraosseous lesion with osteolytic features. Radiological differential diagnosis included metastases
column10: myeloma and haemangioma. Systemic tumour screening studies (haemogram
column11: haematological smear
column12: tumour markers
column13: proteinogram and cervico-thoracic-abdominal CT scan) were negative. A bone scan with HDP-Tc99M was performed
column14: showing a rounded deposit in the area of the lesion. Percutaneous fine needle puncture-aspiration of the tumour was inconclusive for the diagnosis
column15: as only haematic fragments were obtained.  Finally
column16: it was decided to operate on the patient on the basis of the clinical progression of the lesion
column17: with its aesthetic implications
column18: as well as to obtain a definitive histological diagnosis. During surgery
column19: a bone-dependent tumour was identified
column20: with multiple dilated vascular channels in its sinus
column21: expanding the external table. To avoid manipulation of the lesion
column22: it was decided to include it in a craniectomy specimen with a circumferential margin of 1 cm of apparently healthy bone. The resulting bone defect was reconstructed by means of a methylmethacrylate cranial plasty
column23: which was fixed to the surrounding bone with titanium mini-plates. The postoperative period was uneventful. The definitive anatomopathological diagnosis was intraosseous cavernous haemangioma.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 60-year-old woman underwent laparoscopic left radical nephrectomy for a 9.7x7.5 cm lower pole renal tumour. During the operation
column2: peritumoral para-aortic and mesocolon adhesions were found
column3: where some large lymphatic vessels were ligated or coagulated
column4: careful dissection of the hilum was performed and the distal ureter was clipped
column5: with no intraoperative incidences and bleeding of less than 100 ml. The anatomopathological study showed solid
column6: cystic clear cell renal carcinoma with areas of intratumoural bleeding
column7: Fuhrman grade 2-3
column8: stage pT2 pN0. The postoperative period was uneventful
column9: a decrease in haemoglobin of 1.5 g/dl (from 13.2 to 11.7) was detected
column10: and the patient was discharged from hospital five days later. One month after discharge
column11: he consulted for an increase in abdominal perimeter causing dyspnoea and discomfort
column12: and imaging studies showed diffusely distributed ascites
column13: suggestive of chylous ascites. Analyses showed Hb 11.1 g/dl
column14: leukocyte formula and lymphocyte count normal
column15: normal renal and hepatic function and mild hypo-proteinemia - albumin 2.9 g/dl (N: 3.4-5)
column16: total protein 5.8 g/dl (N: 6.4-8.2). She was treated conservatively
column17: without diagnostic or evacuating paracentesis
column18: with a low-salt and low-lipid diet
column19: protein supplements and spironolactone 50 mg/day
column20: with symptomatic and abdominal perimeter improvement
column21: hospital discharge after six days
column22: and complete healing confirmed by abdominal ultrasound one month later. Six months later she has no symptoms or signs of recurrence
column23: and the abdominal ultrasound is normal.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Background: 45-year-old man with a history of chronic alcoholism accompanied by chronic pancreatitis and insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus
column2: presenting with very low dietary intake. He was admitted to hospital several times for flare-ups of his chronic pancreatitis. In 2002 he underwent surgery to remove a pancreatic pseudocyst which became complicated and ended with a cystogastrostomy which resolved favourably. In February 2003
column3: he was admitted again for emphysematous cholecystitis with complicated perivesicular abscess and a cholecystostomy with Pezzer tube was performed to perform cholecystectomy in a second surgery. He was discharged with a cholecystostomy tube drainage of approximately 500 ml. In November 2003
column4: she attended surgery for a qualitative examination of the stool
column5: which showed an increase in fat and food debris
column6: a foul odour and a pasty consistency. No treatment was prescribed. Current illness: In February 2004
column7: she attended the emergency department with a 3-month history of bilateral eye pain
column8: redness
column9: itching
column10: photophobia and reduced visual acuity. She was admitted to the Ophthalmology Department for study and treatment. Ophthalmological examination revealed peripheral ulcerative keratitis and visual acuity of less than 10% in the right eye. In the left eye
column11: there was a central corneal ulcer with stromal necrosis and hyphema
column12: and she only had light perception. Imaging tests were negative. Corneal cultures were negative. ENT
column13: digestive and rheumatology examinations were not significant. The patient was referred to the Nutrition Unit for weight loss of 16 kg in the last 6 months. The nutritional assessment revealed severe caloric and mild protein malnutrition
column14: weight of 52 kg with a BMI of 18.2 and loss of 23% of her usual weight in the last 6 months
column15: tricipital fold of 5
column16: 2 mm (42% of the 50th percentile for her age and sex)
column17: arm muscle circumference of 18.3 (74% of the 50th percentile for her age and sex)
column18: hypoproteinaemia with albumin 2.42 g/dl and Retinol Transport Protein 1.5 mg/dl (Reference value: 3.5-7.5 mg/dl)
column19: severe deficit of fat-soluble vitamins
column20: especially Vitamin A (Vitamin A: 0.24 ng/ml. Reference value: 0.4-0.8) and vitamin D (Vitamin D: 0
column21: not detectable in blood. Reference value 15-100 ng/ml). Both vitamin B complex vitamins
column22: vitamin C and zinc were normal. The 24-hour stool malabsorption study showed the presence of mild malabsorption (Nitrogen: 2.5 g
column23: faecal fats 6.3 g and faecal sugars 3.8 g)
column24: however when this last stool sample was collected the patient was already on treatment with Pancrease®. Treatment: The patient's diet was supplemented with special hyperprotein and hypercaloric formulas for diabetics (Resource diabet® 2 shakes every day)
column25: the deficient vitamins were administered orally (Natecal D® 2 tablets every day
column26: Auxin A+E 2 tablets every/day)
column27: and pancreatic enzymes were added (Pancrease® 2-0-2). Evolution: In April 2004 cholecystectomy was performed and cholecystostomy was closed. We evaluated the patient 3 months later and he had a BMI of 20
column28: the anaemia had subsided and the ophthalmological problems had evolved favourably. The corneal ulcers have healed and visual acuity has almost completely recovered (right eye 100% and left eye counts fingers (table I).  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 71-year-old man presents with right testicular pain
column2: non-radiating
column3: of three months' duration
column4: with an increase in testicular diameter and consistency in the last month. He presents with constitutional syndrome
column5: with a weight loss of 3 kg in the last month. Peak fever up to 39ºC
column6: profuse sweating
column7: non-clinical micturition
column8: no haematuria. Of note was COPD with treatment with inhalers and chronic home oxygen. On physical examination
column9: the patient was affected
column10: with mucocutaneous pallor
column11: crackles on pulmonary auscultation
column12: oedema in the lower limbs
column13: no adenopathies
column14: haematomas in both upper limbs. The genital examination of the right hemiscrotal showed oedema of the lining
column15: increased consistency of the epididymis and teste
column16: with disappearance of the epididymal-testicular groove
column17: with no signs of fluctuation or abcessation. Digital rectal examination of the prostate adenomatous prostate
column18: grade II-III/IV. Analyses: haemoglobin 8.1 g/dl (previous 13.5 g/dl)
column19: platelets 51000
column20: 9100 leukocytes. Coagulation fibrinogen elevation 1500 (limits of normality below 400). Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
column21: BHCG
column22: CEA
column23: AFP
column24: normal renal
column25: hepatic and pancreatic function. Chest X-ray
column26: minimal vascular congestion
column27: normal abdominal X-ray. Renal and bladder ultrasound without alterations
column28: prostate measuring 4.5 x 4 x 4.1 cm. Testicular ultrasound
column29: left testicle normal
column30: right testicle with three heterogeneous areas with decreased echogenicity
column31: no calcifications affecting the upper pole
column32: lower pole and epididymis
column33: no hydrocele.  With the diagnostic suspicion of testicular abscess versus testicular tuberculosis
column34: brucellosis or testicular tumour
column35: we performed a radical orchiectomy via the inguinal route. The pathological anatomy reports
column36: macroscopically
column37: a testicular tumour measuring 8 x 6 x 4 cm
column38: with a 5.5 cm lobulated whitish mass in section
column39: which infiltrates the albuginea and epididymis but does not go beyond the external layer or the hilar border. Microscopically
column40: the testicle is affected by diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
column41: with a high proliferation rate (minb1 > 80%)
column42: and CD 20+ markers. Stage 1E-B.  With the diagnosis of primary testicular lymphoma
column43: we requested a full body CT scan for staging
column44: showing homogeneous splenomegaly
column45: isolated retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy of less than 1 cm
column46: as notable findings. Post-surgical evolution of the patient showed profuse sweating
column47: fever in peaks
column48: asthenia and oedema of the lower limbs. Analyses persist
column49: anaemia 8.9 g/dl haemoglobin
column50: platelets 37000
column51: and normal leukocyte and lymphocyte formula. With the diagnosis of B symptoms in a patient with primary testicular lymphoma
column52: we performed a bone marrow biopsy
column53: obtaining a cylinder measuring 3 x 0.3 cm
column54: in which there is hypercellular bone marrow with regenerative and dysplastic changes
column55: at the expense of the granulocytic series. There is marked interstitial plasmacytosis
column56: infiltration by lymphoblastic cells.  As there was no evidence of bone marrow infiltration
column57: we performed a blood smear to justify the cause of the anaemia and thrombocytopenia. Platelet aggregation was observed and a direct Coombs' test was performed
column58: which was weakly positive for immunoglobulin G
column59: the cause of the aggregation. On admission to hospital the patient began with dysphonia and dysphagia and fibroscopy was performed
column60: showing a polypoid lesion in the pyriform sinus. The cervical CT scan was normal. During admission the patient was prescribed Rituximab and the following day the first cycle of CHOP (cyclophosphamide
column64: presenting intense improvement of the B symptoms
column65: with disappearance of the fever. Chemotherapy treatment was started with 6 cycles of R-CHOP. Coadjuvant genital radiotherapy and cerebral chemoprophylaxis were administered. At 12 months the patient was free of disease. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 46-year-old patient consulted for pain in the hypogastrium
column2: painful ejaculation
column3: haemospermia and a sensation of heaviness in the testicles
column4: attributed until then to a right varicocele that had been known for a year. His personal history included an episode of acute prostatitis one year prior to consultation. On physical examination
column5: the patient was in good general condition
column6: had a right varicocele and no masses were palpable in both testicles. Rectal examination showed an irregular prostate
column7: slightly enlarged with indurated areas and somewhat painful on examination. A comprehensive urological ultrasound was requested
column8: which showed a hypoechoic nodular image in the right testicle with surrounding hypervascularisation and a simple cyst in the left testicle. The abdominal-pelvic CT scan showed several images in the liver that could correspond to metastases or haemangiomas. Subsequent MRI confirmed that they were haemangiomas. The chest X-ray showed no alterations. Tumour markers and PSA values were normal. Alpha-fetoprotein: 6 ng/ml
column9: beta-HCG: 0.1 ng/ml
column10: PSA: 1.5 ng/ml. In view of all these findings
column11: it was decided to perform a radical right inguinal orchiectomy. Macroscopically
column12: the specimen showed a nodular formation of identical colour to that of the testicular pulp measuring 2.5 x 1.8 x 1.5 cm in the upper pole of the testicle. The histopathological report was of a diffuse Leydig cell tumour infiltrating perineural spaces
column13: adjacent capsular vascular channels and smooth muscle; moderate atypia and few mitoses. After 10 years of follow-up
column14: the patient is asymptomatic
column15: no metastases have been observed and tumour markers have remained negative. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 72-year-old patient was admitted for elective surgery for aneurysm of the infrarenal abdominal aorta and right hypogastric artery. Personal history: right nephrectomy in 1983 for renal cell carcinoma
column2: AHT controlled with amlodipine and old inferolateral AMI with silent heart disease. The DIVAS showed diffuse aortic ectasia and a fusiform aneurysmal dilatation whose neck was 17 mm from the left renal artery
column3: with a 7 mm mural thrombus inside and a maximum lumen size of 35 mm at the level of the inferior mesenteric artery. The aneurysmal dilatation affects both primitive iliac arteries
column4: and a second 13 mm fusiform aneurysm is observed in the right hypogastric artery. Patency of the celiac axis
column5: left renal artery
column6: superior mesenteric artery and occlusion of the inferior mesenteric artery was confirmed. The patient underwent surgery and an aortic endoprosthesis (Quantum Cordis®) 36-12 with extension to both iliac arteries and embolisation of the right hypogastric artery. The control renal arteriography was normal. Two hours after the operation
column7: sudden onset anuria was observed
column8: which did not improve with diuretic perfusion. Urgent arteriography (6 h postoperatively) showed total occlusion of the ostium of the left renal artery due to cranial migration of the stent. Urgent revascularisation surgery was decided by means of splenorenal shunt by left posterolateral lumbotomy at the XII rib level. Dissection of the left renal pedicle (1 artery
column9: 1 vein)
column10: renal reperfusion by lactated Ringer's solution at 4 C and end-to-end anastomosis with the splenic artery (discontinuous stitches of Prolene® 6/0). Reperfusion of the kidney was performed 12 hours after the onset of anuria
column11: with gradual recovery of colour and consistency
column12: maintaining a good pulse at the anastomosis. Spontaneous diuresis reappeared at 48 h
column13: having previously required a haemodialysis session due to hyperkalaemia and acidosis. The control Angio MRI (2 months) showed the permeability of the stent
column14: the absence of endoleaks and stenosis in the splenorenal anastomosis. At present
column15: the patient continues to have well controlled blood pressure with amlodipine and a creatinine level of 1.4 mg/dl.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 13 year old boy
column2: with no personal history of interest
column3: who comes to the health centre for consultation because for some months he has noticed a lesion on his left leg that does not cause any symptoms and has not changed in size. She refers to a possible traumatism to this area two years earlier after a fall on skates. He is in good general condition and is asymptomatic. A bony prominence of approximately 1.5-2 cm is palpated about 3-4 cm above the left internal malleolus. There is no local swelling
column4: haematoma or pain on palpation. There are also no distal neurovascular alterations or functional impotence.  A simple anteroposterior and lateral X-ray of the affected leg was requested
column5: showing a bony lesion. The radiological report gives the diagnosis: "The anteroposterior and lateral X-ray of the ankle shows a well-defined bony relief
column6: at the expense of the cortical layer
column7: with no apparent soft tissue involvement
column8: in the medial aspect of the distal third of the left tibia compatible with osteochondroma".  Given that it was an asymptomatic mass and had remained stable and conserved its size
column9: it was decided to follow its evolution in the consultation room and in the event of possible changes to carry out an imaging test and/or to make an appointment with the traumatology department for a check-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 59-year-old woman with no past history of interest was admitted for pain in the right epigastrium-hypochondrium radiating to the scapula together with jaundice and food intolerance of 5 days' evolution. On examination he had a heart rate of 80 bpm
column2: afebrile (36.3º)
column3: with jaundice of the skin and mucous membranes and on palpation the abdomen was soft
column4: depressible and non-painful. The ED blood test showed a total bilirubin of 11.63 mainly due to direct bilirubin (7.12)
column5: amylase of 135
column6: GPT 221
column7: LDH 557
column8: leukocytosis of 14
column9: 400 and eosinophilia of 5
column10: 480 (normal value: 0-0.8). An abdominal ultrasound was performed
column11: which revealed a well-defined cystic lesion measuring 6.9 x 6 cm in the right hepatic lobe
column12: compatible with a hydatid cyst
column13: together with multiple biliary lithiasis. Bladder
column14: pancreatic body
column15: kidneys
column16: spleen and bladder were normal. No free peritoneal fluid. In view of the findings
column17: the patient was started on albendazole treatment. After one day of admission the patient presented an episode of anaphylactic shock with dyspnoea and desaturation (pO2 50 mmHg
column18: SatO2 86.9)
column19: fever (38º)
column20: bilateral wheezing
column21: erythematous skin lesions and eosinophilia. The emergency abdominal CT scan showed no new data with respect to the ultrasound and after administering 80 mg i.v. of urbason and 1 i.v. ampoule of Polaramine®
column22: she underwent emergency surgery for anaphylaxis with the following findings: partially calcified hydatid cyst in segment V-VII and VIII
column23: intimately adhered to the diaphragm. Intraoperative ultrasound showed a cyst in contact with the inferior vena cava and right suprahepatic vein. The patient underwent puncture

column1: A 3-year-old boy was being studied by neurologists for suspected neurofibromatosis type 1 as he met at least one major diagnostic criterion (scattered café-au-lait spots). column2: homogeneous and isodense thickening of the NO with intact meninges compatible with the diagnosis of glioma of the NO in its intracanalicular and intraorbital portion
column3: thus confirming the diagnosis of neurofibromatosis type 1 as it fulfilled two major diagnostic criteria. Given that he had no lagophthalmos and his VA was preserved
column4: it was decided to have check-ups every 3 months during the first year

column7: 4 years after diagnosis
column8: both the VA and the radiological size of the lesion remained stable
column9: so for the time being we did not consider chemotherapy treatment and monitored the patient every 6 months

column1: A 31-year-old woman with a history of multiple sclerosis on treatment with interferon and bulimia nervosa
column2: diagnosed two years ago
column3: came to the emergency department for acute abdominal pain after a binge. She was undergoing individual and group psychotherapeutic treatment. She denies self-harm attempts or previous psychiatric admissions. She started binge eating when she was 15 years old in relation to the stress caused by exams and since then
column4: her life has revolved around binge eating and purgative behaviours. She reports that binge eating interferes with a normal working and social life. Since the onset of the eating disorder
column5: the number of binges exceeds monthly. The purgative measures she habitually uses are induced vomiting and laxatives. The patient comes to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain of 7 hours' duration
column6: accompanied by a feeling of fullness
column7: nausea and vomiting. She reported having eaten a large amount of food in the last few hours
column8: after which she had induced vomiting on several occasions without being effective. Physical examination revealed the patient's thinness: height 159 cm
column9: weight 42 kg (BMI: 17)
column10: the patient's abdomen was globular
column11: tympanic
column12: with scarce bowel sounds. Temperature 36.3 oC
column13: blood pressure 125/65 mmHg and heart rate 75 bpm. Plain abdominal X-ray showed a large gastric dilatation. Lymphocyte count: 19
column14: 800 with 93.5% neutrophils. Amylase 286 IU/l
column15: glycaemia: 229 mg/dl
column16: Na: 147 mmol/L
column17: K: 3.2 mmol/L
column18: LDH: 570 and creatinine kinase (CK) of 92. He was prescribed IV fluids
column19: enemas and nasogastric tube placement. Neither the enemas nor the nasogastric tube were effective. Ten hours later
column20: the patient went into preshock. Physical examination showed lividity in the lower limbs and weakness of the paedial pulses
column21: as well as a heart rate of 120 bpm
column22: blood pressure 80/60. Blood glucose: 430 mg/dl
column23: amylase: 1
column24: 485 Ul/l
column25: ALAT: 1
column27: LDH: 8
column29: CK: 8
column31: C-reactive protein: 32 ng/ml and metabolic acidosis with pH: 7.07
column32: PO2: 32 mmHg
column33: PCO2: 78 mmHg
column34: bicarbonate: 22.6 mEq/l and lactic acid of 33 mg/dl. Computed tomography examination showed large gastric dilatation
column35: occupying most of the abdominal cavity with a hydro-aerial level and aortic compression. The large gastric dilatation compresses the rest of the abdominal structures including the great vessels
column36: aorta and cava and their branches
column37: which is the cause of the low attenuation coefficient images identified in the pancreas and kidneys in relation to areas of ischaemia of these viscera.  Given the severity of the patient
column38: and the absence of improvement with conservative measures
column39: a laparotomy and gastrotomy was performed with extraction of food material (approximately 7 litres) from the gastric chamber
column40: in which a large amount of undigested food debris was found. Two days later
column41: a control CT scan was performed
column42: which showed a significant decrease in the volume of the gastric chamber and the restoration of the aortic calibre
column43: as well as the recovery of normal renal and pancreatic perfusion. After 4 weeks of admission to the ICU
column44: due to the existence of multi-organ failure related to hypoperfusion of abdominal viscera
column45: acute hepatic failure due to toxic-ischaemic hepatitis and toxic-metabolic encephalopathy
column46: pancreatic ischaemia
column47: intestinal ischaemia
column48: circulatory shock
column49: abdominal ischaemic-perfusion syndrome
column50: acute renal failure and acute respiratory failure
column51: she was discharged from the ICU in good clinical condition.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient is a 34-year-old male with no medical history of interest

column1: We present the case of a 30-year-old male from sub-Saharan Africa with a history of angiodema
column2: no previous surgery and no chronic treatments. He consulted for diarrhoea with mucus and blood for several weeks. Physical examination revealed splenomegaly and non-painful hepatomegaly. The haemogram showed a haemoglobin of 10.3 g
column4: 000 platelets
column6: 460 leukocytes
column7: with a normal formula. Liver function showed elevated liver enzymes (GOT 48
column8: GPT 63) and prothrombin activity 53%. On immunochemistry
column9: total IgE was 960 mg (VN < 100). Peripheral blood smear showed moderate anisocytosis with polysegmentation of neutrophils
column10: with no atypical cells. Serology for hepatotropic viruses
column11: HIV
column12: Toxoplasma
column13: cytomegalovirus
column14: Salmonella
column15: Brucella
column16: hydatidosis
column17: leishmaniasis
column18: fascioliasis and amoebiasis was negative
column19: with the exception of serology for Schistosoma which was positive at a titre of 1/512 (IgG). Stool and urine cultures and stool parasites were negative. Abdominal ultrasound showed indirect signs of chronic liver disease and a homogeneous splenomegaly of 16 cm
column20: with varicose veins in the splenic hilum. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy showed grade II/IV varicose veins in the oesophagus and very congestive gastric mucosa in the stomach
column21: especially in the antrum and gastric body
column22: and pseudotumoral varicose veins in the gastric cardia. A colonoscopy was performed
column23: revealing a petechial rectitis with a small polyp measuring 0.6 cm
column24: which was removed. Pathological examination of the rectal biopsies revealed a mixed inflammatory infiltrate with focal abscess formation and a moderate presence of eosinophils
column25: with no noticeable depletion of goblet cells. After multiple sections of the polypoid formation
column26: oval structures of refractive cuticle measuring 150 microns in maximum diameter with massive internal calcification were observed in the submucosa.  With the diagnosis of schistosomiasis with rectal and hepatic involvement
column27: treatment was started with praziquantel at a dose of 50 mg/kg body weight in three doses. The patient improved clinically and analytically
column28: with normalisation of liver function parameters and haemogram. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and abdominal ultrasound six months after treatment showed the disappearance of the oesophagogastric varices and the ultrasound signs of chronic liver disease.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 55-year-old man was referred to our hospital in November 2005 for odynophagia and oral bleeding. Physical examination revealed a necrotic ulcer 4-5 cm in diameter in the tonsillar pillar and left tonsil
column2: which was biopsied and found to be squamous cell carcinoma. The CT scan showed ipsilateral laterocervical adenopathies
column3: both submaxillary and jugulodigastric. Blood tests and other examinations were normal. A diagnosis of locally advanced squamous cell carcinoma of the oropharynx (T3-N2b-M0
column4: Stage IVa) was established and chemoradiotherapy treatment was started. Treatment consisted of hyperfractionated radiotherapy (120 cGy per fraction
column5: 2 fractions/day
column6: up to 7
column7: 680 cGy)
column8: and cisplatin
column9: 20 mg/m2/day in continuous perfusion for 120 hours
column10: between days 1-5 and 21-25 of treatment. At the end of treatment
column11: both physical examination and CT scan showed complete response. The patient remained asymptomatic until March 2007 when he came to our hospital with asthenia
column12: instability and abdominal pain followed by massive haematemesis with clinical and haematological involvement (Hb 7.1g
column13: haematocrit 21.5%). Gastroscopy showed an ulcerated tumour in the distal oesophagus
column14: over the cardia extending to the greater curvature and anterior and posterior face of the stomach. The result of the biopsy was epidermoid carcinoma compatible with metastasis of laryngeal carcinoma.  Throughout the hospital stay
column15: several transfusions were necessary and treatment with somatostatin was started
column16: despite which the bleeding remained active. Palliative radiotherapy treatment was then started with haemostatic intent
column17: administering 20Gy in 5 fractions of 400cGy with good digestive tolerance and achieving remission of the bleeding episodes. The patient was discharged and remained asymptomatic for another 5 months
column18: after which he died of metastatic dissemination.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Woman
column2: 27 years old
column3: nursing professional in the hospitalisation area of Internal Medicine
column4: suffered an accident at work involving a puncture with abbocath during the working day on 23/11/1989. A review of the clinical case of the source patient and the respective confirmatory tests were carried out
column5: and no information on transmissible diseases was found in the clinical history. The tests carried out on the patient and the worker were negative for viral markers for hepatitis. 15 days later

column7: abdominal pain in the right hypochondrium
column8: of mild intensity
column9: continuous
column10: without irradiation
column11: not relieved by changes in posture or outpatient treatment

column13: vomiting and asthenia. She denied choluria

column17: Lysozyme®

column1: A 13-year-old boy with a personal history of Asperger's syndrome
column2: attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and hypothyroidism
