column1: This is a 42-year-old man with no medical history of interest
column2: and with vasectomy surgery as the only urological history. He came to our clinic due to a chance finding of a nodule in the right testicle. An ultrasound scan was requested
column3: which revealed a well-defined
column4: homogeneous
column5: hypoechoic image of homogeneous density
column6: located in the upper pole of the right testicle. The alpha-fetoprotein and beta-HCG tumour markers were normal
column7: as was the rest of the physical examination
column8: where no signs of hormonal overproduction were observed. It was therefore decided to perform an intraoperative biopsy of the nodule
column9: which was reported as a low-grade spindle-shaped tumour without being able to rule out malignancy
column10: so it was decided to perform a radical right orchiectomy via the inguinal route. The patient had a good postoperative evolution and was discharged the following day. The definitive anatomopathological report was a non-specific spindle-shaped tumour of the sexual stroma. No signs of recurrence or progression have been observed in the subsequent follow-up of this patient.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Infant
column2: Caucasian
column3: the first child of young
column4: healthy
column5: non-consanguineous parents (mother aged 28 and father aged 30)
column6: with no history of hereditary-familial pathology
column7: renal or known hypertension. Gestation correctly monitored and without alterations. Euthocic birth at 37 weeks without complications
column8: presenting an Apgar test of 9/10. Anthropometry at birth
column9: weight 2
column10: 760 grams
column11: with a cephalo-caudal diameter of 48.5 cm and head circumference of 34.7 cm. VDRL
column12: AntHBs
column13: HIV negative
column14: non-immune Toxoplasmosis and immune rubella. Bilateral auricular appendages
column15: low implantation of the pinna
column16: cutaneous granulomas
column17: micrognathism with mandibular hypoplasia
column18: coloboma located in the left eye and solid scrotal tumefaction apparently not painful on palpation. Vaccination schedule up to date.  The infant was transferred from another hospital at 19 days of life with a diagnosis of urosepsis. He was initially admitted to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit to stabilise the condition by means of support measures and antibiotic therapy with ampicillin
column19: gentamicin and cefotaxime. Reno-pelvic-scrotal ultrasound revealed bilateral uretero-hydronephrosis and thick-walled bladder
column20: right scrotal swelling
column21: with apparent hypo- and hyperechogenic images with septa and apparent testicular destruction. Once the parameters were stabilised and with negative uroculture
column22: we performed a serial voiding cystourethrogram showing dilatation of the posterior urethra
column23: trabeculated bladder and no presence of vesico-ureteral reflux
column24: suspecting posterior urethral valve disease.  Whole body bone radiographs did not detect bone alterations or vertebral alterations. We performed fulguration of the posterior urethral valves and right inguinal orchidectomy. The postoperative period passed without complications. The catheter was removed on the seventh postoperative day. He was discharged with normal renal function
column25: negative uroculture and correct diuresis. At the fourth month of life he was hospitalised with a diagnosis of respiratory infection in the context of bronchiolitis
column26: with positive urocultures for polymicrobial flora
column27: he was medicated with antibiotherapy and discharged with antibiotic prophylaxis with trimethoprim-sufamethoxazole. At the fifth month with aseptic urine
column28: we performed endovenous urography and renal cintilogram with MAG-3 and furosemide test
column29: showing bilateral ureteral dilatation
column30: right renal bifidity
column31: with normal bladder capacity and complete emptying of the bladder
column32: urethra apparently without alterations
column33: bilateral renal function is preserved
column34: responding to the furosemide test. We reached the diagnosis of bilateral non-obstructive ureteral dilatations associated with pyelic bifidity. We decided to carry out check-ups every 6 months. In the last control the 15 month old child showed normal renal function
column35: good diuresis and urinary sediments without alterations.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 52-year-old male patient attended the emergency department with loss of vision in his right eye after a week's evolution. His past history included: right nephrectomy for renal carcinoma seven years earlier and right pneumonectomy for pulmonary metastasis three months earlier. At that time he was not receiving any treatment. On ophthalmological examination his visual acuity was 0.1 in his right eye and unity in his left eye; the anterior pole and intraocular pressure were normal. Funduscopy of the right eye showed a uniform whitish choroidal mass at the level of the inferior temporal arcade of approximately four papillary diameters
column2: with associated retinal detachment (RD) involving the macula
column3: with no signs of intraocular inflammation. The left eye was normal. A B-mode ultrasound was performed showing a 3x6 mm cupuliform choroidal mass of medium-high reflectivity
column4: without choroidal excavation. Angiography showed a mass with early hypofluorescence
column5: late hyperfluorescence and a slightly mottled pattern. Given the patient's history
column6: the medical oncology department was consulted and performed the appropriate tests to rule out progression of the process. During this time the lesion and associated DR increased in size
column7: affecting the macula. Initially
column8: radiotherapy treatment was proposed to the patient
column9: but he rejected it and opted for surgery. Enucleation was performed one month after diagnosis. Pathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of renal carcinoma metastasis
column10: without extending beyond the choroid and without infiltrating the optic nerve. During one year of follow-up by the medical oncology department
column11: no progression of the process was observed and the patient only received immunotherapy with interferon. One year after diagnosis of the choroidal metastasis
column12: signs of progression have appeared and the patient has also received hormone therapy and chemotherapy
column13: with no clear improvement.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 55-year-old patient receiving cadaveric transplant. Induction: daclizumab-tacrolimus-MMF-steroids. Maintenance: tacrolimus-MMF-steroids. Creatinine 1 and 1.2 mg/dl; creatinine clearance: 96 ml
column2: without proteinuria. Nine months post-transplant
column3: he presented viruria (107 copies/ml) for BKV
column4: without renal dysfunction
column5: with negative viremia. High viruria persisted with negative viraemia
column6: which was positive at month 12 (> 104 copies/ml)
column7: the biopsy showed interstitial nephritis
column8: tubular nuclear alterations linked to BKV. Immunosuppressive medication was rotated to sirolimus 2 mg/day and cipro-floxacin 500 mg/day (10 days) was added. Renal function remained stable
column9: with a clearance of 86 ml
column10: no proteinuria and a decrease in viral load in urine and blood. At present
column11: the patient retained his kidney and did not require dialysis.  |O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 77-year-old man came to the hospital emergency department for vomiting for a week associated with absence of bowel movements
column2: with pain in the right inguinal region lasting three days. No cognitive impairment but severe social deterioration. He reports that for the last year he has only been drinking liquids
column3: with a weight loss of 15kg during this period (usual weight approximately 70kg; current weight on admission 55kg). He has not left the house for 15 days with bed-chair life
column4: lives with his 87-year-old blind wife and has poor personal hygiene. The patient had a personal history of untreated supranasal terebranous basal cell epithelioma and gastric ulcer previously treated with cimetidine. Physical examination on admission revealed signs of peripheral hypoperfusion
column5: severe cachexia and irreducible right inguinoscrotal hernia
column6: with probable intestinal contents and a distended abdomen painful on palpation. Intestinal obstruction secondary to incarcerated inguinal hernia was diagnosed and surgery was performed
column7: with resection of the ischaemic and perforated intestinal segment with latero-lateral anastomosis and herniorrhaphy. During surgery
column8: diffuse peritonitis and haemodynamic instability were observed. Given the presence of signs of shock and decreased level of consciousness despite being unsedated
column9: the patient was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). Antibiotic treatment with imipenem was started
column10: with a favourable evolution during the first four days
column11: until a progressive increase in signs of infection and inflammation (leukocytosis of 38.320 leukocytes/mm3 and CRP of 273 mg/L) suggestive of abdominal sepsis
column12: with haemodynamic instability
column13: acute renal failure (oedematous state
column14: anuria and serum creatinine up to 3.35 mg/dL)
column15: sudden anaemisation (haemoglobin levels of 6.2 g/dL and haematocrit of 18.5%)
column16: and biliary contents leaking from the drains. In view of these findings
column17: a new surgical intervention was performed. From the nutritional point of view
column18: the patient presented severe calorie-protein malnutrition
column19: with severe hypoalbuminaemia and hypoproteinaemia (albumin 1.4 g/dL and protein 3.7 g/dL)
column20: and it was decided to start
column21: after haemodynamic stabilisation
column22: IV nutritional support from the second day of admission to the unit. Initially
column23: total parenteral nutrition (TPN) was prescribed with a macronutrient intake corresponding to a 70kg patient with severe metabolic stress. The Pharmacy Department identified the patient as being at high risk of suffering RS
column24: given his cachectic state and the personal history previously described (loss of > 20% of body weight in one year
column25: severe psychosocial problems and depression in the elderly). Given the added complexity of the patient's acute renal failure and the high risk of RH
column26: a progressive start of nutritional support is recommended
column27: adapting the macronutrient intake to the patient's actual and not ideal weight. In accordance with the recommendations of the main clinical guidelines for the prevention of RH
column28: 6 prophylactic administration of thiamine is recommended
column29: and parenteral nutrition is started with a caloric intake of approximately 15 kcal/kg of current weight (caloric distribution of 39% carbohydrates
column30: 39% lipids and 22% proteins)
column31: a total volume of approximately 1500 mL and close monitoring of nutritional and analytical parameters (mainly intracellular ions). Phosphate
column32: potassium and magnesium intake is restricted during the first days
column33: due to hyperphosphataemia (phosphate 8.91 mg/dL)
column34: hyperkalaemia (potassium 5.27 mEq/L) and hypermagnesaemia (magnesium 3 mg/dL) triggered by acute renal failure. Calorie-protein intake is slowly increased on consecutive days
column35: with special caution with nitrogen intake during the first week due to the patient's renal failure. From the tenth day onwards
column36: the patient's nutritional requirements are finally met. The energy intake is 30 kcal/kg (caloric distribution of 48% carbohydrates
column37: 30% lipids and 22% proteins)
column38: with a protein intake of 1.6g/kg
column39: adapting to the patient's metabolic situation. During the first few days
column40: the analytical and nutritional parameters evolved favourably in parallel with the improvement in renal function
column41: until the onset of abdominal sepsis and all the complications described above.  Given the patient's age
column42: the current disease and the poor prognosis of the complications that developed
column43: a decision was made at a joint session to limit the therapeutic effort
column44: and the patient died on the 17th day of admission.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Female patient
column2: 44 years old
column3: referred to our unit due to an increase in volume in the zygomatic region and progressive limitation of mouth opening of 10 months of evolution. The medical history was not relevant. The extraoral physical examination showed facial asymmetry due to an increase in volume in the left cheek
column4: with diffuse limits
column5: bony consistency
column6: painless
column7: with normal skin appearance. The mouth opening was 30 mm. The temporomandibular joint (TMJ) was normal on palpation
column8: with no noises or pain on opening. On orthopantomography we observed an enlarged left coronoid process. The diagnostic hypothesis was a coronoid tumour.  An incision was made over the anterior border of the mandibular ramus
column9: disinserting all the insertions of the temporalis muscle. A fibrous pseudocapsule was found around the enlargement
column10: which was released. Coronoidectomy was performed. The buccal opening was immediately restored to 43 mm. The postoperative course was uneventful
column11: and the patient was discharged after 48 hours. Histopathological study reported the presence of fibres
column12: neoformation bone and hyaline cartilage tissue. The diagnosis was osteochondroma. Subsequent check-ups were uneventful. Definitive discharge was given at 10 months
column13: with almost complete remodelling of the cheek deformity.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 19-year-old male patient referred from a regional hospital for surgery for hydrocephalus. He had a history of approximately 1 year of left hemicranial headache that worsened on exertion. In recent weeks the headache had increased in intensity and frequency. The neurological examination showed only bilateral papillary oedema. The patient provided a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan showing supratentorial ventricular dilatation with an Evans index of 0.43
column2: periependymal clearing in the frontal horn and a small tectal lesion that was not modified by contrast. The fourth ventricle was normal.  With the diagnosis of stenosis of the aqueduct of Sylvius
column3: an endoscopic premamillary ventriculocysternostomy was performed through a right frontal trephine hole according to the standard technique3. A Mayfield clamp (Ohio Medical Instrument Co
column4: Inc.
column5: Cincinnati
column6: Oh
column7: USA) was used for head immobilisation. The immediate postoperative period was uneventful
column8: although the patient suffered from headache. Forty-eight hours after surgery and prior to the scheduled discharge from hospital
column9: a new MRI was performed in which the presence of a left parietal epidural haematoma with a mass effect on the ipsilateral lateral ventricle was noted.  A left parietal craniotomy was then performed
column10: showing a perforation that went through the entire bone without affecting the dura mater. The haematoma was drained and a small bleeding dural artery was coagulated. The patient was discharged after 6 days with only some degree of headache. One year after surgery he is asymptomatic and the tectal lesion shows no change on MRI studies.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Eight year old boy born and living in Sierra Leone who consulted Saint John of God Hospital in Sierra Leone for a lump on the lower eyelid of the left eye with an evolution time of about one month. The father reported a history of contact with papaya leaves. On examination
column2: there was a hard lump covering the outer two thirds of the lower left eyelid
column3: with ulcerations on the skin surface and mucosa of the lower left eyelid. There were also adenopathies on both sides of the neck. The rest of the examination showed no relevant findings.  The impossibility of performing microbiological cultures in the field made it necessary to administer systemic and local antibiotic coverage as the first therapeutic option in case it was an infectious process. Oral amoxicillin/clavulanic acid
column4: and topical tobramycin and acyclovir were administered. However
column5: the most striking symptom was the stony consistency of the tumour
column6: together with regional lymphadenopathy suggestive of a neoformative process. Finally
column7: contact with papaya led to the possibility of contact dermatitis due to the latex exuded by these fruits when they are green1. A skin biopsy was performed and sent to a referral hospital. Pathology showed a fibrin and polynuclear exudate in the superficial area of the ulcer and granulation tissue in the deep regions
column8: where histiocytes with herpes-like intranuclear inclusions and giant multinucleated cells with nuclei containing intranuclear inclusion bodies were identified. Skeletal muscle from the deepest biopsy site showed a non-specific focal inflammatory reaction. PAS staining was negative. The diagnosis was: ulcerated lesion with features compatible with herpes virus infection
column9: accompanied by probably bacterial superinfection.  After three weeks
column10: the lower eyelid tumour began to decrease in size
column11: as did the induration
column12: while the ulcerations healed. At one and a half months
column13: the repair was complete.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 76-year-old female patient consulted a hospital emergency department for pain in the mandibular area that had been developing for three days. After the medical examination
column2: the patient was sent home with the diagnosis of "mandibular arthrosis" and was prescribed painkillers and recommended to see a dentist. Hours later
column3: the patient came to our surgery
column4: where we applied the protocol for the study of patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) and
column5: as a complementary examination
column6: we performed an orthopantomography. Among the patient's personal medical history
column7: it should be noted that she had suffered from arterial hypertension for 3 years and hypercholesterolemia for a year. In the anamnesis regarding the temporospatial characteristics of the pain
column8: the patient reported episodes of pain in the bilateral submandibular region
column9: of three days' duration
column10: which now radiated to the precordial area and the throat. The episodes of pain last between five and ten minutes
column11: with a sensation of shortness of breath and accompanying sweating. On this day he had three episodes. This pain has been resistant to the painkillers prescribed by the emergency department. After a complete stomatological examination
column12: we found an opening click in the right temporomandibular joint and crepitus on the left side. Occlusally there was a crossbite and deviation of the dental midline. Mandibular function was preserved with a maximum opening of 39 mm. The orthopantomography showed signs of mild arthrosis in the left temporomandibular joint. These findings did not justify the patient's pain
column13: so we made a clinical diagnosis of presumed "ischaemic heart disease" and referred the patient urgently from our practice to a hospital for evaluation and treatment. The patient was admitted to the hospital and while undergoing clinical examinations
column14: she presented again with several episodes of jaw pain. The electrocardiogram (ECG) showed signs of enlargement and systolic overload of the left ventricle
column15: negative T in II
column16: III
column17: aVF and from V4 to V6. After performing the relevant complementary studies: blood tests
column18: chest X-ray
column19: echocardiogram and diagnostic catheterisation
column20: a severe lesion was found in two coronary vessels. Angioplasty was performed and after three weeks she was discharged with a diagnosis of unstable angina (Grade III
column22: severe lesion of two coronary vessels and double degenerative aortic lesion. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 70-year-old male patient
column2: who was admitted to the emergency department of the Hospital Pablo Tobón Uribe
column3: with symptoms of approximately one hour of evolution consisting of chest tightness
column4: general malaise
column5: asthenia and diaphoresis; which began after having ingested 100 mg of sildenafil
column6: denies ingestion of another sexual stimulant or cocaine and without sexual intercourse after its consumption. The patient's only clinical history was arterial hypertension
column7: pharmacologically controlled
column8: and he denies previous episodes of angina or nitrate consumption. The clinical examination and vital signs were normal; however
column9: after the initial assessment he presented cardiorespiratory arrest secondary to ventricular fibrillation with response to a single defibrillation of 200 joules. The initial electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevation in the inferior (II
column10: III and aVF) and anterior (V2-V4) leads with reciprocal changes in aVL
column11: with no electrocardiographic extension to the right ventricle.  Cardiac enzymes on admission revealed a creatine kinase (CK) of 170 and a creatine phosphokinase-MB fraction (CK-MB) of 6. Electrolytes
column12: coagulation tests and blood cell counts were normal. Initial management was with aspirin 100 mg
column13: lovastatin 40 mg daily
column14: metoprolol 25 mg every 12 hours
column15: enoxaparin 60 mg every 12 hours
column16: oxygen at 3 lt/min and streptokinase 1'500
column17: 000 units administered over 30 minutes. No changes secondary to reperfusion were demonstrated. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit
column18: where episodes of complete A-V block with spontaneous resolution were documented during the first hours of evolution. The EKG taken at 24 hours of evolution revealed QS in the inferior face and a late progression of the R wave in the anterior face. Enzyme monitoring showed increased CK and MB fraction at 6 hours (4476 and 165) and 12 hours (3839 and 136). The next day coronary angiography showed diffuse disease of the anterior descending artery with 50% lesion in the distal third and 40% lesion in the proximal third of the first diagonal branch. The circumflex artery had a 50% lesion in the middle third and diffuse disease of its obtuse marginal branches. The right coronary artery had an irregular lesion suggestive of a partially resolved thrombus producing a maximum stenosis of 50%; distally the posterior descending artery had two 40% lesions.  The patient evolved satisfactorily without further complications and pain-free. He was discharged for outpatient follow-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 55-year-old patient attended the emergency department with a visual acuity (VA) deficit in the right eye (RA). The VA was 0.1 in the OD and 1 in the left eye with correction. His personal history included a deep vein thrombosis in the right leg 5 years earlier and arterial hypertension under treatment. He had no known family history of thrombophilia. Intraocular pressure
column2: biomicroscopy and ocular motility were normal. Ophthalmoscopy of the OD showed peripapillary flame haemorrhages
column3: vascular tortuosity
column4: cotton wool exudates and macular oedema. Fluorescein angiography confirmed the existence of an oedematous central venous thrombosis. The basic coagulation study showed elevated tissue prothrombin levels (1.55 Uml) and a thrombophilia study was requested
column5: which revealed increased resistance to activated protein c (1.5). In the genetic analysis
column6: DNA fragments including nucleotides 1691 of the factor V gene and 20210 of factor II were amplified by PCR
column7: and electrophoresis subsequently identified the mutation 1691 G-A of factor V and 20210 G-A of factor II. The rest of the study included haemogram
column8: sedimentation rate
column9: general biochemistry and other causes of hypercoagulability (proteins S and C
column10: antithrombin III
column11: fibrinogen
column12: antinuclear antibodies
column13: homocysteinemia and antiphospholipid antibodies) with no significant findings. It was decided to anticoagulate the patient with acenocoumarol (sintrom®). From the ophthalmological point of view
column14: he did not require photocoagulation
column15: as he did not develop retinal ischaemia.
