column1: This is a 65 year old female patient who was regularly seen in our department after having undergone two operations for retinal detachment (RD) in her right eye (OD) in 1978. The first surgery consisted of diathermy in the upper nasal quadrant where there was a retinal tear and placement of a segmented scleral implant. One month later
column2: after suffering a recurrence of DR
column3: a complete scleral cerclage was placed and knotted in the inferior temporal quadrant and diathermy was performed in this quadrant due to retinal degeneration. The patient had a good postoperative period in which good indentation of the segmented implant and prominent cerclage were observed. Although she had no symptoms
column4: in 1997 the examination revealed scleral perforation with intrusion of the cerclage of half an hour's extension in the inferior temporal area
column5: in an extensive area of chorioretinal atrophy. Due to the extent of the intrusion and the extensive area of chorioretinal atrophy
column6: it was decided to observe the patient.  One year later
column7: the patient underwent cataract surgery in the right eye by phacoemulsification and implantation of a lens in the capsular sac. Seven years later
column8: YAG capsulotomy was performed in the OD due to capsular opacity. The patient came to the clinic one month later with HV in the OD. Ultrasonography showed the HV
column9: the absence of RD and the intrusion of the cerclage. After partial resorption of the HV during the first month
column10: the patient had a new bleed and vitrectomy was performed to clean the blood.  Sixteen months after surgery
column11: the patient remains asymptomatic with no extension of the intraocular size of the cerclage.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 62-year-old female patient who underwent surgery in December 2010 for papillary serous carcinoma of the left ovary with involvement of a lymph node of the aorto-caval chain (stage IIIC). She subsequently received adjuvant chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel
column2: ending in June 2011. Later
column3: she started follow-up and remained asymptomatic until April 2013
column4: when a CA 125 elevation of 88.4 U/ml (0-35 U/ml) was detected. A CT scan showed an image adjacent to the colon and she underwent anterior resection of the upper rectum with intraoperative biopsy of a liver lesion which confirmed the metastatic nature. A second line of treatment with carboplatin and paclitaxel was started
column5: showing a CA 125 value of 123.3 U/ml. After a first cycle with good tolerance
column6: we scheduled the second cycle and during the first few minutes of the carboplatin infusion
column7: he presented a sudden onset of dyspnoea
column8: vomiting
column9: loss of consciousness and an SAC/TAD of 70/50 mmHg. The infusion was stopped and after the administration of corticosteroids the symptoms began to subside. The Allergology Unit recommended a desensitisation5 scheme with slowing of the infusion rate. For this purpose
column10: three solutions were used with concentrations of 0.02
column11: 0.2 and 2 mg/ml respectively
column12: in addition to premedication the night before and half an hour before the infusion with: - Cetirizine 10 mg - Prednisone 1 mg/kg - Ranitidine 150 mg - Montelukast 10 mg Despite this
column13: a few minutes later
column14: he began with dyspnoea
column15: sweating and blood pressure of 85/60 mmHg
column16: forcing the infusion to be stopped and recommending no further use of any platinum salt. In September 2013
column17: it was decided to start 3rd line chemotherapy with trabectedin and pegylated liposomal adriamycin. After the third cycle
column18: the markers normalised and she completed the sixth cycle
column19: and is currently disease-free.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 25-year-old man was admitted in May 2007 due to non-specific abdominal discomfort of 48 hours' duration accompanied by rectorrhagia on the morning he came to the emergency department. His personal history included a slight decrease in coagulation factor VII
column2: two episodes of self-limited lower gastrointestinal bleeding in 1999 (gastroscopy
column3: colonoscopy
column4: scintigraphy with Tc99
column5: enteroscopy
column6: intestinal transit and arteriography without lesions) and another episode in 2004 (gastroscopy
column7: colonoscopy and ileoscopy and scintigraphy with marked red blood cells without abnormalities) manifested as haematochezia. Physical examination revealed nothing remarkable and the patient's haemodynamics remained stable. Emergency tests showed normal haemogram
column8: biochemistry and coagulation. Given the patient's history
column9: it was decided to begin the study with a scintigraphy with labelled red blood cells. Five hours after administering the tracer
column10: a pathological deposit was observed in the right flank
column11: compatible with activity in the small intestine at the level of the ileum
column12: cecum or ascending colon. In order to rule out possible bleeding in these locations
column13: it was decided to perform a colonoscopy that same afternoon
column14: in which haematic remains were observed along the entire path explored up to 15 cm of the ileum
column15: without finding a clear bleeding point. In view of the persistent lower gastrointestinal bleeding
column16: the patient remained stable
column17: and it was decided to transfuse 2 red blood cell concentrates and perform an arteriography in which no abnormalities were observed.  In view of these findings
column18: it was decided to perform an endoscopic capsule enteroscopy (ECE) to assess the rest of the small intestine. The same afternoon of the day of the procedure
column19: the patient presented with frank rectorrhagia with clinical and analytical repercussions (haemoglobin 4.7g/dl
column20: and haematocrit 13.7%). In this situation
column21: 3 red blood cell concentrates were transfused and the on-call surgeon was contacted
column22: deciding to perform a new urgent arteriography without evidence of a bleeding point. In this new clinical scenario
column23: an urgent laparotomy was performed in which Meckel's diverticulum was observed 50 cm from the ileocaecal valve with active haemorrhage from it
column24: with no evidence of proximal bleeding. Ileal resection was performed including the diverticulum with termino-terminal anastomosis with a satisfactory subsequent evolution. The capsule examination visualised the following day showed the presence of abundant fresh haematic debris in the distal sections of the ileum.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: In the month of March 2005
column2: a 30 year old patient presented for observation at the Department of Odontostomatological Surgery of the Università degli studi di Milano-Bicocca
column3: at the San Gerardo di Monza Hospital
column4: for a consultation on dental element 2.8 (upper left third molar). The patient did not present any relevant clinical symptoms
column5: except for a slight pain in the area of the third molar. The extraoral examination revealed no relevant signs and palpation of the neck lymph nodes showed a normal situation. Intraoral examination revealed partial mucosal inclusion of element 2.8
column6: with no particular variations in colour and consistency on palpation of the area under examination. Radiographic analysis with orthopantomography
column7: element 2.8 showed increased radiolucent areas.  The patient
column8: who had no systemic pathologies
column9: had element 2.8 removed in March 2005 and a biopsy of the adjacent tissues
column10: measuring approximately 1.0 x 1.0 x 1.0 centimetres. The diagnosis on the basis of the histological report was plexiform ameloblastoma.  Further radiographic diagnosis by means of computerised axial tomography with the Dentascan programme showed the involvement of a large area of the left maxilla reaching the base of the orbit.  In May 2005
column11: under general anaesthesia
column12: a hemi-maxillectomy was performed with wide safety margins starting from the first upper left premolar
column13: according to the principle
column14: supported by many authors
column15: which inspires the therapy of malignant tumours
column16: of "resection in apparently healthy tissues".  Further histological analysis of the surgical specimen confirmed the diagnosis of plexiform ameloblastoma. Regarding the prosthetic treatment
column17: impressions of the jaws were made prior to surgery and after casting
column18: a simulation of the surgical procedure was performed on plaster models. With the help of CT
column19: the margins of the resection were established
column20: with particular attention to the anterior margin
column21: which was important in order not to prejudice the correct positioning of the palatal prosthesis.  The palatal obturation prosthesis was mucosa-supported and dento-retained with hooks in elements 2.3 and laterally 1.4 and 1.5 and 1.7 and 1.8. At the end of the operation
column22: the fit of the prosthetic restoration was checked and found to be adequate.  Figure 9 shows how after 6 months
column23: normotrophic and well vascularised tissues can be observed in the resection area.  The prosthesis has been periodically checked and adapted to the tissue conditions according to the healing and the possibility of adding the teeth
column24: keeping them out of occlusion
column25: will be considered until the reconstruction phase with implants.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We describe the case of a 67 year old woman
column2: with no urological history of interest
column3: who presented with macroscopic monosymptomatic haematuria with clots of 2 days' evolution. Initially
column4: conservative treatment was decided with bladder catheterisation and a saline solution washout circuit. After 24 hours the patient was anaemic and hypotensive
column5: requiring vasoactive amines and polytransfusion of blood concentrates. An abdominal-pelvic CT scan was performed
column6: which revealed a bladder completely occupied by a large bladder clot and secondary moderate bilateral ureterohydronephrosis.  The patient was operated on endoscopically and approximately 1 litre of clot was evacuated. The bladder mucosa is hyperemic
column7: with diffuse bleeding
column8: with no evidence of endovesical lesions. Electrocoagulation of several areas with active bleeding was performed. The patient was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit with orotracheal intubation and support treatment with vasoactive amines. Intravenous aminocaproic acid is added to the treatment. After 24 hours the bladder was again clotted and the patient continued to be anaemic and haemodynamically unstable
column9: despite having received a transfusion of 10 blood concentrates. In view of this situation
column10: we decided to perform bilateral percutaneous nephrostomy (BCN) with the dual intention of solving the obstructive problem caused by bladder obstruction and attempting to reduce bleeding at this level. Bilateral percutaneous nephrostomy was performed under general anaesthesia in the Valdivia position
column11: placing 8 Ch catheters through the lower calyx
column12: with no incidences.  Twenty-four hours after bilateral CPN
column13: the patient improved significantly
column14: ceasing haematuria and not requiring new blood transfusions. Two days later
column15: vasoactive amines and orotracheal intubation were withdrawn
column16: and the patient was discharged from the Intensive Care Unit on the fourth day. Once the acute symptoms were over
column17: a new endoscopic examination of the bladder was scheduled with biopsies. The anatomo-pathological study revealed as the only notable alteration the presence of an eosinophilic material around the blood vessels of the submucosa. This substance stained with Congo Red stain and turned apple green under polarised light with birefringence
column18: which confirmed that it was amyloid. The immunohistochemical study of the lesion with monoclonal antibodies (clone mc1)
column19: specific against the AA protein of amyloid was positive
column20: allowing the diagnosis of secondary bladder amyloidosis (Type AA). The postoperative period was uneventful
column21: the nephrostomies were removed after 20 days and the patient was discharged after one month.  After 6 months of follow-up
column22: the patient has not presented haematuria again and is awaiting studies to rule out systemic involvement due to amyloidosis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 24-year-old drug addict
column2: HIV-negative woman with a 9-month history of nodular pulmonary infiltrates with a clinical diagnosis of possible granulomatosis. She presented 1 month ago with fever and abdominal pain due to a right adnexal mass. On examination
column3: a 12 cm right ovarian mass was seen
column4: together with another 2 cm mass in the middle of the transverse colon
column5: which was removed. At the same time
column6: the patient reported a 4 cm tumour on the right thigh
column7: located deep in the subcutaneous cellular tissue. The ovarian tumour and the mesenteric nodule had a lobulated external surface
column8: the section surface of which showed solid and cystic areas. In the ovary
column9: the cells were predominantly epithelioid in morphology with prominent nucleolus and diffuse growth pattern with small cystic spaces or pseudofollicles. In the mesenteric nodule a spindle cell morphology predominated. Alternating hypercellular and hypocellular areas were observed. There were extensive and frequent areas of geographic necrosis with a tendency to preserve those tumour cells surrounding the vessels resulting in a peritheliomatous pattern. At higher magnification
column10: the spindle-shaped tumour cells showed an oval nucleus and a non-prominent nucleolus. More than 10-20 mitoses per 10 high magnification fields were observed. Immunophenotypically the tumour expressed vimentin
column12: HMB-45 and actin. Staining for S-100 was intense and diffuse. The tumour did not express epithelial markers or other markers such as CD 117
column13: CD 68
column14: CD 99
column15: collagen IV
column16: oestrogen receptors
column17: progesterone receptors and inhibin. The thigh tumour subsequently removed was unrelated to the epidermis and histologically superimposable to the ovarian tumour. The distribution of the tumour nodules
column18: the combination of histological patterns and the immunohistochemical profile was consistent with the diagnosis of metastatic malignant melanoma
column19: originating from a primary tumour of unknown origin as the patient was scanned and no worrisome pigmented lesions were found and there was no evidence of regression of one of them.  Treatment with chemotherapy (Cisplatin
column20: Interleukin II
column21: Dacarbazine and Interferon alfa) was started and 3 months later
column22: the patient died developing multiple abdominal metastases
column23: including a 13 cm contralateral ovarian mass
column24: retroperitoneal adenopathies and multiple subcutaneous metastases.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 35-year-old man
column2: with a history of lupus
column3: unaffiliated hepatitis and circumcision at the age of 4 years
column4: consulted for bifidity of the urinary stream. On examination
column5: the meatus was normal and there were no fistulas. The penis was larger than normal and the corpora cavernosa were erect
column6: with no involvement of the glans penis.  On cross-examination
column7: he states that he has been in this situation for as long as he can remember and that
column8: as a child
column9: he used to hold his penis with a string around his waist so that his erection would not be noticed. Regarding his sexual activity
column10: he affirms his homosexual choice and his satisfaction with the size of his penis and his permanent erection
column11: which allows him to have successive and indefinite coitus. He has no ejaculation problems. Penile Doppler ultrasound was performed
column12: with time/velocity values in the corpora cavernosa compatible with erection (right cavernous systolic velocity of 51 cm/sec and 41 cm/sec on the left side). Probable arterio-cavernous fistula in the proximal portion of the right corpus cavernosum. MRI angiography demonstrates arterio-cavernous fistula on the right side
column13: which is present in both the arterial and venous phases and confirms the diagnosis of high-flow arterial priapism.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 38-year-old man
column2: with no urological history of interest
column3: who consulted for a slowly growing
column4: progressive and painless tumour on the left scrotum that had been present for seven months. Physical examination revealed a soft mass of about 3 cm
column5: not painful on palpation or adhered to adjacent structures
column6: with negative transillumination and normal testicles. With negative testicular markers
column7: an ultrasound scan was performed
column8: which was reported as a homogeneous paratesticular lesion with regular borders of about 2 cm
column9: suspicious of lipoma.  Given the diagnostic doubts
column10: a surgical exploration was performed in which a lipoma of about 2 x 1.5 cm was observed in the spermatic cord
column11: yellowish in colour
column12: soft in consistency and easily resectable. Given the suspicion of paratesticular lipoma
column13: a left inguinal excision of the mass was performed
column14: separating it from the spermatic cord. Subsequently
column15: the anatomopathological study revealed the presence of a well-differentiated LPS of the lipoma-like subtype. It was decided not to complete the surgery with orchiectomy due to the small size of the tumour and its lower grade stage associated with a good prognosis. After 26 months of surgical treatment the patient is asymptomatic with no evidence of tumour recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 26 year old patient was referred from the outpatient department of the digestive service to assess some lesions that had recently appeared on the preputial skin. His family history includes Crohn's disease in a twin brother; his personal history includes Crohn's disease diagnosed six years earlier
column2: which has presented with severe outbreaks during these years and has required treatment with corticoids and immunosuppressants. In one of these flare-ups
column3: surgery was necessary
column4: in which a total colectomy and ileostomy were performed according to the Brooke technique. The immediate postoperative course was satisfactory. In the months following the operation
column5: he developed severe granulomatous rectitis
column6: treated with deflazacort and mesalazine rectal enemas. The patient is also being studied by the haematology department for persistently prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT). He was referred to us from the Digestive outpatient clinic for presenting a lesion on the preputial skin that had been present for a year and a half
column7: in the form of an erythematous
column8: ulcerated plaque. It had been treated with topical corticosteroids with the diagnosis of suspected pyoderma gangrenosum
column9: but had not progressed satisfactorily. In addition
column10: the patient reported itching and some suppuration
column11: so a sample was taken for culture
column12: which showed growth of urethral colonising flora with no pathological significance. It was decided to perform a circumcision
column13: sending the preputial skin to the pathological anatomy service with the following result: non-caseating granuloma
column14: with ulceration
column15: typical of metastatic Crohn's disease.  After excision of the lesion
column16: no recurrence was observed after one year of follow-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 38-year-old male
column2: hypertensive
column3: with sensorineural hearing loss
column4: referred for low visual acuity (VA). The family history recorded three deaf-mute male siblings and another with low vision. Uncorrected visual acuity (VA) was 0.3 in the right eye (RA) and 0.2 in the left eye (LA). An anterior lenticonus was detected and fundus examination revealed an AM in both eyes
column5: surrounded by a perimacular ring of whitish dots. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) was performed with Stratus OCT-3 (Carl Zeiss Meditec
column6: Dublin
column7: CA)
column8: which verified the presence of AM
column9: stage IV
column10: with a basal diameter of 1
column11: 347μm in OD and 1
column12: 409μm in OI
column13: with hyperreflectivity in inner retinal layers and cystic changes in adjacent tissues. After a systemic study (including renal biopsy)
column14: a diagnosis of SA was made
column15: and the patient is currently on haemodialysis due to severe renal failure
column16: maintaining the characteristics of AM.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Previously healthy child. His only history is that he was operated on for left cryptorchidism; he is correctly vaccinated for his age. When he was five years old
column2: he presented for the first time with bilateral parotid inflammation (with erythema
column3: swelling and pain)
column4: accompanied by fever
column5: which was managed on an outpatient basis with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and oral anti-inflammatory drugs. He had a second episode
column6: also managed on an outpatient basis. The third episode required hospital admission due to poor clinical evolution and general malaise after starting treatment with oral amoxicillin-clavulanic acid. Physical examination revealed a bilateral laterocervical tumour (initially on the right) that obliterated the mandibular angle
column7: with no signs of fluctuation or secretion or inflammatory signs of Stenon's duct. Blood tests showed a significant leukocytosis (24 100/mm3) with neutrophilia (78.7%)
column8: C-reactive protein (CRP) of 4.11 mg/dl and elevated α-amylase (up to 1451 U/l). During admission
column9: an ultrasound scan showed enlarged parotid glands with increased density
column10: heterogeneous and hypoechoic foci. The patient was treated with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid for two days intravenously
column11: followed by eight days of oral treatment
column12: analgesia and anti-inflammatory drugs
column13: with good subsequent evolution. The Paediatric Infectious Diseases Department followed up the patient
column14: from where the study was completed. An immunity study was performed
column15: which was normal
column16: rheumatoid tests were negative
column17: and a serological study was negative
column18: except for the mumps vaccination serology
column19: which was positive. She has not presented any new episodes for more than a year.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 25-year-old woman
column2: with no past history of interest
column3: was studied for a history of abdominal pain predominantly in the right hypochondrium. Physical examination and laboratory tests
column4: including a liver profile
column5: were normal. An abdominal ultrasound was performed
column6: which revealed an 8-centimetre
column7: multiloculated
column8: hypoechoic cystic hepatic lesion with hyperechoic areas and calcium
column9: located in hepatic segments 4-5 and with papillary projections towards the hepatic hilum. Given the impossibility of ruling out malignancy
column10: surgical treatment was recommended. The patient underwent surgery and a cystic lesion of about 10 centimetres in diameter was found on the hepatic hilum
column11: in segments 4 and 5
column12: on the portal bifurcation and the middle hepatic vein. A cystopericystectomy with vascular control was performed without exclusion. The postoperative course was favourable and the patient was discharged after one week. The definitive histological diagnosis showed a ciliated liver cyst.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a three-year-old preschooler who presented to his health centre with a bitemporal
column2: daily
column3: evening headache lasting for hours
column4: which subsided after analgesia. The pain does not occur during sleep and does not interfere with her daily activities. There is no aura
column5: sonophobia or photophobia. No vomiting or other symptoms. Personal history of no interest. Normal psychomotor and postnatal development. Physical and neurological examination was normal. Referred to Ophthalmology
column6: where pathology was ruled out. A blood test was requested
column7: with a ferritin level of 8 ng/ml
column8: and the haemogram and other biochemistry were anodine. Following this
column9: treatment with oral iron was started. Two months later
column10: she consulted Neuropaediatrics for persistent headache and was referred to Neuropaediatrics (normal brain magnetic resonance imaging [MRI]) and an analytical control was performed to assess the previous iron deficiency
column11: determining IgA anti-transglutaminase antibodies (> 128 U/ml) and IgA (normal). Subsequently
column12: a biopsy was obtained confirming coeliac disease with Marsh type II-III villous atrophy
column13: and low-resolution histocompatibility system typing (human leukocyte antigen [HLA]) was performed
column14: obtaining a DQ2 haplotype of coeliac susceptibility in cis. Following diagnosis
column15: the patient was started on a gluten-free diet and progressed favourably
column16: with disappearance of the headache and correction of ferritin levels. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 50-year-old man with a history of arterial hypertension under treatment and appendicectomy at the age of 25
column2: consulted for epigastralgia
column3: melena and asthenia for the last fifteen days. He did not report dysphagia
column4: heartburn or altered bowel habits. The physical examination was normal
column5: there were no palpable masses or visceromegaly in the abdomen
column6: and there were no signs of malnutrition. Laboratory tests showed the presence of hypochromic microcytic anaemia with Hgb of 10g/dl and Ht of 33%. Chest and abdominal X-rays showed no alterations of interest. Upper endoscopy showed a normal oesophagus
column7: a gastric cavity without haematic debris with normal mucosa and erosions on an oedematous mucosa in the duodenal bulb; biopsies were taken from the antrum and body
column8: and the biopsies were reported as chronic gastritis without activity
column9: and helicobacter pylori was not detected. In the abdominal ultrasound
column10: the liver
column11: gall bladder and pancreas were normal. With the diagnosis of upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage due to erosive duodenitis and anaemia secondary to digestive losses
column12: he was discharged for outpatient follow-up with treatment with antisecretory drugs. The patient was readmitted three weeks later for a new episode of melena. A new upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was performed
column13: revealing a normal oesophagus
column14: gastric cavity mucosa and duodenal bulb
column15: with isolated haematic remains at the level of the second portion of the duodenum
column16: It was therefore decided to perform a pulsation enteroscopy
column17: revealing a friable
column18: ulcerated tumour in the proximal jejunum that partially stenosed the jejunal lumen and did not allow the endoscope to pass
column19: but did allow multiple biopsies to be taken at the edges of the tumour. An intestinal transit was carried out in which a short stenosis was observed in the proximal jejunum
column20: which allowed the passage of contrast material.  The extension study was completed with an abdominal CT scan
column21: which revealed the presence of a mass in the proximal jejunum with no significant locoregional or retroperitoneal adenopathies
column22: no focal hepatic lesions suggestive of metastasis
column23: and no other radiological alterations that could be assessed. With the diagnosis of low-grade leiomyosarcoma of the small intestine and after ruling out distant tumour extension or local invasion in the imaging studies
column24: surgical treatment was decided with resection of the tumour and subsequent duodeno-jejunal anastomosis. The patient's evolution was satisfactory and did not require adjuvant treatment.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Patient aged 76 years
column2: with a history of thalassaemia minor
column3: type 2 diabetes mellitus
column4: adequately controlled with low doses of oral antidiabetics (Hb 1AC 6.8). He had an appendectomy in his youth and a testicular hydrocele surgery. The patient was admitted due to a 15-year history of incapacitating syncope and orthostatic syncope
column5: which had even functionally limited him in recent years
column6: to the point of preventing him from going out in the street. He was partially studied for this reason in 1996. In this study
column7: a complete paroxysmal AV block was found
column8: which was initially interpreted as the cause of the symptoms
column9: so that a VDD pacemaker was inserted without the patient's symptoms having completely subsided. It was decided to extend the study at the time
column10: and an echocardiogram was performed
column11: which except for a slight hypertrophy of the left ventricle showed no other alterations
column12: as well as an abdominal CT scan
column13: which was normal. The neurological examination was normal at the time. The patient was discharged with the diagnosis of idiopathic orthostatic syncope
column14: and treatment was started with etilefrin
column15: spironolactone and fludocortisone. The patient
column16: however
column17: did not improve his symptoms
column18: presenting syncope on orthostasis almost daily
column19: with frequent trauma
column20: together with a state of presyncope maintained while the patient remained seated. Given the incapacitating symptoms
column21: it was decided to admit the patient to complete the study and adjust the treatment. In the anamnesis
column22: in addition to the syncope
column23: the patient only reported nocturia 4-5 times a day
column24: and diarrhoea of 4-5 abundant watery stools
column25: without pathological products
column26: of about ten years of evolution
column27: not accompanied by weight loss or toxic symptoms. The anamnesis by organs and apparatus was negative. Physical examination revealed a significant drop in BP on sitting compared to lying down
column28: from around 120/80 mm Hg to 60/40 mm Hg
column29: with no other manifestations other than an intense pre-syncopal sensation. During these episodes
column30: the patient had no sweating or compensatory tachycardia. Physical examination only showed some behavioural disinhibition of the patient
column31: not accompanied by signs of frontal release. The rest of the neurological and general examination was normal. The following complementary tests were performed for the study of the patient: biochemistry: glucose 127; cre 1.16; total proteins 7; albumin 3.78; calcium 9.9; phosphorus 2.9; uric acid 8; cholesterol 125; triglycerides 174; sodium 140; potassium 4.76. CBC: leukocytes 6
column32: 740 (normal formula); red blood cells 4.34; Hb 9.7; MCV 68.7; platelets 169
column33: 000. Liver profile: normal. Vitamin B12 levels 925 and folic acid 16. Hormonal study: prolactin 10.4; FSH 9.2; LH 7.3; testosterone 277; night cortisol 9; basal cortisol 38; rhythm cortisol 76%; total porphyrins < 200; aldolase 3. Electrophoretic spectrum: albumin 53.8%; alpha1 3.3%; alpha2 15.3%; beta 13.7%; gamma 13.9%. Blood in stool: negative. Cranial CT scan: The study showed signs of diffuse atrophy in relation to the patient's age
column34: with no other relevant findings. Colonoscopy: No lesions were seen in the areas visualised. Biopsies were taken from the proximal descending colon to rule out macroscopic colitis. Small diverticular orifices throughout the colon. Biopsy of colorectal mucosa: usual characteristics. Specific staining for amyloid was performed and was negative. Echocardiogram: hypertrophic left ventricle with systolic function at low limits of normality with slight global hypokinesia. Mild mitral insufficiency. No evidence of amyloidosis. Arrhythmological study: VDD pacemaker with single lead
column35: normofunctioning. The pacing rate was reduced without obtaining ventricular rhythm (complete AV block with ventricular pacing at 40 bpm). Cold pressure test: BP with the patient in decubitus position 112/68. After 30" with hand on ice: BP 108/56. HIV serology: Negative. Chest X-ray: No significant findings. Abdominopelvic CT scan: No significant lesions. Plasma catecholamine levels in decubitus and seated position: low basal levels
column36: without the expected elevation in seated position. Urine catecholamine levels: low. Given the normality of the complementary tests
column37: the diagnosis of pure autonomic failure is established
column38: withdrawing the hypotensive drugs from the treatment
column39: maintaining only etilefrine and fludocortisone
column40: together with symptomatic measures
column41: subjectively improving the patient.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 81-year-old female patient presented to the emergency department with asthenia
column2: anorexia and right lumbar pain of 2 weeks' duration. Haemodynamically stable
column3: and with fever (38.5 degrees) for 3 days. With a history of heart failure associated with atrial fibrillation
column4: with no history of urological diseases. Physical examination revealed pain on deep palpation located in the right hemiabdomen
column5: with no signs of peritoneal irritation
column6: with the presence of a palpable mass and positive renal Murphy on the right. Analyses showed leukocytosis (22
column7: 390 with left shift)
column8: normochromic normocytic anaemia
column9: with renal function within normal parameters
column10: leukocyturia and microscopic haematuria. Reno-vesical radiography showed multiple radiopaque stones located in the right kidney. Abdominal-pelvic computed axial tomography with intravenous contrast injection showed an enlarged right kidney
column11: with cortico-medullary disorganisation and the presence of multiple large lithiasic formations located in the renal pelvis.  With the diagnosis of pyonephrosis and to stabilise the general deterioration
column12: we decided to perform a pecutaneous nephrostomy at first. We witnessed abundant purulent fluid coming out of the nephrostomy
column13: the culture of which revealed polymicrobial flora. Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy was started. After four days and as the surgical conditions were more suitable
column14: we decided to perform a right nephrectomy by lombotomy. The description of the surgical specimen is as follows: Kidney (13x8.5x5 cm) sent with ureteral segment 10 cm long and with presence of perirenal adipose tissue. There is dilatation of the pyelocaliceal tree and marked atrophy of the renal parenchyma. Inside the pyelic tree there is purulent content and stones are identified
column15: the largest of which is 4.5 cm. There are foci of suppuration with abcedification of the renal parenchyma and perirenal adipose tissue. In the pelvis and adjacent calyxes there is white tissue with a soft consistency measuring 6x5 cm
column16: 10 cm away from the ureteral surgical top. Histological examination showed adenocarcinoma with predominant areas of tubular pattern and focal areas of tubulovillous pattern.  The neoplasm presents characteristics of intestinal type adenocarcinoma
column17: being possible to identify intestinal type Goblet cells characterised by the presence of apical intracytoplasmic mucus vacuoles.... The nuclei in some areas are uniform and monotonous and in other areas are more aggressive
column18: irregular
column19: of different sizes and with frequent mitotic activity. The neoplasm invades the subepithelial connective tissue. Glandular metaplasia of the urothelial epithelium is identified in the lining of the pyelocaliceal tree. Six months after surgery the patient died.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 34-year-old woman
column2: of Argentinean nationality
column3: referred from Neuropaediatrics to the Metabolic Diseases Unit of the Hospital Ramón y Cajal
column4: in order to rule out metabolic disease
column5: because she had two children aged 12 and 9 years
column6: from different fathers
column7: with microcephaly and severe mental retardation. The patient reported having had another child who
column8: due to cardiac malformation
column9: died at 3 months of age. She was married
column10: spoke normally and performed activities of daily living. She sometimes had problems with money exchange and had not been able to complete her studies but could read
column11: write
column12: add
column13: subtract
column14: multiply and divide (only by 1 digit). His IQ was estimated at 70-75
column15: corresponding to mild-moderate mental retardation. He was not undergoing any treatment or reported any known illnesses and had no family history of interest. In both children
column16: Phe levels were normal
column17: 70 and 92 micromol/L. However
column18: Phe levels were determined in the patient and were 1
column19: 140 micromol/L (normal < 120 micromol/L). Phe levels at diagnosis
column20: between 660 and 1
column21: 200 micromol/L
column22: condition a classification of mild-moderate PKU phenotype. Differential diagnosis was made with disorders of pterin metabolism
column23: which were found to be normal. The following mutational changes were found in the PAH gene: c.165delT (p.Phe55fs) / c.q62G > A (p.Val388Met)
column24: with both children being carriers of the p.Phe55fs mutation only. After the diagnosis of phenylketonuria in the mother
column25: an overload of Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) was performed to discover a possible response to this pharmacological treatment
column26: since in some PKU patients it is possible to improve PAH activity by giving pharmacological doses of its cofactor
column27: but in this patient the phenylalanine levels did not undergo significant changes and therefore she was considered a non-responder.  Treatment was started with a diet limited in phenylalanine in order to maintain phenylalanine levels below 660 micromol/L (maximum levels allowed in adults without pregnancy) and weekly control of phenylalanine in blood. To this end
column28: we adjusted the diet to 20-25 g of high biological value proteins/day (PAVB: milk
column29: eggs
column30: meat
column31: fish
column32: cheese
column33: cereals and pulses) divided into breakfast
column34: lunch and dinner (5-10 and 10 g)
column35: with freedom in vegetables
column36: natural fruit
column37: peeled potatoes
column38: olives
column39: sugar
column40: oils
column41: butter
column42: corn starch (Maizena®)
column43: spices and low-protein foods Loprofín®
column44: Aglutella® and Aproten® purchased through the Association of PKU patients in Madrid. To the PAVB were added 60 g of special proteins without phenylalanine (PrXPhe) distributed in 4 intakes/day
column45: in the form of special preparations containing essential amino acids without phenylalanine with carbohydrates
column46: essential fatty acids
column47: ions
column48: oligoelements and vitamins. The weekly evolution of the Phe levels during the first 3 months of follow-up showed levels of 498 ± 15 micromoles/L. Subsequently the family returned to Argentina where they are currently undergoing treatment.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 62-year-old man diagnosed in September 2003 radiologically by CT scan of a stenosing tumour of the sigmoid colon with metastases in regional lymph nodes and liver (stage IV). Endoscopic biopsies were taken of the neoplasm
column2: the diagnosis of which was intestinal adenocarcinoma. It was considered unresectable and was treated with a palliative shotgun colostomy in the transverse colon and first-line chemotherapy with FOLFOX protocol (oxaliplatin-5-fluorouracil-leucovorin). He was re-evaluated after 6 cycles
column3: showing tumour stabilisation
column4: and at the end of 12 cycles tumour progression was observed with distant lymph node and adrenal metastases. In March 2004
column5: the patient presented with mandibular pain and swelling of 3 weeks' duration
column6: and a vegetating tumour was observed in the right anterior mandibular gum. A cervical CT scan showed a solid lesion in the right hemimandible eroding bone
column7: 4 cm in diameter
column8: compatible with gingival neoplasia
column9: without lymphadenopathy. A biopsy was performed
column10: showing a neoformation independent of the surface mucosa
column11: which was composed of atypical
column12: irregular glands of variable shapes and sizes
column13: with a columnar lining and abundant mitoses. Using immunohistochemistry techniques
column14: the tumour was positive for cytokeratin (CK) 20 and CEA (carcinoembryonic antigen)
column15: and negative for CK7
column16: which led to a diagnosis of metastatic adenocarcinoma highly compatible with intestinal origin. He received 4 cycles of second-line chemotherapy according to the FOLFORI protocol (CPT11-5 fluorouracil-leucovorin)
column17: and gingival analgesic radiotherapy
column18: with disease progression and progressive deterioration being observed
column19: and exiting 9 months after diagnosis of the gingival metastasis. column1: Caucasian male
column2: 53 years old
column3: with no significant past history
column4: who started in February 2007 with left nasal obstruction and epistaxis. He consulted in June for a bluish tumour in the left nostril visible through the nostril. A surgical biopsy of the mass was performed and reported as "nodular melanoma". Computed axial tomography (CT) showed a tumour displacing the septum and extending to the left ethmoid cells. No adenomegaly was palpable in the neck and regional and distant pathology was ruled out by imaging (CT) and laboratory studies.  He underwent surgery in August 2007. The first surgical manoeuvre was a cervicotomy to ligate the left external carotid artery in order to minimise intraoperative haemorrhage. An intraoperative freeze biopsy was performed on a lymph node found isolated in the carotid bifurcation during the arterial ligation manoeuvre described above. The biopsy was reported as negative. A horizontal rhinotomy was continued with section of the columella and vertical section of the upper lip. The bony and cartilaginous septum was resected by advancing the chisel parallel to the hard palate. The en bloc resection of the septum was completed with the tumour originating in the left inferior turbinate. Once the resection was completed
column5: a persistent tumour of 5 mm in diameter was found at the level of the lamina cribrosa of the ethmoid
column6: which was not resected due to the lack of neurosurgical equipment. The wound was sutured in planes
column7: after packing the surgical site with gauze. The patient evolved with paralysis of the left common ocular motor nerve
column8: which resolved spontaneously in 3 weeks. Pathological anatomy: the deferred study reports: infiltrative epithelioid mucosal melanoma with areas of melanoma in situ. Incomplete resection of the upper margin. Cervical lymph node with melanoma infiltration.  Radiotherapy with three-dimensional reconstruction (6
column9: 500 cGy) and 6 cycles of chemotherapy with dacarbazine were indicated. The evolution was favourable and there was no evidence of disease after a 4-year follow-up.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 38-year-old woman diagnosed with multiple sclerosis on treatment with interferon beta and ankylosing spondylitis treated with ibuprofen and metamizole. The relative who lived with her reported that she had been unable to defecate for three days
column2: with abdominal pain and distension. At around 01:30 hours
column3: she administered a 240 ml enema (a so-called rectal laxative) and went to bed. At 5 a.m. the relative found her unconscious and with traces of dark green vomit on her face and around her. She was attended by the emergency medical service
column4: who found her with signs of certain death and did not apply resuscitation measures. Autopsy findings: height: 1.54 m; weight: 52 kg: 52 kg; body mass index
column5: normal (21.9 kg/m2); traces of dark green fluid in nostrils
column6: inside and around the mouth; abdominal distension; on opening the abdomen
column7: large dilatation of the stomach and duodenum occupying most of the visible abdominal cavity
column8: reaching down to the lesser pelvis ; the remaining abdominal viscera are hidden by the stomach
column9: which is completely filled with dark green fluid (bile and a few haematic remains in the form of "coffee grounds"); the walls of the stomach are thinned and with areas of haemorrhagic appearance in the mucosa; the stomach contains 3.5 litres of dark green fluid; gastric contents in the airway.  Histopathological study diagnosed
column10: in the stomach
column11: congestion in the vessels of the lamina propria and autolysis of the glandular epithelium; in the brain
column12: inactive plaques of multiple sclerosis; and bronchoalveolar aspiration.  Toxicological screening only detected sub-therapeutic concentrations of metoclopramide
column13: ibuprofen and diazepam.  |O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O

column1: A 75-year-old man who had previously received complementary intravesical treatment with MMC and BCG. After tumour recurrence
column2: he started treatment with intravesical gemcitabine. During the first instillation
column3: the patient presented intense local burning
column4: dizziness and profuse sweating (grade 2)5
column5: which made it necessary to stop treatment. Although hypotension (90/60 mmHg) occurred post instillation
column6: blood pressure normalised (130/80 mmHg) within a few minutes with postural measures. Dysuria improved over the next 24 hours with oral anti-inflammatory treatment.
