column1: Male patient
column2: aged 10 years
column3: referred to the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Department of the Piñero Hospital to be assessed for an increase in volume in the right mandibular angle region of two weeks' evolution; with no medical history of interest. The swelling was not painful on palpation and there was no report of paraesthesia.  Intraoral examination revealed bulging of the vestibular and lingual table of the lower jaw. The teeth were healthy and without mobility; the mucosa appeared normal.  Radiographically
column4: a radiolucent
column5: unilocular lesion with sclerotic borders was observed. Root resorption of tooth 37 was also evident.  The biopsy result was fibroma ossificans
column6: so the lesion was scheduled for enucleation under general anaesthesia. The pathological anatomy confirmed the result of ossifying fibroma.  The last clinical-radiographic control was performed at eight months
column7: with a good evolution and radiographic evidence of bone neoformation and increased thickness of the mandibular basal. The patient remains under follow-up to rule out recurrence of the tumour...   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Two newborns
column2: male and female from the same mother
column3: died at 10 and 45 minutes of life respectively
column4: and underwent post-mortem examination. The first of the corpses
column5: corresponding to the female
column6: was referred with the clinical judgement of severe respiratory failure with suspected Potter's Syndrome and severe oligohydramnios; she was born by emergency caesarean section due to breech presentation and the Apgar test was 1/3/7; minutes later she died. External examination revealed a subcyanotic colour
column7: triangular facies with mongoloid parpebral fissures
column8: micrognathia
column9: broad nasal root and prominent occiput. The abdomen
column10: globular
column11: hard and slightly dented
column12: allowed the palpation of two large masses occupying both renal fossae and hemiabdomenes. When the cavities were opened
column13: the presence of two large renal masses measuring 10 x 8 x 5.5 cm and 12 x 8 x 6 cm with weights of 190 and 235 g respectively
column14: stood out. Although the renal silhouette could be discerned
column15: the surface
column16: dented
column17: showed numerous cystic formations of serous content; when cut
column18: these cysts were heterogeneous in size
column19: with those located at the cortical level being larger
column20: giving the kidney a sponge-like appearance. The right and left lungs weighed 17 and 15 grams (usual weight of the set of 49 grams) showing a uniform reddish hue; both were compressed as a result of the diaphragmatic elevation conditioned by the large size of the kidneys. The rest of the organs showed no significant macroscopic alterations except for the positional alterations derived from the renal compression. In the second carcass
column21: the male
column22: similar morphological changes were observed
column23: although the size of the kidneys was even larger
column24: with weights of 300 and 310 grams. The rest of the abdominal viscera were compressed against the diaphragm. In both cases
column25: a detailed histological study was performed
column26: focusing especially on the kidneys where multiple cysts of different sizes with saccular morphology were demonstrated at the cortical level. These cysts occupied most of the corticomedullary parenchyma
column27: although the preserved areas showed no significant alterations except for focal immaturity. These cysts were lined by a simple epithelium varying from flat to cubic. The smaller
column28: more rounded medullary cysts were lined by a predominantly cubic epithelium. After the renal cysts
column29: the most striking alterations were found in the liver where proliferation and dilatation
column30: even cystic
column31: of the bile ducts at the level of the portal spaces were observed. These findings led to a diagnosis of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease in both cases.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 20-year-old male was referred from a hospital outside the city of Managua (Nicaragua) after suffering trauma to the left arm from a moving vehicle
column2: resulting in a transverse open fracture of the middle third of the humerus type III C according to Gustilo's classification
column3: initially treated with an external fixator and vascular lesion of the brachial artery which could not be repaired. She arrived at our hospital 12 hours after the accident. Physical examination of the upper extremity revealed an absence of distal peripheral radial and ulnar pulses
column4: a negative Allen test and a decrease in temperature. We performed a real-time Doppler study with a high-frequency linear B-mode probe that showed flow with attenuated waves in the proximal brachial artery
column5: but not in the middle and distal portions
column6: where there was an absence of colour Doppler
column7: power Doppler and spectral signals
column8: with no flow in the distal arteries (radial and ulnar). The patient was admitted to the operating theatre where we found a linear wound on the anterior surface of the arm and complete section of the biceps brachii in the middle 1/3
column9: distal and proximal end of the brachial artery knotted with 2-0 silk
column10: with a gap of 8 cm in length
column11: exposed fracture of the middle third of the humerus displaced and forearm with tension
column12: decreased temperature and stiffness. We kept the limb in warm ischaemia and decided to perform sequential reconstruction of the limb in 2 stages. First reconstruction time: vascular repair In collaboration with the Vascular Surgery Department
column13: we proceeded to take a 20 cm long graft from the greater saphenous vein of the left lower limb and transposed 10 cm of graft to the vasobrachial arcade
column14: with end-to-end anastomosis by means of loose stitches with 8-0 nylon under 4.3X magnification. The fracture line is thus exposed. We therefore achieved revascularisation of the limb 16 hours after the accident. We also performed an anterior forearm fasciotomy to treat the compartment syndrome associated with the trauma. Second reconstruction time: internal fixation and coverage After demonstrating adequate perfusion of the tissues in the area of the injury and distal to it
column15: and 48 hours after vascular repair
column16: we performed internal fixation of the humerus fracture with an endomedullary nail 8 mm in diameter and 24 cm in length
column17: with distal and proximal blocking. Once the possible reconstruction options for covering the neurovascular structures and the fracture line had been evaluated
column18: we decided to transpose the ipsilateral latissimus dorsi muscle-cutaneous flap.  With the patient in the right lateral decubitus position
column19: we delineated the flap area with a length of 22 cm x 11 cm width; in order to restore elbow flexion function
column20: we took only the lateral portion of the latissimus dorsi muscle on the same side as the injury. The lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle is incised to achieve adequate exposure
column21: and the elliptical incision corresponding to the skin component of the flap is continued. We continue the dissection cephalad over the anterior surface of the muscle up to the subscapularis area
column22: performing submuscular dissection in the areolar plane close to the chest wall.  We locate the descending branch of the thoracodorsal artery
column23: first identifying the branches that go towards the serratus muscle
column24: and the circumflex scapular artery
column25: which are ligated and divided so that there is no torsion of the pedicle after transposition.  Once the main pedicle of the flap has been located
column26: we proceed to make the medial cut of the muscle
column27: making sure to include only the tissue necessary to cover the defect.  Incise the axillary area in a zigzag fashion
column28: with distal extension along the lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle to transpose the latissimus dorsi flap to the anterior aspect of the arm to provide coverage of the fracture tract and vascular repair saphenous grafts. We finished with direct primary closure of the donor site after placement of a closed drainage system.  Once the flap has been transposed
column29: we fix the coracoid process and the remaining fibres of the biceps muscle belly proximally and fix the bicipital tendon distally with non-absorbable nylon 0 sutures.  The remaining muscle flap and fasciotomy were covered with partial thickness grafts 7 days after transposition of the latissimus dorsi flap
column30: once the distal oedema of the extremity had subsided and the granulation tissue showed no clinical signs of bacterial colonisation.  The patient spent 10 days in hospital with adequate distal perfusion of the tissues
column31: and vascularisation of the superficial and deep palmar arch was demonstrated by 8 MhZ hand-held Doppler auscultation. The latissimus dorsi flap
column32: with no evidence of venous congestion or arterial insufficiency
column33: provided stable coverage over the humeral fracture tract and over the saphenous vein grafts to the brachial vessels. The donor area was also uncomplicated
column34: with removal of the closed drainage system at 13 days postoperatively. Graft integration was 100%. The patient started physical therapy 4 weeks after the initial procedure
column35: with flexion and extension movements of the elbow. After a 6-month follow-up
column36: he has flexion and extension ranges between 60-180 degrees
column37: even with some limitation to full flexion function
column38: which will require more physical therapy to be able to perform strenuous work
column39: since daily tasks
column40: such as dressing and studying
column41: can be performed without difficulty.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 65-year-old woman with no personal history of interest was admitted with a high fever of 1 week's duration with no apparent source
column2: for which reason a thoracoabdominal CT scan was performed
column3: showing a large mass (9x8x7 cm) in the right upper pole of the kidney
column4: in close contact with the liver. She reported no other symptoms except pain and functional impotence in the left lower limb for months of evolution
column5: followed up by the Neurosurgery Department and diagnosed
column6: after CT scan of the spine and Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Imaging (NMR)
column7: with degenerative pathology
column8: stenosis of the L4-L5 canal and spondyloarthrosis. She did not present constitutional syndrome or abdominal pain.  Physical examination revealed a soft and depressible abdomen
column9: globular
column10: without palpation of masses or megaliths. No pain on examination. Bilateral renal perfusion was negative. Laboratory tests showed no alterations in biochemistry with liver profile
column11: total proteins and calcium in normal range. Haemoglobin count was 9.4 g/dL and 22
column12: 500 leukocytes (N: 72.9%). Haemostasis without findings. Sterile blood cultures and urine cultures <10
column13: 000UFC/ml. Broad-spectrum antibiotic and antipyretic treatment was started
column14: despite which the patient presented daily febrile peaks with clinical repercussions in the form of asthenia. In view of the CT findings
column15: an MRI scan was performed
column16: confirming a solid mass in the right upper pole measuring 14x10x10 cm in diameter
column17: with great signal heterogeneity and necrosis inside. The lesion extends upwards towards the liver with signs of hepatic infiltration. The right renal vein and vena cava are free. There are retrocaval adenopathies
column18: pleural effusion and diaphragmatic thickening.  Given the liver involvement
column19: the case was discussed with the General and Digestive Surgery Department
column20: who agreed to perform a multislice CT scan to determine more accurately the level of involvement of this organ and to plan the surgical intervention. A heterogeneous mass with a necrotic appearance and a maximum diameter of 11 cm was observed in the upper half of the right kidney with no plane of separation of the postero-superior segments of the right hepatic lobe
column21: with contiguous involvement of the same.  Following renal embolisation
column22: surgery was performed by means of supra- and infra-umbilical median laparotomy. Examination showed renal tumour infiltrating the liver (segment VII) and diaphragm
column23: with pathological lymphadenopathies in the renal hilum and free peritoneal fluid with no evidence of peritoneal implants. Samples of peritoneal fluid were taken for culture
column24: cytology and gram negative results. Right radical nephrectomy was performed
column25: including en bloc the VII hepatic segment
column26: right adrenal and portion of the diaphragm. Cholecystectomy and lymphadenectomy. Pathological analysis revealed conventional type renal cell cancer of high cytological grade (Fuhrman grade 4)
column27: with foci of sarcomatoid transformation and extensive areas of tumour necrosis. Two satellite nodules on the peritoneal surface of the diaphragm and metastasis in a lymph node in the renal hilum. No involvement of the renal venous or excretory system or the adrenal gland. Stage pT4G3N1 according to UICC. After a satisfactory postoperative period with a progressive decrease in leukocytosis
column28: oral chemotherapy treatment with angiogenesis inhibitors was started. The second control CT scan performed two months after the operation showed right pleural effusion with basal and posterior pleural nodular lesions. The cytology of the pleural fluid was compatible with adenocarcinoma.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Patient aged 53 years at the time of diagnosis with a personal history of a caesarean section
column2: arterial hypertension and tachycardia treated with Atenolol
column3: who came to the Emergency Department with a 5-month history of progressive dull pain in the left flank and microhaematuria. Ultrasound and then abdominal-pelvic computerised axial tomography (CAT) scans revealed a large solid mass measuring 20x16x13 cm arising from the left renal pole
column4: without associated venous thrombosis. Para-aortic adenopathies were also observed. All this was compatible with a left renal tumour.  In view of this finding
column5: an extension study was carried out with a general analysis showing mild iron-deficiency microcytic anaemia and hyperuricaemia
column6: a normal chest X-ray
column7: a bone scan showing an image with a slight increase in tracer uptake corresponding to soft tissue
column8: with a rounded morphology
column9: located in the hypochondrium and in the hypochondrium
column10: located in the left hypochondrium and void
column11: exceeding the midline
column12: and 3 foci of tracer uptake
column13: one in the left iliac blade
column14: the second in the left hemivertebrae L4 and L5 and the third at the level of the right hemivertebra L2
column15: which could correspond to bone involvement due to contiguity or be metastatic
column16: and an abdominal MRI scan which confirms the findings of the CT scan. With the presumptive diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma with retroperitoneal adenopathy
column17: the patient underwent radical left nephrectomy
column18: removal of all the pararenal fat and the left adrenal gland and para-aortic and interaortocaval lymphadenectomy from the renal artery to 3 cm from the common iliac artery. Removal of the mass was difficult due to infiltration of the transverse mesocolon and tail of the pancreas
column19: which were released
column20: leaving the mesocolon untouched. The anatomo-pathological (A.P.) result was as follows: Collision renal tumour (Leiomyosarcoma (21 x 15 cm) and renal carcinoma papillary type nuclear grade 3 (7 x 3.5 cm)). The weight of the whole specimen was 2539 grams. The tumour was in contact with the surgical edge in most areas. The renal parenchyma was microscopically respected and no tumour infiltration was observed. The ureteral fragment and renal hilum were free of tumour infiltration. The immunophenotypic profile of the tumour was as follows: Actin
column21: Desmin
column23: Synaptofusin and CD 56 and c-kit negative; Smooth muscle actin positive in the sarcomatous zone and keratin cocktail (E1
column24: E3) positive in the carcinomatous zone. At the level of the para-aortic chain
column25: 16 adenopathies were isolated
column26: the largest measuring 2.5 cm
column27: with metastases in 14 of them
column28: 13 from the carcinoma and 1 with mixed metastases (sarcoma+carcinoma). Six adenopathies were isolated in the interaortocaval chain
column29: the largest measuring 1.4 cm
column30: three of which were carcinoma metastases. The mesocolic bed was infiltrated by leiomyosarcoma. In the perisuprarenal adipose tissue 4 adenopathies were isolated
column31: 3 of them with metastasis of the carcinoma and another with mixed metastasis (carcinoma+sarcoma). The left adrenal gland
column32: the perirenal fat and the gall bladder showed no tumour elements.  We were therefore faced with a renal collision tumour consisting of a stage IV papillary type renal cancer (pT3-4pN2) according to the TNM classification and a stage IV renal leiomyosarcoma (pT2bpN1) according to the AJCC classification
column33: not radically resected and with possible bone metastases according to bone scintigraphy. The postoperative period was uneventful and the patient was referred to the Medical Oncology Department. It was decided to propose complementary chemotherapy treatment with Ifosfamide 5 g/m2 in a continuous infusion of 24h x 1 day + Adriamycin 60 mg/m2 x 1 day/21 days against the sarcomatous component of the tumour. A CT scan was previously requested in which a small soft tissue enlargement was observed behind the pancreatic tail and renal bed
column34: which could be compatible with present disease. The patient started treatment according to the planned schedule 3 weeks after surgery. She received a total of 6 cycles with good clinical tolerance. After the 4th cycle
column35: an abdominal CAT scan was performed
column36: which was normal
column37: and at the end of the 6th cycle
column38: a bone scan was performed
column39: which showed no pathological findings. The patient underwent regular check-ups and 3 months later a chest X-ray was performed showing images suggestive of bilateral pulmonary metastases
column40: which were confirmed by a CT scan showing multiple bilateral millimetric pulmonary metastases. In order to identify the origin of these metastases
column41: Thoracic Surgery was consulted and it was decided to perform a left videothoracoscopy with biopsies. The P.A. diagnosis was metastasis of poorly differentiated carcinoma with an epithelial component (renal). In view of this diagnosis
column42: 6 months after finishing the first chemotherapy regimen
column43: it was decided to start a second line of treatment with a chemotherapy regimen with Gemzitabine and Fluoropyrimidines9 that had proved useful in stage IV renal carcinoma: Gemcitabine 1000 mg/m2 days 1 and 8 + Capecitabine 1000 mg/m2/12h days 1-14/21 days
column44: which the patient accepted.  Treatment was started with a 20% dose reduction which was maintained for the rest of the treatment given the patient's general condition (ECOG: 1-2). After the second cycle
column45: the patient suffered a complication of pulmonary thromboembolism from which she recovered but which caused a delay of 4 weeks in the administration of the third cycle. After 6 cycles of treatment
column46: which she received with acceptable tolerance except for grade 4 anaemia
column47: she was re-evaluated with a body CT scan which showed persistent pulmonary metastases with the appearance of liver and spleen metastases and local relapse. In view of this progression
column48: treatment with IL-2 was proposed for 6 weeks (1 week of induction with 18 Million Units (MU) x 5 days and 5 weeks: 9 MU days 1 and 2 and 18 MU days 3 to 5)10. The patient accepted the treatment with moderate toxicity with secondary constitutional symptoms grade 2
column49: anaemia grade 3 and emesis grade 1
column50: maintaining her general condition. At the end of treatment
column51: a new re-evaluation was performed with a CT scan showing progression of the disease with a large mass in the surgical site measuring 19x10x5cm
column52: which had grown with respect to the previous CT scan
column53: and persistent metastases in the rest of the previous sites. The patient's general condition worsened
column54: with the appearance of abdominal and lumbar pain
column55: and on physical examination a 5cm epigastric mass was palpated
column56: corresponding to the underlying mass. Given this new progression
column57: it is considered that the tumour is resistant to chemotherapy or immunotherapy schemes against renal carcinoma and it is proposed to start palliative treatment with liposomal Adriamycin against the sarcomatous component of the tumour. The patient accepted the proposal and received a first cycle. However
column58: a week later she went to the emergency department for hypovolemic shock with metabolic acidosis and pre-renal renal failure secondary to hyperemesis of 4 days' evolution and grade 4 anaemia. The patient recovered from this episode but a week later she began with faecal vomiting of probable obstructive origin due to compression of the retroperitoneal mass
column59: causing progressive deterioration of the patient and the patient died of multi-organ failure 19 months after diagnosis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O column1: A 48-year-old male
column2: a long-standing diabetic
column3: poorly controlled
column4: who presented to the Emergency Department of our hospital with a 5-day history of pain
column5: oedema and increased temperature in the left upper and lower eyelid
column6: according to the patient
column7: secondary to blunt trauma that initially caused a minor dermabrasion. On admission
column8: he was assessed by Ophthalmology and diagnosed with preseptal cellulitis. Eight hours after admission
column9: he developed a necrotic eschar in the involved tissue. On the first day of hospitalisation he underwent surgical cleaning and debridement of all the necrotic tissue. Material was sent for bacteriological culture
column10: identifying Streptococcus Pyogenes. Based on this result
column11: the patient was assessed by Infectious Diseases and treatment was started with Meropenem
column12: Vancomycin
column13: Clindamycin and Amphotericin.  On the second day of hospitalisation
column14: he was assessed by the Wound Clinic of the Dermatology Department and treatment was started with negative pressure therapy at 125 mmHg continuously
column15: with the aim of controlling exudate
column16: promoting granulation and reducing dead space. This therapy was suspended 3 days later (on the fifth day of hospitalisation) due to progression of the erythema towards the contralateral palpebral portion. The patient continued in the care of Ophthalmology and Dermatology
column17: being treated with physiological solution and isodine-based dressings and covered with alginate patches
column18: a procedure which managed to control the infectious process.  Fifteen days after hospitalisation
column19: he was assessed by Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery
column20: who observed skin loss of the entire upper eyelid
column21: partial loss of the orbicularis oculi and levator muscle (the latter was disinserted)
column22: good granulation tissue and focal loss of conjunctiva.  One month after the initial assessment
column23: the patient underwent surgery and the granulation tissue was debrided until partial closure of the eyelid was achieved
column24: identifying an intact tarsal plate. We performed local flaps to close defects in the conjunctiva
column25: lateral canthotomy
column26: full-thickness graft in the medial canthus and right frontalis musculocutaneus flap
column27: which we attached to the superoexternal remnant of the orbicularis oculi muscle of the eyelid.  Four weeks later
column28: we performed the pedicle section and frontalis flap thinning
column29: seeing that the patient presented palpebral movement dependent on frontalis myorrhaphy with the orbicularis oculi remnant.  The patient persisted with greater volume and eversion of the reconstructed eyelid
column30: so 2 months later we thinned the flap again and corrected the lagophthalmos by lateral canthopexy
column31: freeing the palpebral ligament and reinserting it into the orbital rim.  After 2 years of evolution
column32: the eyeball was covered with complete closure and opening of the eyelid
column33: with no visual repercussions. No new surgical treatment was required.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A seventeen year old male with no previous history of interest presented with pollakiuria
column2: urinary itching
column3: urgency and self-limited haematuria. Urine analysis showed 30-50 red blood cells per field. Urine culture was negative. An abdominal ultrasound was performed
column4: showing a small lesion measuring half a centimetre in diameter
column5: solid with anterior hyperechogenic enhancement.  Cystoscopy was performed and two small raised lesions were observed on the right side
column6: outside the ureteral orifice
column7: with apparently normal mucosa
column8: similar to two igloos. Suspecting an inflammatory lesion
column9: treatment with A.I.N.E. was prescribed for ten days without the lesions disappearing
column10: and surgical intervention was decided. TUR of both bladder lesions was performed
column11: and the anatomopathological report was that of bladder leiomyoma
column12: describing the lesion as a "proliferation of spindle cells arranged in intertwined fascicles with blunt nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm without atypia
column13: necrosis or significant mitotic activity. Immunohistochemistry showed intense diffuse cytoplasmic positivity for smooth muscle actin. column1: A 72-year-old woman with a history of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis treated with NSAIDs and under study for chronic diarrhoea of several months' duration by the Digestology Department of another centre. During a diagnostic colonoscopy
column2: the patient suffered an iatrogenic perforation of the descending colon
column3: for which reason she was urgently referred to our centre. With the diagnosis of intestinal perforation
column4: the patient underwent emergency surgery by the General Surgery on-call team
column5: performing a median laparotomy with primary suture of the descending colon. After intraoperative catheterisation of the patient
column6: there was an immediate appearance of frank haematuria
column7: for which reason we were consulted. After initial assessment of the patient and in the absence of other associated symptoms
column8: conservative management was decided and the patient's progress was monitored. In the hours following the operation
column9: the intensity of the haematuria increased and continuous bladder lavage and intravenous treatment with E-aminocaproic acid was started
column10: which did not resolve the symptoms
column11: leading to progressive anaemia that required the transfusion of six units of red blood cell concentrate in the following days. Subsequently
column12: the intensity of the haematuria subsided
column13: although in the two weeks following the operation
column14: it recurred in the form of self-limiting episodes that partially subsided with conservative measures. Six days after the operation
column15: ultrasound was performed
column16: which showed bladder occupation by an image suggestive of a clot
column17: and cystoscopy
column18: which was inconclusive due to intraluminal occupation by a large clot. During the examination
column19: an attempt at lavage was made
column20: which was unsuccessful due to pain
column21: and only the trigonal area could be explored
column22: revealing a filiform clot protruding from the left ureteral meatus. Imaging tests were requested: intravenous urography showed normality of both ureteropielocaliceal systems
column23: which appeared slightly ectatic due to the presence of multiple intravesical repletion defects suggesting the presence of the known clot. The CT scan provided no further information
column24: with similar findings to the previous examination
column25: ruling out pathology of the upper urinary tract.  Given the persistence of the episodes of haematuria and the emission of clots
column26: an examination was scheduled under general anaesthesia
column27: and after profuse lavage with Ellick
column28: the presence of an excrescent lesion with an apparently tumour-like appearance was observed
column29: which was dropping from the cupula along the entire posterior wall
column30: with only the trigonal-peritrigonal area being spared. Given the suspicion of a bladder tumour
column31: extensive transurethral resection was performed
column32: leaving the lesion flat. The anatomo-pathological study of the material submitted showed the presence of amyloid material distributed around the submucosal vessels
column33: as can be seen in the haematoxylin-eosin staining. The eosinophilic character of this material was also revealed by staining with Congo red. Furthermore
column34: immunohistochemical study of the material
column35: with monoclonal antibodies (clone mcl) specific against the AA protein of amyloid
column36: confirmed that the submucosal perivascular deposits corresponded to AA amyloid which stained characteristically by immunoperoxidase reaction. Based on these findings
column37: a diagnosis of secondary bladder amyloidosis was made.  The patient's post-operative evolution was favourable and she was discharged on the 10th day after the operation and subsequently followed up in our outpatient clinic. The patient is currently being followed up for 30 months
column38: with quarterly cystoscopies during the first year and six-monthly during the second year
column39: with no recurrence of the disease to date. Only focal areas of amyloid material in the mucosa were observed in the first cystoscopic controls
column40: which have not generated any subsequent complications.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 49 year old male patient was referred to our centre following the exodontia of a third molar in the fourth quadrant and curettage of granulation tissue at the apical and distal level of the exodontia. The only personal history of interest was a smoking habit of 35 paq.-year and an alcoholic intake of 150g/d. The patient's family history included the death of his father from colon cancer. The symptoms on physical examination were pain and inflammation in the region of tooth 48 of several months' evolution
column2: which did not improve after the tooth was exodonated
column3: also presenting a bulge of bony consistency on palpation in the vestibular region of the fourth quadrant and with strictly normal mucosa on physical examination.  After analysis of the tissue extracted during the exodontia of tooth 48 by the Pathological Anatomy Service
column4: it was reported as squamous cell carcinoma with well-differentiated cells. A clinical-radiological extension study was carried out at head and neck level
column5: where a destructive neoformative lesion was found on computerised tomography affecting the body and mandibular branch and multiple right cervical adenopathies at all levels. At thoracic-abdominal level there was no evidence of distant neoplastic pathology and the general blood analysis showed no alteration in any of its parameters. The case was discussed in the Functional Head and Neck Unit (UFCC) of our centre and was classified as a T2N2bM0 and radical surgical treatment was decided together with radiotherapy treatment using a three-field isocentric technique and concomitant chemotherapy. A segmental mandibulectomy was performed from part 43 to the right subcondylar region
column6: modified radical right cervical lymph node removal
column7: temporal tracheostomy and reconstruction by means of microvascularised osteomyocutaneous fibula graft. The pathological anatomy catalogues the piece as Keratinising Squamous Carcinoma and involvement of 23 of the 35 lymph nodes removed with extracapsular invasion of the same
column8: classifying it as pT2pN2b.  3.5 months after surgery
column9: recurrence was observed after a new cervical CT scan due to the appearance of cervical tumours compatible with massive recurrence in the form of multiple bilateral adenopathies. The possibility of a new cycle of chemotherapy was discussed but ruled out due to the rapid massive recurrence
column10: the lack of response to treatment and the low level of tolerance to chemotherapy on the part of the patient. The patient was referred for palliative care and died 6.5 months after surgery due to massive loco-regional recurrence.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 44-year-old man with Crohn's disease diagnosed 15 years previously
column2: who was admitted to the general surgery department for abdominal pain and diarrhoea of one week's duration
column3: compatible with a flare-up of his disease. Under home treatment with corticoids and mesalazine

column5: ileocaecal valve and cecum
column6: following ileocaecal perforation
column7: as well as other operations for anal fistula with abscess in the buttock
column8: for drainage. During the current admission

column11: resecting his rectum. The postoperative course was uneventful until

column13: he suffered a generalised tonic-clonic seizure lasting 3 minutes
column14: without sphincter incontinence. A general biochemistry was performed
column15: showing a calcium corrected for albumin of 8.42 mg/dl (rn: 8.7-10.6)
column17: albumin 2.5 mg/dl (rn 4-5.2)
column18: glucose and sodium within the reference values. Subsequently

column20: which showed no abnormalities. An electrocardiogram on the day of admission showed a normal sinus rhythm at 79 bpm

column24: a 24-hour electroencephalographic recording was performed
column25: which showed no alterations. Given that the patient showed signs of dehydration and malnutrition
column26: as well as decreased intake and asthenia
column27: a referral was made to the Nutrition Unit for assessment of nutritional support if necessary. On questioning
column28: she reported paresthesia in the lower limbs
column29: which she recently perceived more as intense pruritus
column30: with no other symptoms. He also refers that he has had 3 convulsive episodes of similar characteristics to the current ones in the last 5 months
column31: with no subsequent clinical repercussions
column32: having consulted the Emergency Department on one occasion
column33: where
column34: as it was the first convulsive episode
column35: no antiepileptic treatment was prescribed. On examination
column36: the patient weighed 55.1 kg and was 172 cm tall (BMI 18.63 kg/m2). He reported a weight loss of 7 kg in the last 6 months
column37: which represents a weight loss/time ratio of 15.23%
column38: implying severe malnutrition. The examination revealed mild cutaneous-mucosal dehydration and a moderate decrease in fat and muscle mass
column39: which was subsequently diagnosed as moderate mixed energy-protein malnutrition
column40: according to the anthropometric and biochemical parameters of the classic nutritional assessment. The rest of the physical examination was normal
column41: with no clinical signs of hypocalcaemia or hypomagnesaemia such as Trosseau's sign
column42: Chovstek's sign
column43: muscle spasms
column44: tremor or tendon hyporeflexia. A dietary history for the months prior to admission showed that his calorie intake was insufficient for his needs and that he was also deficient in certain food groups such as dairy products
column45: fruit
column46: vegetables and red meat. Given the existence of dehydration with negative water balances due to a high ileostomy debit
column47: and low blood electrolyte levels
column48: monitored parenteral treatment was started to replace volume
column49: electrolytes and other micronutrients
column50: including phosphorus and magnesium. Prior to this
column51: a blood sample was taken to determine these micronutrients in view of the suspicion of a possible deficiency. That same day the patient suffered a seizure similar to the previous ones. The blood test showed a magnesium level of 0.76 mg/dl (rn: 2.40-5.40) with phosphorus
column52: calcium
column53: potassium and sodium within the reference values. A perfusion with high doses of magnesium sulphate was prescribed with progressive normalisation of her blood levels
column54: with high doses of oral magnesium lactate being sufficient for maintenance treatment
column55: as maintenance treatment. After stabilising the figures with oral administration

column1: A 52-year-old man with a personal history of 10 cigarettes/day ex-smoking and diagnosed with a bicuspid aortic valve with normal systolic function. A year earlier he had undergone surgery for acute sigmoid diverticulitis with perforation and peritonitis and 4 months after the operation he developed right femoral-popliteal deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
column2: and had been treated with acenocoumarol since then. The study performed 3 months after the episode to rule out hypercoagulability syndrome showed a prothrombin time (PT) of 12.67 sec (VN 9-12 sec)
column3: an activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) of 66.23 sec (VN 26-39 sec)
column4: platelets 140. 000 /dL
column5: Ig G anticardiolipin antibodies 127 GPL/ml (VN 3.2-16.5) and IgM anticardiolipin antibodies 9.2 GPL/ml (VN 3.9-41). Serum levels of antithrombin III
column6: protein S and protein C were normal. He consulted for asthenia and intermittent fever of 38ºC since one month before
column7: which in the 4 days prior to admission had begun with haemoptotic expectoration
column8: dyspnoea on moderate exertion and the fever had become persistent. Physical examination showed a good general condition
column9: with only a temperature of 38ºC and no other relevant alterations except for the colostomy. The blood test showed haemoglobin 14.5 g/dl
column10: red blood cells 4
column13: mean corpuscular volume 89.7 µmc
column14: leukocyte count 8170/dl and leukocyte count was normal. ESR was 50 mm in the first hour. INR was 2.5
column15: adjusted for acenocoumarol. Biochemistry
column16: ions and transaminases were normal. Urinary sediment showed no abnormalities. Rheumatoid factor
column17: cryoglobulins
column18: antinuclear antibodies (ANA)
column19: anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA)
column20: anti-glomerular basement membrane
column21: anti-peroxidase
column22: anti-histone
column23: anti-Ro
column24: anti-SSA and anti-SM were normal or negative. Arterial blood gases FiO2 0.21: pH 7.53
column25: pO2 65 mmHg
column26: pCO2 39 mmHg. The electrocardiogram was normal and the echocardiogram confirmed a bicuspid aortic valve without other alterations. Chest X-ray showed bilateral alveolar infiltrates with normal cardiac silhouette. Blood cultures and sputum culture for bacteria and mycobacteria were negative. Ventilation/perfusion scintigraphy and computed tomography angiography showed no evidence of pulmonary thromboembolism
column27: so anticoagulant treatment was discontinued and treatment with amoxicillin/clavulanic acid was started
column28: with clinical improvement and disappearance of fever
column29: but haemoptysis sputum and infiltrates persisted in the chest X-ray. Bronchoscopy was performed and no endoscopic abnormalities were found. Bronchoaspirate culture showed no growth for bacteria
column30: fungi or mycobacteria and cytology showed no malignant cells. Spirometry
column31: lung volumes and diffusion were normal. After discharge from hospital
column32: the patient continued to present haemoptotic sputum. A new high-resolution computed axial tomography (HRCT) scan showed bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and ground glass. A new bronchoscopy showed no intrabronchial alterations and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) showed 512 cells/ml: neutrophilic polymorphonuclear 1%
column33: eosinophilic polymorphonuclear 1% and histiocytes 98%. Prussian blue staining showed 80% haemosiderophages.  Peripheral blood levels of anticardiolipin and lupus anticoagulant antibodies remained elevated. Based on the findings described above
column34: the patient was diagnosed with primary antiphospholipid syndrome and secondary pulmonary haemorrhage
column35: and treatment was restarted with acenocoumarol and acetylsalicylic acid. During one year of follow-up he presented occasional haemoptotic sputum
column36: but the chest X-ray and pulmonary function (spirometry
column37: diffusion and arterial gases) remained normal and only the CT scan showed some areas of ground glass.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 53-year-old male
column2: who started with pain and impotence in both lower limbs
column3: numbness in the legs with paraesthesia and
column4: in recent weeks
column5: difficulty in walking. The symptoms were partially relieved when lying down and did not worsen when sitting. The predominant symptomatology was sensory
column6: with severe pain in the lower limbs. The pain increased with Valsalva manoeuvres and suffered cyclical worsening. The whole picture began in September 2002
column7: one year before being seen in the neurosurgery department. The patient's only antecedents were back pain and a bilateral inguinal hernia operation years before
column8: under general anaesthesia. Magnetic resonance imaging showed an extradural
column9: intrathecal
column10: polylobulated
column11: intrathecal collection compressing 90% of the dural sac. It was reported by the radiologist as an L2-L3 synovial cyst.  Spinal angiography was not performed
column12: although neither the MRI images nor the surgical procedure revealed any type of vascular malformation. Intervention A laminectomy was performed from L4 to L2. At L3 and L2
column13: fragments of bone and cartilaginous tissue began to be obtained
column14: infiltrated by a dark liquid which
column15: in addition
column16: spilled into the operative field with an appearance similar to fuel oil. The tissue is removed from the area
column17: decompressing the dural sac
column18: and the incision is closed. Pathological anatomy The pathology report describes the extemporaneous and postoperative specimens as osteocartilaginous tissue
column19: muscle and fibrous tissue
column20: with areas of haemorrhage and macrophages in the periphery laden with haemosideric pigment.  No other lesions or malignant or atypical cells were observed. Postoperative outcome Postoperative recovery was excellent with no complications and total improvement of symptoms. After one year of follow-up the patient remains totally asymptomatic.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: An 80-year-old woman came to hospital with diplopia of 7 days' duration. The diagnosis was complete paralysis of the right third cranial nerve with pupillary involvement. She did not report headache
column2: jaw claudication or stiffness in the neck and joints. His personal history was only significant for arterial hypertension. His ophthalmological history was of no interest. Ocular motility examination in the left eye (OI) was normal. The right eye (OD) had palpebral ptosis and limited motility in all gaze positions except abduction. The pupillary reaction to light in the OL was 3 mm to 2 mm
column3: the pupillary response in the OD was slow from 5 mm to 4 mm. There was no afferent pupillary defect. Slit lamp examination was characteristic of bilateral cataract. Fundus examination was normal. Cerebral magnetic resonance angiography did not detect pathology. In the laboratory
column4: the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) was 28 mm/h
column5: C-reactive protein was 0.2 mg/dl (normal
column6: <0.8 mg/dl) and platelets were 175
column7: 000/ml3. Rheumatoid factor
column8: antinuclear antibodies
column9: anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies
column10: anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies and luetic serology were negative. The diagnosis of TA was considered and a temporal artery biopsy was performed.
