column1: A 26-year-old female patient attended our department for bilateral oedema of the upper eyelids
column2: which had been present for 2 years. Ophthalmological examination revealed lesions of imprecise limits (infiltrative aspect of the epidermis) on the nasal part of both upper eyelids
column3: with an orange hue in the temporal area
column4: firm in consistency
column5: and extending along the eyelid crease. They were non-motile
column6: non-painful masses that did not extend beyond the orbital rim. The rest of the examination was normal. In order to try to make a differential diagnosis between entities such as orbital pseudotumour
column7: collagen disease
column8: sarcoidosis
column9: etc.
column10: a systemic examination was performed
column11: and all the results were normal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the orbit showed that the masses were practically symmetrical and even infiltrated the levator muscle of the upper eyelid
column12: without affecting the eyeball. Corticosteroid treatment was started (thinking of an inflammatory process located at the eyelid level)
column13: with high doses of methylprednisolone (1 g of Urbason®
column14: HOECHST FARMA)
column15: which reduced the size of the tumours
column16: but with recurrence of the tumours when this medication was discontinued. In view of this
column17: and not having reached a diagnosis
column18: an incisional biopsy was performed
column19: obtaining three pieces of pinkish-yellowish tissue. Histological examination showed lax connective tissue
column20: almost all of which was infiltrated by histiocytic cells characteristic of xanthogranulomatosis
column21: which tended to form a granulomatous pattern. Immunohistochemical staining for histiocytic cells (CD 68) was positive. This led to a diagnosis of palpebral xanthogranulomatosis. Further tests were performed to rule out multi-organ involvement: abdomino-thoracic CT
column22: cranial and orbital CT
column23: chest X-ray
column24: abdomino-pelvic ultrasound and bone scan with Tc 99m diphosphate. All were normal. It is therefore a case of pure orbital xanthogranulomatosis
column25: or Erdheim-Chester disease
column26: with no systemic manifestations. At present
column27: after a new course of corticosteroids (methylprednisolone 80 mg/24 hours
column28: Urbason®) and with a maintenance dose (methylprednisolone 4 mg/48 hours
column29: Urbason®) on a continuous basis
column30: the process remains relatively stable.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 76-year-old patient
column2: with no known allergies
column3: with a history of dyslipidaemia
column4: arterial hypertension
column5: old acute myocardial infarction
column6: triple aorto-coronary bypass for 3-vessel disease
column7: one year old
column8: and TUR for leiomyoadenomatous hyperplasia of the prostate
column9: two years old. No previous testicular trauma was reported. He also had no clinical
column10: radiological or laboratory history of tuberculosis or brucellosis. He consulted the urology department for testicular discomfort
column11: consisting of intermittent chronic mild pain
column12: of 4 months' evolution
column13: with a hard and irregular nodule on examination in the right testicle with no accompanying spontaneous pain or pain on palpation. Ultrasound findings revealed a low echogenicity
column14: lobulated
column15: nodular focal lesion 2 cm in diameter in the lower pole of the right testicle
column16: vascularised
column17: and therefore compatible with neoformation. The left testicle had no pathological findings of interest.  Abdominal and pelvic CT scan with contrast shows no evidence of retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy. Blood tests showed normal values for alpha-fetoprotein
column18: HCG and LDH (HCG: 1.74 U/l; alpha-fetoprotein: 2.07 ng/ml; LDH: 299 mU/ml). The patient underwent a right inguinal orchiectomy. The macroscopic anatomopathological study showed a scrotal pouch with hydrocele measuring 8 x 5 x 2.5 cm with 5 cm of epididymal duct. The section showed a testicle measuring 5.5 x 2.5 x 2.5 x 2.5 cm
column19: of fibrous consistency
column20: with no macroscopic lesions compatible with neoplasia. Microscopic examination showed testicular parenchyma with vacuolated degeneration of germ cells and Sertoli cells
column21: with vesicular nuclei
column22: and a mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate with lymphocytes and plasma cells on the walls of the seminiferous tubules. There are numerous granulomatous formations with abundant multinucleated giant cells located in the stroma between the seminiferous tubules and some of them inside the seminiferous tubules. No neoplastic cellularity was observed. PAS and Ziehl Nielsen staining showed no mycotic microorganisms or mycobacteria. Histopathological findings suggest the diagnosis of idiopathic granulomatous orchitis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 11-year-old white girl with a history of previous health problems. She was admitted when her parents noticed an increase in abdominal volume for approximately 12 days
column2: accompanied by weight loss and lack of appetite. On physical examination
column3: the mucous membranes are pale
column4: and there is a palpable tumour of 8-10cm in the right abdominal flank
column5: with defined borders
column6: firm and non-painful consistency
column7: which passes the abdominal midline. Routine tests show a haemoglobin of 90mg/lt and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 130mm/1 hour. Chest X-ray is normal
column8: as is the bone survey
column9: simple abdominal X-ray shows calcifications in the tumour
column10: IVUS shows normal sized kidneys
column11: good bilateral renal elimination
column12: no dilatation of the excretory tract
column13: In the IVUS the kidneys are of normal size
column14: good bilateral renal elimination
column15: no dilatation of the excretory tract
column16: only slight displacement of the right kidney downwards and outwards due to the tumour and in the ultrasound scan a solid
column17: echogenic mass of 11cm in diameter
column18: located in the right abdominal flank above and towards the lower pole of the right kidney
column19: but without infiltrating it
column20: is observed. Surgical treatment was decided with the preoperative diagnosis of Neuroblastoma
column21: after blood replacement by transfusion. During the operation
column22: several tumours were observed in the meso of the transverse colon
column23: the largest measuring 7cm
column24: which were resected and removed in their entirety. Macroscopic examination of the surgical specimen revealed whitish tumours with apparently good delimitation
column25: a firm consistency and a whirling appearance
column26: with focal calcifications. Microscopic study showed that the intestinal tumour was made up of a proliferation of fibroblastic cells
column27: with characteristics in some areas similar to smooth muscle cells
column28: foci of calcification and necrosis
column29: and the histopathological diagnosis was myofibromatosis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 42-year-old male
column2: asymptomatic
column3: was ophthalmologically assessed for a check-up of his type II diabetes of 3 years' evolution. On physical examination
column4: corrected visual acuity was 1.0 in both eyes. The anterior pole was within normal and the intraocular pressure was 16 mmHg in both eyes. Intrinsic and extrinsic motility was normal. Indirect ophthalmoscopy showed a right optic nerve with band or bow-tie atrophy and left papilla described as pale; there were no signs of diabetic retinopathy.  A visual field was performed (Humphrey 30-2 Allergan Humphrey test
column5: San Leandro
column6: California
column7: USA) showing right homonymous hemianopsia. In view of the suspicion of an intracranial space-occupying lesion
column8: a brain computed tomography (CT) scan was performed in which a 2 cm diameter calcification was observed in relation to the amygdala and the head of the left hippocampus. Brain MRI showed a heterogeneous lesion in the head of the left hippocampus
column9: with calcification and an adjacent haemorrhagic area.  The colour test was normal. On pre-surgical cerebral arteriography and vascular mapping
column10: the patient presented an allergic reaction to contrast with cutaneous manifestations
column11: which subsided after treatment with antihistamines. Surgical intervention was performed by craniotomy and a complete resection of the lesion was performed. Pathological examination of the lesion revealed a subependymoma. The definitive diagnosis was subependymoma of the temporal horn of the left lateral ventricle with involvement of the retrochiasmatic pathway and optic atrophy in the left band. In the last ophthalmological examination
column12: the patient remained unchanged
column13: with the same degree of atrophy of the optic nerves and the rest of the examination was normal.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 22-year-old man came to the clinic with a painful lymphadenopathy in the left laterocervical region that had been present for 4 months and had not decreased in size with the use of antibiotics or NSAIDs. He reported several days of fever of up to 38 ºC and profuse night sweats
column2: coinciding with cough and pharyngeal discomfort
column3: symptoms that disappeared in a few days. On examination
column4: the patient had a lymphadenopathy in the left laterocervical region measuring 2 cm in diameter
column5: not adhering to superficial or deep planes
column6: not painful on palpation and with an elastic consistency. He also had two other lymphadenopathies of similar characteristics
column7: approximately 1.5 cm in diameter
column8: in the left supraclavicular region and right laterocervical region. The rest of the examination showed no findings of interest. A complete blood count
column9: biochemistry with tumour markers (CEA
column10: α FP
column11: PSA)
column12: chest X-ray
column13: abdominal ultrasound and immunological study (ANAs
column14: ANTI-RNP
column15: ANTI-SSB
column16: ANTI-Sm
column17: ANTI-RO
column18: ANTI-CENTROMER
column19: RF and immunoglobulins) were performed
column20: with normal results. Mantoux was negative. Serology was performed
column21: with the following results: toxoplasmosis
column22: brucellosis
column23: CMV
column24: EBV
column25: HIV
column26: syphilis
column27: adenovirus
column28: mycoplasma
column29: HBV
column30: HCV
column31: Salmonella typhi and paratyphi
column32: C. psitacci
column33: pneumoniae and trachomatis and Rickettsia negative; immunised for rubella and measles (IgG +
column34: IgM -); positive serology for mumps (IgG + weak
column35: IgM +). Biopsy of the left laterocervical adenopathy was performed
column36: with the following result: lymph node showing preserved architecture
column37: except in an area affecting the cortical and paracortical areas where a necrotic process associated with T lymphoid proliferation was observed
column38: consisting of highly activated lymphocytes
column39: with the presence of immunoblasts and abundant histiocytes
column40: many of which phagocytose cellular detritus. No granulocytes are present. The rest of the lymph node shows follicles with activated germinal centres and stimulation of the paracortical area. This biopsy was diagnostic of histiocytic necrotising lymphadenitis or Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 71-year-old woman with a history of arterial hypertension
column2: renal transplant and choledocholithiasis presented to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of fever
column3: more intense abdominal pain in the left iliac fossa
column4: liquid diarrhoea without pathological products and occasional alimentary vomiting. On examination
column5: the patient was febrile
column6: haemodynamically stable
column7: well hydrated
column8: eupneic and normal colour. The abdomen was soft and depressible
column9: with pain on deep palpation
column10: without clear focalisation and without signs of peritoneal irritation. Additional tests included a blood test that showed discrete leukocytosis (10
column11: 200/μl) with a CRP of 2 mg/dl
column12: neutrophilia
column13: and a plain abdominal X-ray that was normal. In view of the suspected diagnosis of acute diverticulitis
column14: an abdominal CT scan was performed
column15: showing some diverticula in the small intestine
column16: with evidence of a 16 mm diverticulum in the jejunum
column17: with inflammatory signs and a high-density foreign body in its interior with a "Y" morphology
column18: suggesting an animal bone as the first diagnostic possibility. A millimetre-sized bubble of pneumoperitoneum and inflammation of the adjacent fat were also observed adjacent to the diverticulum
column19: these findings being compatible with acute perforated diverticulitis of the small intestine with a foreign body inside the diverticulum.  With these results and in view of the patient's acceptable general condition
column20: she was admitted to the ward for treatment with digestive rest
column21: broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotherapy (Imipenem 500 mg every 6 hours) and observation. During the stay
column22: the patient's fever improved but the abdominal pain persisted
column23: so scheduled surgery was decided. During the operation
column24: multiple diverticula were found in the jejunum
column25: one of them with inflammatory signs
column26: but without intra-abdominal abscesses. The gallbladder appeared distended and the common bile duct was larger than 1 cm in diameter. Intestinal resection with reconstruction by laterolateral anastomosis
column27: cholecystectomy and exploration of the biliary tract were performed after confirmation of choledocholithiasis by cholangiography
column28: extracting the stone and leaving a 4 mm Kehr drain in the common bile duct.  The immediate postoperative period was uneventful
column29: reintroducing the diet with good tolerance and digestive transit. A trans-Kehr cholangiography was performed
column30: which showed the absence of choledocholithiasis. On the tenth postoperative day
column31: the patient had sudden abdominal pain associated with hypotension and elevated pancreatic enzymes and was transferred to the ICU with a diagnosis of moderate acute pancreatitis
column32: dying 24 hours later as a result of multi-organ failure.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 30-month-old girl who came to the emergency department for presenting in the last two days with slight gait instability and intention tremor. The parents reported that three weeks earlier a mild generalised rash without fever had appeared
column2: which resolved spontaneously in a few days. His personal history included no known allergies or previous trauma and his vaccination schedule was up to date
column3: including varicella (chickenpox). Her psychomotor development was normal. She was re-evaluated 48 hours later
column4: highlighting a worsening of ataxia that prevented her from standing upright
column5: associated with severe irritability and irregular sleep. Physical examination on admission showed the patient to be in good nutritional condition and there were no meningeal signs
column6: external signs of trauma or other pathological findings. The neurological examination revealed slurred but intelligible speech appropriate to the context
column7: cerebellar ataxia
column8: and intense and generalised intention tremor. Cranial nerves
column9: strength
column10: muscle tone and osteotendinous reflexes were normal and symmetrical. On admission
column11: electroencephalogram (EEG) and brain tomography (CT) with iodine contrast were performed
column12: which revealed no electroencephalographic or structural abnormalities. Urine toxins were negative. Lumbar puncture showed mild lymphorrhoea with negative biochemistry and cultures
column13: including Herpes group
column14: neurotropic virus and Borrelia. Serology for Herpes simplex virus
column15: Epstein-Barr
column16: Varicella-zoster
column17: enterovirus
column18: Salmonella sp.
column19: Streptococcus pyogenes and Borrelia burgdoferi showed no pathological findings. On the fifth day after symptom onset
column20: the patient presented with intention tremor and severe truncal ataxia that made sitting difficult. The tremor was aggravated by probable intentionally reinforcing myoclonus and the irritability was extreme. Rapid
column21: saccadic
column22: multidirectional
column23: chaotic but conjugated eye movements then appeared
column24: which were also visible with the eyes closed
column25: and which decreased when the patient was able to fixate his gaze. Given the clinical diagnosis of opsoclonus (SOMA)
column26: the search for a possible tumour was initiated. An abdominal ultrasound was requested
column27: with normal results
column28: and a simple chest X-ray showed a left parasternal thoracic mass. A thoracic CT scan showed a left paravertebral intrathoracic mass
column29: compatible with NCT
column30: confirmed after surgery as localised ganglioneuroblastoma. Neuron-specific enolase in blood and 24-hour urine catecholamines were also requested and found to be normal.  The opsoclonus decreased after initiation of high-dose oral prednisone (2 mg/kg/day)
column31: and was no longer observed 15 days after surgery. Ataxia and irritability improved markedly
column32: but one year later she still requires treatment with oral prednisone at minimal daily doses for relapses of mild gait instability and irritability
column33: with no evidence of tumour recurrence to date. His psychomotor development continues to progress normally.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 46-year-old man
column2: with no history of pathology of interest except vasectomy at the age of 42
column3: presented to the emergency department for a perineal tumour of insidious onset and progressive increase in size over the last few days
column4: with no repercussions on erectile capacity or urination. He categorically denied any history of trauma. On examination
column5: he had a perineal tumour in the left paracavernosal region
column6: non-fluctuant
column7: non-painful
column8: of fibroelastic consistency. Soft tissue ultrasound was performed with diagnostic orientation towards perineal haematoma dependent on the proximal portion of the left corpus cavernosum. Nuclear magnetic resonance imaging showed a hypointense area of approximately 8x2x0.8 cm located in the posterior region of the left corpus cavernosum with integrity of the tunica albuginea and Buck's fascia.  Bacteriological study of material obtained by puncture was performed with negative culture. Oral antiplatelet treatment and physical measures were administered
column9: with reabsorption of the haematoma and complete resolution after 4 months.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 12-year-old woman reported having suffered a left facial abscess of dental origin. The predominant clinical manifestations at the time of our assessment were inability to open her mouth. The most significant finding in the CT scan and in the Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Imaging (NMR) was the absence of the left parotid gland and the mandibular deformity with fusion of its posterior wall to the maxilla and left pterygoid process
column2: with the consequent anterior displacement of the mandibular condyles due to severe dysplasia of the temporomandibular joint. Given the clinical situation described
column3: tracheotomy was required to proceed with the extrarticular release of the maxillomandibular ankylosis
column4: extraction of the affected teeth and coverage with a standard mucosal flap. In the immediate postoperative period the buccal opening was fixed by 2 cm using a retromolar wedge.  At the present time the patient maintains a 2.4 cm buccomandibular opening
column5: which allows solid oral feeding. Confirmation of this entity was made by anatomopathological study which reported changes compatible with chronic osteomyelitis.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 47-year-old man with long-standing type 2 diabetes on treatment with metformin (850 mg/8 h) and glimepiride (4 mg/day)
column2: an active smoker and regular drinker. He had had several episodes of acute non-lithiasic pancreatitis. A week before admission
column3: he had a syncopal episode while working in the fields. Subsequently
column4: he presented intense asthenia
column5: hypoorexia and general malaise with orthostatism. He attended the health centre with a blood pressure of 70/35 mmHg and capillary glycaemia of 20 mg/dl
column6: for which glucagon was administered i.v. In the emergency department
column7: hypotension persisted
column8: with signs of extracellular volume depletion and tachypnoea. Blood tests showed plasma Cr 10.3 mg/dl
column9: glycaemia 287 mg/dl and lactic acid 20 mmol/l. Arterial blood gas revealed a pH of 6.87 with bicarbonate of 2.2 mEq/l. Orotracheal intubation was performed and he was admitted to the ICU with assisted ventilation and inotropic administration. Subsequently
column10: haemodialysis was performed for four hours followed by continuous venovenous haemofiltration with analytical improvement. At discharge he had a Cr of 1.20 mg/dl
column11: pH of 7.46 and bicarbonate of 24.6 mEq/l.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 56-year-old woman
column2: diagnosed with pSS 13 years previously. She presented with dry syndrome
column3: asthenia and frequent episodes of polyarthritis. During this time
column4: she followed prolonged treatment with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and steroids. In addition
column5: in recent months
column6: methotrexate had been associated with little improvement in symptoms. Three months after starting dental treatment with dental implants
column7: he was admitted with facial oedema
column8: febrile syndrome and decreased diuresis. Physical examination revealed deterioration in general condition
column9: blood pressure (BP) of 160/90 mmHg
column10: fever and submandibular oedema with evidence of active infection in the lower dental arch. There was no distal oedema or skin lesions. Laboratory tests showed Hb 9.2 g/dl
column11: creatinine 2.9 mg/dl
column12: urea 110 mg/dl
column13: normal liver profile
column14: lipid profile
column15: ANCA and immunoglobulins. ANA positive
column16: anti-DNA negative. Low C3 and C4
column17: 46 and 1.6 mg/dl
column18: respectively. Serology for HBV
column19: HCV and HIV negative. Blood cultures negative. ANA
column20: anti-Ro
column21: anti-LA and rheumatoid factor (RF) antibodies remained positive since the diagnosis of SSp. He had also occasionally presented hypocomplementemia. Urine proteinuria (2 g/l) and microhaematuria were observed. Renal ultrasound was normal. The patient developed an afternoon fever
column22: despite antibiotherapy
column23: and oliguria
column24: and dialysis treatment had to be started. Suspecting acute glomerulonephritis (GN)
column25: probably postinfectious
column26: given the history of the mandibular infectious process and hypocomplementemia
column27: a renal biopsy was performed with the following results: The cylinder for light microscopy contained 8 glomeruli showing diffuse capillary occlusion by thrombi of PAS-positive proteinaceous material. They were accompanied
column28: in some glomeruli
column29: by segmental infiltration of inflammatory cells. The interstitium showed isolated foci of lymphoplasmacytic inflammation and the arteries were unchanged.  Direct immunofluorescence (DIF) showed strong positivity for IgG
column30: IgM
column31: kappa and lambda thrombi
column32: but weaker for C3 and IgA. C1q and fibrinogen were negative. Ultrastructural study was performed at a later stage. column1: A 54-year-old man was admitted to hospital with an episode of chest pain lasting one hour. The ECG showed Q waves together with E-ST in inferior leads and D-ST in leads I
column2: aVL and V4-V5. In right precordial leads a marked J-wave followed by a convex and descending D-ST ending in a negative T-wave could also be observed. With the diagnosis of inferior AMI he received fibrinolytic treatment with tenecteplase. One hour later the ECG
column3: recorded with mild precordial pain
column4: revealed no inferior ST-segment elevation
column5: a negative T-wave in aVL and a J-point elevation > 0.2 mV with descending ST-segment and negative T-wave in leads V1-V2
column6: suggesting an electrocardiographic pattern of SB. Five hours later the ECG showed a prominent J-wave with convex and saddle E-ST in leads V1 and V2
column7: respectively. There was also a J-point elevation associated with a positive E-ST and T-wave in leads V3-V4. Three days after admission the ECG revealed an inferior qR pattern along with a negative T wave in leads III and aVF
column8: a manifest J wave in leads V1-V2
column9: a concave E-ST with positive T wave in leads V2-V3
column10: and no S wave in the left leads. He had no ventricular arrhythmias during hospitalisation. The peak values of creatine kinase and troponin I were 1
column11: 398 U/l and 23.2 ng/ml
column12: respectively. Coronary arteriography revealed a proximal (95%) stenosis of the right coronary artery and a stent was placed. After discharge
column13: 6 months later he underwent a flecainide challenge test (2 mg/kg intravenously over 10 minutes) which was negative for a diagnosis of SB.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 43-year-old housewife
column2: allergic to iodinated contrast agent and smoker of 1 packet of cigarettes a day
column3: hysterectomised and right hysterectomised for endometriosis. The patient was being studied by the haematology department for isolated leukocytosis; an abdominal ultrasound scan was performed
column4: finding a destructured left kidney with cystic images or hydronephrosis
column5: and she was referred to our clinic. On interrogation
column6: she refers to a 27-day admission
column7: when she was 12 years old
column8: to another hospital for lumbar pain with haematuria
column9: without knowing the diagnosis. She also reported occasional mechanical low back pain with moderate asthenia. Physical examination: no findings. Complementary tests: haemogram with slight leukocytosis without deviation of the leukocyte formula
column10: the rest being normal
column11: biochemistry and coagulation normal. MAG-3-Tc-99m renogram: normal right kidney. Heterogeneous uptake in the left kidney with superior calyceal dilatation
column12: retention in the left upper pole presenting a slowing of the excretory curve whose activity disappears in late images. CT scan without contrast: left upper polar renal cystic mass of approximately 12 cm maximum diameter displacing pancreas and spleen. Internally it was made up of multiple cysts of different sizes and had heterogeneous internal septa
column13: some of them thick and irregular
column14: suggestive of cystic multinodular cystic nephroma or cystic renal cell carcinoma. It was decided to perform a nephrectomy with left lymphadenectomy. The anatomopathological study of the specimen showed a kidney with a multicystic tumour measuring 9x10 cm that occupied most of the kidney. The contents of the cyst are amber without the presence of solid parts or adherence of the tumour to the capsule. The cavities are lined by a simple epithelium with frequent cells with a "tack" morphology. The intercellular stroma is fibrous. Well-demarcated lesion of preserved renal parenchyma. Pathological diagnosis of benign multilocular cystic tumour of the kidney.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A three-year-old girl
column2: with no personal or family history of interest
column3: was referred by her paediatrician to the Allergology Department for presenting
column4: for the last year
column5: recurrent episodes of disseminated habonosis lesions without angioedema. The outbreaks appeared every one or two months
column6: usually persisted for a week and were sometimes accompanied by odynophagia. The parents did not associate these symptoms with any possible external triggering agent
column7: including drugs or food. Physical examination at the first visit revealed hypertrophy of the palatine tonsils
column8: with no other noteworthy findings. Skin tests with a standard battery of pneumoallergens common in the region (including dust mites
column9: pollens
column10: fungi and animal epithelia)
column11: latex
column12: food
column13: plant panallergens and Anisakis simplex were negative. General laboratory tests (biochemistry
column14: haemogram
column15: erythrocyte sedimentation rate
column16: thyroid hormones and urine) were normal
column17: as were serum immunoglobulin classes IgA
column18: IgM and IgG. Total IgE was 104.5 IU/ml (normal reference values 100-120 IU/ml). Anti-streptolysin O antibody (ASLO) levels were 1571 IU/ml (laboratory reference value
column19: 0-200 IU/ml). No parasites were observed in the stool examination. After treatment with penicillin G-benzathine intramuscularly for four months (one dose per month)
column20: the child was asymptomatic and ASLO levels progressively decreased to normal.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 33-year-old woman was referred to the Ocular Oncology Unit for evaluation of a pigmented lesion in the iris of the right eye (OD) discovered during routine examination. On examination she presented with average myopia in both eyes with a visual acuity of 0.8. The left eye showed no pathological findings
column2: while in the OD there was a rounded pigmented mass of approximately 3-4 mm in diameter in the superoexternal quadrant of the anterior chamber (AC) between the 9 and 11 o'clock meridians. IOP was normal
column3: and gonioscopy showed occupation of the angle by the mass without satellite lesions. Examination under mydriasis showed that it originated in the ciliary body
column4: producing a notch in the transparent lens and a fundus without pathology. Computed Axial Tomography (CT) showed the existence of a rounded mass located between the root of the iris and the ciliary body with moderate contrast uptake
column5: 8.3 mm in height and 7.5 mm in diameter
column6: with no signs of extraocular extension. A diagnosis of probable melanocytoma of the ciliary body was made
column7: and as the patient was asymptomatic and had good visual function
column8: it was decided to observe her periodically. The patient remained stable for 36 months until
column9: coinciding with an episode of corneal erosion due to the use of contact lenses
column10: she developed inflammation in the CA
column11: with the presence of pigment dispersion
column12: excavation of the tumour mass and an increase in IOP that was resistant to the usual medical treatment. This condition was diagnosed as melanocytomalytic glaucoma and surgical treatment was decided. An ab externo iridocyclectomy was performed with excision of the tumour mass. The patient has evolved favourably and after one year maintains a VA of 0.3. Histopathology revealed a pigmented mass measuring 9x8x8 mm
column13: with a large central necrotic area and the rest composed of densely pigmented
column14: polyhedral cells with a rounded
column15: central nucleus
column16: characteristic of melanocytoma with large areas of necrosis. No atypical cells were found.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 49-year-old man
column2: smoker of 12 cigarettes a day and ex-drinker for 3 years. He came to the emergency department for presenting progressive dyspnoea in the previous days
column3: accompanied by oedema
column4: dizziness and syncope
column5: without accompanying chest pain or orthopnoea. The relevant history included a case of infective endocarditis on a myxoid mitral valve
column6: complicated by valve perforation and severe mitral insufficiency
column7: initially treated with antibiotics and subsequently with replacement of the mitral valve with a mechanical prosthesis by sternotomy. He was discharged 10 days before the current admission on treatment with acenocoumarol
column8: bisoprolol
column9: furosemide and amiodarone. Examination revealed a fair general condition
column10: arterial hypotension (TAS 90 mmHg)
column11: jugular ingurgitation and hepatomegaly of 3 fingerbreadths. Laboratory tests showed a significant elevation of transaminases (AST: 5
column12: 550 U/L; ALT: 3
column13: 826 U/L) and LDH (10
column15: with slightly elevated bilirubin levels (2 mg/dL). He also had anaemia (Hb: 9.2 g/dL)
column16: impaired renal function (Cr: 1.76 mg/dL; urea 88 mg/dL) and an I.N.R. of 9.86. Serologies for HAV
column17: HBV
column18: HCV
column19: HIV
column20: EBV
column21: CMV and autoimmunity were negative. Ingestion of drugs and other hepatotoxic products was ruled out. The electrocardiogram showed no alterations of interest and the ultrasound showed marked hepatomegaly with diffuse alteration of echogenicity related to steatosis
column22: and the hepatic vascular study was normal. Given the suspicion of a possible cardiac origin of the clinical picture
column23: an echocardiogram was performed which confirmed the presence of massive pericardial effusion
column24: predominantly in the free wall of the right ventricle
column25: where it reached 60 mm thick
column26: and in the left ventricle with 29 mm thick. The right ventricle as well as the initial portion of the pulmonary artery appeared completely collapsed
column27: evidence of severe echocardiographic tamponade.  In view of these findings
column28: the patient was transferred to the Coronary Unit where diagnostic and evacuative pericardiocentesis was performed using an anterior approach (3rd left parasternal intercostal space) with extraction of 600 cc of haemorrhagic fluid
column29: leaving a slight effusion located at the apical level (encapsulated). Samples were sent for biochemistry
column30: microbiology and cytology
column31: confirming a haematic effusion with a haematocrit higher than the plasma haematocrit
column32: with the microbiological study and cytology being normal. At the same time
column33: corticosteroid treatment was started with a good clinical response. Laboratory tests showed normalisation of creatinine levels (0.72 mg/dL) and a progressive decrease in transaminase values (AST: 304 U/L; ALT: 227 U/L) and LDH (568 U/L). Prior to discharge
column34: a control echocardiogram was performed which showed mild pericardial effusion of fibrinous appearance
column35: loculated
column36: asymmetrically distributed
column37: predominantly located at the anterior level and apex of the right ventricle
column38: with no evidence of haemodynamic compromise. Given the good clinical and analytical evolution
column39: liver biopsy was not necessary and he was diagnosed with ischaemic hepatitis due to low cardiac output in relation to cardiac tamponade secondary to post-pericardiotomy syndrome with haemorrhagic transformation.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Male patient aged 59 years with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and right lower lobectomy six months ago for squamous cell carcinoma of the lung (T2N0M0) at the reference centre
column2: without having received any subsequent treatment. No known allergies or other history of interest. He consulted for clinical manifestations compatible with left renal colic of moderate intensity with ureteral irradiation
column3: without voiding syndrome and accompanied by haematuria with emission of filiform clots. He reported having lost approximately 8 kg in the last 2 months. Examination revealed a slight mucocutaneous pallor
column4: slightly positive left fist percussion. The abdomen was soft and depressible with no masses or megaliths. The rest of the examination was of no interest. Haematological examination showed mild anaemia
column5: with normal biochemistry and coagulation. The urine sediment showed microscopic haematuria. Ultrasound showed a cortical cyst in the upper pole of the left kidney measuring 5 cm in size and a solid-cystic tumour of the same size in the lower pole without ectasia of the excretory tract. The right kidney
column6: bladder and prostate were normal. Given the suspicion of a renal mass versus a complex renal cyst
column7: it was decided to perform a thoraco-abdominal-minopelvic CAT scan
column8: which revealed post-surgical changes in the left lung with bilateral emphysema. Retroperitoneal adenopathies in the aorto-caval territory measuring over 1 cm in diameter and a heterogeneous renal mass measuring 5 cm in diameter.  With these findings and the suspicion of renal carcinoma vs. metastasis
column9: it was decided to perform a directed CT FNA
column10: which obtained squamous cells from the left kidney.  With the diagnosis of left renal metastasis of pulmonary squamous cell carcinoma (Stage IV)
column11: it was decided to refer the patient to the Medical Oncology Department. He started treatment with Cisplatin 75 mg/m2 and Vinorelbine 25 mg/m2 on the first and eighth day of every 21 days
column12: until 3 cycles were completed
column13: and then a response evaluation study was carried out. After receiving 3 cycles of chemotherapy with cisplatin-vinorelbine
column14: a discrete growth of the renal mass was observed
column15: so it was considered that there was no response. For this reason she started a second line of chemotherapy with docetaxel 100mg/m2 every 21 days
column16: of which she has received 3 cycles. She is awaiting a CT scan to evaluate the response and
column17: depending on the results
column18: a PET scan has been considered to decide on a possible surgical approach to the renal lesion
column19: if there are no new pathological foci. In any case
column20: the prognosis is the same as for any metastatic pulmonary neoplasm.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 33-year-old man with no history of interest and no known family history of thrombosis came to the emergency department for intermittent diffuse abdominal pain of several days' evolution with nausea and some alimentary vomiting. Physical examination revealed diffuse pain on abdominal palpation with no signs of peritoneal irritation. The most relevant analytical data were: glucose 84 mg/dl
column2: urea 30 mg/dl
column3: creatinine 0.9 mg/dl
column4: amylase 29 U/l
column5: lactate dehydrogenase 241 U/l
column6: aspartate aminotransferase 26 U/l
column7: total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dl
column8: C-reactive protein 4.1 mg/dl
column9: haemoglobin 14.4 mg/dl
column10: platelets 301. 000 mm3
column11: leukocytes 6
column13: prothrombin activity 85%
column14: fibrinogen 518 mg/dl and D-dimer 5
column15: 871 ng/ml. An abdominal ultrasound showed an enlarged portal vein (1.6 cm in diameter)
column16: with no flow within it on Doppler study. An abdominal CT scan showed thrombosis of the portal vein and superior mesenteric vein
column17: with no other alterations. The patient was treated with enoxaparin (1 mg/kg every 12 hours) for 10 days
column18: with a favourable evolution
column19: and then continued treatment with acenocoumarol. The thrombophilia study identified heterozygosity for the G20210A mutation of the prothrombin gene
column20: with factor V Leiden
column21: activated protein C resistance
column22: lupus anticoagulant
column23: IgG and IgM anticardiolipin antibodies
column24: proteins C and S
column25: antithrombin and plasma homocysteine being normal or negative. An MRI angiogram performed 10 months later showed a 15 cm splenomegaly and an enlarged but patent portal vein with cavernomatous transformation (with small periportal collateral vessels). An oral gastrointestinal endoscopy performed 14 months after the initial picture was normal. After 15 months of follow-up treatment with acenocoumarol
column26: the patient remains asymptomatic.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O

column1: 85 year old patient referred for sudden loss of visual acuity (VA) in the left eye (LA). He was not taking any medication and had no ophthalmological or general pathological history. On examination
column2: he showed hand movement VA (WM) in the left eye. Fundus examination (FO) revealed a rounded
column3: yellowish-white macular lesion with a probable retinal macroaneurysm at the upper temporal limit. It was studied with optical coherence tomography (OCT)
column4: which showed a preretinal mass of uniform density
column5: retained by the posterior hyaloid
column6: which corresponded to an accumulation of fibrin.  After discussing with the patient the possibility of performing a vitrectomy to evacuate the premacular fibrin
column7: a wait-and-see approach was adopted. The evolution was good
column8: with recovery of VA with the OI
column9: which was 4/10 at 3 months. When the fibrin cleared
column10: a macroaneurysm was observed in the superior temporal arch. FFA and a new OCT were performed
column11: which showed recovery of foveal morphology
column12: with posterior hyaloid detached. As the aneurysm was found to be patent
column13: it was decided to perform photocoagulation around the aneurysm. Examination of the OD showed no abnormalities.  Photocoagulation caused thrombosis of the aneurysm. The VA of the LAA was maintained at 4/10.  One year later
column14: the patient returned to our hospital
column15: this time for acute loss of vision in the RA. He had VA with MM OD and 4/10 with OI. In FO there was a preretinal haemorrhage in OD. A wait-and-see approach was again adopted
column16: with recovery of VA
column17: which improved to 4/10 in 3 months. FFA was performed
column18: which revealed an arterial macroaneurysm in the inferior temporal arcade OD
column19: while OCT showed detachment of the posterior hyaloid in the macula.  Photocoagulation was performed around the aneurysm
column20: with thrombosis of the aneurysm. The patient currently has a VA of 4/10 in AO
column21: with dense corticonuclear cataracts that will be operated on soon. In addition
column22: a vascular risk study was carried out on the patient
column23: which revealed hypertension and atrial fibrillation
column24: which are being controlled with medical treatment.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 30-year-old Caucasian male
column2: with no significant medical history
column3: was referred to our department for a melanoma of the choroid in the left eye (LO) in November 2005. Since August 2005
column4: the patient had noticed a unilateral decrease in visual acuity (VA) in the LA. For the past month he had been complaining of eye pain in the left eye. The VA of the right eye (OD) was 10/10 with a spherical correction of -0.5 D
column5: that of the OI was <1/10 without correction and 8/10 with an added spherical correction of -5 D. The ophthalmological examination of the OD showed no peculiarities. The slit-lamp examination of the OI showed marked ciliary injection
column6: a mild inflammatory reaction in the anterior chamber and a bulging iris; the ocular pressure (OT) was 17 mmHg. A circumscribed amelanotic mass was prominent in the nasal sector of the fundus. Ultrasound B showed thickening of the ocular wall exceeding 5 mm. A hypoechogenic area was observed in the extra-scleral space. On fluorescein and indocyanine green angiography this lesion was surrounded by well visualised choroidal folds; no intratumoural vascular network of its own was observed.  An orbito-cerebral magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan confirmed the contrast-enhancing nodular scleral thickening in the postero-internal region of the RO
column7: without revealing other lesions.  A thorough work-up for rheumatic aetiology (rheumatoid factor
column8: antinuclear antibodies
column9: cANCA
column10: antiphospholipid antibodies) and infectious aetiology (HAART
column11: toxocarosis) was negative. Blood calcium levels were normal: 2
column12: 39 mmol/l. Chest X-ray was normal. The slightly increased angiotensin converting enzyme: 73U/L (normal
column13: 10-55) was compatible with a granulomatous condition
column14: but the rest of the examinations did not provide any other arguments in favour of sarcoidosis or tuberculosis. Based on the anamnesis
column15: clinical
column16: angiographic
column17: ultrasound and MRI findings
column18: the diagnosis of giant posterior scleritis was made. An extra-scleral biopsy was performed and histopathological examination confirmed granulomatous scleritis compatible with sarcoidosis (absence of pathogens visible by Ziehl-Neelsen
column19: Gram
column20: methamine silver and PAS staining).  Oral corticosteroid treatment was started at a dose of 1 mg/kg/day
column21: gradually reducing the dose
column22: due to a good therapeutic response
column23: to 0.5 mg/kg/day after 6 months of treatment. A local guideline of dexamethasone 0.1%
column24: 1 drop 3 times a day
column25: to treat inflammation in the anterior chamber; and atropine 1%
column26: 1 drop 3 times a day
column27: to reduce ciliary spasm
column28: was added to the LAA. The OI control examination at 6 months showed a VA of 10/10 with a spherical correction of +0.50D. The ciliary injection disappeared as well as the inflammatory reaction in the anterior chamber
column29: the lens was clear; TO was 15 mmHg. In the fundus
column30: the solid elevation in the nasal sector was flattened. On ultrasound B the total thickness of the eye wall in the lower nasal sector was approximately 2 mm.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 52 year old patient with a personal history of terminal renal failure of an unaffiliated aetiology who received a heterotopic transplant in FID from a cadaveric donor in January 1999. He had previously required haemodialysis from 1980 to 1983
column2: and peritoneal dialysis from then until the time of renal transplantation. There were no post-transplant complications. The patient was given triple immunosuppressive therapy with Cyclosporine
column3: Prednisone and Mycophenolate
column4: presenting immediate diuresis with progressive improvement of renal function
column5: with creatininemia at discharge being 1.8 mg/dl. After an uncomplicated and asymptomatic post-transplant period of 51 months in which he maintained stable renal function (creatininemia: 1.2-1.4 mg/dl)
column6: a 1.5 cm vascularised solid nodule was observed in the lower pole of the renal graft in a control ultrasound scan. Subsequent ultrasound-guided FNA revealed RCC.  In June 2003
column7: by reopening the previous Gibson incision in FID
column8: and after freeing the renal graft from the surrounding adhesions
column9: a 1.5 cm well circumscribed exophytic tumour was identified in its lower pole-anterior aspect. Lumpectomy was performed with a margin of more than 0.5 cm of macroscopically healthy parenchyma
column10: and samples of the base were sent intraoperatively and reported to be free of tumour involvement. For haemostatic purposes
column11: intraparenchymal stitches of the bleeding vessels and 'mattress' approach stitches supported by Goretex and Surgicel were performed.  The definitive histopathological diagnosis was Fuhrman type I papillary renal carcinoma
column12: Fuhrman grade 2
column13: UICC stage I (pT1a
column14: Nx
column15: Mx) with resection margins and peritumoural fat without tumour involvement. There were no complications in the postoperative course of the lumpectomy
column16: and immunosuppressive therapy was not modified. In the almost three-year follow-up
column17: carried out initially quarterly and subsequently every six months
column18: by means of a renal function study and ultrasound or MRI
column19: there is no evidence of tumour recurrence to date
column20: maintaining adequate renal function with creatininemia of 1.18 mg/dl
column21: and creatinine clearance of 115.5 ml/min without proteinuria.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 68 year old female patient
column2: who came to the pain clinic referred by her GP
column3: diagnosed with severe spondyloarthrosis
column4: mainly at the expense of the lumbar spine. She had been prescribed generic transdermal fentanyl 25 μg/h for 2 weeks
column5: with regular pain control (VAS
column6: 7-8). After examination of the patient
column7: the exchange of generic fentanyl for Durogesic® Matrix 25 μg/h was considered. After 2 weeks
column8: the patient presented better pain control (VAS
column10: requiring 1 g paracetamol on its own as a rescue treatment. At 3 months she continues with Durogesic® Matrix 25 μg/h
column11: with acceptable pain control (VAS

column1: A 24-year-old woman referred from primary care for bilateral loss of vision of 6 weeks' evolution. No family history of interest. Her personal history included treatment with Topamax 150 mg a day for 2 months for epilepsy refractory to conventional therapy. The maximum VA in the right eye was 0.6 and 0.7 in the left eye (OI). The visual field showed a bilateral central scotoma and the fundus showed bilateral maculopathy with greater pigmentary changes in the left eye. Given the temporal relationship between Topamax intake and vision loss
column2: this drug was withdrawn
column3: but after a year of follow-up the patient has not recovered vision
column4: although the process remains stable.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 13-year-old girl comes to the health centre accompanied by her mother
column2: who asks to be vaccinated against tuberculosis. She is planning a study trip to the United States and is told that this is one of the requirements for access to education in certain centres in that country. She is informed that the vaccine is not available at the health centre
column3: as it is not included in the current immunisation schedule of the Community of Madrid
column4: as well as the possibility of attending the International Vaccination Centre. However
column5: the mother stated that
column6: due to her profession
column7: she had access to this vaccine and only requested that it be administered at the centre
column8: with the family themselves providing the vaccine. After the vaccine was administered and the girl complained of pain at the injection site
column9: accompanied by a feeling of dizziness
column10: she was attended to according to the protocol. On checking the packaging of the vaccine
column11: it was found that the 2 ml vial that had been inoculated was not a single dose
column12: the usual form of presentation of the vaccine
column13: but contained 20 doses
column14: which were inoculated intramuscularly
column15: given the volume of the presentation (the usual dose for adults is 0.1 ml
column16: injected subcutaneously). After verifying that the girl's condition is good and that her vital signs are normal
column17: the family is informed of the error made and the relevant health authorities are informed. To obtain as much information as possible about the vaccine
column18: we contacted the Institute of Toxicology and the Preventive Medicine Service of the Hospital Universitario 12 Octubre
column19: the Management Department of the Reference Area
column20: as well as the Infectious Diseases Service of the same hospital and the manufacturing laboratory (Pharmacia Spain) and the International Vaccination Centre. The girl was clinically monitored at the Infectious Diseases Department of the Hospital Universitario 12 de Octubre for six months
column21: with analytical studies and immunity tests
column22: all of which were normal both at the onset of the event and during its evolution. She did not develop any type of reaction at the injection site either in the immediate period or during the follow-up period
column23: and was discharged without any incident. She did not receive any anti-tuberculosis treatment during her follow-up.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present a 43-year-old man who came to our department for assessment of a left frontal tumour of 6 months' evolution without previous trauma at that level. The patient reported no pain in the tumour
column2: only a feeling of heaviness and left fronto-occipital headache. Physical examination revealed a tumour measuring 1 cm in diameter with minimal perilesional erythema. On palpation it appeared as a hard mass
column3: not adherent to the bone plane without alteration of the frontal branch of the facial nerve. He also reported a similar nodule in the right costal region. A CT scan and an ultrasound-guided fine needle puncture-aspiration (FNAUS) of the costal tumour were requested. The CT scan showed a mass of approximately 0.7 cm at the level of the left frontal region
column4: well defined
column5: which did not invade adjacent tissues and showed no bone destruction. FNAUS of the right costal region was reported as a lipoma.  It was decided to perform a biopsy-excision of the tumour under local anaesthesia. Intraoperatively a lesion firmly attached to the fascia of the frontalis muscle and the pericranium was observed. A subperiosteal dissection including frontalis muscle and pericranium was performed
column6: no erosion of the underlying frontal bone was observed. Closure of the surgical defect was straightforward and simple. The postoperative period was uneventful and there was no recurrence after 18 months of postoperative follow-up. The anatomopathological study describes macroscopically an irregular white-pardusc nodular fragment measuring 0.9 × 0.7 × 0.4 cm. Microscopy revealed a connective tissue with a circumscribed
column7: poorly demarcated nodular lesion composed of a proliferation of oval-fusiform elements arranged in a lax matrix with a swirling-storiform pattern together with osteoclastic giant cells
column8: some extravasated red blood cells and a scattered mononuclear inflammatory component. Immunohistochemistry showed positivity for CD68 antibody and vimentin protein in the giant cells and with less intensity in the oval cells. Negative for S-100 protein. Positivity for Ki 67 antibody
column9: representing a proliferative index of less than 5%.  The study concludes with the diagnosis of benign neoplasia of mesenchymal origin type FN.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Female patient
column2: 68 years old
column3: right-handed
column4: married
column5: occupation: home. Condition that began 4 years prior to her arrival at the pain clinic

column7: very intense
column8: with periods free of pain although with a sensation of "traction"
column9: without other irradiations
column10: initially lasting for seconds an average of 4 times a day
column11: without sensory alterations. Initially treated by neurologist with carbamazepine 200 mg c-8 hrs. Two years later the pain increased and also began to appear in the frontal and periorbital region on the same side
column12: adding electric touch pain
column13: which was predominant
column14: and for this reason gabapentin 300 mg c-12 hrs was added. She had no previous history of importance. The initial physical examination was essentially normal. column1: This is a 16-year-old adolescent
column2: a competitive basketball player since the age of 5
column3: who went to the Andalusian Centre for Sports Medicine (CAMD) in Almeria to undergo a medical examination requested by his Federation. In the anamnesis
column4: he reported episodes of palpitations
column5: short and self-limited
column6: during rest and exertion. The resting ECG showed a very short interval between P and R waves (PR interval) with a delta wave
column7: compatible with pre-excitation
column8: for which he was referred for cardiological assessment. His personal history included a previous evaluation at the age of 9 years
column9: in an asymptomatic patient
column10: with a normal ECG and the reference of a paternal uncle
column11: affected with a recently ablated arrhythmia. A new resting ECG confirmed a pre-excited sinus rhythm
column12: compatible with right anteroseptal pathway and structural heart disease was ruled out by echocardiography. The 24-hour rhythm holter showed permanent pre-excitation and no arrhythmias. The treadmill stress test with Bruce protocol was conclusive and free of arrhythmias
column13: maintaining the WPW at maximum heart rates.  Considering the previous data and his condition as a competitive athlete
column14: he was sent for electrophysiological study (EPS) and ablation of the anomalous pathway. The procedure was performed with two electrocatheters: one for diagnosis with His recording and the other for mapping and ablation in the perihisian septal region. In sinus rhythm
column15: orthodromic tachycardia was induced and radiofrequency (RF) was applied over the bidirectional atrioventricular (AV) accessory pathway. Tachycardia and pre-excitation were interrupted
column16: terminating the procedure. The patient was left with right bundle branch block (RBBB)
column17: probably of traumatic origin. There is no description of the effective refractory period of the anomalous pathway. At the first subsequent follow-up
column18: the patient reported the same clinical manifestations prior to ablation and management to interrupt the tachycardias. The baseline ECG and 24-hour holter maintain the sinus pattern with WPW
column19: with no documented tachycardias. The parents have been asked to consult the electrophysiology specialist again in order to offer the best treatment options in relation to sports practice.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 27-year-old woman with a debut of the disease two years ago in the form of severe pancolitis and subsequent corticodependence
column2: on maintenance treatment with azatriopine and oral mesalazine. He was admitted for abdominal pain
column3: bloody diarrhoea and headache accompanied by motor deficits in the left lower limb. Physical examination: diffuse abdominal pain on deep palpation. Rectal examination with fresh haematic debris. Discrete functional impotence in the left lower limb and paraesthesia in both upper limbs. Laboratory tests on admission showed haemoglobin 11 g/dl
column4: ESR 78 mg/l and minimal enzyme mobilisation (GOT 74 IU/l
column5: GPT 96 IU/l
column6: GGT 182 IU/l
column7: FA 148 IU/l). Neurological assessment indicated computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain
column8: showing thrombosis of the longitudinal venous sinus. Rectosigmoidoscopy: severe mucosal involvement from the anal margin. Biopsies compatible with active ulcerative colitis
column9: ruling out infection by cytomegalovirus. Treatment was started with intravenous corticosteroids at full doses (1 mg/kg/day) and low molecular weight heparin
column10: with progressive normalisation of bowel movements. After a week of hospitalisation
column11: increased abdominal perimeter with semiology of ascites and neurological deterioration (myoclonias in lower limbs
column12: decreased visual acuity)
column13: accompanied by increased cytolysis (GOT 600 IU/l
column14: GPT 463 IU/l) and coagulopathy. Abdominal Doppler ultrasound was performed: hepatomegaly. Porta of 9.5 mm capturing Doppler only in its right branch. Prominent hepatic artery. Suprahepatic with minimal flow uptake
column15: flattened. Echogenic content in inferior cava. Ascites. Further study by CT and abdominal angio-MRI: intrahepatic cava decreased in calibre with image of intraluminal thrombus. Loss of signal intensity of the suprahepatic vessels along their entire length. Porta permeable. Hepatomegaly. Ascites.  Other causes of liver disease were ruled out and a diagnostic paracentesis was performed (leucocytes 20
column16: glucose 86
column17: protein 1.8
column18: albumin 1.4
column19: GASA 1. Cytology negative). Study of thrombophilia with relative deficit of hepatic synthesis factors (factor V 36.63%
column20: VII 21%)
column21: without primary procoagulant disorder (antiphospholipid antibody
column22: Ham's test and Leyden's factor V
column23: negative. Prothrombin and methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase gene
column24: homocysteine
column25: antithrombin III
column26: protein C and S were normal). With suspicion of Budd-Chiari syndrome
column27: treatment with full-dose sodium heparin is started. Clinical deterioration continued over the following days
column28: with tension ascites and severe coagulopathy (prothrombin activity 38%). After multidisciplinary assessment
column29: the patient was transferred to another centre for attempted placement of a percutaneous intrahepatic percutaneous portosystemic shunt system
column30: from which we were informed of the need for joint fibrinolysis due to associated portal thrombosis. The subsequent evolution was torpid with the appearance of haemorrhagic complications at different levels
column31: including a massive cerebral haemorrhage and the patient's final death.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 44-year-old man with a previous history of depression and alcoholism was taken to a regional hospital three hours after voluntary ingestion of arsenic. The patient was found to be agitated
column2: with nausea
column3: vomiting and severe watery diarrhoea. His blood pressure was 75/45 mmHg

column5: PO2 91 mmHg

column8: fluid overload

column25: PO2 105 mmHg
column26: PCO2 38 mmHg and bicarbonate 18 mmol/l. Chest X-ray was within normal limits. ECG showed sinus rhythm at 95 beats/minute
column27: prolonged QTc interval (0.70 seconds) and ST-segment depression in leads I
column28: II
column29: aVL and V2 to V6. Several minutes later
column30: ECG recording revealed several episodes of polymorphic and self-limited ventricular tachycardias compatible with PAD

column34: 28/20 mmHg; pulmonary wedge pressure
column35: 12 mmHg; cardiac index
column36: 4.7 beats/minute/m2 and systemic vascular resistances
column37: 435 dynes.sec.cm-5. He was treated with aggressive volume expansion

column40: blood pressure rose to 120/65 mmHg and systemic vascular resistances reached 1019 dynes.sec.cm-5. column45: at the cardiac level
