column1: A 41-year-old woman diagnosed with RRMS since the age of 29. Given the lack of effectiveness of interferon-beta
column2: it was decided to switch to natalizumab (EDSS 2)
column3: without the appearance of new outbreaks during this treatment. This drug was discontinued after two years due to positive VJC serology and
column4: after a four-month washout period (PL) without any pharmacological treatment
column5: it was decided to start fingolimod (EDSS 2). Two months after onset and after radiological stability of the disease for more than two years
column6: three new demyelinating lesions appeared on brain magnetic resonance imaging (CMR) with no clinical evidence of a flare-up. Thereafter
column7: the disease was radiologically stable until 28 months later
column8: when the patient suffered a flare-up with an increase in the number of lesions in both semioval centres. Despite the clinical worsening after the resolution of the flare (EDSS 3)
column9: the patient continues on fingolimod (30 months from onset to date). Regarding the safety of fingolimod
column10: lymphopenia was evident from baseline (300-900 cells/mmc)
column11: not leading to withdrawal.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 69-year-old male patient with a history of partial gastrectomy 30 years ago for peptic gastric ulcer with Billroth II reconstruction was admitted for eight days of clinical manifestations consisting of abdominal pain located in the mesogastrium together with a slight increase in serum amylase and lipase levels (amylase 550 IU/l

column4: suggesting neoplastic infiltration
column5: which was confirmed after histological study of the endoscopic biopsies. The patient underwent surgery
column6: with total gastrectomy and oesophago-jejunal anastomosis.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 62-year-old woman with a history of hypertension
column2: hypercholesterolemia and hypertriglyceridaemia. column3: pt3b
column4: negative nodes) she presented with sepsis of urinary origin and was admitted to the semi-critical unit with intensive antibiotic and diuretic treatment. Three days after admission
column5: the patient reported sudden onset tinnitus accompanied by bilateral hypoacusis of a significant degree. The patient had no vertiginous or unstable symptoms. There was no otalgia
column6: otodynia or sensation of otic fullness. Facial mobility was preserved. The physical examination was strictly normal
column7: with audiometry revealing profound hypoacusis of the right ear and cophosis of the left ear
column8: with normal impedance testing.  Once the sensorineural nature of the hearing loss had been confirmed
column9: a review of the patient's clinical history and a new anamnesis were carried out in order to carry out an aetiological study. Once the relationship with systemic diseases
column10: intracranial infections and trauma was ruled out
column11: the hypoacusis was attributed to the administration of intravenous furosemide in the initial management of septic shock. Furosemide administration was discontinued
column12: and the association of other ototoxic drugs was proscribed. Treatment with high-dose parenteral corticosteroids (methylprednisolone 120 mg/24) and oral pentoxifylline (400 mg/ 8 h) was given according to the protocol for sudden hearing loss. (400 mg/ 8 h). After 7 days of parenteral treatment
column13: oral corticosteroid treatment was continued in a descending pattern for a further 14 days (Prednisone 60 mg/day for 7 days and 30 mg/day for 7 days)
column14: maintaining pentoxifylline at the same dose for several months. Audiometry two weeks after treatment showed an improvement in tonal hearing with the appearance of auditory traces in the low frequencies in the left ear and an increase in the thresholds in the right ear.  Six months after treatment
column15: the patient's hearing in the right ear has recovered to 58%. The left ear has residual hearing in the low frequencies
column16: but no clear recovery has been observed. The patient continues to be monitored at our centre
column17: and the fitting of an acoustic prosthesis in the right ear has been recommended. Oncologically
column18: she has started complementary treatment with chemotherapy
column19: without affecting her hearing levels.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 52 year old male patient with a medical history of controlled arterial hypertension and stage V chronic renal disease of 6 years of evolution on haemodialysis 3 times a week who started his illness when he presented with odontalgia of the lower incisors
column2: dysphagia
column3: odynophagia
column4: increased volume in the painful submandibular region and local hyperthermia
column5: for which reason the patient attended the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Unit of the Hospital General del Oeste "Dr. José Gregorio Hernández" (CBMH). José Gregorio Hernández" (CBMF-HGO); 24 hours later
column6: given the patient's systemic clinical conditions and presenting leukocytosis of 27
column8: with neutrophilia of 82.4% and creatinine at 7.5 mg/dl
column9: it was decided to admit him. Physical examination revealed icteric sclerae
column10: a severe increase in volume with a predominance of the submental and bilateral submandibular region and a mouth opening limited to approximately 15 mm. Intraoral examination revealed partial maxillomandibular edentulism
column11: generalised chronic periodontal disease with grade IV mobility of 3.1 and 4.1
column12: presence of local irritants
column13: halitosis
column14: severe enlargement of the floor of the mouth and bilateral sublingual space with glossoptosis.  In conjunction with the Infectious Diseases and Internal Medicine departments
column15: empirical treatment was started with crystalline sodium penicillin 4
column17: 000 IU every 6 hours intravenously and aztreonam 1 g intravenously on a daily basis. A CT scan showed an isodense image in the parapharyngeal space compatible with an increase in volume
column18: showing a decrease in the airway lumen in the cervical region and corroborating the diagnosis of Ludwig's angina.  After 10 days of treatment
column19: the evolution was torpid. A re-evaluation by the infectious diseases department indicated 1 g intravenous vancomycin
column20: which caused significant clinical improvement in the patient. After systemic stabilisation of the patient
column21: an exodontia of 3.1 and 4.1 and surgical drainage of the sublingual
column22: submandibular and submentonian spaces was performed through a bilateral submentonian and submandibular incision inferior to the mandibular basal
column23: which allowed access
column24: communication and the establishment of 3 passive drains with a Nellaton probe for 3 daily washes of saline solution for 3 weeks. The patient's evolution after surgical drainage and antibiotic therapy replacement showed a decrease in volume increase and a stabilisation of the respiratory rate. The last recorded haematology revealed a white series of 8
column26: at the expense of neutrophils (78%)
column27: haemoglobin of 9.5 g/dl
column28: haematocrit of 32.7% and creatinine of 6.8 mg/dl. All these conditions led to medical discharge.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 48-year-old male patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus
column2: systemic arterial hypertension and hypothyroidism
column3: diagnosed 8 years previously
column4: with inadequate control

column1: We present the case of a 26-year-old female patient who came for consultation with pain in the right wrist of 7 years' duration with no history of trauma. The pain at rest was mild
column2: but increased with manual activity and especially with forced extension of the wrist. It did not improve with symptomatic medical treatment. The dorsal radiocarpal joint interline and the proximal pole of the scaphoid were painful on palpation. There was no palpable tumour. Wrist mobility was slightly limited in the last degrees of flexion and extension. The radiological image showed a radiolucent
column3: well-defined
column4: oval lesion located in the mid-dorsal third of the scaphoid. The CT scan showed the dorsal eccentric location of the lesion and a stippling compatible with calcifications. The MRI showed signs of marked bone oedema in the scaphoid
column5: except in the distal third
column6: and adjacent synovitis. With the diagnosis of a suspected benign lesion (enchondroma
column7: intraosseous ganglion)
column8: surgical treatment of the lesion was decided. This was performed via a dorsal approach to the scaphoid. After opening the joint capsule
column9: the dorsal aspect of the distal epiphysis of the radius and the scaphoid was exposed
column10: revealing a pearly
column11: wine-red tumour in the middle third of the scaphoid
column12: occupying the dorsal crest of the navicular bone. Exhaustive curettage of the lesion was performed and the defect was filled with cancellous bone graft from the iliac crest.  The remitted material consisted of islets of cartilage matrix surrounded by abundant cellular tissue consisting of pseudo-chondroblastic cells. These cells were round or ovoid with hyperchromatic nuclei
column13: clear or moderately eosinophilic cytoplasm and a clear plasma membrane. Cell pleomorphism was minimal and the mitotic index very low. Some cells contained iron. Among the pseudochondroblastic cells there were abundant osteoclast-like giant cells. In some areas there were areas of irregular calcification. There were also some areas of cystic transformation resembling aneurysmal cysts. The pathological diagnosis was carpal scaphoid chondroblastoma.  After surgical treatment
column14: the wrist was immobilised with an antebrachial splint for 3 weeks and the patient was subsequently referred to the Rehabilitation Service. At the 3-month check-up
column15: complete recovery of wrist mobility and radiological image of bone consolidation of the iliac crest autograft were observed. Two years after surgical treatment there is no evidence of recurrence and there is still complete disappearance of pain with mobility of the wrist similar to the contralateral one
column16: as well as a completely normalised radiological image of the scaphoid.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 29-year-old male (165 cm
column2: 68 kg)
column3: Afghan
column4: police officer
column5: who suffered an open traumatism to the right elbow during an attack secondary to the impact of a firearm (probably AK-74 7.62 mm). Following the incident
column6: a tourniquet was placed at humeral level
column7: a granulated haemostatic was applied topically (Celox® SAM Medical Products
column8: Newport
column9: Oregon
column10: USA) and tranexamic acid (1 g iv) was administered. He was evacuated by medical helicopter to the Spanish Role 2E in Herat (Afghanistan) arriving at the triage room 70 minutes after sustaining the injury.  On primary assessment
column11: the wounded man had GCS 15 pts
column12: peripheral SatO2 98%
column13: heart rate 110 bpm
column14: non-invasive blood pressure 130/80 mmHg and good pain control (VAS 2/10) after administration of midazolam (3 mg iv) and ketamine (30 mg iv). The presence of a gunshot wound with entry wound in the elbow without exit wound was confirmed. X-ray showed a fracture of the left distal humerus
column15: a fracture of the left proximal ulna and a fracture of the left proximal radius. Surgical intervention was decided for debridement
column16: cleaning
column17: removal of bone splinters and placement of an external fixator on the left arm under general anaesthesia. During the pre-anaesthetic study
column18: no significant alterations were found in the blood analysis
column19: ECG or airway assessment. The patient could not remember when he had last eaten and accepted the informed consent in the presence of an interpreter. In the operating theatre
column20: grade I monitoring (peripheral O2 SatO2
column21: heart rate
column22: non-invasive blood pressure and capnography) augmented with a bispectral analysis device (BIS®)
column23: continuous haemoglobin monitor (Masimo® Radical 7) and oropharyngeal thermometer was used. The casualty was premedicated with midazolam (1 mg iv) and ketamine (20 mg iv). After 3 minutes of denitrogenation with 80% FiO2 achieving 100% SatO2
column24: rapid sequence anaesthesia was induced with fentanyl (150 μg iv)
column25: propofol (130 mg iv) and rocuronium (30 mg iv). Standard laryngoscopy (Cormak II) was performed
column26: the airway was isolated with a 7.5 mm endotracheal tube and the pneumotaping balloon was filled with air (8 ml). After selecting protective ventilation parameters (VT 420 ml
column27: PEEP 7
column28: FiO2 45%) no alveolar recruitment manoeuvres were necessary. Anaesthetic maintenance was performed with a mixture of O2
column29: air and sevofluorane. During the 75 minutes of the surgical procedure the patient remained tachycardic. The intervention performed was open reduction under scopic control
column30: transarticular osteosynthesis by implantation of Hoffmann II Stryker external fixator in multiplanar configuration
column31: pulsatile lavage of the wound and debridement of the necrotic tissue involving the extesor carpi ulnaris
column32: flexor carpi ulnaris and tricipital tendon. Anti-tetanus prophylaxis
column33: antibiotic (cefazolin 2 g iv and metronidazole 500 mg iv)
column34: gastroprotective (omeprazole 40 mg iv)
column35: anti-emetic (granisetron 3 mg iv)
column36: anti-inflammatory (desketoprofen 50 mg iv)
column37: ocular (oculo-epithelial ointment together with forced eyelid closure)
column38: orthopaedic (joint protection) and thermal (operating room temperature regulation
column39: fluid warmer and hot air blanket). To improve pain control
column40: in addition to multimodal analgesia (metamizole 2 g iv
column41: paracetamol 1 g iv
column42: ketamine 30 mg iv and fentanyl 150 μg iv)
column43: an ultrasound-guided peripheral nerve block was used at the interscalene level using 37 mg of bupivacaine 0.25%. Education was uneventful and no opioid antagonisation or muscle relaxant reversal was required. The patient was admitted stable and with good pain control to the intensive care unit and subsequently transferred to the inpatient ward. He was discharged from Role 2E 72 hours after the attack and evacuated to an Afghan military hospital for soft tissue healing and future osteosynthesis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 77-year-old woman with no past history of interest consulted for a scalp lesion of more than two years' evolution with progressive growth over the last year
column2: which bothered her when rubbed. It was a 6 mm hard erythematous-violaceous papular lesion in the parietooccipital region. This lesion was excised by slicing and silver nitrate
column3: it bled a lot and it was not possible to obtain a sufficient sample for anatomopathological study (AP). After 6 months
column4: the lesion grew again with similar characteristics in the same place
column5: and was removed by elliptical excision and electric scalpel. The AP analysis reported the presence of differentiated thyroid tissue in the skin. The tumour was located in the middle and deep dermis and consisted of follicular structures of variable sizes containing colloid material with peripheral vascularisation and lined by a row of cubic cells with a low number of mitoses. Immunohistochemical examination detected intense cytoplasmic and intracolloid expression of thyroglobulin
column6: keratin 7 and 19. With these findings the patient was referred to us for evaluation of metastasis of previously unknown thyroid cancer.  In the anamnesis the patient was asymptomatic and had no medical history of interest. Physical examination revealed a grade Ib goitre with a 2-3 cm nodule in the LTD that ascended well on swallowing
column7: with no palpable lymph nodes
column8: the rest being normal. Complementary tests: TSH 0.55 mU/L (0.35-5.5)
column11: undetectable anti-TPO and anti-TG antibodies and negative TSI
column12: which have remained the same throughout follow-up. Thyroid ultrasound showed a multinodular goitre
column13: with a dominant nodule measuring 25 x 15 mm of mixed echogenicity with hyper-hypoechoic areas and coarse calcifications in the LTD
column14: and poorly defined hypoechogenic areas in the caudal area
column15: where the FNA was performed and reported as a follicular tumour. One month later
column16: a thyroidectomy plus lymphadenectomy of the central compartment was performed. The intraoperative biopsy was reported as papillary carcinoma. AP analysis of the surgical specimen was reported as mixed papillary and follicular carcinoma
column17: well differentiated (90%) and solid with 10% poorly differentiated
column18: partially encapsulated with extensive infiltration of the capsule and its vessels. The size of the encapsulated portion was 15 mm and 30 mm for the whole tumour. No extrathyroidal extension was seen and the surgical margins were free
column19: the closest being 1 mm posterior. When the central compartment was emptied
column20: 4 lymph nodes were obtained and found to be free of tumour.  An extension study was performed before radioiodine treatment by means of a metabolic study with 8.26 mCi of 18FDG
column21: brain and pelvic MRI and bone scintigraphy
column22: which was negative. Seventy days after the intervention
column23: 104.7 mCi of I131 was administered after TSHrh. Baseline serum TG was 351 µg/L (1.6-60). Stimulated TG 1788.7 µg/L (47-10000) with baseline TSH of 117 mU/L (0.37-4.7). Post-I131 RCT showed post-thyroidectomy remnants located in the left posterior chamber
column24: together with diffuse miliary involvement in both lung parenchyma compatible with metastasis. One month after radioiodine ablation and on treatment with 100 µg levothyroxine
column25: he presented TG 37 µg/L (1.6-60)
column26: TSH 1.96 mU/L and T4l 1.43 ng/dL
column27: at which time the dose of levothyroxine was increased to 125 µg. At the evaluation 6 months after radioiodine ablation the TG was 2.78 with TSH 0.03 and T4l 1.96
column28: so she was given another dose of radioiodine of 125 mCi; and 2 months later TG<0.20 µg/L was detected with TSH 0.04 mU/L and T4 1.6 ng/dL. The patient will be re-evaluated in 4 months by quantification of stimulated TG after TSHrh and subsequent RCT to confirm cure.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O

column1: A 51-year-old woman
column2: with a history of unilateral adnexectomy for endometriosis
column3: who after 24 hours of evolution presented with fever of up to 40oC and odynophagia
column4: which partially subsided with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Subsequently
column5: vomiting and several diarrhoeal stools appeared
column6: with persistence of the febrile syndrome
column7: so she went to the health centre. After medical assessment
column8: antipyretic treatment and home observation were prescribed. Hours later
column9: his general condition worsened
column10: with hypotension
column11: and he also reported headache and dorsalgia
column12: so the Emergency Department was notified and he was transferred to hospital. Physical examination revealed a fair general state
column13: tachypnoea at rest and tachycardia
column14: and blood pressure could not be detected
column15: nor was it possible to palpate the peripheral radial pulses. There was no nuchal rigidity or neurological focality. Laboratory tests and blood gas analysis revealed marked leukocytopenia (2
column16: 440/ml) and metabolic acidosis (pH 7.21; HCO3 14 mmol/l; EB -11.1 mmol/l). The patient was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU)
column17: where
column18: despite treatment with corticosteroids and intravenous antibiotic therapy
column19: she worsened and died 2 hours later
column20: after cardiopulmonary resuscitation manoeuvres. Due to the torpid evolution and the uncertain origin of the shock
column21: death was not certified. Autopsy findings Significant findings on external examination included a generalised skin rash
column22: more pronounced on the head and on the anterior face of the upper third of the thorax
column23: and petechiae on the tarsal conjunctivae of both lower eyelids.  In the internal examination
column24: macroscopically it is observed: - Moderate pulmonary congestion with significant pulmonary oedema of alveolar and interstitial characteristics with bronchial foam. - Right pleural effusion. Mild pericardial effusion. - Exudative fluid in retromammary subcutaneous tissue on both sides
column25: purulent appearance. - Liver with steatotic appearance with haemorrhagic stippling. - Both adrenal glands with congestive-hemorrhagic marrow.  - The brain had a generalised congestive and oedematous appearance
column26: with a casual finding of a cyst in the left parietal lobe.  Samples of the brain
column27: lung

column38: pleural effusion and swab impregnated with subcutaneous exudate from the right pectoral muscle were submitted for toxicological
column39: microbiological and histopathological studies. The results of the microbiological study carried out using antigenic techniques
column40: culture and real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) detected the presence of N. meningitidis serogroup C in peripheral blood
column41: serum and
column42: in small quantities
column43: at the encephalic level. Epidemiological characterisation of the strain and the study of antibiotic resistance by minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) were carried out. Histopathological findings in the brain included congestion and oedema
column44: as well as the existence of a transitional-psammomatous meningioma. Both adrenals showed severe haemorrhage; the liver showed signs suggestive of shock in the initial phase
column45: and at the renal level there were alterations compatible with DIC. In addition
column46: splenomegaly and some neutrophilic myocarditis were diagnosed. The toxicology study showed only positive results for dipyrone or metamizole. Based on the findings described above
column47: the causes of death were established as multi-organ failure due to fulminant meningococcal septicaemia (N. meningitidis serogroup C) and Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 74-year-old man with a history of ischaemic heart disease treated with beta-blockers
column2: isosorbide mononitrate
column3: antiplatelet agents and proton pump inhibitors. He was referred to the Digestive System for a 9-month history of intense asthenia
column4: anorexia and progressive increase in sweating
column5: with a weight loss of 15 kg
column6: associated with diffuse abdominal pain and abdominal distension. Laboratory tests revealed iron deficiency anaemia. Among other diagnostic tests
column7: a colonoscopy under sedation was requested. An initial colonoscopy was performed
column8: revealing from the rectum to the cecum an infinity of sessile lesions with a polypoid appearance of between 3-6 mm
column9: more frequent in number in the right colon and forming conglomerates at the level of the ileocaecal valve
column10: also affecting the terminal ileum. The pathological anatomy of biopsies at different levels showed non-specific colitis with lymphoid follicular hyperplasia and an eosinophilic infiltrate of up to 60% of inflammatory cells. After the results obtained and in view of the patient's progressive clinical worsening
column11: it was decided to perform a gastroscopy and repeat the colonoscopy to take new biopsies. Multiple sessile polypoid lesions of different sizes (larger than 8-9 mm) were observed in the gastric and duodenal mucosa. They were irregular and bulging with marked vascularisation
column12: some eroded at the apex
column13: decreasing in number as the patient progressed towards the distal duodenum
column14: and the lesions described in the previous colonoscopy were also confirmed. The histopathological result of the gastric
column15: duodenal and colon biopsies was a dense diffuse lymphoid infiltrate in the mucosa and submucosa with glandular destruction and lymphoepithelial lesion
column16: with small-sized lymphocytes and centrocytoid habitus with positivity for CD 20
column17: cyclin D1
column18: and bcl-2 with a Ki-67 of 30%
column19: all compatible with gastric
column20: small intestine and colon infiltration by mantle lymphoma. After the endoscopic findings
column21: the patient was referred to the haematology department where studies were completed
column22: confirming the definitive diagnosis of stage IVB non-Hodgkin's lymphoma of the mantle with gastric
column23: small and large intestine involvement.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 60-year-old non-smoking
column2: non-alcoholic woman
column3: with no clinical history of interest
column4: who reported no relevant medical or surgical procedures and came to our department for an exodontia of the lower left first premolar. At the time of the intraoral clinical examination
column5: an asymptomatic tumour lesion measuring 15 mm in diameter was observed on the left buccal mucosa. It is pale pink in colour similar to the mucosa and has a smooth surface. On the right buccal mucosa
column6: a tumour lesion of 10 mm in diameter is observed. This lesion is hypochromic compared to the buccal mucosa and has a smooth surface. The provisional diagnosis for both lesions is a traumatic fibroma associated with a poorly adapted prosthesis. At the time of history taking the patient did not report having undergone facial infiltration treatment with biopolymers. The diagnostic method is an excisional biopsy and the treatment is surgical removal. The excision is performed by anaesthetising the area. The incision was made with a number 15 scalpel blade and sutured with 3-0 black silk. Closure of the right lesion was performed with Vicryl and then 3-0 black silk. At the time of surgical excision of the left lesion
column7: the macroscopic appearance is that of a lipoma due to its internal colouration and the fact that it is encapsulated.  For the left lesion the microscopic study indicates a reactive lesion lined by a flat stratified lining epithelium of variable thickness. Beneath the epithelium there is a lesion consisting of abundant randomly arranged collagenous fibres interspersed with fibroblasts and some blood vessels delineated by normal appearing endothelium. This confirms that it is a traumatic fibroma. Histopathological examination of the right mucosal lesion reveals the presence of abundant empty rounded spaces surrounded by numerous foamy looking histiocytes
column8: indicating that they are phagocytosing lipids and have this appearance. After obtaining the microscopic examination images
column9: the patient indicated that 10 years earlier she had undergone a treatment of facial infiltrations with biopolymers on the forehead and at the corners of the mouth. The patient did not report any symptoms associated with adverse effects.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 40-year-old patient attended the outpatient department of the Digestive Service for a study of elevated transaminases in a routine blood test. In the abdominal ultrasound study
column2: a LOE was detected in segments 2 and 3 of the liver with a maximum size of 4 cm
column3: with solid characteristics compatible with the diagnosis of hepatoma. The abdominal multislice computed axial tomography (CT) scan showed a focal lesion with lobulated borders measuring 4 cm in diameter in segments 2 and 3
column4: with intense enhancement after injection of intravenous contrast in the arterial phase; and with washout in the portal phase
column5: findings compatible with the diagnosis of hepatocarcinoma. There was no evidence of other focal lesions. The intrahepatic bile duct was not dilated and the gallbladder showed no lithiasic images.  Fine needle aspiration puncture (FNA) of the lesion was performed under ultrasound control with negative results for malignant cells and with a positive CD 34 in the immunohistochemical study.  Systematic blood tests were normal
column6: as were liver function
column7: immunoglobulins
column8: antibodies and tumour markers. Viral markers were also negative. Given the diagnosis of probable hepatoma on non-cirrhotic liver
column9: surgical resection was decided. Segments 2 and 3 were resected laparoscopically
column10: using two No. 12 ports
column11: periumbilical and in the right hypochondrium
column12: and a gel port in the left hypochondrium. The intraoperative histological study diagnosed hepatocellular proliferation with no histological signs of malignancy
column13: the lesion being 2 cm from the edge of the surgical resection. In the anatomopathological study
column14: the nodular formation showed liver tissue with a compact trabecular pattern of up to 3 cell layers
column15: with proliferation of the large muscular arteries surrounded by a dense connective stroma
column16: where no preserved portal spaces were identified. The pathological diagnosis was focal nodular hyperplasia. The postoperative course was uneventful and he was discharged on the fourth postoperative day.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 12-year-old girl with a history of prominent ears treated by otoplasty at the age of 8 years. A keloid progressively developed in both ears from one year after the operation. The keloids invaded the upper edge and posterior face of the upper poles. The right ear had a horizontal size of 3.2 cm and a vertical size of 2 cm
column2: and the left ear was 2.7 cm x 1.5 cm respectively. The patient reported no pain or itching. Excision was indicated due to the large size of the lesions
column3: with aesthetic and psychological repercussions. The operation was performed under general anaesthesia. Surgical treatment consisted of the following technique: an incision was made on the posterosuperior aspect of the keloid
column4: from which a thin flap of the keloid skin cover was dissected
column5: maintaining a pedicle of attachment to the normal skin on the anterior aspect of the ear. After lifting the flap to a suitable size
column6: the remaining keloid was excised. The flap was sutured to the defect without tension. The size of the flaps was 2.5 cm x 1.5 cm on the right ear and 2 cm x 1 cm on the left ear. Pathological examination showed that the keloid nodules were covered by epidermis
column7: and atrophy of the skin appendages was observed. Surgery was associated with other treatments
column8: commonly used to prevent recurrence: intraoperative injection of corticosteroid (triamcinolone acetonide) into the surgical site
column9: application of silicone gel to the resulting scars and pressotherapy with an elastic band. Silicone gel and pressotherapy were used for one year after surgery. The patient was monitored periodically.  The right ear flap had a small suture dehiscence
column10: which healed by secondary intention within a few weeks with topical treatment. No necrosis or other complications developed. A satisfactory repair of the defects was achieved
column11: with restoration of the normal contour of the ears. On the right ear a recurrence developed 5 years after the operation
column12: forming a keloid in the operated area measuring 1.5 cm x 1 cm
column13: which was treated with the same surgical procedure. There has been no recurrence in the left ear. At 18 years of age
column14: both ears look good and the patient has regular check-ups.    |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 74-year-old female patient attended the emergency department because she had suffered an accidental blunt trauma at home
column2: of moderate intensity to the left eye (OI)
column3: after hitting it with the edge of the bedside table. His medical history included mild ametropia without optical correction and type 2 diabetes mellitus under treatment with oral antidiabetic drugs. He had no other personal or family history of interest. His visual acuity (VA) was 0.6 in the right eye and light perception did not improve with pinhole in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination revealed haematoma and oedema in the left upper eyelid
column4: intact conjunctiva with intense generalised chemosis
column5: intact and transparent cornea and 100% hyphaema that prevented assessment of the rest of the ocular structures. OI hypotony was observed with an intraocular pressure of 5 mm Hg. Imaging tests (computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging) revealed an incised upper nasal paralimbal scleral incision wound of approximately 10 mm and the presence of a prolapsed intact lens in the subconjunctival space. The conjunctival chemosis rapidly evolved into generalised hyposphagma
column6: revealing an upper nasal subconjunctival mass corresponding to the prolapsed lens. The patient underwent a 360º peritomy
column7: extraction of the prolapsed lens
column8: suture of the scleral wound and treatment with intravenous and reinforced topical antibiotherapy. One month after surgery
column9: the patient's hand movement VA improved to 0.1 with correction of +14.00 dioptres. The slit lamp showed a clear cornea
column10: upper nasal corectopia with loss of iridian tissue and adherent debris. The fundus
column11: which was not visible due to media opacity
column12: showed retina in situ in the B-mode ultrasound. At twelve months
column13: combined vitrectomy via pars plana and suture of the intraocular lens to the sulcus was performed
column14: achieving a spontaneous VA of 0.3 at eighteen months.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 43-year-old male
column2: previously healthy and asymptomatic
column3: attended the thoracic surgery department in order to complete the study of a middle mediastinal tumour identified in a routine study.  In the pharyngo-oesophageal study
column4: after the administration of barium contrast
column5: a stenosis of about 3 cm in length was observed in the middle third of the oesophagus with well-defined contours and which reduced the oesophageal lumen by 50%. These findings are compatible with an extrinsic compressive process.  A three-way right videothoracoscopy was performed. The presence of a tumour was identified in the middle mediastinum at the level of the azygos vein (cephalic to this vein)
column6: mobile
column7: hard
column8: with no adhesions to adjoining structures. Dissection is started by opening the mediastinal pleura and separating the tumour from what appears to be the muscular fibres of the oesophagus (this is done using a videothoracoscopy hook and an electric scalpel). The tumour
column9: which measures approximately 3 cm in diameter
column10: is then enucleated. The oesophageal mucosa is identified at its deep edge and its tightness is checked. The postoperative course was uneventful and the patient was discharged after 48 hours. At the review carried out 6 months after surgery
column11: the patient was asymptomatic and living a completely normal life
column12: with no dysphagia or symptoms of gastro-oesophageal reflux
column13: afebrile and with normal respiratory function tests. The anatomopathological report of the fragment was diagnosed as an oesophageal leiomyoma. Macroscopically
column14: it was 5 cm in size
column15: irregular in shape
column16: with a polylobulated surface and a certain tendency to form swirls. Microscopically
column17: the tumour consisted of bundles of smooth muscle fibres strongly positive for anti-actin
column18: multidirectional in arrangement
column19: without cellular atypia or mitosis. Occasionally
column20: hyaline amorphous material appears in the form of irregularly distributed droplets.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 32 year old female patient
column2: referred to the pain unit by the ophthalmology department for pain secondary to herpetic involvement of the ophthalmic branch of the left fifth cranial nerve
column3: with poor response to treatment with tramadol (50 mg/8 h) prescribed by the ophthalmology department. His past history included repeated episodes of keratitis and uveitis in the last 2 years
column4: labelled as herpetic in origin. At the first consultation (2001)
column5: the patient reported a picture of left eye pain of about 3 months' duration
column6: with paroxysmal episodes that increased with certain stimuli such as wind
column7: cold or dry eyes. Physical examination revealed no neurological deficits. The pain was rated by the patient with a visual analogue scale (VAS) value of a maximum of 7-8 (during paroxysms) and a minimum of 2. The diagnosis was post-kerkeratotic herpetic neuralgia of the ophthalmic branch of the left fifth cranial nerve. Treatment was started with gabapentin and tramadol in progressive doses
column8: without achieving good pain control and with the appearance of side effects in the form of vomiting and drowsiness. A series of drug rotations were carried out (amitriptyline
column9: topiramate) at different doses which produced no improvement in pain or adverse manifestations. With the patient's consent
column10: treatment was started with low-frequency electroacupuncture (EA) (2-4 Hz/s)
column11: the intensity used being that accepted by the patient as tolerable. It was applied in fortnightly sessions lasting 30 minutes. The points chosen were: yintai
column12: bilateral taiyang
column13: 18 bilateral ID
column14: 4 bilateral IG
column15: 3 bilateral H
column16: initially combined with gabapentin (300 mg/ 12 h).  After 6 sessions of EA
column17: the patient started to report better analgesic control and better drug tolerance
column18: so gabapentin was increased (900 mg/24 h) and tramadol solution (25 mg every 6-8 h) was added for paroxysmal seizure management only. EA sessions were done on a weekly basis. This was followed by improved analgesic quality
column19: but vomiting persisted. It was decided to discontinue tramadol and to progressively increase gabapentin (2400 mg/24 h) for 2 months. With this new treatment plan
column20: the paroxysmal seizures were gradually controlled in terms of intensity
column21: frequency and duration. After 3 months of clinical stability
column22: the patient reported almost no continuous pain
column23: the paroxysmal crises had decreased in frequency and intensity
column24: and she presented better tolerance to drowsiness. A progressive tapering of gabapentin was started over 3 months until its discontinuation. At the end of this period
column25: the patient reported only paroxysmal seizures of a lower intensity (VAS 4-5) and with inter-crisis intervals of 7-10 days. These were managed with low doses of tramadol solution (25 mg)
column26: which was effective for pain control
column27: but was accompanied by nausea
column28: which is why the patient stopped using it. After a period of 6 months with weekly sessions of EA and acceptable control of the condition
column29: a gradual spacing of these sessions was started. Currently
column30: the patient continues treatment in our unit (last consultation January 2009)
column31: only with EA sessions every 30-45 days
column32: without any other type of medication
column33: with adequate pain control. Attempts have been made to space out the acupuncture sessions every 60 days
column34: but analgesic control is of poorer quality.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 49-year-old Peruvian man who had lived in Spain for 10 years and last travelled to his country in 1995
column2: with no history of interest except sexual assault in 1996
column3: with severe tearing of the anal canal that caused rectorrhagia requiring transfusion of two red blood cell concentrates; no toxic habits or risk practices for HIV infection. Consultation for symptoms of 4-5 stools per day
column4: liquid
column5: without pathological products
column6: of about 6 months of evolution
column7: with added fever of up to 39ºC in the last two months. Weight loss of 2-3 kg during this time; mild abdominal pain; holocranial headache. The rest of the anamnesis by apparatus was unremarkable. On physical examination
column8: fever of 38.5°C well tolerated
column9: with normal cardio-pulmonary auscultation
column10: abdomen discreetly and diffusely painful on palpation
column11: with no signs of peritoneal irritation
column12: rectal examination with preserved sphincter and no alterations
column13: and strictly normal neurological examination. Laboratory data: erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 35; haemogram
column14: blood biochemistry
column15: basic coagulation study
column16: thyroid hormones and routine urine tests were normal. Anti Hbc and anti HBe positive; HCV
column17: RPR
column18: Rose Bengal
column19: Ac. Leishmania
column20: cryptococcus ag. and Mantoux negative. Antigenemia for CMV 70 cells; Toxoplasma positive; HIV positive (ELISA and Western Blot). CD4 96; Viral load 153
column21: 690 copies. Blood cultures (X3) negative (2 batches); fresh parasites negative for cryptosporidium and microsporidia; enteropathogens and Clostridium difficile toxin negative; duodenal juice and biopsy of 2nd duodenal portion without pathogens; CMV is isolated in colon biopsy culture
column22: the rest of the study at that level being negative; CMV is isolated in urine cell culture. Fundus examination showed no evidence of CMV retinitis. Imaging tests: Chest X-ray
column23: abdominal ultrasound
column24: oesophago-gastroscopy
column25: colonoscopy and gastrointestinal transit without notable alterations. Cranial CT scan showed an intra-axial mass
column26: with predominantly annular enhancement after IV contrast
column27: centred in the region of the anterior arm of the internal capsule and left basal ganglia
column28: with significant associated vasogenic oedema (differential diagnosis toxoplasmosis/lymphoma). Treatment was started with Ganciclovir IV for treatment of CMV infection
column29: as well as Sulfadiazine and Pyrimethamine OV
column30: plus IV corticosteroid for the brain mass
column31: with disappearance of fever and normalisation of diarrhoea 48 hours after starting treatment. Fourteen days after starting treatment
column32: the patient was still asymptomatic; the cranial CT scan was repeated
column33: showing a considerable decrease in the size of the lesion
column34: which supports the diagnosis of cerebral toxoplasmosis. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We describe the case of a 37-year-old man with a previous active life who reported osteoarticular pain of variable location in the last month and fever in the last week with peaks (morning and evening) of 40 C in the last 24-48 hours
column2: for which he went to the Emergency Department. Before the onset of the symptoms
column3: he had been in Extremadura in a brucella-endemic region
column4: eating unpasteurised goat's milk and cheese from such cattle. Several cases of brucellosis were found among the diners. During admission for the study of the febrile syndrome with epidemiological antecedents of possible exposure to Brucella
column5: the patient presented a picture of right orchiepididymitis. Physical examination revealed: temperature 40.2°C; T.A: 109/68 mmHg; Fc: 105 bpm. He was conscious
column6: oriented
column7: sweating
column8: eupneic
column9: with good nutritional and hydration status. No palpable head and neck lymph nodes
column10: no goitre or jugular vein engorgement
column11: with symmetrical carotid pulses. Cardiac auscultation rhythmic
column12: without murmurs
column13: friction or extratonos. Pulmonary auscultation with preservation of vesicular murmur. Abdomen soft
column14: depressible
column15: without masses or megaliths. In the neurological examination
column16: no meningeal signs or signs of focality were detected. Extremities without varicose veins or oedema. Peripheral pulses present and symmetrical. The urological examination revealed an enlarged right teste
column17: not adhered to the skin
column18: with areas of fluctuation and intensely painful on palpation
column19: with loss of the epididymo-testicular boundary and positive transillumination. The analytical data showed the following results: haemogram: Hb 13.7 g/dl; leucocytes 14
column20: 610/mm3 (neutrophils 77%); platelets 206
column21: 000/mm3. ESR: 40 mm 1 hour. Coagulation: TQ 87%; TTPA 25.8 sec. Biochemistry: glucose 117 mg/dl; urea 29 mg/dl; creatinine 0.9 mg/dl; sodium 136 mEq/l; potassium 3.6 mEq/l; GOT 11 U/l; GPT 24 U/l; GGT 34 U/l; alkaline phosphatase 136 U/l; calcium 8.3 mg/dl. Urine: sediment normal. During admission
column22: blood cultures were requested: positive for Brucella and specific serology for Brucella: Rose Bengal +++; Coombs test > 1/1280; Brucellacapt > 1/5120. The imaging tests requested (chest X-ray
column23: abdominal ultrasound
column24: cranial CT scan
column25: transthoracic echocardiogram) showed no significant pathology
column26: except for the testicular ultrasound
column27: which showed thickening of the scrotal sac with a small amount of fluid with septa and an enlarged testicle with small hypoechoic areas inside that may represent microabscesses. With the diagnosis of orchiepididymitis secondary to Brucella
column28: symptomatic treatment (antipyretics
column29: anti-inflammatory drugs
column30: rest and testicular elevation) and specific antibiotic treatment was started: Doxycycline 100 mg orally every 12 hours (for 6 weeks) and Streptomycin 1 gram intramuscularly every 24 hours (for 3 weeks). The patient's condition improved significantly after one week of hospitalisation
column31: and he was discharged home
column32: where he completed the antibiotic treatment regimen. Subsequent visits to the clinic showed complete remission of the symptoms.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 21-year-old woman
column2: carrier of the VHL gene
column3: presented with a cerebellar haemangioblastoma diagnosed 2 years ago
column4: when she went to the emergency department in cardiorespiratory arrest. In the ophthalmological examination
column5: a papillary superior temporal HCR of ½ papillary diameter of yellowish appearance was seen in the OI
column6: with another satellite HCR
column7: which
column8: like a small juxtapapillary HCR
column9: was not seen in funduscopy but was seen in angiography
column10: giving a hyperfluorescent saccular image
column11: the rest of the ophthalmological examination being normal in AO as was the OCT of the macula
column12: with a VA of the unit in both eyes.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 40-year-old man with recently diagnosed PNH was referred for renal evaluation. In the previous 9 months he had presented with repeated episodes of dark urine and low back pain. He presented with severe haemolytic anaemia
column2: haemoglobin 7.7 mg/dl
column3: undetectable haptoglobin
column4: elevated LDH 3
column6: requiring red blood cell transfusion. Ferritin and transferan saturation normal. Renal function normal
column7: creatinine 0.8 mg/dl
column8: proteinuria 427 mg/24 h
column9: with albuminuria 120 mg/24 h. Haemoglobinuria with normal sediment
column10: negative glycosuria and normal fractional excretion of phosphate. In the following 10 months he presented repeated haemolytic crises
column11: with macroscopic haemoglobinuria. He reported difficulty concentrating and recurrent headache. An MRI showed marked signal hypointensity in the renal cortex on all sequences
column12: and a brain MRI revealed multiple subcortical lacunar lesions. Due to brain involvement attributable to PNH
column13: treatment with eculizumab was initiated.  The patient progressed
column14: with no new haemoglobinuria crises
column15: resolution of anaemia and normalisation of LDH (decreased haptoglobin persisted). Seventeen months after the start of treatment
column16: a new MRI showed normalisation of the signal in the renal cortex. Renal function remained normal
column17: with proteinuria 130mg/day and negative haemoglobinuria.  |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 20-year-old patient attended the emergency department with lumbar pain and fever. The patient underwent urine cultures
column2: blood cultures and a tumour marker study (tests that were negative). A computerised axial tomography (CAT) scan detected a tumour mass affecting the upper pole of the right kidney. The tumour was then surgically resected.  The surgical resection specimen consisted of a tumour mass 14 cm in diameter
column3: with infiltration of the upper pole and middle segment of the kidney
column4: and involvement of the sinus and pyelocaliceal system. The presence of tumoural lymphatic vascular invasion was observed in the renal tissue and adjacent fat. Medullary metastasis of the adrenal gland
column5: invasion of the perirenal fat and nodules of the interaortic caval chain. Using immunohistochemical techniques on paraffin sections with different monoclonal antibodies (Dako)
column6: the following staining pattern was found to be compatible with a desmoplastic small round cell tumour: cytokeratins 8
column8: glial fibrillary acidic acidic protein (-)
column9: desmin (+)
column10: vimentin (+)
column11: synaptophysin (+)
column12: chromogranin (-)
column13: actin (weakly +)
column14: and S-100 (weakly +).  A cytogenetic study of the t(11;22) (p13;q12) translocation involving the EWS1 and WT1 genes was also performed by fluorescence in situ hybridisation (FISH) using the LSI EWSR1 (22q12) Dual Color Break Apart Rearrangement Probe (VYSIS) kit. This consists of a mixture of two probes that completely flank the EWS1 gene locus
column15: the more centromeric probe is labelled with Spectrum-Orange and the more telomeric with Spectrum-Green. As a result of this design
column16: any translocation involving the EWS1 locus results in the separation of the red-green fusion signal into a red and a green signal. The pattern observed in our case corresponds to the normal pattern
column17: with the presence of two red-green fusion signals per tumour cell
column18: thus confirming the absence of translocation in the patient.  The patient was treated with three cycles of CAV
column19: four cycles of Ifosfamide/VP-16
column20: and subsequently CTX
column21: ADR
column22: and VCR. As a result of this treatment no tumour infiltration was detected in the bone marrow. However
column23: a reappearance of the tumour and liver metastasis was subsequently detected by CT scan. After which there was no response to treatment and the patient died two years after the initial diagnosis.   |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
